column2: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 6 -- Miss Effa E. Preston, whose ambition was to be a lion tamer, is retiring this month after having taught in the public schools here for thirty-eight years.

MOST of us take our vacations between Decoration Day and Labor Day. But I took mine this year while the dog-woods and lilacs were in bloom and so have already had an opportunity to appraise the merits as vacation reading fare of several of the books published in the first half of 1953.

ABILENE, Tex., June 6 (AP) -- Walter Davis, Olympic high-jump champion, missed the world record by a sixteenth of an inch tonight as he leaped 6 feet 10 15-16 inches in an exhibition at the National Intercollegiate track and field meet.

BERLIN, June 6 -- The Rev. Philip Joseph Crosby, Australian Roman Catholic missionary who was interned by the North Koreans for three years, arrived here today and said he was the last of the non-Asian civilians held, except for eighteen White Russians and several Turks.

BRITAIN'S Elizabeth II, a stamp collector, and Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill, whom she recently knighted, will receive soon the No. 1 and No. 2 copies of one of the most elaborate philatelic albums ever published, and each book will contain mint examples of all the postal commemoratives, 106 varieties representing 78 governments, issued for the Coronation last Wednesday.

LONDON -- A new era in sea travel was begun a month ago with the maiden voyage from Norway to Britain of the new 7,000-ton liner Leda. Outwardly, as she plowed across the North Sea on her twenty-one hour voyage from Stavanger to the River Tyne, there was nothing about her glossy black hull, her gleaming white superstructure or her rakish black and white funnel to suggest anything out of the ordinary.

PARENTS of teen-agers don't have to be told that these youngsters can be pretty baffling. Their perception, their understanding and their knowledge at times surprise adults. At other times their perverseness (or what looks like it to adults) is enough to tempt parents to disclaim ownership.

The magnitude of the problem with regard to wheat which now faces our Government has been brought sharply into the open by recent testimony before the House Agriculture Committee. This committee is now considering proposals to raise the minimum wheat acreage quota to be allowed if the Government tries to reimpose marketing controls on wheat growers.

You'd think that the Winter Garden people would be satisfied with having "Wonderful Town," a solid hit, in their house without trying to squeeze extra cash out of seats from which one absolutely cannot see the show!

The auction season, which always seems to come to an abrupt end at this time of year, will terminate officially this week for the country's largest house, the Parke-Bernet Galleries, and very soon after that for most other galleries. As usual, some of the galleries will hold sporadic sales, but important merchandise and quantity of selection will not be available again through this channel until summer's end.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 6 -- Fine weather today brought out sixty-five craft, the largest fleet of the campaign, for the season's fifth Yacht Racing Association regatta on Long Island Sound. Eight classes were represented.

IN his review of my book "Malenkov: Stalin's Successor" Warren B. Walsh writes that I accept the theory that "Malenkov and Beria are partners rather than opponents." I would like to supplement the reviewer's observations.

ST. LOUIS, June 6 -- For a brief time today the Browns were even with the Yankees, but the seventh-place club could not stay with the champions, who moved from a 2-2 tie in the fifth to a 6-2 triumph, their ninth in a row. This matched the longest string since Casey Stengel took charge of the Bombers in 1949, since the 1950 Yankees won nine straight, too.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., June 7 -- The defending champion and the tournament favorite were eliminated in the semi-final round today as Billy Dear Jr., of Morris County and Lloyd Ribner of Aldecress became the New Jersey amateur golf championship finalists at the Essex Fells Country Club.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 6 -- Hi-Lo's Forbes, owned by Mr. and Mrs. E. M. Wagner of Landover Hills, Md., and driven by Henry Clukey, broke the world record for pacing on a half-mile track when he won the $6,000 Port Washington free-for-all in 1:58 3/5 tonight before 32,488, a record for Roosevelt Raceway.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, June 6 (AP) -- The West Germans have drafted ambitious plans for a new aviation industry to challenge United States and British supremacy in the air when an eight-year Allied ban is lifted.

The continued vulnerability of the Government bond market to occasional sudden price declines on a light volume of business is an uncomfortable fact belying the projects of debt management theorists and likely to aggravate for many months to come the formidable financing jobs confronting the Treasury.

COBALT, Ont., June 6 -- Residents of this battered little mining town have two exciting things to talk about these days. One is their jubilee from July 5 to 16. The other is the prospect that the once-fabulous silver mines here may again become important to the world -- this time as a source of cobalt, the essential jet-engine metal.
PARENTS or teachers may well tuck all three of these factual books about animals, into the children's summer knapsacks before they trek off to the country.
The Giants nimbly made off with another game at the expense of the last-place Cubs at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

RADIO'S role in allowing home listeners to sit in on historic events used to seem an ephemeral one. But with the rise of the documentary phonograph record, it is becoming clear that radio's work has been of lasting value. By keeping recordings of its broadcasts, radio has established archives of audible history.

MR. SELIGMAN was a war worker in Washington; he later saw Army service; and is now the vice president of a theatre corporation in Cincinnati. Out of this experience and a not inconsiderable ability to write, he has produced this story about influence peddling in the nation's capital. It's called "Honey on the Hill" for rather obvious reasons.

SEOUL, Korea, June 7 (AP) -- South Korean infantrymen, battling at close quarters by the eerie light of flares, regained early today more than half of the eastern-front ground they lost to North Korean Reds yesterday.

AN average episode in the newspaper career of Henry McLemore would be that time he covered a Mississippi flood dressed in a Tulane University football suit. The United Press was in a hurry and the uniform was the only warm outfit he could borrow.

Women active in behalf of the Girls Service League have taken over blocks of seats at the matinee of the Sadler's Wells Ballet on the afternoons of Sept. 26 and Oct. 3 at the Metropolitan Opera House and a large portion of the house on the night of Oct. 8 to raise funds for the organization. Mrs. Fraser M. Horn is chairman and Miss Virginia Thaw, vice chairman, of the benefit committee.
PORT CHESTER, N. Y., June 6 -- The remarkable successes of a 4 1/2-year-old red smooth dachshund, Ch. Hardway Welcome Stranger, continued in the twenty-first show of the Greenwich Kennel Club today.

NOW 59, Roger Vercel, whose first novel came out in France in the early Thirties. appeared here first in translation in 1935 with "Captain Conan." American popularity arrived when the Book-of-the-Month Club chose "The Tides of Mont St. Michel" in 1938.

ROME, June 6 -- Somewhere between 25,000,000 and 28,000,000 Italians out of a total electorate of close to 30,500,000 are expected to vote tomorrow and Monday in their country's first general elections since 1948. Their votes will determine the political complexion of both the Senate and the Chamber for some years to come.

CONSTRUCTION of new legimate theatres within office buildings and apartment houses in New York appears to have emerged from the visionary stage. Last week the City Council passed local laws providing for amendments to the city building code that would permit the erection of the new playhouses. The changes in the code, which formerly prohibited building above the stage, are expected to be approved soon by Mayor Impellitteri.

MILAN, Italy, June 6 (AP) -- The American Chamber of Commerce in Italy sent a telegram of "strong opposition and exception" last night to statements of the Cleveland industrialist. Frederick C. Crawford, before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

IN his apartment near Columbia University, Maurice Young, a tall, ruggedly good-looking fellow, is working on his Master's degree. On the surface, his study room reflects the normal grind before final examinations -- the desk littered with research papers in his chosen field.

TANGLEWOOD will embark on a fresh experiment this summer. It will attempt to set up a helpful environment for the creation of new operas by American composers, and if it has any kind of luck with this venture, it will be showing a fruitful way to other institutions in the United States.

MARY COLUM'S review of Van Wyck Brooks' "The Writer in America" reports that he is a propagandist for a "belief in the goodness of man and optimism." She suggests that "the ghost of Irving Babbitt" is behind this philosophy.

COLUMBIA, S. C., June 6 (UP) -- T. C. Callison, State Attorney General, said today he believed "a great majority of both races in South Carolina will be perfectly satisfied" to attend segregated schools, even if the Supreme Court outlawed segregation.

BOOKS about the Soviet Union normally fall into two categories. The "I was there" group written by former correspondents, diplomats, ex-slave laborers and the like -- usually confine themselves to a description of what the author saw and heard during a long or short stay behind the iron curtain The "I worked hard in the library" group is based primarily upon research in and study of different Soviet publications.

THERE is no better way for the rose lover to beat the calendar and have June the year around than to collect books about his favorite flower. Rose literature is so rich and varied that the enthusiast will find books dealing with every phase from its history to its symbolism, to its care and propagation.

PITTSBURGH, June 6 (AP) -- Sand traps at the Oakmont Country Club will be furrowed for the National open golf championship next week, but not to the extent that they were ridged at the course for previous open tourneys.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 6 -- For the second time within two months, the Greenwich Representative Town Meeting will debate Monday evening two controversial issues -- a primary bill that would alter the nominating procedure for public offices and a move to discontinue rent controls now governing the 5,000 rental units in Greenwich.

FOR nearly thirty-five years Ward Morehouse, now with The New York World-Telegram and Sun, has specialized in Broadway after dark. Any Cybernetic calculator probably would grind its gears to dust before computing the square miles of pulpwood consumed by various New York newspapers in carrying the eight million words Morehouse pecked out for them with two fingers on his typewriter.

SABA, N. W. I. -- A delightful and unusual summer holiday for an adventurous vacationist who is in no particular hurry can be made by plane and schooner combination. From the American Virgins east to Antigua are the best cruising waters in the world, according to yachtsmen.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- For a party that took such a pasting at the polls only seven months ago, the Democrats are in a remarkably buoyant and optimistic frame of mind.
Hunter College will conduct this summer its first vacation demonstration school to help prepare teachers of children from the gifted to the mentally and physically handicapped.

Despite the "Battle of the Brands," waged with increasing fury since the growth of the supermarkets and other self-service retail outlets, many old brand names are still going strong. A check with the Brand Names Foundation last week disclosed that some of these are 125 to 247 years old and identify products such as food, liquor, silverware, china and books.

SALAMANCA, N. Y. -- In the roster of New York State Parks, Allegany State Park, which begins just south of this town, rates as one of the state's largest. Its 57,000 hilly, rolling acres, lying along the Pennsylvania border near the western corner of the state, are beautiful to see and fun to visit.

TECHNICAL developments in bridge between about 1936 and 1949 were few and far between; then there began to be a lot of them. Introduction of point-count valuation caused new books to be written. The authors of new bridge books like to introduce new bidding devices.

From a recently published history of France it appears that some of the troubles of the Governments of the Fourth Republic have an ancient origin. There is the question of taxes, which all Frenchmen, it is said, are loath to pay.

DENVER, June 6 (AP) -- The marriage of Ethel Merman, stage and screen star, to Robert F. Six, president of Continental Air Lines, has been confirmed in a company announcement. They were married at Mexicali, Mexico, on March 9.

UNTIL I worked in "Julius Caesar," I had always been somewhat sceptical as to the artistic merit of presenting Shakespeare's plays in another medium. The film of "Henry V." it is true, was a remarkable achievement.

' Your Undoubted Queen' For centuries British writers have been explaining to the rest of the world two national mysteries: the British character and the British monarchy. One of them, Walter Bagehot writing in the days of the Empress-Queen Victoria, summarized the monarchy's attributes as follows:

HOPES that the fabulous treasures of the Barnes Foundation in Merion, Pa., would be freely available for public view are now dashed to the ground. This week the Pennsylvania State Supreme Court by a 4-2 vote refused to overrule a decision by the Montgomery County Court which last year dismissed a bill in equity seeking to force the foundation to open the art collection to the public.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 6 -- Gov. Christian A. Herter said here today that the world had discovered since World War II that "while it is terribly possible to lose a war it is tragically impossible to win a war." Speaking at the 164th Williams College commencement, he added:
New York University will offer 1,364 courses in the summer sessions of its schools and colleges.

BOSTON, June 6 -- A "federal union" of the American Unitarian Association and the Universalist Church of America has been accepted on a preliminary basis by a majority of the accredited churches involved.

THOMAS LOVE PEACOCK, the English novelist, sagely observed to his early nineteenth-century readers that "fresh air and liberty are all that is necessary to the happiness of children." Would it were still so in this uproarious mid-twentieth century with its auto-ruled streets, cramped play areas and parents who "just can't find the time" to guide their children into creative activity.

With the Federal Government having to take over for long-term storage an estimated 1,000,000,000 bushels of wheat and corn, which must be added to what is already in commercial storage, the farmer's chance of finding elevator space for storing his grain this year is poorer than ever.

SKEPTICS who scoff at the gilding which the film-makers sometimes put on the usually quite adequate lilies of factual history might pause for a moment to consider the extraordinary sequence of events leading up to a recent Hollywood triumph -- and then, perhaps, better understand.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican-Liberal of New York, warned yesterday that the United States might be driving Western European allies and possibly the entire free world into stronger trade relations with Russia.

CHUCK, a 13-year-old boy living in the Florida Pineland, knows animals the way most folks know folks; he says so himself toward the end of the story. After an attack of polio, when Chuck is inclined to make little effort to walk again, Piney the baby skunk completes his cure.

AFTER six years of living apart the Cannon sisters, Tracy and Tina, inherit a rundown old house in the Berkshire Mountains. Twenty-two-year-old Tracy is a popular though restless debutante. Tina, at 16, has shuttled back and forth between expensive boarding schools and her aunt's cheerless home.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 6 -- The Alumnae Association of Smith College elected Mrs. G. Lyle Fischer of Glencoe, Ill., president at the group's annual meeting today. More than 1,600 alumnae are at the college this weekend for a reunion program and the College's seventy-fifth college commencement.

MISS PICKEREL, the sensible spinster who kept her feet on the ground, so to speak, even when she landed on Mars, is back again and equal to any emergency. This story concerns rocks full of uranium, her twin nephews, Homer and Harry, and, of course, her beloved cow.
A baccalaureate service this afternoon opens New York University's 121st commencement week, to be capped Wednesday morning by the awarding of degrees to 7,300 graduates.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 6 -- The news that an armistice seems to be in the making in Korea is the news the United Nations has been living for these past three years. But beyond the thankfulness that the killing would stop, there was no great elation, no political sigh of relief, but a feeling of vast uneasiness.

President and Congress The first session of the Eighty-third Congress is well advanced; and so far little legislation has gone to the President for signature. The Congress would like to go home in August, and the White House is quite willing because many Cabinet members are eager to get in some concentrated work unbroken by trips to the Hill to testify.
Harry Gilroy's piece on Brooklyn Bridge's seventieth anniversary was fascinating. Would he answer three questions?

Governor Dewey announced yesterday at the State Capitol in Albany a list of twenty-one persons who will give their views tomorrow on the State Crime Commission's recommendations for cleaning up the racket-ridden New York waterfront.

" COMMUNISM," said Orwell, "is the patriotism of the deracines." "The Captive Mind" by Czeslaw Milosz is the most important soul-searching ever published about this love affair -- actually a love-hate ambivalence -- between communism and uprooted intellectuals.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 6 (UP) -- Eighty-two crew members escaped the explosions and fire from 160,000 barrels of high-test gasoline after two huge tankers collided in the Delaware River near here early today. The Coast Guard reported one body had been recovered and two other men were believed missing.

FOUR bills to obtain Government assistance for music and other fine arts have been submitted to the House of Representatives by four Congressmen. The bills have been referred to the House Committee on Education and Labor.

The first week in June was ushered in with a sharp decline in stocks, bonds and commodities. Among the factors credited with keeping financial markets under depressing influences were the continued suspense regarding Korean truce negotiations and uncertainty about taxes.

NOW that tomatoes have been set out, gardeners are not always satisfied to watch them grow. They may also be interested in obtaining earlier or more numerous fruits by the use of plant growth hormones.

Men and women who teach in or administer schools and colleges will again become students when the six-week program of the Columbia University summer session at Teachers College opens on July 6. Teachers will come from every state in the union and from many foreign countries.

CLEVER camouflage conceals the television set in many homes today. Several examples illustrated here show the present trend toward incorporating the "monster" into a storage unit which is made to serve other purposes as well, thus justifying the necessarily bulky appearance of the set.

HARTFORD, June 6 -- Insurance company taxation has become a major issue in Connecticut. It came to the fore during the final week of the General Assembly session, which ended May 30 after a five-month meeting. Democrats, during a debate on insurance company taxes, said they would make the issue a major one during the 1954 state election campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 -- Robin Roberts, the Phillies' big fireball right-hander, scored his ninth victory of the season and the 100th of his major league career today as he set back the Braves with three hits for a 6-2 triumph.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Holes in the leaves of tomato seedlings set out recently are made by flea beetles; dust weekly with rotenone. To prevent spread of late blight disease, favored by warm, rainy days and cool nights, spray plants with a copper fungicide according to directions. A hormone spray on the first blossoms encourages earlier setting of fruit.

WASHINGTON. AT a large private gathering in Washington a few weeks ago President Eisenhower introduced his younger brother, Milton, who is president of Pennsylvania State College, by saying, "he's a man of whom I've always been proud to say -- my brother."

PARIS, June 6 -- Foreign Minister Georges Bidault, who alone with Robert Schuman has conducted French foreign policy since World War II, announced today that he would try to form a Cabinet and would ask approval of the National Assembly Tuesday or Wednesday.
Warren B. Walsh has performed a vital service in his article "Can We 'Co-Exist' With Soviet Russia?" (May 24) by stating what the basic differences are between the Soviet and Western worlds.

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., June 6 -- Mustang, owned by Rodney Stephens Jr., won the New London-to-Shelter Island week - end cruise in the Class A-1 division for large cruising boats, scoring on corrected time for the two days of sailing that ended today after a stopover at Montauk Point Friday night.

Women headed by Mrs. Irving Miller Snow, chairman; Mrs. Frederic H. Fairweather, vice chairman, and Mrs. William A. Barstow, chairman of the hospitality committee, are furthering the success of the second annual outdoor dinner dance to be held on the night of June 11 on the Park Avenue Terrace and the adjoining auditorium of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church.
IT has been said of Luigi Cherubini that he lived so long and acquired such a reputation as a pedant that people forgot that he had once been a composer.

A fourth blood donor center will be opened by the American Red Cross here next Wednesday at the Sub-Treasury Building, recently renamed Federal Hall, at Wall and Nassau Streets. It is for the convenience of the many New Yorkers employed in the financial district.
THE teen-age insecurity that results from rocking between childhood and adulthood forms the pattern of this absorbing story.

Mrs. Ben F. Whitaker's Grecian Queen was a tired filly in the final yards of the $63,600 Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park yesterday, but she managed to keep going long enough to win by a nose from the Belair Stud's Sabette, who had been ten lengths back of her with a little more than a quarter of a mile to go.
MIAMI, June 6 (UP) -- A 15-year-old boy described today a fight for his life with a seven-foot alligator.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- President Eisenhower has made what may turn out to be a major concession to high-tariff Congressional Republicans in agreeing to enlargement of the United States Tariff Commission as the price of favorable action on his request for a one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.
It is an encouraging sign of the times that the General Federation of Labor in Israel (The Histadrut) has decided to throw in its lot with the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

Whether the United States Mint will manufacture the 20,000,000 tokens the New York City Transit Authority needs if it increases the fare on the subway lines remained uncertain yesterday despite efforts by Governor Dewey to obtain a favorable commitment from Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey.

Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, heroic skipper of the ill-fated Isbrandtsen cargo liner Flying Enterprise, will get the Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal on Tuesday. The medal was voted by Congress fifteen months ago but the captain's heavy sailing schedule has postponed formal presentation.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad -- Kipling, would have felt at home here. This British colony of polyglot population, tropical mountains, coffee and cocoa plantations, oil wells, asphalt lake, steel bands, calypsos and sunburned planters has something of the flavor of his tales.

One more Wednesday noon-to-2 P. M. concert will be given by the New York Public Library in the Fifth Avenue building before the popular recorded programs are moved to Bryant Park. This week's offerings in Room 213 will include selections from Mendelssohn's "Midsummer Night's Dream," the 'Liebestod" from Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" as recorded at the 1927 Bayreuth Festival and works by Bach, Schubert, Strauss and Mozart.

A STANDARD canard of the long-hair litterateur is that slick magazines such as The Saturday Evening Post never print stories of genuine literary merit. It is true that the Post prints its share of shallow diversions, but any long-hair who ventures from his ivory tower to a newsstand must honor the corrections of experience.

A clean single to left center by Jackie Robinson, a bad-hop single on a double play ball by Roy Campanella and Gil Hodges' second home run of the game, all in the ninth inning, yesterday gave the Dodgers a 5-4 victory over the Cardinals at Ebbets Field and returned them to first place in the National League.

ALTHOUGH most annuals are usually grown in and need full sun, I have found that a surprising number tolerate and give fair to good bloom in light shade. And then there are a few which actually prefer some shade.

MILWAUKEE, June 6 -- The sad news from Brooklyn on Thursday afternoon that the Dodgers finally had turned back the Braves, 10 to 5, brought to this baseball-crazy city the rude realization that you can't win them all, especially against the champions, but the thrill of having taken the series from the Dodgers and moving into first place still had dizzy Milwaukeeans walking around in circles and pounding strangers on the back.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 6 (AP) -- Aubrey Lewis, Negro star from Montclair High, today broke three records as he led his school to a Group IV title at the thirty-fifth annual New Jersey Interscholastic A. A. track and field championships.

Fordham University's 108th commencement week will begin with baccalaureate services at 11 A. M. today and continue to Wednesday. Degrees will be conferred on 1,360 students at two ceremonies on the campus. The College of Arts and Sciences will hold its exercises on Tuesday at 3:30 P. M. Commencement exercises for the other schools will be on Wednesday at 4:30 P. M.

Recent field studies have disclosed that Brazil possesses some of the earth's richest deposits of uranium and thorium, sources of atomic energy, and this wealth is expected to be turned to the production of cheap industrial power within five years, the chief of Brazilian atomic research declared yesterday.

Atlantic City will see today what is expected to be the largest convention of dealers ever held by a single manufacturer. About 7,500 retailers of radios, television receivers and appliances made by Philco Corporation will appear in Convention Hall at the invitation of William Balderston, Philco president.
The United States has lost its sense of maritime history and is drifting back to a policy of dependence upon the vessels of foreign maritime nations, it was charged yesterday.

Within the next week or two, nearly 30,000,000 boys and girls will pour happily out of the nation's classrooms to begin their summer vacation. But for educational officials it will not be a time of complete relaxation. Rather, for many, it will be a time of stocktaking, of looking back at problems partially solved and looking ahead at unfinished business requiring attention.
TAEGU, Korea, June 6 (AP) -- An Air Force officer was arrested today and accused of having ordered two enlisted men to shoot a Korean at an Allied air base in South Korea last September.

DALLAS, June 6 (UP) -- Gay Brewer of the University of Kentucky and Joe Conrad of North Texas State set up an all-collegiate final today for the Southern amateur golf championship Brewer won a year ago.

A PREVALENT myth has it that the short story collection cannot climb over a ceiling of 6,500 copies sold. Publishers have maintained it and readers appear to have sustained it. This year, however, and perhaps unprecedented, some eighteen collections (not counting anthologies and the like) are appearing on publishers' lists like brave pawns on a chessboard.

AT a Rilke commemoration in the Twenties, the Austrian writer, Robert Musil, indignantly scored the "second-class public burial" that the publications of the day had accorded the great lyric poet. Musil must have felt that a similar fate would be in store for him -- and it was.

CHANTILLY, France, June 6 -- Ernie Arend Jr. of Deal, N. J., last American in the French amateur golf championship, bowed out in the semi-finals today after beating the only other remaining United States player in the morning quarter-finals.

ASNIERES -- where Constant and Yvonne Boursier and their three children live -- is to Paris as Jamaica, say, or Hoboken is to Manhattan: far enough out to qualify as suburban; not distant enough, and in the wrong direction, to be either quaint or smart.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Senators Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, and H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, endorsed today a proposal by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Senate Republican leader, that the United States seek a military alliance with Britain, France and other allies to counter communism in the Far East.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 6 -- The Dutch and Australian Governments have reached an agreement in principle to join forces in the economic, social and administrative development of New Guinea.

CINCINNATI, June 6 -- Neither cultural fads nor nationalism nor philanthropy can or should displace the religious faith of Judaism as basic for Jews, Rabbi Levi A. Olan of Temple Emanu-El, Dallas, Tex, said in the sermon at graduation exercises of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion this morning in Rockdale Avenue Temple.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 6 (AP) -- Rex Ellsworth's Fleet Khal outlasted the favored Calumet Farm's A Gleam in the stretch today to capture the $27,850 Vanity Handicap at Hollywood Park.

STANTON, Del., June 6 (AP) -- One of the largest crowds in the history of Delaware Park -- 28,847 -- saw Post Card give Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords a third straight triumph in the Brandywine Handicap today.
DETROIT, June 6 (AP) -- Minus production and credit controls the auto industry is roaring along at near record levels.
Unless Congress exerts exceptional efforts to extend it, the Reciprocal Agreements Act will expire next Friday.

TO many enthusiastic growers of modern iris, it is a surprise to learn that there is a whole colorful section of iris that supplement and extend the blooming season of the tall Bearded varieties. They are the bulbous rooted iris, especially the hybrid race known as Dutch iris.

The New School for Social Research announces the formation of a Public Relations Association, to consist of students and alumni of the school who have taken courses in the field of public relations and communications. At the opening meeting this Tuesday Edward L. Bernays, authority in this field, will speak on "Public Relations Graduates Never Graduate."

One of the best bits of post-coronation news is the announcement that the choir of St. Paul's Cathedral in London will visit the United States this year for a two-month tour of more than forty engagements. This magnificent choir, which participated in the coronation, has never before left the United Kingdom.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 7 -- United Nations and Communist truce delegates met in three short sessions at Panmunjom today, then adjourned until 11 A. M. tomorrow [10 P. M. Sunday, Eastern daylight time], without announcing an agreement in principle on a truce in the three-year-old war.

MOAB, Utah -- Thanks to the needs of uranium mining companies and oil exploration outfits, a hair-raising, eighteen-mile stretch of so-called highway has been bulldozed to Dead Horse Point near here, a spot 3,000 feet above the muddy Colorado River which local fanciers of scenery consider equal to any view of the Colorado that one can find in the more accessible Grand Canyon in Arizona.

The announcement by Gordon Dean, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, that a breeder reactor is in successful experimental operation is of the highest importance. A breeder reactor is one in which plutonium or some other fissionable material would be produced at a more rapid rate than it is consumed in a chain reaction.

There are all kinds of fishermen, as well as persons who do not fish at all. Probably the most baffling of the cult are the still-fishermen, those who spend hours in a small boat or on the bank with a bamboo pole or a bait rod, apparently sitting in the sun with no pressing purpose, no worries, no energy.

REFLECTING the widening amateur interest and activity in color photography, Photography Magazine in its July issue, out this week, inaugurates a series of sixteen-page color sections, the largest ever published by a photographic magazine, designed to illustrate and describe the varied uses and techniques of the medium.

MOSCOW, Sunday, June 7 -- The Soviet Council of Ministers announced this morning a new Russian set-up for Austria that places Soviet policy firmly under the direction of the Moscow Foreign Office through the employment of a new civilian High Commissioner and the relegation of the military to the secondary role of commanding the Soviet Army's occupation forces.

NO better orientation could be desired for understanding the plans and achievements of the 1952 Swiss Expeditions to Mount Everest, this year's British operation, and the French attempt projected for 1954 than these two additions to the literature of the Goddess Mother of the World.

Under present exceptionally high income tax rates, corporation executives and other employes have little incentive or opportunity to provide for their future security. Increased compensation to those already in the higher brackets offers no real solution.

Back in 1903 a blond seaman arrived here from the little Norwegian village of Lillesand determined to get away from life aboard ships. He was 20-year-old Jacob H. Hanssen, who during four years of sailing to the four corners of the earth had made the painful discovery that he got seasick every time out.

DURING the latter part of April anyone traveling through the countryside by car or train may have noticed patches of bronze green spikes emerging from the earth, generally near large trees. By now these patches are large green leaves on stems a foot to a foot and a half tall, and if any one of these leaves were lifted this weekend probably there might still be a white flower underneath.

THREE weeks ago this Sabbath encyclical consisted of a highly moral lecture on the necessity for literate books in musical comedies. "Can-Can" was the sinner pilloried on that occasion. Now it becomes necessary to take similar action against the Rodgers and Hammerstein "Me and Juliet," which opened ten days ago at the Majestic.

A peak attendance of 125,000 Jehovah's Witnesses from ninety countries is expected July 19 to 26 at Yankee Stadium and a trailer camp in New Jersey at their next triennial international assembly, J. O. Groh, executive director of the Watchtower Convention, 557 West 157th Street, announced yesterday.
PARIS, June 7 -- A further increase in the French trade deficit with the European Payments Union has been reported for May.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 7 -- Susan, piloted by Emil Mosbacher Jr., led a fleet of seventeen internationals over a nine-and-a-quarter-mile course today in the season's sixth Yacht Racing Association regatta on Long Island Sound. The victory was the second in two days and third in a row for Susan.
Educated persons must take up their responsibilities to the community if bosses and demagogues are to be driven from public life, New York University's class of '53 was told yesterday.

A one-story taxpayer building containing eleven stores and occupying a plot 80 by 100 feet at 258-60 East Gunhill Road, in the Bronx, has been sold by the Remens Realty Corporation to an investing client of Leo Kotler, attorney.
SEOUL, Monday, June 8 (AP) -Through yesterday, men still fought and died in the mountains and in the skies of Korea.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $76,743,199,646. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Control of the National Paper and Type Company has been acquired by Otis, McAllister Co., one of the country's largest coffee importers. J. B. Sprague Johnson, chairman of Otis, McAllister, disclosed over the week-end that his company had purchased 105,000 common shares, or 82 1/2 per cent, of the outstanding common stock of National Paper and Type.

Modernization and expansion of the retail outlet promises to be one of the fastest growing factors in the economy this year. The Store Modernization Institute reported yesterday as the result of a survey that in 1953 retailers will spend more than $5,000,000,000 in sprucing up their present premises, building new ones and in putting in the latest in materials handling equipment both in their warehouses and stores.

" GRINNELL, Iowa, June 7 -- K. C. Wu, former Governor of Formosa, received an honorary Doctor of Laws degree today from Grinnell College, where he was cited as "a valiant fighter for democratic principles in the Orient."

JERSEY CITY, June 7 -- Honorary degrees of Doctor of Laws were conferred today by St. Peter's College upon the Most Rev. Thomas A. Boland, Archbishop of Newark, and the Very Rev. Philip E. Dobson, president of Canisius College, Buffalo.

The casual life of summer with its added freedom for boys and girls may provide more opportunities for young children to gain in musical understanding than the busiest concert season, according to Hugh K. McElheny, music director at the New Lincoln School and the Vassar College Summer Institute.

Prices of cotton futures held steady last week on the New York Cotton Exchange. At the close of trading on Friday final prices were unchanged to 45 cents a bale higher. There were many influences tugging at the market from both directions but they tended to cancel themselves out.

LONG RIDGE, Conn., June 7 -- A lone, wild beaver has moved into a small lake on a private estate here, only thirty-four miles from Times Square, and is waging a constant determined battle against the owners for the riparian rights.

Controller Lazarus Joseph criticized present state old-age assistance yesterday as insufficient to meet the demands of the growing population of persons over 65 years old. He charged also that the state's contribution to the city's welfare budget was inadequate.

" The Spirit of St. Louis," a new plume of reminiscences by Charles A. Lindbergh, has been scheduled for Sept. 14 publication by Scribner. The author describes his book as being "about flying and an aviator's line in the beginning third of the twentieth century."

ROBERT EDLER VON MUSIL, an Austrian writer who died in exile in Switzerland eleven years ago, spent the last twenty years of his life working on an enormous novel which he left unfinished. Today less than one-fourth of that novel is published in this country under the title Musil applied to the whole: "The Man Without Qualities."* No novel in recent years has been heralded by such fanfares of critical hosannas.
ARCADIA, Neb., June 7 -- A tornado struck a farm near here today where ten persons were holding an informal family reunion, instantly killing all ten and knocking the farm buildings to the ground.

Summer brings a special message to our city's children -- an open invitation to share in the delightful offerings of the season. For most children this means a vacation in the country, a swim in the lake, a trip to the mountains or the seashore.

Children of all ages were on hand yesterday to view plastic trapeze artists performing on papier-mache swings and a rubber hippopotamus waddling in a wooden cage, part of the Dickenson Brothers Circus displayed at the New Church ( Swedenborgian ), 118 East Thirty-fifth Street.

NEWARK, June 7 -- Six thousand employes of six breweries in the Newark area will vote tomorrow at a series of meeting in the Labor Lyceum here on a contract designed to end a sixteen-day strike. Agreement on new terms was reached at 4 A. M. today by negotiators for the New Jersey Brewers Association and the three American Federation of Labor unions concerned.

WITH UNITED STATES I CORPS, Korea, Monday, June 8 -- President Syngman Rhee of the Republic of Korea said today that he had not yet decided whether he would accept the terms outlined by President Eisenhower's letter appealing for cooperation and acceptance of an impending armistice.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A record sum of $20,391,000 in cash was turned over to the United Jewish Appeal today to enable it to carry out urgent programs of rescue, settlement, welfare and rehabilitation in Israel, and on behalf of needy Jewish men, women and children throughout the world.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- State and diplomatic officials declined tonight to comment directly on reports that the United States might take the initiative in reviving negotiations between the British and Egyptian Governments to resolve their Suez differences.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Legislation aimed at removing the Long Island Rail Road from the jurisdiction of the Interstate Commerce Commission was proposed today by Representative Steven B. Derounian, Republican of New York.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The number of births in the United States continues to rise, the Public Health Service reported today.

MEXICO CITY, June 7 -- The State Department has ordered a 25 per cent cut in personnel at the United States Embassy in Mexico as part of its general economy drive affecting all American missions in the hemisphere.

PITTSBURGH, June 7 -- This week the steel industry was still going strong with no signs of any slackening in the high operating rate in evidence. Last week's activity was unchanged at 100.5 per cent of capacity. It was a sure bet that the industry would continue at or near 100 per cent for the balance of this month -- and into July. This view was based on:

ROME, June 7 -- If all Italians vote the way they are voting in the ancient Roman town of Tivoli, a typical community about twenty miles from the capital, today's election will be uncomfortably close. Tivoli is known to travelers because of the green gardens and lively fountains of the Villa d'Este.

A state of "indifference" and "the quality apathy" are major impediments to man's progress, the Rev. Laurance I. Neale said yesterday in his sermon on "New Alibis for Old," in the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

KATONAH, N. Y., June 7 -- In a setting that would not have been amiss for eighteenth - century princely entertainment, Mozart's opera, "The Elopement from the Seraglio," was presented here last night at Caramoor, the estate of Mrs. Lucie Bigelow Rosen.

The Department of Commerce, which received responsibility for the national merchant marine in the reorganization of governmental agencies several years ago, is now embarking on an intensive drive for a sound shipping policy.

While controversy rages in Washington over the reduction of the Air Force's budget and as its B-47 medium bombers were marking up speed records for mass and individual flights to England, the Boeing Airplane Company of Seattle launched a calm and reasoned explanation of its eight-jet strategic bomber, the B-52, by way of editorial advertisements in this and other newspapers beginning today.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -Following is the text of President Eisenhower's letter to President Syngman Rhee of the Republic of Korea on a Korean truce, as released by the White House today:

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- President Eisenhower has told President Syngman Rhee of the Republic of Korea that acceptance of the latest Communist proposals for a Korean truce "is required" of the United Nations and called for their acceptance also by the Government of South Korea.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 7 -- John N. Matthews' sharp-looking 12-meter Vim captured the Henry C. Taylor Trophy as the New York Yacht Club's annual two-day cruise finished tonight off the Mattinicock Point bell buoy.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 7 -- An Irish setter familiar to a number of persons who aren't regular visitors at dog shows scored in the event of Longshore-Southport Kennel Club today.

The need for more Roman Catholic priests to serve as "bridge builders between God and man" in this country as well as in foreign missions was stressed yesterday by the Rev. Charles J. McManus of the St. Patrick's Cathedral staff.

DALLAS, June 7 (UP) -- Joe Conrad, a little, freckle-faced senior from North Texas State, methodically took the southern amateur golf crown away from the defending champion, Gay Brewer of the University of Kentucky, today by a 6-and-4 margin.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, announced yesterday that he was adding 140 temporary employes to the staffs of rent offices in the metropolitan area to process 8,000 complaints by tenants that their landlords were failing to provide services and facilities.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Robert B. Anderson, the Secretary of the Navy, claimed special advantages for naval air power over land-based planes today in the midst of the controversy over cuts in Air Force funds. The Navy, by using aircraft carriers, does not need bases on foreign soil, he said, and these carriers "are able to deliver their planes close to the targets."

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, June 8 -- An official spokesman for the Republic of Korea Government said today that President Eisenhower's letter to President Syngman Rhee had caused no change in the attitude of the Korean Government.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 7 -- A meeting of the United Nations General Assembly following a truce in Korea may be delayed at least until mid-July, delegates here believe, to give the United States, Britain and France time to reconcile conflicting views at the forthcoming Bermuda parley.

READING, Pa., June 7 (UP) -- Betsy Rawls lost an eight-stroke lead today in the final round of the women's Eastern open golf tournament but won $1,250 first-prize money in a sudden-death play-off with Patty Berg.

A new Sunday dramatic documentary series on the part played by American industry in the community, featuring comments by leaders in each major field, will begin June 21 from 1:30 to 2 P. M. over the A. B. C.-TV network.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 7 --Premier Nguyen Van Tam demanded today that treaties linking Vietnam to France be scrapped for new ones that would let this state take part in international decisions affecting its own future.

PITTSBURGH, June 7 (AP) -- Memphis' golfing dentist, Dr. Cary Middlecoff, and Claude Harmon, the Winged Foot Club pro from Mamaroneck, N. Y., defied Oakmont's reputation for invincibility with sparkling sub-par practice rounds today -- then both said the course could be beaten.

ALGIERS, June 5 -- Evidence of human industry in the early millenniums of the Pleistocene epoch, 500,000 years or more ago, was presented by a French palaeontologist here tonight in the form of crudely chipped stone implements that may well be the oldest known works of man.
ABILENE, Tex., June 7 (AP) -- Pardon Walter Davis, please, if he takes an engineer along with him to the national A. A. U. track and field meet at Dayton, Ohio, June 26-27.

It is good news that the Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Representative Daniel A. Reed, has agreed to cease obstructing the passage of the bill extending the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act and will graciously permit his committee to vote on the extension tomorrow morning.
TOKYO, Monday, June 8 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,639 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korean time:

The pastors of two mid-Manhattan churches celebrated anniversaries in the ministry yesterday and recounted in their sermons the great changes that had come to their churches and to the surrounding city during the years.

ROME, Monday, June 8 -- Italians trooped to the polls in large numbers yesterday on the first day of two days of voting for a new Senate and a new Chamber of Deputies. The large turnout is believed to have improved the prospects of the Center coalition led by Premier Alcide De Gasperi and composed of his Christian Democrats, the Right-Wing Socialists, the Liberals and the Republicans.

Msgr. Thomas J. McMahon, national secretary of the Catholic Near East Welfare Association, in a baccalaureate day sermon in the St. John the Baptist de la Salle Chapel of Manhattan College, assailed yesterday the anti-Christian forces that would try to drive a wedge between the clergy and the laity of the Catholic world.

The third game of the series of eighteen between Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires for the chess championship of the West was adjourned after forty-one moves at the Argentine Chess Club in Buenos Aires yesterday, according to a report received through Argentine news sources.

Summer television is upon the hapless viewer with the first of the "replacements" that no doubt will continue well into August. The initial victim, besides the set owner, is Hoagy Carmichael, the composer and gravel-throated singer, who is filling in for Sid Caesar and Imogene Coca from 9 to 10:30 P. M. Saturdays over N. B. C.

HARDLY any New Yorker who hears the twenty-four-hour-cycle sound-effects background for the Museum of Natural History's current "Man of the Montana" show could guess what time and anguish went into the recording.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Atomic Energy Commission has launched an all-out program to produce hydrogen bombs and is making atomic weapons so fast it needs more space to store them, it was revealed today.

Anybody who has tried to mail a package after 6 o'clock at one of the major post offices in the country -- the Grand Central Branch -- cannot but feel that the office is run with a deliberate contempt for the taxpayer.

Copies of the first handbook on group bicycle play to be published by the Bicycle Institute of America are available, the institute has announced. Titled "Bike Fun," the booklet contains a hundred ideas for lively two-wheeler games, hikes, races, stunts and similar activities for young enthusiasts.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 7 -- Princeton University's traditional year-ending program will begin Thursday with alumni reunions and end Tuesday, June 16, with the 206th commencement.

The first of a series of open-air Sunday morning worship services for families planning to spend most of their day of rest in picnicking was conducted yesterday at the Whitestone Bridge Drive-In Theatre, Bruckner Boulevard and Hutchinson River Parkway, the Bronx.

NAPLES, Italy, June 7 -- A tour of ten small communities with an aggregate population of about 100,000 yielded statements today from local that Mayors, priests and politicians that the majority of voters in the national elections were interested only in supporting the party that might be most helpful to them personally.

The John Hay Whitney Foundation has granted Opportunity Fellowships to fifty-two young men and women for the coming academic year. These awards, totaling $100,000, are given to young persons who show exceptional promise in one field or another.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 7 -- Dr. Henry Allen Moe, secretary general of the Guggenheim Foundation, said tonight at Wesleyan University's 121st commencement that "Johnnies-come-lately to the cause of freedom are as dangerous as the barbarians from the Asiatic steppes who are again preparing to march."

You have had occasion to comment editorially on the recent report to President Eisenhower of the National Manpower Council regarding the dearth of "brain power" in this country. The present shortages of engineers and scientists are extremely serious, since they are interfering with the strengthening of our defenses and the over-all development of our economy.

Our good friend. James Beard, the New York cook book author and excellent cook, came back the other day from Los Angeles, where he has just spent a month developing recipes for a meat-tenderizing product. He brought news of California cooking.

Inclusion of a provision for a seven-member Tariff Commission in a White House-Congressional compromise bill for extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act stirred anxiety among foreign traders late last week as they weighed implications of the move.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 7 -- Coffee interests here continue to demand that the Government allow them to sell their drafts in the free exchange market, thus receiving more cruzeiros for their drafts drawn in dollars against coffee sales for the United States.

DETROIT, June 7 (AP) -- Pitcher (Skinny) Brown, who isn't skinny, made three fat hits -- a single, double and home run -- and knocked in three runs today in hurling the Red Sox to a 4-1 victory over the Tigers. It was the Tigers' thirteenth straight defeat, tying the club record for consecutive losses set at the start of the 1920 season.

SUMMIT, N. J., June 7 -- On Leave and Stary Star, two horses owned by Fred Blum of Brooklyn, finished as champion and reserve in the jumper division in that order at the twenty-seventh annual Watchung Riding and Driving Club horse show today.

SYOSSET, L. I., June 7 -- Psychic Sally, a 6-year-old chestnut mare owned and ridden by Mrs. John T. Maloney of Syosset, won the hunter grand championship in the Helping Hand horse show on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. J. J. McDonald today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 7 -- Reuben Mamoulian should know in a matter of weeks whether he will be in Spain this fall to film his and Maxwell Anderson's adaptation of the opera, "Carmen," or be back on Broadway to direct the musical drama, "Devil's Hornpipe," also by Mr. Anderson.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- Grain futures registered a partial recovery after plunging to new levels early last week. Long liquidation appeared to have run its course, for the time being at least, although buyers were still inclined to be cautious in following upturns.
The City Fusion party has asked kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz to be its candidate for Mayor, Michael Potter, chairman of the party yesterday.

For 108 years the Prison Association of New York, 135 East Fifteenth Street, has worked ably to achieve its three objects, which are to improve the condition of prisoners, to improve prison discipline and to encourage reformed convicts after their discharge from jail by helping them to find a means of livelihood.
Late spring and early summer group exhibitions make up most of the new fare in New York's art galleries this week.

President Eisenhower's chief adviser on atomic problems told nineteen graduating rabbis yesterday that "faith is the only cure for world uncertainty" in the atomic age, and urged them to "live in the assurance that God is still in His Heaven."
BERLIN, June 7 -- The reassignment of Mr. Ilyichev to Austria raises the question whether or not Moscow will name a new Ambassador to East Germany.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 7 -- Gen. Sir George W. E. Erskine arrived this afternoon by plane to take command of the revived wartime East African Command stretching from the frontiers of Ethiopia and the Sudan to the Zambesi River. Strategically, the command includes Southern Rhodesia, carrying it to the borders of the Union of South Africa, as the Southern Rhodesian Command receives "advice" from the East African Command.

Shipping industry spokesmen and labor representatives drew up yesterday conflicting presentations they will make at the waterfront reform hearings Governor Dewey is to conduct here today and tomorrow.

The industrial potential of atomic energy will be explored in detail at the first Exposition of Basic Materials for Industry, to be held here next week. The exposition will be held at Grand Central Palace, June 15 through 19, and an accompanying conference on basic materials will be put on at the Roosevelt Hotel June 16, 17 and 18.

Greater emphasis should be given by the country's educational institutions to preparing young people for political leadership, Alben W. Barkley, former Vice President, said last night during a discussion on the New York Times Youth Forum of what lies ahead for high school and college graduates.

ST. LOUIS, June 7 -- When Casey Stengel turns to his bench for help, it is not the Yankees who are in trouble -- it's the opposition. Reserve strength, one of Casey's not-so-secret secrets of success, was most important today at Busch Stadium, where the champions came from behind the Browns in each game to triumph by 9 -- 2 and 7 -- 2, and now own an eleven-game winning streak.
BELLEVILLE, N. J., June 7 -- Joseph Angyal of the New York Athletic Club won two events today on the Passaic River in the regatta of the New York Rowing Association.

ZURICH, June 7 -- Investors in Switzerland suddenly became keenly interested in German dollar bonds last week when cables from New York stated that the German-American Validation Committee about to be constituted would begin investigation forthwith into the legality of the ownership of German dollar bonds aggregating about $700,000,000 of which about $50,000,000 are believed to have been looted in Berlin by the Soviet army in 1945 and consequently will be declared invalid.

The companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell group last year had a consolidated net income of u125,605,000, according to the annual report of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company released for publication today. This compared with a net income of 120,353,000 in 1951.

Haydn's "Missa in tempore belli," one of his major scores, was presented late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall by the Interracial Fellowship Chorus. The group did the mass so well that it brought itself a long way forward toward becoming an important factor in the city's musical life.

San Antonio, Tex., has been in the throes of a movement intended, so its sponsors say, to put down subversion and restrain subversive influences. The public library was taken as a good place to begin. The former acting city manager, since replaced, suggested it might be a good idea to burn some books.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (UP) -- The Braves overpowered the Phillies with six home runs today as they swept a double-header, 6 -- 0 and 5 -- 3, to move back into first place in the National League by seven percentage points.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls-in Congress during, the period May 30 through June 5 are given in the appended tabulation

BALTIMORE, June 7 (2P) -- Art Bragg, Morgan State national 100-meter champion, limped home the last twenty yards to give the winning 440-relay team a time just nine-tenths of a second off the world mark in the highlight of the South Atlantic-Morgan State track and field championships today.

CLEVELAND, June 7 (AP) -- Coming from behind in both games, the Indians ran their unbeaten Sunday winning streak to twelve games today by whipping the Athletics, 8-4 and 4-3. The Indians have won five double-headers and two single games on Sunday this season.

VIENNA, June 7 -- Last week's acknowledgment by Rude Pravo, Prague central Communist organ, that Czechoslovak currency revaluation had caused resentment among workers was confirmed today by the Czech Vice Premier, Zdenek Nejedly.

MONTREAL, June 7 (AP) -- Professional golfers from the United States retained the Hopkins International Trophy today by completing the three-day competition against Canada's team with a 27-18 victory.

CAIRO, June 7 -- Hope has been strengthened here within the last few days that a settlement of the British-Egyptian dispute over future control of the Suez Canal Zone can be reached without the violent clash that appeared to be a distinct possibility as recently as three weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Joseph C. O'Mahoney, former Democratic Senator from Wyoming, declared today, on becoming a director of the North American Aircoach Systems, Inc., that expansion of air transportation was endangered by the Civil Aeronautics Board policy of virtual exclusion of newcomers in the air carriers' industry.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UP) -- The Civil Defense Administration said today that the National Security Council had recommended use of blood plasma only in emergencies where dextran or other blood expanders were not available.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Department of Commerce moved today to prevent any foreign ship or aircraft scheduled to call at Communist Chinese ports from fueling in the United States, or its territories, without approval of the department's Office of International Trade.

LONDON, June 7 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation is considering a protest to United States networks on the advertising commercials transmitted in the United States in conjunction with video coverage of the coronation, for which the B. B. C. provided kinescope films.

PITTSBURGH, June 7 -- Building managers and owners at long last are coming into full realization of their great stake in the preservation and improvement of "downtown" or central business districts in the fact of a decentralization movement which has gained ground during the post war period in nearly every metropolitan area.

IT was a bitter disappointment when Native Dancer lost the Kentucky Derby. It was a bitter disappointment when Native Dancer won the Preakness. And now the Gray Ghost is taking dead aim at the third of the major 3-year-old classics, the Belmont Stakes at beautiful Belmont on Saturday. Will he disappoint again? It is fervently hoped that he won't.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 7 -- Peg's Pride, aged gray gelding from the Hutchinson Stables of Closter, N. J., who took four blue ribbons, gained the grand championship and the jumper division title at the Westchester-Fairfield P. H. A. horse show today on the Frank Altschul estate. Nancy Clapp rode Peg's Pride to a 20-point total.
PUSAN, Korea, Monday, June 8 (AP) -- United Nations Prisoner of War Command said today the Allies hold just under 125,000 North Korean and Chinese Red prisoners.

Officials of all types of transportation companies will press for repeal or a reduction of the 15 per cent tax on domestic and some forms of foreign travel when the House Ways and Means Committee begins tax-revision hearing on June 16.

PARIS, June 7 (UP) -- Nineteen-year-old Roger Lagarde of France became the youngest player ever to win the French amateur golf championship today when he defeated 45-year-old Harry Bentley of Great Britain, 2 and 1, in a drizzling rain.

According to reports from Washington last week, the Administration is drafting a "master plan," designed to "keep the economy of the country in balance by effective curbs on inflationary, as well as deflationary movements."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 7 -- Education is only part of the equipment needed to deal with change, Prof. John H. Finley told Harvard College seniors in his baccalaureate sermon today.

The return of Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne to Broadway after a hiatus since 1950 has been deferred. Last scheduled to open here early next year under the aegis of John C. Wilson and Hugh Beaumont, the popular acting couple isn't due now in "Quadrille" until September or October, 1954.
A plea for "peace with honor'' in Korea was voiced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ernest R. Palen in his sermon at the Middle Collegiate Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UP) -- The Republican National Chairman, Leonard W. Hall, said today that an armistice in Korea was "coming to fruition" because of the "firm attitude of President Eisenhower toward communism."

The Cubs' long-deferred offensive finally went on display at the Polo Grounds yesterday and so far as Leo Durocher and his Giants were concerned it could not have been more ill-timed. For it cost them a couple of ball games just when it appeared as if they were going somewhere.

Irving Brodsky has purchased for investment from Louis Denberg and Joseph Goldfine the parking lot measuring 100 by 100 feet, at 326-32 West Fortieth Street facing the Port Authority Terminal. The lot adjoins the new Diane Stores Building and is operated by the Kinney System, Inc., under a long-term net lease at a total net rental of $357,000.

TOKYO, Monday, June 8 -- United Nations and Communist armistice delegations signed today a general agreement for an exchange of prisoners after a cease-fire in Korea. The Allied spokesman who made the announcement said only "administrative matters" now stood in the path of a truce.

Establishment within the American Federation of Labor of a special "department of justice" to ferret out union racketeers was recommended yesterday by Alex Rose, president, and Marx Lewis, secretary-treasurer, of the United Hatters Cap and Millinery Workers International Union.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- (AP) -- Harry Dorish, making his first pitching start of the season, ended a six-game losing streak for the White Sox today, hurling a five-hit, 5-1 victory over Washington in the second game of a doubleheader before 18,480 fans.

The British Broadcasting Corporation has made informal representations to the National Broadcasting Company, protesting against the methods used by "Today," a morning television program, in reporting the coronation, it was indicated last night.

Ceremonies to be held in City Hall Plaza at noon tomorrow will honor thirty-four members of the uniformed force of the Fire Department. With Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet presiding, Mayor Impellitteri will present medals awarded for heroism and other meritorious acts in 1952.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Jean Monnet, president of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, declared today that progress toward the integration of Europe would not be affected by a truce in Korea or by a Soviet "peace offensive."

Robert B. Blaikie, Democratic leader of the Seventh Manhattan Assembly District, said yesterday that Mayor Impellitteri had left the independent voters who elected him "high and dry" and had returned to the Democratic party machine.

BONN, Germany, June 7 -- The moderate wing of the Free Democratic Party, which supports Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's middle-of-the-road policies, won today the first round in its struggle to purge the party of Right-Wing extremists before the election campaign gets under way.

LONDON, June 27 -- It is expected here that British-Egyptian talks on the Suez Canal Zone will be resumed before the end of June. This became known today in the face of a prediction yesterday by a high Egyptian Government source that diplomatic activity to ward resolution of the British Egyptian dispute would be resumed within a few days.

The Rev. Francis X. O'Sullivan of St. Sylvester's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn urged the 355 college seniors at Fordham University yesterday to use their religious and academic training to further social and racial justice.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UP) -A House Appropriations subcommittee made public tonight a staff report calling for a $300,000,000 cut in annual pension and compensation checks to veterans.

JERUSALEM, June 7 -- Three Israeli soldiers were believed to have been killed or wounded inside Jordan in the last twenty-four hours as two patrols were said by Jordanian spokesmen to have been driven back across the truce demarcation line after having probed Arab Legion positions.

Routing the Cardinals, 10 -- 1, yesterday at Ebbets Field to sweep the three-game series wasn't enough to keep the Dodgers in first place in the National League. The amazing Milwaukee Braves won two from the Phillies and moved into the top spot by seven percentage points.

PARIS, June 7 -- Foreign Minister Georges Bidault, who is trying to form the next French Cabinet, declared today that a solution of the Indo-China problem might he found at a three-power conference with the United States and Britain at Bermuda.

Columbia University announced here yesterday the establishment of a new Institute for the Study of Human Variation. It will seek to learn about man by observing the physical differences between individual and drawing, from these, conclusions about the workings of the human mind, the body and the mechanism of evolution.

CANTON, N. Y., June 7 -- (AP) -Sherman Adams, the Assistant to President Eisenhower, declared today that a Korean truce would still leave the free world in danger and he cautioned against any defense letdown lest it invite an atomic attack by Russia.

In his letter to President Syngman Rhee, President Eisenhower set forth the ground upon which the United States is prepared to accept the current truce program in Korea. He made a strong case, and most Americans, we believe, will concur in the position that he has taken.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 7 -- What he described as a growing tendency of the Government in the United States to meddle in the affairs of individuals in provinces where it did not belong was assailed here today by A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University, in his baccalaureate address before a capacity audience in Woolsey Hall.
To keep "the American climate American" requires greater participation by Zionists in local community life, Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress, declared here yesterday.
LONDON, June 7 -- Although the corooatinn ceremony is now history, the markets and business generally are finding it difficult to get back to normal.

SAIGON, June 7 (UP) -- French planes flew ninety-nine sorties to day against Communist communications and hideouts in the Red River delta, where the Reds are reported building up for an offensive against the French Union defenders.

Monday's reputation is a bad one at best. In song and story, to say nothing of the inner feeling of all mankind, Monday is celebrated as being a close kin to the gallows. This view is not without justice, for Monday definitely is blue.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 7 -- production and performance that must rank as an unusual triumph of music-dramatic presentation took place this afternoon when Handel's baroque opera, "Orlando Furioso," was mounted with a fidelity to style and spirit as an event of Sweden's 1953 music festival in the old Court Theatre of Drottningholm Palace.
BEACON, N. Y., June 7 (AP) -- Three inmates of the Matteawan State Hospital for the criminally insane escaped early today and more than 100 state police set up road blocks throughout the area.

NEW PLATZ, N. Y., June 7 (UP) -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, chairman of the Atomic Energy Committee of the House of Representatives, urged today an immediate start on construction of a power-producing atomic energy reactor.

There are many reasons why mother-and-daughter fashions are popular nowadays. A diminutive reproduction of a pretty dress seems to accent and endear its good points, and a little girl feels grown up and proud wearing an exact copy of her mother's costume.

In his letter to President Syngman Rhee, President Eisenhower set forth the ground upon which the United States is prepared to accept the current truce program in Korea. He made a strong case, and most Americans, we believe, will concur in the position that he has taken.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 7 -- What he described as a growing tendency of the Government in the United States to meddle in the affairs of individuals in provinces where it did not belong was assailed here today by A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University, in his baccalaureate address before a capacity audience in Woolsey Hall.
To keep "the American climate American" requires greater participation by Zionists in local community life, Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress, declared here yesterday.

HOBOKEN, N. J., June 7 --Members of the graduating class of the Stevens Institute of Technology were told today that they, as a part of the 19,000 graduates of engineering schools in the United States this year, would face the "long-distance" competition of the 50,000 engineers Russia will turn out this year.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- A budget break-down of the atomic program showed these main categories, with the reductions from President Truman's recommendations in brackets:

CLEVELAND, June 7 (AP) -- Joe Tipton, Cleveland catcher, suffered a broken ring finger on his right hand when he was struck by a foul tip in the ninth inning of the opening game with Philadelphia today.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- A Communist airlift allegedly smuggling guns and ammunition from Texas and other American areas into Panama to supply weapons for planned revolutions in Latin America is under secret Congressional investigation.
The Society of the Classic Guitar will present Monina Tavora, guitarist, in a program at 8:30 o'clock tonight at Carl Fischer Concert Hall.

DETROIT, June 7 (AP) -- Detroit's B B Chevrolet won the team title for the regular division and Pontiac's Griff's Grill took the booster class crown at the Women's International Bowling Congress tournament today.
LONDON, June 7 -- Londoners continued today to grasp at the splendor that was created nearly a week ago by the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II. They would not let the tumult and the shouting die.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, June 8 (AP) -- Following are the main points of the prisoner-of-war exchange agreement reached today:

SPOKANE, Wash., June 7 -- The Idaho Public Utilities Commission announced here approval of the issuance of necessary securities and a bank credit agreement required for the proposed merger of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company and Washington Water Power Company.

RANGOON, Burma, June 7 -- Burmese official quarters were hopeful here today that evacuation of at least part of the Chinese Nationalist troops from Burma would be achieved as a result of the quadripartite discussions that have been going on in Bangkok, capital of Thailand.

The Dewey Administration protested yesterday against cuts made by the Republican-controlled House of Representatives in President Eisenhower's request for funds to be used by the states in administering unemployment insurance and public employment offices.
Mickey Mantle's 562-foot home run ball has been returned to the Yankees and forwarded to the Baseball Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N. Y.
VIENNA, June 7 -- Foreign Minister Karl Gruber saw "very gratifying news" today in the naming by the Soviet Union of a civilian High Commissioner as its chief representative in Austria.

State officials and oil executives in states bordering the Gulf of Mexico are looking to a new frontier for exploration and development. Since President Eisenhower, on May 22, signed the Submerged Lands Act, restoring the states' title to offshore lands within their historic boundaries, public officials have started making ready to issue new leases and companies have begun assembling crews and equipment for oil operations offshore.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., June 7 -- Lloyd Ribner, a transplanted New Yorker now living in Englewood, N. J., showed the golfers in his new home state a thing or two today when he won the New Jersey amateur championship with a 1-up victory over Billy Dear, Morris County, in a 37-hole match over the Essex Fells Country Club course.

PITTSBURGH, June 7 (AP) -- Joe Nuxhall, the starting pitcher, and Ted Kluszewski hit home runs today as the Redlegs beat the Pirates 11 -- 6, after taking the opening game, 6 -- 1, behind the nine-hit pitching of Bud Podbielan.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Supreme Court decided, four to three, today that the United States was not liable to pay some $200,000,000 in damage claims growing out of the disastrous 1947 explosion in Texas City, Tex.

A preview demonstration of Subscriber-vision, a form of "box office" or pay-as-you-see television, was conducted yesterday at the Belmont-Plaza Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street. The demonstration will be opened to the general public today, continuing through June 17, with special programs offered daily from 11 A. M. to 7 P. M.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 8 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Government has decided to eradicate "locations in the sky" -- Negro quarters perched atop apartment blocks occupied by whites -- Dr. H. F. Verowerd, Minister of Native Affairs, said in an announcement in the Nationalist press today.

Andy Stanfield, one of the Olympic titleholders in the meet, will attempt to lower world marks in the 100 and 220-yard dashes in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union championships at Randalls Island on Saturday. The meet will be a twilight-night affair, with the field events starting at 5 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Defense Department has started a $30,000,000 building program at Fort Meade in Maryland to house the National Security Agency, the operations of which are about as secret as those of the Central Intelligence Agency.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -- The Treasury Department reported today that foreign Governments purchased $599,000,000 in monetary gold from the United States in the first quarter of 1953. There were no purchases by the United States in this period.

The New York City Transit Authority, which takes over the operation of the city-owned rapid transit and surface lines next Monday, was assured yesterday by representatives of the country's three largest token manufacturers that it would have enough tokens available by July 30 to put a fare rise into effect at that time.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 8 -- John S. Coleman, president of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company, said today that Untied States foreign economic policy "will never make sense unless it reflects the dominating position of the United States in international trade."

BONN, Germany, June 8 -- Dr. Hans Joachim von Merkatz, Bundestag floor leader of the German party, the Right Wing of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's coalition, launched a movement today to salvage the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies by disjoining it from the European Defense Community Treaty.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 8 -- The Cabinet announced tonight that it had outlawed as a "terrorist organization" an unnamed group of religious fanatics and ultra-nationalists. The group is believed to have used violence to combat pig-breeding, state-supervised education and reparations from Germany as well as to enforce Sabbath observance, and to have attacked Communist clubs and shops selling Soviet literature.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 8 -- Judge Harold R. Medina of New York City and six others received honorary degrees at the Middlebury College commencement this morning. Judge Medina delivered the commencement address and received an honorary Doctor of Laws degree.
