HAVANA, June 8 -- The Hemingway Trophy, awarded annually to the team of fishing launches catching the greatest poundage of marlin, was won yesterday by the International Yacht Club of Havana for the second consecutive year with 391 1/2 pounds.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday it regretted the inability of the Supreme Court to decide at present the issue of racial segregation in schools.

ROME, Tuesday, June 9 -- With well over one half of the vote counted in the first general elections held in Italy since 1948, the four Center parties headed by Premier Alcide De Gasperi's Christian Democrats had accumulated an impressive lead over the extreme Left-Wing parties, and by a slight margin had polled an absolute majority of the votes cast.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, June 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of today's agreement between the United Nations Command and the Communists on the repatriation of prisoners of the Korean war:

Operations at the country's steel mills this week are scheduled at an average rate of 99.9 per cent of the industry's theoretical capacity, indicating production of 2,252,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 8 -- Five honorary degrees were conferred by Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart today at its 112th commencement -- the first to be held here at the former White-law Reid estate to which the college moved from New York last year.

The latest proposed increase in commutation fares on the Long Island Rail Road, averaging 25 per cent, would make them higher than those charged by any other railroad in the New York area, an official of the parent Pennsylvania Railroad admitted yesterday.

A plea that Congress restore the $9,814,000 for the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, which was cut from the Mutual Security Agency budget for this year, was made yesterday by 100 ministers and elders at the monthly meeting of the Presbytery of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee reported today a bill calling for $716,729,768 in new funds for the Department of Agriculture and set the stage for another Congressional fight over a pet project of the farm bloc.

The Board of Health decided yesterday on the motion of Dr. Harry S. Mustard, former Health Commissioner, to maintain the dating requirement on all containers distributed in the city, as provided in the Sanitary Code. In turning down a request by the dairy industry for elimination of this provision, the board expressed its willingness to consider reopening the question if new evidence should be forthcoming.
PHILADELPHIA June 8 (AP) -- The Cubs committed four errors in the second inning today, to help the Phillies to gain a 7 -- 3 victory.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 8 -- The Kenya Africa Union, outside of the West African parties and South Africa's National Congress probably the most famous African political organization, was proscribed as an unlawful society by the Kenya Executive Council today.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today that its regulation governing the amount of credit or borrowed money that may be used in stock purchases applies to purchasing open end mutual trust shares.

The National Knitted Outerwear Association addressed a memorandum to the Treasury Department yesterday urging it "to correct the serious inequity to American manufacturers of cashmere sweaters of Foreign Assets Control regulations."

UNTIL the invention of the machine gun, the tank and the airplane, professional soldiers were not much better armed than amateurs. Revolutions were still possible. Until the totalitarian methods of exterminating potential leaders and controlling the minds of the young, future leaders were developed and reasonable men might still plan revolutions.

VIENNA, June 8 -- Soviet occupation authorities in Austria announced tonight that from tomorrow they would drop their permanent control of the movement of Austrian citizens and private and commercial vehicular traffic in and out of their zone.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Former President Herbert Hoover, General of the Army Douglas MacArthur and Cardinal Spellman were among thirteen guests that President Eisenhower had at dinner tonight in the White House.

Still puzzled, as well as upset, over what they considered an unnecessary one-day postponement of their game with a United States team, the touring English all-star soccer players finally made their appearance at the Yankee Stadium last night. It was a noteworthy one, too, as the visitors swept to a 6-to-3 triumph before 7,271 spectators.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., June 8 -- Barney Lobel and Steve Doctor of the Connequott Club scored 33, 32 -- 65, seven under par to win top honors in group 1 of the weekly Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro tournament at the Cold Spring Country Club today.

A small begrimed picture found in an attic in Clermont, in upstate New York, a year ago, and purchased along with other things by a Hyde Park antiques dealer, has been established as the earliest known on-the-spot oil painting of a happening in this city's history.

THE fishing pressure seems to have been applied to Long Island over the week-end, and the bay fishing was more productive than might have been anticipated, with some good catches of weakfish reported at Peconic and at a few points on Great South Bay.

A picture of the American West as depicted by English men and women who visited it between 1865 and 1900 will be issued by Scribner Aug. 24 under the title "Westward the Briton." Robert G. Athearn, the author, has based his work on more than 300 books. magazine articles and unpublished manuscripts written by Britons who went West as homesteaders, miners or settlers, on business or for adventure, or just as tourists.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- Active buying swung into the Board of Trade grain and soybean markets today, the prevalent idea apparently being that a truce agreement in Korea would mark the end of the protracted bear market. On this theory buying orders were placed in wheat to meet a lower opening expected on the peace news.

Seamen aboard Norway's tankers and dry cargo ships in worldwide service have become so motion-picture conscious in the last three years that 160 vessels flying that nation's flag now have 16-mm. sound projectors in the ship's regular recreational equipment.
You are to be highly commended for your editorial "Wheat for Pakistan."

Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis will compete for laughs with assorted spooks and banshees in "Scared Stiff," the wide-screen comedy with stereophonic sound, which has been booked as the next attraction at the Mayfair. The comedians are supported by Carmen Miranda, Lizabeth Scott and Dorothy Malone in the Paramount release.

Dr. Jack Geller of Purchase, N. Y., the East's sixth-ranking tennis player, and unranked Gene Garrett of San Diego, Calif., making a tournament comeback after attending the University of Paris for two years, led the way into the second round yesterday in the Brooklyn men's singles championship tournament at the Knickerbocker Field Club.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of upstate New York, said today a Korean truce "certainly" would strengthen the hand of lawmakers who were fighting President Eisenhower's plea to extend the excess profits tax.
MEXICO CITY, June 8 -- The Mexican Congress has begun hearings at last on a controversial bill that would require private business to share profits with its employes.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- What Associate Justice Douglas, speaking for an undivided Supreme Court, held today was in substance this:

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 9 -- United Nations and Communist delegations met briefly at Panmunjom today, with final details of an armistice in the Korean war still to be settled after an agreement yesterday on the vital issue of the disposal of war prisoners unwilling to return to their former homes after a cease-fire.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Otto Verber and Kurt Ponger, Austrian-born former G. I.'s who became members of a Russian spy ring, were sentenced to prison today but received less than the maximum.

In introducing the Fredrica fall collection of fur designs yesterday at 345 Seventh Avenue, Arthur Schwartz, designer and co-owner of this company with his brother, outlined their wise and flexible fashion philosophy for the coming season. Their over-all effect will be one of greater slimness, with an illusion of tallness and look of lightness.

Mayor Impellitteri charged yesterday that remarks by Robert B. Blaikie on a radio program Sunday were "the opening gun in a combination of Mr. Blaikie and Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, to catapult Mr. Halley into the mayoralty nomination of some party."

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 8 -- Israel and Jordan signed today a three-month agreement providing for regular meetings of local commanders along the armistice line between the two countries to prevent illegal border crossings and consequent incidents.

TORONTO, June 8 (Canadian Press) -- European exhibitors at the sixth Canadian International Trade Fair said today that the fair should help to improve Europe's dollar problem. Many of them said they expected to increase trade with Canada and also to improve international understanding.

LOS ANGELEES, June 8 -- The independent retailer is the key to the American distribution system, yet there are forces that would destroy him by wiping out the anti-trust and fair trade laws that protect him.
Prices of United States Government securities drifted downward slight fractions yesterday after four consecutive trading sessions in which advances had been scored.

John Roy Carlson in his letter in your May 29 issue indulges in a diatribe against "McCarthyism" without offering much by way of constructive criticism or suggestion. He says Senator McCarthy's "retirement" will "no more diminish the degree of national hysteria than the death of Stalin diminished the threat of Communist aggression."

The resulting situation would be not merely chaotic; it would be catastrophic. The Republic of Korea cannot, single-handed, fight Communist China and its million soldiers who have been poured into the Korean Peninsula.

Although the fact is not generally known, citizens residing in the District of Columbia were at one time considered capable of self-government. A century and a half ago Washington had a locally elected City Council; 133 years ago it was given a popularly elected Mayor; between 1871 and 1878 it was blessed with a territorial government which introduced many public improvements but came to be regarded with suspicion by Congress and was therefore abolished.

LONDON, June 8 (AP) -- The British Broadcasting Corporation said tonight that it had confirmed that television films of the coronation were "marred in the United States by the introduction of advertisements."

CHICAGO, June 8 -- The fortunes of the du Pont Company, whether good or bad, would not have had any influence on the bonus award Jr., plan of General Motors Corporation, Walter S. Carpenter Jr., chairman and former president of E. I. du Pont De Nemours Co., testified today in the du Pont anti-trust trial before Judge Walter J. LaBuy in Federal District Court.

The prospectus for financing the construction of a bridge over the Michigan's Straits of Mackinac with a $96,000,000 issue of revenue bonds has been revised so as to make the proposed obligation a "gross lien bond" -- that is, one pledged to secure all revenues generated by the project for the amortization of the debt.

Although taxes were double those of the corresponding period of last year, R. H. Macy Co., Inc., bettered its earnings on increased business for the thirteen weeks ended on May 2, according to the unaudited statement issued yesterday.

A week-long blood drive among the 16,000 tenants of the Empire State Building was begun yesterday by the American Red Cross. Among the first to line-up for contributions were two United Nations representatives -- Edward Arce Quiroza, the Bolivian permanent representative, and Allan H. Loomes, a member of the Australian delegation.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- Testifying in an open hearing before the United States Senate Internal Security subcommittee in the Federal courthouse here today two members of the faculty of the University of Chicago and a university part-time student refused to say whether they were or had been members of the Communist party.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, June 8 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, sharply warned the fourteen North Atlantic Treaty nations, in a report issued here today, that airpower "is still today the weakest link in our defense."
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, warned Congress today against any whittling down of the National Military Establishment as the result of a truce in Korea.

The news both from Paris and Saigon shows us clearly that the time is approaching for a new deal in Indo-China. Both sides are dissatisfied with the present state of affairs. In any event, a truce in Korea will bring about a new situation which will be fraught with danger to Indo-China.
PHILADELPHIA, June 8 -- The election of Dr. James C. Charlesworth as president of the American Academy of Political and Social Science was announced today by the board of directors.
A man in the Bronx found a penguin in his front yard Sunday night and yesterday the zoological world was pondering one of its biggest mysteries in years.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a proposed amendment to the Constitution to forbid the seizure of private property "at any time" except by act of Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- The Supreme Court spoke out today against a Government ruling that retailers and jobbers who get goods at lower prices than their competitors must be able to prove their legal right to the savings.

Hard money -- plenty of it -- was on display yesterday at Toots Shor's Restaurant, where Abe Saperstein, owner of basketball's famed Harlem Globetrotters, celebrated the signing of Walter Dukes by having 3,000 silver dollars rolled into the dining room in a wheelbarrow.

Manhattan College will hold its 102d commencement exercises today at 3 P. M. on its Riverdale campus. Cardinal Spellman is to preside at the conferring of 546 Bachelor degrees and four honorary degrees.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N. J., June 8 -- Puzzled and shocked, the residents of Goshen, a hamlet five miles west of here at the southern end of the state, mourned today the death of one of their neighbors.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Eisenhower proposed today to permit the importation of embargoed agricultural products, including 707,000 pounds of butter and 1,709,000 pounds of peanuts annually, in a move to encourage foreign trade.

BAYONNE, N. J., June 8 -- A young Naval Supply Corps officer was honored today at a special military review here. Lieut. (jg) Calvin W. Roberts of Staten Island received a meritorious service commendation for heroism while he was on duty in Korean waters two years ago.
The first local public hearings into violations of the state rent laws by tenants who sublease individual rooms in their apartments at illegal profits were held here last night.

The strong and open opposition of Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, retiring Chief of Staff of the Air Force, to budget cuts sponsored by his civilian superiors, the Secretary of the Air Force, the Secretary of Defense and the President poses once again the whole issue of civilian-military relationships in a democracy.

The tendency of local race-goers to minimize the ability of Jockey George Wallis persists, and the 45-year-old Wallis continues to come through with the odd victory -- at a price. He did that very thing at Belmont Park yesterday, guiding the Phantom Farm's Gideon to victory in the feature race.

Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, condemned atom spies, were denied a new trial yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman after four hours of argument. The jurist also refused to grant a stay of execution pending appeal.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- President Eisenhower nominated Charles E. Slusser, Mayor of Akron, Ohio, today to be Commissioner of the Public Housing Administration.
The cotton futures market here closed barely steady yesterday, unchanged to 6 points lower than on last Friday.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, June 9 -- President Syngman Rhee of the Republic of Korea continued yesterday to manifest a truculent, unbending attitude toward the armistice agreement that was nearing completion at Panmunjom.

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Tuesday, June 9 -- A series of tornadoes -- possibly eight in number -- smashed through parts of Michigan and Ohio last night. It was feared the vicious storms had killed 120 persons and injured several hundred others, besides causing widespread damage to property.

MOSCOW, June 8 -- The magazine Kommunist, the chief ideological organ of the Central Committee of the Communist party, in a leading editorial attacked "the cult of personalities" or "heroes" which seeks to inflate the role of individual figures in history.

The Temporary State Commission to Study the Organizational Structure of the City of New York, appointed Wednesday by Governor Dewey to examine the feasibility of a city manager form of government for the city, met yesterday for the first time.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that restaurants in the District of Columbia could not legally refuse to serve meals to Negroes who were well behaved. It held valid a statute enacted in 1873 that made it a criminal act for proprietors of public eating places to refuse to serve any person solely because of race or color.
Last year, 2,044 ships of 3,105,065 net tons called at the Lebanese port of Beirut, according to a report received here.

RYE, N. Y., June 8 -- Two hundred and fifty gaily chatting men and women from twenty-one New York homes for oldsters rode by bus today to the Miriam Osborn Home for the Aged here to discuss marketing and design of handicraft articles they make.

ST. LOUIS, June 8 -- Back in 1934 Lou Gehrig hit .363, drove across 165 runs and slammed forty-nine homers. That year Larruping Lou became the first Yankee to carry off the coveted triple crown of the American League, the championships in batting, runs-batted-in and home runs.

CALGARY, Alberta, June 8 (Canadian Press) -- The development of the Delhi Oil Corporation in Canada, particularly in connection with its growing pipeline activities, has led to plans for separating the subsidiary company in Canada from its parent body in Delaware, directors of both concerns said today.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Supreme Court ruled today by a vote of six to two that an offering of Treasury stock of the Ralston Purina Company of St. Louis to its "key employes" was subject to the registration requirements of the Securities Act of 1933.

Stockholders of the Cinerama Productions Corporation were notified yesterday that a special meeting would be held on next Tuesday to consider a proposal to assign to a theatre chain the rights to produce and show Cinerama movies in exchange for half the future revenues earned by the films.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Dr. You Chan Yang, Republic of Korea Ambassador to the United States, declared bluntly today that it was the intention of his Government and the South Korean armed forces to fight on, alone if necessary, against the Communists if Korea was left divided in any armistice acceptable to the United Nations.

PITTSBURGH, June 8 (AP) -- Steve Bilko's double in the twelfth inning -- his only hit of the game -- started a two-run rally and enabled the Cardinals to down the Pirates, 5 -- 3. tonight and snap a five-game losing streak. The defeat was the Pirates' fifth straight.
NEW HAVEN, June 8 -- A ceremonial blessed with a happy tradition and color tracing back to 1702, marked the 252d commencement of Yale University here this sunny morning on the Old Campus.

Governor Dewey and the leaders of the State Legislature were brought up against the fact yesterday that, no matter what they might do to clean up the city's crime-encrusted waterfront, the same men still would be running the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., hub of all port investigations.
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 9 (AP) -- United Nations Command Communique 1,640, for the twenty-four hours ending at 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

LONDON, June 8 (Reuters) -- What happened in those historic moments of May 29 when a tall, lean New Zealander and his native guide stood on the peak of Mt. Everest as the first conquerors of the world's highest mountain?

The long discussed match between Carl (Bobo) Olson of San Francisco and Paddy Young of New York for the American middleweight championship at Madison Square Garden on Friday, June 19, was sealed yesterday when the fighters signed contracts for the fifteen-round bout.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Procedures of the Selective Service System in the cases of conscientious objectors, whereby the draft agency resorts to secret records of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, were upheld in a ruling handed down today by the Supreme Court.

The extent to which the use of synthetic fibers has grown as well as the increasing trend to casual wear in men's apparel markets is shown in a study just completed by Esquire magazine. Both developments are expected to have a significant effect on advertising and marketing procedures in the future.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The major church organizations of the United States put their support today behind the Eisenhower Administration's proposal to proposal to open immigration to an additional 240,000 persons during the next two years to help solve an acute refugee problem in a divided world.

The steps to be taken by an estimated 100,000 American holders of 370,000,000 of defaulted German dollar bonds to have their investments officially validated and thereby qualified for public purchase and sale are to be made public soon -- possibly within the next few weeks.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 8 (AP) -- Scotland Hal, owned by Raymond Peterson of Limon, Colo., scored a three-quarter-length victory in the Levittown Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Scotland Hal, making his 1953 debut at the track, won in 2:04 with Del Argo driving.
Representative Phillips of California has made public a staff report pointing the way to practical economies in the politically laden minefield of appropriations for veterans.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- A bill providing severe fines or imprisonment for United States citizens who from now on take employment with the United Nations or related organizations without first receiving security clearance from the Attorney General was passed without an opposing vote by the Senate today.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today that his agency slash claims for fees and expenses in connection with the reorganization of the Boston Terminal Company by almost 50 per cent.

LONDON, June 8 -- Expectations of an early truce in Korea strengthened Far Eastern issues on the stock market here today and had a depressing effect on base metal shares. Most other groups continued film although price movements were small.

LONDON, June 8 -- The two great English Elizabeths have greeted one another across three and a half centuries. Queen Elizabeth II watched at Covent Garden Opera House tonight a chapter in the life of her renowned ancestor and England's past saluted England's future.

The Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority announced yesterday that June 24 had been designated as the date of sale for $21,000,000 of electric revenue bonds. The issue is to be dated July 1, 1953 and to come due from 1955 to 1988.

Governor Dewey's office made public yesterday the names of officials and other persons who will speak today at the second session of the hearings being conducted on the recommendations made by the State Crime Commission in its waterfront report. They are:

DETROIT, June 8 (AP) -- The Tigers ended their 13-game losing streak today by scoring four times in the seventh inning to defeat the Red Sox, 6 -- 3, and thus avoid setting a club record for most consecutive defeats.

Mme. Philomene Le Douzen, charming, white-haired patronne of the Cafe de France, 313 West Forty-sixth Street, reminded us recently of a popular French dessert especially fitting for summer. It is pot de creme au chocolat, a delectable concoction that in France is customarily served cold in little Dresden pots or in small silver or porcelain bowls.

LONDON, June 8 -- British Commonwealth statesmen warmly welcomed today the agreement reached at Panmunjom on the repatriation of Korean war prisoners and began to speculate on the next developments in the Far East. They seemed to think that an armistice in Korea would follow and that eventually Communist China would be seated in the United Nations.

George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, said yesterday that even with a truce near in Korea this organization supported the strongest possible national defense program until Soviet Russia called off the "cold war."
Even the news of the signing of the prisoners-of-war agreement in Korea could not shake stock traders out of their "wait-and-see" attitude yesterday.

British protests over the abuse of commercials in some of the radio and television broadcasts of the coronation in the United States should not be dismissed merely as British "touchiness" on the subject of the royal institutions. The British have a right to take offense at some of the things that were done and some of them were as objectionable to many Americans as they were offensive to all Britons.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, June 9 -- The fighting front turned quiet yesterday as the hour of armistice neared, but the Communists served a grim reminder that the war was not yet over with an air raid on Seoul.

Mayor Impellitteri opened yesterday Anniversary Retail Week, being held in conjunction with the 300th anniversary of the city, by cutting what was described as the "longest ceremonial tape in the world."
OAKMONT, Pa., June 8 -- A hot, humid day marked the end of the preliminaries for the championship qualifying rounds of the fifty-third United States open golf championships.
The memory of Hans Christian Andersen, whose fairy tales have been beloved by generations of children, is to be honored through a statue in Central Park.
A jittery hold-up man shot his accomplice by mistake yesterday when a 56-year-old Manhattan businessman refused to give up his $1,200 payroll and chased the robbers through the streets.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 8 -- "We are content with our system of free enterprise and private capital trying to develop our country," Silvio Gutierrez, the new Venezuelan Ambassador, told newsmen on his arrival here today.
Before an interested but uncooperative audience yesterday two slender policewomen won a battle over two men much heavier than themselves and made their arrest.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- An official threat by the Republic of Korea to fight On alone, if necessary, to unify all of Korea despite a United Nations-approved armistice raised today the question of how long the South Korean Army, equipped and supplied entirely by the United States, could carry on alone if the United States stopped all supplies and withheld supporting air bombardment and naval gunfire.

TRENTON, June 8 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today ruled unconstitutional the operations of the State Building Authority and declared that all the contracts and leases into which the authority had entered were "null and void."

Events tonight: "Don Pedro," opera with music by Mozart, Lemonade Opera, Greenwich Mews Playhouse, 141 West Thirtieth Street, 8:30 o'clock; August Wenzinger, viola da gamba, Eta Harich-Schneider, harpsichordist, New York Public Library, 8:30.

The Giants, being by any standard a body of fearless men, threw themselves into the path of the high-speeding Braves at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The impact almost sent the New Yorkers reeling over the brink of the Harlem River.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., June 8 -- Clem Miner of Rockrimmon and his amateur partner, Dr. William Connolly of Innis Arden, won the weekly pro-amateur best-ball tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association over the hilly Briar Hall course today.

The Avenue of the Americas Association deserves congratulation for recognizing publicly that "the traffic and transit problem of this city and the surrounding areas are not separated and distinct, and the solution to the traffic problem is dependent upon adequate rapid transit facilities" (from your paper of June 2).
ATLANTIC CITY, June 8 -- Large-volume sales of color television sets will not develop before 1956 "at least," a top television and appliance manufacturer predicted here today.

Local 1648, Retail Clerks International Association, A. F. L., has petitioned for an election among employes at Hearn's department stores in Manhattan and the Bronx in an effort to win representation rights from a Congress of Industrial Organizations union that has been conducting a strike against the stores.

BOSTON, June 8 -- Mrs. Grace F. Cudworth of Boston has been elected president of the Mother Church, the First Church of Christ, Scientist, it was announced today at the annnual meeting. She succeeds Lieut. Col. Robert Ellis Key.
IT was just a few years ago that Casey Stengel was explaining why he believed Honus Wagner to be the greatest of all ballplayers.

Five thousand union longshoremen took a work holiday yesterday. They marched from the West Side docks to the Bar Association Building at 42 West Forty-fourth Street, where they picketed to show their disapproval of the two-day waterfront hearing that began there at 10 A. M. It was a surprisingly good-natured demonstration.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8 -- The Harvard Crimson, undergraduate daily newspaper, today published its fifth annual report on academic freedom. It found thirty-five cases of violation of such freedom in United States colleges and universities.
A new type of portable radio for lifeboat operation by persons with no knowledge of radio has been developed by the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -- Turner L. Smith, former Justice Department tax official, acknowledged today that he had discussed hunting trips and hard-to-get theatre tickets with tax attorneys whose letters to him were found in the Patuxent River.

TOKYO, June 8 -- The Japanese, for whom the Korean war provided a bonanza in the form of heavy buying by United States armed forces, heard news the conflict might end soon with concern over what peace in Korea might mean to them.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 8 -- The 290 members of the Vassar College graduating class were told today that, "with wisdom, patience and unflagging efforts, the world can be spared from atomic war."
The home guard of summertime Manhattan attentive to his duty enjoys many consolations for staying put while his more footloose fellow-citizens take to the country or to travel by land or sea or air.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 -- With a windfall of $52,000,000 awaiting distribution after procedural matters are worked out California is ready to go ahead with the leasing of its offshore oil-bearing areas as a result of the signing by President Eisenhower of the Submerged Lands Act.
BEACON, N. Y., June 8 -- State police, Sheriff's deputies and hospital attendants continued to search today for three Matteawan State Hospital patients who escaped yesterday.

Edmund J. Dempsey, formerly with the American Cyanamid Company as assistant to the president, has been named general manager of manufacturing for Lehn Fink Products, Inc., producer of proprietary drugs and cosmetics.

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges, with the Korean peace news weakening some markets and the threatened longshoremen's strike firming others. Volume was generally moderate but the domestic sugar contract was very active.

The National Broadcasting Company has rejected a demand from New York State Secretary Thomas J. Curran, Republican leader, for television time equal to that being given to-Mayor Impellitteri for his weekly series of programs on the city Government that will begin tonight at 7:30 P. M.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 8 (AP) -- John J. McCloy, former United Sttes High Commissioner to Germany, said today that if we hoped to widen this nation's influence for peace and freedom "we have to make it clear we do have the courage and the will to go on."

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- (UP) -- Spokesmen for independent rubber users and organized rubber workers urged Congress today to make sure the "Big Four" rubber companies do not get the lion's share when the government sells its synthetic rubber plants.

PARIS, June 8 -- The French woman's inherent resistance to ready-made clothes is breaking down. For generations the woman who could not afford the Chanels and Molyneuxs has gone to a little dressmaker in some far-away section of the city, probably up many flights of stairs.
The Sanitation Department's drive against "litterbugs" in the city got off to a rapid start yesterday.

For the first time this season the Dodgers were beaten by a team they outhit when the Redlegs gained an 8-5 decision before 12,456 at Ebbets Field last night. The loss, coupled with a Milwaukee victory, dropped the Brooks a game behind the league-leading Braves.

In these days of massive defense preparations the layman has to take the expert's word in many fields as to how much we should spend on weapons. The citizen who pays the bill can't know precisely what he is buying, for if he did know some possible enemy would also know.
PARIS, June 8 -- Foreign Minister Georges Bidault, who will go before the National Assembly Wednesday to seek approval as Premier, said today he would govern for "a long time" or not at all.

Net profit of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd. and its subsidiaries for the nine months ended April 30, last, was $29,756,275, compared with the $27,492,011 cleared a year earlier, the report disclosed yesterday.

Cardinal Hayes captured its first city Catholic High Schools Athletic Association baseball championship yesterday by defeating Manhattan Prep, 6 -- 0, in the final at Fordham University field. The victors ended their season with one defeat in twenty-one games.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 8 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., the United States representative, said tonight that "it is not conceivable" that representatives of Communist China would be admitted to the United Nations Security Council after an armistice in Korea. Asked whether the United States would use the veto to prevent it, Mr. Lodge said that "I haven't gone into all the procedural ins and outs but we'd do everything that was necessary."

The Beryllium Corporation is offering to holders of its outstanding common stock rights to subscribe for 88,385 shares of new common stock at $25.50 a share at the rate of one additional share for each four shares held.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -- Secretary Wilson testified today the Air Force -- not the new budget -- was largely to blame for the controversial twenty-three-wing cutback and that he was merely trying to hold down "extravagant expenditures."

MALONE, N. Y., June 8 (AP) -- A Franklin County Court judge dismissed today an indictment against Alton B. Anderson, Mayor of Saranac Lake and manager of a theatre, that charged operation of a game called "Lucky" in his theatre.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Legislation that would cut wheat plantings about 15 per cent in 1954 was approved today by the House Agriculture Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Syngman Rhee of the Republic of Korea was warned today by one of his country's most powerful and steadfast friends in Congress that any action he might take to upset the Korean truce would not be tolerated here.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 8 -- Forced by unemployment and high prices to readjust previous economic plans, Yugoslavia's economics chief announced today the windup of an ambitious industrialization program started in the first flush of the Communist industrial revolution in this primarily agricultural country.

Summer also means the picnic season, whether the picnic be held in the back yard or in someone else's pasture miles away. New accoutrements designed to make the preparation of such meals as pleasant as their consumption are available in a number of shops.

ATHENS, June 8 -- The Government failed today in several efforts to conciliate the Confederation of Labor and tonight it appeared certain that a general strike scheduled for tomorrow in Athens and Piraeus would take place, tieing-up essential services for twenty-four hours.

The Egyptian Government has purchased the Tudor mansion of the late James A. Stillman, at Park Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street, it was announced yesterday. The structure will house the country's permanent United Nations delegation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -- Hal Roach, the veteran film producer and a pioneer in the making of movies for television with his son, Hal Roach Jr., today announced that the Hal Roach studios would resume production of features for theatrical distribution.
LONDON June 7 -- Diplomatic activity seeking to clear away policy misunderstandings among the Western Big Three powers is at the moment concentrating attention on Asia.

Governor Dewey sought last night a way to avoid creation of a new state agency to administer the waterfront controls proposed by the State Crime Commission to end racketeering and loss of this port's trade.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 9 (AP) -- Both Japan and Germany surpassed the United States in merchant tonnage launched during the first three months this year, the United Nations statistical bulletin showed today.

Playing the role of television narrator in the first of a series of weekly TV shows, Mayor Impellitteri reported last night that great strides have been made since the end of World War II in bringing New York City's hospital facilities up-to-date and making the wonders of modern medicine available to the sick poor.

MOST people don't think that their jobs are romantic or any occupations, for that matter, which require regular toil in office, shop or factory. To be romantic a business ought to be dangerous, picturesque and remote. Cold reason may insist that certain industries are monotonous as well as strenuous, tiresome and poorly paid as well as adventurous.

RANGOON, Burma, June 9 -- The Burmese military mission at the four-nation talks on the withdrawal of Chinese Nationalist forces from Burma has rejected a Formosan suggestion for an immediate cease-fire between the Burmese Army and the Chinese Nationalist troops operating east of Salween.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today that the Truman Administration had quietly abandoned the immediate goal of 143 wings for the Air Force in the budget submitted to Congress last Jan. 9, and that "no one was honest and told the American people."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 9 -- The Algonquin Gas Transmission Company, which is seeking Federal Power Commission approval of a new certificate of convenience and necessity for delivering natural gas to New England, asked Supreme Court Justice Samued W. Eager here today to permit completion of the Westchester County part of a 255-mile pipeline.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- A sudden unexplained change in course of the 14,000-ton Phoenix, an oil tanker, was blamed today for the fiery Delaware River crash in which the Phoenix and another tanker, the Pan Massachusetts, were destroyed Saturday morning ten miles south of Wilmington, Del.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Wheat prices registered substantial gains at the outset of trading here today, but demand faded and prices receded sharply from early tops. The reaction in wheat checked the demand for coarse grains, which had a heavy tone most of the session, and also put a damper on buying of rye.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Switzerland informed the United States tonight that she would not serve on the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission in Korea unless South Korea signed the armistice agreement and joined in the invitation to screen the prisoners refusing to return home.

NEW HAVEN, June 9 (AP) -- Kenneth Sandilands Duncan, the top official with the newly arrived Oxford-Cambridge track squad, proudly proclaimed today that "our chaps did not come here to lose against your Americans."

GREENWICH, Conn., June 9 -- A delegation representing the Havemeyer Park section of Old Greenwich appeared before the Greenwich Board of Selectmen today to demand that the town act to correct improper drainage conditions, which resulted in a flash flood in the area on Sunday. One homeowner, John P. Moffitt, threatened to instigate suit against the town if the conditions are not remedied.
BETHESDA, Md., June 9 (AP) -- Pat O'Sullivan took a 3-stroke lead in the first round of the Women's Eastern amateur golf tournament today with a steady one-over-par 75.

WORCESTER, Mass., Wednesday, June 10 -- The worst tornado to hit New England in seventy-five year roared through central Massachusetts before sundown last night, claiming sixty-nine known dead and devastating hundreds of homes and industrial buildings in a wide area.

Milwaukee's league - leading Braves, continuing their triumphant rampage through the East, made it two in a row over the Giants last night before 23,689 paying spectators at the Polo Grounds. The victory kept Charley Grimm's hustling forces one game ahead of the Dodgers.
LOS ANGELES, June 9 -- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, appealed to his party workers here tonight to support President Eisenhower's efforts to cut the military budget.

FLINT, Mich., June 9 (AP) -- Rescue workers expressed belief tonight they had found all the dead -- 121 in Michigan and eighteen in Ohio -- left behind in nine tornado-ripped cities in the two states.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Supreme Court was asked today by attorneys for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg to reconsider its latest refusal to review their convictions on charges of conspiring to supply Soviet Russia with secret data concerning the atomic bomb.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- One University of Chicago instructor and two research associates refused today to discuss their past or present affiliations with the Communist party and left-wing organizations when called to testify at an open hearing before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 9 -- Twenty-five members of the Princeton Theological Seminary Choir will leave here early tomorrow on the first leg of an eight-week tour that will take them to armed forces bases in Japan, Korea and other parts of the Far East.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 9 -- One of the longest drivers in the game, Melvin (Chick) Harbert, the Detroit golf professional, assumed the lead today in the first half of championship qualifying play in the United States open.
The Rogers Peet Company, manufacturer and retailer of men's and boys' clothing, will open its $1,000,000 store at 600 Fifth Avenue, at the northwest corner of Forty-eighth Street, today.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 10 -- The United Nations and Communist truce delegations met in secret for twenty-three minutes today at Panmunjom, Korea, and then recessed for an indefinite period as staff officers continued to put the final touches on an armistice agreement.

Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., increased its sales in the nine months ended April 30, last, to $76,077,112 from $70,620,343 a year earlier, but earnings were slightly lower, Philip S. Harris, president, reported yesterday.

Stock traders and investors reexamined the world news yesterday and found it still not to their liking -- Korean truce or no. Where news of the signing of the prisoners-of-war agreement barely influenced the list on Monday, all - the - still - unsolved international problems were being widely offered yesterday as excuses for the selling which forced prices down to their lowest levels in a year.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- A $300,000,000 cut in veterans' compensation and pension payments -foreshadowing possible curtailment of benefits to veterans with non-service disabilities -- has been recommended by a House Appropriations subcommittee.

BALTIMORE, June 9 -- Foreign relations should be concentrated within the State Department, under the direction of the Secretary of State, Walter S. Gifford, former United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, said today at the seventy-seventh commencement of the Johns Hopkins University.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted tentative approval today to all major money items in the Administration's $5,474,000,000 foreign aid bill.
The Fifth Avenue facade of St. Patrick's Cathedral served again yesterday as the backdrop for the twenty-first annual flower mart of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association.
Reappraisal of installment credit policies by banks, especially with regard to automobile financing, is required to meet changing conditions, the American Bankers Association said yesterday.

Jean Hersholt is known for many things -- as a movie actor whose career started back in the silent-flicker days, as the creator of Dr. Christian on the radio, as an extensive collector of Hans Christian Andersen and as a lover of good food and drink.
TOKYO, Wednesday, June 10 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,641, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- There is every indication that American business this year will exceed the $27,000,000,000 expenditure on new plant and equipment forecast for it in January, according to a joint survey announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Commerce.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were quiet yesterday and active months closed 3 points lower to 3 higher than on Monday.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- More than 5,000 Red Cross workers from across the country will meet here from June 22 to 24 to work out ways to make every contributor to the organization a more active member.

George Gregory Jr., executive director of Forest Neighborhood House, the Bronx, received the fourth Schaefer Achievement Award yesterday for his "unselfish service in the field of community betterment." The presentation was made at a luncheon at the Biltmore Hotel.

Taking the view that anything that helps drug stores increase sales also aids its own business, Johnson Johnson, has produced a new film, "Design for Selling," which will be shown at state and regional drug meetings. The film dramatically and entertainingly portrays the need and the methods for modernization and the benefits to be derived from it.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Russell A. Nixon, a Congressional lobbyist who as an Army first class private was called to an important role in the denazification and reparations phases of German occupation in 1945, refused to tell the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities today whether he was a Communist then or now.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer, a jurist of solemn mien in the courtroom, granted a mistrial yesterday when a lawyer taxed him with having "introduced levity" in a $400,000 damage action brought against members of the 1950 Board of Elections as individuals.

CHICAGO, June 9 (UP) -- Union and management officials of the Hedco Manufacturing Company signed a contract today giving a year's vacation with pay to employes who had been with the concern ten years. In addition, the contract provides that any employe with ten years of service who prefers to work during the eleventh year will receive double pay.

Two thousand persons, among them 540 recipients of bachelors degrees, heard Dr. Maurice Costello, New York dermatologist, deliver the commencement address at Manhattan College yesterday afternoon in which he cautioned that only chaos could result from the precepts taught by planned parenthood groups. Presiding at the college's 102d commencement was Cardinal Spellman.
MIAMI, Fla., June 9 -- Miami voters turned down today a plan to abolish the City of Miami and consolidate its government with that of Dade County.

LONDON, June 9 -- Answering questions in the House of Commons today Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, gave generous praise to the part President Eisenhower had played in paving the way for an armistice in Korea.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -Turner L. Smith, former Justice Department attorney, said today it was pure "coincidence" that papers he threw into a river involved five tax fraud cases from which the Government got very little.

A marriage license was issued yesterday to Sara Delano Roosevelt, granddaughter of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt and adopted daughter of John Hay Whitney, and Anthony di Bonaventura, a concert pianist whose father operates a barber shop on the East Side.

Knowing that they were the first men to scale Mount Everest and the first to gaze from that snow-capped rocky eminence over 29,000 feet above sea level at the world below them, what were the emotions of Edmund Hillary, the Auckland beekeeper, and Tensing Norkay, his Nepalese companion?

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- The last will and testament of Benjamin Franklin, consisting of ten yellowed pieces of paper, each bearing the signature "B. Franklin," was turned over to the American Philosophical Society today.

TRENTON, June 9 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll declared here today that the legislative committee investigating the dismissal of Nelson F. Stamler as deputy Attorney General had undertaken an "impossible ask" in its inquiry into law enforcement in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Abba S. Eban, Israeli Ambassador, called at the State Department today and left an hour and a quarter later with indications that he had registered his Government's dissatisfaction with a recent report on the Near East by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State.

LONDON, June 9 -- The Soviet Union's relaxation of border controls in Austria, coupled with progress toward peace in Korea helped maintain a cheerful if not a busy atmosphere on the stock markets today.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The American Legion split with President Eisenhower today over his proposal to allow 240,000 immigrants to come to the United States for permanent residence.

A restriction to limit the handling of dogs in the bred-by-exhibitor class at shows to owners or their immediate families was imposed through a rule amendment by American Kennel Club delegates yesterday at their quarterly meeting at the Hotel Commodore.
MILTON, Mass., June 9 -- The birth rate among college graduates is climbing, the college project of the Population Reference Bureau reported today .

President Eisenhower's address today at the annual convention of the National Junior Chamber of Commerce in Minneapolis will be broadcast "live" over WABC and WOR at 4:30 P. M. It will be presented by recording over WNBC at 10:30 P. M. and WCBS at 11:30 P. M. Television coverage will be limited to regularly scheduled news programs.

PARIS, June 9 -- Georges Bidault will go before the National Assembly tomorrow asking for approval as Premier with party groups still undecided on the positions they will take. It means that most of them will act only in course of the debate and that the outcome for the present appears still uncertain.

Last year, when Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Grignon attended the Department of Welfare's foster parents' get-together, they arrived with four children and went home with six. Yesterday, attending this year's party at Children's Center, 2 East 105th Street, where 350 children are awaiting foster homes, they had to content themselves with congenial conversation with 128 other foster parents.

Plans for the first annual New York Export Show, to be held at the 165th Infantry Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, from Nov. 16 to 20, were announced yesterday by Gottfried Neuberger, head of International Trade Shows.

BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- Hugh L. Mehorter, chairman of the New Jersey Racing Commission, today was elected president of the National Association of State Racing Commissioners at the group's nineteenth annual meeting.

A suggestion that the existing system of state aid be abolished as a means of assuring New York "real power" to run its own affairs and of ending repeated appeals to Albany in financial emergencies was made yesterday by Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, in a letter to Devereux Colt Josephs, chairman of the Temporary State Commission on City Management.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Eisenhower's request for a one-year renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act was approved by the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives today, 23 to 2, but immediately ran into new delays in the Rules Committee.

PITTSBURGH, June 9 -- Wage talks between subcommittees of the United Steel Workers Union, C. I. O., and the United States Steel Corporation were resumed today after a three-day recess. The group met for two hours, adjourning at 1:20 P. M. until 10:30 A. M. tomorrow, without comment on progress.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- The Weather Bureau today said last night's destructive tornadoes in Michigan and Ohio were the tenth most costly in the nation's history.
LONDON, June 9 -- In fifteen rounds of dreary, cautious boxing, Randolph Turpin, British middle-weight champion, scored a decision on points over Charles Humez of France tonight:

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Food prices, which brought the consumers' price index down early this year, are going to send it up again. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today that retail prices of food averaged 0.3 per cent higher on May 25 than on May 15.

New York University will graduate 7,237 and confer seven honorary degrees at its 121st commencement today. The exercises will begin at 10:30 a.m. at Ohio Field on the University Heights campus, 181st Street and University Avenue, the Bronx.

Rush-hour throngs at the southbound I. R. T. subway station at Seventy-seventh Street and Lexington Avenue watched in horror yesterday morning as a 27-year-old suitor plunged a knife into the heart of a 16-year-old schoolgirl who he later said was spurning him.

Simon Gantillon's "Maya," first played here in 1928, opened the Terese Hayden hot-weather series at the Theatre de Lys last evening. When the original Ernest Boyd translation was staged here with Aline MacMahon in the leading part, the constabulary closed "Maya" after fifteen performances.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- An abnormality severe tornado season, with May probably having set a record, is reported by the United States Weather Bureau and the Air Force air weather service here.

Election results for eighteen Actors Equity posts, including the office of second vice president for a two-year term and positions on the council, the union's governing body, were announced yesterday. The ballots were cast at Equity's fortieth annual meeting, held Friday at the Astor Hotel.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., announced yesterday a rise in the wholesale price of gasoline in New York State and New England of six-tenths to seven-tenths cent a gallon. The increase, which is effective today, will bring the wholesale price in the New York metropolitan area, excluding taxes, to 15.4 cents a gallon, up seven-tenths of a cent.

Oscar Levant played straight man instead of the piano yesterday. Glumly, the usually glib pianist swallowed chunks of pride as he endured a verbal spanking by James C. Petrillo, head of the American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L.

LONDON, June 9 -- At the close of their coronation conference, the Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth announced tonight they had agreed "that no opportunity should be lost of composing, or at least easing, the differences which at present divide the world."
FORT WORTH, June 9 (UP) -- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias toured a golf course today for the first time since she was operated on for cancer, but she rode on a motor scooter and didn't play any golf.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 9 (AP) -- Sandy Fingo, with Frank Safford in the sulky, won the feature pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight with a 2:06 mile. Diana Streakwas second and Doug Brown third. The winner paid $11.10.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 9 -- James H. Carmine, executive vice-president of Philco Corporation, Philadelphia, said here today the country is entering a healthy era of competitive selling "that will separate the strong from the weak."
DETROIT, June 9 -- Martin P. Durkin, Secretary of Labor, predicted today a move by the Eisenhower Administration to seek amendment of the Taft-Hartley Act during the current session of Congress.

SEOUL, Korea, June 9 -- Thousands upon thousands of Seoul's citizens paraded today through the streets of this war-wrecked city shouting their determination to march to the north to unify their country.

The Customs Brokers and Forwarders Association of America, Inc., and associate groups throughout the country urged Congress yesterday to correct the policy of the Military Sea Transportation Service regarding the handling of cargoes.
ST. LOUIS, June 9 (AP) -- Home runs by Hoot Evers and Gene Stephens and good relief hurling by Ellis Kinder helped the Red Sox gain a 6-5 victory over the Browns tonight.

The police and Bronx Zoo officials were still trying last night to find out how a dozen snakes got into the front yard of a Coney Island home in Brooklyn yesterday morning and how a penguin from a children's zoo in New Jersey managed to make its way last Sunday to the front yard of a Bronx house.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 9 -- The Kenya Administration today set cut to find "sensible" native African political leadership following the suppression yesterday of the second large-scale native political organization, the Kenya African Union.

Twenty dollars or less will buy a large share of fashion in summer dresses. Typical of the designs that show no stint of style and yet are below the $20 mark are the four illustrated here. All from new late summer collections, they will perk up wardrobes and be worn smartly right through the first warm days of fall.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 9 -- An unearned run in the sixth inning today enabled Princeton's baseball team to score a 1-0 playoff victory over Pennsylvania. The triumph entitles the Tigers to play for the Eastern Intercollegiate League championship.

Plans for immediate and large scale expansion in the facsimile and private wire service fields were announced yesterday by the Western Union Telegraph Company. More than double the already rapid rate of installation of these systems is now required, Walter P. Marshall, president of Western Union, said.

BALTIMORE, June 9 (UP) -- Larry MacPhail, former President of Bowie Race Track, today broke a self-imposed silence for the first time since his run-in with the State Racing Commission last April to announce he was resigning as a track director.
FLINT, Mich., June 9 (AP) -- The tornado that hit Flint last night provided a practical test of Michigan's civilian defense organization, and a scene of traditional Red Cross activity.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 9 -- Israeli spokesmen said tonight that twelve hours after Israel and Jordan signed an agreement in Jerusalem to combat infiltration across armistice lines, Arab marauders at 12:30 A. M. today bombed two houses and killed a farmer in Tirat Yehuda, a smallholders village three miles northeast of Lydda Airport.

ALBANY, June 9 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau said tonight that there was little tornado danger for New York State. Forecasters said conditions were not favorable for such twisters as struck the Midwest last night and New England tonight. Cooler air saved the state, the Weather Bureau said.

Today's new film is "Never Let Me Go," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer topical drama starring Clark Gable and Gene Tierney, at the Capitol. Delmer Daves directed and Clarence Brown produced from a screen play by Ronald Miller and George Froeschel, as adapted from the novel "Came the Dawn," by Roger Bax, Bernard Miles, Richard Haydn, Belita, Kenneth More, Karel Stepanek and Theodore Bikel are among the supporting players.

Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, appeared before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee Monday and yesterday to dispute the testimony of one of his uniformed subordinates, Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, retiring Chief of Staff of the Air Force.

LONDON, June 9 -- The possibility that tribal chieftains in Nyasaland will appeal to the International Court of Justice at The Hague to block Britain's plan for Central African colonial federation was raised today in the House of Commons.
TORONTO, June 9 -- With four days to go a record number of American buyers, 1,115 in all has already attended the sixth Canadian International Trade Fair here.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, June 9 -- The Standing Group, top military echelon in the fourteen-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization, has now approved in Washington a broad reorganization of the Allied command arrangements that will make French Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin commander in Chief of all Allied land, air and sea forces in the vital Central Sector of Europe.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, June 10 -- South Korea's National Assembly angrily rejected the impending armistice pact yesterday, as thousands of Koreans demonstrated in Seoul's streets.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 9 -- An air-raid drill that was staged in Nassau County from 7:45 to 7:55 o'clock tonight caused more traffic congestion in neighboring Queens than in Nassau, according to reports that reached here immediately after the test had ended.

Fordham University conferred degrees on 352 graduates of its College of Arts and Sciences yesterday at exercises held on the terrace of Keating Hall on the Bronx campus. Of the class, 124 received Bachelor of Arts degrees and 228 Bachelor of Science degrees.

Members of the Red Cross "Gallon Club," men and women who have donated eight or more pints of blood, will gather at noon today on the steps of Federal Hall, the old Subtreasury Building. Wall and Nassau Streets, to celebrate the opening of a summer donor center in the building.

When children think out for themselves "what a mother should be like" their decisions on the subject are a lot closer to mother's own than many adults would expect, child study researchers have found.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Rudolph Halley appears to be the reply to Governor Dewey's complacent assumption that only Mr. Dewey can rescue New York City from its rudderless drifting.

THIONVILLE, France, June 7 -- Alongside the economic revolution in the six European countries participating in the Schuman plan for pooling coal and steel resources, a social revolution is beginning to take form. Some of the men who are directing the economic changes think that guiding and shaping the social transformation may be the most important part of their task.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 9 -- The Government revealed plans today to revise the tax system, particularly as it applies to peasants. The plan would intensify tax collections which, it was said, have been only up to 50 per cent, and to curtail social benefits as too heavy a burden on the economy.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 10 (UP) -- South Korean troops, backed by tanks commanded by Capt. George S. Patton Jr., recaptured a vital eastern front outpost last night. Republic of Korea troops fought to the crest of "Luke's Castle" in the fourteenth day of a bloody battle and forced North Korean Communists down the other side.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman said yesterday that the order of the day in Washington was "confusion and defeat" but expressed doubt that the public would support for long the "course now being followed in Congress nor the tendencies being shown in world affairs."

One of the nation's largest insurers of trucks and buses, the American Fidelity and Casualty Company, made it quite clear yesterday that it stands strongly behind the nation's highway transportation system and for that reason never will own any securities in railroads.

A Time for Giving Advice This is a season for the giving of advice to the young. Wherever gather seniors in caps and gowns -- in chapels, halls or out under the sky on rows of small, hard chairs -- persons will have been found who are willing and, in a surprisingly large number of instances, able to offer advice.

ATLANTIC CITY, June. 9 -- Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks declared here today that his department was prepared to set up a "Business Services Agency" staffed by outstanding industrialists "to maintain the current record prosperity or to meet whatever adjustments or emergencies may arise later."
Thomas A. Daly has been named manager of technical operation for the aviation gas turbine division of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, and Hewett R. Arnold has been appointed assistant manager.

MONTREAL, June 9 (UP) -- Johnny Bratton, a top challenger for Kid Gavilan's world welterweight crown, pounded out a unanimous ten-round decision over Danny Womber of New York tonight before 3,575 fans at the Forum.
Laurance S. Rockefeller was named foreman of a special Federal grand jury impaneled yesterday to investigate waterfront crimes exclusively.

New records in both domestic and international scheduled airline traffic were set during 1952, according to the fourteenth edition of Air Transport Facts and Figures, which has just been issued by the Air Transport Association. The scheduled airlines carried some 28,500,000 passengers a distance of 15,500,000,000 passenger-miles.

VIENNA, June 9 -- Soviet occupation authorities told the Austrian Government today they would no longer intervene to keep in office against the regime's will Austrian police officials friendly to the Communists. They added that they also would permit all goods, except explosives, to move in and out of their zone without the transport certificates previously required.

Representatives of the Republican and Liberal parties are meeting today for the first time with the officers of the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee to explore the possibility of agreeing on coalition candidates for Mayor and other municipal offices to be filled at this fall's general election.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed irregularly lower yesterday but almost all active items were mixed or higher. Coffee, wool, copper, hides, tin, zinc and cocoa closed lower; sugar and potatoes, mixed, and cottonseed oil, soybean oil, rubber and lead higher.

ROME, June 9 -- Returns from the Italian national elections showed tonight that despite more than $3,000,000,000 of United States aid since the end of World War II, and five years of what is generally regarded by unbiased observers here as the efficient administration of the De Gasperi Government, one out of three Italians voted for the extreme Left-Wing parties.
Issues of new common stock valued at more than $14,000,000 will be made by public utility, chemical and phonograph record enterprises today to their stockholders. The offerings are as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -Rep. Clarence J. Brown, Republican of Ohio, said today military commissaries present a "real threat to free enterprise" and called on the Government to get out of competition with private business.

Directors of Claude Neon, Inc., declared yesterday two cash dividends of 10 cents each on the common stock, payable on July 10 and Dec. 31, to holders of record of June 30 and Dec. 15, respectively. A stock dividend of 5 per cent also was voted for distribution to common stockholders on Sept. 30.

A strong possibility that the American Federation of Labor would charter a new union to battle it out with the racket-ridden International Longshoremen's Association for control of the New York docks was indicated yesterday by George Meany, president of the A.F.L.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9 -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America was challenged today by the producers of "The Moon Is Blue" to defend before a court of public opinion the organization's refusal of a production code seal of approval for the film edition of the hit stage attraction.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 9 -- Automobiles have proved to be "good shelters" and appear to offer better protection against flying debris than the above-ground floors of frame houses in areas beyond the major damage radius of an atomic explosion, the Society of Automotive Engineers was told today.

The Associated Press reported yesterday that, on some of the best authority there is in baseball, it had learned that the transfer of the Browns to Baltimore would be approved at the American League's next meeting in Cincinnati on July 13. The actual transfer cannot be effected until the end of this season, however.

Two attractive members of Hollywood's upper acting echelon are eyeing the stage. They are Deborah Kerr and Mary Astor. Miss Kerr has been asked to appear in "Tea and Sympathy," Robert Anderson's new play, to be staged by Elia Kazan in behalf of the Playwrights Company and Mary K. Frank.

New issues of public utility securities valued at more than $95,000.000 were sold at public sealed bidding to investment banking syndicates yesterday. Of the issues, $23,200,000 of common stock of the American Gas and Electric Company was placed on the market at once, priced at $29 a share. The other offerings, mortgage bonds and debentures, will be offered to investors later in the week. The awards were as follows:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Great strides have been made in employing the handicapped during the past year, and I should like to call attention to the fact that in the field of blindness this drive has been more than successful.

A melange of motifs from the Orient distinguishes a collection of furniture introduced this week by Modernage and available in its New York shop at 16 East Thirty-fourth Street and at its new store in Paramus, N. J.

A proposal for restoring to good standing some $11,000,000 of dollar bond debt of the Republic of Ecuador which has been in default since before World War I has been approved by the Foreign Bondholders Protective Association.

PITTSBURGH, June 9 (AP) -- The Pirates scored four runs in the eighth inning today after two were out, three of them on a pinch homer by Eddie Pellagrini, to defeat the Cardinals, 7-4, and end a five-game losing streak.

Post Office Garage, Inc., Harold E. Witteman, president, builder of the four-story garage and office building at 225-29 East Forty-third Street, has sold the building to a client of John T. McCormick Jr., for cash over a first mortgage of $500,000 at 3 per cent held by the Dry Dock Savings Bank.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- A commodity trader said today he had been fined $200 by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange for criticizing operations in onion futures on the exchange.

An analysis by John McCloy, former United States High Commissioner for Germany, of some of the problems confronting American diplomacy will be published July 6 by Harvard University Press. The book will be "The Challenge to American Foreign Policy." Mr. McCloy discusses civilian authority and the influence the military has acquired in matters of national policy and gives suggestions for strengthening the American foreign service.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Russians are well aware of how their wartime "friendliness" toward us made them the real victors of the Second World War, deepening the cleft of prejudice between us and our natural allies, the British. What was it that kept us from saying, "We have got to cooperate with the British," instead of "We have got to get along with the Russians"?

A first mortgage of $1,500,000 at 4 1/2 per cent for twenty years has been placed by the George Comfort Company, broker, on a one-story factory and office building being built for Lenox, Inc., manufacturer of chinaware, in Pomona, Gallaway Township, N. J.

It would only bring "further divisiveness and schisms" into Israel to attempt to introduce Reform Judaism there, where only the orthodox faith is recognized officially, Rabbi Emmanuel Rackman of Far Rockaway, Queens, declared last night.

MOSCOW, June 9 -- The United States Embassy said today that it had been informed by the Soviet Foreign Office that exit permits would be given to Mrs. Eddy Gilmore, Russian wife of an Associated Press correspondent in Moscow, and three other persons.
Supervisory officers of the Department of Sanitation bore down more heavily yesterday, the second day of the drive against "litterbugs," issuing 491 court summonses compared with 317 on Monday.

Residents of Bronx, Westchester and Rockland counties, comprising an estimated 600,000 taxpayers. will file their Federal income tax returns next year with the Internal Revenue Bureau's Upper Manhattan office rather than in Albany, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Senate Republican leaders reached a firm decision today to bring this session of Congress to an end around July 31 and not to come back, short of a national or world emergency, until January.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization today ordered the end of rent control in twenty-three "critical defense housing areas" after July 31. On that date the communities, in thirteen states and Alaska, will lose the designation as critical areas, under a ruling of the newly created Defense Areas Advisory Committee of the agency.

The Federal Submerged Lands Act signed by President Eisenhower May 22 settles many legal issues involving the fifteen states bordering the Atlantic Ocean, but so far as Maine is concerned, it does not settle the state's seaward boundary as three miles from its coast.

CLEVELAND, June 9 (AP) -- Bob Lemon beat the Senators, 2 -- 1, on a two-hitter tonight for the Indians' sixth straight victory. A bases-loaded pinch single by Hank Majeski scored both Cleveland runs with two out in the eighth.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The thoughtful survey which you have published by Benjamin Fine points out two highly significant symptoms concerning the high schools of New York City. The factors referred to are the extremely low morale among teachers and the very high drop-out rate among students.

The Holy Land, which has stirred the deepest emotions in men of various faiths, has sent here, for millons to see in a nation-wide tour, tangible evidence of the civilizations that have flourished there from prehistoric times.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations has accused the State Department of giving foreign labor journalists a false and "shockingly anti-labor" analysis of the Taft-Hartley Law and of American labor's opposition to it.

In an effort to broaden the American market for its securities, one of the Netherlands' largest industrial corporations is issuing American depositary receipts for American shares. These are certificates representing a share interest in the stock of a foreign corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- Representative Ray J. Madden, Democrat of Indiana, called tonight on the Senate and House Armed Services Committees for a thorough investigation of the relationship between this spring's atomic bomb tests in Nevada and the unusual number of recent tornadoes.

DESPITE rather low water on some rivers as a result of insufficient rain, a lack which is not really noticeable here, New Brunswick anglers have been taking some nice salmon from the Miramichi and St. John, and fish are reported moving up the Cains and Dungarvon.

By taking advantage of a flaw in the city's 1952 bill imposing a liquor license tax, tavern owners won action by the City Council yesterday that will kill the impost entirely after the collection this year.

The Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal -- which can be authorized only by a special act of Congress -- was presented yesterday to Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, who as master of the Isbrandtsen cargo liner Flying Enterprise struggled vainly for thirteen days eighteen months ago to save the ship.

Although the present Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act expires on Friday of this week the legislative wheels have only just begun to move on extending this measure of suck vital importance to our foreign policy. The bill that the House Ways and Means Committee reported yesterday is not a very satisfactory one, but it is better than nothing and ought to be accepted by Congress within the next few days.

Cedric Henning Belfrage, who was taken to Ellis Island for deportation after he refused to tell two Congressional committees whether he was a Communist, was ordered released in bail yesterday by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld.

An offer to have the city administer, as a stop-gap, the waterfront controls proposed by the State Crime Commission until they could be taken over by a New York-New Jersey agency was made yesterday to Governor Dewey by Edward J. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, and Dr. John F. Mahoney, Commissioner of Health, appealed yesterday to workers in their departments and to the medical and nursing professions to support the "Aid to Korea Week" drive of the American-Korean Foundation.

For the final novelty of its season at the City Center, the New York City Ballet last night presented an importation from the West Coast choreographed by Lew Christensen, who is its Administrative Director and also the director of the San Francisco Ballet, where the present work had its genesis earlier in the spring.

BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- Royal Vale, strong thoroughbred from the stable of Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir, is classed as the horse to beat in tomorrow's nineteenth running of the $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap over a mile and a quarter at Suffolk Downs. More than 25,000 spectators are expected. Royal Vale has top weight of 125 pounds.

Through the elementary expedient of saving ground on the inside, Augie Catalano guided C. Mahlon Kline's Kaster to a victory by a nose over Begorra at Belmont Park yesterday. The accomplishment was no mean one, despite the fact that Kaster was the favorite with the crowd of 18,447, for Begorra was ridden by Eddie Arcaro, who thrilled the onlookers with a fine finish.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 9 (AP) -- The development of a new process of making stronger pulps from hardwoods at lower costs was announced here today by a research associate of the New York College of Forestry at Syracuse.
PITTSBURGH, June 9 -- Builders and realty investors today were warned against the possibility of a new era of over-production of office space in metropolitan centers.

NEW YORK'S cliff dwellers have a weakness for all manner of special services, an urban trait that betrays constant retreat from the primitive state. There are establishments in odd corners of the city that cater to such folk, and do well at it.

Philip B. Perlman, former United States Solicitor General, assailed the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act yesterday and criticized President Eisenhower for not taking decisive action, which, he said, was a "prerequisite for early and substantial amendment" of the law.

When Reginald Marsh takes a pen or a lithocrayon in hand he deftly continues an old and honorable tradition, one that reaches back to Hogarth, Rowlandson, Cruikshank on the one hand, and one that includes the great American reporter-illustrators like Homer and Sloan on the other.
