The news from Mexico City that a personnel cut of 25 per cent has been ordered in the United States Embassy is the first tangible sign of the threatened crippling of the American diplomatic service. This is not too strong a term to use -- presuming that the appropriations cuts just made by Congress are not restored to a considerable extent.

The boy who "swept up" with a hand broom and the carpenter who built or changed shelving are following the kerosene lamp and the cracker barrel out of the store. There was not a broom or a handsaw in the National Store Modernization, Building and Maintenance Show which opened yesterday for a four-day run in the basement of Madison Square Garden.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of a few days ago you called attention to the vexed question of the Suez Canal. Permit me to make a few observations on that problem.

ROME, Wednesday, June 10 -- The Center party coalition headed by Premier Alcide De Gasperi's Christian Democrats won 50.2 per cent of the votes in the elections for the Senate Sunday and Monday and so retained control of the upper house by 125 seats of the 237 that were at issue.

Home runs hit by Carl Furillo, Gil Hodges, Pee Wee Reese and Duke Snider and the slick relief hurling of Bob Milliken proved more than adequate as the Dodgers stopped the Redlegs' winning streak at five at Ebbets Field yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (UP) -Del Ennis hit his ninth homer of the season with one out in the ninth inning onight to give the Phillies a 10-9 decision over the Cubs before 6,903 at Connie Mack Stadium.

One of the first consequences of a truce in Korea will be to arm with a new argument the Congressional opponents of President Eisenhower's tax program. Chairman Reed of the House Ways and Means Committee has already declared that a truce will give impetus to his drive "to cut taxes instead of raise them," and we shall hear more of this talk as the debate proceeds.

Two five-story buildings, each containing a store and twenty-one apartments, at 84-86 Hopkins Street in Brooklyn have been sold by Samuel Berman to the Mayer-Sapir Realty Corporation, represented by Herbert L. Scheibel, attorney. Allen Binder, Inc., were the brokers and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The State of New Jersey has designated June 30 for the sale of $150,000,000 of state-guaranteed revenue bonds to help finance construction of the Garden State Parkway from now until December. The sale will be made by competitive bidding, or otherwise, depending upon circumstances.

By way of doing something a little special to climax his current season on the air, Burr Tillstrom, master of the Kuklapolitans, offered on N. B. C. video last Sunday an original operetta based on the legend of St. George and the Dragon. The outcome was not altogether happy.
Arrest warrants for 350 chronic traffic violators, the first of 10,000 warrants to be issued, were distributed yesterday to the police in the five boroughs of the city.

As its final official act at its last regular meeting before it goes out of existence at 12:01 A.M. Monday, the Board of Transportation attempted yesterday to keep down the cost of modernizing the Seventy - Fourth Street power plant that supplies electricity to the I.R.T.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The National Association of Manufacturers informed Congress today that a majority of its board of directors, in a recent poll, favored modification of the organization's stand against continuation of the excess profits tax.

" HELLO, Jimmy," said the Right Rev. Msgr. Cornelius J. Drew, a note of surprise in his voice. "It's nice to see you again." Jimmy Carter, the lightweight champion of the world, shuffled in embarrassment as he stood in the rectory 9f St. Charles' Church in the heart of Harlem. Jimmy isn't much on words. He uses them sparingly.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- One of "the best people" on Henry W. Grunewald's Christmas necktie list was the Federal judge who sentenced him last week for contempt of Congress.

ST. LOUIS, June 9 (AP) -- Federal Judge George H. Moore explained yesterday that he had rejected a debtor plan for reorganization of the bankrupt Missouri Pacific Railroad because it was not in accord with a system of reorganization found to be in the public interest.

DETROIT, June 9 -- A sensational diving catch by Hank Bauer ended tonight's game between the Yankees and Tigers, giving the New Yorkers a thrill-packed 3-2 victory, their twelfth in a row. There were two on and two out, when Bauer, risking his neck, hit the turf in right center, catching up with and clutching the ball slashed by Detroit's Harvey Kuenn.

BASLE, Switzerland, June 9 (AP) -- The Bank for International Settlements said today that full confidence in European currencies could only be restored by a rapid return to a system of general convertibility.

Wearing one of her famous tricorne hats and shaking an undaunted fist at social injustice, Miss Frances Perkins reminded women yesterday of the gains they had made between the times of Queen Victoria and Queen Elizabeth II, in both of whose reigns she has lived.
PARIS, June 9 -- The United States has given France $90,000,000 to enable her to cover her deficits to the European Payments Union for April and May.

Thirty-four firemen were honored yesterday, eleven of them posthumously, for deeds of valor and merit in 1952. The awards were made in City Hall Plaza by Mayor Impellitteri and Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet, who also swore in 402 probationary firemen and promoted 119 others.

One hundred and fifty representatives of city, state, Federal and private law enforcement agencies attended a Federal Bureau of Investigation conference yesterday on thefts from interstate shipments. The meeting was held in the Pennsylvania Railroad Young Men's Christian Association Auditorium in Pennsylvania Station.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- The Athletics today snapped a five-game losing streak with a 2-1 verdict over the White Sox. Harry Byrd blanked Chicago after the first, but he needed help from Lefty Morris Martin in the ninth.

According to reports in underwriting circles, the banking syndicates with commitments in major bond and stock marketings are making good progress in the face of the market's recent instability. The new issue of Consolidated Gas Electric Light and Power mortgage bonds and the new Gulf Power Company mortgage obligations are headed for quick sale at yields of 3.75 per cent and 4.05 per cent, respectively.
Theatre folk from both sides of the footlights will have one more opportunity to obtain souvenirs of the venerable Empire Theatre, which house wreckers began tearing down yesterday.

Vistarama, the new anamorphic type of wide-screen photography and projection with lenses adaptable to both 35mm and 16mm filming, received its first local press and industry demonstration yesterday morning at the R. K. O. Eighty-sixth Street Theatre.

BETHESDA, Md., June 10 (AP) -- Pat O'Sullivan, a steady 26-year-old golfer from Orange, Conn., virtually clinched the women's Eastern amateur golf championship today with her second one-over-par 75 in a row.

STANTON, Del., June 10 (AP) -- Incidentally, the unbeaten juvenile filly from Mrs. Elizabeth Graham's Maine Chance Farm, scored her fourth triumph today in the sixteenth running of the $15,025 Polly Drummond Stakes at Delaware Park.

Car thieves in the West have come up with an efficient little gadget capable of prying open the locks on automobile trunks with a twist of the arm and may export it to Eastern communities this summer, motorists were warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The international compact to outlaw and punish Governments and private persons who destroy, or demonstrate an intent to destroy, all or part of ethnical, national, racial or religious groups (genocide) has been neither acceded to nor ratified by the United States, and the Administration recently assured the Senate it will not press for such action.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Senate and House conferees today agreed on a two-year extension of the Doctor Draft Law. The bill, a compromise between different versions already passed, in effect frees from any future liability all physicians who have served on active duty, in any capacity at all, at least seventeen months since Sept. 16, 1940.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- President Eisenhower says Federal agencies are "pursuing the purpose" of ending racial segregation in veterans hospitals, Navy shipyards and school son Army posts.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 10 -- The board of overseers of Harvard University unanimously confirmed today the election of Dr. Nathan Marsh Pusey as president of the university. This made official a preliminary step taken June 1 by the six-member corporation in selecting the 46-year-old educator who holds three degrees from Harvard.

PARIS, Thursday, June 11 -- By a single ballot Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, failed early today to obtain the necessary 314 votes required to secure approval of the National Assembly for the Premiership. The count was 313 to 228.
The General Electric Company, the nation's largest producer of electrical equipment, offered yesterday a general wage rise of slightly more than 3 per cent to 100,000 of its employes.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 10 -- For the second night following signature of an anti-infiltration agreement between Israel and Jordan, Jordanian marauders crossed the border into Israel last night, according to an Israeli Army spokesman.

In recent weeks there have been several letters printed in the metropolitan press bemoaning the dearth of good Democratic candidates for the coming New York City Mayoralty election and several others deploring the city's outgrowing of its communities, leaving the individual citizens helpless in the machinery of the city's complicated administration of its vital services.
The Board of Health-will hold a public hearing June 22 on proposed minimum standards for classifying cellars in pre-1929 tenements as fit for habitation.

MOUNTAIN IRON, Minn., June 10 -- The first carload of taconite concentrate produced by the United States Steel Corporation in Minnesota is on its way to the blast furnaces from this little town on the Mesabi Iron Range. Officials of Oliver iron-mining division of the corporation took part in ceremonies yesterday, marking the beginning of production at the new Pilotac concentrating plant here.

Visitors and New Yorkers loafing in the bright sun at lunch hour yesterday caught sight of jet fighter planes and troop-carrying aircraft roaring over the city. Not many realized that it was a mock air attack on Manhattan and an Air Force salute to the city on its 300th birthday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10 -- The United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency is planning a $130,000,000 program for the twelve months beginning July 1, but this is dependent upon Congress' appropriating the $71,000,000 that the United States has pledged as its share.

The first model of a new low-cost, easy-to-manufacture artificial leg for distribution in Korea to amputees among the natives will be produced this week, it was announced yesterday by the American-Korean Foundation, headed by Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower.

BOSTON, June 10 -- Officials of the Boston Metropolitan Chapter of the American Red Cross expressed today their appreciation for the public's response to appeals for assistance to tornado-stricken Worcester County.

That basically square lines in furniture can be handled gracefully is indicated by the designs in a new collection of pieces by Jens Risom. Presented here yesterday, the group is available through decorators from his showroom, 49 East Fifty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Some Navy officers have so taken to heart new security regulations on information that they are hiding routine official papers from one another.

NEW DELHI, India, June 10 -- The Indian Government announced today it had decided to withdraw its diplomatic mission from Lisbon as a protest against the Portuguese Government's refusal even to discuss the question of the transfer of its Indian colonies to India.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 10 -- An official Government announcement broadcast tonight indicated that about 950, or possibly close to 1,000. Mau Mau terrorists had been killed in the course of their rebellion. The number of victims of the Mau Mau up to June 3 was given as 411 Africans, 17 Europeans and 4 Asians.

BRISTOL, England, June 10 (UP) -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., and Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, scored straight-set victories today to gain the semi-finals of women's singles in the West of England lawn tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The proposal for a bi-state commission to control the waterfront was generally well received here today, and the indications were that Congress might approve the interstate compact before the adjournment target date of July 31.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 10 -- President Eisenhower expressed his sorrow today over the news that Senator Taft's illness will require him to relinquish his day-to-day duties as the Senate Republican floor leader.

A start toward an attempt to agree on a coalition city ticket was made yesterday at a conference of representatives of the Republican and Liberal parties with members of the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

VIENNA, June 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Union and Austria are exchanging Ambassadors and reestablishing full diplomatic relations. The decision was Moscow's, another move in an apparent appeasement campaign.

Marlon Brando, who went on to make a reputation for himself in the cinema world after his portrayal of the brutal Stanley Kowalski in the Broadway presentation of "A Streetcar Named Desire," will face "live" audiences again. The actor, now a top box-office name in movies, has agreed to star in a revival of Shaw's "Arms and the Man" on the silo circuit during the month of July.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would buy additional storage facilities for the mounting supplies of grain being turned over to the Government under price support programs.
DAINGERFIELD, Tex., June 10 -- The Lone Star Steel Company produced its first steel at its E. B. Germany works here today when at simple ceremonies the mill's No. 2 open-hearth furnace was tapped.

For the convenience of downtown workers and in an attempt to offset the usual summer slump in blood donations, the American Red Cross opened yesterday its fourth local blood donor center -- in the Subtreasury Building, recently renamed Federal Hall, at Wall and Nassau Streets.
In a speech at Minneapolis yesterday President Eisenhower expressed briefly and clearly the overwhelming necessity for unity among the nations of the free world.

THOSE who can recall the weakfishing on Peconic Bay in the so-called "good old days," when the fish were not only plentiful but large, will be moved to tears or ire by the recent communication from the New York State Conservation Department which punctuates the following sentence with an exclamation point -- "The weaks are back!"

WALTHAM, Mass., June 10 -- In a program intended to demonstrate that most forms of artistic expression can be fun, Brandeis University opened its second annual Festival of the Creative Arts tonight by presenting contemporary American comedians in a performance of their techniques.

The echoes of Coronation Day have lingered on in a household far beyond the borders of the Commonwealth; long after the last cheer was raised to the Queen, long after visitors to London from afar began their journeys home, the brilliance of the Coronation in all its medieval splendor has been reflected in the eyes and, unexpectedly, in the speech of a certain young lady.

The Skiatron Electronics and Television Corporation had been unable, until last night at least, to obtain feature movie films from major motion-picture companies to be used in its demonstration of Subscriber-vision, a proposed form of "box office" or pay-as-you-see television.

RENO, June 10 -- The five-man Board of Regents of the University of Nevada voted unanimously late last night to oust Dr. Frank J. Richardson, head of the university's biology department, whose outspoken opposition to policies of Dr. Minard W. Stout, the Nevada school's president, created a country-wide educational controversy.

A new short novel by James A. Michener. Pulitzer Prize-winning author of "Tales of the South Pacific," will soon be published under two titles. It will appear in the July 6 issue of Life magazine as "The Bridges at Toko-ri" and will be published in book form by Random House with the title "The Sea and the Sky."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 -- The Screen Actors Guild adopted a "no comment" attitude today in the face of a proposal by Darryl F. Zanuck, Twentieth Century-Fox production chief, that actors be hired on a double-pay scale, with a lower rate for time spent in rehearsing performances.

The "Man-of-the-Year" award of the Metropolitan Conference of the National Federation of Temple Brotherhoods was presented last night to Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 10 -- Reversing recent policy, Yugoslavia has undertaken to press for a decision on her dispute with Italy over the Free Territory of Trieste, part of which is occupied by United States and British troops and part by Yugoslavia.

DETROIT, Ore., June 10 -- A $70,000,000, Government-built multi-purpose dam in the Willamette Basin was dedicated today by Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, as a symbol of the idea that there was room in the Pacific Northwest for both public and private power, "just as long as the agreements we reach between them are worked out to bring forth the maximum benefits to all."

Four-year-old Dennis Glavas, who the Children's Court Division of the Domestic Relations Court ruled last April was still a Jew in spite of his baptism as a Roman Catholic, was discharged from a foster home yesterday and placed in the care of his Jewish mother.
BERLIN, June 10 (AP) -- The Russians have abruptly halted major operations in the construction of a giant naval base on the Baltic island of Ruegen, informed Allied quarters said today.

Governors Dewey and Driscoll are to be commended for their prompt decision to recommend that special sessions of the New York and New Jersey Legislatures enact the State Crime Commission's proposals regulating waterfront hiring practices by creating a Division of Port Administration.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 10 -- President Eisenhower expounded today his concept of balanced economic and military security. It was based on a realistic air power program, a rejection of isolationism and complete devotion to Allied unity within the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, who is suffering from a serious but not fully diagnosed illness, turned over his day-by-day duties as the Senate Republican floor leader today to Senator William F. Knowland of California.

Recognition of the increased interest of young people in politics and government has led to steps now being taken to reduce the age requirement for voting in this country, Ivy Baker Priest. Treasurer of the United States, told sixty-six members of the graduating class of Finch Junior College yesterday.

Three North Carolina newspaper men received yesterday Sidney Hillman awards for 1952 in recognition of their work in exposing the Ku Klux Klan in their state, which resulted in the conviction of 100 Klansmen.

A public offering will be made today of $150,000,000 of five-year 4 per cent debentures of General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the first public financing by the automobile finance company since 1936, and the first major offering of short-term debt securities in the public market since 1942.
PITTSBURGH, June 10 (AP) -- Manager Eddie Stanky put the Cardinals through a stiff morning workout and they responded tonight with a 5-1 victory over the Pirates.
CLEVELAND, June 10 (AP) -- Three speakers at the convention of the American Institute of Banking agreed today that the times call for special caution in extending loan credit.

Organized labor struck off in a new social welfare direction yesterday with an announcement by the Upholsterers International Union, A. F. L., of plans for a $5,000,000 village in Florida for retiring members.
PARIS, June 10 -- The political complexion of Europe is beginning to change in a manner that can be considered only as unfavorable to the policy and interests of the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 (UP) -- Robin Roberts scored his tenth victory of the season and Jim Konstanty, with relief from Steve Ridzik and Karl Drews, won his fifth as the Phillies defeated the Cubs, 9 -- 1 and 8 -- 5, tonight for a sweep of the four-game series.
LONDON, June 10 -- Most domestic stocks reacted to yesterday's sharp setback on Wall Street and prices declined in nearly all. sections of the market here today.

A new, many-windowed two-story brick building at Spring Street and the Avenue of the Americas became officially the Library for the Blind yesterday after dedication ceremonies at which city and library officials and a few of the 5,000 sightless readers participated.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 10 -- The championship qualifying tests ended today for the United States open, and tomorrow the select field of 157 will set out over the Oakmont Country Club course in the seventy-two-hole tourney that will decide the 1953 titleholder.

A deportation order against a 24-year-old Greek seaman who jumped ship in 1949 and subsequently served two years in the United States Army, including eleven months in Korea, has been affirmed by the Board of Immigration Appeals.

NEWARK, June 10 -- A jury in Federal Court here acquitted today Richard D. Green and the Guild Products Corporation, which he formerly owned, on the two counts of an indictment charging trickery in the sale of surgical dressings to the armed services and filing a false statement with the Government. The case was given to the jury after ten days trial before Judge Thomas F. Meaney. The panel deliberated two-and-a-half hours.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 10 -- Ted Ray, the massive Englishman, had hit a tremendous wood shot in the vicinity of the green during the United States open over the satanically designed Oakmont Country Club course in 1927. He plodded placidly to the green and was jarred loose from his aplomb. The ball was nowhere to be seen.
To dress smartly while awaiting a baby is a simple task, according to Abraham Straus, which proved its point yesterday with a showing of maternity fashions.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The American Red Cross appealed today to citizens across the country for contributions to the organization's disaster fund to help meet record disaster expenses.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 10 -- David F. Austin, executive vice president, United States Steel Corporation. Pittsburgh, warned here today that within the past few months the so-called "Cold War" is being forced into the area of economics with the Communists nations awaiting the day of a United States business collapse.
SEOUL, Korea, June 10 -- There continued to be scattered demonstrations in Seoul by student groups today, who roared their desire to march north to unify their country.

Charles Masterson of Brooklyn made a belated start in the Brooklyn tennis championship yesterday at the Knickerbocker Field Club and reached the quarter-final round by winning two matches. Masterson, 35, defeated Leo Tedesco, Brooklyn, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0, in the second round, then vanquished Winton Charlop, also Brooklyn, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1.

Behind the brilliant one - hit pitching of southpaw Eddie Picker, DeWitt Clinton's nine captured the city Public Schools Athletic League baseball championship yesterday, defeating Boys High, 7 -- 0, at Macombs Dam Park, the Bronx. The winners swept through their regular season undefeated, winning nineteen games.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A Mutual Security bill authorizing $5,312,732,500 in new money to build military and economic strength throughout the free world in the fiscal year 1954 was approved today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

Mark Freeman's letter in your issue of June 8 complaining of parcel post service at Grand Central Postal Station has been reviewed. I am sorry he was put to some trouble. But as a tax-payer he should not be altogether unhappy.

A 25-year-old jobless dishwasher was arrested yesterday, accused of trying to extort money under circumstances that twice before had failed. One of these had been made by the suspect, himself, and had resulted in his imprisonment or more than three years.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 10 (AP) -- The General Electric Company has asked a Federal Court to clear up a muddle with the Radio Corporation of America over rights to license other concerns to use G. E. patents.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Key members said today they had been assured that atomic tests had not caused the series of tornadoes sweeping the country. A proposed Congressional investigation therefore, was unnecessary, they said.
New issues of $72,000,000 of public utility and natural gas securities will be placed on the market today. The offerings are as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Government today announced signing of a contract under which it may get up to 56,000,000 pounds of refined nickel from an undeveloped deposit in British Columbia eighty miles east of Vancouver. Edmund F. Mansure, defense materials procurement administrator, said the new contract "brings us another long step closer to our goal of meeting all future nickel requirements for defense and other essential uses."

If any part of Wall Street was left unscarified during the recent once-a-year appearance of the Bawl Street Journal, the oversight is to be taken care of by the Daily Bond Crier, annual lampoon of the municipal bond business, which will make its 1953 bow tomorrow at the annual outing of the Municipal Bond Club at Rye, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 3, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

Passenger travel through the Port of New York during May showed a sharp drop from the totals of a year ago, a decline attributed by passenger officials to the recent French merchant marine officers' strike and fluctuations in bookings caused by the Coronation.

LONDON, June 10 -- The Soviet Cruiser Sverdlov, prototype for a new class of cruisers reported under construction in Soviet Baltic Sea dockyards, arrived at Spithead today to represent the Soviet Navy at the Coronation naval review next Monday.

The first consignment of burlap woven on mills in Pakistan is on board ship bound for this country, it was announced yesterday at Pakistan House, 12 East Sixty-fifth Street, where the story was told of the completion of the first burlap production facilities in the new country, a grower of jute but without mills on its foundation six years ago.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Top officers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations entertained Vice President Richard M. Nixon and forty-three Senators at a dinner last night.

PITTSBURGH, June 10 -- Although office and loft occupany throughout the country remains well above 95 per cent of available space and rental rates generally have reached a new peak, net earnings of building owners have not reflected proportionate improvement and in some instances have been declining recently, according to reports received today at the convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, and subsidiaries, reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $4,832,540 for the first three months of the year. This was equal to 67 cents a share on the communications and manufacturing concern's outstanding capital stock, and compares with a consolidated net of $4,735,255, or 66 cents a share, in the March quarter a year ago.

The Long Island Transit Authority said yesterday that it would be compelled to abandon its plan to reorganize and rehabilitate the Long Island Rail Road unless the Federal Court set aside a tax settlement of $8,806,000 negotiated recently by the City of New York and William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt railroad.

BONN, Germany, June 10 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer precipitated a debate today in the Bundestag, the lower house of Parliament, to shore up his foreign policy, which appears to have been seriously undermined in recent weeks by the Social Democratic party's campaign for a four-power solution to the problem of Germany's reunification.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 10 -- Walter Nathaniel Ridley, head of the Department of Psychology at Virginia State College, will receive a Doctor of Education degree Monday at the University of Virginia. According to records available here, he will be the first of his race to receive a degree at the doctoral level from any state-supported Southern university.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A bill to bring under Federal regulation political primaries, including preferential primaries, and party conventions for the selection of Federal candidates, and to afford more realistic limitations on campaign spending was introduced today by Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr., Democrat of Missouri.
VIENNA, June 10 -- President Antonin Zapotocky of Czechoslovakia announced today that Czechoslovak trade unions would be purged because of their resistance to the recent Czechoslovak currency reform.

Indications that the craftsmen of tomorrow probably will produce as imaginative and finished work as do many of those of today are given in the fourth annual Young Americans' exhibit, which opens today in the gallery of America House, 32 East Fifty-second Street.

ANKARA, Turkey, Thursday, June 11 -- The Soviet Union has sent a note to the Turkish Government offering to recognize Turkish sovereignty over the border territories of Kars and Ardahan in return for a pledge by Turkey to seek a conference of the powers for revision of the Montreux Convention of 1936, providing for regulation of the Straits, it was reliably reported last night.

The Arabian American Oil Company had crude oil production of 301,860,885 barrels in Saudi Arabia last year, according to the company's report to the Saudi Arabia Government. This compares with an output of 277,962,605 barrels in 1951.

The Celotex Corporation, manufacturer of building materials, had net earnings of $1,155,195 after all charges and income-tax provisions in the six months ended on April 30, according to an announcement made yesterday by O. S. Mansell, president.

The Department of Health officially opened its annual campaign against ragweed yesterday with a barrage of herbicide spray aimed at points in all five boroughs where the plant that is the chief cause of hay fever habitually grows,
BOSTON, June 10 -- New England has more forested land per acre than any other section of the country, yet it produces only half of its annual consumption of more than 2,000,000,000 board feet.
The response of the maritime industries to Governor Dewey's plan for a bi-state agency to establish far-reaching controls over port business had some of the quality of a muffled explosion.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Eisenhower placed a limitation today on the quantity of shelled filberts to be imported into this country.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Protectionist forces suffered a surprise setback today as the House of Representatives, by action of its Rules Committee, received an opportunity to vote down the proposed enlargement of the Federal Tariff Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Eisenhower today named two new members to the Board of Governors of the American Red Cross and thereby displaced from the organization's governing body, for the first time in more than ten years, the Surgeons General of the Army and Navy.

The varied hues of academic attire mingled with the rich purples and bright reds of episcopal garb yesterday as 1,000 persons received baccallaureate and advanced degrees at the 108th commencement of Fordham University.

Coverage by the Health Barometer Plan of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, will be increased from nineteen cities to forty-five in the fall, it was announced yesterday by Harold S. Barnes, director of the bureau.

The medical school graduate of today may face four to six years of service in the armed forces, Dr. John E. Deitrick, Magee Professor of Medicine. Jefferson Medical College, Philadelphia, told the graduating class of Cornell University Medical College yesterday.
CAIRO, June 10 (AP) -- Prince Abbas Halim, a second cousin of former King Farouk, was among eleven defendants acquitted today in a $5,000,000 arms buying scandal. Two others escaped with fines.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- Congressmen from five Western states and Florida introduced bills today to prevent drastic cutbacks in cotton acreage in their areas.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Lieut. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Eighth Army commander in Korea, was nominated by President Eisenhower today for promotion to the rank of full general.

BOSTON, June 10 -- Central Massachusetts counted ninety-two Known dead today, twenty-four hours after a tornado cut a path of death and destruction across a sixty-mile area of Worcester County. It was feared that the toll might reach at least 125 as rescue workers continued searching through the match wood left of more than 2,500 homes.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Martin P. Durkin, Secretary of Labor, was cited today by DePaul University for "the distinction with which he has served the partnership of labor, management and the public for more than thirty years." The citation also commended the Secretary "for his devotion to the principles of social justice and the dignity of the individual" in the field of labor-management relations.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 11 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 428, for Wednesday:
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Fred M. Vinson, Chief Justice of the United States, said today that reform of administrative procedures of departments and agencies of the Federal Government was imperative.

The Republican-controlled state government is violating its philosophy of local self-government by attempting to take over the functions of the city administration, Carmine G. DeSapio, New York Democratic leader, charged last night before a meeting of the New York University Law Review Alumni Association in Vanderbilt Hall, 40 Washington Square South.
Resourceful these dark days only in finding new ways to lose, the slumping Giants yesterday contrived to drop a third straight decision to the Braves.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board today asked Congress to give the Federal Government "minimum control" over bank holding companies.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, June 11 -- Nearly 7,000 Chinese Communists struck Allied lines at the center of the 155-mile Korean battlefront in sharp, bloody attacks early today that penetrated United Nations positions in five spots, the Eighth Army reported.

FRANKFURT, Germany, June 10 (AP) -- A West German court ruling today appeared to open the way for damage suits against German concerns by thousands of persons the Nazis consigned to slave labor in World War II.

New York University conferred degrees on 7,237 graduates yesterday at its 121st commencement exercises on the sun-baked University Heights campus in the Bronx. At least 15,000 persons were on hand to witness the colorful morning ceremony.

SAN JUAN, P. R., June 10 (UP) -- Leonard D. Long, South Carolina. contractor. and Frederick D. Carpenter. former territorial director of the Federal Housing Administration. pleaded not guilty today to charges of conspiracy to defraud the United States Government.
ST. LOUIS, June 10 (UP) -- The Red Sox moved into third place tonight by sweeping a double-header with the Browns, taking the second game, 3 -- 2, after winning the first, 11 -- 2.

The building with forty-nine apartment and four stores at 2000 Monterey Avenue in the Borough Hall section of the Bronx has been purchased by Walter Berger and Leo A. Bercow, operators, from Dr. Jack M. Vure. The property is assessed at $150,000 and was sold through Mrs. Anne Inselstein, broker.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 10 (AP) -- Mighty Grattan sped down the center of the track to collar Sep Hanover and take a one length victory tonight in the Valley Stream Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

BERLIN, June 10 -- Books written by about a score of American authors, including such prominent political analysts as Vera Micheles Dean, editor of Foreign Policy Association Publications, and Walter Duranty, have been removed from the shelves of all Amerika Haus libraries in Germany.
Please allow me to point out a confusing error in the article on Indonesia's Cabinet crisis in THE TIMES of June 3.
Cardinal Spellman. led 9,000 persons in prayer yesterday for the victims of the tornadoes that struck Michigan, Ohio and Massachusetts earlier this week.

Gloria Balaban, 26-year-old niece of Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, Inc., died on Tuesday night in Lenox Hill Hospital, where she had been undergoing treatment for an overdose of barbiturates. The police said Miss Balaban was admitted to the hospital on Sunday afternoon after having been removed from her apartment at 221 East Seventy-eighth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of the Pennsylvania State College, told the graduating class at the University of Pennsylvania's 197th commencement today that the present world struggle called for persuasion, moral example and cooperation to gain the nation's goals.

As firm friends of the Korean people and of the Government of the Republic of Korea we are obliged to join with other firm friends in appealing to the Koreans to assent to the projected truce. We know that the terms are far from ideal. We know, also, how patriotic Koreans must feel about an armistice that still leaves a foreign army, the Chinese Communists, on Korean soil.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address at Minneapolis yesterday afternoon at the annual convention of the National Junior Chamber of Commerce, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Stock prices yesterday turned firmer after selling in the noon hour had produced some of the lowest prices seen since May, 1952. Rails, steels and selected oils led the list upward, but the gains were not sufficient to keep THE NEW YORK TIMES composite average of fifty stocks from showing another loss.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 135,586 today, an increase of 224 in the week. The Defense Department's weekly summary based on notifications to families through last Friday showed:

Volume was light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges, with only hides and potatoes showing sizable increases over Tuesday's activity. Prices closed generally higher in the inactive futures markets and rubber, wool, cocoa, lead, tin and zinc registered gains.
One-family dwellings dominated the trading in Queens areas in transactions reported yesterday.

The somewhat dangerous extension of military influence in Government and the distortion of our concepts of proper civilian-military relationships that has taken place in the last six years have been well illustrated by the current controversy over the new air power budget.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins told the Senate today sixty-two of the 307 Iron Curtain diplomats in the United States had been known or suspected spies, subversives or Communists before coming here.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 10 -- Yale scored two runs on one hit in the eighth inning to edge Harvard, 8 -- 6, today and earn the right to meet Princeton for the Ivy League title. Fine relief hurling by Bob Davis turned back Harvard uprisings in the late innings of the three-hour twenty-minute game.
Magistrate Morris Ploscowe said last night that organized crime was communism's best ally, and that both must be destroyed if democracy was to survive.

Denying the Republican party had any claim to be the party of good government, Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, charged last night that by the end of the coming fiscal year the Republican party by legislation at Albany would have taken more than $600,000,000 out of the pockets of those least able to pay and put it into the hands of real estate lobbyists and speculators.

BERN, Switzerland, June 10 -- The Swiss Government announced tonight that it had changed an earlier decision and would participate in the five-nation neutral repatriation commission for prisoners of war in Korea, even if the South Korean Government refused to confirm a truce agreement.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Louis S. Rothschild of Kansas City, Mo., was named by President Eisenhower today to be a member of the Federal Maritime Board. Mr. Rothschild is president and treasurer of Rothschild Sons, which operates department stores in Missouri, Oklahoma and Kansas.

GEORGE WASHINGTON wrote George Mason in February, 1779, "I cannot refrain lamenting in the most poignant terms the fatal policy too prevalent in most of the states of employing their ablest men at home in posts of honor or profit."

The right of the city to dismiss John P. Crane, former president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, from his $4,150 post in the Fire Department as of Feb. 8, 1951, was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Benedict D. Dineen. The basis of dismissal was newly disclosed information.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 10 -- Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, inveighed today against what he termed "abuses in the exercise of power" and recklessness of investigators in Congress and Government. There is "no place in our democracy for a grand inquisitor," asserted the former chairman of the National Security Board in a commencement address at Radcliffe College.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., today flatly denied that any part of the function of five du Pont company nominees on the board of General Motors Corporation is to "represent" the du Pont company.

Stocks of the three major oil products increased last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Gasoline supplies were up 167,000 barrels to 152,592,000 barrels at the weekend, compared with 152,435,000 a week earlier and 123,436,000 a year ago.

After the completion of five games, including the third and fourth which had been adjourned, Samuel Reshevsky of New York was leading with a score of 3 -- 2 in his match with Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires for the chess championship of the West, according to a report received yesterday from Argentina.
CLEVELAND, June 10 (AP) -- Mike Garcia yielded only four hits tonight while pitching the Indians to a 2-1 victory over the Senators. The victory was the Tribe's seventh straight.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 10 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer and V. Theodore Low of the home club won low gross honors in the annual mixed foursomes tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Century Country Club today.

BUENOS AIRES, June 10 -- The Joint Congressional Committee named to investigate the activities of three United States press agencies ordered six international telecommunications companies today to make available the original copies of all dispatches filed by the news agencies prior to May 1.

The former Charvoz-Roos plant at 185 Hackensack Street in East Rutherford, N. J., has been purchased by the Becton-Dickinson Company, manufacturer of surgical instruments and supplies, through J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker. The sale was held in the United States District Court in Newark in the matter of Will Weiss, receiver for the C. R. Manufacturing Company in receivership.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee voted unanimously today to permit baseball to restrict radio and television broadcasts of its games without fear of anti-trust prosecution.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A study aimed at improving the methods of conducting investigations by groups of the House of Representatives was initiated today by its Committee on Rules.
The General State Authority of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania sold at public bidding yesterday $20,000,000 of its fourth series bonds at a net interest cost of 3.2072 per cent.

BERLIN, June 10 -- In the Communists' first dramatic gesture in Germany since Stalin's death and the subsequent Moscow peace offensive, East Germany's Politburo presented today a program of sweeping reform in the socialization of that region.

A bi-state agency to administer throughout this port the waterfront reforms proposed by the New York State Crime Commission will be created by the Legislatures of this state and New Jersey before the end of this month. It may take several months, however, before the new agency is staffed and begins imposing the controls, including registration of dock workers.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast this year's wheat crop at 1,132,500,000 bushels today.

NEWARK, June 10 -- Harold John Adonis was advised today by his counsel, John Milton of Jersey City, that neither state nor Federal Government officials would commite themselves on the question of bail in the event that he returned from the Netherlands to face three criminal indictments in New Jersey.

DETROIT, June 10 -- The rest of the American League soon may be muttering, "What's the use?" and forget about stopping the Yankees; who routed the Tigers at Briggs Stadium today, 11 -- 4, for the Bombers' thirteenth straight triumph.

DETROIT, June 10 (AP) -- Kid Gavilan, welterweight champion, firing his pet bolo punch at will, won a unanimous ten-round decision over Italo Scortichini of Milan, Italy, tonight at Olympia Stadium. Gavilan weighed 151 3/4 pounds to 155 for Scortichini in the non-title bout.

Retailers were urged yesterday at the Store Modernization Show in Madison Square Garden to make use of every inch of cubage in their high-rent areas and, in handling materials, to avail themselves of "gravity, the cheapest commodity on earth."
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 4 to 12 points net higher than on Tuesday.
With a gun at his head in the form of a threatened indefinite suspension, Leo Durocher yesterday retracted his widely quoted charges that the National League umpires are "ganging up" on him.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Grain futures were generally lower here today on scattered long liquidation coupled with increased local pressure when the market began to weaken Many traders were disposed to even up for the Government report which was issued after the market closed.
ROME, June 10 -- The Center party coalition headed by Premier Alcide De Gasperi holds a slim and unstable margin of control in both houses of Parliament, final election returns showed today.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 11 -- United States officials charged with negotiating a Korean armistice with the Communists were confident today that President Syngman Rhee of South Korea eventually would withdraw his Government's determined opposition to a truce despite threats to the contrary.

The Amurex Oil Development Company announced yesterday that it has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the offering to class A common stockholders of 250,000 shares of new class A common stock.

Cook books new this season include a volume to be published tomorrow in which the culinary possibilities of chicken are fully explored. It is Mrs. Marian Tracy's "Complete Chicken Cookery" (Bobbs-Merrill, 234 pp., $3).
LONDON, June 10 (Reuters) -- Britain's jet fighters will have a new radar "eye" to train their guns on enemy planes, it was announced here today.

LONDON, June 10 -- Discussions between Australia, New Zealand and Britain on defense collaboration in the Pacific were arranged today at a conference of the Prime Ministers of the three countries in London.

After an ownership of a few days, Phillip H. Zipes, operator, has resold the fifteen-story apartment house for forty-one families on plot 50 by 100 feet at 37-41 West Sixty-seventh Street to the West Sixty-seventh Street Realty Company for cash over mortgages amounting to $200,000.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to authorize a grant of up to 1,000,000 tons of wheat to head off widespread famine in drought-stricken Pakistan.

Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas said yesterday that the United States must go to the world -- and Asia in particular -- with our Bill of Rights and not with bombs and guns if we were to defeat communism.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- It's not the post office pens that are so bad, it's the ink, Craig R. Sheaffer, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, told a subcommittee of the House of Representatives today.

Continuing to hit in solid style, the Dodgers remained a game behind the Milwaukee Braves by handing Rogers Hornsby's Redlegs a 13-3 thumping before 15,688 thoroughly satisfied fans at Ebbets Field last night.
Before we take the final irrevocable step in Korea let us be certain we know what we are doing.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Eisenhower today nominated Tom Lyon of Salt Lake City, Utah, to be Director of the Bureau of Mines of the Department of the Interior.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, introduced today the Administration's housing bill and, significantly, it contained no provision for lowering the down-payment requirement or extending the term of Government insured mortgages.

One may as well be as cheerful as possible about the results of the Italian election and say that things might have turned out much worse. It is a big disappointment that the De Gasperi Center coalition of democratic parties did not get an absolute majority of the votes for the Chamber of Deputies, which would have given it a two-thirds control.

It is appropriate that as an important part of its 300th anniversary celebration New York City this week should be observing "Retail Week," so designated by Mayor Impellitteri by proclamation. The observance not only has concentrated attention on New York's retail business as a vital part of the city's economy but also has served as a testimonial that without its great retail stores New York could not be the metropolitan center it is today.

A 40-year-old, mild-mannered man, described by the United States Secret Service as a dangerous maniac, was trapped yesterday in a home for Hebrew aged in New Rochelle, N. Y., and arrested for writing assassination threats to President Eisenhower.
Sales of two estates and acreage in Greenwich, Conn., were reported by brokers.

BOSTON, June 10 (UP) -- Royal Vale trailed for three-quarters of a mile at Suffolk Downs today, then flashed past the field as though jet-propelled to take the nineteenth running of the $61,650 Massachusetts Handicap before 24,342 fans who had backed him down to a 9-to-10 favorite.

After the running of the colt division of the National Stallion Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday, America's No. 1 horse handicapper was kissed, America's No. 1 jockey was booed and backers of the third choice in the $30,700 Widener chute sprint went happily to the cashiers' windows to collect $12.90 in exchange for each $2 ticket.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Statewide drives aimed at forcing the withdrawal of the Federal Government from local and state activities were planned here today at a meeting of 400 business and political leaders from forty-four states.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- Joseph J. Andrade, third mate aboard the Phoenix, testified today that the 14,000-ton oil tanker was equipped with a hard-to-operate steering mechanism. It always had been difficult to operate, he told a three-member Coast Guard board investigating the cause of the collision between the Phoenix and another tanker, the Pan Massachusetts, in the Delaware River ten miles south of Wilmington, Del., Saturday morning.

ROME, June 10 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi, in a fighting mood, denounced today those Italians who, he said, had strengthened the Communists and Left-Wing Socialists by voting in the national elections for the Monarchist party and other groups with "no future."

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges, with most items displaying even less activity than in Wednesday's quiet trading. Sugar, rubber, potatoes, zinc and copper were mixed; coffee, lead, tin and cocoa, higher; and cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides and wool, lower.

Four young women travelers from Memphis, Tenn., about to embark yesterday for a summer-long vacation in Europe, took a stranger's word on Pier 90, North River, that the Cunard liner Queen Mary would sail at 11:30 A. M. instead of 11 o'clock, the scheduled departure time.

In an apparent move to lessen the chance of Controller Lazarus Joseph's getting the Democratic nomination for Mayor, officers of the Central Trades and Labor Council, A. F. L., and the New York City C. I. O. Council sent a telegram to Mr. Joseph yesterday criticizing his belated "discovery" of $12,000,000 in the city's general
WORCESTER, Mass., June 11 -- The Red Cross established at eighty-three today the number of dead in the tornado that swept through Worcester County two days ago.

Veal supplies are increasing, and prices show a substantial decrease this week-end. The record high to which fresh pork prices rose last Friday resulted in sharp curtailment of purchases by consumers. As a result loin pork cuts are lower in cost. Beef receipts continue heavy with prices generally unchanged, with the exception of liver, which is cheaper, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Federal Public Health Service said today that infantile paralysis cases this year were running about 30 per cent ahead of the corresponding period in 1952, a record year with 57,636 cases. Last week forty-seven states reported 248 new cases, more than double the 119 in the similar week of 1952.

Business is planning record expenditures on new plant and equipment in the second and third quarters of this year, according to the results of a joint survey by the Department of Commerce and the Securities and Exchange Commission. The survey was carried out last month.

The "tape technicians" were disappointed in the stock market yesterday. For one thing the recovery was disappointing from a volume standpoint. Further, while a number of issues gained a fair amount of ground, most did relatively little.
The wallpaper industry is planning a two-pronged effort to increase the sale of its products.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "The Farmer Takes a Wife," a Twentieth Century-Fox musical comedy in Technicolor with Betty Grable, Dale Robertson, Thelma Ritter and John Carroll, is at the Globe.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, June 11 -- The Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation has authorized the renovation of Monticello, the home of Thomas Jefferson, at a cost of $250,000.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, June 11 -- The first step toward introducing into North America a process for making steel that has started a technical revolution of major proportions in European steel industries was taken here yesterday.

Trailing by three runs, the Dodgers ripped into Bud Podbielan for seven ringing hits and six runs in the eighth inning to defeat the Redlegs, 9 -- 6, at Ebbets Field yesterday. This ferocious winning assault capped a seventeen-hit attack by the Brooks, whose booming bats have accounted for seventy hits in their last five games.

DETROIT, June 11 -- This business of winning them all might be monotonous, discouraging and downright distasteful to the opposition, but to the Yankees it's a long and thoroughly enjoyable whirl through the American League. At Briggs Stadium today, homers by Irv Noren, Gene Woodling and Mickey Mantle carried the Bombers to a 6-3 victory over the Tigers and the champions' fourteenth straight triumph.

Worsted and broadcloth mills in France and Italy have discovered an enormous new market -- their home market -- Adolph Schuman, president of Lilli Ann Corporation, San Francisco, largest producer of women's coats and suits west of the Mississippi, said in an interview yesterday.

More attention is being paid to distribution problems because of the likelihood of a buyer's market in the near future, the American Marketing Association was told yesterday in Montreal by Charles W. Smith, a marketing consultant with McKinsey Co., management consultant organization.
OAKMONT, Pa., June 11 -- Ben Hogan, the Texas challenger, dealt mighty Oakmont a staggering blow in the first round of the United States open golf championship today.

LONDON, June 11 -- The stock markets were dull and idle today, with suggestions that the Government may be contemplating an early funding loan adding to the general caution. A little selling sufficed to depress prices in most markets outside the commodity groups, where rubber and tin shares maintained a firm tone.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- Charles S. Thomas, Under-Secretary of the Navy, asserted today that the Navy would abolish segregated drinking fountains, restaurants and rest rooms for civilian workers at Southern Navy Yards if ordered to do so. However, he said that he knew of no such order.

West Berlin, despite its isolation within Russian-dominated East Germany, is capable of maintaining steady exports of a wide variety of goods to the United States, representatives of the city's Western Zone industries emphasized yesterday on arriving here to set up a Berlin Marketing Council.

A syndicate headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and Union Securities Corporation will place on the market today $18,000,000 of first mortgage 4 1/4 per cent bonds of Arkansas Power and Light Company due on June 1, 1983, at 101.36 to yield 4.17 per cent. The syndicate bought the bonds Wednesday at competitive sale at a bid of 100.8099.

It was "common knowledge" at City College that collegians were paid for playing summer basketball at Catskill Mountain resort and Dr. Samuel Winograd, faculty manager of athletics at City College, distributed money received from "pools" to some players, it was testified yesterday at a special session of the trial committee of the Board of Higher Education.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Department store sales in the week ended on June 6 were 6 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

Like all worthy occupations, the book publishing profession has its own set of traditions. One of these, of interest at the moment, is summed up under the heading of Summer Reading. This holds that during the vacation months the book buying public discards its usual taste in literature, exchanging metaphysics, as it were, for nothing more weighty than crime detection.

When youngsters suffer long-term illness, too often their disability becomes a hub around which all family plans must move. Such a situation should not arise and need not do so, Mrs. Minna Field, assistant to the chief, division of social medicine, Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Suggestion systems in private business and Government agencies are paying out more than $6,000,000 annually for employe ideas, A. W. Egner, president of the National Association of Suggestion Systems, said today. He spoke at the association's Chicago Midwest Regional Conference.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The House of Representatives Foreign Affairs Committee recommended today a Mutual Security authorization of $4,998,742,500 after cutting President Eisenhower's request by $476,000,000 and making half of the funds earmarked for military aid to Western Europe conditional upon creation of the projected European Defense Community.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The National Federation of American Shipping presented today what it felt was a gloomy picture of the amount of foreign trade carried in American flag ships.

Three rugged Uruguayans put-putted to the United Nations yesterday to be congratulated by their nation's delegate there on having completed a 12,000-mile, three-month trip by motorcycles from Montevideo to New York.

An open - top, Fifth Avenue double-decker bus, painted an improbable gold and jouncing heavily along on its original solid tires, came out of the recent past last night to help Mayor Impellitteri and other officials re-emphasize that the city is marking its three- hundredth anniversary this year.

GARRISON DAM, N. D., June 11 -- President Eisenhower toured the length of North Dakota today, surveying the great plains, greeting the people who grow the wheat and dedicating the greatest earthen dam in the world to the strengthening of the nation.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 11 (AP) -- Snap Up took command on the far turn and pulled away to a three-length victory in the Lynbrook Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Driven by Howard Camden and owned by J. S. Turner of Nassawadox, Va., Snap Up paced the mile in 2:04 1-5.
Allegheny County, Pa., will open bids on July 9 on a $5,505,000 issue of various purpose bonds, it was announced yesterday. The bonds mature from 1954 to 1983.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Clem Graver, 53 years old, State Representative from the Fifteenth District and Republican Committeeman of the Twenty-first Ward of Chicago's southwest side, was forcibly kidnapped tonight as he emerged from his garage half a block from his home.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 11 (AP) -- William C. Foster, former Deputy Secretary of Defense, was chosen today as the first full-time president of the Manufacturing Chemists Association at its annual meeting.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 5 -- Nearly a hundred men of a dozen nationalities are scattered over Yugoslavia helping this country to build up and modernize its industries, improve its crops and improve the health conditions of its citizens in one of the outstanding examples of work in the United Nations Technical Assistance Program.

WALTHAM, Mass., June 11 -- Louis Kronenberger's new comedy, "The International Set," had its first presentation here tonight as a special event of the Brandeis University Festival of the Creative Arts.

TOKYO, Friday, June 12 -- Staff officers of the United Nations and Communist commands met again today at Panmunjom to put finishing touches to an agreement for an armistice in the Korean war but with prospects for a basic settlement of the issue made dubious by the continued bitter opposition of the South Korean Government.

For concentrated destructive fury tornadoes, such as those that have wrought havoc across the country recently, are unmatched by anything else in the weather man's portfolio. Some facts about tornadoes were provided yesterday at the United States Weather Bureau office at 17 Battery Place.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee, investigating possible Communist infiltration into the wartime Office of Strategic Services, received no cooperation today rom two former members of that agency.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Senate Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs reported a bill late today setting up machinery for development, under Federal auspices, of natural resources of the Outer Continental Shelf, seaward of recently recognized offshore state boundaries.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, charged an attempt at intimidation today as Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, attacked him on the Senate floor for "rather gross abuse" of the free mailing privileges accorded members of Congress.

Little hope was seen yesterday of avoiding a seamen's strike Monday night on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, as deadlocked negotiations were not resumed and no meetings were planned for the balance of the week.

LONDON, June 11 -- Queen Elizabeth II, wearing the colorful uniform of the Grenadier Guards and riding sidesaddle on the police horse Winston, took the salute today at the Trooping the Color ceremony traditionally held on the sovereign's official birthday.

WITH most of the trout waters in what is described as "normal" condition, which means that fly fishing should be interesting as well as productive, the real question involves the salt water prospects, which are varied but not too stable.

ROME, June 11 -- Ratification of the European Defense Community treaty is likely to take a back seat in the rush of urgent business that will have to be dealt with by the new Parliament when it convenes the last week of this month.
CHICAGO, June 11 -- Bearish wheat crop estimates caused sharp declines in this grain early today and there was also an early break in corn, rye and soybeans. Oats remained relatively firm.
The nation's steel mills had the second best production month in the history of the industry in May, when they turned out 9,998,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- India delivered to the State Department late today what officials described as a "preliminary favorable reply" to the invitation to membership on the neutral repatriation commission for Korean prisoners-of-war.

TRENTON, June 11 -- Nelson F. Stamler testified under oath here today that he was sent into Bergen County in October, 1950, to investigate gambling and official corruption in a move to forestall the calling of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, headed by Senator Estes Kefauver.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- State Department policies permitting imports of potash and other agricultural items from Iron Curtain countries have come under new scrutiny in Congress. A fresh study of the matter by the National Security Council also is under way.

Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, told members of the bi-state agency's police force yesterday that they had "never been tainted by graft" and that he had never felt called upon to apologize for them.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The United States Court of Appeals today directed the Federal District Court here to enjoin Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. from arresting Serge M. Rubinstein, Russian-born financier, or revoking his bail pending final determination of deportation proceedings instituted by the Department of Justice.

HONG KONG, June 11 -- From fragmentary reports published in mainland newspapers reaching Hong Kong observers here are convinced that Communist China is experiencing a famine of immense proportions affecting a population exceeding 10,000,000.

MOUNT RUSHMORE, S. D., June 11 -- President Eisenhower reported to the convention of the Young Republican National Federation today that his young Administration already had chalked up ten "quite specific accomplishments,'' which he thought was a good beginning.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, June 12 -- President Syngman Rhee said yesterday that the present truce terms, even under conditions proposed in the recent letter of President Eisenhower, "mean death" to Korea. Once again he threatened that South Korea would fight on alone if the present armistice was agreed upon.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, assured Congress today the Military Establishment of the United States, fighting with the armed forces of its Allies, would be able ultimately to win a war with the Soviet Union.

Shipments of rayon and acetate by United States producers in May amounted to 108,900,000 pounds, an increase of 5 per cent over the April total. For the first five months of this year, total shipments amounted to 510,100,000 pounds, an increase of 21 per cent over the 420,000,000 pounds shipped in the comparable period a year ago, according to a report issued yesterday by the Textile Organon, statistical bulletin of the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

Gross sales of Foremost Dairies, Inc., for the twenty weeks to last May 23 rose 80 per cent to $45,000,000 from the $25,000,000 volume for the corresponding period of 1952, Paul E. Reinhold, chairman and chief executive officer, announced here yesterday.
Cantors of Reform, Conservative and Orthodox Jewish congregations formulated a program last night to raise standards and set up a board on certification and accreditation of cantors.
PARIS, June 11 -- The United States yesterday advised its allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that it is ready to participate in a long-term arms-building program in continental Europe.
Although the report may prove a trifle premature, it seems there is still some life left in our Giants.

The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to exempt the Coney Island amusement area, extending north of the Boardwalk between West Eighth Street and West Twenty-third Street, from restrictive rezoning approved by the City Planning Commission on May 20.
BUENOS AIRES, June 11 -- President Juan D. Peron told Argentine landholders today that they could keep their holdings if they farmed them efficiently.

PITTSBURGH, June 11 (AP) -- Johnny Lindell of the Pirates pitched a four-hitter today, but four walks in the fifth inning -- three of them in a row -- coupled with an out on a fly ball and a hit were good for three runs and a 5-3 victory for the Cardinals.
CHICAGO, June 11 -- The public "may bt well advised to prepare for color television next year," I. J. Kaar, manager of engineering of the General Electric Company's electronic's division, said today.

MIDTOWN policemen and volunteer searchers seem to have had no luck in their hunt for the town's most aristocratic dog, International Champion Pulaski's Masterpiece, C. D., C. D. X., U. D.,* stolen a week ago last Friday from Poodles, Inc., at 51 West Fifty-second Street.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 10 -- Zafer, the organ of the ruling Democratic party, demanded today that Turkey confiscate Syrian property in this country and take other retaliatory measures against Syria for allegedly condoning smuggling across the Turkish-Syrian frontier and expropriating the property of Turkish landowners in Syria.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- James F. Masterson, attorney, today sought to block the Securities and Exchange Commission from questioning him again in connection with the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation stock deal that collapsed in February, 1948.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 11 -- The most ancient of all intercollegiate sporting events in the United States, the Harvard-Yale rowing regatta, takes place here tomorrow on the Thames River. It will be the eighty-eighth meeting in a rivalry that began on Lake Winnepesaukee, N. H., in 1852 and marks the seventy-fifth anniversary of the first race in the series to be held at New London.

We are now in the fifth day of what President Eisenhower has proclaimed as "Aid to Korea Week." One purpose of this nation-wide campaign is to raise the almost pitifully small sum of five million dollars for emergency aid to the sick and wounded and homeless and hungry people of Korea.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, announced yesterday that 41,000 reply postcards had been sent to approximately 10 per cent of the enrolled Democrats in Manhattan, asking them whether or not they want Mayor Impellitteri to be the Democratic candidate for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- The Senate completed Congressional action on a $3,444,145,000 money bill for the Treasury and Post Office Departments today, and a House of Representatives committee slashed $382,000,000 more from President Eisenhower's budget.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Senate, though it has been called the greatest of deliberative bodies and often merits the term, nevertheless has frequently taken actions that were far from deliberative. It has behaved irresponsibly, yielded to selfish group pressures, legislated without adequate knowledge of the subject and permitted important bills to be passed by a handful of its membership while the majority was elsewhere engaged.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The United Auto Workers, C. I. O., and the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L., announced today they had renewed a 4-year-old no-raiding agreement and broadened it to include cooperation in collective bargaining and strikes. They also agreed to forego name-calling in any competitive organizing campaigns.

Manufacturers of everything from freight handling machinery to shelving for handkerchiefs should establish a permanent center at which retailers could inspect everything necessary to modernize their stores. This opinion was expressed yesterday at a clinic in the Store Modernization Show at Madison Square Garden by Harry Yedor, a St. Louis fixture manufacturer.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 11 -- Defiance of the color bar which excludes Negroes from public places and requires them to be served at separate counters in Government offices has spread from the Union of South Africa to the British-held territory of Northern Rhodesia where Negroes have started entering white bars and asking to be served.

In an address recorded on film, President Eisenhower lauded Long Island University yesterday for its nondiscriminatory admissions policy and the steps it had taken "to advance the democratic principles of the world."
David W. Jasper Jr. has been appointed head of the legal department of Carrier Corporation, makers of air conditioning, refrigeration and industrial heating equipment.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today made some changes in a decision it handed down last January concerning the division of freight revenues between the railroads in the eastern part of the country and those in the South and in the Southwest.

NEW DELHI, India, June 11 -- The Central Government has approved drastic land reforms that shortly will be introduced in Patiala and East Punjab States Union, commonly called "Pepsu," to counteract growing Communist influence in that strategic region on the Indian-Pakistani border.

A garden-ful of blossoms are displayed on a new collection of silk-screened drapery materials at the Scalamandre Museum, 20 West Fifty-fifth Street. Arranged by John Kent Tilton, director of the museum, the display will continue through Aug. 31.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A group of private industrialists told the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy today that it was prepared to construct a plant for the production of atomic power without substantial Federal subsidy or guarantee. Changes in the basic Atomic Energy Act would be required.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California, Acting Senate Majority Leader, voiced doubt today that Congress would act on President Eisenhower's request for a six-month extension of the excess profits tax.

A provocative and articulate voice on current affairs has been raised on television by Gerald W. Johnson, the author, historian and essayist, who may be heard at 8:45 P. M. Sundays over the A. B. C. network (Channel 7). Viewers are almost certain not to be of one mind on what he says, but they will not find him dull or unoriginal.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- Theron Lamar Caudle told House of Representative investigators today Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, had arranged with Peyton Ford, former Deputy Attorney General, to settle an $118,000 tax fraud case against a Minneapolis physician for $35,000.

PITTSBURGH, Friday, June 12 -- Top officials of the United States Steel Corporation and the United Steel Workers of America, C. I. O., hammered out a pattern-setting wage agreement early today that was expected to provide a package wage increase of slightly more than 9 cents an hour for 550,000 workers in the basic steel industry.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 11 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Glen E. Edgerton, chairman of the board of the Export-Import Bank, said today that the Government foreign loan agency expects to make $55,000,000 this year.

The chant of "up oh-five" will be missing from Wall Street's bond houses today because the traders whose price-cutting offers are expressed cryptically in abbreviated yield decimals will be wielding golf clubs and tennis racquets instead of telephones.
The Trois Hirondelles, the French Couture En Gros or wholesale couture, made its first effort yesterday to start a French wholesale ready-to-wear market in America.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, today announced the appointment of eight new members to the eleven-member Agricultural Policy Committee set up by law to advise him on research and marketing programs.

In his "Treatise on Sweet Dishes," Antonin Careme discussed "Bavarian cheese." Since the start of the nineteenth century when the famous Parisian chef wrote his work, the airy, rich, molded dessert, which takes to many variations, has come to be called Bavarian in French (Bavarois) and Bavarian cream in English.

VIENNA, June 11 -- The flag of the Soviet Union and pictures of its late Premier Stalin and of his Czechoslovak disciple, the late President Klement Gottwald, were trampled underfoot by Pilsen armament workers, infuriated over recent Czechoslovak currency reform, according to the Pilsen newspaper, Pravda.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., June 11 -- A union educator told management, labor and educators here today that action in removing discrimination in industry not only spoke louder than words but was much easier to understand.

A story in yesterday's TIMES by our correspondent in Berlin, Walter Sullivan, reported in some detail on the book-purge that has been going on in the American libraries of information in West Germany. Similar purges are taking place in American libraries throughout the world.

After years of discussion, the Board of Estimate approved yesterday by a 10 to 6 vote the acquisition of land adjacent to the Manhattan plaza of the Brooklyn Bridge to permit widening of the bridge approach. The board's move sealed the doom of the old Pulitzer Building at 63 Park Row.

CHICAGO, June 11 (UP) -- Gus Zernial drove in four runs with two homers today and Cass Michaels knocked in another tally with his 1,000th major league hit, but it took Eddie Robinson's ninth-inning four-bagger to give the Athletics a 6-5 triumph over the White Sox before 3,916.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today to his agency that it make permanent the temporary authority under which Seatrain Lines, Inc., is now serving the port of New York and Savannah, Ga.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization has been transformed from a temporary into a permanent Government agency, under the terms of a reorganization plan, proposed by President Eisenhower, which became effective at midnight tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended June 6, 1953, totaled 775,489 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Dr. Albert Einstein, in a letter made public yesterday, said that every intellectual called before a Congressional investigating committee should refuse to testify, and "must be prepared for jail and economic ruin, in short, for the sacrifice of his personal welfare in the interest of the cultural welfare of his country."
