WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 11 -- James D. Hopkins of Armonk, chairman of the Westchester Board of Supervisors, was endorsed unanimously for County Executive at a meeting this afternoon of the executive committee of the Republican county organization.

I read the generous letter of C. T. Krouse in regard to my fears as to the further injection of the State of New York into the waterfront situation of the City of New York. The issue between Mr. Krouse and myself is clear. I differ keenly on his position that "our present concern over the waterfront situation should be directed to its hopeful correction rather than to the means proposed for such correction."

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, June 12 -- Chinese Communist troops renewed attacks early today in the Chorwon sector of the west-central front, and United States troops fought them off for the second straight day.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jun 11 -- The Turkish Government was consulting United States diplomats and representatives of other North Atlantic alliance members here tonight preparatory to drafting an answer to the Soviet note that renounced Moscow's claims to Kars and Ardahan and proposed reopening the question of the regulation of the Turkish Straits.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- New Soviet overtures to key European countries are being fitted here into a clear picture of a stepped-up Communist campaign to divide the West and isolate the United States from its allies.

The United States Court of Appeals unanimously upheld yesterday Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman's recent decision denying Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, condemned atom spies, a new trial. The Appeals Court also refused to grant a stay of execution.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Air Force today issued a recall order for the thirty-seven C-54 transport planes it had leased to commercial airlines.

The prospective transit operating deficit, which the New York City Transit Authority must overcome by fare increases and economies in the next twelve months, will be substantially higher than the $47,000,000 estimate made by city officials for continued operation of city-owned lines by the Board of Transportation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP) -- The South Korean Ambassador to the United States said today that his country had been threatened by United Nations officials with an embargo on military supplies and food unless Korea agreed to the proposed truce terms.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore won the Women's Eastern Amateur golf championship today by beating Pat O'Sullivan on the nineteenth hole of a play-off match.
RANGOON, Burma, June 10 -- An atmosphere of good feeling persists in Burmese-United States relations despite recent Burma Government action terminating the United States economic aid program here.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., June 11 -- A $4,500,000 old folks home here that has all the appearances of a luxurious, ultramodern residential hotel was dedicated this afternoon at ceremonies attended by 200 welfare leaders and public officials.

Every farmer in the Middle West can see a tornado while it is still far away. The air is hot. Barns and chicken coops are ominously silent. Far off above the horizon is a telltale black cloud. From its base a funnel projects downward. At the sight the family and the hands rush for the cellar to huddle among the vegetables and fruit.

A plea not to ban home-furnishing ideas merely because they are different, experimental or imported, keynoted a luncheon meeting of the Home Fashions League at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday. The occasion was the presentation of the "Trail Blazer Awards" given annually by the organization in recognition of genuine departures in the design and styling of contemporary home furnishings.

PARIS, June 11 -- The news that the Soviet Union has advised Turkey that it formally abandons any territorial claims upon the eastern provinces of that country indicates that Moscow is pressing its "peace offensive" in a new direction, namely the Balkans.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 10 -- Kenya, struggling with her chronic deficit and importing twice what she exports, is making another attempt to link up with Britain's more successful African colonies in an effort to save her tottering economic structure.
TOKYO, Friday, June 12 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,643, for the twenty-four-hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

The annual report issued yesterday by Inwood House, a 123-year-old agency that takes care of unmarried mothers and their babies, stressed the importance of the agency's role in helping to combat the black market in baby adoptions.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- During the week ended June 10, member bank reserves increased $439,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Following are the texts of two speeches by President Eisenhower yesterday as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The first was delivered at the dedication ceremonies of Garrison Dam in North Dakota. The second was an address to the National Young Republican Convention at Mount Rushmore, S. D.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Following are the thirty-two questions on the military budget that Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, submitted to Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, and Mr. Wilson's replies:

A substitute for the shape-up system of waterfront hiring, which the New York and New Jersey Legislatures plan to outlaw this month, will be sought by this port's shipping companies and the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., at conferences starting Monday, it was learned yesterday.

Delegates to the convention of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers, A. F. L., at the Commodore Hotel resolved yesterday not to work on non-unon hat bodies of those imported from Soviet satellite countries.

Dr. Joseph B. Cavallaro, who since May 18 has been chairman of the Board of Higher Education, declared last night that too many college students were wasting time and money because they had no vocational objectives.
SEOUL, June 11 -- The bitter dispute between the Republic of Korea Government and the Eighth Army over broadcast privileges, which began two days ago, seemed to be settled today.

The city's first test of air raid sirens in four months left most local inhabitants -- who knew what the noise was all about -- undisturbed yesterday but gave a few anxious moments to several hundred persons who somehow did not know or did not remember that a test was in progress.
OMAHA, June 11 (AP) -- Lafayette opened the National Collegiate baseball tournament today with a 6-2 victory over Colorado State as pitchers Ron Owen and Roger Gordon held the Bears to four hits.

Madison Square Garden will be the scene of its first championship fight in almost two years when Jimmy Carter, 29-year-old world lightweight titleholder from South Ozone Park, Queens, squares off tonight with George Araujo, 22-year-old dance master from Providence, R. I.

Samuel Shellabarger, in his many years of writing, has produced three novels about the Renaissance, a biography of a Renaissance personage, "The Chevalier Bayard," and a biography of the eighteenth century essayist and epigrammist, "Lord Chesterfield."
BONN, June 11 -- The Soviet Government's sharp reversal of tactics in East Germany has spread confusion and fear in the ranks of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government coalition.

ALTHOUGH I haven't kept an accurate count, it seems to me that almost every year we read of several small boat voyages across the Atlantic. Sometimes they are made by as many as a dozen people, sometimes single-handed. Heroic or foolhardy, whichever they are, they are so frequent that they don't even stir up much fuss in the newspapers.

CLEVELAND, June 11 (AP) -- The Senators' Walt Masterson held the second-place Indians to three singles today as his team broke the Tribe's winning streak at seven games. Ed Fitzgerald's bases-loaded single in the seventh provided the margin in the 2-1 victory.

Madison Square Garden will be the scene of its first championship fight in almost two years when Jimmy Carter, 29-year-old world lightweight titleholder from South Ozone Park, Queens, squares off tonight with George Araujo, 22-year-old dance master from Providence, R. I.
BONN, June 11 -- The Soviet Government's sharp reversal of tactics in East Germany has spread confusion and fear in the ranks of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government coalition.

ALTHOUGH I haven't kept an accurate count, it seems to me that almost every year we read of several small boat voyages across the Atlantic. Sometimes they are made by as many as a dozen people, sometimes single-handed. Heroic or foolhardy, whichever they are, they are so frequent that they don't even stir up much fuss in the newspapers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 -- Ideas for motion pictures often originate not only in strange ways, but sometimes are passed along to producers by persons occupying high positions. President Eisenhower and Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce, it was confirmed today, suggested two months ago to Darryl F. Zanuck that he might find the substance for a real-life dramatic film adventure in the files of the Foreign Service of the State Department.
Joseph W. Dixon has been elected chairman of the executive committee of the American Securities Corporation.

BOSTON, June 11 (UP) -- Tony DeSpirito, the 1952 jockey champion, put on a magnificent riding exhibition today at Suffolk Downs by riding five straight winners, including Noch Eins in the featured Bostonian Purse.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 11 -Mrs. Henry Babcock of Piping Rock and Mrs. Marshall MacLeod. Huntington Country Club, scored 66, 70 -- 136 to win the two-day thirty-six-hole tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Deepdale Club today.

The combination of Greentree and Atkinson was a "lock" at Belmont Park yesterday. Trainer John Gaver sent two fillies and a colt into competition and each one, under the flawless guidance of Master Teddy, scored easily.

Tide, the sales and advertising magazine, has been bought by the Billboard Publishing Company, publishers of Billboard and Vend, from Magazines of Industry, Inc., it was announced yesterday. It was not a stock transaction, but Tide henceforth will be a division of the Billboard company, Roger S. Littleford Jr. and William D. Littleford, co-publishers of the Billboard, said.
A new project to provide psychiatric guidance and supervised group living for children awaiting placement in foster homes has been started by the city, it was announced yesterday.

Two little girls on their first annual boat ride and outing as guests of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled and two women who have attended nearly all of the outings were among the 1,500 persons who enjoyed the twenty-fourth annual trip up the Hudson yesterday on the excursion steamer Alexander Hamilton.

PARIS, June 11 -- After the defeat of Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, through opposition of the Radicals, President Vincent Auriol offered tonight to the Radical leader, Andre Marie, the chance to form a Cabinet. In view of the failure of the three preceding candidates, M. Marie caused no surprise in asking until Friday before giving his reply.

Determined to give film fans a sample of her versatility on the stage, too, Sally Forrest of the screen aims to oblige in "Three Stories High." In Winifred Wolfe's panoramic "love story," dealing with the occupants of a single room in a brownstone boarding house, Miss Forrest will delineate not just one role, but three.

As thousands of persons employed in the financial district watched, the lower Manhattan waterfront was "buzzed" by seven helicopters just after noon yesterday when the city's Department of Marine and Aviation dedicated New York's Heliport No. 2 on Pier A in the Hudson River near the Battery.

RYE, N. Y., June 11 -- A wedge pitched from thirty yards off the green for a birdie 3 gave Mrs. Donald O'Brien of Winged Foot and Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of Westchester the low gross award in the women's Westchester and Fairfield best ball two-day tournament.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Independent Bankers Association of America urged today that Congress restrict expansion of bank holding companies.
MELBOURNE, Australia, June 11 -- Melbourne's "master plan" for the 1956 Olympic Games was approved at a conference held here today.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, testified today in Federal District Court that men who gain high place in big corporations usually are essentially honest. They do not take advantage of their positions to exert improper influence on other companies, he said while under cross-examination in a three-hour appearance as a defense witness in the du Pont antitrust trial before Judge Walter J. LaBuy.

The Trico Products Corporation, manufacturer of automotive accessories, yesterday reported net income for 1952 of $2,522,347, compared with $3,181,007 a year before. Common share earnings were equal to $3.74 a share, against $4.71 a year ago.

Borrowing for tax purposes was a major influence in the $65,000,000 increase in loans to business by New York banks during the week ended on Wednesday. The advance was the first in nine weeks, and cut the decline in such borrowings since the first of the year to $287,000,000 against a reduction of $347,000,000 in the similar period a year ago.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 -- Dr. James B. Conant, United States High commissioner for Germany, in his farewell commencement address as president of Harvard University today, expressed his personal conviction that the European Defense Community would become a reality within a few months.

The first general increases in steel base prices since last summer appeared virtually certain to follow yesterday's agreements between the steel companies and the United Steel Workers for a wage advance of 8 1/2 cents an hour.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The text of a note delivered yesterday to the Soviet Government by the United States Ambassador in Moscow follows:...

FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT built the setting for J. Malcolm Morris' "The Wise Bamboo.''* All it needs now is some fine tunes and a libretto by Rodgers and Hammerstein to go on the musical comedy stage. The scene is Mr. Wright's architectural masterpiece, the Imperial Hotel in Tokyo; the time is the fabulous first half decade of the American occupation.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Eisenhower Administration emphasized today that a truce in Korea would have no effect on the President's tax program.
VIENNA, June 12 -- The new move by the Western occupation powers to prod the Soviet Union on an Austrian treaty was greeted tonight by Austrian Chancellor Julius Raab with high hopes.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 12 -- August 10 has been set by Prime Minister Louis S. St. Laurent as the date on which a new Canadian Parliament will be elected. This date, the Prime Minister explained at a press conference this evening was the only suitable time before November.

Reflecting a rise in net sales, the Ryan Aeronautical Company in the six months ended with April increased its net income to $792,833 from $347,675 in the corresponding period of the preceding year, the report disclosed yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, June 12 -- The most crucial labor-management negotiations since President Eisenhower's inauguration ended here today with the peaceful signing of a wage agreement between the giant United States Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O.

A concentrated attack and five innings of shut-out relief pitching by Jim Hughes enabled the Dodgers to score a 7-4 triumph over the Cubs before 17,764 at Ebbets Field last night. The victory lifted the Brooks back into first place in the National League, displacing the Braves.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 12 -- The bane of aircraft engines operating in the Arctic has been reduced from hours to minutes, and even seconds, through the development of two new devices that were described here today at the closing session of the annual mid-summer meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

Three fans were arrested at Ebbets Field after interrupting the game between the Dodgers and the Cubs last night. Each was held in $500 bail on disorderly conduct charges when arraigned in Night Court.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- (AP) -- Prentiss M. Brown, chairman of the Detroit Edison Company, says an "erroneous" position taken by the Federal Power Commission is holding up the proposed pooling of Michigan and Canadian power. Mr. Brown, former Democratic Senator from Michigan, urged the Senate Commerce Committee yesterday to pass a bill that would knock down the F. P. C. contention.

The Government's waterfront investigation got under way yesterday cloaked in "protective" secrecy. A special Federal grand jury impaneled Tuesday to look into waterfront crimes heard its first witnesses.

Mexico, which not very long ago was an importer of sulphur, has become an exporter of the essential yellow mineral. More than that, within the next two years it is expected to be second only to the United States as a major supplier.

PARIS, June 12 -- President Eisenhower's Western speeches in the last two days have been read by political experts here as an assertion of executive leadership and as an effort to insure a majority of his own party in Congress in support of that leadership.

Brilliantly colored kites overhead, a paper fish floating in mid-air, straw mats underfoot and examples of all the crafts of Japan set on shelves combine to create the atmosphere of a local folk festival at the Kogei Shop, 23 East Sixty-seventh Street.

MEXICO CITY, June 12 -- The Federal District Government today banned hostesses from the capital's night clubs and rejected an outraged howl from the night club owners union that the action threatened the industry with ruin and the country with all sorts of evil consequences.

The number of steamship companies facing a seamen's strike Monday night was increased yesterday to almost 100 as the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., served a deadline notice on forty-five unaffiliated lines. The union negotiates with more than fifty other dry cargo, tanker and collier companies, all of whom are members of some industrial organization.
An appeal for $5,000,000 in aid to Korean civilians was made yesterday at a rally arranged by the American-Korean Foundation in Rockefeller Plaza.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -Prediction that the equal rights amendment pending for more than thirty years would win in the Senate this session and in the House next fall was made today by speakers at the opening session of the national convention of the National Women's Party.

Jimmy Carter had little trouble keeping his lightweight championship of the world against the challenge of George Araujo of Providence at Madison Square Garden last night. While a gathering of 7,132 looked on the Bronx battler knocked out his foe in 2 minutes 16 seconds of the thirteenth round of the scheduled fifteen-round clash.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 12 -- Elia Kazan and Budd Schulberg have a pair of new sponsors in Sam Spiegel, the independent producer, and United Artists, for the film drama they propose doing this summer about the strike-ridden New York and New Jersey waterfronts.
KINGSTON, Tenn., June 12 (UP) -- Two small boys, distant cousins of President Eisenhower, celebrated Christmas in June today because they had "helped" a Republican get elected here last year.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The steel manufacturing cities of Pittsburgh, Youngstown, Ohio, and Wheeling, W. Va., need the St. Lawrence Seaway, Congress was told today.
CARLISLE, Pa., June 12 (AP) -- Church-related colleges must solve their financial problems or give an inferior eductaion, a college president warned today.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 12 (AP) -- Walter McKlyo, owned by Al Linehan Jr. of Adrian, Mich., put on a stretch drive to win the Roslyn Pace by a neck tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

The Skiatron Electronics and Television Corporation obtained yesterday feature films from two major producing companies for use in its current demonstration at the Belmont-Plaza Hotel of Subscriber-vision, a form of "box- office" television.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 12 -- The Harvard crew that had put Navy's world champions to their most rigorous tests of the year gave a superb display of effortless oarsmanship today to close its season in triumph over Yale on the Thames River.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 12 -- The combined leadership of the Authors League of America and the Screen Writer Guild, both independent unions, admitted tonight defeat in a Goliath and David contest with the newly formed Television Writers of America for jurisdiction of writers employed in live network television shows.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- A formula by which United States and other stockholders will be compensated for their holdings in the tin mines nationalized by the Bolivian Government has been worked out with the Patino Tin Mining Corporation there, it was announced today.

ST. LOUIS, June 12 (AP) -- Eddie Robinson broke a 3-3 tie with his sixth homer of the season in the fifth inning as Mario Fricano hurled the Athletics to 5-3 triumph over the Browns tonight. It was St. Louis' eleventh straight loss.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The United States, Britain and France, again chiding the Soviet Union for its obstruction of a state treaty with Austria, have called for an "exact text" of a pact the Soviet Government would be willing to sign.

NEW DELHI, India, June 12 -India has only "provisionally" agreed to serve on the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission to supervise the exchange of Korean prisoners of war, authoritative sources said today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 12 -- Four hundred million Moslems began the celebration tonight of Idul-Fitr, the greatest holiday of their year. Its arrival was signaled at 9:30 P. M. when a new crescent-shaped moon was seen briefly and marked the end of Ramzan (or Ramadan), a period of severe fasting, prayer and almsgiving that began with the new moon that appeared May 15.

New York newspapers during the first five months of this year carried 65,075,217 lines of advertising for a gain of 3.83 per cent over the 1952 figure, according to a compilation of Media Records figures. Nevertheless, the following losses were shown: classified, 6.24 per cent; financial, 3.95 per cent; and department stores, 0.48 per cent. Automotive advertising rose 34.62 per cent; retail, 5.03 per cent; and general 4.27 per cent.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 12 -- A California date-grower may have touched off a new gastronomical fight today that could become as well-known as the battle of the Maine potato vs. the Idaho spud. Theodore Carlson, Minnesotan by birth and Californian by adoption, told United Nations correspondents today that when it came to dates, the Saudi Arabians had our own West Coast growers beates as far as the tastiness of the fruit was concerned.
LONG RIDGE, Conn., June 12 -- The determined beaver of Long Ridge has lost its five-week battle to dam up the lake on a private estate here.

SEOUL, Korea, June 12 -- Maj. Gen. Choi Duk Shin, who had served as the South Korean representative on the United Nations truce delegation, charged today that the Chinese Communists sought an armistice in order to stock up on food to sustain an offensive southward.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, today blamed Secretary of State John Foster Dulles for the decision of the House Foreign Affairs Committee to withhold $1,000,000,000 in European aid funds until the European army pact was ratified.

President Eisenhower has just issued what is described as a "conditional proclamation" setting new import quotas on certain oils. The proclamation will go into effect when and if Congress heeds the Administration's plea to discard Section 104 of the Defense Production Act (sometimes referred to as "the cheese amendment").

MOSCOW, Saturday, June 13 -- It was announced officially this morning that L. G. Melnikov had been relieved as Secretary of the Ukraine Communist party for "profound mistakes in the selection of personnel and the carrying out of national policy."

The Eye Bank for Sight Restoration, which has its offices at 210 East Sixty-fourth Street in this city, is an institution that ought to be better known than it is. Eight years ago, when surgeons demonstrated that it is possible to substitute a healthy cornea for one that is diseased, the Eye Bank sprang into being.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Arthur E. Summerfield, the Postmaster General, called today for a "full report" on charges that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, had abused his free-mailing privilege last year.

JERSEY CITY, June 12 -- Municipal officials of Weehawken, N. J., were enjoined today from interfering with construction by the Port of New York Authority of a third tube for the Lincoln Tunnel pending arguments in Superior Court on June 23.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 12 -- Moakley House, the new Cornell University recreation center, was formally dedicated today as a feature of the class reunions. The building and an additional nine holes to the university golf course were the gifts of more than 600 Cornellians and others, who contributed $270,000.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Eisenhower Administration's bill to give to Pakistan 1,000,000 tons, or 37,300,000 bushels of United States Government-owned wheat, was approved unanimously today by the Senate Agriculture Committee. It may be passed by the Senate itself before next week is out.

NONGKAI, Thailand, June 12 -Photographs of Ho Chi Minh and the Vietminh flag with its yellow star have disappeared from the homes and the shops of the Vietnamese who are living in this Thai bordertown as an energetic, hardworking, politically suspect minority group.

ATHENS, June 12 -- The military staff delegations of Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia, which for the last nine days have been discussing ways and means of offering combined integrated resistance to any possible Soviet attack, issued a joint communique today saying that the talks just ended had been carried out in an atmosphere of great cordiality.

The five-story apartment house on a plot about 25 by 100 feet at 537 East Eighty-seventh Street has been purchased by Rita Berger from John and Edward J. Ganter. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Interest in the stock market lagged yesterday and the tape showed it. It was the narrowest session since October and the slowest since August. Volume fell to 920,000 shares. In fact, in one hour -- between 2 P. M. and 3 P. M. -- only 100,000 shares changed hands.

CLEVELAND, June 12 (AP) -- Fine sailing weather and higher fleet capacity were credited today for record-breaking bulk shipments on the Great Lakes in May. The Lake fleets, strengthened by the addition of fourteen new vessels in the past year, hauled 23.050.676 net tons of iron ore, coal and grain during the month.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission asked today for the views of interested persons by July 31 on the need for an inquiry into the practices of public loaders at New York Harbor piers and the responsibilities of the shipping companies to control the loading of freight.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- Theron Lamar Caudle testified today that his superiors at the Justice Department had taken over a tax case in which Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, had been interested and had failed to get a "fair settlement'' for the Government.

Two hundred and fifty secretaries to Senators and Representatives in Washington, forming a little congress of their own, arrived in New York yesterday for three days of sight-seeing. The Congressional Secretaries Club, as the group is called, toured the United Nations Buildings. Officers of the club were greeted by Mayor Impellitteri in his office at City Hall.

Joseph B. Cavallaro, recently elected chairman of the Board of Higher Education who stirred up considerable controversy when he advocated an investigation of communism in the municipal colleges, reiterated his stand yesterday and declared that no member of the Communist party in a teaching post could be restrained from poisoning the minds of students.

PITTSBURGH, June 12 (AP) -- The Braves dropped into second place, a half game behind the Dodgers, as they broke even in a twin bill with the Pirates tonight. Milwaukee lost the first game, 4 -- 2, but roared back to take the second, 11 -- 2, scoring 10 runs in the first inning.

ON CENTRAL FRONT, Korea, Saturday, June 13 (UP) -- A Chinese Communist officer and two enlisted men, who said they had hidden out behind United Nations lines for two years, surrendered last night because, so they said, they believed the war was over.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 12 -- A report on synthetics prepared by the United Nations Secretariat, released today, shows that when a new synthetic product enters the market, there is no "uniform pattern" of its impact on an established natural product and the competitive effect varies from industry to industry.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Under a ruling today by Controller General Lindsay C. Warren, the Government must pay the former Federal Security Administrator, Oscar R. Ewing, for expenses on his Far Eastern tour of last mid-November through mid-January.

Dr. Albert Einstein's advice to intellectuals to refuse to testify before Congressional committees was described last night by Louis Fischer, the author, as "the sort of courage that is rare nowadays."

Nine aspirants for a one-man show at the A. C. A. Gallery -- all of whom received honorable mentions in last year's competition -- are represented there by three examples each of their work. They were picked from a group of 119 exhibitors out of several hundred who submitted work to the fourteenth annual competition.
MOSCOW, June 12 -- Perle Mesta, former United States Minister to Luxembourg, arrived in Moscow today.

TORONTO, June 12 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's biggest trade show -- the Canadian International Trade Fair -- closed its doors today after a two-week run. Officials said it was "the most successful yet."

CHICAGO, June 12 -- John L. McCaffrey, president of the International Harvester Company, accused a local of the United Automobile Workers today of inviting company employes "to spoil work and deliberately make bad products."

LONDON, June 12 -- Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh rode to the City today to feast on barons of beef at the old Guildhall with the Worshipful Livery Companies of Master Merchants and Craftsmen who have controlled the commerce of the capital since the Middle Ages.
PARIS, June 12 -- Maurice Cardinal Feltin, Archbishop of Paris, added his voice today to the appeals against the approaching execution of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg for espionage.

CUSTER STATE PARK, S. D., June 12 -- This was an unlucky day for the bigger brook trout hereabouts because President Eisenhower was on the loose in French Creek Canyon with a fly rod. The little fish were safe, though.

Two five-story apartment buildings occupying a blockfront between Valentine and Briggs Avenues in the Bronx have been sold by Cortland Associates to the Valbrigg Company, represented by Howard Rikoon, attorney.

In your excellent article of June 3 covering the reaction of the Sultan of Morocco against the French-sponsored petition signed by the Pashas and Kaids, asking the deposition of Mohammed V, you mentioned that El-Glaoui, the Pasha (Administrator) of Marrakesh is the leader of the Berbers.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., June 12 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of the Century Country Club and Mrs. Fred E. Wright, the home-club champion, tied at 75 for low-gross honors in the season's first monthly tournaments of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association at the Leewood Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The telephone company has frustrated those economy-minded patrons who discovered that a cardboard washer, followed by a real nickel, would get them a 10-cent call, A fraud-prevention device patented this week by Richard K. Thompson Jr. of Springfield, N. J., for the Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., weighs the washer and finds it wanting.

BOSTON, June 12 -- Winthrop w. Aldrich, United States Ambassador to Britain, called today in a speech at Harvard for immediate support of President Eisenhower's projected program of a "healthy two-way trade" with other nations as vital to the political and security interests of the United States in the free world.

Novelists, writers of westerns comic strip artists and film and radio script writers have long had an authorative source for their reconstructions of the badmen and outlaws on the American scene and of the sheriffs who pursued them.

BIGWIN INN, Ont., June 12 (AP) -- The Canadian pulp and paper industry, which accounts for about $1 of every $7 earned by Canadians, faces vigorous competition in world markets, the president of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association said today.
KANSAS CITY, June 12 (AP) -Reached by The Associated Press at his ranch near Taos, Mr. Vincent said today:

Funds to be received in Methodist churches throughout the country tomorrow will be used for loans and scholarships for young people of the denomination who desire to attend colleges and universities. The project, which is administered by the Methodist Board of Education, helped 6,000 students last year.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today tentatively granted the application of the Press-Union Publishing Company for a radio station in Atlantic City, N. J., to operate on 1,490 kilocycles, 250 watts, unlimited time.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., June 12 -- Although her putter failed on three occasions, Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks had no difficulty taking the low-gross prize of the Women's Cross County Golf Association one-day tournament with a 33, 38 -- 71 at the Huntington Country Club today.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 13 -- Staff officers of both sides continued their efforts today to hammer out details of the agreement for an armistice in Korea for signature perhaps next week, but no indications came that the South Korean Government would yield in its rejection of any truce that left the peninsula divided.

Special agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday rounded up two men who were charged with participating in the theft of a four-ton trailer containing $100,000 worth of merchandise from a West Side street Thursday night.

President Eisenhower will dedicate Sagamore Hill, Theodore Roosevelt's Home at Oyster Bay, L. I., as a national shrine tomorrow afternoon. The President is scheduled to speak at 5 o'clock, weather permitting, from the front porch of the nineteenth century mansion, from which the former President once made notable addresses.

The American Jewish Tercentenary Committee announced yesterday the formation of a Committee on Religious and Educational Participation for next year's observance of the 300th anniversary of Jewish settlement in the United States.
Squawking fowl and roaring trucks in mid-Manhattan have created a problem that adds to traffic confusion and accident hazards, the Thirty-Fourth Street-Midtown Association said yesterday.

ROME, June 12 -- The declining political influence of the United States in Europe was a factor in the Italian election. There is no simple explanation of the result, but among the contradictory motives that determined the vote is the changing European attitude toward America.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- The investigation into the kidnapping of State Representative Clem Graver, Chicago Republican, who was abducted from his garage last night, was without tangible clues tonight but the police repeatedly ran across information pointing toward a powerful crime syndicate.

PARIS, June 12 -- In many respects the Soviet Union has recaptured the diplomatic initiative in this period of so-called peace offensives that had been seized by the United States through President Eisenhower's remarkable speech of April 16.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 12 -- The Canadian delegation to the United Nations circulated here today the text of a major foreign policy address by Lester B. Pearson. Secretary of State for External Affairs.

CLEVELAND, June 12 -- Behind Whitey Ford and Allie Reynolds, the Yankees beat the Indians, 4 -- 2, tonight for their fifteenth straight victory and increased their American League lead over runner-up Cleveland to seven and one-half games.
The cotton futures market here was quiet yesterday and closing prices were 2 points higher to 6 points lower than on Thursday.

Copper deliveries to fabricators in this country last month were the largest for any month in more than six years, and refined copper production for May set a post-World War II record, according to figures reported yesterday by the Copper Institute.

VIENNA, June 12 -- A prediction that the Austrian Government will refuse to recognize the right to restitution of Jewish victims of Nazism now living abroad is being made by Nazi-friendly newspapers here in advance of next week's negotiations between the Government and Jewish world organizations.

PHILADELPHIA. June 12 (UP) -- Southpaw Jack Collum stopped the Phillies with six hits and singled home two runs in the seventh inning tonight to give the Redlegs a 4-1 victory before 6,510 chilled fans at Connie Mack Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Craig S. Vincent, who, with his wife, operates a 160-acre "guest ranch" in New Mexico about ninety miles from the atomic energy installation at Los Alamos, has refused to say whether it was a Communist indoctrination establishment, according to testimony that the Senate Internal Security subcommittee made public today.
TOKYO, June 12 (AP) -- Gen. Mark W. Clark today announced command and staff reassignments involving six officers of general or flag rank in his Far East Command.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 12 -- A charge that "swindles" were in the making in power and timber in the Pacific Northwest under the Eisenhower Administration was made tonight in a speech to Oregon Democrats by Senator Wayne Morse, a former Republican turned independent.

BERLIN, June 12 -- In fulfillment of its new conciliation policies Soviet-occupied East Germany began today to turn more toward building up goodwill in West Germany and less toward its Communist goals of recent years.
OMAHA, June 12 (AP) Michigan downed Boston College, 6 -- 2, tonight to join Texas as the only undefeated team after two rounds of the National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball tournament.

LONDON, June 12 -- A scientific partnership between an American and a British biochemist at the Cavendish Laboratory in Cambridge has led to the unraveling of the structural pattern of a substance as important to biologists as uranium is to nuclear physicists. The substance is nucleic acid, the vital constituent of cells, the carrier of inherited characters and the fluid that links organic life with inorganic matter.

The role of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the effects of the projected Pentagon reorganization on civilian-military relationships in the Department of Defense are two of the background factors in the current controversy over the size of the 1954 military budget.
A white-haired woman of 83 years, who was to leave tomorrow for Geneva, Switzerland, on a vacation, suddenly vanished yesterday afternoon.

EASTON, Pa., June 12 -- The United States must aim at winning support of the three-fifths of the world's population who are illiterate, if America is to be successful in the "cold war," Dr. Frank C. Laubach, literacy specialist, for World Literacy, Inc., said today in an address at the 118th annual commencement of Lafayette College.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today that the level of police salaries in many localities was a scandal. He called for public support, including that of the American press, in bringing about corrective measures.
CAMDEN, N. J., June 12 -- The last of four $400,000 tugs built by RTC Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden for the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad in the last year was launched here today.

LONDON, June 12 -- The stock markets were quiet again today, with business still restricted by uncertainty over events in Korea and continued speculation that the new Government loan would be issued soon. Despite the caution prices strengthened, notably among industrial leaders.

WORCESTER Mass., June 12 (AP) -- The known death toll from the tornado that ripped through Central Massachusetts Tuesday rose to eighty-five today with the finding of a 2-week-old infant swept from his mother's arms by the fury of the winds.

PARIS, June 12 -- Edouard Herriot, pre-war Premier who as Speaker of the National Assembly has been removed from active politics, made public today an appeal that he had directed to his own Radical party to set aside its partisan desires and help to form a stable Cabinet in the sole interests of France.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies during May showed an aggregate gain of 2.9 per cent over volume of the like 1952 month, according to a compilation of forty-three companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 12 (UP) -- A westbound Greyhound bus rammed a parked freight truck on the Pennsylvania Turnpike today, killing five persons and injuring thirty as the impact sheared off the right front section of the bus.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 12 -- Monmouth Park opens its eighth campaign tomorrow, a fifty-day season that continues through Aug. 10. A field of seventeen sprinters is expected to go post-ward for the inaugural feature, the $15,000 added Oceanport Handicap.

For a week a monkey couple had the run of Delancey Street. No one minded much until they invaded a family kitchen yesterday noon. The police were called and chased the monkeys back into a loft they share with a group of teen-age boys and a St. Bernard dog. There was also a goat there for a while.

The Temporary State Commission to Study the Organizational Structure of the Government of the City of New York selected Dr. Wallace S. Sayre, chairman of the Department of Government at City College, as its research director yesterday and chose Arthur H. Goldberg, a former assistant corporation counsel, as its counsel.
LONDON, June 12 (Reuters) -- It was a bowlers' benefit in the second day of the first England- Australia test match, with thirteen wickets dropping for 184 runs at Nottingham today.

Mayor Impellitteri signed yesterday after a brief public hearing twenty-one local laws intended to modernize the city's archaic theatre building code. The legislation, which was offered by Councilman Hugh Quinn, Queens Democrat, and passed by the City Council two weeks ago, became effective with the Mayor's signature.

The Community Service Society, largest voluntary nonsectarian family and health agency in the country, is remodeling its seventy-year-old camping program along mental health lines, Stanley P. Davies, general director, reported yesterday.
The speech by Rudolph Halley at the annual convention of the United Hatters, Cap and Milliniery Workers International Union, A. F. L., at the Commodore Hotel yesterday follows:

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 12 -- President Getulio Vargas today appointed Governor Jose Americo de Almeida of Parahyba State as Minister of Public Works in place of Alvara de Souza Lima, who resigned following a disagreement with Governor Almeida over drought control measures.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 12 -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, said today that he had been encouraged by the increased consumption of beef throughout the nation and that this development was slowing the decline of market prices being paid to cattle raisers.
TOKYO, Saturday, June 13 (AP) -Eighth Army communique for Thursday's activities:

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Army announced plans today to shut down seven of its installations in this country, some of major size, and said that several divisions would either be consolidated or transferred to other stations.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Prof. Harold C. Urey, the Nobel prize-winning atomic scientist, interceded with President Eisenhower today on behalf of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who are awaiting execution in Sing Sing Prison next Thursday for transmitting atomic secrets to Soviet Russia.
CHICAGO, June 12 (UP) -- Authorities began a study today of the high number of young men who acquired police records after they were classified 1-A but before they were drafted.

The General Instrument Corporation, manufacturers of television, radio and electronic products, had the largest sales and earnings for any initial quarter in its thirty-year history, Abraham Blumenkrantz, chairman of the board, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Elizabeth, N. J.

City Council President Rudolph Halley strongly urged the Liberal party yesterday to run its own Mayoralty candidate in the fall and implied equally strongly that he would be happy to be that candidate. He chose an appearance before the convention of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers, A. F. L., as the occasion for making public his views.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 12 -- Five Yale University scientists, one of them a young woman, have become the first oceanographers to chance upon a phenomenon of nature that sporadically slaughters fish and sea birds off the coast of Peru.

The proposed legislation authorizing a substantial grant of wheat to Pakistan should be promptly and enthusiastically adopted. There are a dozen good arguments in favor of it. There is no good argument against it. The Administration has sponsored it and there seems to be solid favorable sentiment on both sides of the aisle.

New York weather is traditionally mean, and except for those all-too-short idyllic spells of mid-spring and early fall it is the constant butt of insults from native and visitor. Reading of the ordeal the people in Massachusetts and the Middle West have undergone in the last few days, we might make another estimate of our place on the map.

NEW DELHI, India, June 12 -- Finding it virtually impossible to run an education institution in New Delhi without getting involved in local politics, the American Jesuits Education Association has given notice to the Central Ministry of Education of its intention to withdraw from management of the institution.

In a broad sense the city in which we live may be thought of as a gigantic home. After all, it is called "home" by its eight million inhabitants and, most important of all, it has a domestic problem -- that of housekeeping.

LONDON, June 12 (AP) -- The Bel gian, Danish and Italian tennis teams each took a 2-0 lead today in the European zone Davis Cup eliminations, while Germany and France were even at the conclusion of the quarter-final round.
The removal of Mr. Melnikov as head of the Ukrainian Communist party seems to be one of the most important single internal developments within the Soviet Union since the death of Stalin last March.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, June 13 -- Thousands of Chinese Reds attacked United Nations positions across the Korean central front last night and early today in the third straight day of heavy enemy assaults.

The huge interchange serving eight arterial highways surrounding the Queens Borough Hall at Kew Gardens, comprising the most complicated traffic unscrambler in the city, is nearing completion after two years of work.

CUSTER STATE PARK, S. D., June 12 -- President Eisenhower expressed the earnest hope today, in a message to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India, that the prisoner of war agreement reached in Korea a few days ago would lead speedily to an armistice and a just peace.

Eugene Pascal, restaurateur by vocation, fisherman by avocation, has a suggestion that well may interest home cooks with husbands also addicted to the rod and reel. The co-owner of L'Auberge de France, 58 West Fifty-sixth Street, offered us his simplified version of an old Marseilles recipe for soup based on fish fresh from the ocean.

Activity improved in most commodity futures markets here yesterday but it still remained fairly light. Wool, tin, copper and potatoes closed mixed; sugar, cocoa, hides, cottonseed oil and soybean oil lower, and coffee, zinc, lead and rubber higher.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., June 12 -- Industrial leaders were told today they must extend in-plant educational projects to the schools and community to bridge the gap between living and learning.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -The American Bankers Association (A. B. A.) today told Senators new legislation restricting operations of bank holding companies was "most desirable."

The National Cancer Hospital of America, a Detroit organization, was permanently enjoined yesterday from soliciting funds here by Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey, who also ordered the appointment of a receiver of the corporation's funds in this state.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- Wheat prices had a precipitate slump today, July crashing through the $2 mark without any important resistance, all deliveries registering the lowest prices for wheat on the Chicago Board of Trade in more than three years.

RAPID CITY, S. D., June 12 -- The Young Republican National Convention was warned today that the party faced an uphill fight requiring new electoral techniques to re-elect a Republican Congress in 1954 and carry out in full President Eisenhower's campaign pledges.

CUSTER STATE PARK, S. D., June 12 -- President Eisenhower expressed the earnest hope today, in a message to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India, that the prisoner of war agreement reached in Korea a few days ago would lead speedily to an armistice and a just peace.

RAPID CITY, S. D., June 12 -- The Young Republican National Convention was warned today that the party faced an uphill fight requiring new electoral techniques to re-elect a Republican Congress in 1954 and carry out in full President Eisenhower's campaign pledges.

However much one may instinctively sympathize with Professor Einstein's suggestion that intellectuals called before Congressional investigating committees should refuse to testify, it has to be pointed out that this would be most unwise. Two wrongs never did add up to one right.

A 42-year-old Bronx window cleaner dangled precariously for a half hour from a midtown fifth-floor window after a hook of his safety belt became loosened yesterday. Crowds in Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street saw him rescued by persons in the building.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to the homemaker:

Seven public school teachers who refused to answer questions on alleged Communist party membership before Congressional committees may be discharged from their jobs at Thursday's special meeting of the Board of Education, it was announced yesterday.

" Brant Coopersmith of Newark, in his letter published June 1, asserts that the implication that interest rates now berg determined in a free market is false; that the possibility of a free money market is a fiction. There is an alternative view.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 12 -- Although the field drew closer to him, Ben Hogan, the challenger from Texas, still maintained the lead at the end of the first thirty- six holes in the United States open golf championship today.

After a wait of six months, Martin Gabel has received the dramatization by Harry Kurnitz of his mystery novel, "Reclining Figure," and plans to start immediate production activities. The producer's intentions are to bring it to Broadway next fall, after the usual out-of-town preliminary performances.

On the Other Foot The floating supply of the common stock of the Regal Shoe Company in the hands of the general public must be pretty small as a result of the recent buying of the shares on the part of the Brown Shoe Company and the General Shoe Corporation. Regal has 512,098 shares of stock outstanding, of which 169;321, or 33 per cent, is held by the estate of John J. Daly, former president.

DETROIT, June 12 (UP) -- Jim Delsing cracked Sonny Dixon's first pitch in the bottom of the ninth inning for a home run tonight to give the Tigers a 2-1 victory over the Senators before 12,675 fans at Briggs Stadium.

A three-hit explosion against Dave Koslo in the seventh inning gave the Cardinals all their runs in a 3-1 victory over the Giants before 23,529 paying spectators at the Polo Grounds last night. The defeat dropped the New Yorkers two games below the .500 mark, which they had hoped to regain for a spring into the first division.

Somewhat gingerly, yet with an air of bravado, Allen Richmond rang the doorbell. A moment's pause -- and then footfalls could be heard. The woman of the well-kept stucco-front suburban house opened the door about six inches and asked cautiously: "Who's there?"

Sara Delano Roosevelt, granddaughter of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Anthony di Bonaventura, musically talented son of a Seventeenth Street barber, were married yesterday afternoon in a small Italian church on the lower East Side to which the groom and his family belong.

ROME, June 12 -- The executive committee and directorate of the Christian Democratic party are to meet next week to evaluate the results of this week's elections, which showed that all Center parties had lost much ground in the five years since the last general elections. The party's past and future policy will be discussed.
CHICAGO, June 12 (UP) -- The Red Sox checked an eighth-inning rally by the White Sox and held on for a 4-3 victory tonight before 26,567 Comiskey Park fans.

THOSE who are unable to make a trip to the St. Lawrence bass waters in New York for the 4opening on Tuesday, but are too impatient to await the general New York opening on July 1, can invest in a New Jersey non-resident license and begin fishing for largemouth and smallmouth on Monday.

To the surprise of everyone in the secretary's office, the names of eight 3-year-old colts -- instead of the four or five that had been expected -- went into the entry box at Belmont Park yesterday for today's eighty-fifth running of the Belmont Stakes.

The 1953 Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowship has been awarded to Charles Bracelen Flood for his first novel, "Love Is A Bridge." The story, begun in Archibald MacLeish's writing course at Harvard University, deals with individuals seeking a "decent" life.

Hans Kohn, reviewing J. G. de Beus' "The Future of the West," cannot agree with Mr. de Beus' notion that democracy arose from medieval Christianity. Mr. Kohn feels it arose from the tolerant atmosphere of some assorted Cartesian sensists, including, of all people, the unhappy Spinoza.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fiftieth annual match-play championship will get underway tomorrow over the hilly, well-trapped, Metropolis Country Club course in White Plains.

THERE are many plays we learn so thoroughly that they become automatic -- and in this fact lies much danger. The play we make automatically is almost always right, of course, but when on rare occasions it is wrong it can be very costly.

LONDON, June 13 -- Motor coaches bringing sightseers from all over Britain to see the Coronation decorations and illuminations in London have been causing such traffic jams -- the worst that the capital has ever seen -- that they are to be banned from the center of the city.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives completed hearings today on the proposed continuation of the excess profits tax with all signs indicating further delay, and quite possibly no action at all, on the President's request.

E. B. WHITE once wrote: "On any person who desires such queer prizes, New York will bestow the gift of loneliness and the gift of privacy * * *. It can destroy an individual, or it can fulfill him, depending a good deal on luck.

Representative Jacob K. Javits reiterated last night his willingness to run for Mayor if wanted as a candidate by the Republican party, of which he is a member, and the "good government forces." He defined the latter as consisting of the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee, the Liberal party and the City Fusion party.

SARANAC LAKE -- The Adirondacks, long the vacation-land of campers, hikers, hunters and fishermen, have been built up during the year to welcome and accommodate vacationists and the motoring tourist as never before.

BECKENHAM, England, June 13 -- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla., the United States top-ranking tennis player, was beaten in the final of the Kent championships today by George Worthington in a stunning upset, 6 -- 4, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

OMAHA, June 13 (AP) -- Undefeated Ron Owen of Lafayette ran his winning streak to ten games tonight as he tossed a three-hitter for a 4-3 victory over Stanford in the third round of the National Collegiate A. A. baseball tournament.

THE apparent nearness of an uneasy cold-war peace made it clear last week that a showdown of the "what's next?" variety was at hand. Business seems to have reached a peak in the current boomlet. Without the impetus of full-scale fighting to clear the economic weather, gray clouds are spotted on the horizon.

The Foreign Ministers of the British Commonwealth have completed a series of meetings as important and impressive in its results as any since the war ended. It was the happy occasion of Queen Elizabeth's coronation that brought them all to London, but it was the unique and extraordinary virtues of that almost indescribable organization that provided the forum.

A revolution in residential and commercial year-round air-conditioning may be just around the corner. General Electric Company, the largest electrical manufacturer in the world, revealed last week it was ready to mass produce and distribute its heat pump.

In recent years the number of roadside parks along our highways has mushroomed tremendously. That must prove hat outdoor eating, at least, has failure for the 84 per cent of the population that prefers to live in cities.
BRISTOL, England, June 13 (AP) --Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, Amer-

THERE was a time, twenty years ago roughly, when it was difficult to talk dispassionately about Arthur Rimbaud. The French symbolist poet, who looked like a sneering angel, generated fervor and fever. Discussions around Rimbaud were chaotic mainly because it was close to impossible to disengage the poetry from the poet.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- State Department officials are considering the possibility of demanding the recall of Dr. You Chan Yang, the South Korean Ambassador, after a Korean truce has been signed.

PARIS, June 13 -- Three successive candidates for the French Premiership in the past three weeks have told the National Assembly that governmental instability was ruining France's prestige with the Allied nations and casting discredit on the parliamentary regime among the people of France.

New York University has appointed Dr. Miguel A. de Capriles associate dean of its School of Law, to direct a new Office of Institutional Research and Educational Planning, it was announced yesterday by Dr. David D. Henry, executive vice chancellor. Dr. de Capriles will administer a $250,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation made to finance a two-year N. Y. U. self-study.

KARACHI, June 13 -- In the last two months, twelve representatives of the United States Government, including Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Mutual Security Administrator Harold E. Stassen, Congressmen, economists and agricultural experts, have visited Pakistan to study the country's problems.

FERNDALE -- Just about the hottest piece of resort real estate within ninety miles of New York City is Sullivan County, a 986-square-mile cut of the Catskills, which, if it isn't "the Marilyn Monroe of counties," as a Sullivan hotel man recently said it was, is none the less a nicely endowed handiwork of nature's.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, has wrathfully informed the Senate that President Eisenhower's nominee as chief of the Federal Bureau of Mines "is an ignorant man" when it comes to coal mining.

Four boys and a pretty blonde girl put their dogs through elementary obedience exercises on a large playing field off Pelham Parkway in the Bronx recently. There was nothing particularly remarkable about the performance, but it was different. The young handlers were blind or nearly blind.

POCONO Mountain resort operators have spent more than three million dollars this year on new or expanded facilities in preparation for their summer guests. Swimming pools, golf courses and even an ice rink and alterations account for most of the expenditures.
STOCKTON, Calif., June 13 (UP) -- Bud Held, former Olympic star, made the second best javelin throw in American history tonight with a heave of 246 feet 1 1/2 inches.

An example of the complex and interlocking character of Far Eastern problems is offered in the case of the Vietnamese and Laotians who are resident in Thailand. They are called "refugees," since many of them crossed the border -- in this case the Mekong River -- when French authority was restored in Laos after the war.

COMPTON, Calif., June 13 (UP) -- The longest discus throw in American history was headed for the records today, posted by the world champion, Fortune Gordien, who hurled the platter 186 feet 2 1/4 inches at the Southern Pacific Amateur Athletic Union championships.

THE renting of cars to individuals, an inevitable development in this nation of renters, has soared to the $100,000,000 business level on the wings of America's flock of vacationists. A business that was once primarily a convenience for traveling salesmen is capitalizing on Americans' love of automobile touring by making cars available to non-owners and those who want to do their motoring a long way from home.

IN his own way, Joe Morris was the Frank Case of Tokyo during the hectic days of the American Occupation and the early part of the Korean War. First as an Army officer, later as a civilian, he managed the world-famous Imperial Hotel. His clientele, in its own way, was as unruly and pleasure-loving a crew as Case's literary boarders at New York's Algonquin.

In what amounted to a re-run of the May 23 Preakness at Pimlico, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's grand 3-year-old colt, Native Dancer, yesterday won the eighty-fifth Belmont Stakes at cold, rainy, windy Belmont Park.

THE three main reasons for having plants on or around a terrace or porch are for shade, for privacy and for decoration. Lucky is the home owner whose outdoor living room, whatever it may be termed architecturally, is shaded by tall, old trees or has the privacy afforded by well-placed shrubs.

IN this volume the former Assistant Secretary of State in charge of public information and public affairs tells the story of the achievements and failures, the trials and tribulations of the information service of the Department of State.

TRANSLATION is always a trying and thankless art. In the field of poetry its demands on the translator are even unreasonable: its highest achievement is anonymity; and, ironically, to succeed the poet-translator must command a craftsmanship that transcends his individual needs.

The flag is one of the oldest of our social symbols and one of the best understood. In any part of the world and in any language the raising of a flag has a definite meaning about which there is little confusion. It is a standard, a rallying point, a mark of unity and support.

After a brief lull, the post-Stalin purge within the Soviet Union has begun again, and now penetrates the inner circle of Soviet rule. This time its victim is one of the fourteen most important persons in the entire country, L. G. Melnikov, alternate member of the Central Committee's Presidium (the old Politburo) and Communist party boss of the Ukraine.
A brand-new American-designed electric power plant will be dedicated with considerable fanfare within the next few weeks on the Greek island of Euboea, in the Aegean Sea.
OAKMONT, Pa., June 13 -- Ben Hogan stepped to a new place in the history of American golf today by winning the United States open championship for the fourth time.

Picking up points in the eighteen events staged, the New York A. C.'s power - packed squad clinched the team crown in the sixty-third annual senior Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, last night.
LONDON, June 13 (AP) -- Italy and Denmark gained the semi-finals of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition today with decisive triumphs over Sweden and the Philippines, respectively.
The shipping industry is waging a strong campaign to drive the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service out of competition with the privately owned merchant fleet.

HARTFORD, June 13 -- A state-wide "town meeting" will be held in Connecticut on June 22 to vote on two proposed amendments to the State Constitution. The special election was directed by the General Assembly, which ended its five-month session on May 30.

Randy Turpin of Britain yesterday consented to fight the winner of Friday night's Garden bout between Paddy Young and Bobo Olson for the undisputed world middleweight boxing championship, James D. Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, disclosed.

THE general concern of Americans over the problem of communism may have come late in the day, more than thirty years after Lenin's coup of November, 1917. But if it is late, it is all-pervasive. The problem of communism confronts us today in half a hundred places -- in Korea, in Moscow, in Guatemala, Iran and who knows where?

WHY this novel isn't a career girl's "The Cocktail Party," is hard to say. For "The Cocktail Party" T. S. Eliot took suggestions from all sorts and conditions of literature -- the "Alcestis" of Euripides, for example, and a Mississippi raftsman's song.
ANYONE who thinks of trees as subjects for climbing or sitting under, as lumber material, or as beauty marks on the landscape, will find something appealing in these three books.

THE abundant musicality of the Negro people is strikingly evidenced in recent recordings. And by one of the flukes of simultaneous release, the new records tell a fairly complete story. They show that musicality as it still exists in Africa, and they reveal how the Negroes have enriched the musical lives of all the places to which they have been transported.

ATHENS, June 13 -- In a statement, "To the Greek People," in newspapers and over the radio today, Premier Alexander Papagos defended his Government against Opposition attacks. The Chamber of Deputies was closed two days ago at his instance.

ALBANY -- Vacationists visiting New York's eastern Adirondack area this summer will find that the major change in the resort landscape is bumper crop of mushrooming new motels along the main-travelled roads from Saratoga Springs north to Schroon Lake and Ticonderoga.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn -- The tourist business along the 10,000 miles of shoreline provided by the man-made reservoirs and lakes of the Tennessee Valley Authority is expected to boom this season. As an example, it is estimated that around 25,000 boats will be needed to meet the demands of an anticipated 20,000,000 visitors.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: As fast as they fade, cut blossoms from perennials, roses and shrubs. This prevents seed formation which takes strength from the plant and gives an untidy appearance. Daily or weekly removal of the dead flowers encourages a second bloom on perennials such as coralbells and phlox as well as annuals such as cornflowers.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 13 -- The struggle for the right to train African children in African nationalism has started here in the courts. A case started by Peter Mbiyu Koinange, the most famous native African figure in East Africa after Jomo Kenyatta, jailed leader of the African Union, and principal of the Githunguri Teachers College, has brought back into focus the essential nature of the native African movement in Kenya.

WITH the closing of the City Ballet and the final studio recital by Paul Swan tonight, "live" dancing will turn the season over to the New York Dance Films Society. The first of its three subscription performances will take place on Thursday evening in the air-conditioned Museum of Modern Art.
DETROIT, June 13 (UP) -- Jim Delsing's grand-slam home run paced the Tigers to a 7-6 victory over the Senators today before 4,765 fans at Briggs Stadium.
SYDNEY, Australia, June 13 -- The decline in American buying of wool this year has seriously affected Australia's dollar trade balance. Wool is Australia's greatest individual dollar earner.

SIX trumpeters from the household cavalry sounded a fanfare from the stage as Queen Elizabeth II entered the royal box at the Covent Garden Opera House for the gala performance of "Gloriana," written by William Plomer and composed by Benjamin Britten.

BOSTON, June 13 -- The New England council held its 111th quarterly meeting at Manchester, Vt. this week and the various committee reports indicated that New England's economy has gained ground this year, with no serious setbacks in the wind for the second half year.

MORE than five years after its declaration of independence Israel is still fighting a war -- "the little war," the battle of the borders. Since becoming a nation she has never known an extended period of quiet on all her borders at the same time.

Thirty men and women from 60 to 85 years old were doing their daily calisthenics last week on the open air terrace of the William I. Sirovich Day Center at 203 Second Avenue, and they seemed to be having a good time. At least they did not have to be there. They could have been home sitting in a stuffy room or wandering the streets instead.

BANGKOK, June 13 -- Four-power military talks here on measures to evacuate General Li Mi's Chinese Nationalist guerillas from eastern Burma are scheduled to be reopened soon following the return from Formosa of Col. Fu-Teh, chief Chinese Nationalist representative. Colonel Fu-Teh, who flew to Taipeh on June 2 to report to his government on earlier evacuation discussions, is expected to return to Bangkok with instructions that may speed up the talks.

Only once in its eighty-three-year history as a modern nation has Italy given a parliamentary majority to a single party in a democratic election. The once was in 1948 when Premier Alcide De Gasperi's Christian Democratic Union beat off a Communist threat and emerged with 48 per cent of the popular vote and a clear majority in the Italian Assembly, or Lower House of Parliament.

BOSTON, June 13 (UP) -- Wilbert Wilson of Boston gained a seventh-round technical knockout over Charlie Goulart of Somerville tonight when an eye cut prevented Goulart from continuing in their televised scheduled 10-rounder at Mechanics Building.

KANSAS CITY, June 13 (AP) -- Security arrangements for top-secret Governmental documents of the Truman Administration are highly efficient, Harry S. Truman found out today when he himself inadvertently tripped a burglar alarm.

In an appeal for public contributions yesterday, Andrew S. Roscoe, chairman of the Brooklyn Red Cross, said that the American Red Cross had allocated $550,000 last week for disaster relief in flood and tornado-stricken areas. He urged that donations be sent to the Brooklyn Red Cross center at 57 Willoughby Street, Brooklyn 1, N. Y.
LE MANS, France, Sunday June 14 (AP) -- Tom Cole of Sayville L. I., was killed today in the Le Mans Grand Prix auto race where his Ferrari overturned at the Maison Blanc corner of the course.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Opposition to some of the main features of the Administration's plan for reorganizing the Department of Defense is shaping up in several quarters.

PORTLAND, Me. -- There's no escaping it, the State of Maine is showing her age. The seaport city of Belfast will observe the 100th anniversary of the adoption of her charter as a city Aug. 14, 15 and 16. The town of Veazie will mark its 100th birthday July 3 and 4.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 13 (AP) -- Top-seeded Tony Trabert, Cincinnati, in a five-set tennis match that took three and one-half hours to play, defeated third-seeded Harry Likas, San Francisco, 14 -- 16, 8 -- 6, 1 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, today in the men's singles semi-finals of the national hard-courts tennis championships.
" SUMMER SCHOOL," C. B. S. television education series for elementary school students, will return for a second semester on July 6 with a Monday-through-Friday schedule from 4 to 4:30 P. M.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Senatorial eyebrows were lifted last Thursday when the junior Senator from Wisconsin scolded the junior Senator from New York for allegedly sending out too much mail under his frank -- meaning that he paid no postage on it.

HAVANA, June 13 -- Fear that the "strong hand and isolationist" policy of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, is influencing the United States' treatment of Latin American countries was expressed today by Eusebio Mujal, Secretary of the General Confederation of Cuban Workers, which controls the island's labor.

VIENNA, June 13 -- The most violent expressions of popular discontent with Communist rule that have occurred in any Soviet satellite have been taking place in Czechoslovakia since her currency was devalued two weeks ago.

LOS ANGELES -- Although the traditional harbinger of summer in these parts, the opening of the Hollywood Park race track, was delayed nearly a week by a horsemen's dispute, the Southwest now can be attested as well launched on a "golden season" well studded with both fixtures and innovations of significance to the vacationing public.

MOST suburbanites and vacationists take a simple delight at times in just lazing on the porch, or veranda, on a summer day or evening. At other times the porch affords a cool retreat where guests may be entertained in reasonable comfort at minimum effort on a hot summer night.

PARIS, June 13 -- Andre Marie, Minister of Education in the outgoing French Cabinet, consulted Radical party leaders today and obtained the backing of his party to continue talks until Monday in the hope of winning a majority to give him its support as Premier. His prospects remained very much in doubt.

The city coordinated drive against tuberculosis cases not in hospitals will start early in July and may reach as many as 1,000 patients by October, Dr. Arthur B. Robins, director of the Health Department's Bureau of Tuberculosis and head of the project, declared yesterday.

WHILE vacation travel by motor this year bids fair to set a record everywhere, New England is expected to prove the stellar attraction for recreation seekers from New York City during the summer months.

Insurance-hungry Americans will pour approximately $9,000,000,000 into the coffers of the nation's life insurance companies for life protection and annuities this year. The rate of premium payments so far this year indicates this record level will be reached easily.

ON the basis of one of those attenuated projections which make flushed dreamers of baseball statisticians, an otherwise earthbound lot, it was figured out recently that if Roy Campanella, the catcher for the Brooklyn Dodgers, kept on hitting home runs as briskly as he has been, he would wind up the 1953 season with at least as many as Babe Ruth did when he set an all-time record of 60 in 1927.

NOTHING printed here this morning will destroy the cozy delusion that drama critics make or break plays. On and off Broadway people feel more comfortable with myths than with actualities, and facts are an unwelcome intrusion on belief.

WE'VE known for some time, by merely glancing rightward, that "Desiree" and "The Silver Chalice," "The Power of Positive Thinking" and "Annapurna" were top dogs in the various bookstores over our nation.

The Ford Fund for the Advancement of Education has announced that it will continue its support of the self-study programs adopted by a number of liberal arts colleges last year. Invitations are being issued to all liberal arts colleges throughout the country to apply for assistance in conducting a critical appraisal of their work in liberal education.

HERE we go again on one of society's favorite topics -- today's woman. Is she happy or unhappy? What is her role, career or home? What do men think of her? What should she be taught in college? Has she made a success in politics?
LAREDO, Tex., June 13 (AP) -- A thunderstorm splashed .58 of an inch of rain on parched Laredo last night, 'twenty-eight hours after hundreds had gathered in the plaza and prayed for rain.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 13 -- Eleven young women bowed to society tonight in a group presentation at the annual ball for the Greenville Backer Boys Club at the home of Mrs. George Dupont Pratt in Skunks Misery Road. Before the ball they all had been guests of Mr. and Mrs. H. Irving Pratt at their home in Oyster Bay, where their daughter, Miss Ellen Hallowell Pratt, was honored as a debutante.

The administrative and legal staffs of the Board of Transportation labored far into the night yesterday to complete most of the work involved in transferring to the New York City Transit Authority the control and operation of the $1,700,000,000 municipal transit system.
GLASGOW, June 13 -- A touring American track and field squad won three events -- setting records in two of them -- before 25,000 today in the Glasgow Police Coronation games.
The college rowing season ends Saturday with the holding of the fifty-first regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association.

RANGOON, Burma, June 13 -- Officials here say Burma's ambitious welfare state and economic development program will suffer in some respects from this country's recent decision to terminate United States aid, but will nevertheless be continued with all available means.

THE present theatrical season here must go down as one of the dullest on record. Jean Jacques Gautier, the "Figaro" critic, in a despairing moment, qualifies it as "hopelessly dismal," and his chief lament is the lack of new plays of importance by French authors.

Out-of-town buyers were active in wholesale markets here last week placing fall orders, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. Considerable optimism was expressed for fall business. Suits were expected to show moderate increases in sales over last year and coats, dresses and costume suits promise to make sizable gains.

THAT group of chamber music enthusiasts in which every one works for love, and whose chief service is a directory of several thousand amateurs who are eager to play in ensembles with other instrumentalists, has shortened its name.

Last year the steel industry's labor-management relations discussions seemed almost as hopelessly bogged down as were the contemporary negotiations at Panmunjom. The crisis had been dramatic and costly. President Truman had seized the steel mills to prevent a strike and the Supreme Court had ordered him to give them back.

FORT LEE, N. J., June 13 -- A special bipartisan New Jersey legislative committee began hearings here today to determine how much the Port of New York Authority should pay the Township of Weehawken for properties and other rights necessary for construction of the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel.

ALMOST exactly 105 years ago, in 1948, Ezra Taft Benson, great-grandfather of the present Secretary of Agriculture, came to Washington from Utah on a mission for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints. There he observed Congress first-hand in the act of appropriating funds for operation of the Federal Government.
