In the academic year just ending, a record number of foreign students have attended American colleges and universities. The upward trend has continued since the end of World War II, and the upper limits are not yet in sight.

CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) -- Jay Jay Gee, a dark brown Illinois-brew filly, ran a strong race all the way for a two-and-a-half-length victory in the $15,000 Miss America Stakes, the feature of today's Lincoln Fields program.

THE Connecticut River, a 400-mile stream that bisects New England north and south from the Canadian border to Long Island Sound, is being rediscovered as a recreational paradise more than 300 years after the first settlers moved there at the start of the westward trek of population.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- In late February, 1951, newspapers here and in Europe published dispatches from Czechoslovakia reporting that fires had broken out in the Gbely oil fields, in the Bratislava area.

MANY gardeners think of the iris season as being short-lived, but actually bloom can extend from spring to fall. This can be accomplished by planting very early and late kinds, in addition to the better - known groups which have been making such a splash lately.

TROUT fishermen are enthusiastic specialists, not only where the species of fish is concerned but in the matter of tackle and methods, so it is not too surprising that a certain amount of heat is generated when these assorted means to a common end come up for discussion.
New York State savings banks' new pool of common stock investment money now amounts to more than $3,500,000 on the basis of subscriptions to the banks' own Institutional Investors Fund.
HARRISBURG, June 13 (AP) -- Dick Lyster, 25-year-old Philadelphia school teacher competing on an injured leg, today set a Middle Atlantic Amateur Athletic Union high-jump record on a muddy field.

BOX-OFFICE television, with the viewer paying for what he sees at home, seems to be attracting new attention. Indeed, the idea of the public financing the programs that come into the home may prove to be the next big controversy for the Federal Communications Commission to resolve.

THOSE familiar with Isaac Deutscher's previous writings, particularly with his controversial biography of Stalin, will need no reminder of his special interests and point of view concerning Soviet subjects. Mr. Deutscher was first a participant in and subsequently an assiduous student of Soviet communism.

IF by ballet music -- and let us admit the modern dance for the purposes of this brief discography -- we mean the accompaniments to all choreographic works that are or have been in the international repertoire, the selection ranges from Bach to Morton Gould and beyond.

PITTSBURGH, June 13 -- The Braves scored a run in the nint]% inning today to defeat the Pirates, 5 4, and tie the idle Dodgers for the league lead.

A victim of nazi persecution who managed to escape Gestapo detection for five years will be among the 2,600 students receiving degrees at City College's 170th commencement exercises Wednesday evening.
BOSTON, June 13 (AP) -- Suffolk Down's stewards made an unusual ruling today by disqualifying a horse in a first-place dead heat in favor of the third fiinsher.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sunday, June 14 -- Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, commander of Colombia's armed forces, seized the Government in a bloodless coup last night and the national radio announced early today that he had assumed the Presidency.

MONTPELIER, Vt., June 13 -- Fremont L. Lovett, head of three public utilities, and True C. Morrill, dean of the evening division of the Bergen Junior College. Teaneck, N. J., were killed today in a plane crash at Warren, about fifteen miles from here.

ST. PIERRE -- Travelers need not cross the Atlantic to visit France and trade with francs. With a little advance planning one can drive over 1,200 miles of good highways from New York to Sydney, N. S., then cross 175 miles of water by boat or air to the small islands of St. Pierre-Miquelon.
TO THE EDITOR: Regarding Robert C. Doty's "The French Family Boursier" (June 7): How sad Boursier's lack of interest in political affairs of France. * * *

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio has thrown his weight behind a move within the Senate Appropriations Committee to slash a substantial amount -- perhaps more than $l,000,000,000 -- from the Eisenhower Administration's $5,474,000,000 foreign aid request.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 13 -- It now appears that the Korean war is at last drawing to a close and the debate already has started on what the United Nations accomplished. The victory is not complete, but the circumstances are certainly more encouraging than they were in 1935, when the League of Nations failed to stop Mussolini's conquest of Ethiopia.

ONE of Wade Carlson's partners never could decide whether he wanted to go to Montana, to California or back to his native Belgium. All that Jack knew was that he preferred to be anywhere except the stench-filled Alaskan cabin where these northern pioneers bivouacked through a bitter winter while digging for gold.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, June 14 -- American and South Korean forces grappled Communist troops in bloody hand-to-hand combat today after Red guns unloaded their heaviest bombardment of the Korean war.

Korean truce negotiations continued to dominate the financial picture for the third consecutive week. This added to the intensified uncertainty over taxes and Government money policies evidently exhausted investors' patience.

Ben Hogan carded a 283 yesterday to become the third player in history to capture the United States open championship for the fourth time. The Texan capped his last round of 71 with a brilliant finish to defeat Sam Snead by six strokes on the tough Oakmont (Pa.) Country Club course.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The full United States Supreme Court considered at its regular Saturday closed conference today a request for a stay of execution for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, convicted atomic spies scheduled to die Thursday in Sing Sing.

BATH, N Y., June 13 (AP) -- A severe storm racked Steuben County today, dumping hailstones ranging in size from beans to baseballs as deep as two feet in some places. Snowplows had to open a main highway.

" It seems we can't win, no matter what we do," said high Customs officials here yesterday as they considered the first month's results of a new baggage inspection speed-up program designed to clear as quickly as possible the hundreds of thousands of travelers arriving this summer.

RAPID CITY, S. D., June 13 -- The Young Republican National Federation, with more than 1,000 delegates from forty-five states, unanimously supported today a "collective security" foreign policy based on continuing membership in the United Nations and declared American sacrifices in Korea "have not been in vain.

Brooklyn College will confer degrees on 1,950 men and women at 5 P. M. today at the college's twenty-eighth commencement on the campus quadrangle. Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of the college, will preside.

The world was moving fast last week toward a sharp turning in the road of East-West struggle. With truce in Korea apparently at hand -- barring an eleventh-hour hitch caused by bitter protests by South Korea -- it was increasingly clear that a new phase was about to open, full of enormously complex and critical problems for the free world.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -A state-by-state survey showed today that the Eisenhower Administration would face a veritable grass-roots rebellion of Governors if it tried to impose a national sales tax.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 13 (AP) -- Ayotallah Abolghassem Kashani, Iran's chief religious leader, complained today that the government was clamping down on Moslem activities but letting the Tudeh (Communist) party operate with a free hand.

Most birds hatch their own eggs. Floodwater mosquitos let bacteria do the work. The discovery was made by Profs. William R. Horsfall and Alfred F. Borg of the University of Illinois in the course of research conducted to check the propagation of mosquitoes.

The Genocide Convention, which is already in force after having been ratified by forty-one nations representing half of the population of the world, is still not sufficiently known and is even misunderstood by some persons. Genocide is a rare crime of great magnitude.

WERE this beautiful volume four times as large, its author might have done justice to the tremendously ambitious task of combining a history of the horsemen of Argentina. Mexico, and the United States with a critique of literature on the gaucho, the charro, and the cowboy.

THE formality of the concert hall can be a fearsome thing. The distance between the performers on the stage and the auditors in the first rows may be only a few feet, but there are times when it must seem like miles both to the musicians and the listeners.

WOODSTOCK -- It is symptomatic of the personality of Woodstock that possibly nowhere else in the Catskills, a mountain range sprawled over a four-county area almost four times the size of Rhode Island, can you find a shop selling authentic Nigerian devil masks at $200 apiece.

Dr. John J. Theobald, president of Queens College, will present diplomas on Wednesday afternoon to 428 graduates at the twenty-third semiannual commencement on the quadrangle. The graduating class is the largest in the college's sixteen-year history.

BECAUSE James Jones' novel "From Here to Eternity" exposed (a) the brutality of the pre-Pearl Harbor Army and (b) the sordid side of Honolulu military night life, pundits who read the book wondered if they would ever hear the crack, "No, but I saw the movie."

TRENTON -- The New Jersey Supreme Court has upheld the constitutionality of a 1952 act that permits the state to guarantee a $285,000,000 bond issue by its Highway Authority, assuring completion of the Garden State Parkway now being built.

TEN-year-old Marcel went off into the French Alps to tend the cows for the summer with his father's words ringing in his ears: "Don't talk to anyone. Don't visit. Each keeps to his own. That's the only way to avoid trouble." The boy means to obey, but circumstances are against him.

ST. LOUIS, June 13 (AP) -- Gus Zernial, the American League's home-run leader, slammed No. 16 today in a power-packed attack that paced the Athletics to an 8-3 triumph over the Browns, who now have lost their last twelve games.

THE trip to Alaska over the Alaska Highway is becoming highly popular with motorists who want something a little out of the ordinary for their annual vacation. Last year gas station and restaurant owners along the 1,527-mile highway estimated traffic as high as one car every five minutes during the tourist season from June to October.

JOHN W. ALDRIDGE'S review of Edmund Wilson's "I Thought of Daisy" strikes me as insensitive criticism of a work that deserves something more. Mr. Aldridge's reduction of this novel of Greenwich Village manners, in which, it is true, the civilized hero often reflects, to a bare formula, for "the novel of developing consciousness," is most academic, and tells nothing of the bright detail that flavors the whole.
BALTIMORE, June. 13 (AP) -- A powerful Middle States women's tennis team shut out the defending champion, New England, 9 -- 0, today to win the annual Sears Cup in the four-team competition.

The idea of having a corporation like the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development help finance private undertakings in backward lands through equity investments and loans is regarded as impracticable under present circumstances.
RICHMOND, Va., June 13 -- Dr. Douglas Southall Freeman, retired editor of The Richmond News-Leader and a leading military historian, died today of a heart attack at his home here.

The sleek, white training ship, Empire State, of the State University Maritime College sailed from Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, late yesterday with 400 young cadets for a three-month, 10,000-mile cruise to England, Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands, France and Spain.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 13 -- Middlebury College today announced the awarding of six fellowships for study at the twenty-eighth session of its Bread Loaf Writers Conference. The session will be held from Aug. 12 to 26 at Middlebury's mountain campus under the direction of Theodore Morrison, novelist and Harvard University professor.

Unbeaten in eight games here this year, the Liverpool soccer team of England's First Division will close its tour today against the Young Boys Club of Berne, Switzerland. The contest, last in the local international series this season, leads a double-header at the Yankee Stadium.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 13 -- Ben Hogan used to be as brittle as an electric light bulb during the playing of the United States Open. The slightest jar and he'd explode. When he spoke, he spoke in monosyllables, a bundle of nerves and tightly compressed tensions.

MANY must, I know, share my feeling of sadness that the beautiful and moving Coronation service from Westminster Abbey had to be interrupted over certain stations by an unnecessary commercial announcement at a particularly unfortunate time.
TOKYO, Sunday, June 14 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,645, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korean time:

ONE of the hottest roulette games (figuratively speaking) in the history of movies is being played by the film-makers in Hollywood today. This is the large-scale gamble in which the big producers and studios are involved in attempting the critical transition to a new look for the motion-picture screen.

PARIS, June 13 -- As the world inches toward an end to the bloody fighting in Korea, increasing attention is being devoted by statesmen to the other active battlefield of the so-called "cold war," the Communist-led insurrection in Indo-China.

In the Eighty-third Congress President Eisenhower has a far thinner party majority than most newly elected Presidents -- ten in the House, one in the Senate. The House is the easier for the President to manage. Rules are rigid and the leadership has a good deal of control.

IN the living room of an apartment in a sedate residential hotel in the East Fifties, noted for the virtue of its lady guests, stands a photograph of an actor boldly inscribed, "Dear Marion, It is common knowledge that I love you. Wally Cox."

SALT LAKE CITY, June 6 -- While city youngsters received diplomas or began school vacations this week, 368 of their country cousins received an unhappy and specific lesson in economics at the seventeenth annual Intermountain Junior Fat Stock Show held at the Union Stockyards.

TO THE EDITOR: Leonard Engel's article, "Polio: New Weapons and New Hope" (May 31) was excellent and showed careful study of his subject. We appreciate his reference to the Sister Kenny treatment and the fact that crippling after-effects of polio are reduced by this treatment.

SPORTS-WRITER Tom Meany and colleagues have used the personal-history vignette with telling results in this colorful and informal presentation of the Brooklyn Dodgers. Here is the Dodgers' history, in terms of the men who are making it today.

MONTREAL, Que. -- It is said, perhaps too glibly, that Quebec and Montreal are "France in America," or some such marvel. They aren't quite. Montreal is at least superficially very Western Hemisphere, and Quebec looks more French in a long-distance photograph than it feels French at close range.

MONTPELIER, Vt. -- Vermont is one of those simple old-fashioned places where price rhenges come slowly, and where nickels and dimes are still hard currency to be earned and respected. Among the slow-changing prices are those of hotel and other accommodations and of meals, all of which are just about what they have been, which is reasonable.

IN the last two or three years one of the most firmly grounded notions in the mind of the motoring public -- well, the motoring public here in the East anyway -- has begun to totter. That is the idea that the only road across the state of Pennsylvania is the Turnpike.

A VACATION in complete seclusion, with the rest of the world held firmly at bay by a deep, wide moat? The northeastern United States and southeastern Canada offer the vacationist his choice among several hundred thousand such retreats.

CARLISLE, Pa., June 13 (AP) -- The United Presbyterian Church of North America joined two sister denominations today, taking the first step toward approval of plans for a single Presbyterian Church in the United States. By unanimous vote the ninety-fifth United Presbyterian General Assembly received the plan union for the three Presbyterian Churches for study, comment and revision.

PROVIDENCE, R. I. -- Rhode Island's bid for its share of the thousands who annually vacation in New England has been enhanced this summer by the addition of a sports program of national interest. The state is making a determined effort to lure new visitors and get them to stay longer in its summer playground area.

Twenty-five years ago this June, Dr. Manfred Sakel introduced the insulin- shock treatment for mental, emotional and nervous ills -- one of the great advances in psychiatry. Though other ways of giving shock treatment have been devised since then, Dr. Sakel's method still holds its own.

THE phrase, "Either be a whole or join one" which V. Smith Used in a review and assigned to Goethe, a correspondent, Curt Joel, in your letter columns, has now assigned to Schiller. Actually the distich was written in 1796, the time of the greatest cooperation between Schiller and Goethe.

A good many thousands of regatta fans along the shores and embankments of rivers, harbors and lakes will see daredevil driving during the season's championship race meets that have been assigned by the American Power Boat Association.

LEONIA, N. J., June 13 -- Mrs. Carl C. Dietsch, a housewife here, has made thirty visits to the United Nations Building in the last year and a half, but not for herself alone. Each time she has taken a group of children from the Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, elementary schools, high schools, or Sunday schools -- in all, 150 children.

FROM the standpoint of the repertory, the New York City Ballet should circle the genial brow of Lew Christensen with a laurel, for his two new works were both great fun and unquestionable hits, adding a definite brightness to the season.

THE circular bench under the apple tree wears a new coat of white paint, the hammock swings invitingly on its metal stand in the shade, and a new green chaise has just arrived for the terrace. Suburban and rural America abandons the living room and TV set and moves outdoors to enjoy summer and the garden on the porch, veranda, piazza or terrace.

IF Scooter Jones wasn't playing baseball, he was talking it. When a Little League was formed in town, he discovers unhappily that it takes less "heart for baseball" and more talent to make a team. He and other rejected boys start a new league and their disciplined practice helps them gain smoother diamond performance.

IF a biography of a man makes the reader feel that he is living with him it is a good biography. By that test "Shanghai Pierce" is excellent. Old Shang, as he came to be called, took pride in his voice, which, "too loud for indoor use," generally announced him before he was seen.

MEXICO CITY, June 12 -- The neighboring towns of Ocotlan and Tlaxcala, not far off the main highway that winds south from the capital, have long been rivals. But suddenly their ancient feud has flared with unaccustomed fierceness.

WATERTOWN -- This is one vacation area that has no doubt when its summer season begins for real. The tough little black bass set the date at day after tomorrow, by becoming fair game in Lake Ontario and the St. Lawrence River on June 16, two weeks before they can be hooked anywhere else in the state.

ONE of our great explorers, when asked why he climbed mountains, once replied blithely: "Because they're there." Col. P. H. Fawcett, on the contrary, sought lost cities which have never been proved to be there.

Debutantes headed by Miss Helen Ogden and including Miss Nancy Doyle are aiding in plans for the performance of "Can-Can" on Thursday night at the Shubert Theatre for the benefit of the Madison Square Boys Club, and the nightcap party in the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza afterward.

TOO many mountaineers take themselves seriously. They enjoy being photographed on the summit of a defenseless mountain, waving an ice-pick in one hand and a flag in the other, while their faces glow with triumph. Mercifully, Felice Benuzzi, confronted with a mountain, is quite incapable of taking himself seriously.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 13 -- Turkey was reported today to be ready to participate in a conference for revision of the Montreux Convention regulating the Dardanelles Straits provided all signatories and the United States were invited.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 -- The nation is enjoying record prosperity and virtually full employment, the Secretary of Commerce, Sinclair Weeks, asserted tonight at the June conference of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

VANCE RANDOLPH has made his name synonymous with the folklore of the Ozarks. He has collected their folksongs -- more than 800 of them -- in four stout volumes. He has published several collections of their tales, tall and otherwise, most recently "We Always Lie to Strangers" and "Who Blowed Up the Church House?" For a quarter of a century he has been publishing articles on the Ozark dialect in "Dialect Notes" and "American Speech."

When last week the Supreme Court called for a reargument in October of the five cases on segregation in the public schools it bared the searching of its own mind. It said to the nation that faces the perplexities of segregation and the paradox it poses in our democracy that on this question as it applies to the public schools there is no doctrine of infallibility available.

REPLACING the large and cumbersome stamps in the "Italy at Work" designs is a group of small definitives which have an artistic "Italia" vignette -- a feminine profile surmounted by a garland. Pierson Ostrow is informed the values and colors are 5-lire gray, 10L red, 12L green, 20L brown, 25L violet, 35L scarlet, 60L blue, 80L ochre.
SEATTLE, June 13 (AP) -- The national Woman's Christian Temperance Union elected a new president today for the first time in nine years and took a pot-shot at Yale's Laboratory of Applied Physiology.

PLANNING the vegetable plot so that the summer crop fits in with vacation is not easy. Whether a vacation is taken early or late, the answer lies in making the most of the long part of the season at home. There still are many adjustments that can be made so that harvest is enjoyed before and after the holiday trip, even if it is taken at midseason.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 13 -- Cornell University's new engineering campus moved another step toward completion today with the dedication during alumni reunions of two laboratories for the study of engineering materials.

MIAMI BEACH -- It is no longer special news that the Miami area has become one of the country's most popular summer resorts, but the natives have not yet become accustomed to seeing once boarded-up Miami Beach hotels doing a thriving business during June, July and August.

Five hundred persons attending a rally of the Baltic States Freedom Committee last night, on the thirteenth anniversary of Russia's march on Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania, adopted a resolution urging the United States to submit the case of the "enslavement" of the three countries to the United Nations.

TRENTON -- The vacationist or week-end visitor who prefers picturesque rolling hill country and forested mountain slopes to ocean beaches will find plenty of choices in New Jersey. No matter what sort of holiday he has in mind, it is not likely that he will be disappointed.

YOUR critic repudiates the so-called Ibsen-form only to embrace one or other of the equally outdated dramatic modes of the past fifty years. The plays which are the real menace to the living theatre are not the plays built in imitation of Ibsen, whose technique remains one of the finest for convincing delineation of character in all its subtleties, but those built upon the by-products of the plays of Chekhov.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 13 -- Twelve of Suffolk County's smaller incorporated villages, which did not hold elections last March, will choose local officials at the polls on Tuesday.
LONDON, June 13 -- Jim Peters, Britain's 34-year-old Olympic runner, today recorded the fastest time ever for the marathon distance of 26 miles 385 yards.

STANTON, Del., June 13 (AP) -- Scimitar, an improved gray colt owned by the Blue Stone Farm of W. Ellis Johnson of Paoli, Pa., splashed to a thrilling neck victory over the Saxon Stables' top-weighted favorite, Invigorator, in the $31,300 Kent Stakes at Delaware Park today.

IT is a pleasure to welcome to the ofttimes sententious shelves of science fiction a book which displays wit, humor and a slightly bawdy twinkle in the eye of its narrator. Manning Draco, thirty-fifth-century insurance investigator for the Greater Solarian Insurance Company, Monopolated, is a trouble shooter.

A week-end in a Catskill Mountain resort is not, necessarily, the most relaxing thing in the world. There is much to do, many people to see and meet, and many high-calory-count meals to put away. Of course, there is no compulsion, but the temptation is there -- tennis courts, softball diamonds, dancing classes, horseback riding, at least one swimming pool, and sometimes two golf coutBel.

THE natural fibers are much in favor for today's homes. Objects woven of straw, wicker, bamboo, cane, twigs, rattan, reed, rush and other fibers have a cool, light look. This may explain their perpetual popularity in tropical climes as well as their summertime use in more temperate places.

SEOUL, June 13 -- Taking a back seat this week to news of demonstrations here against the armistice and reports of sporadic fighting across the 155-mile front was the problem of rebuilding and rehabilitating this nation of about 20,000,000 people.

SEATTLE, Wasn. -- Passenge-bookings from the Northwest to Alaska may be rather tight this summer as a result of the sinking last fall of the Canadian Pacific's Princess Kathleen. The ship has not been replaced and this leaves just seven vessels to handle the Alaska passenger traffic.

FOUR years ago, Menasha Skulnik, after a rollicking fifteen-year love affair with Second Avenue audiences that showed no signs of abating, told an interviewer that "just once" he would like to do a show on Broadway; then, he vowed, he would be satisfied to return to the bosom of his fervid downtown following for the rest of his days.

HANOVER, N. H., June 13 -- The most striking thing about this aerial whistle-stop tour by President Eisenhower is that he is politicking as effectively as former President Truman ever did. And Mr. Truman was regarded by many as the consummate politician.

A FEW years ago, after considerable failure on my part, I made a survey on growing clematis -- one of the most beautiful of all our flowering vines. This disclosed wide differences of opinion as to the various difficulties I was experiencing and their remedies.
The Union of South Africa, once the land of the Hottentot and the Bushman, today is undergoing an industrial expansion that promises to make it one of the world's great manufacturing powers.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Hard dilemmas have been raised, though on a distant horizon, for the Eisenhower Administration by the nature of the coming peace in Korea and the partial incapacitation of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

The Joint Distribution Committee, the major American Jewish agency aiding distressed Jews overseas, released yesterday its 1952 annual report and announced that it would require a minimum of $25,491,000 in 1953 to carry out its programs on behalf of 185,000 Jewish men, women and children in twenty countries.

THYANGBOCHE MONASTERY, Nepal, June 6 -- The only men ever to have conquered Mount Everest told today how they embraced each other on the icy summit and had a "good look" at the world below before descending twenty minutes later.

According to the American Red Cross, eighty-three perished when a tornado swept through Worcester County, Mass., on Tuesday. Some 2,500 homes were wrecked, from 8,000 to 10,000 persons were without shelter because their homes had been destroyed. The damage done to property is supposed to be not less than $45,000,000 and possibly more than $80,000,000, according to Red Cross guesses.

EVER since schools began teachers occasionally have asked older children to help the younger ones. The bigger children enjoyed the distinction and the smaller ones liked the change, too. Most often, however, the main purpose of such a plan was to relieve the overburdened teacher of a few routine responsibilities.
NAGS HEAD, N. C. -- The ferryboat trip from the North Carolina mainland to the isolated Outer Banks is an experience unique in these United States and a journey back in time.

ACCORDING to legend, four centuries ago a member of Coronado's expedition into Arizona found a fabulously rich gold mine, long since lost. Evan Dawson, a wealthy business man, has organized a scientific expedition to search for the lost mine.

MANHASSET, L. I., June 13 -- The North Shore Hospital, a $4,000,000 voluntary hospital which is scheduled to open the last week in July on the twelve-acre plot donated by John Hay Whitney and his sister, Mrs. Joan Whitney Payson, has been open this week for preview tours by groups from the seven communities that it will serve and whose residents helped to raise the funds.

EDGARTOWN, Mass. -- A lighthouse of interest to landlubbers and seafaring men alike has recently been completed and opened to the public here on the island of Martha's Vineyard. It is the thirty-foot brick tower and lantern erected by the Dukes County Historical Society to house the ninety-eight-year-old Fresnel lens removed from the Gay Head lighthouse last fall when that beacon, long noted in whaling and shipping annals, was modernized and electrified.

Ground was broken yesterday on New York University's Bronx campus for the Gould Student Center. The ceremony, held during the annual Alumni Day, was abbreviated by rain that began to fall as Dr. Henry T. Heald, chancellor, welcomed the graduates and turned to a downpour as he handed the spade to Robert Arum, president of the 1953 University Heights student council.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 13 -- The first Yacht Racing Association championship regatta conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club this season gave victories to, among others, Bill John Jr.'s International, Dodger, her first in the title series, and Fred Hibberd Jr.'s Lightning, Flash, her fifth, and some unscheduled minutes of tension to the race committee today.
Domestic supplies of wheat for the crop year beginning on July 1 promise to be the highest on record.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 13 -- Rain blocked the scheduled start of Princeton's colorful alumni "P-Rade" today, but the torrents failed to dampen the enthusiasm of the 5,000 graduates who had planned to participate.

IF I had not been working with 3-D motion pictures for the last thirty years, and if I were to be called upon to appraise the 3-D movie art based on the current examples, I would doubtless give the art somewhat the same discouraging reports I have been reading.

TO THE EDITOR: With regard to a statement by Robert C. Doty in his article on "The French Family Boursier": "Asnieres has no past; if the Sun King or Napoleon the First ever slept there, the fact has gone unrecorded," it might be noted that in more recent history the name of Asnieres has not gone unrecorded.

KINGSTON -- Of all the resort personnel in the country, one of the most celebrated, most magnetic and most overworked is a gent 134 years old -- a tall, horrendously bearded man who, they claim in these parts, is the poltergeist of the countryside.

BERN, Switzerland, June 13 (AP) -- Switzerland changed her mind and decided today to serve on the Korean armistice and prisoner of war commissions whether or not South Korea accepts the terms hammered out by the Communists and the United Nations Command.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, June 14 (AP) -Street demonstrations in South Korea against a truce reached the point yesterday where two United States soldiers fired carbines over the heads of stone-throwing youths.

CLEVELAND, June 13 -- The Yankees continued today to make a runaway of the American League race. The campaign is only one-third over and the champions, who overwhelmed the runner-up Indians, 9 -- 4, at Municipal Stadium for their sixteenth straight triumph, are eight-and-a-half games ahead of the Cleveland club. Most of the other teams have been outdistanced.

Special economy coach fares for family and group travel, which were scheduled to expire on June 30, will be extended to Dec. 31 on fifteen Eastern railroads that have been offering them for the last year.

WHAT'S new in home freezing? A group of authorities who were asked that question agreed that householders are showing great interest in freezing prepared foods. The Oregon Agricultural Experiment station reported findings on the freezing of cake, especially chocolate cake.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -- The United States is expected to continue its tight ban against exports of strategic materials to Communist China after a Korean truce, it was indicated today. However, there are indications that nonstrategic trade with the Chinese mainland may be permitted.

HONOLULU -- Nineteen hours by air from Honolulu and scarcely more than a day's flying time from San Francisco and Vancouver lies a virtually untapped tourist frontier -- the South Pacific. Lying south of the Equator are hundreds of lovely tropical islands, many of them refreshingly untouched by the modern world and all of them populated by some of the friendliest, most hospitable people to be found anywhere.

BERLIN, June 13 -- The Soviet Union said today that its former Military Control Commission in Soviet-occupied East Germany had been partly to blame for the mistakes that underlay the reversal of the last few days by the East German Government of many of its basic policies.

A FLORIDA Congressman, Charles E. Bennett, Democrat of Jacksonville, is sponsoring a movement which he hopes will result in postal paper bearing vignettes and inscriptions "expressing to the world the sincere desire of the American people for peace."

CAMP LEJEUNE, N. C., June 13 (AP) -- More records tumbled today in the finals of the All-Marine and the All-Navy track and field games. Five records were bettered as West Coast Marines dominated the close of the three-day event.

RONALD ALEXANDER, whose "Time Out for Ginger" will be concluding a successful local run of seven months on June 27 at the Lyceum Theatre, has completed a new comedy that is scheduled for presentation here this fall.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, is preparing to send to the White House soon recommendations dealing with methods of handling security information by all Government departments, agencies and employes, an Administration source disclosed today.

Goucher College will inaugurate this fall an experimental program in elementary teacher training, leading to a master of education degree. To encourage graduates of liberal arts colleges to enter the teaching profession, twenty fellowships have been made available through financial help from the Ford Fund for the Advancement of Education.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 13 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff, Sam Snead and Lloyd Mangrum joined in criticizing their late starting times in the national open golf tournament today and, without mentioning names, hinted that Ben Hogan had received preferential treatment with his 9 A. M. (New York time) start.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 14 -- A strong probability has now begun to appear that the South Korean Government of President Syngman Rhee in the last analysis will not cause a showdown in Korea by forcibly resisting an armistice if the Communist and the United Nations delegations reach agreement and the neutral nations involved act as custodians of war prisoners and as policemen against possible violations of the terms.
CHICAGO, June 13 (UP) -- Sherman Lollar belted a home run with the bases loaded to enable the White Sox to beat the Red Sox, 5 to 2, today and snap a five-game Boston winning streak.

The Architectural League of New York will hold "garden" parties in a setting of natural planting and outdoor sculpture at its Garden Week observance beginning Tuesday. LONDON, June 13 -- The results of the commercial sponsorship of the United States television broadcasts of Queen Elizabeth's coronation were being used by British Labor party leaders today as an argument against the Conservative Government's proposal to introduce commercial television and radio here.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Eisenhower Administration is considering setting up a Federal Agricultural Advisory Commission by Executive Order rather than through legislative action by the Congress.

CUMBERLAND FALLS STATE PARK, Ky., June 13 (AP) -- The president of The Associated Press Managing Editors Association asserted today "we in newspapering are continuing to lose prestige. VACATIONISTS who choose to travel by air to their favorite resorts in the United States, Canada, Mexico and overseas points this summer will find more airline seats available to them than in any previous year.

The plot involves the brother of a notorious outlaw, a tough-handed ranchman and his part-Cherokee stepdaughter, as well as assorted gunmen, oil men, cattlemen and the loyal old broken-down boss wrangler.

When it was all over and we were standing on the pier on this side of the Atlantic again, we still had money in our pockets.

ST. JAMES, L. I., June 13 -- To make it available for most of the current season, work is being speeded toward completion of the public boat basin in St. James Harbor.

MORE than 120 miles of white, sandy New Jersey beach and twenty-one miles of Jersey boardwalk, the most attractive stretch of Atlantic coast line north of Florida, were thrown open to the public on May 30 for the summer vacation season.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- An advisory committee reported today to Harold E. Stassen, Director for Mutual Security, that steps should be taken to curb the fast growth of populations in some regions of Asia, Latin America and elsewhere.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 13 (UP) -- The University of Virginia appeared ready and willing but was silent today on an expected invitation to join a new athletic conference organized by seven former members of the Southern Conference.

THE Mexican War has figured too seldom in historical fiction Mr. Gerson's novel rouses that somewhat torpid conflict from its long siesta and puts zip and vinegar in it. He has done this with a robust yarn of a robust Texan adventurer, one Jonathan Wyatt, a man who has a way with percussion rifles and explosive senoras.

Statistics released by the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference reveal that City College, which won its first title in the 12-year old history of the loop, placed second in the seven-team circuit in batting and next-to-last in team fielding.

HANOVER, N. H., June 13 -- President Eisenhower arrived here at 8 o'clock tonight after a 1,555-mile nonstop flight from Rapid City, S. D., during which he made an aerial survey of the tornado damage at Flint, Mich., and radioed his sympathy and a promise of help to the stricken city.

VIENNA, June 13 (AP) -- Communist Hungary opened up the Iron Curtain today for a group of Western correspondents for the first time since 1949. At least five reporters from United States, British and French news agencies and newspapers were given visas valid for a month.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va. -- This place, not to be confused with Charleston, the West Virginia state capital, is better known to the horse-racing set than to the tourist, for it is the home of the Charles Town race track whose summer meeting opens on July 3 and continues through Aug. 8.

ROME, June l3 -- The Center parties retained control of both the Senate and Chamber in this week's general elections but by such a slim margin that the life of any future Center Government will be precarious in the extreme.
MILWAUKEE, June 13 (AP) -- What's making the Braves so boisterous?
LOS ANGELES, June 13 (AP) -- The Government plans to seize two tankers on charges of illegal registry.

The week just ended was a disturbing one for the peoples of the free world. The fate and future of a brave Ally are in the balance. Never have the Korean people needed to feel our friendship as they do now.

KEENE, N. H., June 13 (AP) -- Dr. Albert C. Johnston, 52 years old, Negro radiologist at Elliot Community Hospital, says he will not fight a request of trustees that he resign because of alleged neglect of duties.

THE American Recording Society, which was established by a grant from the Alice M. Ditson Fund of Columbia University to aid American music, takes the broad-minded view that it is helping the cause by reviving neglected older works as well as bringing forward new ones.
The letter by Arthur Zelvin entitled "Concept of Balance of Power to Preserve Peace Questioned" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 24 points up a very real dilemma of world politics.

BOSTON -- From the Berkshires to the beaches, Massachusetts summer hosts are prepared for a vacation season that will offer tourists a variety of scenes ranging from mountain quietude to seashore surf orchestrations, with lakes, rivers and meadowland in between.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- A combined Oxford and Cambridge track team matched its prowess against four American collegiate squads at Franklin Field today and lost both ends of the double dual meet as the United States athletes achieved fine efforts in field competition and in the shorter running events.
LOS ANGELES, June 13 -- The tide of illegal immigration from Mexico across the United States is continuing its rise to unparalleled levels, and is running nearly double what it was a year ago.

LUMBER operators, trappers and hunters were all invited, back in 1893, to get out and stay out of 2,750 square miles of Ontario. The result is Algonquin Provincial Park, a vast wilderness frequented by bear, beaver, otter, deer, moose, wolves, foxes and other wildlife, to say nothing of thousands of nature lovers.

DALLAS, June 13 -- An early June heat wave slowed department store buying over the Southwest during the last week, but business in general continued to hold steady. Temperatures ranging through the high nineties cut heavily into customer volume. The heat emphasized the seriousness of the drought in parts of Texas.

HARTFORD, Conn. -- Sports car road races, long popular with Europeans but a relative novelty hereabouts, are part of a varied schedule of special events which the State of Connecticut will provide this summer for the 500,000 or more guests it is planning to entertain. On July 4 and 5 the Sports Car Club of America will sponsor road races in the town of Thompson in the eastern part of the state.

Last week's news from Panmunjom, Berlin, Vienna and Moscow was crowded with reports of new Communist gestures toward peace and conciliation. There seems to be little doubt now that the current Soviet peace offensive is the most massive of the post-war period and that it reached a new peak in the past week.

The State Crime Commission has drafted a bill for submission later this month to the special session of the State Legislature, prescribing specific business and labor practices in the crime-ridden Port of New York.

After more than fifty years of unproductive investigations, the world's greatest port is about to be put under government controls designed to drive out its racketeers and corrupt union leaders and eliminate the business practices of some shipping owners who have the ethics of a Barbary pirate and the contempt for human rights of a whip-wielding eighteenth century skipper.

Rain, which had been threatening all day, closed in on Ebbets Field yesterday just after the Dodgers had taken a 2-1 lead over the Cubs in the bottom of the second inning. There was a father-son-crowd of nearly 20,000 in the stands, so the umpires waited one hour and twenty minutes.

I HAVE never been very tolerant of the high claims made for particular subjects as "the best" means of education and training the young. The well-meaning people who talk of education as if it were a substance distributable by coupon in large or small quantities never exhibit any understanding of the truth that you cannot teach anybody anything that he does not want to learn.

HOBOKEN, N. J., June 13 -- This city will hold the first run-off election in its history next Tuesday, when voters of the Second Ward will determine whether Edward J. Murname, former City Commissioner and former County Freeholder, or Mrs. Ethel F. Kelly, a member of the Board of Education, will represent that ward in the new City Council.

LOUIS MacNEICE and W. R. Rodgers, both of them North Irish, both in middle life, and both dealing here with symbols drawn largely from classical mythology, are minor poets of great elegance and considerable power.
TORONTO, June 13 -- Engineers are convinced that Toronto's subway -- due to open late this year -- will be the quietest ever built.

BOTH fiction and non-fiction have brought us many tragic stories of men and women committed to public mental hospitals. Here is a novel whose background is the private mental sanitarium, where there appears greater hope for recovery than in our public institutions.

BONN, Germany, April 13 -- West German imports from the United States declined almost 50 per cent during the first quarter of this year because of restrictive American trade practices, according to W. M. Menne, president of the Association for the Promotion of German-American Trade.

The Joint Review Board of the National Boxing Association and the New York Athletic Commission disclosed yesterday after a conference at the Hotel Astor that promoters of the Archie Moore-Joey Maxim fight for the light-heavyweight championship at Ogden, Utah, June 24, "will be pleased to accept outside supervision of the weigh-in."

JAY VICKERS, writer, discovers that he is a latent mutant. A pawn in the developing struggle between alarmed humanity and the supernormal mutants, Jay helps provide a solution. There are an innumerable number of possible worlds in existence, each a second ahead or behind another.

BOSTON -- New England's colleges and universities, prolific producers of scholars and ivy, offer a particularly rewarding experience in tourism during the next few months for first-time visitors to the region as well as to returning alumni.

The ancient and almost universal custom of hero-worship has met a reversal in Soviet Russia where only a few months ago it flourished in a peculiar form. Hero-worship originally among the Greeks was a cult of the dead, but in Soviet Russia, where so many old customs have been turned upside down, it was also the cult of the living par excellence.

WALT DISNEY, who made the critical gentry and the public sit up and take notice when he released "Fantasia" back in Nov. 1940, is in the process of trying a repeat performance in a present-day projection medium.

FAIRPLAY, Colo. -- This is the season when residents of Colorado's four great mountain parks relax their pre-occupation with raising food to welcome the summer crop of visitors seeking scenic beauty, cool weather, good trout fishing and a change from standardized vacations.

Peron's war on democracy in Argentina is an old story. Years ago he began to strip the universities of professors, however non-political, who refused to do him homage. He corrupted the labor unions, replacing their leaders with stooges. His assault on the free press was dramatized by his destruction of La Prensa.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 13 -- The first export of phosphates from Israel's Negev mines, a trial shipment of 500 tons, is due to leave Haifa for Italy tomorrow, the Government Press Division disclosed today. Officials said the phosphate content of the ore was "higher than originally expected."

EDMUND FULLER, who tills fiction and non-fiction fields, has harrowed the literature of mutiny to compile this book. He does not pretend that it is a complete record, but his selection of mutinous incidents -- twenty-eight in all -- is excellent and varied enough to include mutiny from the days of Rome to modern times.

President Eisenhower will dedicate Sagamore Hill, Theodore Roosevelt's home at Oyster Bay, L. I., as a national shrine this afternoon. The President is scheduled to speak at 5 o'clock. Other speakers will be Governor Dewey, Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, and former President Herbert Hoover.

NIAGARA FALLS -- Among those who relish good vacation country with the same savor that a gourmet reserves for fine wines, western New York State rates along with the best. Long sandy beaches? Lake Ontario and Lake Erie have them. Mountains?
THE trip from Boston along the Massachusetts coast through Plymouth and out to Provincetown on Cape Cod can be entertaining and is certainly educational.

BUYING two or three weeks of summer is not unlike buying a summer suit. A family man shopping around for a vacation place is subject to the same uncertainties, pressures, changes of heart, graceful exiting and final fittings. The summer place (and that suit) must look good, be cool, stylish, cut to taste and inexpensive.

IT'S beginning to look as though the trend toward the curved type of wide screen is bringing about a discernible trend in the subject matter of film stories as well. The feeling here is that the wide screens (in various dimensions) are eminently suited for expansive pictorial exposition, so that producers are searching the Bible once again for the stuff of spectacle.

ENGLISH cricket fans may be happier this summer now that admissions to their game are being exempted from Britain's Entertainments Duty, but it is not likely they will soon be allowed to forget the uproar in Commons before this momentous action was recently taken.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 13 -- Fighting off two strong challenges by Ankaway and Volto Man, Scotch Spencer, driven by Neal Houslet, scored a 2:06 2/5 victory over Ankaway in the Old Westbury junior free-for-all pacing feature before 10,003 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

MADISON, Wis., June 13 (AP) -- Wisconsin Republicans censured their senior Senator, Alexander Wiley, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, today for his refusal to support the proposed Bricker amendment to the United States Constitution.

Business in the first quarter this year forged ahead at an inspiring rate, lifting industrial production to a peacetime high and manufacturers' profits to the best levels in two years. The increased activity was translated into a rise of 9 per cent in the net income of 585 manufacturing companies, which reported a total of $1,531,258,205 for the initial three months of 1953 compared with $1,401,139,836 for the corresponding period a year ago.

ONLY last week this column was deploring the scarcity, in 1953, of detective short stories in book form. Hardly had I written that lament when there appeared a volume of shorts so fresh and satisfying as to be unusually welcome in any year, let alone in this current drought.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 13 -- The visitor to Dixie encounters with swift and dramatic impact the evidences of second-class citizenship imposed on Negroes -- the segregated schools, drinking fountains, local transportation facilities and dining and sleeping accommodations.

Supporters of freer foreign trade policies were assured last week of a "fighting chance" to defeat the proposed enlargement of the Tariff Commission that is included in the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act extension bill scheduled to go before the House tomorrow.

Still reeling under the impact of a series of misadventures that has seen them lose six of their last seven encounters, the Giants yesterday received something of a break though it cost the front office a little more money.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- The Blumhaven Library of Philadelphia, in an effort to spur the search, offered a $5,000 reward today to anyone who discovered the whereabout of a long-lost copy of Abraham Lincoln's Gettysbury Address.

A campaign to raise $11,000,000 for extensive improvements at the 103- year-old University of Rochester is now under way. A new women's center, including residence halls for 450 students, a physical education building and a swimming pool, will be constructed as an essential step in the program to combine the undergraduate men's and women's colleges on one campus under a new coeducational policy.

THE focus of this novel is the crisis in the middle years of Jane and Fletcher Wyant, provoked by an uncommonly exciting Other Woman named Laura Corban. Her husband, Ellis Corban, is assistant to Fletcher, a big gun at the Forman Furnace Corporation, and his specialty is not in making love but in wheedling and conniving his way toward success.

THE Second Annual Osborne Color Transparency Contest, sponsored by the Osborne Company, of Clifton, N. J., calendar publishers, was announced last week by Charles N. Parton, executive vice president of the company.

APPARENTLY there was a time -- March 20, 1935 -- when the author of this seamy chapter of New York social history did think a house was a home. On that day -- a flip through newspaper morgue clippings shows -- the gendarmerie swarmed into a Polly Adler bawdy shop after a bit of tapping on her Wickersham listing and wanted to know who all the girls were.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- In 1842, Midshipman Philip Spencer, a son of John Canfield Spencer, Secretary of War in the cabinet of President John Tyler, was hanged for mutiny by the Navy almost immediately after his trial by court-martial. Even the son of a Cabinet member had no appeal from a death sentence imposed and swiftly executed under military law.

Since ice cream is wet anyway, a sudden downpour didn't deter 700 Boy and Girl Scouts and Camp Fire Girls from consuming it yesterday afternoon when the third annual Junior Jamboree held by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals proved to be something of a washout.

SOMEWHERE in space is a world whose inhabitants live in an atmosphere of sulfur, at a temperature of 2,000 degrees Fahrenheit. To these, the oxygen air and mean temperature of Earth would make it an Iceworld.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Clues to kidnapping of Clem Graver, Republican State Representative, were sought today in Springfield, the capital, as the trail of the three abductors in Chicago turned cold. Mr. Graver was snatched from his garage near his home in the Twenty-first Ward on the West Side Thursday night.

" PERHAPS there was democracy in ancient Athens," writes Hans Kohn, "but it might be difficult to find it in medieval Europe * * *." I am not prepared to argue the question of democracy in medieval Europe, but I suspect there is at least a case for it.

THE Catnip Man, gentle hero of an earlier story by Mrs. Holberg, appears again with his young champions, the Andrews twins. An adult may view Bob and Nancy's tattered friend with something less than enthusiasm, but young readers and listeners share the twins' devotion to him and are equally concerned with his loneliness and poverty.

DETROIT, June 13 -- It often is said that as goes the auto industry so goes the nation's business generally. It used to be said that anything affecting the nation's economy also affected the auto industry.
ASIDE from the ever popular rail trips to the West Coast and the western national parks there are many shorter trips on air-conditioned trains available to the summer vacationist in the East.

I WOULD not want to go on record as being in favor of all roadside signs, some of which blot out the beauties of the landscape. However, as a motorist I do thoroughly approve of one kind of highway sign that has become an integral part of the American highway scene.

THIS year of 1953 could be called -- with only slight inaccuracy, which we shall clear up presently -- the Centennial of Aspirin. It therefore seems fitting that science is celebrating the event, so to speak, by suggesting that this Old Dog Tray of a drug merits study along with the most modern of the "miracle drugs."

THERE is always a genuine thrill of excitement when a ship pulls away from a pier, as every trans-Atlantic ship traveler knows, and this excitement runs as well through the ships that ply the Great Lakes on the summertime cruises.

CLEVELAND, June 13 -- No signs of industrial leveling off are apparent in this area although some business leaders are not so sure that there will not be a letdown late in the third quarter or early in the final three months of the year. In July many plants shut down for vacations and inventory taking.

COLLECTORS of photographs related to a specific subject hitherto have been obliged to rely largely on their individual efforts to track down sources and collections of useful material. The search has been laborious, time-consuming, expensive, generally only partially fruitful and often frustrating.
The Department of Parks Marionette Circus this season will give eighty-eight outdoor performances at seventy-two parks and playgrounds in the five boroughs.

SAY what you will about off-season travel, it is in summer that America goes on vacation. The fullest range of holiday possibilities is open at this time of year; the northern resort areas are active and at the same time, as the result of a new trend, "winter" resorts are welcoming guests at dramatically reduced prices.

An auction sale of French and English furniture, paintings and porcelains, rugs and other decorative and useful objects for the home will be held on Thursday at 11 A. M. at the Plaza Art Galleries, 9 East Fifty-ninth Street.

ROME, June 13 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi is under strong pressure from various quarters to take a decided turn to the Left and widen the base of his future Government to include the Left-Wing Socialists.

THE lead article of a travel section might not be the most politic place to print this, but a firm sense of duty compels one to report that the weather of the United States has been incontrovertibly subversive so far this year, subverting both public morale and the resort business.

Thomas A. Edison, who invented the device in 1877 chiefly for use by business, once said, "I don't want the phonograph sold for amusement purposes." Eldridge Johnson, founder in 1901 of the Victor Talking Machine Company, Camden, N. J., believed the phonograph was a musical instrument that should be in all American homes.

THE Camera Magazine and American Photography, the two oldest amateur periodicals in the field, were purchased last week by Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, publishers of Photography Magazine, and will be discontinued with the August issues.

ATLANTA, June 13 -- Factories in Southeastern states added nearly 86,000 workers to their payrolls in the twelve-month period ending in April, the regional Bureau of Labor Statistics in Atlanta reported this week. Total employment of 1,972,200 reflected over-the-year increases of 51,700 in the non-durable goods segment of industry and 34,100 in the durable goods field.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -- House of Representatives investigators predicted today that Supreme Court Justice Tom C. Clark would be asked to explain his handling of cases when he was Attorney General. A five-man Judiciary subcommittee investigating alleged "irregularities" in law enforcement is sharply split over the question of "inviting" Justice Clark to testify.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 13 -- Contests mark the election in only one of eleven incorporated villages in Nassau County on Tuesday.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 13 -- Nancy Jane Imboden of Scarsdale, winner in the open and American Horse Shows Association medal classes, took the saddle seat horsemanship title at the thirty-seventh Greenwich horse show at the Blind Brook Club today.

MERION, Pa., June 13 -- Champion Braeval Biscuit, a cream-colored miniature poodle owned by the Seafren Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Saunders L. Meade, Malvern, Pa. gained the best-in-show award in the Bryn Mawr Kennel Club thirty-third annual all-breed show today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 13 -- Horacio Lafer resigned today as Minister of Finance. The resignation will be accepted by President Getulio Vargas and a new Minister of Finance will be appointed either today of early next week.
LOS ANGELES, June 13 (UP) -- Senator William F. Knowland warned today that the Korean armistice negotiations might still collapse.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- California business activity was down slightly in April, according to the Wells Fargo index. The April index stood at 302.1, compared with the March index of 303.5. The April figure was still well above the 279.0 index for April, 1952.
EATONTOWN, N. J., June 13 -Cinda, the only filly in the race, was the winner of the Oceanport Handicap, the $19,200 event that served as the feature on the opening-day's card at Monmouth Park today.
Few Britishers understand American merchandising methods as well as does Adam Johnstone, 40-year-old president of the Drake America Corporation.

YOUR correspondent, having flown almost to the doors of the Royal Opera House of this city, arrived here barely in time for the final performance of the 1953 festival season of the Royal Danish Ballet. He was in luck, he thought, for if the arrival was tardy the occasion was perfect as a savoring of one phase of the art of the capital and indeed of the Danish people.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 13 -- A heavy rain that began falling at 12:05 P. M., today forced the postponement of the Princeton-Yale baseball game that was to have decided the Eastern Intercollegiate League championship. The contest will be played at University Field here Tuesday at 2:30 P. M.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Business activity continued at a high level in the Chicago area during April, business indices of the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry revealed. Electric power power production reached a new high mark of 1,333,755,00 kilowatt-hours compared with 1,190,202,000 kilowatt hours in April, 1952. Contracts awarded on building projects for the month were 2,381 this year compared with 1,748 in April, 1952.

WHAT kind of future for South Korea? The human and property toll in a country cruelly ravaged by the three-year war suggests the scope of a problem that will occupy that country and the West for a long time to come: nearly one million civilian casualties, more than three millions of her people displaced, 500,000 of her homes reduced to ashes, a billion and a half dollars of industrial, transport and mining assets destroyed.

OPATIJA, Yugoslavia, June 13 -- The Central Committee of the Yugoslav Union of Communists will meet Tuesday to take up current problems, chiefly the confusion caused among rank-and-file Communists by economic and political changes begun by their leaders in control of the Government.

Although a business partnership is merely an aggregation of individuals, for income tax purposes it is regarded as an accounting entity. While not a taxable entity, a partnership is required to make returns showing the allocation of its income to the partners, and the distributive share of each is taxable to the partner.

THE arrival within a span of one week of three such exceptional films as "Julius Caesar," "Man on a Tightrope" and the Coronation documentary, "A Queen Is Crowned," has devilishly plunged the choice of subject for this Sabbath article upon the determination of eeny, meeny, miney, mo.
The first home for Greek seamen in the Port of New York, the Greek Seamen's House at 261 West Twenty-eighth Street, was formally opened last Wednesday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 13 -- Gov. William G. Stratton, Republican, has devoted the first six months of his administration to eradicating reminders of his Democratic predecessor, Adlai E. Stevenson, and reintroducing "practical politics" into state government.

SHE looked "like somebody's little old grandmother," but in 1861 she was "the most powerful woman in America." Harriet Beecher Stowe didn't really start the Civil War all by herself, as historical novelist Karl Brown in his enthusiasm gives us to understand.

School is out for the last time next week for 850 Hunter College graduates, and many of them will pack four years' memories in a sheepskin and begin to make practical use of their education. Among those who prefer to work for higher degrees, however, are two mothers and one grandmother, who returned to college after absences of from ten to twenty-two years.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Thirty-six women will engage in advanced research projects in the academic year 1953-54 under $63,700 in fellowships awarded today by the American Association of University Women.

IT is good to read a novel about the war in North Africa where the Nazi generals aren't remade knightly (for a while in 1953 they were doing better in the books than on the battlefield). What is more, this small novel is a compact, honest and cleanly told story that pretty much ignores the generals in favor of the people who did the fighting.
The paradox of Israeli and Arab is emphasized at the frontier Israeli kibbutz of Nizanei Oz, just opposite the Arab own of Tulkarm. There, a six-foot-deep trench has been dug across the asphalt road.

SOME writers suffer from literary claustrophobia. Hem them in between four walls and they chafe unhappily. Take the case of James Ramsey Ullman, as outdoor an author as ever broke into print. If the seventeen short stories in this collection prove anything at all, they establish his uneasiness under a roof, even with a martini in his hand.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- A Senate Special Committee reported today that the psychological strategy of the United States was in bad shape, caused mainly by the lack of coordination among the State Department, the Defense Department and the Central Intelligence Agency.

JERUSALEM, June 13 -- Brig. John Bagot Glubb Pasha, commanding general of the Arab Legion, flew here from Amman today for a rare meeting with top United Nations truce officials. It was reported that the discussion covered "ways and means of curbing infiltration and reducing incidents" along the troubled armistice line bounding Israel's occupied territory.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 14 -- The powerful Sioux Indians, who once terrorized the Great Plains and shattered the cream of the United States cavalry, may have attained their dominance through a stroke of fortune.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Nearly 7,000 marchers seeking clemency for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the condemned atomic spies, paraded placards by the White House this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Eisenhower's leadership will be tested at least once, and perhaps twice, in the week ahead in votes on the floor of the House of Representatives.
Representative Jacob K. Javits expressed confidence yesterday that Governor Dewey would support him for Mayor should the forces of "good government" unite on him as a candidate.

Peter and Mercia Ryhiner, big game hunters who have never carried a gun on any of their safaris, arrived in New York last week-end with $50,000 worth of wild animals from Assam, northeast India, for various zoos in the United States.

The New York Pioneer Club athletes picked up two more individual titles when the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships were completed in Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. Three field events, which had been postponed because of the poor conditions caused by Saturday's rain, were decided.

Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union. C. I. O., was denounced yesterday by Controller Lazarus Joseph as a politically motivated, revenge-seeking labor leader whose own followers soon would try to remove him from power.

Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's addresses yesterday at Dartmouth College, from the Columbia Broadcasting System's recording, and at Oyster Bay, L. I., as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 14 -- The two-day program of the thirty-seventh annual Greenwich horse show, marked by competition in ten divisions among 850 entries, ended today at the Blind Brook Polo Club with the presentation of championship rosettes.

It is getting on toward a time of year favorable to the production of postscripts. Postscript writing is a small art that is much neglected; for the most part, postscripts are hastily conceived phrases, often disjointed -- half-formed afterthoughts about persons, or about things done and undone.

Dr. Daniel Bukantz of the Fencers Club successfully defended his national individual foil championship yesterday on the New York Athletic Club strips with ten victories in eleven bouts. Among his victims were Allen Kwartler, runner up, and Ralph Goldstein who placed third.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 14 -- A controversy that threatens to become a partisan political issue with conceivably unfortunate effects on the Pacific Northwest's economy is developing in the field of electric power.

ZURICH, June 14 -- The committee of the International Institute for Banking Research, private body whose membership includes commercial banking executives from fifteen European countries, met in Paris last Wednesday to draft the text of resolutions passed at the fifth semi-annual session of the institute held recently in Milan.

FRANKLIN BOROUGH, N. J., June 14 -- A young couple and a woman passenger in their car were killed here early today when their vehicle collided head-on with another automobile on Route 23 near the intersection of Mabie Street.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Investigating Senators today reported fraud and abuses in imports of more than 60,000,000 bushels of damaged Canadian wheat -- officially classed as "unfit for human consumption."

CLEVELAND, June 14 -- The Yankees achieved their seventeenth and eighteenth consecutive victories and increased their league-lead over Cleveland to ten and one-half games by turning back the Indians, 6 -- 2 and 3 -- 0, before 74,708 fans today.

PARIS, June 14 -- Despite the continuance of the Cabinet crisis, prices in France have remained stable and that fact is considered by observers a hopeful and comforting factor at a time when everything seems shaky.

A year ago the Paley Commission appointed by President Truman to investigate our raw materials position for the future warned that our high-grade, low-cost iron ore supplies from the Lake Superior region were likely to approach exhaustion in the foreseeable future and that our steel industry must depend increasingly "upon deposits of lower grades around Lake Superior" as well as imports.

BERLIN, June 14 -- In the first three days of East Germany's new "gentle" policy, a total of 4,029 persons have been released from prison and 1,500 others are about to be freed, according to an official announcement today.

ST. LOUIS, June 14 (UP) -- Carl Scheib and Cass Michaels combined to give the Athletics a sweep of a double-header with the Browns as they won the second game, 3 -- 1, after taking the opener, 4 -- 1.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- The White Sox won a double-header with the Red Sox, 6 -- 0 and 1 -- 0, today on the pitching performances of Billy Pierce and Sandy Consuegra.

The production of men's clothing during April continued to show substantial increases over the corresponding period of last year, according to Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. Summer suits containing less than 50 per cent wool continued to gain in importance.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 -- "It was the most delicate situation that ever confronted me in my life," admitted Branch Rickey as he studied the ash on his cigar. The Mahatma was discussing his controversial trade of Ralph Kiner to the Chicago Cubs, a deal that is still creating ripples of resentment throughout the Golden Triangle area and into the countryside beyond.

Sellers' markets and "easy dollars" are becoming things of the past, it is asserted by Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly business review, released for publication today.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 14 -- In an emergency effort to reverse the exodus of professionally trained persons, the Government of Jordan has virtually abolished civil service classifications for qualified specialists and will offer instead individual contracts providing salaries as close as possible to those prevailing abroad.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 14 -- Sagamore Hill, home of Theodore Roosevelt, twenty-sixth President of the United States, and its summer capital from 1901 to 1908, became today a national shrine, dedicated by Dwight D. Eisenhower, the thirty-fourth President, and Thomas E. Dewey, Governor of New York.

TOKYO, Monday, June 15 -- Amid mounting indications that a truce in Korea was near, Lieut. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, United States Eighth Army commander, warned last night in an unusual broadcast to United Nations fighting forces that an armistice would not mean that the Korean war was over.

The four municipal colleges, enrolling more than 100,000 students, constitute the largest system of higher education in the United States. New York City has an important stake in these institutions and in the young citizens who attend them. Everything must be done to maintain the highest possible standards.

Critical conditions have developed in the city's prisons because of the inadequacy of existing facilities to care for an increase in inmate population, Commissioner of Corrections Albert Williams warned in his 1952 annual report made public yesterday.
READING, Pa., June 14 (AP) -- Two racing drivers were killed and another was seriously injured today in a ten-car accident at the spring championships at the Fairgrounds.

Despite the popular trend toward specialized fields in education, there appears to be a widespread movement to reinvigorate the ideals of a "liberal education" that embody the broader concepts of knowledge.

CARLSTADT, N. J., June 14 -- An afternoon calendar of sixteen speed-boat races under the auspices of the New Jersey Outboard Association on the Hackensack River brought several ties in the point scoring, but under the new interpretation of rules this season were decided on the fastest of the two heats in each event.
Sir Gladwyn Jebb, United Kingdom delegate to the United Nations, took a skeptical view yesterday of the peace offensive by the Russian Government.
TOKYO, Monday, June 15 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,646, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Monday, Korean time:

Dr. Douglas Southall Freeman, journalist, historian, lecturer, teacher and radio commentator, rose at his usual hour of 2:30 A. M. last Saturday in his Richmond, Va., home, prepared and delivered his 8 o'clock radio news broadcast, and spent the morning working on the sixth volume of his biography of George Washington.

PANAMA, June 11 -- Attorneys for the United States tuna clipper Star Crest have asked Efrain Correa, Captain of the Port (equivalent to Collector of Customs), to reconsider his order confiscating the vessel for alleged violation of Panamanian laws.

If it is a suspicious sign for an American citizen to wish to know something about communism, then the 33,938,285 citizens who voted for Dwight D. Eisenhower last November are guilty by association. President Eisenhower, a former soldier who knows what courage is, urged it upon the students in his commencement address yesterday at Dartmouth.
CHICAGO, June 14 -- A retrograde price movement late in the week erased gains in wheat, the bearish Government June crop estimates on Wednesday having put a damper on any bullish enthusiasm.

Before John St. Clair Harvey sailed for home on Saturday, he hit out at wine retailers in this country. The chairman of John Harvey Sons of Bristol, England, known here for its sherries and ports, said he could name only a dozen retailers in this country who in his opinion really cared about wine.
DETROIT, June 14 (UP) -- Eddie Yost, Mickey Vernon and Jackie Jensen hit home runs today as the Senators defeated the Tigers, 6 to 1, before a crowd of 11,494.

The Rev. Charles E. Book, in his first sermon as a staff member at the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street, declared yesterday that effective religious education was lacking in both the home and the church. He posed the possibility of a "second generation of religious illiterates."

Ricardo Balbiers, unseeded player from Chile, won the Brooklyn men's singles tennis championship yesterday by defeating first-ranked Charles Masterson of Brooklyn, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, in the final-round match at the Knickerbocker Field Club.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- While experienced regatta drivers were pulling off the course and calling quits because of rough water that battered and cracked their fragile little boats, a 24-year-old former G. I. from the Bronx, Edward Fenton, starting his first speed-boat race, made the best time today in the annual Delaware River marathon for outboards.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 14 -- Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, who seized the Presidency of Colombia in a coup yesterday, announced today that a convention called by his predecessor to reform the Constitution would be held tomorrow as scheduled.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 14 -- After six months of preliminaries, a recount of the ballots in last November's Senatorial contest between Senator Dennis Chavez and Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, retired, may get under way this week.

Flag Day, the 176th anniversary of the adoption of the flag by Congress, was observed yesterday in Union Square by the Fourteenth Street Association. It was the first holiday to be celebrated there by the group in its recently announced campaign "to reclaims Union Square for Americans."

The story about beavers sent from Long Ridge, Conn., by Ira Henry Freeman calls for replies from those who are experienced in such things. In my opinion, Fred Patzke and his employer need have no further worries about beaver damage since this bit of publicity has appeared, for publicity is the thing that beavers hate the most.

Eleventh-hour negotiations covering 43,000 Atlantic and Gulf Coast seamen will be resumed today with little chance seen of averting a crippling shipping strike when the present two-year agreement expires at midnight today.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Where's the new mortgage money that lenders were supposed to offer after the Government boosted interest rates nearly six weeks ago ? It hasn't shown up yet.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 14 (AP) -- Fire broke out in a Sao Paulo dry goods store early today and spread to a Negro dance hall above, causing panic and a heavy death toll. Reports of the number of dead varied from sixty-three to seventy. Most were trampled to death or suffocated. Seventy other persons were injured.
THE Sanitation Department's sweep against "litterbugs" the other day aroused the reflection that the town hasn't changed much in 300 years.
