LONDON, June 14 -- The might of Britain's Navy lay at anchor tonight in Spithead as Queen Elizabeth II went aboard the royal yacht Surprise at Portsmouth to spend the night under the big guns that will salute her tomorrow in her coronation review.

A busy summer and fall program has been mapped for Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Native Dancer, the exciting gray galloper who won the $118,600 Belmont Stakes and clinched the 3-year-old championship of 1953.
A lot of cobwebs have been swept out of the American Federation of Labor since George Meany became its president a little more than six months ago.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 -- Steel demand was high last week, operations were still at top levels and there was no sign of an impending decline for the near future. That was the steel industry's answer to Korean cease-fire negotiations -- and to contemplated cuts in the defense program.
NAIOBI, Kenya, June 14 -- The threatened eviction of the hippopotamus from his home waters is beginning to embarrass the Kenya Government.

Dozens of passengers and crewmen aboard ferry boats, excursion craft and other vessels in the Upper Bay witnessed last night a dramatic police rescue of two men who had been tossed into the water when their small sailboat was overturned by strong winds near Bedloes Island.

You need not have gone as far afield as you did in your story of June 2 to describe a good articulation program for children leaving the elementary school at the end of the sixth year. The junior high schools of New York City are able to match very desirable practice you mentioned.

OMAHA, June 14 (AP) -- Charles Eyer's single to center field in the eleventh inning scored Ray Hunt from second base to give Lafayette an 2-1 victory over Boston College the National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball tournament today. The loss eliminated the Eagles.
HANOVER, N. H., June 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of the citation accompanying an honorary degree awarded to President Eisenhower by Dartmouth College today:

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, June 15 -- The South Korean Fifth and Eighth Divisions buckled today under a crushing attack by thousands of Chinese, who rolled back the Korean battle line as much as two miles in some places.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) -- The Air National Guard will triple the number of its tactical and support units in the next three years in a move to step up enlistments.

PUSAN, Korea, June 14 (AP) -- Anti-Communist North Korean prisoners beat one fellow-prisoner to death and injured seven others yesterday when the eight disclosed they were Communists, the United Nations Command said today.

SOME seventy-five miles north of Nairobi, in Kenya Colony, almost exactly on the Equator, stands Mount Kenya, the second highest mountain in Africa. Statistically, Kenya isn't so impressive, as mountains go. There are forty-one higher mountains in South America, thirty-seven in Asia and nine in North America. But Kenya's 17,040-foot summit rises from a tropical plain.

Miguel Najdoff of Buenos Aires, challenger for the chess championship of the western hemisphere, is expected to equal the score of Samuel Reshevsky of New York upon the completion of the seventh game of their match, adjourned after forty moves, according to a report received yesterday through Argentine news sources.

Fear is the basis of modern living, and its misuse has given rise to forces of totalitarianism within and without our nation, the Rev. Dr. Norris L. Tibbetts said yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street. Dr. Tibbetts preached in the absence of Dr. Robert J. McCracken, who is on vacation.

A message of hope for parents and friends of cerebral palsied children is carried in "Courage, Achievement," a new booklet just published by the Department of Health. Photographs with brief captions depict a day with children of a special cerebral palsy class in a public school.

VIENNA, June 14 -- Although there has been much talk of the prospects of increasing trade between the free world and the Communist bloc as a result of the current Soviet "peace offensive," to date there has been no significant growth of such commerce.

LE MANS, France, June 14 (AP) -- Tom Cole, a 31-year-old London-born driver from Sayville, L. I., was killed today as a British team won the twenty-four-hour Le Mans endurance auto race with a record-smashing performance.

The youthful chant "School's out!" will be heard soon in many households. Parents may wonder what they can do to keep their children happily occupied. Easily constructed play equipment for the backyard, utilizing discarded or inexpensive materials, might be one solution to this problem.

The world's basic need today is for "a nucleus of Christian men and women who, day in and day out, rejecting expediency," faithfully obey, at whatever cost to themselves, the divine commands to love God and all the people He created, the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan declared yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Billy Rose is convinced he has discovered a find for his eye-filling production of "Orpheus in the Underworld." To project the leading feminine role of the chaste Diana, a lyric soprano, Susan Yeager, has been signed by Mr. Rose until June, 1956. In the words of the entrepreneur. Miss Yeager is a tall, stunning-looking blonde, who hasn't sung in New York before.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (UP) -- Gran Hamner hit a two-run homer in the seventh inning to lead the Phillies to a 4-1 victory over the Redlegs today after a ninth-inning double by Jim Green-grass defeated the Phils and Robin Roberts, 2 -- 1. in the opener.
PITTSBURGH, June 14 (AP) -- Don Liddle and Bob Buhl, a pair of rookie pitchers, hurled the Braves to victory over the Pirates in a double-header, 7 -- 3 and 8 -- 0, today.

WEST FRANKFORT, Ill., June 14 -- A grim struggle against economic strangulation has stirred the 11,384 citizens of this once thriving mining center in southern Illinois to band together to fight for their city.

WASHINGTON. June 14 (UP) -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, took issue today with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's charge that the recent ammunition investigation "pointed out the general picture of treason."

Property owners strongly object to repeated misstatements by State Housing Commissioner Stichman and Rent Commissioner McGoldrick that tenement owners are permitted sufficient rental increases under the State Rent Law to repair and maintain buildings properly, when the whole purpose and intent of the law is to prevent them from obtaining enough income to meet these costs.
The coup d'etat in Colombia is one of the biggest pieces of news to come out of Latin America in a long time. It may prove to be good-news.

In a widespread effort to stimulate greater purchases of Israel bonds, the Israel Bond Organization began yesterday a "Big (Bonds of Israel Government) Week" to enroll 100,000 subscribers to the bonds "to help the new democracy achieve economic independence."

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 14 -- Sagamore Hill, dedicated for years to the happiness of the six lively children of Theodore Roosevelt, provided a comfortable background for the antics of his great-grand-children today.

PARIS, June 14 -- Minister of Education Andre Marie continued his talks with French political leaders today without winning acceptance of the plans he has been drawing up for dealing with the French financial and political crisis.

The Pacific freight rate war, which has sent tariffs as low as 70 per cent below normal and caused a drop of some 40 per cent in trade in three months, is expected to continue unabated as a result of the United States Supreme Court's refusal last week to grant relief to conference lines on an order restraining use of a dual rate system.
Pockets set their own fashion trend this season according to their shape, treatment and placement on suits, dresses and many casual clothes.

When "even Christians cannot love one another" there can be little hope for peace and goodwill among men, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell told his congregation yesterday in a sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.
Tara Hill came to Rose Hill yesterday afternoon with Uileann pipes, Ceiddidhe bands and colleens bent on jigging in the twenty-first annual Feis of the United Irish Counties Association of New York.
MYERSTOWN, Pa., June 14 (UP) -- The congregation of two Pennsylvania churches today paid their annual rent -- a red rose.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Monday, June 15 -- King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, who has been demanding complete independence for his country within the French Union, arrived here in voluntary exile last night after suddenly crossing the Cambodian-Thailand border with about thirty of his followers and asking permission of Thai frontier guards to proceed to Bangkok.
Keyed to a decorative as well as practical use in the home are some new tables, lamps and clocks assembled by Dart Associates and available in a number of stores.
TOKYO, June 12 -- Japanese industrialists have developed long-range plans to restore this nation to its position as the arsenal of Asia.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California, the acting Republican floor leader in the Senate, said today that the United States should get not only a truce but also a peace treaty in Korea before agreeing to join the Soviet Union in any broad big-power talks on world peace.

Balcour Realties, Inc., sold the apartment house for sixty-two families on plot 154 by 103 feet at 2525 Morris Avenue, near Fordham Road, to an investing client of Louis Gothelf, attorney, in a deal negotiated by Abbott Adams, Inc., and Herman Austin, brokers, for cash over mortgages amounting to $197,000.

CONCORD, Mass., June 14 -- The Puttencove Kennels' white standard poodle, Ch. Blakeen Bali Ha'i, captured best in the show in the thirty-ninth event of the Middlesex County Kennel Club today. The main prize, seventh for the poodle, was gained under the handling of Bob Gorman. The final was judged by Mrs. Mary McCammon.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved within a limited trading range last week, and closed the trading period with insignificant net gains. Friday's final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 2 to 12 points, or 10 cents to 60 cents a bale.

In Italy the Democratic-Center coalition has apparently failed by an eyelash to win a majority of the popular vote for the Chamber of Deputies -- and the "bonus" of 64.5 per cent of the seats provided for under the new electoral law -- in the recent general election.

BAY SHORE, L. I. June 14 -- Bernard Mann's chestnut gelding. Music Master, from Port Washington, L. I., won the open jumper championship at the eighth annual Bay Shore Horse Show on Robbins Field today.

A warning against "unsound booms" has been sounded by Dr. Arthur F. Burns, recently appointed economic adviser to President Eisenhower. He said that the need of action to prevent them was corollary to the need of action against depressions.
Extension of the "no standing, loading or unloading" rule to the two one-way avenues on the West Side will go into effect tomorrow as the necessary 778 signs are installed.
HANOVER, N. H., June 14 -- Standing before one of the largest libraries for undergraduates in the country, President Eisenhower this morning denounced "book burners" and thought control.
LONDON, June 14 (AP) -- Belgium and France advanced to the semi- final round of the European Zone Davis Cup eliminations today with victories over Great Britain and Germany.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) -- The American Civil Liberties Union declared today that the Eisenhower Administration's new employe security program contained "serious defects" that could prevent a "fair hearing."
The public libraries in the United States are in a deplorable condition.

Transactions in the foreign exchange market during the past week were extremely light in comparison with previous weeks. British pound sterling and Canadian dollar moved within a narrow range and at the close had registered only minor changes.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 14 -- To one of the reporters assigned today to cover the dedication of Theodore Roosevelt's home as a national shrine, the occasion had a special meaning. He alone among the nearly 100 members of the "working press" at the event could remember from personal experience the days when reporters spent the summers at Oyster Bay, calling on the former President daily.

Narcotic addiction in adolescents is a symptom of "the serious deprivations suffered by many children living in large and overcrowded cities," according to a report issued yesterday by the Committee on Public Health Relations of the New York Academy of Medicine.

PAZIN, Yugoslavia, June 14 -- President Tito proclaimed today "a great victory" against the Com-inform with the disclosure that the Soviet Union had requested resumption of normal diplomatic relations with Yugoslavia.

ROME, June 14 -- The prolonged political deadlock in France is having visible effects all over Europe. Not only does it delay the Bermuda meeting at a time when it is imperative for the Western Powers to act to concert their policy vis-a-vis the Soviet Union. The American has to be on this side of the Atlantic to perceive just how dangerous the waiting time is and how effectively Moscow is exploiting it.

A special committee of the Senate has now submitted its report on the information services of the United States after almost a year of careful study and first-hand investigation. This report is not a smear on anyone. It is a thoughtful job, and its findings will be, and ought to be, received thoughtfully.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 14 (AP) -- World communism prepared today to open a peace conference here. For the first time since 1950 Western correspondents were invited behind the Iron Curtain to report the meeting. The conference, which for several years has acted as a sounding board for Moscow policies, opens a week of discussions tomorrow.

NEWVILLE, Pa., June 14 (AP) -- A one-and-a-half-hour religious service in a large tent today celebrated the founding of the United Presbyterian Church in America 200 years ago on a farm twenty miles away.

The political reformers of the first half of the twentieth century have met with "certain and total failure" because of their attempt to "rule Almighty God out of human affairs," Auxiliary Bishop James J. Navagh of Raleigh, N. C., declared yesterday in a commencement address at St. John's University in Brooklyn.

Among the experts called into the nation's service by the War Industries Board in World War I was the late Wesley Clair Mitchell, then and during the years that followed, a member of the faculty of Columbia University. Professor Mitchell headed the Price Section of the Board.

SEATTLE, June 14 -- Architects throughout the nation are being kept busy drawing plans for new construction of all types in a continuance of the high level of activity they have enjoyed for almost a decade.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 14 -- The United States as we know it today would not exist except for its universities and the freedom of their faculties "to search for truth and to follow its beacon wherever it takes them," Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, said today in his baccalaureate address to the class of '53.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 14 -- Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale, today announced gifts of about $12,000,000 to the university in the last year.

PARIS, June 14 -- News of the flight of the King of Cambodia into voluntary exile in Thailand as a means of forcing France to grant his country independence was received here with surprise in Government circles.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 14 -- George O. Arkin of New York, grand master of B'rith Abraham, charged here today that "the same forces of bigotry" that gave birth to the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act were "preventing the ratification by the Senate of the genocide convention."
HANOER, N. H., June 14 (AP) -- President Eisenhower allocated $500,000 to Massachusetts, $125,000 to Michigan and $100,000 to Iowa today to aid in tornado and flood relief.
SEOUL, Korea, June 14 -- This hard-pressed country is now moving into a strange twilight area, one that could mean a brooding, troubled peace.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 14 -- Anyone who has had the distinction of winning the United States Open Golf Championship for the fourth time during an unusually arduous week of golf might be expected to take a vacation. Not so Ben Hogan, who won here yesterday with a 5-under-par score of 283. Hogan soon will begin preparations to compete for the first time in the British Open Championship at Carnoustie, Scotland.

SFAX, Tunisia, May 21 -- It took Ibrahim Ben Hamida Zeide forty-eight years of dogged labor to become what he is today, a respected landowner and philanthropist. The road was long and arduous, but the reward made the journey seem easy.

With control and operation of its $1,700,000,000 transit system passing into the hands of the state-mandated New York City Transit Authority at 12:01 A. M. today, and a fare rise by July 30 regarded as inevitable, the city now faces the problem of readjusting fares charged by the nine companies operating private bus lines.

BONN, Germany, June 14 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer warned the people of West Germany today against agreeing, because of the Soviet Government's tactical reversal in East Germany, to a solution of the German problem based on the Potsdam accord.

While the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund is desperately seeking contributions from nation, in particular this nation, to carry out its pledged programs for this year, an anomalous situation has developed in Washington on our intentions.
Brooklyn College conferred degrees on 1,950 graduates yesterday at its twenty-eighth commencement. About 6,000 guests attended the late afternoon ceremony in the campus quadrangle.

MEXICO CITY, June 14 -- The Army's assumption of political power in Colombia may well be the decisive factor in restoring peace to that troubled and unhappy country, ravaged by almost five years of civil war between the Conservatives and the Liberals.

LONDON, June 14 -- The prospect of an early peace in Korea is the dominating influence in the markets here which are behaving more or less according to the different angles from which such a prospect can be viewed.

RUMSON, N. J., June 14 -- The Mardormere Kennels of Glen Head, L. I., had the best-in-show winner of the twenty-third annual event of the Monmouth County Kennel Club today in a greyhound, Ch. Cherry Bounce of Mardormere.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 14 -- The champion in the International Class last year, Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., is well on his way to a repeat triumph in that division in long Island Sound sailing. Mosbacher long has held the respect of other skippers, and Fred Hibberd Jr., 14 years old, rapidly is gaining similar high regard.

The winning streak of Liverpool's touring soccer team, which had extended through thirty games on this continent in three trips, finally came to an end yesterday. The red-shirted booters from England, however, managed to remain unbeaten, gaining a 1-all tie with the Young Boys Club of Berne.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 14 -- Senator Alexander Wiley of Wisconsin, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, warned the Chinese Reds tonight that "they shall not, they must not divert their Korean-based forces toward the south, in the event of an armistice, in the mistaken hope that they can swallow up Southeast Asia without an instantaneous reaction from the world."

The hypothesis that a faction headed by First Deputy Premiers Lavrenti P. Beria and Vyacheslav M. Molotov of the Soviet Union is winning a struggle with another faction headed by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party secretary, is receiving increased consideration in diplomatic circles following the purge of Leonid G. Melnikov, hitherto one of the most powerful men in the Soviet Union.

The Dodgers had a double triumph wrapped up yesterday until shortly before 8 P. M., when Ralph Kiner smacked the twelfth grand-slam homer of his career, tying the score at 6 -- 6 and also matching the National League record for grand slams which for years had been the sole property of Rogers Hornsby.

ROME, June 14 -- Revision of the "Atlantic pact" policy followed by Italy in the last four years and reconsideration of Italy's attitude favoring ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty were among the conditions that Left-Wing Socialist leader Pietro Nenni put forward today for participation of his party in any future center Government.

The Advertising Council has elected Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University, to succeed Dr. James B. Conant on the council's public policy committee. Dr. Conant, former president of Harvard, resigned from the committee when he was named United States High Commissioner to West Germany.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 14 -- Audie Murphy has signed to star in a film based upon his own life. Universal International, to which he is under contract, has purchased the screen rights to his autobiography, "To Hell and Back."

The skies cleared as if by magic at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but aside from bringing out a last-minute sizable gathering of 21,615, the event brought little cheer to the Giants. They blew both ends of the double-header with the Cardinals as Eddie Stanky deftly tripped them with a couple of lefthanders.

All the best thinking on prices over the last twenty years has been crammed into one husky volume by Jules Backman of New York University. He has quoted everybody from Gardiner C. Means to the United States Steel Corporation, from Henry Hazlitt to Alvin H. Hansen. He even takes one trip back into the last century to discover what Alfred Marshall meant by "in the long run."

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 98.7 per cent of the industry's theoretical capacity, indicating production of 2,226,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The actual output last week was 2,208,000 tons of raw steel on an operating rate of 97.9 per cent, down 1.7 points from the preceding week's actual rate.

BERGEN, Norway, June 15 -- Norway's first international music festival came to an end tonight before a wildly enthusiastic audience on the 110th anniversary of the birth of Edovard Grieg, with a program of his compositions interpreted unforgettably by native artists, in the city of his birth.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 15 -- Khwaja Nazimuddin, who was dismissed as Prime Minister two months ago, announced today the formation of an executive committee in the politically powerful Moslem League, of which he is president.

Exhibits by the Atomic Energy Commission, the Federal Civil Defense Administration and eighty-four companies supplying a varied array of materials ranging from balsa wood to the nuclear reactor metal zirconium attracted an estimated 2,300 visitors to the opening yesterday of the five-day Exposition of Basic Materials for Industry at the Grand Central Palace.
Weakness in the wheat and other grain pits disturbed securities investors and traders yesterday, with the result that five of every eight issues traded closed off on line day.

All the benches in a leafy grove in the southeast corner of Bryant Park were filled to capacity yesterday noon, and standees were so numerous there was scarcely foot room for another. The occasion was the opening of the New York Public Library's summer concert season.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture issued a complaint today against Cargill, Inc., Minneapolis grain concern, and Erwin E. Kelm, its vice president, charging that they had "attempted" and "in fact did manipulate" prices of oats on grain markets in 1951 and 1952.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 15 -- British forces fighting the Mau Mau rebels reported today their first really major victory and success of the first stage of the general offensive to smash the Mau Mau. In the week, 125 Mau Mau were killed by British troops and Kikuyu Home Guards tearing their way through a large section of the Aberdare Forest where members of the anti-white terrorist organization have taken refuge and killing everyone they met.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 15 -- Marty Sowle went fishing today at his favorite spot on the harbor breakwater. With his back to the mainland, he sat gazing out at the lighthouse, where he had been the keeper for fifteen years.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 15 -- The American Council for Judaism was denounced here today by B'rith Abraham, national American-Jewish fraternal order, for opposing the State of Israel upon the ground that Judaism is merely a religion.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 15 (AP) -- Humble Oil and Refining Company, the nation's 1952 leader among domestic producers, increased its Texas and New Mexico crude prices today by an average of about 25 cents a barrel.

Charles M. White, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, said yesterday his company expected to announce by the end of this week a steel price increase "which might range between one-fourth and one-half cent a pound."

CHICAGO, June 15 -- A flood of selling orders hit the wheat market again today and caused drastic declines in all deliveries, prices at times being off the 10 cent daily limit. Apparently the selling represented large-scale disposal of lines bought on recent declines on the theory that liquidation had run its course.

CLEVELAND, June 15 -- At the forty-ninth annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America here today, A. H. Motley, publisher of Parade, Sunday newspaper supplement, said domestic and foreign markets must be expanded to avoid a depression after Government spending is reduced.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy said after a White House visit today that the Joint Chiefs of Staff organization did not work too well during the war and he was not sure that it would work at all now. He laughed as he made this comment, however.
A consolidated net income of $2,416,777 for the nine months ended on April 30 was reported yesterday by Northrop Aircraft, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Radioplane Company.

The city's transit system, running millions of dollars in the red, passed yesterday into the control of the state-mandated Transit Authority, which promptly set a small green light on the economy tracks.

PARIS, June 15 -- The executive board of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization voted today to continue until the fall at least its provisional practice of sending the United States loyalty questionnaire along with its own unmodified application form to United States citizens seeking posts on the organization's secretariat.
YONKERS, June 15 -- Low scores marked the play as 114 teams, high for the season, competed at the Hudson River Country Club today in Westchester P. G. A. pro-amateur golf.

LONDON, June 15 (AP) -- London's "big" tennis season got a sloppy start today at the Queen's Club with plenty of rain, injured players and clubhouse chatter on seedings for the main show at Wimbledon next week.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 15 -- King Norodom Sihanouk, who exiled himself from Cambodia to dramatize his country's demand for full independence from France, declared through an official spokesman here today that he would ask Thailand to raise the question of Cambodian independence in the United Nations.

ROME, June 15 -- There neither can nor will be any change in the fundamental lines of Italian foreign policy, based on active participation in the North Atlantic community of nations, according to the magazine Esteri, which usually reflects the opinion of the Foreign Ministry.

New York County Republican leader Thomas J. Curran renewed yesterday his request for time in which to answer Mayor Impellitteri's initial telecast on city hospitals and to reply to the Mayor's future telecasts in the series "How New York City is Run."

The National Broadcasting Company has renewed Margaret Truman's contract for another year. Between July 1 and the end of June, 1954, she will make a total of nine guest appearances on television or radio programs.
ONE day early this season a visiting newspaper man cornered Casey Stengel in the dugout at the Yankee Stadium and soon had him squirming.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Air Force Chief of Staff, said today that less than $1,500,000,000 added to the Administration's budget would "enable the Air Force to continue its build-up to a 143-wing objective."
Both the borrowing and the lending side of the public market for debt securities market backed away from the consummation of public utility bond sales at public sealed bidding yesterday.

TOKYO, June 13 -- A major political battle appears certain to develop in Japan over plans of the industrialists and some Government officials to restore this nation to its former position as Asia's arsenal.

Restoration to nearly normal of several victims of Parkinson's disease, also known as shaking palsy, by a new surgical procedure on the brain was announced here yesterday by the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would hold a hearing on June 24 on whether to deny a Canadian stockbroker's application for permission to do business in the United States.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 15 -- Hapoel Hamizrachi of America, Zionist Labor organization, called upon Soviet Russia today to allow Jews to emigrate from behind the Iron Curtain.

Buyers attending the Work Clothes and Sportswear Show at the New Yorker Hotel have become noticeably price-conscious for their fall merchandise commitments, exhibiting manufacturers reported yesterday.

The occupants of the two opposite wings of City Hall -- Mayor Impellitteri and City Council President Rudolph Halley -- squared off in a verbal slugging match yesterday. Each assailed the other's voting policies in the Board of Estimate.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 15 -- The Yugoslav State Secretariat for Foreign Affairs announced today it had agreed to accept a new Soviet Union Ambassador here and promised to send an ambassador to Moscow shortly, ending a rupture of normal diplomatic relations that began in 1949.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A proposal to increase virtually all mail rates, with a possibility of a 4-cent rate for letters, was outlined by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield at the White House this morning as President Eisenhower conferred with Republican leaders.
TRIESTE, June 15 -- Despite the possibility that with the Italian elections over chances for a solution to the Trieste dispute would improve, a settlement appeared today to be as remote as ever.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 15 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fiftieth anniversary championship got under way today over the Metropolis Country Club's course, with Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge winning the medal.

There is plainly something wrong somewhere when a single member of Congress, merely because he happens to occupy a key position on a legislative committee, can not only use his position to defeat a basic piece of legislation but can actually throttle it by seeing that it doesn't even come to a vote.

A golden, frothy look has been imparted to a new collection of lighting devices called the Claremont group, available through decorators at Lightolier, 11 East Thirty-sixth Street. The collection consists predominantly of ceiling fixtures, with a wall light and a standing lamp included in the group.

BONN, Germany, June 15 -- Reviewing the achievements of the Federal Government's free market economy in the last five years, the Deutsche Industrie Institut reported today that 1,700,000 new jobs were created since the currency reform of June 20, 1948.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- A young dancing instructor here was accused today by Federal authorities of presenting a friend's flat feet in order to avoid military service. The dancing teacher and his friend appeared this morning before Commissioner C. S. Bentley to be charged with draft evasion.
Terrific! Terrific!
Books by Marx, Lenin and Stalin may be borrowed without restrictions or questions in public libraries in thirty cities of the nation checked yesterday by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Chief Judge John Biggs Jr. of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals says the backlog of cases in the Federal District Court of Southern New York is the worst in the country.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The American Association of University Women announced today the compilation of a Money Management portfolio for presentation to the membership at its national convention in Minneapolis June 22 to 26.

CLEVELAND, June 15 -- Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, proposed today that the equivalent of a "political amnesty" in public opinion be established for persons who had joined Communist fronts but then had clearly dissociated themselves before the Berlin Airlift in 1948.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- The Republic Pictures studio in North Hollywood has started a construction program to expand and modernize its facilities. Four new sound stages, covering an area of 250,000 cubic feet, will be added to the fourteen stages now standing, it was announced today by Herbert J. Yates, president, coincident with the start of building.

The Liberal party is not committed to coalition or to any single candidate for Mayor and will enter the second conference on fusion "looking for the best non-partisan, independent Mayor we can find," Adolf A. Berle Jr., State Chairman, said yesterday.

Three hundred business agents of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., in the metropolitan area began yesterday a four-day check of the safety equipment on all trucks and the union credentials of their drivers.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Arthur Gardner of Michigan was sworn in today as Ambassador to Cuba in the presence of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, other high State Department officials and a group of friends.

Bernard Sobol, representing the Pennsylvania Railroad, told Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Brooklyn yesterday that the parent railroad had approved the Long Island Rail Road's offer to pay the City of New York a total of $8,806,000 in settlement of the tax claims against the bankrupt railroad.
TOKYO, June 15 (AP) -- Eighth Army communique, for Sunday's operations:

PITTSBURGH, June 15 (AP) -- Lew Burdette, Braves' relief hurler, hit Third Baseman Danny O'Connell with a pitched ball to force in the winning run in the tenth inning tonight as the Pirates downed Milwaukee, 3 -- 2, and toppled the Braves out of the National League lead. The Braves fell to second place, six percentage points behind the idle Dodgers. Meanwhile, the Pirates snapped a four-game losing streak.

Development of a progressive and liberal trade-tariff policy by the Eisenhower Administration was predicted yesterday by Harry S. Radcliffe, executive vice president of the National Council of American Importers.

PARIS, June 15 (AP) -- Imports of American coal by Western Europe will be cut more than half in 1953 from the 1952 total of 20,200,000 tons, the coal committee of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation estimated in a report made public today.

NEW DELHI, India, June 15 -- Nepal's famous Koirala family shared both good and ill fortune today, two brothers being in jail for defiance of the Government while their half brother was elevated to the Prime Ministership of the tiny Himalayan kingdom for the second time.
SPITHEAD, England, June 15 -- British warships, spread out for seven miles along this windy roadstead, saluted today a slender young woman in white, Queen Elizabeth II.

The effort to bring to book an estimated 10,000 traffic violators gained new impetus yesterday as seventy-one delinquent motorists paid a maximum fine of $50 on each ticket for a total of $9,850, while 203 others who appeared voluntarily paid $3,490 in smaller fines.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 15 -- An international working party representing producers and consumers of tin began meeting here today "to consider proposals for international action regarding tin."

On May 24 a man known only as "Old Mike" died in his two-room, cold-water flat at 35 Allen Street on the Lower East Side. The body was removed to the morgue at Bellevue Hospital. It would have passed eventually into the hands of medical students or been buried in Potter's Field.

The city sold 1,059,468 automobile use tax stamps for $7,338,280 between May 25 and the close of business last night, according to figures compiled by City Collector Alexander E. Frontera. Yesterday was the final day the $5 and $10 auto use tax stickers for 1953-54 could be bought without incurring a penalty.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 15 -- A field of seventy-nine, representing forty-three colleges throughout the country, launched the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships under ideal playing conditions today.

Lord Jowitt's critical appraisal of the Alger Hiss perjury trial. "The Strange Case of Alger Hiss," will be issued by Doubleday on July 17. It was scheduled originally for publication last month, but was withdrawn when some factual errors were discovered in the text.

RYE, N. Y., June 15 -- The Standard-Vacuum Oil Company, a foreign oil producer and distributor and one of several large New York corporations that have sought recently to move their headquarters from overcrowded New York into suburban areas, announced today it would withdraw its rezoning application, which, if approved, would have permitted it to establish a group of administration buildings for 700 executive personnel here.

Charging that Fyke Farmer was an "intruder" and an "interloper," Federal Judge Irhving R. Kaufman denied yesterday the Tennessee attorney's application in behalf of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, condemned atom spies, for a stay of execution and a writ of habeas corpus.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Supreme Court refused today to order new trials for two members of the United States Air Force who received military death sentences for the rape and murder of a girl on Guam.

Aten-acreparcelcomprisingtwoblocksboundedbyBroadway,LaSalleStreet,AmsterdamAvenueandWest123dStreetwasboughtatauctionfromthecityyesterdayfor$1,302,046bytheMorningsideHeightsHousingCorporationforredevelopmentwithcooperativeapartments.

WINNIPEG, June 15 (AP) -- A drop of three cents a bushel in the domestic price of wheat was announced today by the Canadian Wheat Board following a five-cent decline in the world price. The new price is $2.02 a bushel for No. 1 northern, basis in store Fort William.

Negotiations for a new contract between the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., and Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators broke off suddenly late last night amid warnings by Joseph Curran, union president, that 43,000 affected seamen may refuse to sail today.

SANTA FE, N. M., June 15 (UP) -- The State Police today killed two prisoners at the New Mexico State Prison in a gun battle and broke up a riot after convicts had seized twenty guards and a deputy warden as hostages.

New York University has received contributions and pledges of $200,000 for the endowment in perpetuity of a chair of Hebrew Culture and Education, it was announced yesterday. Chancellor Henry. T. Heald will present citations of appreciation to one hundred donors of $1,000 or more at a luncheon tomorrow at the Statler Hotel.

Fifty-nine Salvation Army cadets solemnly dedicated their lives yesterday afternoon to a career of "caring for the poor, feeding the hungry, clothing the naked, loving the unlovable, and befriending those who have no friends."

The first hint of fall fashions comes in mid-summer with the appearance of velvet in accessories. The softness and luster of velvet blend harmoniously with lighter fabrics, such as chiffon, satin and even woven straw.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A House of Representatives Judiciary subcommittee issued an invitation today to Associate Justice Tom C. Clark of the Supreme Court to testify before it concerning unspecified matters that took place during his tenure of office at the Department of Justice.

TRENTON, June 15 -- New Jersey lawmakers at a public hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee heard conflicting views advanced today over the propriety of legalizing bingo, raffles and other minor games of chance. The hearing was held to select one of three proposals to amend the State Constitution.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- The desire of families moving from cities to the suburbs to shop locally is changing the country's buying habits, Mrs. Marie Kiefer, secretary-manager of the National Association of Retail Grocers, said today in her annual report to the group's fifty-fourth annual convention on Navy Pier.

RYE, N. Y., June 15 -- A field of 102 players representing twenty-eight private and prep schools was reduced to a workable list of thirty-one survivors today as the twenty-second Manursing Island Club Eastern Interscholastic Invitation Tennis Tournament plowed through two rounds of singles competition.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 15 -- Princeton University's Class of '53 celebrated Class Day today with traditional pageantry that traces its origins to the university's first commencement in 1748.

There were more than Thomas Campbell's "Mariners of England" in Spithead yesterday off the Isle of Wight as the naval power of Britain assembled for Queen Elizabeth's coronation review. Campbell's England has expanded into a mightier concept, that of the British Commonwealth of Nations.

RANGOON, Burma, June 15 -- U Nu, Prime Minister of Burma, said in an interview here today that he expected no new aggressive moves from Communist China toward Southeast Asian countries if peace is achieved in Korea.
CLEVELAND, June 15 -- Following is the text of the address by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, to the graduating class of John Carroll University here today:

For the first time in the history of the city school system, a high school may be dropped from the rolls. It is Wadleigh High in the Harlem area, which is only two-thirds occupied and is regarded as an unprofitable operation.

Reports that shifts under way in the make-up of Brazil's Cabinet might foreshadow a slackening in that South American country's recent efforts to solve difficult trade problems caused concern among exporters and related banking interests here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 88 Korean war casualties in a new list that reported 14 killed, 45 wounded, 2 missing, 24 captured and 3 injured. The following names were listed for New York and Connecticut (none for New Jersey):

MELBOURNE, June 15 -- Australia's adverse dollar balance is increasing despite great improvement in her general trade balance. During ten months ended May 31 dollar imports were valued at 94,428,000 and dollar exports at only 58,711,000, leaving a deficit of 35,717,000, compared with a deficit of only 27,836,000 during the corresponding period of the last financial year.
GENEVA, N. Y., June 15 -- Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore announced tonight plans for the first project of the Government Affairs Foundation, Inc., of which he is president.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Supreme Court upheld today by 6 to 3 the convictions of Harry A. Stein, Nathan Wissner and Calman Cooper, who were sentenced to death for the slaying of Andrew Petrini in what has become known as "The Reader's Digest Murder Case."

"Loose money" or discretionary spending power held by non-farm families reached a new high of $90,200,000,000 in annual rate during the first quarter of this year, according to the latest marketing memo of Macfadden Publications, Inc.

SEATTLE,June15--Leadingmanufacturersofbuildingmaterialsandequipmentarepreparedtokeeptheiroutputclosetocurrentpeaklevelsinmostlinesinthemonthsjustaheadregardlessoftheoutcomeofnegotiationsforinternationalamity.

The-Fashion Institute of Technology, a junior college for training of technologist and managers in the apparel trades at 225 West Twenty-fourth Street, has named Dr. Lawrence L. Bethel as president, it was announced yesterday by the board of trustees.

After sentencing a young man to a ten-day jail term for causing a disturbance at Ebbets Field last Friday, Magistrate Abner C. Surpless said yesterday in Flatbush court that he thought "maybe a spanking machine" should become part of the court apparatus.

Thursday: "Sunny weather with pleasantly mild temperatures * * *." Eyes went from desk tops out the windows, delighting in the bright sun casting its warm geometrical swatches of light against the other office buildings. Minds slithered away to beaches and mountain retreats, cabins and bungalows, stuffed trunk compartments and winding roads.

The William Church Osborn Memorial Playground was dedicated yesterday with two husky 11-year-olds objecting that the new half-acre recreation site in Central Park had ruined a good sliding pond. The playground, at Eighty-fourth Street just west of Fifth Avenue, features a memorial gate and ornamental fence that was paid for by private subscription as a lasting tribute to Mr. Osborn, one of the city's leading benefactors, who died Jan. 3, 1951.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- In what was hailed at the time as a splendid example of "judicial statesmanship" the Chief Justice of the United States, five years ago, held for the entire Supreme Court that, while the Constitution does not forbid neighbors to make racially restrictive covenants as to occupancy of their properties, judicial enforcement of such covenants transgresses the Constitution.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 15 -- Frank M. McPhee of Youngstown, Ohio, captain of last fall's varsity football team and an all-America end selection for the last two seasons, won today the highest honor Princeton University can confer upon an athlete.

ABOARD THE U. S. S. BALTIMORE, June 15 -- By a fluke of the wind, combined with briskly running seas, the heavy cruiser Baltimore was the first of the ships that cheered Queen Elizabeth II when she reviewed the fleet at Spithead today.

BERLIN, June 15 -- The East German Government announced today new travel regulations that would facilitate family visits between the two parts of Germany and might presage the abolition of the forbidden belt along the inter-zonal border.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 -- Harry Bridges, West Coast longshore leader, greeted the news of the Supreme Court reversal of his case with great jubilation at union headquarters here today.
This country should strive to remove "any and all blemishes" that the Communists have propagandized, Dr. Joseph B. Cavallaro, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, declared here yesterday.

The dismissal of eight public school teachers and six faculty members of city colleges who had refused to answer questions before a Senate subcommittee investigating communism in the country's schools was upheld yesterday in a three-to-two decision by the Appellate Division, Second Department.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Edward T. Stodola, an examiner for the Civil Aeronautics Board, recommended today approval of a merger of Eastern and Colonial Airlines.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 15 -- Natal Province business and industrial leaders held emergency meetings today to consider the implications of a threat by the Nationalist Government to use economic sanctions against Natal to strike at the secession movement led by Senator Heaton Nicholls.

STRASBOURG, France, June 15 -- The first steps toward the building of a new United Europe have been successfully taken and the way to prosperity "comparable to that of America" lies clear ahead, Jean Monnet, president of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, said in a report to the community's Political Assembly, which met here today.
CLEVELAND, June 15 (AP) -- Federal Judge Emerich B. Freed issued a consent judgment today enjoining twenty companies from restricting manufacture and sale of corrugated sheet metal for culverts.

Twosix-storybuildingscontainingsixty-oneapartmentsat163and171EasternParkway,Brooklyn,weresoldbyMaxMiller,HermanL.BricknerandJuliusLangtoA.WalzerandMiltonUydressforinvestmentinadealnegotiatedbyDavidB.Applebaum,brokers,forcashovermortgagesamountingt o$237,500.

Raymond M. Hilliard resigned yesterday as executive director of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City. His move had been expected as a result of the withdrawal from the council of fifty-three Roman Catholic agencies because of the admission of a planned parenthood group.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 -- The Executive Committee of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Alumni Association endorsed today the Institute's action in retaining three professors -- former Communists -- who testified freely before the House of Representatives Un-American Activities Committee.

PARIS, June 15 -- An announcement tonight by Andre Marie, Minister of Education, that after a fourth day spent in consultations he would defer his decision on trying to form a Cabinet aroused fears in political circles that the French crisis was approaching a deadlock.

One can be entirely sympathetic toward the idea of Asian nationalism in general and toward independence for the states of Indo-China in particular and still feel that the gesture of King Norodom of Cambodia in sending himself into exile is badly timed and ill-advised.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Government lost in the Supreme Court today an attempt to revoke the citizenship of Harry Renton Bridges, West Coast labor leader, as a prelude to a new attempt to deport him.
Percy MacKaye's "The Scarecrow," first presented in New York in 1911, will be revived this evening at 8 o'clock at the Theatre de Lys, 121 Christopher Street.

A sharp attack on Congressional proposals 1o increase wine tariffs was made yesterday by Richard L. Blum Jr., president of Julius Wile Sons Co., Inc., large importer of wines and spirits, following a two-month visit to his European suppliers.

The body of a wealthy, eccentric 50-year-old spinster who, the police say, hoarded stock dividends but shunned cash, was found yesterday in the kitchen of the four-story home at 127 East Seventy-first Street, where she lived alone.

THE TIMES of June 11 carries a story by Walter Sullivan which describes the "purge" of Amerika Haus and affiliated libraries in Germany of books by American authors who apparently failed to measure up to the standards of McCarthy's child-wonder thought-police.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 15 (AP) -- Galen Hanover took the lead at the start and never was headed as he scored a two-length victory over favored Power Chief in the Syosset Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

More than 7,000 confectioners, gathering at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for the seventieth convention and twenty-seventh trade show of the National Confectioners Association, heard favorable reports yesterday on tonnage and dollar volume for 1952 and predictions of even better results this year.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- A former Government prosecutor denied today that his Department of Justice supervisor had tried to squelch a 1951 tax scandal inquiry or to punish Charles O'Gara, the assistant United States attorney who exposed the case.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Maurice B. Mitchell of Scarsdale, N. Y., a vice president and a member of the board of directors of the Muzak Corporation, New York, the last three years, has been elected president of Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Inc., Wilmette, Ill.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 16 -- A new demonstration against an armistice broke out in Seoul this afternoon -- this time directed against India, named by the United Nations and Communist truce delegations as the neutral power to guard prisoners who are unwilling to return behind the Iron Curtain after a cease-fire in Korea.
The British Ministry of Materials announced over the week-end that its stocks of zinc remaining for sale will amount to about 70,000 tons by next month after transfers to strategic reserves.

Fifteen fathers, all members of the Grand Lodge of Masons of New York State, are scheduled to donate a pint of blood each to the Red Cross this morning to mark the approach of Father's Day. The blood, to be given at the Blood Donor Center, 70 West Fortieth Street, will be processed into gamma globulin and be used to fight poliomyelitis in children.

Your comments on the exasperating prolongation of the French crisis, like those of most American newspapers, have been extremely tolerant and fair. The slight irony of your editorial of June 12 "Musical Chairs in Paris" is more than justified.

As far as the favorite players at Belmont Park yesterday were concerned, the name of the feature race could have been extended to apply to the entire card. The main attraction was a six-furlong event called the Confectioners Handicap, and this happy choice of a title clarioned the fact that chalk was transformed into candy for the more knowing among the 21,264 on hand.

The date of the Canadian general elections has just been set for Aug. 10 by the Liberal Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent. All signs point to August being a good choice for his party, which has now ruled the Ottawa Parliament uninterruptedly since 1935. As in Britain, Canadian Governments have five-year terms, but an election can be called sooner if the Government is defeated or if the Prime Minister wishes to seize an opportunity.

COMPLAINTS about the weekend fishing, excepting those from the small number who seemed to have picked the wrong place at the right time, were few, and both fresh and salt water provided several surprises.
OCEANPORT, N. J., June 15 (AP) -- J. L. McNight's Blue Rhymer, prepping for Saturday's $20,000 Regret Handicap, captured the $5,000 Oh Susanna purse easily today before 11,194 fans at Monmouth Park.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that between 1946 and 1953 he had collected a total of $723.96 from the Government in pay for accrued unused leave time.

ANSONIA, Conn., June 15 -- Mayor Impellitteri of New York returned to the scene of his boyhood tonight to deliver a high school commencement address and, in doing so, touched off a town-wide scramble for tickets to see the local boy who had made good in the big city.

LONDON, June 15 -- The stock markets were dull today, mainly because investors were awaiting terms of the Government's conversion loan of 100,000,000 ($280,000,000). As the market closed it was announced the issue would be at 3 per cent and would be offered for cash subscription at par.

ATHENS, June 15 -- Premier Alexander Papagos, accompanied by his wife and aides, principally Foreign Minister Stephan Stephanopoulos and Panayotis Sifneos, the Premier's Under Secretary, left today on a Turkish ship for Istanbul. The visit is described as "official" and "courtesy."

A decorating scheme based on texture rather than color has been used in a model home now on view in East Meadow, L. I. The house is one of the first to be built by Sy H. Corak and Michael V. Chaiko in their proposed development of 101 homes to be known as Broad-lawn Estates.

VANCOUVER, June 15 (Canadian Press) -- Sale of United Distillers of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries to the B. C. Distilleries a unit of Distillers Corporation Seagrams, Ltd., has been approved by the directors, A. L. McLennan president of United Distillers of Canada, announced today.
ATLANTA, June 15 (AP) -- Two Professionals and an amateur tied for the medal with four-over-par 75's today in the qualifying round of the twenty-fourth women's Western open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Four Senators asserted today that a proposed constitutional amendment to limit treaty-making power would strip the President of his historic control of foreign relations and tie his hands in the "cold war."

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (UP) -- Gil Turner of Philadelphia, aided by his manager's hunch, handed Johnny Saxton of New York his first defeat in a forty-one bout career tonight with a split ten-round decision.
The cotton futures market was barely steady at the close yesterday, with quotations 7 to 18 points net lower than on last Friday.

TRENTON, June 15 -- A serious and obviously worried Joseph Doto, alias Joe Adonis, notorious racketeer, took the stand today in a desperate attempt to avoid deportation to Italy. Testifying under oath at an immigration hearing in New Jersey State Prison here, he sought for seven hours to convince Government officials that he was a native-born American.

The nursing team, a method of hospital service that brings nurse's aides and practical nurses into conference each day with graduate nurses to plan the care of individual patients, had a public demonstration yesterday at the city's Francis Delafield Hospital, 163d Street and Fort Washington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- In a decision that may have wide application throughout the country, the Supreme Court ruled today that a California home-owner could not be sued for damages for failure to live up to a restrictive racial covenant clause in a real estate contract.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Following is the vote by which the House refused today, 215 to 185, to remove from the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Bill a provision enlarging the Tariff Commission:

Two leading television receiver manufacturers expressed confidence yesterday that their sales in the second half of the year will either match satisfactory first half levels or exceed them. The RCA-Victor division of Radio Corporation of America expects to hold steady in the last six months and CBS-Columbia, Inc., said manufacturing subsidiary of the Columbia Broadcasting System has budgeted for a 50 per cent increase in sales in the twelve months beginning July 1.
Spithead and its broad approaches, the vast reach from the Solent to Southsea and from the Isle of Wight to the Hampshire coast have long epitomized the maritime greatness of Britain.

I have always found your editorial comments to be most stimulating and provocative as well as being possessed of a high degree of literary excellence and oftentimes pungent humor. However, I must remark on your attempt to find humor in the fact that the subway riders of New York will soon be using tokens instead of dimes for their daily rides.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Department of Defense announced today its plans for bringing home from Communist prisoner camps in the Far East up to 5,000 United States military personnel, many of whom have been held captive for almost three years.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Supreme Court rejected today two late-hour legal attempts to obtain a stay of execution for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the condemned atomic spies. However, this evening Justice William O. Douglas agreed to hear a new plea from the Rosenberg lawyers in his chambers tomorrow morning.

The appointment of Frank J. Ewers as vice president of the Prudential Steamship Corporation, operators of regular berth service from the United States to the Mediterranean and the Middle East, was announced here yesterday by Stephen D. Stephanidis, chairman of the board.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission opened an oral hearing today on the railroad industry's plea for preservation of present freight rate levels, after refusing to order a postponement.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 15 -- Yale's baseball team rallied for four runs in its last time at bat to defeat Harvard, 8 -- 5, today before an alumni-day crowd of 5,500. Catcher Jim Rowe decided the game by clouting a three-run homer after Bob Wahlers had tied the score on Phil Mathias' single in the ninth inning.

Initsfirstchangeofownershipsince1866,theoneand two-storyofficebuildingat12-10Broadway,LongIslandCity,Queens,hasbeensoldbyAnnaBrunnerandFrankLangtoHalper,carpentrycontractors.QueensIndustrialswasthebroker,andtitlewasinsuredbytheTitleGuaranteeandTrustCompany.

The Ohio Edison Company and its subsidiary, the Pennsylvania Power Company, showed a consolidated net income for the twelve months to May 31, last, of $17,602,428, compared with the $14,682,839 net reported a year before, the statement revealed yesterday.
The appointment of Col. Sidney H, Bingham by the new Transit Authority as its general operational manager augurs well for all New Yorkers.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -Chief Judge Bolitha L. Laws of United States District Court today gave Interhandel, a Swiss holding company, an additional thirty days to produce papers in connection with its suit for control of General Aniline and Film Corporation.

Negotiating committees representing pier workers and employers agreed yesterday that the controversial shape-up system of water-front hiring must go, but put off efforts to work out a substitute employment formula until July 15.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House of Representatives voted today a one-year extension of the reciprocal trade program that, in a controversial departure, in effect scrapped the nonpartisan character of the Tariff Commission.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 16 -- The Chinese continued today to harass Allied positions on the east-central front in Korea after their massive assault, which had ground two miles into United Nations lines and threatened to reach the Thirty-eighth Parallel, stalled last night under a record-breaking Allied air attack.
CLEVELAND, June 15 (AP) -- A four-for-four player trade with the last-place Tigers today left the Indians still needing what their manager, Al Lopez, wants desperately -- some consistent hitters.

Back in town after charging through the American League opposition for eighteen straight victories, the Yankees will be out to tie the junior loop winning-streak mark tonight when they engage the Browns at the Stadium.

Everybody loves a mystery and, when it involves the sea, it frequently seems all the more fitting somehow. The latest enigma is one that has ichthyologists and oceanographers chewing at their pipestems.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced specifications today for bins to store 50,000,000 bushels of Federal surplus stocks.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- The Senate voted $716,775,000 today for the Agriculture Department in the new fiscal year after defeating an attempt to increase funds for soil conservation payments to farmers.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 15 -- Bob Watson and Pete Cassella, Brookville, clipped eight strokes from par with 32, 32 -- 64, to take the honors in Group I during the Long Island Professional Golfers Association amateur-pro tourney at the North Hempstead Club today.

Butter-rich sweets that keep their flavor even in hot weather and lusciously moist chocolate-coated raisins were among the new developments in candies food editors sampled yesterday at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Host for the occasion was the National Confectioners Association, which is holding its seventieth annual convention here this week.

As the city announced last night that its housing inspectors would begin tomorrow a survey of 600 Harlem dwellings in response to a request by State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman, the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York challenged the principal candidates for Mayor to take the housing issue out of the forthcoming city campaign by agreeing in advance on a housing program.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 15 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, who assumed the Presidency in a bloodless coup Saturday, tonight received the "full support" of the National Convention called by his deposed predecessor to re-form the Colombian Constitution.

CENTRAL FRONT, Korea, June 15 -- The winding dirt roads to the front are clogged with trucks loaded with men bewildered and frightened because they do not know where they are going or what will happen to them. The aid stations and field hospitals are overflowing with wounded soldiers who cry out for help.
Leo Durocher's unpredictable Giants, it develops, have some formidable weapons stowed away, but apparently they are still of mind to keep the matter a secret.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The new, heavy Communist offensive in Korea was described by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, today as a possible serious obstacle to the signing of an armistice agreement in the near future.

Driving errors that cause accidents -- and ways to avoid them -- were outlined yesterday in a safety exhibition and clinic arranged by the Greater New York Safety Council. A group of exhibits, including several testing devices, was shown on the Eighth Avenue concourse of the IND Subway at Forty-second Street.
The City Planning Commission made a special trip to Staten Island yesterday for an informal hearing on proposals for rezoning throughout the city.

Commodity prices were lower on the New York exchanges yesterday following other items, particularly grains. Volume eased from Friday's improved activity in all markets except cocoa, world sugar and coffee. Cocoa, wool, coffee, potatoes, hides, rubber, copper, lead, zinc and tin closed lower.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- John Foster Dulles, the Secretary of State, disclosed today that there had been a literal though small-scale burning of books after Congressional investigations as his department had moved to rid the shelves of its Information Service libraries overseas of works by Communist authors.

The City of Chicago, Ill., sold by negotiation yesterday an issue of $16,000,000 of water works system revenue certificates of indebtedness to a banking group headed by First Boston Corporation, Bear, Stearns Co., Hirsch Co. and Paul H. Davis Co.

PORTSMOUTH, England, June 15 (AP) -- The British submarine Andrew surfaced off the English Channel today after a voyage made under water all the way from Bermuda. The trip covered 2,500 nautical miles (2,875 land miles) and evidently took about two weeks.

Persisting in the adoption of the Nimzowitsch defense in the eighth game of the match for the Western chess championship of the world between Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires, the former played to a draw for the fourth time, according to a report received from Argentina yesterday.

Burglars worked long hours early yesterday morning in the administration building of the Bronx Zoo, but got only an estimated $2,500 in coins from one safe on the second floor. Two other safes, one containing several thousand dollars, showed signs of arduous work with acetylene torch and drill, the police said, but it withstood all efforts of the safecrackers.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 15 -- Communist China accused the United States today of encouraging Dr. Syngman Rhee of intriguing to sabotage a Korean armistice agreement as the World Peace Council, an unofficial organization supported by the Soviet Union and its admirers, opened its fourth session there.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 15 -- Elgin B. Robertson, president of Elgin B. Robertson, Inc., of Dallas, Tex., has been elected president of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, it was announced here today at the opening session of the group's summer general meeting.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The trend to peace and goodwill among union leaders seems to have reached the ultimate in an exchange of brotherly letters between Joe Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., and Harry Lundeberg, who directs the Seafarers International Union and the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L.
Charles I-I. Wulf has been made vice president and general manager of the G. N. Coughlan Comi Pany, West 0rlge, N. J., maker of household chemicals.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner to Germany, predicted today that the six-nation European Defense Community treaties would be ratified within a year. The plan calls for establishment of a defense army that would include German soldiers along with those from five other nations.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "Pickup on South Street," a Twentieth Century-Fox melodrama with Richard Widmark, Jean Peters, Thelma Ritter and Murvyn Vye, is at the Roxy. Samuel Fuller directed and Jules Schermer produced from a screen play written by Mr. Fuller and a story by Dwight Taylor.

Useful the year round for holding the flowers and greens that give a fresh touch to a room, new ceramic vases, available in shops here, come in a variety of designs that might make them suitable for decorative objects when not filled with blooms.

BERLIN, Wednesday, June 17 -- Soviet-controlled East Berlin was in a ferment last night after thousands of construction workers had marched through the streets shouting anti-Government slogans and calling for a general strike at 7 A. M. today.

Since Percy MacKaye wrote "The Scarecrow" in 1908, no one expects it to epitomize the modern comic spirit. But in the performance put on at the Theatre de Lys last evening, it represents something else that is also interesting. It represents the romantic theatre of pure imagination.
The Federal Government will be asked to pay the bill for the new waterfront employment centers to be set up under the pier reform bills being drafted by state leaders in New York and New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee indicated today that it planned to leave to state, local or institutional authorities the task of searching for Communists among teachers in schools and colleges in areas where determined action against Reds in classrooms had been demonstrated.

Check collections among approximately 3,000 banks in six major cities will be speeded soon by establishment of a new ground-air shipment network announced yesterday by a New York company which specializes in check transit operations.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 16 -- As the climax to its 175th anniversary, Louisville is staging an outdoor drama entitled "The Tall Kentuckian," which opened last evening in the Iroquois Amphitheatre. Compounded of drama, music and dancing it chronicles most of the life of that tall Kentuckian, Abraham Lincoln, who moved on to Illinois when he was still a boy and went to Washington many years later when he was a man.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 16 -- Registering four unearned markers, three of them in the sixth inning, Princeton captured the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League crown today by halting Yale, 4 -- 2, in the final of a round-robin elimination play-off.

With the average increase of about 25 cents a barrel in crude oil prices in the mid-continent and the Southwest now having been met by most leading purchasers, higher prices for gasoline, fuel oil and other petroleum products appear to be in prospect.

In the summer of 1919 a young man who had joined the staff of Alfred E. Smith, then Governor, to help work out plans for reorganizing the state government used to stroll occasionally along a ribbon of land in Flushing, Queens, known as the Kissena Corridor.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 16 -- Ilya Ehrenburg, well-known Soviet writer and propagandist, made a speech this afternoon at the World Peace Council containing several phrases that might have been uttered by an orator or statesman in the Western World.

Ambitious plans of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service to rid Alaska of wolves were received with some coolness here yesterday at the opening of the thirty-third annual meeting of the American Society of Mammalogists.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 16 -- The body of a registered nurse, identified as Una Beatrice Eisan, 36 years old, from East Orange, N. J., was found on a lonely path at West Beach early this morning. The victim of what the police say was a rape attempt had been struck on the head several times with a sharp object and then run over by a car, according to Dr. Frank C. McMahon, medical examiner.

LONDON, June 16 -- The stock markets continued quietly dull today. Business remained sparse partly because of uncertainty caused by the Communist offensive in Korea. Hence a little selling sufficed to depress prices.

PIERMONT, N. Y., June 16 -- John P. Micklas of near-by Tappan, N. Y., was convinced today that somewhere in this municipality there is a snake in the grass who put a snake in his car. The episode ended at 4 P. M. when John Orth, curator of the Bear Mountain Trailside Museum, identified the reptile as a harmless garter snake.

The annual two-day flower show of the Second District (Long Island) Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., opened yesterday at 2:30 P. M. in Cathedral House, Cathedral Avenue, Garden City. Members of the eighty-eight garden clubs on Long Island created more than 125 individual flower arrangements to illustrate the theme of the show, "June Is for Brides."

THE Nova Scotia salmon fishing is showing a definite improvement over that of recent years, and a number of anglers who are unable to afford the more expensive leased-water fishing of Quebec and New Brunswick seem to be turning to the open waters of this province.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A demand for early French assurance of independence to Indo-China featured a report today from the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives on the $4,998,000,000 Mutual Security authorization bill providing military, economic and technical foreign aid in the fiscal year 1954.

Edward L. Warner, former co-captain of the City College basketball team who served six months in jail after admitting his part in "throwing" games, testified yesterday that there had been an "understanding" that he and other players would be paid for a tour of South America in the summer of 1950.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 16 -- The first of two eighteen-hole qualifying rounds in the thirty-seventh annual Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association championship was completed today over the Yale Golf Club course.

TRENTON, June 16 -- Joseph Doto, alias Joe Adonis, categorically declared here today for the first time since the start of the present deportation proceedings against him that he is an American citizen.

The baseball season's longest winning and losing streaks ended simultaneously last night at Yankee Stadium, where a surprising reversal of their usual roles saw the lowly Browns, who had lost fourteen straight games, register a 3-1 upset over the first-place Yankees, who had won eighteen in a row.

Louis A. Siegel, president of the coat and suit manufacturing company of Leeds, Ltd., has been elected president of the Educational Foundation for the Apparel Industry, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the board of directors of the Fashion Institute of Technology.

THE most gratifying part about the recent United States Open -- for this reporter anyway -- was the opportunity it afforded for a rare glimpse inside of Ben Hogan. It was almost as if Blazin' Ben raised up his motor hood for the very first time and exposed to view the intricate, delicate mechanism of sports' finest golfing machine.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- A single by Bob Elliott in the eleventh, followed by Ferris Fain's triple with the bases filled, scored four runs for the White Sox as they tightened their grip on third place by defeating the Senators, 7 to 3, tonight.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 16 (AP) -- The national convention of Brith Sholom, a fraternal order, today urged the United Nations and all democratic countries to use their power to bring persecuted Jews from under the yoke of Russia and her satellites.

A number of children now considered "unadoptable" by social agencies might be placed with good chances of success if more professional workers in the adoption field would modify their current thinking and attitudes about "risky" placements, according to Ruth Taft, director of the adoption department, Children's Services of Connecticut, at Hartford.
The bounty of June includes, the first fresh green peas from nearby gardens. Except for corn on the cob, no other vegetable benefits so much from a short interval between the harvest and the table.

PARIS, June 16 -- The growing protest here against execution of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, convicted in the United States as spies, represents an odd combination of humanitarian and political motives. It reflects a revulsion against the death sentence for espionage in peace time, disturst of justice in the United States and a desire to show that United States officials have been led into error by an unduly passionate pursuit of the "cold war."

Twelve fathers, all members of the Grand Lodge of Masons of New York State, gave blood yesterday at the Red Cross center at 70 West Fortieth Street as their contribution to the observance of Father's Day on Sunday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 16 -- Westchester County postmen walked their routes a second time tonight, making the extra trip after hours to collect $40,000 in contributions for the United Cerebral Palsy Association of Southern Westchester.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The home building industry told Congress today that there would be a cutback in housing starts, resulting unemployment and possible depression if the terms of Government-insured mortgages were not liberalized.

Turkey has agreed to pay Britain 7,500,000 ($21,600,000) in seven and one-half years in settlement of her debt for military equipment and materiel supplied by London before and during World War II, it became known in New York yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Congressional tax writers lent a sympathetic ear today to pleas for income tax deductions to offset child-care expenses of working mothers

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Senate today passed and sent to the White House a two-year extension of the doctor draft law. In effect, it frees from any draft liability all physicians who have served on active duty at any capacity for seventeen months since Sept. 16, 1940.

LONDON, June 16 -- Back to austerity, back to controls and back to socialism seemed to be the keynotes of the 1953 policy statement issued today by the National Executive Committee of the British Labor party.

CHICAGO, June l6 -- Members of the Illinois House of Representatives in Springfield moved today to throw the weight of the Legislature and the power of the State Treasury behind the search for Representative Clem Graver, Republican of Chicago, who was kidnapped near his home on the West Side last Thursday.

CLEVELAND, June 16 -- The Advertising Federation of America re-elected top officers, elevated three men to advertising's "Hall of Fame," presented awards to three winners of the A. F. A. essay contest and selected Boston as the site of its 1954 convention at tonight's session of the organization's forty-ninth annual convention.

Many manufacturers are losing sales because they have not "engineered" their merchandising efforts to the consumer level, it was asserted yesterday by Morris L. Levinson, president of the Kaywoodie Company, pipe manufacturer. At the same time, he said, few producers make sufficient effort to impart to their distributors valuable sales lessons learned through years of experience.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 16 (AP) -- Prince Eton scored a wire-to-wire victory tonight in the Galvanizers Special Pace at Roosevelt Raceway, holding off the fast-closing Imprudent by a neck.
