Modern industrial and defense production technology is putting increasing emphasis on the search for materials which can meet the requirements of an "almost universal trend toward higher operating temperatures," a naval research official declared yesterday at the opening session Of the Basic Materials Conference at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The fight to save Julius and Ethel Rosenberg from death in the electric chair was waged in high places in Washington today. The couple has been sentenced to die in Sing Sing prison on Thursday for betraying secrets of the atom bomb to Soviet Russia.

ROME, June 16 -- Something of a sensation was caused in political circles this morning when L'Unita, Communist party newspaper, published an article by Palmiro Togliatti in which the Communist leader warned the left-wing Socialist leader, Pietro Nenni, that he would "break his political neck" if he consented to participate in a center government.

Brake trouble caused a fifty-minute tie-up on the Broadway line of the I. R. T. subway between Ninety-sixth and 125th Streets, yesterday, in the morning rush hour. It was believed to be the first mishap since the new Transit Authority took over operation of the municipal system.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles has disavowed a department document that the Congress of Industrial Organizations had protested as "shockingly anti-labor."

ATLANTIC CITY, June 16 -- Irving L. Hodes, attorney of Newark, N. J., was unanimously elected grand master of B'rith Abraham at the closing session today of the three-day annual convention of the fraternal order.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 16 -- The annual Long Island Father and Son golf championship resulted in a deadlock at the Hempstead Golf Club today as three teams posted net scores of 65.

Business generally, and the candy business in particular, has no reason to fear any decline in Government spending. This declaration was made yesterday by H. B. McCoy, acting administrator of the National Production Authority, which is soon to be merged into a Business Services Agency in the Department of Commerce.

Arthur Godfrey, currently confined to a Boston hospital where he underwent a major operation on his right hip last month, plans to make television appearances from his farm home near Leesburg, Va., during a period of convalescence.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, said today there was no difference in "purpose" between him and President Eisenhower on the so-called Bricker constitutional amendment to curb Presidential treaty-making powers.

CINCINNATI, June 16 -- The Giants got off to a sprightly start on their fourteen-game Western tour tonight as they toppled Manager Rogers Hornsby's Redlegs, 7 to 5, in the opener of a twilight-night double-header before a crowd of 18,509.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 16 -- The two men appointed Monday by President Sukarno to resolve the country's thirteen-day-old cabinet crisis met today for the first time in what they described as a "cordial atmosphere."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 16 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council opened its twelfth session here today to review reports on territories in the Pacific area under the Council's aegis, and to examine 400 petitions from inhabitants of these and other trust territories in Africa.

The Supreme Court of the United States has come to the end of its regular term after some nine months, more or less, during which no modern counterpart of the Dred Scott decision or the Dartmouth College case appeared upon its records. The Court, like the rest of us, is feeling its way through a period in which it is often hard to make up one's mind.

A three-week tour of the United States will be begun soon by Dr. Hans Ehard, Minister President of Bavaria, he announced yesterday as he arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on a Trans World Airlines plane.

Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the Faculty of Medicine at Columbia University, accused the state yesterday of "abdicating" on essential medical standards and surrendering to "mediocrity" by repealing, in effect, educational requirements for internes and residents in hospitals.

Cooling sprays from flow of water through hydrants controlled by newly-installed devices will be provided for youngsters seeking relief from heat in the summer. According to Dominick F. Paduano, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, the city will foot the bill for the showers.

The monthly policy meeting of the governors of the New York Stock Exchange slated for tomorrow holds more than its usual share of interest for commission houses. The board is expected to take action on the proposed schedule of new commission charges which it is believed would bring in 12.5 per cent more revenue, a welcome relief in these days of small volume.

The Avon, a cozy theatre at 251 West Forty-fifth Street, has been sold by the Columbia Broadcasting System to Abraham and Frederick Dreier. The deal was confirmed yesterday by Abraham Dreier, who operates a national chain of sixteen hotels, including the Piccadilly, Plymouth and Riverside-Plaza in New York, with his son, Frederick.

PARIS, June 16 -- The executive board of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization has chosen Dr. Luther H. Evans, librarian of Congress, as its candidate for the post of Director General. A special conference of the member states on July 1 is expected to approve the board's choice.

RYE, N. Y., June 16 -- The ousting of three more seeded players, including the top-rated Peter Pressinger, representing The Hill, featured the Eastern Interscholastic tennis championships for private schools today at the Manursing Island Club.

PARIS, June 16 -- Speaker Edouard Herriot today summoned the French National Assembly to meet Thursday morning to pass on the designation of Andre Marie, Minister of Education and hero of the French resistance, as the next Premier of France.

A new microwave transmission system for the operation of communications, railroad switching and signalling will be installed on the ninety-mile railway now under construction to haul iron ore from the United States Steel Corporation's new mine in Venezuela, it was announced yesterday. The railway will run from the Cerro Bolivar mine to the harbor in Puerto Ordaz.
The only hope of saving the lives of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg seems to be the granting of clemency by the President.

ATLANTA, June 16 (AP) -- Patty Berg rallied to defeat Betty Jameson in nineteen holes today to keep intact the list of favorites who scored victories in the first round of the women's Western open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Inter-American Commission of Women held a noon ceremony today to celebrate twenty-five years of progress and the signing today of the agreement that established the commission as a specialized unit of the Organization of American States.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, announced yesterday that incomplete returns from a postcard poll among enrolled Democrats in Manhattan showed that 79.2 per cent of those replying do not want Mayor Impellitteri as the Democratic candidate for Mayor this year.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Conferees of the Senate and House of Representatives reached agreement today on a bill extending the Defense Production Act for two years to June 30, 1955, but without authority for price, wage or credit control.

The Ford Motor Company is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary. To be sure, its most famous product, the Model T, has been obsolete for a quarter of a century, but its introduction was a historic technologic event. Henry Ford did not invent the automobile nor even any part of it.

Cleverly planned by well-known designers to be easily executed by the blind, summer aprons, bags and baskets were shown yesterday afternoon at the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

The one-story taxpayer at 4539 Third Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Ettinger Brothers to Nathan Cohen and Milton Weiss, who will occupy the premises for their wholesale and retail greeting card business. The sellers, now retiring from business, had occupied the property as a department store for forty-seven years.

Refuse to Heed Conference Call -- Moslems in North in Split With South' s Nationalists LAGOS, Nigeria, June 15 (Reuters) -- Two prominent Nigerian Nationalists said today that they would declare the colony's independence, "whatever the consequences," if Nigeria did not receive dominion status by 1956.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 -- Accounting is in the electronic age -- to such an extent that there is a tendency to flood management with so much data that important facts may be obscured. Joseph Pelej, partner in the New York firm of Price Waterhouse Co., so reported today at the opening technical session of the thirty-fourth international conference of the National Association of Cost Accountants here.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The English Electric Export and Trading Company, Ltd., has been awarded part of a contract for hydro-electric equipment for the Chief Joseph Dam at Brewster, Wash., it was announced today at the Pentagon.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 11 -- The Belgian Sabena Air Line, which already operates services raging from trans-Atlantic flights down to local helicopter mail-carrying, now plans to serve the man in the street who wants to go short distances in a hurry.

The American National Theatre and Academy, a nonprofit group chartered by Congress in 1935, completed yesterday a two-day session at the Carlyle Hotel. Among its actions were the adoption of two resolutions. One assigned top priority to Warren Caro's pilot project in establishing resident stage groups outside of New York.

The Soviet press yesterday for the first time devoted special attention to the Rosenberg case. Under such headlines as "The Affair of the Rosenberg Couple," leading newspapers in Moscow ran a dispatch of the Tass News Agency in New York.

ALBANY, June 16 -- Governor Dewey presented a framed citation today to Mrs. Richard Kelly, a housewife from near-by Watervliet, as the one-millionth person to receive a free chest X-ray since the state inaugurated its anti-tuberculosis program nearly six years ago.

PITTSBURGH, June 16 (AP) -- A Westinghouse Electric Corporation official told 8,000 employes at a mass meeting today that the awarding of Government contracts to foreign concerns was endangering the jobs of American workers.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 16 -- Burmese and Chinese Nationalist representatives attending a four-nation military conference here have begun discussing a tentative United States draft of a proposed joint agreement for the evacuation of Gen. Li Mi's Chinese Nationalist guerrillas from eastern Burma, it was announced today.

Forty-two foreign Girl Guides and exchange camp counselors arrived here yesterday aboard the liner United States to spend the summer in Girl Scout homes and camps. They came as guests of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America and their visit is being made possible through the Juliette Low World Friendship Fund.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Senate approved unanimously today the Eisenhower Administration's bill to give 1,000,000 tons, or about 37,300,000 bushels, of wheat to Pakistan to end hunger and avoid political instability there.

ST. LOUIS, June 16 -- A seventh-inning single to right by Rip Repulski, which scored Steve Bilko from second base, broke a tie that had held from the fourth inning and enabled the Cardinals to gain a 6-5 triumph over the Dodgers tonight before a Busch Stadium crowd of 28,974.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today, 13 to 2, proposed legislation to authorize the United States to join with Canada in constructing the St. Lawrence Seaway. The bill approved is identical to one on which a hearing is being held by the House Public Works Committee.

New York's record on public housing cannot be matched by any other city in the nation and it is a generation ahead in breaking down discriminatory housing barriers, Mayor Impellitteri said last night in the second of his series of television talks on city affairs.
Gross operating income increased nearly 14 per cent and net income about 13 per cent in the fiscal year ended on April 30, the Cosden Petroleum Corporation reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- Liquor retailers told Congress today that whisky was being sold at almost all military bases at wholesale prices despite a 1901 law forbidding the practice.

Representatives of six of the nation's symphony orchestras agreed yesterday to poll the other orchestras of the country for their views on the establishment of a Federal Department of Fine Arts, with the head of the department an officer of Cabinet rank.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 16 (UP) -- President Getulio Vargas faced a major Cabinet crisis today with the resignation of six of his ten ministers. A seventh minister, now in Paris, also was said to have cabled his resignation.

Two youngsters found $120 while bicycle riding on East Fiftieth Street near the East River yesterday and promptly turned it over to the police because their "consciences" would have bothered them otherwise, they said. Then one boy returned to the scene after his supper to find another $50, bringing the total to $170.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Rear Admiral R. E. Wilson, deputy Commander of the Military Sea Transportation Service, today recommended a merchant fleet construction program of 214 vessels, made up of 165 cargo ships, six passenger ships and forty-three tankers.

ROME, June 16 -- What worries non-Communist Italians most as they digest the election results is the continuing strength of the Communists. The vote of the extreme Left exceeds their total in the national poll of 1948. When a third of the population of the oldest Western state votes Communist in spite of improved conditions the phenomenon naturally causes bewilderment throughout the free world and acute anxiety among the people most closely concerned.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Howie Pollet and Johhy Klippstein scattered five hits in pitching the Cubs to a 3 -- 2 victory over Pittsburgh before 11,427 today after the Pirates had won the opener of the double-header, 6 -- 5.

Stock prices sagged yesterday to their lowest levels in thirteen months, but rallied in late dealings. The late gains, which coincided with a strong recovery in the grain markets, were not sufficient however to wipe out all the damage sustained early in the day.
BONN, Germany, June 16 -- The workers' demonstrations in East Berlin today jarred West Germans out of their complacency and smugness born of increasing prosperity.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, June 17 -- Allied forces appeared today to have checked the big Chinese Communist pre-armistice drive along the east-central Korean front.

Little pictures by orphaned South Korean children, made as tokens of gratitude for their contemporaries here who have helped provide clothing for them, were turned over yesterday to representatives of four national youth organizations.

Additional preferred and common stocks of the Kansas Power and Light Company are being offered publicly today in a dual financing operation undertaken on behalf of the company by investment banking groups headed by the First Boston Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 136 Korean war casualties in a new list that reported 19 killed, 101 wounded, 10 captured and six injured. The following names were listed for New York and New Jersey (none for Connecticut):
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 -- Eleven newspaper men and one woman were announced today as winners of Nieman Fellowships for study at Harvard University during the college year starting next September.

The thirty-four national and local Jewish agencies associated in the National Community Relations Advisory Council issued a statement yesterday describing the Supreme Court's decision on Monday concerning restrictive racial covenants in real estate contracts "a further blow against racial and religious ghettoes in American life."

MADRID, June 16 -- Ambassador James C. Dunn told United States and Spanish business men tonight that he expected an increase in investments of private capital in Spain to follow the conclusion of United States-Spanish military and economic agreements.

BOSTON, June 16 (UP) -- Ray Boone, acquired twenty-four hours ago in a trade with Cleveland, achieved a brilliant performance for Detroit tonight as he led the Tigers to a 5-3 victory over the Red Sox before 19,151 at Fenway Park.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- The wheat market staged its most spectacular recovery in several months today, with indications that investment buying had at last swung into the pit. Lower prices were registered in the early trade, but in the last hour the demand became urgent.

MANILA, Wednesday, June 17 (AP) -- General Carlos P. Romulo, Democratic party candidate for President of the Philippines, last night rejected an offer by Ramon Magsaysay, Nacionalista party candidate, to join forces against President Elpidio Quirino, Liberal party candidate for re-election.

BAYONNE, N. J., June 16 -- A crusade started last March by a housewife in this city to make the basic costs of college education deductible income tax items has resulted in an invitation to present her views to the House Ways and Means Committee in Washington on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Eisenhower's denunciation of book burning and thought control, in a speech at Dartmouth College on Sunday, has brought limited public reaction to the White House. But the telegrams and letters thus far support the President overwhelmingly.

LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- Australia's Ken Rosewall and three Americans advanced today into the third round of the Queens Club lawn tennis tournament -- the major test leading to the Wimbledon championships June 22 -- July 4.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Paik Too Chin, Premier of South Korea, arrived at National Airport this evening for informal talks with American officials on problems separating the United States and the Seoul Government on the terms of a Korean truce.

MEXICO CITY, June 16 -- The State Department's instructions to its diplomatic missions regarding the removal of books from United States libraries throughout the world apparently carry the kind of security classification that might be expected on wartime troop movements.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 16 -- The upset of the fourth-seeded today marked the second day of competition in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships being held on the Military Academy's clay courts for the second successive year.
It was 4 P. M. and the four "Little Women" were having tea.

KRUININGEN, the Netherlands, June 13 -- Daily at the hour of low tide, a railroad stationmaster stands at the end of the line here. In his hand is a table of the tides, on his feet are rubber boots. Near by stand two locomotives ready to move.

Checks and pledges representing contributions of more than $100,000 by employes of the Consolidated Edison Company were presented to representatives of six charities yesterday in the utility's offices, 4 Irving Place.

The Senate, regrettably, has knocked out of the Agriculture Department supply bill a relatively small item that could pave the way for a revolutionary development in the nation's handling of its land-erosion and flood-control problem. This $5,000,000 provision (in a $700,000,000 bill), which we hope will be restored in conference, had been voted by the House to initiate a program of integrated watershed treatment work on fifty small tributary streams throughout the nation.

The R. C. A. Victor division of Radio Corporation of America has eased credit to its distributors all over the country and distributors have made credit easier for dealers. R. C. A. Victor declined yesterday to give any reason for its action, but dealers said it marks a determined effort to minimize or eliminate the traditional summer slump in sales.

WHEN H. L. Davis was a boy of 12 he started punching cattle and herding sheep in the sagebrush country of eastern Oregon, an experience he never got over. Two of his four novels, "Honey in the Horn" and "Winds of Morning," are based upon those early adventures, and so are eleven of the thirteen short stories now gathered together in "Team Bells Woke Me."*

ALBANY, June 16 -- Governor Dewey announced today the membership of an eleven-man temporary state commission that will undertake the first major investigation looking toward a reorganization of the state's court system since 1846.

Installations of signs to make effective the "no standing, loading or unloading" regulation on Ninth and Columbus Avenues between Fourteenth and 110th Streets was completed yesterday. The second half of the program, the installation on Tenth and Amsterdam Avenues, will be carried out today.

In THE TIMES of June 15 is the report of a sermon delivered by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in which he refers to a statement supposed to have been made by me recently in St. Patrick's Cathedral to the effect that communism is a by-product of the Protestant Reformation.
DEARBORN, Mich., June 16 -- The Ford Motor Company, founded fifty years ago when coal was sovereign, used atomic energy tonight to light its birthday candles.

Volume improved yesterday on most of the New York commodity exchanges, with hides and domestic sugar most active. Prices closed irregular with hides, rubber, lead and potatoes ending mixed. Sugar, wool, soybean oil, tin and copper were lower and coffee, cocoa, cottonseed oil and zinc closed higher.

Permanent plastic crosswalk markers are to be installed in Times, Herald and Madison Squares by the Department of Traffic. Contract bids for 6,000 disks will be opened tomorrow by Commissioner T. T. Wiley. Work is to begin within thirty days and is to be completed before Aug. 1.

For a country like Austria -- so greatly dependent on foreign trade -- efforts to maintain and increase exports to the United States will have a major influence on how well her people will get through the coming winter, it was declared yesterday by Paul Foerster, vice president of the Austrian Federal Chamber of Commerce.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 16 -- Continuing the fine golf that had won for her the qualifying medal, Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge easily advanced today to the second round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fiftieth anniversary championship.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee revealed today that the United States was prepared to give Japan military assistance for limited rearmament.

The schools are closing now, again releasing not only the students but a certain divergency of viewpoint. This is a basic one and universal, and no doubt it began in connection with the first cave schoolhouse, as a much earlier June came around.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles warned today against reducing the nation's military power in a world where "the chips are down almost everywhere."
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 16 -- National coastwise ship service has been only partly paralyzed by the strike called last night by the maritime union.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., June 16 (AP) -- Guilty pleas were entered today by thirteen men indicted by the special grand jury investigating Saratoga gambling. It was the largest number to admit guilt at the same time since the inquiry began more than two years ago.
TOKYO, June 16 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique for the twenty-four hours onded at 6 A. M., Tuesday, Korean time:

SUNCOOK, N. H., June 16 -- Residents of this tiny hamlet off the travel highways turned back the clock briefly today to express their confidence in the future by staging an old-fashioned fishing party to welcome the families of two new industries that had moved into town.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (UP) -- A three-run rally in the eighth inning, capped by Eddie Joost's two-run single, enabled the Athletics to beat the Indian 9 -- 7, tonight. The game stretched the A's winning streak to seven games.

ALBANY, June 16 -- Governor Dewey has set June 24 as a target date for calling the Legislature into special session to act on anticrime proposals growing out of the State Crime Commission investigations of the New York waterfront and of political corruption in the state.

In the wheat futures market, as in most futures markets, for purpose of orderly trading an arbitrary limit is set on the amount by which prices may decline during a single day. In the case of wheat the figure is 10 cents. On Monday selling pressure became so severe that price declines reached this limit of 10 cents a bushel, bringing a halt to trading for the day.

City College's 107th commencement exercises will be held this evening in Lewisohn Stadium with 2,694 students receiving baccalaureate and master's degrees and certificates. Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of the college, will give the commencement address and preside at the cermonies.
One-half of the nation's merchant marine faces immobilization as a result of the breakdown last night of negotiations between seamen and their employers.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 16 (AP) -- Electrical engineers heard today that binaural broadcasting promises to bring another sound dimension to radio just as 3-D has brought visual depth to movies.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 16 (AP) -- Thailand's Cabinet today decided to permit King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia to remain as a political refugee, but forbade him to form a government in exile.

Plans for erecting a fifteen-story apartment building with terraces and penthouse suites were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the southeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas and Sixteenth Street, in the Chelsea section, by the Greenwich Savings Bank to Joseph, Victor and Irving Sager.

RANGOON, Burma, June 16 -- Burma this year may resume her position as the world's premier exporter of rice. Production last year increased and if output grows this year as expected a surplus of at least 1,600,000 tons, perhaps more, will be available for sale abroad.

Carbon steel prices were increased $3 to $10 a ton today by the nation's largest steel-maker, the United States Steel Corporation and its general operating divisions, the American Steel and Wire, the National Tube, and the Tennessee Coal and Iron divisions.

Mayor Impellitteri and Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan conducted promotion and appointment ceremonies yesterday in City Hall Plaza, at which the Police Department was brought to the greatest numerical strength yet achieved. With the appointment of 350 probationary patrolmen, membership of the department was raised to 20,024.

THE Scovill Manufacturing Company, one of three companies that won a bid yesterday to make transit tokens for New York, has been turning out that sort of thing for the last 151 years. Started with brass coat buttons back in 1802 up on Mad River at Waterbury in Connecticut, where the Scovill mill still stands. Lamson Scovill, fourth generation button man, has offices here in the Chrysler Tower.

The New York City Transit Authority placed orders yesterday with three manufacturers for 20,000,000 tokens to be used in place of coins for operation of rapid transit turnstiles when the fare on city-owned lines is increased at the end of next month.

City officials, including Mayor Impellitteri and Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan, joined with several thousand parishioners of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem to pay final tribute yesterday to the Rev. Dr. Adam Clayton Powell Sr., pastor emeritus of the parish since 1931.

The cotton futures market here closed 11 points higher to 2 points lower yesterday, with a moderate volume of business. Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange opened 2 to 7 points higher than at Monday's close, eased slightly on hedge selling, and later recovered on price fixing.

SEATTLE, June 16 -- Forestry conservation in this country at long last is nearing the goal of replenishing the nation's timber supply in spite of industrial cutting, fires and destruction by insects, experts reported today.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 16 -- Replying to the latest series of Soviet "peace" overtures directed to the Balkan area, Premier Alexander Papagos of Greece declared tonight in Istanbul that Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia must "reinforce our unity and cooperation in the political and military field, while pursuing our rearmament program."

The Swedish American Line 'passenger vessel Stockholm will 'be qthdrawn from transatlantic service in the fall for two and a half months. Reconstruction will increase her passenger capacity to 600 from 400, the line announced here yesterday.

' he Burbank, Calif., LTnified chool District sold $3,710,000 of bonds yesterday to the Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association and associates. The group submitted the lone bid of 101.334 for the 4 per cent coupon bonds due from 1954 to 1978.

Vardis Fisher, who for more than thirty years has been writing fiction and teaching creative courses, has interrupted his "Testament of Man" series of novels to write a book entitled "God or Caesar" for beginning writers of fiction.
Douglas B. Martin has been elected vice president in charge of sales of the Amplex division of the Chrysler Corporation, and Karl H. Kuhlen has been appointed sales manager of the division.

The Bolivian Government of President Paz Estenssoro has made what appears to be a fair arrangement to recompense American shareholders in the nationalized Patino tin mines. Presumably similar arrangements will be made with the two other great companies which once monopolized the industry, the Hochschild and Aramayo interests.
Form continued to please the devotees of the turf yesterday. The favorite players in the crowd of 17,283 at Belmont Park greatly enjoyed the proceedings on the racing strip.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 16 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, new Chief of State, today began the task of restoring peace in Colombia, torn by nearly five years of bloody strife between the Conservative and Liberal parties.

Mayor Impellitteri shortly will have an opportunity to contribute toward maintaining a high standard of judicial ability on the Magistrate's Court bench by reappointing two outstanding incumbents. The term of Magistrate Eugene R. Canudo expires June 30 and that of Magistrate Morris Ploscowe on Aug. 15.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 16 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, praised President Eisenhower's recent admonition against book burners today and suggested that the nation would come to view his remarks on the subject as a great state paper.

Apparel delivery deadlines which are based solely on the manufacturer's production conveniences are costing retailers tremendous mark downs, it was asserted last night by Bernard G. Cohn, president of the Independent Retailers Syndicate, a New York resident buying office.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 17 -- The United Nations and Communist armistice delegations met for twenty minutes at Panmunjom today while the Allied command here set up preliminary mechanism to implement the expected ceasefire in the three-year-old Korean war.

JERUSALEM, June 16 -- The threat that Israel would invade Jordan unless the Government in Amman controlled marauders raiding across the armistice lines was made in the Knesset (Parliament) here today by Eliezer Livneh, a representative of the ruling Mapai party in the Foreign Affairs and Security Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16 -- A new cut-back in Warner Brothers film operations will take place on Friday, when the company's cartoon studio in Hollywood will discontinue production for a minimum period of three months and possibly longer.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Admiral William M. Fechteler for the grade of full Admiral while serving as Commander in Chief of Allied Forces in the Mediterranean area.

MILWAUKEE, June 16 (AP) -- The Braves regained the National League lead by a game and a half tonight, nipping the Phils, 6 -- 5 and 3 -- 2, in a double-header while the Cards were downing the Dodgers.

NEW DELHI, India, June 16 -- A Japanese attempt to conquer unclimbed Mount Manaslu, 26,658-foot peak and sixth highest mountain in the world, has failed according to a report tonight from Katmandu, capital of Nepal.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today President Eisenhower's nomination of Charles E. Slusser, business man of Akron, Ohio, to be Public Housing Commissioner.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 16 -- France will not negotiate with King Norodom Sihanouk as long as he remains in voluntary exile in Thailand, French circles said here tonight. The interpretation here is that the King's sudden flight from Cambodia in support of his demands for independence amounts to an ultimatum which France cannot accept.

Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday that it would install electronic "trouble shooting" devices on its fleet of new Super- Constellations to detect, locate and identify engine troubles before conventional instruments showed any of the symptoms.

At the annual meeting yesterday of the Allied Stores Corporation, stockholders approved an increase in the authorized cumulative preferred stock from 267,486 shares of $100 par to 400,000 of $100 par and an increase in the authorized common from 2,500,000 no par shares to 4,000,000 of no par value.

County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz of Brooklyn announced yesterday his acceptance of the City Fusion party's nomination for Mayor in a noon-hour speech before 500 longshoremen gathered near Pier 6, First Avenue and Forty-second Street, Brooklyn.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 16 -- Two candidates for re-election to the Board of trustees of this village polled the same number of votes in a village election here today. Under a local law, the board must "determine by lot" which candidate is the winner.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Eisenhower nominated three private citizens today for high ranking posts in the diplomatic service of the United States.

TOKYO, June 16 -- Japanese Government leaders hailed today the prospect of an early settlement of the Korean war as a step toward the restoration of peace in Asia. At the same time they warned that a truce there should not be regarded as evidence of a "fundamental change in the world policy of the Communist bloc."

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, speaking hopefully today of a Korean truce, declared that United Nations forces would hardly intensify their battle effort with peace a possibility. He suggested that the Communist battle pressure might be deliberately aimed at impressing the forces of the Republic of Korea.

Your issue of June 11, carrying a letter from our new Postmaster, Harold Riegelman, answering a complaint of Mark Freeman regarding lack of parcel post mailing facilities at Grand Central Postal Station after 6 P. M., shows that the new Postmaster is evidently sincere and doing his best.

SINGAPORE, June 16 -- Two terrorist chieftains have been killed by their own bodyguards, a special Government communique said today. They are Law Fatt of the Communist Central Committee of North Panang, and Ha Yong, the terrorists' propaganda chief.

WASHINGTON, June 17--United States labor leaders who will meet with labor delegates from seventy-two other countries and territories in Stockholm next month declared their disbelief today in the sincerity of the Soviet Union's peace campaign.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 17 -- Four young women, daughters of North Shore families, who were graduated this month from Eastern schools, made their debuts together tonight at a supper-dance at the Piping Rock Club.

BERLIN, June 17--Soviet tanks, troops and armored cars moved into East Berlin and martial law was declared this afternoon after 20,000 to 50,000 rioting workers had threatened to swamp the local police and seize the East German Government.

Bootleg whiskey, so carefully disguised that experts admitted they could not tell it from legitimate stock, was shown yesterday at a meeting of industry officials, state legislators and members of the State Liquor Authority.

Among the pieces of unfinished business facing the present Congress the supplementary offshore oil bill is an outstanding one. This measure would give the Federal Government the power, which it now lacks, to make leases for development of the oil, gas and sulphur deposits of the Continental Shelf seaward of state boundaries.

When the American Lyric Theatre is able to be lyric, it is promising. At the end of a dismal program of random pieces it concludes the evening with a bar-room opera, "Brandy Is My True Love's Name." -- well sung, well staged and interesting.
Private and public housing should be encouraged through additional aid from state funds and municipal tax concessions, Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Here's how Justice William O. Douglas has voted on pleas by the Rosenbergs to the Supreme Court:
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The House approved today by a voice vote a revised bill extending for two years the Government's power to allocate scarce defense materials.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 17 -- The pangs of conscience are apparently so strong in alcoholics that while they "see things" when inebriated they "hear things" after they have stopped drinking.

BONN, Germany, June 17 -- The West German Chancellor, Dr. Konrad Adenauer, and his Government associated themselves today with the cause of striking East Berliners who, he said, had given "a manifestation of their will to freedom" by demonstrating against the East German Communist Government.
D. E. Inman has been appointed engineering manager of general industrial products of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Pittsburgh.

LONDON, June 17 -- Observers here were excited and impressed today by the rioting in East Berlin -- by the evidence of acute dissatisfaction behind the Iron Curtain, by the exposure of the weakness of the East German Communist regime and by the discovery that the will to revolt still exists in Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- A naval official and commercial ship operators told Congress today that expanded construction and operating subsidies were necessary for defense and to keep the American merchant marine competitive with foreign fleets.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 17 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman said the Republican party in the last four months "has demonstrated it's the party of special interests."

Edward L. Warner, former co-captain of the City College basketball team, testified yesterday that Nat Holman, the school's suspended basketball coach, had warned the players at least on one occasion against associating with gamblers.

Alan Dale, singer, will replace Jimmy Blaine as master of ceremonies on the "Talk of the Town" program beginning Monday. The variety show is televised over Channel 7 on Mondays through Fridays from 11 P. M. to 12 midnight.

MONTREAL, June 17 (AP) -- The Montreal Star said today that the police were searching for a young Czechoslovakian whose plans for getting into the United States with forged papers and a United States Army uniform were "wrecked by an improbably 164,000,000-to-one coincidence."

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 10, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

About 20,000 to 40,000 Chinese Communists--the equivalent of two to five Chinese divisions, a small fraction of the seventy to eighty enemy divisions in North Korea--have underscored the limited combat effectiveness of the South Korean Army.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Eisenhower made public today a proposed new security information program that would rescind the order issued by President Truman in 1951 and would, according to General Eisenhower, "open the door for citizens to obtain more information about their Government."

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Amid the furor about book-burning, it should be reported that the book of books about communism is right there in the office of the President of the United States -- to the left, of course.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Tom C. Clark, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, declined today the invitation of a House of Representatives Judiciary Subcommittee to testify in regard to some of his activities when he was Attorney General and Assistant Attorney General, a period from 1943 to 1949.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 18 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,649, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

Two lawyers who did not represent Julius and Ethel Rosenberg officially were credited yesterday with raising legal points on which Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas based his stay of execution of the convicted atom spies.
WASHINGTON, June 17--President Eisenhower believes his news conferences are running too long and today he reprimanded a reporter for having failed to give the cut-off signal earlier than he did.

The New York City C. I. O. Council appointed a committee of ten labor leaders yesterday to confer with leaders of the political parties and prospective Mayoralty candidates to find a candidate who will serve the best interests of the people of the city and who will merit their support.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A Federal Grand Jury indicted today the United Tanker Corporation of New York and two individuals connected with it on charges of illegally chartering to an alien corporation a former United States surplus tanker.

Frank N. Bowers, president of the International Freighting Corporation, Inc., was elected chairman of the American Committee of Lloyd's Register of Shipping at the organization's annual meeting yesterday at 17 Battery Place. Mr. Bowers succeeded Frank B. Zeller, president of the Royal Liverpool Group, insurance underwriters.

NOW that the first hay is in the barn, the stubble pastures offer little cover for the woodchuck and force the varmint shooter to make a more careful stalk, but these conditions have made things more interesting for the long-range varminter, who scorns the easy shots.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 17 -- The defending champion and two other former winners were among those remaining after the second round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fiftieth championship had been completed over the hilly Metropolis course today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption in May had averaged 37,390 bales for each working day. This compared with an average of 35,228 bales a year ago and 36,687 in April this year.

Five patrolmen and one police lieutenant were honored yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on Unity for furthering good human relations in their daily work. They received wrist watches at the committee's annual luncheon in the Biltmore Hotel in the presence of Commissioner George P. Monaghan, and with the congratulations of Mayor Impellitteri.
Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges with coffee and zinc showing the best volume of the month and sugar moderately active, but with light trading in other items.

In connection with the matter of Portuguese Goa, in India, I would like to remark that the historic position of Portugal in India antedates that of all other nations, and even goes back before the discovery of America. The Portuguese have been in Goa for some 500 years, and Goa stands today as the oldest and firmest bastion of Western culture in the Orient.

Inspectors of the Department of Housing and Buildings began a check-up yesterday morning of 600 Harlem apartments in a four-square block area bounded by West 135th and 149th Streets and Fifth and Eighth Avenues to determine whether there were violations that make slums of the houses.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 18 -- The South Korean Government, breaking loose from United Nations control, today ordered the release of all the North Korean anti-Communist prisoners held in stockades south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

Autobiographical books by three members of the Fourth Estate are scheduled for publication in the next two months. On July 9, Doubleday will issue Robert St. John's "This Was My World," an account of his work as a reporter and editor.
CINCINNATI, June 17 -- There are times when it is difficult to fathom what the Giants are doing in the second division. Tonight was one of those times.
The immobilizing effect of the National Maritime Union's seamen's strike spread slowly, but effectively, along the country's shorelines yesterday.

The Atomic Energy Commission is looking to private industry for help in developing broader uses for new products resulting from atomic research, so that production costs of these products may be substantially reduced, an A. E. C. official said yesterday at the Basic Materials Conference at the Roosevelt Hotel.

The plan of State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman to have Mount Sinai Hospital extend its clinic services into the Carver Houses, Madison Avenue from Ninety-ninth Street to 106th Street, will be assailed editorially in the forthcoming issue of New York Medicine, official organ of the New York County Medical Society, the society said yesterday.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 17 -- The merger of the Missouri Synod Lutherans with the American Lutheran Church group was discussed here today as the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod opened its forty-second triennial national convention.

A sound approach to the problem of overweight, the diet just released by the National Dairy Council is high in protein, moderately high in fat and low in carbohydrates. It is based partly on the regime worked out by Dr. Margaret Ohlson at Michigan State College, partly on an adaptation of the Michigan diet devised by Dr. Charlotte Young of Cornell University.

For twenty-six handicapped children between the ages of 4 and 13 -- members of cerebral palsy classes at Public School 135 -- a climb of 32 1/8 inches presents a challenge comparable to that faced by the expedition that recently scaled Mount Everest.

A marked shift of opinion showing increased support for lower tariffs was indicated yesterday in a survey conducted by Standard Factors Corporation. It concerned twenty-six manufacturers having combined sales of more than $300,000,000 in 1952.

As measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES composite average of fifty issues, the stock market enjoyed its sharpest one-day advance since May 2, 1952, yesterday and recovered nearly all the ground lost during Monday's and Tuesday's selling drives.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- House of Representatives investigators said today they had "intercepted" a shipment of 100 per cent defective tank parts from a Michigan concern to the Mount Rainier Ordnance Depot, Tacoma, Wash.

" New Horizons" a discussion of the aims of the Republican national and state Administrations, will be a feature of the conference of the New York State Federation of Women's Republican Clubs, Jane Todd, its president announced yesterday.

Chairman Philip J. Cruise of the New York City Housing Authority clashed head-on with Brooklyn officials and business interests before the City Planning Commission yesterday over whether Ulmer Park, Brooklyn, should be developed as a housing site or left for waterfront industrial expansion.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- The House of Representatives voted today to restrict free hospital care for veterans with civilian-type ailments and to curb certain other G. I. benefits in an effort to save some $75,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Eisenhower said today his Administration was making progress in drafting proposed Taft-Hartley Law amendments but said he could not say exactly when the work would be finished.

MOSCOW, Thursday, June 18 (AP) -- The first Soviet comment on yesterday's East Berlin troubles appeared in Pravda today under the headline: "The failure of the adventure of foreign hirelings in Berlin."

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Eisenhower and key members of Congress enhanced today the credit rating of the European Coal and Steel Community, the six-nation organization developed to establish a common market for coal and steel. Members of the community are France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxenbourg.

SEATTLE, June 17 -- A new type of ecclesiastical architecture is developing in this country to mark a welcome departure from the earlier emphasis and dependence on heterogenous mixtures of church styles dating back to ancient times, the American Institute of Architects was told today.

ALBANY, June 17 -- The Communist party today denounced as "a heresy hunt" the investigation that the Board of Regents has held over the last six months to determine whether the party should be officially classified by the State Educaiton Department as a subversive organization.
Lester A. Ahlers has been named treasurer of the Western Union Telegraph Company, succeeding William P. Waters, who has retired.

Steel price advances averaging $3.60 to $4.50 a ton were announced yesterday by four major producers, with a fifth scheduled to post its higher figures today or tomorrow, when other companies are expected to follow suit.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 17 (AP) -- The wife of a dismissed Ohio State University professor sat before a Congressional committee today and refused to answer twenty-two questions, including the key query: "Are you now a member of the Communist party?"

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17--The Screen Actors Guild today advised its members who are being paid at above minimum scale rates to guard against being "stampeded into mass salary cutting" as a result of the slack employment situation in the film industry.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 17 -- Danish General Vagn Bennicke is due here tomorrow morning to succeed Lieut. Gen. William E. Riley of the United States as Chief of Staff of the United Nations truce supervision organization.

Peter and his wolf visited Ebbets Field last night, escorted by Sam Levenson and the N. B. C. Symphony under the direction of Milton Katims. The music was Prokofieff's, as was some of the text. But there were a few moments where the Gowanus inundated the Ukraine.

At the 107th commencement exercises of City College last evening in Lewisohn Stadium Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of the college, cautioned the 18,000 students and guests to "let no soft words and honeyed phrases from the new lords of the Kremlin deceive us."
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Following is a summary of the main issues covered by President Eisenhower in his news conference today:

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Wheat futures on the Board of Trade scored limit upturns of 10 cents today, before reacting. Two days ago there were limit declines. Earlier in today's sessions there was an irregular trend with fair setbacks, but cash and commission house buying against flour sales took the slack out of the market and shorts found offerings limited.

Employing boys under 16 and girls under 18 on Government contracts cost business men in New York and New Jersey $23,380 in damages in the last eleven months, according to a report made public yesterday by Frank J. Muench, regional director of the United States Department of Labor's wage-hour and public contracts division.

TRENTON, June 17 -- Nelson F. Stamler admitted here today that he had not told the truth when he testified last January before the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council in respect to Willy Moretti, syndicate gambler slain in Cliffside Park in October, 1951.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Pentagon officials opened their defense today of the far-reaching plan to reorganize the top levels of the military establishment.

The Germans of East Berlin have made a gesture that will rank high in the history of Germany and of European civilization. They fought for liberty against tyranny -- blindly, hopelessly and bravely. They branded communism with an iron that will sear so deeply the Reds will never lose the scar.

A $5,500,000 issue of New Jersey Power and Light Company first mortgage bonds is to be offered today by a group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co. The bonds, 4 1/2 per cent series due May 1, 1983, are priced at 101.70 and accrued interest, to yield 4.15 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of Justice William O. Douglas' order today granting a stay of execution to the convicted atom spies, Julius and Ethel Rosenberg:
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by White House rules:

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The House of Representatives Public Works Committee heard today that estimated toll revenues from the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway would be almost double annual costs. N. R. Danielian, president of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Association, said that on that basis the long-disputed project was "safely self-liquidating."

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 17 (UP) -- The Liberal party resumed today its normal role in Colombia's political life after the four-day-old Conservative Government of Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla gave it full guarantees and the promise of amnesty to political prisoners.
Potential development of a wide range of products made from chemically strengthened paper was demonstrated yesterday by the American Cyanamid Company.
PORT BARROW, Alaska, June 17 (AP)--Hundreds of thousands of lemmings, said to face a "starve or drown" choice, are choosing drowning again in a mass migration into the Arctic Ocean's frigid waters.

PARIS, June 17 -- A warning by Wilfred Baumgartner, Governor of the Bank of France, that the franc will be endangered unless increased loans proposed from the bank are covered by specific resources may cause difficulty in the National Assembly for Andre Marie when he seeks the Premiership tomorrow.

BERLIN, June 17 (Reuters) -- United States officials tonight questioned East Germany's Deputy Premier Otto Nuschke, who was swept across the border into West Berlin today by angry anti-Communist rioters.

Edna Ferber, novelist, who last April called New York the most "disgustingly filthy" city in the world but declined to serve as assistant general chairman of a city-wide clean-up campaign, has suggested a "road gang" method of punishing contributors to such delinquency.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (UP) -- Bobby Avila, who hit his fifth homer of the season, batted in four runs tonight and Bill Wight won in his first relief appearance for the Indians as the Tribe defeated the Athletics, 9 -- 6. The Indians ended their losing streak at six games and snapped the A's winning string at seven.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were rather quiet yesterday and price changes were small. The close was 5 points higher to 3 points lower than on Tuesday.
Miami, Fla., has sold two bond issues totaling $27,100,000 to a group headed by Smith, Barney Co.

DOVER PLAINS, N. Y., June 17 -- Mrs. Anne Brooks McAdoo Serge, niece of the late William G. McAdoo, Secretary of the Treasury under President Woodrow Wilson, was found dead here in her automobile Monday night on the eve of her arraignment on charges of tax fraud. The police said the 51-year-old woman had committed suicide.
CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- Ransom Jackson's bases-loaded single ended a four-hour, sixteen-inning struggle as the Cubs defeated the Pirates 5 -- 4, today.

Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of Pennsylvania State College and chairman of the American-Korean Foundation, Inc., expressed the hope yesterday that a cross-country Korean relief train, similar to the 1947 Friendship Train, might be under way by the fall.

Generoso Pope, owner and publisher of Il Progresso Italo-Americano, the city's largest Italian-language newspaper, left a net estate of $3,042,341, and Dr. Walter Damrosch, conductor and composer, left a net estate of $1,406,590, according to estate tax appraisals filed yesterday at the State Office Building.

William Wyer, Long Island Rail Road trustee, defended yesterday the action of the bankrupt road in seeking to settle its tax case with New York. The railroad owes $13,304,000, but the city is willing to accept $7,500,000 as a compromise.
I recently arrived in New York from South Africa, after an absence of fifty-four years, and you can imagine how interested I am in the changes in this wonderful city.

Two things bothered the convention of the National Confectioners Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. The first was the drop in per capita consumption despite bigger, richer families. The second was Government policy on sugar, peanuts and cocoa.

LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- The Kremlin has sternly rebuked the top Communist leaders in Lithuania and ordered drastic shake-ups in the party and government in that captive Baltic State, the Moscow radio said tonight.

LONG BEACH, L. I., June 17 -- Four hundred officials assembled here today as the Conference of Mayors and Other Municipal Officials of the Cities and Villages of the State of New York began a three-day meeting.

For the third successive year the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island is conducting an appeal for the church agencies in Kings, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The problem of ministering to these agencies may be grasped from the fact that one-third of the population of this state lives in the Long Island diocese and one-half the population of New York City lives in Brooklyn and Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- An Armed Services subcommittee of the House of Representatives was told today that the Reserve forces of the Army and the Air Force were poorly trained and equipped, mostly because of ineffective Pentagon policies, and that the Navy's program also needed reform.

Two new films are opening today at first-run theatres. At the Radio City Music Hall is MetroGoldwyn - Mayer's "Dangerous When Wet," a musical comedy starring Esther Williams and Fernando Lamas. In prominent roles are Jack Carson, Charlotte Greenwood and Denise Darcel.

I count that week lost which is not begun by a careful examination of your summary of the news of the week in your Sunday issue. I have often marveled at your skill in including the really important matters. But on Sunday, June 7, I think you missed something important, and that was the introduction of a resolution in the Senate on world disarmament and economic development on June 3.

Dr. James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner for Germany, said yesterday that demonstrations by Germans living in Soviet-controlled East Berlin were "a spontaneous manifestation of the spirit of freedom."

LONDON, June 17--Today, behind closed doors at 10 Downing Street, Prime Minister Sir William Churchill and other members of the Conservative Government were reported to be discussing an issue that has caused a small rift in their party--the proposal to introduce sponsored television in Britain.

An expansion of the jurisdiction of the Narcotics Term of the City Magistrates' Court so that it will include adult addicts applying for voluntary commitment will become effective on July, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh announced yesterday.

A drop last week of 1,835,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 150,757,000 barrels, compared with 152,592,000 a week earlier and 121,993,000 a year ago.
Maybe the way to get rich at a race track is to wait till Conn McCreary has a birthday and then bet on his mount in a stakes race.

Joseph B. Cavallaro, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, coming directly from LaGuardia Airport after testifying before a Senate committee in Washington, reiterated yesterday afternoon his position on investigations of subversive activities in public education at the Queens College commencement exercises on the college quadrangle, 6530 Kissena Boulevard, Flushing.
SINGAPORE, June 17 -- The fifth year of Malaya's emergency ended today with the killing of five more terrorists. Three of these were killed in the Kuantan area of Pahang State.
DETROIT, June 17 (AP) -- The automobile industry, one of the steel industry's biggest customers, probably will make no price changes following the rise in steel prices.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Williston B. Palmer, Assistant Army Chief of Staff for Logistics, said today that the Administration's defense budget would not buy the ammunition facilities the nation would need for all-out mobilization.

Slums are continuing to be created, Averell Harriman said yesterday at the opening of a photography exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York. His remark was graphically substantiated by camera evidence in the show, which is titled "New Yorkers Live Here."

BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- Willard Nixon celebrated his twenty-fifth birthday by limiting Detroit to five hits and driving in two runs today in a 17-1 victory for the Red Sox. His Boston team-mates helped with a seven-run fourth inning and Dick Gernert chipped in with his tenth and eleventh homers.

Blood collections in the New York area on Tuesday totaled 1,046 pints, the Red Cross reported yesterday. Employes of the Long Lines Division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, 32 Sixth Avenue, gave 181 pints of blood; the New York Life Insurance Company, 51 Madison Avenue, accounted for 151 pints: and employes of Greer Hydraulics Company, 454 Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, gave 152 pints.

Asserting that there was no dissent in the Liberal party on the need for a change in the city administration. Adolf A. Berle Jr., its state chairman, said last night that the party was pledged to exploratory conferences with the Citizens Nonpartisan Committee and a Republican committee to see whether an agreement could be reached on a coalition ticket.

Dominick F. Paduano, a Water Commissioner with a heart, has come through with an up-to-date 1953 version of the old hydrant spray that used to cool the kids in New York's steaming summer streets. For several years, ever since the water shortage, opening the hydrants for that delightful purpose has been forbidden.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., June 17 (AP) -- The operator of a motel near this mountainous western Pennsylvania town said Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court had registered at his motel tonight and then learned by radio that a special session of the court had been called in the Rosenberg case.

The number of bats wintering in caves in the eastern part of the United States in the last year declined markedly compared with other years, it was reported here yesterday at the thirty-third annual meeting of the American Society of Mammalogists.
It took this city's official Visitor Information Center to find out for a Massachusetts woman why she could not buy kangaroo tail soup in the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Washington's mood of optimism over a Korean armistice was abruptly, but perhaps only temporarily, shaken tonight with reports that the South Koreans had allowed to go free anti-Communist North Korean prisoners of war.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture official in charge of dried peas denied today there was anything wrong with an 80,000-ton transaction on the West Coast.

A group of five five-story apartment buildings at 1186 Lexington Avenue and 112 to 126 East Eighty-first Street has been sold by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustees for the bondholders and stockholders of the Lexington Avenue and Eighty-first Street Corporation, to investors in a deal negotiated by Imre von Schreiber and Eugene A. Hegy, brokers.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 17 -- A statement issued for Cambodia's King Norodom Sihanouk here today warned that any attempt by the French to install a new king or new regency council in Cambodia would be "illegal."

BERLIN, June 17 -- The voices of debate that could be heard throughout East Berlin last night as pro-Government political workers tried to head off serious trouble were drowned out today by the wild cries of thousands of angered citizens.

Ever since May 22, when the Brown Shoe Company announced it had reached an agreement with the stockholders of the Regal Shoe Company to purchase a controlling interest in that concern, Wall Street has been wondering exactly how much stock Brown already held when it made its announcement.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, announced today that his Appropriations subcommittee would reopen its hearings on Air Force procurement to give Henry J. Kaiser an opportunity to testify publicly about his concern's manufacture of C-119 Flying Boxcar cargo airplanes.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, June 18--Before the sudden comparative quiet fell early today over the east-central war front, troops of the Republic of Korea Eighth Division on the western side of the enemy penetration launched a series of counter-attacks against stubborn Chinese Communist resistance.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- Senator Jenner said today that his subcommittee had received evidence that in the early Nineteen Forties the College of the City of New York had about forty faculty members in a Communist unit, and that Brooklyn, Queens and Hunter Colleges had smaller units.

ATLANTA, June 17 (AP) -- Betsy Rawls' hole-in-one and Pat Lesser's upset victory over the co-medalist, Mrs. Jackie Pung, highlighted second-round matches today in the women's Western open golf tournament.

A Bronx realty concern found itself trapped yesterday between being damned if it did and ditto if it didn't. A Special Sessions Court convicted the company, for the third time, of violating the multiple dwelling law by renting an apartment to a tenant whom the landlord corporation has repeatedly tried through another court to evict.
BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- The International Hydro-Electric System has been authorized by a Federal judge to sell several New York and Maine water power properties to Dartmouth College for $9,970,000.

RANGOON, Burma, June 17 -- An uneasy atmosphere hangs over the four-nation talks taking place in Bangkok for withdrawal of Chinese Nationalist forces from Burma, according to reliable sources here. The possibility is increasing, these sources say, that the Burmese military mission may abandon negotiations to remove the group, which fled from the Communist advances in Yunnan, "in disgust" because of the serious obstacles raised by Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist delegates.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 18 (UP) -- Gen. Mark W. Clark's headquarters statement on Syngman Rhee's action freeing anti-Communist North Korean prisoners:

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Joseph B. Cavallaro, chairman of the New York City Board of Higher Education, told the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today that he had been active through much of his first month in that office preparing for a permanent and effective war on subversion in the city's colleges.

ASCOT, England, June 17 (UP) -- Choir Boy, a bay son of Hyperion, produced one of the loudest cheers in the history of the fashionable Ascot race meeting today when he carried Queen Elizabeth's royal purple colors to victory in the Royal Hunt Cup.

LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla., America's first-ranking player, angrily walked off the court of the Queen's Club today after being beaten by an unseeded Australian in the third round of the London tennis tournament.

ERIE, Mich., June 17 -- One of the nation's most efficient steam generating electric power plants was dedicated here today before nearly 1,000 representatives of industry, finance and government. It marked another step in the vast post-war expansion program of the Consumers Power Company to meet the increasing demands for electricity throughout the industrial and farming territory of Michigan.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- United Nations delegates said tonight that if the release of prisoners of war by South Korea broke up the truce talks the sixty-nation General Assembly would be called quickly into an emergency session.

The second troopship to bring Korean veterans directly to New York from the war area slipped through fog into the harbor yesterday morning to a less tumultous welcome than that which greeted her predecessor in April.

Manufacturers of soft goods must adjust their thinking to new methods of pricing, packaging and promotion before they can sell through super markets, Victor Le-bow, marketing consultant, said yesterday. Addressing a meeting of the textile section of the New York Board of Trade at the Ark-wright Club, he said more soft goods items have failed of acceptance in super markets than have proved successful.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson has issued new orders clamping a tighter economy lid on military research and development spending during the next twelve months.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- The State Department said today it was trying to find out just what had occurred in the reported book burning incident in Sydney, Australia.

The East Berlin rioting was hailed yesterday by the Voice of America in broadcasts beamed to all parts of the world as having "once and for all times exposed the fraudulent nature of Communist regimes." The broadcasts quoted comments from President Eisenhower, Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, Ernst Reuter, Mayor of West Berlin, and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany, among others.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 17--Lieut. Gen. John Bagot Glubb, Chief of Staff of the Arab Legion, accused Israel today of deliberately promoting tension along the Jordanian trucial boundary with probable territorial expansion in mind.

The taxpayer property at the southeast corner of Bruckner Boulevard and Castle Hill Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Julian Marx in a transaction negotiated by Darling McDonald as brokers. Edward J. Fontanna was attorney for the seller and Jay Winston acted for the buyer. The property, held at $70,000, fronts eighty feet On Castle Hill Avenue, 105 feet on Bruckner Boulevard and 105 feet on Houghton Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 17--Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court stayed the death sentence of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg today, but Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson called a special term of the court for noon tomorrow to review the stay.

NEW LONDON, June 17 -- The proper application of women's organizations to a community is not at all unlike the application of physically handicapped persons to a proper role in industry, the June conference of the Connecticut Service Bureau for Women's Organizations was told here tonight.

The current strike of C. I. O. seamen raises these questions: Why was the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service not called upon by the parties until shortly before the contract was due to expire? Why did the service not intervene earlier upon its own motion?

THAT eminent authority on antiques, Satchel Paige, offered some delicious quotations for a recent Colliers' magazine article. Considering the fact that the ageless Satch celebrated his 39th birthday for something like ten straight years in Jack Benny fashion, he is well qualified to discuss the passing scene.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- United States battle casualties in Korea now total 136,029, an increase of 443 over last week's report, the Department of Defense announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- Justice Clark said that men on the high bench should avoid "the strife of public affairs and partisan politics."

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- At the request of the State Department, the House Foreign Affairs Committee has decided to shelve a resolution asking the United Nations to start action against the Soviet Union for the 1941 mass murders in the Katyn Forest.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Post Office received permission from the Interstate Commerce Commission today to raise parcel post zone rates 36 per cent.

ST. LOUIS, June 17 -- Blasting Ben Wade for three runs in the fifth to break out of a 1-1 tie, the Cardinals went on to score five times off Joe Black in the seventh inning and beat the Dodgers, 9 -- 3, before 24,027 fans at Busch Stadium tonight.

The New York Shipping Association, speaking in the name of all employers of pier labor, protested yesterday against the plan of Governor Dewey of New York and Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey to set up a bi-state agency to regulate business practices and wipe out crime on the racket-infested waterfront.

Returning to the summer home where one has spent every summer he can remember always causes something of a psychic shaking-up -- or is it a shaking-down? With two homes throughout one's childhood it would be expected that one's winter friends would be the real friends, prevailing as they did for nine months out of every twelve.

The traveling time across Long Island by helicopter from north to south is five minutes. This was demonstrated yesterday by New York Airways, the company that has helicopters buzzing around the metropolitan area's major airports, carrying mail, parcel post and freight.

It was "row, row, row" yesterday for a half dozen Immigration and Public Health officials, who went down the bay to examine and clear 100-odd Belgian naval cadets and apprentices aboard the barkentine Mercator.

Parents of girls college-bound in the fall would do well to see that their daughters got adequate vocational counseling before they committed themselves definitely to a major field of study, analysis of a survey released yesterday discloses.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- Walt Disney's employment contract as board chairman and executive head of production for Walt Disney Productions is "unreasonable, excessive and out of proportion in view of the corporation's net earnings and considering that it has never paid any dividends," a minority stockholder's suit, filed today in Superior Court in Los Angeles, has charged.

A degree of normalcy returned to the Stadium yesterday, when the Yankees defeated the Browns. However, the 5-3 revenge of the Bombers against the rivals who had snapped their eighteen-game winning streak the night before was not without an unusual twist.

Governor Dewey has announced the appointment of a commission of high caliber to study reorganization of the state court system. To head this task of major importance he has named Harrison Tweed, one of the distinguished figures of the New York bar.
MILWAUKEE, June 17 (UP) -- The Braves gained a seven-run lead in the first three innings and then went on to beat the Phillies, 9 to 6, tonight before a cheering crowd of 32,771.
The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, paper producer, reported yesterday an estimated net income of $8,324,000 for the fiscal year ended on April 30.

The use of premiums as a merchandising "gimmick" will help give sales the needed boost when the rug of government spending is pulled out from under industry, it was predicted yesterday by Duane Jones, head of the agency bearing his name.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, June 18 (AP) -- The explosive 30,000-man Chinese Communist offensive in the hills of east-central Korea broke off abruptly today. The foe in three days' fighting had taken about 5,000 casualties.

Labor will continue to press for higher wages as long as its productivity increases, Elmer E. Walker, general vice president of the International Association of Machinists, A. F. of L., declared yesterday. He spoke at the opening session of the American Management Association's general management conference in the Statler Hotel.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 17 Perky Cullinane of St. John's School, Washington, D. C., and Tuffy Henderson of Woodberry Forest, Orange, Va., shared medalist honors with 36-hole aggregates of 151 as the second of the 18-hole qualifying rounds in the thirty-seventh annual Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association championship was staged today over the Yale Golf Club course.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 -- The fate of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will depend largely on what is done at the Big Three Bermuda conference later this month, Bernard M. Baruch declared here today.
SEOUL, Thursday, June 18 (UP) -- The text of President Syngman Rhee's statement on the release of anti-Communist Korean war prisoners:
LONDON, June 17 -- Prices continued to drift lower in slow business on the stock markets today. Only South African gold mine and foreign bond issues showed any real improvement.

WASHINGTON. June 17 -- Expenditures for military and economic aid to other nations in the first quarter of this year were higher than those of any quarter in more than five years, according to Commerce Department figures.

CLEVELAND, June 17 -- A Korean truce and resultant defense cutbacks would have no appreciable effect on the American economy, James J. Nance, president of the Packard Motor Car Company, told delegates to the convention of the Advertising Federation of America today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Eisenhower affirmed today his confidence in the abiding wisdom and strength of the American people to think and write as they saw fit, and to read books of their own choosing.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 17 -- Material progress would be made, ultimately benefiting the country as a whole, as well as the utility industry and its customers, by building a full-scale nuclear power plant promptly to produce electric power, using present techniques.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 17 -- The historic ban against admitting Negroes to Louisville's white city parks has run into difficulties, with Abraham Lincoln playing a major role.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, June 17 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, who will succeed Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway as Supreme Allied Commander here July 18, intends to name Maj. Gen. Cortlandt van Rensselaer Schuyler of the United States Army as his Chief of Staff.
RYE, N. Y., June 17 -- Deerfield, Landon and Choate were waging a keen contest for the team championship of the twenty-second Manursing Island Club Eastern interscholastic tennis tournament today.

LONDON, June 17 (Reuters) -- The British Government tonight denied charges by Senator Joseph McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, that British hips have carried Chinese troops and strategic materials to Communist China.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Eisenhower said today that the workers' riots in the Soviet sector of Berlin were a good lesson on the meaning of communism and a significant exposure of the propaganda about "happiness" behind the Iron Curtain.

Real estate with an assessed value of $8,500,000 previously under control of the Board of Transportation has been turned over to the city government thus far as a result of the leasing of the municipal transit system to the New York City Transit Authority. Other parcels with an assessed value of $5,000,000 to $6,000,000 are in process of being released to the city.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 17 (AP) -- Greek complaints that Turkey should have told her Balkan allies officially of recent Soviet overtures were reported today as the Greek Premier, Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, continued his official visit here.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Eisenhower said today that any great and deep tax reduction, as he put it, must await establishment of some kind of world peace and security arrangement in which we have confidence.
