Although a great admirer of Professor Einstein as a man and as a scientist, I must add my voice to others who will disagree with his advice to intellectuals to refuse to testify before Congressional committees. I am afraid Dr. Einstein is being misled.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Dr. Abram L. Sachar, president of Brandeis University at Waltham, Mass., said today that the type of intellectual intolerance now being metaphorically called "bookburning" would not last long in this country.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 17 -- The Simon F. Rothschild Cup, chief prize in the annual New York City Newspaper Publishers and Retail Dry Goods Association Tourney at the Century Country Club today, went to Horace Liberman of Arnold Constable.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 18 -- The United Nations and Communist staff officers were reported yesterday to have reached agreement on the demarcation line across the peninsula from which the troops of both sides would retire after an armistice in the Korean war.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 17 -- Gilmore Rothrock of Cornell advanced to the quarter-finals of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it will make emergency price support loans on wheat stored on the ground in arid areas of the Southwest, where a shortage of storage facilities has been reported.

Irving Schwartzberg, convicted college basketball fixer released from the City Penitentiary last Dec. 20, was back in a cell yesterday on charges that he was the mastermind of a ring that defrauded city banks of more than $30,000.

Some major production revisions are being made on "Carnival in Flanders," the Broadway-bound musical now trying out in Philadelphia. By next week the musical will have a new first act, a new ballet by Jack Cole called "Plundering the Town" and a new top performer.

NEWARK, July 17 -- A flying technique devised jointly by the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee and the Air Line Pilots Association to reduce the noise caused by transports in the communities surrounding airports was demonstrated at Newark Airport today. The plane flown was an Eastern Air Lines Lockheed Constellation.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Eisenhower cited today the Tennessee Valley Authority, vast water control and power project, as an example of what he meant by "creeping socialism."
SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 17 -- Ted Bishop of Winged Foot, who held the national amateur championship in 1946, regained the William Rice Hochster Memorial Trophy today at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club.
A new collection of wall coverings and a new group of shower curtains offer a variety of choices to homemakers who wish to decorate the bathroom.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 18 (AP) -- Abner (Longy) Zwillman, reputed link in the underworld chain of command, was accused today of a criminal charge of dodging $55,114 in income taxes. A complaint alleging income tax evasion on his 1946 returns was filed last Monday, a few hours before the statute of limitations would have expired and blocked prosecution.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, June 19 (AP) -- Rushing in reinforcements after military leaves were canceled. United States troops quickly rounded up nearly 1,000 of the prisoners freed yesterday.

ATLANTA, June 18 (AP) -- A se ries of one-sided matches today sent two top professionals, a longtime amateur and a college girl newcomer, into the semi-finals of the women's western open golf championship.
FORT DIX, N. J., June 18 -- One trainee was killed and sixteen other soldiers were injured today when a mortar shell exploded prematurely during a demonstration on the mortar-firing range here.
IT'S more than three months since the city asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to use a WNYC beep for radio-controlled street lighting, but no word's come through on it.

One of the perennial questions on the lips of many viewers is why fine television programs so often completely disappear after a single performance and never are seen again. Why couldn't a good show be presented a second time on kinescope film to accommodate those who may have missed the original presentation?
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 18 -- The Thai police department moved today to clamp down on the publication of material dealing with the differences between France and Cambodia.

Gloria Krieger, 19-year-old soprano from Portland, Ore., received today court approval of a seven-year contract with Columbia Pictures, which gives her a starting salary of $300 a week and provides for increases ranging up to a maximum of $1,250 weekly.

BABYLON, L. I., June 18 -- Nine handsome youngsters, part of a most unusual family, swam contentedly about a lake in the Hunter Park section of this community today while their "mother" walked along the shoreline in a fretful condition, and the man who considers himself the foster father of the nine smiled with pride.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 18 -- The co-medalists, Perky Cullinane of St. John's School, Washington, and Tuffy Henderson of Woodberry Forest, were eliminated in the second round of match play in the Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association championship today.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Lee M. Thurston, a Michigan educational official, to be United States Commissioner of Education.

The Sanitation Department band played and the Fire Department Glee Club sang, but Miss Edna Ferber, author and outspoken critic of New York's streets, was definitely absent yesterday at clean-up, paint-up, fix-up award ceremonies at City Hall.
BERLIN, June 19 (AP) -- Raiding squads of the People's Police and Communist party functionaries broke into many workers' apartments in East Berlin today in their hunt for resistance leaders.

On May 31 the average market price of all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange was at the lowest level since June 30, 1951, the Exchange reported yesterday. At $40.32 the average compared with $40.44 at the end of April and with $38.73 at the end of June, 1951.

LONDON, June 18 -- Developments in Korea and East Germany put a brake on business in the stock markets today. However, most markets looked a little stronger than of late and prices tended to improve. British Government securities were a weak exception, losing a further one-quarter per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended June 13, 1953, totaled 797,425 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 21,936 cars, or 2 8 per cent more than for the preceding week, 166,383, or 26.4 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 29.458, or 3.6 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A former Federal Bureau of Investigation undercover agent swore to the Senate Investigating subcommittee today that he attended a secret meeting last December when a "goon squad" organizer announced that the Communist party had selected him to "liquidate" Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court of the United States exercised his clear statutory powers Wednesday to stay the execution of two American citizens convicted after due process for conspiracy to commit espionage, and there is much substance for disagreement with his action and the reasons he gave for it.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- President Eisenhower announced with "particular satisfaction" tonight that the United States was turning over an additional $50,000,000 in economic aid for the Western sector of Berlin.

Congressman Charles A. Wolverton of New Jersey, chairman of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, and Congressman Robert Crosser of Ohio, ranking Democratic members of that committee, have just introduced in the House identical bills whose sponsorship do them honor.
DETROIT, June 18 -- Robert Moses, an occasional essayist of New York City, received tonight the first national award of $25,000 in the General Motors Better Highways Contest.

The bi-annual regional directors' meeting of the Fashion Group, Inc., was held yesterday at the Astor Hotel. Nineteen representatives from various sections of the United States gathered for a program that opened with an address by Miss Virginia Pope, fashion editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES and president of the Fashion Group. She told of her recent coverage of the coronation.

American industry should prepare now to weather a business recession in order to ward off Government intervention should one occur, Paul E. Crocker, treasurer of Pepperell Manufacturing Company, textile producers, said yesterday. He spoke before more than 1,500 top executives of companies from all over the country at the American Management Association's general management conference in the Statler Hotel.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, today denounced the action of his party's state convention in Madison, Wis., last Saturday in censuring him for not supporting the Bricker Amendment.

CAIRO, June 18 -- The Kingdom of Egypt was proclaimed a republic shortly after 10 o'clock tonight with Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, leader of the military group that seized power last July, as its first President and Premier.

SYRACUSE, June l8 -- Navy, Washington and Cornell were picked today in a poll of the coaches to lead the field of eleven across the line in that order in the varsity race of the 51st Regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association, to be held here Saturday on Onondaga Lake.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- House hearings on St. Lawrence Seaway legislation ended today with foes attacking the project as one that would serve "only a selfish few."

Noting the continued popularity of that old stand-by, lightweight cotton corduroy, as a garment material for both children and adults, a report on tests concerned with its color-fastness has been included in this month's issue of The Journal of Home Economics.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 18 -- Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, the Greek Premier, conferred yesterday with Government leaders here as Greece and Turkey sought to forge a united front against what both countries consider one of the most serious challenges the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has faced since its creation four years ago.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Israeli Embassy struck back today against charges by Jordan that Israel had aggressive designs on neighboring Jordan and had deliberately incited border violence with that country.
The United Hunts Racing Association inaugurated its two-day meeting at Belmont Park yesterday, with the $11.350 New York Turf Writers Cup hurdles handicap occupying the feature spot.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 18 -- Continued progress was reported here today in discussions by the four-nation committee considering ways and means of evacuating Nationalist Chinese troops from Burma.

The National Labor Relations Board has made such progress on its backlog of cases that now, for the first time, less than a year elapses between the time a charge is made to the board and a decision is issued, George J. Bott, general counsel, said yesterday.

BERLIN, June 18 -- The three Western powers demanded tonight that the Soviet Union lift its military barrier virtually cutting Berlin in two and denounced as a "travesty of justice" the Soviet execution of a West Berliner as an alleged instigator of yesterday's riots.

INCHON, Korea, Friday, June 19 -- At least thirty-three non-Communist Korean war prisoners were killed and ninety-three wounded when captives in a prison enclosure near here made a mass break for freedom last night. About 400 escaped into the nearby countryside.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- James L. Guilmartin of Miami, Fla., nominated by President Eisenhower to be United States Attorney for Southern Florida, was described today as "fresh out of New York" and without a "Cracker accent."

Somehow the reasons why men cultivate mustaches and the mental processes connected with the decision to begin on one receive far more discussion, written and oral, than the reasons why mustaches are abandoned, or shorn.

On the basis of a financial report received yesterday from Controller Lazarus Joseph, the City Council will fix next week a basic real estate tax rate Of $3.33 for each $100 of assessed valuation for 1953-54, subject to a mandatory upward revision next December which is expected to bring the average annual rate up to or close to a record-breaking $3.60.

Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., chief of the United States delegation to the United Nations, said yesterday that exaggerated hopes for the United Nations had led to exaggerated criticism of the organization, which he termed an essential instrument for the prevention of war.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The immigration and naturalization service has taken into custody fifty-five Chinese, twenty-four of them from the New York area, for possible deportation to Red China, the Attorney General, Herbert Brownell Jr., announced today.

The International Basic Economy Corporation announced yesterday the election of Robert C. Fulton Jr. as president to succeed Nelson A. Rockefeller, who has designed to become Under Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in Washington.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The United States established at noon today full diplomatic relations with the new Government of Colombia headed by Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, it was announced simultaneously at the State Department and the Colombian Embassy.

Special agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation apprehended yesterday Raymond F. Fox, a 32-year-old Queens truck driver, and accused him of kidnapping Jacques Loup Stern, 21, son of the late Jacques Leon Stern, former French Colonial Secretary.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $790,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

THE proposed rules on the importation of feathers, as disclosed by the Department of the Interior, applying to domesticated as well as wild birds, would work considerable hardship on both the amateur and professional fly-tier, and representatives of these groups yesterday petitioned the Department for an extension. This would permit qualified persons to study the proposals and suggest such changes as might appear necessary.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (UP) -- The Air Force today announced a reduction in its construction program of heavy presses, the massive tools designed by the Germans for mass production of airplane parts.

Department stores with annual sales volume in excess of $1,000,000 recorded their second lowest net profit ratio in nineteen years in 1952, according to a survey report published yesterday by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Good Association.

Stockholders of Robertshaw-Fulton Controls Company, at their special meeting yesterday in Greensburg, Pa., ratified an amendment to the company's certificate of incorporation to permit the creation of 160,000 shares of new preferred stock of $25 par value.

Speaking of book burning: In Chicago on April 12, the anniversary of President Roosevelt's death, a mob broke up a meeting of the Council of American-Soviet Friendship. More than a dozen persons were injured. Uncontrolled by the police, 100 or more books, including Dr. Corliss Lamont's book "Soviet Civilization," were burned or otherwise destroyed in the street.

A lawyer was stabbed to death in his office at 152 West Forty-second Street by a disgruntled client a little before noon yesterday. The assailant, captured without a struggle by associates of the lawyer, was arrested on a charge of homicide.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A special subcommittee of five members was created in the House of Representatives today to consider the impeachment of William O. Douglas, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.
MONTREAL, June 18 (UP) -- The United States will turn from an exporting into an importing nation, a leading Canadian business man said today.

Capt. J. S. Delano, president of the American Pilots Association, was elected a vice president of the United Seamen's Service at the eleventh annual meeting of its trustees, Marshall E. Dimock, chairman of the executive committee, announced yesterday.
BOSTON, June 18 (UP) -- Four modern baseball records for hits and runs in an inning were set by the Red Sox today as they crushed the Tigers for the second day in a row. The score was 23 to 3.

At the annual meeting yesterday of Group IV Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, T. Arthur Nosworthy was elected chairman of the group. He is president of the Bronx Savings Bank. New members of the executive committee include C. William Borchers, executive vice president of the North Side Savings Bank, and Henry R. Sutphen Jr., president of the American Savings Bank.

The revised Bricker resolution, reported favorably to the Senate by a 9-5 vote of the Judiciary Committee, is still in our opinion a harmful proposal that could seriously interfere with the conduct of foreign relations by the United States.

Supplying of products for recreation and athletics is now "big business," according to the forty-fourth edition of the Directory of Sporting Goods Jobbers and Manufacturers' Representatives, just published. The net worth of the 1,200 jobbers disclosing such information is more than $463,000,000.

Sir Gerald Templer, High Commissioner in Malaya, has marked the rounding out of five years of warfare against the Communist terrorists on a note of cautious optimism. There is no reason to be complacent, he said, but there is ground for satisfaction in the fact that incidents of murder, arson and abduction have been brought into a sharp decline.
DETROIT, June 18 -- Mr. Thurston, who has been Michigan's superintendent of public instruction since 1948, is widely regarded in educational circles here as a cautious administrator.

SEATTLE, June 18 -- Substantial progress in the movement to spread new industrial plants over a wide area as a precautionary measure against bombings was reported today to the eighty-fifth annual convention of the American Institute of Architects.

OSSINING, N. Y., June 18 -- Warden Wilfred L. Denno and his staff at Sing Sing Prison heard over the prison radio shortly before 7 o'clock tonight the news of the Supreme Court's recess until noon tomorrow without a decision in the Rosenberg case.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Employment in non-farm industries rose by 150,000 between April and May, mainly because of the spring upturn in construction and other outdoor work, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The rise in construction employment was the smallest reported for this time of year since 1945, but the decline in manufacturing employment was less than usual.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The House of Representatives plunged into bitter debate today on the controversial $4,998,732,500 foreign aid authorization bill after a warning from its Republican managers that the foreign policy leadership of President Eisenhower was at stake.

BERLIN, June 18 -- Willi Goettling, West Berliner who was shot today by Soviet troops for his alleged role in yesterday's East Berlin rioting, was identified by the West German police as an unemployed painter with a wife and two small daughters.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (AP) -- An error and three scratch hits spoiled a good relief pitching performance by Morris Martin tonight as the Indians scored twice in the twelfth inning to down the Athletics, 6 -- 4.

President Eisenhower seemed to be making two mutually inconsistent points in his Wednesday press conference. One was that the Tennessee Valley Authority represented what he had previously described as "creeping socialism." The other was that he is not out to destroy T. V. A. although, if the T. V. A. experiment were repeated, he would like the local people to have a greater interest and a greater voice in it.

TOKYO, June 18 (UP) -- Gen. Mark W. Clark knew in advance that President Syngham Rhee did not intend to allow North Korean prisoners to be handed over to the neutral commission and to be subjected to indoctrination lectures by Communist agents.

BONN, Germany, June 18 -- The proclamation of martial law in the East sector of Berlin has raised the question of the survival of the East German Communist Government and party as they are now constituted and led.

TRENTON, June 18 -- Direct evidence was presented to a legislative committee here today that Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons had detailed information in respect to gambling and obvious corruption in Bergen County nearly two years before Nelson F. Stamler was assigned to ferret it out and three months before Walter G. Winne was reappointed prosecutor of that county by the Governor.

Stockholders of Algemene Kunstzijde Unie, N. V. (A. K. U.-United Rayon Manufacturing Corporation) approved the payment of a dividend of 9 per cent of the par value of the ordinary shares for the year 1952, at a meeting in Amsterdam yesterday, according to an announcement released here by the company.
ELIZABETH, N. J., June 18 -- A property owners' "march" on Trenton in an attempt to block a state rent control law was announced here today by the Property Owners Protective Association.

LONDON, June 18 (AP) -- An all-Australian semi-final turned up in the men's singles division today, and the United States suffered another rude jolt when its ace doubles team was ousted from the London lawn tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Democrats in the Senate blocked a final vote late today on a compromise controls bill, written in Senate-House conference, on the basis that the Senate should not be rushed into approving a provision the House proposed for creation of a Small Business Administration.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The National Production Authority reduced to six items the number of scarce materials on which it considers strict inventory controls must be retained. The list, established after outbreak of the Korean war, at one time contained well over 100 items, and has been steadily whittled down.

The Yankees gave the American League further cause to cry "uncle" yesterday. Off on a brand new winning streak, Casey Stengel's world champions made it there in a row over the Browns with a pair of shut-out victories in a Stadium double-header witnessed by 15,953 spectators.

Members of Congress will debate various public issues in a series of filmed television programs being produced by Facts Forum, an organization that originated in Dallas, Tex., two years ago with H. L. Hunt, wealthy oil operator, among its charter members. Mr. Hunt, currently visiting here, said that the half-hour programs would be offered at "about cost" to stations throughout the country.

IT was a lovely day outside with the sun shining brightly and it was pleasant inside the restaurant. The tinkle of the bartender's cocktail shaker provided cheerful background music. The food was delicious. But the two editors from one of our finest and oldest publishing houses were gloomy. "Look what's happened to poetry," said the senior editor. "
SEOUL, Friday, June 19 (AP) -- The text of President Syngman Rhee's reply to President Eisenhower's letter of June 6:

ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 18 -- Winning the girls' championship of the twenty-eighth annual marble tournament here today. Arlene Riddett, 15 years old of Yonkers, N. Y., will go into the boys' finals tomorrow, giving rise to the possibility that a girl may become champion in both divisions for the first time in tournament history.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 -- A United Nations agency has developed a novel cooperative visa plan to help stranded European refugees get out of Communist-controlled Shanghai.

A demand by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., for a "general" wage increase for 20,000 workers in eight East Coast shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company was rejected by the company yesterday as wage review conferences were resumed.

Stock traders and investors did not know what to make yesterday of Syngman Rhee's actions or of the anti-Communist riots in East Berlin. Consequently, trading on the New York Stock Exchange slowed to 1,010,000 shares, with the result that it was the narrowest session in nine months.

UMATILLA, Ore., June 18 -- Army engineers have tentatively set Dec. 1 as the date for the dedication of the huge $282,000,000 multipurpose dam named for the late Senator Charles L. McNary, Oregon Republican. The low-level structure that lies across the Columbia here in a rich wheat and cattle growing area nearly 300 miles from the river's mouth is about 95 per cent complete.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Representative Ernest K. Bramblett, Republican of California, pleaded innocent today in United States District Court to eighteen charges of payroll padding and receiving kickbacks from his office employes.

Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, former chairman of the. General Advisory Committee of the Atomic Energy Commission, asserts in an article in Foreign Affairs, published today, that the time has come to give the American people and the nation's allies much more information than they now have about the size and effectiveness of our atomic stockpile.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 18 -- Professor Clarence W. Mendell, 70-year-old retired dean and former athletic chairman, was named acting athletic director of Yale University today. President A. Whitney Griswold announced that Dr. Mendell, who is Sterling Professor Emeritus of Latin Language and Literature, will take over the duties of Robert A. Hall, beginning July 1.

CAIRO, June 18 -- The United States will offer technical assistance to Egypt on a broad range of educational problems including rural and vocational training and in the field of public health under the terms of two new agreements signed here today.
Expressions of concern and protest over the fate of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, convicted atom spies, continued to come from different parts of the world yesterday before the Supreme Court's recess.
TOKYO, Friday, June 19 -- The world's worst air disaster killed every one of 129 United States servicemen aboard a giant Globe-master transport plane in a fiery crash near Tokyo yesterday.
TOKYO, Friday, June 19 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,650, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

American manufacturers anxious to overcome dollar-exchange difficulties, or expand markets in England, were urged yesterday to consider improved opportunities for new plant development in Britain's Lancashire industrial center.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold stepped publicly into the Korean situation for the first time today with a denunciation of the Republic of Korea for releasing North Korean prisoners of war.

Tax borrowing raised New York bank loans to business enterprises for the second successive week, lifting such credits $122,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday. The two-week rise, amounting to $187,000,000, compares with a gain of $189,000,000 in the similar period a year ago.

Plans to house girls and women living alone in New York on low salaries were announced yesterday by the Volunteers of America, which has purchased for the purpose the nine-story building at 336-40 West Eighty-fifth Street. Formerly operated by the Three Arts Club as a residence for girls, the building contains 200 rooms and was sold for $400,000 in a deal negotiated by Bart Greene of Carstens Linnekin, Inc., brokers.

PARIS, Friday, June 19 -- France's longest political crisis since World War II continued into its fifth week today with the rejection by the National Assembly of Andre Marie, the Radical party's wartime resistance hero, by a vote of 272 in M. Marie's favor to 209, with more than 100 abstentions. He required 314 votes.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Western Union Telegraph company today announced proposed changes in rates for its leased wire facilities which company officials said would reduce overall charges to patrons by about $367,000 a year.

KINGS POINT, L. I., June 18 -- Harvard led with 186 points after thirteen races at the end of the second day of the national intercollegiate dinghy sailing championship. The regatta is being held in Long Island Sound off the United Estates Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A Senate investigation to "determine the extent of American culpability" in South Korea's release of anti-Communist North Korean war prisoners in defiance of the United Nations was proposed today by Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, Republican of New Jersey.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., June 16 -- A Utah business man declared today that fringe benefits paid workers throughout the nation average about 20 per cent of a company's payroll costs and will probably play an important part in future economic cost studies.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The House today rejected a proposal that would have allowed an investigation of a veteran's finances if he asked for free medical care for an ailment not connected with his military service.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- President Eisenhower today dispatched to President Syngman Rhee of the Korean Republic a secret but sharply worded message demanding the immediate recapture of thousands of anti - Communist North Korean prisoners of war set free by South Korean guards in violation of United Nations agreements.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Two enemies of the United States in World War II, Germany and Italy, were listed for large military aid grants today in a Senate report on the Mutual Security authorization bill for the 1954 fiscal year. It showed Germany getting $375,722,000 and Italy $316,538,000.

PUSAN, Korea, June 18 -- Some of the 25,000 North Korean prisoners of war who escaped this morning with the aid of South Korean guards roamed the back alleys of this city tonight and mingled openly with the populas, with no fear of pursuit from either United Nations or Korean troops.

LONDON, June 18 -- The nationalized British transport system showed a profit of 8,400,000 ($23,520,000) last year, it was announced today in the annual report of the Transport Commission. The system includes railway trucks, ferries, buses, local transportation in London and the provinces, docks, inland waterways and some hotels.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Dr. Allen V. Astin, director of the National Bureau of Standards, will get his first opportunity next week to present for the record his side of the controversy over AD-X2, additive for storage batteries.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to speed action on President Eisenhower's request for renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act by foregoing the usual public hearings.

BELGRADE, June 18 (AP) -- The Belgrade radio announcement of the approval of a Soviet request to move ships through the 300-mile Yugoslav section of the Danube did not disclose the types of vessels involved, but called them warships.
WASHINGTON, Jun 18 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, named Dr. J. B. Matthews as executive director of the Senate Investigating subcommittee today.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- (UP) -- House investigators agreed today there is "no evidence" of "political favoritism" in the Department of Agriculture's sale of 80,000 tons of dried peas at a cut-rate price to three West Coast firms seven weeks ago. But Democrats on a House Agriculture subcommittee continued sharp criticism of the department.

ALBANY, June 18 -- The Public Service Commission today blocked plans of the New York Water Service Corporation to increase rates charged to about 18,000 customers in the Woodhaven and Ozone Park sections of Queens and 2,000 in the Haverstraw area of Rockland County.

Frederic D. Sasse, as successor trustee, has sold the fifteen-story apartment house for seventy-nine families on plot 59 by 128 feet at the southeast corner of Second Avenue and Eleventh Street to an investing client of Judd Gurfein, attorneys, in deal negotiated by Milton F. Dombek, broker.

Although Mary Martin has been signed for "Kind Sir" until next May 29, producers already are anxious to engage her for the 1954-55 campaign. One of the managements desiring her services is the team of David Merrick and Joshua Logan in behalf of "Marseilles," a musical amalgamation by Mr. Logan, S. N. Behrman and Harold Rome of three Marcel Pagnol plays ("Marius," "Fanny" and "Cesar").
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The White Sox overcame a two-run deficit with a six-run splurge in the ninth inning to defeat the Senators, 8 -- 4, tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A series of witnesses with long backgrounds in military affairs and defense legislation today told a subcommittee of the House of Representatives that the Administration's plan to reorganize the Defense Department would cripple civilian control of the military forces and dangerously centralize military power.

The element of timing can be a critical one in many human courses of action. Most of us will agree that the anti-Communist prisoners of war in Korea should be set at liberty. They are actually not prisoners at all but deserters from the enemy's camp to our own cause. Many of them were impressed into the Communist Army against their will.
LAKELAND, Fla., June 18 (AP) -- The Florida Citrus Commission plans to spend $2,500,000 in advertising Florida citrus fruit this year.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Department store sales in the United States for the week ended last Saturday were 4 per cent below sales for the similar period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 18 -- Yugoslavia, which agreed to exchange Ambassadors with the Soviet Union last week at Moscow's request, has granted permission for twenty-six Soviet war vessels, now docked in Vienna, to pass through the Yugoslav section of the Danube River on their way to the Black Sea area for repairs.

Two former United States fliers, one-time prisoners of Rumanian Nazis, held a sentimental reunion last evening with the man who had helped them in a Bucharest prison nine years ago and whose two sons now are being kept as hostages by Rumanian Communists.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 18 -- Vincent Fitzgerald of Garden City took the lead in defense of his metropolitan seniors golf championship today by scoring 39, 39 -- 78 over Winged Foot's west course as the twenty-sixth title tournament started.

MOSCOW, June 18 -- Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen of the United States has been advised by Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov that exit permission has been approved for four more Russian wives of American citizens, including the wives of three more American correspondents in Moscow.

TOLEDO, June 18 (AP) -- Skee Riegel and Freddie Haas ripped four strokes off par with 67's today to take the lead over twenty- eight other professionals in the first round of the 72-hole $18,000 Inverness invitation golf tournament.

LONG BEACH, L. I., June 18 -- State action on the problem of municipal liability for accidents that occur on public property was urged here today at the annual state conference of mayors and other community officials.

The English teacher at James Madison High School in Brooklyn to whom Dr. Albert Einstein wrote last week urging that every intellectual called before a Congressional investigating committee should refuse to testify even if it meant jail or economic ruin was ordered ousted from his job yesterday by the Board of Education.

Reflecting the recent increases in crude oil prices in virtually every field east of the Rocky Mountains, prices of gasoline and other major oil products, were raised yesterday in several areas. Generally, gasoline prices were advanced a cent a gallon at the wholesale level and other products around a half cent.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- A virtual 100 per cent increase in the numerical strength of the American merchant marine was recommended to Congress today by Solon B. Turman, president of the Lykes Brothers Steamship Company, New Orleans.

Although sales of Armour Co. and its domestic subsidiaries were lower in the thirteen and twenty-six weeks ended last May 2, earnings were substantially higher than for the corresponding periods last year, according to the report issued yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- President Walter O'Malley of the Dodgers may be winging his way West again to find out what's wrong with his team. Today, for the third straight time, the Brooks bowed to the Cardinals and by the most emphatic score of the series, 12 -- 4. They now are three games back of the first-place Braves.

The Russians wanted an example to strike terror, so they executed Willi Goettling of West Berlin. If anything is certain in the confusion and terror and wonder of what is happening in Eastern Germany it is that the Russians have made a martyr. There will be a statue to Willi Goettling some day and it will be built by workers, for he was a laborer.

The thirty-sixth season of Lewisohn Stadium concerts will open Monday evening, with Leonard Bernstein conducting the Stadium Symphony Orchestra and with Zino Francescatti as soloist in the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto. The concert will open with Beethoven's "Eroica" Symphony.

HOUSTON, Texas, June 18 -- The forty-second triennial convention of the Lutheran Church, Missouri Synod, heard a proposal today that it borrow $10,000,000 during the next three years for capital investment.

Enough money has been raised to assure the continuing operation of New York City Center of Music and Drama, Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of directors, said yesterday in disclosing that the center had received a $25,000 grant from the New York Foundation of 61 Broadway.
The cold soups that have become popular in the last decade or so often are referred to as "sophisticated" when actually, in the countries from which we borrow them, they are quite generally used.

A tract of eleven acres in the Sunny Ridge section of Harrison, N. Y., has been purchased by Edwin Bayer and Ernest J. Calcagni through their Sunny Ridge Estates, Inc., for improvement with houses in the $55,000 price class. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The American middleweight championship will be decided tonight at Madison Square Garden, when Carl ( Bobo ) Olson. Honolulu-born San Franciscan, faces Paddy Young. New York West Side southpaw, in the feature bout of fifteen rounds. The International Boxing Club, sponsor of the event, anticipates a crowd of 10,000.

Hope for a quick end of the three-day seamen's strike, which is slowly clamping a vise on one-half of the nation's privately operated merchant fleet, faded late yesterday when the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., suddenly increased the monetary formula it had demanded earlier of 100 tanker and dry-cargo ship operators.

VIENNA, June 18 -- Chancellor Julius Raab suggested in the Austrian Parliament today that the Russians should round but their recent concessions to this country by abolishing censorship of the mails, telegraphs, telephones and control of the Austrian radio, by discontinuing their controlled shops and by evacuating their troops pending conclusion of a state treaty.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A booklet to promote better understanding between parents and teachers as to children's progress through report cards was issued today by the Association of Childhood Education.

At the end of this year, George L. Harrison announced yesterday, he will retire as chairman of the board of the New York Life Insurance Company. Devereux C. Josephs, now president, will succeed him as chairman and Clarence J. Myers, executive vice president, will become president on Jan. 1.

The New York City Transit Authority ordered an additional 21,500,000 tokens yesterday for use on rapid transit lines when the fare is increased on July 30. It had previously placed orders for 20,000,000 tokens.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, June 19 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists, apparently heedless of losses, assaulted the flaming central front at six places early today. The Eighth Army said the Reds attacked each of the United Nations' points in company strength or stronger. A Chinese Communist company numbers 150 to 175 infantrymen.

RICHMOND, Va., June 18 -- A private, voluntary coordinating agency to promote state-wide health and medical care on a community self-help basis has directed the placement of fifty-four physicians in forty-three Virginia localities burdened with rural health problems.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield said today the scheduled 36 per cent advance in parcel post zone rates would be made effective Oct. 1.

ATHENS, June 18 -- An exchange of Ambassadors between Moscow and Athens is regarded in diplomatic circles as a probability following logically upon the other Kremlin peace overtures already made to Greece's two Balkan allies. Turkey and Yugoslavia.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, June 19 -- The United Nations Command appeared today to be faced with an impossible task in trying to round up the approximately 24,000 anti-Communist prisoners of war who "escaped" yesterday from their camps in the south with the cooperation and full approval of the Republic of Korea Government.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Wheat futures continued to show strength today, while there was a generally heavy tendency in coarse grains, and soybeans were distinctly weak. Uncertainty regarding truce prospects in Korea was further increased by the action of President Rhee in freeing prisoners of war.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Federal Trade Commission charged the makers of a shampoo and a soap with "false and misleading advertising" today. At the same time, it announced that two other concerns had agreed under the terms of stipulations with the commission to refrain in the future from questionable advertising claims.

RYE, N. Y., June 18 -- Donald Dell of Landon School, Washington, D. C. No. 2 in the seeding, and John Foster of Choate School, Wallingford, Conn., seeded fifth, won their semi-final matches at Mansuring Island Club today and will meet tomorrow for the singles championship of the twenty-second eastern interscholastic tennis tournament for private and prep schools.

Your recent editorial "Battle Over Natural Gas" discusses the Court of Appeals finding that, contrary to the Power Commission opinion, the Federal Power Commission had the authority to regulate the production and sale of natural gas (frequently produced with crude oil) by the producer. Such a finding is untenable.
Two men found guilty of operating an income tax refund scheme that defrauded the Government of $986,000 received jail sentences yesterday from Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy.

CINCINNATI, June 18 -- Dave Koslo gained his first victory of the season and the Giants their first series triumph in a fortnight today as the Polo Grounders took the finale from Manager Rogers Hornsby's Redlegs, 6 to 3. Before this laudable feat was written into the records, Hoyt Wilhelm's baffling skill was needed.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 18 -- A new champion will wear the crown of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association this Saturday, as Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks today eliminated the defending champion, Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood.

ALTHOUGH the heavyweight division is naturally the top-ranking class in boxing, the middleweights rank second from the standpoint of glamour, appeal and importance. Yet no division in the entire busted beak industry has had a more muddled and morbid history than the 160-pound class.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The House Judiciary Committee, after a heated discussion, today postponed until Tuesday its decision on whether to issue a subpoena to require Tom C. Clark, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, to testify before one of its subcommittees.

UPPER SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., June 18 -- Daniel J. Deodati of Staten Island today was elected president of the New York State Pharmaceutical Association at its seventy-fifth annual convention at Saranac Inn here.

Despite a ten-point drop in the stock market, as measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES composite average of fifty stocks, the aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange showed relatively little change between May 15 and June 15.

The New York City Housing Authority raised $19,413,000 yesterday through the sale of temporary loan notes at interest rates ranging from 2.12 per cent to 2.20 per cent. Maturity dates range from Jan. 18 to Feb. 1, 1954 and all are dated July 20, 1953.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Supreme Court is expected to announce at noon tomorrow its decision as to whether it will set aside the stay of execution granted to Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the atom spies, by Justice William O. Douglas.

Despite a ten-point drop in the stock market, as measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES composite average of fifty stocks, the aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange showed relatively little change between May 15 and June 15.

The New York City Housing Authority raised $19,413,000 yesterday through the sale of temporary loan notes at interest rates ranging from 2.12 per cent to 2.20 per cent. Maturity dates range from Jan. 18 to Feb. 1, 1954 and all are dated July 20, 1953.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Supreme Court is expected to announce at noon tomorrow its decision as to whether it will set aside the stay of execution granted to Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the atom spies, by Justice William O. Douglas.

The General Electric Company is preparing to increase prices on some of its large household appliances and other consumer items, Roy W. Johnson, executive vice president in charge of the appliance and electronics groups, said yesterday. He did not specify what appliances will be affected or when the increases will go into effect.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 18 -- Mrs. George Whitney and Mrs. Edward F. Hutton are honorary chairmen and Mrs. Edward H. Gerry is general chairman for the sixth annual parish fair of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Advent, which takes place tomorrow on the church ground on the Jericho Turnpike.

ALBANY, June 18 -- Governor Dewey announced tonight that he was calling the members of the Legislature back to the capital for a special session beginning at noon Thursday, June 25, to deal with corruption uncovered by the investigations of the State Crime Commission.

LONDON, June 18 -- The prospects for a four-power meeting following the Bermuda conference of Sir Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister, President Eisenhower and the Premier of France are regarded here as slight.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 18 -- The Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships being held this week on the clay courts of the United States Military Academy moved into the semi-final round today.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Stringent controls over exports of scrap iron and steel will be retained through the rest of this year, Samuel W. Anderson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs, announced today.

TOKYO, Friday, June 19 -- The Government-controlled Peiping radio charged today that Americans had "deliberately connived" with Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of South Korea, in staging the mass outbreak of anti-Communist prisoners of war.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned active during the last forty minutes of trading yesterday and closed steady, 9 to 16 points net higher on the day on active months.

LONDON, June 18 -- Prime Minister Churchill, speaking in the belief that he reflected the feelings of all important political factions in Britain, said today he was "shocked and grieved" by the action of the South Korean Government in liberating 25,000 anti-Communist North Korean war prisoners.

Dr. Tibor Nyilas of the Salle Santelli and Paula Sweeney of Detroit captured titles as the national fencing championships continued yesterday. Dr. Nyilas retained his saber crown by topping fifty-one rivals in the competition held at the New York Athletic Club. Miss Sweeney carried off the women's championship, competing in a field of eighteen.

ROME, June 18 -- A Foreign Ministry spokesman took exception at a press conference today to a Trieste dispatch published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Tuesday in which it was suggested that the three-power declaration of 1948 on Trieste was no longer taken seriously by authoritative Italian circles.

A trial board of the Board of Higher Education was told yesterday that three officials of City College deliberately withheld a letter sent by the school's assistant basketball coach to one of the players, because they felt its publication in the newspapers would be detrimental to the college.
A chase that ranged over four nations ended yesterday with the rounding up of six men charged with assorted hold-ups that netted $75,000 in eight months, including a $25,000 robbery in the Bronx.

Pork prices declined for the second successive week as consumers continued to ignore this high-priced meat. Loin roast of pork dropped 4 cents to 69 a pound and loin chops at 89 cents a pound were 6 cents lower than a week ago.

Columbia University announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Richard H. Logsdon as director of libraries. Dr. Logsdon succeeds Dr. Carl M. White, whose resignation as director was announced recently. Dr. White will devote his time to the Columbia School of Library Service, of which he is dean.

BURGENSTOCK, Switzerland, June 18 -- The chances that either India or Switzerland now would participate in a neutral commission to supervise the repatriation of war prisoners in Korea seemed remote to diplomatic circles in Switzerland today even in the event a truce is signed.

Twenty candidates for Mayor or other places on a city-wide coalition ticket were suggested last evening at a conference of representatives of the Republican and Liberal parties and the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee.

Volume eased yesterday on most New York commodity exchanges with only cocoa, lead and cottonseed oil showing substantial gains. Wool, lead, zinc, copper, tin, rubber and hides closed higher. Coffee, sugar, cottonseed oil and soybean oil ended mixed, and cocoa and potatoes were lower.

CLEVELAND, June 18 -- Future grievance negotationswith the , railroads will be futile unless management spokesmen retract threats to obtain a no-strike pledge with the aid of a "Congressional black jack." chiefs of five railroad unions declared in a joint statement issued here today.
The National Federation of American Shipping sought yesterday to insure participation of American-flag vessels in the proposed plan to furnish wheat for Pakistan.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "The 5,000 Fingers of Dr. T." a comedy-fantasy in Technicolor, produced by the Stanley Kramer Company for Columbia release, with Peter Lind Hayes, Mary Healy, Hans Conried and the child actor, Tommy Rettig, is at the Criterion.

The seventieth convention of the National Confectioners Association closed at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday with approval of a resolution denouncing international sugar controls, domestic sugar quotas, Government subsidies to agriculture, particularly on peanuts, and approval of the extension for one year of the Reciprocal Trade Act.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 18 (AP) -- Mighty Grattan charged down the middle of the stretch to win the Floral Park Pace by a half-length tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

The Department of Sanitation, made cautious by the rich harvest of $10 towing fees from owners whose cars were impounded for defying the alternate-side parking rules, is transferring the collection of these fees from its three car pounds in outlying parts of Manhattan to its headquarters at 125 Worth Street.

Two hundred veterans of the war in Korea had a chance to relax last night at the 212th program arranged by the Lambs Service Men's Morale Corps since its founding in May, 1942. What distinguished the reception, dinner and show -- the first in six years -- was that all of he guests had seen service under the United Nations command.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Benjamin F. Fairless, board chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, pledged his support to President Eisenhower today for a six-month continuation of the excess profits tax. After a call at the White House, he related that the President had asked him how he felt about the proposed extension.

" Tolstoy: A Life of My Father," by the Russian writer's only surviving child, Alexandra Tolstoy, has been scheduled for Sept. 16 publication by Harper. The author, who is the head of the Tolstoy Foundation, which aids refugees from the Soviet Union, accompanied her father as an old man when he fled from his home.

RYE, N. Y., June 19 -- John Foster of Choate, seeded fifth, captured the singles championship of the twenty-second Manursing Island interscholastic tennis tournament today and clinched the team title for the Wallingford, Conn., school.

After having cleared the fourteenth of the fifteen jumps in the two-and-a-quarter-mile Temple Gwathmey Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, Montpelier's Sea Legs bowed a tendon -- but still managed to finish second five and a half lengths behind the first horse.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it will grant farmers 80 per cent of price supports on wheat stored outdoors in certain areas of the Southwest.

MOSCOW, June 19 -- The Kiev newspaper Pravda of the Ukraine reported today a number of additional personnel changes, including the release from responsibilities as Deputy Chairman of the Ukrainian Council of Ministers of Anatole M. Baranovsky.

BURGENSTOCK, Switzerland, June 19 -- The release of North Korean war prisoners by President Syngman Rhee was "deplorable and most objectionable and a deliberate attempt to sabotage the armistice agreement," a spokesman for Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nebru of India said here today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The text of the Supreme Court ruling, read from the bench by Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson: the concurring opinion by Justice Tom Clark in which he was joined by Justices Vinson, Reed, Jackson, Burton and Minton; and of Justice Jackson's concurring opinion in which he was joined by Justices Vinson, Reed,Burton, Clark, and Minton, and the texts of the dissenting opinions of Justices Black and Douglass. follow:

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Trading in grain futures slowed down a little from the rapid pace during the week, but was still active today on heavy profit taking in wheat, which caused a fair recession, and by active buying of corn which rose to the highest level in some time.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Responsible foreign policy officials are feeling today very much like the parrot whoze cage was uncovered as usual at 8 o'clock one morning and then, for reasons known only to its owner, covered up again two hours later.

PARIS, June 19 -- Abandoning the ineffective constitutional procedure, President Vincent Auriol appealed today to former Premiers and to the leaders of the French political parties as a patriotic duty to assist in solving the Cabinet crisis that has paralyzed the French Government for a month.

Employes of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company have ratified a new contract with the company that grants a 5-cent-an-hour wage increase across the board, it was disclosed last night at a meeting of Local 100, Utility Division. Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. A spokesman for the city's Labor Relations Division announced that the union members had voted by an almost 8-to-1 majority to accept the offer.

THE late reports from Maine indicate the fishing is holding up to the prediction of "the best in years," with landlocked salmon plentiful in the northern lakes, bass fishing excellent and quite a few fresh-run salmon being taken from the Narraguagus and Dennys Rivers.

BOSTON, June 19 (UP) -- George Kell, playing despite a painful back injury, singled home the winning run in the fifth inning tonight as the Red Sox beat the Browns, 4 -- 1, before 10,567 fans at Fenway Park.
A net profit of $7,052,680, after providing $5,750,000 for taxes, was reported yesterday by the United Shoe Machinery Corporation in its annual statement for the fiscal year ended last Feb. 28.

With the recent publication of the 1952 edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES Index, it is interesting to note that The Index is as old as THE TIMES itself, for it, too, goes back to 1851. Long is the span from that first Index, recorded in careful Spencerian hand in a small ledger, to the 1952 giant of 1,293 pages which summarizes more than a half-million news items in two-and-a-quarter-million words.

BERLIN, June 19 -- The three Western powers in Berlin urged the Soviet Union today to forbid the use of firearms by its troops and by the East German police in the Soviet sector of the city to prevent further bloodshed.

OSSINING, N. Y., June 19 -- Stoic and tight-lipped to the end. Julius and Ethel Rosenberg paid the death penalty tonight in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison for their war-time atomic espionage for Soviet Russia.

A week ago spokesmen for the National Association of Manufacturers appeared before the House Ways and Means Committee in opposition to the Administration's proposal for extending the life of the excess-profits tax for six months. They did this, moreover, in the face of the fact that a telegraphic poll of the organization's members had just shown a substantial majority in favor of supporting President Eisenhower on this issue.

CAIRO, June 19 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammad Naguib, first President and Premier of the newly proclaimed Republic of Egypt, tonight in the palace of Egypt's former king, administered the oath of office to his new Cabinet, including members of the Revolution Council that put him in power.

"' THE ILIAD' is the monumental gate through which we enter the literature of Western civilization," Henry Rowell observes in his fine essay on a man Max Beerbohm called "those famous poets, Homer." Within the gate lie many adventures in reading. Thirteen of these are briskly and authoritatively sketched by savants from Johns Hopkins, Mr. Rowell among them, in a new book called "Literary Masterpieces of the Western World."*
SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 19 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight he did not consider the New Jersey governorship election "a test of the Eisenhower Administration."

The Jewish Sabbath began last night at 8:13 o'clock, exactly eighteen minutes before official sundown as determined by the United States Weather Bureau for this latitude. The Sabbath will end at 9:13 o'clock tonight forty-two minutes after the formal hour of sunset.

Mondays are hard on all of us, but Fridays are getting be nightmares to the partners in Wall Street's commission houses. One broker commented yesterday, "A bomb could hit the New York Stock Exchange floor on a Friday any time after lunch and it probably would not hit any one.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Postmaster General, Arthur E. Summerfield, today announced a sharp increase in United States surface parcel post rates to foreign destinations, estimated to increase charges by $17,000,000 a year.

BERLIN, June 20 (AP) -- A crowd of 2,000 Germans, aroused by events in East Germany, raided a Socialist Unity (Communist) party office in the United States sector late today and forced several Red officials to flee through the back door.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, today joined Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, in the latter's movement designed to consolidate all Congressional investigations of subversive activities within the jurisdiction of a single joint committee of fourteen members.

DETROIT, June 19 (AP) -- Motor vihicle production in the United States this week will consist of 142,464 cars with 17,450 trucks, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. Last week 138,315 cars and 17,479 trucks were built. The statistical agency said this week's output compares with 94,347 cars and 24,901 trucks assembled in the comparable 1952 week.
Contributions were made yesterday by 318 rookie patrolmen to the blood bank of the American Red Cross at the Manhattan center, 70 West Fortieth Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- Kuo-cheng Wu, recently resigned Governor of Formosa and now minister without portfolio in the Chinese Nationalist Government of Chiang Kai shek, told the Commonwealth Club here today that war between the democracies and Communist China was inevitable.

What, indeed, is so rare as a day in June? Little did James Russell Lowell realize when he posed this purely rhetorical question that a time would come when June would have a Day to suit almost every occasion.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 20 -- Communist armistice delegates at Panmunjom demanded today that the United Nations recapture all 25,000 anti-Communist prisoners of the Korean war released by the order of Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- An Internal Revenue agent who assisted a grand jury investigating the San Francisco Collector's office in 1951 testified today he found nothing to warrant prosecution.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Administration officials today countered charges that the proposal to reorganize the administrative and command structure of the Department of Defense posed a threat of military ascendancy over civilian officials.

Analysis of foreign trade statistics for the first three months of 1953 shows a falling-off in United States exports to Latin America. Monthly shipments to that area show a low of $231,000,000 in February and a high of $246,000,000 in March, compared with a monthly average last year of $290,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The House of Representatives authorized today an appropriation of $4,998,732,500 for military, economic and technical aid to fifty-six free governments and dependencies resisting communism. The vote sending the measure to the Senate was 280 to 108, with one Representative merely voting "present."

Once more a so-called "foreign aid" bill has started its course through Congress. Yesterday's action by the House indicates that for at least another year, and probably for some years to come, we will be providing the means by which our friends strengthen themselves against possible attack.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Three stained glass windows stored since the beginning of World War II have been returned to the national headquarters of the American Red Cross in preparation for the national Red Cross convention next week.

MILWAUKEE, June 19 -- Amid an insufferable heat that converted Milwaukee's Municipal Stadium into a cauldron of stewing humanity, Jolly Cholly Grimm's front-running Braves were struck by a bolt tonight that flattened them out with startling effect. But it didn't come from the steaming heavens above.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, June 20 (AP) -- Following is the unofficial text of the letter today from the Communist High Command in Korea to Gen. Mark W. Clark. United Nations Commander.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 19 -- It may be pure coincidence, of course, but the fact that Paramount has already rolled up a $12,000,000 gross with "The Greatest Show On Earth" may have influenced Columbia Pictures to become circus-minded, too.

JERSEY CITY, June 19 -- A request for a pension for the 80-year-old son of Jersey City's Civil War Mayor, because the late official's honesty had left his family impoverished, was being studied today by Mayor John V. Kenny.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 19 -- India, applying racial segregation in reverse to white South Africans, has set aside three hotels "of first class standard" in Bombay for South Africans visiting India, according to an announcement here by Air India International Limited.

HONG KONG, June 19 -- The Panamanian Consul, Mario E. Guillen, declared today he did not believe any bona fide Panamanian flag vessel was now in a Chinese Communist port. He added that registry of such ships would be automatically canceled if they were discovered making calls along the China coast.

ROME, June 19 -- The instinctive reaction of the non-Communist European to events in Berlin is highly significant. "If only this had happened before the election," sigh the Italians, and this comment expresses a general sentiment. Countries with an internal Communist problem do not think first of the effect of the workers' revolt in connection with the eventual fate of Germany.

CLEVELAND, June 19 -- Miss Edna Mae Gay, head of the Firemen's Fundgroup, Nashville, Tenn., was elected president of the National Association of Insurance Women at the concluding session of the twelfth annual convention today. She succeeds Mrs. Christine M. Buchwald of Cleveland.

An interesting sidelight of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta at Syracuse today is the fact that a blind oarsman, the 190-pound Oral O. Miller, will pull the No. 4 oar in Princeton's junior varsity shell. Miller is the first blind athlete ever to represent the Orange and Black in intercollegiate competition.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- The Indians gained ground on the league-leading Yankees for the first time in twenty-five games tonight when they defeated the Senators, 4 -- 2, on Mike Garcia's steady eight-hit pitching.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 19 (AP) Stockholders of Silex Company today cleared the way for a acquisition of the Chicago Electric Manufacturing Company by the Hartford glass coffee maker manufacturer.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Jacob D. Beam, a career diplomat who is now counselor of the United States Embassy in Moscow, was chosen by the State Department today to be deputy director of its policy planning staff. He will succeed John H. Ferguson in the unit responsible for long-range strategy planning.

The two-story industrial building at 6112-6120 Johnson Place in West New York, N. J., has been purchased by Alex Pozner, owner of the Play-Knit Mills, from Nunziante and Ottilio D'Alessio, who have figured prominently in the silk-dyeing industry in the area for many years. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 19 -- Although a synodical committee had recommended its adoption, the Lutheran Church, Missouri Synod, postponed action today on the second and final part of a doctrinal agreement with the American Lutheran Church.
FORT JACKSON, S. C., June 19 (AP) -- The Army gained two first places and enough runner-up titles to gain 39 points and an opening-day lead in the annual interservice track and field meet today.

Control of the Interstate Natural Gas Company of Monroe, La., has been acquired by Olin Industries, Inc. In making the announcement, John M. Olin, president, said that Olin now owned 770,000 shares, or about 81 per cent, of Interstate's 953,000 shares. The price paid for the stock was $45 a share, he said, and the same price has been offered to the other stockholders for their shares.

Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman denied at 7:45 o'clock last night an application for a writ of habeas corpus on behalf of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the atom spies, made by an attorney who pleaded with the judge to call Sing Sing prison and stay the execution until he could present his entire argument. He indicated this would take an additional hour.

Mrs. Geneva Jackso was sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions to a sixty-day workhouse term, while her common-law husband. Jacob, received a suspended sentence as a result of their conviction for assaulting a policeman.
I wish to thank you for the splendid coverage you gave to Dr. Einstein's historic letter. I understand that its echoes are still reverberating throughout the world.
The Brooklyn rackets grand jury -- in existence since December, 1949 -- had its term extended yesterday for another six months. It had been scheduled to expire at the end of the month.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 19 -- In an all-Hill School final, Finley McRae of Mobile, Ala., became the new Eastern interscholastic golf champion today by defeating Don Merkelbach of Glen Ridge, N. J., 3 and 2.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The United States Government worked in haste today to save a Korean truce that some responsible men regarded as all but lost through South Korea's angry defiance of the United Nations.
TOKYO, Saturday, June 20 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,651, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korean time:

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 19 -- State Representative C. William Horsley, Republican of Springfield, refused to sing for the House of Representatives today and his bill to protect the mourning dove from hunters died.
When Herschel Bregman came here from Minsk at the age of 77, his children told him not to bother to become an American citizen.

STRASBOURG, France, June 19 (Reuters) -- Jean Monnet, president of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, said here today that President Eisenhower's recommendation of United States loans to the community marked a turning point in the relations between Europe and the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Charles L. Cooper of Los Angeles patented a roller-coaster power system this week that is designed to eliminate that snap in the passenger's neck that is experienced as the car goes up the first hill. His drive equipment takes a firm hold of the car in the station and accelerates it smoothly to high speed from a standing start.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Eisenhower and the Supreme Court refused today to save Julius and Ethel Rosenberg from death in the electric chair.

Despite the fact that rumors were heard from 1948 to 1951 about the "dumping" of basketball games by City College players, nobody in "high authority" at the institution ordered an inquiry, Dr. Samuel Winograd, former faculty manager of athletics at the college, testified yesterday.
How silly can we get?
SYRACUSE, June 19 -- Navy's Olympic champion eight, a crew that has made rowing history, tomorrow defends its intercollegiate title and a winning streak without parallel.
ST. LOUIS, June 19 (UP) -- Wilmer Mizell twirled an eight-hitter tonight to give the Cardinals a 10-2 victory over the Pirates.

TOKYO, June 19 (AP) -- All giant C-124 Globemasters flying the airlift between Japan and Korea were grounded today pending a thorough investigation of history's greatest air disaster, which killed 129 United States servicemen yesterday.

A third session will be required to reach a decision in the tenth game of the match between Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires for the chess championship of the West being played in the Argentine capital according to a report received yesterday.

Mayor Impellitteri signed yesterday a local law authorizing the License Commissioner in his discretion to permit the sale of liquor in legitimate theatres subject to rules and regulations drawn by that official.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Eisenhower sat in today on a meeting with key legislators and his own staff to try to work out a program for revising the Taft-Hartley Act. The participants reported excellent progress and another meeting will be held on Tuesday.
MOUNT WASHINGTON, N. H., June 19 -- Dartmouth College already is planning what it will be like in 1969, when it will celebrate its 200th anniversary.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19 -- The United States told delegates attending a conference of the International Labor Organization in Geneva today that it did not believe in erecting barriers or pulling down curtains "to hide our methods and discoveries from our neighbors and friends in the world."

After reading your editorial "A Cambodian Gesture," in which you describe the King's voluntary exile as "badly timed and ill-advised," a Cambodian like myself can only meditate (rather sadly) on how little even a great and usually well-informed newspaper like THE NEW YORK TIMES seems to know of conditions in my country.

With reference to the letter in your Letters to THE TIMES of June 4 from Kenneth D. Robertson Jr., in which he stated that "Representative Walter Judd of Minnesota is quoted as saying that S. 1917, the bill to admit 240,000 additional immigrants from Europe, 'will do just as much good to our enemies as if it were written in the Kremlin,'" I have just had a letter from Dr. Judd.
BERLIN, June 19 -- A study of the timing, methods, and slogans used in the East Berlin uprising points to the existence of a nameless and faceless workers' underground organization in East Germany.

Cook County, Ill., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on July 7 on $15,000,000 of highway construction bonds dated July 1, 1953, and due July 1, 1973. The bonds are subject to call annually from 1954 to 1972.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19 -- Jordan and Israel have agreed to a new arrangement for the payment of blocked bank accounts of Arab refugees the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission announced today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 19 -- Dr. William A. Irwin, economist of the American Bankers Association, addressing the graduating class of the Graduate School of Banking at commencement exercises tonight at Rutgers University, outlined a program which he said the United States should follow if it is to consolidate and maintain its world position.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 19 -- This was a day of last-minute preparation for thirty yachts in the race to Annapolis that begins tomorrow. It will be the foremost ocean race of the Eastern season, covering 466 miles. It is being conducted by the New York Yacht Club in cooperation with the United States Naval Academy Sailing Squadron and the Annapolis Yacht Club.

SEATTLE, June 19 -- The American Institute of Architects wound up its eighty-fifth annual convention today following the passage of a resolution calling for a free and natural development of the fine arts in this country and condemning any proposals or laws which might lead to Government supervision or control in the field.

ALBANY, June 19 -- The State Banking Board authorized New York savings banks today to invest in $536,298,000 of interest-bearing obligations being issued by the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, the Central Bank for Cooperatives, the Phillips Petroleum Company and the Arkansas Power and Light Company.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 19 -- A sweep of the varsity semi-finals by the University of California's brilliant tennis team featured the competition in the Eastern intercollegiate championships today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Foreign traders were warned here yesterday that they must expect a reduction in the foreign commercial services supplied in previous years when the new fiscal year opens on July 1.

The military group that has ruled Egypt since July 26 of last year has now swept away the last yestiges of monarchy. A republic has been proclaimed. Egypt's successful military dictator has named himself President and has installed several more army officers as Cabinet members.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The following is the text of a letter made public today by Emanuel H. Bloch, attorney, from his client, Ethel Rosenberg, to President Eisenhower:

BEIRUT, Lebonon, June 15 -- Two scientists, acting as a water-investigation team in the Litani River basin, are providing water to an area in Lebanon that for generations has gone on severe water rationing during the dry summer season.

Nine homing pigeons that apparently had lost their way in a race from France to England earlier this month and had landed far at sea on the United States-bound liner Veendam, were homeward-bound again yesterday on the same ship.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A bill to simplify and modernize customs procedures, thus removing some major obstacles to foreign trade, was approved tentatively today by the House Ways and Means Committee.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The text of President Eisenhower's statement turning down the Rosenberg clemency appeal:
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to the homemaker.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19 -- Members of the Asian-African bloc at the United Nations were summoned today to meet Monday to discuss the new crisis in Korea.

HONG KONG, June 19 -- A note drafted in the handwriting of the Rev. Harold W. Rigney, former rector of the Roman Catholic Fujen University in Peiping raised new hopes for his safety today following earlier uncorroborated reports that the jailed American priest had died while a prisoner of the Chinese Communists.

Salle Santelli successfully defended its three-weapon crown by defeating the Fencers Club, 2 -- 1, as the national fencing championships were concluded at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. The three-weapon final was a highlight of the week-long tournament during which nine titles were decided.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that he supported the United Nations but that he "definitely" did not believe that the "United States should surrender her entire sovereignty to international organizations."
The four-day-old seamen's strike, which immobilized 125 vessels and threatened to paralyze one-half of the nation's fleet of 1,500 ships, came to an end at 12:45 A. M. today.

In the first sale of the property since 1904, the building at 56-58 Avenue B and 235-237 East Fourth Street, containing eight stores and thirty apartments, has been conveyed by the 56 Avenue B Corporation to the Raber Realty Corporation.

Various segments of the theatrical industry were represented yesterday at a luncheon given in honor of Councilman Hugh Quinn, Queens Democrat, for his "devoted and pioneer work" to effect the passage of twenty-two local laws permitting construction of Broadway playhouses within office buildings or apartment houses.

DETROIT, June 19 -- General James A. Van Fleet, retired Eighth Army Commander, denounced the Korean truce terms today as appeasement of aggression. He said that Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of South Korea, had virtually no option but to turn loose the anti-Communist North Korean prisoners.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, with prices for active months 3 to 11 points lower than on Thursday.

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was light in most markets and the world sugar contract had one of the dullest sessions of the year. However, hides experienced the most active day since April 17 and coffee and cottonseed oil were traded in sizable volume.

A lovely evening and a very large turnout greeted the Goldman Band last night in Central Park Mall at the opening of the thirty-sixth season of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts. The band's long-time leader, Edwin Franko Goldman, selected a program of original band music for the occasion.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Defense Department made public today the names of the United States servicemen killed in the C-124 disaster near Tokyo yesterday. Those from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, with next of kin, follow:

Carl (Bobo) Olson of Honolulu scored an easy victory over Paddy Young of Greenwich Village in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night. Fighting for what was billed as the American middleweight championship, the Hawaiian gained the unanimous decision by a wide margin.

Stock prices closed firm yesterday in the slowest trading witnessed on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange since last August. Volume fell to 891,020 shares from 1,010,000 on Thursday, and the market narrowed to 1,030 issues. At the close 399 showed losses, 379 gains and 252 no change.
