BRUNSWICK, Me., June 19 -- Mrs. Harvey Dow Gibson officiated today at the laying of the cornerstone for the Harvey Dow Gibson Hall of Music at Bowdoin College. The music temple, given by the Gibson family and the Manfacturers Trust Company and business associates of the late New York banker, a Bowdoin graduate in 1902, will cost an estimated $250,000.

The National Broadcasting Company announced a schedule yesterday of eleven college football games to be televised in full next fall and eight others that will be covered in part. The schedule was arranged in cooperation with the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which supervises the appearance of its member teams on television.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Eisenhower arranged today to make a face-to-face appeal to Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of upstate New York, for action on continuation of the excess profits tax.

A study conducted by the New York State Library reveals that of the forty-eight states only three meet the standards of the American Library Association in regard to library services. The report shows that the annual per capita state expenditure for library services ranged from $2.50 for Wisconsin to less than 25 cents in Nevada, with the median expenditure reported to be 80 cents.
Harry E. McCullough has been named general sales manager for television and radio of the Crosley division of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation.
Lack of information about new financial and economic policies in Brazil continued yesterday to cause apprehension and speculation among export concerns with interests in that country.

LONDON, June 19 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy, the United States tennis star, who earlier in the week threw his racquet at a linesman who he thought had missed a call, umpired a match in the London lawn tennis tourney today.
It comes as a pleasant surprise these days to find Governor Dewey and our city officials in agreement on anything. But on one thing at least they do agree, and that is hay fever. They hate it.

A Fulbright award granted last April to Dr. Naphiah Lewis of Brooklyn College to study in Italy during the next academic year has been canceled by the State Department, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said here yesterday.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 19 (AP) -- Guinea Gold, owned by Peerle S. Hungerford of Shelbyville, Ind., took command in the middle of the stretch and won the $10,000 Oyster Bay Pace by a half-length tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Guinea Gold, driven by Jimmy Cruise, was clocked in 2:00 3/5.

Dr. Albert W. Dent, president of Dillard University, New Orleans, was elected president of the National Health Council yesterday to succced Dr. Robin C. Buerki, whose resignation was accepted by the council's board of directors.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 -- Marriage counselors would save themselves much grief if they could acquire a profound knowledge of the nature of man and woman, of God, and of the purpose of life, Dr. Herbert Ratner of Oak Park, Ill., said today.
LONDON, June 19 (Reuters) -- Britain's welfare state doctors have become alarmed at a new and unforeseen development in socialized medicine -- a much greater risk of being sued by their patients.

LONG BEACH, N. Y., June 19 (AP) -- Mayor Edwin E. Michaelian of White Plains was elected president today at the closing session of the annual convention of the New York State Conference of Mayors and other Municipal Officials.

Neither of the mothers of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, convicted atom spies, would comment to newspaper men yesterday after their children had lost a last-minute legal fight before the Supreme Court and had died in the electric chair.

ATLANTA, June 19 (AP) -- Louise Suggs of Atlanta and Patty Berg of St. Andrews, Ill., two painstaking professionals, ousted two amateurs, Pat Lesser and Dot Kirby, today in the semi-finals of the women's western open golf tournament.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 19 -- The future disposition of Royal Dutch Shell's rich oil holdings in North Sumatra has become a principal stumbling block to the formation of a new Indonesian Cabinet.

An innovation in supply techniques has been developed by the United States Navy at its Bayonne, N. J., Naval Supply Depot. Termed "operation bin loading," the method provides for the loading as a unit of as many as 100,000 ordnance spare parts laid out in individual bins, with the contents of the bins recorded on business machine record cards.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, June 20 (AP) -- United State Sabre jet pilots bagged six MIG's and damaged three more yesterday. Other Allied planes showered blinding flares over the eastern Korea front last night in one of the brightest pyrotechnic displays of the war.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 19 -- Incensed by statements by Lieut. Gen. John Bagot Glubb, Chief of Staff of the Arab Legion, in an interview published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, the Israeli Foreign Ministry informed today Britain's charge d'affaires.

That bromide about one man's meat being another man's poison often comes to a food writer's mind. Some Chinese-Americans may refuse milk or cheese cake, because in insular districts of China cow's milk and its products are unknown. But the same people who find cheese cake strange may eat bear's paw with an enthusiasm that most of us find hard to share.
" Elizabeth Is Queen," Warner Brothers feature length film on the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, will open simultaneously at the Little Carnegie and Bryant Theatres on Monday, June 29.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 19 -- A device to protect aircraft antennas, movable surfaces and radio equipment against damage by lightning has been used successfully on fifty craft, it was reported here today at the closing session of the summer general meeting here of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 19 -- Tom Robbins blazed around the championship West course of Winged Foot Club, where he formerly held sway as club champion, in 38, 36 -- 74 today and recaptured the metropolitan seniors, golf championship and the Horace L. Hotchkiss Trophy. He has won this title in three of the past five years.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A full-scale debate on the thirty-year-old Equal Rights Amendment, scheduled for Wednesday at the Minneapolis convention of the American Association of University Women, is expected to bring a switch of the 124,000-member organization from the "against" to the "for" side.

Police details in this country and abroad coped effectively yesterday with apparently well-planned demonstrations over the execution of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, atom spies. The most angry protests were registered in London and Paris, where thousands of persons participated in outdoor rallies.

Against the Tigers, who had surrendered forty runs and forty-seven hits in their previous two games in Boston, the Yankees were able to net only two runs and five hits yesterday. This meager output resulted in a 3-2 defeat for the Bombers before 7,251 paying spectators at the Stadium.

Mayor Impellitteri denounced yesterday as "a fraud on the people of the city, particularly those of Manhattan," the postcard poll taken by Tammany on whether the Democrats of New York County wanted him as the party's nominee for Mayor.

The extensive promotional campaigns being conducted by soap manufacturers is hurting the sale of women's hosiery as well as creating bad public relations for the industry. This is charged in the latest newsletter of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers sent to members yesterday.

Northeast Airlines, Inc., cleared up all arrears on its preferred stock, with the declaration yesterday of $1.25 a share payable on July 1. The regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents for the June quarter payable on July 1 also was declared. Arrears on the preferred date back to the previous payment made in December, 1951. The Atlas Corporation owns 98 per cent of the 43,938 preferred shares outstanding.
CINCINNATI, June 19 (AP) -- Robin Roberts, the "winningest" pitcher in the major leagues, defeated the Redlegs, 10 -- 3, tonight, to register his eleventh victory for the Phillies.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- The Navy said today that a "substantial number" of its ships would be armed with guided missiles in the next year, and that it was buying planes capable of delivering "small" atomic bombs.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, called on Governor Dewey yesterday to lay aside partisan differences and include in the agenda for the special session of the Legislature, called to meet next Thursday, a ten-point program of legislation that he said was essential to the welfare of the people of the state.

TOLEDO, June 19 (AP) -- Jack Burke of Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., and Freddie Haas of New Orleans staged par-shattering performances today to tie at the halfway mark in the 72-hole Inverness invitation touranment with 10-under-par scores of 132.
When Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were put to death last night two years, two months and fourteen days had passed since they were sentenced to die for betraying their country.
RICHMOND, Va., June 19 -- A. A. Vandergrift, retired Marine general of Lynchburg, was one of two reluctant Virginians being mentioned today as possible Republican candidates for Governor.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- The National Society for Crippled Children and Adults announced today that beginning this month its publication. The Crippled Child, would be addressed expressly to parents of handicapped youngsters instead of to the professional workers who have made up the major part of its readership until now.

The one-story taxpayer at 35-02 to 35-14 Crescent Street, corner of Thirty-fifth Avenue, in Long Island City, Queens, has been contracted for purchase by Jack Brause, real estate operator, from the Queens Meadow Realty Corporation, of which S. Lyne is president.

ASHLAND, Ohio, June 19 (UP) -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of South Korea charged in a cablegram to the Ashland (Ohio) Times-Gazette today that the United States was being influenced by European countries that "are too far gone toward communist ideology."

KINGS POINT, L. I., June 19 -- Harvard won the seventeenth national intercollegiate dinghy sailing championship today when the Crimson skippers, Charles S. Hoppin, Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., and Jim Nathanson, Quincy, Mass., duplicated victories that brought them the title and the Henry A. Morss Memorial Trophy last year.
The following books of a religious and an inspirational nature have been issued recently:
SEOUL, Korea, June 19 -- The United Nations Command was not prepared for the precipitate action taken by Dr. Syngman Rhee. President of South Korea, in freeing non-Communist prisoners of war.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, June 19 -- Science, with the welfare of this country and its President in mind, has come forth with another explanation of what happens when a golfer attacks a golf ball. This report was compiled by Dr. Thomas H. Osgood, a physicist and dean of the Graduate School of Michigan State College.

HONOLULU, June 19 -- A Federal jury today found Jack W. Hall, regional director in Hawaii for the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, and six other defendants guilty of a Communist conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the United States Government by force and violence.

TOMS RIVER, N. J., June 19 (UP) -- Although friends tried to keep the news from him, Michael Rosenberg, 10-year-old son of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, learned his parents were to be executed as he watched television today.

Sympathizers of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg bombarded judges with new appeals last night and staged rallies in a desperate last-minute flurry of efforts to save the condemned atom spies from the electric chair.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A canvass of views on President Eisenhower's proposed security information order indicates that it will virtually wipe out the possibilities of abuse inherent in President Truman's controversial order, which the new one is designed to rescind.

HOBOKEN, N. J., June 19 -- A veteran of the German foreign diplomatic service, discharged in 1942 when he differed with Adolf Hitler and Baron Joachim von Ribbentrop over a proposed "trade agreement" with Spain, sailed today on the Holland America Line's steamer Veendam to become chief of the economic section of the West German Republic's legation at Lisbon, Portugal.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 19 (AP) Supporters of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh barred Communists from their ranks today as they shouted praises for the aged Iranian leader at a rally in Parliament Square.
Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, who previously had made no declaration of his intention of running for Mayor, came near to making such an announcement last night.
The state of Liberty was reopened to the public yesterday afternoon immediately after the settlement of a forty-four-hour strike by the crews of the boats that carry sightseers to Bedloes Island.

PUSAN, Korea, June 19 -- Many young strangers clad in ill-fitting clothing are walking boldly through the drizzling rain today in the dark back alleys of this city. The faces of the newcomers all bear a striking similarity -- they are lean and seem slightly more alert than those of the men of this city who have been wearied by long months of misery.

LONDON, June 19 -- Uncertainty prompted by recent events in Korea and East Germany continued to keep business at low level on the stock markets today. But the tone of the markets generally was described as firm and prices again tended to improve.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., June 19 -- The Aanronsburg Assembly, dedicated to seeking a formula for national serenity and world peace through brotherhood and understanding opened a three-day conference on the campus of the Pennsylvania State College here tonight.

Success of a plan to inaugurate another seasonal selling period for linens and domestics appeared assured yesterday as three trade associations gave their support to a Linen Closet Week from Oct. 4 to 10.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- A disputed grand-slam home run by Ransom Jackson in the fifth inning and a three-run blast by Ralph Kiner in the sixth helped the Cubs beat the Dodgers in today's first game at Wrigley Field, 11 -- 8, before 18,776 fans, who sweltered with the players through a 100-degree heat.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Harry M. Moses, president of the Bituminous Coal Operators' Association, said tonight that John L. Lewis was doing a poor job of organizing the soft coal mines of the country.

HANOI, Vietnam, June 19 (UP) -- The French Army's biggest fuel dump in northern Indo-China was swept by fire and explosions today after a daring night raid by a four-man "suicide" team of Communist Vietminh commandos.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (UP) -- Sandy Consuegra, with ninth-inning relief help from Harry Dorish, won his second game in a row tonight as the White Sox defeated the Athletics, 5 -- 2, for their sixth victory in their last seven games.
Mrs. Ethel Rosenberg was the ninth woman to be put to death in New York State since the electric chair was introduced in 1890. The eight who had preceded her had been convicted of murder.
Negotiators for the Todd Shipyards Corporation rejected yesterday union demands for a "general" wage increase and improvements in the pension and insurance plans.

RALEIGH, N. C., June 19 -- The Most Rev. Vincent S. Waters, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Raleigh, has decreed that segregation in Catholic churches of the diocese "will not be tolerated." His order is contained in a letter that will be read in the churches of the diocese on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The House Judiciary Committee was informed today of a change in the attitude of the Federal Trade Commission on the controversial issue of so-called "basing point" pricing by business. Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, called the change significant.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 19 -- Rent controls should be retained in Greenwich because "in an attractive and well-governed community like Greenwich, landlords have a value commodity and can and will charge what the traffic will bear." Third Seicetman John F. Sullivan said today.
LINCOLN, Neb., June 19 (AP) -- Sim Iness, who a week ago was hit in the mouth by a stray discus, tonight hurled one 183 feet to set a National Collegiate A. A. record.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 19 -- Turkey and Greece are now more apprehensive about the prospects of forging an effective Balkan defense than at any time since the conclusion of their tripartite pact with Yugoslavia in February.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 19 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks and Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge will meet in the thirty-six-hole final of the fiftieth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship tomorrow over the Metropolis Country Club course.
William Lurie and Alastair B. Martin were among the seeded players to advance as play started yesterday in the annual Eastern clay court championships at the Clifton Tennis Club in Arrochar, S. I.

ALBANY, June 20 -- The number of high school students taking automobile driver training courses as a part of their secondary school education has risen to a record 90,000, the State Education Department announced today.

SPONSORED by the Royal Institute of International Affairs under the general editorship of Arnold Toynbee (who supplies a clarifying introduction), "The Middle East in the War" draws together from an encyclopedic range of published sources the detailed record of what happened in and to the Middle East during World War II.

MADISON, Wis., June 20 (AP) -- Criticism of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconson, by a member of the University of Wisconsin class of '93 caused a brief flurry at a meeting of the Wisconsin Alumni Association today.

This Thursday, June 25, will mark the third anniversary of the Korean war. It is a war that has never been popular in the West and that has exacted a heavy toll in blood and treasure. The United States alone has suffered 138,000 casualties, including 24,000 dead.

We call it the beginning of summer when the solstice comes, when the day's length is at its maximum. And, to be sure, that first green-fevered rush of spring is at an end. The throbbing compulsion to leaf and bud has slowed down, settled down to the summer's pace of growth and fruiting.

THE debate on the safety value of having airline seats facing rearward has been reopened by the announcement by one of the largest non-scheduled operators that the interiors of its fleet were being rearranged so that its passengers would sit facing the tail of the plane.

DARIEN, Conn., June 20 -- Peg's Pride, aged gray gelding from the Hutchinson Stables of Closter, N. J., won the first two jumper events as the twenty-fourth annual Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show opened today. Peg's Pride took the Professional Horsemen's Association Challenge Trophy after scoring in an open jumper class.

The American Spaniel Club, which has never had a national championship field trial for cocker spaniels in its seventy-two-year history, will have one this year. The dates will be Dec. 8 and 9 and the grounds the Crab Orchard Wildlife Refuge at Herrin, Ill.

COME television or high water, the approach of the vacation season again brings with it the annual symptom of American culture known as the strawhat theatre. In the country and at the shore hundreds of managers will be offering live entertainment from now until the frost begins to settle.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Administration began a drive this week to develop a program for increasing American private investment abroad in line with its "trade not aid" policies.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (UP) -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley has told Senators that Russia was steadily increasing her atomic bomb stockpile and now was shipping jet aircraft to Soviet satellite states.

BERLIN, Sunday, June 21 (UP) -- The West Berlin newspaper Telegraf said today that 100,000 German workers had revolted in the uranium mining area of Saxony while an angry mob at Rathenow lynched the local head of the Communist State Security Services.

WHILE driving on a straight road would appear to be the safest and simplest kind of motoring, surveys by the American Automobile Association indicate that most accidents in rural areas occur on just such stretches of highway.

STRASBOURG, France, June 20 (AP) -- The Common Assembly of the European Coal and Steel Community today pressed Jean Monnet, president of the High Authority of the pool, for details concerning the industrial development program that is scheduled for United States financial support.

CINCINNATI, June 20 (UP) -- The Phillies combined three walks and singles by pinch-hitter Connie Ryan and Del Ennis to score all their runs in the eighth inning, today to defeat the Redlegs, 3 -- 1, in 102-degree heat.

SYRACUSE, June 20 -- The eight-oared varsity from the United States Naval Academy completed a two-year record of conquest without parallel as it won its twentieth consecutive race on Onondaga Lake today and became the first crew since 1941 to carry off the championship of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association two years in a row.

Is Henry Giniger, author of "Monsieur Eiffel's Fancy" (June 7) perhaps related to the late Monsieur Eiffel, or is he merely the president of "the private company that runs it [the Eiffel Tower] for the city of Paris?" For Monsieur Giniger is, indeed, the first person my husband and I know who has looked upon that monstrosity of architecture and come away with a good word for it. * * *

Brother Bonaventure Thomas, president of Manhattan College, announced yesterday nineteen promotions among the faculty and the appointment of Brother Adelbert James as head of the Education Department. The former head of that department, Brother Agatho, is retiring to devote all his time to heading the college's Division for Religious.

MILWAUKEE, June 20 -- For a few fleeting moments this sizzling afternoon Leo Durocher's Giants appeared to be about to toss their weight around some more in the National League flag race by taking a second straight game from the front-running Braves.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- United States defense leaders, convinced that the Soviet Union is making spectacular progress on guided missiles, will spend more than a billion dollars in this field during the next year. This became known today with the release of testimony by defense experts asking approval of the multi-billion-dollar military program for the fiscal year starting July 1.

BOSTON, June 20 (UP) -- Mel Parnell, defying temperatures that reached 120 degrees on the mound, won his own well-pitched game today with a two-run single as the Red Sox defeated the Browns 4 -- 2, at Fenway Park and ran their winning streak to four games.

SALEM, Ore., June 20 -- The bronze "Venus Victorieuse" by the French sculptor Renoir has been withdrawn as a memorial to the Oregon pioneers as the result of protests that it was inappropriate both as a memorial and as the gift of the late Carroll B. Moores.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 20 (AP) -- Joe Conrad of San Antonio and Jimmy Vickers of Wichita, Kan., moved into the final of the Trans-Mississippi Golf Association's golden jubilee tournament with 1-up victories today.

There is paper for nearly every business purpose, but it is doubtful whether any has contributed more to the progress of business than the safety paper used in bank checks. This paper dispelled the suspicion with which checks were once regarded and enabled them to attain their present high repute in banking and commercial dealings.

A MODEST family income and three school-age children eliminated "Travel" from out budget until we found that travel costs could be limited to car expenses, sight-seeing cost and camping fees. Then we decided that we would "see our country," using a tent for shelter, and our regular housekeeping allotment for food, the latter to be purchased as needed in towns on the route, and prepared in the car or in picnic areas.

MARKED by unusual realism and plausibility, this English thriller headlines John Armstrong, a scientist at work on a new weapon based on a substance called, from its power and unpredictability, satanium. Since his name is known to the Russians as that of a nuclear physicist, he works under an assumed name, Forsyth.

OTTAWA, June 20 -- In a manifesto and a speech he delivered in his home town of Guelph last evening, George Drew, the Progressive-Conservative leader, opened the Canadian general election campaign for his party and on Monday, at Windsor, Prime Minister Louis S. Laurent will open for the Liberals.

The name of Karl yon Frisch is known the world over because he is the man who observed that when a worker bee discovers a supply of nectar she announces the fact on her return to the hive in a dance. The bees in the hive watch with interest and then fly off to the source of nectar.

There is a beaver boom in New York State. The Conservation Department this month reported that 9,194 beavers were trapped in the state in 1953, a record catch for the century. Connecticut, not to be outdone, came up with a beaver in a Long Ridge lake a few weeks ago.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 20 (AP) -- Jockey Willie Shoemaker registered six victories in eight starts at Hollywood Park today, but it was Ralph Neves on Pet Bully who captured the featured $25,000 Inglewood Handicap.

A wide range of program of old and new recordings of classic and modern works will be heard this week at the concerts of the New York Public Library, established for the summer in Bryant Park on a Monday-through-Friday schedule from noon to 2 P. M.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 20 -- Six generals commanding the Chinese Nationalist troops in Burma were scheduled to arrive in Bangkok this week-end to join the discussions under way here aimed at the evacuation of the Chinese Nationalist force to Formosa.

FOUR high school students won the top awards of $300 each in the $4,000 Eighth Annual National High School Photographic Awards sponsored by the National Scholastic Press Association in cooperation with the Eastman Kodak Company.

The summaries of more than a half million news items, arranged alphabetically by subjects, persons and organizations, appear in the 1952 edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES INDEX, which has just been published. The volume, compiled under the direction of Joseph C. Gephart, editor, contains 1,295 pages, three columns wide, and is printed on rag paper.

The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico's continuing need for development capital is reflected in plans of the island economy's basic electric power enterprise -- the Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority -- to borrow $21,000,000.

WHEN the plane of a famous scientist crashes in the Sierra Nevada Mountains, Mace, a mountain boy, and Wint, a city youth, set out on a pack trip to find the missing man. Wint's ignorance of trail life tests Mace's patience, but the city boy proves his worth in other ways.

THE history of children's literature from its earliest, unrecognized beginnings to the present day has an element of struggle and conflict that makes it dramatic reading. Furthermore, it is lit with the freshness and vigor of childhood itself, for though it deals with books it is concerned also, and primarily, with the child, his wonder, his imagination, his power of growth, his sense of play, his innate taste and discrimination.

ROANOKE, Va., June 20 (AP) -- Virginia Republicans today nominated State Senator Theodore Roosevelt Dalton for Governor, gave him the two running mates he wanted and promised to go after the Democrats in earnest next November.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 20 -- This resort might well be called the railroad capital of the world next week when 7,000 railway officials and transportation specialists from all parts of the United States, Latin America and other countries convene here for a $20,000,000 exhibit of the latest railroad equipment and supplies.

Commenting upon the deaths of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison before sunset Friday, Rabbi Ira Eisenstein from his pulpit yesterday morning at the Synagogue of the Society for the Advancement of Judaism (Conservative), 15 West Eighty-sixth Street, emphasized that "Jewish tradition is unalterably opposed to capital punishment.''

THE writer who attempts to retell a classic is apt to come out second best. This is the case with Mr. Spinatelli whose pleasantly flamboyant novel is concerned with the adventures of Benvenuto Cellini, and therefore has to stand comparison with the sculptor's own eloquent "Life" -- a volume, supposedly autobiographical, called by John Addington Symonds "the nearest approach there is to a great Italian novel of life and character."

KATMANDU, Nepal, June 20 (AP) -- Tensing Norkay, the native hero of the Himalayas, and Sir Edmond P. Hillary of New Zealand returned here today in royal processional grandeur from their conquest of Mount Everest.

MASSAPEQUA PARK, L. I., June 20 -- Construction of a thirty-room elementary school building is scheduled to begin next month on the site of the last of the "cow pasture" airports that dotted Nassau County's landscape while it was earning its title as the Cradle of American Aviation.

Frank Rosenblum, secretary-treasurer of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O., assailed yesterday Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and Congressional investigating committees, which, he charged, have usurped the rights of American citizens. He urged labor and the liberal community to exercise their legal powers to "stop McCarthyism dead in its tracks."

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 20 -- President Eisenhower's critical remarks concerning the Tennessee Valley Authority this week stirred up a good deal of feeling in the seven-state area whose economic life is so closely to tied to T. V. A.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Jackie Robinson, crippled right knee and all, came off the bench in the seventh inning today and lined a pinch double into the left field corner that tied the score at 3 -- 3 and sent the Dodgers on to a 5 -- 3 triumph over the Cubs at Wrigley Field.

THE general rejoicing in Britain did not stop on the glorious 2d of June, when the crown of St. Edward was placed on the fair head of a young Queen. As this is written the holiday spirit still pervades London, which for more than three weeks has been the bright mecca for millions of Coronation pilgrims.

ROME, June 20 -- The Communist party directorate made a bid today for the inclusion either of the Communists or of the Left Wing Socialists, to whom they are bound by a "unity of action pact," in Premier Alcide De Gasperi's next Cabinet.

C. at Port Washington will have an assembly of the largest fleet of power cruisers ever marshalled for a predicted log race on metropolitan waterways. At last count, M. L. The riots in East Berlin last week were the first sign of mass resistance to Communist authority since the war. They pitted sinews against steel in a losing battle for a deathless cause. They roused a people famous for solid quiescence in the face of brutal rule, to the verge of revolution.

Hunter College will confer 824 degrees tomorrow at its 104th commencement. The ceremony, to be held at the Bronx campus, Bedford Park Boulevard and Navy Avenue, will begin at 5:30 P. M. Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, will preside.
The new Bricker amendment, just reported by a divided vote of the Senate Judiciary Committee, is as incompatible with our national interests as the old version.

The Laundry Workers Joint Board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C. I. O., broke ground yesterday for a new $1,000,000 health center at 224 East Thirty-fourth Street to provide free medical services for 18,000 members.

THE author of the book about the river with the funny name, "The Winooski," (Rivers of America Series), has come up with another good one in "Sidewheeler Saga," a nostalgic chronicle of those lovely creatures called steamboats.

ABOARD U. S. S. LLOYD AT SEA, June 20 -- Thirty yachts in three divisions were bearing to the southward today in the first stages of the biennial ocean race from Newport to Annapolis, a distance of 466 miles.

An experimental project designed to help foreign students become better acquainted with life in the United States will be conducted this summer by Michigan State College. Sponsored by the Government's Technical Cooperation Administration, the program will bring together fifty students representing sixteen countries in Latin America, Southeast Asia, the Near East and Africa.

Under appointments as Fulbright lecturers, nine faculty members of Columbia University soon will journey to other parts of the globe, Dr. John A. Krout, vice president and Fulbright adviser at the university, announced yesterday. The appointments are effective for the academic year beginning in September.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, June 21 (AP) -- Chinese Communist forces renewed their probing thrusts today against South Koreans in the Pukhan River area of the east-central front but ignored sectors manned by United States and other troops of the United Nations member states.

Capitalizing on the inept fielding of their opponents, the Yankees tallied six runs on five hits yesterday to defeat the Tigers, 6 -- 2, before 19,408 sweltering Ladies' Day spectators at the Stadium. Three Detroit errors gave the Bombers five unearned runs.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -In Room F-76 on the street floor of the Capitol -- the gadget-littered office of Dr. George W. Calver, psysician of Congress and the Supreme Court -- hangs a framed cartoon of a corpulent member of Congress being examined by a physician.

TWENTY-EIGHT MILLION Italians went to the polls a fortnight ago to elect a new Chamber of Deputies and Senate. One out of every three voted for either the Communist or the Left-Wing Socialist parties, which have been attempting for the last eight years to turn Italy into a Soviet satellite.

ASHREWD and affectionate observer of French country folk, Rosalys Hall, author of 'The Merry Miller," has concocted another original tale about them. This one is set in the French Alps and concerns M. Latour, who drove the bus from Cow-in-the-Valley to Cow-in-the-Mountain, "a man of passion and impetuous" who cherished a well-concealed love for all animals.

HARTFORD, June 20 -- The Citizens Charter Committee of Hartford, which has the label of the "good government" organization in the city because of its successful sponsorship and control of the council-manager form of government here, is threatened with the loss of its control to political forces this year.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- General Bradley told the Senate committee that he believed Russia was "pulling back" in the cold war because the Russians feared increased United States military strength and needed time to consolidate their position at home.

HONG KONG, June 20 -- Two leading pro - Nationalist Chinese newspapers here published editorials today applauding the release of thousands of anti-Communist North Korean prisoners by President Syngman Rhee of South Korea and criticizing the United States for its position on an armistice.
TOKYO, Sunday, June 21 (UP) American paratroopers of the 187th Airborne Regimental Combat Team began arriving in Korea today, Gen. Mark W. Clark's United Nations headquarters announced.

The Kiwanis International's thirty-eighth annual convention to be held tomorrow through Thursday at Madison Square Garden, is expected to draw 14,000 persons here from all forty-eight states, Hawaii, Alaska and Canada. This would be the largest convention in Kiwanis history.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 20 (Reuters) -- Twelve hundred African home guards mopping up anti-white Mau Mau terrorists in the Aberdare Mountains have killed ten and wounded five in the last forty-eight hours, it was announced today.

PARIS, June 20 -- President Vincent Auriol's emergency committee of former Premiers, called upon by him to help in solving France's month-old Cabinet crisis, met today and immediately ran into all the differences and difficulties that have been preventing the French National Assembly from reaching an accord.

The women's United States open, heretofore conducted under the auspices of the Ladies Professional Golfers Association, will be staged for the first time this week under the sponsorship of the United States Golf Association.

Commodity and securities markets fluctuated widely last week in confused trading as truce negotiations and tax discussions neared a decision. An indication of the mixed opinions which prevailed was shown when stocks slumped to the lowest levels in thirteen months, then recovered briskly, while wheat and other grains broke sharply, but rebounded later.

JUNE is the month to gather flowers and ferns not only for bouquets now, but also for winter. As a matter of fact innumerable flowers from gardens, fields and roadsides may be cut and dried during summer for winter bouquets.

ROTTERDAM JUNCTION, N. Y., June 20 (AP) -- Mr. Balch called on Governor Dewey here today to put before the coming special session of the Legislature a ten-point program that included items rejected by the Republican majority at the regular session.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Walter Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today the United States must create 2,000,000 new jobs each year through 1956 to avoid a serious economic sag.

William A. Adams, chief of staff of the Department of Correction since 1948 and associated with the department for almost four decades, will retire on July 1. Correctional Commissioner Albert Williams has announced.
Six hundred patients of the Gold-water Memorial Hospital on Welfare Island had an exciting two and a half hours yesterday at their annual carnival.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 20 (UP) -Communist-led Vietminh troops launched two heavy attacks on French Union positions in the Red River delta, south of Hanoi, the French High Command announced tonight.

NEW BRAUNFELS, Tex. -On Pan American Highway 81, between Austin and San Antonio, the Mexico-bound tourist in need of a respite from heat and travel may easily miss just the right intersection, just across the Guadalupe River.

Seven hundred small dancing girls gave yesterday's 92.6-degree heat the cold shoulder and cavorted energetically in the twenty-sixth annual dance festival of the New York City Department of Parks in Central Park.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Chicago, Cook County and Illinois State Police have spent ten days in futile search of State Representative Clem Graver, a 53-year-old Republican member of the so-called West Side bloc of Chicago in the State Legislature, who was last seen being hustled into an automobile near his home at 9:55 P. M., Thursday, June 11.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I -- With a summer calendar liberally sprinkled with outdoor spectacles which include an air show, Indian pow-wow, county fairs, international tennis matches, speedboat races and a tercentenary celebration, the eight villages at the eastern tip of Long Island, collectively known as "The Hamptons," are preparing for one of the busiest vacation seasons in their history.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 20 -- The Western Big Three conference in Bermuda has again been postponed. The conference was scheduled to start a week from Monday, but the hotel reservations for that date are being canceled. Originally the meeting had been scheduled for June 16, but was postponed because the French were unable to form a Government.

IN a recent issue of The London Observer a friendly review of our own Edwin Way Teale raises the question of British and American "attitudes toward nature." Geoffrey Grigson, the reviewer, comes to the almost obligatory conclusion that they are different and that the advantage is not wholly on the American side.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, June 20 (Reuters) -- After seventy-nine years of British rule, the Gold Coast, one of Britain's most prosperous colonies, on Africa's west coast, is ready for self-rule and dominion status, the Government said today.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 20 (AP) -- The Wimbledon tennis championships, which started with a croquet, game and a garden party in London in 1877, open Monday with a group of young players holding the spotlight in the field of 224.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (UP) -- Bob Elliott hit his sixth homer of the season in the eighth inning today and the two-run drive off Morrie Martin, relief pitcher, capped a five-run rally by the White Sox as they came from behind to defeat the Athletics, 6 -- 4.

A GROWING concern of serious photographers, that their efforts in creative directions are doomed to futility unless an understanding audience is prepared to receive them, is reflected in Minor White's editorial in the July issue of Aperture, just published.

WHEN one is very little - "smaller than a rosebush, smaller than a kitchen stool, smaller than anyone on the street" -- it is hard to believe that you will be any bigger. Therefore, this is a very encour aging picture story for anyone comparable in age and size to the Very Little Girl.

Two of the nation's leading investment banking houses -- Morgan Stanley Co. and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. -- are engaged again in a fierce competitive struggle. Ironically, the issue involves a public utility -- the Consumers Power Company -- initially used as the target for competitive bidding by the Securities and Exchange Commission in December, 1939, when Jerome N. Frank headed the governmental regulatory agency.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 20 -Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, and William G. Saltonstall, principal of Phillips Exeter Academy, were among the nine honorary degree recipients today at the 148th Bowdoin College commencement.

ROME, June 20 -- The United States Embassy in Rome and American consulates throughout Italy were heavily guarded by the police and carabinieri today because hostile demonstrations were feared during a fifteen-minute strike of public services called by the Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor to protest the deaths of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg.

The situation of both the free Republic of Korea and the United Nations in the face of Communist aggression and two years of frustrating negotiation for a truce has been complicated and delicate. The very collective action of the United Nations that saved the Republic initially and is responsible for the fact that the Republic is still alive was difficult to organize.

CLEVELAND, June 20 -- The ore fleet's bid to establish a loading record for June struck a snag this week when a heavy fog, which dropped visibility to zero in several districts, bunched carriers at Duluth and the Soo.
WHILE some local show places close for two or three months at the beginning of summer, others install group shows which remain on view with little or no change until the autumn season opens.

THE yellowing of yew and certain other evergreens, even after a wet spring, puzzles many a property owner. This dieback, generally symptomatic of drought, actually can be blamed on the taxus or black vine weevil. This pest also damages hemlocks, chamaecyparis, azaleas and rhododendrons, but taxus (yew) is its chief target.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Former President Herbert Hoover expressed disagreement with President Eisenhower today on one of the chief features of the Eisenhower plan for reorganization of the Defense Department.

GIVE me permission to declare here that mankind is much too concerned with concrete facts which it ought not try to digest. Yet men will try. We long to amass knowledge we cannot use, to prove dates and incidents which prove nothing.

THE Norwegian section of the International Society for Contemporary Music, led by its admirable chairman, Pauline Hall, was host to what has probably been the most international, the most social, the most contemporary-minded, and even the most musical of its twenty-seven festivals.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 21 (AP) -- General Clark declared today that the release of anti-Communist prisoners was "completely unauthorized," saying "the entire responsibility rsets squarely upon President Rhee and the Government of Korea."

Reports of the conquest of Everest have filled the papers with strange new words, seldom heard or read by flatlands people -- the jargon of the mountaineering craft. Now with six other peaks in the Himalayas and the Karakorum ranges about to be assailed by other expeditions from several countries (including the United States), these terms are likely to keep on appearing. Here is a useful glossary:

NEW DELHI, India, June 20 (Reuters) -- A Japanese expedition reported today that bad weather halted on June 1 its effort to scale unconquered Mount Manaslu about 1,000 feet short of the summit of the 26-658-foot Himalayan mountain. Col. Sir John Hunt's British climbers had reached Mount Everest's summit on May 29.

BIRTHDAYS, at first so eagerly awaited, and then, gradually (for members of one sex, if not for the other), a matter of comparative indifference -- sometimes assumed -- do have their uses above and beyond the vexation, the regret and, even, the despair which they can bring.

LESS accent on culture and more on sports and light entertainment is noticeable on current Canadian television programs. There are more United States network shows being aired on all three Canadian television stations now in operation with completion of a microwave relay system from Buffalo, N. Y., via Toronto and Ottawa to Montreal. Practically all major American sporting events are telecast simultaneously in Canada.

ONE of the psychiatrists who came in the Nineteen Thirties to Sheppard - Enoch Pratt Hospital in Baltimore, where Harry Stack Sullivan had done his first classical work on schizophrenia, said that he thought Sullivan must already have died, so great even then was his legendary fame.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 20 -- Col. Alex Kawilarang, commander of the Indonesian forces in West Java, has ordered large-scale operations in the mountainous districts south of Jakarta to put down violently mounting attacks by dissident groups throughout that region.

PAUL GAUGUIN, whose art and personal history have intrigued the movie makers in the past, is up for a full screen treatment again. The artist's life will be the basis of a feature to be filmed independently in color on location in Arles, Tahiti and the Marquesas by Oceanic Productions, Inc., it was confirmed last week by James Agee, film critic and scenarist who is currently finishing the script for the company.
MASHUA, N. H., June 20 (UP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, said today that the United States should set up a "Pacific NATO."
FORT JACKSON, S. C., June 20 (AP) -- A powerful Army team easily outdistanced all opposition with 88 points and seven first places to win the annual interservice track and field meet today.

TUCSON, Ariz., June 20 -- Prosecution of all Mexican border-jumpers found in Arizona in the United States District Court with prison terms of thirty days for first offenders to six months for repeaters is being attempted in an effort to reduce the flow of "wetbacks" into the state, but in nearly three weeks the chief effect has been to fill five county jails to overflowing.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Senators won a protested 7-3 decision over the Indians tonight, slamming Early Wynn and Dave Hoskins for nine of their ten hits in the first four innings to produce all their runs. Bob Porterfield posted his eighth victory as the second-place Indians dropped eleven games behind the league-leading Yankees.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 20 -- Assets of the Louis W. and Maud Hill Family Foundation now exceed $19,500,000, making it one of the largest philanthropic funds in the Midwest, according to a report of officers of the organization covering the last three years.

Three hundred, more or less, Indians, more or less, paraded down Fifth Avenue to Union Square yesterday morning and were greeted by Mayor Impellitteri. He told them that inasmuch as their ancestors had sold Manhattan to the Dutch "at far below its value" he was initiating an "Indian Festival Week" to help even the score.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 20 -Khwaja Nazimuddin, former Prime Minister of Pakistan, ended a political career of thirty years when he resigned today as President of the politically decisive Pakistan Moslem League party after a week of fruitless effort to regain control of the Government.
MOSCOW, Sunday, June 21 -Georgi Mikhailovich Popov, former Mayor of Moscow, was today made Soviet Ambassador to Poland, succeeding Arkady A. Sobolev, who has been transferred to other work.
ATLANTA, June 20 (UP) -- Louise Suggs shot men's par golf today to defeat Patty Berg, 6 and 5, and in her fourth women's Western open golf championship.

Competition in the drug field is perhaps as fierce as in any other segment of the American economy and without extensive advertising, sales efforts and merchandising no manufacturer can hope to stay in business.

VINELAND, N. J., June 20 -- Fred Wood, manager of radio station WWBZ, declared "misleading" today a Federal Communications Commission official's charge that the Vineland station was a "bookmakers' delight."

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Diplomatic sources said today that because of the inability of the French to form a Government, the Western Big Three meeting in Bermuda would be delayed until sometime in July.

THE TIMES of June 14, under a Washington dateline, carried a most interesting article covering the report of a Senate Special Committee appointed some time ago to consider, among other things, "the effectiveness of the Government's Overseas Information Service, and various propaganda efforts, including the Voice of America."

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 20 -- Terminating just a week of voluntary exile in Thailand, King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia left suddenly this afternoon by automobile to return to his homeland. The 30-year-old monarch's departure, as unheralded and dramatic as his arrival here, was accompanied by no public explanation of his action.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Senate Small Business Committee will resume hearings Monday in the controversy over the storage battery additive AD-X2. The National Bureau of Standards issued an adverse report on the additive and the report led in March to the forced resignation, later postponed, of Dr. Allen V. Astin, director of the bureau.

TOBAGO, B. W. I. -- Over two centuries ago an obscure English author named Daniel Defoe published an account of "The life and strange surprising adventure of Robinson Crusoe, who, having been cast ashore by shipwreck lived alone on an uninhabited island off the coast of America, near the mouth of the great river Oroonoque."

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 20 (Reuters) -- The Communist-sponsored World Peace Council today launched a world-wide appeal, to be known as "the Budapest appeal," for negotiation between the Big Five powers.

BURLINGTON, Vt., June 20 (AP) -- Trustees of the University of Vermont voted today to suspend Dr. Alexander Novikoff of the College of Medicine without pay effective July 15 unless before that date he indicates his willingness to testify before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee. The group is headed by Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold will fly to Ottawa next week to discuss the United Nations position in the Korean crisis with Lester B. Pearson, President of the General Assembly.

THIS year the world marks the golden anniversary of man's first controlled flight in a powered heavier-than-air machine. In the fifty years since the Wrights lifted their propeller-driven box-kite off the sands at Kitty Hawk, N. C., aviation has become a giant.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 20 -- Gifts and bequests of $604,930 have been received by Wellesley College since July 1, 1952, Miss Margaret Clapp, president, announced this afternoon at the annual luncheon of the Wellesley College Alumnae Association.

THE more one sees of lavish productions in the opera house, in the theatre, on television and in films the more one becomes convinced that money cannot take the place of ideas, taste and energy. Please understand, there is no prejudice here against money, and one would wish institutions like the Metropolitan Opera and the City Center to have all the financial resources they think they need.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Eisenhower made what was described as a personal face-to-face appeal to Representative Daniel A. Reed today for action on continuation of the excess profits tax. The result, if any, was kept secret.
MIDHURST, Enland, June 20 -- Led by G. H. (Pete) Bostwick, who scored five goals, the Meadow Brook (L. I.) polo team defeated Cowdray Park, 6 to 5, today to win the Duke of Sutherland Cup.

MONTEVERDI was born just three years after Shakespeare, and that the two men had far more than mere contemporaneity in common is revealed in an excellent recording released by the Concert Hall Society of the Italian master's L'Incoronazione di Poppea.

PUDGE RYAN, red-headed, fat and pugnacious, is misunderstood by all his classmates, especially Dick and Ellen Evans. It is not until a summer of fun is almost marred by quarrels, mishap, near-tragedy and a touch of mystery that he wins his way to their friendship and finds happiness.

THIS is a closely reasoned comedy on the question "What is Man?" It is one of those stories that seem to move not so much by the author's artifice (though in fact he is wonderfully resourceful) as by an inner satirical energy in the idea itself.

A YOUTH, whose tattersall vest and dirty white buck shoes identified him as fresh out of one of the New England boarding schools, walked into the Public Gardens here last week and remarked to his companion: "Boy, they sure go ape over culture in Boston."

THE sole complaint to be made of H. C. Branson's writing is that it is infrequent. He has written only seven detective stories in twelve years, and it's been four years since the last one. But these few novels are uniformly so meticulous in detection and so subtly revealing of human character that they rank high among connoisseurs' delights.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, June 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of the United Nations Command's letter of June 18 to the Communist truce delegation regarding the breakout of anti-Communist North Korean prisoners from camps in South Korea:

THE DALLES, Ore., June 20 -- Despite a swollen Columbia River, work is pushing ahead here on a multipurpose concrete dam equivalent in length to seven Empire State Buildings if toppled over and laid end to end.

LOS ANGELES, June 20 -- Eric Larrabee, an associate editor of Harper's Mazagine, today defended pocket-size books against charges of obscenity and pornography in a preconference session of the American Library Association convention which opens here Monday.

UNLIKE most of our legendary American giants - Paul Bunyan, Pecos Bill and the others who came from the forests and the plains -- Big Mose Humphreys was a city man. Whether he really lived in New York of the Eighteen Forties is a point for historians and folklorists to argue; Miss Shippen says he did.

LET there be no quibbling this morning. The Ford Motor Company's special anniversary show, which made national video darlings of Ethel Merman and Mary Martin, easily was one of the very best entertainment programs yet offered on TV.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 21 -- Hundreds of non-Communist prisoners of the Korean war staged a new series of mass breakouts last night and early today from four compounds south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel, while the fate of an armistice hung in the balance.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (UP) -- The senor Democratic farm leader in the House of Representatives said today that the attempt of Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, to get a "flexible" price support law was doomed in this Congress.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 20 -- Dr. Stephen Kemp Bailey, Associate Professor of Government at Wesleyan University, hangs his cap and gown on a peg in the campus faculty room and strides down to the musty old brownstone Town Hall here, where he marches confidently into the Mayor's office, rolls up his sleeves and wastes no time at all puttting into practice what he preaches.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The charge last week by Senator McCarthy that Senator Lehman had abused the Senate's free mailing privilege has brought the New York Democrat a deluge of 3-cent stamps, dollar bills and one $10 check. Mr. Lehman's office reported today. It said the stamps and money were being returned. Mr. McCarthy said he had received about twenty letters, most of which took his side.

BANFF, Alberta -- The Luxton Museum, Limited, a fine collection of Indian relics, utensils, weapons and clothing, plus an assortment of stuffed animals and birds and some Stone Age kitchen equipment, was opened here last week. It occupies a one-story log structure near the Indian Trading Post on the edge of Banff's small business section, and it is filled with all kinds of things collected by Norman K. Luxton, who operates the Trading Post.

VIENNA, June 20 -- The strikes, riots and lesser demonstrations provoked in Czechoslovakia two weeks ago by the devaluation of the Czechoslovak currency and the consequent lowering of living standards have been followed this week by far more revolutionary disturbances in East Germany.

A BIG-LEAGUE baseball team plays half its games on the road -- which is to say, away from the comforts of home and the loving noise of the home town fans. Between games a road trip is a droning round of Pullmans, buses and hotel lobbies. In each enemy ball park, it means exposure to bloodthirsty screams and unfamiliar, tricky playing conditions; even the grass is hostile.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 20 -- Three senior members of the Princeton faculty have been appointed to endowed chairs in economics, physics and Oriental languages and literatures, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced today.

ATLANTA, June 20 -- Cash income of Southeastern farmers was $57,889,000 lower in the first four months this year than the corresponding period of 1952, the Atlanta Regional Office of the Department of Commerce reported here.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The tone and contents of the Communists' response to the South Korean Government's release of war prisoners buoyed up again today official hopes for a truce in Korea, even though it might be delayed.

On the world's most critical fronts -- Korea and Germany -- there were explosions last week. Each explosion represented a grave crisis for one of the leaders in the world struggle -- Washington and Moscow.

THE working title of this volume, the author confesses, was "How to Think About a River." He gave it up, out of modesty, not wishing to pretend to have the whole answer. The present title suggests floods, but only one chapter deals with the Kaw Valley and Kansas City catastrophe of 1951.

THIS charming memoir tells the story of Robb White and is bride, Rodie, and their flight from the banalities of civilization and, especially, from Rodie's Trust Fund and her family's plantation in Georgia.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Plants of all ages, from seedlings to towering trees, meet competition from weeds. Loosening the soil between rows after a rain with a long-handled hoe, a wheel hoe, tractor or other suitable tool uproots the weeds. Cultivating once a week is advisable, unless a mulch is spread. Hand weeding may be necessary in special plantings.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 12 -- With the arrival of a Japanese pearling fleet of twenty-five luggers in the Arafura Sea, off the northern coast of Australia, there are misgivings about the future of this industry in Australian waters.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 20 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds marked today the twentieth anniversary of his induction as the youngest president in the history of Princeton University.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The bipartisan front in Congress supporting the Eisenhower Administration's foreign policies is showing a good deed of strain, and the position has not been helped by President Syngman Rhee of South Korea.

Storm signals have been flying over the domestic copper market for the last two months. Even the traditional optimists among the big copper producers have agreed that world supplies look topheavy in view of the slow buying abroad. Predictions of an imminent break in copper prices have become common place.

Father's Day shopping brought a rise in sales to New York and Brooklyn department stores last week and a gain of about 12 per cent was recorded. Traffic and sales were heaviest in men's furnishing items, with departments selling gadgets, housewares, and tobacco items reporting better than usual volume.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The United States is collecting increased oil and gas royalties from production on Federal domains.

BONN, Germany, June 20 (AP) -- The Free Democrats, second largest party in Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's coalition government, demanded today that the Western Allies give West Germany immediate sovereignty by putting into effect the still unratified peace contract.

PRIZES of photographic equipment and concert tickets worth more than $1,500 will be awarded for the ten best pictures taken by amateur photographers on Tuesday evening, June 30, at Lewisohn Stadium, when Leonard Bernstein will conduct an all-Tchaikovsky program by the Stadium Symphony Orchestra.

The discussions now under way at the International Labor Organization's Annual Conference in Geneva will, it is hoped, lead the way toward a better understanding of how to increase productivity in manufacturing and agriculture in order to raise the world's living standards.

JOSEPH ROSENSTOCK, director of the New York City Opera, is taking a leaf out of Rudolf Bing's book. He is entrusting one of his major new productions to a famous stage director who has had no previous experience directing opera.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 20 -- A sharpshooting Jack Burke, 30-year-old transplanted Texan from Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., birdied four straight holes on the back nine today for a 69 to take a 2-stroke lead at the fifty-four-hole mark in the $18,000 Iverness invitational golf tournament.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles today disclosed two shifts in their 1953 National Football League schedule to permit the nationwide telecast of games with the Chicago Cardinals and the Pittsburgh Steelers.

Wool jersey fabrics are being reintroduced into the men's clothing industry for the first time since the Twenties. William Heller, Inc., textiles, is offering the knitted cloth for summer suits, slacks and jackets on a limited basis and will increase its output for the fall.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 20 -- A discus throw that exceeded the listed world record, the second fastest mile ever achieved by an American and a new meet record for the shot-put kept a crowd of 15,000 well entertained tonight as the thirty-second National Collegiate A. A. track and field meet ended.

LONDON, June 20 -- Lewis Hoad of Australia upset Ken Rosewall, his fellow-countryman who is seeded No. 1 for the Wimbledon championships, 8 -- 6, 10 -- 8, today to win the men's title in the London lawn tennis championships.

In London Dr. Edward C. Bullard of Britain's National Physical Laboratory has set forth again his hypothesis that the earth is a huge dynamo. We say "again" because he has been expounding his hypothesis for some years, so that it is not exactly scientific news. It is the most plausible hypothesis so far advanced to account for the earth's magnetism.

MILWAUKEE, June 20 (AP) -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, in an attack on "McCarthyism," said tonight he prayed President Eisenhower would "give us at long last the leadership we seek in offering battle to the forces of ignorance and inquisition."

HEART BOOK -A completely revised and greatly expanded edition of "Nomenclature and Criteria for Diagnosis of Diseases of the Heart and Blood Vessels," has been prepared by the New York Heart Association, and is now being distributed by the American Heart Association and its affiliates.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (UP) -- Representative William H. Ayres, Republican of Ohio, said today the House of Representatives Veterans Housing subcommittee probably would recommend repeal of a Veterans Administration order banning discounts on G. I. home loan mortgages.

At twilight last Friday in the death house of Sing Sing Prison, the executioner threw the switch which supplies current to the electric chair. The case entitled "United States of America v. Julius Rosenberg, Ethel Rosenberg * * * defendants" was ended.

BERLIN, June 20 -- Stalin Allee. the broad new boulevard which East Germany's Communists had hailed with pride and joy as their "first Socialist street," this week became for them a symbol of humiliation and failure.

From Dhirubhai Mehta of Ghatkopar comes word that India will issue a series, probably four values, commemorating the recent conquest of Mount Everest by E. P. Hillary of New Zealand and Tensing Norkay, a Nepalese guide who lives in India.

Unlike Queen Elizabeth II, a very young lady cried throughout her coronation yesterday in Columbus Park at Park and Mulberry Streets. Victory over 113 other contestants was too much on a hot afternoon for Joyce Ligh 3 years old, of 46 Mott Street, who was crowned queen of the thirteenth annual baby contest held by the Chinese Community Club, 24 Pell Street.
GOOD music continues to be a staple item on the radio summer programming agenda with the microphones ranging far and wide over the country to pick up their offerings.

According to an estimate of Maj. Gen. Thomas Timberman, American commander in West Berlin, the Russians have brought in two armored divisions, including about 25,000 men, to keep down the population of East Berlin. Other thousands of Russian troops have been deployed to maintain order in other cities in the Russian zone.

Navy's Olympic champions gained their twentieth straight victory yesterday, retaining their intercollegiate title at Syracuse. Cornell was second. Washington took the junior varsity and freshman races.
Everybody asks the same questions these days. What goes with Milwaukee? Will they fold? Are they really that good?

CRABGRASS starts to invade lawns in June. It appears first as a pale green two-leaved grass that is not unsightly. It becomes progressively coarser as the summer advances, until in midsummer, when the red seedheads form, the lawn appears moth-eaten.

For a long time the law governing the taxation of stock dividends was oversimplified. The leading decision on this subject, by the United States Supreme Court in 1920, was interpreted to mean that a dividend paid in stock of the same corporation generally was not taxable as income. Since the Nineteen Thirties the law has slowly crystallized.

By next July 30, New York's Transit Authority announces it will have a sufficient supply of local transportation tokens to put a higher fare into operation. The new tokens will be merely an extension of an old American custom since, according to collectors, more than 5,000 such coinages (for transport services alone) have been in use at one time or another since this country's founding.
In terms of this country's export-import trade in nonmilitary goods during recent months, the dollar gap seems to be nearing the vanishing point.

The men who, above all others, were kept busy at yesterday's Belasco Theatre broadcast of the N. B. C. Symphony were those handling the percussion. Don Gillis conducted a program of his own music, and he likes to score heavily for a variety of effects.

WE have here a stimulating and provocative study by contrasts of the American and Chinese ways of life. The author, a Chinese, has lived in several sections of his native land, has been a student in England, has traveled in Europe, and now, having chosen to make his home permanently in the United States, is teaching anthropology in Northwestern University.

OUT in South Dakota's Black Hills, which the President visited less than a fortnight ago and which drew two million tourists last year, something new has been added. The attraction is a chair lift on 7,000-foot Terry Peak not far from the town of Lead.

Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires, challenger of Samuel Reshevsky of New York for the chess championship of the West, finally, after three sessions, succeeded in winning the tenth game of the series being played in the Argentine capital, according to a report received yesterday.
CLINTON, N. Y., June 20 (AP) -- Robert F. Wagner Jr. declared here tonight that Governor Dewey was to blame for New York City's financial plight.

QUITE a to-do has been made by Victor about the speed with which the original-cast recording of Rodgers and Hammerstein's Me and Juliet was produced (something like five days from studio to stores). Although, from the purchaser's point of view, this might seem an unlikely point on which to wax enthusiastic, the resultant twelve-inch LP reveals that it is one of the few noteworthy aspects of the disk.

TRENTON, Jun 20 -- When the New Jersey Legislature reconvenes here Monday after a four-week recess, three important and extremely controversial matters will be awaiting its consideration. All require prompt action, but there is reason to believe that one may be shelved until the fall and perhaps until after the November election.

BOSTON, June 20 (AP) -- River Divide Farm's Andre proved his recent Tomasello Memorial victory was no fluke by beating practically the same field as a 14-1 shot in the $10,000 Puritan Handicap today at Suffolk Downs.

Shipyards serving the barge and towing industry of the inland waterways launched 287 vessels in the first quarter of 1953, reducing the backlog of firm construction contracts to 491, it was announced yesterday by the American Waterways Operators, Inc.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 20 -- The proposal was made at a meeting of white settlers this week that German peasants without land since the amputation of Germany east of the Oder and Neisse Rivers be brought into Kenya as settlers.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., June 20 -- Segregation is indefensible morally and spiritually, whatever its origin, and must be eliminated from both society and the church, the Aaronsburg Assembly agreed tonight in endorsing a report submitted by a panel that had spent the day studying prejudices in religion.

IN what the author assures us was the "587th year before the birth of Christ" one Beladar personal physician to and closest friend of Nebuchadnezzar, King of Babylon, is summoned to the royal presence -- and is at once sent on a mission as a super - spy to a strange little spot called Judea where the King has heard, the Hebrews and a few other peoples are plotting with Egypt's Pharaoh against his crown.
Most of Manhattan's West Side, from Greenwich Village to 110th Street, was surveyed recently by New York University's Center for Human Relations Studies.

WATER gardening is easy and pleasant. A pool needs practically no care most of the year if a natural balance is maintained between fish and plants. Fish are essential because they feed extensively on the mosquito larvae growing on the surface of the water.

I NOTED with interest the article on "Pay-as-you-see TV" in last Sunday's TIMES. With all of the discussion of future possibilities in box-office TV, it should be pointed out that the only operating box-office TV systime today is theatre TV.

NOROTON, Conn., June 20 -- Stan Ogilvy, who lost the John Taylor Arms trophy to Bob Smith a year ago, got off to a good start as the fifteenth annual Noroton race week for Star Class sloops opened its five-day run this afternoon off Noroton Yacht Club.

HONOLULU, June 30 -- Several thousand workers belonging to the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's union were still off their jobs today on Hawaii docks and in the sugar fields, in protest against a Federal Court jury verdict yesterday holding Jack W. Hall, Regional director of the union in Hawaii and six others guilty on Communist conspiracy charges.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 20 -- "Absolute segregation" between whites and non-whites on Johannesburg's transport system has been demanded by Nationalist members of the all-white City Council here. To carry out Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's apartheid policy, they want no Negroes, persons of mixed blood or East Indians to travel in street cars, buses or trolley buses in which whites ride.

PUSAN, Korea, June 20 -- With the Republic of Korea determined to free 9,000 more anti-Communist prisoners-of-war and the United Nations Command equally determined to hold them, further dissension between Koreans and Americans seemed inevitable tonight.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, announced yesterday the final result of the postcard poll that asked 41,000 enrolled Manhattan Democrats whether they wanted Mayor Impellitteri to be the Democratic candidate for Mayor.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 20 -- Cinda showed today that she can go just as well against the fillies as she can against the colts. Competing in the $23,100 Regret Handicap, the 4-year-old daughter of Occupy carried the colors of Jouett Shouse to victory by a half-length over Hal Price Headley's Recover at Monmouth Park.
ALBANY, June 20 -- Governor Dewey has rejected the State Crime Commission's proposal for a permanent state investigating agency with broad powers to root out organized crime and political corruption.

SOUTH COVENTRY, Conn. -- A celebration honoring one of the nation's best-known patriots, Nathan Hale, will be held at the Hale homestead in this eastern Connecticut village today. The event is being sponsored by the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society of Connecticut, and the public is invited both to the celebration and to an inspection tour of the 177-year-old house, which is owned and maintained by the society.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 20 -- Dick Williams brought Lord Steward forward with a rush in the stretch to score a two-length victory over favored Gene Mac in the $6,000 free-for-all Flower Hill trot before 28,775 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

Referring to the discussion of Dr. Pei's proposals for a world language, I submit Yiddish, the language of the North European Jews, as a candidate. As an already internationally used language, I think nothing can compare with it. * * *

Because of its position of world leadership in a time of international tension, the United States faces a critical problem of civil-military relations. Is the job of the professional military man limited to leading masses of troops in battle ? Or should he also be prepared to help make some of the more important diplomatic and economic policies of the nation ?

WHERE is Russia headed? Is the massive "peace offensive" now being conducted by Moscow merely a tactical maneuver, or does it represent a fundamental and permanent change of policies and goals? These are the key questions today as the free world surveys and seeks to evaluate the flood of conciliatory statements and gestures which have come from the Kremlin and its minions in the little more than one hundred days since Joseph Stalin died.
One does not find personalities in corporate balance sheets. But the 1952 annual report of the National Can Corporation admits that concern's newest capital investment is Robert S. Solinsky.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 20 -- Rallying on the last seven holes, Roslyn (Cookie) Swift, 22-year-old golfer from the Glen Oaks Club, Great Neck, L. I., won the women's metropolitan golf championship by defeating Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge by 3 and 2.

LONDON, Sunday, June 21 -Diplomatic quarters in London indicated last night that it was extremely unlikely the Bermuda conference would take place June 29. It was pointed out here that even if a new French Premier should be chosen early this week, the French Government probably could not be fully constituted before the end of the week and the Premier could not immediately leave Paris to meet President Eisenhower and Sir Winston Churchill.

Your analysis of subscription video touched only lightly upon what seems to be the most significant deterrent, the economic strain it will cause. Admittedly, pay-as-you-see TV would transform television from an economical mode of entertainment to a more costly type.

Paul Hoffmann's Cayuga, a converted 8-meter sloop, won the City Island Yacht Club's first-day race for large cruising yachts yesterday by leading 14 rivals on a 24-mile run from Eastchester Bay to Oak Neck Buoy and return.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Congress has been whittling away with creditable if unspectacular industry lately at the huge stack of appropriations bills that always constitutes the chief obstacle to adjournment on schedule. The re-results are by no means insignificant.

STANTON, Del., June 20 -- Spring Hill Farm's Jamie K., won his first stake race today as he charged from behind at the top of the stretch in the $30,000 added Leonard Richards stakes at Delaware Park to score in a field of seven.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 20 -- Emil (Bus) Mosbacher's Susan registered her fifth triumph of the season today as the Indian Harbor Yacht Club conducted its sixty-sixth annual regatta on Long Island Sound.

BERLIN, June 20 -- A Tass dispatch broadcast by Moscow today accused the United States, British and French commandants in Berlin of being responsible for disorders orders this week in East Berlin. The dispatch derided a protest note by the three commandants that summoned the Soviet commandant to cease using military force to suppress the workers.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 20 -- Small groups, apparently Communist-led, demonstrated in Tel Aviv and Haifa today against the deaths of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg. In Tel Aviv 200 persons assembled outside the United States Embassy which was heavily guarded by the police.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- Phil Swett of Lagrange, Ill., captain of the 1952 Yale track squad, was high scorer today in the fifty-second annual Central Amateur Athletic Union track meet. won by Chicago's Catholic Youth Organization team.

JOHN GOODWIN'S Grand Guignol of life in Haiti, as it seems to three Americans who arrive there in search of some kind of faith, is more Baedeker than novel. But it is not the kind of Baedeker that will encourage tourist trade.

Chairman Bob Christenberry of the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday ordered a complete investigation of the May 2 fight at Syracuse, N. Y., in which Danny (Bang Bang) Womber won an upset decision over Kid Gavilan, welterweight champion, in a nontitle match.

When the University of Chicago in 1942 adopted the highly unorthodox procedure of admitting students who had not finished high school, the educational world was startled. Most educators had assumed that only a student with a high school diploma was capable of carrying a college program.

QUEENS -- Librarianship Queens College announces the establishment of an experimental instructional program in special librarianship this fall. The program is designed to meet certain needs which appear to be peculiar to special libraries and to provide a proving ground for the development of new courses in librarianship.

TO some bustling cliff-dwellers the recent, surprising glimpses of a familiar, twinkling horse-faced man above and beneath the face of Manhattan may have momentarily suggested, and rightly, a French farce.
