THE off-shore fishing season is just beginning, and with the school tuna due shortly, followed closely by the white marlin and broadbill, this activity will soon reach its peak, to be followed immediately by a flurry of complaints from unhappy anglers.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., June 20 -- A 21-year-old student pilot with four and a half solo hours went aloft this morning for an hour's practice of air acrobatics. He landed back here almost eight hours later after obtaining instructions at two other airports to find his course and causing a multi-state search for him by the Civil Aeronautics Patrol.

JERSEY CITY, June 20 -- Bobby Courter, 12 years old, of 71 Cedar Avenue, Montclair, N. J., one of the youngest stockholders in the Erie Railroad, realized a small boy's wish today when he rode in the locomotive of the line's Chicago Limited, but his reaction was that of a typical stockholder.

The report made last week to the American Institute of Architects that forest growth is nearing a point of equilibrium with demand could mislead the innocent bystander into the unwarranted conclusion that the timber problem is as good as solved in our country. As a matter of fact it isn't.

For several years I have taught Marxian economics at Columbia University in the summer and the University of Virginia in the winter. It will be seen, therefore, that I agree enthusiastically with President Eisenhower that we ought to examine Communist ideas rather than merely suppress them.
The city experienced its hottest day of the year yesterday as the temperature soared to 92.6 degrees on the last day before the official start of summer.

JASPER, Alberta -- As the train rolled slowly through the Athabaska River Valley, twisting below the snow-whitened peaks of the Canadian Rockies, the visiting firemen from the East, out to see the reopening of the rebuilt Jasper Park Lodge, were startled to find lilacs just beginning to bloom in the village dooryards and tulips just reaching their peak.

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., June 20 -- -- Chet Sanok of Forest Hill and Norval Postweiler scored a 4-under-par gross of 35, 32 -- 67 today to take the first-round lead in the annual Roche Memorial invitation golf tournament at the Maplewood Country Club.
CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- Jackie Robinson of the Dodgers today took over the lead from Stan Musial and Ralph Kiner in the left-field rivalry of the All-Star baseball poll.

C. R. Simboli's letter referring to Dr. Mario Pei's article, "Conquest of Babel?" (May 24) on the subject of the use of Latin as an international language proves again that only a Latin teacher can really love it. He says it is studied and spoken by many.

A new type of air power was displayed over England last week as Boeing B-47 Stratojets and KC-97 Stratofreighters of the United States Air Force Strategic Air Command carried out its first operational missions in the United Kingdom.

After six months of operations in an atmosphere of tight money and realistic rates, New York City banks, shortly to render their mid-year earnings reports to the supervisory authorities, find themselves continuing in a transition period.

THE coleus is again coming into popularity. For too long this foliage plant has been relegated to public parks and railway stations where its purple red tones have inharmoniously companioned scarlet sage or red cannas.

Scoring victories in four of the six singles matches and two of the three doubles tests, the Middle States Tennis Association team defeated the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, 6 -- 3, yesterday at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, Queens, to win the annual Church Cup intersectional team competition.
BERLIN, June 20 (AP) -- Communist raiding parties in East Germany tonight were seeking out workers who caused strikes, committed arson and rioted against Red rule on Wednesday.
A flurry of auction sales of furniture and decorations this week enlivens a season about to enter the doldrums.

BALTIMORE, June 20 -- Carl Murphy, president of the Afro-American newspapers, with editions in Baltimore, Washington, Richmond, Philadelphia and Newark, N. J., was elected president of the National Newspaper Publishers' Association at the organization's annual meeting, which closed today.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 20 -- T. R. McConnell, chancellor of the University of Buffalo, has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of the Educational Testing Service for one year, it was announced here today. He succeeds Dr. Katharine E. McBride, president of Bryn Mawr College.

SUDIE EMERSON, trained as a landscape architect, returned to her home town in Texas with one ambition, to use her skill improving the landscape. In spite of a grandfather who disapproved of working women and some hopeful suitors, Sudie went to work.

SEOUL, Korea, June 20 -- President Syngman Rhee has made up his mind to dismiss Gen. Sun Yup Paik as South Korean Army Chief of Staff within the next day or two. The general is considered a pivotal figure in the crisis in Korea.

YONKERS, June 20 -- There were a couple of "interesting firsts" today at the Yonkers Kennel Club Dog Show. One was that the bloodhound Champion Bourbon of Panther Ledge, owned Clendenin J. Ryan of Allamuchy, N. J., went best in show for the first time.

TODAY is the "Long Day" of the year when summer arrives and finds its own flowers already blossoming in the country. As church bells ring out at twelve o'clock (E. S. T.) the sun will reach its most northern point in a six-month journey up from the Tropic of Capricorn, and will shine upon our northern landscape for fifteen hours and about eighteen minutes.

Jack Raymond's interesting story of United Nations aid to Yugoslavia which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES June 12 under a Belgrade dateline left out one important aspect of the U. N. work there: aid given to mothers and children through the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

An interesting sidelight to the anti-Russian riots and demonstrations that took place in the Soviet Zone of East Berlin last week is a glimpse of health conditions there as recently reported by a refugee physician.

Five players who never before have been members of the team are included in the squad of ten chosen to represent the United States in the 1953 Walker Cup matches with Great Britain at the Kittansett Club in Marion, Mass., Sept. 4 and 5.

BERLIN, June 20 -- The uprising of the East Berlin working class this week dramatized the problem of Germany's reunification in a manner which neither the parliamentary debates in Bonn nor the Soviet Government's recent maneuvers has been able to approach.

IN the interval of writing her pleasant light novels, G. B. Stern has for some years produced a series of what can best be described by the old term, "commonplace books." Not memoir, essay, or anthology, they partake of all three genres.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Government officials whose job descriptions relate them one way or another to security information took a deep breath this week and plunged into President Eisenhower's proposed new security order.

The appointment of W. J. Fisher, former deputy transport controller and director of the traffic service branch of the Canadian Maritime Commission, as general manager of the newly-formed Canadian Shipowners Association was announced yesterday by Melvyn G. Angus of Montreal, president of the association.

ALTHOUGH there may be some temptation to overestimate the politics in Twentieth Century-Fox's "Man on a Tightrope," now on the Mayfair's screen, there also may be some inclination to overlook the moral in this film.

THE other week at the American Booksellers Association convention some energy was expended on scoring the Hemingway-Life deal ("The Old Man and the Sea" came out in the magazine before it did as a book) citing it as the kind of thing that keeps books from selling as well as they might.

Theodore White has written a remarkably lucid and perspicacious article on the French National Assembly in "Behind the Stalemate in French Politics" (May 31). In his description of the difficulty encountered in forming a majority, Mr. White might have added that since time limits provided in the Constitution of the Fourth French Republic have elapsed, it is now possible for the Executive to call for a dissolution of the Assembly.

With eleven Olympic champions in the lists, a brilliant field of athletes will compete for twenty-one titles in the Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor track and field championships at Dayton, Ohio, on Friday and Saturday.
In rapid succession Patrolman John Forget of the Bergen Street station, Brooklyn, helped bring one person into this world and to put another in jail early yesterday morning.

HIS eyes were deep set and limpid brown, and had devils in them that danced a flickering rigadoon in tempo with the wavering candlelight. The cheek-bones were prominent and the lips, wide and full, were set in an almost straight line over a determined chin.

Three seniors of the Thomas A. Edison Vocational High School in Queens rode off with the honors at a city-wide teen-age automobile driving contest yesterday and will represent the city in a state competition next week.

JOSE FERRER, arch proponent of the rich, full life, paused here briefly last week amidst his perennial peregrinations to drop off a hopeful note -- he thinks he will be able to persuade Olivia de Havilland to make another try for Broadway laurels.

BUDAPEST, June 20 -- The philosopher Plato wrote of a cave in which people were chained so that they could look only toward the back of the cave. Shadows of persons passing behind the prisoners were taker to be real beings. When one captive burst his bonds, peered about and reported that these were, indeed, shadows and that true humans had color, shape and form, he was utterly disbelieved.

YOUNG Tom King is the completely spoiled, conceited grandson of a wealthy, self-made lumberman. Allergic to schools, he has "busted out" of three of them. Bored with everything, he reluctantly accepts the challenge to prove himself by taking a job, under an assumed name, with a logging crew on one of his grandfather's timber tracts in the North Woods.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (UP) -Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Senate Republican leader, said today he expected the Republican program of labor legislation to call for about fifteen Taft-Hartley Law amendments -- most of them to meet complaints from the labor movement.
BELOIT, Wis., June 20 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley replied tonight to Wisconsin Republicans who censured him a week ago for his opposition to the proposed Bricker amendment to the Constitution.
Oilmen call it "suitcase rock," because when they hit it they know there's no chance of finding oil with this particular well. They have drilled a dry hole and might as well pack up and move on.

MADISON, Wis. -- For many years Wisconsin has been known to vacationists as a land of lakes and forests. Although this reputation is still justified, there is much more for the tourist in Wisconsin than hunting, fishing and swimming.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (UP) -- President Eisenhower got a new flycasting rod today, recalled his low-paid early Army days and skipped his usual Saturday afternoon round of golf.

THE other day, James Caesar Petrillo, the president of the Musicians' Union, a small, bellicose man of 61, who has faced down everyone from Presidents of the United States to presidents of mere networks and recording companies, operated on Oscar Levant, the pianist, a tall, bellicose man of 46, on the ground that the part-time wit had reneged on some concert engagements.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 20 -- Thirty universities working together are sponsors of the nonprofit Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies, whose campus is the nation.

STOCKHOLM, June 20 -- The execution of the death sentences of the Rosenbergs has drawn no press comment in Sweden because of the traditional two-day suspension of Swedish newspapers during the midsummer holidays. The Swedes learned about the end of the Rosenbergs through a brief paragraph in the noon newscast on the National Broadcasting net.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia. June 20 -- Despite repeated requests, Yugoslav authorities have thus far not permitted Western experts to examine a new Soviet jet fighter plane that crashed here more than a month ago.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Optimism about the general business outlook for the remainder of the year is expressed by members of the Young Presidents' Organization. Some 80 per cent are hopeful about sales and earning prospects of their companies.

At a press conference held in 1950 Gordon Dean, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said that some day a dummy model of the atomic bomb would be put in Macy's window. In an article published in Foreign Affairs, Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer virtually holds that the day has come.

PARIS, June 20 Feeling ran high here today following the execution of the death sentences on Julius and Ethel Rosenberg. Although the language used depended on the politics of the newspaper or person, disapproval was common to all the opinions expressed.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- United States officials are moving to counter the Communist's use of the Rosenberg executions as propaganda in the cold war.

PANMUNJOM, June 20 (UP) -- Following is the text of a letter from Marshal Kim II Sung, North Korean Premier and Gen. Peng Teh-huai, commander of the Chinese People's Volunteers, to Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations Commander:

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 20 -- Clifton Mayne, 19-year-old sophomore from the University of California, captured the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship today by defeating his team-mate, Fred Hagist, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, 11 -- 9.

The execution of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg on Friday night brought to an end a case that has stirred more worldwide interest than any American judicial proceeding since the Sacco-Vanzzetti trial a quarter of a century ago. The Rosenbergs were sentenced to death for a new kind of crime in a new age -- the age of atomic destruction.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 20 -- The Nassau County Democratic party, relegated since the county charter was granted in 1938 to the role of minority voice, has split into at least three camps over a possible change in leadership at party elections after the September primary.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 20 -- Foodstuffs are getting short here and prices are soaring as a result of the maritime strike, which is confined to workers on coastwise ships.

William P. Gottlieb's "Photography With Basic Cameras" (New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $1.50) is both a remarkably simplified beginner's book and an excellent lesson in teaching. A forty-four-page elementary course in the use of fixed-focus cameras in the under-$15 category, the book has been written for the youngster with no knowledge of photography.

JOHN McGRAW invented the play and perfected it. Every other manager, it would seem, has been trying to out-McGraw McGraw ever since. But it was not until Wee Willie Keeler, the ideal man to make it click, joined the Baltimore Orioles in 1894 that McGraw put his play to use. Wee Willie was an artist with the bat. "I hit 'em where they ain't," he said. And did.

The advance in the price of crude oil last week, averaging about 25 cents a barrel, in most fields east of the Rocky Mountains in the face of excess inventories of refined products is generally considered as compensation for domestic producers' maintaining an excess productive capacity of around 1,000,000 barrels a day for national security purposes.

THE gardener of today would do well to take a few leaves out of the eighteenth century gardener's notebook. At least that's the opinion of Alden Hopkins, landscape architect for the Colonial Williamsburg Restoration in Williamsburg, Va.
Ten horses raced in the $29,350 Queens County Handicap at Aqueduct yesteday. The ninth choice, a 27-1 shot, won.

ATHENS, June 20 -- In a forty- five minute broadcast to the Greek people tonight, Spyros Markezinis, the Economic Minister, painted a picture of the present economic situation in such bright colors that many persons, having in mind the current general rise in commodity prices, the tightness of credits and the increase in unemployment, professed some difficulty in recognizing it.
Strike-bound ships manned by the National Maritime Union began to move yesterday as locals of the C. I. O. union began ratifying a settlement of the four-day dispute with shipping operators.

LONDON, June 20 (UP) -- A Moscow radio "travelogue" pictured Los Angeles today as a place of misery pervaded by the smell of oil and New York as a city where the beggars visit Russian ships and get handouts of hot borscht.

That the atom is made up of a nucleus about which electrons rotate, much as the planets rotate about the sun, is common knowledge. But what of the forces within the nucleus -- the forces that are released by the atomic bomb, when nuclei are made violently radioactive? This riddle was discussed in a conference of prominent nuclear physicists held at Indiana University.

ALBANY, June 20 -- Special sessions of the Legislature, such as the one called for next week to deal with the New York City dock situation, other recommendations of the State Crime Commission, and the New York City Transit Authority, have been comparatively rare occurrences since Governor Dewey took office ten and a half years ago.

COLORADO SPRINGS. Colo., June 20 (UP) -- North Texas State will try for its fifth straight team title in the week-long National Collegiate Athletic Association golf championships, starting on the Broadmoor course on Monday.

THE figure of the priest, dedicated, troubled and compassionate, appears with less and less frequency in first flight contemporary fiction. His disappearance from the Grade-A field would seem to be the result of some sort of Gresham's law, for he pops up more and more often in novels designed to have a best-seller trajectory.

A RED-LETTER day on any rosarian's calendar is the opening of the National Rose Show. This year, as if to prove that roses are really rugged plants that grow almost anywhere, the event will be held in Minneapolis, Minn., on Thursday from 2 to 5 P. M. and Friday from 9 A. M. to 4 P. M.

After many months of study and preliminary design, the American Gas and Electric Company, the Babcock Wilcox Company and the General Electric Company have reached agreements in accordance with which General Electric will design and manufacture a 120,000-kilowatt turbine, and Babcock Wilcox will design and build the boiler for it.

PRODUCTIVE capacity stands as a colossus over the industrial scene. Distributive capacity apparently does not quite match the ability of manufacturers and the nation's farmers to produce and therein lies a danger that can bring a lot of trouble to the business community.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Norman Cousins. president of the United World Federalists, said tonight that "the action of the Syngman Rhee Government in freeing the North Korean prisoners represents a fundamental challenge to the life of the United Nations itself."

SHUVAL, Israel, June 15 -- Between the Egyptian-occupied Gaza Strip and the Hebron Hills held by Jordan lies the northern Negev of Israel. Here an arid rolling plain that the Israelis have sown to barley and wheat stretches as far as you can see in all directions.

Marcel Eichi, who operates a beauty parlor in the five-story building at 14 East Fifty-sixth Street has bought the building from the 14 East Fifty-sixth Street Corporation through Emanuel Schwartz, broker, and plans to use the entire structure for his business.

The pressure toward conformity in every area of life has "never been so strong in our time," the Rev. Dr. Chester A. Pennington declared yesterday morning in his sermon on "The Right of Rebellion" at the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

BUENOS AIRES, June 17 -- Although there have been no book burnings by United States officials here, fourteen volumes, representing eleven authors and editors, have been removed from the shelves of the library of the United State Information Service in the last three months.
Kiwanis International's first convention in this city became the largest in its history last night when registrations exceeded 13,000 delegates, wives and offspring.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Spec Shea limited Cleveland to three hits to register his sixth victory today as the Senators defeated the Indians, 5 -- 1. Art Houtteman, making his first start for Cleveland, was the victim of jittery infield play which cost the Indians three runs in the first inning.

SO Abe Saperstein had the silver dollars, all 3,000 of them, trundled into the room of wheelbarrow and Walter Dukes accepted them in exchange for his signature on a Harlem Globetrotter contract. That's why the 7-foot Dukes already has begun to drop basketballs through the hoop for the Globetrotters instead of for the New York Knickerbockers whom he left holding the bag -- an empty one, naturally.

ABOARD U. S. S. LLOYD AT SEA, June 21 -- Bolero, the big yawl owned by John Nicholas Brown, appeared to be leading today in the 466-mile race from Newport to Annapolis, but there was no certainty about it.

William C. Chanler, chairman of the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee, said yesterday that his organization, which is trying to bring the Republican and Liberal parties into a "good government" coalition, would not support any candidate for Mayor put forward by the Democratic organization of the city, which he described as "the Tammany machine."

The major league record for most double plays in a doubleheader is ten (Washington, 1943). The Yankees made five, while defeating the Tigers, 6 -- 3, in the opener at the Stadium yesterday and added two in the first two innings of the afterpiece, but they flubbed the next one -- their last chance.

A new formula governing the use of the waters of the Delaware River by New York City, Pennsylvania and New Jersey is expected to clear the way for an early start on the city's proposed construction of a huge new $140,000,000 reservoir at Cannonsville, N. Y., to impound the waters of the Delaware's West Branch.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 21 -- The Halligans took over at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Name of Jesus on Petersville Road this morning -- with one of the family celebrating his first solemn high mass as a priest and four relatives assisting on the altar.

Several hundred books by more than forty authors have been removed from the shelves of United States libraries abroad in connection with at least six confidential State Department directives between Feb. 19 and June 21, according to a survey covering twenty capitals conducted by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A pet rhesus monkey named Tommy made a break for freedom late yesterday in a residential section of Queens, on the eve of being sent to the Central Park zoo, and precipitated a perspiring pursuit that lasted for two and a half hours. Between 6:30 and 9 P.M., eight policemen and nearly 100 citizens took part in the chase.

What amounts to a new version of "The Crucible" will be unfolded tonight at the Martin Beck Theatre. The extensive revamping goes into effect exactly five months to the night after the premiere of Arthur Miller's play, which won the Antoinette Perry Prize for being the best drama of the past season and was in a dead heat with "Picnic" in the Donaldson sweepstakes.

Outstanding in today's patterns is the dress sketched at the right-hand side of the illustration, Advance Pattern 6238. It is a new expression of the "separates" style. Two identical halves make the dress. As can be seen in the accompanying drawing, one half overlaps the other, crossing it in a diagonal line from shoulder to hem.

MOSCOW, June 21 -- Pravda today demanded "the highest vigilance" on the part of the Soviet people against what it described as undermining efforts by the American intelligence directed against the Soviet Union.

CLINTON, N. Y., June 21 (AP) -- Averell Harriman said today the Republican Administration in Washington was weakening the United States' strongest pillars against a new world war -- its military strength and the unity and strength of this nation's friends and allies.

CINCINNATI, June 21 (AP) -- Gus Bell's three-run homer, his fifteenth, snapped a five-game Redleg losing streak today as Cincinnati whipped Philadelphia, 5 -- 3, after bowing, 5 -- 2, in the opener of a double-header.

ATHENS, June 17 -- The United States Information Service Library with nearly 10,000 volumes, mainly on specialized nonpolitical subjects has existed since the immediate post war period. Throughout, it has been in charge of a trained librarian who has known what was suitable.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -- Harry S. Truman, in his shirt sleeves and driving his own car, motored into Washington today for his first visit to the capital since he left it Jan. 20.
DARIEN, Conn., June 21 -- Miss Diana, Johnny Scarlett and Mr. O'Malley took hunter division titles. Black Watch the jumper laurels as the two-day Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show ended today.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The White House announced today that Wednesday, July 8, was "the present target date" for the meeting in Bermuda of the President of the United States, the Prime Minister of Britain and the Premier of France.

The Rev. Maurice A. Dawkins, minister of education of the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, proposed in his sermon yesterday morning the teaching in the public schools of the facts about churches, synagogues and religious groups.

RYE, N. Y., June 21 -- Gus Salerno, Hampshire professional, paired with two Ryewood Country Club members for net and best-ball cards of 61, ten below par, as Ryewood's second pro-member golf tournament ended in a tie today. With Arthur Margolyes, Salerno had nines of 30 and 31. With Ernest Geiger it was 31, 30.

Still staggering under a record load of tenant complaints that followed rent increases granted to landlords last May 1, local offices of the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission reported yesterday they had disposed of 2,712 or 28 per cent of the cases.

BELGRADE, June 18 -- Before the arrival of Roy M. Cohn and Gerard D. Schine, investigators for Senator McCarthy, the Public Affairs officer here took some books off library shelves as "out of date." Among them were Upton Sinclair's "Dragons' Teeth," which won the Pulitzer Prize in 1943, books by Frederick L. Schuman, political scientist, and Gunnar Myrdal, Swedish economist.

The American Radio Association C.I.O., representing 2,000 seagoing radio operators aboard American-flag ships, has won what it considers an important victory in obtaining jurisdiction over any and all forms of radio and electronic communications in the contract settlement reached Saturday with East Coast freighter and passenger, tanker and collier companies.

ANTWERP. Belgium, June 21 -- The 3,330-ton Panananian freighter Areti, here to take on cargo for the Iron Curtain port of Constanta, Rumania, has been prevented from loading by a longshoremen's boycott.

PARIS, June 21 -- The French cotton industry has just published a plan approved by the employers that calls attention to the difficulties they are meeting. The main conclusion reached is that because of all these difficulties the professionals of this branch of the industry do not believe in the possibility of a single market in their sector.

Ten thousand members of the Holy Name Society in the Diocese of Brooklyn, hundreds fewer than were in two parades down Bedford Avenue in Flatbush, braved yesterday's blistering heat to attend a religious and patriotic rally at Ebbets Field.

New Deal economists, searching for a rationalization of the so-called Recession of 1937-38, hit upon the novel explanation that it had been produced by "sticky prices." These economists, it seems, had observed that certain prices had shown themselves to be less vulnerable than others to a general downturn in business.

The life and career of Andre Benoist, who died on Friday at the age of 74, illustrate strikingly how important can be the role of those whose function is to help others without seeking the limelight for themselves. Mr. Benoist was one of the most gifted pianists of our generation, but he was known and loved not as the solo performer but in his supporting capacity.

ALBANY, June 21 -- Governor Dewey moved today to rid the Port of New York of "gangster control" by a reform plan that urged the Legislature to cut off the fund-raising powers of any waterfront union local that continued to employ an officer or agent who had been convicted of a felony.

MANILA, June 21 -- A thousand shouting delegates attending the Democratic party convention nominated Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo today by acclaim to run against President Elpidio Quirino and former Defense Secretary Ramon Magsaysay in the Philippine presidential campaign.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- "Miksis will fix us" ran one line of a parody at the New York baseball writers' show eight years ago. It was an ironic statement, since Eddie Miksis then was a young Dodger who hadn't helped the club during a record sixteen-game losing streak in 1944.

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., June 21 -- Chet Sanok of Forsgate and Norval Postweiler captured the Roche Memorial member-guest golf tournament over the Maplewood Country Club course today. The pair tacked a 68 to an opening-day 67 for a winning total of 135.
Five new films, including an importation from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

MILWAUKEE, June 21 -- The Giants, spurred to action by one of Leo Durocher's most fantastic shake-ups -- a move that switched Alvin Dark from shortstop to left field, came close to tossing a serious road block in the path of the league-leading Braves today.

Net profits of the Davega Stores Corporation were up sharply in the fiscal year ended last March 31, compared with the previous twelve months; and net sales increased moderately, according to the annual report made public over the week-end.

TRENTON, June 21 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, emphasizing that "one hard-hitting, efficient agency is what we need" to clean up "coruption" in the Port of New York, made public today a special message on pier legislation. The message will be submitted to both houses of the Legislature when they reconvene tomorrow after a four-week recess.

LONDON, June 21 -- The prospect of a Korean truce has stimulated British commercial interest in the China trade though economic and political limitations on East-West commerce will continue even beyond an armistice.

PUSAN, Korea, June 21 -- This temporary capital, which is a mass of high tension even under ordinary wartime conditions, seems even more alive now following the escape of thousands of anti-Communist Korean war prisoners from United Nations stockades.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, confidently predicted today that the Administration-backed proposal to extend the excess profits tax for six months, now locked in the House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee, would be reported and passed.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $79,352,718,354. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

It took about a half century to do it but a Dandie Dinmont terrier finally won an American all-breed event. It happened yesterday at the fourteenth annual show of the Staten Island Kennel Club. The dog to turn the trick was the mustard- colored Waterbeck Watermark, an import owned by Sarah Swift's Cliffield Kennels of Bedford Village.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 21 -- A weekly television show, designed to sell Hollywood on an institutional level and coincidentally to generate interest in particular pictures, now looms as a strong prospect for presentation over the American Broadcasting Company network.

KARACHI, June 18 -- Thirteen books by American authors have been removed from among 9,000 volumes in the library of the United States Information Service here in Pakistan. Of the thirteen, seven have been temporarily withdrawn, and the United States Embassy is withholding the titles and authors' names pending a further check with the State Department in Washington.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 21 -- Two precocious teen-agers, Ken Rosewall of Australia and Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., have been installed as the top-seeded favorites among the representatives of thirty-two nations entered in the tennis championships which open on the Wimbledon lawns tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today that any person who invoked constitutional rights in refusing to tell a Congressional committee whether he was a Red "obviously is a Communist."

SYRACUSE, June 21 -- Syracuse said good-by today to the oarsmen who participated in the fifty-first regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association yesterday and welcomed another group of athletes who will begin to play here tomorrow in the sixty-ninth National Collegiate Athletic Association tennis championships.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 21 (AP) -- Jack Burke of Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., won the $3,400 top prize in the $18 000 Inverness golf tournament today with a 72-hole score of 272, twelve under par.
DAMASCUS, Syria, June 21 (Reuters) -- Syria received a new Constitution today, heralding a return to parliamentary government after eighteen months of military rule.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- A draft of proposed Taft-Hartley Law changes is being prepared secretly by a group of labor union and industry lawyers with White House approval, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Guy Farmer, Washington lawyer, is reported to be President Eisenhower's probable choice for chairman of the National Labor Relations Board. The resignation of Paul M. Herzog as board chairman takes effect June 30.
LONDON, June 21 (Reuters) -- The Moscow radio tried today to link the East Berlin riots with a "plot" by a mysterious United States "general."

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 21 -- For the first time in several weeks the Mau Mau came back over the week-end in force, overwhelmed a Kikuyu home guard post, burned it down and released Mau Mau prisoners held there. Two other posts were attacked, eighty native huts were burned, native shops were looted and seven Kikuyu tribal guards were reported killed and three wounded.

LONG BEACH, L. I., June 21 -- South Shore Long Islanders marked the advent of summer with an all- day marine festival that centered here with an afternoon speedboat regatta on Reynolds Channel, separating Long Beach and Island Park.

LONDON, June 21 -- Prime Minister Churchill and his staff will leave Britain on the 42,500-ton battleship Vanguard on the night of Tuesday, June 30, for Bermuda. A statement issued at 10 Downing Street said tonight that the party would reach Bermuda in time to welcome President Eisenhower and "the French representatives" on July 7.

" The word of God is what unites us in the Christian brotherhood," the Rev. Dr. Hanns Lilje, Lutheran Bishop of Hanover, Germany, explained in a sermon yesterday at the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Sixty-fifth Street and Central Park West.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 18 -- The only book removed from the shelves of the United States Library here is Morris U. Schappes' "A Documentary History of the Jews in the United States, 1654-1875," which was mentioned as "pro-Communist" before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigation in early April.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The United States has decided to offer separate arms aid agreements to Arab Governments in a move to bolster the strategic Middle East against communism.

ZURICH, June 21 -- Switzerland has endorsed the recommendation of the Organization of European Economic Cooperation that the existence of the European Payments Union be prolonged another year as from July 1, 1953. This endorsement came when the Swiss National Council last Thursday approved a motion before Parliament to extend the supplementary credit of the Confederation to E. P. U. by 275,000,000 francs, considered ample for all predictable needs till June 30, 1954.

WNYC will inaugurate a radio series of elementary language courses in French, Spanish, German, Italian and English beginning July 6. The armed forces' conversational method of instruction will be used. French will be presented for two weeks, Mondays through Fridays from 2 to 2:30 P. M., with Spanish following for a similar period, and then the other languages, through Sept. 11.
BOSTON, June 21 (AP) -- Jimmy Piersall, Red Sox outfielder, helped himself get picked off second base today by the Browns, who thereby pulled off an odd double play.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP) -- Dr. Robert L. Johnson, director of the International Information Administration, said today that he believed President Eisenhower's so-called "book-burning" talk at Dartmouth College last Sunday "was only a figure of speech."
PITTSBURGH, June 21 -- At least two factors which have accounted for an "extra" surge of steel demand for the past several months have been removed from the market. They were:

MADRID, June 18 -- Officials of the United States Information Service have removed eleven books by five authors from the library shelves following directives from Washington. The authors and their books follow:

ALBANY, June 21 -- The Democratic minority leaders of the Legislature announced today that they planned to introduce bills at the special session opening Thursday to postpone any transit fare increase in New York for six months and to increase the city's real estate taxing power.

VIENNA, June 18 -- About two dozen book titles have been removed from libraries of the United States Information Service in Austria as the result of State Department directives. The first directive ordered the purging of books by known Communists or fellow-travelers, while the second listed some fifteen authors whose books were to be removed.
The following book, published recently, is intended for widowed and divorced mothers:...

KANSAS CITY, June 21 (AP) -- Joe Conrad of San Antonio, Tex., made the greatest comeback in the history of the fifty Trans-Mississippi golf tournaments to defeat Jimmy Vickers of Wichita, Kan., 2 up, in a 36-hole championship match today. Conrad was 6 down after the morning round.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the period June 13 through June 19 are given in the appended tabulation:

In steadily increasing volume over the past few years, requests for information on establishing day care centers have reached headquarters of the Child Welfare League. To help answer these and to spur the organization of such programs, the league announced yesterday the publication of a new seventy-page booklet, "Guide to the Operation of Group Day Care Programs.."

WILDWOOD, N. J., June 21 -- William F. Hewitt of North Wildwood was elected today commander of the Department of New Jersey, Disabled American Veterans, at the thirty-third annual convention. He succeeded Edward J. Kuntz of Union City.

LONDON, June 21 -- Last week was very idle and very dull in the stock markets. This was scarcely surprising with the great Spithead naval review and the Ascot races falling in the same week, to say nothing of the disquieting turn of events in Korea and the anti-communist disturbances in East Germany.

One of the more overworked expressions in the broadcasters' lexicon is "public service." Whatever the true meaning of the ambiguity, the term originally was designed to imply a program fulfilling a public need, wherein the broadcaster expended efforts beyond the call of selling air time.

Ryer Associates, Inc., investors, bought the apartment house for thirty-one families on plot 65 by 100 feet at 217 East 182d Street 'northwest corner of Ryer Avenue the Bronx, from Dr. Harry Freedman for cash over a first mortgage of $67,950 held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

Lightning killed three persons in the Bronx yesterday afternoon and injured nine in the metropolitan area as freakish thunderstorms leap-frogged about the city in the climax of the first day of summer and the hottest June 21 in the city's history.

Nearly half of all the independent institutions of higher education in the United States are in financial difficulty, unable to balance their budgets. Financial problems beset the colleges and universities to a greater extent than ever before.

Following is a partial list of titles of books removed from one or more libraries of the United States Information Service abroad in connection with one or more of five confidential State Department directives between February and May:

The congregation of Temple Isaiah was joined yesterday afternoon by the neighbors in dedicating a new house of worship at Grand Central Parkway and Seventy-fifth Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens. The religious ceremony of dedication took place Friday night.

TOKYO, June 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations commander, denying a Communist charge that the Allies had aided in the escape of non-Communist North Korean prisoners.

PARIS, June 21 -- Visiting the Hungarian People's Republic is, in a certain symbolic sense, like climbing the pleasant slopes of Mount Vesuvius. On the surface all seems tranquil, yet one is aware that underneath there exist forces of explosive potential. Whether they will erupt cannot be foreseen.

The youthful King Norodom Sihanouk has acted wisely in ending his voluntary exile and returning to Cambodia. He can better carry on his efforts in behalf of independence from his own country than he could in neighboring Thailand. He has already submitted some proposals to the French and they were under consideration at the time of his flight.

Pleas for widespread financial support for Israel to consolidate its economic structure and enhance its position as a democratic stronghold in the Middle East were voiced at several meetings yesterday by Zionist and Israeli officials and by Representative Jacob K. Javits.

President Eisenhower is wise and right in moving toward a sharp modification of the security order issued by President Truman in 1951. Under the previous order almost fifty Government agencies not even connected with defense or national security could "classify" information: that is, withhold it from the public.

ST. LOUIS, June 21 (UP) -- Three key doubles and Murry Dickson's nine-hit pitching enabled the Pirates to halt the Cardinals' five-game winning streak, 5 -- 2, today at Busch Stadium. The victory also ended the Pirates' string of losses at five.
No matter what the season, the home cook in search of avocados can find them in the market. But though this tropical fruit is available the year 'round, it is most plentiful in summer.

BERLIN, June 21 -- The nine top members of the German staff of RIAS, the official United States radio station in Berlin, threatened today to resign in a body if their political director, Gordon Atkinson Ewing, was recalled to Washington to testify before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

NOROTON, Conn., June 21 -- Stan Ogilvy, with Flame, led the Star Class fleet for the second successive day this afternoon to take a commanding lead for the championship of Noroton Yacht Club's fifteenth annual race week.

BONN, Germany, June 21 -- Former high officers of Hitler's Waffen SS or Elite Guard, pledged strong support today for the European Defense Community treaty and demanded the right to serve in the contingents that the West German Federal Republic would contribute.

The Manhattan blood center of the New York Red Cross Chapter at 70 West Fortieth Street will be moved this week to the Red Cross Chapter House on Lexington Avenue at Thirty-eighth Street, where it will open Thursday at 10 A. M.

The first of a three-volume biography of Sigmund Freud by Dr. Ernest Jones will be issued in September by Basic Books, entitled "The Life and Work of Sigmund Freud." Subtitled "The Formative Years and the Great Discoveries," the volume takes its subject from his birth until 1900, when he was 44.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 21 -- The sudden return to his homeland of Norodom Sihanouk, King of Cambodia, has given rise to speculation that he wishes to resume negotiations for Cambodian independence, which the French refused to discuss so long as he remained in Thailand.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A spokesman for President Eisenhower and John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, will leave for Korea tomorrow to try to impress Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President, with the United States' determination to carry through a truce with Communist forces in Korea.

RALEIGH, N. C., June 21 -- Roman Catholic congregations of Eastern North Carolina generally showed little change today as the result of the decree by Bishop Vincent S. Waters that segregation would not be tolerated.

Rarely has the tide of international events moved more swiftly or more powerfully than in the past month since President Eisenhower announced his projected Bermuda meeting with Prime Minister Churchill and the Premier of France. That meeting had to be postponed twice because France was unable to agree on a successor to Rene Mayer, whose Cabinet fell almost simultaneously with the announcement of the Bermuda meeting.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The 1,800 local offices of state employment services list about 46,000 job openings and Secretary of Labor Martin P. Durkin said today that the figure indicated "continued general tightness of the labor market."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 21 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union has taken a first step toward relaxing its grip over the Danube Commission, which controls shipping on Eastern Europe's main waterway, the official Yugoslav news agency Tanjug reported today.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 21 -- A "sheriff's posse" mounted on nineteen matched Palomino ponies churned the dust of the country-side here today in a hot pursuit -- not of a fugitive but of a fancy.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- A spectacular price advance followed announcement that the Government would make emergency loans on wheat piled on the ground in arid districts of the Southwest, where there is little storage room. This was coincident with active buying of futures by cash interests against liberal sales of flour, which changed pit sentiment abruptly.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said last night that Governor Dewey at a conference last month had refused a compromise he and Senator Herbert H. Lehman had offered for development of the hydroelectric power resources of the Niagara River.

No more appropriate time could be chosen for the convening of a large group of librarians than during this period when books and book selection policies of American libraries at home and abroad have been brought into question by various Congressional committees and freelance censors.
IN all New York there are only a few who paint churches with light as Charles Thomas Henry does. It is a delicate art.

The city's Committee on Slum Clearance Plans disclosed yesterday that it had obtained the cooperation of Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, in introducing legislation in Congress to make up to $35,000,000 more in Federal funds available for rehabilitation of blighted areas here.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 21 -- One of the greatest display of railroad equipment and supplies ever assembled in one place since early man invented the wheel was rolled into this resort for the exhibit of the Railway Supply Manufacturers Association which opens here tomorrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -- Harold E. Stassen, Mutual Security Administrator, outlined a program, designed to close the dollar gap between the United States and other nations of the free world, in a major address here today at the opening of the eighth world congress of the International Junior Chambers of Commerce.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 21 William H. Stanley's Bumble Bee, with Arthur Knapp at the tiller, took the honors in the International Class in the Riverside Yacht Club's annual regatta on Long Island Sound today. It was the tenth program of a series of thirty-six championship races under the auspices of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

American Christians relegating religion to the status of "an optional side issue" in their lives wrongly consider themselves "a morally superior chosen people," the Rev. Dr. C. Iver Hellstrom declared yesterday at Riverside Church.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 21 -- The Dutch foreign exchange position has shown constant improvement during the past few weeks, reflected in substantial liberalization of Dutch tourist allowances. Not only has the allowance been raised from 600 to 1,000 guilders per person but it also will be available henceforth for any number of trips -- except to the dollar area -- provided that no more than 75 guilders is spent each day.
At the time approaches for selection of candidates for Mayor by the political parties and independent groups there is no clear indication of what will be the alignment at the city election on Nov. 3.

AARONSBURG, Pa., June 21 -- Several thousand Americans of all faiths and races converged on this central Pennsylvania hamlet of 312 residents this afternoon to join the Aaronsburg Assembly in commemorating "the gift of Aaron Levy."

The thirty-sixth consecutive season of summer concerts at Lewisohn Stadium starts tonight and will continue for six weeks through Saturday evening, Aug. 1. Leonard Bernstein will conduct tonight's concert, and Zino Francescatti will be the violin soloist. Mr. Bernstein will be making his first Stadium appearance in five years.

The city amended its traffic code yesterday to conform to the new state law governing hand signals by automobile drivers. The new rules specify two distinct arm movements for a vehicle turning right or left and call for a third signal if the driver intends to stop or to decrease speed.
Digby Morton, who designed glamorous gowns for the Coronation, is now creating shirts with a mannish-look for women.
WASHINGTON. June 21 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board wants the Federal Government to help the aviation industry develop a commercial jet airplane -- and thereby overcome a British lead.

To rescue Sunday sailors clinging to a capsized sloop, to lead the Coast Guard to a disabled power boat, to unscramble a traffic tangle on an arterial highway, to catch an aviator stunting over the city streets or to search for escaped prisoners in woods or swamps, there is nothing so handy as an "eggbeater."

Those who are confronted with the problem of decorating a bare wall might consider a number of new wall hangings, other than pictures, available in shops here. Wood, a stone-like substance and metal are but a few of the materials used.

WIVES, as all properly trained husbands know, are wonderful. They cook, sew and clean. They bear and raise children. They cope with problems while their husbands are at the office -- with things which don't work, with people who don't come and with people who come and won't go, with measles and tantrums. They organize life and tactfully guide their husbands in the way they should go.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (UP) -- The White Sox, blanked, 5 -- 0, by the Athletics on Harry Byrd's seven-hitter in the opener, routed Carl Scheib and won the second game of the double-header, 9 -- 4, today.
The New York City Housing Authority ordered the eviction of 369 families from its projects in the first four months of 1953, it was learned yesterday.

June is more than just another month of thirty days. In the mind of every girl it means a much sought-after goal. It is the midyear mark that she associates with a veil of lace, rice and strains of "Lohengrin" and Mendelssohn's "Wedding March."
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today a reduction in support prices for cottonseed in a move aimed at halting heavy accumulation of supplies by the Government.

NEW DELHI, India, June 21 -- The citizenship of Tensing Norkay, Sherpa tribesman who climbed Mount Everest May 29 with Sir Edmund P. Hillary of New Zealand, has become the subject of a controversy between India and Nepal.

TOKYO, June 19 -- The United States Information Service in Japan, whose program is the largest in any sovereign country and second only to that in Germany, began the process of weeding out "undesirable" books a year ago when it inherited twenty-three information centers, including libraries, from the occupation government.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 9 -- The development of a highly promising process for the production of coke from available resources of poor-quality coal, the discovery of oil in the Vojvodina region and tremendous advances in the production of hydroelectric energy have highlighted industrial advances in this country.

Instead of being a seafaring people, as might be expected in an island, Puerto Rico is a progressive agricultural country. Agriculture, a basic industry everywhere, should not be restricted in Puerto Rico. On the contrary it should be aided, so as to allow continued development and improvement through mechanization and diversification.
PARIS, June 18 -- Officials here are very reticent about the policy directives they have received from the State Department on the subject of objectionable books.

The American Jewish Congress, making public yesterday a three-year study it has submitted to the State's Board of Regents, held that strong evidence existed that most medical schools in New York State "appear to treat Jewish applicants for admission less favorably than non-Jewish applicants."

WHITTIER, Calif., June 21 (AP) -- The president of the American Book Publishers Council said today in attacking censorship movements that if Americans were "so weak that we can't tolerate hostile ideas, I submit that it is not the ideas but our own weakness which precipitates our downfall."
Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, expressed full support yesterday for 800 striking employes of Hearn's department stores here.

BERLIN, June 21 -- The Soviet Union offered today to reopen East Berlin if the Western powers would "guarantee to cease sending provocateurs and other criminal elements" into the Soviet sector of the city.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Because of bigger shipments of aluminum promised by Canada, this Government may withhold further aid from the multimillion dollar "third round" of United States aluminum expansion for defense.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Company announced yesterday that it would file today in Supreme Court a request for an order directing the Board of Estimate to take immediate action on the company's long-pending applications for a 15-cent fare on the bus lines it operates in Manhattan and Queens.

BOSTON, June 21 (AP) -- Bobo Holloman, with an assist from Satchel Paige, blanked the Red Sox by 2 -- 0 on two hits in the second game of a double-header today. Holloman's victory ended a Browns' losing streak at six games. The Sox, with Hector (Skinny) Brown twirling a three-hitter, won the opener, 3 -- 1.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 21 -- The General Federation of Labor (Histadrut), which has had no international affiliations since it left the Communist-controlled World Federation of Trade Unions in 1950, will join the Western democracies' International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.
CAIRO, June 18 -- The United States library here received in the middle of May a directive classified as confidential listing sixteen authors whose works were to be withdrawn from circulation.

Book burning and book banning are "symbols of a hysteria" that grips the minds of men and makes them strike out against that with which they do not agree, the Rev. Dr. Benjamin M. Hersey declared yesterday morning in a sermon prompted by the recent controversy over books in the overseas libraries of the Office of Information.
TOKYO, Monday, June 22 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,653, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korean time:

Only the aged now remember the slogan of the late Hoosier Vice President, "Tom" Marshall -- "What this country needs is a good five-cent cigar." Among the younger and more innocent it has tended to be "a good five-cent anything."

Five members of the Police Department who shot it out with armed thugs were cited for honorable mention in general orders issued yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan. Two of the awards were posthumous.

Four records were set and two tied as the New York Athletic Club, with 89 1/4 points, captured the metropolitan A. A. U. junior track and field championship at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. The New York Pioneer Club was second with 73 3/4 points.

TOKYO, Monday, June 22 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations Commander, flew to Korea this morning for a possibly crucial conference with President Syngman Rhee of South Korea. He was accompanied by Ambassador Robert D. Murphy, the United Nations Command's special political adviser on armistice problems.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield said today that the Republicans intended to get the Post Office Department as far away from deficit financing "as practicable" and to run it on a "business-and-service" basis.

Cotton futures prices in the domestic market marked time last week. Net changes at the end of the five-day trading period on the New York Cotton Exchange ranged from 45 cents a bale lower to 55 cents a bale higher. In the preceding week, the futures market advanced 10 to 60 cents a bale.

A general air of dullness prevailed throughout the foreign exchange market during the past week. Business transacted was mostly routine and total volume was reported to be at the lowest level for some time past.

Representatives of some hefty sections of the American business world have just been meeting -- and dining -- with Treasury Secretary Humphrey and Commerce Secretary Weeks to figure out means of persuading more American "venture capital" to go abroad.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, June 22 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Pyun Yun Tae said today that the South Korean Government was considering withdrawing the South Korean Army from the United Nations Command.

The sixteen authors named specifically in one of the confidential State Department directives, which called for the banning of their works in libraries abroad regardless of the title of the individual work, were:

Emanuel H. Bloch, attorney who represented Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, used the word "murder" at their funeral service yesterday to describe their deaths last Friday evening in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison. Mr. Bloch placed their "murder" at the doors of President Eisenhower, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. and J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Ancient historical legends die hard, as is evidenced once again by the letter headed "Reason for Book Destruction" appearing in the June 13 issue of THE TIMES. The writer repeats the old accusation that the Moslems, at the time of their conquest of Egypt in the seventh century A. D., burned the ancient library in Alexandria, adding the reasons the Caliph Omar Ibn al-Khattab allegedly gave for this vandalism.

POMONA, N. Y., June 21 -- The tale of the babes in the woods, who died and were covered with leaves by the kindly animals, has come true here in reverse. But the ending is only half as tragic as in the childhood classic.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, June 22 (AP) -- South Korean troops won back a hill outpost in the "Finger Ridge" sector today in a pre-dawn attack against the Chinese Communists who dented the Allied line a week ago.

Of all man's afflictions one of the most annoying, and offering an intriguing variety of symptoms, is the ailment known as prevacationitis. It may descend upon its victim at any time between spring and summer's end; its duration varies from person to person, as does its intensity.

PARIS, June 21 -- President Vincent Auriol urgently requested former Premier Antoine Pinay tonight to try to form a Cabinet in time to represent the French Government at the Western three-power conference in Bermuda on July 8.

ROME, June 18 -- Two book programs are in force here. The first is a translation program, whereby the United States Information Service subsidizes translations into Italian of books helpful to the democratic cause. The service gets 1,000 copies of each title.

BRIDGEPORT, Wash., June 21 -- On a river where construction men talk matter-of-factly about "world's largest" and "world's longest" dams and powerhouses there is rising from the sub-bed of the Columbia here, 200 miles downstream from the Canadian border, a hydroelectric power plant that ultimately will be rated second only to its neighbor, the Grand Coulee, as the region's greatest energy producer.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Thousands of buyers from retail stores throughout the country were converging on Chicago today for the semi-annual home furnishings market, which will open tomorrow in the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart.

LONDON, June 18 -- A cloak of discretion or secrecy has covered the removal of books from the State Department's London library under its directive from Washington, although considerable detailed information has leaked out or has been released from United States Information Service libraries elsewhere.

As president of one of the power companies that offer to develop Niagara I was disappointed in your recent editorial in support of state development of Niagara. I think the merits in support of private enterprise making this development are in the consumer's interest.

A new Cuban decree which would require United States exporters to supply manufacturer or supplier invoices and follow a "codifier" number system in order to meet consular legalization and invoicing requirements, has been protested by a major trade group here.

NEW DELHI, India, June 17 -- The United States Information Service in India has removed from circulation by its library here books by fifteen authors. Many other of its books are being read for screening by a committee of five key officers of the service and the United States Embassy.

Two books this week show how American business, particularly business here in New York, "shines like a good deed in a naughty world." The first book is the third edition of Dr. John W. Wingate's "Buying for Retail Stores." The second, written fifteen years ago and only now issued here, is Dagobert D. Runes' "The Soviet Impact on Society"**.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 18 -- The United States Information Service here says books from Washington always have been carefully screened before inclusion in our libraries here and in Istanbul, Izmir, Adana, Edirne and Balikesir for the exclusion of material of any sort objectionable to the Turks, including writings of Communist authors.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 22 -- "My hope is that the United States has the same confidence in the present Government of Brazil as we have in the United States Government," said Minister of Finance Oswaldo Aranha today.

BERLIN, June 22 -- East Germany's Socialist Unity (Communist) party conceded today that many workers had been embittered by the events of the past few days and issued a ten-point expansion of its new appeasement policy in an effort to win them over.
" Port Call" day at Fort Hamilton turns an Army post into a community of mothers and babies who live up to both their domestic and their military responsibilities without slighting either.
Ben Hogan, the United States open golf champion, left by plane yesterday for Prestwick, Scotland, and his first try at the British open title.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 22 (AP) Galen Hanover closed fast on the outside to win the Oceanside Pace by one length tonight as the Grand Circuit meeting opened at Roosevelt Raceway. Warner Bull brought Galen Hanover home in 2:06 4-5 on a good track for the sidewheeler's second straight victory.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 (AP) -- Enos Slaughter drove in four runs with a single and double tonight to lead the Cardinals to a 6-3 victory over the Pirates. The Redbirds now are a game and a half behind the second-place Dodgers.

ALBANY, June 22 -- Democratic leaders in the Legislature have decided to endorse seven of the eight anti-crime bills drafted at Governor Dewey's request for the special session that opens here Thursday noon.

The five-story apartment house at 62 East Eighty-third Street, which was remodeled in 1950, is under contract of sale by Pedro S. Paredes to Irving Enkells, real estate operator. Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., was the broker and the attorneys were Strauss Ferdinand for the seller and Richard Nussbaum for the buyer.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- Members of the House of Representatives today voted themselves additional tax deductions and at the same time sought to set an example of economy by moving to deprive the Capitol architect, David Lynn, of his official limousine.

The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., announced yesterday that members of six of its locals employed in Bethlehem Steel Company shipyards had voted overwhelmingly to authorize union leaders to call a strike if they could not reach a satisfactory agreement in wage review discussions with the company.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower had fourteen guests at a private dinner tonight. Like the guests at another recent dinner that included former President Herbert Hoover and General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, tonight's list was made up of persons prominent in many fields.

Delegates to the Kiwanis International convention at Madison Square Garden yesterday heard criticism of the present leadership of the United States in the field of foreign policy from the Governor of Tennessee, and their wives heard a member of the Administration appeal for understanding of its tax policies.

CLEVELAND, June 22 -- The Office Employes International Union, A. F. L., has gained approximately 15,000 members in the last two years and now represents 50,000 workers, Paul R. Hutchings, president, reported at the opening session of the union's convention today. The union has 221 locals in the United States and Canada, he told the 200 delegates.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 22 -- The two key political figures in Indonesia's 19-day-old Cabinet crisis returned their mandate to President Sukarno today after failing to reach agreement over whether to consult the Communist party as well as other parties in the formation of a Cabinet program.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Indians blasted Walter Masterson for three home runs in the sixth inning and captured the second game of a double-header, 5 -- 2, today, after taking the first game by the same score on a fourteen-hit attack that included a home run by Larry Doby.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 22 -- Playing superlatively against a fine field of sixty rivals, Mrs. Mortimer May of the Middle Bay Club won the Women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship medal with 39, 33 -- 77 at the Nassau Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, retiring Air Force Chief of Staff, said today that "more and more people seem now willing to take the gamble that new weapons will enable the Air Force to win a war quickly."

In a hearing marked by a bitter dispute between opposing counsel, the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission accused a West Side landlord last night of overcharging Puerto Rican tenants by as much as 400 per cent for accommodations that were described as overcrowded and rat and roach-infested.
Dr. Samuel Winograd, assistant professor of hygiene at City College, admitted yesterday that while on the college's basketball team in 1934 he also played professionally for about $20 a game.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 23 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark called on President Syngman Rhee in Seoul this morning for the second time in two days, as Allied authorities sought to win from the rebellious South Korean leader some guarantees that no further action would be taken by the young republic to block an armistice when truce talks are resumed, possibly this week.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 22 -- Dr. Susan B. Riley, president of the American Association of University Women, defended tonight the right of educators to practice and teach freedom of inquiry. She said that without that freedom America's public school system would lose its role in development of the informed citizenry necessary for the perpetuation of democracy.

Net assets of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., last Dec. 31 were $261,230,193, it was announced yesterday. This was a decline of 4.7 per cent from the $274,314,438 reported a year earlier. The report pointed out that the company is "increasingly becoming a management company," managing Investors Mutual, Inc., Investors Selective Fund, Inc., and Investors Stock Fund, Inc.

Higher prices for gasoline and other oil products were announced yesterday by leading marketers through the greater part of the area east of the Rocky Mountains, reflecting recent increases in the price of crude oil. In New York, New England and the coastal states to the North Carolina border, the rise was the second in less than two weeks.

LONDON, June 22 -- Prices kept reasonably steady on the stock markets here today despite a continuing low level of business. A more optimistic interpretation of events in Korea was reflected in cessation of recent selling of British Government securities, which mostly held to opening levels.
Charles F. Burkhard sold the dwelling at 79-59 Sixty-ninth Road in Middle Village, Queens, to John J. Shuman for occupancy. The Wilmort Service Corporation was the broker.

STANTON, Del., June 22 (AP) -- Benbow, giving Paul Mellon's Rokeby Stables a consecutive double on the program, drove to a neck triumph today before 11,469 in the Tom Roby Steeplechase Stakes, which ushered in that phase of the sport at Delaware Park.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Before Associate Justice William O. Douglas left Washington last week-end (his second attempt) for the Pacific Northwest this correspondent asked him to clarify two points in connection with his stay of execution in the Rosenbergs' case that had evoked criticism of his course from lawyers, members of the Court and other citizens.

In the six months prior to its reorganization, Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $1,875,000 after providing $2,300,000 for taxes and $200,000 for contingent liabilities, it was reported yesterday. On last Feb. 28 the motion picture theatre operations in the United States were divorced from the production and distribution end of the business.

The opening by the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation of its first self-service drug store on Thursday at Smithtown, L. I., marks the beginning of a large expansion program by that organization. The company plans a combined grocery and drug self-service supermarket operation eventually and this store will be a testing ground.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 22 -- Representatives of thirteen Asian and Arab countries agreed today to support a Korean armistice and expressed the hope "that the Republic of Korea will cooperate to this end. In a communique issued after the hour-and-a-half meeting the group stated also that it felt that "the United States, as the state entrusted with the unified command [of United Nations forces] should be given every opportunity to obtain this cooperation."
SEOUL, Korea, June 22 -- There was at least a little hope today in the tangled Korean crisis.

TRENTON, June 22 -- The New Jersey Legislature moved swiftly tonight to expedite the compact between Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York designed to restore law and order to the Port of New York's long-corrupt waterfront.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 22 -- King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia has set up headquarters at Battambang, in Western Cambodia, and will lead a campaign for independence for his country from there.

The front-running Yankees, idle yesterday, will open a three-game series with the White Sox at the Stadium tonight. This evening is billed as Kiwanis Night, a highlight of the International Kiwanis Convention now taking place in New York.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission finally closed its books today on the Ogden (Utah) Gateway freight rate case by throwing out all petitions for reconsideration.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- All grain and soybean futures were weak today at the start, but while there were substantial recoveries in coarse grains, rye and soybeans, wheat was under pressure and made its lows for the day late in the session.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- To prevent a possible "serious retardment" of military construction at many overseas installations, the Senate passed without controversy today a bill to continue for another year benefit payments when American workers were killed or injured in war-risk hazard work.

Mount Sinai Hospital officials and members of the New York County Medical Society should get together and reconcile their differences over the clinic that the hospital plans to staff and operate in the state-aided Carver Houses, spokesmen for both sides of the controversy agreed yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 22 -- Dr. Ira Eisenstein, president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, lashed out here tonight at the "state of terror and intimidation" created among the "seekers of truth" as a result of the methods used in investigations by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and Representative Harold N. Velde, Republican of Illinois.

The city of Dallas, Tex., received bids yesterday on bond issues totaling $10,200,000 and maturing from 1954 to 1973. An interest cost of 3.232 per cent, submitted by a syndicate headed by Northern Trust Company of Chicago, was the best bid.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 22 -- Full agreement between the representatives of the United States, Thailand, Nationalist China and Burma on procedures for evacuating Nationalist Chinese troops from Burma was announced here today by Edwin F. Stanton, United States Ambassador.

MADRID, June 22 -- Spanish economic circles said today that the United States proposal to grant Spain $226,000,000 in military and economic aid during the 1953-54 fiscal year was most welcome for it came while the country was suffering from the consequences of a long drought.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- In an opinion that he acknowledged was written only for history, Justice Felix Frankfurter of the Supreme Court set forth today his reasons for dissenting from the majority ruling last Friday that revoked the stay of execution granted by Justice William O. Douglas to Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the atom spies.
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 23 (UP) -- President Rhee said today that much of the criticism of his stand was based on a lack of understanding of what he wanted.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- Paul E. Hadlick, general counsel of the National Oil Marketers Association, asked the Department of Justice today to investigate recent gasoline and oil prices increases to see whether the anti-trust laws had been violated.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Harold R. Christoffel was sentenced today to sixteen months to four years in prison for falsely swearing before a Congressional committee in 1947 that he never had been a Communist. The sentence was imposed by the United States District Judge, F. Dickinson Letts, who denied Christoffel bail pending another appeal.

The Philippine political campaign has been somewhat further complicated by the entry of Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo as the now officially and unanimously chosen candidate of the new Democratic party. Since he has gone into the campaign with a relatively small organization and against two formidable antagonists speculation centers at the moment upon whether he will take strength away from President Elpidio Quirino, the Liberal candidate, or from Ramon Magsaysay, candidate of the Nacionalistas.

A youthful, neatly dressed thug robbed a bank of $1,900 yesterday afternoon while hundreds of shoppers passed its door at 150 West Thirty-fourth Street. The crime was committed calmly at the Century Federal Savings and Loan Association, across the street from Macy's.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Soviet Union's sudden relaxation of travel restrictions on foreign residents raised speculation in diplomatic circles tonight that the United States might consider a similar easing of curbs on the movement of Soviet citizens in this country.
HONOLULU, June 22 (AP) -- Sugar workers returned to work late today but Honolulu's waterfront still was shut down by mass walkouts protesting last week's convictions in a Communist conspiracy case.

Newspaper accounts of that newly discovered picture, said to be "the earliest-on-the-spot" painting of a New York event, and on loan through the summer at the Museum of the City of New York, brought confident identification of the event itself and of the painter.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today members of the staff of his Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations were combing the Pittsburgh area for witnesses who could give full details on a reported Communist plot to kill him.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Eisenhower Administration disclosed plans today to strip Civil Service protection from additional Federal jobs -- possibly many thousands.

" When I air-travelled to Europe, 2 pairs of 'Alldac' slacks were included in my wardrobe. They were so wonderful that immediately upon my return I purchased several 'Alldac' suits, for in my opinion, the routine travel of a Long Island commuter takes as much out of clothing as a trip to Europe!"

ATHENS, June 22 -- Principal among several long term economic projects that Spyros Markezinis, the Minister for Economic Planning, mentioned yesterday in his outline of what must be achieved to help Greece advance, are electrification to help industry and land reclamation to help agriculture.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, June 23 (AP) -- The United States Eighth Army reported today that 10,000 Communists were killed or wounded last week -- most of them in the big Chinese drive against South Korean positions on the east-central Korean front.

BONN, Germany, June 22 -- Chancellor Adenauer appealed today to President Eisenhower, Prime Minister Churchill and Rene Mayer, French interim Premier, to do everything in their power to bring about a restoration of human rights in East Germany and the reunification of the German people

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Mr. Ritchie was the first witness in the investigation by the Senate committee to find out if the Government and the Bureau of Standards in particular had treated him fairly. Dr. Astin was ousted several months ago by Secretary Weeks after the bureau reported AD-X2 did not put new pep into old but mechanically sound storage batteries.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- The National Farmers Union demanded today that the Eisenhower Administration accept its "legal and moral obligation" to protect farmers by building "adequate" storage bins for the 1953 bumper wheat crop.
