Two Spanish Line passenger ships -- the Magallanes and Marques de Comillas -- which have been familiar visitors to this port for the last quarter of a century, have been shifted elsewhere as the company moves into the final stages of planning for its new service from New Orleans to Havana and Spain.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Senate refused today to accept without opportunity for full study a Republican proposal, put forward with Administration backing, for creation of a permanent Small Business Administration.

Burgess Meredith has been chosen to serve as master of ceremonies on 'Junior Omnibus" when the program, produced by the TV-Radio Workshop of the Ford Foundation, makes its debut over the N. B. C. television network next September. The program is designed for viewers in the 8-to-16 age group.

Sheridan's eighteenth century comedy, "School For Scandal," the third production of the series being presented by Terese Hayden at the Theatre de Lys, 121 Christopher Street, opens this evening at 8 o'clock. Liska March is associated with Miss Hayden in the presentation.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 (AP) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has abandoned its "separate but equal" theory in favor of a goal of total integration in its fight to abolish racial discrimination.
Two Manhattan waterfront figures faced possible state prison terms as the result yesterday of legal actions in General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that the protests of nine German nationals would not stop him from calling back to this country for questioning the American Deputy Director of RIAS, the United States radio station in Berlin.

PARIS, June 22 -- The French Government has notified Washington and London that it accepts the date of Wednesday, July 8, for the meeting at Bermuda of heads of Governments of the Big Three Western Powers. The French Foreign Office has been much annoyed by hints from London that the meeting might be held without the French in the absence of a fully authorized French Government.

The board of directors of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation has approved a multi-million-dollar research and development program for a jet cargo plane with speeds close to 500 miles an hour.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Tuesday, June 23 (AP) -- Dr. Syama Prasad Mookerjee, leader of the Hindu extremist Jan Sangh party and a bitter foe of Jawaharlal Nehru, Indian Prime Minister, died today in a prison here.

LONDON, June 22 -- The "coronation fever" that has afflicted London for a month has largely abated and traffic was approaching normal today as the work of dismantling thousands of pounds worth of decorations and grandstands began.

Net asset value of the common stock of the Electric Bond and Share Company on March 31 stood at $152,756,000, or $29.09 a share, according to the annual report for 1952 signed by George G. Walker, president, and Curtis E. Calder, chairman of the executive committee, being mailed to stockholders today.

A $500,000 Yeshiva University scholarship fund was established at a dinner last night to honor Dr. Samuel Belkin, president of the university. The dinner, marking Dr. Belkin's tenth anniversary as head of the school, was at the Astor Hotel.
LACONIA, N. H., June 22 -- The Merrimac River Valley is beginning to cash in on a new industrial revolution, a century after the first textile barons began to exploit the region.

A CLEAR week-end put the pressure on both fresh and salt water fishing areas, and the results were generally satisfactory, with some excellent fly fishing reported in New York and Pennsylvania streams, and good bluefish catches from eastern Long Island.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Eisenhower Administration sent the Army Chief of Staff and two Assistant Secretaries of State to the Far East today to deal on the spot with the military and political crisis provoked by the South Korean Government's unauthorized release of more than 27,000 anti-Communist prisoners of war.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- A Federal court jury acquitted Clovis D. Walker, former head of the Agriculture Department's Cotton Branch, today of the charge he had "leaked" cotton trade secrets to an Egyptian broker.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 22 -- The Foreign Ministry today informed Dean Koch, representative of Radio Free Europe, that the Israeli Government did not want Radio Free Europe to open a bureau here, did not want Radio Free Europe representatives interviewing Israelis here and hoped Radio Free Europe would not do these things against the Government's will.

VIENNA, June 22 -- Workers who took a prominent part in the recent demonstrations against the currency reform in Czechoslovakia are to be excluded from trade unions, and their paid holidays, pensions, sickness compensation, canteen meals and family bonuses will be reduced or refused.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee approved today a bill to continue for another year most major features of the Federal housing program.

The British Labor party's new statement of policy, "Challenge to Britain," shows a bankruptcy of ideas in what was one of the most vigorous, popular and fruitful political movements in British parliamentary history. Whether one approves of socialism or not, there is no denying the profound imprint of the Labor movement on what is now known as the Welfare State.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- Paramount is going ahead with preparations for its recently announced remake of the silent screen epic, "The Covered Wagon."

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 22 -- Jack Mallon and Jack Parker of the Cold Spring Harbor Club won the Class I honors in the weekly Long Island P. G. A. pro-amateur tournament at the Hempstead Golf Club today with a seven-under-par 65.

Merger of the publications Dun's Review and Modern Industry was announced jointly yesterday by J. Wilson Newman, president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and Eldridge Haynes, president and publisher of Modern Industry. Starting with the August issue, the magazine, under the name Dun's Review and Modern Industry, will become a Dun Bradstreet publication.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today United States business men and farmers spent about $145,000,000,000 for new production equipment in the eleven years from 1942 through 1952. Of this approximately $50,000,000,000 was for expansion of productive facilities.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., June 22 -- Another indication of the growing trend among parents, teachers and young people themselves to formulate standards for youthful behavior was revealed here today in action taken by the newly formed Parents' League of Charlotte.

The International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., announced yesterday a plan to do away with the shape-up system of hiring dock workers through establishment of twelve hiring centers, to be operated jointly by the union and employers, in the Port of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The question as to whether Americans are borrowing too much too fast is attracting increasing attention as the result of the fact that total United States debt -- Government, business and individuals combined -- showed another big increase to a record high in 1952, and it still going up all along the line.

While many foreign governments maintain information offices in New York that handle hundreds of inquiries daily from Americans seeking data about foreign lands, none of them has established a lending library service here comparable to those conducted overseas by the United States.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., June 22 (AP) -- University of Texas golfers, finding the mountain-fringed Broadmoor course to their liking, gained top honors today in the first-round qualifying play of the fifty-sixth National Collegiate A. A. golf tournament.
PERTH AMBOY, N. J., June 22 -- Housewives here were advised today to change their traditional Monday wash days in an attempt to solve the city's "brown water" problem.

In THE TIMES of June 19, in an article entitled "East German Reds' Future Believed Shaky After Riot," it is said that the East Berlin uprising was the first challenge of its kind to Soviet power since the establishment of the system of satellite states after the Second World War.

NAPLES, Italy, June 22 -- With a hearty "well done and good luck," Adm. Robert B. Carney, Commander in Chief of Allied Forces in Southern Europe of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, took leave this morning of the international staff of his headquarters, which he established in this city just two years ago.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 -- Mr. White said today minority groups in this Nation were becoming fearful of expressing themselves freely because of a "hysteria of fear" that seemed to be gripping the United States. He said that some persons seemed determined to suppress and keep silent any group that openly disagreed with their policies.

Anthony Smith, an Oxonian student of zoology, became interested in the blind white fish that live in the Iranian underground irrigation channels. He and three other students -- a chemist, a geographer and a botanist -- went on an expedition to seek the fish in 1951.

LONDON, June 22 -- In a note delivered today, the British Government strongly condemned the "treacherous" action of the South Korean Government in releasing anti-Communist North Korean prisoners of war.
Jove nods now and then and even THE NEW YORK TIMES gets out of focus with about equal frequency. An example is the editorial of June 19 entitled "T. V. A. vs. 'Socialism.' "
PORTHCAWL, Wales, June 22 (AP) -- Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., opened her bid for the British women's amateur golf championship today by defeating Ireland's Pat O'Sullivan, 5 and 3.

The demand for higher education is increasing throughout the world, and in some countries university enrollment has doubled since the end of the war, it was reported here yesterday at an international education conference.

Your leading editorial of June 19 on the release of Korean anti-Communist prisoners by President Syngman Rhee noted that the move was made "at the wrong time, in the wrong way and for the wrong motive." Few will disagree with you on the first two counts, but the wrongness or rightness of his motive depends on what it was.

On the basis of a survey from twenty foreign capitals published in this newspaper yesterday there seems to be some uncertainty as to the picture of America that the State Department, particularly through the editing of its information libraries abroad, intends to present to the world.

MOSCOW, June 22 -- The Soviet Foreign Office advised the United States and other embassies in Moscow tonight that travel restrictions for foreigners in large regions of European Russia, Byelorussia, the Ukraine, the Caucasus area and Central Asia had been removed.

Traders paid more attention to the domestic business situation than to the uncertainties of international affairs yesterday and prices moved ahead to their best levels in two weeks, finishing generally higher on the day despite small profit-taking near the close.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 22 -- True to tradition, the opening day of the all-England tennis championships on these historic grounds provided its share of surprises as Tony Mottram of Great Britain and Fausto Gardini of Italy, champions of their countries, were upset.

Miss Catherine Cowell, nutritionist of the East Harlem Health Center, will leave for Puerto Rico next month to attend the Social Workshop Conference at the University of Puerto Rico. The Puerto Rican Department of Labor holds this "background conference" each summer for professionals working in this country among Americans of Puerto Rican origin.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday with 20 points off on July and other months 10 points lower to 1 point higher than on last Friday.
HARTFORD, June 22 -- Two State Constitution changes were approved overwhelmingly by Connecticut voters in an apathetic state-wide special election today.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- The importance of newly developed materials and techniques in the home furnishings industry was stressed both at a press conference held here this morning and in several of the new offerings to buyers at the wholesale home furnishings markets now in session in this city and in Grand Rapids, Mich.

ASPEN, Colo., June 22 (AP) -- The role of the designer in society -- to blend functions with artistic concepts -- was stressed today at opening sessions of a week-long international design conference here.

LUXEMBOURG, June 12 -- A great economic revolution is under way in Western Europe. Throughout Italy, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, West Germany and Luxembourg, the industries whose products form the foundation of modern industrial society, coal, iron and steel, are in a state of ferment and effervescence the like of which has not been seen in Europe at least since the great industrial expansion of the closing decades of the nineteenth century.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 22 (UP) -- The La Paz police chief, Lieut. Col. Fidel Rojas; the former police chief, Col. Victor Valdez, and more than a dozen other prominent persons have been arrested on charges of subversive activity, the assistant police chief, Col. Victor Ramirez, said today.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, June 23 -- Many of the world-shaking decisions made by the South Korean Government recently have been conceived, discussed and debated in the most humble surroundings.

TRENTON, June 22 (AP) -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll announced today that the state would take over Island Beach on July 1. Formal ceremonies marking the acquisition of the 2,200-acre peninsula will be held at Trenton.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today President Eisenhower's nomination of Raymond Henry Fogler of New York as Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed irregular yesterday in unusually light trading. Sugar, cottonseed oil, wool, hides, rubber, lead, zinc, copper and potatoes ended mixed. Coffee and tin were higher and cocoa and soybean oil closed lower.

Higher interest costs and "hard-money" policies are catching up with the little man and his credit requirements. Within the next week to ten days, it was learned yesterday, the Manufacturers Trust Company, second largest supplier of consumer credit among the city's big commercial banks, will raise its rate on used-car and personal loans to 4 1/2 per cent, deducted in advance.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- Federal Judge James McLaughlin held legal today contracts totaling $57,000,000 between the Southwestern Power Administration and five Missouri "super" electric cooperatives.
BOSTON, June 22 -- William H. Howard, vice president of the Young Rubicam Advertising Agency, asserted today that both newspapers and retailers were failing in their respective advertising jobs.
The military and political crisis caused by the undisclosed action of Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President, in releasing more than 27,000 Korean prisoners-of-war was deepened yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, June 22 -- The thirty-first annual conference of the National Industrial Advertisers Association opened today in the William Penn Hotel, with delegate registration expected to reach the 1,200 mark by tomorrow morning, when general business sessions begin.

The Goldman Band gave its 2,000th concert last night. Despite the dubious weather, 13,000 persons assembled on the Mall in Central Park to enjoy the music and to applaud the felicitations by Mayor Impellitteri and Park Commissioner Robert Moses to those who have made such an impressive record possible.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 22 -- William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said today that the investment of more than $8,000,000,000 in plant and equipment by the nation's railroads since the end of World War II had produced a "revolution in motive power" by placing in service nearly 18,000 Diesel-electric locomotives.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture bowed before a Congressional scolding today and offered 23,200 tons of dried peas to the highest bidder.

In reaching with New Jersey and Pennsylvania a new formula governing use of the Delaware River and its tributaries as a source of water supply, New York City has probably shortened materially the time required to dispose of current water litigation proceedings before the United States Supreme Court.

The New York and New Jersey Legislatures face a major challenge this week in the two bills proposing the creation of waterfront commissions to cooperate in regulating pier activity under an identical program. Each state would set up its own agency until Congress approves a bi-state organization.
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 23 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,654, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:
DETROIT, June 22 (AP) -- Happy and bewildered, two June high school graduates today had their diplomas and $95,000 between them after signing with the Tigers as bonus players.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 22 -- Yugoslav sources said today that members of their delegation to the meeting in Bucharest, Rumania, of a special committee of the Danube River Commission had been molested and the leader of the delegation had been physically attacked by Rumanian police agents.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 22 -- Both the business and the individual taxpayer can look forward to increasingly fairer treatment from Congress and the Bureau of Internal Revenue if the present attitude in Washington continues, Benjamin Grund of New York, immediate past chairman of the Federal tax committee of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, said here today.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Henry J. Kaiser contended today that his company was producing C-119 cargo planes for the Air Force more cheaply, comparatively, than the plane's developer did in the early stages of production.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Blair S. Williams 2d of Old Chatham, N. Y., a Korea war veteran who was wounded twice in action, died in Tuscon, Ariz., yesterday from injuries suffered in a head-on automobile accident there on Saturday, according to word received here by relatives.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- E. Roland Harriman, president of the American National Red Cross, appealed to Red Cross chapters today not to join in federated fund drives.

President George N. Shuster of Hunter College conferred 824 degrees yesterday at the college's 104th commencement. More than 3,200 guests attended the ceremony, which was held at the college's Bronx campus, Bedford Park Boulevard and Navy Avenue.

George Farkas, department store executive, declared yesterday that the city was doomed to die of a variety of political and economic diseases unless the present "popularity contest" method of choosing the head of the city government was discarded.

THE trade winds blew with more than their customary vigor this season and the transaction that provoked the most controversy was the deal which sent Ralph Kiner from the Pirates to the Cubs. Baseball men still are talking about it, and they are inclined to regard it with more than ordinary suspicion because the Cubs were involved.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 23 -- Pravda declared in a three-column front page editorial today that events in Berlin and South Korea illustrates that the enemies of peace would not stop at "the most extreme means" in order to prevent the reduction of international tension.

As was to be expected, last week's outbreaks in East Germany are having repercussions far beyond the original areas affected. Chancellor Adenauer has appealed to the three chief Western Powers to do all they can to restore human rights to the East Germans and to reunify the German people.

At a public hearing yesterday by the Board of Health, spokesmen for civic welfare organizations gave general approval to the minimum standards, drafted by the Department of Health and the Department of Housing and Buildings, under which some cellar apartments may be occupied until July 1, 1955.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, introduced a bill today to permit the sale of businesses under Government control which cannot now be disposed of because they are involved in litigation.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The House Committee on Government Operations, disregarding Eisenhower Administration requests, moved today to block that part of the Defense Department reorganization plan that critics say would give too much power to the Chairman and the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

LOS ANGELES, June 22 -- "McCarthyism" and kindred efforts to limit the circulation of ideas in print were denounced tonight by Robert B. Downs, president of the American Library Association, in his report to the organization's seventy-second annual conference here.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- A limousine, courtesy of the Packard Motor Car Company, waited outside Mr. Truman's suite to whisk him anywhere he wanted to go.

Business in this city is showing a general volume increase for the first half of 1953 and should continue this trend for the rest of the year, according to a report issued yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York on its mid-year survey.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 22 -- A quietly conducted feud over the similarity in the names of the North Shore Hospital at Manhasset and the long-established North Country Community Hospital in Glen Cove finally was brought into Supreme Court here today for a very public settlement of the matter.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 22 -- Word that the works of Mark Twain have been approved by the State Department for inclusion in United States overseas libraries has been received by the United States Information Service here.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast today a fall crop of 35,500,000 pigs, a decrease of 5 per cent from last year's level. It also reported that this year's spring crop was 50,726,000 head, a decline of 10 per cent from the 1952 crop.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- A three-run first inning and a four-run fourth inning marked by home runs by Ralph Kiner and Hank Sauer enabled the Cubs to gain a 9-4 victory over the Dodgers before 11,708 fans at Wrigley Field today.

When Patrick King joined the Immigration Service in 1918 it was natural for him to ask for mounted patrol assignment along the Mexican Border. Mr. King was an expert in the handling of horses and mules, having served for a while as a civilian groom for British Army animals during the Boer War and later having studied to become a veterinary.

A uniform jury system for counties outside New York City, aimed at obtaining better jurors and wider community representation, will be recommended to the Legislature when it convenes in special session Thursday.

Carlin Products, Inc., manufacturer of musical toys, has leased the one-story garage-type building at 51-61 Union Street in Brooklyn from the R. C. Garage Corporation for five years. The transaction was negotiated by Colony Realty as broker.

Because someone forgot to tell the Department of Public Works about a nearly-forgotten burial ground in Flushing, Queens, work has abruptly stopped on the construction there of an 850-car parking field. Operations came to an end last week after bulldozers of the contractor, Frank Mascali Sons, Inc., of 120th Street and Thirty-first Avenue, Flushing, dug up some tombstones that had, with the passage of time, fallen over and become buried.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- The Joint Commission on Accreditation of Hospitals today released a list of 3,265 hospitals in the United States, Canada, Hawaii, Alaska and eight Latin-American nations that had been approved by the commission. Of the total, 2,834 hospitals were fully accredited as meeting high standards for the care of patients.

Senator McCarthy has done more than any other person in these United States to erase from high places in Government, colleges, schools, radio, churches and business the Communist gangsters who are pledged to overthrow our Government.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 22 -- Home club professionals took the bulk of the honors today in the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur tournament at the Winged Foot Club. Al Mengert, the assistant pro, equaled the competitive record for the West course with a 7-under-par 65, and Claude Harmon, the head professional, teamed with Charles Bohmert to take the best-ball event with 62.

New Yorkers enjoyed a brief respite yesterday from the current heat wave. Blackened skies brought thunder, rain and winds that pushed the temperature down twenty-one degrees in seventy-five minutes in mid-afternoon. The high was 87 degrees at 1:50 o'clock and the low was 66 at 3:05 P. M.

Operations of the nation's steel mills will take a sharp spurt this week to an estimated 99.1 per cent of capacity from last week's actual rate of 96.8 per cent, the American Iron Steel Institute reported yesterday. Translated into production, this week's rate will amount to an estimated 2,235,000 tons, against 2,183,000 tons a week ago.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- An audience officially estimated at 22,000 was on hand tonight at Robin Hood Dell in Fairmount Park for the launching of a new idea in summer outdoor music -- a concert series with no admission charge.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Jess M. Ritchie, manufacturer of the controversial AD-X2, told the Senate Small Business Committee today that certain elements in his battery additive helped extend the life of storage batteries but refused to say what these agents were.

The New York City Transit Authority moved one step nearer to a fare increase yesterday by directing its general manager, Sidney H. Bingham, to prepare a tentative operating budget for the fiscal year starting July 1 for submission to it by next Monday.
BOSTON, June 22 -- The world could eat twice as much whale meat as it does now, if three-quarters of the annual catch was not thrown away as waste, a British scientist said today.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 22 (AP) -- Service station operators forecast higher gasoline prices in New Jersey and pinned the blame on major oil companies today.

A court motion by Hearn's department stores to enjoin picketing by striking employes was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally. The Court granted Hearn's the right however, to renew the motion after submitting further evidence on whether or not the employes engaged in a sit-down strike.

NEW DELHI, India, June 22 -- The debate as to whether Tensing Norkay, Sherpa mountain climber, or Sir Edmund P. Hillary of New Zealand was the first to reach the summit of Mount Everest has threatened to develop into an ugly situation with racial implications, according to reports today from Katmandu, capital of Nepal, where Col. Sir John Hunt's victorious expedition is resting.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Little change in prices of home furnishings through the remainder of this year was predicted by industry officials today at the opening of the summer furnishings market in the Merchandise and American Furniture Marts.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today extended price support loans on 1952-crop cotton another twelve months to give grower-borrowers additional time to redeem and sell the commodity. Thus loans maturing on July 31 will run to the same date next year.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Dr. Milton Eisenhower, president of Pennsylvania State College, conferred today with his brother, President Eisenhower, and other top Administration officials before departing tomorrow on a thirty-six-day aerial trip that will take him into every South American republic as a goodwill ambassador.

One new film opens today at a first-run theatre. At the Holiday is "Count the Hours," a melodrama starring Teresa Wright, Macdonald Carey and Dolores Moran. Doane R. Hoag and Karen DeWolf wrote the scenario of the R. K. O. presentation, which Don Siegel directed, Benedict Bogeaus produced.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman, thoroughly enjoying a visit to the capital, greeted Democratic and Republican friends alike today but warned the Republicans that his party was "in good health and will be when election time rolls around."

CLEVELAND, June 22 -- The National League for Nursing opened its first convention today with emphasis on improving the mental health of mothers and young children. The convention, which will continue through Friday, has 4,000 delegates.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., June 22 -- The Nassau Daily Review-Star, a newspaper published six days a week here for thirty-three years, bowed to mounting costs of labor and materials and closed the doors of its plant on Sunrise Highway here last Saturday.

Again I invite the readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES to share in the satisfaction of helping a group of blind, aged and handicapped women and girls to go on vacations this summer at our Shelter Island Camp.

State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman charged yesterday that the city's Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, Bernard J. Gillroy, and his deputy, Frederick S. Weaver, were "setting themselves up as censors" in refusing to give his subordinates information on housing violations.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 22 (AP) -- David Harum of Coral Gables, Fla., top seeded, swept to an easy victory before rain halted play today in the Forty-fifth National interscholastic tennis tournament.

It is too bad that certain groups are retrospectively making a race out of the Everest climb, when obviously it was, and necessarily had to be, a cooperative venture. Just which members of the party put a foot on the summit is interesting and perhaps important too, but sparring over who was on top first demeans the achievement.

The blow to Soviet prestige inflicted by the disorders in East Germany last week is likely to have significant repercussions on the jockeying for power within the Kremlin, diplomatic sources believe. They expect an immediate result to be a loss of face for Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov and Internal Affairs Minister Lavrenti P. Beria.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 22 -- Vardens and vestrymen of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. James the Less here announced today the election of the Rev. George P. Kempsell Jr. as rector of the Parish. The Right Rev. Horace V. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Diocese of New York, approved the election.

Hueso made a forceful finish to beat Dictar in the Shevlin Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. With Basil James doing the riding, Hueso moved into the win spot just at the finish of the $25,100 fixture, beating Dictar by a neck. The victory was worth $17,850 to Hueso's owner, Robert P. Levy.

DETROIT, June 22 (AP) -- Appointment of Ray R. Rausch to head the automotive divisions of Kaiser Motors Corporation was announced today. Mr. Rausch, who was executive vice president and general manager of Willys Motors, recently purchased by Kaiser, will have charge of the production of Kaiser and Willys cars and commercial vehicles.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 -- Feeling reasonably satisfied with the way events have gone thus far, Leo Durocher and his Giants today advanced leisurely upon the Mound City where tomorrow night they open their three-game series with the Cardinals.

SYRACUSE, June 22 -- Hamilton Richardson of Tulane University started out in quest of the national intercollegiate tennis championship today with the opening of play on the composition courts of Syracuse University.

RICHLAND, Wash., June 22 -- Plutonium, a major ingredient of the atomic bomb, is being manufactured today at the near-by Hanford Works at a cost per pound that atomic energy officials would not have thought possible even two years ago.

HONG KONG, June 22 -- With famine conditions existing in substantial parts of North China because of a wheat blight, the Central Food Ministry and the All-China Federation of Cooperative in Peiping have issued a joint directive instructing their buying agents to pursue an "energetic purchasing" policy so that the state can acquire about 80 per cent of the food now available for marketing.

Manhattan-bound service on the B. M. T. Brighton Beach subway line between Prospect Park, Brooklyn, and Canal Street, Manhattan, was disrupted for nearly five and a half hours yesterday by a derailment near Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, at 7:36 A. M. Thousands of work-bound passengers were delayed as much as forty minutes by the tie-up, which limited but did not halt service in the opposite direction.
NORFOLK, Va., June 22 (AP) -- John Nicholas Brown's 73-foot yawl, Bolero, passed the Chesapeake Bay lightship tonight well in the lead in the 466-mile Newport-to-Annapolis yacht race.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 23 (AP) -- Harold John Adonis, former clerk in the office of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, said today he would not return home to face a bribery charge until he was assured that reasonable bail would be set.

PARIS, June 23 -- Having failed to win sufficient support from the French political parties, former Premier Antoine Pinay informed President Vincent Auriol tonight that it would be impossible for him to form a Cabinet.

Nursing is more than a profession, it is a vocation, Cardinal Spellman told 109 graduates of the St. Vincent's Hospital School of Nursing yesterday afternoon. He spoke at the school's commencement exercises in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON. June 23 -- Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, informed Henry J. Kaiser, the industrialist, today that a high official of the Kaiser Company had tried to defeat him in his campaign for the Senate last year.

Customs and traditions may differ from nation to nation, but the over-all problems and needs of education are generally the same throughout the world. This was brought out yesterday at an international conference on higher education.

A basic real estate tax rate of $3.33 for each $100 of assessed valuation was set yesterday by the City Council for the first six months of the 1953-54 fiscal year. A mandatory upward revision next December is expected to bring the average rate for the full fiscal year up to or close to a record-breaking $3.60.

Nine seasons ago Elliott Murphy startled the world of outdoor entertainment by successfully fusing singing, dancing and swimming into a program appropriately labeled "Aquashow." A restless soul, Mr. Murphy has added another element to the 1953 edition, which opened last night at the amphitheatre in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, the former World's Fair site.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 -- Representatives of seventeen nations this morning signed for their governments the interim protocol on production and distribution of opium, which has been in preparation at an international conference at United Nations headquarters since May 11.

The Blair Holdings Corporation has acquired control of Stanwell Oil and Gas, Ltd., a Canadian independent oil company, V. D. Dardi, Blair president, disclosed yesterday. With this transaction Blair joins the list of American companies participating in the development of Canadian natural resources.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Eisenhower today proclaimed July 4 as a national day of "penance and prayer."

JAKARTA, June 23 -- Mukarto Notowidigdo, the outgoing Foreign Minister in Premier Wilopo's Government and a member of the Nationalist party, told correspondents today he would try to include "all ideologies" in formation of a Parliamentary Cabinet.
Cotton futures closed irregular yesterday, 1 point off to 16 points up. There was considerable evening up on the New York Cotton Exchange in old July, since today is first notice day.

The wives of city pensioners who die during their thirty-day waiting period for retirement would be protected under a bill adopted yesterday by the City Council. The legislation, if approved by the Board of Estimate and signed by Mayor Impellitteri, would apply only in a case where a pensioner had selected the option under which the widow received the pension after the employe's death.

With the match even after twelve games of the series of eighteen, Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires, his challenger for the chess championship of the West, made a determined effort in the thirteenth to break the tie, but had not succeeded after forty moves, according to a report received yesterday from Argentina.
CHICAGO, June 23 -- Major appliance manufacturers indicated today that they are dubious about passing along to the retail level any cost increases that may result from higher steel prices.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Eisenhower saw his brother, Dr. Milton Eisenhower, depart on a goodwill mission today to the South American republics.

The latest Soviet move, easing somewhat the restrictions on travel within that country by foreigners, is, on the face of the announcement, a welcome move. Whether it is more than a propaganda gesture remains to be seen, since in the past the Soviet authorities have had many other means of restricting foreigners' travel besides the purely formal prohibitions which have now been made more lenient.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 23 -- United States authorities here hope that the evacuation of Chinese Nationalist troops from Burma can begin early next month. If the troops themselves cooperate and obey instructions it is estimated that the evacuation job can be completed in a month or six weeks after it is started.

The Community Service Society of New York gave increased attention last year, while helping 24,303 families, to the treatment of family problems that might have led to delinquency or other forms of personal and social difficulty.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 23 -- Mrs. Mortimer May of Middle Bay had to come from behind before advancing to the second round of the women's Long Island match-play championship at the Nassau Country Club today. Mrs. May, the medalist yesterday with a 77, was 3 down to Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood at the end of nine holes and had to fight for a 1-up victory.

NOROTON Conn., June 23 -- Stan Ogilvy of Larchmont continued to make a runaway of Noroton Yacht Club's fifteenth annual race week for Star Class sloops today when he won his third consecutive victory with Flame. Joe Burbeck had Capstar second after a twelve-mile voyage, which included a long cross-Sound reach to Lloyd's Neck and a beat back.

LOS ANGELES, June 23 -- "The general farm economy of the United States is not headed for an economic tailspin," Jesse W. Tapp of San Francisco assured the Town Hall meeting in the Biltmore Hotel here today.

The thirty-sixth season of summer concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium got under way last night, twenty-four hours behind schedule because of Monday afternoon's storm, but the delay proved to be a boon. The weather last night was as beneficent as it ever gets in New York at this time of the year, and the music was both great and handsomely played.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 23 -- Women should do an absolute minimum of housework, according to Mrs. Lenore Sater Thye, one of the 3,000 home economists attending the forty-fourth annual meeting and exhibit of the American Home Economics Association, which opened here yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 23 -- John Nicholas Brown's yacht, the Bolero, first to finish in the New-port-Annapolis yacht race two years ago, was in first position again as this year's race neared its end late today.

The average market price of all bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange fell last month to the lowest month-end level since May 31, 1941, the Exchange reported yesterday. The May 31 figure was $94.42, against $95.46 at the close of April and $94.22 on May 31, 1941.

BERLIN, June 23 -- Otto Grotewohl, East German Premier, said tonight that his Government, shaken to its foundations Wednesday by the nation-wide riots, would not resign but he promised fundamental changes during the next two weeks.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 -- Manager Leo Durocher's hopes of continuing his gay dash through the West came a fearful cropper tonight as Manager Eddie Stanky's sizzling Cardinals butchered Giant pitching to win the opener of a three-game series, 15 to 8, before 12,019 cheering fans.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Republican members of the Senate were urged by their leaders today to support the $5,318,000,000 foreign aid authorization recommended by the Foreign Relations Committee but without prejudice to heavy cuts by the Appropriations group in the separate money bill that is to follow.

THE TIMES of June 17 editorially expressed undue alarm at the prospect that the Congress will fail to supply funds requested by the Agriculture Department to initiate a program of integrated watershed treatment work on fifty small tributary streams.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 -- Lester B. Pearson, President of the United Nations General Assembly, told President Syngman Rhee of South Korea today that his unilateral action in releasing prisoners threatened both "the results already achieved and the prospect of a peaceful solution of remaining problems." Mr. Pearson said that as President of the Assembly he had been shocked by Dr. Rhee's action.

LUXEMBOURG, June 13 -- The establishment of a common market for coal and steel in the six major producing countries of Western Europe creates two outstanding problems of regional economic adjustment. These are in the Italian steel industry and in the Belgian coal industry.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Raymond Henry Fogler of Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y., was sworn in today as an Assistant Secretary for the Navy. The former president of W. T. Grant Company, retail store chain, took the oath at a Pentagon ceremony in the presence of high Navy officials.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- Burt Lancaster and Harold Hecht have found a new home in United Artists for their independent producing company, Norma Productions. The star and his partner recently ended an association of four years with Warner Brothers.

Grand Street Boys Foundation Maintenance Scholarships, providing $1,200 a year for four years, were awarded yesterday to five graduates of the city's high schools. They were presented by Dr. C. Frederick Pertsch, Associate Superintendent of Schools, at the Board of Education, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

A special blue ribbon panel of 300 will be called starting July 6 for the selection of a jury in a test case of the "illegality of the public loading racket." General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman ruled yesterday.

LONDON, June 23 (AP) -- Jan Cwiklinski, captain of the Batory, was decorated by Communist Poland for his part in the Eisler escape episode. The Batory, pride of Red Poland, is the ship Russian spy Valentine Gubitchev took home from New York.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 22 -- Ismet Inonu,. former President of the Republic and leader of the opposition Peoples' Republican party, declared today Turkey should reject Soviet overtures for reopening the Straits question unless Moscow agreed ih advance to recognize unconditional Turkish sovereignty over the strategic waterway.

The writer of your headline to an article on Page 9 of your issue of June 22 wholly misunderstood or misinterpreted what I said on June 21 on the "Citizens Union Searchlight" broadcast over WNBC. I never said that the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee would not back a Democrat, as the headline states.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Robin Roberts pitched his fourth victory over the Cubs and his twelfth of the season as the Phils downed the Bruins, 6 -- 1, today.

The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, C. I. O., reopened contract negotiations yesterday with East and Gulf Coast steamship operators and reportedly sought a 10 per cent wage increase, extra vacations, improved welfare and other benefits.

Investment banking syndicates will place on the market today new issues of securities valued at more than $95,000,000. Among the offerings are debentures of a finance company, mortgage bonds of a telephone company, common stock of a public utility company and convertible preferred stock of a manufacturer of temperature control apparatus. The new issues are as follows:

BONN, Germany, June 23 -- The United States Government has agreed in principle to a request from the West German Government to raise the status of their respective envoys in Bonn and Washington to the rank of Ambassador.

Stock prices continued to forge ahead yesterday spurred by strong demand for petroleum arid rail issues. At the close THE NEW YORK TIMES composite average of fifty stocks stood at 177.06, up 1.05 on the day and a respectable distance from the thirteen-month low of 170.68 to which it sank just a week ago.

A squad of young college girls met yesterday and took a few courses not generally found in a standard curriculum. Briefed in such exotic pursuits as how to conduct an egg-in-spoon race for "grasshoppers" (the 5 and 6 year olds), how to use a fire hydrant for street showers and how to bandage a skinned knee, they prepared themselves for a summer as assistant directors of Police Athletic League play streets.

The Communist party issued a statement yesterday charging that Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, who were executed as atom spies last Friday night, were "foully murdered by the joined forces of President Eisenhower, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. and J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Jewelry is presented in an unusual and artistic manner in a current exhibit at the Gallery of Art, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street. Designed by Majeska, the pieces are created exclusively for La Tausca.
Carl A. Setterstrom has been made general manager of the textile fibers division of Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation's chemicals division.

Ten thousands Baptist Sunday! school teachers and church leadersi from forty-one states began classes yesterday in religion and teaching methods. The sessions are under Jthe sponsorship of the National Sunday School and Baptist Training Union Congress, which is holding its forty-eighth annual meeting this week at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory, Sumner and Jefferson Avenues, Brooklyn.

The three-masted Belgian naval training ship Mercator, in port since last Thursday, will sail tomorrow at 9 A. M. from Pier 14, North River, at Fulton Street, to return home by way of Quebec, Canada, Iceland and Ireland.

CINCINNATI, June 23 -- Dave Beck, president of the Labor Teamsters Union, A. F. L., met here today with Karl F. Feller, president of the International Union of Brewery Workers, C. I. O., and invited the latter group to join the American Federation of Labor by merging with the teamsters.
WASHINGTON June 23 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved a bill today carrying $455,490,100 for flood control and navigation projects in the year to start July 1.

TOKYO, June 23 -- Warning that Japan faces a possible trade deficit of more than $1,000,000,000 this year, United States Ambassador John M. Allison urged Japanese business and government today to take drastic steps to curb the present unfavorable trend.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Dr. Allen V. Astin, director of the National Bureau of Standards, defended today tests made by his agency that showed that AD-X2, a controversial battery additive, had "no beneficial effect."

There is still no substitute for well-defined characterizations; fictional people should bring a story alive through their personalities, traits and actions. Some television dramas observe this fundamental; others don't.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 23 (AP) -- The powerful Pacific Coast Conference track squad crushed the best in the Big Ten today with an 82 1/6 to 49 5/6 victory in the twelfth meeting between the conferences.

Maybe it just seems so, but are there not more bugs this year than usual? Always there are bugs, of course, for bugs are as much a part of summer as going to the beach -- where many of them live, also.

NEW DELHI, India, June 23 -- Indian authorities were anxious over the political effect of the death today of Dr. Syama Prasad Mookerjee, leader of the strong orthodox Hindu opposition. About sixty of his adherents, who had been in frequent clashes with the police recently over the agitation for a settlement of the Kashmir dispute, were arrested in small disturbances growing out of gatherings today in several parts of the capital.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The president of Northwest Airlines, Harold R. Harris, described today proposals by two rival applicants to serve the Far East as "an act of cannibalism" that would "devour Northwest's Orient routes."

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., June 23 -- Joseph Fisher of Wykagyl and his 17-year-old son, Jimmy, won the Metropolitan father-and-son golf championship today at the Forest Hill Field Club with a gross score of 77.

The service for blood donors. given for four years at the Manhattan center of the American Red Cross at 70 West Fortieth Street, will be transferred tomorrow morning to the chapter headquarters at 315 Lexington Avenue near Thirty-eighth Street.
CLEVELAND, June 23 -- Every young nurse should serve a tour of duty with one of the military nurse corps, Capt. Winnie Gibson, director of the Navy Nurse Corps, said today.

H. E. Humphreys Jr., president of the United States Rubber Company, predicted yesterday that the rubber-fabricating industry would establish a new production record in the first half of this year by converting more than 730,000 tons of rubber into finished products.

ABOARD U.S.S. LLOYD, off Chesapeake Bay Lightship, June 23 -- The Bolero was first around Chesapeake Bay Lightship by almost ten and a half hours in the Newport-Annapolis race today. About 125 miles remained to the finish.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (UP) -- The Senate today passed a compromise bill designed to prevent top Government officials from collecting pay for vacations they do not take.
Six "youth ambassadors" have been chosen to spend six weeks beginning July 6 on a goodwill visit to Puerto Rican families. Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, June 23 -- After having studied the new regulations for travel by foreigners in the Soviet Union, diplomats said tonight it appeared that it might now be possible to travel fairly extensively in the Soviet Union by automobile.
TOKYO, Wednesday, June 24 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 431, for Tuesday:

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The House of Representatives Judiciary Committee decided today against issuing a subpoena directing Tom C. Clark, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, to testify before one of its subcommittees that has been investigating the Department of Justice.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Tom Lyon, 65 years old, nominated by President Eisenhower as director of the Federal Bureau of Mines, startled Senators today with testimony that he was drawing a $5,000-a-year pension as a retired official of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Gaile Galub, American Red Cross liaison officer with the Unified Command on Korean Relief Problems, told the international relations group at the national Red Cross convention today that International Red Cross teams were available in Korea to aid war prisoners in case of a truce.
Local 222 of the International Jewelry Workers Union, A. F. L., and its parent union have come to the parting of the ways, the international announced yesterday. But the local said it wasn't so.

Spain's leading dollar-earner -- green olives -- may be in short supply here late this year because of heavy early-season damage to the crop. This was reported yesterday by Victor M. Calderon, who heads Victor M. Calderon Co., Inc., United States agent for a number of Spanish exporters.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, told the Senate today that a 1943 report by an Internal Revenue agent charging pay-offs to public officials by a Pittsburgh racketeer had mysteriously disappeared.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A niece of a Speaker of the House of Representatives in the Eighteen-Nineties, who had spent forty-one years in the educational field, twenty-four of them in Government service, balked today when asked by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee whether she was a Communist at any period of her career or was one now.
Dr. Detiev W. Bronk will resign as president of the Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore to become the chief executive officer of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

LONDON, June 23 -- Consumer resistance to the purchase of pork and mutton, in plentiful supply in Britain for the present, at least, has resulted in demands on the Government to explain its policy on the distribution and rationing of meat.

Shipyard workers' representatives asked for a 12-cent hourly wage increase yesterday, but their negotiations with two major shipbuilding and ship repair companies ended early today without an accord having been reached.

Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga yesterday refused to dismiss indictments against twenty-five persons charged by the Staten Island rackets grand jury with violation of the gambling laws and other crimes. He also set fall dates for their trials.
YONKERS, June 23 -- George M. Poillon of Millbrook today captured the low gross prize in the annual spring tournament of the Westchester Seniors Golf Association at the Hudson River Country Club.

The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation of Bethpage, L. I., announced yesterday the award of engineering scholarships to ten Nassau and Suffolk County students. This makes 100 youngsters the company has started on their way to promising futures in aviation since the plan began ten years ago.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, June 24 (AP) -- A political opponent of President Syngman Rhee was beaten early today shortly after a mob of about 500 South Koreans ransacked his home and destroyed its fixtures.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, June 24 -- Six thousand Chinese shock troops, supported by heavy mortar and artillery concentrations, attacked early, this morning on a vital sector of the Korean front north of Kumhwa. The attack was apparently repulsed in the area of "Boomerang Ridge," north of Kumhwa but continued in the "Sniper Ridge"-"Triangle Hill" area to the east.

In assessing the reasons for various acts and attitudes of the Chinese Communists the possibility of pressure from famine should not be overlooked. It is now abundantly clear that food supply conditions in a large area are critical. The Peiping regime has broadcast several statements to the effect that it is "dealing vigorously" with the situation, but there is no hiding the fact that multiplied millions of Chinese are starving.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (UP) -- The Government reported today that a $40 basement bomb shelter would safely protect humans within 3,500 feet of an atomic explosion.

ESTES PARK, Colo., June 23 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis was urged here tonight to support Christian clergymen who, it was said, had been subjected to "unfair and unwarranted attacks" by Congressional investigating committees.

PITTSBURGH, June 23 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers, C. I. O., made its bid today for a guaranteed annual wage, a move that if successful could set the pattern for the steel and aluminum industries. The union presented this proposal and other issues in a two-hour bargaining session with the Aluminum Company of America.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 (UP) -- The results of other leading matches today at Wimbledon:
PARIS, June 23 -- A two-year legal battle for the custody of two Jewish war orphans, Robert and Gerald Finaly, was won tonight by Mine.
Manuel Siwek, president and a director of Wonder Books, and vice president of Grosset Dunlap, Inc., has been elected a director of the latter company.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 23 -- The New York State Thruway Authority will require at least $150,000,000 more to complete its 535-mile superhighway network, Bertram D. Tallamy, the authority's chairman, said today. Nearly all of the $500,000,000 authorized for the project by the State Legislature will be needed for constructing the main 427-mile route from New York to Buffalo.

PORTHCAWL, Wales, June 23 (UP) -- Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., and Marlene Stewart of Fonthill, Ont., scored two victories each today to carry United States and Canadian hopes into the fifth round of the British women's amateur golf championship.

Local 202, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., and the Butter and Egg Merchants Association signed a new two-year contract last night, setting up a seven-man commission to "deal with economic problems" of the butter and egg industry.

CHICAGO, June 23 (UP) -- Representative Sidney R. Yates, Democrat of Illinois, declared today that President Eisenhower had failed to exert leadership on several important issues, including "book burning" in the United States libraries abroad.

The Yankees, who have made a practice of cooling off the contenders in four world championship campaigns under Casey Stengel, were cooled off rather convincingly themselves last night by the White Sox.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., June 23 -- Former Vice President Albert W. Barkley asserted today that greater effort on the part of the American advertising industry is necessary so that people of the world may not be lulled into insensibility to the danger of communism.

New designs in table linens, towels and a blanket, imported from countries including Italy, France, Belgium and England, are on view at Max Littwitz, Inc. The shop is newly situated at 801 Madison Avenue.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 23 -- The American Association of University Women unanimously adopted a resolution today urging the responsibility for the preservation of freedom to learn and freedom to teach "be placed on the educational institutions themselves, and that alleged violations of law be dealt with by our legally constituted law-enforcement agencies and courts."

IS there anyone who doesn't knock on wood, or throw a pinch of spilt salt over his shoulder, or hold odd notions about the number 13? As long as such unthinking homage is paid to supernatural beliefs, ours cannot yet be called a completely scientific age. Ever since our prehistoric ancestors were frightened of the dark and the unknown, men have believed in the most frightful things and have taken pleasure in their fear.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 24 -- South Korean President Syngman Rhee has served formal notice on Gen. Mark W. Clark that the Republic of Korea forces will be withdrawn from the United Nations Command if the armistice in Korea is signed in its present form.

The decision of the House of Representatives to allow its members to deduct from their taxable income the total cost of living expenses in Washington is not the wisest way to accomplish a laudable purpose. The intention is, of course, to increase net Congressional incomes, an objective with which we are in wholehearted agreement.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Eisenhower, according to a reliable informant, made a new personal appeal to Representative Daniel A. Reed today for action on continuation of the excess profits tax, again without success.

BEE experts in New York were not astonished the other day when a swarm set up house in a neon sign over the Horn Hardart shop on Lexington Avenue between Fifty-eighth and .Fifty-ninth Streets. It seems bees frequently turn up in the city this time of year.

Despite this city's reluctant acceptance of the state-mandated Transit Authority and the fiscal program that goes with it, New York's financial problems remain unsolved, "through no fault of the City Administration," Mayor Impellitteri told the City Council yesterday.

CAIRO, June 23 -- Scores of thousands of Egyptians today chanted their allegiance to the five-day-old republic and cheered its first President, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, as he pledged that Egypt would "not give in one inch" in asserting her national rights.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, returning to the controversy over "book burning," announced today that he planned more public hearings designed to show whether some of the authors involved were Communists.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Air Force told Congress today it had tracked carefully the debris from atomic explosions for thousands of miles without finding any connection between atom blasts and unusual weather.

LONDON, June 23 -- The potentialities of trade between Britain and the Communist countries are decidedly less than propagandists have indicated, the General Council of the British Trades Union Congress reported in a survey published today.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries set a new sales record and had the second highest earnings for a first-half-year period, according to the report yesterday of Harvey S. Firestone Jr., president, covering the six months to April 30.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Lewis L. Strauss, New York financier and rear admiral in the United States Naval Reserve, has been chosen by President Eisenhower to be chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.
CINCINNATI, June 23 (UP) -- National League headquarters here today received a formal protest of the Redlegs' 5-3 victory over the Phillies on Sunday at Crosley Field.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The United States declined today to modify its travel restrictions on Soviet diplomats here until more "detailed" information had been received indicating the extent of the easing of foreign travel curbs in the Soviet Union.

The word Fusion has lost its significance in our city as a coalition of all parties and voters interested in good government. The City Fusion party was incorporated in 1933, and obtained a place on the ballot, which it still retains. But in 1949 it polled only 12,818 votes in a total poll of over 3,500,000.

The final report of the special committee of the United Nations and the International Labor Organization on forced labor, published today, is likely to remain for a long time a milestone on the road of man's age-long struggle for dignity and his right to labor without coercion by the state.

SEOUL, Korea, June 23 -- Throughout the day, Dr. Rhee made it very plain he was not going to change quickly. He granted a number of private press interviews and patiently outlined his beliefs and objectives.

ROME, June 22 -- During the month of June there has passed through Rome a colorful procession of dignitaries from the Near and Far East on their way home from the coronation of Queen Elizabeth. Some of them pause here to rest and discuss the state of the world.

Volume improved yesterday on most items on the New York commodity exchanges, but sugar and potatoes were unusually quiet. Prices were irregular with sugar, wool, lead, copper, zinc and potatoes closing mixed. Cottonseed oil, soybean oil and hides were lower and coffee, cocoa, rubber and tin ended higher.

ARCHIE MOORE and Joey Maxim, two elderly gentlemen with pacifistic tendencies, will fight for the light-heavyweight championship of the world in Ogden, Utah, tonight. It isn't quite far enough away, particularly when television bridges the miles. Jack (Doc) Kearns arranged things far better in his younger days when he was managing Jack Dempsey.

Controlling stock interest in the American District Telegraph Company, a 62 per cent-owned subsidiary of the Western Union Telegraph Company, is about to be sold to the Grinnell Corporation, one of the nation's leading manufacturers of fire extinguishers and burglar alarm systems.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Outsmart and the Greentree Stable's Hoodwink engaged in a thrilling stretch drive in the Tokalon at Aqueduct yesterday, with Outsmart hitting the wire first by a close margin. Before the official sign in Outsmart's favor went up, however, the stewards had to consider a claim of foul against the winner.

Warnings that failure of Republicans; Liberals and independent Democrats to agree on a coalition ticket for Mayor and other offices to be filled this year might leave the city at the mercy of Democratic "machines" were given yesterday by the Citizens Union and supporters of Representative Jacob K. Javits, a leading possibility to head an anti-machine slate.

LONDON, June 23 -- Capt. Jan Cwiklinski, master of the Polish liner Batory on which Gerhart Eisler, German-born Communist leader, fled from the United States in 1949, has left his ship and sought asylum in Britain.

LONDON, June 23 -- The stock markets here remained extremely quiet today, with uncertainty over the international situation still the main restricting factor. But the undertone generally was described as steady and prices as a whole showed only minor irregular movements.

OGDEN, Utah, June 23 (AP) -- Archie Moore of California, 36 years old, remained the betting favorite today to retain his world light heavyweight championship against Joey Maxim, 31, of Cleveland, over the fifteen-round route tomorrow night.
MILWAUKEE, June 23 (UP) -- Southpaw Warren Spahn struck out twelve batters and gave up only two hits in a losing cause tonight as the Pirates nipped the Braves, 1 to 0.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 23 -- Spiritual leaders of the conservative branch of Judaism deplored today the "spiritual absenteeism" in contemporary society, and called for greater emphasis on religious values and meaningful prayer to counteract "the pressures of the machine age."

SYRACUSE, June 23 -- Twelve players from the Pacific Coast and one each from the East, Middle West, South and Southwest remained in the running for the national intercollegiate tennis championship tonight at the Skytop courts of Syracuse University.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold announced today receipt of a cablegram from Mincho Neichev, Foreign Minister of Bulgaria, dispatched apparently in line with the current Soviet "peace offensive," conveying that Government's acceptance of an offer by Greece to participate in a bilateral border commission for adjustment of mutual problems.

Four corporations a labor union and five of their officers were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating the Sherman Anti-trust Act. They were charged with conspiring to monoplize in interstate commerce the hauling of scenery and equipment used by theatres, motion picture producers and television stations in this city.

The trip to all the South American countries on which Dr. Milton Eisenhower started yesterday is much the most important move yet made by the new Administration in the field of inter-American affairs. It is not that the President's brother can himself do anything specific or make policy, since that will not be his role.

The deportation arrests here of Felix Kusman, a former bodyguard of Gerhardt Eisler, and Louis Shomberg, a long-time racketeer, were announced in Washington yesterday by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. Both men, seized at their homes, were taken to Ellis Island.

Even in an unsteady performance Sheridan's "The School for Scandal" is a mighty good comedy. According to the omniscient statistician in the next office, it has not been done here professionally since 1931. At Theatre de Lys, where it was put on last evening, it has all sorts of artistic shortcomings.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Rules Committee of the House of Representatives refused clearance today for two bills aimed at thwarting President Eisenhower's plan to increase the military planning powers of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman had breakfast today with Democratic Congressional leaders, lunched with his old White House staff, and dined with former Cabinet members.

A lobster bisque, bouillabaisse in the Marseilles manner, and a "potage" of smoked pork and vegetables are the first of several soups canned by Liebig of Aubervilliers to arrive here from France. The fourteen and one-half ounce tins are 85 to 95 cents each, but the contents are so finely made they are worth the price.
The strain which local government borrowing is causing in the market for tax-exempt bonds was visible in several ways yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A beaming Mrs. Harry S. Truman greeted about 350 old friends today at a "for-members-only" meeting of the Women's National Democratic Club.

Two highly contrasting pictures of the progress the city has made since 1946 in improving its school system and meeting its educational needs were presented yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri and Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman.

GENEVA, June 23 -- An earnest plea to countries of the free world to make peace if it can be achieved more than just an end to fighting for hundreds of millions of underfed, underclothed and undernourished human beings all over the world was made today by David Morse, Director General of the International Labor Organization, in a major address to the thirty-sixth International Labor Conference meeting here.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 23 -- A serious situation threatening a split between the states of Indo-China is developing around the demand of Norodom Sihanouk, the King of Cambodia, for the complete independence from France of his country.

MOSCOW, June 23 -- Western diplomats, after a close study of today's Pravda editorial, advanced the conclusion that the Soviet Union has not been swayed from its policy of seeking a detente with the Western powers by events either in Korea or Berlin.
COLORADO SPRINGS, June 23 (AP) -- Stanford University ended North Texas State's four-year reign today as team golf champion of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

A directory issued yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, appears to be an answer to William H. Howard, vice president of Young Rubicam, Inc., who on Monday took newspapers to task for concentrating their ad efforts on competing with each other instead of selling newspaper space as a medium.

HONG KONG, June 23 -- Twenty-three persons, including a group of foreign Roman Catholic missionaries, among them at least seven American and two French priests, have been arrested in Shanghai on charges of carrying on espionage activities "under the guise of religion."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 23 -- Forty-five high school students from the greater New York area representing major religious, racial and national groups assembled today in Alumnae House on the Vassar College campus for the eighth annual high school conference on human relations.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 23 (AP) -- Super Chief, owned by the Three H Farm of Las Vegas, Nev., put on a brilliant stretch drive tonight to win the Secretary pace on the Grand Circuit program at Roosevelt Raceway by a length over Mighty Grattan.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 23 -- Hugh W. Cross of Washington, D. C., an Interstate Commerce Commissioner, said here today that the I. C. C. was about to undertake a far-reaching reorganization designed to expedite its work and to meet a "staggering" backlog of cases.

PARIS, June 23 -- Matyas Rakosi, the indomitable little Communist who is Premier of Hungary and, subject to the whims of imperial Moscow, her absolute master once boasted that he had destroyed his opposition by "salami tactics."

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Senate Republican leaders yielded to the Eisenhower Administration today and agreed to act at this session on proposed protocols, or amendments, to the North Atlantic Treaty that had lain dormant.

llaThe personal experiencs a Korean prisonerof-war camp of Phillp Deane, a correspondent for The London Observer, will be reated in a book to be ssued by orton on July 27. It is c ,led "I s a iaptive /n Korea- Mr. eane was ' captured when the American troops vere first overrun and with American soldiers and a group of American. British and French civilian officials anel missponaries spent nearly three years in captivity.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres today. "Melba," a Technicolor biography with music, starring the Metropolitan Opera coloratura, Patrice Munsel, as the Australian diva, is at the Capitol.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The consumers' price index rose 0.3 per cent between mid-April and mid-May, from 113.7 to 114, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. It was the third consecutive monthly rise.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Business activity maintained a strong pace in the second quarter of the year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WITH the promise of an excellent bluefish season, coastal anglers who enjoy light tackle fishing face a real opportunity. The blue is a scrapper, and horsing such a fish in on heavy tackle costs the angler a lot in sport.

It seems clear that the Soviet Union, despite its relaxation of travel curbs on foreign diplomats and correspondents, has still retained prohibitions on the chief industrial and armaments production centers of tile Urals and Siberia. These centers would be least exposed to foreign attack in time of wa,-.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Foreign countries added about $750,000,000 to their gold and dollar reserves by doing business with the United States during the first three months of this year, the Department of Commerce said today.

LONDON, June 23 (Reuters) -- Britain's bulk-buying cotton agency, the Raw Cotton Commission, suffered a trading loss of about 25,000,000 ($70,000,000) in the year ended last August, according to its annual report, published today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 23 -- Hans Hedtoft, leader of the Social Democratic party and former Premier, declared today that Denmark should decline with thanks the proposal of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to station Allied air forces in Denmark during peacetime.

The greatest opportunity for a change in emphasis in shoe production is in increased output of children's footwear, the New England Shoe and Leather Association reported yesterday. A study of future population trends, based on data of the Bureau of the Census, shows that the country's population will increase 11.6 per cent in the decade between 1950 and 1960, the association said.

TROY, N. Y., June 23 (AP) -- The Rand Pharmaceutical Company, Inc., of Rensselaer, has filed a $1,490,000 suit against the Norwich Pharmacal Company, alleging that a shipment of blood pressure tablets contained the wrong ingredient.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 -- A petition challenging the existence of separate facilities for Negroes and white persons in railway stations in the South will be filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission within the next four weeks, a spokesman for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced today.

Nat Holman, suspended City College basketball coach, wanted his assistant, Harry (Bobby) Sand, dismissed in 1950 for having allegedly offered a financial inducement to a team member to make a summer tour of South America, Dr. Samuel Winograd, former faculty manager of atheltics at the college, said yesterday.

According to figures contained in a Washington dispatch published in this newspaper yesterday the gross debt of the American economy expanded by approximately $40 billions in 1952, carrying it to a record high of $640 billions.

BOSTON, June 23 (AP) -- Milt Bolling's two-out double in the tenth inning ruined Bob Chakales' five-hit pitching stint for Cleveland and gave the Red Sox a sweep of their day-night program with the Indians, 2 -- 1. Dick Gernert's wind-blown fly dropped for a two-run triple in the eighth inning to give the Red Sox a 6-4 triumph in the afternoon.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 -- Soviet use of a system of forced labor for the dual purpose of political coercion and economic gain was confirmed today by a United Nations investigation. The committee, in a 621-page report, found "no evidence" to prove Russian charges that forced labor existed in the United States, particularly in the South.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 23 -- The forty-second triennial convention of the Lutheran Church--Missouri Synod approved a step toward unification with American Lutheran Church here today. The synod upheld the constitutionality of the adoption' in 1950 of a common confession of the two groups.

George E. Roosevelt, nonsalaried chairman of the Long Island Transit Authority, told Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday that the proposed tax settlement between the Long Island Rail Road and the city would not expedite the reorganization of the bankrupt commuter railroad.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- The possible decadence of the modern movement within twenty-five years was forecast here today by Alfred Auerbach, home furnishings consultant, who long has been associated with the "avant garde" segment of the industry.

CINCINNATI, June 23 -- Billy Loes was within two outs of his ninth victory at Crosley Field tonight when Roy McMillan beat out a bunt on which Billy Cox made a fine but futile play. Then Grady Hatton batted for Clyde King and belted a two-one pitch over the right field barrier for a 3-2 Redleg triumph over the Dodgers.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Wheat futures moved in a seesaw course today. They opened sharply higher on the announcement that no more wheat would be available from Government stocks until further notice, but free selling met the advance and all early gains were erased.

Italy is now shipping wool textiles to the United States at a rate of 50 per cent more than a year ago, it was learned yesterday. Shipments for the first three months of the year were 466,478 square yards, as against 315,438 a year ago.

Detective James E. Furey Jr. of the Forgery Squad and his daughter, Maureen, 5 years old, were injured critically at 3:05 P. M. yesterday when an automobile the detective was driving skidded in a mud puddle on Flatbush Avenue near the Belt Parkway, Brooklyn, and struck an electric light pole.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Readjustments in the economy resulting from declining defense spending within the next few years "need not be serious in a growing and healthy economy" such as this country enjoys, the Committee on Economic Policy of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States held today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 23 -- Commendations of the Westchester County American Legion for its projected Americanism Award to Rabbi Benjamin Schultz of New York were announced today by James B. White, Americanism chairman of the Legion.

A decrease last week of 1,222,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies amounted to 149,535,000 barrels, compared with 150,757,000 a week earlier and 121,613,000 a year ago.

PARIS, June 24 -- Although the French Government accepted the proposal by Washington and London that the heads of the Governments of the United States, Britain and France should meet in Bermuda July 8 to discuss relations with the Soviet Union, it is not clear how France can be represented if her Parliament fails to choose a new Premier by that date.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Dick Kokos' two-run homer off Bob Porterfield with two out in the ninth inning gave the Browns a 7-6 victory over the Senators tonight. Roy Sievers blasted a three-run homer for the Browns in the eighth inning.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Federal Reserve Board moved today to expand bank credit by an estimated $5,780,000,000 in the face of constantly mounting interest rates and in anticipation of Treasury plans next week to raise about $6,000,000,000 of new money to meet Government running expenses.
