The political, social and economic issues of the Middle East are discussed by John Kimche in a book titled "Seven Fallen Pillars: The Middle East from 1945 to 1952" that will be published by Praeger on July 15. The author, a roving correspondent for Reuters in the post-war Middle East, also explains the complicated pattern of the region's history between the wars to show the fateful sequence of policies and opportunities.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Selling pressure in wheat increased today, traders anticipating hedge pressure as the Midwest harvesting of red winter wheat expands. The result was a sharp recession in prices. In corn and oats the July futures were relatively strong, while there was more aggressive selling of the deferred futures.

ALTHOUGH the porgies seem to outnumber the weakfish, and some of them even make more of an impression on scales, both are reasonably plentiful at Peconic Bay, and offer reasonably good sport on very light tackle.

LONDON, June 24 -- The stock markets were idle today, volume of business being scarcely sufficient to produce a trend in prices. Nevertheless, British Government securities maintained a steady undertone and price movements were restricted to minor changes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 -- Full-scale production of pictures will be resumed at Warner Brothers immediately after the July 4 week-end, with six pictures slated to go before the studio's new "All-Media" camera in quick succession.

NOROTON, Conn., June 24 -- Stanley Ogilvy, with his Flame, completed a sweep of Noroton Yacht Club's fifteenth race week for Star sloops by winning the fourth and final event of the series today for a perfect score of 100 points.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- John A. Hannah, Assistant Secretary of Defense for manpower and personnel, told the Reserve Officers Association today that the armed services were facing a long period of stringent manpower shortage.

In a cash deal marking the first change of ownership of the property since 1845, the three-story private dwelling on lot 20 by 103 feet at 155 West Thirteenth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, has been sold by J. Waldron Gillespie to Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, through the Duross Company, broker.

On Saturday, rejoicing in a rare sunny week-end and hoping to shake off a cold, I went to Riverside Park, removed my shirt and began to sun bathe. This is, as all virtuous citizens must recognize, an offense against the civic conscience. In less than five minutes, a police officer discovered me and issued a summons.

A new course, Explorations in Science, will be offered at Hunter College next semester for the first time. An experimental course in integrated science, it will take the place of the requirement for non-science majors who volunteer for a three-semester sequence.

Grecian Queen let Canadiana set a tremendous early pace in the $30,000 Gazelle at Aqueduct yesterday, but when the mile-and-a-sixteenth race was over, Grecian Queen was in first place, a length and a half ahead of the import from north of the border.

The Southern Pacific Company sold $8,445,000 of equipment trust certificates yesterday to an underwriting group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., which bid 99.024 for the securities with a 3 5/8 per cent coupon. A competing bid of 99.52791 for certificates naming a 3 3/4 per cent coupon was submitted by Salomon Brothers Hutzler and associates.

A new method for manufacturing "textured yarn" has been developed by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., it was announced last night by Dr. Donald F. Holmes, sales development manager of the company's textile fibers department.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Dr. Allen V. Astin testified today that, far from being a secret, the ingredients of AD-X2, the controversial battery additive powder, were known down "to five parts per million" as a result of tests by the National Bureau of Standards.

The Wooster Express of Hartford, Conn., has leased the new trucking terminal at 5-25 Borden Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, from the Arged Realty Company in a transaction negotiated by the James H. Burns Company as broker.

TRENTON, June 24 -- Excerpts from the text of the opening statement by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll before the special legislative committee investigating the dismissal of Nelson F. Stamler as Deputy Attorney General follow:

WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 -- Betrayed by his bulk, Enrique Morea of Argentina was defeated by Ian Ayre of Australia, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 4, 11 -- 9, 6 -- 2, in a mildly unexpected result today as the field in the men's singles of the all-England tennis championships moved into the third round before 25,000 spectators.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 24 -- Cognizant of speculations that their tripartite Balkan pact had been weakened by recent Soviet policy, Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia issued a formal statement today reaffirming their determination to carry out the Ankara treaty of friendship and military collaboration in the spirit in which it was signed last February.

At 4 o'clock in the morning of Sunday, June 25, 1950, the armed forces of North Korea swept across the Thirty-eighth Parallel and with that action the Communist rulers of Soviet Russia began the most savage, vicious and bloody aggression that the free world had seen since the collapse of Nazi power five years before.
The State of California sold bond issues yesterday totaling $26,000,000 at interest costs ranging from 3 per cent to 3.011 per cent.

LUXEMBOURG, June 14 -- Up to now, the technical revolution in the European steel industry and, to a somewhat lesser extent, in the coal industry, has exerted more influence on the basic economic structure of the six countries participating in the European Coal and Steel Community than the community itself.

ST. LOUIS, June 24 -- Delegates to the annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People were told today their organization was not planning any legal moves that would expand or improve separate facilities for Negroes.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 24 -- Mrs. Mortimer May of the Middle Bay Club, the medalist, chipped in from 30 yards off the edge of the home green for a winning par 4 to defeat Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Seawane Harbor, 1 up, in the second round of the twenty-third annual Women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship at the Nassau Country Club today.

BERLIN, June 24 -- With the Soviet position in East Germany suddenly and dramatically weakened, now is the historic opportunity to achieve a united pro-Western Germany, Dr. Ernst Reuter, Mayor of West Berlin, said today.

TRENTON, June 24 -- Inclusion of comparative studies of Soviet Russia in the curriculum of all tax-supported schools in New Jersey, to emphasize the advantages of living under the American system, was advocated in a report released here today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

Settlement of contract negotiations on the same basis that ended last week's four-day strike of two other maritime unions seemed assured last night as talks were continued between representatives of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, C. I. O., and the Committee for the Companies and Agents, Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The State Department today reorganized its press relations division to end its nominally direct connection with the Secretary of State and place it under the Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs. An order making the change, dated yesterday, was circulated late this afternoon.
Joe Adonis' conviction for contempt of the Senate was reversed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals and he was ordered acquitted.
ST. LOUIS, June 24 -- Sal Maglie, called the Barber, is back in business again, shaving the corners with razor sharpness, and when this situation prevails the Giants invariably look neat and fresh.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Glitter, lacking in last January's somewhat somber presentation of the "good design" exhibit, was noticeably present in the new additions to that display presented here today. Now in its eighth edition, the project, jointly sponsored by he Merchandise Mart of this city and the Museum of Modern Art of New York, attempts to select from home furnishings merchandise available to the American public those items the committee considers most desirable.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Charles R. Slight Jr., president of the National Association of Manufacturers, called for a gradual reduction of foreign trade barriers of all kinds in a talk today at a furniture market luncheon sponsored by the Home Fashions League of Chicago in the Sheraton Hotel.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 24 -- The homemaker, either in panel meetings or through reports of surveys, has spoken up for herself at the annual meeting of the American Home Economics Association, now in progress here.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 25 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,656, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 24 -- The American Association of University Women today maintained its opposition to a proposed amendment to the Constitution granting equal rights to women.

Wall Street traders did not like the domestic news yesterday. The cut in the American Smelting dividend, the omission of the Goodall-Sanford dividend and confused reports on the Pacific Western Oil Company's latest drilling efforts upset the stocks of those companies with sufficient force to exert a mildly depressing effect on other sections of the list.

Prospects for the cotton textile industry are unusually favorable and the position of mills on orders and stock is one of the most comfortable in history for this time of the year, according to W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., June 24 (AP) -- Medalist Merle Backlund of Colorado and Eddie Merrins, the favorite of Louisiana State, were toppled today in a wave of upsets that swept the first round of match play in the fifty-sixth N. C. A. A. golf tournament.

The National Board of Fire Underwriters has announced the appointment of Charles A. Loughlin as chairman of its committee on laws. He is vice president and general counsel of the Home Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A nation-wide appeal for funds to build the superstructure of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception will be made Dec. 6. The date, designated by the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States, was announced by the Most Rev. John F. Noll, Bishop of Fort Wayne, Ind., chairman of the national appeal for funds for the shrine.

HARRINGTON, Del., June 24 -- Top honors in the National Chicken Cooking Contest today went to Mrs. Frank H. Tharp of Lewes, Del., on the third and final day of the sixth annual Delmarva Chicken Festival.
Mayor Impellitteri declared last night that he wanted to set straight the record about New York and this is what he said:

LONDON, June 24 -- Britain having successfully, exploded an atomic bomb last October is now proceeding with the development of "atomic weapons to meet various service requirements," Duncan Sandys, the Minister of Supply, announced in the House of Commons today.

BOSTON, June 24 (AP) -- After spotting the Red Sox three runs in the first inning, the Indians surged from behind for a 13-9 victory today by generating seventeen hits. Dale Mitchell, Bob Avila and Jim Hegan each connected thrice to pull the game out of the fire for Early Wynn.

MANILA, June 24 -- Ailing President Elpidio Quirino has permitted announcement that he will leave Saturday for the United States to undergo hospitalization in Baltimore for a stubborn illness of uncertain definition which has kept him partly incapacitated since mid-May.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, June 24 -- Scotland pledged herself anew to the service of Queen and country in a solemn covenant of dedication in historic St. Giles Cathedral here today in the presence of the monarch herself and her consort the Duke of Edinburgh.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., June 24 -- James E. Fisher of Wykagyl scored a 35, 33 -- 68, three under par, to win the medal today in the Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship at the Forest Hill Field Club.
Business will continue at a high level during the second half of this year, according to a nation-wide survey of banking opinion just completed by the American Bankers Association.

Governor Dewey's reform program for New York's racket-ridden waterfront -- to be considered by a special session of the Legislature in Albany today -- was attacked yesterday by both dock union and employers.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- When the House of Representatives in 1910 cut down the powers of Speaker Cannon in what was hailed as a "great reform," it augmented the already large influence of the committee chairmen to the point that has enabled Representative Daniel A. Reed of New York thus far to block President Eisenhower's request for a six-month extension of the excess-profits tax.

With the completion of a six weeks' tour of Central and South America, Helen Keller has worked for the blind on every continent, she said yesterday. Through her companion, Polly Thomson, the noted blind and deaf author and lecturer told reporters who met her at La Guardia Airport that Latin-American countries were making "great progress in their work with the blind and deaf."

More attention should be given in the United States to Western Europe's economic and political problems, in place of the heavy emphasis on accelerated rearmament efforts. This was the basic point made yesterday by Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A bill for the development of the vast power potential at Niagara Falls by private utility companies was approved today by the Committee on Public Works of the House of Representatives. The vote was four-teen to seven.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Senate voted today to use Federal revenues from offshore oil and other resources for Federal aid to education.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today a one-year renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act without a disputed House-approved amendment upsetting the bipartisan composition of the United States Tariff Commission.

LOS ANGELES, June 24 -- The first award of the Melvil Dewey Medal for distinguished work in the library field was made at the seventy-second annual conference of the American Library Association today to Dr. Ralph R. Shaw, librarian of the United States Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Gordon Dean, retiring chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, predicted today that economic industrial power would be produced by nuclear energy "in a very few years -- certainly less than ten."

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Net working capital of American corporations climbed to a new high level during the quarter ended on March 31, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. In a periodical survey of the liquidity of corporations the agency said that net working capital stood at $86,900,000,000 at the end of March, the highest total ever reached.

Alphonse A. Amato, who was the first witness in the Staten Island gambling inquiry to be convicted of criminal contempt, was sentenced yesterday to a one-year penitentiary term. Amato, a 32-year-old longshoreman, who lives at 76 Winfield Avenue, Glassmere, S. I., had been found guilty on May 12.

The letter about the "Importance of Goa," which appeared in your issue of June 18, was somewhat shocking to me, as perhaps it would be to anyone who knows the meaning of Gandhi's words about peace and brotherhood, and to those who know the main purpose of the U. N. and the North Atlantic Pact.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 25 (AP) -- Gen Mark W. Clark said today United Nations soldiers had achieved their avowed purpose in three years of fighting in Korea by halting Communist aggression and hurling the invaders back across the Thirty-eighth Parallel.
SEOUL, Thursday, June 25 -- Three years ago today, war began here.

CHICAGO, June 24 (UP) -- Connie Ryan drove in three runs with two doubles and a triple today and scored three times himself as the Phils beat the Cubs, 8 to 2, for the tenth straight time this season on Karl Drews' five-hitter.

Leonard Bernstein selected the music of Robert Schumann for his program last night with the Stadium Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium. Aldo Parisot was soloist in the 'Cello Concerto, while the orchestral pieces were the Second Symphony and the "Manfred" Overture.

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume generally continued to improve with cottonseed oil registering the most active day since May 8, but potatoes remained unusually dull. Coffee, sugar, soybean oil, hides, copper and potatoes closed mixed.

A 46-year-old pinboy in a Harlem bowling alley, who had been in jail more than two and one-half months pending trial on a charge that he had violated the Sullivan Law by carrying a switchblade knife, burst into tears yesterday when a jury in Bronx County Court acquitted him and turned over $11 With its unanimous wish for good luck.

ROME, June 24 -- The new Parliament elected two weeks ago is to be inaugurated tomorrow morning and on the eve of its first session, Pietro Nenni, Left-Wing Socialist leader, made one more bid for the inclusion of his party in Premier Alcide De Gasperi's next Government.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 24 -- William White, president of the New York Central System, told leaders of the railway industry from North, Central and South America "there is no reason to expect within the foreseeable future any new development comparable to Dieselization as a factor in cutting costs of railroad operation."

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- George F. Markham, a labor union official and a wartime naval combat intelligence officer, refused today to tell the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives whether he was or ever had been a Communist, but he did assert that he was ousted from the Reserves last autumn by "kangaroo proceedings."

PARIS, June 24 -- Encouraged by all the Right and Center political groups, Joseph Laniel, conservative leader of Paul Reynaud's Independent party, agreed tonight to seek the Premiership. He will ask approval from the National Assembly, Friday.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 24 -- Individuals in this troubled era need more than ever the security and quiet strength good family living can bring, Miss Dorothy S. Lawson, chief of the Bureau of Home Economics of the New York State Education Department, declared today.
Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican, made formal announcement yesterday of his candidacy for Mayor on a coalition ticket.

The Murray Corporation of America, manufacturer of parts and assemblies for automotive vehicles, increased its sales substantially in the nine months ended on last May 31, but earnings were somewhat below those of the corresponding period of the previous year, according to the report issued yesterday.

Progress made by the engineering firms of Day Zimmerman and Coverdale Colpitts in bringing up to date their analysis of the municipal transit system will be reviewed today by the New York. City Transit Authority at a meeting with the consultants at 370 Jay Street, Brooklyn.

The special committee set up by the Board of Higher Education last week to study measures designed to root out alleged subversives on the municipal college faculties held its first meeting yesterday. The presidents of three city colleges and the dean of another participated in the closed session, which was held at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue.

The motion picture "The Moon is Blue" was denounced yesterday by Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, as "an occasion of sin," which seriously violated "standards of morality and decency." The Cardinal reminded all Roman Catholics of their obligation to avoid seeing it.

To increase the effectiveness of its advertising and promotion programs the American Gas Association has added a new service. Five new promotion representatives have been named to call on member companies in all parts of the country to convey first-hand information regarding the programs.

I note the letter of C. C. Burlingham appearing in THE TIMES of June 24, in which he makes mention of the City Fusion party. I have nothing but high regard and commendation for Mr. Burlingham's efforts to help to clean up New York City. But he is utterly mistaken as to the role of the City Fusion party.

A gentle flurry of scrap buying on the part of some large consumers who had been out of the market some time while working down substantial inventories has strengthened prices of the better grades, industry sources reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A new political "who-done-it," not unfamiliar in Washington politics, arose today over the case of why Paul Nitze, a prominent policymaking official in the State Department during the Truman Administration, didn't get a big job in the Defense Department of the Eisenhower Administration.
WASHINGTON, June 24 --The Administration's plan to overhaul the Department of Defense was cleared today for a House of Representatives vote on Friday by the Committee on Government Operations.

In less than a week it will become expensive to be casual or forgetful about giving hand signals while driving in New York State. Next Wednesday failure to use hand signals may cause a driver to use his hands to pay a $4 fine.

The American Gas and Electric Company reported yesterday that net earnings for the first five months of this year were 19 per cent higher than in the corresponding period a year ago. In the five months to May 31 consolidated net income of the company, one of the largest operating utilities in the United States, amounted to $13,863,096, compared with $11,643,194 in the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, told the Senate today he had asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate a "dastardly smear attack" which he said had spurred the Wisconsin state Republican convention to adopt a resolution of censure against him.

ESTES PARK, Colo., June 24 -- The American public school system was vigorously defended here today by the Central Conference of American Rabbis against charges of secularism, Godlessness and "even direct hostility to religion."

Directors of General Mills, Inc. increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock with the declaration yesterday of 62 1/2 cents a share for payment on Aug. 1. Shareholders had been receiving 50 cents quarterly. A year-end extra declared on last May 25 will also be paid on Aug. 1.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Declaring that Western Union was "rapidly drifting toward trouble," a Senate subcommittee suggested three alternatives to place the nation's only domestic telegraph carrier in a more sound financial position. They were:
BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., June 24 (AP) -- Real estate men were urged tonight to help curb real property taxes by working to hold down all governmental spending.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 24 -- A flag-bedecked bus left this morning carrying fourteen Boy Scouts of Troop 92 with their scoutmaster-driver for a 10,000-mile trip through twenty-seven states and Canada in sixty-four days.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 24 (AP) -- Power Chief, owned by Jacques Grenier of Long Beach, Calif., scored his sixth victory of the year in the Fashion Trends Pace, tonight's feature of the Grand Circuit meeting at Roosevelt Raceway.

President Eisenhower's choice of Lewis L. Strauss as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, to succeed Gordon Dean, whose resignation takes effect at the end of this month, is excellent. As one of the members of the commission when it was created. Mr. Strauss grew up with it.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, announced today cancellation of all contracts with Willys Motors, Inc., a subsidiary of Kaiser Motors Corporation, except for the completion of aircraft in stages of final assembly.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UP) -- Miss Edna Best Stephenson, State Department information specialist, has been suspended from her $8,000-a-year job for issuing, without proper clearance, a memorandum on the Taft-Hartley Law that irked labor leaders.

Any historical group financially able to restore and maintain the 288-year-old Van Cortlandt Manor House at Croton-on-Hudson as a national shrine "would have no difficultly in obtaining it," John D. Rockefeller Jr. said yesterday.

GENEVA, June 24 -- The calm that customarily rules the political life of the canton of Geneva has been shattered by the sudden realization of business circles and conservative political leaders that a Communist effort to prevent the establishment here of a large European laboratory for the study of nuclear physics has gathered enough public support to come very near to wrecking the project.

The Yankees are so far ahead of the American League field that they can well afford to give a little ground. However, Manager Casey Stengel, who had been relishing the thought of a serene summer, is beginning to get a little alarmed at the manner in which his four-time world champions are performing.

There is the stark -- deadly stark -- reality that Koreans, just as Americans, are sick of war; but the possible truce in Korea might mean an irrevocable "death sentence" to the desperate desire of the Korean people to live like human beings, not like sub-humans half slave and half free.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 24 -King Norodom Sihanouk of the Indo-Chinese State of Cambodia, said today that his country would remain in the French Union only if it were given independence similar to that accorded to Pakistan by Britain.

Emphatic opposition to a city manager form of government for New York was expressed yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri in a letter to Devereux C. Josephs, chairman of the Temporary State Commission to Study Organizational Structure of the Government of the City of New York.

Blood collections totaled 809 pints on Tuesday, the Red Cross announced yesterday. The largest amount, 133 pints, was donated at the Neptune Motor Company of Long Island City, Queens. Other units collected 104 pints at the Columbia Broadcasting System and 107 pints at the American Tobacco Company, both in Manhattan.

CAIRO, June 24 -- A Cairo Government spokesman hinted strongly tonight that Egypt would align herself with the neutralist bloc of Asian nations in an effort to end British "imperialist" occupation of the Suez Canal zone.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 24 -- The Rabbinical Assembly of America urged President Eisenhower here today to assert his leadership in his party and in the country "by repudiating in emphatic terms the tactics of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican, and other legislators" in the investigation of communism.

PARIS, June 24 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, retiring Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, who is to become Chief of Staff of the United States Army, pointedly asked civilian governmental delegates on the North Atlantic Council here today to speed up action on recommendations, made five months ago, for a more effective defense of West Europe.

A proposed Constitutional amendment to limit the President's power to make treaties and Executive agreements was assailed yesterday by a committee of the New York State Bar Association as "unnecessary, unwise, divisive and dangerous'' and opposed to the security of the United States.
MOSCOW, June 24 -- The Moscow radio announced late today the opening of subscriptions for a 15,000,000,000-ruble 1953 state loan -- just half the size of the loans issued in the last two years.

Unfortunately, all of the civic recitals that the public has had from Mayor Impellitteri in recent months have been in one note -- the state is to blame for everything and is driving the city into disaster in spite of the best -- even heroic -- efforts of the city administration to save the situation.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 24 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair took a one-stroke lead in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's thirtieth annual medal-play championship by firing a 3-over-par 38, 40 -- 78 over the lower course of the Baltusrol Club today.

SYRACUSE, June 24 -- The first break in the upper ranks of the national intercollegiate tennis champion occurred today with the defeat of three of the eight men who were expected to gain the quarter-final brackets.

Tom Lyon acted wisely yesterday in asking that his nomination as Director of the Federal Bureau of Mines be withdrawn. His action was prompt and necessary because his own testimony before the Senate Interior Committee proved his lack of qualification for this particular post.

The acquisition by the Johns-Manville Corporation of a recently discovered asbestos ore deposit in northern Ontario was announced yesterday by A. R. Fisher, president. The property is in the vicinity of the company's Munro asbestos mine and mill in Reeves Township, near Matheson.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Eisenhower and his Congressional leaders agreed today on the use of extraordinary parliamentary measures to force action on continuation of the excess profits tax, but the first such move soon bogged down.

Walter P. Hedden, for ten years the director of port development for the Port of New York Authority and an employe of the bi-state agency since 1922, will retire tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, chairman. He is 55 years old.

TRENTON, June 24 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll took the stand today and testified under oath as the final witness before the legislative committee investigating the dismissal of Nelson F. Stamler as deputy attorney general. For five hours and twenty minutes he sought to deny or explain away the charges placed against him by previous witnesses.

BURTONWOOD, England, June 24 -- Lord De L'Isle and Dudley, the Air Minister, gave his official blessing today to an Anglo-American Hospitality Committee holding its first meeting at the United States Air Force base here.

The thirty-four-family apartment house at 814 East 181st Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by the B. C. Holding Corporation, headed by Isidor Kaufman, from Rose Gross. It is assessed at $100,000. Pearce, Mayer Greer were brokers and title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

ATHENS, June 24 -- Bulgaria's expression of a willingness to accept a Greek proposal to cooperate in a settlement of frontier differences is regarded in Greek official circles as another move in the Kremlin's peace offensive and not one of much importance.

BONN, Germany, June 24 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer appealed today to Erich Ollenhauer, leader of the Social Democratic party, to join with the West Germany Government in carrying out a bipartisan foreign policy in view of the events in East Germany.

A former infantry landing craft, stripped to the hull and rebuilt as a gay excursion craft, was entered into service yesterday by the Day Line Sightseeing Company, an affiliate of the Hudson River Day Line.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- A $14,000,000 air-conditioned hotel, with a drive-in lobby, 1,000 rooms and a 1,400-seat ballroom, will be erected as a part of the Penn Center development by the Sheraton Corporation of America.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 24 -- The latest tournament to come under the sponsorship of the United States Golf Association will get under way tomorrow when the women's open championship will be played at the Country Club of Rochester course.

MILWAUKEE, June 24 (UP) -- The Pirates moved out of the National League cellar tonight by defeating the league-leading Braves for the second straight time, piling up six runs in the eighth inning to score a 10-to-1 victory.

A badly split City Planning Commission overrode the wishes of Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority yesterday by rejecting the $15,500,000 Ulmer Park housing project in Brooklyn and removing the project from the master plan.

RENO, Nev., June 24 (AP) -- The Max C. Fleischmann Foundation of Nevada announced today another million dollars in gifts to hospitals, schools, churches and conservation programs throughout the country.

AMSTERDAM, N. Y., June 24 -- Five places where the state's first Thruway -- the old Erie Canal and the expanded barge canal system -- had to be shifted in the Mohawk Valley to make way for the motor Thurway were visited today by fifty state officials inspecting construction progress of the main 427-mile New York to Buffalo route of the superhighway.
The cotton futures market closed 4 to 27 points lower, with trading on the New York Cotton Exchange fairly heavy all day.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 24 -- Bolero, the big, beautiful black yawl owned by John Nicholas Brown, commodore of the New York Yacht Club, became the winner of the Newport-to-Annapolis ocean race tonight.

ALBANY, June 24 -- Prompt enactment of Governor Dewey's recommendations for eliminating waterfront racketeering appeared assured tonight as legislators began assembling for an extraordinary session of the Legislature called to start at noon tomorrow.

OGDEN, Utah, June 24 (AP) -- Archie Moore of California held on tenaciously to his world light heavyweight championship tonight, taking a unanimous fifteen-round decision over Joey Maxim of Cleveland in Utah's first title bout.

Five thousand six hundred "horses," all packed in one engine, are being offered to the airlines of the United States and foreign flag operators for the first time in the history of United Aircraft Corporation of East Hartford, Conn. The powerful turboprop power plant is produced by the company's Pratt Whitney aircraft division.

ARMONK, N. Y., June 24 -- The former Embassy Country Club's thirty-room clubhouse north of here was destroyed by fire shortly after 5 P. M. today. The sprawling structure of English stone-and-timber design had been a fabulous night club in the Prohibition era, patronized by New York's business, social and political leaders.

Mysterious things happen daily in a certain corner of the restaurant of the Dixie Hotel, 250 West Forty-third Street. The mystery involves the knives and forks, the glasses, the matches and the salt and pepper shakers on the luncheon table around which a group of business and professional men gather.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., June 24 -- Dedication ceremonies for the Long Island Lighting Company's new central operating headquarters, said by company officials to be the first installation of its type in the country were held at its main building here today.

MEXICO CITY, June 23 -- The Federal Government was reported today to have expropriated in eastern Mexico 10,000 acres of rich agricultural land owned by four men who were close friends of former President Miguel Aleman.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The House Commerce Committee will investigate recent rises in gasoline and oil prices.

The official opening of the New York office of the National Congress of American Indians and its affiliate, Arrow, Inc., at 680 Fifth Avenue, was marked yesterday with the presentation to Indian leaders of a check for $22,500 for a mobile health education center for the Navajo Indians at Crown Point, N. M.

HONOLULU, June 24 -- Some 300 delegates met here today in an emergency convention of territorial locals of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, independent. The purpose of the two-day sessions, a spokesman said, is to consider union strategy in the light of the conviction of its Hawaii regional director.
" Situation unchanged" was the report early today from wage review talks between shipyard workers and two of the larger East Coast shipbuilding and ship repair companies.

Emanuel H. Bloch, attorney for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, is to be asked by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York for an explanation of the "murder" charge he made last Sunday against President Eisenhower.

Wladyslawa Grabowska and Sergej Lubelski shuffled uneasily in the manager's office in the Times Square branch of the Chase National Bank at Seventh Avenue and Forty-first Street yesterday. They were worried about having been called to the bank.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 25 -- South Korean President Syngman Rhee appealed today to the United Nations to allow the young republic to fight on alone in the struggle against communism and promised that the struggle would be "to the death."

Samuel Reshevsky of New York succeeded in averting imminent defeat in the thirteenth game, which had been adjourned, in his chess match with Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires, according to a report received yesterday from Argentina.

VIENNA, June 24 -- The Communist press of the Hungarian regime appears to fear a revolt of the workers like that which recently occurred in Czechoslovakia and East Germany and has apparently determined to head it off by appeasing them in advance.

Prize-winners in a national "housewives" contest, held by the Christophers, were announced yesterday. Thousands of entries, each of which was a true story illustrating "what a housewife can do, with God's help, to change the world for the better," were received from more than 100 cities.

LONDON, June 24 -- Britain's foreign policy experts are pondering various additional measures to bring the South Korean Government into line with United Nations policy and get a truce in the Korean war.

STANTON, Del., June 24 (AP) -- The Llangollen Farm's home-bred colt Porterhouse accounted for his third triumph in four starts at Delaware Park today as he led home seven other juveniles in the sixteenth and richest Christiana Stakes:

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 24 (UP) -- Thasian Hero set a new track record in winning the first division of the $15,000-added Long-fellow Handicap today over the turf course at Monmouth Park and Euclid galloped to victory in the second division.

PITTSBURGH, June 24 -- The creation of an advertising and research fund to be tapped in times of business decline to stimulate sales was proposed today by a tax expert in an address before the thirty-first conference of the National Advertising Association.

R. K. O. Radio Pictures will release a group of twelve features in color during the next six months, according to James R. Grainger, president, who said that the program represented the heaviest use of color to date by the company.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 24 (AP) -- The husband-wife archers, Lloyd and Anne Corby of Boonton, N. J., retained wide leads in their respective divisions today in the Eastern Association tournament at Springfield College.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 (UP) -- The results of the other leading matches today at Wimbledon:

Michael Todd brings back "A Night in Venice" for a second season at the Jones Beach (L. I.) Theatre tonight at 8:30 o'clock. The musical extravaganza, which has a score by Johann Strauss and book and lyrics by Ruth and Thomas Martin, will offer Jack Russell and Nola Fairbanks in the romantic singing roles.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 17, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 287 Korean war casualties in the longest daily list issued since the heavy fighting last fall.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (UP) -- The House Banking Committee, in response to complaints from builders, voted today to repeal a Veterans Administration order banning discounts on G. I. home-loan mortgages.

Donald T. Forsythe, editor and publisher of The Carthage (Ill.) Journal, was elected by acclamation president of the Kiwanis International yesterday on the third day of the thirty-eighth annual convention in Madison Square Garden.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 24 -- Sir Arthur Fadden, the Acting Prime Minister, announced in Canberra tonight the next tests of atomic weapons by the British Government with the assistance of the Australian Government would be in an isolated area on the Woomera rocket range in central Australia.

LEFTY GOMEZ had just been belted all over the lot. Bobby Feller had allowed almost no hits. But thanks to a home run by Joe DiMaggio, the Singular One staggered off the mound with a 1-0 victory. That's when the frisky Gomez uttered one of his memorable statements.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The national convention of the American Red Cross voted today to wage a country-wide campaign against damaging canards, such as the often-told untruth that the Red Cross sells blood in Korea.

CINCINNATI, June 24 -- For the second straight evening a homerun pitch in the ninth inning beat the Dodgers when tonight Gus Bell whaled Jim Hughes' first delivery deep into the right-field bleachers with two mates aboard to gain a 7-4 victory for the Redlegs.

" Money invested in a library gives much better returns than mining stock." That was the sage observation of Sir William Osler in 1908. It is a piece of advice that has been taken to heart by many business organizations in the Greater New York area which have developed some 670 specialized libraries to serve special needs.

A cooperative program of higher education that would enable graduate students to attend universities in different countries while preparing for degrees was suggested yesterday by Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, as a means of promoting world understanding and culture.

At the luncheon of the Urban League of Greater New York officials of Mount Sinai Hospital and the New York County Medical Society expressed a willingness to discuss the controversy that has arisen over the clinic that Herman Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, and Mount Sinai want to establish in Carver Houses, a state-aided project.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP) -- The last-place Tigers defeated the almost as lowly Athletics for the second straight time tonight, 6 -- 3, as the winning pitcher, Ned Garver, survived a three-run Philadelphia flurry in the eighth inning. Steve Souchock's two-run homer headed a four-run Tiger rally in the first.

For the first time in three years fresh pineapples from Mexico are appearing in stores here. Shipments, which have been arriving weekly since April, will continue through August. They supplement the larger supplies we receive from Cuba and Puerto Rico.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Tom Lyon of Salt Lake City, who testified that he was receiving a $5,000 revocable pension annually from the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, withdrew himself today from consideration as director of the Federal Bureau of Mines with the assertion that the 1952 Federal Mine Safety Law was a "phony."
SEOUL, Korea, June 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Syngman Rhee's letter to Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations commander, dated June 20:

HONG KONG, June 24 -- Chinese Communist soldiers were reported today to have set up barbed wire barriers along the street leading past the Church of Christ the King in Shanghai to block off a group of Chinese Roman Catholics who had been protesting the round-up of foreign Catholic priests there June 15.

BERLIN, June 24 -- The three Western commandants in Berlin sent a note today to Maj. Gen. P. T. Dibrova, their Soviet counterpart, rejecting his contention that agents from West Berlin were responsible for the riots in the Soviet sector last Wednesday.
A colorful cross section of Australian wildlife, the largest ever to come here from the land down under, arrived yesterday aboard the United States Lines freighter Pioneer Sea.

Reflecting new capital issues by sales finance companies, there was a $146,000,000 drop in New York bank loans to business in the week ended on Wednesday -- the sharpest decline since the week ended on July 2.

Since the end of World War II there has been a large increase in the number of Jews on farms in the United States in contrast to the decline in farm population generally, Theodore Norman, general manager of the Jewish Agricultural Society, Inc., said yesterday in his 1952 report.

CINCINNATI, June 25 -- The Dodgers snapped their losing streak at four games today at Crosley Field and did it with considerable violence. Loosing a sixteen-hit barrage, including five home runs, on three pitchers, they scored a 12-3 victory over the Redlegs and headed for Milwaukee tonight hoping to erase the leading Braves' two-game edge over them.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, June 25 -- The most realistic "war alert" yet staged by Supreme Alied Headquarters here ended successfully today after nine days of intense activity modeled on what might be expected to happen if war were to break out in Europe.
HOUSTON, Tex., June 25 -- The Lutheran Church, Missouri Synod, asked its twenty-nine districts in the United States today to assume responsibility for Negro mission programs.
LONDON, June 25 -- The stock markets here recovered today from their depression of the past few days. Quiet buying, especially for industrials, resulted in many price rises.

BOSTON, June 25 -- Life insurance companies have a $1,700,000,000 stake in the New England economy, it was reported today by the Boston University College of Business Administration. The assets of New England's life insurance companies total $12,800,000,000, or one-fifth of the national total, the report added.

Leaders of the Liberal party intend to ask representatives of the Republican party today if they will accept Representative Jacob K. Javits, a Republican, as the Republican candidate for Mayor as the first step toward naming a coalition city ticket.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 25 -- The purely functional house was decried at several meetings here today at the annual conference of the American. Home Economics Association.

A need to improve international relations through trade and investment was emphasized yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council in announcing plans for the fortieth National Foreign Trade Convention, Nov. 16-18, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The appointment by Pope Plus XII of Bishop Bryan J. McEntegart of Ogdensburg as rector of the Catholic University of America here was announced today by Archbishop Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, and Archbishop Patrick A. O'Boyle of this city.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman told freshmen House Democrats today they should work hard and be loyal to their leaders if they want to get ahead in Congress.

Offhand, this might appear to be a matter of interest only to a lawyer or to another aphis, but it developed from a Flatbush Magistrate's Court hearing yesterday afternoon that Brooklyn's famed Norway maple trees were full of aphides.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- Undaunted by a negative response from the administration in British Togoland to his plea that he be granted a scholarship, a 54-year-old minister has dispatched a petition to the standing committee of the United Nations Trusteeship Council, which reviewed his communication today.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 25 -- Leaders of the railroad industry of North and South America were told here today that one of the more important problems confronting the railroad electrical engineers is how to produce enough current to supply the increasing number of electric-powered devices incorporated in modern railroad cars.

HONG KONG, June 25 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt arrived here today from Japan and said in an airfield interview that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. Republican of Wisconsin, would cease to be a "headline" once the American people realized that "safety lies in knowledge and not in fear."

BOSTON, June 25 (AP) -- Tommy Collins of Boston, obviously suffering from the after-effects of his recent ten-knockdown beating by the lightweight champion, Jimmy Carter, lost to Teddy (Redtop) Davis of Hartford, Conn., on a technical knockout in 1:29 of the tenth and last round tonight at the Boston Garden.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- The House of Representatives, facing the biggest United States wheat surplus in history, voted today to relax production controls on the 1954 crop so that growers would have to cut plantings only 15 per cent.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, June 25 (UP) -- The Brazilian currency remained steady today, closing at 45 cruzeiros to a dollar, against 53 last Saturday, despite Finance Minister Oswaldo Aranha's disclosure that Brazil owes $1,000,000,000 in world markets, or about $400,000,000 more than generally believed.

GENEVA, June 25 -- True to assurances given early in the current Soviet "peace offensive" at the spring meeting of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, a Russian timber trader turned up today at the opening of a European timber experts meeting.
Permit me to comment on the June 20 dispatch of M. S. Handler, in which the belief is expressed that a strong underground organization of workers exists in Eastern Germany.

Detailed plans for the science building, the second of fourteen structures scheduled in the long-range $25,000,000 expansion program of St. John's University, are now being made by Henry V. Murphy, architect, of 1 Hanson Place, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Administration leaders scored a victory tonight in their fight to force a vote in the House of Representatives on continuation of the excess-profits tax as the Rules Committee voted to bring a modified extension bill to the floor.

AUGUST STRAUSS, chosen the other day as sixth president of the 124-year-old Fulton Market Fishmongers Association, owns among other odd papers a check for $5.26 drawn on the Hide and Leather National Bank of New York by the firm of fishmongers, Wilson Barry.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- With a show of candor as rare as it was refreshing in a man occupying his position, the Republican national chairman, Leonard W. Hall, has given one of the reasons why the President's program is having hard sledding in Congress so soon after General Eisenhower's overwhelming victory at the polls of 1952.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 25 -- The American Association of University Women voted unanimously today at its biennial convention to continue its support of participation in the United Nations and of a foreign policy designed to develop conditions favorable to democracy and economic well-being throughout the world.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- A spokesman for the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., today reported collapse of negotiations aimed at settlement of a seamen's walkout that has tied up seventeen oil tankers in Great Lakes ports.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 25 -- A proposal to create a uniform system of public defenders to protect the rights of persons who are charged with offense against the law and do not have funds to hire their own lawyers was referred to the Department of Justice for study today by the Twenty-third Judicial Conference of the Fourth Circuit.

In formally announcing his candidacy for Mayor of New York Representative Jacob K. Javits laid great stress on the necessity for a coalition ticket that would unite all good government forces in this city in a solid front against the Democratic machine.

ALBANY, June 25 -- The Republican-controlled Legislature beat down today an attempt by Democratic lawmakers to force the New York City Transit Authority to postpone any increase in fares until after next fall's Mayoralty election.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- A security slip was disclosed today with publication of recent testimony about military secrets by Army officials before a House of Representatives Appropriations subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A former State Department official told the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today that the biggest single contribution to infiltration of subversives into that department was the transfer to it in 1945 of five war agencies, most, if not all of them, targets for Soviet espionage.

GLEN COVE. L. I., June 25 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks, the newly corwned Metropolitan champion, gained the final round of the twenty-third Women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship with a 6-and-4 victory over Mrs. Saul Weinsier of Fresh Meadow at the Nassau County Club today.

ESTES PARK, Colo., June 25 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis called today for the passage by Congress of the genocide resolution, repeal of the McCarran-Walter immigration law and the defeat of the Bricker amendment.
The Peruvian vocalist Yma. Sumac was a featured performer in the Latin-American concert offered by the Stadium Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium last evening.

Steve Allen will be master of ceremonies for a new variety program, to be presented over Channel 4 Mondays through Fridays from 11:20 P. M. to midnight, beginning July 27. The regular cast will include Bill Lawrence, singer, and a female vocalist still to be selected.

The Red Cross opened its new air-conditioned blood donor center in the New York Chapter House, Thirty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue, at 10 A. M. yesterday, without fanfare and on a "business as usual" basis.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- Declaring that the Korean situation was deteriorating, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India called today for a "very early meeting" of the United Nations General Assembly to discuss what was to be done as a result of the release of prisoners in the custody of South Korea.
Operations of the Bulova Watch Company in the fiscal year ended March 31 resulted in increased earnings, according to the annual report issued to stockholders yesterday by John H. Ballard, president.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Dr. Arthur S. Flemming, president of Ohio Wesleyan University, was sworn in today as Defense Mobilizer at an unusual White House ceremony.

Despite Cardinal Spellman's denunciation of "The Moon Is Blue" as being "an occasion of sin" and a violation of "standards of morality and decency," the motion picture will have its local premiere, as previously scheduled, at both the Victoria and Sutton Theatres on Thursday, July 9, a spokesman for United Artists distributors of the romantic comedy, said yesterday.

PARIS, June 25 -- Marshal Alphonse Pierre Juin, commander of the central European sector of North Atlantic Treaty forces, spoke out today against "pressure" on France to abandon Morocco that he said was being exerted by both totalitarian and "seemingly" liberal forces.

The consumer price index (often loosely referred to as the cost-of-living index) advanced between mid-April and mid-May for the third consecutive month. The combined result of these three monthly advances has been to bring the index back to 114, which is within less than three-tenths of one per cent of the post-Korean peak. That peak, 114.3, was reached twice in 1952 -- in August, and again in November.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, June 26 -- The Republic of Korea Government has drawn up plans for further drastic measures that would cause embarrassment to the United Nations Command should future negotiations between President Syngman Rhee and the United Nations Command concerning a truce acceptable to South Korea prove fruitless.

Volume continued yesterday at the slightly higher levels reached earlier this week on the New York commodity exchanges. Cottonseed oil again registered the greatest activity since May 8 and soybean oil had the largest volume since June 2. Prices were irregular with sugar, potatoes, cocoa, wool and hides mixed. Coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and copper were higher and zinc, lead, tin and rubber closed lower.

ONCE upon a time a record-breaker first indicated that he was approaching when he was far off in the distance so that an observer could watch him every inch of the way. Nowadays, though, they just burst in on a guy suddenly and startle him out of a year's growth. Where do they come from anyway?

ST. LOUIS, June 25 -- Members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People were urged tonight to begin at once a series of community programs designed to promote acceptance of legal decisions outlawing segregation and discrimination.

ST. LOUIS, June 25 -- The insufferable heat currently frying the Midwest may not be the Giants burning up the National League, but this much can be said on the subject: Our Polo Grounders, who for so long had been running nowhere in the race, definitely seem to be on the move.

BLOOMFIELD N. J., June 25 -- Four college sophomores scored a pair of victories today and advanced to the semi-final round of the Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship at the Forest Hill Field Club.

Magistrate Albert D. Schanzer dismissed a disorderly conduct charge yesterday in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, on the grounds that the defendant, instead of causing a crowd to collect, had, in fact, caused a crowd to disappear.
There is something new on the cathode midway -- a program peopled by former United States Senators. Incumbents cannot qualify for admission.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Department of Justice and the Bureau of Internal Revenue were asked today by Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat Of Manhattan, to check for possible violations of corrupt practices, lobbying and tax statute violations by New York electric utility companies.

LOS ANGELES, June 25 -- The American Library Association, with a membership of 21,000, in concert with the American Book Publishers Council today promulgated a declaration of principles espousing complete freedom in the circulation of books and denouncing efforts to limit literary expression and inquiry as incompatible with democracy.

Some practical aspects of child guidance were discussed yesterday noon by Dr. Peter Neubauer with a group of counselors before they left for camp. Amidst suitcases, coffee cups and sandwiches, more than one hundred young men and women, all of whom will take over some of the duties of parents in camps operated by the Community Service Society, were gathered at society headquarters, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Department, store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 13 per cent above those in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 25 -- Bolero, the 73-foot yawl owned by John Nicholas Brown, New York Yacht Club Commodore, was lying in Spa Creek tonight with her lazaret loaded with silverware.

WITH reasonable cooperation from the weather man, this week-end should provide some excitement for the offshore angler, for a half-dozen school tuna have been brought in during the past three days and the vanguard of the large schools may move in closer to the coast within a few days.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Eisenhower is understood to have sent to President Syngman Rhee of South Korea a proposal that Dr. Rhee leave Korea for a conference with "very high officials" of the United States in an attempt to find a common front in the truce crisis.

Agreement on a new one-year contract between East and Gulf Coast shipowners and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, C. I. O., was reached at 2 A. M. yesterday on a basis parallel with that which ended a four-day maritime strike last Saturday.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Senators set some kind of a record today by passing an annual Federal housing bill in less than five minutes and with almost no debate or discussion.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- A new battle over color television was opened today by the Radio Corporation of America.

WHEN Eric Maria Remarque wrote a novel about the horrors of war and called it "All Quiet on the Western Front" he expressed the front-line soldier's reaction to official communiques that concern themselves only with major actions and masses of men. But men meet death on an individual basis and die as bravely and sometimes as uselessly in minor skirmishes as in world-famous battles.
Evidence came to light yesterday that the reorganized. Federal Trade Commission is using the method of conference and compromise to keep manufacturers in line.
PARIS, June 25 -- Robert Schuman, former Foreign Minister, is now urging a negotiated peace in Indo-China and a Four-Power conference to unify Germany, with security guarantees to the Soviet Union.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 25 -- Patty Berg set a course record with a 71 as she assumed the lead in the first round of the United States Golf Association women's open championship at the Rochester Country Club today.

The third volume in Maxwell Geismar's five-volume study of the novel in America has been scheduled for Sept. 17 publication by Houghton Mifflin. It will be titled "Rebels and Ancestors." The work focuses on the literary scene from 1890 to 1915 and in particular on the works of Frank Norris, Stephen Crane, Jack London, Ellen Glasgow and Theodore Dreiser.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Southwestern cattlemen pleaded today for quick Government aid in the form of emergency credit, lower-priced feed and action to strengthen sagging prices.

ALBANY, June 25 -- The State Civil Service Commission put into motion today the machinery of a two-year-old law enacted at Governor Dewey's request to weed subversive employes out of the state service.

Rarely has the Soviet citizen so much trouble keeping straight with the party line as in the last few weeks. Since Stalin's death, so many of yesterday's truths have become today's errors and yesterday's villains become today's heroes, or vice versa, that the Soviet citizen trying to keep up with it all must be reminded of the great turnabouts that followed first the Nazi-Soviet Pact of 1939 and then the Nazi attack of 1941.

New York and Westchester officials who have been commuters on the Putnam Division of the New York Central System appeared yesterday to oppose the dropping of six trains on this line at a hearing before the Public Service Commission, 233 Broadway.

Capt. Herbert E. Berger, assistant chief of staff for personnel to the commandant of the Third Naval District, will round out thirty-five years of active duty when he retires next Tuesday. He is 53 years old.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 25 -- "Hazel Flagg," the Broadway musical hit that stems from the 1937 movie, "Nothing Sacred," is under-stood to have been acquired by Paramount and will be re-tailored to suit the comedy dimensions of Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis.

A beautiful and serenely unscientific-looking sailing vessel slipped into New York Harbor yesterday afternoon carrying some very scientific evidence designed to settle a long-standing argument among geologists and oceanographers.

Whether the punishment of the Rosenbergs was excessive or not there is a lesson in the manner in which their lives were brought to an end which we should do well to ponder. I do not see how any civilized and sensitive human being can fail to be disgusted by the accounts of their deaths which appeared in the press.
TOKYO, Friday, June 27 -- South Korean President Syngman Rhee met for two hours and forty-five minutes today with Assistant Secretary of State Walter S. Robertson.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield proposed today that Congress order higher postal rates to bring in $240,625,000 more revenue each year.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended June 20, 1953, totaled 812,578 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 15,153 cars, or 1.9 per cent more than for the preceding week, 168,609, or 26.2 per cent more than for the corresponding per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago. week last year and 20,364, or 2.4

ITHACA, N. Y., June 25 -- Although individuals and organizations in many nations are working to strengthen family life, only the United States has undertaken seriously to study family life as part of its educational program, Dr. Muriel Brown said today.

SYRACUSE, June 25 -- With a superior order of tennis that bore the stamp of authority in the fluency and dispatch of his strokes from every quarter, Hamilton Richardson of Tulane defeated John Ricksen of California, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, today in the national intercollegiate tennis championship.

Premier De Gasperi won an easy first round of the parliamentary battle in Italy yesterday when Christian Democratic candidates were elected to the presidencies of the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate. His troubles are only beginning, but it still looks as if the small majorities which the Center coalition holds will permit him to form a democratic Government to tide over the summer months.

TRENTON, June 25 -- The New Jersey Legislature adopted today a resolution calling for a constitutional amendment to legalize bingo. At the same time, it approved the so-called Waterfront Commission Act, which is designed to establish adequate controls over the Port of New York waterfront.
Gloria Swanson won yesterday a breach of contract suit brought in Supreme Court by a producer who said he had aided her in her screen comeback.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 25 (AP) -- Three seeded entries, headed by top-ranked David Harum of Coral Gables, Fla., and an outsider, Donald Dell of Bethesda, Md., gained the semi-finals of the national interscholastic tennis tournament today.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Most furniture dealers at the summer home furnishings market are displaying an "ultra - conservative" buying policy that may mean a scramble for available goods this fall, Clyne Crawford, president of the Crawford Furniture Corporation of Jamestown, N. Y., warned today at the American Furniture Mart.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, and David J. McDonald, head of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., held a secret meeting yesterday in Washington, and scheduled further talks in the future.

LONDON, June 25 -- A bipartisan furor of protest greeted an attack on the United States in the House of Commons today. The attack, an aftermath of the executions of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg for espionage, was disavowed by the leaders of both the Conservative and Labor parties.

The Federal Reserve Board's move to unfreeze more than $1,100,000,000 of bank money now immobilized in statutory reserves caused the bond market to stage its best demonstration of strength yesterday since the central bank put the market for Treasury securities on a free basis in 1951.

The Treasury's big June overdraft on the Federal Reserve System has been cut to $296,000,000, according to latest report, reflecting a reduction of $527,000,000 from a total direct borrowing from the central bank which at one time reached $823,000,000.

Paul R. Ducey, a Columbia University graduate student of anthropology, embarked here yesterday on a year's trip to Scotland, made possible by three traveling scholarships awarded for his outstanding academic record.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 25 -- Kenya's security forces had another successful day today after establishing yesterday a twenty-four hours record for the number of Mau Mau terrorists killed. Today, patrols along the edge of the Aberdare Forest area and in the reserves killed thirty-one presumed Mau Mau.

Thomas May, described by the Government as "a strong-arm man" on the East River piers, told Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan yesterday that he was willing to appear before a special Federal grand jury investigating waterfront crime. Judge Ryan then postponed May's sentence on an extortion charge until next Thursday.
A new aspect has been added to the business of electric power production in Belgium.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The State Department said today that more than 300 book titles by about eighteen authors had been removed from United States libraries abroad under specific directives to rid the Government's overseas information program of works by Communist, pro-Communist or "controversial" writers.

A. C. Rudy has been appointed manager of the New York sales branch of the Berger Manufacturing division of Republic Steel Corporation, and C. K. Reynolds has been named manager of steel kitchen sales.

Even in the sunny summertime rainy days occur. They give vacationing school children a good chance to go into the kitchen and develop their culinary capabilities. Cooking can be fun for children even if their mothers who must do it daily do not always think so.

Consulting engineers to the New York City Transit Authority told the city's new transit managers yesterday that $14,843,000 in savings were possible in the next few years through improved operation of the municipal subway, elevated and surface lines.
The first wave of the estimated 250,000 city youngsters who will enjoy summer residence and day camping programs this season surged through railroad and bus terminals yesterday.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 25 -- The long parade of witnesses refusing to answer Congressional investigators' questions on subversion has brought the Constitutional privilege against self-incrimination into "popular disfavor," the New York State Bar Association's Committee on Civil Rights said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 (AP) -- Western Union president Walter Marshall said today that his communications company would proceed with negotiations with the Bell Telephone System "at the earliest possible date" to take over "TWX" and leased wire circuits now owned by the telephone company.
An off-duty probationary Nassau County policeman shot and killed a motorist last night after they had argued and exchanged blows on the Belt Parkway in Rosedale, Queens.

The American Enka Corporation announced yesterday that it had been granted a certificate of necessity by the Office of Defense Mobilization to cover the construction of a new nylon plant. The certificate authorizes a write-off over a five-year period of 40 per cent of an estimated cost of $35,000,000. J. E. Bassill, president, said that the location of the new plant would not be fixed until the completion of surveys now under way.

LONDON, June 25 -- Not only political issues but also military and atomic energy questions may be discussed at the three-power conference in Bermuda, it was indicated today by the list of associates and advisers who will accompany Sir Winston Churchill, the British Prime Minister, to the meeting.

MANILA, June 25 -- A fresh political storm was brewing today over President Elpidio Quirino's refusal to delegate the powers of his office to Vice President Fernando Lopez during his indefinite absence in the United States. Mr. Quirino is flying from Manila to Baltimore Saturday for diagnosis and treatment of his persistently plaguing ill health.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 25 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India said today he found the United States and the Soviet Union strikingly alike in their "worship of technology," however far apart they might be on political and economic questions.

Prospects for a peaceful settlement of the wage review dispute involving more than 30,000 East Coast shipyard workers appeared brighter yesterday despite reports of no progress as negotiators met only briefly and recessed until today.
President Eisenhower has challenged the Communists anew to hold free elections in Soviet satellite countries.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- An exhibition that proves that traditional furniture and traditional styles still bear a strong relationship to today's living opened here this morning on the seventeenth floor of the Merchandise Mart. Called "Today in Tradition," the display is made up of seventy pieces in thirteen settings, each arrangement confined to pieces copied from, adapted from or influenced by a single important period style.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A United States District Judge, stressing the duty of the judiciary to protect civilian rights from invasion by military authority, ordered the Air Force today to return former Sgt. Robert W. Toth to this country from Korea, where he had been taken to face a murder charge before a court martial.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -- The Athletics salvaged the third and final game of their series with the Tigers tonight as Harry Byrd pitched a 5-2 victory. He struck out eight batters, including all three in the fifth inning.

Dr. Jacob Greenberg, associate superintendent of schools since 1934, was designated yesterday by the Board of Education as deputy superintendent to succeed the late Dr. Frederic Ernst. Dr. Greenberg has been in charge of the division of personnel and teacher training.
VIENNA, June 25 (AP) -- William H. Hale, former New York author, has announced his resignation as chief of the United States High Commission's Office of Public Affairs in Austria.

Emanuel H. Bloch, attorney for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, atomic spies who were put to death in Sing Sing last Friday, said yesterday they died paupers. They made handwritten wills in the death house the day they went to the electric chair, he said, naming him administrator of their estate and guardian of their children, Michael, 10 years old, and Robert, 6.

SEOUL, Korea, June 25 -- An estimated 300,000 persons turned out in Seoul today to hear Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President, plead the cause of unification of North and South Korea. Today was the third anniversary of the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The House voted today to dispose of the Government's wartime synthetic rubber plants to private enterprise, thereby taking the United States out of the rubber business. Some twenty-eight plants built at a cost to the Government of $518,347,000 would go on sale to qualified bidders.
Earlier this week at the National Chicken Cooking Contest at Harrington, Del., Mrs. Frank H. Tharp of Lewes, Del., won $500 for the following fried chicken recipe:

MILWAUKEE, June 25 (UP) -- Johnny Lindell hit a three-run pinch homer in the ninth inning to tie the score and the Pirates went on to defeat the league-leading Braves in twelve innings, 6 to 4, today.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 25 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair, the defending champion, at the end of thirty-six holes held a 3-stroke lead today in the women's New Jersey Association's thirtieth annual fifty-four-hole medal play championship.

BONN, Germany, June 25 -- The Bundestag, lower and decisive house of the Bonn Parliament, adopted a new electoral law today that is aimed at guaranteeing the return of a stable majority in the forthcoming general elections.

The six-family apartment house at 264 Linwood Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Rose Van Inderstine to Joseph Anetrello. Enrico DeMartino was the broker and the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company insured title.

En route to a 4-2 victory over the Yankees at the Stadium yesterday, the White Sox employed two pitchers, five first basemen, two third basemen, a couple of catchers and a pinch-hitter, yet only fourteen Chicagoans played in the game.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Eisenhower issued today an Executive Order withdrawing Civil Service protection from about 134,000 Federal jobs, thus making it possible to dismiss Democrats holding confidential or policy-making positions.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, June 26 (AP) -- More than 13,000 Chinese Communists hit the western and eastern Korean fronts early today. In both sectors, furious fighting raged after daybreak.
Cotton futures closed irregular here yesterday, 5 points lower to 8 points higher than on Wednesday.

Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said here yesterday that the United States was becoming realistic in its attitude toward the United Nations and learning that it was not an automatic peace maker.
At a meeting here yesterday of the Cinerama Production Corporation, stockholders approved transfer of the company's production and exhibition rights to the Stanley Warner Corporation.
Samuel Reshevsky of New York recaptured the lead in his chess match with Miguel Najdorf of Argentina for the championship of the West, according to a report from Buenos Aires yesterday.
NEWARK, June 25 -- Approval of an increase of $18,250,000 in annual revenue was asked today by the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company of the Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

CLEVELAND, June 25 (AP) -- Jack Burke Jr. and Ellsworth Vines today fired a pair of 66's -- a half-dozen strokes under par -- to share the first-round lead in the $15,000 Manakiki open golf tournament.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 -- Jaroslav Drobny defeated Budge Patty, 8 -- 6, 16 -- 18, 3 -- 6, 8 -- 6, 12 -- 10, today in a tennis match that lasted more than four hours and required ninety-three games, the longest singles contest in modern Wimbledon history. It was one of the finest matches seen here since the war.

GARRISON, N. Y., June 25 -- An enlarged building for St. Christopher's Inn, which for more than fifty years has been giving food and shelter to homeless men and asking no questions, will be dedicated Saturday and put right to work.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- Allegations that many draft boards across the country are permitting draftees to escape Army service by deliberately failing aptitude tests, were made this afternoon at the twenty-seventh annual convention of the Reserve Officers Association.

The skeleton of a baby, believed by its finder to have been placed in the foundation of a biblical city wall as a sacrifice about 4,000 years ago, was brought here yesterday from Arab-Palestine by Prof. Joseph P. Free, archaelogist of Wheaton College, Wheaton, Ill.
TRENTON, June 25 (AP) -- Corporations may make donations to charitable and educational institutions, the New Jersey. Supreme Court ruled today.

CLEVELAND, June 25 -- A move to oust Paul R. Hutchings as president was launched today when delegates to the Office Employes Union, A. F. L., nominated Howard E. Coughlin of New York, now a vice president, to oppose him in tomorrow's election.

ST. LOUIS, June 25 -- Walter White, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said today he had sent a telegram to Secretary of State John Foster Dulles asking why his book, "A Rising Wind," had been banned from United States Information Service libraries in Bombay and Calcutta, India.

The recorded voice of City Council President Rudolph Halley charging that the war veterans living in the temporary housing colony at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, were up against "big dough" in their efforts to extend the existence of the project touched off a dispute yesterday in the Board of Estimate.

A petition submitted by parents that sought to force the Board of Education to renovate or give up the 96-year-old public school at Ninth Avenue and Fourteenth Street was rejected yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 25 -- Eleven Olympic champions headed the blue ribbon collection of nearly 400 athletes who assembled here today for the Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor track and field championships.

The 65-year-old widow of a former New York detective lost her life yesterday in a fire that swept her bedroom, where she was confined as an invalid. Another woman, who was in the kitchen when the flames broke out, suffered burns of the face, hands and back.

Things were settled early as far as the majority of the 17,697 fans at the Aqueduct race track were concerned yesterday. True, most of them remained to witness the feature event, the $8,975 Amagansett Hurdle Handicap, which was won by the favored War Rhodes.
WESTBURY, L. I. June 25 (AP) -- Driver Joe O'Brien celebrated his thirty-fifth birthday tonight at Roosevelt Raceway by steering Mighty Sun to a three-length victory in the Wantagh Pace.
