WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered a series of up and down changes in rail rates on grain and grain products moving from Western producing areas to destinations in the South.
Ambitious world travelers can now circle the globe in regularly scheduled flights in 99 hours 16 minutes and still get to see the sights -- at sixteen airports.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Gordon Dean, retiring chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, proposed today that the United States tell the Soviet Union frankly and publicly the approximate destructive power of our atomic-weapons stockpile. Such a disclosure, he declaired, would keep the Soviet Union from blundering into a war out of ignorance because they might have underestimated our retaliatory power.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Dr. Harold C. Weber asserted today that neither the Massachusetts Institute of Technology nor the National Burea of Standards tests of AD-K2, storage battery additive, "covvered enough ground to tell whether the stuff was good or bad."

ALBANY, June 25 -- The State Board of Regents was urged today to brand the Communist party as a subversive organization advocating the violent overthrow of the United States Government, and to prohibit party members from holding positions in the public schools and colleges of the state.
TOKYO, Friday, June 26 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,657, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

LONDON, June 25 -- Three chemists at the British Government's low temperature station at Cambridge claim to have discovered the precise way in which plants and animals convert glucose sugar into ascorbic acid (Vitamin C).

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- The Senate today passed, by a voice vote, a Federal oil leasing bill for the ocean-bottom lands of the Continental Shelf and earmarked the Government's share of any revenue for education.

The Twentieth Century Fund has named J. Frederic Dewhurst executive director, effective Aug. 9, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Dewhurst, present economist of the fund, will succeed Evans Clark, who is retiring after twenty-five years in the post and has been elected to the board of trustees.

Sight-seers in Lower Manhattan viewed an unusual ship yesterday when the Belgian training craft Mercator left port after a one-week visit. The Mercator is a barkentine, a three-masted sailing vessel relatively rare in modern waters.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, announced today that he would introduce a bill to arm the Justice Department with wide new powers to investigate wrongdoing in any executive agency of the Government.

YONKERS, June 25 -- Bertram D. Tallamy, chairman of the Thruway Authority, indicated tonight that to complete the main New York to Buffalo Thruway on schedule at the end of 1954, construction of most of the final twelve-mile link in Westchester County would have to be on an around-the-clock basis.

CHICAGO, June 25 (UP) -- The Phillies blasted four Chicago pitchers for nineteen hits, including eight doubles, a triple and a home run, for a 13-to-2 victory and their eleventh straight triumph without a loss to the Cubs this season.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., June 25 -- Arnold Lippman, Yale senior who holds the Westchester junior championship, tied two older rivals for the medal in the Westchester district qualifying round of the New York State men's amateur championship at the Leewood Golf Club today.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., June 24 -- Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, today assailed the "demagogues" who were trying, he contended, to make political capital out of the 15 per cent rent increase over rent levels of March, 1943. The rise was authorized by the Legislature in March.

The Democratic minority in the Legislature is mistaken in seeking a ninety-day delay in the effective date of Governor Dewey's longshore reform measure so as to permit the shipping companies, truckers and the union to prepare a voluntary program of their own.

ROME, June 25 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi's Government won an easy victory today when its candidates were elected Presidents of the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate on the first ballot shortly after opening of the new Parliament.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan issued a directive yesterday to all commanding officers of precinct and detective forces to give "vigorous and sustained attention" to the problem of suppressing the illegal use of fireworks.

BERLIN, June 25 -- Last week's riots, according to official East German sources, took the lives of twenty-five persons and have forced the Government to scrap much of its five-year plan as well as curtail its rearmament program.

Two new films will arrive at first - run theatres today. "Miss Robin Hood," a British-made comedy with Margaret Rutherford, Richard Hearne and James Robertson Justice, is at the Beekman. John Guillermin directed and Donald Wilson produced, from a screen play by Val Valentine and a story by Reed de Rouen.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The White House and Republican officials were reported to be annoyed by the failure of their personnel screening system on Tom Lyon, whose nomination as director of the United States Bureau of Mines was withdrawn today by President Eisenhower.

The new board of directors of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City accepted yesterday the resignations of fifty-three Roman Catholic agencies and three Catholic board members that had been submitted as a result of the decision last month to admit a planned parenthood group to the council.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today issued grants for five new television stations, at New Haven, Conn.; Kansas City, Mo.; Beckley, W. Va., and Marshall, Tex. Two of the grants went to Kansas City for a proposed share-the-time operation on Channel 9.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Eisenhower signed today the Congressional authorization granting up to 1,000,000 bushels of wheat to Pakistan, and a few hours later the first shipment of 9,600 long tons of grain was being piped aboard the Anchorage Victory at Baltimore.
As one broker put it, the stock market in the first half hour of trading yesterday "looked like a million bucks." But the pick-up was short-lived and stock prices faltered as volume diminished.

ALBANY, June 25 -- A series of six bills designed to improve the administration of criminal justice in New York State and to strengthen the Governor's power to deal with local political corruption were rushed toward final legislative approval at a special session of the Legislature today.

Beef still holds the spotlight in food markets this week-end, with ten-inch cut rib roasts selling for as low as 45 cents a pound in some stores. In general, beef and other meat prices are unchanged from last week.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 25 -- The Rabbinical Assembly of America, in a series of resolutions adopted unanimously today, called for the granting of "amnesty in public opinion to those who had clearly dissociated themselves from Communist fronts before the Berlin airlift of 1948."

If Congress sticks to the announced purpose of the Republican leaders to adjourn the end of July it has a mere five weeks to redeem some of the hope and promise of the new Administration. As things have been going we are not very optimistic about the outcome.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Browns swept a three-game series from Washington and extended their winning streak to four games tonight by beating the Senators, 3 -- 1. Harry Brecheen, 38-year-old left hander who was replaced by Satchel Paige in the seventh inning, posted the victory.
LOS ANGELES, June 25 -- Following are the texts of the manifesto on book freedom and of the resolution on overseas libraries voted today by the American Library Association.

PITTSBURGH, June 25 -- Industry must use its "Sunday muscles" to move into distribution the products it makes, a group of industrial advertisers was told today by David F. Austin, executive vice president, commercial, of the United States Steel Corporation.

Labeled "The World's Biggest Musical Show," Michael Todd's production of "A Night In Venice" opened its second season at the Jones Beach (L. I.) Theatre last night before an audience that nearly filled the more than 8,000-seat stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- During the week ended June 24 member bank reserves decreased $785,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The principal changes reducing reserves were decreases of $880,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $26,000,000 in gold stock, and an increase of $17,000,000 in foreign deposits with Federal Reserve banks.
CHICAGO, June 25 -- Grain futures were all under pressure of free selling today, with the action of wheat watched by traders. Soybean futures moved contrary to the grain trend.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Michigan members of Congress today asked the Secretary of the Air Force Harold E. Talbott, to negotiate a new contract for production of aircraft at the huge Willow Run plant near Detroit. He announced yesterday cancellation of contracts with the Henry J. Kaiser interests for building cargo-transport planes at Willow Run.

The Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority, major public power enterprise of the island commonwealth, accepted the offer yesterday of a banking syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation and B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., to buy a new issue of $21,000,000 of the authority's serial bonds at an interest cost of 4.8095 per cent.

More rapid development of a balanced economy in Brazil, in keeping with its vast potentialities, will depend on much larger capital investment from the United States, it was declared last night by Guilherme N. de Araujo, commercial counselor of the Brazilian Embassy in Washington.

Even the youngsters leaving school this June to find their way in life may not face a more difficult period of adjustment than forty-nine women, all over 40 years of age, who were graduated yesterday afternoon from a ten-week training course in domestic skills.

BOSTON, June 26 (AP) -- Larry Doby got two consecutive homers and Al Rosen connected for his fifteenth of the season while driving in five runs each today as the Indians overwhelmed the Red Sox, 15 -- 4, to square the four-game series.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Senate Democrats made heavy attacks today on the Eisenhower Administration's reduced budget for the Air Force. They declared the reduced budget would leave the United States with no foreseeable adequate defense against a Soviet air attack.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, will be the 1953 recipient of the Bernard M. Baruch Distinguished Service Award, with gold certificate of merit, highest honor of the Veterans of Foreign Wars. This was anounced here today by James W. Cothran, commander in chief of the V. F. W.

The interim fares now charged by eight of the nine private bus companies operating under city franchises were extended yesterday by the Board of Estimate to Sept. 30. A ninth operator, the Queensboro Bridge Railway Company, obtained an interim fare rise of 3 cents effective through Dec. 31, subject to revision by the city on Oct. 31. The company now charges 5 cents for a trip across the bridge.

VIENNA, June 25 -- The detailed negotiations that began yesterday between the Austrian Government and experts representing the Joint Executive Board on Jewish claims against Austria have already revealed a wide gap between Austrian and Jewish estimates of the value of the property for which indemnification is claimed.

In March, Stella, Unger acquired the musical rights to one of John Golden's greatest hits, "Seventh Heaven," Austin Strong's romantic fantasy that had the stamina to hold on for 704 performances. Yesterday Miss Unger confirmed reports that she and Victor Wolfson, who is recalled as the author of the sentimental "Excursion," were at work on the song and dance adaptation as well as the lyrics.

MOSCOW, June 25 -- The Communist party's chief theoretical organ, Kommunist, today published an attack on persons who conceal their "chauvinism and nationalism" under the flag of patriotism and declared that the Soviet people should not "fence themselves off from the culture of foreign lands."

Two ex-Presidents of the United States were in the Capitol on Wednesday. One of them, Herbert Hoover, has been an ex-President so long that he must be used to it. The other, Harry S. Truman, is still, so it seems, enjoying his recovered private citizenship.

A ten-story apartment house to accommodate 120 families at 213-225 East Sixty-ninth Street was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The cost is estimated at $1,250,000. S. Elghanayan of 574 West End Avenue is the owner and Roasario Candela and Paul Resnick are the architects.

A joint United States-Canadian air defense exercise, the second in history, will be held next month to train North America's sky sentries and to test the defenses of our "live frontiers" of the skies.

After registering satisfaction that France at last has a Premier, there is little good one can say. A relatively unknown figure, Joseph Laniel, chosen because no one had anything against him, who put forward a program of platitudes and generalities, was finally able to get a majority.
CLEVELAND, June 26 -- Miss Ruth Sleeper of Boston was re-elected president of the National League for Nursing at the closing session today of its first convention.

The taxpayer building at 35-02 to 35-14 Crescent Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Queens Meadow Realty Corporation to Stolz Associates, Inc. Frank Whitman was the broker and the City Title Insurance Company insured title. The property, assessed at $125,000, was sold subject to a mortgage of $98,125.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Colonel Greene had been editor and general manager of The Combat Forces Journal since it began publication in 1950 when The Infantry Journal and The Field Artillery Journal were merged. He had been editor of The Infantry Journal since 1940 and associate editor for two years before that.
ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP) -- The sale of the F. Burkart Manufacturing Company to Textron, Inc., of Providence, R. I., was approved today by stockholders of the St. Louis company.

The attempt of high-tariff Republicans to turn the Federal Tariff Commission into a partisan body by the addition of a seventh member has been defeated in the Senate Finance Committee after winning on the floor of the House. We may now hope that this "more adequate protection," to quote Representative Simpson of Pennsylvania, will be left out of the act extending the Reciprocal Trade Agreements program until June 12, 1954.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Sharp declines were registered in the wheat pit on the Board of Trade today, and for a time the weakness unsettled all other commodity futures on the floor. The main factor continued to be the prevailing opinion that the red winter wheat crop will be difficult to store.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -A Kaiser Motor Corporation official admitted today he made an incomplete statement on his company's finances at a 1948 Securities and Exchange Commission hearing on the company's unsuccessful attempt to sell common stock that year.

ROME, June 26 -- The departure of Admiral Robert B. Carney to become Chief of Naval Operations in Washington is the occasion for reviewing the first two years of NATO in the Southern Theatre. One gets a better perspective on what the organization has accomplished when one remembers that Italy started two years ago with no army at all and that Greece and Turkey were not members of the organization until last year.

Sales of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation for the six months ended on May 31 established a new high for the period, rising 68 per cent over the volume for the corresponding six months a year earlier, but earnings were somewhat lower, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock issued a show cause order yesterday calling on acting Collector of Customs Francis B. Laughlin to explain why thirtyseven employes in the export control section should not be retained in their jobs. The order is returnable next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Eisenhower has informed Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, that the spirit of freedom shown by the recent demonstrations of workers in Berlin and East Germany will have repercussions "throughout the Soviet satellite empire."

ALBANY, June 26 -- Bills recommended by Governor Dewey to set up a bi-state commission to regulate waterfront labor practices in the Port of New York and eliminate racketeering, pilferage and other pier evils were approved unanimously in the Senate and Assembly today as the extraordinary session of the Legislature ended at 4:10 P. M.

BERLIN, June 26 -- The East German Government staged today what was publicized as a loyalty parade of workers that apparently followed studiously the same route as that taken June 16 and 17 by the striking building workers. It was those earlier marches that touched off the riots throughout East Germany.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 26 (UP) -- The Federal Government declared Montgomery County an emergency polio area today and ordered mass injections of gamma globulin in its first test against an outbreak already under way.

APPARENTLY there has been some unscheduled by-passing by the tuna schools, for a wire from Provincetown, Mass., states that no fewer than thirty-nine school tuna, ranging from 50 to 75 pounds each, were taken only five miles off New Beach.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The American Farm Bureau Federation today opposed two major features of legislation intended to make marketing quotas on wheat more attractive to growers.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -A Boston salesman of a battery "booster" powder testified today that he tested the controversial AD-X2 on a Navy submarine battery with "amazing" success.

WESTBURY, L. I. June 26 (AP) -- Paige Direct, owned by Paige H. West of Snow Hill, Md., scored an upset victory tonight in the Massapequa junior free-for-all pace at Roosevelt Raceway's Grand Circuit meeting.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -Fred S. Rogers, member of the Federal Parole Board, today defended before House of Representatives investigators his approval of the 1947 parole of Burt K. Naster, Chicago industrialist convicted of income tax evasion in July, 1945.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 26 -Jewish Agency officials disclosed today that if present trends continued, more persons would in a year or so be leaving Israel than entering as immigrants.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- A few Senators on the floor today put through a $452,956,940 money bill for the Department of the Interior by a voice vote.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said today that industrial production in May had remained slightly below the March high. Small declines were registered in many durable goods lines but the output of nondurable goods was at a record level.

Lower East Side pupils of Junior High School 65 at 45 Forsyth Street, many of whom have benefited from social agency camping programs, turned the tables on the usual donors yesterday when they presented to seven camps a total of $1,100 they solicited in their neighborhood in the last three weeks.

Ernest R. Acker, president of the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation at Poughkeepsie, N. Y., declared yesterday that any suggestion that his company had violated the law by its fight to preserve the role of private enterprise in the development of hydroelectric projects at Niagara Falls "is completely without foundation."
HANOVER, N. H., June 26 (AP) -- Dartmouth College honored with a memorial tablet today four alumni who, 100 years ago, took part in the first scientific examination of crude oil.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 26 -- How teachers can start as early as kindergarten to include "homemaking" activities in their classroom programs was demonstrated today in one of the special exhibits at the state-wide conference for homemaking teachers being held at Cornell University.
New Yorkers, who are bearing up more or less under a new heat wave, may take some satisfaction from the fact that even the Eskimos sweltered yesterday.
Sales of two dwellings and a homesite in the Riverdale section of the Bronx were reported by Robert E. Hill, Inc., broker.

CINCINNATI, June 26 (UP) -Ted Kluszewski smashed his twentieth and twenty-first homers of the season and, in the second game, Jackie Collum limited the Pirates to four hits tonight as the Redlegs swept a twilight-night double-header, 8 -- 4 and 4 -- 1.
A study of the reports which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on June 22 should reveal to any fair-minded. American the folly of the new policy for which Senator McCarthy is largely responsible.

The stock market yesterday was the dullest affair witnessed in Wall Street since the dog days of last August. With only 830,000 shares exchanged and dealings limited to 1,012 issues, there was nothing to distinguish the session's performance.

Albert Abraham Cohen, a 55-year-old taxi driver who has amply demonstrated his bravery in thirty years of cruising dark and lonely back streets of Manhattan and the Bronx, just about kept his scared self in tow yesterday while he stood in the sun-lit City Council chamber and became the most decorated cabbie in New York's history.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 26 -- The Eisenhower Administration, which has opposed the constitutional amendment proposed by Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, to limit the President's power to make treaties and Executive agreements, is "reconsidering its position," the State Bar Association was told here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 26 -- Lester B. Pearson of Canada, President of the United Nations General Assembly, decided today, after a conference in Ottawa with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, not to take steps to call the Assembly back into session for the time being.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 -Walt Disney has been making extensive tests with CinemaScope in connection with his current cartoon feature, "The Lady an the Tramp," a dog story.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Hope for a truce in the excess-profits tax fight faded almost to the vanishing point today and the Republican leaders prepared for a battle Monday in the House of Representatives. They still held the door open for amicable settlement of the issue that now overshadows all differences over the merits of continuing the tax -- the use of drastic and extraordinary parliamentary methods to force an extension bill to the floor.

Efforts to agree on a coalition candidate for Mayor almost reached an impasse yesterday at the conference of representatives of the Republican and Liberal parties and the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.
PALISADES, N. J., June 26 -Sediment samples from the ocean bottoms sealed in long glass tubes suggest that the continents have grown from the early ocean-covered world like great big warts.

The New York and New Jersey Legislatures are to be commended on the prompt passage of bills creating identical waterfront commissions to reduce criminal and corrupt practices in the Port of New York and to regularize waterfront labor. We believe that Congress will approve with equal promptness the compact between the two states for a single bi-state commission to administer the plan.
The already thin lines of the Coast Guard's protective forces are sure to be stretched further if the service's $211,850,000 budget goes through the Congressional mill unchanged.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 26 -- The American Association of University Women today adopted a resolution urging stronger measures against the illegal sale and distributton of narcotics, calling it "one of the major problems of schools."
Following are excerpts from Senator Alexander Wiley's foreign policy speech here yesterday:

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today an anti-trust consent judgment has been entered in the Federal District Court at Cleveland against the NormaHoffmann Bearings Corporation.

LONDON, June 26 -- In a leading article twice as long as usual the influential London weekly The Economist called on President Eisenhower and Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, today to reconstruct at Bermuda the policy of containment of communism followed by former Secretary of State Dean Acheson and the late Ernest Bevin who was Britain's Foreign Secretary.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Senator Homer Capehart, Republican of Indiana, said today that if Congress is given a final voice in the sale of Government-owned synthetic rubber plants it could delay the sales program as much as three years.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 26 -- The County Airport Corporation, tenant of the $10,000,000 Westchester County Airport in Purchase, gave a $12,375 check to County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach here today to pay for operation of the control tower at the field for three months after July 1.
TOKYO, Saturday, June 27 (UP) -- The worst rains in sixty-one years beat down anew today, after a brief respite, and the toll in flooded southwest Japan mounted to at least 134 dead and 607 missing.

LONDON, June 26 -- The British Government has taken out patients on a new light steam engine that burns low-grade fuel, including green wood, and may be an important power source in undeveloped but heavily forested regions of the tropics.

Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, chairman of the New York City Transit Authority, confirmed yesterday that the authority voted at its meeting on Monday to retain the public relations firm of A. A. Schechter Associates, 250 Park Avenue, for three months at $2,000 a month.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 26 -- John H. Lewis Jr. of Lafayette, 16-year-old candidate of the National party, today was elected Governor of the New Jersey Boys State at Rutgers University.

For 5-year-old Karl Kampenmuller, on his way alone from Austria to rejoin his mother and stepfather in Colorado after a year's separation, the stop-over here yesterday proved to be a whirl of ice cream, soup and orange and prune juice.

ST. LOUIS, June 26 -- Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, declared tonight that the fight against racial discrimination now being waged by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People had helped strengthen the moral leadership of the United States and had helped show the rest of the world that America could "practice democracy as well as preach it."

If churches in America fail in their obligation to strengthen the religious faith of the young persons in our military forces, "we shall succumb to communism," Maj. Gen. Charles I. Carpenter declared in an address in Brooklyn yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (UP) -- The University of Pennsylvania will slash its financial aid to athletes in a move interpreted as swinging a once-mighty football power into an all-Ivy League gridiron program.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 26 -- Patty Berg increased her lead from three to eight strokes at the end of the second round of the United States Golf Association women's open championship at the Rochester Country Club today.

Because July 1 is Canada Day among our neighbors to the north, WNYC will devote four programs totaling four and a quarter hours of air time to Canadian items on Wednesday. From 6 to 6:45 P. M. Lester Pearson, United Nations General Assembly President and Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, will speak on "Canada's International Situation and Point of View."

BAYONNE, N. J., June 26 -- A 200-year-old pair of handsomely carved Florentine oak doors, brought to this country in the Eighteen Nineties for the Gould family's mansion "Castlegould," at Sands Point, L. I., will be presented by the Navy to Florida for the Ringling State Museum at Sarasota, it was learned today.
This could be serious.

May I congratulate you for your survey of books removed from American Information Service libraries in twenty foreign capitals and for your leading editorial "America: Edited and Revised." The publication of the whole truth on such matters is an essential element to keeping our democracy alive.

LONDON, June 26 -- Capt. Jan Cwiklinski, master of the Polish liner Batory, who left his ship to seek asylum in Britain last week, disclosed today that he had been warned that "arrest and prosecution" awaited him if he returned to Communist Poland.

I hope that it is not too late for me to reply to Mdani Ben M'barek's letter of June 13, for I particularly want to take him to task for a misstatement which can have grave consequences if it is believed.

BOSTON, June 26 -- Denis W. Delaney, former Collector of Internal Revenue at Boston, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court today to accepting a $2,500 bribe and evading personal income taxes. He was fined $5,000 and sentenced to a year and a day at the Federal House of Correction at Danbury, Conn.
ALBANY, June 26 -- The Board of Regents today authorized three Long Island school districts to issue a total of $6,162,000 worth of bonds to finance the construction of four elementary schools.
LONDON, June 26 (UP) -- Pravda, Soviet Communist party organ, criticized Tass, official Soviet news agency, today for delayed and faulty news distribution, the Moscow radio reported.
About the burning of books at home and abroad, don't let scorched authors overstimulate your tear ducts. The mistake to cry over was made when the books were purchased.

Six military policemen, including two commissioned officers, walked into a Pittsburgh steel mill on May 13 last, arrested a civilian worker, Robert W. Toth, an honorably discharged Air Force sergeant, handcuffed him, forced him into a uniform and flew him to Korea.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 26--The Republican People's party, which, for twenty-seven years, applied close state control over Turkey's economy, pledged tonight to support private enterprise in exploiting this country's petroleum deposits and in a wide range of other industries if it is successful in next spring's general elections.
Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, denied categorically yesterday that the United Steelworkers or any other affiliate was withdrawing from the C. I. O.

Lead volume established a record high yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange with 113 contracts traded. The previous daily high was sixty-three lots traded on March 27 of this year. Volume this week, excluding yesterday's figure, was only twenty-nine lots.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York, still retaining a one-point lead in his match with Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires for the chess championship of the West, began the fifteenth game of the series in the Argentine capital, according to a report received yesterday.

CLEVELAND, June 26 (AP) -Jack Burke Jr. of Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., held a three-stroke lead today at the half-way mark in the seventy-two-hole $15,000 Manakiki golf tournament. The former Texan tacked a 67, 5 under par, to his opening 66 for 133.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, June 27 (UP) -- The South Korean Government admitted today that it had arrested and was holding the leader of the main Opposition party, who is an outspoken critic of President Syngman Rhee's efforts to prevent a Korean armistice.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 26 -An estimated total of 3,000 members of the Communist-controlled State Railway Union (Sbka) demonstrated today before President Sukarnos' palace with a demand the Government and the Army launch full scale operations against the marauding Darul Islam bands now terrorizing West Java. The fanatical Moslems want to overthrow the secular Indonesian Republic and establish an Islamic state.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 26 -Faced with the threat of uprising by King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, French authorities announced today they had sent strong reinforcements to Pnompenh, the Cambodian capital, to protect French civilians there.

HARRISON, N. J., June 26 -- A flag and a framed scroll attesting to its "successful and efficient civil defense plant protection program" was presented today to the Hyatt Bearings Division of the General Motors Corporation by the State of New Jersey.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 26 -Britain's Colonial and Development Fund has made a loan equivalent to $5,700,000 to the municipality of Nairobi to start replacing its Negro slums, one of the focal points of the secret antiwhite terrorist Mau Mau organization of the Kikuyu tribe.

While a Los Angeles couple was asleep, a sneak thief entered their suit on the twenty-first floor of the Sherry-Netherland Hotel early yesterday morning and escaped with jewels valued at $40,000 and $200 in cash. The intruder overlooked other jewelry worth $13,700 that also was atop a dresser in the bedroom.
FRANKLIN LAKES, N. J., June 26 -- A big black bear is on the loose in these parts and Police Chief Arthur Pickering has taken time out to tell everybody not to shoot at it.

Harry (Bobby) Sand, suspended assistant basketball coach of City College, declared yesterday that, during a game in 1950, he had been advised to "quiet down" after informing his superiors that the team's co-captain was not playing "normally."

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (UP) -- Gus Zernial hit a bases-loaded single off Satchel Paige, with two out in the ninth, to give the Athletics a 6-5 victory over the Browns tonight and snap a four-game St. Louis winning streak.

Indian chiefs and members of tribes in New York and Western states joined yesterday in a ceremony to re-enact the ratification by George Washington of the general treaty with the tribes of the Six Nations in September, 1789.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 26 (AP) -- Savings and loan associations in New York State have been almost free of embezzlements so far, a deputy superintendent of the State Banking Department said today.

LOS ANGELES, June 26 -- President Eisenhower today called for complete freedom of expression in the United States and criticized as un-American "zealots" who with "more wrath than wisdom" sought to suppress information and ideas.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Leo Durocher announced a few days ago his currently smooth-sailing Giants would rely on a four-man staff of starters henceforth. He was still keeping them afloat today, but it took a bit of bailing to do it.
LOS ANGELES, June 26 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message today to the American Library Association's seventy-second annual conference in Los Angeles:...

ST. LOUIS, June 26 (UP) -- Stan Musial continued his sensational hitting tonight, pounding out two home runs and a double to drive in five runs as the Cardinals shut out the Phillies, 7 -- 0, on the three-hit pitching of Stu Miller.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that President Eisenhower was considering the possibility of a high-level parley between representatives of the United States and Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of South Korea, after a truce was signed but before the political conference that would follow it.
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, June 27 -- Nine thousand Chinese Communists drove South Korean troops off five or more main-line positions on the east-central Korean front today in a grim unceasing battle.
High-pressure pumping stations operated by the Fire Department in Manhattan and Brooklyn will be closed down Monday morning as an economy measure.

The six-story commercial building also containing a store at 217 Bowery has been sold by the Freebro Realty Corporation to the 217 Bowery Realty Corporation in a transaction negotiated by Harry Glass as broker. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, June 27 -- Although the proceedings of yesterday's conference between President Rhee and Secretary Robertson were secret, there were indications that some progress had been made toward untangling the Korean problem.

The boathouse being built on the east shore of the Seventy-second Street lake in Central Park is 70 per cent completed and will be opened to the public use late in August, the Parks Depart ment reported yesterday. The concrete walls of the $250,000 structure are raised and the brick facing with limestone trim is in place.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 26 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair, became the Women's New Jersey Golf Association champion for the second straight year as the thirtieth annual fifty-four-hole medal play tournament was concluded over the lower course of the Baltusrol Golf Club today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 26 -While official Pakistan voiced gratitude for the United States grant of 700,000 tons of wheat that will begin to arrive about the third week in July, United States Government representatives here prepared to supervise jointly with the Pakistan Government the distribution of the grain to faminethreatened areas.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A manufacturer new to the production of some copper items included on the controlled materials list will be required after Tuesday to use defense orders for the current month as the basis for calculating his probable quota for the next month, the National Production Authority ruled today.

MADRID, June 26 -- In a pastoral letter published today, Enrique Cardinal Pla y Deniel, Archbishop of Toledo and Primate of Spain, sharply criticized what he called "squandering of money" to celebrate certain religious and social events.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -Douglas Hoge of Cincinnati was elected president of the International Junior Chamber of Commerce, without opposition, as the worldwide organization of young business men ended its eighth annual conference here today.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -A House of Representatives Appropriations subcommittee made public today what it called "military intelligence" estimates that the United States now was producing jet fighters and bombers faster than the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- A call for more accurate price comparisons by retailers when merchandise is placed on sale was issued today by Leonard Stratton, vice president of Wieboldt Stores, Inc., Chicago. He described a tendency to exaggerate markdowns as "one of the most cancerous things in our industry."

Settlement of a wage review dispute was reached yesterday between the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Todd Shipyards Corporation and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., on the basis of a 7-cents-an-hour wage increase across the board.

LONDON, June 26 -- A week of cautious waiting tinged with apprehension ended today with the stock markets striking a slightly more confident note. However, the slide in British Government securities continued, although this market was described as looking a little firmer at the close.

LUBBOCK, Tex., June 26 -- Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, arrived in the drought-stricken Southwest this afternoon prepared to tell the farmers and ranchers specifically what the Government planned to do to help them.

The State Department is still having trouble with the question of what books ought to be put into its information libraries abroad and what books ought to be left out or taken out. The system of choice and exclusion remains fumbling, bumbling, ineffective and undignified.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., June 26 -- Two township committeemen and a dozen residents agreed at a hearing here today that Weehawken should reap a share of the profits for allowing the Port of New York Authority to construct a third tube from New York City to this township.

BALTIMORE, June 26 -- The first shipment of the United States Government's grant of 1,000,000 tons of surplus wheat to relieve famine conditions in drought-ridden Pakistan started from Baltimore today, only fifteen days after President Eisenhower had asked Congressional authorization for the gesture.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -Former President Truman declared tonight that slashes in defense spending by the Eisenhower Administration could involve this nation in a third World War because the rulers of the Soviet empire watched our defense appropriations and planned their moves accordingly.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -The Tigers shelled Johnny Schmitz for five runs in the fifth inning to gain a 7-0 lead and coasted to a 7-3 victory tonight. Clyde Vollmer smashed a three-run homer for the Senators, who have lost six straight games.

The Long Island Lighting Company told the Public Service Commission yesterday that wage increases effective next Wednesday and recent increases in the price of fuel oil would reduce its estimated rate of return on capital investment from 5.72 to 5.40 per cent.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., June 26 -- Five years ago today a small group of village folk and farmers in this community and the surrounding countryside gathered for a routine meeting of the Hunterdon County Agricultural Society. One or two of those present were "rash" enough to suggest that a general hospital be erected within the county, the only one in the state without such an institution.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 26 -- Four meet records were broken and another was tied tonight in the first session of the Amateur Athletic Uiion's sixty-fifth annual national outdoor track and field championships, staged before 9,500 spectators in the Dayton High School Stadium.

TOKYO, June 26 -- The United States Government through its Embassy here assured Japan today that military assistance rendered by the United States under the mutual security program would not obligate Japan to send military forces abroad or to use them for any purpose except in self defense.

Senator Alexander Wiley, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, urged President Eisenhower yesterday to take firm action on the home front against Republican opponents of his foreign policy and on the diplomatic front against both "appeasement" by our allies and the Soviet war threat.

PARIS, June 26 -- Robert and Gerald Finaly, the two Jewish war orphans who have been the innocent centers of the worst religious storm of post-war France, were returned to this country today from Spain where they had been hidden for almost five months.
NEW DELHI, India, June 26 -- Designs are being prepared for a special issue of Indian stamps commemorating the first climbing of Mount Everest, the Government announced today.
The New Jersey school districts of South Orange and Maplewood announced plans yesterday to sell $4,491,000 of bonds on July 14, Dated July 1, 1953, the bonds will come due Jan. 1, 1955 to 1979.

A PROSPEROUS advertising mandarin once said: "When a new employe starts work here I ask him what time he goes to his analyst and whether our business hours will interfere." An honorary descendant of Mrs. Malaprop roared: "Anyone who goes to a psychiatrist ought to have his head examined." A distinguished medical administrator who had just com pleted a season on the couch was questioned by his analyst:
The bond market rally caused by the lowering of bank reserve requirements was extended in yesterday's trading session, but on a lesser scale.

CHICAGO, June 26 (UP) -- The Government today ended rebuttal testimony in its civil anti-trust suit against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., General Motors and others, and except for perhaps one day's session the case was ready for summer recess.

SYRACUSE, June 26 -- Two perfectly tossed lobs that trapped Gilbert Shea in his tracks in the opening game started Ronald Livingston on the way to an unexpected semi-final round victory that won the team honors for the University of California at Los Angeles for a second successive year in the intercollegiate tennis championships today.

BOSTON, Saturday, June 27 (UP) -- Chicago's red-hot White Sox ran their winning streak to five games early today when they rallied to beat Boston, 5 -- 3, before 20,442 rain-dampened Fenway Park fans. The game was delayed 70 minutes by rain.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The paper necktie made its debut among this week's patented inventions. The specific creation is a ready-tied four-in-hand that hooks over the wearer's neckband. As it is coated with plastic, the new tie can be wiped clean like the "rubber" collar that grandfather wore.

There can be no denying that a hedge is a very nice thing indeed. Marking the boundaries of the property, it has none of the austerity of a stone wall or the somewhat forbidding air of a picket fence.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Eisenhower today ousted Josiah Marvel Jr. and Raymond S. McKeough from the International Claims Commission.

The English have a special gift for flower arrangements. The great love they have for their gardens is expressed with equal understanding in the floral decorations in their homes, whether they are using flowers grown in a hothouse or those gathered in the fields.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The railroads asked today for an increase of at least 45 per cent in payments for carrying the mail. If authorized, the rise would amount to about $143,550,000 a year.

GENEVA, June 26 -- The Governing Body of the International Labor Organization ruled today that legislation in force in Czechoslovakia concerning trade unions is "contrary to the principle of freedom of the association."

The Equity Library Theatre, whose aim it is to afford to performers the opportunity to showcase their talents and to encourage interest in the theatre through its subsidiary projects, has completed its ninth season of play production in the black.
CHICAGO, June 26 -- Seventeen members were elected today to the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association. The House is the association's policy-making body and is elected by mail vote.

A 69-year-old Australian woman, her near-blindness having been arrested by specially designed eye-glasses providing extremely sharp focus while diminishing the brilliance of image, is flying home tonight after a five-day stay in New York.

ESTES PARK, Colo., June 26 -- Without "dedicated" parental co-operation on the home front, religious education at its best can achieve little more than mediocre success, the Central Conference of American Rabbis was told here today.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 27 -Walter S. Robertson, Assistant Secretary of State, said today that he was "very optimistic" of a settlement of the crisis that arose when President Syngman Rhee of South Korea refused to accept an armistice in the Korean war on terms virtually agreed upon by Communist and United Nations delegations at Panmunjom.

Chicken doused in aromatic herbs, the dish that earned a prize for Mrs. David Saperton in the National Chicken Cooking Contest at Harrington, Del., this week, is only one of about 2,000 poultry recipes the New York housewife has collected here and abroad.
PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- Critics of the church were challenged today to name even one outstanding Protestant clergyman who is a Communist.

This is the day they're asking Greentree Stable's Tom Fool to carry 135 pounds. The occasion will be the fifty-third running of the Carter Handicap. The scene will be the Aqueduct race course and the big question among the 35,000 turf fans expected this afternoon will be whether the heavily muscled Tom Fool can tote that kind of weight and win.

Leonard Rosenman of this city and Louis Mennini of Rochester, N. Y., have each received a commission of $750 to write operas for the Berkshire Music Center, Tanglewood, Mass., it was announced yesterday.

In much of the discussion of the possible aftermath of a truce in Korea has been the theme of the need of a prompt accommodation with the Chinese Communists for the sake of Japanese recovery. Japan, it is suggested, cannot hope to survive and progress without access to the "vast" Chinese market now denied to her by our obstinacy in refusing to acknowledge that Peiping is in the saddle.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 26 -- The world food situation is growing steadily worse, although Americans are eating more than ever, Mrs. Anna Arnold Hedgeman, former assistant to the Federal Security Administrator, said at the closing general session of the annual conference of the American Home Economics Association this morning.

NEWARK, June 28 -- Superior Court Judge G. Dixon Speakmen held today that "Skillo" was pre-dominantly a game of chance, not skill, and issued an order, effective July 6, terminating the temporary restraint against police officials who had banned the game under gambling laws.

ROME, June 26 -- $100,000,000 barter deal of Iranian crude oil against Italian manufactured goods is under discussion and is about to be concluded, according to Mohammed Djahanguir Ahi, Deputy Mayor of Teheran and vice president of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's Industrial Emergency Council.
CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, June 26 (AP) -- Ben Hogan learned all about tough Carnoustie today and walked off the course without finishing his practice round for the British open starting July 6.
TOKYO, Saturday, June 27 (AP) -Eight Army communique covering Thursday's activities:

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 26 -- Britain's attempt to create a Central Africa bastion by federating Southern and Northern Rhodesia with Nyasaland is already encountering racial trouble and may duplicate -- in milder form -- the racial struggles of the Union of South Africa and Kenya.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 26 -Scoring a 33 on the first nine of the second round, Miss Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks defeated Mrs. Alexander McFadden, Meadow Brook, 11 and 9, for the women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship at the Nassau Country Club today.
Ten thousand skirt and sportswear workers in and around New York will receive wage increases of 7 to 10 per cent beginning July 15, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, June 26 -- France had a Premier tonight, after five weeks of painful political convulsions. Joseph Laniel, whom the National Assembly approved today by 398 votes to 206, will therefore head the French delegation to the Western Big Three conference in Bermuda which has been twice postponed on account of the French Cabinet crisis.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The House Armed Services Committee today unanimously approved a bill giving the Defense Department authority to establish a $500,000,000 reserve of machine tools.

The official Communist theoretical magazine, Political Affairs, was accused yesterday of using "Soviet anti-Semitism" in an article in its June issue to attack Arthur Osman and other leaders of the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers Union, C. I. O., who have purged the union's staff of Communists.

Of the new issue of 568,565 shares of General Public Utilities Corporation stock offered to the company's shareholders, about 64 per cent was subscribed to through the exercise of rights. The balance of 36 per cent was sold under secondary "rounding out" subscription privileges, used for the first time, and through placements made by securities dealers.

Two more publishers have jumped on the three-dimensional bandwagon. The St. John Publishing Company here announced yesterday that "The Mighty Mouse" comic book that will appear on the newsstands next Friday will be entirely in three-dimension.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was slightly irregular yesterday, closing 5 points lower to 11 points higher on active months.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 26 (AP) -- The seventh annual New Jersey Girls State ended a six-day meeting today with Gov. Eleanor Lipski of Freehold announcing her Cabinet and Government appointees.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The House of Representatives debated for five hours today the Administration's controversial plan to reorganize the Department of Defense, but deferred a vote until tomorrow.
American trade-mark owners were urged yesterday to take more vigorous and organized action to protect themselves against counterfeiting of their products in foreign markets.

The official Communist theoretical magazine, Political Affairs, was accused yesterday of using "Soviet anti-Semitism" in an article in its June issue to attack Arthur Osman and other leaders of the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers Union, C. I. O., who have purged the union's staff of Communists.

Of the new issue of 568,565 shares of General Public Utilities Corporation stock offered to the company's shareholders, about 64 per cent was subscribed to through the exercise of rights. The balance of 36 per cent was sold under secondary "rounding out" subscription privileges, used for the first time, and through placements made by securities dealers.

Two more publishers have jumped on the three-dimensional bandwagon. The St. John Publishing Company here announced yesterday that "The Mighty Mouse" comic book that will appear on the newsstands next Friday will be entirely in three-dimension.

The first of several sermons in which two preachers will take part will be delivered at 5 P. M. July 5 at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine). The dual sermons also will be preached on each succeeding Sunday throughout July.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -A military appeals board has upheld the conviction of Lieut. Col. Melvin B. Voorhees for violating Army censorship regulations, but has thrown out four of the five charges against him.

The story of William Bonney, who as Billy the Kid became part of the history of the American Southwest, has been told in many media from biography to ballet. A new volume for the list will be published July 14 by Duell, Sloan Pearce-Little Brown, entitled "Billy the Kid," a novel by Edwin Corle.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 26 -- The two 18-year-old Australian stars, Ken Rosewall and Lewis Hoad, reached the quarter-finals of the men's singles in the All-England championships today but on their form the seedings seem to be slightly confused.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., June 26 -- Forty-five executives of the motion picture industry completed their third annual tour today as directors of the Variety Club's Will Rogers Memorial Hospital near here.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The first section of the Annual International Scholarship Teen-Age Tour of the American Field Service, now in its sixth year, arrived here today for a week's sight-seeing.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee has assigned a "task force" to start hearings early next month on a bill that would prevent the certification by the National Labor Relations Board of Communist-dominated labor unions as collective bargaining agents for workers.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 26 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today that a national committee would be appointed to study the anti-trust laws and suggest amendments or revisions in the best interests of the country's economy.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, communications and manufacturing concern in both the domestic and international fields, announced yesterday that it had filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval to issue $35,883,300 of twenty-year convertible debentures.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- A 58-year-old ruling supports the authority of the House Rules Committee in sending to the House floor yesterday an excess-profits tax bill over the objection of the legislative committee having jurisdiction over taxes.
Trade, aid or what ?

Joe Giardello, Philadelphia middleweight, scored over Ernie Durando of Bayonne in the main bout of ten rounds last night. Using his left to excellent advantage and muffling his rivals counters, Giardello gained the unanimous decision in one of the most uneven contests ever to serve as top attraction at Madison Square Garden.

Nathan L. Miller, Governor of New York in 1921 and 1922 and later general counsel for the United States Steel Corporation, died at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon in his suite in the Pierre Hotel. He was 84 years old.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:

MILWAUKEE, June 26 -- Two-run homers by Duke Snider and Gil Hodges tonight gave the Dodgers a 4-3 triumph over the Braves and reduced the league leaders' margin over the Brooks to one game, at the same time reducing the 35,145 ardent fans at the County Stadium almost to despair.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 26 -- H. M. Rainie of Boston, vice president of the Boston and Maine and the Maine Central Railroads, was elected chairman of the purchases and stores division of the Association of American Railroads at the closing session of the group's twenty-seventh annual meeting at Convention Hall here today.
As a lifetime reader of THE TIMES I am impelled to write this letter to express the heartsick fear engendered by recent news columns.

Sales taxes for the current fiscal year, which began on July 1, 1952, brought the city $245,518,691 through Thursday, City Treasurer Spencer C. Young announced yesterday. In the previous complete fiscal year the yield was $203,919,856. Collections for the two months ended on May 31 were $32,959,082.
The B. M. T. subway between Canal Street and De Kalb Avenue in Brooklyn was tied up for three hours yesterday when a power cable caught fire at Canal Street and the Bowery at 12:15 P. M.
Following is the text of the address last night by former President Truman before the national convention of the Reserve Officers Association in Philadelphia, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
COCHABAMBA, Bolivia, June 24 -- Landowners here are becoming more and more apprehensive about their property rights as the Government prepares to tackle the knotty problem of agrarian reform.

Political party organizations, or "machines" as they are called by their opponents, are losing their power in New York City. Recent elections in the city have been decided largely on the personalities of the candidates and on what the successful candidates have led the voters to believe were the leading issues.

MANY words have been written and many photographs have been published of flower arrangements created by members of garden clubs and other experts all over the country. However, little has been written or reported about children's ideas on the art of flower arranging.
BOSTON, June 27 (UP) -- A poetically minded Baltimore historian opened a campaign today to save the Constellation, the Navy's oldest warship, from rotting in the Boston Naval Shipyard.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 27 (AP) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, demanded tonight to know if Randolph Burgess, deputy to the Secretary of the Treasury, received a pension from and held stock in the National City Bank of New York.

ALL Berlin -- or all that large part of Berlin's population which is interested in opera -- is conscious of a struggle being waged between East and West Berlin which is never reflected in the papers. It is not reflected because the Communist-controlled (or frankly Communist) papers of the East make no mention of the operas produced in Western Berlin, while the West Berlin papers ignore the operatic productions of the East.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- President Eisenhower, with one short paragraph, opened the way this week for the dismissal of several thousand Federal employes and thereby set off charges that he was assaulting the Civil Service system.

MANY states are now finding it difficult to meet the demands brought on by the trend toward outdoor recreation, and although hunters and fishermen, more than forty million strong, constitute the major problem, those interested in hiking, boating and camping have posed new problems for the responsible agencies.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- An Administration official said today the Government expected to wind up the present fiscal year on Tuesday about $8,500,000,000 "in the red." This would be a deficit of about $2,500,000,000 more than President Truman estimated in his January budget.

IN the nineteenth century England experimented briefly with monarchy, but the idea was ahead of its time. This fact, and not the pretty-pretty romance that most writers have timidly worked over, gives the story of Victoria and Albert its interest, its sense of possibilities.

GENEVA, June 22 -- Swiss journalists and a considerable part of public opinion have hailed as a triumph for freedom of the press a victory won by Pierre Beguin, editor of the Gazette de Lausanne, over small groups of stockholders that sought to establish control over the paper with a view to changing its long-established editorial policy.
A fight between a subway conductor and an unruly passenger stalled southbound traffic on the I. R. T. for a half hour last night.

THE warmer coastal waters in summer attract lobsters inshore and, to the delight of almost everyone, the supply of the shellfish increases. Availability reaches its peak, and prices decline to their lowest point, in early autumn. But most of us cannot wait until then to feast on a food that, despite its popular name, "Maine lobster," now comes to us most abundantly from Canada, according to the Fishery Council.

LONDON, June 27 -- Without any warning 10 Downing Street announced today that, on the advice of his doctors, Prime Minister Churchill had postponed his Bermuda meeting with President Eisenhower and the new French Premier, Joseph Laniel, and would take it easy for at least a month.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 27 -- Hal Wallis and Joseph H. Hazen dissolved today their independent film-producing partnership and announced that Wallis-Hazen Productions, Inc., was going out of business. The action, which took Hollywood by surprise, was attributed by the partners to the confusions that exist about the future course of the film business because of experiments with new productions and exhibition techniques.
Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick, concerned over the threat of radio and television to the minor leagues, today asked for a full understanding of baseball's position.

DESPITE the attacks of left-wing critics, mystery novels are by no means invariably "escape" literature; quite a number have dealt, and often intelligently, with social problems. As a current example, take Lloyd S. Thompson's HEAR NOT MY STEPS (Abelard, $2.50), which tells of anti-Japanese prejudice in a small California valley town.

Rear Admiral Ralph E. Jennings, deputy commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier and Atlantic Reserve Fleet, leads the list of ten naval officers stationed in the New York area who will retire Tuesday. Born in New York, he was the wartime commander of the aircraft carrier Yorktown, known as the "Fighting Lady."

BALTIMORE -- One of the nation's historic monuments will be rededicated in a new location here on Thursday at ceremonies to be attended by Governor McKeldin of Maryland, members of Congress and civic and railroad officials.

" America and Britain -- A Vital Partnership" by Lester Markel (June 14) brings to focus many vital points for well being and progress. But what has been ignored is the real value of partners and friendship of all men and nations.

Though it is not likely that H. R. 3534 will be debated by the Congress at its present session, its introduction serves at least the useful purpose of calling attention to a gross injustice to patentees, of whom many are either original inventors themselves or small business firms.

DALLAS. LITTLE theatres and college theatres we have had in the Southwest since the 1920's. The region still has them and several long-lived ones, those of Dallas, Houston, Tyler, Tulsa, Shreveport and New Orleans are established factors in roll-your-own resident civilization.

A MOVE "to put Brooklyn on the photographic map" got under way in that borough last week with the inauguration of the Brooklyn Camera Conference, an organization of amateur photographers whose purpose is to promote the use, display and appreciation of photography in that area.

IN the year 1182 Ibn Jubayr was the secretary of the Berber prince who governed Granada. Young, devout, punctilious even in the notes which he addressed to himself, with a taste for adventure and a notable eye for women, he seems to have been restless in the royal service.

The atomic age took a big step forward last week. It was propelled by that symbolization of the electric age, the General Electric Company, which is celebrating its seventy-fifth anniversary this year.

WITH THE FIRST MARINE AIR WING, Korea, June 27 -- Capt. Ted Williams, a veteran of thirty-eight missions in Korea, has been ordered back to the United States by Marine flight surgeons for treatment of an ear and nose ailment, a Marine Corps spokesman said today.

ALBANY -- There may be some delays en route for the motorist touring New York this summer, but stretches of new or refinished highways traversing the state are in prospect as a result of the heavy schedule of the Public Works Department.

AMONG Samuel Eliot Morison's assets are prodigious energy, youthful zest and mature historical experience. These (plus an assist from the Navy and a small group of research assistants) have now helped him produce the eighth volume of a fourteen-volume series on the United States Navy's operations in World War II.

HEITOR VILLA-LOBOS, who for inspiration has often turned to the folk-music of his native Brazil, in 1926 wrote a cycle of sixteen piano pieces, Cirandas, based on popular Brazilian tunes. The cycle has now been recorded for M-G-M by the pianist, Joseph Battista, working under the close supervision of the composer.
CULVER CITY, Calif., June 27 (UP) -- Robert Cons, Purple Heart veteran of Korea, today won the sixth annual Western Hemisphere marathon, upsetting Aldo Scandurra of the Millrose A. A. of New York.

MOSCOW, Sunday, June 28 -- In a special dispatch from its cor-i respondent in Germany, Pravda] reported today that, thanks to "theI enlivening of private retail trade,"[ the supply of goods in East Germany was rapidly improving.

Columbia University's fifty-fourth Summer Session Institute will open on July 9 with a lecture on "America's New Role in World Affairs" by Chester Bowles, formerly Governor of Connecticut and more recently Ambassador to India.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- President Eisenhower wrote Sir Winston Churchill today of his "deep" distress at the news of the British Prime Minister's ill-health, which, said the President, "is of great concern to all of the world."

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 27 -- My Celeste emphasized the value of persistence today. The 7-year-old mare owned by Miss Constance Morabito won the $28,600 Molly Pitcher Handicap at Monmouth Park, and in so doing made a success of a task that she began four years ago.

EVER since the Nazis' Gotterdammerung in 1945, Berlin has remained the stage of intense drama. The latest scene in the drama was the extraordinary wave of strikes and riots, spreading from East Berlin throughout Soviet-occupied East Germany.

Steel price advances have not yet set off another inflationary spiral, according to the summary of the monthly report for June of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. The summary said June and the first half of the year were marked by a high rate of industrial activity.

Elizabeth Janeway's "Why They Become Communists" (June 14) is a fine piece of work. But, although she says so by inference, I still have not seen someone state, and in plain language, what I believe underlies the reason for so many American Communists, namely, the proverbial American good heart.

The most-powerful sea navigation light of its kind in the world, made by a British firm, has been installed by the United States Coast Guard in the Ambrose Light vessel. It is now visible at night from its station thirty miles from New York. From this famous travelers' mark the new beam shines with a power of 5,560,000 international candles.

Sir Winston Churchill -- descendant of the Dukes of Marlborough, soldier, author, First Lord of the Admiralty in two global wars, Prime Minister in one -- has been a part of world history for half a century. His great decisions -- to fight to the end in 1940, to oppose Stalinism in 1946 -- have altered its course.

Messager's operetta is somewhat faded nowadays, not having the high spirits of Offenbach, the musical solidity of Sir Arthur Sullivan or the unfailing melodic inspiration of the Strausses.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., June 27 (UP) -- Dr. H. C. Byrd became today the center of speculation as a possible candidate for Governor of Maryland as he set the stage for his retirement from the presidency of the state's university.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Opponents of President Eisenhower's plan to reorganize the Defense Department were decisively defeated in the House of Representatives today in an attempt to prevent it from taking effect on schedule at 12:01 A. M. Tuesday.

At 12:03 A. M. yesterday Henry G. Hanna, a stalwart Navy veteran and reservist who earns his living driving a truck had been commander of the Windsor Terrace Post of the American Legion in Brooklyn for eighteen minutes.

BACK in 1920, Thor. Mich., was a pretty little place with its quaintly turning Main Street, its town hall, two schools and the substantial company buildings. Thor differed from other sleepy, tree-shaded villages because it was a mining town and underneath its quiet, country look, violent struggles went on in the earth.

Since there are conflicting interpretations of the United Nations commitment to the cause of Korean independence and unity, it may be profitable to examine the record to discover what major steps have been taken and what positions have been assumed and maintained.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 27 (UP) -- The King Ranch's lightly weighted but fast-closing Rejected came up in the stretch today to capture the $110,200 Westerner for the 3-year-old championship of the West before a crowd of 45,000 at Hollywood Park today.

The recent increase in the rate on G. I. loans to 4 1/2 per cent means that such credits now provide the same return to the lender as Federal Housing Administration-insured loans. Lending institutions, therefore, are re-examining their loan policies in the light of the changed conditions.

Moscow made headlines around the world last week by announcing what seemed to be a substantial easing in the hitherto rigid restrictions on travel of foreigners about the Soviet Union. Where formerly the great bulk of the inhabited areas of the country had been completely forbidden territory, the new regulations made most of the Soviet Union nominally open for travel.

SCULPTURE has never really lost its ageless connection with magic and religion; but it nearly lost its life in the nineteenth century. Andrew Ritchie's volume is a call to order on the subject. Like all well-done art books, this one can persuade that its special subject is the very primal essence of all art, which it isn't.

PARIS, June 27 (AP) -- Premier Joseph Laniel, working rapidly to get his Cabinet functioning, prepared tonight a list of Ministers that included six former Premiers. He made few changes in key posts from the outgoing Government of Rene Mayer.

Factors which influence the life cycle of school buildings will be determined by a new research project now under way at the University of Michigan. The study will try to help school boards, consultants, planners and architects toward better decisions in the planning of school systems and in building design.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 27 -- With delays in jury trials in Brooklyn Supreme Court having built up to four years and seven months, the New York State Bar Association heard an appeal today for more judges to overcome the rising case load.

MANY orchestras have polled audiences to determine the works to be played on isolated "request" programs, but recently the National Symphony of Washington, D. C., sent out a check-list to the 10,000 persons on its mailing list asking for popular guidance to determine enough works for a whole season.

Greentree Stable's 4-year-old colt Tom Fool took up 135 pounds, spotted the friskiest of the opposition six or seven lengths in the first half of the run, and then charged down the stretch to a two-length victory and a record-equaling clocking in the role of 13-to-20 favorite in the $59,800 Carter Handicap at the Aqueduct track yesterday.

THE children of today may have transferred their allegiance from cowboys to space cadets, but the overall enthusiasm for rodeos seems as great as ever, judging by the long list of rodeos scheduled in twenty-one states and Canada during the next three months.

PARIS, June 27 -- The general public in France and Western Europe generally will be keenly disappointed by the postponement of the Bermuda meeting of heads of the Western Big Three Governments, which the average man saw as the prelude to high-level talks with Soviet leaders and possibly to better relations.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today the "unblocking" of about $15,000,000 in foreign property assets of fourteen free world countries -- the last that remained "frozen" under World War II controls.

MIAMI BEACH, June 27 -- A system of national standards for the teaching profession, to permit qualified teachers from one state to teach in another was urged today by the National Commission on Teacher Education and Professional Standards.

Stock prices moved higher during the week for the best gain since mid-March despite the stalemate in Korean truce negotiations. Thus, June and the first half of 1953 are coming to a close with two of the major uncertainties that ushered in the year still to be decided -- what to do about the Korean war and about taxes.

As I am a reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES, I do not know but hope that other newspapers are giving the American people unvarnished facts instead of feeding us on blind emotionalism based on factionalism instead of reason.

THE gentlemen who run Twentieth Century-Fox are planning to walk both sides of the street for at least a year despite repeated studio announcements that it will make all its pictures in the wide-screen CinemaScope process.

SHANGHAI, in the gayer and giddier days when it was known as "the Paris of the Orient," was probably the most misunderstood city on earth. Percy Finch, one of the better known Shanghai newspaper men during the period between World Wars I and II, has set himself in this book to the task of clearing away some of the weeds of popular misconception, and of telling what Shanghai really was.

IN the review of "Slave Mutiny," by William A. Owens, President Martin Van Buren is referred to by the reviewer, Samuel Flagg Bemis, as "a Northern man with Southern principles." This is most unfair to Van Buren.
A 60-year-old woman who jumped from a second-floor window and a 45-year-old couple were seriously injured in two early-morning fires in Brooklyn yesterday.

Women's failure to advance in the business world is one part prejudice and one part their personal attitudes, key business and professional men and women of the nation told the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Inc., in answer to a questionnaire on "What Holds Women Back ?"

At 4 P. M. today acting Police Capt. Elwin J. Cooney, 55 years old, will wind up his last working day amid the ringing, clacking, squawking telephones, teletypes and radios of the Communications Bureau and call it a career.

THE Panmunjom truce agreement specifies that within ninety days a peace conference will be held to discuss the conflicts which now disturb Asia. This means that the American people and their government must soon come to grips with such complex and intensely controversial issues as the unification of Korea, the war in Indo-China, Formosa, trade with Communist China, and our future relations with Japan and with the dynamic newly independent nations of South Asia.

EAST LANSING, Mich., June 27 (AP) -- Batting power features the 1953 All-America college baseball team, announced today by John H. Kobs, Michigan State baseball coach who heads the selection committee of the American Association of College Baseball Coaches.

LONDON, June 27 -- Widespread suspicion that Timothy John Evans, a 29-year-old bus driver, was unjustly three years ago for the murder of his infant daughter has brought demands here that the case he reopened and that the whole question of capital punishment be restudied.

A 28-year-old inspector for the Department of Housing and Buildings was booked yesterday on a charge of extortion after a landlord in Jamaica, Queens, had arranged to pass to the official marked bills as an alleged bribe not to report the conversion of a cellar to a three-room apartment.

Just ahead lie the days and weeks that try the gardener's mettle. Is he a gardener, or merely a planter? Can he tend as well as harvest? Can he take sunburn and backache, mosquitos and deer flies? Is he a weeder ? And a duster? And a sprayer?

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A high official of the International Information Administration told a Congressional committee this week that the book purge in the United States overseas libraries had been "exaggerated out of all proportion."

SINCE there have been indications of a new liveliness in the field of the modern dance during the past season, it is perhaps timely to consider the general state of health of that particular branch of art. In spite of the encouraging evidences of renewed vitality, the patient unfortunately seems to be still in a serious condition.

EGYPT'S transition from monarchy to republic, with Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib as the first President, foreshadows philatelic changes which are probably already in progress. The long series recently begun after King Farouk went into exile -- only a few values have appeared -- may be scrapped, and stamps with Naguib's portrait adorning some of the denominations may be expected.

United States Public Health officers will be entitled to overtime pay similar to that now received by Customs and Immigration officers for work outside regular hours under the provisions of a bill referred last week to the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Continue to spray roses, and also pick up and burn leaves with black spot. After the first heavy bloom, feed the bushes lightly by sprinkling a 5-10-5 fertilizer and cultivating it into the soil Cultivate after a good rain and then mulch in order to discourage weeds and reduce maintenance for the rest of the summer.

He saw reluctant little Chloe moved from grand house to grander, isolated from the normal companions of childhood, steered into the society of royalty, presentation at the Court of St. James and betrothal to a parasitic German prince.

MILWAUKEE, June 27 -- Peewee Reese hit a home run off Jim Wilson at the start of the tenth inning tonight to give the Dodgers a 4-3 triumph over the Braves and put the Brooks in a first-place tie with Manager Charley Grimm's team.
CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- The North Central Association's executive committee today refused to modify its ban on subsidies for college athletes.

One of the prime goals of modern engineering researchers today is the developing of structural materials able to withstand greater heat for longer periods. Metallurgists, chemists and ceramics experts are learning how to combine their skills to tackle the job jointly -- and they are making sound progress with techniques that were only laboratory dreams a decade ago.

IT was still September of 1904 and Michaelmas term had not yet begun, when a strange procession made its way uncertainly up the Broad. The young men carried assorted suitcases and gazed curiously at their ancient Gothic surroundings. Several wore wide-brimmed Stetson hats and one sported a six-shooter, large and gleaming, on his hip.

GLEN COVE, L.
