I., June 27 -- Killenworth, the former George du Pont Pratt estate, owned since 1950 by the Russian Embassy in Washington, went on the auction block at City Hall this morning for arrears in school taxes for the last half of 1952. The lien was purchased for $2,969 by Joseph Harris of Baldwin.

THIRTY-FIVE years as minister of Christ Church (Methodist) m New York City, twenty-five years of radio broadcasting, and more than two million letters from inquirers contribute to the background of Ralph W. Sockman's answers in this book to questions people ask about believing in the Christian religion.

PARIS, June 27 -- The lack of a fully authorized government in France for thirty-five days, at a time when critical world issues were up for decision, has thrown into somewhat invidious relief the contradictions, obscurities and uncertainties in French foreign policy and in the position of France in the world today.
Milton Bracker's story in THE TIMES of June 22, "Books of Forty Authors Banned by United States in Overseas Libraries," prompts me to recall the background on why these libraries were established.

Baffled, blanked and beaten, 5 -- 0, the bewildered Yankees continued to skid yesterday at the Stadium, where Casey Stengel's men dropped their sixth straight game. After Mike Garcia and the Indians had completed this latest humiliation of the world champions, only seven lengths separated the first and the second clubs in the American League.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 27 -The Netherlands Foreign Minister, Joseph M. A. H. Luns, en route to Australia in the course of a tour of Southern Asia, denied emphatically today that the Dutch hoped to evolve a military pact with Australia over disputed West New Guinea (Iran), vast jungle territory that Indonesia claims as her national boundary.

A SEQUENCE of autobiographical notes and sketches, "The Human Kind" covers the six-year period of World War II. The prologue sets the mood and its action occurs a few years before the outbreak of the war.
RAOUL FAURE introduces us to a lizard Galileo, depicting our human ways with the satirical device that has done service from Aristophanes to Orwell.

WHEN Thomas Edison started making movies in his "Black Maria" studio all he needed was sunshine. If Mr. Edison were still around in the movie business he would find he would also need more licenses than cameras, and that a study of the laws of the land was as much required knowledge as anything concerned with the laws of optics.
ROME, June 27 -- The Vatican newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano, said today that oppression of Roman Catholics in Poland was growing rapidly.

I READ with great interest Charles Lee's enthusiastic review of Lajos Zilahy's new novel, "The Angry Angel." But Mr. Lee did not, and could not of course, object to one chapter in the novel that deals with the "mysterious death" of my uncle, Count Paul Teleki, Prime Minister of Hungary in 1941.

DID you ever see the look on a customs official confronted by a pile of suitcases with a child sitting on each one? It begins with surprise and changes to benevolence, and whether the look is in English, French, Italian, Swiss or Portuguese the chances are that it is followed by quick clearance of the baggage.

FOR all the wailing over the unpalatability of Shakespeare for schoolboys -- two Philadelphia teachers have just published a "modernized" version of "Julius Caesar" to make it go down more easily -- enough of the youngsters seem to be growing up with a taste for the old boy.

The Hell Gate Pilots Association, which has been guiding shipping through the harbor's back door for the last hundred years, is marking its centennial with its membership feeling that, in many ways, the old times weren't half so rugged.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 27 (AP) -- Noel Brown, top-seeded, today won his semi-final match, but it remained for Les Longshore, Anniston, Ala., to provide the pyrotechnics by upsetting second-ranked Tony Vincent, Coral Gables, Fla., 6 -- 8, 6 -- 4, 8 -- 6, in another semi-final match of the Southwest open tennis tournament.

IF ALL garden flowers were grown under ideal conditions most of them could stand up through storms and high winds and not topple over. However, since home gardeners must make the best of the space and exposures available, plants often require staking to keep them erect and to preserve a neat appearance in the garden.

" Locusts are swarming east across the great Sind Desert of Pakistan to ravage vast areas in a country already fighting famine," reports the Karachi correspondent of this newspaper. We are having locust troubles, too. East of the Mississippi the well-known seventeen-year locust has come out of the ground.

Cardinal Spellman presented prizes in two essay contests yesterday afternoon at the chancery of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, 451 Madison Avenue to twenty eighth grade boys and girls from 285 parochial schools.

SIDI-BEL-ABBES, Algeria, June 22 -- For more than four years Sidi-bel-Abbes, home of the French Foreign Legion and long a citadel of colonial conservatism, had the paradoxical distinction of being the only city in North Africa with a Communist Mayor and a Communist City Council.

STANTON, Del., June 27 -- Earning his sixth major stakes conquest of the year and remaining a contender for championship honors, Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir's English-bred star, Royal Vale, today carried top weight of 130 pounds to a driving victory in the $28,900 Sussex Handicap at Delaware Park.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Leo Durocher's finest calculations were upset today as his Giants, blundering on the baselines and unable to untrack themselves on the attack, bowed to the forlorn Cubs, 2 to 1, before a surprised gathering of 13,725.

THURMONT, Md., June 27 -- President Eisenhower broke away from his week-end haven in near-by Camp David this morning and with Mrs. Eisenhower paid a visit to the Gettysburg farm where he had planned to live in retirement before he entered politics.

MILLICENT SELSAM, author of several science books for children, writes this time of all kinds of babies. Some of these -- giraffes, monkeys, kittens and humans -- are born miniature likenesses of their parents.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A small and obscure Government agency, hidden in the rear of one of those Washington "temporary" structures that seem to remain a permanent part of this city's landscape, was suddenly snapped out of apparent anonymity this week.

THE problem of writing about real children in a peaceful spot and involving them in adventures that will be exciting and not too improbable has always been a difficult one for any juvenile author. In "Slick 'n Me" Alf Evers has had a try at solving it but unfortunately he has not been entirely successful.

More than 50,000 fans are expected at the exhibition game tomorrow night, when the Yankees and Dodgers, world series rivals in 1941, 1947, 1949, 1952 and possibly next October, play at the Stadium for the Mayor's Trophy. The attraction, presented for the third straight year, will be for the benefit of sandlot baseball.

The Dodgers won, 4 -- 3, at Milwaukee last night on Peewee Reese's homer in the tenth inning to tie the Braves for the National League lead. The Cubs, with Warren Hacker on the mound, toppled the Giants, 2 -- 1. The Yankees were shut out by the Indians, 5 -- 0, at the Stadium for their sixth straight loss.

EDITH WHARTON was as defiant of posterity as she was of her own varnished social world during her lifetime. She bestowed her private papers on Yale University, stipulating that they remain unavailable until 1969.

At the Santa Barbara meeting of the Pacific Coast section of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, Horace R. Byers, professor and chairman of the University of Chicago's department of meteorology, detailed methods which, he believes, would settle the current dispute on the efficacy of rain-making.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 27 (AP) -- Earl Moeller of Oklahoma A. and M. won the final of the fifty-sixth National Collegiate A. A. golf tournament, beating William Williamson of North Carolina University, 3 and 2, today.

TUSSELING -- as small boys do -- in Uncle Crook Nose's truck, Eagle Feather and Teasing Boy accidentally released the brake and the truck rolled into a tree. Eagle Feather sturdily went off to give Crook Nose a summer's work for the damage done.

PLANT doctors have found that they can apply the methods of medical doctors. To cure or prevent troubles, plants can be made to take a dose of medicine through their leaves or roots. This dosing is comparable to the pink pills" or antibiotic injections given to cure human ailments.

RECENTLY museum directors from all over the country met in Buffalo for their annual conference. In joint sessions, they listened to papers and ate box lunches. In private groups, they made plans for joint exhibitions and discussed common problems from maintenance to masterpieces.

A system of partial Federal income tax exemption for small businesses that would reduce failures and encourage the establishment of new enterprises will be presented to Congressional finance committees at the earliest opportunity, Joseph Kolodny, managing director of the National Association of Wholesale Tobacco Distributors, announced last week.

BALLET fans will welcome Gloria Whitcomb's new adventures in Hollywood. Now a top ballerina, Gloria is chosen by a famous producer to star in his movie about Pavlova. Because she is untrained as an actress, she finds that her arrival is widely resented by the motion picture professionals.

BONN, Germany, June 27 -- The Allied High Commission today decontrolled and handed over to the German Federal Republic as the successor state to Hitler's Reich the former Hermann Goering Works, consisting of steel plants and iron-ore mines in Lower Saxony and coal mines and coking plants in the Ruhr.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- One of the many innovations President Eisenhower has brought to Washington is a Vice President with a passion for anonymity. Richard M. Nixon is carving out a career for himself which, to be successful, must be kept in the background.

LONDON, June 27 -- Making a surprise assault on the legendary 4-minute mile, lanky Roger Bannister of England today ran the distance in 4:02 -- the third fastest time ever recorded and only six-tenths of a second off Gunder Haegg's world record.

ENCOURAGED by the public's reception of the special economy fares for family and group travel, fifteen Eastern railroads have decided to extend these rates to Dec. 31. They had been scheduled to expire on Tuesday.

Experts from a British firm have just returned from the North African desert, where they have been testing a new type of pilotless target aircraft. Several of these small radio-controlled planes were built for the tests. Large numbers will soon be produced to be used for training gunners.

LONDON, June 27 (AP) -- New woes in the Soviet-captive Baltic States were reported tonight in a Moscow radio broadcast accusing the Red leadership in Latvia of nearly every sin in the Communist creed.

The struggle for representation of 600 unlicensed personnel in the marine division of the Atlantic Refining Company moved closer to decision last week as the National Labor Relations Board scheduled a hearing for Tuesday in its Philadelphia regional office.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Eisenhower Administration's reduced budget for the armed services was slashed by $1,337,422,500 today by the Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives.

WITH the fading of the aura of predatory ruthlessness created around him by his journalistic contemporaries, the original John D. Rockefeller is becoming a national hero. Seen in this new light, he is the American business man of his generation writ large.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINS, W. Va., June 27 -- A world struggle for survival between the American and the Soviet judicial systems is under way and judges and lawyers of this country must fight to preserve their system, Robert G. Storey, president of the American Bar Association, told the Judicial Conference of the Fourth Circuit here today.

Cleanliness as next to godliness was endorsed by speakers yesterday at a noon-hour ceremony arranged by the People's Civic and Welfare Association in front of 230 West 125th Street. William S. Bryant, "Mayor" of Harlem, presided at the celebration that highlighted the association's neighborhood improvement drive.

On June 10 President Eisenhower sent to Congress a message urging the immediate grant of 700,000 tons of wheat to combat famine in Pakistan. Within fifteen days the requisite legislation had been adopted, the bill signed by the President, a ship loaded and the first nine thousand tons were on the way.

ON the way to Bergen, Grieg's birthplace, and the scene of Norway's new international festival, you fly over immense towering mountains, snow-flecked, with a glacier or two thrown in for good measure, and you look deep down in great gashes between them, down to fjords and lakes and great rushing streams, and strips of verdant valley.

THIS is the story of a journey from darkness into light, the story of the peace an intelligent and courageous woman made with herself when she came to terms with death. When young Goodrich C. White Jr., bomber navigator and first son of the author, went down in his flaming plane over the Baltic Sea, his mother refused to face the fact of his death.

MANILA, June 27 -- President Elpidio Quirino left the Philippines this evening to seek medical treatment in the United States, but he kept firm control of all the administrative powers and machinery of government by executive decree. He intends to manage his country's involved affairs by phone from a Baltimore hospital, or wherever he may be.

A NOVEL is or, let us say, should be, something like a crystalline mineral which takes some inevitable form from an exact combination of substances under the influence of pressure and temperature. Yet the world of fiction, like the world of minerals, is full of examples in which the crystalline form is neither apparent nor recognizable.

TOKYO, June 28 (AP) -- The toll of modern Japan's worst flood seemed certain to pass 1,000 today, with more than 600,000 homeless and damage well in excess of $33,000,000. More rain was forecast for the stricken southern island of Kyushu.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 27 -- Little David, an aged chestnut gelding belonging to the Brook Run Stable of Greenwich, a post entry, ridden by Patricia Burke, today made a faultless round of the tricky twelve-barrier course in the eastern trials for the United States equestrian jumper team at the Fairfield County Horse Show.

BOSTON, June 27 (UP) -- A gust of wind blew Minnie Minoso's long fly into fair territory for a two-run double today as the White Sox came from behind in the ninth inning to defeat Boston, 6 -- 5, and take their sixth successive victory.

HAYDN was 68 when he wrote The Seasons and it was his last major composition. It stands thus as a sort of summarizing work, one in which his musical genius found rich and varied utterance and in which he left, one feels, a sort of testament of his ultimate feeling about the world.

Mayor Impellitteri will open the Police Athletic League playstreet on Henry street, between Gouverneur and Grand Streets, tomorrow at 2:30 P. M. The ceremony will mark the opening of forty-five playstreets, eleven playgrounds and three of the larger youth centers that the Police athletic League will operate until Aug. 28.

THE old-fashioned person who used to refer to "modern art" as if it were all of a piece -- and mostly incomprehensible -- must be having a bad time of it. And the Museum of Modern Art through its summer installation on the third floor is making such reference still more untenable.

HONG KONG, June 27 -- Ho Chi Minh's Vietminh insurgents in Indo-China, who moved regular troops from Vietnam into Laos a few months ago to set up a Communist-sponsored Laotian Government at Samneua, have recently been giving special propaganda attention to Cambodia in broadcasts emphasizing the "unity" of the Vietnamese, Laotian and Khmer (Cambodian) peoples.

ORSON WELLES, as busy an expatriate as any, is joining forces with none other than Sir Alexander Korda to produce a feature film titled, "Paris by Night," in England and France in the near future, it was learned last week.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Atomic artillery, guided missiles and a host of other advanced weapons, many still on the secret list, are being quietly worked into Army training to a degree that may radically alter many traditional techniques of ground warfare.

The recent price rises in crude oil and products east of the Rocky Mountains have resulted in more than the usual protests. Coming at a time when prices of most commodities, particularly farm products, were in a rather sharp downward readjustment, the oil price increases attracted the attention of the Department of Justice and also of the House Interstate Commerce Committee, which has called hearings for July 1 to explore the reasons for the advances.
ROANOKE, Va., June 27 (UP) -- The ten-member Southern Conference met in closed session here today and gave official notification that no new members would be admitted "at this time."

THE subtitle of this alleged manual for motorists ("A handy guide to chaos on the highway") will warn the reader what to expect. It seems evident that "The Half-Open Road" will never be endorsed by the driving-school of the AAA.

JOHN JOSEPH McGRAW was "the most hated, admired, envied, feared and respected player of all time * * * the game's greatest manager." Thus is baseball's stormiest petrel described by his wife in this fascinating and historically important biography.

Federal shipping authorities estimate that the movement of 1,000,000 tons of grain to Pakistan, under the aid measure signed last week, will require approximately 110 voyages by vessels of the Liberty or Victory ship classes. The first of the ships already is at sea, and a spokesman said the National Shipping Authority expected to expedite remaining voyages.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., June 27 -- Police Chief Leo Lunney estimated that 30,000 people crowded into this village of 5,000 today for the fortieth annual convention and parade of the New Jersey and New York Firemen's Association.

Memoranda left by a decedent for the guidance of executors, although affirmed in the decedent's last will and testament, may not be controlling with respect to the deductibility of charitable or educational bequests for Federal estate tax purposes.

A considerable change in the methods of manufacturing, advertising and merchandising men's sports shirts has taken place over the last ten years. Design and style are now of utmost importance; there is a marked tendency toward ensemble buying -- matching shirts, shorts or slacks and jackets -- and stores which previously catered exclusively to women are now stocking men's sports shirts.

WHEN classroom teachers start to teach by television, a review of the fundamentals of the art of teaching is in order, They must realize anew that every good teacher is an entertainer: He must secure and hold the attention of his audience while he communicates to them what it is his purpose to teach.

The Republic of Korea is one of the smallest and weakest nations on the globe. It has a population of 20,000,000, an area of 40,000 square miles -- about the size of Kentucky. The few industries it once possessed have been blasted by war; its major cities are in ruins; its agricultural production is below subsistence level.

ONE of the hundred-odd survivors of Ferdinand Magellan's voyage around the world was a Venetian named Don Antonio Lombardo. Lombardo kept a diary which is the prime source for material on the great voyage itself. He was by Magellan's side when the Captain General was killed in a senseless skirmish in the Philippines.

Your editorial of June 21 on the "Korean Crisis" leads me to write this. After a sympathetic but factual analysis of the crisis brought on by Dr. Rhee's release of 29,000 P, W.'s, you rightly state: "President Rhee and his Government must somehow be persuaded to bow to this group of hard facts.

MARKED by a broad humanity, moral indignation and a desire for social justice, T. K. Quinn's book represents one phase of the American tradition: the equalitarianism of Jacksonian democracy, Populism and the Wilsonian New Freedom.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower was reported today to be planning a last-minute written appeal to the House of Representatives for support in his battle to extend the excess profits tax. A top House Republican leader said the appeal probably would take the form of a letter to Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts or the Majority Leader, Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana.

The Eisenhower Administration last week waged an all-out struggle against opposition in Congress -- Republican opposition. The decision is due this week. The prospect is that if the Administration loses, its power to keep its own party in line may suffer lasting damage; if it wins, it will be at the expense of deeply wounded feelings among important elements of the party.

John A. Robertshaw of Greensburg, Pa., looked in on Wall Street twice last week. He visited the financial community on Tuesday to arrange for his company's sale of 160,000 shares of new 5 1/2 per cent convertible preferred stock. And he returned on Friday to sign the necessary papers to get the $3,760,000 proceeds of the offering to bring back to Greensburg.

More and more superhighways now are being built about the country. East and west, north and south, they run through the summer sunshine, the shortest distance at slightest gradient between two points.

The Brooklyn General Post Office, Washington and Johnson Streets, will be open twenty-four hours a day after Wednesday. The move is part of a general extension of hours announced yesterday by Edward J. Quigley, postmaster.

ST. LOUIS, June 27 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called on President Eisenhower today to fulfill his campaign promises to eliminate "second-class citizenship" and urged specifically that he order an end to segregation on Government projects, in National Guard and Organized Reserve military units and in Federally supported housing projects.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 27 --The belief that the third postponement might have administered a fatal blow to the Belqnuda parley arrangemerlts was' expressed in some circles today as officio[Is and hotel men pondered the effect of the news that Sir Winston Churchill, ;British Prime Minister, would be obliged to. rest at least one month.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 27 -- Turkey's fast growing Labor movement was assured today by the Republican People's party, this country's principal political opposition, that it would get the right to strike, subject to certain limitations, if the party came to power in the general elections next May.

EXCEPT for a few scattered public sales scheduled for July the stamp-auctioning season in New York will end this week. Since its start, about mid-September in 1952, there has been a gross turnover of $3,000,000 at some 160 auctions, according to conservative estimates by several Manhattan auctioneers.

FOR the wild flower gardener, summer's hot, dry days are likely to be critical. The wild plants commonly attempted in the home garden are usually woodland natives that need relative coolness and a fair amount of moisture.

More than 190 technical papers on a wide range of subjects in the field of engineering materials will be presented at the fifty-sixth annual meeting of the American Society for Testing Materials, beginning today and continuing through next Friday at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall in Atlantic City.
PARIS, June 27 -- Robert and Gerald Finaly reached a haven today after five months of clandestine wandering while a stormy battle was being waged for their bodies and souls.

ST. LAMBERT, Que., June 27 (AP) -- The Oxford-Cambridge track and field team scored in four events today at the Eastern Canadian championships. David Law winning the Coronation Mile and Chris Chataway the three-mile run.

VIENNA, June 27 -- A tentative promise made to the Austrian Government here some weeks ago by the Soviet High Commissioner that Austrian war prisoners still in the Soviet Union would be amnestied was confirmed in Moscow last night.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Senators scored three runs in the ninth inning to defeat the Tigers, 6 -- 5, tonight. Washington contributed only a single to the winning rally as Detroit pitchers walked three and Shortstop Harvey Kuenn committed a damaging error.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 (UP) -- Other leading results today in the Wimbledon tennis championships:

Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., began yesterday against the New York City Transit Authority the same type of "war of nerves" that he has often waged against the Board of Transportation, former operator of the city-owned transit lines.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 27 (UP) -- President Victor Paz Estenssoro warned the Bolivian people yesterday to be "alert and prepare for eventual civil war."

PRINCETON, N. J., June 27 -- A letter written by George Washington at the close of the Revolutionary War, in which he outlined his policy for assuring "the future reputation, tranquility, happiness and glory" of the United States, has been acquired by Princeton University, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced today.

I HAVE read your critic's thoughtful and excellent article concerning the effect of critics upon productions in the theatre. While I have no question as to the actuality of his conclusion that it is the theatregoing public which makes or fails to make a play successful.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 28 -- President Syngman Rhee of South Korea and Walter S. Robertson, Assistant United States Secretary of State, held their third meeting in Seoul today in an attempt to reach a solution to the crisis that arose when Dr. Rhee refused to accept armistice terms drafted by Communist and United Nations negotiators at Panmunjom.

Looking in perfect physical condition and neatly dressed in a dark blue suit, white shirt and blue-figured necktie, Harry S. Truman arrived in New York yesterday on his first visit to the city since he left the Presi dency.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -The House of Representatives today approved by a voice vote and returned to the Senate a bill to continue for another year major features of the Federal housing programs.

Dana Adams Schmidt's "Israel's 'Little War' of the Borders" (June 14) was a real eye opener. By now it should be obvious to everyone concerned that the partition borders of Israel are a standing invitation to trouble and a major stumbling block to stability and progress in the Middle East.

ISRAEL'S Ingathering is bringing together Jews of all nations, all colors. Black, white and brown are mingled, particularly in the training groups of Youth Aliyah. Psychologists, working with these groups, are startled to find that children from the "oriental countries" cannot even be measured by Western intelligence tests, for their very thought processes are different. And yet, the children blend.

There is probably nothing in the world Winston Churchill would rather do than go somewhere on a ship, preferably a battleship. There is probably no project dearer to his heart than a full agreement with the United States and France and some kind of settlement with Russia that would lift from the world the awful fear of war.
CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- Hasty House Farm's Ruhe blunted Hill Gail's 1953 comeback with a driving upset victory today in the $50,000 added Equipoise Mile at Arlington Park.

DURING the past month a new schedule of admission fees for automobiles, motorcycles and trailers was put in effect by the National Park Service at twenty-nine national parks and monuments. Under the new system, permits for visitors planning maximum stays of fifteen days will cost no more than formerly; the price of annual permits, however, covering repeated visits during the year, will be double the fifteen-day fee.

BELGRADE, June 27 -- Ever since Marshal Tito's break with the Cominform in 1948 there have been enough Westerners who denied that it was a real break to provoke repeated argument and avowal that it was.
PHOENIX, Ariz. -- The most useful bit of equipment that the Easterner who plans to motor through the Southwest this summer can bring along is a sizable supply of caution.

Ever since reading "New Masterworks for The Cloisters'' in your issue of June 7, I have been eager to visit Fort Tryon Park and hear the din as the bluish-gray monkeys "clamor playfully" on the Monkey Cup. What a disappointment to find them as quiet as in a cloister!

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- More than one-quarter of all imports, and at least one-sixth of the nation's exports, can be traced directly to foreign investments made by American capital, according to the Department of Commerce. A study, prepared by the Department, is being circulated among foreign traders for their comments.

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 27 -- Jack Sunderland of Orange, N. J., seeded second, set the pace for the opening rounds today of the New Jersey men's tennis championships at the Oritani Field Club. The F. B. I. agent easily defeated Dave Seifer of East Orange, N. J., 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.

There is a lost battalion of stockholders for whom $1,000,000 is waiting. Where are 5,800 stockholders of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, once headed by the late Wendell L. Willkie? The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, organized by the Morgan-Drexel-Bonbright and American Superpower interests in the late nineteen-twenties, has been dissolved in conformance with the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

BERLIN, June 27 -- The three Western High Commissioners asked their new Soviet counterpart today to end martial law in East Berlin, to restore normal communications between the two parts of the city and to remove barriers erected by the Communists last year on the East-West German border.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 27 -- Mrs. Jacqueline Pung of Honolulu and Betsy Rawls of Spartanburg, S. C., tied for the United States Golf Association's women's open championship today with seventy-two-hole scores of 302.

Congratulations should go to Paul R. Williams, a distinguished architect of Los Angeles, who has just joined such outstanding persons as George Washington Carver, Marian Anderson and Dr. Ralph Bunche as a recipient of the Spingarn Medal. This is one of the most felicitous of our national honors, since it singles out Negroes who have made an unusual contribution to our community life.

MADRID, June 27 -- Evidence of the deep interest the United States Navy has been taking in Spain's strategic value to the defense of the Western Mediterranean was contained in a speech today by Vice Admiral J. H. Cassady, Commander of the United States Sixth Fleet, at Ciudadela in Minorca, one of Spain's Balearic islands.

NEW DELHI, India, June 27 -- India will withhold her troops from duties related to the work of a repatriation commission during a Korean armistice until conditions are such that they can "function peacefully," Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today.

All branches of the New York Public Library in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island will be closed next Saturday, Independence Day. In the Fifth Avenue building, the main reading room and information division will remain open, as usual, from 9 A. M. to 10 P.M.

SEOUL, Korea, June 27 -- Life in South Korea this week appeared pretty much as it had during the past year and a half. With the exception of Thursday -- the third anniversary of the war -- there was no outward indication that the republic was going through an extremely critical period.

IF by land, the proper approach to this queen of islands is by way of Boston, down the south shore through Plymouth and across the Cape Cod Canal to Buzzards Bay and Woods Hole. This is true even if you start from New York, for you are thus spared the vexation of plowing your way through Providence, an estimable town in all respects save its evident hankering to confuse, bewilder and delay the passing motorist.

CAIRO, June 27 -- Arab Legion Headquarters in Amman, the capital of Jordan, has disclosed evidence of a renewal of what is declared to be the considered policy of the Israeli Government to expel Arab residents from the territory it occupies under the 1949 armistice agreement.
SYRACUSE, June 27 -- Hamilton Richardson of Tulane University is the new national intercollegiate tennis champion.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -Mr. Wolfe had been scheduled to fly to Washington to face questioning on Monday, but his departure was canceled today for undisclosed reasons following a last-minute cable from Washington.

GILBERT ROLAND, after almost thirty-five years in Hollywood, and having tasted both the sweet and the bitter fruits of fame, still is going strong as a screen personality and putting into his work the drive and enthusiasm that also make him a man to contend with on the tennis court.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -An attack on the Administration power policy by a group of liberal Senators today marked Senate debate on the $473,762,900 money bill for flood control and navigation projects.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -Investigators for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy disclosed today that Rockwell Kent, the painter; Lillian Hellman, the playwright, and Dorothy Parker, the writer, were among twenty-three persons to be called as possible witnesses next week to testify on the State Department's overseas libraries and information centers.

CINCINNATI, June 27 (UP) -- Ted Kluszewski hit his twenty-second homer and a run-producing single in the midst of a ten-run, seventh-inning uprising that enabled the Redlegs to trounce the Pirates. 15 -- 5, today.

NEW YORK'S social approach to alcoholism is the basis for a new examination of the whole problem by the Yale Center of Alcohol Studies. To rehabilitate some of the men on skid row statistics are now flowing to the university so that the scientists can recommend better treatment.
BONN, June 27 -- The revolutionary urprising in East Berlin and in East Germany on June 16 and 17 has transformed radically the nature and scope of the German problem.

" Aspirin is the hero of this story, all of us six million people in New York, swallowing it, day after day. All of us in pain, needing it. Aspirin is an evasion. But so is life. The way we live it. You take aspirin in order to keep going * * *"

THE equivalent of selling sun lamps to tropical aborigines has been undertaken by local record makers. They are selling noise to New Yorkers -- real noise, not just violent forms of tonalism or bop. Anyone in town suffering from decibel deficiency does not have to move next door to a busy fire house.

THE League of Composers has not lost its zest to do battle for the contemporary composer, and it is now embarked on a fresh crusade. It is seeking to persuade the concert artist, American as well as foreign, that it is his duty to perform at least one work of our own time on all programs in the course of his tours through the country.

It would be hard to find a lake, river, bay, harbor, creek or mud pond that won't have some kind of a speed boat regatta over the coming Fourth of July week-end. No section of the country will be without the exciting daredeviltry.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 27 -- Ralph L. Craig's Wilmington's Star from Urbana, Ohio, tonight defeated a strong field of pacers in the $10,000 Glen Head free-for-all at the Roosevelt Raceway.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (UP) -- Duane Pillette hit the first homer of his major league career today and went on to pitch the Browns to a 6-1 victory over the Athletics.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 27 -- The United States, which for forty-four years has been striving for an international agreement to limit opium production, saw that dream become a reality when the representatives of nineteen countries signed an opium protocol here this week designed to control the drug.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 27 -- The crisis among the 1,000,000 Kikuyus that produced the Mau Mau rebellion against domination by whites has resulted in a detailed soil study of the Kikuyu reserve and a project for solution of the African Negroes' predicament.

A hundred years ago -- day and date is not certain -- a whiskered hero from the Texas wars borrowed a pan from a Shaker maiden at New Lebannon, N. Y., and first successfully condensed milk over a low fire and using a partial vacuum. His name was Gail Borden.

The United States Marine Safety Corporation, an organization specializing in the instruction of merchant marine personnel in fire fighting, accident prevention, safety and atomic defense, has opened new offices at 80 Wall Street, it was announced here yesterday by John J. Dunleavy Jr., president.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The "new look" security program promulgated April 27 by the Eisenhower Administration has moved pretty well out of the casting stage so far as the principal characters are concerned but seems still considerably short of full-dress staging.

INCLUDING dogs and cats in the family party on summer vacation motor trips has become an established custom among thousands of dog-lovers and cat-lovers, respectively. While they prove jolly and faithful companions, according to those who love them, it is well to remember that caresses and kind words will not take the place of proper diet and other, care, something as true of pets as of children.

Hot weather and preparations for seashore, mountains or camp pulled up sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores in the week ended yesterday to a figure estimated to be 8 per cent more than sales in the corresponding week of 1952. The gain covered a broad variety of goods in both hard and soft categories.

READING, Pa. -- For five days beginning this Wednesday, Kutztown, Pa., on U. S., 222 between Reading and Allentown, will be the hub of the Pennsylfawnische Deitch. At the fairgrounds in this Berks County community the fourth annual Pennsylvania Dutch Folk Festival, sponsored by the Folklore Center of Franklin and Marshall College in Lancaster, will feature all facets of Pennsylvania Dutch culture.

TELEVISION'S summer replacement season is well along on its course, although a few more programs are scheduled for July premieres. The following opinions on some of the newcomers -- including drama, music and quiz programs -- were gathered during a tour of the channels last week.

In his column on June 22 E. H. Collins emphasized the fact that the cost of living has failed to decline despite the decreases reported in wholesale prices and in sensitive prices. He also noted properly that this was contrary to past experience, when declines in living costs tended to follow decreases in wholesale prices.

The Federal Reserve System has just set the stage for what is probably the most irksome task the nation's central banking system ever has undertaken. The job is to expand further the money supply of an inflated and booming economy so that the Treasury can readily borrow money to pay current expenses far outstripping the tax funds that are at hand from the last Congress' unbalanced budget.

Barricaded behind two snarling dogs, a man -- believed dead -- dozed peacefully on a park bench yesterday while patrolmen, Park Department employes and ambulance attendants tried to bypass the animals to reach him.

QUENTIN GOURLAY is the heroic young man who was introduced to the world in Mr. Ronald's earlier novel, "Man Born of Woman." In this present volume Quentin's adventures between his twelfth and twenty-first years are vigorously set down, along with the side adventure of about a dozen other characters remarkable for both their diversity and their vitality.
ALL around the country and all about the house the children are On Vacation. Camp directors and staffs of counsellors will help direct the youthful energies of many thousands of fortunate youngsters.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP) -- A fight long smoldering on the American business scene is under way here between the trucking industry and the railroads. At the heart of the controversy is the question of what highway weight limits should be imposed on trucks.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., June 27 -- Donald R. Wilson of Clarksburg, W. Va., past national commander of the American Legion, and Manuel Tello, Mexican Ambassador to the United States, will speak at the twenty-fifth annual memorial services for Capt. Emilio Carranza at Carranza Memorial Park, near Tabernacle, on July 11.

THERE are cracks in the Soviet monolith. They have appeared in the satellite states, in the workers' uprisings and protests in Czechoslovakia and throughout East Germany. They have appeared in the U.S.S.R. itself, in the purges in the Ukraine. There have been others.

From all over Communist East Germany last week -- in reports of escaped eyewitnesses, through official announcements of repressive measures, between the lines of propaganda handouts -- came evidence of unrest. In Halle saboteurs sent a synthetic rubber plant up in smoke.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 27 -- Action by the United Nations against aggression in Korea, constituting "a new formula in the history of political conflicts," demands that the world adapt itself to accept "such unfamiliar developments as a war which ends without total victory for any party but only for a principle," Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said in a recorded speech broadcast today.

MADISON, Wis., June 27 -- Wisconsin Republicans are hoping to ride out the storm of criticism that followed their censuring of Senator Alexander Wiley for his support of President Eisenhower's opposition to the Bricker amendment. That action was taken at the state convention on June 13 when a resolution was passed assailing the Republican Senator.

Most of us would have dismissed as evidence of mental aberration the publication four or five years ago of an advertisement that read: "Wanted: Man of good character to direct twelve-billion dollar enterprise. Technical knowledge or managerial experience unnecessary.

News that full agreement has been reached in the Bangkok conference between Nationalist China and Burma on the repatriation of Chinese guerrillas is heartening. The good offices of both Thailand and the United States have been well used in this case. The technique of the conference has been peculiar, since the Burmans and the Chinese have not negotiated face to face but only through intermediaries, because Burma does not recognize the Nationalist Government of China.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 27 -- A world record leap of 6 feet 11 1/2 inches by Walter (Buddy) Davis in the high jump provided a smashing finish to the Amateur Athletic Union's sixty-fifth national outdoor track and field championships today.

A new program of fellowships, scholarships and study awards, designed to help meet the "recognized need for additional and more highly trained skilled leaders in adult education,'' was announced yesterday by the Fund for Adult Education, established by the Ford Foundation.

PARIS, June 27 -- Whether they are planning a long-term peace or eventual war, the masters of the Kremlin, when they look westward from Moscow, must clearly be worried most by two projects for strengthening the Allied world along the European peripheries of the Soviet bloc.

HOME owners must face a force that would destroy a popular shade tree. The few hot dry days in early June have suddenly brought out the symptoms of maple wilt. This is an internal fungus disease which causes large branches, and sometimes the entire tree, to wilt and die.

LUBBOCK, Tex., June 27 -- Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, took a personal look at the drought area around here today and then promised that cattle men and farmers in the Southwest would receive long-term Federal loans for their farms and stock herds, while feed would be furnished through the Commodity Credit Corporation.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan appealed to parents, motorists and pedestrians yesterday for "active cooperation" in a drive to reduce accidents, especially those involving children, in the Fourth of July week-end and the school vacation period.

To most people sterilization means the killing of microbes by heat or chemicals. The Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association reports another method which may be preferable in some cases. It is an old method, one which played its part in the discovery of the viruses and which consists of putting the liquid through a porcelain filter with pores so fine that bacteria are held back, just as if they were tea leaves in an ordinary strainer.
AT THE KOREAN FRONT, June 27 -- The South Korean Army has suffered some local reverses in this section, but that does not mean that its ability as an effective fighting team should be underestimated.

THIS is a good time to take inventory of the rock garden from the point of view of maintenance. This planting, however large or small, has had its pageant of bloom. Perhaps the anemones and primulas were outstanding in May, and June surely turned the rock garden into a rosy haze of dianthus blossoms with some blue from campanulas.
ONE day last spring this reporter stood behind the batting cage with Master Mickey Mantle while Ed Lopat served up pitches at frustrated Yankee swingers during a training session in Florida.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 27 -- Lonach's Questa, a perfect mannered bitch owned by John F. McMahon of Yonkers, N. Y., was judged best of winners at the fifth annual specialty show of the German Shepherd Dog Club of Long Island on the grounds of the Garden City Hotel today.

ARISING spirit of disenchantment with this country's allies is being observed in the Republican Congress. It could not properly be called isolationism in the usual meaning of that term, and it is not exactly nationalism. But certainly it is not too hospitable to the United Nations, which assuredly, is at the lowest point of Congressional esteem in its short and hard history.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 27 -The Coalition Government led by Dr. Urho Kekkonen resigned today because of differences over economic policy between the Agrarian and Socialist partners in the Cabinet. Dr. Kekkonen, the Agrarian leader, will formally hand the resignation to President Juho Paasikivi on Monday.

THAT droll and resonant world figure, Harry Lillis "Bing" Crosby (unnumbered millions on either side of the Iron Curtain regard him as The Voice of America), has talked his autobiography to Pete Martin.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Truman Government-in-exile (from Washington, that is) made its first en masse return to Washington this week for a round of gay social festivities and high politicking aimed toward a day when a Democrat could be put back in thee White House.

EDINBURGH, June 27 (UP) -- Queen Elizabeth II, the drawn swords of her household cavalry gleaming, rode to the gate of Edinburgh Castle today and demanded that the Governor and garrison admits her at their "highest peril."

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 -- Cramp and fatigue plagued the older guard -- but with different results -- in this most exhausting of international tennis championships today as Gardnar Mulloy and Jaroslav Drobny limped and lunged around the courts under a blazing sun as the men's all-England singles field completed the quarter-final round.

CLEVELAND, June 27 (AP) -- Ted Kroll, 33-year-old New Hartford (N. Y.) professional, stormed out of the pack with a 4-under-par 68 today to take a one-stroke lead at the end of fifty-four holes in the seventy-two hole, $15,000 Manakiki open golf tournament.
I SAY a day without a salt. A trudge. The air was ordinary, the colors common; men, animals, and trees indifferent. Something had stopped working.

ESTES PARK, Colo., June 27 -The Central Conference of American Rabbis called on religious bodies throughout the country today to join with it in "condemnation" of the "undemocratic" investigative procedures it ascribed to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, Senator William Jenner of Indiana and Representative Harold H. Velde of Illinois.

RYE, N. Y., June 27 -- John G. Hupfel's sloop, Marquesa, won the first phase of Pequot Yacht Club's annual two-day cruise to American Yacht Club and back by heading the fleet on the 22 1/4-mile voyage from Southport to Scotch Caps off here today.

THE National Broadcasting Company is losing no time in putting into effect its newly granted Federal Communications Commission temporary authority to test the compatible color video system during regular broadcast hours.

A NEW railroad car intended to provide enclosed sleeping accommodations at coach fares has been designed by the Budd Company and is being offered to the nation's railroads. The new coach, perhaps the most revolutionary development in rail transportation since the introduction of the reclining seat, reserved accommodation coaches and individual-room Pullman cars, would presumably attract to the railroads many travelers who now use buses, air coaches or private cars for reasons of economy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 27 -- Despite the blackness of the situation in Korea, most delegates continue to believe, without being able to offer any very convincing reasons, that an armistice can be saved. That is the reason why there is practically no support so far for India's suggestion that the General Assembly be called back into session almost immediately.

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., June 27 -- A power squadronite and trained navigator from the Stamford Yacht Club. Vincent C. Hall, in his 36-footer Deuteron, won the first predicted log test today for the new Huckins Trophy with an amazing accuracy.

ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) -- The Cardinals withstood Philadelphia's challenge for third place, driving the Phillies three games behind the Redbirds by winning tonight's game, 4 -- 3, after handing Robin Roberts his hardest hammering of the season in a 7-4 afternoon contest.

Because the job of superintendent of schools may be the biggest administrative job in the community, the occupant should be paid accordingly. This advice is contained in a report, "What to Pay Your Superintendent," issued jointly by the American Association of School Administrators and the National School Boards Association.

EXCEPT that the arrival of summer in the realm of movies has been slightly complicated this year by a virulent epidemic of wide screens and 3-D, both of which have resulted in discomforts which the public seems reluctant to report, there appears to be very little difference in the average quality of the entertainments it has brought.

WHEN a boy sets out on a beautiful Saturday morning for a walk through the woods and fields near his home he is bound to turn up some interesting experiences. Especially if the boy loves to pretend, as Billy does, that he is a great explorer and collector.

MIAMI, Fla., June 27 (AP) -- Harry O. Voiler, 62 years old, Miami Beach hotel owner, who was publisher of The Miami Beach Morning Mail for two months in 1950 before it went out of business, has been ordered deported.
An appraisal of the elementary school curriculum and suggestions for its improvement are set out in an extensive report issued last week by a committee of thirty-two prominent educators.

THE half-year mark is just ahead, and with the passing of each day the prognosticators of a business recession in the second half of the year probably are wondering when it will start. The chances are good, of course, that it won't start at all.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that only proper union leadership -- not criminal prosecution or Government regulation -- could eradicate racketeers from the ranks of organized labor.

Formal dedication ceremonies will be held Thursday for the new Clinical Center of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. In contrast to the ordinary large hospital, whose function is primarily patient care with research as a secondary interest, this new fourteen-story structure is unusual both in design and function in that it has been designed, constructed equipped and staffed specifically for research.

THE cocktail party season, the first of President Eisenhower's term, is clinking to a close. The Administration is reported to look with some disfavor on this Washington institution, as something which does not enhance the capital's reputation, interferes with hard work and makes the official more vulnerable to outside pressure. If this attitude is correctly described, it is hard to discern that it is having any effect.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 27 -- Patience was one thing sailors competing in the regular Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association regatta had to have plenty of today. There was very little wind through the long afternoon and skippers made liberal use of spinnakers as they tried to take full advantage of every puff.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- Enos Slaughter of the Cardinals moved ahead of his rivals today in the balloting for the right-field position on the National League team in the annual all-star baseball game.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, June 28 (AP) -- Pounding rains and raging mountain streams today stalled the Chinese Communist offensive on Korea's east-central front, giving the South Korean soldiers time to shore up their defense line twelve miles north of the Hwachon Reservoir.
MILWAUKEE, June 27 (UP) -- The Braves today voluntarily agreed to tear up the contract calling for $1,000 a year rental for the new County Stadium and negotiate a new $25,000 contract.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 27 -- At a Communist meeting yesterday in Novi Sad, rank-and-file Communists were warned that an active political opposition to their leadership in Yugoslavia was developing to the point where some anti-Communists were said to be harboring hopes for return to a pre-war regime.

SINCE it treats exactly the same material, "Oh, What a Wonderful Wedding" is bound to be compared with Edward Streeter's "Father of the Bride." Mr. Streeter got there fustest, but Miss Rowans has followed him with the mostest and the funniest.
TOKYO, June 27 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Saturday, Korean time:

The executive committee of the Affiliated Young Democrats, Inc., decided yesterday to begin the circulation this week of primary petitions for the city-wide offices for which party nominations will be made at the primary election on Sept. 15.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 27 (AP) -- Newark A. C. swimmers won three of four events today in a New Jersey Amateur Athletic Union-sanctioned women's outdoor swimming meet.
BALTIMORE, June 27 -The Maryland governorship primary will be held in May next year and Dr. Byrd is perhaps the foremost of five possibilities for the Democratic nomination.

THE Roth-Stone system of contract bridge bidding has become -- or at least is becoming -- the most controversial subject the game has known since Ely Culbertson and the Four Aces team engaged in battles of bidding theory back in 1934.
The impending truce in Korea will call for new decisions on a number of issues. These, I suggest, may be outlined as follows:

PASSENGERS flying the airliners operating out of New York International Airport (Idlewild), La Guardia and Newark Airports, may expect fewer delays when the new instrument landing system, approved by the Civil Aeronautics Administration, is put into effect.

UNIONTOWN, Pa. -Vacationists driving through this southwestern corner of Pennsylvania will find it interesting to take a look at the Fort Necessity National Battlefield Site, eleven miles from Uniontown on U. S. 40, the Old National Road which spans the continent from Atlantic City to Oakland, Calif.

On Wednesday the city will fill 180 openings for laborers. To be sure they are at the head of the line at 8 A. M. that day, seven young men from the Bronx pitched camp Friday night outside the administration building of the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Playground, 100 Cherry Street, where the applications will be processed on a first-come-first-served basis.

IF a picture is worth making but presents technical problems, a resourceful photographer should be able to find ways to solve them. And he can if he learns to master his equipment and techniques, David B. Eisendrath Jr., a leading photojournalist, told the Village Camera Club last week.

WHEN the highest authority in our land brought out into the open the question of "book burning," he struck a match and started a small intellectual conflagration. "Arise and bid me strike a match," Yeats wrote.

EARLIER this month, iris fanciers from all over the country attended the annual convention of the American Iris Society in Boston, Mass., and had an opportunity to see the newest kinds of tall Bearded iris. The program included visits to thirteen iris gardens.

Foreign exchange market continued on the dull side through another week of indecisive movement on the part of any of the major exchanges. British pound sterling and the Canadian dollar moved within a fractional range on limited orders that were made to fill only necessary requirements.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Republican leadership of the House of Representatives banked tonight on getting needed Democratic help to bring the excess profits tax extension to the floor tomorrow. High confidence was voiced that, once this initial victory had been won, the extension would be voted overwhelmingly.

The United States trans-Pacific airlift to Korea, which will be three years old tomorrow, has involved the transportation of 1,500,000 pounds of blood and 8,000,000 pounds of mail to military personnel.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 28 (AP) -- Dr. Albert F. Zahm, a pioneer in the study of aeronautical science, has returned to live at the University of Notre Dame, where he conducted experiments in flying long before the first airplane flight.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, said today he had induced a grafting Government worker to confess, but the Justice Department had had to get permission from the man's boss before it could prosecute.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UP) -- Stockmen who pressed the Government for higher wool tariffs and relaxed grazing regulations on national forests will have to settle -- temporarily, at least -- for a lot less than they wanted.

J. Whitney Bunting, president of Oglethorpe University, says in opening his book, Ethics for Modern Business Practice*, which he edits with eight other contributors, "Ethics has had a long and profitable life." He and his colleagues proceed to document the truism.

NEW DELHI, India, June 28 (AP) -- Club-swinging police charged a hysterical, hero-worshiping crowd that mobbed Mount Everest conquerors Tenzing, the Sherpa guide, and Edmund P. Hillary upon their arrival today at New Delhi's Palam airport.

Any earnest inquiry into the reasons for the unpleasantness that is Monday leads inevitably to the conclusion that among the chief causes of Monday's dreariness is that it happens to be a wait-until day.

ST. LOUIS, June 28 -- Harold E. Stassen, the Director for Mutual Security, appealed today to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to take the lead in correcting misconceptions by other nations on the treatment of Negroes in the United States.
" The Prescott Proposals," a new play by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, is scheduled for production here in the fall by Leland Hayward.

Harry S. Truman's early morning walk is never more striking than on a summer Sunday at 7 o'clock, when most New Yorkers are asleep. Having arrived here on Saturday too late for his customary outing, the former President stepped out quite early yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, June 28 -- Because of needed furnace repairs and the approach of vacations it will be harder for the steel industry to maintain a steel rate of 100 per cent or close to it. Many units have been running at full tilt for months on end.

TRENTON, June 28 -- The New Jersey Division of Motor Vehicles, in an effort to reduce substantially what it considers to be inexcusable accidents, will begin requiring within the next three months that every applicant for a driver's license or learner's permit submit first to a complete physical examination.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., June 28 -- The Merrill Center of Economics was opened formally here today by Amherst College on a sixteen-acre estate recently donated by Charles E. Merrill, New York stock broker.

TOKYO, Monday, June 29 (AP) -- The toll of dead, injured and homeless in a ravaging flood on Japan's southern island of Kyushu rose steadily today as flood waters, fed by seven days of torrential rains, surged higher and forced virtual evacuation of two large cities.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 28 -- Greenwich will reach a fiscal milestone Wednesday when the penultimate payment is made on the municipal debt. It now totals only $91,000, contrasted with $6,455,000 in 1932, when the town adopted the pay-as-you-go financial policy that precludes bonding.

TOKYO, Monday, June 29 -- President Syngman Rhee of South Korea and Walter S. Robertson, Assistant United States Secretary of State, held a fourth meeting in Seoul today in a continuing effort to iron out differences blocking an armistice in the Korean war.

Thousands of 7 to 17-year-old girls, all daughters of migrant industrial workers, are now engrossed in scouting activities as a result of special Girl Scout pilot projects in three critical defense areas in this country. This information was disclosed today with the release of the organization's 1952 report to Congress.

New York lawyers will honor Charles C. Burlington today as "the first citizen of New York." He will receive the medal of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York for "exceptional contributions to the honor and standing of the bar in this community."
BABYLON, L. I., June 28 -- Fingerprints from the civilian files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation enabled the police today to arrest a suspect in the Belmont State Park lake murder mystery.

The election of Vice Admiral Glenn B. Davis, U. S. N., retired, an ordnance expert and former commander of the battleship Washington, as president of the Isthmian Steamship Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, was announced over the week-end.

May produced the largest volume of newspaper advertising in history in the fifty-two cities surveyed by Media Records and reported on yesterday. The total of 244,446,405 lines was exceeded only by the 245,003,540 in the same papers in October, 1952.
PHILADELPHIA, June 28 (AP) -- Sixty hotel employes have good evidence today that it does not cost anything to be kind and that it can pay off in unexpected ways.
TOKYO, Monday, June 29 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,660, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korean time:

GADSDEN, Ala., June 28 (AP) -- A Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company official said today a group of workers had been suspended Friday for "giving the stare treatment" to two employes who had testified for a "right-to-work" bill pending in the Alabama Legislature.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, June 29 -- The Chinese Communist Army poured out a thunderous artillery barrage and slammed more than 12,000 troops into the western front north of Seoul today in an unusual broad daylight attack. Chinese Red attacks usually start in the night.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UP) -- Frank C. Nash, Assistant Defense Secretary, indicated today that Europe would need American military aid for at least another ten years, and said that any sharp cut at this time would have a "catastrophic effect."
BOSTON, June 28 (AP) -- Chicago's White Sox routed Boston by 13 -- 4 today for their seventh straight victory and fourteenth in their last sixteen games.

A rally of the American Labor party, held at the Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday for the avowed purpose of starting the party's city election campaign and of "voicing the desire of thousands of New Yorkers for an immediate truce in Korea," drew 3,500 persons instead of the 15,000 expected, and produced only scant reference to a campaign.

NEW ORLEANS, June 28 -- A three-day healing by a Senate subcommittee brought a statement of praise last week for the efficiency of the Port of New Orleans. Investigation of the affairs of Local 1,419, International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and its president, Dave A. Dennis, will, however, be pursued.

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 28 -- Sidney Schwartz of Brooklyn, top-seeded, eked out a 5-7, 6-3, 6-4 victory over Robert J. Kerdasha of New York City today, while three seeded players were eliminated in the second and third rounds of the New Jersey state men's tennis championship at the Oritani Field Club.
THURMONT, Md., June 28 -- The crippled lad spoke up when President Eisenhower asked him this morning what he liked for dessert.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Billy Hoeft's eight-hit pitching gave Detroit a 5-1 victory over Washington in the second game of a double-header today after the Senators had won the opener, 5 -- 2, behind Walter Masterson.
William A. M. Burden will succeed Nelson A. Rockefeller as president of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, John Hay Whitney, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.
The movement of cotton prices in the domestic market last week was featured by active liquidation in next month's delivery.
Christ came to give mankind more than "properly adjusted bifocals" to cure their blindness, the Rev. Dr. J. Gordon Chamberlin declared yesterday at Riverside Church.
The bill that the Senate has passed for federally controlled development of the undersea oil resources of the outer Continental Shelf is far superior to the one passed by the House a month ago.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The 4,890 active national banks in the United States and its possessions had assets amounting to $103,939,000,000 on April 20, Controller of the Currency Ray M. Gidney announced today.

The Kroger Company, which operates a chain of more than 1,800 retail food stores, announced over the week-end that net income for the first twenty-four weeks of 1953, amounted to $6,565,676, an increase of $668,090 over the like period of last year.
PARIS, June 28 (AP) -- Northern Light, a 7-to-1 shot owned by a wealthy hotel operator, Francois Dupre, won the Grand Prix de Paris, Europe's richest race for 3-year-old horses, today.

VIENNA, June 27 -- After more than a year's haggling between management and labor, the Austrian Government has devised a productivity program that will bring it $10,000,000 of United States aid under the Moody amendment.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- There is a move afoot in Congress to restore Ford's Theatre, where Abraham Lincoln was shot, but a nephew of Ulysses S. Grant is against the idea. He contends the project would glorify an assassin.
GENEVA, June 28 -- Voters of the canton of Geneva decisively rejected today Communist-inspired proposals to forbid the establishment on Genevese territory of a European nuclear research laboratory.

MIAMI BEACH, June 28 -- American school teachers are reluctant to consider controversial questions in the classroom, according to a study of 522 school systems covering every section of the United States. The report was released here today at the opening session of the ninety-first annual convention of the National Education Association.

Dr. Kuo Cheng Wu, former Governor of Formosa, who is Minister without portfolio in the Chinese Nationalist Government, said here yesterday that the United Nations might attain a truce in Korea but it could not maintain peace with Communist China.
LONDON, June 28 -- The Prime Minister, Sir Winston Churchill, complying with the instructions of his physicians, spent today relaxing at Chartwell, his country residence in Kent.

The Rev. Edward O'Reilly Cassidy, who began his studies for the priesthood in Ireland twenty-five years ago and completed them, after many interruptions, at Niagara University this year, celebrated the solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.
LONDON, June 28 -- A Briton who has devoted most of his life to Americans in London will sail for New York on Thursday to observe the breed in its native habitat.

Raysteve Realties, Inc., contracted to buy the four-story apartment house at 2543 Church Avenue, between Bedford and Rogers Avenue, Brooklyn. and has resold the contract to Mrs. Olga Gelblum. Berman-Glassman Associates, Inc., were the brokers in the sale of the house, which occupies a lot 40 by 120 feet, near the Erasmus Hall High School in Flatbush and contains sixteen apartments.

Joseph Wood Krutch, one of the country's outstanding dramatic and literary critics, has resigned as Brander Matthews Professor of Dramatic Literature at Columbia University and is giving up his teaching career. Now living in Tucson, Ariz., Mr. Krutch will devote himself entirely to writing.

The real unifying force between England and the United States is "our common worship of God as revealed in Jesus Christ," the Rev. David Glyn Evans, minister of the Basingstoke Congregational Church in Hampshire, England, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

There is a fairly widespread belief, if we are to conclude from recent public opinion polls, that corporate profits in the United States are higher than they ought to be. Polls on this question, however, have produced an interesting paradox.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UP) -- President Eisenhower has relied heavily on industrialists and bankers in filling overseas diplomatic posts. choosing one from this group for each career State Department official sent abroad.

BOSTON -- Famous chefs from all over the country come to Massachusetts' Cape Cod in summer to prepare meals for the tourists who fill the hotels, rooming houses and motels. But not one of them can tell the story of the "hearty and sweet" dishes so typical of this region.

CINCINNATI, June 28 (AP) -- Cincinnati's Gus Bell drove in seven runs on his eighteenth and nineteenth homers and two doubles today as the Redlegs downed the Pirates, 4 -- 1 and 9 -- 2, for a clean sweep of their five-game series.

NEENAH, Wis., June 28 (AP) -- Bob Switzer, 21, McHenry, Ill., finished first in the annual 92-mile Winnebagoland outboard marathon in record time today, but his prize was held up because his motor allegedly did not meet technical measurement requirements.
What Air Force magazine calls "the greatest military problem of history -- the air defense of the United States," is basically only part of the far greater problem of security in the atomic age.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 28 -- Two hundred and twenty-eight newly graduated Princeton University seniors, representing 37 per cent of the students who received Bachelor degrees earlier this month, have won honors for distinguished academic work in their two upper-class years, Howard W. Stepp, university registrar, reported today.

It will be the Yankees versus the Dodgers for the benefit of sandlot baseball tonight at the Stadium. Although playing an exhibition game, both sides will go all out as they did in their first two meetings for the Mayor's Trophy.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 28 -- Despite the elements, union difficulties, trouble with supplies and equipment breakdowns, the amazing Anderson family yesterday completed the monolithic pour of a 3,000,000-bushel grain elevator in near-by Maumee at a cost of $750,000.

Christian truths, to be effective, must be broken down into "the small change" of everyday living, the Rev. Dr. Albert P. Stauderman said yesterday morning in a sermon at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church. Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.

Family worries and personal problems can crop up in any home, in any walk of life. Sometimes a person's best efforts to solve them alone are not enough. Then trouble may pile up. For 104 years the Community Service Society has been a friend to families in time of trouble.

BONN, Germany, June 28 -- The viewpoint of the Western Allies and the West German Federal Republic in the face of the unarmed workers' uprising in East Berlin and elsewhere in East Germany, which has been described as passive, has struck a serious blow to the unity of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's coalition as the general election nears.

MILWAUKEE, June 28 -- After routing the Braves, 11 -- 1, at County Stadium today, the Dodgers were flying high in more than one respect as they headed for Idlewild Airport in their chartered plane and in first place by one game.

Negotiations for a settlement of Jewish restitution claims against Austria are now under way in the Austrian capital. These talks were launched at a recent meeting between Chancellor Dr. Julius Raab and his associates and Dr. Nahum Goldmann, heading a delegation of world Jewish organizations and spokesmen for Austrian Jewry.

ST. LOUIS, June 28 (AP) -- Granny Hamner's double in the eleventh inning started the Phillies on the way to the winning run today as they defeated the Cardinals, 4 -- 3. Jim Konstanty, who rescued Karl Drews in the sixth inning, received credit for his eighth victory.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified 247 Korean war casualties today in a list that included fifty killed, 172 wounded, seven missing, four captured and fourteen injured. The following were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the City Housing Authority, announced yesterday that he would give private real estate interests an opportunity to demonstrate whether they could operate middle-income housing projects cheaper than public managers.

Although the number of persons on the city's relief rolls dropped 3,952 to 255,421 in May from 259,373 in April, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy reported yesterday that the cost of providing public assistance had increased $106,286 in May over that for April.
BUFFALO, June 28 (AP) -- The U. S. Army 2,900-meter relay team set an unofficial American record today in the National A. A. U. track relay championships.

Four per cent of 160,000 working women who received a query on their economic status said they made more than $6,000 a year, it was reported yesterday by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Inc. Forty-five per cent reported earnings of less than $3,000, while 43 per cent earned between $3,000 and $6,000.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., June 28 -- Frederick Dewey's Golden Hind was winner of the final race in the Pequot Yacht Club's annual two-day cruise today when the schooner led the fleet home in the 22.7-mile-thrash on Long Island Sound from Scotch Caps off the American Yacht Club at Rye.

KANSAS CITY, June 28 -- The clothing expenditures in the nation were about $21,000,000,000 a year, but more than half was spent by only about one-quarter of the families, Dr. Day Monroe of Topeka said at the annual conference of the American Home Economics Association, which closed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Pentagon officials made final preparations today to put into effect at 12:01 A. M. Tuesday President Eisenhower's plan for an efficient and "ever prepared" defense establishment.

An American tanker and a Brazilian cargo ship collided last night in a blinding fog near Barnegat Light Ship off the New Jersey coast, killing at least one of the freighter's crew. Twenty-three of her crew were still missing at midnight, three and one-half hours after the crash, and rescue boats kept circling cautiously through the rolling murk looking for survivors.

CLEVELAND, June 28 (AP) -- Dr. Cary Middlecoff of Memphis won the $2,400 first prize in the seventy-two-hole Manakiki open golf tournament today, defeating Ted Kroll of New Hartford, N. Y., on the second hole of a "sudden death" playoff after they had tied at 275.

ZURICH, June 28 -- The annual report of the Bank for International Settlements in Basle surveys current world development and the course Europe must pursue for achievement of complete self-support now that American aid is fast coming to an end.

One of the great difficulties in obtaining intelligent public understanding of the problems connected with the national budget is the fact that those problems usually center about sums expressed in billions of dollars -- amounts which are almost incomprehensible to the average citizen, whose personal budgetary thinking is normally in terms of hundreds or thousands of dollars.

Robert F. Wagner, Borough President of Manhattan, announced yesterday that he was available for the Democratic nomination for Mayor and ready to "fight it out" in the Democratic primary on Sept. 15 against Mayor Impellitteri or anyone else.
LONDON, June 28 -- There has been no relief to idleness in the stock markets in the last week and the underlying trend of security values remains downward.

A major forward step in the struggle against the illicit narcotics trade has been taken during the past week. Nineteen members of the United Nations have signed a protocol designed to cut international production of opium from 2,000 to 500 tons annually. Only seven countries are to have the right to export opium and its use is restricted to medical and scientific purposes.

LONG VALLEY, N. J., June 28 -- Dio, a bay gelding owned by A. G. Homewood of Scarsdale, N. Y., and shown by Katherine Tremper of White Plains, took the championships in the green and working hunter divisions at the fifth annual Highfield Farms horse show today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 (AP) -- Pitcher Carl Scheib of the Athletics won his own game, 2 -- 1, with a ninth-inning single after Catcher Joe Astroth had tripled with two out and the score tied, 1 -- 1, in the second game of a double header with the Browns today.

ONCE upon a time it was quite fashionable to talk about any Yankee-Dodger exhibition game as "a world series preview." Ahem. What's that again? The Yanks and the Brooks will meet at the Stadium tonight in a tremendously important affair. Its importance arises from the fact that all proceeds will go to the sandlot baseball players of New York and the sandlots are the major league nursery school.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 28 -- Screen, stage and all subsidiary rights, including television, to the Richard Bissell novel, "7 1/2 Cents," have been purchased by Frederick Brisson in association with Robert Griffith and Hal Prince.

Thirty leading American oil companies had a combined net income of $2,020,000,000 last year, as compared with $2,090,000,000 in in 1951, a decline of 3.3 per cent, according to a booklet prepared by Frederick G. Coqueron of the petroleum department of the Chase National Bank.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 28 -- Increased activity of Mau Mau bands in settled areas is taken as an indication that the new East African commander, Gen. Sir George Erskine, is succeeding slowly in forcing the terrorists out of their Aberdares mountain range stronghold.

ROME, June 28 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi will present his own and his Government's resignation to President Luigi Einaudi tomorrow and thus give rise to a Cabinet crisis that is expected to end in about two weeks with the formation of a Government composed entirely of Christian Democrats and a few "technicians."
