CHICAGO, June 28 -- Expected big receipts of red winter wheat cast a shadow over the entire market last week. Other grains were affected by the sharp recessions in wheat prices, as potential buyers of the bread grains backed away from what they expected to develop in the way of hedge pressure.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- The Giants brought their second Western tour of the year to a triumphant close today as they clubbed Phil Cavaretta's Cubs into submission, 12 to 2, behind Jim Hearn's six-hit hurling.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UP) -- Senator Lister Hill said today there was "great danger" that a House-Senate conference committee on the Continental Shelf Mineral leasing bill would scuttle his "oil for education" plan.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- The Methodist Church commemorated the 250th anniversary of the birth of its founder, John Wesley, with a mass rally this afternoon in rain-soaked Franklin Field of the University of Pennsylvania.

The nomination of Dr. Detlev W. Bronk as the new scientific and administrative head of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research will be greeted with satisfaction by the scientists of the country. They expressed their high opinion of him when they elected him president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

As a writer of plays, motion pictures, novels and short stories, Ben Hecht has become known as one who is always punching. Loaded with a great deal of verve, his output frequently is trade-marked with elements that are sardonic, breezy, tough and humorous.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 28 -- The New York Athletic Club won by a single point over the Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia in an open regatta sponsored by the host club over the New York A. C.'s lagoon course in Pelham today.
The C. B. S. radio network presented a one-hour documentary last Friday evening on what Korea means to people living along the Thirty-eighth Parallel in the United States.
In last Wednesday's Books of The Times column, the author of "The Supernatural In Fiction" was confused with the book's English publisher. The author's correct name is Peter Penzoldt.

Paderewski archives to house the musical works, papers and memorabilia of the life of Ignace Jan Paderewski will be established in New York, possibly next year, under the auspices of the Paderewski Foundation, Inc.

WITH THE FIRST MARINE AIR WING, Korea, June 28 (AP) -- Uncertain whether he will resume his baseball career, Ted Williams packed his flying gear today preparatory to returning -- probably this week -- to the United States.

A small piece of material, quickly run-up seams, a few hand stitches for a minimum of trimming add up to a recipe for attractive children's clothes, whipped up in a few moments with the help of well-cut patterns. Shown today are diminutive garments for summer sports and beach activities.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 28 (UP) -- Hundreds of doctors, nurses and volunteers were mobilized today as Montgomery County prepared to inoculate some 30,000 children under 10 years of age with gamma globulin to halt the spread of infantile paralysis.

FOR twenty years a large proportion of the world's population has cherished Bing Crosby. Singhalese coolies delight in the familiar sound of his bubbling baritone. Icelanders warm to his casual charm. People who haven't looked at a movie magazine since their fifteenth birthday, who never listen to the radio and who never buy popular records still can't escape a vivid impression of the breezy Crosby personality.

MAYBE Postmaster General Benjamin Franklin wouldn't have approved, but the incoming mail department at the General Post Office here has installed a wired music service that gives soft song for sixteen minutes of each half hour around the clock.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 28 -- Just back from his chores in the Newport-to-Annapolis race, during which he served as first mate on the victorious Bolero, Cornelius Shields Sr., of Larchmont, did himself proud again today. For that matter, so did his 19-year-old son, Cornelius Jr.

Of all the pacts which have come into international law under the auspices of the United Nations perhaps the most stirring and hopeful to the people of the world is the pact to outlaw genocide. It is not too hard to understand this -- for it is a pact of, by and for the people.
MOSCOW, June 28 (AP) -- Government and Communist party leaders went to the Bolshoi Theatre last night to see a new opera by Yuri Shaporin, "The Decembrists."

March of Dimes grants, amounting to $2,283,384 to twenty-one universities, medical schools, hospitals and organizations for the support of polio research and professional education programs, were announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

Secretary of Agriculture Benson, touring the drought area of western Texas, passed through Lubbock on Saturday. Lubbock itself, as our reporter, Paul Kennedy, wrote, lies "on a shallow water basin that extends almost fifty miles in any direction from the city."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 20 -- The only United States Information Services program in a Communist country is operated quietly and effectively in Yugoslavia by a small staff that must run a continuous gantlet of the State Departments anti-Communist policies and existing political conditions in this country.

MOSCOW, June 28 -- A new Minister of Internal Affairs has been named in Byelorussia and a number of Latvian nationals have been advanced to important posts in the Latvian Communist party after severe criticism of the Latvian party leadership for failures in connection with the nationalities' policy.

The five-story apartment house at 53 East Sixty-fifth Street, between Park and Madison Avenues, has been sold by the Bank of New York to an investing client of Reuben J. Aronson for cash over a ten-year purchase money mortgage of $32,000.

HAZLETON, Pa., June 28 -- For fifty years the Anthracite Board of Conciliation, the oldest permanent arbitration machinery in American industrial history, has been helping to keep the peace between labor and management in the anthracite mines of northeastern Pennsylvania.
The greatest school construction and modernization program in the city's history, involving the expenditure of $100,000,000, has been mapped for 1954 by the Board of Education.

PARIS, June 28 -- Premier Joseph Laniel's Cabinet, standing for a truce in the French political strife, will be presented to the National Assembly Tuesday and on winning approval should be well established at least until autumn.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 28 -- With a record-equaling round of 71, Betsy Rawls of Spartanburg, S. C., defeated Mrs. Jacqueline Pung of Honolulu in the play-off today to win the United States Golf Association's women's open championship title at the Rochester Country Club.

COULEE DAM, Wash., June 28 -- At off-peak hours, when the Pacific Northwest's industrial and commercial demand for electric power is at a minimum, six huge motors are pumping water from Lake Franklin D. Roosevelt behind Grand Coulee Dam to transform central Washington sagebrush desert into green fields.
A slump is difficult to explain. Someone suddenly stops hitting, the defense wavers, the pitching falters and before anyone is really aware, everyone's in it.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 28 -- In the first detailed presentation of the Yugoslav assessment of recent events in the Soviet Union and its satellite countries, Dr. Edvard Kardelj, second ranking communist of this country, declared that the era of Soviet hegemony in international workers' movements and in socialism had ended.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 28 -- Political circles said tonight that dissolution of Finland's unicameral Riksdag (Parliament) and the calling of an extraordinary general election in autumn appeared the likeliest way out of Finland's Cabinet crisis.

J. H. Oldenbroek, general secretary of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, called yesterday for effective international cooperation among free trade unions to defeat attacks on free labor, not only in totalitarian nations but also in democratic countries.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 28 -- Richard Carroll called the police early this morning to report "lions, tigers, elephants and hyenas" surrounding his house at 61 Loughlin Avenue, Cos Cob.

AMSTERDAM, June 28 -- Since the return of the Dutch Foreign and Finance Ministers from London, the newspapers and financial quarters here have been discussing the problem of convertibility. It is generally agreed, however, that the Dutch monetary situation is now very sound.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 28 -- Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, left Texas this afternoon for Washington after a three-day inspection tour of the drought-ravaged western portion of the state.
Jose Pousa, 10 years old, a born fisherman, was drowned last night in the Central Park lake that so often had filled him with excitement and pleasure.

WICHITA, Kan., June 28 -- The City Commissioners, facing recall petitions from the citizenry over enforcement of Wichita's 98-year-old "blue laws," backed down late yesterday because City Attorneys could not determine the legal definition of "articles of necessity."

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 28 -- Efforts to get Chinese Nationalist troops moving out of Burma were centered here today on a group of field representatives of the refugee Chinese forces who have arrived from Burma.

As the conservative extremists in Congress severely threaten the foreign and domestic programs of the "liberal" Eisenhower Administration, the national Democratic leadership faces a sharply accelerated challenge.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 28 -- The Government has shed its enforced seasonal lethargy in this capital and begun the implementation of several reform programs. The effect has been a widespread revival of hope among a weary people that an era of constructive action has been launched.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 28 -- Probably no people in the world are so sensitive as the Israelis to what people of other countries, especially Americans, think about their country. For there is no country in the world so completely dependent on outside -- especially United States -- economic support.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 28 -- Little David, aged chestnut gelding owned by the Brook Run Stable, Greenwich, again met the challenge of the twelve-barrier course in the eastern area trials for the 1953 United States equestrian jumping team at the Fairfield County Horse Show today.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., June 28 -- The Hunterdon Medical Center was described as an "altruistic experiment conceived in the minds of the people and brought to fruition through their own efforts" at dedication ceremonies at the hospital one mile north of here this afternoon.

COSENZA, Italy, June 28 -- Until a few years ago Calabria was Italy's forgotten province. Occupying the toe of the Italian boot, between the Tyrrhenian Sea and the Gulf of Taranto, it was almost like a lost island of that Magna Graecia to which it once belonged.

ABINGDON, England, June 29 -- The 40,000 voters of this rural English constituency will choose their Member of Parliament tomorrow, but tonight they were talking not about war or peace or Russia or America but about food -- its price and the quantity and quality available.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 29 -- A group of United States attorneys has urged the Egyptian Government to lift its blockade on Israeli-bound vessels using the Suez Canal, and has declared that such a step is vital for the peace and welfare of the Middle East.

Twenty sailors and one marine, all from the United States aircraft carrier Bennington at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, gave blood yesterday at the Brooklyn Red Cross blood center, 57 Willoughby Street, for the mother and stepfather of a fellow serviceman.

The John G. Hellman Company, Inc., was the low bidder at $1,295,304 yesterday as Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen opened new bids for electrical work at Coney Island Hospital, Avenue Z and Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 29 -- The idea of accepting Soviet support in their struggle for self-determination in Cyprus seemed today to be accepted generally by Greek Cypriots, representing just over 80 per cent of this British-owned island's population.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 29 -The Islamic religion and mores, long ignored or actually repressed by the secular Turkish Republic, are beginning to play an increasingly important role in this country's political life with the approach of general elections next spring.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- Joseph Karesh testified today that he did not "see anything to" charges of corruption in the handling of tax cases by the United States Attorney's office in San Francisco.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- The State Department is rushing the publication of an official history of United States diplomacy under the Roosevelt and Truman Administrations.

A light, informal look is the keynote of a new group of English furniture introduced by the Harry Meyer Company and available through decorators. The group, called Countryshire, is designed in simple lines. The pieces are made of fruitwood with a light, mellow finish.

The congratulations of the New York community go to Charles C. Burlingham, justly called "the first citizen of the city," for the award to him yesterday by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York of its medal for "exceptional contributions to the honor and standing of the bar in this community."

NEW DELHI, India, June 29 -- At an impressive function President Rajendra Prasad presented to Col. John Hunt, Edmund Hillary and Tenzing gold medals in recognition of their "magnificent achievement" in climbing Mt. Everest. The presentation ceremony was held at the forecourt of Rashtrapati Bhavan, official residence of the President.

The Gruen Watch Company had a net profit of $1,688,938 after taxes and all charges in the fiscal year ended March 31. This is equal to $4.25 a share and comipares with $953,134, or $2.40 a share, in the preceding fiscal year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 29 -- Communications from the Ministries of Foreign Affairs of Albania, Rumania and Hungary, released today by the United Nations, contained denials that these countries were holding Greek nationals who crossed their borders during the civil war in Greece, and who wish to return to their homeland, as alleged by the Greek Government.
SEOUL, Korea, June 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of Gen. Mark W. Clark's letter delivered to the commanders of the Chinese and North Korean troops at Panmunjom today:

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Representative W. M. (Don) Wheeler, Democrat of Georgia, today accused Associate Justice William O. Douglas of treason as one of six grounds for impeachment from the Supreme Court.
The Republic Steel Corporation announced yesterday it had perfected a process for making powdered iron and will build a new plant at Toledo, Ohio, to produce the powder on a commercial scale.

OMAHA, Neb., June 29 (AP) -- Terms of a union-management contract agreement involving the Overland Greyhound Bus Lines were announced here today. A union spokesman said the same wage increase pattern was being followed by twenty-five other Greyhound corporations throughout the country.

Adults gathered on Henry Street between Governeur and Grand Streets yesterday didn't make any effort to hide the fact that they were envious of the small fry in the neighborhood. They stood per-spring in the hot street as the youngsters scampered about in the spray from a hydrant.
Here recently on a brief visit, James Hart, president of the Sherman and Ambassador Hotels in Chicago, discussed with us the state of hotel cookery in America.

LONDON, June 29 -- In a surprise move, the British Government has proposed to the United States and France that in view of the postponement of the Bermuda meeting of the three chiefs of government an interim conference of lower-ranking ministers should be held in the near future.
Prices closed lower yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Volume eased from Friday's improved activity with only world sugar registering more trades.

Case Goods took a long way home but managed to get there in plenty of time to win the $12,900 Astoria Stakes at the Aqueduct race track yesterday. Showing a disposition to run out approaching the stretch, the filly owned by William Goadby Loew was forced into the right course by Jockey Hedley Woodhouse and triumphed by two and a quarter lengths.

The foreign parcel post rate increase from 14 cents per pound to 45 cents for the first pound and 22 cents per additional pound, as announced June 19 by Mr. Summerfield, seems to be a "penny-wise, pound-foolish" step.

TAEGU, Korea, June 29 (AP) -- the United States Supreme Court may be asked to rule on a provision of the new military code of justice under which Robert W. Toth was arrested to stand military -- rather than cirri -- trial on charges of slaying a Korean. the Judge Advocate of the Fifth Air Force said today.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Combined tightening of credits and an increasing of interest rates indicate that tight money is beginning to exert its pressures, Wallace Johnston, president of the National Appliance and Radio-Television Dealers Association, said here today in the Conrad Hilton Hotel at the midyear meeting of the group.

TRENTON, June 29 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll declared here tonight that he expected to sign the Waterfront Commission Act tomorrow, designed to set up controls over dockside employment in the Port of New York. The act received the final approval of the State Legislature on Thursday, at which time an identical measure was adopted by the New York State Legislature.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Eisenhower will designate 152 counties in Texas and forty in Oklahoma tomorrow as disaster areas and allocate $8,000,000 for emergency relief of stockmen and farmers in those drought-stricken districts, Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today.

MT. HOLLY, N. J., June 29 -- Two men held as material witnesses in a bold attempt to kill a self-styled "pay-off" man for a Burlington County gambling syndicate were released late today as the police intensified their search for the shotgun used by a hidden gunman.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey today broadened United States export controls to forbid shipment of strategic materials by United States citizens to "Iron Curtain" countries from other nations than the United States.

After a demonstration of strong support in the House of Representatives President Eisenhower's plan of reorganization of the Defense Department went into effect this morning. The Senate had not questioned the program, but there was some criticism of it in the House, and especially of its modification of the role of the Joint Chiefs and their Chairman.

Our form or government, as set out in the Constitution, was intended to be tripartite -- the legislative to make the laws, the executive to execute them and the judicial to interpret them. All three are supposed to be equally powerful, none more so than either of the others. But that has seldom been so.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the transfer of the membership of James Carstairs to Richard M. Cantor and the proposed transfer of the membership of the late Edward C. Anness to Eugene Greenberger.

It's slim pickings in Wall Street these days, at least for the big commission houses. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange slowed to 800,000 shares yesterday -- the lowest level since last August -- as traders and investors determined to sit out the current wrangling over the excess profits tax extension and the major uncertainties in the international situation.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that he planned a search for a list of more than 100 American atomic spy suspects and might try to call former President Harry S. Truman as a star witness. Mr. McCarthy is chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

NEWARK, June 29 -- Professional organizers and solicitors received between 60 and 70 per cent of more than $600,000 that was contributed since 1947 by business men to two "police welfare" organizations in New Jersey, it was testified today before the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council.

VIENNA, June 29 -- Tales of increasing scarcity of food in Rumania, of minor food riots in Bucharest, of growing discontent expressing itself in passive resistance, and of a new inflation only one year after the 1952 currency devaluation have reached Vienna from diplomatic sources.

A proclamation by Mayor Impellitteri, designating Sept. 6-12 as International Maritime Week, was made public yesterday by Julian K. Roosevelt, chairman of the international lifeboat and tugboat races to he held in the Hudson River Sept. 12 under auspices of the American Seamen's Friend Society.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- The aircraft industry reported today that its planes had flown 85,000,000,000 passenger-miles in the last twenty-seven years.
BOSTON, June 29 (UP) -- Lou Boudreau hit a double and Leo Durocher belted a single as the managers saw action tonight in the Giants' 6-3 exhibition victory over the Red Sox before 17,122 fans.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., June 29 (AP) Jockey Eddie Arcaro celebrated a "day" in his honor today at Narragansett Park -- where he was an apprentice back in 1934 -- by winning both the featured $7,500 Eddie Arcaro Purse and a special race against Joey Renick and Jimmy Lynch.

Lead paint may be fatal to small children who chew on their toys, furniture or other painted objects, the Department of Health warned yesterday following the death on Saturday of two 3-year-old boys in Cumberland Hospital, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- President Eisenhower signed today the so-called "doctors draft" bill under which the armed service's plan to induct 7,707 physicians and 4,552 dentists during the next two years.

Stanley Clifford Weyman, who has posed as a foreign envoy, a lawyer and a naval officer and actually worked as a United Nations press representative, was in the toils of the law again yesterday. It was his twelfth arrest since 1911, when he was sent to prison for two years for grand larceny.
If it were given to tooting its own horn the Anthracite Board of Conciliation, now celebrating its fiftieth anniversary, would call itself an institution. Actually that is what it is.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 29 (AP) -- The Mossadegh Government instituted strict import controls today in a drastic effort to rein back the rising inflation in Teheran's bazaar.

ROME, June 29 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi presented his own and his Cabinet's resignation today to President Luigi Einaudi, who asked him and his collaborators to remain at the head of Italian affairs as a caretaker Government till a new Cabinet can be formed.
Standard Gas and Electric Company will file amendments to the plan now on file with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Robert J. Levy, board chairman, announced yesterday.

One hundred and fifty members of the Park Association learned to know a little more about the growth of the city's recreational facilities yesterday, and at the same time escaped the sweltering heat for the afternoon. They took part in the association's annual cruise, which this year took them up the breeze-swept East River, past the Bronx and Queens, to Long Island Sound and Rye.
living there but that the situation still was calm in the Indo-Chinese state.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee received testimony today that Government-owned alcohol butadiene plants at Kobuta, Pa., and Lousville, Ky., are not salable at reasonable prices, but should be leased to private industry.

This one didn't count, but the Yankees lost another game last night at the stadium, where Casey Stengel's team bowed to the Dodgers, 9 -- 0. The contest was for the benefit of sandlot baseball, which will receive some $80,000 from the game in which last year's world series rivals met. The attendance was 56,136.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Defense officials are undecided whether plans for using C-123 assault troop carrier planes should be dropped, Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, said today.
MEXICO CITY, June 29 (AP) -- The head of the National Coffee Commission said today that Mexico this year will become the world's third ranking coffee producer. It has ranked fifth.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., June 29 (AP) -- Jackie Burke of Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., dropped out of the thirty-fifth Professional Golfers Association tournament today and his withdrawal emphasized the probability of a wide open contest starting on Wednesday for the title Jim Turnesa won last year.

Color television receivers will become a reality early next year, Benjamin Abrams, president of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, predicted yesterday. Only those who have no faith in American industry, he said, maintain that not even limited quantities of color sets will be marketed for several years.

Cool color sparked with bright, uncluttered furniture arrangements and home-like touches of books and candles create a cheerful atmosphere in a new model house decorated by Samson Berman Associates. The house, situated in the Junard Homes development at 2 Regent Place off Willis Avenue in Roslyn, L. I., is now open for public inspection.

The formal meeting of representatives of the Republican and Liberal parties scheduled for this afternoon apparently affords the last thin chance for another four years to redeem the City of New York from the political sewer into which it has been plunged during the O'Dwyer and Impellitteri administrations.

Daniel Kornblum, director of the city's Division of Labor Relations, made an effort last night to forestall a threatened strike against the Green Bus Lines, Inc., which carries 200,000 riders daily in Jamaica and the Rockaways, Queens.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 29 -- Byron Price, Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations and head of the Department of Administrative and Financial Services, today turned over to the United States mission a check for $1,500,000, which represents the

A variety of objects suitable for decorative purposes either in contemporary or traditional settings are available at a number of shops. They range from such modern items as mobiles, which the summer breezes might set in motion, to such historic ones as a reproduction of a statue of a devotee of the Cretan Snake Goddess, dated nearly eighteen Centuries before Christ.
ST. LOUIS, June 29 (AP) -- Paul Minner, usually a problem for the Cardinals, limited the Redbirds to six hits, only two in the first seven innings, as he pitched the Cubs to a 6-2 victory tonight.

John Trumbull, patriot-artist, who was once aide de camp to Washington and later recorded much of the first President's career on canvas, wrote an autobiography in which he presented his observations on the men and events, art, diplomacy and travel in the early days of the nation.

The moment the city's youngsters have been waiting for through nine seemingly endless months of homework, examinations, report cards, teachers' stern looks and carrying textbooks will arrive at 3 o'clock today.

BERLIN, June 29 -- After a year-long campaign of intensive recruiting, of attacks on pacifism and propaganda for the need to rearm, East Germany's Communists are now saying that not only is re-armament unnecessary but a reduction of armed forces must be considered.
It can cost parents a lot to send their youngsters to public high school, an educator's survey reveals.

Last week America's librarians, as represented at the Los Angeles convention of their national association, adopted some courageous resolutions on "Freedom to Read." Now they are home again, perhaps arguing with their trustees or finding answers for persons who think the general public can't be trusted to choose its own reading and who hold, in effect, that anybody who is not subnormal mentally is probably subversive.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -- Jose Ferrer and Katharine Hepburn have made a "verbal" agreement to produce on their own next year a straight motion picture version of "The Taming of the Shrew," Shakespeare's comedy that carried the memorable credit line "with additional dialogue by Sam Taylor" when Douglas Fairbanks and Mary Pickford made it in 1929.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Marine Corps said today that Ted Williams would come back from Korea Wednesday but that he probably would not play any baseball this season.

OTTAWA, June 29 (Canadian Press) -- Counsel for the British Columbia lumber industry charged today that Canadian railways had raised freight rates on British Columbia lumber as part of a "bargain" with Pacific Northwest railway interests in the United States.

The five Republican borough leaders issued a statement last night declaring that they would support any one of twelve persons, including Representative Jacob K. Javits, as a coalition candidate for Mayor.

Harry S. Truman, pointing yesterday to the historic significance of the era in which he served as Senator, Vice President and President, assured sponsors of the library at Grandview, Mo., which will house his papers, that it was a "national" rather than a "personal" project.

PARIS, June 29 -- Officials of the Gaullist movement, the Reunion of the French People, formally announced tonight that members who had accepted posts in the new Cabinet of Joseph Laniel, formed yesterday, had read themselves out of the movement by so doing.

Martin Agronsky will conduct program of news commentary over the American Broadcasting Company television network on Sundays from 9 to 9:15 P. M., beginning July 12. The program also will include an interview with a personality in the news.

The City and County of San Francisco borrowed $9,000,000 yesterday on three separate bond issues at interest costs averaging about 2.559 per cent. The bonds were quickly sold out by banking systems at yields ranging from 1.6 per cent to 2.65 per cent. The maturities run from 1954 to 1968.
A governmental finger will continue to be in the agricultural pie for some time to come.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- With the Defense Production Act expiring at midnight tomorrow, conferees of the Senate and the House of Representatives failed to reach agreement today on compromise terms for an extension. Another meeting is scheduled for tomorrow morning.

KANSAS CITY, June 29 (AP) -- Stories of threats, intimidation and coercion at the hands of labor union representatives and the payment of "protection" money were told today before a Congressional committee investigating Kansas City labor strife.

A second feature-length film record, in color, of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II was presented here yesterday at the Little Carnegie and the Bryant Theatres. This one, photographed and assembled by Associated British-Pathe and released by Warner Brothers, is fifty-one minutes in length and has a commentary written by John Ludney and narrated by Leo Genn.

The New York Housing Authority announced yesterday that it was easing its income rule for families seeking apartments in low-rent housing projects. Anyone whose family income is $200 to $400 higher than the old levels, or no more than $3,300 annually for

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 29 -- The Spirit of Hope, a brilliant yellow and green plane dedicated to cerebral palsy sufferers, was named at the Westchester County Airport today. On Friday it will fly in the women's transcontinental air race from Lawrence, Mass., to Long Beach, Calif.

BONN, Germany, June 29 (AP) -- The chiefs of the West German diplomatic missions in Washington, London and Paris were raised today to the personal rank of Ambassador at the request of the West German Chancellor. Dr. Konrad Adenauer.

NEW DELHI, India, June 29 -- Representatives of India and Burma began today what is officially described as a significant trade conference. Although the discussions will mainly relate to concluding a barter deal for exchanging Burmese rice for Indian manufactured goods, both sides will explore possibilities of enlarging commerce between the two Asian neighbors.

The House Ways and Means Committee has under consideration a bill that would re-establish as mandatory anti-smuggling and law enforcement arms, the United States Customs Port Patrol and the Customs Border Patrol.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 29 -Premier Adnan Menderes, in a lengthy declaration issued here tonight, strongly denounced insinuations spread recently by elements in Turkey that this country should withdraw from Korea and follow an independent policy in the "cold war."

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Spokesmen for the White House and the State Department emphasized today that the forthcoming meeting of British and French foreign ministers with John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, in Washington was to be considered no substitute for the postponed Bermuda discussions of the heads of the three Governments.

No myth has been more sedulously spread by Soviet and Communist propaganda than the notion that the Soviet Union has an "enlightened" minorities policy toward the half of that country's population which is non-Russian. Recently, however, this myth has taken again several hard jolts in news from the Ukraine and from Lithuania.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- An early break between the Kremlin and the Chinese Communist regime of Mao Tse-tung was predicted in the Senate today by the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee as debate on the $5,318,000,000 foreign aid authorization bill began.
Cotton futures closed steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, with final prices 6 points higher to 5 lower than on Friday.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- E1 Paso Natural Gas Company of El Paso, Tex., was authorized today to increase the daily capacity of its natural gas pipeline system by about 400,000,000 cubic feet.

A Coast Guard board of inquiry will convene at 10 A. M. Wednesday at 80 Lafayette Street to investigate the cause of the collision Sunday night of the American tanker Gulftrade and the Brazilian freighter Loide - Panama twelve miles off the New Jersey shore near Barnegat.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 29 -- The four-nation committee that has been meeting here in an effort to achieve the evacuation of the Chinese Nationalist guerrilla troops in Burma faced a discouraging outlook today.

Oscar Steiglitz and Barnet Heller, a pair of pumpernickel bakers in Brooklyn, found a way of leavening their chores on a hot and humid night with a fresh breeze and light music. Their recipe for comfort worked fine Sunday night, but Mr. Steiglitz and Mr. Heller decided yesterday it was too costly to be practical.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 29 -- Despite a drop of two points in the old cost of living index of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, the Westchester Board of Supervisors voted unanimously today to maintain the annual bonus of 3,500 county employes at $60 a year at least to the end of the year.
The first of four American track and field squads which will compete in Europe this summer left by plane yesterday for London.

Walter Winchell, newspaper, radio and television commentator, conceded yesterday at a pre-trial libel suit examination that he might have been "duped" by Communist propagandists into presenting a favorable picture of Russia and its leaders at times in the last eight years.

" The Little Clay Cart," the fourth and final play in the series presented by Terese Hayden at the Theatre de Lys, opens tonight at 8 o'clock. Like the three preceding revivals, the Hindu drama will run for a week. Liska March is associated with Miss Hayden in the venture.
DENVER, June 29 (AP) -- Twenty-six years ago today four men took off from Curtis Field, on Long Island, in an overloaded airplane on a pioneer trans-Atlantic flight.

Lee Sala, Donora (Pa.) middleweight, gained a unanimous decision over Garth Panter of Salt Lake City in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. Sala, who was favored, staved off a last-round rally by the loser. Sala weighed 161 1/4 pounds and Panter 161.

LONDON, June 29 -- The stock markets drifted rather aimlessly today with business still sparse and prices moving narrowly up and down. However, the undertone in most markets was again firm except in British Government securities.
The American Council for Judaism, Inc., announced yesterday that it was expanding and reorganizing its department of religious education and activities.

A series of post-season exhibition baseball games may be played by the Giants in Japan next fall Horace Stoneham, president of the National League club, accepted tentatively yesterday an invitation for a trip to Tokyo and other Japanese cities. If the Giants go, it will be the first Japanese tour by one entire major league club.

Four leisurely young men who were unusually considerate to their victims robbed twenty persons in a period of four hours yesterday in the nome of a woman physician at 404 Fifty-fifth Street, Brooklyn. At one stage of the operation they served refreshments supplied by their involuntary hostess.

WITH the trout streams low and running a temperature, and the trout far from responsive, the general opening of the New York bass season tomorrow comes at an opportune time for the fresh-water anglers, who were not too happy over the results of the past week-end.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 (UP) -- Cpl. Paul F. Schnur Jr., one of twenty-two former captives of the Communists brought home on a secret flight from Korea last month, has disclosed he received an "undesirable discharge" from the Army under a regulation covering "disloyal or subversive" individuals.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- Representative Errett P. Scrivner, acting chairman of the House of Representatives Military Appropriations subcommittee, said today this country had developed a "small" atom bomb three times as destructive as the one that destroyed Hiroshima.

BOSTON, June 29 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, was discharged today from the New England Baptist Hospital, where he had been a patient since June 5. Accompanied by his wife, Clarissa, the diplomat left by motor car for Newport, R. I., for a period of convalescence at the estate of John Barry Ryan.

At the time your statesmanlike and generous editorial in support of the state power program for Niagara appeared I expressed to you the Power Authority's appreciation. I wish to restate that appreciation publicly and comment on the letter from Alexander M. Beebee of the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation that appeared in your columns on June 22.

BOSTON, June 29 -- Harry L. Martin, president of the American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., asserted today that the "reaction of a wholesome and wrathful American indignation" had begun to set in against name-calling by investigators into subversive activity in the press, the libraries and the churches.

Private - placement financing passed the $5,000,000,000 mark in 1952 for the second consecutive year, according to the yearbook compiled by E. V. Hale Co. of Chicago. The total was $5,032,803,000, compared with $5,085,238,000 in 1951.

The New York City Transit Authority put a $250,184,300 ceiling yesterday on operating and maintenance expenditures of the city-owned transit system for the fiscal year starting tomorrow. It gave notice at the same time that it would try to shave this figure by at least $5,000,000, and probably more, in the course of the year.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, June 30 -- Fighting on the western Korean front dropped off sharply today after battered South Korean infantry had fallen back from four hills north of Seoul.

Public Service Commission inspector, testifying under cross-examination by Long Island Rail Road attorneys at a hearing into safety and service on the carrier, said it employed several safety devices not found on other commuter rail lines operating in the New York area.
There will be no "gate crashers" for 180 city laborer jobs tomorrow if the weary men who have been camping on an East Side street since Friday night can help it.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Organization, not socialization, of medicine was advocated by Dr. Paul B. Magnuson, who served as chairman of the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation, in a copyrighted interview published today by U. S. News and World Report, independent weekly magazine.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Mohammed Ali, Attorney General of Pakistan's Northwest Frontier Province, holds that United States professors and technicians would be more effective instruments of American foreign policy than United States money and politicians, at least in his country.
The Army may soon be taking motion pictures of speed violators in an effort to promote safer driving at military installations, Maj. C. E. McCandless, First Army safety director, said yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, June 30 -- The mission headed by Walter S. Robertson, Assistant Secretary of State, came out here with no magic key to the solution of the difficult Korean problem and thus far has made no really notable accomplishment.
Three men were rounded up early yesterday as they were breaking open a safe in the Metropolitan Branch Post Office at 47 Debevoise Street, Brooklyn.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 29 -- Three teams tied for top honors in the thirty-fourth annual Father and Son tournament at the Garden City Golf Club today.

SYRACUSE, June 29 -- American family life will be scrutinized by a psychiatrist, sociologist and child development expert during a "Workshop in Family Relations" beginning tomorrow at Syracuse University.

SEOUL, Korea, June 29 -- Chough Pyung Ok, who took a public stand in support of the United Nations Command and against President Syngman Rhee's wishes, is being held incomunicado here in a small dingy room. No one in the Government is willing to say when he will be tried.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The retreat today from a politically untenable position by enough Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee to foreshadow action on extending the excess-profits tax forced Chairman Reed to abdicate his role as economic dictator of the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A union delegation visited Arthur S. Flemming, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, today to protest against what it called a widespread relocation of industrial plants.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- The last evidence went into the record at the du Pont anti-trust trial today before Judge Walter J. La Buy in Federal District Court. The trial then was recessed until next fall, when briefs will be filed and closing arguments held.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 29 -- Parched Texas ranchers and farmers looked toward Washington today for disaster relief developments and toward skies that brought drought-ending rains to the eastern part of the state.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 29 -- The United Nations may have to take on a new budget burden of about $500,000 to pay tax money to Washington for foreign-born employes who desire to keep their immigrant status here as prospective United States citizens.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 29 -- The organization known as Youth Aliyah, meaning "youth migration," which since World War II brought from Europe to Palestine tens of thousands of Jewish children whose parents were killed by the Nazis, now is bringing to Israel children from Middle Eastern and North African countries.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- A New York writer who balked at saying whether he ever had been a Communist, praised Russia and attacked the House Un-American Activities Committee today on the anti-Semitism issue.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 29 -- At a meeting of Israeli and Jordanian General Staff officers today, Jordan agreed to take measures to prevent the infiltration of Jordanians into Israel. Israel meanwhile agreed to assist by providing Jordan with a swift flow of information about the activities of infiltrators on the Israeli side of the border.

The fifteen-foot outboard motorboat Florence arrived in port yesterday from Portsmouth, Ohio, via Florida. The ship's complement consisted of Harvey H. Hecker, who is 76 years old and can't swim a stroke. Captain Hecker is a spry, tanned and blue-eyed veteran of the Spanish-American War and World War I.
Gimbel Brothers, here and in Philadelphia, announced last night the completion of plans for "the largest suburban shopping center on the Eastern seaboard."

Erica Morini, one of the world's finest violinists, was the soloist last night with the Stadium Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium. She was heard in the Bruch Concerto in G minor, a work that is often treated like a warhorse but which, in her hands, emerged a thoroughbred.

Buying was unusually heavy at the National Ladies Sportswear Outerwear Show, exhibitors reported yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel. Attendance on Sunday was 750 and on the second day an additional 1.200 buyers registered. Many of the buyers were from out of town and the New York stores are expected to visit the lines today through Thursday.

It is good news that British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden has so far recovered from his latest operation that he has left the Boston hospital where he spent some time and has gone to Newport, R. I., to recuperate. Mr. Eden's physician gives assurance that with needed rest the patient will make a "complete recovery."

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 29 -- The most important development in the field of race relations in this country is the widespread recognition that racial and cultural conflicts merely represent "immaturities in democratic development," the tenth annual Race Relations Institute was told today.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Further declines were registered in all grain futures here this morning, and while there was' a fair recovery from the low point in wheat, selling of coarse grains was persistent. Buying support in all pits came largely from profit-taking shorts, although a little support came from commercial interests and some from investment buyers.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to take a showdown ballot July 8 on President Eisenhower's proposal to admit 240,000 victims of political and economic upheavals in Europe to this country over the next two years.

Some profound changes have been brought about with the arrival of the Atomic Age, but no substitute has yet been found for the country editor. In fact, with the mass migration of cliff dwellers to Suburbia the role of the man (or woman) who puts out the community weekly has taken on added importance, and his ranks are increasing rather than diminishing as new communities develop.

Sponsor magazine, representative of television and radio interests, has engaged Life in combat. In its current issue Sponsor angrily seeks to debunk a recent study undertaken by the picture publication on the effectiveness of its advertising.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Thirteen Senators introduced today a "Drought Disaster Relief Act" that would authorize Government loans to farmers and stockmen at 4 per cent interest and would provide for Federal purchase of feed and other supplies for resale to farmers. Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas, introduced the bill, with the twelve other Senators as co-sponsors.

WISCONSIN DELLS, Wis., June 29 (AP) -- Five national interscholastic track and field records and two marks being tied were approved today at the thirty-fourth annual meeting of the National Federation of State High School Athletics Associations.

PARIS, June 18 -- Political hostilities between France and the little principality of Andorra, perched high in the valleys of the Pyrenees Mountains between France and Spain, have reached the point where the French Government has ordered economic sanctions and has threatened to take more drastic steps if necessary to end their controversies.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Senator Hugh Butler, Republican of Nebraska, chairman of the Interior and Insular Affairs Committee, said today that the people of Hawaii had taken "positive steps to destroy Communist influence in the territory." Their action, he added, had removed his objections of earlier years to the admission of Hawaii as the forty-ninth state.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission will ask a Federal court tomorrow to allow another year for the exchange of securities in two public utility holding companies which are being liquidated. The action will be sought in a petition to Senior Circuit Judge John Biggs Jr. at Wilmington, Del.
LONDON, June 29 (Reuters) -- England faces almost certain defeat on the last day of the second test cricket match against Australia tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- A $7,500,000 stop-gap wheat export subsidy program was announced today by the Department of Agriculture. Secretary Ezra Taft-Benson said in a statement that it was designed to avoid a break in the export movement of United States wheat to traditional foreign markets.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Army is considering the adoption of a fixed tour of duty in the Far East to replace the rotation system after the fighting stops in Korea.
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 30 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,661, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 29 -- In protest against the Malan Government's determination to evict 90,000 Negroes with homes in the western area of Johannesburg and lead them in the open veldt to build new houses, Patrick Duncan, son of the former Governor General of the Union of South Africa, soon will enter prison serve 100 days at hard labor-

E. M. Braden has been appointed director of regions of the Chrysler division of Chrysler Corporation. Burton B. White has been named supervisor of silicone rubber sales development for the silicone products department of the General Electric Company.

MOSES LAKE, Wash., June 29 -- Clearing a seridesert tract of its sagebrush, leveling it to receive irrigation water, planting crops and building some kind of shack for at least temporary living is no clock-punching pastime, yet most war veterans who have bought land in the Columbia Basin Project see it as a great opportunity.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The magazine Air Force, a champion of American air power, appeared today with a dramatic epitaph to the debate over the Administration's cuts of more than $5,000,000,000 in the Air Force's budget for the fiscal year to start Wednesday.
CINCINNATI, June 29 (AP) -- Warren C. Giles, president of the National League, today disallowed the Philadelphia clubs protest of a game played with the Redlegs here June 21.

Michael Clemente, overlord on Manhattan's East River piers who already is facing extortion and income tax charges, was indicted anew yesterday -- this time for perjury resulting from his testimony before the State Crime Commission.

Fall buying in the wholesale market here last week was heavy, with stores confident that consumer buying will continue at a high level during the third quarter of the year, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. Sportswear and separates continued to be in great demand and the recent heat wave spurred ordering of summer merchandise.
Four college scholarships, said to be the first awarded by a maritime union, have been granted by the welfare plan of the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L.
Nothing, I suspect, reflects the tone of city government more accurately than its Municipal Court. A tour of duty as juror in this court is, at present, a saddening and embittering experience.

The runner-up for the title last year, Mrs. Louis Ganzenmuller of Sea Cliff, L. I., scored a decisive victory to open her bid yesterday for the women's Eastern clay courts tennis championship at the Bayside (Queens) Tennis and Racquets Club.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 29 -- A Yale University scientist has introduced evidence that genes, the tiny particles in the body that govern the individual's characteristics, may have not one but three functional parts.

The Chilean Line, Inc., has appointed Jose Claro as executive vice president. Mr. Claro, who succeeds Luis E. Gubler, also will be general manager for the United States and Canada of the Compania Sud-Americana de Vapores (Chilean Line), the line's parent company with headquarters in Valparaiso, Chile.

The increasing power needs of the Pacific Northwest will require $240,000,000 a year in new generating and distribution facilities between now and 1960, Paul B. McKee, president of the Pacific Power and Light Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the California group of the Investment Bankers Association of America in Santa Barbara, Calif.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 29 -- A home-club pair, pro Herman Barron and member Stan Schneider, who were among the first to play this morning, and Ansel Snow, representing Concord - Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., with Sleepy Hollow's Robert Davis, the last to finish in a Westchester P. G. A. record pro-amateur field of 118 pairs, tied for best-ball honors at Fenway today. They had 63's, eight under par.

BAYPORT, L. I., June 29 -- Working in 90-degree heat last Saturday, nine members of the new Men's Auxiliary of the Levittown Girl Scouts, assisted by their daughters, labored warmly but good-humoredly to finish an Adirondack type lean-to for Camp Edey's initial summer season, opening next Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- An immediate showdown on extending the excess profits tax was called off in the House of Representatives today as Republican leaders obtained last-minute assurances that a bill would be brought out by the Ways and Means Committee.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 30 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations commander, called on the Communists yesterday to resume negotiations at Panmunjom for an armistice in the Korean war and intimated that he was prepared to sign quickly on the terms already virtually agreed upon, despite the stubborn opposition of President Syngman Rhee of South Korea.

MIAMI BEACH, July 29 -- A warning that "false economy" in cutting the budget of the United States Office of Education would endanger the nation's public schools and colleges was made here today by top spokesmen for American education.

BOSTON, June 30 -- Sammy White slammed a two-run homer with two out in the ninth and gave the Red Sox a 5-4 victory over the Yankees before 32,837 fans at Fenway Park tonight. Allie Reynolds' failure to dispose of this one man cost the Bombers their eighth straight setback, the longest Yankee losing streak since the 1945 club dropped nine in a row.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -- The Screen Actors Guild, on the unanimous recommendation of the executive board, called on its 8,000 members today to vote approval of a new by-law that would require future members to sign a declaration of loyalty to the United States as a condition for obtaining, and continuing to hold, membership in the union.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Syngman Rhee of South Korea is understood to have demanded of the United States a total and iron-bound military alliance as his price for agreeing to a truce in the Korean war.

An analysis of the prices posted with the State Liquor Authority to go into effect in package stores today indicates that New Yorkers will find only a few cents' difference in the prices of their favorite brands. A few bonded whiskies have been reduced in price.

NEWARK, June 30 -- Chief of Union County Detectives Louis T. Lombardi testified today at a public hearing of the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council that the County Detectives Benevolent Association of New Jersey, Inc., of which he is president, had continued solicitation of funds although its own counsel had advised that it was illegal.

Two radically different professions share a common interest with home decorators. Psychologists and marketing executives with commercial instincts agree with the color blenders that aquamarine is a cooling color. This week more than 300 of the country's leading department stores have moved aquamarine bathtubs into their street window displays.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- The House Commerce Committee opens hearings tomorrow to find out why the oil industry has raised gasoline, fuel oil and other petroleum product prices in the face of an oil surplus. The first witnesses will include dealers who have particularly protested a 2-cent-a-gallon gasoline price rise in some East Coast areas.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, July 1 (AP) -- The Eighth Army today denied that lack of ammunition or armored vests had caused the deaths of two Pennsylvania soldiers who wrote home just before they were killed that their bullets and armor had been taken away because of an expected truce in Korea.
MOSCOW, June 30 (UP) -- A physician accused in the discredited "doctors plot" has been appointed to a new medical advisory board of the Soviet Health Ministry, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- House of Representatives judiciary subcommittee gave every indication today that it would oppose further action toward impeaching William O. Douglas, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, for "high crimes, and misdemeanors."

The political eyes of New Jersey are focused on Hoboken, New York's neighboring city across the Hudson, which today installs a new Mayor and a new form of municipal government. Hoboken -- the "mile-square city" -- has been governed by a five-man commission form of government since 1915.
The Liberal party, at an informal city convention last night in the Statler Hotel, unanimously selected City Council President Rudolph Halley as its candidate for Mayor.

Two new producers, A. Joseph Tandet and Bernard Friedman, have taken an option on Franz Spencer's "The Happy Ant Hill" with the intention of presenting it on Broadway next fall. The Messrs. Tandet and Friedman, theatrical lawyers, are negotiating with a top-notch Hollywood performer for the leading male role.

HEADQUARTERS, FIFTH AIR FORCE, Korea, Wednesday, July 1 -- Sabre jet pilots of the United States Air Force scored yesterday their most sensational success of the war here as they knocked fifteen Soviet-built MIG's from the skies over North Korea.

LONDON, June 30 -- American television is not the only video. A sampling of British programing makes it clear that viewers in the United States are missing a number of excellent types of presentations on their home screens. They also are escaping from some colossal bores.

Stores selling maternity clothes have much to offer the fashion-minded woman who is awaiting her baby. Such popular details as the sleeveless vogue and deep cuffed necklines have been quickly reflected in maternity designs. Interesting, too, is the growing popularity of the full-length coat that is bein gseen now in attractive costume ensembles.

The Red Cross obtained 834 pints of blood in the New York area on Monday. At the Roosevelt Hotel, Madison Avenue at Forty-fifth Street, 331 pints were donated on Monday by employes of the hotel, of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., the Lummus Company, Carrier Corporation, State Insurance Fund and Combustion Engineering, Inc.

For the city's youngsters, the summer arrived at 3 P. M. yesterday -- nine days and two hours after the official calendar proclamation. Within seconds of the schools' closing for the 1952-53 year, most of the 900,000 public school pupils had not only put sufficient mileage between themselves and their schools, but had erased without too much difficulty all thoughts of academic endeavors.
TOKYO, June 30 -- Japan officially notified the United States today that she was prepared to negotiate an agreement for United States assistance under the Mutual Security program.

Magistrate Charles Solomon reluctantly directed yesterday that the charge against Henry G. Hanna, 33-year-old American Legion post commander, for selling lottery tickets be heard by three justices of Special Sessions.

Mayor Impellitteri broke ground yesterday for the new Coney Island Municipal Hospital. It will cost more than $15,000,000 and is the final large item in the $192,000,000 post-war program of the Department of Hospitals, either in construction or already in operation.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, July 1 (AP) -- South Korean President Syngman Rhee has criticized the British Prime Minister, Sir Winston Churchill, for having criticized Dr. Rhee's release of 27,000 anti-Communist North Korean prisoners from United Nations compounds in South Korea.
The Champion Paper and Fibre Company reported yesterday net profit of $8,873,918 for the fiscal year ended March 31, compared with $9,936,191 in the preceding fiscal year.

NOT many years ago the sponsors at the Professional Golfers Association championship were rubbing their hands in glee. They had corralled the four biggest names in the divot-digging sport as their headline attractions and they frankly didn't care which two reached the final. The Big Four were Ben Hogan, Sammy Snead, Jimmy Demaret and Bobby Locke.

With or without polarized glasses, film company stocks were among the few visible movers in the stock market yesterday. Evidently many investors had taken a cue from a declaration Monday by Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of New York, that there was a mass of tax bills before the Ways and Means Committee, including one to exempt theatres from the 20 per cent admission tax, "and I'm going to get them out."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -- Walt Disney Productions has contracted with Twentieth-Century-Fox to use its CinemaScope filming process on three feature-length pictures and an unlimited number of short subjects.

With the supply of ship tonnage exceeding current demands for cargoes, the ship charter and cargo market for both dry cargo vessels and tankers is declining and is showing more of a downward trend than the traditional and usually slight annual summer decline would account for, shipping observers reported here yesterday.
Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires won the eighteenth and last game of his match with Samuel Reshevsky of New York, according to a report from the Argentine capital yesterday.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, who is not a candidate for re-election, will begin tonight a series of weekly discussions of current and past problems of his Administration. The series will be presented Wednesday nights, 9 to 9:30 o'clock over WATV, Channel 13.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The State Department announced today that the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France would meet here July 10 for talks of unspecified duration on "problems of mutual interest."

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed into law today a bill allowing speedy naturalization of aliens serving at least ninety days in the United States armed forces since the outbreak of the Korean war.

GENEVA, June 30 -- The pronounced desire on the part of European governments to aviod irritating the Soviet Union at this time made itself feit at the opening meeting of the United Nations Economic and Social Council's summer session here today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining took over command of the Air Force today from Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, who retired after thirty years of service. General Twining became the first to take office of the new set of service chiefs appointed by the Eisenhower Administration.

DETROIT, June 30 -- A new foreign trade controversy arose in Detroit today as the Public Lighting Commission recommended rejection of a Swiss bid to supply the city with a 50,000-kilowatt steam turbine generator for $649,500 less than the lowest American bidder.
Two correction officers at the City Penitentiary on Rikers Island were arrested yesterday on charges of having delivered $100 from a Manhattan narcotics peddler to a penitentiary inmate.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress today asking authority to send Government - held surplus farm products abroad to relieve famine in friendly, countries:
There is at least one office-holding Democrat in New York who is proving a thorn to the patronage-minded Republican Administrtaion in Washington.
MIAMI BEACH, June 30 -- Book burning and any stifling of free inquiry were condemned today by leading educators at the ninety- first annual convention of the National Education Association.

Announcement of the publication of two more "how to" books the other day suggested an inquiry into the output to date of works in this field dedicated to instruction and improvement. It can be reported that the output has been staggering.

Volume continued light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Hides however showed good activity and potatoes trailed the highest volume for the month set on June 1 by one car lot. Prices closed irregular with cocoa, wool, tin, lead, copper and zinc higher.

The credit man's role as a consultant for business is taking on increased importance, according to Mortimer J. Davis, executive vice president of the New York Credit and Financial Management Association. And the aid that the credit man can render in merchandising in general, he said, is unsurpassed by that of almost any other type of executive personnel in the vast commercial field.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 30 (AP) -- The Brookfield Farms' Influence, a 14-1 shot, upset the form before 10,852 today and captured the featured $6,000 Prudery Purse, beating Play Toy by three lengths in the six-furlong race at Monmouth Park.
The four seeded players in the women's Eastern clay court tennis championship reached the quarter-final round yesterday at the Bayside (Queens) Tennis and Racquets Club. None of them lost a set.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 30 (AP) -- Adios Boy, owned by J. S. Turner of Nassawadox, Va., smashed the Roosevelt Raceway pacing record for 2-year-olds tonight. The bay son of Adios stormed home by five and three-quarter lengths in 2:04 2/5, cracking the old mile standard of 2:05 set by Hillsota in July of last year.

LONDON, June 30 -- Details of a new decree, introduced by Czechoslovakia to curb alarming absenteeism and labor fluctuation in industry, were publicized today by all Czech newspapers and the State-run Prague radio.

HENLEY, England, June 30 (UP) -- The Henley Royal regatta, one of the world's top rowing events, opens tomorrow with oarsmen from the United States, France, Belgium, Germany, Holland and Switzerland challenging British crews for major honors.

A parade of passenger liners, led by the great Cunarder Queen Elizabeth, largest vessel in the world, entered New York yesterday to discharge 5,000 passengers in the half-mile area between West Forty - sixth and West Fifty - seventh Streets.

Last night at midnight the fiscal year 1952-53 for the United States Treasury passed into history; today we are entering the year 1953-54, a year which could be a critical one in the history of American fiscal policy.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 30 -- Thousands of Montgomery children, 9 years old and under, began taking hypodermic injections of gamma globulin this morning as part of a mass program designed to curb the spread of polio paralysis in Montgomery County.

Asserting that a pilot project had demonstrated the need for a broad program of complete local recreation centers, Mayor Impellitteri advocated yesterday, the spending of another $8,000,000 to round out the plan.

The Giant bats, which spoke so loudly during the New Yorkers' triumphant swing through the West, were stilled last night by the pitching artistry of Murry Dickson, the one high-salaried employe remaining on the roster of the last-place Pirates.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., June 30 -- On the eve of the thirty-fifth Professional Golfers Association championship, the organization's executive committee named fifteen of its leading members as candidates for the United States Ryder Cup squad that will meet a British professional golfing team, Oct. 2-3, at Wentworth, England.
The American Lyric Theatre last night presented its second bill of the summer season at 320 West Fifty-seventh Street.

PARIS, June 30 -- The virtually outlawed nationalist Neo-Destour party of Tunisia, many of whose leaders have been banished by the French, put out a consiliatory statement tonight saying that it was ready to cooperate with French "in a climate of confidence."

HONG KONG, June 30 -- One of the most elusive basic statistics in the Far East -- the exact size of China's tremendous population -- may be established in the first comprehensive modern census taken in that country. The counting of heads in China is scheduled to begin tomorrow with all vital statistics being frozen for tabulation purposes as of midnight tonight.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 30 -- Dr. Ray E. Phillips, an American missionary in South Africa for thirty-five years, said today that native protests against discriminatory race laws were awakening some industrial and business groups there to the costliness of restrictive practices.

BETHEL, Conn., June 30 -- The largest sycamore tree in town, at the fork of Routes 202 and 53, provides a pleasant, shady location for the Bethel Volunteer Fire Department's stand for its second annual sale of fireworks. It will also be its last stand, since the Connecticut Legislature recently approved a state-wide ban on fireworks to be effective after this year's Fourth of July, Saturday.

BATTIR, Jordan, June 25 -- Perched on the steep southern slope of the Valley of Roses, a narrow ravine winding westward from Jerusalem toward the sea, this ancient village, called Bether in the Bible, is today a testament that warring peoples can live at peace if they try hard enough.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- The Browns spoiled the White Sox homecoming tonight, routing Billy Pierce during a twelve-hit assault that produced a 4-2 victory and ended a seven-game Chicago winning streak.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 30 -- Several hundreds of Thais, other Asians, Europeans and Americans gathered today at Don Muang Airport to say farewell to United States Ambassador Edwin F. Stanton and his wife, who are leaving after seven years in Thailand.

I should like to report a strong impression which is the result of seventeen months abroad. It is this, that if there is one American who more than any other is injuring his country by un-American activities it is Senator Joseph McCarthy. We who are abroad have come to expect that his acts and ideas will be thrown in our faces wherever we go.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Eisenhower nominated Whitley P. McCoy, Professor of Law at the University of Alabama, today to be director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- The Government has decided to let a team of Soviet citizens enter the United States next month to participate in an international chess tournament in New York, it was learned today.

Witty Brothers will offer its first line of year-round suits and topcoats in blends of Dacron and wool this fall, it was announced yesterday by Spencer Witty, vice president of the company. Witty, the first manufacturer to introduce suits of 100 per cent Dacron, will use varying percentages of the fiber in different styles and fabrics.

BERLIN, June 30 -- The Soviet Union indicated tonight it might continue to restrict entry into East Berlin indefinitely in an effort to reduce Western influence in the Soviet-controlled areas of Germany and Berlin.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, proposed in the Senate today a constitutional amendment that would provide for selection of Presidential electors in the same manner and in the same number as Senators and Representatives of each of the forth-eight states.

The Colonie, N. Y., Central School District sold $3,280,000 of bonds maturing serially from 1954 to 1982 at an interest cost of 3.4 per cent yesterday. The bonds were bought by the New York State Controller's Office as an investment for public employe retirement funds.

" Quackery in the Public Schools," by Albert Lynd, an expansion of his article that appeared in The Atlantic Magazine, will be issued Sept. 10 by Atlantic-Little, Brown. In his attack on what he considers malpractice in public education, Mr. Lynd answers such questions as: "Who decides on the kind of education your child should have? Have you ever been consulted about it?
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture officially set the price support level on the 1953 wheat crop today at $2.21 a bushel. Last year's national average was $2.20.

Four persons were wounded last night when a group of youths, said to be members of a neighborhood gang, fired a number of random pistol shots as they ran through East 105th Street, between Park and Madison Avenues.

Georgi N. Zarubin, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 3:13 P. M. yesterday on a Scandinavian Airliner for Copenhagen, Denmark. From there he will fly to Helsinki, Finland, and then to Moscow.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 30 -- The appeal of Jomo (Burning Spear) Kenyatta, who was sentenced to seven years imprisonment on April 8 on charges of managing the anti-white Mau Mau rebellion, will start tomorrow in Kitale, the appeal alleges a long series of errors of law and of procedure in the first trial.

WASHINGTON, June 30 --Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, made public today the letter he had written to Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, on the disposition of a list of about 150 American atomic spy suspects that Mr. McCarthy held was given to President Truman in the mid-Nineteen Forties.

The Presidential orders withdrawing civil service protection from an estimated 134,000 federal positions and establishing a new classification outside the merit system may not be so bad as the Administration's enemies contend. But they do raise a good many legitimate doubts about the Administration's intentions.
Strong opposition to Senate ratification of the renewed International Wheat Agreement was announced yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in June was slightly higher than in both the previous month and the corresponding month a year ago. For the first six months of this year the turnover was 192,980,733 shares, compared with 171,913,501 a year earlier and 247,188,683 in the first half of 1951.

An annual minimum outlay of $20,000,000 for maintenance and repair work in the city school system, was urged yesterday by Charles J. Bensley, chairman of the Board of Education's buildings and sites committee.

LONDON, June 30 -- The continued quiet business on the stock markets here was relieved today by increased buying of British Government securities, which gained up to one-quarter of 1 per cent. The gilt-edge section had been the weakest part of the market recently.

FORT DIX, N. J., June 30 -- The fabled card sharper who used to ride the best Mississippi River sidewheelers and later shifted to swank ocean liners and railway Pullmans to find victims now has direct descendants who travel second class for the same reason.

Chief Judge Thomas Walter Swan and Judge Augustus N. Hand of the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, are retiring from their judicial posts. Judge Swan has notified President Eisenhower that his retirement is effective today and Judge Hand will retire tomorrow.

Since removing caps and gowns in 1943, members of that year's graduation class at Vassar College have extended their talents and efforts well beyond the kitchen and nursery, according to a ten-year alumnae report on their activities.

On June 3, 1877, the Rev. Willard Parsons told his congregation in the pleasant little community of Sherman, Pa., that there should be health-restoring country summer vacations for poor children living on New York City's East Side. Mr. Parsons had served these city children as minister and he knew their needs.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The New York law firm of Sullivan Cromwell, with which John Foster Dulles was associated until he became Secretary of State, has more than $14,000,000 in claims pending before the International Claims Commission, whose two Democratic members were dismissed by President Eisenhower on Saturday, a commission spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today a hearing examiner has recommended dismissal of a price discrimination complaint against the "big three" soap manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- Farm crop prices dropped about 1 per cent during the thirty-day period ended June 15, the Department of Agriculture said today. They thus continued the decline which began last September with reversals only in March and May.

A close friend of the estimated 33,000,000 homemakers in this country is celebrating its thirtieth birthday -- the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics of the United States Department of Agriculture.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 30 -- Archbishop Makarios III, ethnarch of the Greek community here, said in an interview today that he was studying ways and means of bringing the Cyprus question to the United Nations, probably in the autumn, if by then pressure on Britain to allow the island to be administered by Greece remained ineffective.

WITH the school tuna now plentiful off Montauk, a lot of anglers who fail to make advance reservations will be doing their week-end fishing for cod and pollock on the party boats rather than trolling for tuna on charter craft.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 142 Korean war casualties. The list contained the names of forty killed, eighty-six wounded, seven missing, one captured and eight injured. No casualties were reported from New Jersey or Connecticut. Casualties from New York were:
DETROIT, June 30 (UP) -- Al Rosen and Dale Mitchell pounded two-run homers as the Indians defeated the Tigers, 6 -- 4, tonight in a game limited to five innings by rain.

Led by Gen. Albert Orsborn, international leader of the Salvation Army in London, many other officials of that organization and civic and social leaders were among the 1,000 persons who paid final tribute yesterday to Commissioner Ernest L Pugmire, national commander since 1944, at a funeral service in the Centennial Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street.

RED HOOK, N. Y., June 30 -- What a surprise guests at Sunset Lodge will have tonight at their masked ball when the identity of the woman wearing the costume of fresh leaves is revealed! Yet for the woman the biggest thrill of the day came this afternoon when she rode a horse for the first time in five years.
Former President Harry S. Truman was the guest of honor last night at a surprise dinner party arranged by his daughter, Margaret.

The Pennsylvania Electric Company borrowed $12,500,000 in the public market yesterday on first mortgage thirty-year bonds at a bid of 101.689 for interest of 4 1/8 per cent submitted by a syndicate headed by Equitable Securities Corporation.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., June 30 (UP) -- The chairman of the American Petroleum Institute denied today that the petroleum industry was "stealing from the public domain" as a result of the recently passed offshore oil bill.
HARTFORD, June 30 -- Connecticut's sales tax, which has been 2 per cent since 1948, will rise to 3 per cent tomorrow under legislation approved by the General Assembly that adjourned May 30.
