The research departments of several Wall Street brokerage firms were busy yesterday taking a closer look at Gimbel Brothers, Inc., now that the company has a program for opening suburban stores. Although Gimbel's subsidiary. Saks Fifth Avenue, has operated branch stores and specialty shops for a number of years, the parent company has been one of the few holdouts in favor of the large downtown department store.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Senate Republican Conference agreed today to back a one-year renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act without trying to upset the bipartisan composition of the United States Tariff Commission.
Trescott A. Buell has been appointed assistant treasurer of the Western Union Telegraph Company.

SARGON, Vietnam, June 30 (Reuters) -- An uneasy quiet hung over Pnompenh, capital of Cambodia, today, but official sources here said there had been no clashes between the Cambodian troops and the French. Cambodian troops have occupied Government buildings.

SEOUL, Wednesday, July 1 (AP) -- History's greatest jet victory overshadowed the ground war, which slackened except on the Central and Eastern fronts where the Chinese Communists seized two hills in see-saw fighting.

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 30 -- Three more seeded players were eliminated today, but the second-seeded man, Jack Sunderland of Orange, N. J., moved in the quarter-final round in the New Jersey State men's tennis championships. Sunderland, defending champion, defeated Henry H. Bassford Jr. of Brooklyn, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 4.

A merchandising program involving pricing levels with a "safety margin" feature to assist the agricultural and garden seed industry was advocated yesterday by Stephen Beale of Detroit, executive vice president of Ferry Morse Company, a leading breeder, grower and distributor of seeds of all types.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Hawaii Statehood Commission agreed today to accept statehood without the inclusion of Palmyra and the string of small islands and rocks to the leeward of Hawaii within the boundaries of the proposed new state.

The use of abandoned slate quarries in northeastern Pennsylvania as underground reservoirs for the seasonal storage of heating oil is being considered by the Esso Standard Oil Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), it was announced yesterday.
While trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, the market closed 4 points lower to 8 higher.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., June 30 -- Scoring 41, 41 -- 82 at Fairview's par-74 layout, 18-year-old Judy Frank of Aldecress today won in Women's Metropolitan Golf Association competition by 5 strokes.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Three youths who distinguished themselves last year received from President Eisenhower today the Young American Medals for Bravery or Service awarded by the Justice Department.

At a gathering of seventy-five outstanding scientists, engineers and business men this week Ralph J. Cordiner, president of the General Electric Company, pleaded for more fundamental research by industrial laboratories and supported his argument with the announcement that his own company planned to increase its research staff from 1,000 to 1,500.

Last night at Ebbets Field the Phils and the Dodgers played a game that was reminiscent of the old Baker Bowl days, when it was a case of "last team up wins." But the Brooks didn't quite live up to the ancient script. They left the tying run on third base in the tenth inning and the Phils won, 10 -- 9.

" The Little Clay Cart" is an ideal selection for a summer series. and the production that opened last evening at the Theatre de Lys is original and interesting, like the production of "The Scarecrow" two weeks ago. Next week "The Scarecrow" will go back on the stage for a run, alongside a new air- conditioning plant guaranteed to work even when there are people in the house.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 30 -- The retirement of Dr. Americo Castro, who for thirteen years has been Emory L. Ford Professor of Spanish at Princeton University, was announced today by Prof. J. Douglas Brown, dean of the faculty.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- America's merchants established a "hall of fame" here tonight and announced that four pioneers in mass distribution had been selected as the first members. Chosen by a vote of financial editors and professors of business and commerce were:

BONN, Germany, June 30 -- Dr. James B. Conant, United States Ambassador, made it clear today that the United States Government would reject any Soviet proposal to hold a high-level four-power conference to solve the German problem unless Moscow was prepared to end its dictatorial control in East Germany and accept in advance Germany's reunification on the terms outlined in the Allied note of Sept. 24, 1952.

CINCINNATI, June 30 (AP) -- Eddie Mathews ended Milwaukee's eight-game losing streak with his twenty-second home run in the top of the tenth inning tonight for a 6-4 triumph after the Redlegs had defeated the Braves, 6 -- 3, in the opener of the twilight-night double-header.
HANOVER, N. H., June 30 -- A record of $635,487 in contributions from 16,221 contributors was set today as the Dartmouth College Alumni Fund ended its thirty-ninth annual drive.
Librarians and all readers owe a vote of thanks for the bright and deft manner Topics of The Times used in portraying library and book service in private organizations on June 25.
LOS ANGELES, June 30 (UP) -- Six "liberal" Los Angeles Councilmen "went fishing" today in a move aimed at deciding the choice of a new council president.

Open Show of the Lester Manor Stable and Virtuous, owned by G. C. Ganter, engaged in a rousing duel in the Seagirt, the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, with the Open Show winning by a nose. The outcome was expected by the crowd of 18,094 for Open Show was the favorite and Virtuous the second choice among the six who competed in the mile-and-a-sixteent allowance event.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican of Steuben County, N. Y., today joined those introducing legislation to allow sale to private interests of the Government's share in General Aniline and Film Corporation.

Carpenters and dock builders, members of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, A. F. L., announced last night that they had reached an agreement with the General Contractors Association. They predicted that it would set a pattern for the entire construction industry in the metropolitan area, involving more than 250,000 workers.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 30 (Reuters) -- The Netherlands today offered compromise proposals to end five-year negotiations on self-government for 360,000 natives of the Dutch West Indies.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 (UP) -- The results of other matches today in the all-England tennis championships:

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 -- The United States continued its stranglehold on international women's tennis as the four top-seeded players moved into the semifinals of the All-England championships in the presence of the Duke of Edinburgh, the Duchess of Kent and another capacity crowd today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Eisenhower Administration, the Republican leaders of the Senate and Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, sought for three hours today a ground for compromise on Mr. Bricker's proposed amendment to the Constitution to limit the treaty-making power.

PARIS, June 30 -- Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, received today a belated invitation to a meeting of the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France in Washington -- the extension of what was to have been a meeting between United States officials and the Marquess of Salisbury, acting British Foreign Secretary.

TORONTO, June 30 (Canadian Press) -- Can-Amera Oil Sands Development, Ltd., a company with Canadian and United States interests recently incorporated in Alberta, announced today that it believes it has found a process which will "unlock" the Athabasca oil sands of northern Alberta.

Advice for the home seamstress on sewing Dacron, one of the relatively new synthetic fibers being used for ready-made garments, is included in a report in this month's issue of The Journal of Home Economics.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, July 1 -- The Senate agreed without a dissenting voice yesterday to let President Eisenhower decide whether $1,000,000,000 of military aid funds for Western Europe should be held up pending creation of the European Defense Community and the single continental army for which it provides.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 30 -- Ten leaders in engineering materials were presented the award of merit of the American Society for Testing Materials today for contributions to the field, particularly for their work with A. S. T. M. technical committees.

A crazed unemployed shipping clerk, who described himself to the police after his capture as a "professional justice man," burst onto the stage of a television theatre while a rehearsal was under way yesterday at 2 P. M., stabbed a cameraman twice and broke a water pitcher over the head of one of the actors.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 30 -- Polluted waters caused three more names to be added today to the list of public bathing beaches denied permits in the first 1953 rating of Nassau County swimming waters by Dr. Earle G. Brown, County Health Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Congress whisked three major bills dealing with economic controls and housing to passage today and then rushed them to the White House for President Eisenhower's signature before midnight when current authority in these areas expired.

ST. LOUIS, June 30 (AP) -- The Cubs tonight routed the Cardinals with an eighteen-hit barrage and handed the Redbirds their third straight defeat, 10 -- 3, as Frank Baumholtz pounded out four blows and Ralph Kiner three, including his sixteenth home run.

Bonds called for redemption before maturity in June totaled $83,158,000, the largest amount for any month since January, when $124,241,000 was redeemed. The month's total compared with $14,232,000 in May and $31,508,000 in June, 1952.

A "task force" of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee will soon hold hearings on a bill by Senator Butler of Maryland to prevent the National Labor Relations Board from certifying a Commnuist-dominated union as collective bargaining agent for employes.

PARIS, June 30 -- Premier Joseph Laniel had no trouble under the political truce in obtaining a large majority vote of acceptance of his new Cabinet by the National Assembly today. He did not even speak in its defense and merely asked that criticism of the Cabinet's make-up be shelved. The vote was 386 to 212.

CAIRO, June 30 -- An agricultural development project in the Gaza strip and the northern coastal area of the Sinai Peninsula, which may ultimately provide livelihood for 50,000 of 208,000 Palestinian refugees there, was the subject of an agreement sighed today by the Egyptian Government and the United Nations Relief and Works Agency.

BOSTON, June 30 -- Averell Hariman, former Director for Mutual Security, said tonight that President Eisenhower should clarify further his position on "book burners," or the removal of books from overseas libraries, despite his recent messages on the subject at Dartmouth College and to the American Library Association.

The Republican "bosses" have turned down Representative Jacob K. Javits as their candidate for Mayor, and Mr. Javits already "has thrown in the sponge," Kings County Judge Samuel Leibowitz charged yesterday.
TOKYO, June 30 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 434, for the period from midnight to 6 P. M. Tuesday, Korea time:
DAVENPORT, Iowa, June 30 (AP) -- Narcissus the meadowlark thinks his mate is hiding inside an automobile wheel.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, June 30 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, presented an engraved scroll here today to Admiral Robert B. Carney of the United States Navy in tribute to "the remarkable" progress achieved by Admiral Carney in developing Allied defenses in the Southern European Command during the last two years.
A series of new rules designed to promote safer driving will go into effect throughout the state today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Drought and surpluses, current twin problems of the Eisenhower Administration and of agricultural producers, brought further Government action toward relief today.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 1 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark called the top commanders of United States forces in Korea and the Far East to confer today with the Army Chief of Staff. Gen. J. Lawton Collins, at Tokyo headquarters. The conference came while the United Nations awaited a reply from the Communists to a proposal to conclude an armistice despite the bitter opposition of President Syngman Rhee of South Korea.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., June 30 -- The taste of fermented mash in well water in the neighborhood of the Burnley farm here led to a raid by Bureau of Internal Revenue agents and the confiscation of a still, said to be capable of producing 700 gallons of 180-proof alcohol a day, in an old barn on Terrill Road today.

STANTON, Del., June 30 (AP) -- The Rokeby Stables Benbow, winner of the recent Tom Roby stakes here, raced to a seven-length triumph today in Delaware Park's version of the Spring Maiden Steeplechase of about two miles.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 30 -- Guilty of weaving in and out of traffic at high speed on the Hutchinson River Parkway in Harrison last August, James W. Boulware, 28 years old, was sentenced in County Court today by Judge John P. Donohoe to serve two and a half to five years in Sing Sing Prison and pay a $1,000 fine.

ALBANY, June 30 -- Governor Dewey set the stage today for a wholesale housecleaning in the crime-ridden Port of New York as he signed into law two bills authorizing a two-state waterfront commission with powers to crack down on racketeers.

The executive committee of the Board of Higher Education voted yesterday to request $35,000 in municipal funds to conduct its own investigation of alleged subversives on the four city college faculties.
DUBLIN, June 30 (AP) -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valera called for a showdown on his Government today in the Dail (Parliament) with a demand for a vote of confidence.

REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, June 30 -- A visit to the south suggests why land reform is a more controversial subject in Italy than foreign policy. Dividing the big estates raises as many questions as it answers. It brings into high relief the tragic fact that there will never be enough land in this country to go around.

The gravity of the situation in Cambodia, where the King is leading a movement for complete independence from France, throws a sharp light on the whole problem of the French Union. The French Empire is as complex as the British, with colonies, protectorates and dependencies in all stages of civilization and economic and political progress.
New financing in June reflected the unsettlement in securities markets in the month. Public offerings of bonds and stocks here were smaller than in the preceding month and a year ago.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Two senators said today they feared the United States might be forced into fighting South Korea if the Communists should decide to accept truce pledges made by Gen. Mark W. Clark.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The State Department, under heavy attack for its so-called "book-burning" or book-banning policies, has begun to show some concern over what its highest officials believe is a misunderstanding of its overseas information task.

THERE is nothing quite so unpredictable as literary reputation. Some authors, such as Spenser or Dryden, enjoy enduring fame because of their importance in their own era, although none but students read them now. Some, such as Shakespeare and Dickens, are immortal because their works are never failing sources of delight for the readers of every age.

SUMMIT, N. J., June 30 -- Thomas Harmon Jr. and his amateur partner, Louis Seton of Montclair, won the New Jersey pro-amateur best-ball championship over the Canoe Brook South Course today. Teaming perfectly, Harmon and Seton turned in a 6-under-par 34, 32 -- 66 and took the title in the largest field ever to play in this event.

VIENNA, June 30 -- Hungary has followed the example set by the Soviet Union after Stalin's death and by other Soviet satellites since by abolishing the post of general secretary of the Communist party and dissolving its Orgburo, or Organization Committee and reducing the size of its Politburo from seventeen to nine members.

JAKE BACHTOLD was rewarded with a golden New York Central Railroad pass yesterday -- for fifty years of clock watching, of all things. He mumbled his thanks and returned to his room to resume clock watching, which he had interrupted for the ceremony.

CAIRO, June 30 -- Egypt's Finance Minister obtained Cabinet approval tonight for a program of national austerity -- including cuts in Government salaries and increases of taxes and tariffs -- to counterbalance the years of corruption and extravagance that brought the nation to the verge of "financial collapse."

SUMMIT, N. J., June 30 -- Thomas Harmon Jr. and his amateur partner, Louis Seton of Montclair, won the New Jersey pro-amateur best-ball championship over the Canoe Brook South Course today. Teaming perfectly, Harmon and Seton turned in a 6-under-par 34, 32 -- 66 and took the title in the largest field ever to play in this event.

VIENNA, June 30 -- Hungary has followed the example set by the Soviet Union after Stalin's death and by other Soviet satellites since by abolishing the post of general secretary of the Communist party and dissolving its Orgburo, or Organization Committee and reducing the size of its Politburo from seventeen to nine members.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- A Government Operations subcommittee of the House of Representatives charged today that millions of dollars of Federal housing funds in Los Angeles had been poured into political and lobbying activities "in brazen disregard of Federal criminal statutes."
LONDON, June 30 (Reuters) -- English batsmen rallied against Australia's bowlers today to draw in the second cricket test.

During the fiscal year ended today, the amount of corporate bonds on the so-called "legal list" increased more than $1,300,000,000 to reach a total in excess of $24,000,000,000, the largest volume on record, according to an announcement just issued by William A. Lyon, Superintendent of Banks.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A House of Representatives Judiciary subcommittee that has spent nearly seventeen months delving into reports of scandals and mismanagement in the Department of Justice concluded its task today, convinced that the conditions it was appointed to investigate largely had been eliminated.

Shipping leaders and representatives of private and Government transportation agencies attended a testimonial luncheon at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington yesterday for Frazer A. Bailey, retiring this week as president of the National Federation of American Shipping. The luncheon, given by the Propeller Club of Washington, was attended by 300 guests.

Strained egg yolks in paste or custardlike consistency, the latest in processed baby foods, are being introduced by Gerber's and Swift Co., which report their new products are available in several chains here.
Mrs. Mary Overbaugh, who celebrated her 105th birthday yesterday, credits her long life to having been "a good Christian girl."

It is time that Government agencies and individuals concerned with loyalty compile a "white list" of those who support American principles of freedom and democracy, Helen G. Irwin, president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Inc., declared yesterday.

The chance of delays on the Long Island Rail Road is greater because of the possibility of parts failure in a number of electrical safety devices not used by other commuter lines in this area, the railway argued yesterday before the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that the recent riots in Berlin, along with disorders in other satellite areas, confirmed his theory of more than three years ago that the Soviet Union was "over-extended" in its attempted control of about 600,000,000 non-Russians.

ALBANY, June 30 -- Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, State Commissioner of Education, said today, as the school year closed, that "despite a continuing shortage of elementary school teachers in the rural areas and despite a school housing problem brought about to a large extent by shifts in population and by increased enrollment, the school year 1952-53 has been one of progress."

GUATEMALA, June 30 (AP) -- A big mystery blast in a grocery warehouse here early today sent sheets of flame sweeping through a crowded near-by hotel and homes, killing at least thirty persons and injuring thirty-one.

A Kings County grand jury recommended yesterday that legislation be enacted to prohibit a physician, a nurse or any other person from executing in blank a birth certificate. The panel has been investigating since October, 1951, the so-called black market in illegitmate babies.

TOKYO, June 30 (UP) -- Northern Kyushu today began digging out from the layers of mud, rock and debris left behind by the worst flood in modern Japanese history. Reports from hitherto isolated communities pushed the casualty toll over 2,000.

The state commission seeking to reform the city's management announced yesterday its tentative conclusion that the conventional city manager plan did not seem suitable for so large and complex a city as New York, but that a variant calling for a "strong Mayor with a professional manager" should be studied further.

With July 4 coming on a Saturday for the first time in eleven years, the city's business community has had some difficulty deciding how to celebrate the holiday, but it appeared yesterday that nearly a third of the local concerns will be closed all day Friday of this week.
In a recent article from Paris you represent the French as "staying officially aloof from the controversy now raging" in Morocco between the Sultan and what was referred to as "the local chieftains."

With July 4 coming on a Saturday for the first time in eleven years, the city's business community has had some difficulty deciding how to celebrate the holiday, but it appeared yesterday that nearly a third of the local concerns will be closed all day Friday of this week.
In a recent article from Paris you represent the French as "staying officially aloof from the controversy now raging" in Morocco between the Sultan and what was referred to as "the local chieftains."

PARIS, July 1 -- When Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, visits Washington July 10 for talks among the Foreign Ministers of the three Western powers, he may be able to submit details of a French plan for a new deal and greater political independence for Indo-China. Such, at any rate, is the hope of specialists in the subject, whose recommendations for such a policy were discussed today by the principal Ministers of the French Government.
CEDARHURST, L. I., July 1 -- Mrs. Frank Maloney of Meadow Brook won the Women's Long Island Golf Association's one-day point-par tournament at Rockaway Hunting Club today by amassing 39 points.

A two-language television show will have its premiere Monday night at 11 o'clock when WOR-TV offers the "Spanish Hour" in English and Spanish. The musical variety series will present Carmen Torres, singer of Santo Domingo; Lucienne, a Spanish dancer, and Angel Rosa and his orchestra.

The program last night at Lewisohn Stadium was listed as "Slavic" and contained music by Prokofieff and Dvorak. It was a charming concert, containing as it did Dvorak's sure-fire symphony, and three of Prokofieff's most effective pieces, all brilliantly led by Leonard Bernstein.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- By a narrow margin, the stockholders of the National Bank of Germantown and Trust Company approved today its merger with the Girard Trust Corn Exchange Bank, a midtown institution with fourteen offices.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Eisenhower said today that it was not so important whether the Republican majority in Congress always agreed with him. More significant, he declared, was that the Republican party was developing a progressive program for the people.
Motorists here are observing the pattern of arm signals that became legally effective yesterday, according to police reports.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Most manufacturers are disappointed with business at the Summer Home Furnishings Market here but are optimistic about their industry generally for the remainder of the year, Don Van Noppen, president of the Southern Furniture Manufacturers Association, said today.

HOBOKEN, N. J., July 1 -- Promising that members of his administration would show that they were civic builders rather than just politicians, Mayor John J. Grogan became this waterfront city's first executive under the new Mayor-Council form of government.

Two associates of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, Dr. Merrill W. Chase and Dr. George E. Palade, have been promoted to associate members, the association announced yesterday at its offices at York Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.
I was both entertained and instructed by your editorial of June 22 on "Mr. Humphrey's Dinner," being particularly struck by this passage:

DETROIT, July 1 (AP) -- Little Ted Gray, posting his third straight victory, snapped the Indians' six-game winning streak today by holding the runner-up American League club to six hits and fanning nine as the last-place Tigers won, 4 -- 2.

The Wheatley Stable's 2-year-old colt, Quick Lunch, trained by 78-year-old Jim Fitzsimmons and ridden by 44-year-old Nick Wall, did a front-running job to win the $13,975 Tremont Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. Quick Lunch was the 8-to-1 fourth choice.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- It is difficult to see how any language can be found on which the President and the convinced supporters of the proposed amendment of the treaty-making powers of the Executive and the Senate can agree. The President today repeated his belief that no treaty can circumvent or supervene the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The White House said today that President Eisenhower beat a midnight deadline by fifteen minutes last night in signing into law legislation to keep economic controls and housing programs alive.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 -- It will be Victor Seixas of the United States against Kurt Nielsen of Denmark for the All-England tennis championship.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Eisenhower indicated today that he had modified his outright oppositoin to the proposed Bricker amendment to the Constitution which would restrict the treaty-making powers of the President.

Sales in eleven New York and Brooklyn department stores in June averaged 3.5 per cent above those of June, 1953, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The rise was the only one in the second quarter of the year, as April showed a 3 per cent decline and May one of 5 per cent.

As part of the reorganization of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, the Treasury Department yesterday ordered Bronx, Rockland and Westchester Counties aligned with the Upper Manhattan District instead of the more distant Albany District.

To keep pace with the "regeneration" of the lower East Side, Beth Israel Hospital hopes to construct on property it already owns on Sixteenth Street a nurses' residence, a convalescent unit, a neuropsychiatric unit and a division of geriatrics, Charles H. Silver, president of the board of trustees, said yesterday in his annual report.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 1 -- Officials of the French High Commission in Indo-China here believe they may be on the verge of an outbreak of hostilities in Cambodia if the answer to a virtual ultimatum to the French Government by Norodom Sihanouk, King of Cambodia, is much longer delayed.

William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, in citing an estimated deficit of $4,661,325 in the road's income this year, asked the Public Service Commission yesterday for a release from its order requiring the installation of centralized door control to improve safety and speed in operation of passenger service.

With the coming of warm weather it will be well for motorists to take stock of two automobile items that will need careful attention during the summer -- speedometer and tires. In summer, with more traffic on the road, most communities practice rigid enforcement of traffic laws, especially speed limits.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Canadian Government has sent a strongly worded note to the United States protesting new American quotas on foreign shipments of dairy products, fats and oils. The new restrictions, which became effective today, raise "grave problems for the whole structure of international cooperation," the Canadian note said.

A single, comprehensive court having jurisdiction over family problems now handled by unrelated tribunals here was suggested yesterday in an interim report on a special study made for the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
CHICAGO, July 1 (UP) -- The third-place White Sox slugged the Browns for a seven-run inning today and posted a 13-4 victory to move within five and a half games of the league-leading Yankees.

THEODORE SAMUEL WILLIAMS is being sent back from Korea, preparatory to a discharge from the Marines. But Captain Williams apparently hasn't changed a bit. Unwittingly or not, he always gets involved in a controversy of some sort. The latest is that he both will and will not be discharged from service in time to rejoin the Red Sox for the last month of the season.

Despite widespread feeling that the brisk business and industrial activity of June and of all the first half represents the top of the a boom, "there are few signs that any great falling off is imminent," according to the July bank letter of the National City Bank of New York, issued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Faced with the largest supplies of wheat on record and acting as required by law, Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson proclaimed today marketing quotas for the 1954 wheat crop in an attempt to stem the mounting surplus.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- Members of the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L., struck a group of Pacific Coast shipyards today in a wage disagreement. At a number of yards some of which have navy contracts, other A. F. L. craftsmen refused to cross picket lines and tied up all work in the plants.
TOKYO, Thursday, July 2 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,662, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Wednesday, Korean time:

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 1 -- To the accompaniment of mutterings about "extravagance," the national trade union federation known as Histadrut, Israel's biggest and most powerful economic organization, formally opened today its new headquarters in the most splendid and modern office building in the country.
YONKERS, July 1 -- Expanded plans for a $30,000,000 regional shopping center here in southern Westchester County were made public today by developers.

LONDON, July 1 -- The Conservative party retained the parliamentary seat contested yesterday in a by-election at Abingdon with almost the same percentage of the total vote that it received at the general election in 1951.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Senate Small Business Committee called upon Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield today to explain why his department issued a fraud order early this year denying the use of the mails to the makers of AD-X2, the controversial battery additive, and then, within a week, suspended it.

MIAMI BEACH, July 1 -- With public school attendance growing at the rate of 1,000,000 a year, the country faces a severe teacher shortage that already has reached serious proportions, 7,000 educators attending the National Education Association's annual convention heard here today.

HARTFORD, July 1 -- A reorganized administration of Connecticut's State Fish and Game Department, with emphasis on a program of wildlife conservation and restoration in the state, became effective at the state capitol today.

RIGHT now New Jersey seems to be the bluefish center, and boats from Brielle, Shark River and the Highlands are bringing in catches ranging from sixty to 125 pounds with plenty of fish in the five and six-pound class.
ST LOUIS, July 1 (UP) -- Gerry Staley pitched a ten-hitter tonight to give the Cardinals a 10-5 victory over the Cubs.

GLEN COVE, L. I., July 1 -- A three-year attempt by the Russians to obtain tax immunity on their Glen Cove mansion was abandoned today, with the receipt from the Soviet Embassy in Washington of a check for $9,053 to cover in full the taxes to date.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Eisenhower expressed his deep belief today that a satisfactory end would emerge from the efforts by the United States to win the acceptance of a Korean armistice by Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of South Korea.

New issues of securities valued at more than $50,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings include interim notes and common stock of natural gas companies, first mortgage bonds of a public utility company and equipment trust certificates of a Western railroad. The issues are:

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., July 1 -- Vic Ghezzi, 40-year-old professional from the Inwood Country Club, Inwood, L. I., equaled the course record of 66 to assume the lead in the first qualifying round of the Professional Golfers Association championship at the Birmingham Country Club today.

SEOUL, Korea, July 1 -- It was revealed today that the special United States mission in Korea had received assurances from President Syngman Rhee shortly after its arrival that "President Eisenhower has met all our requests," only to have the issue confused later when Dr. Rhee again put forth his old demands, which the Americans consider unreasonable.

Robert F. Loree, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council, has just filed a statement with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee strongly opposing ratification by the Senate of a renewal of the International Wheat Agreement. The council, says its chairman, regards the wheat program as economically unsound.

Mrs. Louise Ganzenmuller of Sea Cliff, L. I., the ranking favorite in the women's Eastern clay court tennis championship, was beaten in the quarter-final round yesterday at the Bayside Tennis and Racquets Club in Queens

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (AP) -- The Bank of America, the world's largest private bank, in its mid- year statement today, reported resources of $8,017,573,360, a gain of $448,928,441 over those of a year ago.
BERLIN, July 1 -- A record number of 467 members of East Germany's People's Police fled to the West during June, the West Berlin city government announced today.

A great deal of sensible, well-designed furniture was introduced at the wholesale home furnishings markets in the Midwest last week and reported in this paper. However, a remarkable number of atrocities (many more than usual), shocking enough to haunt this reporter's memory, also were presented.

KITALE, Kenya, July 1 (Reuters) -- Elaborate security precautions were taken here today when Jomo (Burning Spear) Kenyatta and five other African leaders appeared before the Kenya Supreme Court to appeal against their seven-year hard labor sentences for organizing the Mau Mau terrorist society.

A drop last week of 2,570,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 146,965,000 barrels, compared with 149,535,000 a week earlier and 120,902,000 a year ago.

In your excellent editorial of June 19 "Germany Fights On" the statement was made that "Germans have been fleeing westward from the Soviet Zone at the rate of more than 15,000 a month for many months."

Agreements providing wage increases for 82,000 dressmakers and for a thirty-five-hour week for 18,000 New York undergarment and negligee workers were announced yesterday by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L.

BERLIN, July 1 -- A number of top Soviet officials were reported tonight to have been recalled from East Germany for the coming Soviet policy talks in Moscow. This seemed to indicate that the chief subject would be the crisis in East Germany, swept by anti-Communist disorders last month.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Eisenhower conveyed to the House of Representatives today his "personal endorsement in all major particulars" of the $34,000,000,000 Defense Appropriation Bill on which debate was starting. The major particulars include a cut of $5,000,000,000 in funds for the Air Force below what President Truman asked in January.
First-quarter output of the container and packaging industry was generally above the corresponding period of last year and in many lines approached the high first-quarter volume of 1951.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- A Pan American World Airways executive said today that carrier should be permitted to fly to the Orient by the most direct route and not be required to fly more than 2,000 miles out of the way to "featherbed Northwest Airlines at a price of millions of dollars to the taxpayers."

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Eisenhower restated his position today on what kinds of books should be in the State Department's libraries at 189 International Information Service centers overseas, established to fight communism.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- High-level talks aimed at an agreement on revision of the Taft-Hartley Act have been suspended, at least temporarily, and informed opinion is that the chances of success this year are remote.

The Institute of World Affairs, Inc., 522 Fifth Avenue, has named Dr. Walter Rice Sharp as director of its annual summer seminar in advanced studies from next Thursday to Aug. 26 at the institute's 600-acre campus at Twin Lakes, Conn.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- The first day of the new crop year saw a strong market for coarse grains and a substantial recovery from early weakness in the wheat market. Recent Government moves of various kinds, all tending to denote an intention to use existing regulations for maintaining farm prices, have had a reassuring effect.
The department store merchants are not doing so badly as the gloom merchants have been saying. Their decline in sales volume has been slight, not sharp, and their profits have improved.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, July 2 (AP) -- A South Korean drive on the east-central front was jarred into reverse yesterday by about 3,000 Chinese Communist troops who hurled the Allied infantrymen from two key heights in sudden counter-attacks.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Walter P. Marshall, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, said today that his organization would shortly offer to buy the teletype system that now is part of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $12,000,000,000 organization.
TUNIS, Tunisia, July 1 -- An assassin's bullet today killed Prince Azzedine Bey, heir presumptive to the crown of Tunisia and one of France's friends in this troubled North African protectorate.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 1 -- (AP) -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's speedy Beachcomber, gradually moving up among the topnotch 3-year-olds, scored his fifth straight triumph today in the first division of the Select Handicap before 13,909 at Monmouth Park.

LONDON, July 1 -- Although obviously disturbed by charges that a young bus driver was hanged unjustly for murder three years ago, the House of Commons sidetracked today an attempt to suspend the death penalty for five years.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- A Senate Appropriations subcommittee approved a $5,238,002,664 money bill for the Veterans Administration and three other agencies today after slicing $46,367,000 from the figure passed by an economy-minded House of Representatives.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Champ Carry, president of Pullman, Inc., demonstrated today for Chicago manufacturers a new many-purpose plastic called Kel-F. A product of atomic energy development, it comes in powder form and may be fabricated into thousands of items, he said.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (UP) -- Home runs by Wayne Terwilliger and Ed Fitz Gerald proved decisive tonight as Chuck Stobbs pitched the Senators to a 5-3 victory over the Athletics at Connie Mack Stadium. The box score:

Thirty-six thousand boys and girls roared out of the city yesterday by train and bus for camps in upstate New York, New England and other neighboring areas. Their childish voices added up to a deafening din in Grand Central Terminal and the Port Authority Bus Terminal, where they and their parents, grandparents and other relatives swarmed from early morning on.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Defense Department officials planned today to fight for restoration in the defense budget of funds to carry on the training of instructors in troop information and education.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis Taylor of Beverly Hills, Calif. -- the parents of Elizabeth Taylor, the motion picture actress -- reported yesterday the robbery of $10,000 worth of jewelry from the St. Regis Hotel where they have been stopping since last month.

The rising cost of borrowing money has necessitated a change in the indenture for the proposed $150,000,000 issue of tax-exempt state-guaranteed bonds of the New Jersey Highway Authority to be offered for sale on July 8.

At 8 o'clock yesterday morning 7,500 job seekers made an effort to alter the physical law that no two objects can occupy the same space at the same time. They found it could not be done, and settled almost immedately into a long orderly line.

Rene d'Harnoncourt, director of the Museum of Modern Art, has been elected first vice president of the Association on American Indian Affairs, Inc., 48 East Eighty-sixth Street. He succeeds the late Edouard Lindeman.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Government said today that it had closed its books at the end of the 1953 fiscal year yesterday with the largest deficit in its peacetime history -- $9,389,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Eisenhower said in his press conference today that the White House planned to issue a summary of a survey of the Government's psychological warfare activities prepared by a committee headed by William H. Jackson of Princeton, N. J.

NAIROBI, Kenya, July 1 -- The creation by the United States Mutual Security Agency of a program of credits for African peasants in Uganda and Tanganyika, where the Negro's status is superior to that in Kenya, has created an issue here because Kenya was left out.

Pleased with their designation of a Democrat, Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, as candidate for Mayor, leaders of the Liberal party gave consideration yesterday to designation of a Republican. Newbold Morris, as the party's candidate for President of the City Council.

Wearing down the redoubtable Robin Roberts in the stifling heat of Ebbets Field with a late barrage of extra base hits, the Dodgers last night beat the Phillies, 5 -- 4, in the second straight ten-inning contest between the teams.

Late this season Broadway theatregoers may see a revue, at present untitled, based on the writings of James Thurber, humorist and artist. Cheryl Crawford, who would produce it, already has conferred with Mr. Thurber and is now reading his writings to determine which are best adapted for the transition into sketch form. Who will be engaged to make the adaptation will be decided later.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- The nation's first atomic submarine will be "in the water sometime next summer," according to Gordon Dean, outgoing chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 2 -- After the latest Rhee-Robertson talks in Seoul this forenoon, reports circulated there that Dr. Rhee in his new message had again called insufficient President Eisenhower's offer to work for a security pact for the Republic of Korea along the lines of the United States agreements with Australia, New Zealand and the Philippines.

For more than fifteen years committees of Congress and of the Executive branch have investigated and exposed the shocking conditions under which migratory workers are in many cases compelled to labor. In this entire period the same findings and the same recommendations have followed each other with unfailing regularity and yet nothing has happened.

Sixty thousand red-fezzed Shriners and 40,000 of their wives and friends will gather here next week to make ready for frolic, spectacular parades and the seventy-ninth annual session of the Imperial Council of the Ancient Arabic Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine.

ROME, July 1 -- One of most highly respected newspapers in Italy, the Gazzetta del Popolo of Turin, now in its 106th year of continuous publication under the same masthead and therefore claims to be the dean of the Italian press, changed hands today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 1 -- American churchgoers who attain real inner experience of "the great truths of religion" invariably realize a sharp reduction in whatever race and cultural prejudices they possessed before, the tenth annual Race Relations Institute at Fisk University was told today by Dr. Gordon W. Allport, noted psychologist.

BOSTON, July 1 -- Louis M. Lyons, curator of the Neiman Foundation at Harvard University, asserted today that editors too generally explained away in "equivocal rationalization" a controversy between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post.
Cotton prices closed 2 to 17 points lower on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday with the weakness most pronounced in old July.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill, July 1 -- Gov. William G. Stratton today vetoed "with regret" the loyalty oath bill sponsored by Senator Paul Broyles, Republican of Mount Vernon. The bill would have required state and local government employes to take an oath that they did not belong to the Communist party or other subversive organizations.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Eisenhower asserted today that the uprising in East Germany had spread like wildfire without preconceived plan, but he said the United States planned no physical intervention on the Soviet Union's side of the Iron Curtain.

BRISTOL, England, July 1 -- (Reuters) -- Gloucestershire was all out for 137 shortly after tea in the cricket match against the Australians here today, but the visitors finished the day's play with only 71 for four after losing three wickets in the last half hour.

HENLEY - ON - THAMES, England, July 1 (AP) -- Princeton and Kent School crews were among the sixteen survivors today as competition for the Thames Challenge Cup opened in a day of fitfully changing weather at the Henley Royal Regatta.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by White House rules:

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- The National Oil Marketers Association told Congress today that big oil companies had made "arrangements" to raise fuel oil and gasoline prices despite an oil surplus that should have led to competitive price cuts.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Two major farm organizations today opposed a proposal by Western cotton growers for a change in the method of figuring state cotton acreage allotments if acreage quotas are imposed in 1954 as expected.
A hot and humid Independence Day week-end was predicted by the Weather Bureau as the mercury soared yesterday to a high of 92.2 degrees at 4:30 P. M.

CONCORD, N. H., July 1 (UP) -- Gov. Hugh Gregg tonight appealed to President Eisenhower for help to control widespread forest fires that have laid waste to more than 4,000 acres of New Hampshire timberland.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics received credit for having supplied much of the philosophy underlying the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations in a ceremony today celebrating the thirtieth anniversary of the bureau.

ALBANY, July 1 -- Governor Dewey, speaking just five days after the close of a special session at which all but one of his major proposals sailed smoothly through the Legislature, disclaimed today absolute control of the law-makers' decisions.
BOSTON, July 1 -- The slumping Yankees today lost their ninth straight, 4 -- 0, as Mel Parnell fashioned a superb four-hitter for the Red Sox at Fenway Park.
CINCINNATI, July 1 (AP) -- Eddie Mathews took over the National League home run leadership today as the Braves pounded out a 10-to-2 victory over the Redlegs.

In announcing its confiscatory "monetary reform" a month ago the Communist puppet regime of Czechoslovakia made plain that one of the chief objectives of this drastic step was to eliminate the large-scale absenteeism of workers in factories and mines. This absenteeism, abundant complaints have made clear, has been an effective form of passive resistance which has held back frantic efforts to meet the Moscow-dictated goals in Czechoslovakia's heavy industry.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Sen. Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, criticized "our muddle" in Korea today, telling the Senate "we have retrograded politically and morally in our relations with the brave Korean people, Government and President."

Because of recently intensified fighting on the Korean battle-fronts, a special appeal for whole blood to be flown immediately to Korea was relayed from the military authorities to the public yesterday by T. Morgan Williams, chairman of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
Albert E. Urich has been appointed general manager of purchases for the Gulf Oil Coropration.

A special citation for pedestrian safety during 1952 in New York was received by Mayor Impellitteri at City Hall yesterday. The award for attaining second place among cities of more than a million population in the American Automobile Association's National Pedestrian Contest was presented by William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York, local unit of the association.

VIENNA, July 1 -- The joint executive board for Jewish claims on Austria finished today the presentation of its cast to the Austrian Government for indemnification of Jewish victims of nazism and expects an answer from the Government next week.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Leonard F. Erickson, New York advertising executive, today was named director of the State Department's Voice of America, effective July 27.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- A Government rubber expert told Senators today that he estimated the price of rubber might go up 3 cents a pound when the Government's synthetic rubber plants were sold.

NEWARK, July 1 -- Thomas H. Bloom, 59-year-old ex-convict, who in five years of supervision over the "welfare fund" of the County Detectives Benevolent Association of New Jersey, Inc., promoted it from insolvency to a $600,000 operation, was arrested today after leaving the witness stand at a public hearing of the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council.
The melancholy observation of Hegel that "peoples and government have never learned anything from history * * *" seems to have been justified by recent events in Korea.

Canada is still a land of the "great cold" in the minds of many Americans who rarely get farther than Brooklyn. But a dispatch yesterday from Auburn, N. Y., indicates that some parts of the up- and-coming Dominion suffer from heat in the summer.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- President Eisenhower today declared sections of Colorado, New Mexico, Kansas and Arkansas to be major disaster drought areas and Congress promised prompt action to provide additional aid.
Robert A. Lovett, former Secretary of Defense, has been elected to the board of the Freeport Sulphur Company.

A Kings County grand jury that has been investigating the City Magistrate's Courts in Brooklyn since last August handed up a presentment yesterday calling for the establishment of a downtown Brooklyn night traffic court to save automobile drivers both time and expense for routine violations.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 1 -- Ayatollah Sayed Abolghassem Kashani, fiery Moslem religious leader who had attacked Premier Mohammed Mossadegh as a would-be dictator who ran the risk of being hanged, was turned out of his Speaker's chair in Parliament today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee said today thirty United States citizen employes of the United Nations and its affiliates had refused to swear they never were Communists.

The heavy outbound passenger ship traffic this week, brought about by the approaching peak of the eastbound trans-Atlantic passenger season and the outflow of summer vacationists to the West Indies, will reach a climax tomorrow when thirteen liners carrying more than 7,300 travelers sail within twelve hours. Six thousand passengers already have left this week.

Resources of the Manufacturers Trust Company as of June 30 amounted to $2,700,243,933, compared with $2,691,583,352 at the end of March, according to the bank's quarterly condition statement, issued today. Deposits at the end of the respective reporting periods were $2,474,464,789 and $2,467,462,046.
A durable and laundryproof chemical finish for textiles to make clothing fashioned of treated fabrics resist even the intense heat of a blow torch was announced and demonstrated here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Far-reaching changes in the Social Security Act, including broader insurance coverage, higher benefits and sharp increases in the payroll tax schedules were proposed in identical bills introduced in Congress today by eleven Senators and ten Representatives.

WESTBURY, L. I. July 1 -- Ten of the country's outstanding side-wheelers, led by Hi-Lo's Forbes, the world record holder for a mile pace on a half-mile track, will start tomorrow night in the eighth annual invitation $25,000 National Pacing Derby on the Grand Circuit card at Roosevelt Raceway.

TOKYO, July 1 (Reuters) -- The death roll in Japan's disastrous floods rose to 622 today as medical teams fought to prevent a threatened epidemic of dysentery. Local authorities reported that fifty persons already had been stricken with the intestinal disease and four had died.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, July 1 -- Air Marshal Sir Basil Embry, a recent chief of the Royal Air Force Fighter Command and hero of several sensational escapes from German captivity in World War II, has been chosen by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as Commander in Chief of the Allied Air Forces in Central Europe.

PARIS, July 1 -- By agreeing to discuss both the future of Germany and the future of Indo-China at their Washington conference next week, the Western Big Three foreign ministers are in effect agreeing to take a look at the future shape of non-Soviet Europe.

Your editorial of June 25 deploring President Rhee's unyielding stand against Korean acceptance of the United Nations' proposed truce for Korea is typical of the thinking which has maneuvered the United States into its present unenviable position. Apparently the "realistic" thinkers in the U. N. never expected the Korean regime to defy its camouflaged appeasement of the Russian and Chinese Communists.

Miss Pearl Bloom, a wealthy Manhattan and Brooklyn realty operator of 210 Riverside Drive, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions to a seven-count information charging her with receiving "excessive rents" in violation of the State Rent Control Law.
Because Saturday will be a holiday, news of good week-end buys is being printed today instead of Friday, as is customary.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 1 -- Mary L. Blair, Oyster Bay, L. I., the defending champion and top-seeded entrant, today eliminated two rivals to move into the final bracket of the annual New York State junior girls' tennis singles championship at the County Tennis Club of Westchester.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Eisenhower designated today Louis S. Rothschild of Kansas City, Mo., to be chairman of the Federal Maritime Board.

DETROIT, July 1 -- The Murray Corporation of America announced today that it had purchased the Eljer Company of Ford City, Pa., one of the country's largest manufacturers of plumbing fixtures, in a move to diversify its operations.

Members of the Kings County Medical Society voted Tuesday night at a closed meeting to suggest four changes in the written code of ethics of the New York State Medical Society. Critics said yesterday, after the votes had been counted, that three of the suggestions would set the teaching of medicine back 100 years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 1 -- Robert Rossen's return to the movie business will be made under the banner of United Artists, with which he has signed a contract for two pictures as an independent producer, director and writer.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 1 (UP) -- Fresh teams of doctors inoculated thousands more children with gamma globulin today in Montgomery County's full-scale fight on infantile paralysis.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 24, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

Investment banking syndicates offered to buy $17,233,000 new bonds of the city of Houston, Tex., yesterday at interest costs ranging down to 3.3426 per cent for general obligation bonds and to 3.929 per cent for water revenue obligations.

LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP) -- The political deadlock at the City Hall continued today as Norris Poulson, former Congressman, took over as Mayor and a group of City Councilmen ended a two-day "fishing filibuster'' and returned to their Council seats.

ALL kinds of signs and portents are appearing in the literary sky these days. Never in my memory have so many books made so much news. The reading habits of America are being tested and shaken. In the long run this may be good for us all. Meantime, a look at the lit'ry landscape of 1953 at the mid-year mark shows it is decidedly full of dynamic elements.
One fireman died and fifteen others were injured last night while fighting a five-alarm blaze that damaged twelve stores in an East Bronx shopping center.
Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges in continued light volume. Activity on most items eased but potatoes registered the heaviest trading since May 21.

It was insufferably hot at the Polo Grounds yesterday, which is probably the only plausible excuse for the inept performance the Giants put on display before 4,429 fans, as they blew another ball game to the tail-end Pirates.

Harry S. Truman got on television by accident yesterday. It happened in the course of his early morning "constitutional." The former President left the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where he has been staying since Saturday, at 7 A. M. as usual.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- National Airlines said today that what it called the "illegal acquisition of control of Colonial Airlines by Eastern Air Lines" should be referred to the Justice Department for immediate prosecution.

PARIS, July 1 -- Dr. Luther H. Evans, Librarian of Congress, was elected today to a six-year term as Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. The vote was 39 to 17, with much of the opposition apparently based on a fear of United States political and intellectual domination. Dr. Evans succeeds Jaime Torres Bodget of Mexico who resigned last November

BUENOS AIRES, July 1 -- A general amnesty that would free hundreds of Argentine political prisoners held on unspecified charges appeared to be in the making today as the Peronista press devoted columns to an appeal made by leaders of the conservative National Democratic party.

Commercial speeds of about 400 miles an hour in the air are no longer extraordinary. Engines for passenger planes that develop more than 5,000 horsepower each are now available. Residents of New York City have noted the increase in horsepower. The roar often makes conversation impossible for a minute or two in Manhattan apartments and backyard gardens.

The Bankers Trust Company is planning a series of rate increases on its consumer installment loans. Reflecting the continuing upward trend in interest levels, the scheduled rises will lift the bank's maximum rate on small personal loans to 5 per cent, deducted in advance.

BONN, Germany, July 1 -- Social Democratic party leaders maneuvered Chancellor Konrad Adenauer into a position today on the question of Germany's reunification that may have serious repercussions on the outcome of the forthcoming general elections and United States policy on Germany.

A State Supreme Court award of $291,173 made to 415 custodians of public schools used as polling places for their services on registration, primary and election days in 1943-48 was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division.

WASHINGTON, July 1(AP) -- Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida, accused Hawaii officials today of juggling their estimates of the racial population of the islands to meet objections raised to statehood for Hawaii.

A fish fry, prepared either indoors or out, is an attractive possibility for the Fourth of July weekend. Midwesterners and Southerners need no introduction to this, their favorite kind of piscatorial feasting. We might learn from them -- and from others -- how to prepare this economical food in a style befitting the holiday.

LONDON, July 1 -- The stock markets here struck a more confident note today although business remained small except for trading in British funds. Government securities gained up to five-sixteenths of 1 per cent on the day.

Following Tuesday's announcement that the State Department would issue visas to the Russian chess players for a match here on July 15, Harold M. Phillips, president of the United States Chess Federation, yesterday sent the list of the American players to Folke Rogard of Stockholm, president of the International Chess Federation.
DETROIT, July 1 -- Dr. Clarence B. Hilberry, acting president of Wayne University, was confirmed in the presidency by a 6-to-1 vote of the Detroit Board of Education today.

Ten men have been enabled to carry on advanced studies at the Guggenheim Jet Propulsion Center at Princeton University through fellowships granted yesterday by the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- The Department of Defense today reported a new total of 137,512 United States battle casualties in Korea, an increase of 650 over last week's report.

The proposed Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution has a better chance of winning in the Eighty-third Congress than it has ever had in the thirty years it has been pending, leaders of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Inc., declared yesterday.

LONDON, July 1 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright of Arkansas, author of the Fulbright Fellowship Law financing foreign study by United States students, received the honorary degree of Doctor of Civil Law at Oxford University today.

Four paintings recently purchased for the collection of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center brought to light a story, in classic vein, of a struggling, self-taught artist, making headway against strong odds.

It is a good idea for the Foreign Ministers of the Big Three to meet in Washington next week, now that the Bermuda conference of the heads of state has had to be postponed. It is obvious that there cannot be too many contacts between the United States, Britain and France in these critical days and, anyway, there was a feeling that the original conference was not going to be well enough prepared.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Bob Satterfield, a light heavyweight, unleashed a hard right to the chin to knock out the fourth-ranking heavyweight, Bob Baker, in 2 minutes, 32 seconds of the first round of their scheduled ten-rounder at Chicago Stadium tonight.

Two new films open at first run theatres today. At the Mayfair will be an evening opening of Paramount's "Scared Stiff," a mystery comedy starring Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis. Lizabeth Scott and Carmen Miranda have the feminine leading roles.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Senate passed without a record vote today the $5,318,732,500 foreign aid authorization bill and sent the measure to conference with the House of Representatives for adjustment of differences.

Recently there were a couple of damp days. After a long, wet spring, these were somewhat unfortunate, and they thoroughly outraged such individuals as the proprietors of beach resorts. Indeed, they were disturbing to all those whose business or pleasure took them outdoors, for a dismal rain in June is far worse than a severe ice storm in December.

An account of the expedition to Arnhem Land carried out in 1948 under the auspices of the National Geographic Society, the Commonwealth of Australia and the Smithsonian Institution will be published Aug. 14 by Frederick A. Praeger. It will be titled "Adam in Ochre."

Fat men soon will enter the spotlight. Rexall Drug Stores all over the country yesterday introduced the Delafield reducing plan for men. Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, the agency master-minding the promotion, breathlessly dubs it "the first systematic slimming-down plan for overweight men ever to reach the consumer market."

The pace of stock trading, with 910,000 shares dealt in, was still too slow yesterday to permit most brokerage firms to break even. But the stock market technicians were cheered by the fact that it was an improvement over recent sessions when the tendency of prices was easier.

HONG KONG, July 1 -- The Peiping People's Daily, primary organ of the Chinese Communist party, has criticized party workers in Honan and Chekiang Provinces for having engaged in "reckless expansion'' of state farms in the face of opposition by private land-holding peasants.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 1 -- Vassar College's gates were opened today to 225 adults and children who, through July 29, will participate in the twenty-eighth annual Summer Institute for Family and Community Living.
Dr. Alfred P. Ingegno, president of the Medical Society of the County of Kings, said last night that the society was against "fee-splitting," which he called both unethical and unlawful.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program announced yesterday a goal of 15,000 pints of blood for July. T. Morgan Williams, chairman of the program, said the blood collected would be used to fill whole blood requests from Korea, to help meet local needs and to provide a sufficient surplus for processing into gamma globulin for use by health officials in fighting polio.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- A House of Representatives committee learned today that 107 State Department employes had been discharged this year as a result of investigations concerning homosexuality or questionable security.
LIBERTY, N. Y., July 2 -- The two biggest resort hotels in the Catskills were hit by strikes today as they prepared for a capacity influx of vacationing guests over the Fourth of July week-end.
C. H. Buckley has been appointed product sales manager for beer and carbonated beverage containers of Continental Can Company.
A special naturalization bill, signed last Tuesday by President Eisenhower, saved George Pohjola, a Finnish seaman who served in the United States Army, from being deported yesterday.

The troopship General Sturgis brought 1,618 soldiers to Staten Island yesterday from Korea, most of them silent about either war or peace but vociferous on the subjects of heat (too much) and home (at last).

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Government today offered surplus stocks of its livestock feed to drought stricken Southwestern farmers at cut rate prices. The aim is to halt distress sales and encourage the holding of animals on farms and ranches.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 2 -- Penetrating a guard maintained over the whole of the Great Northern railroad system, terrorists attempted early today to blow up a bridge on the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic:
The second and third-seeded players followed the No. 1 favorite out of the women's Eastern clay court tennis championships yesterday at the Bayside Tennis and Racquets Club in Queens.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- One of Hawaii's Territorial Senators testified today that the economic life of Hawaii was Communist dominated.

A strike that had made 1,000 carpenters idle and was scheduled to take 4,000 more from their jobs on Monday was settled yesterday on the basis of an immediate wage increase of 15 cents an hour, with an additional 10 cents to be paid next Jan. 1.

President Eisenhower's request for stand-by authority to send surplus food abroad when famine or some other emergency calls for it has met with some opposition in Congress. In some quarters the attitude seems to be that though hunger is important the balance of powers between Congress and the White House is more important still.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Representative Adam C. Powell Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, said today President Eisenhower would act within a few days to ban racial discrimination in Government contract work.
Commissioner Donald McMillam was named National Commander of the Salvation Army yesterday by Gen. Albert Orsborn, international head of the organization.

The mass migration of boys and girls to summer camps dwindled yesterday with only 11,000 departing from Grand Central Terminal, 1,500 from the Port Authority Bus Terminal and none from Pennsylvania Station.

A well-rested Carl Erskine held the Phillies to seven scattered hits yesterday while Brooklyn was pounding Karl Drews and two successors for eight blows good for twenty bases. The result was an 8-0 triumph.

The New York Stock Exchange is a relatively late starter in advertising. But some of the companies whose stock is traded at the Exchange have been big advertisers for many years. The current issue of the Stock Exchange's monthly bulletin, The Exchange, shows that seventeen of the twenty largest national advertisers this year are listed on the Big Board.

The Forty-second Street-Mid-Manhattan Association held its annual meeting yesterday at the Commodore Hotel and elected as president E. Leslie Sefton, president and general manager of the hotel. Mr. Sefton succeeds William J. Wallis, who had been president of the business group five years.

The soaring temperature almost got the best of Wall Street yesterday. The stock market opened firm and active. But after an hour or so of quickened trading during which rail issues tacked on gains of a point or more, the list wilted. By the close, for every ten issues finishing higher, five were lower and six were unchanged.
Leading a list of safety measures for outdoor activities, detailed in a "Vacation Safety" bulletin of the National Safety Council, are pointers for families doing gardening or improving yard areas.

The Metropolitan Opera, which began remodeling its parquet floor on April 20, provided a "work-in-progress" showing of the job yesterday. The floor will hold 116 more seats than formerly when the new season opens on Nov. 16. Nearly everything about it is new, but the old boards have been salvaged-and are being re-used to prevent squeaks.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- An agreement paving the way for joint action in wage negotiations and organizing campaigns by the nation's two leading meat packing unions was announced today by the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen, A. F. L., and the United Packinghouse Workers of America, C. I. O.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the Eisenhower Administration moved today to aid Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in the forthcoming West German elections and to help keep aflame East Germany's spirit of revolt against the Soviet Union.

BERLIN, July 2 (AP) -- The voice of East Germany's ailing 77-year-old president, Wilhelm Pieck, sounded from the obscurity of a Soviet rest home tonight to try to rally his rebellious countrymen for communism.

CLEVELAND, July 2 -- Responding to an appeal by Dr. Francis E. Townsend for funds to finance a national pension campaign, 1,500 delegates to the Townsend Club National Convention contributed an estimated $29,000 at the closing session today.

ST. LOUIS, July 2 -- Street cars and buses began rolling here again today as operators and maintenance men returned to work, ending a wildcat strike that had tied up public transportation since midnight Tuesday.
The semi-annual report of the National City Bank of New York disclosed yesterday a decline in major items of its balance sheet as of June 30 from the figures reported three months and a year ago.
Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, made the following statement yesterday in accepting the Liberal party's nomination for Mayor:

The city's newest debutantes -- two jaguars born in Central Park Zoo May 7 -- were formally presented to zoo society and the general public at 9:30 A. M. yesterday. By way of showing their appreciation of this happy event, they stood on their hind legs and growled out an impromptu, and unrhythmical, jungle duet.

A larger volume of new money financing was provided by the capital markets in the first six months of this year than in any half-year period since the war, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York notes in its monthly Review, issued yesterday.

The nation is the poorer because it has lost the services, through retirement, of two eminent jurists, Chief Judge Thomas Walter Swan and Judge Augustus N. Hand of the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit. Both men were appointed to this court in 1927 by the late President Coolidge, and both have had outstanding careers in American jurisprudence.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today and recommended to the Senate for ratification -- a treaty process requiring a two-thirds vote -- four agreements on German debts long owed to the United States Government and to United States citizens.
Six proposals were endorsed by stockholders of El Paso Natural Gas Company at a special meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del., permitting a sharp increase in the company's authorized securities.

PARIS, July 2 -- Mrs. Hedwig Rosner of Israel, aunt of Robert and Gerald Finaly, arrived by air today and went to the private estate at St. Leonard, near Paris, where the boys have been staying since their return from Spain a week ago.

Financial representatives of West Germany and the United States have just completed the negotiation of a tax treaty, it was disclosed yesterday by Wolfgang F. Meersmann, leader of the German group. The chief immediate effect is expected to be stimulation of American private investment in West Germany.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 2 -- This country's highest leaders expect that the satellite countries, like the Soviet Union, will seek to normalize diplomatic relations with the West, including Yugoslavia, despite continued reports of serious disturbances on the borders of Yugoslavia allegedly perpetrated by her neighbors.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 2 -- A stranger to New York racing this season, Direct Rhythm, the fast moving 5-year-old from the stable of W. G. Reynolds of Louisville, Ky., won the $25,000 National Pacing Derby at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

LONDON, July 2 (Reuters) -- The sterling area's gold and dollar reserves increased by $46,000,000 during June, Britain's treasury announced today. This increase brought the reserves to $2,367,000,000 on June 30, their highest level since early in 1952 but still far below the mid-1951 peak of $3,867,000,000.

Guaranty Trust Company of New York registered a moderate decline in deposits, loan volume and total resources during the quarterly period ended on June 30, according to the bank's condition statement issued today.
KATMANDU, Nepal, June 20 (Reuters) -- The story of our final ascent really begins on the morning of May 28 after a rough night on the south col (pass).

LITCHFIELD, Conn., June 30 -- This town is proud of its historic past, its lovely setting of hills and its fine old elm-shaded houses. It has also long been the admiration of visitors who have come from far and wade to see among other surviving witnesses of an earlier day, magnificently broad North and South Streets, bright jewels in Litchfield's crown.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The House unanimously passed and sent to the Senate intact today the Defense Appropriation Bill backed by President Eisenhower. It carries a total of new funds amounting to $34,434,140,500 to support the Army, the Navy, the Air Force, the Marine Corps and the office of the Secretary of Defense for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1954. The roll call was 386 to 0.
CINCINNATI, July 2 (AP) -- Clifton Mayne, University of California sophomore, today led the way into the semi-finals of the fifty-fourth annual Tri-State tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Rear Admiral Homer N. Wallin, Chief of the Navy's Bureau of Ships, has notified naval shipyard personnel that "a further reduction in employment levels of the naval shipyards will be necessary during the coming months." He added, however, that no drastic cuts were contemplated.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 2 (AP) -- Three United States stars -- Gene Sarazen, Johnny Bulla and Ed Oliver -- withdrew today from the British open golf championship, which begins here Monday. An official of the Royal and Ancient, golf's ruling body in Britain, said official notification was received that this American trio would not be in the field.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- Economy-minded members of the House of Representatives questioned today whether Army officers should spend their time decorating cocktail lounges, and whether the Navy needed to appoint a three-officer board every time a dog or cat died at sea.

Jersey and corduroy are taking the fashion spotlight as the newest of the old fabrics for fall. No longer stepchildren of the sports department, these two Cinderellas offer some of the most interesting innovations in the fabrics field.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- Three homers marked the Cubs' 4-2 victory today over the White Sox at Wrigley Field in the fourth mid-season boys' baseball benefit game.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- On the ground that seventy incriminating documents had been seized illegally by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, the Federal Court of Appeals reversed today the conviction of Charles E. Nelson, backer of a Washington numbers syndicate, and ten co-defendants and granted them a new trial.

The Ford Motor Company presented yesterday a check of $25,000 to the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York at a special ceremony at the appeal's headquarters. 200 West Fifty-eighth Street. The check was the company's contribution to the appeal's 1953 drive.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 2 (AP) -- United States District Judge W. R. Wallace ruled today that the Hughes Tool Company of Houston was a monopoly operating in violation of both the Sherman and Clayton Anti-Trust Acts.
Thomas Maher, 45 years old, of 2437 McClay Avenue, the Bronx, is a pigeon fancier with perseverance.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Senator McCarthy said Dr. Wilkerson was called before the subcommittee "to show another typical author whose works under no circumstances" should be used in United States information libraries abroad.

All indications point to the conclusion that the makers of Soviet foreign policy are now holding a meeting of the first importance.
