The Soviet Ambassadors to Washington, London and Paris have been recalled home this week, along with, apparently, some of the highest ranking occupation officials in East Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said today that during May consumer credit increased $544,000,000 to $26,716,000,000. This was an increase of $5,011,000,000 or nearly 20 per cent in one year.

In the face of the huge federal deficit it is not easy to argue for restoration of cuts made by an economy-minded Congress, but the threatened closing of the Armed Forces Information School at Fort Slocum, N. Y., is one of those things that could save a relatively few dollars and yet in the long run prove immeasurably expensive to the nation.

Once upon a time there lived, far away in Denmark, a fuzzy little fowl whose name was Ugly Duckling. And now a statue to the Duckling, in a group including Hans Christian Andersen, has been approved for Central Park.

PARIS, July 2 -- In a note to be delivered tomorrow to the three states of Indo-China, the French Government will propose simultaneous but separate negotiations with them to revise the existing agreements between the states and France in order to broaden their independence.

The City Center of Music and Drama has received a grant of $200,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation to be applied toward expenses of creating new productions in opera and ballet, it was announced yesterday by Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of directors.

The financial district predicted yesterday a successful outcome for the Treasury's offering of short-term tax anticipation certificates. Under present money market conditions, newly relaxed by the unfreezing of more than $1,000,000,000 of bank reserve balances, the new issue of tax certificates will be subscribed for heavily by the commercial banks, it was said.

Thousands of New Yorkers started their Fourth of July weekend yesterday afternoon, rushing forth early from the city's heat by car, bus, train, ship and plane, in hopes of finding cooling relief at beach, lake, country and mountain resorts.

PARIS, July 2 -- Delegates to the special general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization sought a compromise tonight on the application of the United States loyalty investigation to UNESCO's personnel.

WESTFIELD, N. J., July 2 -- An owl that has forsaken the nocturnal habits of its ancestors by remaining wide awake by day and sleeping at night has become a pet at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Lester B. Woolfenden of 478 St. Marks Avenue.

STANTON, Del., July 2 (AP) -- Running on his own after Trainer Frank Bonsal had scratched Laran, Samuel A. Peck's Potpourri needed no help in breezing home a six-length winner of the featured Miss Request Purse at Delaware Park today.

Neither heat, humidity, insects nor other assorted "bugs" stayed the Nassau County Clearing House Association's new check clearing organization from completing its first night of operations at 6 A. M. yesterday. The new overnight check collection procedure in which all forty of Nassau County's commercial banks are participating, is described as unique for the nation.
Futures closed 1 point higher to 6 points lower than on Wednesday on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, with the volume of business rather small.
NEW DELHI, India, July 2 -- Serious political differences within Jammu and Kashmir State, whose allegiance is disputed between India and Pakistan, are plaguing New Delhi.

H. Brand's comment published June 26 on your correspondent's report from Berlin of June 19 raises a question of vital importance in our world-wide fight against communism, the question of "spontaneous" or "organized" resistance.

GENEVA, July 2 -- United Nations officials and Western diplomatic circles here are trying to evaluate the unusual events connected with the Soviet Union's participation in a meeting of European, timber experts that ended here yesterday.

The Fourth of July is the time not only for picnics, parades and fireworks, but also for blueberry pie. For it is around the first of this month that New Jersey starts shipping the sweet, juicy fruit here in volume.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 2 (AP) -- Princeton's 150-pound eight, with a record-breaking performance, and the oarsmen from the Kent School of Connecticut today rowed into the quarterfinals of the Thames Challenge Cup competition on the Thames.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- Three law firms have asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve a $3,409,000 fee for their work in the liquidation of the holding company system of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, it was disclosed today.

Two second-generation representatives of well-known Broadway names have joined forces as a new production team. David Aldrich, son of Richard Aldrich, the producer, and Anna Wiman, daughter of the late Dwight Wiman, who has taken over his theatrical enterprises, plan to present "Sodom, Tennessee" here in November.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 2 (UP) -- Olavi Rinteepaa of Finland set a world record of 8:44.4 for thhe 3,000-meter steeplechase in an international track and field meet at Olympic Stadium today, clipping the mark of 8:45.3 set by Horace Ashenfelter of the United States in the Olympics last summer.

About 450,000 Americans will visit Europe this year, an increase of more than 10 per cent over last year when 400,000 travelers from this country crossed the Atlantic, it was predicted yesterday by Ralph T. Reed, president of the American Express Company.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Treasury today set an annual interest rate of 2 1/2 per cent on the $5,500,000,000 or so of tax-anticipation certificates it will offer in the market on Monday. The certificates, dated July 15, with maturity next March 22, are to provide funds on which the Government will operate through the first quarter of the 1954 fiscal year, which began on Wednesday.

The Federal Reserve Board's reduction of bank reserve requirements should not be interpreted as any change in basic credit control policy, but as evidencing the unwillingness of the central bank to permit interest rates to jump suddenly to levels that might endanger the normal growth of the economy.

Directors of the White Motor Company yesterday approved the acquisition of the Autocar Company, producer of heavy duty trucks, in exchange for preferred stock of White Motor to be created for the purpose. Shareholders of both companies are scheduled to vote on the proopsal at special meetings to be called for the purpose.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., July 2 -- Reeling off a second-round 66 to tie the course mark, Johnny Palmer of Badin, N. C., led the qualifiers in the Professional Golfers Association championship at the Birmingham Country Club with a score of 134 today. The total equaled the thirty-six-hole qualifying record for the tourney.

The ten-year contest between the Celanese Corporation of America and the Federal Trade Commission on what the company's textile product should be called is close to an end, it was learned yesterday. James A. Purcell, commission hearing examiner, has dismissed without prejudice the complaint originally instituted on March 24, 1943.

The American Enka Corporation, rayon yarn manufacturer, which recently entered the nylon field, had a net income of $3,170,907 in the twenty-four weeks ended on June 14, an increase of 27 per cent from the $2,491,619 in the corresponding period last year, J. E. Bassill, president, reported yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has signed Fredric March for "Executive Suite." The studio air-mailed a copy of the screen play to an emissary in Europe, who was instructed to track down the vacationing Mr. March and present the script to him, plus financial terms of the employment offer.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Wheat futures showed a strong trend today while there was a reactionary market for coarse grains. Strength in wheat was mostly on local buying, traders being influenced by the lack of any heavy country offerings of red winter wheat and by the fact that harvesting in the Southwest was nearly over with no evidence of any special storage difficulties.

NEW CITY, N. Y., July 2 -- Designations for District Attorney filed here today by both major parties indicated that Rockland County Democrats, in choosing Henry V. Stebbins of Tappan, were planning an all-out campaign to win a major county office, a feat accomplished only six times in the last thirty-three years.

KANSAS CITY, July 2 (AP) -- Edward Chevlin, a veteran labor leader, told a Congressional subcommittee today that he had been beaten, intimidated and threatened by officials of a local of the Teamsters Union, A. F. L.

THE balloting will end tonight for the starting line-ups for the All-Star game at Cincinnati on July 14. Strange and perplexing are those line-ups likely to be. The fans select them by popular vote and yet the fans can't be blamed for certain anomalies that are likely to appear. It may sound ridiculous, but there is a strong chance that Jackie Robinson won't make the National League starting team.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 2 -- Pakistan launched today a long-range, comprehensive agrarian reform program. It is designed to bring 400,000 acres under cultivation and increase the yield on the 57,000,000 acres that now bring less than the minimum requirement for the country's 76,000,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration announced today that it was combining three of its main divisions under one new head, thus taking its first big step in a reorganization program.

MIAMI BEACH, July 2 -- To meet the urgent school needs of today, the Federal Government should contribute 10 per cent of the school operating expenses, or a minimum of $600,000,000 annually, key educators declared today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Senate tonight passed a year's extension of the nineteen-year-old reciprocal trade agreements law that had been requested by President Eisenhower. Passage was by voice vote. The bill now goes to a Senate-House of Representatives conference to iron out differences between the Senate version and the House bill.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The three Democratic members of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations today denounced as "a shocking and unwarranted attack against the American clergy" a magazine article by J. B. Matthews, the subcommittee's new executive director.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 2 (AP) -- Cedar Farm's Buff, who had won only one race in nine previous starts this year, scored an impressive victory at Monmouth Park today over juveniles eligible for stakes races.
PUSAN, Korea, July 2 (AP) -- About 400 anti-Communist North Korean war prisoners recently released from United Nations stockade reported to the South Korean Army replacement center near Pusan today.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Dr. Sorenson declared he had not considered Dr. Fisher qualified to be his deputy, but he had tried to make use of him.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Eisenhower's agricultural advisory committee expects to make before the end of the year recommendations on one of the most explosive political issues facing the Republican Administration -- Federal farm-price supports.

ALBANY, July 2 -- Governor Dewey signed into law today six measures passed by the special session of the Legislature last week in an effort to tighten enforcement of the criminal law and rid the state and local governments of any corrupt officials.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has subpoenaed the books and records of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, and several metropolitan wholesale newspaper distributors, it was learned last night.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 2 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge won the low gross honors with a 79 and Mrs. Uzal H. McCarter of Upper Montclair captured the low net prize today in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class A one-day medal play at the Essex County Country Club.

Two mules lured children off the streets of Brooklyn yesterday and into Owl's Head Park to listen to stories. When the youngsters ran alongside the animals, their immediate hope was to get a ride in the cart the mules were drawing. They seemed satisfied, however, to get instead brief session with books at the foot of a shady elm.

BONN, Germany, July 2 -- The Bundestag blocked today ratification of the London Debt Agreement and tied the hands of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in any negotiations with France on the future status of the Saar.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2 -- The United Nations Technical Assistance Administration reported today it would need $37,700,000 during the year to carry on existing projects and start others that have been found sound. Only 75 per cent of this amount is available, it said in its 483-page annual report, which is supplemented for the first time with special maps and charts depiciting the expansion of the program.

Volume on the New York commodity exchanges continued light yesterday, but cocoa had its greatest activity since June 2. Prices ended irregular with cocoa, sugar, cottonseed oil, wool, hides and copper mixed. Coffee, potatoes and rubber closed higher, and soybean oil, lead, tin and zinc were lower.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- A foreign aid official said today one of the reasons he had taken Government-paid trips to his home town in Nebraska was to recruit "technicians for Burma."

New light on conflicts between Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and other leaders of the Soviet Government over German policy has been made public in a book written by seven former high officials of the Soviet Government in Germany, all of them now refugees, which has just been published by the Research Program on the U.S.S.R., a subsidiary of the Ford Foundation.
SAIGON, July 2 (AP) -- The repatriated Chinese included thirty-one generals and 1,300 officers.

TWENTY-ONE years ago New York University's School of Education started putting out a special pocket guidebook, "Around New York," for summer students from all over the United States and from some forty foreign countries.
For a little while yesterday visitors to the Metropolitan Museum of Art at Fifth Avenue and Eighty-second Street saw what they might have thought to be four of the art exhibits walking about outside.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The choice of books that should be made available to readers necessarily devolves on the individuals entrusted with that duty. In tax-supported, general-purpose public libraries this is the task of the official in charge, aided by such advisers as he may choose.

People who think that the new Soviet regime is basically changing its tune as well as those who feel that Mao Tse-tung, Chinese Communist leader, is an agrarian reformer who may become another Marshal Tito are indulging in "wishful thinking," according to Dr. K. C. Wu, Minister Without Portfolio in the Nationalist Chinese Government and former Governor of Formosa.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Even books on plumbing seem to have run afoul of the State Department's rules about writings suitable for its overseas libraries.

An account of how the German secret service outwitted the Dutch and British Intelligence for nearly two years will be issued by the British Book Centre on July 20 under the title "London Calling North Pole." The author is H. J. Giskes, former chief of German Military Counter-Espionage in Holland, Belgium and northern France.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 2 -- The employes' trust of Arthur D. Little, Inc., one of the largest industrial research organizations in the world, acquired controlling interest in the company today through the purchase of common stock for $1,300,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 2 (AP) -- To beat the heat of burning fuel, jet engine parts will soon be coated like an ordinary kitchen stove with a material similar to porcelain, a research engineer said today.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 2 (AP) -- Milt Campbell, a 19-year-old local boy, and Bob Richards, California's pole-vaulting parson, head a field of about twenty candidates tomorrow and Saturday in the national Amateur Athletic Union decathlon championship, toughest event of all in track and field.

It is more than six years since former Secretary of State Marshall, speaking at the Harvard commencement, called for an international war against "hunger, poverty, desolation and chaos." The Marshall Plan as such has passed into history. The kind of aid that we give or lend to our friends has largely changed from economic to military.

NAIROBI, Kenya, July 2 -- Mau Mau chiefs now make their followers take a new form of oath and have introduced a black sorcery ritual of obscene character with the evident purpose of making it impossible for them to return to normal life in the Kikuyu tribe.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 2 -- The death of a 24-year-old Indiana physician in a high-altitude testing pressure chamber at the Randolph Air Force base School of Aviation Medicine was declared "one in a million" by a base spokesman today.

TRENTON, July 2 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll signed today a measure extending the absentee voting privilege to civilians in New Jersey for the first time in twenty-eight years. The prerogative has been confined to military personnel since 1925.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 -- In a devastating display of outright hitting, top-seeded Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., routed Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, 6 - 1, 6 -- 1, in thirty-two minutes today to gain the women's final of the All-England lawn tennis championships.
Williamsburg, an Irish-bred owned by Lawrence R. Troiano, made a game closing rally to win the $11,300 Forget Hurdle Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

BOSTON, July 2 -- Gov. Hugh Gregg of New Hampshire said today he had received word from President Eisenhower that the Federal Civil Defense Administration had been instructed to allot $50,000 to help in combating forest fires in the state. Governor Gregg, who had asked for $100,000, said that the message indicated that further funds might be forthcoming.

The story contained in your edition of June 26, on the speech of Marshal Juin on Morocco, contains two misstatements of fact. In view of the great respect which I hold for the reportorial standards of THE NEW YORK TIMES I believe they should be corrected for the purpose of avoiding confusion on the subject.
Maj. Gen Hugh J. Casey, chairman of the New York City Transit Authority, sought yesterday to discourage speculation that the new transit fare would be 12 1/2 or 13 cents.

MONTAUK, L. I., July 2 -- A long line of charter boats lolling in their slips, and the cheerless faces of a score of skippers, gave mute testimony that the week-day doldrums were pressing an air of lassitude on the Montauk docks.

TOKYO, Friday, July 3 -- Walter S. Robertson, United States Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, held his seventh meeting today with President Syngman Rhee. After a conference of an hour, it was announced that the negotiations would continue in an effort to persuade the South Korean leader to withdraw his opposition to an armistice in the three-year-old war.
BONN, Germany, July 2 -- The Bundestag (lower house of Parliament) tonight enacted a law indemnifying victims of Nazi persecution and their heirs living in Germany and abroad.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India has renewed his suggestion that the United Nations General Assembly reconvene soon to take up the Korean question. Mr. Nehru's message was contained in a cablegram sent yesterday to Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs and President of the General Assembly.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 2 -- The Chinese Nationalist Government announced this afternoon the completion of the repatriation of about 29,000 interned Nationalist soldiers and their dependents from Indo-China. The returned soldiers, who number more than 20,000, are expected to be incorporated in the Nationalist army.
Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, accepted yesterday the Liberal party nomination for Mayor and said he was in the contest to stay, no matter who the other candidates for Mayor would be.
DETROIT, July 2 (UP) -- The Indians dropped to within two percentage points of third place today when they lost to the Tigers, 4 -- 2, at Briggs Stadium.

BOSTON, July 2 -- Forced into overtime by George Kell's ninth-inning homer, the Yankees pounced on Sid Hudson for two runs in the tenth to score a thrilling 5-3 victory over the Red Sox today. The long, long losing trail was relegated to the past and, after nine straight defeats, all was well with the champions.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Federal Government's $64,000,000 Clinical Center, described as a revolutionary stride in medical research, was dedicated today. The fourteen-story building includes a 500-bed hospital section and 1,100 scientific laboratories.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 2 -- Chinese nese Nationalist troops interned in
With Leonard Bernstein serving as both conductor and piano soloist, the Stadium Symphony Orchestra played an all-Mozart concert at Lewisohn Stadium last night.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Department store sales in the week ended June 27 were 3 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. The Federal Reserve Board reported this in making public the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, July 3 (AP) -- Bitter see-saw fighting raged again today on the east-central Korean front as South Korean infantrymen, striking in three prongs, drove dug-in Communists off "Lookout Mountain."
TOKYO, Friday, July 3 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,664, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

ORADELL, N. J., July 2 -- Mrs. A. J. Bryant of Upper Monclair shot a 38, 39 -- 77 today for a one-stroke victory in a Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament at the Hackensack Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of the board of Trans World Airlines, asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to extend T. W. A.'s route 1,000 miles from Shanghai to Tokyo.

Sydney Paley of Jersey City, who is on three years' probation in this country as the result of a conviction by a United States Consular Court at Tangier, Morocco, on charges of conspiracy and complicity in armed robbery on the high seas, arrived here yesterday aboard the American Export liner Constitution to seek vindication from the State Department in Washington.
Thanks are due to THE NEW YORK TIMES for two splendid editorials -- "T. V. A. vs. Socialism" appearing June 19, and "America: Edited and Revised" appearing June 23.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- The House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities today produced evidence that it said "completely corroborates" testimony that Mrs. Byron G. Darling, wife of a former Ohio State University professor, was once a Communist.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, told the Senate today the Internal Revenue Bureau had finally found a missing report on "notorious Pittsburgh racketeers and their alleged payoffs to certain public officials."

LONDON, July 2 -- The controversy in Great Britain over commercial television stemming in part from reports of the practices of American video networks, led the Conservative Government today to postpone temporarily a showdown on the introduction in this country of sponsored TV.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Six Pacific Coast Congressmen urged Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson today to see that lumber, plywood and aluminum are considered along with steel as possible materials for construction of wheat storage bins.

ALBANY, July 2 (AP) -- Six New York City school teachers, suspended or dismissed for refusing to answer questions as to membership in the Communist party, lost their appeal to the Appellate Division today. The Appellate Court unanimously affirmed a decision last April by Justice Donald S. Taylor of the State Supreme Court.

Major steamship operators in the Port of New York estimated their pilferage losses so low in the course of the State Crime Commission's investigation that the commission rejected the data as valueless, it became known yesterday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 2 (AP) -- King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, who has threatened the French with warfare unless Cambodia gets its independence, asked his people today to accept sacrifices so that the little nation could build up its army.
MILWAUKEE, July 2 (UP) -- Bud Podbielan gave up five hits as he hurled the Redlegs to a 3-to-1 victory over the Braves tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a three-year extension of the international wheat agreement today.

PARIS, July 2 -- The United States and France now have agreed after twenty-two months of discussions on the construction of a strategic fuel pipeline to run from the small port of Bonges, near St. Nazaire, on the Atlantic coast across France to La Ferte Alais near Paris and then to the area of Metz at the rear of the United States armed forces guarding West Germany.

LONDON, July 2 -- Prices continued to rise slowly in nearly all sections of the stock markets today. The further improvement during June in gold and dollar reserves became known too late to have any effect on prices.
CHICAGO, July 2 (UP) -- Pickets were set up in key Great Lakes ports today by striking maritime union sailors who demanded their wages match the level paid salt water seamen.

Snow removal problems that seemed so dreary last winter are more pleasant to think about on these humid summer days. So the property owners of land at the top of Hillcrest Drive in Coshocton, Ohio, are installing an automatic "electric eye" unit to start their road's snow-melting system operating as soon as the first snow flies.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 2 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley carded 38, 38 -- 76, and then won a draw from Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century, also 38, 38 -- 76, to take the gross prize in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Garden City Country Club today.

AT its best the writing of fiction is a great art, the finest method yet discovered by man with which to record and interpret the adventure of living. At its second best it is a skilled performance by a professional entertainer. But in this imperfect world the writing of fiction is also an occupation and a habit. Novelists, like the rest of us, must eat.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 2 -- Gov. George N. Craig of Indiana today approved the site for the Western section of the Indiana Turnpike. When completed, the turnpike will provide a direct superhighway link between Chicago and the Eastern seaboard connecting with the Ohio, Pennsylvania and New Jersey turnpikes.

Tracy S. Voorhees, a member of the Long Island Transit Authority, told Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday that if the Long Island Rail Road's plan to settle its tax claims with the city was approved, the bankrupt line's rehabilitation program would have to be abandoned.

CLEVELAND, July 2 (AP) -- The Rudolph Deutsch Company sold the twenty-five carat Moon of Baroda diamond today for around $100,000 to Meyer Rosenbaum, a Detroit jeweler. The company did not make public the specific price but did value the pear-shared gem at $100,000.

BOSTON, July 2 -- The American Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., adopted today a report by a human rights subcommittee calling on local units of the international organization to press for fair-employment hiring clauses in their contracts with publishers.

BAYONNE, N. J., July 2 -- The ship's radio operator who was widely hailed as a here for sticking to his post and tapping out the S.O.S. for the Morro Castle when she caught fire nineteen years ago was held by the police here tonight as a material witness in a double murder.

The racket-ridden International Longshoremen's Association eager to head off moves by the American Federation of Labor to set up a rival union in the Port of New York, has indicated its willingness to surrender full authority over the union's affairs to an administrator appointed by the parent organization.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- During the week ended July 1, member bank reserves decreased $345,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Repayments from the proceeds of new financing by public utilities and petroleum and chemical companies were reflected in a $170,000,000 drop in New York bank business loans in the week ended on Wednesday -- the largest decline since the late Thirties.

A Brooklyn jewelry union that ran afoul of the American Federation of Labor's anti-racketeering committee after its ex-convict business agent had been indicted on charges of bribing a witness in a murder trial has found a new home in the A. F. L., it became known yesterday.

As a prime contractor to the Military Air Transport Service, operator of the Korean Airlift, Seaboard Western Airlines yesterday completed its 2,145th crossing of the Pacific between Travis Air Force Base, California, and Tokyo.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., July 2 -- Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich captured low gross honors and Mrs. Charles P. Luckey of Bedford earned possession of the Jane Brooks Robbins Memorial Trophy in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association's competition at the Mount Kisco C. C. today.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., July 2 Patricia O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn., one of two amateurs in the Triangle round-robin tournament for women, took the lead away from the professionals as the first round was completed at the Shackamaxon Country Club today.
VIENNA, July 2 -- The Hungarian Government of Premier Matyas Rakosi has resigned, according to an announcement tonight by the Budapest radio.
LONDON, July 2 (Reuters) -- George Emmett today saved Gloucestershire from quick defeat by the Australian cricketers, who hit 402 runs before declaring at the ninth wicket.

Mrs. Ellen Knauff, a German-born war bride, abruptly walked out of a hearing yesterday on her petition to become a United States citizen. Admitted to this country on Nov. 2, 1951, after a three-year battle to be cleared of espionage charges, Mrs. Knauff explained that she could not understand the "rehashing" of charges.

BALTIMORE, July 2 -- Described as the world's major collection of railroad memorabilia, the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's Transportation Museum, housing items spanning a century and a quarter of commercial railroading in the United States, was dedicated today.
Mayor Impellitteri called on former President Harry S. Truman yesterday afternoon in his suite in the Waldorf-Astoria Towers.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 3 -- At the first session of Parliament since the April elections, in which Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan greatly increased his majority, the Nationalist Government resumed today its effort to take away from the courts virtually all their power to overrule acts of Parliament.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, July 4 -- Chinese Communists shattered South Korean bunkers on "Lookout Mountain" with a devastating artillery barrage yesterday, then seized the key heights on the eastern front once more.

Independent Democrats are urging Rudolph Halley, designated by the Liberal party as its candidate for Mayor, to enter the Democratic primary on Sept. 15 in an attempt also to win the Democratic nomination.

The Industrial Bank of Commerce reported as of June 30, 1953, total deposits of $71,997,673 and total assets of $84,836,070, compared, respectively, with $73,138,835 and $86,189,144 on March 31. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $13,205,541 against $13,902,264; holdings of United States Government securities to $11,788,337 against $13,479,652; and loans and discounts to $59,074,533 against $58,060,155.

Raymond Irrera of Astoria, has been named chairman of the 1953 building awards committee of the Queens Chamber of Commerce, according to John T. Clancy, president of the organization. Mr. Irrera is a former president of the Queens Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 3 -- A community-wide project of tracing family trees that was started many months ago will culminate here soon with the publication of "East Hampton History and Genealogies."

Four persons were mauled and bitten -- two of them seriously -- on the grounds of a Bayside, Queens, nursing home last night when seven boxer dogs attacked them. The dogs had been in a fenced enclosure.

DETROIT, July 3 (AP) -- Motor vehicle production dipped almost 21 per cent as an estimated 129,471 cars and trucks were built this week, compared with 162,924 in the previous week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. The automotive industry rested on its laurels as General Motors Corporation and Chrysler Corporation United States plants closed to observe a long Independence Day week-end.

Two sheets of paper, covered on both sides with writing in a small and precise hand, are the stellar piece in an exhibition titled "Milestones of Freedom" opening today at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 3 -- Basic changes in life in the United States resulting from industrial and armed forces requirements, present to future homemakers the task of learning to make a good home anywhere and "to put down roots quickly in any community," 2,000 teen-age members of the Future Homemakers of America were told today.

BOSTON, July 3 (UP) -- The Massachusetts American Legion today accused the Cleveland Indians of "tampering" with a 17-year-old baseball star considered a possible replacement for First Baseman Luke Easter.
MILWAUKEE, July 3 (UP) -- The second-place Braves picked up ground in the National League pennant race today with an 11-1 victory over the Redlegs before 14,121 fans at County Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Edward Sylva, Attorney General of Hawaii, today disputed the contention of a self-described former Communist that the party dominated the island's International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, independent.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (UP) -- Al Rosen hit his twentieth homer of the season and fifth in five games as the Indians defeated the Tigers, 8 -- 1, tonight while Early Wynn treated a crowd of 17,219 to a six-hit pitching performance for his eighth victory.
The call of the wild was so strong in one small camper yesterday that she managed to imitate it successfully enough to stop the bus she had just missed.

PARIS, July 3 -- The French Government handed to Paris representatives of the three Indo- Chinese states today a note proposing to negotiate to "adapt" the accords of 1949 to the positions those states have acquired since then "in the community of free peoples."

The sixty-family apartment house at 2401 Davidson Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Mabel Sherman to an investing client of Martin Teichman, attorney, for cash over mortgages of $244,350. The property is assessed at $275,000.

MADRID, July 3 -- An understanding has been reached between Washington and Madrid to wait for final action by the United States Congress on the foreign aid bill before proceeding with the final steps concerning the conclusion of bilateral economic and military agreements, well informed United States circles said today.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Effective as of July 1, in the interest of economy, the daily statement of the Treasury will be issued in condensed form except for the last day of each month, it was announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (AP) -- John Nicholas, a chef, and his wife stopped on their way home from Atlantic City to Philadelphia Monday. Their 13-year-old daughter, Dolores walked over to the bank of a creek near the highway. She found a large egg nestled in the trees.

BOYLE, Ireland, July 3 -- The earliest known dwelling place in Ireland, a "township" inhabited 4,000 years ago by Stone Age Irishmen, has been discovered near here as a consequence of partly draining a lake whose waters will be used to raise the level of the River Shannon.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The State Department has ordered a complete inventory of the books in its 189 overseas libraries.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 3 -- The perils of modern traffic, plus the care of modern apparatus that limits the spare time of firemen, have reduced Dalmatian mascots of the Elizabeth fire department to a lone four-year-old dog, it was revealed today.

Although the 537 trainmen who reported "sick" on the Long Island Rail Road yesterday were "cured" in a few hours when a formula for adjusting their grievances was found, even this short strike inconvenienced thousands of commuters and vacationists. The trainmen may have valid gripes.

Advertising people like a fast dollar. They also aid their fellow citizens for nothing when an emergency arises. Approximately $1,000,000 in relief funds for the tornado-stricken Worcester, Mass., area has been raised by a tornado relief advertising campaign planned and executed by the New England Council of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.
A rhesus monkey appeared mysteriously yesterday morning in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn, and cavorted in the nave for more than two hours while 1,000 persons attended three masses.
PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- The Giants were victims of what virtually amounted to a first-round knockout today. Custom and the rules alone made it obligatory that they play the remaining eight innings.

TRENTON, July 3 -- On July 16 Joseph Doto, alias Joe Adonis, the racketeer, will be released from the New Jersey State Prison where he has served twenty-six months of a maximum sentence of two and a half years on a gambling conviction in Bergen County.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, declared today that "oppressive taxes" were largely responsible for the $9,389,000,000 Federal deficit in the 1953 fiscal year, which ended Tuesday.

LONDON, July 3 -- The stock markets finished the week on a firm although quieter note today, with sentiment strengthened by a favorable interpretation of the rise in the gold and dollar reserves for June.

SINGAPORE, July 3 -- Two thousand British, African and Gurkha troops have launched one of the biggest air and land offensives of the Malayan campaign against Communist terrorists deep in the jungles of Pahang. The offensive, covering an area of twenty-five square miles, is aimed at trapping a gang of eighty Communists.

PARIS, July 3 -- The full application of the United States loyalty investigation program to United States citizens employed by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization was left in doubt today after a general conference of the educational group voted a compromise resolution on the subject.

HENLEY - ON - THAMES, England, July 3 (UP) -- Princeton's 150-pound crew gained the semi-finals of the Thames Challenge Cup competition today at the Royal Henley regatta, but Kent (Conn.), a four-time winner of the blue-ribbon rowing event, was eliminated when it lost in the quarter-finals.

ROME, July 3 -- A cloud of anxiety darkens the political horizon in Italy. Today President Einaudi, after consulting various party leaders, asked Alcide De Gasperi to form a new Government. As head of the party which just missed having an over-all majority in the election and is still by far the strongest party, Dr. De Gasperi is the inevitable choice to succeed himself.

EASTON, Pa., July 3 -- Commissioners of Northampton County voted today to remove two pages from a recently published county history because of complaints made in April that passages on the pages were unfair to the Irish and to Roman Catholics.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 3 -- A Syracuse University child development expert said today that society was only at the "threshold of understanding" when it came to creating a "really healthy home environment" for the newborn and toddler child.

HONOLULU, July 3 (UP) -- Jack Hall, the Hawaii labor leader, and five others convicted with him on Communist conspiracy charges two weeks ago were sentenced today to five years' imprisonment and a $5,000 fine each.
TOKYO, Saturday, July 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,665, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korean time:

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today Attorney General Herbert Browneil Jr had ordered a search of Justice Department files to determine whether former President Harry S. Truman ever handed it a list of about 150 Americans suspected of spying for the Soviet Union.

Bon voyage gifts for the many vacationers going abroad this summer are no problem -- if the trip is to be made by ship. Fancy food shops and the delicacy sections of department stores offer a wide assortment of handsomely wrapped packages, and most of them will make deliveries just before sailing time.

An increase in the wholesale price of gas, which the Federal Power Commission authorized the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation to charge four local companies, will be passed on to consumers here, the Public Service Commission announced in a ruling yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- The wheat market today took the bearish private crop forecasts in stride, and most of the session showed a strong tone, although it closed off 3/8 cent to 1 1/4 cents. Country offerings continue light and indicating that growers have no intention of selling any more wheat than they have to.

LIBERTY, N. Y., July 3 -- Only prosaic foot-pickets were in evidence at Grossinger's and the Concord today, but in New York a union official said that the "strike" of three American Federation of Labor unions against the two large Catskill resort hotels was proceeding with spectacular aerial and highway announcements.

Just as summer is upon us in full fury, the city wants to sell a snowplow. It is among a long list of items, no longer useful to the municipality, for which bids will be opened at 11 A. M. July 14 at the Purchase Department in the Municipal Building.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Ransom Jackson, third baseman, smashed two homers and sparked a seven-run eighth inning with a bases-filled single as the Cubs trounced the third-place Cardinals today, 10 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- Several thousand Reserve officers will be released from active duty because of budget cuts, the Army, Navy and Air Force announced today. The exact number has not been calculated but they will be released in the next twelve months.

CAIRO, July 3 -- Egypt's President and Premier, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, affirmed today the intention of his revolutionary government, foreshadowed in recent events, to assign top priority to a solution of economic problems as a necessary preliminary to the attainment of political goals.

SIEMREAP, Cambodia, July 2 -- In the first interview he has granted at his new West Cambodian headquarters King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia reiterated here last night his determination to accept nothing less than complete independence of his kingdom from France.

The contemporary struggle for freedom in America will be the theme of many sermons in churches here tomorrow, "Our Fight for Freedom" will be the topic of Dr. Charles C. Cole Jr. at 11 A. M. at the Washington Square Methodist Church, 133 West Fourth Street.

James T. Sherwin, New York State chess champion in 1951, who was graduated from Columbia University recently, won his opening-round encounter in the second international tournament for the junior championship of the world at Copenhagen yesterday, according to a report received from Danish news sources.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The United Textile Workers, A. F. L., revoked today a charter it had issued last Monday to a Brooklyn union of jewelery workers. Anthony Valente, president of the textile union, said "certain pertinent facts" were not known at the time the charter was issued.

EDMONTON, Alta, July 3 (UP) -- Earl Walls, Canadian heavyweight champion, knocked out eighth-ranking Rex Layne of Ogden, Utah, in 1:10 of the first round of a scheduled ten-round non-title bout tonight.
PARIS, July 3 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a note sent by the French Government to the three states of Indo-China:

The newly installed Government of France has acted with commendable speed in calling for fresh negotiations with the three Associated States of Indo-China with a view to broadening the base of their progress toward independence. The question had been hanging fire during the time that Paris was trying to obtain a Cabinet and the delay added an element of difficulty.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) --An Army Board of Review today upheld the court-martial sentence of Lieut. Col. Melvin B. Voorhees, but affirmed only one of the five charges that had been brought against him in connection with the publication of his book "Korean Tales."

ONEIDA, N. Y., July 3 (AP) -- The Sylvan Beach-Verona Beach summer colony was threatened with possible destruction early today when a tank barge sank a mile and a half offshore in Oneida Lake and spewed her cargo of 275,000 gallons of flammable fuel oil on the lake.

ROSLYN, L. I., July 3 -- The design of a new type of surgical operating building, in which as many as seventy-five surgeons and physicians can participate in a single operation to improve a heart-crippled child, was disclosed here today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- Not since it was hoisted atop City Hall tower almost fifty-nine years ago has the statue of William Penn looked down upon so many changes taking place at one time in the "greene countrie towne" Penn founded between the Delaware and Schuylkill Rivers in 1682.
LOS ANGELES, July 3 -- A deadlock that stalled operations of the Los Angeles City Council all week was resolved today in the selection of a compromise candidate to head the body.

The price of tin dropped 1 1/2 cents a pound here yesterday to 87 cents -- the lowest level since July 11, 1950. Dealers attributed the drop to a combination of factors: weakness in the Singapore market, slow buying in Europe which resulted in a price break yesterday on the London Metal Exchange, and the usual tendency by United States consumers of holding to the market sidelines during periods of declining prices overseas.
BOSTON, July 3 -- Gov. Christian A Herter ordered all Massachusetts woodlands east of the Connecticut River closed at 6 P. M. today until further notice because of the "explosive" forest fire hazard.

Market operators were busy yesterday buying and selling a certain issue on the New York Stock Exchange. The Graham Paige Corporation was the target. It no longer is an automotive concern. The company is now engaged in the business of specialized investments.

TURKU, Finland, July 3 (AP) -- Wes Santee, Kansas' miler, was beaten in a 1,500-meter race today by Dennis Johansson of Finland. The loss was the first for Santee at the metric mile or the American mile since before last year's Olympic Games.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that the sheet and tin mill finishing equipment at its new Fairless Works in Morrisville, Pa., will begin operating during this quarter. Shipments of hot and cold rolled sheets and tin mill products will be made at first in limited volume and size range.

MADISON, Wis., July 3 -- Spokesmen for the Republican party of Wisconsin denied here today that a resolution passed yesterday by the thirty-five-man executive committee modified the action of the State Republican convention on June 13 that censured Senator Alexander Wiley for his opposition to the Bricker amendment.

E. W. Haley has been appointed assistant to the vice president of the Columbia - Southern Chemical Corporation, a subsidiary of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company. C. F. Bingham succeeds Mr. Haley as director of sales.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 -- Edgar Bergen, who returned last night from a European filming tour in connection with his own movie autobiography, "Little Acorns," is looking around now for a young actor to impersonate him in the early stages of the story, starting with high school days in Chicago.

BOSTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Senators exploded for five runs in the seventh inning to give Specs Shea his seventh pitching victory against one loss with a 9-4 decision over the Red Sox. Each team made four errors, the Red Sox making three on the first four plays.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:

BAYONNE, N. J., July 3 - Unable to raise $25,000 bail as a material witness in a double murder case here, George W. Rogers, 57-year-old radio repairman and ex-convict, faced today a week-end in jail as the police followed slim clues in the death by bludgeoning of an 83-year-old former Typographical Union official and his 58-year-old spinster daughter.

Trofim D. Lysenko, Soviet biologist, who fostered the banning of "bourgeois genetics" from Soviet science, has recently come in for sharp personal and theoretical criticism by Soviet scientists, two students of Soviet scientific affairs reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- A proposal to settle the three-year lawsuit involving the supply of natural gas to a large part of New England has been submitted to the Federal Power Commission, it was disclosed today.
Five men who distinguished themselves in the tumult of Korean battlefields were honored with awards for valor yesterday in the quiet of Bedloes Island, at the base of the Statue of Liberty.
Several art exhibitions enliven a slow season in museums and galleries.
The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service invited operators of privately owned ships to offer their vessels for charter yesterday.

Whitey Ford banished the harrowing memory of the Yankees' nine-game losing streak a little deeper into the recesses of Manager Casey Stengel's mind by pitching a brilliant two-hit, 4-0 shutout yesterday against the Athletics before 11,833 paying spectators at the Stadium.
BONN, Germany, July 3 -- The Bundestag reversed itself today on the French Government's post-war economic aid claim of $11,800,000 and ratified the entire London Debt Agreement.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- A Department of Agriculture official estimated tentatively today that prospective cotton quotas for 1954, under present law, would be limited to approximately 17,500,000 acres.

Senator Wiley's address, which you published June 27, is admirable indeed. The demands which he would have us present to Malenkov are just and the very minimum But he has left out the most important demand, the one upon which lasting peace depends.

President Eisenhower made a sharp break with a very old tradition when he asked that we make this Independence Day a national day of prayer. "The Great and Glorious Fourth" has always been associated with tub-thumping and flag-waving, with bands and marching men, with picnics and fireworks.

THURMONT, Md., July 3 -- President Eisenhower beat the Fourth of July exodus out of Washington this morning and got in eighteen holes of golf this afternoon at the Monterey Country Club in near-by Blue Ridge Summit, Pa.

In the last half century the hospital has evolved into something more than an institution where the sick are cared for. All the great voluntary hospitals not only perform this time-honored function but carry on research and teach. As the trend gathered momentum we saw the rise of the medical center, which encompasses a dozen different kinds of hospitals and scores of laboratories and which is always an integral part of a medical school.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- An acoustic sleep-inducing apparatus that he calls the "Slumberbug" was patented this week by Charles Beazley of Chicago. (Patent 2,644,153). The cabinet shown in the drawings looks like a small radio receiver. The device has no electronic tubes, but uses "the normal sinusoidal voltage wave" of alternating house current which, Mr. Beazley says, has an appreciable harmonic content.

A sudden strike of 537 trainmen, who reported sick between 10 P. M. Thursday and yesterday noon, crippled the Long Island Rail Road, cutting its service by half in yesterday's morning and afternoon rush hours.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 3 (UP) -- Thousands of French Union troops were sent to Cambodia today to reinforce the garrison of the restive kingdom against any emergency arising from King Norodom Sihanouk's campaign for independence.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 3 -- Queen Elizabeth concluded today a successful but sometimes anxious Coronation visit to the Irish corner of her kingdom. The final day, regarded as the most uncertain of the tour, passed without incident.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 3 (AP) -- A pair of outsiders who had won only one race in twenty-nine starts between them stirred a crowd of 16,800 at Monmouth Park today by taking the first two races and returning a daily double of $1,448.80.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 -- Playing some of the finest tennis of his long international career, Victor Seixas of the United States trounced Kurt Nielsen of Denmark in straight sets today to win the coveted All-England championship before a capacity crowd that sat under cold, gunmetal skies.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., July 3 -- Pat O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn., one of the two amateurs in the field of sixteen, continued to lead the Triangle round-robin golf tournament today at the Shackamaxon Country Club as she shot an even-par 74 for the 6,400-yard course and increased her point-total from 15 to 27.

A syndicate headed by Paul Green, attorney, has purchased the nine-story and penthouse apartment building for thirty-eight families at 111 East Seventy-fifth Street and has insured title with the City Title Insurance Company. Green Ettinger were the attorneys for the buyers of the property, which was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $200,000.

" Washington's Officers Slept Here," by Edward Pinkowski, is the only book published today. It is a history of the thirty-four houses in Valley Forge in which American officers lived in the winter of 1777-78. The author gives the background of each officer, portrays the family with whom he lived and describes the house. The book is published by the Sunshine Press of Philadelphia at $5.
TOKYO, Saturday, July 4 -- President Syngman Rhee, in an Independence Day message, called on the American people today to continue the fight against communism side by side with South Korean soldiers.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Internal Revenue Bureau has advised the United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund it does not qualify for income tax exemption. The bureau also reiterated a 1948 ruling that individual beneficiaries of the fund were liable to income tax on their benefits.

There are those gardeners who, by transplanting, thinning out, redesigning, cutting down, adding here and subtracting there, each year change the face of their gardens. These would be the young, the energetic and the restless, often regarding change as synonymous with improvement and progress.
ROME, Italy, July 3 -- A Foreign Ministry spokesman replied with unusual heat today to remarks on the Trieste situation made by Ales Bebler, Yugoslav Foreign Under Secretary, in Trieste yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 3 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge appointed a commission of twelve members today to study the possibility of establishing a system of educational television in Connecticut. The commission's appointment was directed in a bill approved by the General Assembly, which adjourned on May 30.

ALBANY, July 3 (AP) -- About fifteen State Civil Service employes have been discharged or face charges that could lead to dismissal on the ground of allegedly subversive activities, the Governor's office announced today.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer, winner of fourteen of his fifteen starts, including the Preakness and Belmont Stakes, heads a line-up of six 3-year-olds in the $50,000 added Dwyer Stakes at Aqueduct today. He's a horse of distinction; the others haven't done much to distinguish themselves. It seems likely that The Dancer will be a 1-to-20 proposition in the mile-and-a-quarter run.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 3 (AP) -- Malcolm, owned by Gene Acres of Chicago, scored a two-length victory over Thunderation tonight in the Farmingdale trot at the Grand Circuit meeting at Roosevelt Raceway.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 3 -- Former President Harry S. Truman, who laid the cornerstone for the United Nations permanent home here, came back today as a private citizen to take his first look at the completed $68,000,000 world headquarters. It is "topnotch," he decided.
There's no such thing as a little war to man in the a fight. A veteran becomes a veteran when bullets whistle by him and when he realizes that he cannot dodge the one that has his number on it.
BERLIN, July 3 -- Berlin's official Communist newspaper accused East Germany's labor unions today of working more on behalf of factory management than on behalf of the workers.

New York's Seventh Avenue, scene of brisk activity in the last four weeks as thousands of garment buyers toured the manufacturing establishments for their fall lines, took on a deserted aspect yesterday with the start of the Fourth of July week-end.

BOSTON, July 3 -- The American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., closed its twentieth annual convention today by accepting a report of its collective bargaining committee seeking a weekly minimum salary, goal of $150 for experienced key personnel and a minimum of $75 for all adult classifications.

Activity on the New York commodity exchanges slowed down yesterday as many brokers and dealers started a three-day weekend. Volume was light and confined to the usual evening-up at the end of the week. The New York Commodity Exchange closed at noon, limiting trading, but rubber showed more activity than during the last week-and-a-half.
A truck driver, a hotel cashier and a food shop were held up yesterday by robbers who escaped.

NEW DELHI, India, July 3 -- Burmese and Indian officials here have failed to reach an agreement on a rice deal, although coming to an understanding to enlarge the volume of trade in other commodities, it was learned today from official sources.
The Coast Guard opened hearings yesterday on the collision last Sunday between an American tanker and a Brazilian freighter off New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture allocated 9,050,000 100-pound bags of rice today for export during the las half of the year.

NEWARK, July 3 -- Alvah Watts, 17 years old, of Jermyn, Pa., a high school student working on a factory night shift here during his summer vacation, was killed today at 4:30 A. M. when an out-of-control car operated by a driver with a learner's permit plowed into a curb in Frelinghuysen Avenue where the youth was sitting with three fellow workers waiting for a bus.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- Representative John W. Heselton, Republican of Massachusetts, introduced a bill today to clamp sweeping Federal controls on the oil and natural gas industries as a result of "unwarranted" price jumps in gasoline and other petroleum products.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 3 -- More than a score of vacationers were stranded today in the wilderness of Superior National Forest, in Minnesota's rough Arrowhead country, when Federal agents seized their means of egress -- three airplanes -- and arrested two pilots.
CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 3 (AP) -- Ben Hogan read Carnoustie's greens with the concentration of a scholar today as he tuned up his game for next week's British open golf championship.

HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., July 3 -- The annals of broadbill fishing were not .augmented by so much as a terse comment as the result of our activities today, although miles of water foamed behind the stern of Hans Hinrich's Alone, a craft which is dedicated to the pursuit of this mighty fish.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, July 3 -- A long-pending major reorganization of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's air forces on the European Continent will take place in early August, Supreme Allied Headquarters announced today.

LONDON, July 3 -- Tenzing, the Sherpa guide, and Edmund Hillary, the New Zealand bee keeper who climbed Mount Everest, were welcomed by dignitaries and plain citizens today at London airport when they and ten of their companions of Col. John Hunt's Everest expedition arrived from India.

JACKSON, Miss., July 3 (AP) -- This Deep South commonwealth moved today to save segregation in schools by equalizing facilities for both races while in adjacent Alabama Negroes opened a legal attack to gain entrance to the State University. The Supreme Court has held Negroes must be admitted to white schools unless equal educational facilities are provided for them.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 3 -- In one of the greatest first-day demonstrations in the 35-year history of the event, Milton Campbell, the local boy who made good, swept into a commanding lead tonight as the first half of the national decathlon championship was completed.
WASHINGTON, July 3 UP) -- The United States Merchant fleet, both private and Government-owned, totals 3,348 ships but only 29 per cent are rated in good condition by the Maritime Administration.

The ringing in my ears caused by the detonation of fireworks precludes my listening to the radio or to conversation, and therefore I shall use this peaceful interlude to express my views on the subject.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., July 3 -- Pilots and deck hands operating ferry boats across the Hudson River between Newburgh and Beacon struck this afternoon. Their action stalled hundreds of holiday week-end motorists in the two towns and broke the 210-year record of uninterrupted service by the ferry.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent over the week ended June 30 to 109.4 (1947-49 = 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Prices of farm products averaged lower, as a result of declining prices for cattle, hogs and many fresh fruits and vegetables.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- James W. Riddleberger, a career diplomat, has been named United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia. State Department officials confirmed the selection of Mr. Riddleberger after Yugoslav news agencies had said that the choice had been approved by Marshal Tito.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 3 -- Pan American Airways is believed to have lost its contract with the New Zealand post office for the transportation of air mails between New Zealand and the United States, according to The New Zealand Herald's parliamentary correspondent in Wellington, who said an official announcement was expected shortly.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 3 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, who was President of the 1949 session of the General Assembly, said today that "the structure of collective security so laboriously built up over the years is threatened with destruction in Korea."

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 3 (AP) -- The Hungarian Government appeared today to be revising its economic policy and preparing to adopt a "new political trend" like that in East Germany as the new Communist-ruled Parliament met to approve a streamlined Government.
VIENNA, July 3 -- The Hungarian Parliament, elected in May, met in Budapest today to choose a new Presidium and will be asked tomorrow or Sunday to approve a new Government.

Bright, pleasant weather -- like yesterday's, with the temperature about 80 degrees and the humidity considerably lower than it was on Thursday -- was expected to favor the 177th birthday anniversary of the United States today.

LOS ANGELES, July 3 (AP) -- A fire that in twenty-four hours blackened 12,000 acres of brush and timber in Angeles National Forest today roared on out of control, threatening cabins and ranches on the east slope of the San Gabriel Mountains.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., July 3 -- In a day of many upsets, Felice Torza, 33-year-old St. Charles (Ill.) representative, emerged with two stunning victories to his credit in the Professional Golfers Association championship at the Birmingham County Club today.

The Senate Committee on Appropriations, hypnotized by the magic word "economy," has just recommended that the budget of the United States Children's Bureau be reduced by $100,000. This will save every inhabitant of the United States, if the word saving is justified, less than one-tenth of a cent.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Congress is being urged to eliminate from the defense budget, already passed by the House of Representatives, funds which would enable the armed services to process iron land steel scrap in this country.
TOKYO, July 3 -- Ikebana, or Japanese flower arranging, has become as complex an art as painting under the freedom of expression characterized by the post-war years.
The Parish of Orleans, La., which refused on June 23 to sell $10,000,000 of school bonds at an interest cost of 4 per cent, arranged yesterday to sell a smaller amount at a cost of 3 3/4 per cent.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 3 -- Rabbi Irving Miller, president of the Zionist Organization of America, advised Israelis tonight not to be taken in by propaganda to the effect that the Eisenhower Administration was adopting a new Middle East policy of impartiality that would express itself in a reduction of aid to Israel and in favoring the political claims of the Arab states against Israel.

The Playwrights' Company has scheduled the new Maxwell Anderson-Rouben Mamoulian musical, "Devil's Hornpipe," for presentation in late December, this being the time of the year when Broadway showmen organize their plans for the fall and winter theatrical activity.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- The Polish Government has agreed to let an American girl, Arlene Migacz, 19 years old, of Chicago, and Barbara Yancik, the Polish wife of a United States airman, leave Poland and come to the United States, the State Department said today.

STANTON, Del., July 3 (AP) -- The distaff division of the thoroughbred runners moves into the $100,000 class tomorrow with eleven fillies and mares named for the sixteenth running of the New Castle Handicap at Delaware Park.

Your editorial of June 30 about Charles C. Burlingham, "First Citizen," must have had the high approval of many organizations besides our own, which proudly claims Mr. Burlingham as one of its own: long a trustee, and now honorary vice president, of the Community Service Society.

KANSAS CITY, July 3 (AP) -- Three members of a special House investigating subcommittee urged today that a Federal grand jury be called immediately to clean up what they called gangsterism in the Kansas City labor field.

Because of the holiday today, Red Cross blood collection in the city will be postponed until Monday. Normally some bloodmobile units operate on Saturdays, although the collection centers are closed. Today not even the bloodmobile units will function.

A 70 mm. microfilm process and viewer, believed to provide the most practical method of preserving and viewing newspaper and magazine clippings, has been developed by University Microfilms and the Microtronics Corporation in cooperation with THE NEW YORK TIMES, and the first unit has been purchased and installed in the research department of this newspaper.

MIAMI BEACH, July 3 -- No one has the right to tell an American what he should say or what books he can read, Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, told the closing session of the National Education Association's convention here tonight.

In passing a one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act the Senate had the wisdom to knock out of the House-approved bill a mischievous provision that could do much to wreck the whole spirit of the law. That is the provision adding an extra member to the Tariff Commission, thus turning it from a bipartisan six-man body into a mere instrument of whatever political party happens to be in power.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Senators called today for a renewal of the debate between Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, and Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg over Air Force funds and development.

Heat is the great leveler in the city's streets. It slows down the tempo of locomotion and melts the usual reserve of the city dweller. Normally street traffic presents faces as a steady pale blur or a jack-in-the-box tempo. Now a man can take the time to observe his fellow-citizens and sufferers.

A new community of stores, offices, restaurants and gardens is rising from sixty-eight acres of barren fields and swampland in southern Westchester. It is the $30,000,000 Cross-County Center in the Fleetwood-Bronxville area of Yonkers, one and one-half miles north of the Bronx boundary.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Senator Charles E. Potter of Michigan, a Republican member of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, said today that it was his "present" opinion that J. B. Matthews, who joined that group as executive staff director eleven days ago, should not be retained.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 3 -- A Greenwich man received the unusually stiff fine of $50 today for having sold fireworks without a license.

MANHASSET, L. I., July 3 -- Supreme Court Justice D. Ormonde Ritchie denied today an injunction sought against the North Shore Hospital here by the North Country Community Hospital of Glen Cove to prohibit the use of the name North Shore Hospital.
The recent exchange of opinion on two sides of the Atlantic and later domestically revolves around a single subject: Do the American people wish to live and attempt to survive in a Communist world ?

STAMFORD, Conn., July 3 -- A traffic improvement plan containing recommendations for both immediate and long-range relief from increasingly irksome snarls, especially in the central business section, has been submitted to Police Chief John B. Brennan by Fred W. Hurd, traffic engineer.

ROME, July 3 -- President Luigi Einaudi offered the task of forming a new government to Premier Alcide De Gasperi this morning. Dr. De Gasperi, however, refused to commit himself. He undertook only to approach all the parties represented in Parliament and will advise President Einaudi next Tuesday whether he thinks a Cabinet headed by himself would have any chance of obtaining a vote of confidence in the Senate and Chamber of Deputies.

For the first time in over a decade the Secretary of Agriculture has been forced to ask wheat growers in this country to vote on whether or not wheat marketing quotas shall be applied next year. Such quotas, an indirect but potent form of production control, must be approved by two- thirds of our wheat farmers to become effective.

Metallurg, Inc., metallurgical, mining and manufacturing company, has leased the twenty-second floor in the twenty-six story office building being built by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, owner-builder, at 99 Park Avenue, southeast corner of East Fortieth Street.

GALVESTON, Tex., July 3 (UP) -- Houston and Galveston shipyards are completing a $3,000,000 marine repair job to give a new bow section to the Fort Mercer, a tanker that broke in two in a storm in the Atlantic last year. The bow section of the tanker sank, but the stern, containing the machinery, was saved.

The cotton futures market closed steady yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, 3 to 13 points higher than Thursday. The market opened quiet and held within a narrow range all day. Twenty July notices were issued and stopped.

Millions of Japanese beetles are swarming over parts of New Jersey and Long Island, attacking shrubs and flowers and bringing pleas from agricultural authorities that homeowners act promptly to help stamp out the pest.
TAMPA, Fla., July 3 (AP) -- Women golfers who play for pay got notice today that Babe Didrikson Zaharias, greatest of them all, was coming back.

I have received a letter requiring me to bring back the books and magazines I had borrowed from the American Reading Room here in Zurich, because this institution was going to be liquidated. The necessary funds to keep it going, as I found out, had been stopped by Washington.

Five parcels of real estate in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn, consisting of apartment and commercial buildings and a former Elks Lodge, were sold by Joseph P. Day, Inc., for various owners at an auction held on Thursday at the McAlpin Hotel.

NEPTUNE CITY, N. J., July 3 -- Willis Fussell, 62 years old, of Silver Spring, Md., was burned fatally and his wife, Frances, 56, was burned critically today when the car in which they were riding collided with a fuel oil truck on Route 35.

BONN, Germany, July 3 -- United States Government agencies in Washington and Bonn are considering a plan to ship huge quantities of Government-owned surplus butter, wheat, meat, dried beans and other foodstuffs into East Germany.
TAMPA, Fla., July 3 (AP) -- Women golfers who play for pay got notice today that Babe Didrikson Zaharias, greatest of them all, was coming back.

Blows were dealt the free flow of world news in Argentina in the last six months. Readers of newspapers in Spain looked in vain for any mention of British pre-Coronation activities. An Associated Press correspondent was ordered out of Teheran for writing about hot-headed Iranians attacking Americans.

Elizabeth Janeway's "Why They Become Communists" (June 14) while offering very good common-sense advice on dealing with communism in the United States, unfortunately does not adequately combat the question posed by her title.

During this holiday week-end we have been thinking, rightfully, of the independence of these United States. We have had an opportunity to reread our magnificent Declaration. It still shines as one of the brightest stars in our national firmament. It is still the inspiring declaration of faith that it was in 1776.

IT is now known, of course, to all who watched the premiere performance of "The Goldbergs," over N. B. C.-TV last Friday night, that the long-awaited "Mrs. Bloom" did not appear. It can be reliably reported, however, that the script for the July 10 episode in the family saga calls for the heretofore invisible and silent lady to be both seen and heard.

I WANT to tell you about a remarkable man whom I never met and never will because he died last March. His name was Paul Howard and he lived in Adelaide, South Australia. He was an amateur pianist, amateur only in the sense that he never took money for his services.

THIS hymn to the Catholic Church has a treble of fast-moving action and a bass of the author's most serious reflections. Bruce Marshall, who wrote the popular novel, "The World, the Flesh and Father Smith," and the popular play, "Father Malachy's Miracle," has here written an ambitious story about the Spanish Civil War which is a psalm to "the pure Church in the catacombs" and a denunciation of "the lazy one in the cathedrals."

TOMBSTONE, Ariz., was marked for fame from the moment that Ed Schieffelin gave the grim name to his silver claim on the slopes of the Mulesboe lountins. He had been assured that his tombstone was all that the Apaches would permit him to locate in the region.

PARIS, July 4 -- Such are the complexities of a French Cabinet crisis that its causes and results can seldom be judged on the spot. There are so many front drops, so many properties brought out and so much skirmishing in the wings that one can never see the backdrop of the political drama until things have settled down.

Hundreds of millions of dollars in bank credit will be transferred around the country daily by means of a new automatic teletypewriter communications network to be placed in operation by the Federal Reserve System tomorrow.
CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 4 (AP) -- Dour Scots took Ben Hogan to their hearts and quietly wished him well in the British open golf championship beginning here Monday.

THIS week H. M. V. presents two vocal records of unusual distinction, a group of songs by Beethoven, Schubert and Schumann as interpreted by the baritone, Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, and Russian songs and arias sung by the basso, Boris Christoff.

Barro Colorado Island in the Canal Zone has forty-two species of termites. To cope with them. rows of upright posts have been planted. They look like grave stones, half buried in the soil. The wood of the posts is impregnated with various kinds of repellents and poisons.

The Yankees defeated the Athletics, 6 -- 3 and 4 -- 0, at the Stadium yesterday, Tom Gorman relieving Ed Lopat to take the opener and Jim McDonald pitching the second victory. The Dodgers beat the Pirates, 6 -- 5, in the first game of a twin bill, then lost by 5 -- 2. The Giants halted the Phils, 4 -- 2, before bowing, 10 -- 4.

SIX commemorative stamps having vignettes based on themes associated with science, religion, sports and man's conquest of arid areas will be issued by Israel in August and September. Jacques Minkus, recently appointed director of the Israel Philatelic Agency in America, Inc., announced here last week that this fourfold program is as follows:

TANGA, Tanganyika, July 4 -This little palm-shaded port and city in northern Tanganyika is the most important center of one of the world's low-wage and low-profit industries -- production of sisal fiber. This year after a relatively short post-war boom sisal returned to its normally low prices.

Only one pitcher needed no help in yesterday's double-header at Ebbets Field before 30,029 fans, the season's largest Brooklyn crowd. Bob Friend went the route and hurled the Pirates to a 5-2 triumph in the second game after the Dodgers had downed the Bucs, 6-5, for the ninth time in a row in the opener, employing four pitchers in the process.

A NOVEL demonstration of the results achieved by a photographer who put her camera to work in the interests of local history and architecture is on view through tomorrow at the Rochester Memorial Art Gallery.

TODAY'S column, for me at least, stands as a rude reminder of the flight of time. Ten years ago this week Page Two assumed its present form. More than once, in the ensuing year, I wondered whether it would arrive at a first anniversary, let alone a tenth, and a similar uncertainty has been recurrent ever since.

SINGAPORE, July 4 -- Thirteen Communist terrorists were killed in a large-scale operation conducted by security forces in the jungles of Pahang, a special communique announced tonight. The authorities had maintained complete secrecy on the operation.

TRENTON -- Just ten miles south of Atlantic City the visitor to New Jersey's shore crosses Great Egg Harbor and enters the state's historical peninsula of Cape May. Actually south of the Mason-Dixon Line, it has a climate like Virginia's and annually attracts 250,000 or more vacationists and tourists.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 4 -Incidentally of the Maine Chance Farm and Lady Bouncer, owned by William G. Helis Jr., shared premier accomplishments in the Colleen Stakes at the Monmouth Park race track today. The Colleen was run in two divisions, with Incidentally beating eight others in the first half, and Lady Bouncer beating ten opponents in her section.
HOUSTON, Tex., July 4 -- Scenes reminiscent of the depression Thirties, when drought transformed huge areas into "dust bowls," are visible again in the Southwest.

WIDESPREAD adoption of more aggressive programs to overcome the increasing complexities of highway problems resulting from the increase in traffic volume was urged for members of the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators by Don McClaugherty, president of the organization.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- It was one step forward, one backward for the Giants today as Manager Leo Durocher's men came staggering to the July Fourth mark far removed from the National League's pennant contention.
