In your issue of June 26 you publish a letter from Bertrand Russell, who accuses you of seeming to maintain "that one should always obey the law, however bad." He adds he cannot think you have realized the implications of this position.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- While the Eisenhower Administration was in office for almost half of the 1953 fiscal year, few if any neutral experts are inclined to assign responsibility to it for the record peacetime deficit that the Government ran up in the twelve-month period.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., July 5 -- Mrs. Jackie Pung, the chunky Hawaiian-bred long-hitting star who broke into the spotlight last year by winning the United States amateur golf crown, gained her first major professional victory today.

Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market moved within a narrow trading range last week. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange last Friday active contracts were only 20 cents a bale higher to 40 cents a bale lower than a week earlier.

LOS ANGELES, July 5 (AP) -- The Morning Star, skippered by Richard Rheem of San Francisco, took a twenty-mile lead over her nearest competitor today in the first full day of the Los Angeles-to-Honolulu yacht race.
CAMDEN, N. J., July 5 -- Firemen today examined the smoking ruins of Camden Convention Hall to find a clue to the cause of a general alarm fire than wrecked the block-long building yesterday.

Though the school buildings have just closed their doors and happy throngs of children are headed for country holidays, we show three back-to-school patterns today. They are a part of the Patterns of The Times American Designer Series.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 5 -- The hum of lathes and boring machines at Mechanical Products, Inc., of Hadera sounded more than usually sweet today to six Americans and one South African, who run the plant, for their accounting department had reported that they had ended their first fiscal year in Israel "in the black."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 5 -- Barbara Friedemann of Larchmont and Nancy Jane Imboden of Bronxville captured the horsemanship championships of the twenty-eighth Harrison horse show today as junior riders participated in a thirty-four-class program at the Kentucky Riding Stable.

HOUSTON -- Texas cookery has been described by one authority on fods as "a political-social-gastronomical hodgepodge." The state has been under six flags -- those of France, Spain, Mexico, the Republic of Texas, the Confederate States of America and the United States.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 5 -- The appointment of Dr. Emil Artin, mathematician, and Dr. Hadley Cantril, psychologist, to two of Princeton University's oldest endowed chairs was announced today by Dr. J. Douglas Brown, dean of the faculty.
The major United States scheduled airlines operating trans-Atlantic flights estimate that slightly more than a third of the persons traveling between New York and Europe this year will go by air.

LONDON, July 5 -- A new system of identification for civil aircraft flying to the East Coast of the United States has gone into effect here by agreement of the major airlines flying the trans-Atlantic route. Since Wednesday pilots have received sealed envelopes, along with their flight plans, at their last take-off-point before their arrival in the United States.

ZURICH, July 5 -- Reports published in New York that the Senate Appropriations Committee had heard Mutual Security Administrator Harold E. Stassen, United States Ambassador to Austria, Llewelyn E. Thompson and others on alleged misuse of United States aid to Austria has aroused great indignation in Switzerland.

VIENNA, July 5 (AP) -- Meanwhile, it was learned that Communist Bulgaria had legalized forced labor. The country's leaders have enacted a law whereby a Bulgarian worker who leaves his job without permission by his manager, and a young apprentice who quits his professional school, face imprisonment and heavy fines.
Certain recent public opinion polls, it was noted here last week, have revealed the existence of an impression that the contemporary level of corporate profits is higher than it ought to be.

Except for the usual hazards of bellowing buses and snarling taxicabs there is something quite orderly about driving an automobile in Manhattan. As the motorist progresses from the East Side to the West Side of the island the numerical designations of the avenues increase, and the same simple pattern is followed in the numbering of the streets northward from First Street, about a mile above the Battery.

The National City Bank of New York has leased the entire ground floor and basement space in the twenty-two-story air-conditioned office building to be erected at 1430 Broadway, on the site of the old Empire Theatre at the corner of Fortieth Street.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, July 6 (AP) -- The tail of a typhoon from the Philippines curled around Korea today and virtually rained out the war, pelting most of the peninsula with at least an inch of rain.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 4 -- A purge campaign has been initiated here against "trashy" literature, aimed directly at comic strips and romance adventures, which appears to have serious anti-Western and even anti-United States overtones.

The Most Rev. Joseph F. Flannelly, Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, declared that besides prayer, reverence must be given to God.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 5 -- The United States concern Morrison-Knudsen International Company, Inc., of San Francisco has been awarded a contract by the Turkish Government to construct a $35,700,000 hydroelectric project in the Seyhan River Valley in southern Turkey.

PARIS, July 5 -- French Socialists in their national congress here today adopted a motion favoring a conference of four or even five powers including Red China, "to achieve a settlement of international problems and restore an atmosphere of peace." Peace in Korea and Indo-China should be the price of admitting Red China, the motion said.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) -- The Red Sox shelled two Athletics pitchers for eight runs in the first inning today and then coasted home behind the six-hit pitching of Lefty Mel Parnell for a 10-2 victory.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 5 (Reuters) -- The Polish press openly acknowledges that there is popular discontent in the country, though sources in touch with Warsaw said here today that Berlin press reports of major disturbances were exaggerated.

DALLAS, Tex., July 5 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas, said tonight President Eisenhower had needed Democratic help for his program. Senator Johnson described the Republican party as "an albatross around his neck."

HARTFORD, July 5 -- The Connecticut Public Expenditure Council, a privately financed organization that acts as a "watchdog" on state expenditures, declared last week that Connecticut's taxpayers "have every reason to feel that a halt must be called on the increasing cost of government."
DALLAS, Tex., July 5 (UP) -- Texans prayed in their churches and fields today for rain to end a month drought that has brought the cattle industry to the brink of disaster.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Republican leaders of Congress will come to grips this week with a series of major problems, involving both the domestic economy and world relations, that must be decided promptly if the scheduled July 31 adjournment is to be achieved.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Recent declines in farm prices, particularly grains, have brought complaints from some farmers and farm-state Congressmen that the Government's price support program is a failure.

A United Press survey made public yesterday shows the comparative helplessness of that perennial gambler, the farmer, even in these days of scientific agriculture: drought in the Southwest and in parts of the Middle West and East; army worms ranging from West Virginia to Nebraska; grasshoppers in Colorado; late frosts in West Virginia; too much water in some areas, too little water in others.

In your issue of June 23 C. L. Sulzberger reported very interestingly about Hungary's present economic situation. Much as I agree with many of his conclusions, I should like to direct your attention to a passage which, in my opinion, does not stand close scrutiny.

VIENNA, July 5 -- Because rioting Czechoslovak workers in Pilsen tore down pictures of the late President Klement Gottwald and Stalin during the disturbances that greeted the devaluation of Czech currency at the beginning of June, Communists removed the statue of Thomas Masaryk, founder of Czechoslovakia.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 5 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon, in a Battle of Gettysburg commemorative speech here tonight, called on all Americans to "learn what the Communists advocate."

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the period of June 27 through July 3 are given in the appended tabulation:

LONDON, 5 -- A decided rally in gilt-edged stocks in the past few days has helped to restore a more confident tone to the stock markets generally. Apart, however, from increased activity in gilt-edged securities, the markets as a whole have remained idle as a result of the usual summer ebbing of business, added to which nothing has occurred recently to dispel or diminish the general uncertainty and obscurity that surrounds business prospects.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- A London court refused recently to allow funds for a fresh biography of Victoria Woodhull, early United States feminist, later Mrs. John Biddulph Martin, wife of a London banker, but Library of Congress shelves already are rich in the Woodhull lore.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- Officials of four big oil companies go before a House investigating committee tomorrow to answer charges that they engaged in "collusion" to force recent "unwarranted" gas and oil price increases.

BOSTON, July 5 -- More than 20,000 persons tonight gathered on the banks of the Charles River under a starry sky to hear the opening program of the twenty-fifth annual Esplanade Concert series. They brought to more than 6,000,000 the number of Bostonians and summer visitors who have attended the outdoor symphonic concerts, which began July 4, 1929.

OMAHA, July 5 (AP) -- Masten Gregory of Kansas City, driving his second major race, roared across the finish line first today in the 201-mile feature event of the national sports car races at the Offutt Air Force Base.

Customer advisers are needed in department stores to supplement sales personnel, according to a study by students of the City College School of Business and Civic Administration. Despite sales training programs, a shopping survey of men's furnishings' sales personnel showed, the department stores are not up to the service level of the specialty outlets.

Vision defects serious enough to create road hazards were registered by one-fifth of 8,000 motorists who were tested recently by the Greater New York Safety Council. The results of the tests were made known yesterday by Norman Olman, director of the council's street and highway safety division.

The National Community Relations Advisory Council, the coordinating body for six major Jewish organizations and thirty local Jewish community councils, urged yesterday the exclusion from the United States of Nazis, Fascists and Communists "with equal rigor" under terms of the bill pending in Congress for the admission of 240,000 refugees and displaced persons.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that record high cattle slaughter, due in part to stepped - up marketings from drought-hit Southern states, would increase annual beef consumption to all-time highs in 1953.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., July 5 -- A spectacular rally helped Claude Harmon of the Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N. Y., to defeat Bill Nary of Kansas City in the Professional Golfers Association championship at the Birmingham Country Club course today and carried him into the semi-final round.

While contemplating the anniversary of this country's physical independence, the Rev. Dr. Ralph Walker urged consideration yesterday of another kind of independence -- that of the spirit and how it was exemplified in the life of "the greatest independent, Jesus Christ."

NEWARK, July 5 -- Three men tied up the night watchman at the Seaboard Freight Lines terminal here early this morning and made off with a five-ton truck containing 880 cases of whisky. The value of the cargo was estimated at $60,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 5 -- A man described as a fugitive from a mental institution in New York was arrested heretoday after he had attempted, the police said, to hold up a cashier in the Tray-more Hotel on the Boardwalk with a toy pistol.

TOKYO, July 5 -- The announced determination of President Syngman Rhee to carry on the war in Korea alone should the United Nations sign an armistice with the Communists that is unacceptable to the South Korean Republic may cause the most complicated military situation of modern war, competent observers here believe.
COLOGNE, Germany, July 5 (AP) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today that "communism is on the march everywhere" and that Germany would face deep misery unless it allied itself with the West.

BERLIN, July 5 Premier Otto Grotewohl of East Germany, in a statement published today, promised the peasants lower crop quotas and other concessions. He indicated that the Government was concerned about the loyalty of the rural population as well as that of industrial workers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 5 -- Religious organizations throughout the United States have opened a drive to get Congress to save the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund from financial collapse.

MILWAUKEE, July 5 (AP) -- Red Schoendienst's pinch-hit home run with two on in the sixth inning gave the Cardinals a 4-1 triumph over Milwaukee in the second game of a double-header halted by darkness at the end of eight innings today after the Braves had won the opener, 4 -- 0.

East Germany is no longer alone as a repentant Communist state, for the turnabout in Hungary this past weekend is in some ways even more astounding. The new Budapest regime headed by Premier Nagy has declared in effect that the whole Communist economic policy hitherto pursued was a mistake and a failure.

In his recent letter, Daniel James, managing editor of The New Leader, describes himself as "a militant supporter of T.V.A." and pays it tribute for its "demonstration that electric power can be made available at rates much lower than those set by the utility lobby." The quite easier demonstration is that this statement is completely erroneous and misleading.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 -- Former President Herbert Hoover told a press conference here today that he felt relations with "the whole, boiling Asian continent" represents America's most vital current problem.

JERICHO, Jordan, June 22 -- In the shimmering, red desert of the Jordan River Valley, at 300 feet below sea level, where the salty land of the plain is officially registered as "dead and waste" and the bare mountains round about are blackened, as if by the blazing sun, lies a flourishing green plantation that promises to give the whole valley a new life.

WHEN Alfred Noyes was a 21-year-old Oxford undergraduate his first volume of poems was published. When he was 24 he of wrote one of the most famous English poems of the twentieth century, "The Highwayman." Since then he has written some thirty other books -- poetry, criticism, novels, short stories, essays and biography.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Sixteen players, chosen by nearly 4,500,000 fans in a world-wide poll, were named today for the twentieth annual big league all-star game at Cincinnati's Crosley Field on July 14.

This article is dedicated to those who, in planning their picnics this last week-end, remembered the lunch, the ice, the drinks, the barbeque grill, the cushions, the portable radio, the suntan lotions and the insect repellents -- but forgot the can opener.
The body of a 32-year-old truck driver, victim of a slaying of the gangster type, was thrown from an automobile yesterday afternoon at an intersection in the East Bronx in view of four persons.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 5 -- The stock exchange here has displayed great strength and activity in the last few weeks. In one week the general stock average rose from 150.67 to 154.12, compared with 138.72 early in the year.

SIEMREAP, Cambodia, July 2 -- King Norodom Sihanouk and his entourage here give every indication of being determined not to yield in the campaign that the King has launched for the complete independence of Cambodia.

The buying power of American workers' wages can be expected to increase at the rate of 2.5 to 3 per cent a year in the next decade or two, according to a study of wages and employment trends to be issued later this month by the Twentieth Century Fund. The fund is a non-profit foundation for economic and social research.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 5 -- The stock exchange here has displayed great strength and activity in the last few weeks. In one week the general stock average rose from 150.67 to 154.12, compared with 138.72 early in the year.

SIEMREAP, Cambodia, July 2 -- King Norodom Sihanouk and his entourage here give every indication of being determined not to yield in the campaign that the King has launched for the complete independence of Cambodia.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Senator William F. Knowland, the acting Republican leader of the upper house, blamed the Truman and Eisenhower Administrations today for the "breach" with Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of South Korea.

NEW DELHI, India, July 5 -- The suggestion of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru for a quick United Nations meeting on the Korea problem was endorsed by the Executive Committee of his ruling Congress party today. The resolution sharply scored the release by South Korea's President Syngman Rhee of anti-Communist North Korean prisoners and his subsequent demands upon the United Nations command.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., July 5 -- Of the 200,000 sight-seers who visit this historic city each year, only about 1 per cent crosses the ochre-colored Rappahannock River to view the site of the three most popular legends concerning the childhood of George Washington.

LONDON, July 5 -- After thirteen years of smiling at the butcher in the hope that he would grant her a decent cut and of being told by the Government what meat she could and could not buy, the British houseswife has begun to reverse the roles.

It will take men of determination and sincerity to save the Children's Fund of the United Nations from disaster. On June 5 the Bureau of the Budget directed the House Appropriations Committee to reconsider the appropriation of $9,800,000 to the Fund -- an appropriation pledged last year by the Truman Administration, supported by the Eisenhower Administration and yet to be acted on by Congress.

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it would file a brief today with the United Nations Administrative Tribunal on behalf of twenty United States citizens dismissed from employment with the world organization by Trygve Lie, former Secretary General.

Two campaigns for the direct sales of fabrics were announced over the week-end. Indian Head Mills, Inc., will merchandise for over-the-counter sale a line of piece-dyed and solution-dyed solid-color acetate taffetas under the Indian Head trade mark.

DUBLIN, July 5 -- Two United States Air Force officers have been stationed at Shannon Airport to brief trans-Atlantic aircraft when Shannon is their last port of call before entering the United States on the T. O. M. C. I. S. procedure.

CATSKILL, N. Y., July 5 -- On the lush green uplands north, south and west of here, New York City high school boys are learning how much work goes into the containers of milk they buy at the store back home.
OTOCAC, Yugoslavia, July 5 (AP) -- Vice President Edvard Kardelj said today, "We are ready" for normal relations with the Soviet Union, but warned that Yugoslavia must guard against future betrayal.

The Military Sea Transport Service, Atlantic Area, is using shipboard recruiting, radio-wireless and other techniques to increase the participation of its officers and men in the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

NEWARK, July 5 -- A four-alarm blaze late this afternoon destroyed the interior of St. Bridget's Roman Catholic Church on Plane Street near William Street, in downtown Newark. The adjoining convent, school and rectory were damaged extensively before the blaze was brought under control in a forty-five-minute fight by firemen.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 5 -- Forest Service planes were busy today flying out some of the vacationers who were stranded in the roadless area of Superior National Forest by Federal enforcement of a ban on private airplane service to the wilderness resorts.
Six new films, including an importation from Russia, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Congratulations are in order for Dr. Albert W. Dent, president of Dillard University, on his election to the presidency of the National Health Council. Dr. Dent, the first Negro in the history of the organization to head the thirty-two-year-old council, is an experienced and successful administrator in the field of health services.

HAMPTON, Va., July 5 -- W. Curtis Martens, a veteran of this regatta-mad tidewater peninsula, which has so many rivers, creeks, bays and roadsteads that nearly every boy and most of the girls learn boating in their toddling days, late this afternoon won the Virginia Cup.

PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP) -- Robin Roberts, aiding his cause with a two-out double in the tenth inning, stopped the Pirates, 2-0, today for the Phillies in the first game of a double-header for his thirteenth victory of the season.
LONDON, July 5 (AP) -- The Moscow radio said tonight that Soviet surgeons were making great strides in curing heart ailments.

ALBANY, July 6 -- The use of a "camera eye" as part of a complex toll-collecting system that will assure the New York State Thruway Authority of the revenue to which it is entitled was described here today by Holden A. Evans Jr., executive assistant to Bertram D. Tallamy, chairman of the agency that will operate the superhighway.

PARIS, July 6 -- The word NEP has a very special significance in the vocabulary of communism. It refers to the New Economic Policy introduced in the Soviet Union by Lenin when, in 1921, the Bolshevik Revolution ran into critical difficulty.

HADLEY, N. Y., July 6 -- Two residents of Queens drowned in the Hudson River near here last evening in an unexplained manner. The victims were Albert Gurra, 27 years old, and Joseph Iadanza, 14, both of 127-19 Ninety-fifth Avenue, Richmond Hill.

The problems of a newly married couple who must share their home with in-laws differ considerably from those of a mature pair in a similar situation. Although certain factors may apply in any case where families "double up," specific difficulties or satisfactions may very well depend on the timing of the move.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 -- With the arrival today from Kansas City of Art Schallock, whom the Yankees recalled from the Blues, Ewell (The Whip) Blackwell, was placed on the voluntarily retired list. The 30-year-old righthander returned to New York this afternoon and will head for his home at Tampa, Fla.

The captain of a Brazilian freighter that collided with the American tanker Gulftrade June 28 off New Jersey testified yesterday that the tanker crew had violated the law of the sea by leaving the scene without his permission.

Leaders of Vietnam and Laos, two of the three Associated States of Indo-China, have taken a heartening view of the French offer of further discussion to broaden the base of independence for the three states. They have supported the French position and welcomed such negotiation. This is the way to progress.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 6 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations urged President Eisenhower today immediately to take the initiative to aid the workers of Soviet-occupied Germany in their struggle against Soviet totalitarianism.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Tom Lyon wants to quit his post with the Defense Materials Procurement Agency, reportedly because he is "discouraged and disgusted" by the events that led to withdrawal of his nomination to be Bureau of Mines Director.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Spending for new construction reached the highest level in history in the first half Of 1953, Government agencies estimated today.

Arbitration under labor-management agreements is an extension of collective bargaining. It is a useful tool and is provided for in most contracts. Of late, however, agreements to arbitrate have been challenged in the courts, which have, at times, defined the scope of arbitration and ruled on the merits of the issues in arbitration.

The Sales Executives Club of New York issued some startling figures yesterday on the cost of salesmen's calls and how they are reduced by advertising. They are the result of a national survey by its weekly publication, the New York Sales Executive, covering a cross section of 1,018 manufacturers in the industrial field.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 6 -- More than pleased with early box-office returns on "The Charge at Feather River," Warner Brothers is retaining the services of its star, Guy Madison, for another feature. The studio wants him to report for "Rear Guard," another buckskin saga that will utilize the all-media Warner camera -- 3-D, wide screen, color and stereophonic sound.

The State of New York won its long legal fight yesterday to collect on the $50,000 fine imposed in 1932 against Russell T. Sherwood, financial agent for the late Mayor James J. Walker, when Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg directed the accountant's brokerage firm to turn over to the sheriff $36,826 in Sherwood's account.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 7 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President, and Walter S. Robertson, United States Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, were scheduled to continue today their talks on a Korean armistice.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., July 6 (UP) -- The schooner Goodwill, largest boat in the trans-Pacific yacht race to Hawaii, today took the lead 405 miles out from the start at San Pedro, the United States Coast Guard escort craft, Yocona, reported by radio.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 7 (AP) -- The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia declared today that the Communist party had "crushed" all members who tried-to sow dissension and subvert the unity of the party.
LOS ANGELES, July 6 -- The longest run in the history of the theatre, a production of the old melodrama "The Drunkard" at the Theatre Mart here, began its twenty-first year tonight.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 6 -- Opposing counsel conferred today to set a time to ask United States District Judge James Alger Fee when he would hear arguments on damages for which the jurist last week ruled fifty-four railroad companies and motor carriers were liable as the result of a six-month strike against Montgomery Ward Co. here.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower may appoint Vice President Richard M. Nixon to be chairman of a revived Government contract compliance committee to curb employment discrimination.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 6 (Reuters) -- Reports on the Nanga Parbat expedition named only Herman Buhl as conquering the summit. Earlier messages had said two or three climbers would attempt the final assault.

In your recent stimulating and thought-provoking editorial on "The Bricker Amendment" you point out that it is just a committee of the Senate, that is to say, the Senate Judiciary Committee, which, by a 9-to-5 vote, has reported favorably to the Senate as a whole on the revised Bricker resolution.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 6 -- Tacitly the official rate of 1.8 Israeli for $1 became the basis for most international trading here after the banks yesterday began collecting premiums of .8 Israeli for $1 on foreign currency releases for other than special categories of imports.

JACKSON, Miss., July 6 (AP) -- A United States district court judge ruled today that Mary Cain, Mississippi newspaper woman, must pay Social Security taxes as a self-employed person. The judge's decision was in effect a ruling on the constitutionality of the Social Security law since that was Mrs. Cain's contention in refusing to pay.

The building of three United States air bases in French Morocco by Atlas Constructors, a five-company combine, is likely to be changed from a cost-plus-fixed fee basis to a fixed-fee or flat sum basis, it was said yesterday.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 6 -- The preparation of independent peoples for self-government is a primary responsibility of the free world. Sir Roger Makins, the British Ambassador to the United States, asserted in an address here tonight.

In a recent letter Robert Payson Hill complained that his tour of duty in Municipal Court was "a saddening and embittering experience." Others who have served will be inclined to agree with his protest about the lack of ash trays in the jurors' assembly room, the insanitary condition of the washrooms, etc. It is to be hoped that his well-reasoned protest will bring some reform.
Red Cross bloodmobile units will make three visits in the New York area today.

A theatrical announcement of double significance was made yesterday by Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of directors of the New York City Center of Music and Drama. There will be a special drama season next fall at the City Center, the civic project that is hard-pressed for funds, and Jose Ferrer, who inaugurated the Center's season of plays in 1948, will direct it, according to Mr. Morris.

BURBANK, Calif., July 6 -- Two foreign airlines have become the first commercial companies in the world to take delivery of Super Constellations equipped with turbo-compound engines, the airliners that may be the United States' answer to the production of turbo-jet and turbo-prop-powered transports in Great Britain.

Surely a time has come when the people of New York City can reasonably ask, without being accused of impatience, that the City Planning Commission conclude its prolonged study and produce a new zoning resolution.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 6 (AP) -- Casanova, owned by Craig's Cimarron Ranch of LeMoore, Calif., overtook the pace-setting Taylor Direct tonight to win the Montauk Pace by a length at Roosevelt Raceway. Mighty Grattan was third.

NEW DELHI, India, July 6 -- A German and Austrian mountaineering team has climbed previously unconquered Nanga Parbat, highest peak next to Everest to be scaled by man, according to news dispatches tonight from Lahore, Pakistan.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 7 (AP) -- United Nations Command Communique 1,668, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

An increase in the minimum starting salary for nurses has been approved by Roosevelt Hospital and Lenox Hill Hospital to give beginners $250 a month instead of the present $225. A correlative increase will give some nurses working on private duty here $13 a day, a rise of $1.
The United States liner United States docks here today, rounding out one year of shipshape operation since she proved herself the fastest ship afloat on her maiden voyage across the North Atlantic.
The City Housing Authority offers a grand gesture to private real estate firms by offering them a public housing project to manage to see whether they can do it cheaper.
BUENOS AIRES, July 6 -- President Carlos Iba+/-ez del Campo of Chile arrived by air this afternoon for a six-day visit during which he will sign a trade agreement.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Ted Lepcio's pinch-single, with one out in the ninth inning, scored Jim Piersall from second base to give the Red Sox a 2-1 victory over Washington tonight. Ivan Delock, making his first start of the season, edged Tommy Byrne in a mound duel, although the Senators' left-hander struck out ten, fanning Hoot Evers four times.

Reporting for a two-week training cruise on the Atlantic, Gov. John Davis Lodge of Connecticut, a Naval Reserve commander, boarded the light cruiser Roanoke yesterday at Pier 26, Beach Street and the Hudson River. The Governor said he was "looking forward" to the cruise because he had become "kind of rusty in this type of navigation," not having been aboard a ship for seven years.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 6 (AP) -- The Harry S. Trumans, tourists from Independence, Mo., visited Ohio's capital today.

The policy committee of the Liberal party will meet at 5 P. M. Thursday to discuss its recommendations for candidates for President of the City Council and Controller to fill out the party's city-wide slate. Before the meeting party leaders will confer on possible candidates for the two offices with City Council President Rudolph Halley, who was endorsed for Mayor at a party convention last Tuesday.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 6 -- After studying the French note delivered last Friday to each of the three states of Indo-China, the Vietnam Government accepted it today as a promise of full independence.

Toronto sends word that its subway, which will be open for business late this year, is expected to be the quietest on or under earth. This news should put New York, which is, after all, the very center of the cultural and industrial world, to sheerest, shame.

Coffee prices opened with gains of 200 points, the limit for the day, over last Friday's close on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. The sharp rise reflected cables from Brazil reporting that heavy frosts on Saturday and Sunday nights, particularly in the southern areas, had damaged the crop. The Parana area was severely affected.

HARTFORD, July 6 -- Connecticut Republican leaders disclosed today that they had "cleared" John A. Danaher of West Hartford, former United States Senator from this state, for an appointment to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy today heard experts debate the merits of approaching the production of industrial atomic power through the construction of one large experimental plant as opposed to a series of smaller ones of differing design.

GENEVA, July 6 -- European economists are tying together two current news items from the United States and discovering some implications about trends in United States foreign economic policy that are, to say the least, somewhat disturbing to them.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Government's psychological strategy program for the "cold war," long afflicted by organizational and leadership problems, suffered another break in its continuity today with the resignation of Dr. Robert L. Johnson, administrator of the State Department's information activities.

Wall Street's customers spent another day lolling in the economic hammock yesterday, with the result that the market did virtually nothing. Volume shrank to 820,000 shares -- third lowest of the year -- and market movement was all but imperceptible.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Army's program to maintain a ready reserve of trained men made up of former draftees is falling flat.

Al Capp, cartoonist and humorist, will be the moderator of an audience-participation show to be presented on the C. B. S.-TV network on alternate Tuesdays from 9 to 9:30 P. M., starting next week. "Anyone Can Win" is the program's title, and members of the studio audiences will have opportunities to win prizes.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Administration announced a plan today to carry forward the "broad industrial mobilization base" fostered by the Truman Administration, but it emphasized that the filling of "gaps" in the nation's defense set-up would be "highly selective."

Huntsmen and riders, from antiquity to modern times, inspired the elegantly sophisticated fall collection of hats designed by Adolfo for Emme, shown yesterday at a preview luncheon in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

In the superheated atmosphere of Flatbush Court, which distinctly is not air conditioned, Magistrate Albert D. Schanzer held yesterday that the noise of room air conditioners constituted a profound question that must be settled by the highest courts.
ST. LOUIS, July 6 (AP) -- President Will Harridge of the American League fined Clint Courtney, Browns' catcher, $100 and suggested he improve his manners, the St. Louis club disclosed today.

BERLIN, July 6 -- For the third time since the Russians imposed martial law in East Berlin during the June 17 riots there the British and United States commandants in the Western sectors asked their Soviet counterpart today to lift travel restrictions between the two parts of the city.

LONDON, July 6 -- High class industrial equities, especially textile and heavy engineering issues, were in demand on the stock market here today and many gains of one shilling (fourteen cents) or more were recorded in a wide selection.

The Maryland State Roads Commission announced yesterday plans for offering on July 21 an issue of $25,000,000 of state highway construction bonds. Dated Aug. 1, 1953, the bonds will come due Aug. 1, 1954 to 1968.

ALTHOUGH the meager financial rewards of writing fiction have been well publicized, the desire to write it multiplies. Writing courses are offered by nearly all our colleges and universities. Scores of writers' conferences are held every summer. Correspondence schools and writers' magazines assure literary novices that they have valuable advice to offer.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Four members of the House of Representatives advocated statehood for Hawaii today but another, Representative John R. Pillion, Republican of upstate New York, said it would open the door to two United States Senators who possibly could be "Soviet agents."

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The far-reaching and controversial nature of the major Administration proposals on which the Eighty-third Congress has not yet acted tends to obscure the amount of secondary legislation, most of it within the bounds set by the President, that was passed at this session by June 25.

PARIS, July 6 -- The leaders of two of the three states of Indo-China -- Vietnam and Laos -- replied today, welcoming the French Government's invitation to negotiate to bring the existing agreements between France and the states into line with current requirements.
Today's column deals with reader letters, among them several from cooks with baking problems. Popovers that do not "pop" bothered two cooks. Mrs. R. A. M. of New York City writes:

Construction work in the city was reported yesterday to be seriously slowed down by a strike of Local 252, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., which has stopped deliveries of sand, gravel and mixed cement.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Representative Charles A. Wolverton, Republican of New Jersey, chairman of a House inquiry committee told the nation's oil companies today that their recent price rises might lead to tighter restrictions on the 27 1/2 per cent tax reduction allowed for depreciation of oil reserves.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, today accused Representative John Taber, Republican of upstate New York, of making "bitter and inaccurate attacks" against the Air Force and Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, who retired last week as its Chief of Staff.

Net sales of the Fedders-Quigan Corporation in the third quarter of its fiscal year, totaling $18,426,629, almost equaled those for the entire preceding sex-month period, bringing the volume for the nine months to last May 30 to $37,433,574.
SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 61 (AP) -- The Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament gets under way tomorrow, but its strictly a Vic Seixas affair so far as the fans are concerned.

Six high officials of a union that has been readmitted to the Congress of Industrial Organizations in New York after being expelled for alleged Communist affiliations refused yesterday to tell the House Un-American Activities subcommittee whether they were Communists.

ROME, July 6 -- The anti-Communist riots in East Berlin were as significant as anything that has happened in the world since the end of World War II, Adlai E. Stevenson said today during a news conference. Whether they will prove to be "contagious" depends on the forces of suppression, he added, but said his personal guess was that they would be "highly contagious."

Columbia University opened its fifty-fourth summer session yesterday as 11,000 students attended classes to begin six-week courses. Final enrollment figures are not yet available, with late registration scheduled to continue through Friday.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 -- Representative Condon was elected to the House last November after serving two terms in the state Legislature.

There is much more going on qualitatively as well as quantitatively in architecture here than in England, according to Nikolaus Pevsner, English art historian, writer on architecture and design and Slade Professor at Cambridge University who has just been made a Commander of the Order of the British Empire.

Exactly one hundred years ago today ten small railroad companies merged to organize the now vast system of the New York Central Railroad. The newly formed railroad with its 154 wood-burning locomotives soon outgrew its infancy. Within eight years of its founding it was servicing the greater part of New York State.

NEW DELHI, India, July 6 -- India will back the fight of colonial peoples, and colored races throughout the world for equality by every means "short of war" or the sending of arms, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today. He was addressing the All-India Congress Committee, supreme policy making body of the ruling party which he heads, and therefore his speech can be taken as the keynote of India's official viewpoint.
Leo Durocher and his unpredictable Giants apparently haven't yet exhausted their supply of surprises.
STILLWATER, Okla., July 6 (AP) -- A recognized authority said today that tornadoes now could be identified and tracked across the skies -- and a thirty-minute warning given before they struck.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower, back from his Fourth of July week-end in the Catoctin Mountains of Maryland got down to "a lot of staff work" this morning and rearranged his White House organization in an effort to improve liaison with Federal agencies.

Louis Rosoff has sold the Villa Victbria Apartments at 2475 Palisade Aenue, the Bronx, to Geller Mitchell The six-story building is an irregular plot about 9B by 160 feet. It was sold through Pearce, ayer Greet as brokers. The property has an assessed valuation of $165,000, of which $39,000 represents land value.

LONDON, July 6 -- Nearly 30 per cent of the posts occupied by Americans at the United States Embassy in London have been abolished and the prospect of dismissal for a large, but as yet undetermined, number of employes is said to be creating morale and operational problems.

An account of Robert Louis Stevenson's last six years of life will be published Aug. 10 by Hastings House, entitled "Tusitala of the South Seas." Written by Joseph W. Ellison, Professor of History at Oregon State College, the book describes Stevenson's search for health among the islands of the South Pacific and of his final settling on Upolu, where he ruled as laird of a clan of native retainers in Stuart tartans.

Yesterday morning, in honor of their second birthday, Fred of John Frederics gave his "Charmers" a special coming out party. The charmers, as is well known by now, are chic little hats geared to youthful faces and budgeted pocket books.

ROME, July 6 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi ended late this evening the consultations with leaders of all political parties represented in Parliament that he undertook last Friday when President Luigi Einaudi offered him the task of forming a new Government.
Tens of thousands of New Yorkers, among the millions who had left the city over the Fourth of July week-end, were missing yesterday when the rest of the population resumed workaday routines.
The cotton futures market closed steady yesterday 16 to 29 points higher than on last Friday, with trading on the New York Cotton Exchange somewhat more active than it has been in recent sessions.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Pan American World Airways today proposed non-stop air service from Tokyo to Seattle, or Portland, Ore., during the winter months when the "jet-stream" is blowing.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would offer to buy cottonseed products from processors to support grower prices of 1953-crop cottonseed, but its payments will average lower than those under a similar program last year.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- The Senate today approved, by voice, a one-year extension of the program under which Mexican farm workers are brought over the border to assist in harvesting crops in this country.

PUSAN, Korea, Tuesday, July 7 (AP) -- The 14,000-ton American freighter Cornhusker Mariner, with forty-five crew members aboard, went aground outside the Pusan breakwater early today and was reported in danger of breaking up.

The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation has completed the purchase of a number of hydro-electric power sites and properties of the Eastern New York Power Corporation and the International Hydro-Electric System, it was announced yesterday by Earl J. Machold, president of Niagara Mohawk.

Terms of the deal under which the Stanley Warner Corporation acquired rights to produce films in the Cinerama wide-screen process as well as to open, equip and operate theatres to show those motion pictures, were announced yesterday by the company.

The New York Transit Authority decided yesterday to acquire 220 more subway cars at a cost of $20,200,000 to provide increased service after the completion next year of improvements to the rapid transit lines in Brooklyn and Queens.

The Prudential and Playhouses Operating Company, headed by Joseph M. Seider, has purchased the 900-car Fifth Avenue drive-in theatre in Bay Shore, L. I., in a sale negotiated by Berk Krumgold, brokers. The seller, Michael Redstone of Boston, Mass., built the theatre last year.

VIRTUALLY all anglers will admit that the offshore fishing season has been launched officially. With school tuna now spread out from New Jersey to Massachusetts, and the first giant tuna, a 750-pounder, brought in from Rhode Island waters, the deep-water possibilities are many and varied.
PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- Belting their Pittsburgh "cousins," the Pirates, for fifteen hits, including three home runs, the Dodgers tonight won easily, 14 -- 2, before 13,497 at Forbes Field.

A college dog might legitimately feel a bit above guarding a grocery store, but that is the only job that Joseph Eufemia of 23-05 Fortieth Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, has to offer Duke, his 22-month-old German shepherd. Mr. Eufemia feels the dog should knuckle down and obey orders.

Business was booming yesterday in the make-believe store in a classroom at Public School 169, where some city children will spend much time this summer. Similar scenes were staged on other floors of the building at Audubon Avenue and 168th Street and in twenty-four other centers maintained by the Play Schools Association in all five boroughs in cooperation with the Board of Education.
Should the New York Stock Exchange continue any longer the ban that it instituted in 1926 on listing corporation common stocks not privileged with full voting rights?
The Dewey Administration was charged yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. with "adding a $2,500,000 utility steal to the multimillion dollar rent and fare grab."

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, today served, notice on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, that more reprints of his speech on "Creeping McCarthyism" were being prepared to meet a demand that took all the first printing of 20,000 copies.

The Chase National Bank of New York reported in its midyear condition statement yesterday declines in deposits and resources from the levels of March 31 and of June 30 a year ago. Loans, which were moderately under those of three months ago, were substantially higher than last year.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, Postmaster General, said here today that within sixty days tests would be made to determine the feasibility of sending all first-class mail between New York City and Chicago by plane.

The July 4 holiday, vacations and hot weather combined last week to depress steel production. For the fifth consecutive week output of domestic mills fell below theoretical capacity. The industry's actual operating rate was 91.8 per cent, or 4.3 points below the preliminary estimate at the start of the week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Tom Fool is, of a certainty, approaching the status of equine greatness. Weight is the touchstone of a horse's considered capabilities, and handicapper John B. Campbell thinks so much of the Greentree Stable's 4-year-old that yesterday he assigned a burden 136 pounds to Tom Fool for the $50,000 added Brooklyn Handicap.

United States exports and imports of goods and service excluding military aid items -- will come close to an even balance for 1953, according to a mid-year revision of January estimates announced yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council's balance-of-payments group.

ST. LOUIS, July 6 (AP) -- Ray Boone's eighth home run of the year broke up a 7-7 tie in the eleventh inning tonight and enabled the Tigers to gain an 8-7 decision over the Browns as they moved to within 4 percentage points of seventh-place St. Louis.
Jack W. Gleeson has been appointed director of business management of the Chrysler division of Chrysler Corporation.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated James H. Smith Jr. of Colorado, an aviation executive, to be Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air.
Bungling burglars broke into seven business establishments over the Fourth of July week-end but the loot they got was hardly comparable to their time and effort.

MADRID, July 6 -- The Spanish employer who deliberately underpays his workers is a "great supporter of communism" and responsible for the anti-religious feeling that may be caused by that social injustice, according to Archbishop Marcellino Olaechea Loizaga of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Valencia.

NEWARK, July 6 -- Veto by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of a bill that would reduce the size of lettering of the words "non-fat" or "skimmed" on milk containers was urged today by Carl Holderman, president of the New Jersey State Council, C. I. O.

SIEMREAP, Cambodia, July 3 -- Demands that King Norodom Sihanouk is making here for changes in the status of Cambodia are aimed not only at full Cambodian independence in its relations with France but also at the accords that link the three Indo-Chinese states of Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam, and with France as a group.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Wheat futures rallied sharply today, from an early setback of as much as 1 cent but met free selling again on the rally and closed irregular. While oats were relatively steady, corn and soybeans were under pressure, crop reports on them from the major producing sections being extremely optimistic.

The home furnishings industry sank deep into the summer doldrums yesterday. Both buying and attendance at opening of the local summer furniture market were painfully light, and carpet mills and lamp producers offering new lines fared no better.

Formation of a new subsidiary, Avco of Canada, Ltd., for a major expansion and integration of the Canadian interests of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation, was announced here yesterday by Victor Emanuel, Avco chairman and president.
Fourth-quarter sales and earnings are expected to be as favorable this year as last, and in some instances better, according to a majority of 1,281 corporation executives.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The protest of Representative Robert L. Condon, Democrat of California, over being barred as a security risk from the May 5 atomic test at Yucca Flat, Nev. led to the prospect today of twin investigations into the matter.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 6 -- Four brothers of near-by Rahway, one of whom returned recently from combat in Korea, were arraigned before Magistrate John L. McGuire today in what the police termed a revenge slaying Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (Science Service) -- A mixture of mustard gas and oils that can be floated on water as a defense against invaders was patented this week after lying in secret patent office files for twenty-eight years.

Disbarment of Harry Sacher, attorney for some of the eleven convicted Communist leaders, from Federal practice in the Southern District of New York was upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals in a two-to-one decision. The lawyer said he would ask the United States Supreme Court to review the decision.

From Jericho, in the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, word comes to this newspaper that a Jerusalem lawyer named Musa al-Alami has produced a miracle in the wastelands of the lower Jordan River, not far above the Dead Sea. It is not a large miracle, for it covers only 2,000 acres, and these are not enough to save the world, the eastern Mediterranean, or even one small kingdom.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 6 (AP) -- Bobby Locke, Ben Hogan and John Panton were the big show today in the first qualifying round of the British open golf tournament over two wind-swept Carnoustie courses.

Department stores with annual sales of more than $1,000,000 continued to show a nominal improvement in net profit for the first quarter of 1953 with a rise of 1.6 per cent of net sales compared with 1.4 per cent for the same period of 1952, according to a report issued yesterday by the controllers' congress, National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The recent decline in securities prices is reflected in the semi-annual report of the General American Investors Company, Inc., being sent to stockholders today. The statement shows that the trust's net assets in the first six months of this year dropped to $48,236,449, or $23.40 a common share, from $52,467,624, or $25.70 a share, at the 1952 year-end.

CINCINNATI, July 6 -- Seven New York locals of the United Brewery Workers Union, C. I. O., have voted to leave that union and join the Brewery Division of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., their lawyer announced here tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff until Aug. 15, when he will retire, declared today that despite the Communists' homegrown difficulties of the moment he saw no marked change in the long-range threat of the Soviet Union to the peace of the world.

Brazil is prepared to offer to United States private enterprise every practical inducement for help in solving its most important economic problem -- increased output and distribution of food -- Augusto Frederico Schmidt, Brazilian industrialist, declared yesterday.

Development of a millinery style so new and different that it would make "last year's best hat utterly obsolete" was urged yesterday on a group of manufacturers by David Weisberg, president of the Millinery Merchandising Executives Association.

Retailers attending trade shows last month were generally cautious in actual buying for fall, according to Bernard G. Cohn, president of Independent Retailers Syndicate, Inc., a new York resident buying office. In a bulletin to member stores, released yesterday, he said that crowded showrooms last month were not to be considered an indication of buying activity, but rather the result of so many buyers being in the market in the same two-week period.

Three members of a youthful Brooklyn gang, suspected of a $2,500 robbery of the Brooklyn Paramount Theatre yesterday morning and the abduction earlier of the movie-house porter, were arrested by the police last night.

PARIS, July 6 -- Measures proposed by the Cabinet of Joseph Laniel to meet the financial situation encountered trouble tonight in the National Assembly's Finance Committee, which rejected a proposed increase in taxes on petroleum products.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 (AP) -- The Peiping radio charged today that the United States was "brew ing a new scheme to wreck the Korean armistice."
Columbia University's Slavic language department will translate 1,000 pages of current Russian research reports in physics in the coming year under a contract with the National Science Foundation.

CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP) -- Mike Garcia pitched the Indians back into second place tonight by beating the White Sox, 6 -- 3, on a six-hitter that was his tenth victory against five losses. A homer by Al Rosen and three hits by Dale Mitchell, who has a 16-game hitting streak going, paced the 13-hit Tribe attack.

The annual report of the Longines-Wittnauer Watch Company, Inc., revealed yesterday a net profit of $1,060,282, equal to $2.65 a share, for the fiscal year ended on March 31, last. In the preceding fiscal year the net profit was $1,001,908, or $2.50 a share, on the 400,000 shares for both periods.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 6 -- The Communists suffered tonight their most severe setback since the August 1951, anti-Communist round-ups when the outgoing Foreign Minister, Mukarto Notowidigdo of the Nationalist party, handed back his mandate to form a Cabinet to President Sukarno after two futile attempts to resolve the thirty-five-day Cabinet crises.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower gave another of his dinners tonight for persons prominent in various walks of life. There were thirteen guests.

MOSCOW, July 6 -- Pravda, the organ of the Communist party, today called President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles "sowers of discord, anxiety and aggression" and warned the leaders of the United States that their "slanderous fabrication and incendiary appeals" would turn against themselves.

An apology for the "outburst" of a group of members of Manhattan Beach Chapter 105, Disabled American Veterans, before the Board of Estimate on June 25 in connection with Manhattan Beach Housing was sent to Mayor lmpellitteri yesterday by Antoine Kimaid, state commander.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 6 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. John W. O'Daniel, commander of United States land forces in the Pacific, arrived today at Pnompenh, capital of Cambodia. General O'Daniel, who is compiling a report on how United States war supplies sent to Indo-China are being used, will confer with the Cambodian Premier and French and Cambodian officials. He also has asked for a meeting with King Norodom Sihanouk.

The heavy price of the stalemated war in Korea -- the unanswerable emotional argument for a truce -- is well illustrated by recent casualty statistics and by a letter of pride and frustration from a battalion commander in the Eighth Army.

The annual report of the Longines-Wittnauer Watch Company, Inc., revealed yesterday a net profit of $1,060,282, equal to $2.65 a share, for the fiscal year ended on March 31, last. In the preceding fiscal year the net profit was $1,001,908, or $2.50 a share, on the 400,000 shares for both periods.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 6 -- The Communists suffered tonight their most severe setback since the August 1951, anti-Communist round-ups when the outgoing Foreign Minister, Mukarto Notowidigdo of the Nationalist party, handed back his mandate to form a Cabinet to President Sukarno after two futile attempts to resolve the thirty-five-day Cabinet crises.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower gave another of his dinners tonight for persons prominent in various walks of life. There were thirteen guests.

MOSCOW, July 6 -- Pravda, the organ of the Communist party, today called President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles "sowers of discord, anxiety and aggression" and warned the leaders of the United States that their "slanderous fabrication and incendiary appeals" would turn against themselves.

An apology for the "outburst" of a group of members of Manhattan Beach Chapter 105, Disabled American Veterans, before the Board of Estimate on June 25 in connection with Manhattan Beach Housing was sent to Mayor lmpellitteri yesterday by Antoine Kimaid, state commander.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., July 6 -- The Winged Foot team of Mike Souchak, assistant to Claude Harmon, and Joe Campbell had a best-ball card of 32, 32 -- 64 at the Mount Kisco Country Club today to win the weekly professional - amateur contest of the Westchester P. G. A. by two strokes. They were eight under par.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- An Administration bill providing disaster loans to farmers and ranchers and special loans to temporarily strapped livestock operators was approved speedily by the House Agriculture Committee today after a three-hour hearing.
GOSHEN, N. Y., July 6 (AP) -- Rain terminated the opening-day Grand Circuit harness horse racing program today at Historic Track after three races.

ALBANY, July 6 -- John A. Gafney announced today that he would retire as Superintendent of the State Police on Aug. 15 to become a consultant on traffic control and police supervision for the State Thruway Authority.

New York, London and Canadian financial interests announced yesterday the formation of Triarch Corporation, Ltd., with authorized Capitalization of $10,000,000 and head office in Toronto. It will provide financial and advisory services to Canadian industrial and commercial enterprises, raise capital for their expansion and develop an arbitrage business in international securities.

LONDON, July 6 -- A proposal that the forthcoming meeting of the chiefs of government of Britain, the United States and France be held in London rather than Bermuda "might well come up" when the foreign ministers of the three countries meet in Washington, R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said in the House of Commons today.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- The Cubs rode to their third straight 2-1 series edge by nipping the sixth place Redlegs in a 7-6 thriller today before 9,718.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 6 -- The New York State women's tennis championships, with a field of forty-four in the singles, opened a week-long stand at the New Rochelle Tennis Club today.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The United States made today a new offer of immediate and long-term economic aid to Bolivia.

BONN, Germany, July 6 -- The June 17 uprising in East Berlin and East Germany has upset the calculations of political analysts on the relative chances of the West German political parties in forthcoming general elections.

SEOUL, Tuesday, July 7 -- The heavy rains continued in the battle zone for the fifth day today. Rivers like the Han, the Imjin and others were swollen to twice or three times their normal width. During the last forty-eight hours houses have been swept away, bridges washed out, and lives and property lost here in the heaviest floods since the war began.

LENOIR, N. C., July 6 (UP) -- The county's second big gamma globulin attack on polio in a week began with mass injections here today. However, a report from the first county-wide inoculation area indicated that the serum was not instantly effective on all those receiving shots.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 137 Korean war casualties in a list that included twenty-nine killed, ninety-eight wounded, four missing and six injured. The following were from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:
JERSEY CITY, July 6 (AP) -- Enjoying a dish of ice cream cost Miss Nellie Drain, an 83-year-old spinster, $18,000 today.

LONDON, July 6 -- An agreement between Communist China and an unofficial British trade delegation for a 30,000,000 ($84,000,000) mutual trade pact was announced by the Communist New China News Agency in a broadcast picked up here tonight.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 6 (AP) -- Royal Bay Gem. prepping for Saturday's $20,000 Lamplighter Handicap here, scored an easy victory over six other 3-year-olds before 21,486 at Monmouth Park today.

NEW CITY, N. Y., July 6 -- An application by the Spring Valley Water and Supply Company to build a reservoir in Clarkstown, which the New York State Water Power and Control Commission approved last year, has been upheld by the Appellate Division, Third Department, to set aside local protests, it was announced today by water company officials.

THERE usually are screams of dismay from the players, managers and other professional experts at the All-Star game starting line-ups voted by those amateur selectors, the fans. The fans have blundered so often in the past that it must come as a pleasant surprise to discover that they have done one of their best jobs this year and this was as tough and as puzzling a situation as ever confronted them.

Two employer groups and Local 28 of the Sheet Metal Workers International Association, A. F. L., reached an agreement yesterday providing for a pay rise of 15 cents an hour retroactive to last Wednesday and another 10 cents on Jan. 1.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., July 6 -- With a dramatic finish marking the last and decisive hole of their match, Walter Burkemo of the near-by Franklin Hills Country Club defeated the metropolitan contender, Claude Harmon of the Winged Foot Club, Mamaroneck, N. Y., by 1 up at the thirty-sixth green in their semi-final meeting in the Professional Golfers Association championship at the Birmingham Country Club today.

PHILADELPHIA, Tuesday, July 7 -- Even a part-time Mickey Mantle was something for 22,297 fans to see at Connie Mack Stadium, where the Yankees won a twilight-night double-header from the Athletics. The Bombers won the first game, 10 -- 5, last night and took the second, 5 -- 3, this morning. The second game ended at 12:43 A. M.

A 64-year-old Puerto Rican, who boarded the wrong plane here last Sunday, should be home for breakfast this morning -- unless things get mixed up again. The last time Juan Martinez left New York for home he ended up in Gander, Nfld., well warmed by Martinis but somewhat chilled by the weather.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 6 -- The specter of political and religious reaction has been raised again in Turkey by widely circulated reports that a secret, subversive society dedicated to the overthrow of much of this country's new order has been operating in Istanbul. The group is alleged to have been affiliated with the small conservative Nation party.
I am convinced that the United States is making a mistake today in yielding to Senator McCarthy's advocacy of Communist methods of propaganda.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 -- A coastwise strike of American Federation of Labor machinists against more than sixty shipyards was marked today by the announcement of a tentative agreement between the International Association of Machinists and a San Francisco yard.

LOS ANGELES, July 6 (AP) -- Irwin Edelman, 54 years old, a sidewalk orator, whose argument was used in getting the Rosenberg atomic spies their last stay of execution, today got a suspended ninety-day jail sentence for not registering as a convicted vagrant.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 7 -- During the first three months of 1953 world production in mining and manufacturing fields maintained levels reached during the final quarter of 1952, and exceeded by 6 per cent the volume recorded for the corresponding quarter last year, the United Nations Monthly Bulletin of Statistics, published today, states.

The J. I. Kislak Mortgage Corporation, a division of J. I. Kislak, Inc., of Jersey City, N. J., has announced the appointment of Jay Kislak as vice president and secretary of the mortgage concern. The elder son of Julius I. Kislak, president and founder of the organization, he also is secretary of the parent company.

Two histories of the Jews in America are planned for publication next year to commemorate the American Jewish tercentennial celebration. The World Publishing Company has scheduled for early in the year Rufus Learsi's new work entitled "The Jews in America: A History."

EUREKA, Calif., July 7 -- A "strike" against the way the truck weight law was being enforced in Northern California left hundreds of sixty-foot trucks and trailers, loaded with trunks of huge redwood and Douglas fir trees, cluttering roadways today.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 7 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation was asked today by Frank B. Durkee, state Director of Public Works, whether it might lend California about $200,000,000 to build a crossing of San Francisco Bay.

The Archbishopric of New York has purchased the National Bible Institute property at 330 to 348 West Fifty-fifth Street and plans to renovate and modernize it for use as a home for the aged. The property, held at $880,000, was sold through John J. Reynolds, Inc., as broker.

Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy announced yesterday that most persons getting welfare grants here had received slightly larger checks on July 3, thus reflecting new mandatory standards laid down by the state and an increase in prices since September, 1950.

Mayor Impellitteri announced last night that the eleventh of eighteen sewage treatment plants needed to cleanse the waters of the New York area would go into operation July 29. This will be the Port Richmond plant, which will serve the northern end of Staten Island.
Mayor Impellitteri conferred with city and Federal mediation officials yesterday to seek to end the strike of 1,200 truck drivers which has crippled construction on many major projects.

The credibility of Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, was accepted yesterday by the Appellate Division when it upheld in a three-to-two decision the dismissal of five policemen who were tried last year by the Police Department for accepting gambling graft.

The demand for life insurance by American families continued at record levels in the first half of this year. Life protection purchased in the period amounted to $19,000,000,000, bringing the total amount in force to a new high of $290,000,000,000.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 7 (AP) -- Bobby Locke, the defending champion from South Africa, won the qualifying medal for the British Open with a two-day total of 136, while Frank Stranahan -- not Ben Hogan -- set the pace for the United States golfing contingent.
ROME, July 7 -- Dr. Alcide De Gasperi reluctantly accepted from President Luigi Einaudi tonight the task of trying to form another Government.

Wildenstein Co., Inc., and Scott Fowles, art galleries established in New York shortly after the turn of the century, have merged. The announcement was made here yesterday by E. J. Rousuck, head of Scott Fowles, and in Paris by Georges Wildenstein, president of his concern.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Eldon Claggett Upton Jr., New Orleans insurance man, to be a member of the Federal Maritime Board for the term expiring June 30., 1957. He would succeed Albert W. Gatov, whose terms has ended.
The United States Wightman Cup team was named yesterday and it indicated more bad news for England's tennis players.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 7 -- Reinert M. Torgerson and Fred Lazard of the Cherry Valley club scored 34, 31 -- 65, seven strokes under par, to win the twenty-third Long Island Golf Association best- ball championship at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

Such leading trends as longhaired fabrics, predominance of jeweled trim, use of tall crowns, fez shapes, the profile line and back interest in silhouettes were highlighted last night at the Astor Hotel when the Millinery Stabilazation Commission presented a comprehensive showing of fall millinery before buyers and merchandising executives from all parts of the country.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, has asked the Army to send him a bill when he uses its airplanes for personal pleasure, the State Department said today.

Wall Street traders have been busy this week dealing in the common stock of the St. Regis Paper Company. The issue was the market favorite on Monday and placed among the ten most active Big Board issues again yesterday as the market letter writers pointed out that directors meet for dividend action on July 22.

GENEVA, July 7 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council voted today, over Russian and Polish opposition, to recommend the continuation of the office of United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for five years. Dr. G. J. Van Heuven Goedhart, who holds the office now, had recommended that the period be extended from three to at least five years to enable the high commissioner to plan operations ahead for a reasonable period of time.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee acted favorably today on a bill urged by President Eisenhower to admit 240,000 additional refugees and other immigrants to the United States in the next two years.
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
LONDON, July 7 (Reuters) -- Middlesex strengthened its position at the head of the English county cricket championship competition today by beating Warwickshire, the 1951 champion, by 148 runs.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- 'Round-the-clock picketing was resumed today by striking members of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., at all docks of the major oil producing companies in the Calumet area.

Two former Communist officials named "several" American clergymen yesterday as members of the Communist party, according to Representative Kit Clardy, Republican of Michigan, acting chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities. Mr. Clardy made the announcement after day-long closed hearings of two subcommittees at the Federal Court House here.

The Lehman Corporation, one of the nation's largest closed-end investment trusts, reported yesterday that its net asset value on June 30 was $65.60 a capital share. This compared with $71.57 a share on June 30, 1952, the close of the company's preceding fiscal year.

In the early days Pierre Monteux used to conduct at the Lewisohn Stadium only intermittently, but since 1946 he has been a regular visitor, and last night he returned to the podium of the outdoor amphitheatre for the eighth consecutive summer. An audience of 7,000 welcomed him.

A vacant blockfront parcel containing twenty-four business lots on the south side of Montauk Highway in Montauk, L. I., has been purchased by Seacliffs, Inc., a New York affiliate of the Carl G. Fisher Corporation of Miami, Fla., for improvement with a number of Florida-type motels.
MOSCOW, July 7 -- The Communist party of the Ukraine has just pledged to the people of that vital Soviet agricultural and industrial area a major short-term program for raising living standards.

Dollar sales volume of the New York metropolitan area's commercial printing industry for May was 10 per cent higher than for the corresponding month last year, according to a monthly sales index report issued yesterday by the New York Employing Printers Association.

BOSTON, July 7 -- A Federal grand jury returned an indictment today of seventy counts against the former firm of J. Arthur Warner Co., Inc., over-the-counter securities dealers, on charges of fraud and deceit in the sale of stocks and bonds.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Paul H. Davis Co., widely known Chicago investment firm, will be consolidated with Hornblower Weeks, investment house with its main office in New York and home office in Boston. Principal partners of the two firms signed an agreement yesterday under which the consolidation is to become effective about Oct. 1.

The Piper Cub seaplane that was picked up by the Polish liner Batory on Aug. 8, 1950, after the pilot of the plane had brought it down in the Atlantic thirteen miles off Fire Island was the subject of a second lawsuit yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Senate permanent Subcommittee on Investigations today heard two more authors whose writings were in United States information libraries overseas refuse to say whether they had been Communists when they wrote their works.

A ring for the dissemination of gambling information was broken yesterday by plainclothes police teams in ninety-five simultaneous raids on subscribers to its telephone service. Scores of alleged bookmakers and policy game operators were taken to the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and questioned through the afternoon and evening.

NEWARK, July 7 -- Superior Court Judge Walter J. Freund held today that the McGuire Act, as a Federal statute, was "ineffective" as a means of compelling non-signatory retailers to comply with the New Jersey Fair Trade Act.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Republican leaders of the House of Representatives abandoned a previously accepted compromise bill today in making final preparations for decisive voting in the Ways and Means Committee tomorrow on renewal of the excess profits tax.

ST. LOUIS, July 7 (UP) -- The Browns set a major league record tonight, dropping their twentieth straight game in Busch Stadium as they lost to the Indians, 6 -- 3. The old record for consecutive defeats at home was nineteen, shared by St. Louis and the 1906 Red Sox.
Harald Bromley has scheduled for local production this fall "Dead Pigeon," a new play by Lenard Kantor, a magazine illustrator and playwright who has not been represented previously on Broadway.

SEOUL, Wednesday, July 8 -- United States and South Korean infantrymen today smashed assaults by more than 6,000 Chinese Reds on the Korean western front after a thirty-six-hour battle and were mopping up at noon.

Five leaders of teen-age gangs in South Jamaica, Queens, lost their parole yesterday and were sent to jail when police learned that rival gangs were caching guns, knives, blackjacks and homemade grenades in arsenals for a full-scale battle over a feud death.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., July 7 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge and Charlotte De Cozen of Baltusrol won the qualifying medal in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's four-ball match-play tournament, at Leewood today, turning in a best-ball one-under-par 33, 37 -- 70 to head a field of thirty-six teams.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., July 7 -- Despite a belated rally on the part of his smaller rival, 34-year-old Walter Burkemo completed the story of the local boy who made good as he won the Professional Golfers Association championship today.

LONDON, July 7 -- The British Television Advisory Committee, which will ultimately advise the Government on the proposed introduction of commercial television here, issued a preliminary report today indicating there would be a shortage of desirable frequency channels for any major television expansion, either commercial or by the state-owned British Broadcasting Corporation.

ROME, July 2 -- Many persons must have wondered in the course of the last century and a half what Casanova looked like and whether there was anything in his apperance to explain the extraordinary attraction he exercised, or said he exercised, over the women of the second half of the eighteenth century.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- About 1,500 members of Local 15 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., voted unanimously today not to work until an inter-union dispute over a woman business agent was settled.
