BOSTON, July 7 -- Scattered showers during the night, and a United States Weather Bureau long-range forecast of more by the week-end, brought psychological, if not actual, relief to New England forestry officials today. All fires were reported under control, but the hazard remained.

LANGHORNE, Pa., July 7 -- A statement of what parents of retarded children want for their youngsters from medical specialists, educators and the community was released here today by the child research clinic of the Woods Schools.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 7 (AP) -- King Baudouin today presented the Cross of the Belgian Royal Order of the Lion and a $10,000 award to Dr. Louise Pearce, an American biologist, for her part in the discovery of tryparsamide, a drug used to fight sleeping sickness.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 8 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,668, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

VIENNA, July 7 -- The Czechoslovak Government in a special Cabinet session yesterday reversed its week-old decree fixing special penalties for workers to curb absenteeism and changing of jobs. The Government's measure had been approved by the Czech Trade Union Congress on June 19 but, according to the Prague radio, it was on the proposal of the trade unions that the Government rescinded it today.

AGRA, India, July 7 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said tonight that the action of Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President, in violation of the prisoner-of-war agreement, degraded the United Nations and countries that had accepted the agreement.

Albert Edward Gibbs, hall porter of the American Club in London from its opening in 1919 until his retirement last June 26, arrived in New York yesterday morning on the liner United States for his first visit to America.

THE pipe organ that has mellowed the air in the Brooklyn Academy of Music for almost fifty years may become a homeless orphan; it may possibly go to the junkies unless some sentimental, music-minded buyer turns up to save it. The Gramercy Construction Company, doing the academy over for the Park Department, is holding off the wrecking job in the hope that the instrument may be saved.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, introduced a bill today to authorize the Justice Department to investigate alleged irregularities committed by employes of other Government agencies. The bill was drafted and approved by the Justice Department, he told the Senate.
CHESTERTOWN, Md., July 7 (AP) -- A Navy Constellation transport plane crashed in flames near here today, killing the six crewmen aboard.

CHARLOTESVILLE, Va., July 8 -- The University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs was told today by one speaker that war with the Soviet Union could be avoided only if the regime in the Kremlin changed and by another that war was not necessarily inevitable but that this country should be ready for it.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 7 -- A few hours after his arrival at Idlewild by plane from Wimbledon, England, today, Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., was on the courts of the Bath and Tennis Club for the start of the annual invitation tournament.

The First Wisconsin National Bank of Milwaukee, Wis., reported as of June 30, 1953, total deposits of $531,934,673 and total assets of $608,588,015, compared, respectively, with $596,952,728 and $667,412,167 on Dec. 31, 1952. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $168,139,335 against $189,445,402; holdings of United States Government securities to $235,080,396 against $283,295,992; and loans and discounts to $172,064,860 against $160,379,721.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 7 -- Ayatollah Sayed Abolghassem Kashani, Iranian religious leader who has become the rallying figure for the opposition to Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, accused the Government today of having used threats, promises of patronage and virtual bribes to insure his defeat last Wednesday as speaker of the Majlis (lower house of Parliament).
OTTAWA, July 7 (AP) -- Canada's imports in May set a monthly record and further raised the country's foreign trade deficit this year, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 8 -- The Communists accepted today the proposal of the United Nations commander, Gen. Mark W. Clark, to complete negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war despite the bitter opposition of President Syngman Rhee of the South Korean Republic and his threats to fight on alone for the unification of the peninsula.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- After ten days of deliberations in the Pentagon, defense officials have decided to fight for restoration of about $500,000,000 of the $1,337,422,500 slashed from the defense budget by the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- On July 8, 1853, a rather crotchety old Yankee sea dog, Commodore Matthew Calbraith Perry, sailed four black ships of the United States Navy into Edo Bay, Japan. The Commodore carried a letter from Millard Fillmore, President of the United States, to the Emperor of Japan, asking that the Land of the Rising Sun be opened to commerce with the Western world.

Walter Winchell, columnist and broadcaster, denied yesterday that he had ever called James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, a Communist, and said he would be glad to publish any evidence that Mr. Wechsler was an anti-Communist.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The White House announced today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon would undertake a goodwill tour of the Far East and of South Asia next autumn, traveling as a personal representative of President Eisenhower. The announcement read as follows:

ALBANY, July 7 -- Governor Dewey said today that any exposure of subversive employes in State service by the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities would hold no political embarrassment for him.

New York City has borrowed $60,000,000 on tax anticipation notes due Oct. 22 at an interest rate of 2 per cent, City Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday. The notes were sold by allotment to twenty-one banks and trust companies, as follows:

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Small receipts at hard winter wheat terminals in Oklahoma and Texas and light country offerings of red winter wheat in the Middle West have changed trade opinion on the bread grain, and the market had a decidedly strong tone today, showing a greater capacity for absorbing the few hedge sales and local profit taking by longs.

A timely warning for vacationists in the form of a chatty letter has been distributed by the Greater New York Safety Council and the city's Welfare and Health Council to 1,000 women's clubs, civic associations and other groups in the metropolitan area.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, July 7 -- Britain's possibly most effective single ally here now that her efforts to keep the white, Oriental and African in Tanganyika pulling together to avoid a race war that threatens so much of Africa is the Aga Khan.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 1 -- Communist - led Yugoslavia has opened her doors to foreign investment, and a contract already has been initiated with a Swiss concern on the construction of a steam power plant in Slovenia.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 7 (AP) -- Sharon Rose, owned by Wales T. Flynt of Crawfordville, Ga., followed the pace until the top of the stretch, then went on to win the Amagansett pace by two lengths tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

CINCINNATI, July 7 (AP) -- Manager Charlie Dressen of the Dodgers today dipped into the ranks of seven clubs to fill out the twenty-five-man National League team that will meet the American Leaguers in the annual all-star game here next Tuesday.
LONDON, July 7 -- Here are some sidelights on the television service of the British Broadcasting Corporation:

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- A bill designed to stimulate business production by allowing a general five-year tax amortization on new capital investments was introduced in the Senate today by Sen. Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana.
CINCINNATI, July 7 (AP) -- The Cardinals choked off a game Cincinnati uprising in the ninth tonight and, led by Rip Repulski's two homers and three-run double, beat the Redlegs, 7 -- 6.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 8 (AP) -- Pravda charged today that the United States was to blame for the Korean truce stalemate.

MILWAUKEE, July 7 (AP) -- Eddie Mathews smashed his twenty-fifth home run and Joe Adcock blasted the Stadium's first inside-the-park round-tripper tonight as the Braves beat the Cubs, 4 -- 1, before 37,113 fans, the largest crowd of the season here.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP) -- The Army reported today it found no basis for criticism of Maj. Gen. Kenneth F. Cramer, United States troop commander in south Germany, but Representative Dewey Short called the report "too general and rather evasive."

A considerable further step toward better economic relationships in the Far East has been made with the conclusion of a new trade agreement between Japan and Nationalist China. The new treaty, now formally signed, provides for an annual exchange of commodities to the extent of $74,500,000 (U. S.) each way.

On the basis of $60,372 collected in the first half of 1953 for 2,114 installations of fuel-burning equipment, it was indicated yesterday that the Department of Air Pollution Control would take in more than $120,000 from this source for the entire year, or about 43 per cent of its 1953-54 budget.
MEXICO CITY, July 7 -- The United States has about given up hope of obtaining Mexico's agreement to a military aid pact.

MEXICO CITY, July 7 -- The Mexican Government has ordered an investigation of what has come to be known here as "The Case of the Vanishing Art Treasures." Nobody seemed to have noticed that various pieces from Mexico's national museums were not on display, until a fortnight ago, when David Alfaro Siqueiros, the painter, opened an exposition of portraits he had painted during the last few years.

VINELAND, N. J., July 7 -- A mother and two children were burned to death and two other children and her husband were burned early this morning in a fire that swept a five-room bungalow on Black Horse Pike at Cecil, ten miles north of here.

The re-election of Vincent G. Barnett as president of the New York Shipping Association, the waterfront employers' group, was announced yesterday. Mr. Barnett is president of the Barber Steamship Lines and of the American West African Line and the Atlantic Stevedoring Company.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Congressional apathy toward the Eisenhower foreign aid program has reached the point where many Administrative officials believe that only direct Presidential intervention can prevent the vitiating of the $5,000,000,000 measure in Appropriations Committees and on the floor of either chamber.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the Government had $3,831,000,000 invested and obligated under farm price support programs on May 31. This was more than double the $1,679,000,000 sum a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Eisenhower today nominated Guy Farmer, a Washington lawyer, to be a member of the National Labor Relations Board. If confirmed by the Senate, he would fill out the remainder of the five-year term from which the former chairman, Paul M. Herzog, resigned. The term will expire on Aug. 27, 1955.

The turnpike route is still a broken line of future promise on the highway map in Ohio and Indiana, but it now extends from the Eastern seaboard to Chicago. Governor Craig of Indiana has taken the final step of preliminary planning in his state by approving the location of the 150-mile $193,000,000 four-lane superhighway.

THE shoemaker who sticks to his last often fails to realize that other people do not know what a last is, or think that it is some kind of cobbler's bench. The broker finds it difficult to believe that millions of intelligent people have no idea what a margin is. Every kind of shop talk and every hobby, sport or special interest bristles with words that are unintelligible to uninitiates.

Japanese shipyards are doing a "fairly fast" job in turning out new vessels despite a lack of modern mechanical equipment that forces the use of much more manual labor than is customary in American yards, according to Arthur Doxsey, vice president of Walter Kidde Co.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 7 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, proposed today that the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions create a special fund to aid East German and East Berlin victims of communism.

Twenty former or current inspectors of ordnance material in defense plants in the New York district appeared before the Defense Activities subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee yesterday at the beginning of a four-day investigation into possible irregularities and "influence peddling" here.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 7 -- Larry Santoro and Gus Manganello, representing Donnybrook, a Saxon Woods affiliate, had a gross 33, 35 -- 68 and net 31, 34 -- 65 to head both phases of the Metropolitan Golf Association's best-ball tournament today at Quaker Ridge.

BABYLON, L. I., July 7 -- A $2,715,000 contract to improve Jones Inlet on the south shore of Nassau County will be let next week, Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, said today. Completion of the project in the spring of 1955 will mark the end of a long-standing peril to navigation and as a secondary benefit will halt the erosion at Point Lookout on the westerly side of the inlet.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives killed a resolution of impeachment against Associate Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas today.

The New York City Transit Authority must make its decision early next week if it is to charge a higher fare during the last five months of 1953. While new economies are still under study, the basic data in so far as they have become public seem to indicate a fare of 13 or 14 cents.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 7 -- A new effort to persuade the recalcitrant commanders of the Chinese Nationalist troops in Burma to remove their soldiers to Formosa was launched here today with the arrival of three new representatives from Taipei.

Well, the children are away at camp now, so this is an excellent time to begin living. This is the time to disconnect the radio, the television and the record player, and in the late afternoon and early evening to sit in silence.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Hector (Skinny) Brown limited Washington to four hits tonight as the Red Sox defeated the Senators, 2 -- 0, to strengthen their hold on fourth place. Brown posted his seventh victory as Boston swept the two-game series.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 7 (AP) -- Newport Dream from Octave Blake's Newport Stock Farm of South Plainfield, N. J., missed the track record for 2-year-olds by one-fifth of a second in taking the $14,200 E. H. Harriman Challenge Trophy at Historic track's Grand Circuit meeting today.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy overrode a majority of his seven-man Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations today and refused to remove J. B. Matthews as its executive director. Mr. Matthews had caused a wide controversy by writing in a magazine article that "the largest single group supporting the Communist apparatus" in this country was composed of Protestant clergymen.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 7 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan told the South African Parliament today that South Africa would remain in the British Commonwealth, although he was perturbed by the danger of the indiscriminate expansion" of its membership.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, has "debauched public discussion in this country," the Rev. Robert C. Hartnett, editor of America, national Catholic weekly review, told summer students yesterday at the New York University Catholic Center, 69 Washington Square South.

The bulk of recent United States imports of Chinese origin have been strategic materials and even these have been stopped as an early 1952 ban took effect, the Office of International Trade pointed out in an explanatory statement released here yesterday.

PARIS, July 7 -- One of the most sensitive yardsticks by which to measure relationships between Communist states and the nations of the free world is the extent of visible or approved anti-Semitism within the Soviet bloc. Since Stalin's death, therefore, foreign capitals have seen keeping a close watch for any development in this sphere.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP) -- Americans for Democratic Action tonight endorsed wiretapping if it was limited to cases of sabotage and espionage and controlled by the courts.

The New York District Council of the International Longshoremenn's Association, A. F. L., voted last night to assess each of the union's members in the Port of New York $5 for a fund to contest the waterfront reform laws recently enacted in this state and in New Jersey.
Your editorial of July 2 about Rudolph Halley is a puzzle. Missing are the shrewd understanding and calm discussion that TIMES readers expect.

BERLIN, July 7 -- Unconfirmed reports from East Berlin tonight said angry groups of building workers on Stalinallee had threatened to strike again if their colleagues arrested after the strike and riots of June 17 were not released immediately.

In reply to a demand by Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan that a public hearing be held before an authorized increase in gas rates is put into effect by four companies in the city, Benjamin F. Feinberg, chairman of the Public Service Commission, told Mr. Wagner yesterday that his demand was late.

Designed for use at the table, a combination cooker and deep-fat fryer by Westinghouse is among new culinary equipment this season. The Cook-N-Fryer can be used for making soups, stews and puddings as well as deep-fat fried foods, such as doughnuts and corn fritters. It is expected to be available in housewares departments within a week or two.

There is no such thing as "miracle" fiber, Dr. Joseph B. Quig of the Textile Fibers Department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. said in a talk at the recent meeting of the American Home Economics Association in Kansas City, Mo.

PITTSBURGH, July 7 -- Preacher Roe hit the first home run of his professional baseball career today as the Dodgers completed a sweep of the three-game series with the Pirates by winning two games, 5 -- 4 and 9 -- 5, before 12,720, including 3,033 youngsters who were admitted free, at Forbes Field.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Governor Dewey of New York disclaimed any connection between his arrival here late today by plane and a series of legislative developments on a bill that would enable private enterprise to develop Niagara Falls power.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed today a bill to authorize the Atomic Energy Commission to sign twenty-five-year power contracts -- with cancellation clauses that could cost the Government $340,000,000 -- for atomic plants at Oak Ridge, Tenn.; Paducah, Ky., and Portsmouth, Ohio.

Timely Reward waited for the proper moment to make his move, and then went on to register a convincing triumph in the feature race at the Aqueduct race track yesetrday. The 5-year-old son of Reaping Reward came along in stretch of the mile-and-asixteenth event and moved to success against Montpelier's Pintor by almost two lengths.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Congress finally got around to voting to repeal two laws -- over 60 years old -- under which enlisted men could buy their way out of the Army for as little as $30.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, said today it would approve some but not all of the freight rate cuts which the railroads are proposing to make on gasoline shipments in parts of the West.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 -- A blood sample may be taken from a person and the resulting data may be used in the trial of the person on a charge involving intoxication, a majority of the California Supreme Court ruled today. A dissenting opinion contended that such steps violated the due process of law guaranteed under the Constitution.

Chairman Reed of the House Ways and Means Committee is scheduled to call his fellow-members together today to resume their long-recessed hearings on general tax revision. At this meeting some member is expected to move that the committee put aside the pending business and vote on the proposal of the President for a six months' extension of the excess-profits tax.

PARIS, Wednesday, July 8 -- Premier Joseph Laniel won his first contest with the National Assembly when it voted early today 306 to 281 to restore to his finance bill the provision for an increased tax on gasoline to cover loans the Government was making from the Bank of France.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The State Department's International Information Administration has ordered its officials abroad to restore to library shelves some of the books removed under the ban on Communist, pro-Communist or "controversial" authors.

And now it is the turn of the Communist masters of Czechoslovakia to take a frightened step in retreat. A few weeks ago they robbed the workers of their savings and in doing so set off an explosive force that has brought the oppressed inhabitants of that once-prosperous country close to outright rebellion.

News that a grant of $200,000 has been made by the Rockefeller Foundation to the City Center of Music and Drama will be welcome to the many friends of the Center who have contributed and worked to assure its continued existence. The $200,000 fund, to be used in the three years ending July 1, 1956, is to be applied toward expenses of creating new productions in opera and ballet.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were influenced by pre-bureau covering again yesterday and final prices were 7 to 31 points net higher than on Monday.

Coffee prices jumped the 200-point limit for the second consecutive day in all but the near-by July position at the opening on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. The rise was the result of continued reaction to the frost reports from Brazil.

A syndicate of investment houses headed by First Boston Corporation will place on the market today $40,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds of the Commonwealth Edison Company. Bearing an interest rate of 3 5/8 per cent, the bonds are priced at 100 to yield 3.625 per cent.

Arthur Persley of Red Cross, La., will attempt to extend his victory string to thirteen straight when he makes his debut in a main event at Madison Square Garden tonight against Orlano Zulueta of Cuba in a ten-round lightweight fight.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., July 7 -- A. Federal Conciliation Service mediator announced this afternoon that the strike on the Newburgh-Beacon ferry had been settled. Ferries will resume normal operations tomorrow at 6 A. M.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, July 7 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Malan said today the United Nations would contribute to the break-up of the British Commonwealth if Commonwealth countries attacked each other through the United Nations.

The apartment house at 2377 Creston Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the 2377 Corporation, represented by Jacob Leibner, lawyer, to an investing client of Leonard Schack, lawyer. It is assessed at $202,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $107,500.

Ecuador's exports for the first quarter of 1953 amounted to $16,107,113, compared with $13,091,583 for the like period last year, according to a special bulletin issued yesterday by the Ecuadorean American Association. The country's imports for the period were valued at $17,146,818, compared with $12,033,429 in the comparable period of 1952.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization outlined today for industry the basic policies by which it will be guided in applying priorities and allocations authority in the future. The mobilization office, under Arthur S. Flemming, is now a permanent Government agency operating under terms of an Executive Order issued by the President on June 30.
A talent more in keeping with city life than hunting birds has been revealed by a cocker spaniel named Meg, who began retrieving lost balls a year ago last May. Her total as of yesterday was 386.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board here yesterday dismissed charges made by the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers Union, C. I. O., that Hearn's department stores in Manhattan and the Bronx had refused to bargain with the union. The union has been on strike against the stores since May 14.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Eisenhower Administration's foreign policy leader in Congress, Senator Alexander Wiley, denounced President Syngman Rhee of South Korea today as an embittered and reckless man who was doing "infinite damage" to all the Allied world and the cause of peace.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP) -- The House today passed and sent to the Senate a bill to increase the maximum liquor-bonding period for Federal tax purposes from eight to twelve years.

WHEN Curt Simmons was a poor boy, he used his muscles to push the lawnmower. But after he received a $65,000 bonus and a handsome salary from the Phillies, he was able to afford an engine-driven lawnmower. It may prove to be the most expensive luxury of his career.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 7 -- Nassau County's Republican organization started this year's election campaign here today by designating candidates for the Sept. 15 primaries. Three were named at the county level, and six for township or district races.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 7 -- The Pakistani Government outlawed today the Ahrar-e-Islam, a strong religious opposition party that participated earlier this year in three riots resulting in the deaths of possibly 1,000 persons.

Rare Ben Jonson wrote a play called "Volpone" a little less than 350 years ago that has held the stage rakishly in any number of versions. Now it has been used as the basis for an opera, called "Volpone," naturally, with a score by George Antheil and a libretto by Alfred Perry, and it still plays well.

AN improved waterfowl picture on the Eastern and Northeastern breeding grounds, where weather, water and nesting conditions have been excellent this spring, may result in a slight increase in the bag and possession limit, and possibly a slightly longer season in the Atlantic waterfowl flyway zone.

PARIS, July 1 -- Prints, especially on broadcloth, are the sensation of French woolens for the coming winter. With the exception of Ducharne's black roses on snowwhite broadcloth, designs tend to zigzag lines, wavy brush strokes or scrolls softly blurred by the pile on fleece.
LONDON, July 7 -- Industrial shares made more widespread gains on the stock markets here today. Oil shares and foreign bonds, particularly Japanese issues, also continued to rise.
TRENTON, July 7 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll signed today the rent control legislation that will go into effect on July 31, when Federal regulations expire.

Dr. William M. Markel, administrator of the New York Red Cross Regional Blood Program, issued yesterday an urgent appeal for donors to provide blood for the balance of this week for emergency shipments to Korea and Japan.

The first joint showing yesterday of millinery designs by Erik Braagaard and Anit Andra was true to the old saying that opposites must attract. Shown at 558 Madison Avenue, the subtle refinement of one proved an excellent foil for the more dressmaker touches of the other.

Kyung Won Lee's letter appearing in your June 25 issue interests me greatly. Mr. Kyung identifies himself as editor in chief of the Korean Messenger and explains the position of the South Korean Government as he sees it regarding the pending armistice in the ravaged peninsula.

Concerned over reports that insurance agents with underworld ties are siphoning off hundreds of thousands of dollars a year in excess commissions and service fees, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan is preparing to crack down on rackets in the administration of union-management welfare funds.
John D. Benedito has been named assistant general sales manager of the Bakelite Company, a division of Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.

At a special meeting of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation to be held here on July 31, stockholders will vote on the proposal to increase the authorized number of founders shares from 212,830 to 538,462 shares.
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- Catcher Matt Batts' error in the ninth inning enabled the White Sox to tally an unearned run and down the Tigers, 3 to 2, before 19,781 at Comiskey Park tonight.

WEST POINT, N. Y., July 7 -- The vanguard of the United States Military Academy's new plebe class, which is expected to total about 730 members, struggled up the hill to the academy from the railroad station at 7:30 this morning. Luggage in hand, they had hardly reached the Plains at the top of the hill before they were caught in the bustle of military life.

Reading in the English Listener of June 11 quotations from articles in your paper of June 3, concerning the Coronation and the British Commonwealth, I felt I must write to congratulate you on their breadth of vision and understanding.

The pushbutton house is here. According to a new series of consumer advertisements by Anaconda Copper Mining Company, to break through Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc. in national magazines late in July, junior can sit at a control panel and open the garage doors for daddy when he drives home and mom can watch the baby in the crib upstairs on a closed circuit television screen.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 7 -- Betty Coumbe of Westfield, N. J., the 1952 finalist, led the way into the quarter-final round of the women's New York State tennis championships at the New Rochelle Tennis Club today with a 6-2, 6-0 victory over Eleanor Blair of New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 7 -- Palmer Lee, 26-year-old actor under contract to Universal-International for more than two years, will get a stellar build-up and a new name as a result of his performance in his latest picture, "The All-American."

Today's new film is "The Moon Is Blue," F. Hugh Herbert's adaptation of his Broadway stage success, directed and produced by Otto Preminger and starring William Holden, David Niven and Maggie McNamara, at the Victoria and Sutton Theatres. Tom Tully, Dawn Addams and Fortunio Bonanova complete the cast of the romantic comedy, which is being released through United Artists.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- A new board to supervise the execution of all national policy relating to foreign relations, and not merely psychological strategy, was reported today to be a principal recommendation of the President's Committee on International Information Activities.
LONDON, July 7 -- "The Moon Is Blue" opened at the Duke of York's Theatre here tonight and was greeted warmly by an audience that seemed to find it amusing and entertaining.

Evidently it took yesterday's considerable budget of favorable corporate news about an hour to penetrate the canyons of Wall Street, for between 10 and 11 A. M. stock prices seesawed in quiet dealings. But from then on the list forged ahead and by the close the market had experienced its best gains since mid-June.

A nineteenth-century forerunner of the present-day news photographer left to posterity a painted scroll that, in an early example of on-the-scene reporting, documents the arrival of Commodore Matthew C. Perry in Japanese waters a century ago.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- James B. Bowler, colorful 77-year-old Democratic alderman, won a special election today to fill the term of the late Democratic Representative Adolph J. Sabath in the Seventh Illinois Congressional District.

The Continental Motors Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries increased their net profit for the six months ended on April 30 to $3,343,658 from $2,726,859 in the corresponding period a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Senate passed a bill appropriating $2,028,940,761 for the Labor and Health, Education and Welfare Departments and related agencies today after voting fourteen increases, most of them over the protest of the Republican leadership.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP) -- Representative John W. Heselton told oil industry leaders today they had failed to justify recent price increases and threatened to press for complete Federal control of their operations.

I have just finished reading the editorial entitled "The Case of Mr. Matthews." You end your editorial as follows: "A man [Matthews] capable of this sort of nonsense [Matthews article, "Reds and Our Churches"] may very well suit Mr. McCarthy. He cannot suit anybody who has a zeal for truth and for fair and accurate research."

After Hoyt Wilhelm had helped Marv Grissom make a triumphant return to the Polo Grounds, Al Corwin last night pitched and batted the Giants to a one-sided triumph over the Phillies. The 5-3, 9-1 sweep of the twilight-night double-header, which raised Leo Durocher's fifth-place New Yorkers three games over the 500 mark, was accomplished before a crowd of 34,736.
ATHENS, July 7 -- The first annual meeting of the Balkan nations bound by the recently ratified Ankara pact took place today.

The Mayor of Spring Valley, N. Y., William Bohlke, said yesterday that the sewage treatment system in his town was "inadequate and outmoded" and that it had been unable to take the sewage load imposed upon it for "several years."

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The chances of Congressional action this session on the request of Arthur E. Summerfield, Postmaster General, for postal rate increases totaling about $240,600,000 appeared to be waning today but still were not written off completely.

Events tonight: "Volpone," Cherry Lane Theatre, 8:30 o'clock; Stadium Symphony Orchestra, Pierre Monteux conducting, Henri Deering, pianist, Lewisohn Stadium, 8:30; Guggenheim Memorial Concert, Goldman Band, Central Park, 8:30; "Don Pedro," Lemonade Opera, 141 West Thirteenth Street, 8:30; American Lyric Theatre, 320 West Fifty-seventh Street, 8:40.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- A change was urged today in proposed amendment to insure that revenues from the outer Continental Shelf, which the Federal Government controls, be used for educational purposes.
ST. LOUIS, July S ()--TheI Browns won their first same at home since June 2 tonight as they] scored five runs in the sixth l inning and went on to defeat the Indians, 0----3.

A landlord charged with thirty-eight housing violations has received eight days to prove that he would "lose his shirt" if the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission reduced rents until the violations were ended.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- Chairman Charles A. Wolverton of the House Commerce Committee said today Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. may have to investigate recent "unwarranted" gasoline and oil price increases.

JERSEY CITY, July 8 -- A 14-year-old boy, a goodwill emissary from the Young Men's Christian Association in Athens, Greece, arrived here today aboard the American Export Lines steamer Exochorda to be the guest for a year of 100 Y. M. C. A. members in suburban Summit, N. J.
TOKYO, July 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of the letter from the Communist high command to the United Nations commander, Gen. Mark W. Clark, as released by the United Nations Command:

The Queens Borough President's office has asked the City Board of Responsibility to investigate the San Martino Construction Company of 81-42 Baxter Avenue, Jackson Heights, which was low bidder on the construction of a sewer in Flushing. The board, an informal agency of the Controller's office, checks bidders' qualifications.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Miles F. McDonald, District Attorney for Kings County, told a House Judiciary subcommittee today he has never known of injury to an innocent person as a result of authorized wiretapping. He was advocating passage of a Federal statute to permit limited use of listening and recording devices to obtain evidence in cases affecting national security.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 8 -- State and Federal agencies are investigating the deaths of thousands of menhaden, also known as boney fish, or mossbunkers, in the Connecticut River area near Long Island Sound.

BROD, Yugoslavia, July 8 -- Premier Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia said today he believed the Soviet Union was in the midst of a real change of policy, and he urged the Western powers to seize this opportunity to reach a "realistic" international settlement.

Five Indian boys and girls in traditional costume arrived at Pennsylvania Station yesterday from Winnebago, Neb., where they are pupils at the Indian Children's Village, an institution that cares for 125 underprivileged Indian youngsters.

FROM Barnegat to Sandy Hook the word is "fluke," for although there are school tuna and bluefish well offshore, and a few charter and party boat skippers insist they have sighted both giant tuna and white marlin, the flatfish seem to be providing most of the food and activity.

The apartment house accommodating twenty families at 160 Henry Street has been sold by the Har-Al Realty Company to the 160 Yrneh Realty Corporation for cash above a mortgage of $58,000. The property is assessed at $80,000. Title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

When the nine 2-year-old colts in the $19,250 Great American Stakes were about a third of the way around the Aqueduct turn yesterday. C. V. Whitney's Fisherman was in ninth place. He didn't stay there long. He cut loose with a flashing run, took the lead outside the eighth pole and won with ease -- by three lengths.

Mayor Impellitteri prepared last night to take personal command of efforts to settle the six-day-old strike of 1,800 building supply drivers as construction experts warned that 100,000 mechanics and laborers would be made idle by tomorrow night if the tie-up continued.

Two former employes of Bethlehem Steel Corporation subsidiaries, who received more than $200,000 in kickbacks from stevedoring and shipping companies, were convicted yesterday in Federal court of income tax evasion and conspiracy to violate the tax laws.

Fred, of John Frederics, has an unusual idea this season. He has put past traditions behind him and has aimed to make his new hats, shown yesterday, the traditional ones of tomorrow. In other words, he has gone very modern. His theory as expressed in his millinery is to give women hats in great variety, which they will enjoy wearing because they are smart, comfortable and the right thing to wear with the present-day fashions.

The Boulevard Gardens Garage at the southeast corner of Fifty-sixth Street and Thirty-first Avenue in Woodside, Queens, has been sold by William K. Dick to the Lou-Rae Parking Corporation, of which Louis Packer is president. James Felt Co. were the brokers and the attorneys were Sullivan Cromwell for the seller and L. Robert Hitzig for the buyer.

The city's crop of babies may drop this year below the 160,000 mark for the first time since 1950, Health Department statisticians predicted yesterday as they scanned vital statistics for the first six months of 1953.

LONDON, July 8 -- Laborite members of Parliament reverted today to their former method of electing their policy-making committee or "shadow cabinet" -- for the seats on which there has been fierce competition in the past. The Parliamentary Labor party rejected a method of voting introduced last year with the aim of blocking the election of Aneurin Bevan, leader of the left wing of the party, and his supporters to the committee.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- A bill to give private industry the right to construct new power plants at Niagara Falls went to the House today. It may be headed for passage tomorrow.

Contributions by employers to welfare funds covering payments to employes in case of death, sickness and accidents are increasing daily. Vast amounts of money are involved. Unfortunately, according to a survey made for this newspaper by A. H. Raskin and published yesterday, it appears that insurance agents with underworld ties are siphoning off large segments of these funds in excessive commissions and "service" fees.

Is New York City too large, too secure in its supremacy as a center of population, business and industry or possibly too lethargic in its governmental leadership to be anxious about the unceasing drift of substantial residents to the suburbs, and the tremendous exodus of business activity to outlying areas ?
One point, outweighing all others, it occurs to me, is not receiving full emphasis in news accounts and editorial appraisals of the worker rebellions in Soviet-ruled East Germany in particular.
Orlando Zulueta of Havana scored an upset victory over Arthur Persley, lightweight boxer from Red Cross, La., in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- The Department of Defense announced today United States casualties in Korea increased by 402 last week to a new total of 137,914.

Animals on the pages of books had an hour's worth of fascination yesterday for children in Washington Square, where the New York Public Library opened its twenty-ninth annual summer program of outdoor storytelling.

It is too bad that Topics of The Times in discussing memorials to fiction (July 3) wandered so far -- from Central Park to Copenhagen -- without mentioning a sculptural attraction for the subway tourist in Brooklyn. To see Paul Bunyan's great blue ox New Yorkers need trek only to the outer edge of Prospect Park instead of journeying all the way to Bemidji, Minn.
I have just returned from Korea.
The State Conservation Department in Albany said yesterday that plans were being made to send a special pollution unit to inspect the sanitary conditions in the Pascack River near Spring Valley.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, July 9 (AP) -- Communist forces smashed against the United Nations front line in four savage attacks last night, and today the Reds were hurled back in bloody defeat by United States and South Korean defenders.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Eisenhower said today that he favored releasing more information on atomic weapons, both American and Russian, in the conviction that an enlightened American people made sound decisions.
There was much rejoicing at the Bronx Zoo yesterday because Penelope and Cecil were acting just as expectant platypuses should act.

LONDON, July 8 -- There have recently been indications in London that the British and United States views on the timing and circumstances of a four-power conference were coming into closer harmony and there is hope here that after the three-power talks beginning in Washington on Friday there will be even less of a difference of opinion.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Following is a policy statement of the Government's Books and Library Program that was released tonight by Dr. Robert L. Johnson, Administrator of the International Information Administration of the Department of State, who said the statement was released with the approval of John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of a White House statement today on the report of the President's Committee on International Information Activities:

John L. Schoenfeld, vice chairman and senior member of the State Commission of Correction, will be sworn in for a fifth four-year term on that board at noon tomorrow. He has been reappointed by Governor Dewey. Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran will administer the oath in a ceremony at his office at 270 Broadway.

THE sea is still running high in current literature. This morning's new novel about boisterous action afloat in World War II is called "The Deep Six"* -- and it is true to the "Mister Roberts" tradition in its fashion. We haven't had a book on Melville's symbolism for a while, but that lull in the "Moby Dick" latitudes can only be temporary.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The first edition of Democratic Digest, a pocket-size monthly magazine of the Democratic party, is off the presses and subscriber copies are in the mail, Clayton Fritchey, deputy chairman of the Democratic National Committee and editor of the magazine, announced today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 8 -- President Sukarno asked Barhuddin Harahap, 36-year-old chairman of the Moslem party parliamentary faction, tonight to form a cabinet in the fourth attempt to resolve Indonesia's thirty-five-day-old crisis. Mr. Harahap's appointment was made after the Nationalist party had failed in attempts to form a cabinet with and without the Moslems and with Communist front support.

Three upstate locals of the United Brewery Workers, C. I. O., with a combined membership of 3,000, have voted to join seven New York locals in transferring their allegiance to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L., it was announced yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 8 -- Opponents of the Metcalf-Hatch Act, the 1952 state law that permits seizure of unclaimed dogs for scientific experiments in certified laboratories, lost another suit today to have the act declared unconstitutional.

The manuscript of James Street's "The Civil War" was recently received by Dial Press. It is described as "an unvarnished account of the late but still lively hostilities as told by James Street," wherein the author gives "a play-by-play picture of our 'Civil War Between the States.' "
ROME, July 8 -- Vittorio de Sica, the motion picture director, has undertaken to act as auctioneer at the sale of modern art in an effort to save from financial ruin the ancient Caffe Greco.

For any soldier of any land and age there has been one classic source of trial and treasure -- the company he is forced to keep. After many years of picking among the thousands of humans the world confronts him with, a man is suddenly squeezed somewhere into the great structure of a national army.

Surgeons at the New York Hospital performed an exploratory operation yesterday morning on Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, it was announced in a bulletin issued by the hospital shortly after noon.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 8 -- Frederick G. Singer, an authority on international trade and tariff policies, asserted here today that the United States was playing its proper role as a creditor nation and that international trade difficulties of other countries did not result from the American international trade system.

SUMMIT, N. J., July 8 -- Lou Barbaro of Hollywood, N. J., took the lead in the thirty-third annual New Jersey State Golf Association's open championship by scoring a 5 under par 36, 31 -- 67 over the South course of the Canoe Brook Country Club today.

PARIS, July 8 -- The fourteen North Atlantic Treaty Organization Governments are currently studying a proposal that, if accepted, would enhance the role of the permanent North Atlantic Council here as a coordinating center for Western strategy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 -- Louis B. Mayer said today that no options on the story and play properties he owns outright had been included in the Cinerama Productions-Stanley Warner Theatres deal announced on Monday in New York.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Senate and House conferees on the foreign aid authorization bill made limited progress today, splitting a $100,000,000 difference in military assistance earmarked for the Middle East and Africa and adjusting other minor conflicts in the measures passed by either chamber.

Thirty-seven men and two women were held yesterday in bail of $500 to $10,000 as police decoding experts studied records seized in Tuesday's widespread gambling raids in efforts to find clues to major bookmakers and policy racketeers in this area.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- The Treasury received offers to lend the Government more than $8,500,000,000 when it set out on Monday to borrow $5,500,000,000, it was announced today.
TOKYO, Thursday, July 9 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,670, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- A barrage of thirteen hits that included seven doubles and two home runs gave the front-running Dodgers an 8-4 victory over the fourth-place Phillies before 22,601 fans at Connie Mack Stadium tonight.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 8 -- A serious dispute has developed among Communist leaders of Bulgaria, according to persons here who by their background and interest are well acquainted with affairs in that neighboring country. The basic issue is whether Bulgaria should relax Stalinist controls as they have been relaxed elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that plantings of cotton this year were 9 per cent under those of last year. This indicated that drought and other unfavorable conditions in growing areas might keep the crop from becoming a surplus problem.
Prompt action by a patrolman on traffic duty and firemen who responded to his alarm yesterday averted a disastrous explosion and fire.

PITTSBURGH, July 8 -- It required two base-clearing wallops by Monty Irvin, the second one a grand-slam homer in the eleventh inning, before the Giants finally got around to pinning down the Pirates for keeps, 10 to 7, just as the clock reached midnight tonight.

The House Ways and Means Committee, in an open revolt against its veteran chairman, Daniel A. Reed, went on record decisively yesterday as favoring President Eisenhower's request to extend the excess profits tax for another six months. The vote was 16 -- 9 for the Administration, which means that aside from the chairman the membership was two-to-one for the President.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 9 -- The United Nations Command ordered its liaison officers to Panmunjom today to fix with their Communist counterparts the time for a plenary meeting to pave the way for an armistice in the Korean war despite the bitter opposition of President Syngman Rhee of South Korea.

PARIS, July 8 -- A desperate effort to clarify the baffling problem of the war in Indo-China will be made by Georges Bidault, the French Foreign Minister, in the meetings he will have in Washington beginning Friday with John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, and the Marquess of Salisbury, British Acting Foreign Secretary.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee approved today, over strong protests of its Democratic members, a program to sell twenty-eight Government synthetic rubber plants by next July 1.
CINCINNATI, July S {YP)--Wilmer IVfizell held the Redlegs to two hits tonight as the Cardinals, sparked by the hitting of Ray Jablonski and Rip Repulski, scored a 7-3 victory.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- President Roosevelt signed a lend-lease bill in 1941 although he called a portion of it unconstitutional in an official opinion that has been kept secret for twelve years.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Administration clarified its position on the Overseas Book and Library Program in a policy statement tonight that termed book burning a "wicked symbolic act" that was not to be condoned.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 8 (UP) -- Dr. Dale R. Dickens said tonight that X-rays showed Don Zimmer, St. Paul shortstop who was hit by a pitched ball, had suffered a skull fracture.

A drop of 2,468,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies aggregated 144,497,000 barrels, compared with 146,965,000 a week earlier and 119,533,000 a year before.

The State of Louisiana borrowed $7,500,000 yesterday in the public market on an issue of highway bonds maturing serially from 1958 to 1988. The bonds were sold to a banking syndicate headed by C. J. Devine Co. at a bid of 100.027 for interest coupons of 5 per cent, 3 1/4 per cent and 3 1/2 per cent, an interest cost of 3.55 per cent.

TORONTO, July 8 (AP) -- Gardner Dickenson, a slender young golfer a few months out of the United States Army, came in early tonight with a five-under-par 66 to join Tommy Bolt of Houston and Ted Kroll of Utica, N. Y., as leaders of a par-breaking parade in the first round of the Canadian open golf championship.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A Democratic effort to force a Federal floor under declining cattle prices stalled Senate action today on the Administration's Emergency Farm Disaster and Drought Loans Bill.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 8 (AP) -- Jamie, a $1,250 bargain basement colt owned by Charles McKinley of Fort Wayne, Ind., won the $7,900 Historic-Dickerson trot today in a four-heat race that was supposed to be a big test for the Hambletonian here Aug. 12.

PARIS, July 8 -- Broader executive powers to make budget cuts and transfer credits than had been granted to any post-war Cabinet are contained in the finance recovery bill that passed on first reading in the National Assembly after a debate lasting through last night and part of today.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Eisenhower and his principal military and diplomatic advisers this evening prepared for Gen. Mark W. Clark, the Commander of United Nations forces in Korea, new instructions embodying a reply to the Communist authorities in Korea who yesterday agreed to go ahead with preparations for an armistice despite South Korea's opposition.

LONDON, July 8 -- The fact that 200 of the United States servicemen stationed in Britain marry British girls every month was cited in the House of Lords today as evidence that the average G. I. was getting along well with the public.

DETROIT, July 8 -- The Ordinance Corps prepared today to embark on a gradual demobilization of the military hardware industry, built up since the start of the Korean War three years ago to equip the Army with modern tanks and other combat vehicles.

GENEVA, July 8 -- Politeness and good will rose from the council table and filled the summer air like incense today when the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations debated East-West economic cooperation.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 8 -- Victor Seixas today played his first match since winning the championship at Wimbledon and crushed as robust a hitter as Edward Dailey of Princeton by 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1 in the invitation tournament at the Bath and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- John Riffe, executive vice president of the C. I. O., said today the union would protest to the A. F. L. against the transfer of the New York brewery locals as a violation of the spirit of a no-raiding agreement that had been agreed to tentatively.
An offering of 339,733 shares of common stock of the Monterey Oil Company is being made today at $24 a share by an investment banking group led by Lehman Brothers.

HONG KONG, July 8 -- British business circles here have shown no great enthusiasm for a 30,000,000 ($84,000,000) "business arrangement" between the China National Import and Export Corporation in Communist China and a group of British businessmen.

The sixty - family apartment house at 595 East 168th Street in the Bronx is under contract of sale to Leo Bercow and Walter Berger, operators and investors. The property is assessed at $220,000 and is being sold by clients of Stanley Russell, lawyer.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 8 -- Two persons were lost and two others were rescued off here today when a light passenger plane of the Cape Cod Flying Service crashed into the sea two miles northwest of Race Point.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved a $5,238,000,000 money bill to finance four Government agencies, including the Atomic Energy Commission, for the next twelve months.

BUENOS AIRES, July 8 -- Presidents Juan Peron and Carlos Ibanez signed today a ten-point treaty of Argentine-Chilean economic unity which they described as the "first great step to closer relations in the future."

The newest resident of James Ewing Hospital is the only one admitted through the window, and probably the only one that wanted to get into the hospital. Named "E. Wing" for purposes of hospital records, it is a tiny yellow canary whose lilting song has cheered the hearts of patients on the second floor since his arrival Monday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 8 -- Tension between Cambodia and France was eased today by a statement from the Cambodian Premier, Penn Nouth, that the French note on independence, while not entirely satisfactory, "constitutes a basis for negotiation."

The M. A. Hanna Company, producers and marketers of anthracite and bituminous coal and iron ore, the first company to announce semi-annual operating results, yesterday reported a net profit of $5,635,889 for the first half of 1953.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Arkansas challenged today the constitutionality of the recent act of Congress giving states titles to submerged offshore lands.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 8 (UP) -- Frank Stranahan, 30-year- old amateur golfer, paced favored Ben Hogan and the best of the Empire golfers today when he fired a two-under-par 70 to take the first-round lead in the British open championship.

TEHERAN, July 8 (AP) -- President Eisenhower has written Premier Mossadegh not to expect any large-scale economic aid from the United States until he reaches an oil agreement with Britain, Iranian sources said today.

JERUSALEM, July 8 -- Plans to mobilize unorganized well-wishers of Israel were discussed at a four-day meeting of World Zionist leaders in Jerusalem but decisions on how these potential supporters should be enrolled were deferred until the session of the Zionist General Council scheduled to meet Dec. 15.

It will be business as usual today for the thirty-seven-vessel fleet of the Moore-McCormack Lines, one of the country's leading steamship lines, which will celebrate the fortieth anniversary of its founding. In the last four decades the green house flag with its white center circle enclosing a big red "M" has become a familiar sight in many parts of the world.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Eisenhower Administration won its hardest fought victory of this Congressional session today as the House Ways and Means Committee approved the renewal until Dec. 31 of the excess profits tax.
WESTBURY, L. P., July 8 (AP) -- Prince Terry, owned by Paul Wixom of Chicago, tonight won the Fire Island Pace by a head at Roosevelt Raceway. Gay Abbe was second with Todd Scott in third place.

The New Jersey Highway Authority financed permanently yesterday more than half of the estimated cost of the 165-mile Garden State Parkway now under construction in sixteen sections from Paterson south to Cape May.

President Eisenhower's suggestion at his press conference yesterday that the State Department quit making a secret of its directives for American libraries abroad, and the Administration's policy statement on those libraries, may be the first steps toward clarifying a thoroughly confused and unsatisfactory situation.

I have recently returned from a five-day visit in your wonderful New York. But I am compelled to say to a newspaper that promises to "print the truth impartially" that there is a woeful lack of courtesy and ordinary decency in the treatment that waiters, bus and taxicab drivers and the tradespeople in general give to visitors.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, declared today he was "getting a runaround" in his efforts to obtain action this year on a proposed constitutional amendment to limit treaty-making powers.

Foreign countries, as a whole, have been accumulating gold and dollar assets with "startling rapidity," but some have increased restrictions on American goods, it was asserted in a re port yesterday by Dr. Claudius Murchison, economic adviser to the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee, overriding objections of the Eisenhowen Administration, approved today a bill to give domestic industries and agriculture increased protection against competitive imports.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 8 -- The Wheatley Hills star, Willie Klein, a three-time winner of the tournament, led the field of 136 players by one stroke with 36, 33 -- 69, at the end of the first round in the Long Island Golf Association open championship at the Meadow Brook Club today.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 8 (AP) -- Joseph M. Roebling's speedy Crisset moved into the stake class at Monmouth Park today by annexing the $15,000 added New Jersey Futurity before 22,719, the biggest weekday crowd of the meet.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 8 -- Ngura Kirilo Japhet of Tanganyika, who, though he spoke only Swahili, came to New York last year to plead the case of his Wameru tribesmen before the Trusteeship Council of the United Nations, got a cool reception when he made a farewell appearance before the same group today.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., July 8 -- Mrs. Jerome Herbert, Old Oaks, and Mrs. Donald O'Brien, Winged Foot, two former Wheeler Cup holders, teamed in best-ball play today, and despite a 72 by Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks, the Metropolitan champion, scored a rousing upset, 1 up on the twentieth hole, over Miss Swift and Mrs. Saul Weinsier.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Republicans at key points in the Senate predicted today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy would accept the resignation of J. B. Matthews, the new executive staff director of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, and possibly soon.

A program of well-known classics was conducted last night in Lewisohn Stadium by Pierre Monteux. An audience of 4,000 turned out to hear the Stadium Symphony in Mendelssohn's "Ruy Blas" Overture, the Brahms First Symphony and, with Henri Deering at the piano, the Schumann Concerto.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- State Department officials expressed some surpise tonight that Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky of Russia might not permit the Soviet chess team to visit the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization today announced the granting of Federal tax benefits to Bethlehem Steel Company to assist the financing of plant facilities costing $30,000,000 for the production of wide-flange structural steel products.

BABYLON, L. I., July 8 -- James H. Northrop, North Babylon school principal, who was dismissed June 5 after charges of misconduct, has been rehired as supervising principal by the new Board of Education, which assumed office July 1 and held its first meeting last night.

GLEN COVE, L. I., July 8 -- Supreme Court Justice Percy D. Stoddart denied today the application of a Long Island lawyer for $50,000 in damages and an order to demolish a chapel being constructed on the Morgan Estates at East Island. The lawyer had brought the action on the ground that his own home 600 yards away was being depreciated because of the work.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Louis S. Rothschild, Maritime Administrator, granted permission to the Matson Navigation Company today to sell to a Panamanian concern the 18,150-gross-ton liner Mariposa.

LOS ANGELES, July 8 -- A scheduled exhibit of the works of the Mexican painter Jose Clemente Orozco at the art gallery of the University of California at Los Angeles has been summarily canceled after a controversy on the artist's alleged left-wing leanings.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Senators survived two home runs by Eddie Robinson and another by Cass Michaels of the Athletics to defeat Philadelphia, 7 -- 4, tonight. Sonny Dixon scored his fourth victory in a relief role.
ELMIRA, N. Y., July 8 (AP) -- Health authorities rushed crews into two polio-stricken counties today to set up what officials called the biggest mass anti-polio inoculation in history.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Eisenhower said today that efforts to create the European Defense Community, with its single army, and the unification of Germany should proceed concurrently. He asserted no nation except an aggressor should fear this dual objective of the free world.
With his second straight route-going job, Jim McDonald last night pitched the Yankees to a 4-2 victory over the Red Sox. The non-televised contest attracted 41,910 paying spectators to the Stadium.

Paired with Bent Larsson, Denmark's representative in the world junior chess championship, James T. Sherwin of New York was a pawn ahead when they adjourned in the sixth round, according to a report from Copenhagen yesterday.

Robert Whitehead has closed the deal granting him the production rights to "Stars in a Person's Backyard," a first play by Miss Jay Presson. The script, tentatively titled, has been under Mr. Whitehead's consideration for the last several weeks. Having acquired it, he now plans to heroin rehearsals in September and to shoot for a New York opening late in l October after the usual out-of-towns preliminaries.

The trend toward producing "high-style" furniture at moderate prices is again reflected in a new collection of forty-five pieces made by the Murray Furniture Manufacturing Company. In the collection, which bears the name of its designer, Milo Baughman, most of the pieces are priced at $50 or under, though prices range from $17 for a small table to $300 for a large couch-bed.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, July 8 (Reuters) -- The South African House of Assembly voted today for continued "co-operation" with the British Commonwealth but turned down a motion for continued "membership."
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and closing prices were irregular, 9 points off on July but unchanged to 8 points up on other months.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- When he gets into an airplane it does not matter whether he travels three hours or six hours, President Eisenhower said today. Thus he indicated he had no aversion to a transfer of the proposed Bermuda conference to London.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 8 -- The United States charge d'affaires, Francis H. Russell, said today the United States "does not favor the Arabs over Israel just as it does not favor Israel over the Arabs." He said the United States was trying to bring peace between Israel and the Arabs and would never cease to believe that peace between them was possible.
CHICAGO, July 8 (UP) -- Sam Mele smashed a grand slam home run during an eighth-run inning today as the White Sox slugged fifteen hits for a 14-4 victory over the Tigers before 23,479.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 8 -- Iran's claims to the Soviet war debt in gold and dollars and demands for the return of a dozen areas along the border occupied by the Russians were presumably presented in a note reported handed yesterday to Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, by Nadir Arasteh, Iranian Ambassador to Moscow.

A two-story factory at 1042 Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by Bernard Ruggieri, as trustee, to a syndicate headed by Simon Mogeloff and represented by George Kossoy as attorney. A first mortgage loan of $100,000 was made by the Corn Exchange Bank and Trust Company in connection with the transaction.

Irene of New York, in her fall millinery collection, might well be called the answer to the prayer of both the woman who wants an excitingly pretty hat and the retailer who wants business, for her designs, with their undeniable flattery, are planned to supply both.

Dr. John F. Erdmann, New York's grand old man of surgery, entered the operating room at old Post Graduate Hospital, now University Hospital, yesterday, as he had done thousands of other times in his sixty-six years of practice. But instead of the customary intent silence the audience in the amphitheatre burst into loud applause.

LONDON, July 8 -- A recovery by British Government securities, a further expansion of business among oil shares and widespread though small gains by industrials were the features of today's trading on the stock markets.

At one of its stormiest meetings in many years, the Richmond County Democratic Committee last night redesignated Borough President Edward G. Baker, the regular organization candidate, as its nominee for the post he now holds. The meeting was held in the Ralph R. McKee Vocational and Technical High School in St. George, S. I.

BERLIN, July 8 -- Despite reports of renewed work stoppages in many parts of East Berlin and East Germany, the Government of the city's Soviet sector said today it would lift tomorrow all restrictions on travel between East and West Berlin and restore rapid transit connections.

Trading in coffee on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange continued to be influenced by reports of killing frosts in Brazil. Conflicting figures have been received but most sources agree that damage to plants will prove catastrophic to the 1954-55 crop in the Sao Paulo and Parana areas.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Heavy mill buying of futures against liberal flour sales increased the buying competition for wheat futures today, the market working sharply higher, with profit-taking at intervals by longs easily absorbed.

A. Spencer Allen began an ambitious campaign yesterday to persuade New Yorkers to shuttle back and forth to New Jersey again, as they did not so long ago to buy cheap cigarettes. This time the objectives will be watches and other items to be sold by S. Klein in Newark at discounts from "fixed prices" averaging 30 to 35 per cent and ranging from 20 to 63 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by White House rules:
WHEN Bob Mathias won the Olympic decathlon championship at Helsinki last summer, he swore the blood oath.

Blubber, or whale fat, is about the only food most of us associate with the Eskimos. But Miss Sally Carrighar, who lived one year in an Eskimo village and two years in Nome, speaks enthusiastically of the diversities and delicacies of the Alaskan diet.

MOSCOW, July 8 -- The Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Andrei Y. Vishinsky, has advised the United States that, if Soviet chess players are not permitted to visit the country house of the Soviet United Nations delegation at Glen Cove, L. I., they will not come to the United States and will not participate in the scheduled match with United States players.

Fred G. Smith has been appointed national sales manager of the adding machine division of Underwood Corporation, and Lawson H. Hilliard has been named national sales manager of the supply division. R. E. Stewart has been aPpointed manager f sales of the ersonnel division of the corporaiion.

UTICA, N. Y., July 8 (AP) -- Willie Turnesa, former United States and British amateur champion, was hard-pressed to defeat a virtual unknown today in the first round of the New York State amateur golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Air Force assured a New Jersey Congressional group today that efforts are being made to restore contracts to two Trenton, N. J., manufacturers.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 8 -- Frances Schneidewind of Essex Fells, N. J., rated No. 2 in the tourney, was the first of the seeded players to be ousted from the New York State women's tennis championships, in progress at the New Rochelle Tennis Club, when she dropped a 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3 third-round decision to Mrs. Margaret Disco of Forest Hills today.

And so, after reading the instructions carefully for the fifteenth time, one sends the young man off to camp again, with the "one pair comfortable every-day shoes," the "one pair shoes for hiking," the "four pairs dungarees," the "one pair dress trousers for Sundays" (he says he never wore these last year, but one follows the instructions blindly, hopefully).

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The events of today in the Ways and Means Committee were inevitable after Chairman Reed made the issue over extending the excess profits tax for six months a clear and major test of the President's fiscal program and of the firmness with which the President would pursue his goal of a balanced budget.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., July 8 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman arrived home tonight after saying the Democrats were voted out of office by "prosperous, fat and easy-going", citizens who "let demagoguery get the best of them." Mr, and Mrs. Truman were greeted on their arrival here from a motor tour to Washington and New York by her brothers, George and Frank Wallace, and their families. Mr. Truman Was jovial and relaxed.

BARNEGAT LIGHT, N. J., July 8 (AP) -- The Navy today wrote into its formal records the story of a bell that prevented a shipwreck and of residents of this Jersey seacoast town who set up an "Operation Good Samaritan."

LOS ANGELES, July 8 -- "In my lifetime we will not see this country abandon the program of managed money into which we have moved progressively since the establishment of the Federal Reserve System in 1913," Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers and for thirteen years head of the Brookings Institution, told public school teachers attending the Southern California Conference on Economic Education at Pomona College today.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Forest Service today endorsed proposed legislation to restrict surface rights granted With mining claims in the national forests.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended July 1:
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 8 -- Freedom for colonial peoples was the keynote at today's session of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

A fine milliner to the tips of his fingers, Laddie Northridge yesterday presented a fall collection as rich in detail as seen in many a season. Viewed at the Pierre Hotel, he showed hats of broadtail, ocelot plush, bronze kid, sleek jersey and glistening panne, silhouettes flashing with jewels with almost a Byzantine color and fabulous grandeur, intricately manipulated felts and velours and fairylike tiaras, called three dimensional, aglitter with twinkling undersealike flowers.

Samuel S. Leibowitz, Kings County judge, charged yesterday that Tuesday's gambling raids, instituted by Frank S. Hogan, District Attorney of New York County, were "politically motivated" to improve Mr. Hogan's chance of nomination for Mayor on a Democratic-Republican coalition ticket and increase his chance of election on Nov. 3.

NORWALK, Conn., July 8 -- Fifteen hundred production workers at the Hat Corporation of America will go on strike Thursday morning, James V. Novaco, president of the Joint Norwalk Board of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union, A. F. L., said today.

Beginning shortly after 6 A. M. airline passengers and other persons in a hurry may spin from one of the metropolitan area's three major airports to another by helicopter. They will have to pay about the equivalent of taxi fares, but they will save considerable time and will escape the miseries of heavy road traffic.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., July 8 (AP) -- The nation's sweet tooth is getting sweeter, and so are candy sales, confection salesmen were told today.
The recent report of the convention of the American Association of University Women in THE TIMES filled me, a member of the organization, with a sense of shame and despair.

Some manufacturing plants in the New York area with contracts to produce ordnance materiel for the armed services are "not functioning properly" and at least two have failed completely to live up to their commitments, a spokesman for the subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee declared yesterday.

National advertising in the United States, running 8 per cent ahead of the record made in 1952, promises to reach close to $8,000,000,000 for 1953. This is reported in the current edition of Printers' Ink.

Rails rattled briskly forward in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, but their advance was insufficient to offset losses among the industrials. Some of the early declines, caused by the House Ways and Means Committee's approval of excess profits tax extension, held to the close, and the market as a whole showed a net loss on the day. Most changes were slight.

A number of American clergymen were identified as Communists or fellow-travelers yesterday by the third former Communist official to so testify in two days before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Eisenhower's committee on psychological warfare warned today that Russia, far from abandoning her basic objective of a Communist world controlled by the Kremlin, would intensify her efforts to destroy the United States in the pursuit of that goal.

First-day response yesterday to the three-day appeal by the New York regional Red Cross blood program for whole blood for immediate shipment to the armed forces in Korea and Japan was described as "good."

After reading various articles in the press and hearing numerous radio commentators refer to a virtual "reign of terror" among the teachers of the United States I must for myself and for my many friends and co-workers in the profession protest this gross exaggeration.

The New York City Housing Authority was blocked yesterday by the State Supreme Court from enforcing the Federal law requiring tenants in Federally aided, low-rent housing projects to sign certificates of nonmembership in organizations designated as subversive by the United States Attorney General.

JOHANNESBURG, Union of South Africa, July 8 -- Dr. H. M. De Kock, Governor of the South African Reserve Bank, advised South Africa today to retain import controls "for the time being" but to lessen restrictions on imports from the dollar area "which would widen the field of competition and reduce South Africa's cost structure."

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, drew gasps today from a room crowded with executives for standard radio broadcasting companies when he told them to "wake up!" and face the fact that "this is a television age."
Another ship has been added to the merchant marine of the Dominican Republic, giving that nation a fleet of four freighters operating between New York and Trujillo City.

LLANGOLLEN, Wales, July 8 -- Welsh was only one of a babel of strange tongues heard today in the sunny, decorated streets of this town on the border of England. Choirs and dancing groups in colorful national costumes have come here from nearly every European country to take part in the seventh annual International Eisteddfod (pronounced Ice-thvod) or festival of dance and music.

It is encouraging to learn from the 1952 report of Herbert R. O'Brien, Director of Civil Defense, that on last Dec. 31 there were 331,277 persons who had volunteered for civil defense duty. The number represented an increase of 142,996 over the 188,281 persons who had volunteered by Dec. 31, 1951.

Home games of the "Fighting Irish" football team will be shown "live" and life-size by television projected on theatre screens over the country, under an agreement between the University of Notre Dame and the newly organized Box Office Television, Inc.
MILWAUKEE, July 8 (UP) -- Wareen Hacker won a duel of "hard luck" pitchers with Jim Wilson tonight as the Cubs downed the Braves, 7 to 3.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Jacob Burck, cartoonist for The Chicago Sun-Times, was ordered deported today on the ground that he was a member of the Communist party after he had entered the United States. The order was issued by Jerome T. McGowan, special inquiry officer for the Immigration Bureau.

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- The rampaging White Sox today moved to within five games of the league-leading Yankees with a 4-2 verdict over the Tigers on Harry Dorish's relief pitching and Sam Mele's two-run homer.

Federal Judge Mortimer W.
