Byers granted yesterday the petition of William Wyer, trustee of the Long Island Rail Road, to permit the bankrupt railroad to settle its tax claims with the City of New York. The judge also approved a final payment to the city of $2,046,831, the money to be taken from the proceeds of the sale of the Rockaway Branch of the railroad to the city.

Bulky files of catalogued evidence obtained in Tuesday's sweeping gambling raids were placed yesterday in the custody of General Sessions Judge Louis J. Capozzoli as twenty-eight search warrants he had issued were returned.
Tallulah Bankhead, the actress, filed two suits in Supreme Court yesterday asking $25,500 from her accountant and her bank for checks raised by her former maid-secretary, Evyleen Ramsay Cronin.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The text of Federal Judge James Alger Fee's ruling in the damage case growing out of the famous 1940-41 strike against Montgomery Ward Co. in Portland, Ore., includes one of the strongest restatements of the dominance of law and the public interest over groups illegally serving their special concerns that has been delivered from the bench since labor unions acquired their power to cripple the national economy.

The State Housing Commissioner, Herman T. Stichman, has repeated and amplified serious charges against the city administration in respect to official pursuit of violations of fire, health and safety laws in multiple dwellings. He cites increases in fire deaths and in fire insurance rates.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, Republican of New Jersey, announced today that he had called a meeting of the Senate subcommittee on Civil Liberties, which he heads, to look into charges by Corliss Lamont that nineteen copies of his books were burned in a riot at Chicago April 12.

Steel production in this country set a record for any June and output in the first half was at a new peak for any half year. Production for the six months to June 30 exceeded the estimated combined output of Russia, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands for all of 1952.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The foreign ministers of Britain and France arrived in Washington today for a series of informal conferences with John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, in an effort to iron out foreign policy differences between them and to devise, if possible, new means of blunting the effectiveness of the Soviet "peace offensive" among European neutralists.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 9 -- Dr. Merle A. Tuve, who directed the development of the proximity fuse, dropped a bombshell in academic circles here tonight when he advocate that all scientific research into secret military devices be removed from American colleges and universities.

His Boots of the Brookmeade Stable showed his old form as he won the Hitchcock Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Second choice to the odds-on Errolford in the test of about two miles, His Boots held the lead through most of the race to score by two lengths.

Uncertainty over Korea, possibly some slight disappointment over prospects for excess profits tax extension and hot weather combined to give the New York Stock Exchange a soft and drowsy session yesterday. Despite the strength of American Telephone and Telegraph and a couple of rails, prices in general staggered lower throughout the day.

An apartment house site 200 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Arlington Avenue and West 232d Street in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been purchased by the Maschiff Realty Company from a client of E. Osborne Smith, Inc., broker.
Twelve Municipal Housing Authorities of the State of Massachusetts sold $23,854,000 of state-guaranteed temporary loan notes at interest rates ranging from 1.82 per cent to 1.92 per cent.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 2 points higher to 10 points lower than on Wednesday.

An internal battle over whether to become affiliated with the American Federation of Labor or the Congress of Industrial Organizations has erupted again in the United Telephone Organizations, an independent union representing 17,000 plant employes of the New York Telephone Company.

Citizenship education combining both knowledge and action was advocated yesterday by William F. Russell, president of Columbia University Teachers College, as an effective counter-measure to the threat of communism.

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of New York banks rose $10,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, reversing the $170,000,000 drop the week before, the Federal Reserve Bank here reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- To anyone who remembers as far back as February, the State Department's new policy statement on its overseas library books had a familiar ring. In fact, it rang like the directive of Feb. 3 that, in the process of being reversed, clarified and shredded, has reduced some State Department officials to a state of raw nerves.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Eisenhower nominated two Assistant Secretaries of Labor today and the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee gave unanimous approval to three other nominees for important labor posts.

OTTAWA, July 9 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent made his greatest bid for popular support in the general election tonight with a nation-wide broadcast from Vancouver, B. C. He asserted that under the Liberal Government Canada has already achieved a high level of social security and has greater equality of income than ever before.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Republican leaders completed arrangements today for the House of Representatives to pass without change tomorrow a bill to renew the excess profits tax through Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Individual savings were $2,500,000,000 in the first quarter of this year, the highest for any first quarter since the end of the war, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today. The total was $100,000,000 higher than in the corresponding quarter of 1952.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee met again today without agreeing on an Administration bill to admit 240,000 refugees and other immigrants to this country. An attempt to compromise differences was under way.

The campaign to increase the consumption of cognac in the United States, begun last October, is paying off, according to a report made yesterday by Harry L. Lourie, executive vice president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, and I. M. Bomba, chairman of the importers' special cognac committee.

Four of the five Democratic county leaders in this city met yesterday at the Commodore Hotel for their first conference on the local political situation. They discussed only issues, and did not even mention possible candidates for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

"A Skeptic's Political Dictionary and Handbook for the Disenchanted," a new work by Max Nomad, will be issued in August by Bookman Associates. The first part of the book is cast in the form used by Pierre Bayle, Voltaire and Ambrose Bierce in their "dictionaries."

Your editorial on July 7 under the heading "Arbitration Enforcement" focused attention upon a serious defect in the whole process of arbitration under labor-management agreements resulting from judicial abuse and interference. You indicated that the Pennsylvania Commission on Labor Legislation had recommended enactment of a law in that state which might eliminate undue intervention by the courts in labor arbitrations.

The Irving Trust Company has announced the promotion of four members of the company's branch office staff. Kenneth M. McGhee has been named vice president, and George W. Lownes, G. Robert Treux Jr. and Don C. Wheaton Jr. have been elected assistant secretaries.

ALBANY, July 9 -- A student who wants to study medicine in New York State stands a better chance of getting admitted to one of the nine professional schools if he is Protestant rather than Catholic or Catholic rather than Jewish, a report to the Board of Regents indicated today.

HAWTHORNE, N. Y., July 9 -- Traps for truck operators who try to avoid the state's new truck tax law were being set tonight in Westchester County by the State Police. Portable scales will be used at unannounced places along the highways in the next few days to apprehend offenders, troopers said at Troop K barracks.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 (AP) -- Marine Capt. Ted Williams returned to the United States today from air combat service in Korea and firmly ruled out any possibility that he would return to baseball this season.

General-care beds in the city's hospitals increased by almost 2,000 from Jan. 1, 1946, to Jan. 1, 1953, according to the latest bulletin of the Hospital Council of Greater New York, published yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, called on the Senate today for the speedy sale of the General Aniline Film Corporation and other properties seized by the Government under the trading-with-the-enemy law.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UP) -- Frank Shea staggered through to his eighth victory of the year today as the Senators defeated the Athletics, 8 -- 4.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, July 10 -- The Government of the Republic of Korea said this morning in an official statement that the Communist letter last Tuesday to Gen. Mark W. Clark agreeing to resume the truce sessions should have been "rejected and dismissed without reply."

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Harold E. Talbott, secretary of the Air Force, demanded and won today an apology from the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., after its acting president, Emil Mazey, had implied that the recent cancellation of Kaiser-Frazer airplane contracts at Willow Run, Mich., was tied to Mr. Talbott's past business associations.
IT turned a year in June since Sam Chevalier began to set the aerial travel pattern that could be commonplace for New Yorkers in 2000 A. D.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 9 (AP) -Parker Byrd cut one and three-quarter seconds from the historic track record for 2-year-old pacers today but Frank Ervin stole the show by driving the winners of four of the five races.
A wide choice of styles and fabrics was suggested for the fall bride and her attendants at the bridal fashion show given last night at McCreery's.
The foreign ministers' conference that opens in Washington today, brings together from Britain and France two old hands in international diplomacy to sit with John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State.
Last night's program at the American Lyric Theatre had a novelty in the form of a new one-act opera by Martin Kalmanoff, set to a libretto by Atra Baer.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., July 9 -Four-year-olds have been going to school in Ridgefield for a quarter of a century, with the town footing the bill most of that time. Nursery classes as part of a public school system are still rare in most parts of the country, but the people of Ridgefield are so pleased with the idea they have voted to build a new elementary school with more spacious quarters for their youngest pupils.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -President Eisenhower today nominated Robert W. Dill, New York stock broker, to be Collector of Customs for District 10 at New York City.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Eisenhower will fly to Amarillo, Tex., tomorrow morning to meet with the Governors of six drought-stricken states, the White House announced tonight.

The Administration bill to add 240,000 refugees and other necessitous immigrants to the regular quotas during the next two years was meeting with opposition yesterday in the Senate Judiciary Committee. Some opponents thought that our nation of about 160,000,000 souls could not absorb that many additional newcomers or that the wrong persons would get in.

BONN, Germany, July 9 -- The West German Government dispatched a note last night to the United States, British and French Governments outlining its required prerequisites for the reunification of Germany and urging that these receive serious consideration by three Western foreign ministers at their meeting in Washington.

LONDON, July 9 -- Britain's first atomic bomb was designed and partly made and assembled at Fort Halstead in Kent, twenty miles southeast of London, by six men, it was disclosed today at a press preview of a film showing the preparation and detonation of the weapon in the Monte Bello Islands off Australia last October.

LONDON, July 9 -- British Government securities led the stock markets today, especially the shorter-term issues, which rose as much as one-quarter per cent. By contrast, industrials were quieter and profit-taking gave price movements an irregular appearance.
CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 9 (AP) -- Ten great golfers were bunched within four strokes to- night at the head of the pack as a scramble developed for the prized British open championship.
LONDON, July 9 -- Speculation about the state of health of the British Prime Minister, Sir Winston Churchill, reached a climax today, two weeks after he had retired to the country for a rest.

Under its program of economic austerity, Brazil reduced by nearly 65 per cent its volume of imports from the United States in the first half of 1953 compared with the like period of last year, according to an announcement yesterday by the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau.

Music lovers who tuned in on Station WQXR last night to listen to Mischa Elman play Beethoven's Violin Concerto in D from Lewisohn Stadium heard the concerto all right but it was Jascha Heifetz, not Mr. Elman, who was the radio soloist.

The market for Government securities had a quiet day yesterday following announcement that subscriptions of more than $100,000 to the Treasury's new offering of 2 1/2 per cent tax anticipation certificates would be subject to allotment to the extent of 67 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Jewish War Veterans of the United States accused John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, today of "fence-straddling" on the critical Middle Eastern problem of Arab-Israeli hostility.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- President Eisenhower asked the Tariff Commission today to investigate the effects of wool imports on the domestic wool price support program.

Private cables from Brazil reported yesterday that frost damage to the coffee crop had been overestimated, and prices dropped on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Beneficial rains were said to be falling in the Parana area and new trees to have survived the frost better than had been expected.

PARIS, July 9 -- French television transmitted from the Eiffel Tower is the closest thing yet on this side of the Atlantic to output from the Empire State tower. If, qualitatively, French video lacks the polish and know-how of American TV, in spirit it often has the same gusto, enthusiasm and happy madness.

WASHINGTON July 9 -- President Eisenhower has informed Premier Mohammed Mossadegh that public opinion in the United States opposes any grant of additional aid to Iran while that country's dispute with Britain over oil remains unsettled.
J. Floyd Smith has been named general sales manager of Sloane-Delaware Floor Products, Trenton, N. J. He was formerly with Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission has unanimously approved New York State's application to join with Canada in construction of the St. Lawrence River power project, it was indicated authoritatively tonight.

To help fill the final quota for whole blood to be flown to Korea and Japan, more blood donors are needed today, Dr. William M. Markel, administrator of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Following are the texts of an exchange of telegrams today between President Eisenhower and leaders of the Commission on Religious Organizations of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, and of an exchange of messages between J. B. Matthews and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy:

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Dr. Robert L. Johnson, Director of the International Information Administration of the Department of State, today issued the following amplification of a statement about the use of books by Communist authors that was included in yesterday's announcement of policy regarding the overseas library program:

TOKYO, Friday, July 10 -- United Nations and Communist truce delegations met for twenty-nine minutes at Panmunjom, Korea, this morning, then adjourned until 11 A. M. tomorrow [10 P. M. Friday, Eastern daylight time] without an announcement of developments.

A showing of fall fashions highlighting important trends in each apparel category was presented yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group at the Astor Hotel. The group is a noncommercial association of women engaged in the fashion industry and banded together for the purpose of education and dissemination of fashion information.

Pie crusts are just one of the many uses to which the ingenious home cook can put packaged pastry mixes. The mixes provide a quick and easy-to-prepare base for a variety of canapes to accompany cocktails. Or they can be blended with a sharp cheese, twisted into long sticks, baked and served with tall drinks, summer salads or even with cold soups like vichyssoise or jellied consomme.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The House passed tonight a bill to allow five private companies to develop the vast power potential at Niagara Falls. Passage came on a 262 to 120 roll-call vote after the chamber had refused, on a 254 to 130 roll-call, to recommit the bill.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that the Portsmouth Steel Corporation of Cleveland had asked permission to purchase from the Alleghany Corporation 85,004 shares of the common stock of the Cleveland Cliffs Iron Company.

Evidence of "irregularities" in some defense plants of the New York Ordnance District may make it necessary to extend the investigation of the Defense Activities subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee to cover the Ordnance Corps in Washington, Representative William E. Hess, Republican of Ohio and chairman of the subcommittee declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Government's new policy statement that some books by Communist authors, if their contents might serve the ends of democracy, could be on shelves of libraries at United States counter-propaganda information centers overseas, drew blasts today from Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and members of his Senate subcommittee that has been investigating the libraries.

There are a number of ways to extract weeds from lawn and garden; the best way is to have the extraction done by somebody else. Getting somebody else to do the weeding may take a little longer, but it is effort well repaid.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 9 -- Dr. Urho Kekkoner, Agrarian party leader, formed a new Finnish coalition Government today. It is a typical minority Cabinet, including eight Agrarians, three representatives of the Swedish People's party and three nonparty economic experts.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 9 -- Joe Brascher of the Hempstead Golf Club shot 37, 41 -- 78 to take the low gross prize during the Long Island Seniors Golf Association one-day medal play tournament at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

TRENTON, July 9 -- The nomination of Robert B. Meyner, Phillipsburg lawyer, as Democratic candidate for Governor, received legal sanction today in a 6-to-1 decision handed down by the New Jersey Supreme Court. Chief Justice Arthur T. Vanderbilt wrote the dissenting opinion.
PITTSBURGH, July 9 -- The Polo Grounds Express, with which Leo Durocher has been tinkering frantically these many weeks, is moving.

ATHENS, July 9 -- Economic and military matters pertaining to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization were believed to have been discussed at today's meeting of the Foreign Ministers of Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia, whose avowed purpose is to strengthen the treaty of friendship and alliance concluded by the three countries last February.

BERLIN, July 9 -- The Soviet sector of Berlin, thrown open to the West today for the first time since the riots of June 17, appeared almost normal with no evidence of strikes and only a few signs left of the upheaval that threatened to upset the East German Government.

MOSCOW, Friday, July 10 -- Lavrenti P. Beria, a First Deputy Premier and Minister of Internal Affairs, has been dismissed from his Government and Communist party posts and handed over to the Soviet Supreme Court for criminal prosecution on charges of seeking to seize power and turn the Soviet Union back to capitalist paths.

The Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation trimmed the prices of its more important copper wire and cable products by 1.57 to 2.10 cents a pound yesterday, becoming the first major fabricator to base those prices on 30-cents-a-pound refined copper.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 9 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. John W. O'Daniel, commander of United States Army Forces in the Pacific, said tonight as he wound up a three-week survey tour of Indo-China that he would recommend an increase of military aid here to combat Communist-led rebel forces.

VANCOUVER, B. C., July 9 (UP) -- Tony Trabert and Hamilton Richardson, two of America's most promising young tennis players, sent the United States off to a successful start in its quest to regain the Davis Cup today by sweeping the opening pair of singles matches against Japan in the first round of American Zone eliminations.
Chess teams of the United States and Soviet Russia reached an apparent stalemate yesterday even before a scheduled match could get under way.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted approval yesterday of a new schedule of commission rates on the purchase or sale of listed stocks under which the rates would be raised an average of approximately 15 per cent.
The President has very wisely stated that our ever-mounting food surpluses should go into empty stomachs rather than to warehouses.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, challenged the Senate Appropriations Committee today to assume responsibility for a "substantial" cut in President Eisenhower's $5,222,000,000 foreign aid request and predicted the whole effort at collective security would collapse as a result.

A vacant site of 95,000 square feet on the south side of Grand Avenue, 100 feet east of Seventy-second Place, in Maspeth, Queens, has been assembled for Safeway Stores, Inc., for improvement with a super market. The sellers are the Elmhurst Lumber Company and Mrs. Ida Landsman.

NEW DELHI, India, July 9 -- The rigid regulations and cumbersome procedures that had been raising awkward barriers to travel between India and Pakistan were removed today with an announcement here and in Karachi, Pakistan, that modifications to the passport arrangements had been ratified by both Governments.

It is too bad that the State Department's excellent declaration of policy on American libraries abroad wasn't made several weeks or even months ago. It is a much-needed explanation of what the library program is all about and a forthright statement of the fundamental fact that the selection of books for library shelves must be determined from their contents, not their authors.

Plentiful fruits and vegetables, many at prices considerably below last Friday's, are among the most attractive possibilities for the week-end market basket. Several of the vegetables are from near-by sources, hence they have the advantage not only of reasonable cost but also of special freshness.

ROME, July 9 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi was virtually certain today that he would succeed in forming his eighth consecutive cabinet and receiving a vote of confidence from the Senate and Chamber. He had assurances that the Right-wing Socialists, who fought the recent elections on his side, would support him at least to the extent of not voting against him.
Rubber was paved into a one-block stretch of First Avenue yesterday to determine whether it would add life and performance to the standard asphalt-mix roads subjected to the heavy pounding of trucks.

A three-man committee named by Mayor Impellitteri to settle the week-old strike of 1,800 building supply drivers announced last night that its first move would be an appeal to the strikers to return to work while settlement efforts went forward.
DETROIT, July 9 -- Labor and management were at odds here today about the effects of the cutbacks scheduled by the Army to shrink the industrial base of the defense program.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 9 (AP) -- Three, and possibly four, volcanoes "blew their tops" across Cook Inlet today and in mid-afternoon Anchorage was in pitch darkness, with fine ash powder sifting down over it.

There is, I suppose, a distinction to be made between wholesale book-banning and book-burning. A simple banning -- and the placing of a book in a library basement or garbage heap -- lacks the imagery of the bonfire. It does not create the vision of storm troopers throwing book after book into a fire, standing around singing while the flames grow higher; while the lights of reason, justice and morality become dim.

Until his purge was announced yesterday Lavrenti P. Beria had been for fifteen years one of the most important persons in the Soviet Union and for most of that period the chief policeman and security officer of the Stalinist empire.

Reflecting new high sales records made in the three and six months ended with June, the Monsanto Chemical Company lifted earnings substantially over the corresponding period last year, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday by Charles Allen Thomas, president.

ST. LOUIS, July 9 (AP) -- A natural gas company reported today it had discovered oil, purely by accident, on the fringe of the metropolitan St. Louis area. Excitement is running high in the suburban area of northern St. Louis County, even though the extent of the oil showing is yet to be determined.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 -- Things will begin humming next Tuesday at Warner Brothers when production is resumed after a complete shutdown that has lasted three months, Jack L. Warner announced today.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., July 9 -Duke Power Company of Charlotte is filing applications for authority to issue $35,000,000 in a new series of thirty-year first and refunding mortgage bonds and 208,321 additional shares of common stock. Officials of the company said today that the letter of application to the Federal Power Commission, the North Carolina Utilities Commission and the Public Service Commission of South Carolina are being placed in the mail today.

The purge of Lavrenti P. Beria from the Soviet High Command raises the possibility that the entire post-Stalin conciliatory policy of the Soviet regime may be reversed, or at least seriously modified. Many of the conciliatory measures, both at home and abroad, particularly the former, carried out since Stalin's death have generally been identified by foreign diplomatic sources as the result of Mr. Beria's influence in the post-Stalinist Soviet ruling group.

The master of the American tanker Gulftrade, Capt. Hibbert C. Kaiser, told a Coast Guard board of inquiry here yesterday that the collision between his vessel and the Brazilian freighter Loide-Panama was caused by improper navigation of the foreign vessel, which should have held her course and speed.
TORONTO, July 9 (AP) -- Four Americans shared the second-round lead in the $15,000 Canadian open golf championship today.
For distinguishing themselves in the Far East four First Army officers were honored at a retreat parade at Governors Island yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Following is the exchange of correspondence between President Eisenhower and Premier Mohammed Mossadegh of Iran, made public by the White House today:

Two new films will open at first-run theatres today. "Affair With a Stranger," an R. K. O. drama featuring Jean Simmons, Victor Mature and Monica Lewis, is at Loew's Criterion. Roy Rowland directed and Robert Sparks produced, from a story and screen play by Richard Flournoy.
ST. LOUIS. July 9 (AP) -- While pitching brilliant five-hit ball, Right-hander Bob Lemon drove in three runs to lead the Indians to a 9-1 victory over the Browns tonight.

President Justice William Lyman of the Municipal Court held a public hearing yesterday on a letter written by Robert Payson Hill a concert pianist, and published by THE NEW YORK TIMES, complaining of the behavior of judges and the condition of the juors' rooms in that court.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended on Saturday rose 1 per cent above those in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Having newly arrived in your hospitable city, I must say I am charmed by the open arms with which the city's food-dispensing employers offer to hire me. Such employment was denied me in Southern states, the health departments of which were narrow-minded enough, after medical examinations, to deny me the privilege of working there.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 9 -- The executive committee of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, holding its convention here, has agreed on a new chairman, Omar Becu of Belgium, head of the International Transport Workers Federation.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Senate passed a bill tonight that would permit Congressional committees to grant witnesses immunity from prosecution for answering self-incriminating questions, but compel them to testify under penalty for contempt of Congress.
Improvements will be made in two former holdings of old estates in Manhattan as the result of changes in ownership of properties on West Fifty-sixth Street and East Sixty-fifth Street.
PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- Robin Roberts failed for the first time since Aug. 24, 1952, to complete a game he had started but the Dodgers still couldn't beat the Phillies tonight at Connie Mack Stadium.

KATONAH, N. Y., July 9 -- Edward Percy Barrett, who has been closer to the development of modern Westchester in the last half century than any other living person, said this afternoon at his law office here that he would retire as a county supervisor at the end of the year.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 9 (AP) -- Duncan Dewar Jr. of Holden, Mass., fired a 2-over-par 72 to gain the medal over 131 amateur rivals in the qualifying round of the twenty-fifth Robert Todd Lincoln memorial golf tournament today at the Ekwanok Country Club.

WESTBURY, L. I., July. 9 (AP) -Shamrock Bobby, a 30-1 shot, and Santon Hal, the favorite, staged a thrilling stretch duel tonight at Roosevelt Raceway with Stanton Hal coming home a nose in front to win the Hitherhills pace. Silver Melody took third as the first nine-race card at Westbury was staged.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- During the week ended July 8, member bank reserves decreased $138,000,000, the Federal R serve Board reported today.

CAERNARVON, Wales, July 9 -- Queen Elizabeth II came to Wales today to receive the homage of the Welsh people, who proudly claim her as a descendant of the royal house of Cunedda, which ruled Wales from Roman times until 1284.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -Ralph S. Damon, president of Trans World Airlines, announced plans today to buy up to twenty super-Constellation airplanes from Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, at Burbank, Calif. The cost would be about $34,000,000.

HALIFAX, N. S., July 9 -- A New York delegate told a conference of motor vehicle administrators today that standardization of license plate sizes if adopted on the target date of Jan. 1, 1955, might disrupt manufacture of New York plates.

The five commissioners of the New York City Transit Authority heard complaints at an all-day closed session yesterday that it would be difficult, if not impossible, to run the public transit system efficiently without some easing of proposed economies.
Harold Holt, Australian Minister of Immigration, Labor and National Service, called on the United States yesterday to assure the world that it would continue its policy of foreign aid.

A pint-sized jet engine that can add tons to an airliner's carrying capacity when used as an adjunct to conventional piston power plants was displayed yesterday at El A1 Israel Airlines' overhaul base near New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 9 -- Al Brosch of Cherry Valley won the Long Island Golf Association's open championship for the eighth time today with a 54-hole score of 212 at the Meadow Brook Club.

SUMMIT, N. J., July 9 -- Chester Sanok of Forsgate today added his second under-par round of the tournament, a 70, to his first-round 68 for a total of 138 to take the lead in the thirty-third New Jersey State Golf Association open championship over the South Course of the Canoe Brook Country Club.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., July 9 -- Charlotte De Cozen of Baltusrol and Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge and Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood and Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's best-ball semi-final matches at the Leewood Country Club today.

LONDON, Friday, July 10 ( Reuters) -- Following are the texts of communiques issued by the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party and the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union on the dismissal of Lavrenti P. Beria from the Communist party and from his post of Deputy Premier and Minister of Internal Affairs, as relayed to London by Tass, official Soviet news agency:

NORWALK, Conn., July 9 -- Picket lines were thrown around the East Norwalk plant of the Hat Corporation of America this morning as 1,500 production workers started a strike for a job stability clause in a new contract.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Eisenhower today reappointed General of the Army George C. Marshall as chairman of the American Battle Monuments Commission, which is responsible for the maintenance of United States military cemeteries and memorials abroad.

EVEN the salt water angler is subject to certain outbreaks of itching feet, and is impressed by tales of the bright green grass on the other side of the fence, which accounts for some of the movement in the direction of Block Island, Martha's Vineyard and Cape Cod.

A committee of six physicians and one clergyman appointed last March by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to investigate premature deaths at Fordham Hospital reported no evidence of racial discrimination, the association said yesterday.

The discussions among the representatives of Britain, France and the United States that are being initiated today can be of major importance and of substantial help. This can be a highly desirable preparation for the meeting of the chiefs of state of the three countries that is expected when Sir Winston Churchill's health has improved.

Play in the seventh round of the world junior chess championship resulted in a triple tie for the Section A lead among James T. Sherwin of New York, Klaus Darga of West Germany and Farre of Spain, all with 5 -- 2, according to a report from Copenhagen yesterday.

Coney Island will have a new and larger post office early in November to replace the present one which, because of its limited facilities, is no longer able to handle the steadily growing volume of mail.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, July 10 (AP) -- Troops of the United States Seventh Division fought hand-to- hand with Chinese Reds near the crest of "Porkchop Hill" on the Korean western front at dawn today and knocked the Reds down the slope.
St. John Terrell, impresario of the Lambertville (N. J.) Music Circus, has scheduled a tryout of his production of "Orpheus in the Underworld," which may be presented here this winter.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday totaled 670,232 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 148,218 cars, or 18.1 per cent fewer than in the preceding week, 222,716, or 49.8 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year and 82,073, or 14 per cent more than during the corresponding week of 1951.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee today completed public hearings on legislation to speed up mining of uranium, and may act on the proposal this month.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 9 -- Harold Burrows of Charlottesville, Va., and Donald Flye of the University of Washington reached the semi-final round of the invitation singles at the Bath and Tennis Club today while Victor Seixas and Gardnar Mulloy were gaining the same bracket in the doubles.
DAMASCUS, Syria, July 9 -- The Republic of Syria will tomorrow take its first step toward return to democratic government after four years of an undisguised military dictatorship.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- In what was construed widely here as a direct shot by President Eisenhower at Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and his Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, the President stated today that he agreed fully with a protest by churchmen that a recently published attack on Protestant clergymen was unjustified and deplorable.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The ousting of Lavrenti P. Beria from the triumvirate governing the Soviet Union came as a surprise not only to the highest circles in Washington but to the Western diplomats stationed in Moscow, according to all indications here tonight.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- A reversal of the price trend in wheat, compared with yesterday featured the market today. Mill buying, which has been a recent factor, was conspicuously absent; hedge, pressure increased moderately, while there was local pressure in the place of active short covering.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Golfing irons and fishing rods and some judicious bending of elbows will mitigate the pain of a Washington summer and the pressure of global crises for 116 civilian and military leaders of the Department of Defense from July 23 to July 26.

LONDON, Friday, July 10 (Reuters) -- Tass, Soviet news agency, reported today that news of Lavrenti Beria's dismissal had been cheered yesterday at a joint plenary session of the party committee of the Moscow Oblast (district) and Moscow City in the Trades Union Hall of Columns.

THERE is a point of no return (that wonderful phrase aviation gave to Mr. Marquand and the rest of us) in the art of literature, as well as in life and in flying. It is a matter of degree. Enough is just right and superbly effective. Too much is ruinous, and the point of no return between enough and too much is not always easy to determine until too late.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Golfing irons and fishing rods and some judicious bending of elbows will mitigate the pain of a Washington summer and the pressure of global crises for 116 civilian and military leaders of the Department of Defense from July 23 to July 26.

The thought of linking architecture -- and ancient architecture at that -- to millinery seems a bit incongruous, but it is not when Sally Victor dreams it up. Yesterday morning she proved what she could do in her fall collection of hats. The result was eminently successful.

Casey Stengel shouldn't have made Mel Parnell angry by leaving him off the American League allstar squad. The stylish Red Sox left-hander, still sizzling at the slight, yesterday shut out the Bombers, 4 -- 0, for the second time in nine days.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 9 -- Amid scenes reminiscent of the trials of terrorists during the British Mandate, fifteen persons went on trial today before a military court in Sarafand Army Camp, near Tel Aviv, on charges of leading or belonging to a terrorist organization.
WASHINGTON, July .9 (AP) -- The American Mining Congress took a dim view today of proposed legislation to tighten laws dealing with mining claims in national forests.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Chairman Charles A. Wolverton, Republican of New Jersey, of the House Commerce Committee, announced today that Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson and Mutual Security Administrator Harold E. Stassen have been called for testimony in connection with the inquiry into recent oil price rises.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., July 9 -- The Tri-County champion, Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis, captured the low grogs laurels in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association one-day competition for the fifth time this season by carding a 38, 43 -- 81 today at Whippoorwill.

PARIS, July 9 -- The Governments of the United States, Britain and France have given formal assurances that their eleven smaller allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will be fully informed on all discussions in Washington among the Western Big Three foreign ministers that deal in any way with Atlantic alliance matters.

On March 10 of this year the Hospital Trustees Committee, appointed by the United Hospital Fund to represent the voluntary hospitals of New York, submitted an appeal to the Board of Estimate for an increase in the rates paid by the city for the treatment of public charge patients cared for in voluntary hospitals.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, struck close to the White House itself today by demanding that Allen W. Dulles, head of the Central Intelligence Agency, be subpoenaed before Senate investigators.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Six airlines and the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L., agreed today on a general wage increase of 9 cents an hour and other improvements for the companies' ground personnel, estimated by the union at nearly 20,000.

Mischa Elman, as soloist with Pierre Monteux and the Stadium Symphony Orchestra in last night's all-Beethoven concert at Lewisohn Stadium, made magnificent sounds in performing the Violin Concerto in D Major.

A mad dog, the Police and Fire Commissioners, a well-wishing stranger and a steamship concern all had a part in bringing about a luncheon yesterday for a policeman and a 13-year-old girl, whom he had accidentally shot and wounded.
UTICA, N. Y., July 9 (AP) -- Bickering over rules marred play today as favorites, including the defending champion, Billy Shields of Albany, advanced in the New York State Amateur golf championship.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 -- The appointment of Ernest J. Bradley, vice president for freight traffic of the Matson Navigation Company, as the company's top Eastern area official with headquartrs in New York, was announced today by Randolph Sevier, president.
LIFE has been full of surprises for Lou Boudreau but never more than this year. Fortunately for the youthful skipper of the Red Sox, though, the recent ones have all been pleasant surprises.
TOKYO, Friday, July 10 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,671, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company announced yesterday that it was decreasing by 4 cents a thouand cubic feet the rate on gas used by 35,000 house heating customers in Brooklyn. The utility company filed its proposed new rate with the Public Service Commission last Monday and received permission to lower it on Tuesday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9 -- Thailand's publicly announced plans for bringing the situation in Indo-China before the United Nations Security Council as a threat to world peace have been quietly put on the diplomatic shelf for the time being.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Defense Department today asked Congress to authorize $529,386,000 worth of construction at Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Air Force installations.

GENEVA, July 10 -- After years of toying with the problem, governments of Western Europe are at last looking squarely in the face the need for this region to get rid, once for all, of quantitative restrictions on intra-European trade.

ST. LOUIS, July 10 (AP) -- The Braves turned loose a twelve-hit attack, including Ed Mathews' twenty-sixth home run of the year, to frustrate the Cardinals' bid for second place with a 5-2 victory tonight. Warren Spahn hurled six-hit ball in registering his eleventh triumph.
FORT WORTH, Tex., July 10 (AP) -- Although long ago grown accustomed to Ben Hogan winning golf tournaments, Fort Worth, his home town, was thrilled today over his British open golf triumph.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Following is a statement by President Eisenhower on the food situation in East Germany, a note from the United States to the Soviet Union and an exchange of letters between the President and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of Germany:
Retirement from New York Stock Exchange member firms of Robert C. L. Timson, from W. E. Hutton Co. on July 31, and Jerome W. Nammack and William J. Nammack from West Nammack on July 16.

A subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee ended a four-day hearing into the production of ordnance materiel in the New York and New Jersey area yesterday by giving a clean bill of health to most of the plants engaged in such work.

Walter Florell turned up with a new philosophy for his fall millinery collection, displayed yesterday at this East Fifty-third Street salon, announcing that all exaggeration was passe. In keeping with that statement, he adhered to a feeling of simplicity on the five points on which his presentation was based -- silhouette, trim, texture, color and fun.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 10 -- A murderer scheduled to be put to death at Sing Sing Prison in Ossining next week offered his eyes for sale today to the highest bidder. The money would go to his mother "so I could do one final thing to help her."

Brokers saw three major influences in the stock market yesterday but only one that operated to create strength or activity. This was a move in the House Ways and Means Committee to exempt motion picture theatres from the 20 per cent amusement tax.

BERLIN, July 10 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said tonight that "every dollar spent providing jobs in West Berlin is worth $100 spent for military divisions in the fight against Soviet tyranny."
MOSCOW, July 10 -- Following is a timetable of recent outstanding events:
Democratic leaders have virtually abandoned the thought of a Democratic - Republican coalition city ticket with District Attorney Frank S. Hogan as the candidate for Mayor, it was reported yesterday.

The vanguard of 100,000 members and guests of the Ancient Arabic Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine for North America arrived here last night for the organization's seventy-ninth convention, which opens on Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The three Democratic members of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, resigned today in protest after the seven-man subcommittee voted 4 to 3 to give the chairman, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, sole power to employ or discharge staff members.
VANCOUVER, B. C., July 10 (AP) -- The United States clinched its North American zone Davis Cup match against Japan today with a decisive victory in the doubles, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

Public schools should introduce factual study of religion where it is "intrinsic to whatever area of human experience is being studied," Dr. Clarence Linton, Professor of Education at Teachers College. Columbia University, told school superintendents and administrators of thirty-eight cities yesterday.

LLANGOLLEN, Wales, July 10 -- The royal train carrying Queen Elizabeth II back to London from her tour of Wales puffed out from the flower decked little riverside station here this evening to the accompaniment of a tumultuous farewell from more than 20,000 persons attending the Eisteddfod, the international music festival here, which the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh visited for half an hour.

BERLIN, July 10 -- The three Western commandants in Berlin forwarded to their Soviet counterpart today a plea from the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions urging the immediate release of the workers arrested after the June 17 uprising.
DETROIT, July 10 (AP) -- The nation's auto makers are aiming at a record 1,760,000 passenger car assemblies in the current quarter of 1953, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

PARIS, July 10 -- French women had their first real introduction to the marvels of plastics at the Second European Chemical Salon, which was held this year in the big exposition grounds at the Porte de Versailles. The salon displayed the latest developments in chemical products from Britain, Holland, France, Italy and Germany and a number of special exhibits brought from the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- American tramp ships may be "forced from the seas" unless the Government agrees to subsidize them, a Senate subcommittee on maritime subsidies was told today.

SUMMIT, N. J., July 10 -- Lou Barbaro of Hollywood Golf Club, Deal, N. J., won the thirty-third New Jersey State open golf championship with a five-under-par 283 over the South Course of the Canoe Brook Country Club today.

AMARILLO, Tex., July 10 -- President Eisenhower told the people of the drought-stricken Southwest today that the Government was not "going to dilly-dally around until every cow on the range is starving in the rain."

Three fresh delicacies, unfortunately scarce and hence a bit on the expensive side, now can be found in a few retail markets. Two, green almonds and fresh figs, come from California, while the third, currants, is grown in New York State.

HONG KONG, Saturday, July 11 -- The Peiping radio remained silent up to midnight last night on the purge of Lavrenti P. Beria in the Soviet Union and the pro-Communist press also passed up the story today pending reaction from Red China's capital.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -- Fourteen volunteers, all missionary trainees, and one professional forest firefighter were fatally burned in the Mendocino National Forest, near Willows, 150 miles northeast of this city, last night.

President Eisenhower has struck, and struck hard, at that peculiar form of un-Americanism which has come to be known as McCarthyism. His telegram to representatives of America's three great religious faiths is brief and to the point. The churchmen had protested the magazine article by J. B. Matthews, newly appointed staff director for Senator McCarthy's investigating committee, impugning the loyalty of thousands of members of the Protestant clergy.

LONDON, July 10 -- Buying dwindled in the securities markets here today and price movements were generally narrow, but there was a firm undertone. Events in Moscow had no apparent effect on sentiment apart from prompting a general inquiry for foreign bonds.

BABYLON, L. I., July 10 -- The action of the North Babylon Board of Education in reinstating James H. Northrop, who had been dismissed as a supervising principal here, has been rejected by John P. McGuire, district superintendent of schools, pending a State Supreme Court decision on an appeal that will be taken on the ouster voted by a previous school board.

VIENNA, July 10 (AP) -- A newspaper put out by Czechoslovak exiles in Vienna suggested today that a struggle for power -- like that which led to Lavrenty P. Beria's downfall -- was going on in Communist Czechoslovakia.
On the theory that chess has no politics, the United States Chess Federation attempted yesterday to persuade the Soviet Russian team to play a match scheduled here, beginning next Thursday.
This is to supplement Mayme Hollensworth's letter of July 6, of Warren, Ark., which appeared in the letters column titled: "City's Lack of Courtesy."

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 10 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, asserted here tonight that there was no feasible alternative to a truce in Korea. He said:

The five-story building with thirty-seven apartments and eight stores at 145 West 169th Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by Geisinger and Rau, operators, from Emanuel and Ida Halpern. It is assessed at $135,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 10 -- Columbia has decided not to release "Gentlemen Marry Brunettes," which Mike Frankovich was to have made independently for the studio, and instead will make "Port of Spain," an adventure-drama, with filming to be done by Mr. Frankovich in Tangiers and London next September.

Two witnesses, the first of a series to be called in the next few weeks, appeared yesterday before a New York County grand jury as the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan began presenting evidence on the so-called new racket of disseminating racing information to bookmakers and policy racketeers.

The Administration's victory in the House yesterday in its fight for retention of the excess profits tax through Dec. 31 was entirely in line with pre-voting expectations. It now remains only for the Senate to give the legislation its approval, and there seems to be no reason to doubt that such action will be forthcoming.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, July 11 (AP) -- Four thousand Chinese Communists slammed against South Korean positions in a series of heavy attacks on a four-mile sector of the east-central front early today and pulled back at dawn.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Republican leadership of the House of Representatives has decided to push for action, before adjournment, on the request by Arthur E. Summerfield, the Postmaster General, for postal increases that will yield about $240,625,000 more in revenue each year.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 10 -- Mrs. Nellie Sheer Kagan of Rockaway and Isabel Troccole of the Bronx won their semi-final matches in the New York State women's tennis championship at New Rochelle Tennis Club today. They will meet at 1 P. M. tomorrow for the title vacated by Mrs. Louise Raymond Ganzemuller of Sea Cliff.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 10 -- The nation's two top ranking tennis players, Gardnar Mulloy of Miami and Victor Seixas of Philadelphia, champion of Wimbledon, took their allotted places in the semi-finals of the invitation tournament at the Bath and Tennis Club today.

The twelve-story and penthouse building containing sixty-four apartments at 21 East Tenth Street is under contract of sale to M. Robert Steel, treasurer of the real estate management concern of S. W. Steel Co. The property, on a plot 100 by 55 feet at the northwest corner of University Place, is assessed at $485,000. Pearce, Mayer Greer and Annie Inselstein were co-brokers in the transaction.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that good to excellent prospects in much of the main farming area of the country pointed to the third largest crop production on record this year.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- President Eisenhower's request for continuation of the excess profits tax until Dec. 31 was approved by the House of Representatives today on a heavily bipartisan ballot of 325 to 77.

VIENNA, July 10 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, who flew to Berlin today after a three-day stay in Vienna, said at a news conference here that the fall of Lavrenti P. Beria, First Deputy Premier and Minister of Internal Affairs of the Soviet Union, probably heralded a change of policy and major internal conflict in Moscow.
ST. LOUIS, July 10 -- A strange quiet has settled over the office of the St. Louis Zoo. Joe, a myna bird, has been banished to the common bird cage because he simply could not keep his mouth shut.
The following is a round-up of new booklets that may be helpful to the homemaker:
DETROIT, July 10 (AP) -- The Browns defeated the last-place Tigers, 8 -- 4, tonight as they put together fourteen hits and belted four home runs.

Klaus Darga of West Germany defeated Heikkila of Finland in the eighth round to take the Section A lead from James T. Sherwin of New York in the world junior chess tournament at Copenhagen yesterday, according to a report from the Danish capital.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Senate and House negotiators agreed today on a $5,157,232,500 authorization for the Mutual Security Program, but a move was under way in the Senate Appropriations Committee to reduce the amount by $1,000,000,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -- United States engineers have refined the atomic bomb to the point where it can be carried by single- engine airplanes from aircraft carriers, according to a semi-official report made public here today.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 10 -- Eighteen Burlington clergymen have issued a statement calling on Gov. Lee E. Emerson to reconsider the proposed suspension of Dr. Alexander Novikoff, a biochemist, by the University of Vermont for his refusal to testify before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Newsreel photographers embarrassed a Frenchman today by asking him to speak in French. The victim was Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister.

LONDON, July 10 -- A new and highly dramatic element of uncertainty was introduced into Soviet affairs today by the dismissal and arrest of Lavrenti P. Beria and, in the opinion of some commentators here, it has cast additional doubt on the wisdom and value of an early four-power meeting.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 10 -- Alabama and Montgomery County health authorities declared today the mass inoculation of all children 9 years old and under against polio was a success.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 10 -- The bombing of the Soviet Legation in Tel Aviv Feb. 9 was attributed to a terrorist organization comprising a mixture of religious zealots and former underground fighters today by Attorney General Haim Cohen at the trial of fifteen suspected members of the organization before a military court in Sarafand.
Jewelry valued at $25,335 was reported yesterday to be missing from the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Louis N. Messing of 101 Central Park West.

The organization of the New York State unit of the Advisory Council to the Democratic National Committee took place yesterday at a luncheon meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel attended by about thirty persons, including present and past State and National Chairmen.
LONDON, July 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of Pravda's editorial today on the purging of Lavrenti P. Beria, as broadcast by the Moscow radio in Russian and translated in London:
MOSCOW, Saturday, July 11 (AP) -- Pravda's new editorial on the Beria case today called on all Communist party organizations to "intensify their revolutionary vigilance."

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., July 10 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood, the 1952 metropolitan champion, and Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood captured the championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's seventh best - ball tournament after six hours of grueling play at Leewood today.

A number of major coffee roasters throughout the country acted yesterday to raise their wholesale prices about 3 cents a pound. The reason given was the fact that coffee futures have gone up around 6 cents a pound in the last few days as a result of reports of heavy frost damage to the new Brazilian crop.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Republican-led House of Representatives Appropriations Committee today questioned the "austerity" aspects of one of President Eisenhower's budget figures and slashed deeply into his requests for new money.

Fans upon which eighteenth-century Europeans lavished some of their finest flights of decorative fancy were placed on exhibition this week at Cooper Union Museum. Part of an extensive collection, these ornamental adjuncts to comfort and costume are being shown for the first time by the museum in a special summer display running through Sept. 4.

Governors of the New York Stock Exchange have adopted a new rule to permit what will be called an "Exchange Distribution" on its floor, with special commissions paid for the solicitation of purchase orders. The plan awaits approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
TORONTO, July 10 (AP) -- Wally Ulrich shot a four-under-par 67 over the Scarboro course today to give him a 54-hole total of 203 and break up a four-way tie for the Canadian open golf lead.
MILWAUKEE, July 10 (AP) -- The men's seedings in the sixty-sixth annual Western tennis tournament held true today as the top four rated players posted victories to advance to the semi-finals.

At the Aqueduct track today Greentree Stable's Tom Fool, the ace of the handicap brigade, has a weighty task. In the mile-and-a-quarter Brooklyn Handicap he'll take up 136 pounds and attempt to outrun horses to whom he'll be conceding 26 to 34 pounds.

John S. Sinclair, chairman of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, yesterday praised the patriotic response of New York donors who made it possible for the New York Regional Blood Program to fill its three-day emergency quota of whole blood to be flown to the Far East. The three days ended yesterday.

George L. Mark, national commander of the Polish Legion of American Veterans, said yesterday that he would seek Federal legislation providing for the admission to this country of 45,000 Poles now in Western Germany.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange will vote on July 23 on a constitutional amendment embodying a new schedule of commission rates to raise their income about 15 per cent. If passed, it would take effect on Sept. 1.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Alderman Clarence P. Wagner, administration floor leader in the City Council and sometimes called Chicago's "unofficial mayor," was killed today when the automobile he was driving on a fishing trip plunged from Highway 53 near International Falls, Minn., and was demolished. His age was 49.
The traditional post-July 4 sales of men's clothing have stirred much dissatisfaction among retailers who feel the practice has caused them needless losses of profits.
Two policemen and two of their prisoners were injured last night when a patrol wagon taking thirteen dice players to Night Court overturned on the West Side Highway.

PITTSBURGH, July 10 (UP) -- The Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa) reached wage agreements today with the United Steelworkers Union, C. I. O., and two A. F. L. unions whereby 30,000 workers throughout the country will receive an 8 1/2-cent-an-hour pay increase.
UTICA, N. Y., July 10 (AP) -- Dr. Rocco Impaglia, golfing dentist from Auburn, today upset Willie Turnesa of White Plains, 2 and 1, in the quarter-final round of the state amateur golf championship.

PEARL HARBOR, July 10 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, new Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, turned over his Pacific Fleet command today to Admiral Felix B. Stump with a caution against overoptimism about the immediate future and a warning that the fleet must continue to be ready for any eventuality.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 10 -- President Eisenhower's refusal to grant additional United States economic assistance to Iran unless Iran settled its oil dispute with Britain was regarded here today as having put Premier Mohammed Mossadegh on the horns of an extremely painful dilemma -- either to come to terms with Britain or grant concessions to the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Four fourteen-year experiments in community self-organization, to promote better family living through education were summarized in a 248-page booklet, "With Facts on Family Living," published today by the Division of Vocational Education, Office of Education.

The report issued by Dr. Greenburg, Commissioner of the new Department of Air Pollution Control, for the first six months of 1953 shows one aspect of the city administration's shortsightedness in penny-pinching with the war on smoke. According to Dr. Greenburg the department, through the fees it collects from building owners making application to install fuel-burning equipment, bids fair to be about one-third self-supporting.

A model house is being opened today by Henry R. Bass and Marvin A. Rosen in their Hilaire Estates colony at Woodhull Road and Delaware Street in Huntington. L. I., where they plan to construct 122 dwellings. Designed by Stanley H. Klein, architect, the model house is in ranch type with three bedrooms and is priced at $13,490.

Three religious leaders expressed gratitude yesterday to President Eisenhower for condemning a recently published article saying that the "largest single group supporting the Communist apparatus in the United States today is composed of Protestant clergymen."

CLIFTON, N. J., July 10 -- Mrs. A. J. Bryant scored a 40, 38 -- 78 over the Upper Montclair Country Club course, her home grounds, today, for a one-shot victory in a women's New Jersey Golf Association tournament.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 10 -- A strike of service employes spread to three Minneapolis downtown hotels today, and the threat of a walkout hung over eight others in a labor dispute between managements and three American Federation of Labor unions.

The prospective award of a $2,715,000 contract to improve Jones Inlet, on the south shore of Nassau County, will initiate an effort to end a navigation hazard and stop erosion at Point Lookout, on the west side of the inlet. The improvement, slated for completion by early 1955, represents a well-earned victory in a campaign waged for fifteen years by Robert Moses in his capacity as president of the Long Island State Park Commission.
New York gave its traditionally warm welcome yesterday to the Meyer Line cargo vessel Havmoy when she arrived shortly after noon on her maiden voyage from Oslo.
PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (UP) -- The Phillies, with Curt Simmons pitching his first victory since a lawn-mower accident of June 4, defeated the Pirates, 13 -- 3, tonight in a game marked by ten errors.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 10 -- The work of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions was held up today by the slowness of subcommittees in returning resolutions for approval. A resolution praising East Berlin and East German workers for their courage in protesting against Communist-imposed slavery was the only one ready for the plenary session, which adopted it with a few unimportant rectifications in phrasing.

BOSTON, July 10 (AP) -- Marion Fricano walked Jim Piersall with two out and the bases filled in the twelfth inning tonight to force in Dick Gernert with the run that gave the Red Sox a 3-2 victory over the Athletics. Piersall had tied the score with a ninth-inning homer.

A sudden strike at noon yesterday of ninety-four navigators in the international division of Trans World Airlines forced cancellation of four overseas flights and was expected to halt all T. W. A. operations from the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens.

MOSCOW, Saturday, July 11 -- No change in Soviet foreign or domestic policy is expected at present as a result of the ouster from high Government and Communist party posts of Lavrenti P. Beria, who was officially branded yesterday as a traitor to his country.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 10 -- Two Israeli soldiers in an outpost position in the hills of Jerusalem were shot dead last night by armed Jordanians and a third was injured, an Army spokesman announced today.

REPORTS from many of the popular salmon rivers of the Maritime Provinces indicate that most of the anglers would be willing to sit around in camp for a day, or even two, while it rained, for low water conditions seem general.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 10 -- The Foreign Ministry informed foreign embassies and legations today that it would move its offices from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem Sunday, thereby completing the installation of Israel's capital in Jerusalem.

Some refrigerator manufacturers content themselves with complaining when sales slump. Others promote. Yesterday Admiral Corporation let it be known that its dealers will have a special offering starting now and ending on Sept. 10.

CINCINNATI, July 10 (UP) -- Ralph Kiner's nineteenth home run of the season and Turk Lown's effective relief pitching gave the Cubs a 4-3 victory over the Redlegs in the second game of a twilight night double-header tonight after Ken Raffensberger hurled Cincinnati to a 6-0 triumph.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 10 (AP) -- Charlie Noyes of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., paced the Robert Todd Lincoln memorial golf tournament's championship flight into the quarter-finals today by defeating the medalist, Duncan Dewar Jr. of Holden, Mass., in a nineteen-hole match today at the Ekwanok Country Club.

May I examine, from the point of view of logic (if anyone is interested in logic in these days of hysteria, fear and tension), the extraordinary position taken by Senator Knowland regarding Syngman Rhee?

ALBANY, July 10 (AP) -- The Albany Times-Union said tonight that a Federal grand jury had considered possible charges against Carroll E. Mealey, former Deputy Collector of Internal Revenue, but declined to indict him.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Two laws added to the statute books today by President Eisenhower's signature will assure a continuance of the task of improving the organization of the Federal Government, and will project an exhaustive study of tax and other relationships between the Federal and local governments.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 11 -- United Nations and Communist armistice negotiators met briefly at Panmunjom this morning while Peiping clamored for "assurance in deeds" that a truce in Korea, once signed, would not be upset by Dr. Syngman Rhee, rebellious South Korean President.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 10 -- After long and patient tutelage by its owner, Loretta Tabak, 18-year-old daughter of Mrs. Ann Tabak, of 205 Second Street, Peter, a nine-month-old parakeet, boasts a vocabulary of seventy-five words, including some expressions the Tabaks wish he would forget.

STAVANGER, Norway, July 10 (AP) -- A United States military transport plane and a Norwegian jet fighter collided today while preparing to land in cloudy weather at Sola Airfield, killing ten Americans and the jet pilot.

Cleveland, Ohio, announced yesterday plans for selling two issues of bonds totaling $16,150,000. On Aug. 11, the city will receive bids on $10,150,000 of various general improvement issues dated Aug. 1, 1953 and due on Dec. 1, 1954 to 1975.

Earl W. Clark, deputy maritime administrator in the Department of Commerce, has resigned and will leave the Federal shipping agency at the end of this month. Louis S. Rothschild, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board and head of the Maritime Administration, said yesterday that Mr. Clark planned to join the New York and Cuba Mail Line, known as the Ward Line.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 10 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold cautiously pointed to the possibility today that the United Nations might have to take steps to repress violations of a Korean armistice by South Korea if President Syngman Rhee decided to go it alone.

Arthur H. Compton, chancellor of Washington University, St. Louis, declared in an interview here yesterday that the McCarran-Walter Internal Security Act, which bars scientists of countries behind the Iron Curtain from admission to the United States, was seriously hampering the progress of our atomic weapons program.

BONN, Germany, July 10 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, who is vacationing in the vicinity of Baden-Baden, said tonight it seemed impossible to him to make any forecast of the effect of Lavrenti P. Beria's downfall on the international situation.

The Playwrights Company, which will be one of the new season's busiest producers of plays, has settled on Tuesday evening, Oct. 27, as the New York opening date for "Sabrina Fair." The Samuel Taylor comedy, second on the production schedule of the organization, will be tested at New Haven's Shubert Theatre for three days, starting Oct. 8, and for two weeks at the Shubert in Boston, beginning Oct. 12.

Three former Protestant missionaries in China, all of whom were persecuted by Chinese Communists, will speak on "Christianity and Communism" at a seminar at the Silver Bay Conference on the Christian World Mission. The week-long session will open next Wednesday at Silver Bay, Lake George, N. Y. A number of classes and seminars will be held each day.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady and off 7 to 17 points net.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- A few minutes after the President, his Cabinet and his staff had bowed their heads in prayer this morning the weekly Cabinet meeting broke up in hilarity, all because a trout hook snagged James C. Hagerty, his Press Secretary, in the trousers.

CHICAGO, July 10 (UP) -- The National Maritime Union, C. I. O., announced today that it had reached agreement with five shipping concerns to settle a strike that had made 300 seamen idle on a score of Great Lakes ships.

Two partners in a Brooklyn butcher store were charged yesterday in criminal informations with contempt for having refused to identify for a grand jury a person for whom they had cashed a $751.71 check almost three years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Rosel H. Hyde, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, predicted chaotic conditions in standard radio broadcast reception in this country if the Senate failed to ratify the North American Regional Broadcast Agreement negotiated by the State Department.

" The Worldly Philosophers: The Lives, Times and Ideas of the Great Economic Thinkers," by Robert L. Heilbroner, will be issued July 29 by Simon Schuster. It is an account of the "academic scribblers" from Adam Smith, Malthus, Marx and Veblen to the economists now "wrestling" with the problems of our contemporary world. Mr. Heilbroner has contributed articles about economics to many national magazines. This is his first book.

What manner of man was this Italian adventurer who possessed the ability to make men envious and to charm women? What special talent, what rare gift of nature was his that caused the name of Casanova to be linked so permanently with romantic intrigue? Perhaps it was the age, the eighteenth century royal courts or his writings that served to perpetuate the name.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- President Eisenhower requested the Kremlin today to allow the United States to send $15,000,000 worth of food through the Iron Curtain to alleviate the hunger of Germans under Soviet control.

DAMASCUS, Syria, July 10 -- Brig. Gen. Adib Shishekly, dictator of Syria since December, 1949, was elected President of the Republic today in a referendum in which apathy and absenteeism were his only opponents.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- The Senate today approved a $5,239,352,664 money bill to finance the Atomic Energy Commission, Tennessee Valley Authority, Veterans Administration and Selective Service System for the next twelve months.
As late as last April Ben Hogan had no plans to compete in the British open at Carnoustie, Scotland. Many professional golfers and friends, however, induced him to change his mind.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The personal income of Americans reached an annual rate of $284,000,000,000 in May, $1,000,000,000 above the rate in April.

Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, and Governor Dewey arrived at La Guardia Airport last night from Florida, where earlier in the day they had witnessed a demonstration of new Air Force weapons at the Eglin Air Force Base in the northwest section of the state.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain and France reaffirmed today their unity and singleness of purpose, and agreed that the policies they had pursued for dealing with the menace of communism had proved themselves in the developments of recent weeks.

The Veterans Administration cautioned yesterday that a veteran receiving educational benefits under the Korean G. I. Bill and his school should make certain that monthly certifications of training were completed, signed and dated by the veteran and a representative of the school.

The Mayor's three-man committee met yesterday at City Hall for two hours with representatives of six sand, gravel and concrete supply companies in an effort to settle the week-old strike of building supply drivers.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., July 10 (AP) -- The 76-year-old skipper of a fifteen-foot home-made outboard motorboat rested here today after a trip up the Hudson River from New York.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 10 -- A corner of a four-story building, nearing completion in the center of this residential community, collapsed this evening, killing two workmen, injuring ten and trapping an undetermined number of others under tons of wet concrete, timber and steel.

TRENTON, July 10 -- Dr. Lester Clee, president of the State Civil Service Commission, announced today the adoption of regulations requiring local authorities to make a strict accounting of services per formed by persons on the public payrolls.

The owner of the canary that flew into a second-floor room of the James Ewing Hospital reclaimed it early yesterday, and for most of the day 17-year-old Bill Deley, a former high school athlete who is seriously ill, was alone with an empty cage that had just been sent by a woman who had heard that the fugitive canary was occupying a cage improvised of hospital materials.

The downfall of Lavrenti P. Beria is clearly a cause for rejoicing in the world's democracies. At one blow this news shatters the whole elaborate facade of "monolithic unity" with which Soviet propaganda has sought to surround the Kremlin since the death of Stalin.

In connection with the information published on June 30 to the effect that Moscow's Government in Bucharest, in answer to the United Nations, has denied the fact that there are Greek children in detention in Rumanian territory, I would like to bring up the following:

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 10 -- The Legislature's Joint Committee on Migrant Labor moved into this Suffolk County seat today for the first of six hearings over the state on proposals to remedy problems created by itinerant farm laborers.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 10 (AP) -- Iosola's Ensign set a world record for 3-year-old pacing geldings in winning the $6,100 Orange County Board of Supervisors Purse today as the Grand Circuit closed its meeting at Historic Track's half-mile oval.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 10 -- The United party Opposition decided unanimously today to block Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's plan to strike the mixed blood voters called Colored off the white register and segregate them on a register of their own.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., July 10 -- Accounting for a sparkling individual round of 75, two over women's par, Roslyn (Cookie) Swift, Metropolitan and Long Island titleholder, paired with Mrs. Melvin Scharf of Glen Oaks to capture low gross honors in the Women's Cross County Golf Association partner's best-ball tournament today.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- The White Sox uncorked a ten-run seventh inning to drub the Indians, 16 -- 5, after the Tribe rallied for three runs in the tenth and a 3-0 opening victory tonight in a double-header before Comiskey Park's largest 1953 crowd, 48,542.

RALEIGH, N. C., July 10 -- In a surprise move Gov. William B. Umstead today appointed a political "dark horse" to fill the unexpired term of United States Senator Willis Smith, who died June 26. The new Senator is Alton A. Lennon, 46 years old, a lawyer of Wilmington, who served two terms in the State Senate from 1947 to 1949.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 10 (AP) -- Thomas B. Scott, owned and driven by Tom Carlock of Greenville, Ohio, scored a wire-to-wire victory tonight in the $10,000 Wildwood Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

BRADLEY, W. Va., July 10 (AP) -- West Virginia named a town after General of the Army Omar N. Bradley five years ago. Today, the retiring chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff was on hand to thank the people of Raleigh and Fayette Counties in southern West Virginia for the distinction of having "fellow Americans dedicate a living community to my memory."

Reacting as usual to the malevolent presence of Sal Maglie, the Dodgers last night bowed to the Giants, 6 -- 1.
