It wasn't quite so humiliating as last Sunday's 20-6 rout at the Polo Grounds but, occurring as it did before 32,889 spectators, the largest Ebbets Field crowd since 1951, the defeat was galling enough to the National League champions.

HAWTHORNE, N. Y., July 10 -- Truck drivers seeking to avoid the state's new truck tax law followed circuitous routes over back roads of central Westchester County today to evade traps set by state troopers, but for most of the daylight hours the troopers in charge were resting at Troop K Barracks here after an exceptionally busy night.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., July 10 -- The Rev. Frederick B. Jansen, rector of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church of Somerville, Mass., testified today at the court-martial of Lieut. Sheppard Carl Thierman, an army medical officer, that the defendant had presided fairly over meetings of the American delegation's steering committee at the World Youth and Student Festival in Budapest, Hungary, in 1949.
The Coast Guard ended its inquiry yesterday into the collision between a Brazilian freighter and an American tanker last month off the New Jersey coast.

A series of eight Monday night concerts by the Chautauqua Symphony Orchestra will be broadcast over the A. B. C. radio network from 8:30 to 9:45 o'clock beginning July 20. Under the direction of Walter Hendl, the concerts will be picked up from the grounds of the music institute in upstate New York.
CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 10 (UP) -- Ben Hogan said today he was going to "take it easy" until the Masters tournament at Augusta, Ga., next spring.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 10 (AP) -- Frank Callahan proved today that the skiff is mightier than the locomotive. And in doing so, he gave the New York and Long Branch Railroad's timetable a salty shakedown.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles hailed today the ouster and arrest of Lavrenti P. Beria, a Soviet First Deputy Premier and Minister of Internal Affairs, as new evidence of a convulsion and of weakness in the Soviet Union.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., July 10 -- Plans to rebuild the Spring Valley sewer system were approved by the State Health Department in a letter received today by Mayor William Bohlke. Action was taken immediately to clean up the Pascack River here, and benefit both local and near-by Jersey residents.

LONDON, July 10 -- A three-week-old strike by film extras against Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer's British production "The Knights of the Round Table" spread today to the entire British film industry and threatened to halt or impede progress on more than a dozen motion pictures.

The American Museum of Natural History will have three expeditions searching for rare and unusual insects and spiders in western United States and Mexico this summer, Dr. Mont A. Cazier, chairman of the museum's department of insects and spiders, reported yesterday.

Seven hundred and eight-seven Boy Scouts and Scout leaders from the metropolitan area -- resplendent in their khaki uniforms and aglow with anticipation -- left New York yesterday to participate in the third national jamboree of the Boy Scouts of America at Santa Ana, Calif., from next Friday to July 23.

TRENTON, June 10 -- The men-folk of New Jersey's first family have answered the call of the outdoors. Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and his two sons, Alfred T., 16 years old, and Peter E., 13, are on their way to Maine over the inland waterway in a new fourteen-foot boat of fiber glass.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- An estimated increase of more than 40,000,000 bushels in this year's wheat crop caused Senators today to lower the recommended planting limits on this crop to 61,000,000 acres next year.

This week's new art exhibitions, largely made up of summer group shows of painting and sculpture, offers one display that would cause a stir at any time of year. At the Serigraph Gallery, shown there for the benefit of the National Serigraph Society School, is a group of nineteenth century American still-life paintings, "Harnett and His School."

The main lines of future Soviet policy indicated by yesterday's major editorial in Pravda commenting on the downfall of Lavrenti P. Beria, former secret police chief, were increased anti-capitalist propaganda at home, continued use of the "peace offensive" strategy abroad, a wide purge of Mr. Beria's followers and a more severe policy toward non-Russian minorities internally.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 10 -- Gallant Ben Hogan, in one of the most dramatic finishes ever witnessed in this staid old birthplace of golf, shot a record 68 on the ancient Carnoustie course today to win the British open championship.

Where are the 3.5 per cent dollar bonds of the State of Israel traded? The paying agents for the issue report that question is put to them many times each week, even though the bonds very clearly state that they are non-transferable and non-assignable until 1954.

PARIS, Saturday, July 11 -- By a vote of 213 to 54, the Council of the Republic, France's advisory second house, rejected yesterday a tax on alcohols and liquors in the Laniel Government's finance recovery bill.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Moderate hedge pressure combined with sales by longs to even up in anticipation of the government report which was issued after the market closed, caused a further slump in wheat prices, which was largely responsible also for recessions in other grains.
Operations of the Superior Oil Company of California in the nine months ended last May 31, resulted in a net income of $10,043,872 after all deductions, according to the report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- A group of representatives of the milling trade conferred today with Nelson A. Rockefeller, Under Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, for the purpose of restoring, if possible, Food and Drug Administration inspection of wheat for rodent and insect infestation.

Ralph Branca, a twenty-one-game-winner with the Dodgers in 1947, yesterday was waived out of the National League and acquired by the Tigers. The right-handed pitcher, a Mount Veernon (N. Y.) native who played baseball and basketball at New York University, was used sparingly by Manager Chuck Dressen this season. He had appeared exclusively in relief roles, having hurled eleven innings in seven games.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- The General Motors Corporation may dispose of its car and truck rental subsidiary, the Hertz Driv-Ur-Self System, Inc., it was learned today. It was understood that the Omnibus Corporation, which last year sold the Chicago Motor Coach Company to the Chicago Transit Authority, and a group headed by Walter L. Jacobs, Hertz's founder and present general manager, may each submit an offer for the property.

Kurt Grossmann's letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 29 recommends that the Austrian Government accept proposals submitted by Dr. Nahum Goldmann as spokesman for a group of Jewish organizations which are demanding $50,000,000 for heirless Jewish assets in Austria.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Federal Power Commission voted unanimously to issue a license to the Power Authority of the State of New York for the construction and operation of its proposed hydroelectric project in the International Rapids section of the St. Lawrence River.

Since the Riis House idea got its start sixty-four years ago when Jacob Riis and his reporter colleagues in the police headquarters press room began bringing flowers to their Henry Street neighbors, this great settlement project has followed the movement of families into four great housing developments -- Stephen Foster Houses in Manhattan, Red Hook and Marcy Houses in Brooklyn and Queensbridge Houses in Queens.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, July 10 (UP) -- Premier Kwame Nkrumah asked the Assembly today to request the British Government to declare the Gold Coast "a sovereign and independent state within the commonwealth."
Traffic improvements intended to relieve congestion and reduce safety hazards in the Madison Square area were urged yesterday by the Twenty-third Street Association.

The Senators made ten hits at the Stadium yesterday. The Yankees made eight. However, if all ten Washington singles were placed end to end, they would just about match for distance the three-run homer that Irv Noren slammed in the second inning and led to a 6-1 victory for Ed Lopat over Bob Porterfield.
The International Longshoremen's Association will propose a new hiring method for dock labor next Wednesday when it will open negotiations with the New York Shipping Association.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations under Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, postponed today at least until Tuesday its plan to question two members of the Central Intelligence Agency.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- President Eisenhower signed a bill today prohibiting the display of the United Nations and foreign flags more prominently that the United States flag, but he protested its ambignous language.

Coffee continued to hold the spotlight in trading on the local futures markets as prices climbed on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices had eased on Thursday but yesterday they recovered most of the losses and in some cases showed increases over Wednesday levels.

IN France there is at least one literary prize for almost every author. This is a humane and generous state of affairs that all countries might well emulate. It makes hazardous, though, the singling out of true excellence. Only when you notice that a French writer has a whole garland of trophies can you he reasonably certain that his countrymen really regard him as an accomplished man of letters.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- A Mexican inventor patented this week an electric instrument for massaging the fingernails. He expects it to be of particular value to pianists, massagists and others subject to manual fatigue, such as stenographers, by improving the circulation at the roots of the nails.

PARIS, Saturday, July 11 -- Charles E. Bohlen, United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, summoned back to Washington to report on the developments that are likely to result from the arrest of Lavrenti P. Beria, left from Orly Airfield shortly after midnight today.
A "large majority" of United Telephone Organizations members want their union to remain independent and it will remain that way, Joseph F. Broderick, general president, said in a statement yesterday.

NEWARK, July 10 -- The citizenship of Settimo Accardo, wealthy racketeer, was ordered revoked today by Federal Judge Richard Hartshorne on the ground that it had been obtained by fraud. He became a citizen in 1945.
ALBANY, July 10 (AP) -- About ten state employes have been discharged for refusing to tell department heads whether they had belonged to Communist organizations, an authoritative source said today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Congress greeted with enormous pleasure today the news that Lavrenti P. Beria had been cast out of the ruling Soviet triumvirate, but the senior foreign policy leaders were thrown into some anxiety as well.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 10 (AP) -- Unless the formula has been changed, Lavrenti P. Beria, high chieftain of the Soviet secret police, sits in one of his own cells in Lubianka Prison tonight, an example of how the Communist party devours its own.

PARIS, July 10 -- Comment in Paris on the removal of Lavrenti P. Beria consisted largely of question marks. But Daniel Mayer, newly elected chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the National Assembly, drew the conclusion that the West should profit by the occasion to "take the initiative and draft precise and concrete peace proposals to present to the Soviet Union."

NEW BERN, N. C., July 10 (UP) -- Representative Graham A. Barden, Democrat of North Carolina, accused Washington correspondents today of being "pampered individuals" who made too much use of "spoon-fed press releases, propaganda handouts and deliberately planted leaks."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 -- California business activity continued at the same high level in May as in April according to the Wells Fargo index. The current index, at 301.0, is only slightly below the peak in March and is 6.4 per cent above the 1952 level.

Beria, who now shares the fate of his predecessors.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 11 -- The champion of Wimbledon and the 1952 runner-up for the United States title will meet tomorrow at 2 o'clock in the concluding round of the invitation tournament at the Bath and Tennis Club.

Security markets, still stymied by domestic and international uncertainties, failed to make much headway last week. With the Korean truce negotiations moving slowly and the decision on extension of the excess profits tax delayed until Friday, caution ruled in Wall Street. For the second successive week stock prices fluctuated irregularly in narrow and dull dealings.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 11 -- Lifting the last barrier to a plan aimed at ridding the Raritan River of pollution, the New Brunswicks City Commission approved this week participation in a tri-county $22,500,000 trunk sewer.

HOW long Sir Winston Churchill will be able to continue as Prime Minister of Britain only Lord Moran, his physician, can guess. But when he does go, one thing is as certain as anything can be in politics: he will be succeeded by the Foreign Secretary and Deputy Prime Minister. Anthony Eden, who is now recuperating in the United States from three major operations.

BERLIN, July 11 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, 1952 Democratic candidate for the Presidency, was held at gunpoint for half an hour today by a group of the East German People's Police when members of his party sought to photograph him in the Soviet sector of the city.

OIL CITY, Pa., July 11 (UP) -- Two naval officers were killed early today when their twin-engine Beechcraft training plane crashed in a wooded area eight miles east of here. The men were identified as Comdr. William R. Eddins, 32 years old, of New Orleans and 9225 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn public information officer at Floyd Bennett Field, and Lieut. Frank L. Nelson of 7 Perth Avenue, Merrick, L. I.
DETROIT, July 11 (AP) -- Credit controls on car buying were lifted more than a year ago, but there are indications they are returning on an unofficial basis.

BACK in the old days the midsummer meetings of the big leagues on the eve of the ALL-Star game were little more than social gatherings. Nothing of consequence was ever accomplished. But the primary get-togethers in Cincinnati today and the official gatherings tomorrow may be much more productive. The sport is confronted by so many problems that every baseball meeting has attained a new importance.

BUXTEHUDE: Cantatas Nos. 25 to 27, Ich bin Auferstehung und das Leben, Ich bin eine Blume zu Saron and Mein Herz 1st bereit, Bruno Mueller, bass; Cantata No. 83, O Lux Beata Trinitas; Margot Guilleaume and Barbara Groth, sopranos (Vox). Expressive works, earnestly sung, but the accompanying violins sound a little edgy.

BONN, Germany, July 11 -- Unification has become the real issue in Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- The Senate today passed by voice vote a bill easing production controls on wheat farmers and allowing them to plant 61,000,000 acres for the 1954 crop. The measure was rushed through in the face of a record high supply in which the Government has invested $1,000,000,000 in price supports.
HOLLINWELL, England, July 11 (UP) -- England beat Canada by four matches to three with three halved in a women's international golf match today.

MYSTERY fans and aficionados of the historical novel have a treat in store in Edgar Maass' "A Lady at Bay." Mr. Maass is the author of one superior historical novel, "Don Pedro and the Devil," and two disappointing best sellers, "Imperial Venus" and "The Queen's Physician."

LONDON, July 11 -- A 25-year-old Englishwoman referred to as "Mrs. McK." has made medical history by being the first human being known to have a double set of the four possible human blood groups O, A, B or AB. She is O and A.

COLUMBINE or aquilegia are finishing two months of bloom in my garden. This is truly one of the indispensable perennials, not just because it blossoms for so long a period but also because it is one of the lightest and most graceful of flowers, whether planted alone or in a mixed border. It is an excellent cut flower, too.

NEW DELHI, India, July 11 -Indian and United States representatives will resume debate this month on a new civil aviation agreement proposed by India, which would limit service to this country by United States airlines. The talks were recessed June 1 with no indication that opposing positions could be reconciled.

UTICA, N. Y., July 11 -- Seaman Billy Shields of Albany, the defending champion, and Tommy Goodwin of Rye, former titleholder, today won their way into the final of the state amateur golf championship.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 11 -Senator A. S. Mike Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma, called tonight for the formation of a United Nations police force to be recruited on a voluntary basis in the smaller nations of the world.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 11 (UP) -- After a 118-year try-out, the State of Illinois finally has decided the first bill Abraham Lincoln guided through the State Legislature is unworkable. It dealt with cows.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Order backlogs for companies in the Chicago area continued the downward trend in June, a move started back in April, the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago reported. Pro duction has fallen off each month for the last three, reflecting a "wait and see' attitude on the part of industry as backlogs slip, inventories gain and national policies on profits, taxes and world trade remain unstable.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- For most men in politics, life is marked off in inexorable two-year cycles which move so swiftly that they have scarcely a chance to celebrate the successful passage of one before the rigors of the next are upon them.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- Among the hazards of driving from Texas to Costa Rica are the frightening vagaries of immigration and customs regulations and the physical terrors of some very bad roads. But the most serious hazard is that such a trip tends to break up families.

WILLIAM DOZIER, who has a great deal to do with the vicarious dramatic adventures of the Columbia Broadcasting System's television audience, is a man with whom any television fan might enjoy a chat.

ATHENS, July 11 -- In winding up their four-day meeting here today the foreign ministers of Greece, Yugoslavia and Turkey in their diplomatic way have done the equivalent of inviting the Soviet satellites to shake loose their Kremlin ties.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 11 -- With a twenty-year-old, secondhand cruiser he bought three years ago when he began yachting, a Red Bank dentist, Dr. Anson G. Hoyt, tonight appeared the winner of the most coveted predicted-log race in the East.

NEW DELHI, July 11 -- The increasing prominence of India in international discussions has placed unusual burdens on this country's leaders at a time when domestic preoccupations also are making immense demands upon the Government.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 11 -- Increase in demand for credit in the Ninth Federal Reserve District exceeds that of the national average, despite a decline in bank loans to farmers, the Minneapolis Reserve Bank reported in its monthly survey of business conditions. Of the $1,376,773,000 outstanding in loans this spring, $428,851,000 went for commercial and industrial purposes; $387,271,000 were real estate loans, and $321,645,000 went to individuals for automobiles, instalment payments, or modernization.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- Miss Willis will become only the third woman in United States history to be named to a full ambassadorship. First was Mrs. Eugenie Anderson, Ambassador to Denmark until she resigned when President Eisenhower took office. In addition, Clare Boothe Luce is now serving as Ambassador to Italy.

Three trans-Atlantic liners of the French Line, among them the 45,330-gross-ton Ile de France, the fifth largest passenger vessel in the world, have been scheduled for a winter cruise program of ten voyages.

United Parcel Service has started a new low-rate service by air from Los Angeles and San Francisco to the metropolitan and suburban areas of Portland, Seattle, Chicago, Philadelphia and New York. A subsidiary of the company, known as United Parcel Service-AIR, is conducting the service.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, July 11 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, in taking over here today the Supreme Command of the North Atlantic Treaty forces in Europe from his predecessor, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, warned the Western World against such "wishful thinking" as that the recent events behind the Iron Curtain foreshadowed a "dissolution of the Soviet empire."

Tom Fool, Greentree Stable's superfine race horse, did something extra special at the Aqueduct track yesterday. He took up 136 pounds, made concessions of from 26 to 31 pounds to his four opponents and won with ease in the sixty-fifth running of the mile-and-a-quarter Brooklyn Handicap.

In a widespread training exercise for American and Canadian air forces and ground observers, planes of the United States Strategic Air Command simulated enemy bombers and "struck" the Pacific Coast yesterday in a surprise attack beginning before dawn.

COLUMBUS, Ohio -- The State of Ohio has been celebrating the 150th anniversary of its statehood since March 1 when a special session of the Legislature was held at Chillicothe, its first capital. The sesquicentennial program will continue through Thanksgiving Day, with the state's celebrations supplemented by separate sesquicentennial observances in each of the eighty-eight counties.

This year's domestic cotton crop may be much smaller than had been expected by Government officials and the trade. Beria, deposed First Deputy Premier and Minister of Internal Affairs, the sternest penalty provided by law for the crimes with which he is charged.

A cable from your Geneva correspondent in THE TIMES of July 13 reported that the United Nations Economic and Social Council decided to remove from its agenda the problem of forced labor. TEANECK, N. J., July 11 -- Archbishop Thomas A. Boland, head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Newark, presided this morning at a solemn high mass in honor of the fiftieth anniversary of the ordination to the priesthood of the Rev. Silverius J. Quigley, pastor of St. Anastasia's Church here for twenty years.

Ready-to-wear wholesale markets were quiet here last week with out-of-town buyers back at their stores awaiting arrival of initial fall purchases, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. Buyers are expected to return late in July to place additional fall orders.

SIX miles beyond the western gate of Paris, the concrete ribbons of the smooth parkway throw off a black access road that rises to a gentle knoll. Here, at this point, where only three years ago no sound was heard more martial than the crack of a farmer's gun poaching hares on the President of France's hunting reserve, now stands a low, gray gridiron building.

A long fight to preserve what the National Park Service has described as the last remaining significant stretch of natural beach and dune land in the northeastern United States has successfully ended with acquisition of Island Beach by the State of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Unions came through the 1953 sessions of the State Legislatures unscathed, but it wasn't easy. Some labor sources consider that the year's record of holding the line was an achievement in view of the number and kinds of bills that had been introduced.

CHORE FOR WEEK: After a rain or, if possible, a thorough watering of the soil, light fertilizing will benefit flowers and vegetables. Feed all kinds of roses and the late summer-flowering 'mums and dahlias An application of liquid or dry fertilizer will stimulate gladiolus and annual flowers, but only aids growth of weeds in lawns with brown patches.
BONN, Germany, July 11 -- The downfall of Lavrenti P. Beria has sharpened debate in West Germany on the desirability of negotiating a four-power solution of the problem of Germany's reunification.
LONDON, July 11 (AP) -- Roger Bannister ran the third fastest mile in British history today when he won the British Amateur Athletics Association race in 4 minutes 5.2 seconds.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 11 -Philip Scott, the 5-year-old bay owned by George W. Reed and P. G. and Jere Gray of Providence, R. I., turned in his best time of the season tonight to capture the $4,500 featured First Army Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.
As a former Rhodes Scholar, may I comment on Richard N. Gardner's article "What Would Cecil Rhodes Say?" (June 28)?

PARIS, July 11 -- Nobody yet knows how much the Soviet monolith is likely to be weakened militarily by the purging of Lavrenti P. Beria. It is too early to foresee whether his arrest will be followed by another of the mass purges for which the Soviet Union is notorious. Yet it is obvious that numerous security officers appointed by Mr. Beria "for their personal loyalty to himself," as Pravda has said, will be punished.
The women's twenty-fourth annual New York State championship starts tomorrow over the Hempstead L. I. Golf Club course, with a small field expected.

A Federal mediator stepped into the strike of ninety-four navigators against Trans World Airlines yesterday, and last night representatives of company and union met separately to consider his proposals. They adjourned shortly after 10 o'clock without decision, but were to resume this morning at 10:30.

ONLY occasionally are New Yorkers underprivileged as far as art exhibitions are concerned. Ironically, however, there are a number of ingenious and informative shows which are conceived and executed here which New Yorkers never see.

ELMIRA, N. Y., July 11 -- An effort to halt the spread of infantile paralysis in an area where it threatens to become epidemic was begun today by a professional and volunteer army of 1,500 in Chemung and Steuben Counties.

FURNITURE introduced at the summer wholesale home furnishings markets held here and in Grand Rapids usually reiterates and establishes those trends which first became apparent at the midwinter markets. The recent markets were no exception. All of the tentative tendencies which were observed in January were reaffirmed in furnishings shown to buyers here last month. The furniture will become generally available to the public in September.

WITH the announcement last week that the dynamo-driven Jose Ferrer, in a magnificent gesture of civic-mindedness, had agreed to find the time from his manifold activities to direct and appear in a three-play drama series at the City Center this winter, friends of the Fifty-fifth Street playhouse were encouraged to believe that once again the drama would become the financial bulwark of the Center's program.

A NEW, cheaper arrangement for tourists between the United States and Cuba has come into effect, the result of a joint effort by the two nations to ease a situation created by the McCarran Immigration Act. Under the new arrangement Americans visiting. Cuba use a multiple-entry tourist card good for two years and costing $2.50.

MONTREAL, July 11 -- Canadian engineers were out on field surveys today, plotting contours and other technical details for the new canals that are going to be built on the Canadian side of the international rapids section to the west of Montreal.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The State Department announced tonight the acceptance of a Korean armistice by Dr. Syngman Rhee, who, as President of South Korea, had blocked a cease-fire for weeks.

The new $8,500,000 terminal building at Newark Airport will be dedicated on July 29, Donald V. Lowe, Commissioner of the Port of New York Authority, announced yesterday. Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey and Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle, retired, will speak.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- President Eisenhower, in a highly jovial mood, was the guest this noon of Republican Senators and Representatives at a buffet luncheon celebrating the first anniversary of his nomination as the Republican Presidential candidate.
NEWARK, July 11 -- Fire Department officials in this area today directed their inquiry into five fires in churches and institutions in recent weeks toward the possibility of arson.
DETROIT, July 11 (UP) -- Letty Bob Cain fired a five-hitter and his team-mates blasted four home runs today as the Browns defeated the Tigers, 7 -- 2, before 6,519 fans at Briggs Stadium.

PROBABLY the very last drawing made by Raoul Dufy, who died on March 23, was a rough sketch indicating how he wished his work to be shown in the retrospective exhibition which has just been opened at the Musee National D'Art Moderne.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 11 -Isabel Troccole of the Bronx defeated Mrs. Nellie Sheer Kagan of Miami Beach and New York, 1 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 8 -- 6, to win the singles championship of the New York State women's clay court tennis tournament at the New Rochelle Tennis Club today.

LONDON, July 11 -- While the downfall of Lavrenti P. Beria has not altered the British Government's view that four-power talks should be held when the time is ripe, diplomatic quarters here said that it was obvious that the timing would have to be governed by events in the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, July 11 -- When members of the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities arrives here Monday, they may find that most of the alleged subversives they are looking for in the Dewey administration are no longer state workers.

BERGEN, Norway -- A four-hour seaplane flight between Bergen and Trondheim is an excellent way for a hurried traveler to take in the splendors of mountains and fjords on Norway's west coast. A tiny, modern airline, little known to tourists, maintains daily service between this country's second and third largest cities, its planes carrying mail, light freight and eight passengers over and into the heart of some of the world's most picturesque scenery.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The foreign ministers of Britain, France and the United States were reported authoritatively today to have agreed in principle upon a future meeting of the Big Four, including the Soviet Union's new leaders, but to be uncertain yet about the timing and necessary preliminaries of such a diplomatic effort to ease world tension.
PARIS, July 11 -- After twenty-four hours of reflection, some of the best-informed diplomats here refuse to assume that the decline of Mr. Beria portends any great change in Soviet foreign policy.

FROM time to time in the past Americans have written books about European bridge systems in order to introduce those systems to American players. A new book recently come to this department, however, is probably the first written by an American about an English system and for publication in England.

WHATEVER the disadvantages and irritations of commercial television in the United States, they tend to assume far less importance after one watches the only major alternative system in operation at present -- the noncommercial and noncompetitive service of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., July 11 -- Violence here this week marked a seven-month newspaper strike in which a union and four newspapers in this Quad City area are trying to determine the extent to which publishers and unions shall control the use of new equipment that may curtail or eliminate union jobs.

The Mutual Security Program has just completed another one of its journeys through Congress, emerging relatively unscathed. President Eisenhower asked for a little less than $5.5 billions. The authorization bill on which conferees of the two houses have agreed would give the program $5,157,232,500. The two houses also succeeded in compromising on certain hampering amendments that the House had written into the bill.

LUGANO, Switzerland, July 11 (UP) -- Mrs. Barbara Scofield Davidson of Milwaukee defeated Pat Ward of Britain, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, today in the women's singles semi-finals at the Swiss international tennis championships and will meet Josepa de Riba of Spain tomorrow for the title.
I read with interest William S. White's article on "New Nationalism" (June 28 ).

"FAR above Cayuga's waters" on the campus of Corner University, Ithaca, N. Y., is a colorful half-acre plot of flowers. Known formally as the Lua A. Minns Memorial Garden, and commonly as the students' garden, this favorite spot on the campus is located on the corner of Garden Avenue and Power Road in front of Bailey Hall.

PARIS, July 11 -- The great Soviet ice floe gripping Europe and Asia between the Elbe River and the Pacific Ocean has begun to show signs of even deeper strain than had hitherto been suspected. Those sharp cracks which had already appeared along the Western edges of the political glacier now seem to have extended their rents far into its heart.
TORONTO, July 11 -- American pros won the major share of the $15,000 Canadian open golf tournament today with Dave Douglas of Newark, Del., rallying to take the $3,000 first prize.

RANGOON, Burma, July 11 (Reuters) -- The Burmese Army said today that it had captured documents to prove that Karen tribal rebels had formed an alliance with outlawed Communists for joint guerrilla warfare against the Government.

CROSS - COUNTRY motorists always find it hard to choose just the right side-trip each day to make that day memorable. For tourists whose route takes them near the spot where Minnesota, Wisconsin and Iowa intersect, Effigy Indian Mounds National Monument make a short stop combining exercise, scenery and history.

President Eisenhower signed an order in Washington yesterday removing William A. Carroll as United States Marshal for the Southern District of New York. The White House said that Mr. Carroll had declined to submit his resignation when requested. His successor, Thomas J. Lunney, was nominated last June 24.

On both local and state levels, citizens' committees for the public schools are growing at a tremendous pace. The "grass roots" movement of citizen interest in education, stimulated four years ago by the founding of the National Citizens Commission for the Public Schools, has now reached large proportions. More than ever before, the average citizen of the community is taking an active interest and a personal pride in the condition of his school system.

GENEVA, July 11 -- A United States legation official said today that Miss Willis already had been accepted by the Swiss Government. She will be the first United States chief of mission to hold the rank of Ambassador here, in accordance with a recent agreement between the Swiss and United States Governments raising the American mission from the status of a legation to an embassy.

BELGRADE, July 2 -- Yugoslavia plans to democratize her judiciary system established in 1947 when she was a leading member of the Communist bloc. The most important change will transfer the rights of "investigation" from the Ministry of Interior to the courts, but other revisions, involving habeas corpus rights, also are contemplated.

A strange silvery-gray metal which the ancient Greeks encumbered with the formidable name molybdenum has advanced to a stellar role in industry's quest for materials that can meet the high stress and temperature demands of modern engineering.

ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N. J. -- Each week-end an increasing number of motorists discovers the scenic five-mile parkway that is already easing congestion along part of U. S. 9W, although it will not be officially opened until September.

In a special program, Sarah Lawrence College is offering an opportunity for work in the performing arts to a limited number of young men next year. Experimental work in theatre, dance, opera, music and stage design -- all part of the regular curriculum, will be opened to young men on both graduate and undergraduate levels. Graduate work will be carried on under Sarah Lawrence's Graduate Studies Program leading to the Master of Arts degree.

A WHOLLY practical book that almost literally sets the exposures for the reader, "Vacation U.S.A. and Your Color Camera," just published by Eastman Kodak, is a reassuring guide both for beginner and advanced amateur.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., July 11 (AP) -- A cloud of dust kicked up by his brother's car ahead apparently caused a 17-year-old motorist to drive into a bridge abutment early today, killing his passenger and injuring himself, the state police said.
Many of the elements of a good mystery yarn lie behind the annual lists of names of missing depositors that banks and trust companies are advertising in newspapers this month.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified seventy-eight Korean war casualties today, including twenty-one killed, fifty-three wounded and four injured. Casualties from New York follow (none were listed from New Jersey or Connecticut):

The Advertising Council is not sitting back in satisfaction over the fact that deaths over the Fourth of July week-end were fewer than the year before and below what the National Safety Council had predicted. Its officials claim a distinct assist as reports come in of the number of media that used the council's slogan, "The life you save may be your own." The number of displays in all media broke all records.
TOKYO, Sunday, July 12 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,673, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korean time:

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 11 -Recent progress in reshaping this country's "emotional preoccupation" with the racial problem has resulted in the broadening of Negro leadership concern over common problems in regional, national and international affairs, the tenth annual Race Relations Institute was told today.

WHATEVER the causes that brought Barrows Dunham, head of the Philosophy Department at Temple University, before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, I should guess that he could hardly be convicted of disloyalty from this book.

Cortisone (compound E) and hydrocortisone (Compound F) have been atomically labeled with carbon 14 for the first time by Drs. T. F. Gallagher, Theodore H. Kritchevsky and David L. Garmaise of the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research, New York City. Charles E. Frosst Co., Montreal, Canada, with the help of the Upjohn Company of Kalamazoo, Mich., prepared the radioactive cortisone and hydrocortisone.

RICHMOND, Va., July 11 -- Virginia's Democratic primary campaign for Governor neared its climax today as voters prepared to go to the polls Tuesday and select either Thomas B. Stanley or Charles L. Fenwick as the candidate.

DURING their annual pilgrimage to mountains, lakes, brooks, hills and seashore, millions of summer vacationists fall in love with nature. If it is true love, they will want to study their wild flowers and trees, birds, butterflies and bees.

When "Wish You Were Here" survived its bad notices the sigh of relief that rose from the drama desks could be heard as far as New Haven. Drama critics could no longer be accused of killing plays. In a recent Sunday article the critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES noted that "the record of last season proves that newspaper critics do not make or break a play."

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 11 -- The expected renewal of full-scale hostilities in Indo-China when the rains cease next winter may well decide the outcome of the struggle that has gone on there for the last seven years.

IN the spring of 1800, a jovial preacher, Josiah Talltatters, with his nephew, Jeremiah, and his horse, Pilgrim, set out from Philadelphia and followed the wilderness roads west. The long and difficult journey was often pleasantly broken by meetings with other travelers around the night campfires, where experiences were related while the children played.

THE repertoire of readily available jazz recordings, which was widely expanded with the arrival of LPs, has been given an added facet by the development of 45 r.p.m. Extended Play records. A good many EPs, it is true, simply repeat material already issued on LP.

HONOLULU, July 11 (AP) -- Two separate races developed today in the 2,225-mile trans-Pacific yacht race as freshening winds heartened yachtsmen speeding toward Hawaii's famed Diamond Head landmark from the California coast.

LISBON, July 11 -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar expressed yesterday Portugal's unshakeable opposition to the Indian demand that Portugal relinquish her possessions along the west coast of India.

A VETERAN of the border, Capt. Alexander Prince knew the Comanches and knew something about the situation in the new Republic of Texas. He had been stationed there before with the Dragoons; his wife had died there, leaving him a lonely man.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The dictum that "psychological strategy" does not exist as an independent medium, voiced this week by a Presidential committee, again illustrated the difficulty of setting up a psychological warfare organization in a democracy.

DALLAS, Texas, July 11 -- The southwestern drought again was reflected in Texas farm prices this week as the state's Agriculture Department disclosed that farm prices slid 5.17 per cent in the month ended in mid-June. The price index was lower largely as the result of a drop averaging about $4 in beef cattle prices.

JULY and August seem to be the proper time to relax and enjoy the flowers in the garden. But actually this is the time when gardeners, who grow their perennials and biennials from seed, prepare for next spring and summer bloom.

Earnings of most of the leading New York City banks and trust companies were higher in the second quarter of 1953 than in the 1952 period, June 30 condition statements show. And for a large majority of the institutions, earnings were substantially better in the first half of 1953 than a year ago.

MADRID -- The Castellana Hilton Hotel, which will be opened to the public this Thursday, brings for the first time to Europe the American idea of streamlined luxury and comfort made famous by Conrad Hilton in his chain of hotels throughout the United States and in Puerto Rico.

A NOVEL can begin with a theme or moral observation, which the author proceeds to illustrate by means of characterization, plot, random items from the notebook marked "human behavior in trying situations."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 11 -Royal Knight, a 7-year-old gray gelding from N. M. Coates' Volco Stable of Morristown, N. J., won both of the classes in which he was entered to take the lead in the jumper division of the New Brunswick show today.

The special Federal Grand Jury impaneled last month to investigate waterfront corruption is boring deep into dock racketeering and other violations and is now sitting almost constantly under the foremanship of Laurance S. Rockefeller, a member of the board of Eastern Airlines and a son of John D. Rockefeller Jr.

EVER since James Ramsey Ullman's memorable "The White Tower," novels about mountaineering have been coming off the press in increasing numbers. Henri Troyat's vivid story of an Alpine climb and its tragic aftermath is one of the best this reader has encountered.
KOREAN FRONT, July 11 -- The war goes on here. It goes on in an endless morass of mud under a cheerless, leaden sky.
LOS ANGELES, July 11 -- Los Angeles Harbor's new $8,250,000 marine terminal was opened officially today with the arrival of the liner Lurline from Honolulu.
BERLIN, Sunday, July 12 -- Martial law was lifted in East Berlin at midnight last night, twenty-four days after it was imposed during the June 17 riots. While Soviet military units ap-...

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 -- Republicans of the Far West are weighing their chances of "crashing" the aging, all-Democratic, Roosevelt-Truman-appointed Ninth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals. The tribunal has seven members.

CHOOSING his title well, Jared van Wagenen Jr. here presents the period that is the most popular in American history. Millions of our machine-age citizens whose ancestors were in foreign lands during those sparsely populated, early nineteenth century times, agree with compatriots whose families have been here longer, that the period represented our nation's noblest hour.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, July 12 -- United States Seventh Division troops pulled off "Porkchop Hill" on the western front last night, ending, temporarily at least, a savage five-day battle with Chinese Communists, and today United States artillery raked the abandoned height with devastating fire.

JAMES MICHENER is not the first to write a story with a jet plane as hero, but he is the first to have written humanly and literately about it in "The Bridges at Toko-ri" (which was written for Life Magazine).

CAMDEN, Me., July 11 -- First steps toward perpetuating the memory of Edna St. Vincent Millay, the poet, who lived here during most of her early years, will be taken when Millay Week will be observed July 14 to 19.

TULSA, July 11 (AP) While Allan Worthington was setting a major league record today with his second consecutive shutout in as many major league games, his older brother listened to the contest at his home here.

CINCINNATI, July 11 (UP) -- Johnny Klippstein held the Redlegs hitless until the sixth inning today and then yielded only four hits the rest of the way as Dee Fondy and Bill Serena each hit homers to produce a 5-2 victory for the Cubs.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 11 (AP) -- Edmund L. Palmieri, a New York lawyer, has brought a suit against the Netherlands to be dealt with by The Hague Court of Justice on Monday, Jan Roggeveen, Dutch counsel for Harold J. Adonis, said today.

ONE Saturday morning several weeks ago, a friend of ours waited at Grand Central Station for the arrival of three young children who would spend the week-end with her and her husband. Suddenly she saw approaching a group of eight boys and girls, assorted ages. The three

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -- In recent months, loans of member banks in the Third Federal Reserve District have risen to record levels. During the first quarter of this year lending climbed $98,000,000 to $2,861,000,000. This increase was more than twice as large as in the early months of last year.

AMARILLO, Tex., July 11 (UP) -- Governors of states in the drought-stricken Southwest today sent eight relief recommendations to President Eisenhower who conferred with them in this city yesterday for four hours.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- Congressional leaders forecast today a personal appeal by President Eisenhower to Congress to appropriate $5,000,000,000 for foreign aid.

For a person who had very little formal education, Harold Vincent Smith learned his lessons well. Today he is president of one of the largest insurance companies in the United States. He also is one of the highest paid executives in the business.

A new channelization and signal control traffic plan to eliminate a bottleneck approach to the Queensboro Bridge will be placed in operation on Tuesday, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley announced yesterday.

A long - sought hold - up man walked into a police ambush in a Brooklyn bakery shop last night, traded shots with a detective, and escaped through a subway tunnel, leaving a wounded 50-year-old woman as a casualty.

BOOKS on space travel in the past few years have been as numerous as shooting stars in a meteor shower. Like these heavenly bodies, some of the volumes have been brighter and have endured longer than others. Arthur Clarke's "The Exploration of Space" is an example.

Operating costs at St. Luke's Hospital last year reached a high of $4,175,221, resulting in a net deficit of $216,889 after income on investments and contributions received direct or through the United Hospital Fund and the Greater New York Fund.
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- Hill Gail and Jamie K. were soundly trounced as a 9-to-2 shot, H. B. Delman's Roaming, won the $22,725 Myrtlewood Handicap by a neck at Arlington Park today.

THERE he was in Florida, writes Pat Frank, beachcombing -- and, oh yes, putting his hand occasionally to producing a novel, a few articles and some short stories -- when suddenly there was a telephone call from New York.

ENGLISH by birth, Americans by adoption, the authors run a cooking school in California. Their book is aimed at party-givers. The recipes, in eight servings, are for dishes that often are rich in heavy or sour cream, sometimes are over-seasoned and occasionally are elaborate to the point of fussiness.

Allan Worthington beat the Dodgers, 6 -- 0, for his second shutout in two major league starts at Ebbets Field yesterday as the Giants won their eighth straight. The 23-year-old Giant rookie also ended the Dodger homer string at twenty-four, one short of the record for both leagues.

SIDNEY HOOK'S review of the Harold Laski biography by Kingsley Martin is unjust to the man. In attacking Laski's views, Mr. Martin failed to take into account those important changes in Laski's opinions during the last years of his life.
During these two vacation months of July and August, 28,000,000 school children are "on the loose."

CINCINNATI, July 11 (AP) -- The homer-happy National League team, boasting one of the most powerful squads in years, rules a 7-5 favorite to score its fourth straight victory over the American League in the twentieth annual All-Star game at Crosley Field on Tuesday.

HOLLYWOOD'S reputation for popping up where least expected recently got a workout when a location company from Paramount turned up high in the Peruvian Andes. The unit, headed by Mel Epstein, the producer, and Jerry Hopper, the director, visited the South American republic to take advantage of the seldom-photographed locale.

The idea to preserve venerable historic landmarks, as described in the article of Aline B. Louchheim, (June 28) is, of course, commendable. It should be applied, however, with a certain amount of esthetic discernment. Only such buildings ought to be saved which do credit to the taste of our ancestors.

The botanical name is Asclepias, honoring Aesculapius, the Greek god of healing. The everyday name is milkweed, and the two best known members of the family, butterfly weed and common milkweed, are now in bloom. Butterfly weed lifts its showy orange flower head in favored places. The common milkweed is everywhere, less spectacular with its tassely tufts of lavender and white florets but full of sweetness, a subtle mixture of tuberose and honeysuckle fragrance.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 11 -- The third congress of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions closed tonight after a seven-day session during which the new situation growing out of an East German labor uprising against communism June 17 came in for major attention.

YOU can't safely judge a book by its by-line alone. Sometimes your favorite author will let you down badly and more rarely a writer whose work you've never been able to stomach will suddenly reveal unsuspected and welcome talents.

AT Hollywood's first demonstration of CinemaScope, Twentieth Century - Fox's own new wide-screen development, some weeks back, the initial reaction among the assembled notables seemed to be that this process was fine for mountains and the Empire State Building, but a little hard on actors, who came out looking twelve feet tall and a mile wide.

MOSCOW, Sunday, July 12 -- Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov, in a note handed to the United States Embassy last night, said that President Eisenhower's offer of $15,000,000 worth of foodstuffs for East Germany was "a propaganda maneuver."

A LATTER-DAY Photo-Secession, though without Alfred Stieglitz, has been under way for some time in this city and elsewhere. At the turn of the century a group of photographers under Stieglitz' leadership broke away from the Camera Club to give photography a lift it sorely needed.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Republicans, who have been enjoying a two-vote advantage over the Democrats in the Senate for three weeks, will find their strength again reduced to a margin of one next week when a new Democratic member from North Carolina takes his seat.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 11 -- Soldiers and sailors who made use of the recreational facilities of the United Shore Service Organization building near the business center here did so in the dark or by candlelight for the last week.

MASSAPEQUA, L. I., July 11 -- A program of continual expansion of school facilities, made necessary by enrollments increasing at the rate of 1,000 a year, has caused school officials of this already heavily assessed middle-income community to effect stringent economies in building construction.

Behind the facades of Seventh Avenue New York's billion dollar fashion industry is shifting into high gear on production of fall and winter coats, suits, dresses and sportswear. Thousands of skilled hands have begun the task of guiding cloth through sewing machines, under shears and pressing irons to produce the garments that America's women will wear later this year.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 11 -- Ben Hogan, trying hard to relax the tension built up during his smashing triumph in the British open golf championship, hurried his plans today for a vacation in Paris.

Schoolhouse Cave in eastern West Virginia has been in the news because eleven members of the National Spelio-logical Society have been exploring hitherto unknown portions of it. Spelio-logists, these explorers of the depths call themselves in their serious scientific moments; spelunkers when they speak lightly of themselves.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 11 -- The Republic of Lebanon will tomorrow hold a parliamentary election that offers more unknowns and variables than a nuclear equation -- including a half dozen spinter parties, candidacies drawn on religious as well as political lines, a new and unpredictable women's vote, intense interest and no clear-cut issues.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 11 -- One of this country's leading Protestant theologians and church executives sharply challenged today the veracity of J. B. Matthews, who was ousted on Thursday as executive staff director of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

LOS ANGELES, July 11 -- The first of eighty-six special trains from all parts of the country is scheduled to roll into Los Angeles tomorrow morning with the vanguard of 50,000 Boy Scouts attending their organization's third national jamboree.

The Bryant Park concerts of the New York Public Library will continue this week to offer a blend of well-remembered classics and modern, less well known works. The programs will be held from noon to 2 P. M. tomorrow through Friday.

Business in the department stores in the week was quite good, helped along by post-holiday clearance sales. However, business also was good in the corresponding 1952 week, and thg weather conditions were about the same. The net effect, according to trade observers, Was that volume in comparison with 1952 was unchanged to 5 per cent ahead, with furniture and summer hard lines doing especially well.

THIS fine old cosmopolitan city of almost 500,000 persons, famous for its devotion to liberty and its tolerance of non-conformists, is in the midst of a book burning, or, more accurately, a book-branding controversy which has aroused much local bitterness and at the same time attracted nation-wide attention.

SHELBURNE, Vt. -- A museum village opened late last summer and now in its first season of full operation is delighting travelers along one of the direct arteries between New York and Montreal. The village is on U. S. 7, which parallels the Vermont shore of Lake Champlain.

Some one in the Yankee organization, striving to stimulate interest and help business, merits a pat on the back for Operation Saturday Night. Staged last night at the Stadium, it was a huge success, artistically as well as financially.

THE beginner (into which class even many good cooks fit when it comes to fish) will welcome this book because the recipes are so simple. However, the experienced fish fancier (and marine epicures are also legion) may find it, for the reason the dishes are so basic, a little uninspired.

The inoculation with gamma globulin of 32,000 children against polio in Montgomery County, Alabama, was declared yesterday to be a success in the sense that there has been a reduction both in the severity and the number of cases. Last week there were more mass injections of gamma globulin in Caldwell County, North Carolina, where 5,825 children under 10 years were the subjects of official concern.

MEXICO CITY, July 3 -- Another of former President Miguel Aleman's close friends has fallen from power and it has become evident that the new President, Adolfo Ruiz Cortines, is purging what is known here as the "Aleman clique" as part of his reform of Mexican political life.

THE lady was wrong, like many an overpositive person. When Robert St. John was a high school freshman in the Chicago suburb of Oak Park his English teacher kept him after school one afternoon. Before attending to him, she told off a senior in her short-story writing class.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Three Chicago pitchers held Cleveland to five hits today as the White Sox rallied for a 5-4 triumph over the Indians to take a game-and-a-half lead in their struggle for second place in the American League race.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 11 -With a light and variable westerly predicted for the overnight voyage, a fleet of thirty-six cruising yachts were off tonight on the twenty-second Riverside Yacht Club-Stratford Shoal race.

DURING his annual summer vacation in Europe Rudolf Bing has been hearing and engaging new singers for the Metropolitan Opera. His full catch is not yet known, but it has been learned that he has a commitment from Irmgard Seefried of the Vienna Opera to sing a few performances, probably of Susanna in "The Marriage of Figaro," and he has signed two new Italian tenors.
Ship chartering continued in the doldrums during the last week, with some increased activity as far as volume was concerned but with no corresponding rise in rates.

BONN, July 11 -- The struggle in Washington to formulate and implement new trade and aid policies has had fewer repercussions in West Germany than in Britain, France and other Western European countries where an unfavorable balance of payments continues to jeopardize economic and financial stability.

A RUMOR that an Italo-British movie unit was in town last week filming the story of Romeo and Juliet, traveled rapidly around sunny, dusty Verona. Long awake to the fact that the lovers' legend, spread throughout the world in Shakespeare's verse, constituted the city's number one tourist lure, the local populace and officialdom immediately began searching for the filmmakers, eager to capitalize on the publicity value this visit was certain to bear.

Whereas this yachting season of 1953 is, among power craft, undeniably a banner year for the cruisers, which at long last have come into prominence with a new array of navigational tests known as predicted log races, the speeding putt-putts and the almost inexhaustible number of classes of inboards are having big doings of their own virtually everywhere.

THE Warner Brothers, who apparently mined a good, if frightening, thing when that gigantic and improbable Mesozoic monster of "The Beast From 20,000 Fathoms" was unearthed via an atomic blast, are planning to stick with that type of fiction, fission and pseudo-science.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, July 12 (UP) -- Following is the text of a joint statement issued by Walter S. Robertson, United States Assistant Secretary of State, and President Syngman Rhee of South Korea:

A plea for tolerance, defense of constitutional government and the preservation of the American way of life was made yesterday by Harvey A. Beffa of St. Louis, Imperial Potentate of the Ancient Arabic Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine for North America.

MANCHESTER, England, July 11 (Reuters) -- England, after recovering from thirty-two for two, lost two wickets in the last fifteen minutes of play to reach 126 for four in reply to Australia's 318 in the third day of the third cricket test match today.

VIENNA, July 11 -- Nowhere except in the Soviet Union is the fall of Lavrenti P. Beria likely to have so great an effect as in the Soviet satellite states. This is the second great shock to reach them from Moscow since the death of Premier Stalin.
PASADENA, Calif., July 11 -- Fortune Gordien of the Los Angeles Athletic Club today set a new world discus record with a toss of 190 feet 7 1/2 inches.

FROM the day Tess, an English girl, saw the old gypsy caravan it occupied her every thought. To everyone's astonishment she stood in the pouring rain to bid for it at the auction. Though she and Ann and Jan pool resources to get paint and the materials for restoration, it gradually becomes her own. Everything else fades into the background.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Quick Senate passage of the Administration's bill for continuation until Dec. 31 of the excess profits tax apparently was assured today as bipartisan managers concentrated on devising means to prevent it from being amended.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Colo. -- Something of the frenzy of the old days prevails today in this last and greatest of the nineteenth-century gold camps as visitors by the hundreds drive around Pikes Peak from Colorado Springs to see the new Cripple Creek Museum or the sixth annual melodrama given twice daily at the Imperial Hotel.

I EXPLICITLY denied that Laski was a Communist; nor did I characterize him as a crypto-Communist. No one, however, can accuse Laski of consistency, and it is true that during the last years of his life he had some second thoughts about the Soviet Union and cooperation of European Socialists with Communists.
FOUR music festivals, in Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Finland, followed each other and overlapped, in the space of a month from May 25 in Copenhagen to June 18 in Helsinki.

LONDON, July 11 -- The little Sherpa family that left a two-room house in Darjeeling, India, to fly to London because Tenzing, the head of the family, climbed Mount Everest, wants to get home again. They are waiting for Queen Elizabeth II to invest Tenzing with the George medal in recognition of his feat.

CRITICISM constitutes one of the noblest of professions, but there are times when critics share some of their victims' acute distaste for it. They recoil from being eternally on the jury, they get fed up with always having to reach a verdict -- not least because the trials so often are longwinded and the defendants so dull.

BUENOS AIRES, July 11 -- With heir party facing extinction as a recognized political organization, he old-line Socialist leadership has ejected President Juan Peron's bid o close the nation's political ranks and has called on him to restore democratic rights to the Argenine citizenry.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- When 78-year-old James B. Bowler becomes a freshman Democratic member of Congress Monday probably few of his colleagues will realize that this white-haired man with the soft voice is one of the last of the hard-fisted politicians and ruler of one of the toughest wards in this city's West Side for nearly half a century.

FRANKFURT, Germany, July 11 (AP) -- George Solti, star conductor of the Frankfurt Opera, said tonight he was being denied entry into the United States pending clarification of a charge that his name was on the membership list of a Communist-sponsored society.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 11 (AP) -- The "Battle of the Bats" will be fought at a joint meeting of the major leagues in Cincinnati on Monday.
VANCOUVER, B. C., July 11 (AP) -The United States completed a 5-0 tennis sweep of the Davis Cup North American zone play-offs against Japan today.

A general election in Canada can roughly be compared in importance to a Presidential election in the United States. There is, however, no comparison between the sound and fury of our electoral battle last year and the peaceful, muted, listless campaign for federal election to take place Aug. 10 in Canada.
I am a Syracuse University student, and therefore was disturbed at what I believe was an inaccuracy in Aline B. Louchheim's "To Save the Houses of Our Heritage" (June 28).

Vassar College's Summer Institute for Family and Community Living is now operating its twenty-eighth annual session on the Vassar campus. Teachers, ministers, social and public health workers and parents with their children are among those from all sections of the country who are participating in the sessions.
Among the President's advisers, Washington observers report, there are three theories on how to deal with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

For years the semi-autonomous Indo-Chinese have been demanding "doc lap" -- full independence -- from France. Recently the pressures on Paris have mounted. The war against the Communist-led rebels in Vietnam has been stalemated. The Cambodians have threatened to join the fight against the French.

A CHEESE like cottage, cream or the Italian ricotta furnishes the basic ingredient of the refrigerated desserts offered here today. From the standpoint of good nutrition these desserts round out less hearty menus, such as the team of soup and salad.

REISSUES of early Carusos, Chaliapins and Lehmanns no longer make a collector's heart throb. The expanding LP catalogue has given us representative examples of most of the great singers; we have today every opportunity of judging for ourselves just how good -- or how bad -- they were. But pianists and violinists of the pre-electric recording era have been shabbily treated.

RALEIGH, N. C., July 11 (UP) -- North Carolina polio fighters are fully mobilized for the first time in the state's history to meet a major epidemic, the state health officer, Dr. J. R. North, said today.

A 25-year-old Brooklyn war veteran who was discharged from the Army three weeks ago was killed instantly and a 19-year-old Staten Island youth was critically injured yesterday in an automobile accident in Dongan Hills, S. I.

The Westchester Kennel Club show, which always has been noteworthy for the number of its specialties, will have more this year than ever. A total of twenty-three for the Oct. 11 event at the Westchester Country Club in Rye was announced last week.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 11 -Landlocked, owned by James Cox Brady and ridden by the home course jockey, Jimmy Stout, was an easy winner of the $26,500 Lamplighter Handicap at the Monmouth Park Race Track today. The result was not pleasing to the greater part of the 33,588 fans on hand, though, for the odds-on favorite, Royal Bay Gem, failed to get into a pay-off slot on the tote board.

Revisions of official thinking about the adequacy of the nation's money supply and about the timeliness of certain of the Eisenhower Administration's debt management objectives are not the only consequences of the recent sharp rise in interest rates.

CLEVELAND, July 11 -- The Great Lakes ore fleet's feat of establishing monthly loading records is expected to be continued in July as there has been no decrease in the demand for the raw mineral by the nation's busy steel plants.

FLAUBERT'S relatively uneventful life continues to fascinate biographers and readers. A number of new facts have been revealed and interpreted by French scholars in the last thirty years. This is the first biography in English to weave them into a truthful and artistic pattern.

TOKYO, Sunday, July 12 -- The Korean truce delegations met for three minutes at Panmunjom this morning, then called a recess until this afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 -- Stu Miller held the hard-hitting Braves to four hits tonight to enable the Cardinals to gain a 5-0 victory. The triumph left the Cards only half a game behind second-place Milwaukee and two and a half games back of the league-leading Dodgers, who lost to the Giants today.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 11 -- The nomination of Anatoli Iosifovich Lavrentiev as Soviet Ambassador to Iran was approved today by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi. Mr. Lavrentiev, now Soviet Ambassador to Rumania, is expected to arrive here next month.
SALEM, Ore., July 11 (AP) -Approximately 800 unruly convicts, corralled in the Oregon State Prison recreation area without water, continued their rebellion against prison authority tonight.

JUNE, the leading month for strawberries, has found many gardeners enjoying the harvest of home-grown fruit. Perhaps many more would find space for this luscious fruit if it were not generally believed that "they are too much trouble" or that "they take up too much space." Actually I have found that this is not at all the case.

PETUNIAS are at their prettiest now at Jones Beach, Long Island. Varieties Popcorn and Snowstorm, Colossal Shades of Rose, Celestial Rose and Comanche are especially floriferous and colorful this year, while Alderman, a bright navy blue, and pale Silver Blue duplicate the dark-and-light shadings of neighboring torenia.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 -- Stu Miller held the hard-hitting Braves to four hits tonight to enable the Cardinals to gain a 5-0 victory. The triumph left the Cards only half a game behind second-place Milwaukee and two and a half games back of the league-leading Dodgers, who lost to the Giants today.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 11 -- The nomination of Anatoli Iosifovich Lavrentiev as Soviet Ambassador to Iran was approved today by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi. Mr. Lavrentiev, now Soviet Ambassador to Rumania, is expected to arrive here next month.

THE average sportsman, whose hunting and fishing activities are cramped by the small areas made available through the courtesy of local landowners, does not realize that he has title to some 135 million acres of land, a vast estate with incredible opportunities for hunting, fishing, camping, hiking and other outdoor pursuits.
Let me commend THE NEW YORK TIMES for its excellent and fair editorial and for its understanding of the interest of the public in Civil Service problems.

Smoother, flatter fabrics with a polished look are stealing the fashion show from the ever popular boucles for fall coats. The furry look in coats, which began a few seasons back with poodle cloth, is being modified and sleeked down by most of the major fashion fabric houses. Zibelines and fleeces are edging into the spotlight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 12 -- Paramount lost no time in purchasing James A. Michener's latest work, "The Bridges at Toko-ri." The 30,000-word novel appeared recently in Life magazine, the publication that commissioned it, and was published in book form shortly afterward.
The origin of the red fezzes being worn by thousands of Shriners visiting the city is as unusual as the fezzes themselves.

MOSCOW, July 12 -- The Soviet press today directed attention to the charge that Lavrenti P. Beria, under the pretense of fighting against violations of the Soviet nationalities policy actually sought to stir up hatred and differences among the nations and races of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The nation may still escape another "record" year on polio cases even though totals to date are running ahead of the same time in 1952 -- the worst polio year on record. In 1952 about 58,000 cases had been recorded by the close of the year.

Charging that the Tammany machine is morally corrupt and politically bankrupt, Robert B. Blaikie, Democratic leader of the Seventh Manhattan Assembly District, announced yesterday that he would enter the Democratic primary on Sept. 15 as a candidate for the nomination for Mayor.

Summer-weight suits will be stressed in purchases for spring, 1954, retailers reported yesterday in a survey of trends in the men's clothing industry conducted by the Clothing Manufacturers of the U. S. A. Regular weight suits, however, will continue to be a close second, according to Harry A. Cabrin, executive secretary of the association.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, accused American Federation of Labor teamsters today of "raiding" a C. I. O. brewery union and declared that such action threatened to destroy the move toward labor unity.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has always shown deep concern in supporting international action for the prevention and punishment of conduct aiming at the systematic destruction of national, religious, racial and ethnic groups.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The success of Walter Spencer Robertson in his current mission to Korea has given new stature here to a quiet but respected diplomat whose real profession has been banking.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., July 12 -- Some of the fastest and deadliest jet fighters and bombers of the Air Force and the Navy are being "flown" here every day -- and this city has no military airport. Among them are the six-jet Boeing B-47 Stratojet bomber that has crossed the country in less than four hours, the carrier-borne McDonnell Banshee and the F-89D all-weather day and night twin-jet fighter known as the Northrop Scorpion.

GLEN COVE, L. I., July 12 -- The besmirched name of "hot rodders" was cleared here today, with the blessings of the Police Department, as twenty hot rodders triumphantly demonstrated their driving skill and the efficiency of their mechanical tinkering.

BERLIN, July 12 -- President Eisenhower has ordered that food be rushed to the frontiers of East Germany and East Berlin despite the Communists' rejection of the United States offer to deliver $15,000,000 worth to relieve shortages, United States officials here said today.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, July 13 -- United States Sabre jets shot down seven Communist MIG's yesterday in furious fights, the Fifth Air Force reported today, and Allied fighter-bombers struck heavily at a key network of rail and road bridges near Manchuria for the third day to stem the flow of supplies to the Communist front lines.

Parents who find that some phase of their youngster's behavior causes them particular concern might do well to try to relax their attitude toward the difficult behavior and concentrate on the child's good points, according to Mrs. Phillip W. Haberman Jr. Mrs. Haberman is the newly elected head of the Council Child Development Center, a combination clinic and nursery school where those 2 to 6 years old are helped with emotional problems.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, July 13 -- The mission headed by Walter S. Robertson, Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, is returning to the United States with sweeping con cessions won in writing from Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President, that official observers feel pave the way for the signing of an armistice agreement in the Korean war.

PARIS, July 12 -- One of the historic trouble areas of Europe -- the Saar and Alsace -- is the scene of an incipient television contest to influence viewers' minds. So far, the Germans seem to have the edge, and the French are far from pleased over a difficult international situation, one of many that may plague video in years ahead.
PARIS, July 12 -- Next Wednesday will be a new financial due date for France when $58,800,000 must be paid to cover the French deficit for June in the European Payments Union.

ZURICH, July 12 -- Since the German Bundestag on July 3 approved the London debt agreement of Aug. 8, 1952, talks have been going on continuously in accordance with a proviso of the agreement that "each debtor should prepare and submit to his creditor a detailed offer of the settlement," the aim being to fix the mode of carrying out the bargain when that agreement comes into force after approval by the American Senate.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- A visiting minister told a congregation that included President Eisenhower today that the world needed leaders "men who echo God, men who mirror his goodwill."

President Eisenhower's offer of $15,000,000 worth of food for East Germany has been rejected in Moscow and in East Berlin with the boorishness and inhumanity which we have been taught to expect from the troglodyte world. In Moscow Foreign Minister Molotov said the offer was "a propaganda maneuver.

AMSTERDAM, July 12 -- Sentiment on the Stock Exchange last week continued favorable although toward the week-end a moderate reaction set in. Foreign purchases which in the preceding weeks had helped to strengthen the market became less prominent and some domestic profit-taking occurred. The stock average rose from 154.12 to 153.12.
DALLAS, Tex., July 12 (UP) -- A mass of cool air brought drenching rains to Oklahoma today, but Texas was only teased by showers as the months-old southwestern drought lingered.

ELMIRA, N. Y., July 12 (AP) -- Parents and their children passed steadily through emergency clinics today as health authorities completed what is described as the greatest mass anti-polio inoculation two days ahead of schedule. When the last clinic closed late in the day, an official count put the number of children inoculated at 34,901.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- The National Planning Association said today there was an "urgent need" for new United States policies to offset the Soviet Union's manpower advantage.

LAST Tuesday 200 New York policemen raided ninety-five relay centers for informing gamblers on horse races or on the numbers of the policy racket. Cynical students of American folkways, remembering the results of earlier spasms of civic righteousness, will have their doubts about the permanent effects of such harassing action in which only small fry are troubled and "the big shots" remain unmolested.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 12 -- Victor Seixas won the invitation tournament at the Bath and Tennis Club for the third successive time today and the Clifford Hemphill Bowl passed into his permanent possession.

BOSTON, July 12 (AP) -- Right-hander Harry Byrd pitched the Athletics to a 4-1 victory over the Red Sox today after Catcher Del Wilber batted in six runs for Boston as Hector (Skinny) Brown won the opener of the doubleheader, 9 -- 5.
OAKLAND, Calif., July 12 (UP) The Transocean Air Lines office here listed the following passengers and crew members among those aboard the DC-6B reported missing between Guam and Hawaii:

Some men have always had a secret desire to highball along in the cab of a locomotive. Others have dreamed of giving orders from the bridge of a superliner -- or perhaps of handling the controls of a supersonic jet plane.

The Citizens Budget Commission puts its finger on a major city expense problem in the brief special memorandum made public this morning, dealing with pension costs for retired employes. It is a problem long recognized, but the only official action in recent years has made it worse rather than better.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $79,012,017,160. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 12 -- Representing 5,000,000 members of the Blue Army of Our Lady of Fatima in the United States, 500 delegates from various parts of the country attended the opening tonight of a five-day Fatima Congress program at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and the American Jewish Committee, two major American Jewish organizations, called yesterday for the immediate enforcement of the Quinn-Oliffe anti-discrimination law in admissions practices by medical schools within the state.

SALEM, Ore., July 12 (AP) -- A three-day revolt by 1,000 convicts at the Oregon State Prison ended tonight.
