Exhausted, hungry and thirsty after being held two days and one night in the prison recreation area without food and water, the prisoners agreed through a three-man convict committee to submit to an individual search and to return to their cells.

VIENNA, July 12 -- Arrears in delivery of farm produce by agricultural collectives and individual farmers have been canceled by a decree of the Hungarian Government, the Budapest radio announced this morning.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- The high-flying White Sox dealt the Indians a crushing blow today, beating them 14 -- 2 and 3 -- 1, before Comisky Park's top 1953 day crowd, 43,419.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 6 -- This continent's largest bird, the emu, which, with the kangaroo, appears on the Australian Commonwealth coat of arms, has been costing Western Australian farmers millions of pounds in loss of production in recent years.

Customs collections in this port last month aggregated $25,806,448, which represented an increase of 30 per cent over the same month of last year, Frank B. Laughlin, Acting Collector of Customs, reported yesterday.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 12 (AP) -- World production of tin dropped from 16,200 tons in March to 14,500 in April, the International Tin Study Group announced today.

Herbert Pell, former Democratic state chairman and ex-Minister to Portugal and Hungary, strikes a refreshing note in your letter columns of July 7. He undoubtedly expresses the position of millions of Americans when he urges that Communist and anti-Communist opinion "confront each other openly in the court of public opinion."

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., July 12--A clamor for termination of the Senate's investigation of last November's Senatorial election in New Mexico has arisen as a result of slow progress and inconclusive findings in a laborious recount of the ballots.

WILLOWS, Calif., July 12 -- A young man who has lived quietly here since childhood confessed early today, according to Sheriff Lyle G. Sale, that he deliberately set the Mendocino National forest blaze that trapped and killed fifteen firefighters in a canyon thirty miles west of this community on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Senator Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, predicted tonight that actual funds for foreign aid would be trimmed by perhaps as much as $1,000,000,000 below the $5,157,232,500 Mutual Security authorization that comes up for final approval this week in Congress.

The Soviet Union formally pulled out of the scheduled chess match with the United States last night because the State Department would not let the Russian players live at the country house of the Soviet United Nations delegation in Glen Cove, L. I.

More people are drawn to "the truth of God's love" by the good example of those who follow His commandments in their daily lives than by "stern precept" or long explanations of dogma and doctrine, the Rev. Harry J. Wolff said yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 12 -- Ferenc Nagy, former Premier of Hungary who was expelled by the Communists in 1947, said here tonight that there was an opportunity ahead for the Western powers to coexist peacefully with the Soviet Union.

NEW DELHI, India, July 12--The settlement of the issue of the property of refugees that affects millions of Indians and Pakistanis is likely to take precedence over the more delicate Kashmir dispute in the talks between Prime Ministers Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Mohammad Ali of Pakistan beginning in Karachi July 25.

Interest rates on short-term loans to business by large New York City banks moved up sharply during the second quarter, according to the Federal Reserve Bank here. Charges on loans made during the first fifteen days of June showed an average level of 3.45 per cent, as compared with 3.25 per cent in March.

Your recent editorial "T. V. A. vs. Socialism" does an admirable job of exposing the fallacy of the "creeping socialism" label recently hung on the Tennessee Valley Authority amid a nation-wide flare of publicity.

PITTSBURGH, July 12 -- The steel ingot rate is slipping but it is too early to tell whether or not the decline is really significant. Last week the rate was 95 per cent of capacity, up three points from the revised rate of 92 in the week before.

Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation has been authorized by the Public Service Commission to transfer $19,273,929 from depreciation reserves to earned and unearned surplus. The order was based on a finding that the utility, in compliance with prior orders of the commission, had made over-accruals for depreciation.

NOORDWIJK, the Netherlands, July 12 (UP) -- Enrique Morea of Argentina won the men's singles title in the Dutch international tennis championships today with a starting straight-set upset of Australia's Lewis Hoad, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.

LONDON, July 12 -- The stock markets are showing more signs of returning activity, spurred on by the sustained strength of the gilt-edged market, which has derived a new stimulus from the Government's latest conversion operation.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, July 9 -- The great Tanganyika peanut fiasco, which failed to produce peanuts and cost the British Overseas Foodstuffs Corporation and the British taxpayer $110,000,000, appears on the way to producing for Africa something of considerably greater importance than peanut-oil margarine.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 12 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh was reported tonight to be determined to take the quarrels between himself and the refractory Majlis (lower house of Parliament) to the people in a referendum.
TOKYO, Monday, July 13 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,674, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Monday, Korean time:

DETROIT, July 12 (UP) -- Johnny [Groth and Vic Wertz spoiled Ralph 'Branca's American League debut with first-inning homers that gave, 'the Browns a 3-to-2 victory over Detro'it 'in ttie second game of a double-header today after the Tigers had won the opener, 8--7.

ST. LOUIS, July 12 (AP) -- Ed Mathews sparked Milwaukee to a 17-hit, 10-1 first-game victory with a grand-slam home run, then the Braves nipped the Cardinals, 4 -- 3, to pick up half a game on the league-leading Brooklyn Dodgers today.

Robert G. McKeon, vice president of the Port Loaders Council, and Thomas Kane, delegate of Local 1757 of the loaders. defended loading on the port's piers yesterday as a "legitimate and essential business enterprise." They charged that the Dewey-Driscoll waterfront reform laws would deprive 2,000 men of jobs to eliminate a relatively few crooked workers.

STURBRIDGE, Mass., July 12 -- Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts will express formal acknowledgement tomorrow of his appointment as honorary chairman of the overseers of Old Sturbridge, Inc., a nonprofit educational trust that maintains an outdoor museum of nineteenth century New England craftsmanship.

The city's fire marshals, who work day and night to suppress the terrorism of arsonists, last year investigated more fires than in any year in the last decade, Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet said yesterday in his 1952 annual report submitted to Mayor Impellitteri.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 12 -- Three times this season victory in the International Class has eluded Bill Luders and his green-hulled sloop Surf. Today, however, the seasoned skipper, who sails out of Stamford, Conn., brought his craft home first to score over one of the year's biggest turnouts of Internationals.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (UP) The Phillies took a double-header from the Pirates by 6 -- 4 and 6 -- 5 scores today. The Pirates suffered their tenth straight loss and their fifteenth consecutive reverse in Connie Mack Stadium.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 12 (AP) -- Lebanese voters elected a collection of old faces to their new Parliament today. The pro-Western Nationalist Bloc made the strongest showing.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare, three months old yesterday, has been slow getting under way because of financial stringencies.

A general air of watchful waiting to see what the outcome of the European and Korean situations will be hung over the foreign exchange market during the past week. Trading was extremely light and price movements were limited.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- During the early part of last week there was a decided shift to the bull side of the wheat market, while there were upturns also in other grains and soybeans showed resistance to selling pressure. But late in the week there was a reversal of this friendly sentiment, most of the wheat gains being erased by a resumption of local selling, added to somewhat heavier hedging sales.

RANGOON, Burma, July 12 -- Nearly 200 Chinese Communist troops have penetrated twenty-five miles into Burmese territory and have established camps in the northern Wa States, a string of petty feudal principalities along the Burma-Yunnan border about fifty miles northeast of Lashio, wartime Allied capital, it was reported here today.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- William B. Bridgeman, test pilot who is said to have flown faster and higher than any other person, and Benjamin F. Greene Jr., electronics expert, were named winners of two top aviation awards today.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee has received a staff report that France is "constitutionally incapable" of balancing its budget and is substituting United States aid for taxes.
Five new films, including an import from England, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
UTICA, N. Y., July 12 (AP) -- Tommy Goodwin won his fourth state amateur golf championship today by dethroning the two-time titleholder, Billy Shields, 2 up.

Asserting that France is "an heir to classical reason and to Christianity's universal message, the Rev. Dr. Rene E. G. Vaillant, vicar of the French Protestant Episcopal Church of Saint Esprit, 109 East Sixtieth Street. underscored yesterday that nation's strong belief "in the superiority of God's loving gift of reason to man."

A view of Hitler, as he saw himself, is presented in "Hitler's Secret Conversations, 1941-1944," which Farrar, Straus Young will publish Aug. 25. The volume presents Hitler's views on his enemies, his friends, his ambitions, failures and secret dreams.

An educational and housing center will replace slums in the heart of downtown Brooklyn if the Board of Estimate approves a re- development plan made public yesterday by the City Committee on Slum Clearance, headed by Robert Moses.

For the first time in its long and cordial relations with the Republic of Switzerland, the United States will now be represented in the capital of that sturdy little nation by an Ambassador. This is the result of a recent agreement between the Swiss and American Governments raising our mission in Bern from the status of a legation to that of an embassy.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 12 -- George Hinman's yawl, Sagola, and Ed Raymond's little ketch, Chanteyman, were the chief winners of the twenty-second Riverside Yacht Club overnight race to Stratford Shoal, which ended off Flat Neck Point this afternoon and early tonight.

James T. Sherwin of New York City, representing the United States in the tournament for the junior chess championship of the world, was one of eight in a field of twenty who qualified for a place in the finals, according to a report received yesterday from Copenhagen.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford and Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway arrived here today for top-level briefing and conferences before joining the Administration's new military high command.

Billy Cox, the once forgotten man, and Roy Campanella were the gilt-edged heroes at Ebbets Field yesterday when the Dodgers snapped the Giants' winning streak at eight games with a ten-inning 4 -- 3 triumph that put Manager Chuck Dressen in a better mood for leading the National League team in tomorrow's All-Star contest at Cincinnati.

REHOBOTH BEACH, Del., July 12 -- Guy Farmer, who will interrupt his vacation here tomorrow for a trip to Washington to be sworn in as chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, wants the states to take on some of the labor-management problems that now go to the capital.

LUGANO, Switzerland, July 12 (UP) -- Mrs. Barbara Scofield Davidson of Milwaukee ignored the boos of the gallery to win the women's singles title today in the Swiss international tennis championships by defeating Josefa De Riba of Spain, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5.

NEWTON, N. J., July 12 -- An unidentified passing motorist saw flames shooting out of St. Paul's Benedictine Missionary Abbey today at 3:30 A. M. and aroused the occupants -- about forty persons, including monks, religious and men spending the week-end in retreat. The fire destroyed a dining room and exhibit hall.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., July 12 (UP) -- "Operation Tailwind," a tactical training operation for United States and Canadian air defense units, was marred today when two jet fighters collided in flight and two of the fliers were killed.

Back in 1921 George N. Peek and Hugh S. Johnson, both of them executives of the Moline Plow Company, of Moline, Ill., presented privately a plan for what we would perhaps call today "reflating" farm prices, then in the throes of the post-World War depression.
KOUVOLA, Finland, July 12 (AP) -- Mal Whitfield, the Olympic 800-meter champion, ran the fastest 1,000 meters ever turned in by an American in an international track and field meet tonight.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 12 (AP) -- Jay C. Jerome of Bennington won the Robert Todd Lincoln Memorial golf tournament today by a 6-and-4 margin over Charles Noyes of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., at the Ekwanok Country Club.

A new collection of drapery fabrics includes a group of pure silk hand-prints, brocades, gauzes and two weaves in Pimasilk, a combination of cotton and silk. The collection is at the United Silk Weavers, 1441 Broadway, and is available through decorators.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, expressed great satisfaction today with a new and tentative French military plan designed to regain the initiative and take the offensive against Communist forces in Indo-China.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The United States was pictured today as a nation whose natural resources were being drained at an alarming pace as the population spiraled upward at the rate of 300 persons an hour.

The "general agreement" that exists among Christian denominations is far more significant than the differences that separate them, the Rev. John M. Krumm, chaplain of Columbia University and head of its Department of Religion, said yesterday at evensong service in the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
SAVANNAH -- Hominy grits is as much a staple dish to Savannahans as oatmeal porridge to the people of Edinburgh.

HAUNTED houses are hard to come by in New York these days. The Mayor has one. One of the old Gracies is supposed to show up, late o'nights, in knee breeches, silver-buckled shoon and powdered wig, doing wingdings and rigadoons according to his mood.

In its first editorial comment on the fall of Lavrenti P. Beria, The Daily Worker today interprets the arrest of the Soviet Interior Minister and Deputy Premier as a defeat for the Eisenhower Administration's "liberation policies" and as a victory for the Soviet Union's peace offensive.

HALIFAX, N. S., July 12 (UP) -- Seven anglers who have proven their skill in many deep-sea contests were named today as members of the United States team for the tenth international Tuna-Cup match off Wedegeport, N. S., Sept. 9-11, the Nova Scotia Bureau of Information disclosed.
As a refresher for hot mid-summer days or an addition to an August vacation wardrobe, Patterns of The Times suggests three items.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The National Manpower Council today praised President Eisenhower's decision of yesterday to end draft deferments for new fathers.

An estimated 75,000 fez-wearing Shriners and their families swarmed into the city by train, airplane and auto yesterday for five days of fun-making at the organization's seventy-ninth convention, which opens today.

The automobile experts come up with two appropriate suggestions for summer car drivers, one suggestion to save the eyes and the other to save money -- and perhaps lives. They aptly point out that this is the time of year when all drivers should wear sun glasses while driving in the bright sun.

When the unwary investor flops open a large, meaty-looking book on the American chemical industry, he hardly expects to find himself involved in the cloth trade crisis of 1616 or Richard Trevithick's first steam engine for hauling cars, in 1803.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 12 -- Mayor Theodore Sander Jr. and the Village Board of Trustees voted today to retain experts and begin an exhaustive investigation into the building collapse Friday evening that cost three lives and injured ten other workmen in Scarsdale's "worst disaster."

Casey Stengel, never one to hesitate when he deems the time right for a change, made a number of switches yesterday at the Stadium. The skipper of the Yankees has enjoyed considerable good fortune with his strategic turns this season, but for a while against the Senators he seemed to be running out of luck.

BRUSSELS, July 12 (UP) -- A doubles victory by Marcello Del Bello and Gianni Cucelli gave Italy a 2-1 lead over Belgium today in a semi-final series in the European zone Davis Cup tennis eliminations.

HONOLULU, July 12--A Transocean Air Lines DC-6B with fifty-eight persons aboard was missing over the Pacific today and presumed to have crashed in the first trans-Pacific commercial air accident since World War II.

HONOLULU, July 12 (AP) -- The schooner Goodwill stretched its lead today as freshening breezes sent most of the thirty-two entries in the trans-Pacific yacht race ahead with a burst of speed in the ninth day since their take-off from California for Hawaii.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, July 12 -- The movement that wants an eventual interracial United States of Africa without restrictions and a federation of British East and British Central Africa first has scheduled a grand camp meeting at Mbeya for next January to lay the cornerstone of what they hope will be a new federal capital.

The New York City Transit Authority will meet at 9:30 A. M. today to fix a new fare for the publicly owned subway, elevated and surface lines amid strong indications that the rate may be set at 15 cents.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Spurred by President Eisenhower's words last night that the food offer to East Germany still stood, procurement officials of the Mutual Security Agency moved quickly today to get off the first shipload this week.

To paraphrase the title of the popular song "Doggie in the Window," the summer version too often is "Doggie at the Gate." It's not a pleasant tune to hear the mournful cries of devoted animals left behind by vacation-bound owners.

Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Church said last night on a television program here that attacks on Protestant clergymen that have linked some of them to Communist fronts were inspired by fear and greed.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- Celebration of the opening of one of the world's most modern marine terminals was marked by the landing of a helicopter at the heloport of the $8,250,000 Matson Terminal in Los Angeles Harbor, as a portent of the ultra modern operations planned at the terminal.

The five-story apartment buildings at 676 and 678 Wales Avenue, in th Bronx, accommodating sixty families, have been sold by the 680 .Wales Avenue Corporation, headed by Seymour IVi. Tannenbaum. to the Selaw Realty Corporation, subject to mortgages , amounting to $51,581 and purchase-money mortgages of $28,408. Title was insured by City Tit1 Insurance Company.

Evidence is mounting that the purge of Lavrenti P. Beria is in part a successful counter-revolution by Great Russian elements in the Soviet leadership against the more egalitarian nationalities policy pushed by Mr. Beria in the four months after Stalin's death.
CINCINNATI, July 12 (AP) -- The American League club owners haggled at length today over the possible transfer of the Browns' franchise and then said only that it would be "further studied."

These days find the railway stations filled with the sound of many feet shuffling. Not only in big terminals -- Grand Central and Pennsylvania -- but also in small stations set along tracks all over the country he who is waiting to take a train, or waiting to meet one, can spy, if he chooses, on dozens of little dramas.

The city has no hours immaculate, and even in the country the earliest hours of the day can be so described only by poetic license. But certainly Central Park, in the midst of the city, appears to better advantage as a rural oasis before the city folk for whom it was created, but are not given to early rising unless the job requires it, get around to making the open spaces seem less open.
LONDON, July 12 (AP) -- Britain's amateur sport czars today threw out of the record books the 4:02 mile run by Roger Bannister on June 27.
Alfredo Salmaggi opened his summer season of popular-priced grand opera at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island Saturday evening with a performance of "La Traviata."

HONOLULU, July 12 (AP) -- A great search was set up swiftly for the missing airliner. The Navy sent planes and ships over a watery strip thirty miles wide and 800 miles long in the path where the DC-6B vanished.
BISMARCK, N. D., July 12 (AP) -- Apparently enraged by a penny sales tax, a gun-toting hotel guest shot up a street and then killed a police chief who arrested him last night.

PELHAM, N. Y., July 12 -- Philip Handleman's 35-foot yawl Chee Chee IV tonight was adjudged the winner on the basis of corrected time of the annual New York Athletic Club Block Island race for sailing craft.

KAPUSKASING, Ont., July 12 -- For the first time since the war supply and demand in the newsprint industry have balanced, according to the statistics that the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association in Montreal has gathered.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 12 -- The Government's moves to suppress the small traditionalist Nation party, on the ground that it seeks to use religion to subvert Turkey's republican institutions, are meeting strong resistance from the accused group and have also been criticized by the People's Republican party, the principal political opposition.

Efforts to mediate the strike of ninety-four navigators against Trans World Airlines were complicated yesterday by the company's announced policy of discharging those who failed to report for their regularly scheduled flights.

FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., July 12 -- Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge, who throughout her many years has donated lavishly to music in America and has commissioned music from virtually every important modern composer, heard a performance of one of her own compositions this afternoon at the second concert of the summer series at Music Mountain.

The cotton futures market turned in last week its best performance in more than a month. Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange rallied at the start of the week and, despite some softening toward the week-end, the over-all net gains were substantial. Final prices showed net gains of 14 to 24 points, or 70 cents to $1.20 a bale.

CINCINNATI, July 12 (UP) -- The Redlegs swept their sixth double-header in seventeen tries by defeating the Cubs, 7 -- 4 and 7 -- 3, today behind the steady pitching of Harry Perkowski and Fred Baczewski, both left-handers.

The Israeli Judges Line will initiate a new direct, regular service between American ports on the Gulf of Mexico, by way of the Caribbean, and the Eastern Mediterranean, Brodie, Gray Co. said here yesterday.

The Lower East Side commercial properties at 98-100 Norfolk Street and 138 Delancey Street, consisting of a four-story building and a two-story building, have been acquired from Mary T. Horn by an investing client of Murray Gottesman. The buildings are occupied by Woolworth and by Rattner's Restaurant. Home Title Guaranty Company insured title.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- Vice presidents of the past have complained that they did not have enough to do but Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today he was a busy man.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 12 -- The Graduate School of Design of Harvard University announced new plans today for training architects, landscape architects and city planners. The changes, which will go into effect next fall, are intended to enrich training in the professional field and to shorten the period of study for the master's degree in architecture.

HONG KONG, July 12 -- The Peiping People's Daily, official organ of the Chinese Communist party, reacted today to the purging of Lavrenti P. Beria, a First Deputy Premier and Minister of Internal Affairs, from the post- Stalin Soviet triumvirate, with a lengthy editorial hailing the action as a "tremendous success" for the Soviet Union and the "toiling people of the world."
A Day Line sightseeing boat circling Manhattan Island with 191 passengers, many of them visiting Shriners. ran aground in Spuyten Duyvil near the northern tip of the island at 4:30 P. M. yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Jesse R. Wilson, Home Secretary of the American Baptist Foreign Mission Society, said yesterday that prison sentences recently meted out to four Baptist leaders in Czechoslovakia for alleged espionage "will not be taken seriously by anyone who knows the pattern ruthlessly followed by the Communists in situations of this kind."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 12 -- Royal Knight, owned by N. N. Coates' Volco Stable of Morristown. N. J., won the open jumper championship and Gen. and Mrs. Charles R. Lyman's Tanahmerah of West Chester. Pa., also a gray gelding, that for working hunters, as the annual New Brunswick horse show ended its two-day run today.
TOKYO, Monday, July 13--The Communists charged today that United Nations planes bombed and strafed a prisoner-of-war camp in North Korea Friday, killing five Allied captives and wounding fifteen.

LENOX, Mass., July 12 -- The sixteenth Berkshire Festival opened at Tanglewood this week-end. The first two concerts, which consisted of Bach programs played by a chamber orchestra in the theatre-concert hall, attracted 7,200 persons.
" Less investigation and more invigoration" were called for yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman in his sermon at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

The New York Red Cross Blood Program met its quota of forty-eight pints of type "O" blood in the Defense Department's emergency appeal for blood for the Far East without opening the city's blood centers for voluntary donations yesterday, the New York Chapter announced.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- The acting Senate Republican leader, Senator William F. Knowland, said today that only nations that had fought in Korea should be permitted to attend a conference to write a Korean peace treaty.

Optimism was expressed by Washington observers last April that something would be done to alleviate the 20 per cent Federal admission tax covering all branches of the amusement world. Yesterday's news stories from Washington indicated that the move had gained momentum with the object of repealing the levy.

LUDINGTON, Mich., July 12 (AP) -- Brisk southerly winds pushed a fifty-five craft fleet northward at a fast clip in Lake Michigan today as the annual Chicago Yacht Club race to Mackinac Island, Mich., neared its end.

CINCINNATI, July 12 (AP) -- A six-man Latin-American baseball delegation arrived today, determined to fight any proposals that would ban Latin-American major league players from participating in winter ball.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 12 -- An opera by Arnold Franchetti, "The Lion," composed for his 13-year-old daughter in 1950, received its first public performance here last evening at the tiny White Barn Theatre.

NOTHING is more annoying to the visiting angler who has flailed the surf with assorted lures for several hours than an encounter with a local expert engaged in landing a big striped bass on the beach.

The State of North Carolina announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Aug. 19 on $14,250,000 of permanent improvement general obligation bonds dated July 1, 1953, and maturing from July 1, 1958 to 1973.

LONDON, July 13 (AP) -- Delegates to the forty - four - nation International Sugar Conference agreed here today that there was grave danger of a world sugar glut unless consumption could be increased.

LONDON, July 13 -- Price movements were narrow and irregular on the stock market here today, with events in Egypt and tomorrow's ending of the current bookkeeping account the main factors in keeping business small.

NOVI SAD, Yugoslavia, July 13 -- The corn is high throughout Yugoslavia. That means, the experts say, that Yugoslavia, which has suffered terrible droughts since the war and last year had to appeal to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization for special aid, will have a bumper crop this year.

The fate of the Administration's proposal to admit 240,000 special-quota immigrants to the United States during the next two years was still in doubt yesterday. The Senate Judiciary Committee couldn't agree, though Senator Watkins told reporters, after a closed session, that the "outright opposition" that formerly existed in that group had disappeared.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A Republican-led effort to block action on the Eisenhower Administration's proposal for a $240,500,000 increase in postal rates to reduce further the Post Office Department deficit failed in committee today in the House of Representatives by the margin of a single vote.

Private financing negotiations involving the placement of $6,935,000 of first mortgage bonds have been completed in behalf of Kaneb Pipe Line Company and Augusta Pipe Line Company, according to announcement yesterday by Glore, Forgan Co., investment bankers.
GLEN COVE, L. I., July 13 -- Thaddeus (Bud) Sweet, a commercial artist, is telling a whopping fish story today. What makes the story so odd is that he can prove it.

CINCINNATI, July 13 -- When the National and American League All-Star teams meet at Crosley Field tomorrow, every manager with a memory of other such classics will have his fingers crossed, hoping that the injury jinx will not hit his man or men.
LOS ANGELES, July 13 -- Five flags fluttered to the top of staffs on this city's new Ocean Terminal today to mark the dedication of the $8,250,000 structure.

JERSEY CITY, July 13 -- The Hudson County Board of Freeholders went over the head of County Supervisor Bernard M. Hartnett today and readopted six resolutions that he had vetoed and nine more that he had returned to them unsigned last week.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 13 -- Diplomatic representatives from Great Britain and the Netherlands pleaded here today for liberalization of United States import restrictions. They said trade shipments to the United States offered the only means by which European nations could close their dollar gap and enter upon a genuine program of "trade, not aid."

A 15-cent fare will be charged on the entire city-owned transit system beginning at 12:01 A. M., July 25, the New York City Transit Authority announced yesterday. Action to increase the fare was the major step in the authority's effort to end years of deficit operation of the municipal subway, elevated and surface lines.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, announced today that his Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations had unearthed a $150,000 "shakedown" of a friendly Government by employes of "the old Acheson State Department."

Spencer J. Drayton, executive secretary of Thoroughbred Racing Associations, yesterday branded as discriminatory Senate Bill 2314 which, he said, "would practically eliminate pre-race news from the sports pages."

DUESSELDORF, Germany, July 13 (AP) -- American track and field stars stole the show at an international track meet before 12,000 spectators tonight by winning eleven of the twelve contests they entered.

Beatrice Martin is the champion of the small hat. In showing her fall millinery yesterday at the Plaza Hotel, she stood fast by the brief curving coif and little pillbox that are flattering to and favored by so many women.

Five devotees of a faith that has neither clergy nor ritual, yet subscribes to the basic tenets of all religions, were in New York yesterday en route to a world Baha'i conference in Stockholm, Sweden.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 13 -- Dispatches from Bandung, the capital of strife torn West Java, reported today that several thousand persons demonstrated before Gov. Sanusi Hardadinata's office demanding protection from marauding Darul Islam guerrilla bands.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Judy 13 -- Rita Hayworth will impersonate Valentina in a new film project of that name announced for fall filming. The star's own company, Beckworth Productions, will produce the story for release by Columbia.

NEWARK, July 13 -- Leonard Dreyfuss, New Jersey Civilian Defense Director, presented to Mayor Leo P. Carlin in City Hall here today a Federal Government check for $60,000 as a contribution toward the $140,280 cost of nine fire engines.

International efforts still were being made yesterday to arrange a chess match between American and Russian teams for this weekend. The Associated Press reported meanwhile from Paris that the Russian team had left Paris to return to Moscow, according to a Soviet Embassy spokesman.

After working forty-five years as a laborer in the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, and being recommended for retirement, Nicholas Lana, 76 years old, was summarily dismissed by the Civil Service Commission after an anonymous letter had been received saying he was working under an assumed name.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 13 -- Joe Gagliardi of Winged Foot, the 1951 champion, headed seventy-eight contenders from the Westchester district in sectional qualifying for next week's metropolitan amateur golf championship, taking the medal with a 5-under-par round of 35, 32 -- 67 at Wykagyl today.

" It is amazing that the President of the United States and eminent members of the Conference of Christians and Jews would object to and try to censor the freedom of expression of a citizen of the United States," Col. Archibald B. Roosevelt, only surviving son of President Theodore Roosevelt stated yesterday in a letter to Representative Harold H. Velde of Illinois, chairman of the Un-American Activities of the House of Representatives.

Peter Pan Foundations is campaigning not only for the favor of the college and high school girl but also for that of her teachers. In announcing plans for a heavy fall back-to-school magazine campaign the manufacturers of brassieres and other form-molding garments says, "the high school and college girl will be reached."

The resignation of Dudley Roberts Jr. and Thomas L. Perkins as president and vice president, respectively, of Cinerama Productions, was announced yesterday. They will be succeeded by Lowell Thomas, as president, and Theodore Kupferman, as executive vice president.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 13 -- The newest weapons in the housewife's battle against dirt, lack of time and shortage of space were unveiled here today at the National Housewares Exhibit in Convention Hall. Seven thousand buyers from the nation's department stores inspected the displays of 554 manufacturers.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 13 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan said today at the first joint meeting of both Houses of Parliament called in seventeen years that amendments to the Constitution would be offered tomorrow to purge the national voting register -- which contains 1,600,000 names -- of 46,000 names of Colored (people of mixed blood).
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Senate ratified by a voice vote today a three-year extension of the 1949 International Wheat Agreement.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- An official of the Congress of Industrial Organizations asserted today that the failure to build up the country's merchant marine "can mean only that those responsible are working against the interest of the United States."

Volume was generally higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges, with soybean oil registering the greatest activity since May 7, rubber since June 24 and potatoes since July 1. Most prices were down. Soybean oil, potatoes, rubber, hides, copper, lead, tin and zinc ended lower; coffee and cocoa, higher, and sugar, cottonseed oil and wool, mixed.

GENEVA, July 13 -- President Eisenhower's rejected offer of food and medical supplies for East Germany already has proved useful to the United States spokesmen faced with the necessity of answering the constant barrage of Soviet propaganda directed at the United States role in world affairs.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -The Eisenhower Administration chalked up an intermediate victory today as the House of Representatives Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration approved a bill to admit 247,000 victims of economic and political upheavals abroad to this country in the next two and one-half years.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- As Adlai E. Stevenson draws near home to complete his world-girdling journey his host of supporters for Democratic re-nomination in 1956 can point to an impressive record thus far of thoughtful and penetrating accounts of global conditions that the best reporters could envy.

Bastille Day, July 14, is celebrated in France and by the friends of France in the same spirit that we celebrate our own Independence Day. Commemorating the fall of the Bastille, infamous Paris prison, in 1789, it symbolizes the revolt against tyranny, the dedication to liberty and to the worth of the individual that have been so conspicuous in France's cultural contribution to the rest of the world during these past 164 years.

An international tour that would take "Porgy and Bess," which is at the Ziegfeld Theatre, to Japan and Australia next year is being considered by sponsors of the folk opera. Although the end of its local run is not yet in sight, inquiries about a tour also have been received from theatre interests in France, Italy, the Scandinavian countries, the Netherlands, Belgium and Switzerland.
LOS ANGELES, July 13 -- The Los Angeles Board of Education today canceled the Ford Foundation teacher-training experiment, which was to have begun next Monday at three universities here.

New casement and drapery fabrics by Jack Lenor Larsen, although woven on a power loom, are distinguished by a hand-woven look. The weaves are derived from ones in a hand-woven collection by this designer. Interesting textures and an unusual combination of yarns are represented in the group, which is available through decorators from the Larsen Studio at 38 East Fifty-seventh Street.

NEWARK, July 13 -- Anthony De Palma, 43-year-old button polisher with Tonks Brothers Company, Inc., was awfully glad when people started showing up in the button factory building at 1197 McCarter Highway this morning. Mr. De Palma had spent the week-end at the bottom of an elevator shaft.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Treasury accepted orders today for $5,900,636,000 of its 2 1/2 per cent issue of tax anticipation certificates offered for sale last Monday. Subscription offers were $8,686,806,000 for the eight-month securities, and the Treasury said its acceptance of about two-thirds of this amount made the issue its largest borrowing since World War II.

The Mathieson Chemical Corporation announced yesterday completion at Lake Charles, La., of the first large-scale plant in this country to make hydrazine. This is the chemical brought out of obscurity by the Germans in World War II for use as a rocket fuel.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 13 -- Dr. Sam Anziano and Chet Munson of the home club clipped eight strokes from par with 31, 33 -- 64 to win the Group I prize in the Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro tourney at the Wheatley Hills golf clug today.

GENEVA, July 13 -- The exchange of manufactured goods and primary products among nations is lagging considerably behind the production of such goods, the Secretariat of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade reported in a comprehensive review of world trade published here today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 13 -- Palmer Hoyt, publisher of The Denver Post, told a group of educators meeting today at Harvard University that "McCarthyism" was probably the most specific cause of unrest within education.

TRENTON, July 13 -- New Jersey claimants for unemployment insurance were told today that when they reported to a State Employment Service office they should be dressed as if they were going to employers for work. Thus, shorts, play and bathing suits or other extreme sports attire for the women and extreme sports wear for the men were not advised.
ISMAILIA, Egypt, July 13 -British soldiers clamped an iron ring of armored cars and machine guns around this strategic Suez Canal Zone town today to force the return of a missing soldier.

Two five-story buildings each containing seventeen apartments at 285-291 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, have been sold by the Pay Day Realty Corporation, of which Benjamin L. Levine is president, to Sam and Anna Goldfarb for cash above a mortgage of $98,280. The Crown Heights Realty Company was the broker and the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company insured title. The property, on a plot 95 by 131 feet, is assessed at $107,000.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission received a proposal today for settling an application of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company for a yearly $17,850,000 increase in natural gas rates to its wholesale customers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14 -- Fifteen Asian and African members of the United Nations asked formally today that their charges of French misrule in North Africa be placed on the agenda of the fall meeting of the General Assembly.

Quick Lunch gobbled up the Wakefield Stakes, the feature race of the Empire City Racing Association's opening day's activity at Jamaica yesterday. Given a front-running ride by Nick Wall, the top-weighted Wheatley Stable colt took the $12,350 event with ease, beating C. T. Chenery's Permian by more than two lengths in the six-furlong sprint for 2-year-olds.

Celery is available here the year 'round, but this is the beginning of the season when it is a particularly worthwhile purchase. From now through next month shipments from Orange County and northern New Jersey are heaviest, and the stalks, because they travel such a short distance to market, are at the peak of crisp freshness.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The White House said today that the accumulation of food supplies for East Germany already had started, and the Mutual Security Agency gave some of the details.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 13 -- Westchester District Attorney Samuel Faile questioned five witnesses today in an effort to determine responsibility for the building collapse that wrecked one-quarter of a four-story office building under construction, killing three workmen and injuring ten, at the corner of Popham Road and Overhill Road in the heart of Scarsdale Friday evening.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Top Administration officials asked Congress today for a new Small Business Administration to replace lending operations of both the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Small Defense Plants Administration.

The first combined fall showing by wash dress manufacturers will draw over 1,000 buyers before closing tonight, M. J. Lovell, director-counsel of the House Dress Institute, predicted yesterday. The exhibit, which opened on Sunday in the Statler Hotel, is presenting fall styles of twenty-five members of the institute.

TRENTON, July 13 -- The St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church of Newark was directed by the Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court today to close down its operation of a weekly skilo game that nets the church $1,000 a week.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Alied Commander in Europe, declared here today, on his arrival from Paris, there had been "no fantastic change" in Soviet policy toward satellite nations in Europe, but said the recent uprisings proved the Soviet had only a precarious hold on its captive countries.

The Department of Defense has asked the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program for more whole blood for direct shipment to Korea tomorrow and Thursday. Dr. William M. Markel, program administrator, urged New Yorkers yesterday to visit the donor centers today, tomorrow and Thursday so the latest request could be filled.

CINCINNATI, July 13 -- Frank Scott, former road secretary of the Yankees and now a players' agent, announced today that the Eddie Lopat All-Stars will leave shortly after the world series for a Pacific tour.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A high British source indicated today that the Western Big Three Foreign Ministers were thinking about a conference with the new Soviet leader in the autumn to explore at least the possibilities of reducing world tension.

One of the great dramas of international diplomacy is to be commemorated today by the appearance of a new 5-cent stamp, marking the centennial of Commodore Perry's successful delivery of official messages from the United States to the Emperor of Japan.

CINCINNATI, July 13 -- On the eve of the All-Star game, club owners of both major leagues listened to complaints of the players today, weighed the merits of the players' suggestions and tossed in a few of their own. When the smoke had cleared from the two conference rooms, no one was certain about anything.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- In a blunt speech that appeared to take his colleagues by surprise, Senator A. S. Mike Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma, challenged the Senate today to assume full responsibility for the acts of its investigating panels.

PARIS, July 4 -- James McNeill Whistler's famous portrait of his mother has been lent by the Louvre Museum to the Franco-American Museum at Blerancourt, in the Aisne department of France, where it will be on exhibition throughout the summer.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 13 -- A power failure cut off electricity last night from tens of thousands of coastal homes and industries as well as from an iron lung, which was pumped by hand for two hours to save the life of a young polio victim.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Dr. Henry M. Kessler of Newark, an international authority on rehabilitation, told the twenty-seventh annual convention of the American Association of Workers for the Blind today that this country's rehabilitation efforts were helping overseas against a surge of anti-American feeling in Europe and Asia.

A carnival-like spirit enveloped the midtown area yesterday as 100,000 merry-making Shriners opened their seventy-ninth convention and prepared to stage a 25,000-man parade on Fifth Avenue this morning with oriental-type pageantry.
Operations of the Industrial Rayon Corporation for the first half of this year resulted in a net income of $4,303,574 after providing $5,480,000 for taxes, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July l3 -- Guy Farmer, 41-year-old Washington lawyer, took the oath as Chairman of the National Labor Relations Board today. He told the staff and a group of labor and management lawyers that he came without an axe to wield or to grind.

Twenty-two charitable institutions will receive $72,000 under the will of William G. Benedikt, 85-year-old retired department store executive. The will was filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mr. Benedikt, who lived at 200 West Seventieth Street, died July 4.

LOS ANGELES, July 13 -- Southern California's $250,000,000 furniture industry today produced its newest designs, fabrics and decorations at the opening of the annual Los Angeles summer furniture market at the Furniture Mart and Shrine Convention Hall.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Wilbur A. Dexheimer of Denver was sworn in today as Commissioner of the Bureau of Reclamation shortly after his appointment had been announced by President Eisenhower.

The Korean opposition to the present truce terms seems to be generally attributed to President Rhee of Korea. Such is not the case. The National Assembly supports his position by unanimous vote, as do the Korean people as a whole.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Japanese diplomatic representatives will join United States officials tomorrow in ceremonies marking the 100th anniversary of the opening of Japan to commerce with the Western world.
Tapping "a reservoir of 476 years" of experience in traffic problems, a five-day conference was opened at New York University yesterday with a view to coordinating traffic programs.

Sales of men's straw and other summer hats in 1954 should be the highest in many years, approaching $50,000,000 at retail, James B. Lee, president of the Frank H. Lee Company, Danbury, Conn., said yesterday at the company's 1954 straw hat sales meeting at the Park Lane Hotel.

The three-story twelve-family house at 149 Beach Sixty-eighth Street in Arverne, Queens, has been sold by Samuel and Sonia Kahan to Mary Kesslin. Herman Robbins was the broker and title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.
LONDON, July 13 -- Members of the House of Commons applauded today when they were told of the measures taken by the British military authorities in the Suez Canal Zone.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The United States Court of Claims decided today that the Federal Government and the Central Railroad of New Jersey should share the responsibility for damage claims arising out of accidents at a grade crossing constructed during the war for the convenience of the Army Air Force.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Senate does not expect to be called on this year to ratify a mutual security pact with South Korea and thus assumes that the scheduled adjournment of Congress at the end of this month will not be disturbed.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Administration's disaster loan and special livestock credit legislation to provide aid to drought-stricken farmers and ranchers in the South-west was passed by Congress today and sent to the White House for President Eisenhower's signature.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, said today that all Army procurement plans were being studied to see what "readjustments" were needed in addition to the new $480,000,000 cutback in tank and truck production.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 13 -- A five-year lease for supplying, maintaining and servicing seventy-five two-way radios for the Nassau County Department of Public Works was awarded this morning to the New York Telephone Company by the County Board of Supervisors.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 13 -- Although unsuccessful a year ago when the tournament was held on her home course, Shirley Ann Smith of Binghampton, a 24-year-old Cornell graduate, captured the qualifying medal in the women's New York State golf championship today.
BRUSSELS, July 13 (AP) -- With Jackie Brichant scoring the decisive victory, Belgium upset Italy, 3 -- 2, today to gain the final round of the European zone Davis Cup tennis tournament.

ALBANY, July 13 -- A former Communist courier and labor organizer from Canada told a House subcommittee on Un-American Activities here today that Soviet agents had promoted a seven-month maritime strike in 1949 in an effort to cripple the Marshall Plan.

NORFOLK, Va., July 13 (AP) -- A Navy seaplane crashed in the ocean today while engaged in antisubmarine training exercises, killing three of its crew. Four crewmen survived the crash and four others were missing late tonight.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 13 (AP) -- Casanova, owned by Craig's Cimarroon Ranch of LeMoore, Calif., put on a stretch drive to defeat pace-setting Taylor Direct by a length tonight in the Sag Harbor Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

The concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium entered their fourth week last night with a program conducted by Pierre Monteux, with Stell Andersen as the piano soloist. In many ways it was an evening of exceptional distinction, but, alas, for the cause of good music, it drew only 2,000 persons.
SYRACUSE, July 13 -- Educational television will fail if educators permit Hollywood and Broadway to dominate the production of education programs, a Syracuse University lecturer said today.

STRATFORD, Ont., July 13 -- Although this Stratford has an Avon River and a bust of Shakespeare in a park, it has never had a professional theatre. It is a railroad shop city with a few small industries and a population of 18,000.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 14 (AP) -- United Nation Command communique 1,675, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

MIAMI, July 13 (AP) -- Hialeah announced today its schedule of stakes races for the coming winter horse racing season, topped by the $100,000 added Widener Handicap and the $100,000 added Flamingo for 3-year-olds.
I have been handed a copy of an editorial entitled "Migratory Labor Bill," published in your paper under date of July 2.

Plans have been furthered at recent meetings for a benefit performance by the Sadler's Wells Ballet Company on the night of Sept. 22 at the Metropolitan Opera House to augment the Scholarship Fund of the Institute of World Affairs. Mrs. Thomas J. Watson heads the benefit committee, and among her aides is Mrs. Walter S. Fischer.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Robert Douglas Coe, former career diplomat, has been picked by the White House to the new United States Ambassador to Denmark, informed officials reported today.

The annual outing of the New York Police Anchor Club, held yesterday at Palisades Amusement Park, atop the Palisades across from 125th Street, provided 8,500 underprivileged children and Mayor Impellitteri with a joyous day. The club is a Knights of Columbus group in the Police Department.
As refreshing to look at on a hot day as a summer landscape are the settings that make up the group of seven newly redecorated model rooms that go on view today at Bloomingdale's.
J. C. Merwin has been elected chairman of the board of the Chain Belt Company, and L. B. McKnight has been elected president and chief executive officer.

ROME, July 13 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi was putting the final touches tonight on his eighth consecutive cabinet which he will submit to President Luigi Einaudi tomorrow. The cabinet, composed exclusively of Christian Democrats, will be sworn in immediately afterwards or at the latest on Wednesday.

SEOUL, Korea, July 13 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President, emphasized in a statement today that his discussions last week with Walter S. Robertson, Assistant United States Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, had not weakened his determination to seek a free and unified Korea.

CINCINNATI, July 13 -- The power of the home run, a commodity to which the American League long believed itself holding a prior right, was again seen the deciding factor as battle lines were being drawn tonight for the twentieth annual All-Star game that will be played tomorrow at 1:30 P. M. (2:39 P. M. Hew York Time) on Crosley Field.

In a news story published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 6, captioned "79 Harlem Children Left for Interracial Vacation," which reported in the first paragraph that "Seventy-nine Negro children from New York slums left city streets behind * * *" has been construed as implying that "Harlem" and "slums" are synonymous.

Steel operations, which usually decline in July because of hot weather and vacations, are still running somewhat below capacity, but the rate last week showed a gain above the preceding' period and a further advance is scheduled for this week.

Mike Green of Miami Beach, first-seeded in the junior division of the Eastern junior and boys tennis championships, led a quartet of competitors into the third round as competition began yesterday at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

The patient efforts of crew members of the Holland-America liner Ryndam to keep alive a wounded sparrow hawk that dropped exhausted to the ship's deck last Tuesday off the English coast ended in failure and burial at sea for the tough and aggressive little bird.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today there was "tentative thinking" here that Japan ultimately should have a security force of about 350,000 men or the equivalent of about ten divisions.

Seventeen college basketball dates have been booked at Madison Square Garden for the 1953-54 campaign. This was announced yesterday as plans for the twentieth consecutive season of the collegiate game at the Eighth Avenue arena were completed.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Senate-House conferees agreed late today on a 62,000,000-acre United States wheat crop for 1954. This compromise was close to the Senate bill's 61,000,000 limit. The House had voted for 66,000,000.

The Pacific rate war, which has ensued since the member companies of two shipping conferences carrying cargoes from Japan to this country opened their tariffs March 12 and plunged rates as low as 70 per cent below normal, may come to an end this week.

Employer groups of the Building Trades Employers Association reached agreements yesterday providing for wage increases for 3,000 hoisting engineers and 5,000 cement and concrete workers, the association announced.

Thomas A. Carroll, removed Saturday on President Eisenhower's order as United States Marshal for the Southern District of New York, clung tenaciously to his "job" yesterday in the absence of official word from Washington.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- An oil company official testified today that prices of gasoline to consumers were more reasonable than those of most other commodities.

James Bruce, former United States Ambassador to Argentina, has just completed his book about that country, which Longmans, Green will issue in September under the title "Those Perplexing Argentines." With anecdotes and thumb-nail sketches, Mr. Bruce gives a picture of the temperament and temper of the people, as well as a glimpse at what they are "likely to mean to our future."

It seems regrettable to me that Norman Thomas in his recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES should join the critics of Einstein's recent suggestion that American intellectuals should refuse to testify before certain types of Congressional investigating committees, and much more regrettable that he should come close to giving a clean bill of health to the McCarthy, Jenner and Velde investigations.

CINCINNATI, July 13 -- Perhaps the most dramatic of All-Star episodes came in 1934 when Carl Hubbell of the Giants fanned in succession Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Jimmy Foxx, Al Simmons and Joe Cronin. The best of these doughty batters was Foxx. Double-X nicked Hub for a foul.

CINCINNATI, July 13 (AP) -- Del Webb, co-owner of the Yankees, suggested today that the welfare of the American League could best be safeguarded by the transfer of the Browns and Athletics to such California cities as Los Angeles and San Francisco.

The Restaurant League of New York, representing 125 of the city's better-known restaurants, announced last night the intention of its members to lay off 1,000 waiters today as a result of scattered strikes yesterday against various restaurants.
Soviet generals have become a key factor in the struggle for power in the Soviet Union.
The announcement by the New York City Transit Authority of the 15-cent transit fare, read by Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, authority chairman, after the meeting of the board yesterday, follows:
A 25-year-old private in the Jordan Army will leave for Boston this morning on the last lap of a journey of nearly 7,000 miles in search of medical care.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 14 -- The Communists charged the United Nations Command today with violating the neutrality of the demilitarized circle at Panmunjom, asserting that an artillery shell landed Sunday night inside the area where the truce delegations meet.

The New York City Transit Authority has taken the cold plunge and raised the fare to 15 cents, effective July 25. It thus obeys, and on schedule, the mandate of the Legislature that operations be in black ink, and also allows for a small surplus of about $9,000,000 against the unforeseen.

Stock prices yesterday had the widest one-day net loss since May 9 and slipped to the lowest level since June 22. The decline was generally ascribed in Wall Street to Korean truce prospects, for the aircrafts, motors, steels and other "war babies" were under pressure almost from the opening gong.

PARIS, July 13 -- The critical comments on the French use of United States aid that were made in a staff report to the Senate Appropriations Committee and published yesterday strike experts here as one-sided and unfair.

MUNICH, Germany, July 13 (AP) -- Georg Solti, a German conductor, refused a United States visa because of alleged membership in a Communist organization, received a clean bill of health from the West German Government today.

GARNETT, Kan., July 13 (AP) -- Scientists have unearthed fossils that may prove to be the the granddaddy of all reptiles. Four complete skeletons, two with skulls, were found in a pasture- near here. They go by the scientific name of Petrolacosaurus Kansensis, but are commonly known as rock lake lizards.
LONDON, July 13 -- For the second time since the general strike of 1926, Britain will import coal this winter.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 13 -- Two fliers pleaded guilty in Federal Court at Duluth, Minn., today to fourteen Government charges of contempt of court, growing out of their flights into areas of the Superior National Forest, banned to aviation by a Minneapolis Federal court order of Sept. 30, 1952.

The Liberal party's city-wide ticket, headed by City Council President Rudolph Halley for Mayor, was completed last night with the designation of Justice Juvenal Marchisio of the Domestic Relations Court for President of the City Council, and Chase Mellen Jr., former Republican chairman of New York County, for City Controller.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Congress passed and sent to the White House today a compromise Mutual Security bill authorizing $5,157,232,500 for military, economic and technical foreign aid in this fiscal year. The measure attached stout strings to more than $1,000,000,000 of military aid funds for Western Europe.

SEATTLE, July 13 (AP) -- The National Public Links champion, Omer L. (Pete) Bogan of Montebello, Calif., almost lost his crown on technicalities today, but managed to survive both a tough opponent and the book of rules for a 1-up victory over Leroy Parrish of Ontario, Ore.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. will make a public offering today of 120,000 shares of common stock of Mechanical Handling Systems, Inc., manufacturer of conveyors and specialized trailers. The stock is priced at $7 per share.
HONOLULU, July 13 -- A Navy transport today was picking up bodies from the waters east of Wake Island where a huge airliner plunged into the Pacific Saturday night with fifty-eight aboard.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, said today he would give the Senate a chance to vote on raising exemptions to $100,000 when it considered a House-approved bill to extend the excess profits tax to Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today dentified ninety-one Korean war casualities. Of the total, sixteen are dead, sixty-seven wounded and eight injured in battle zone accidents. The casualities from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut follow:

CAMDEN, N. J., July 13 -- Medal of Honor, awarded posthumously to Hospital Corpsman Edward C. Benfold, will be presented to his 14-months-old son at the Philadelphia Naval Base on Thursday by Rear Admiral John H. Brown, commandant of the Fourth Naval District.
Futures turned quiet on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were off 25 points from-Friday's closing levels on old July and 1 to 3 points on other months.

Christache Zambeti, the Rumanian diplomat who was expelled from the United States last May for attempting to blackmail a naturalized American, Valeriu C. Georgescu, into spying here for the Communist regime, was a member of the Rumanian secret police who had been ousted several years ago from Turkey for the same reason, Mr. Georgescu reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- James B. Bowler, 78-year-old Chicago Democrat, today succeeded the late dean of the House, Representative Adolph Sabath, as a member of Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Indo-Chinese Associated States of the French Union received new assurances today of French intentions to push as quickly as possible a transfer of political powers to their respective Governments.
LONDON, July 13 (AP) -- The sudden transfer abroad of a friend of Princess Margaret, group Capt. Peter Townsend of the Royal Air Force, was questionel today in the House of Commons.

Ugo Carusi, former United States Immigration Commissioner and Commissioner for Displaced Persons, has been chosen for a high administrative position in the newly integrated refugee program of the Eisenhower Administration.
DAVIS, Calif., July 13 (AP) -- Brokers Tip, winner of the 1933 Kentucky Derby, is dead at the University of California agriculture campus here.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 13 -- Foreign diplomatic observers here said today the results of parliamentary elections in Central Labanon Sunday indicated a victory for moderate and basically Western-oriented forces over appeals of demagoguery and anti - foreign sentiment.

BONN, Germany, July 13 (AP) -- Former Col. Gen. Nikolaus von Falkenhorst, 68, once sentenced to be hanged for the execution of British commandos, was set free today from the British war crimes prison at Werl.

Action by the Bureau of the Census to restrict access to copies of export declarations was hailed yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York as a step relieving American exporters of the burden of furnishing authenticated copies under some foreign countries' regulations.
D. J. Eyer Jr. has been appointed city manager in New York City for Plymouth Motor Corporation, a subsidiary of Chrysler Corporation, and Kenneth R. Porter has been named merchandising manager.

A law transferring jurisdiction over the problem of communism in labor unions to an agency independent of the National Labor Relations Board was recommended yesterday in a majority report of the committee on labor and social security legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
CHICAGO, July 13 -- Bearish crop figures announced in the official July crop report caused a general slump in prices for all grain and soybean futures.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 14 -- More than 60,000 Chinese Communist troops buckled South Korean defenses at both ends of a twenty-five-mile-wide sector on the central front today, hurling the Allied defense line back as much as two miles in the biggest enemy offensive in two years.

RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 13 (UP) -- Art Larsen, the defending champion, won first and second-round victories, one easily and the other by coming from behind, at the national clay court tennis tournament today.

The visit to this country of a group of high-ranking German officials who will be responsible for West Germany's military contribution to the European Defense Community was, we hope, an informative one. The creation of a European Army in which Germany is to play an essential but not predominant role is a cardinal point of American foreign policy, as it is of Chancellor Adenauer's.

Action by the Bureau of the Census to restrict access to copies of export declarations was hailed yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York as a step relieving American exporters of the burden of furnishing authenticated copies under some foreign countries' regulations.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Permission to launch a securities issue involving $420,000,000, one of the largest sums sought in the market in years, was asked of the Securities and Exchange Commission today by the Ohio Valley Electric Corporation of Columbus and its subsidiary, the Indiana-Kentucky Electric Corporation of Indianapolis.

The concerted efforts of industry to eliminate overtime pay in order to reduce production costs will have an adverse effect on installment credit payments, according to Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men.

The long-vexing problem of how an advertising agency can get credit for an advertisement of which it is proud has been solved in one way by McKee Albright, Inc., Philadelphia agency. The agency pays the publication for the recognition.
MOSCOW, July 14 -- The Supreme Soviet, top legislative assembly, has been summoned to convene in Moscow July 28, it was announced today.
LONDON, July 14 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, will return to London from the United States July 26, according to provisional arrangements announced by the Foreign Office today.
CINCINNATI, July 14 -- Peewee Reese, the Dodger captain, who had not made a hit in seven previous All-Star games, henceforth is going to be a firm adherent of the "Good Neighbor Policy."

LONG BEACH, Calif., July 14 (AP) -- An aircraft executive says he is going to court to seek a "fair and just profit" for a sixty-seven-day job of retrieving a wrecked government helicopter from a snowy mountain.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Representative Robert L. Condon, Democrat of California, charged today the Atomic Energy Commission "did not fairly evaluate the information" concerning him when it barred him from the May 5 atomic test at Yucca Flat, Nev.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- William Jay Hoff, formerly of New York, was named general counsel of the National Science Foundation today, succeeding William A. W. Krebs Jr.

DECATUR, Ill., July 14 (AP) -- Federal, state and Macon County officials prepared today for the inoculation of thousands of children under 10 years of age in a fight against a possible polio epidemic.

Eric Linklater, a prolific novelist and at times a playwright, too, will be represented on Broadway around the turn of the year. But not by his own script. It will be a thriller based on his 1951 novel, "Mr. Byculla," a macabre comedy that was adapted by Jo Eisinger.

Activity on the New York commodity exchanges continued to increase yesterday. Copper showed the largest volume since June 1, cocoa since June 2 and hides since June 19. Only tin, in which there were no sales, ended lower. Copper, coffee, sugar, wool, potatoes, lead and zinc were mixed, and hides, cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and rubber closed higher.

The second mishap in three days to a Manhattan Island sightseeing boat occurred late yesterday afternoon when the 160-foot excursion boat Normandie struck a pillar of the 225th Street Bridge at Broadway and the Harlem River. Her 169 passengers were shaken up, but no one was injured seriously.

The Rev. John M. Corridan, associate director of the Xavier School of Industrial Relations, 30 West Sixteenth Street, known as the "waterfront priest," predicted yesterday that "combinations of corrupt union officials, corrupt politicians, and mobsters" were not going to give up their lucrative waterfront empires without a fight.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Experience in New York and New Jersey in dealing with the growing problem of blindness among infants of premature birth was described today at the twenty-seventh annual convention of the American Association of Workers for the Blind as a possible basis for a country-wide program of help to blind babies and their parents.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The text of the Western Big Three foreign ministers' communique on the Far East:
TOKYO, July 14 (AP) -- Eighth Army communiqu, for Monday's operations:

The Aluminum Company of America, which accounts for nearly half of the nation's primary aluminum production, increased its price of standard aluminum ingot by 1 cent a pound, to 21 1/2 cents, and of aluminum pig by 1/2-cent, to 20 cents, effective today.
TRENTON, July 14 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll was back at his desk today after a 350-mile voyage in a fourteen-foot open boat with his two sons, Alfred T., 16 years old, and Peter E., 13.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 14 -- The two houses of Parliament, sitting in joint session, gave a first reading today, 171 votes to 14, to a bill proposing to deprive the Supreme Court of its power of veto over legislation. The bill, introduced by Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan, seeks also to remove voters of mixed blood from the common electoral register and abolish a provision in the Constitution safeguarding nonwhite franchise rights.

Stricter law enforcement methods that would result in heavier penalties for traffic violators and eliminate "ticket fixing" and similar illegal practices were urged ot the highway safety "worshop" conference yesterday at the New York University Law Center.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 14 -- Gadgets and novelties to delight the heart of any homemaker are displayed here today at the National Housewares Exhibit at Convention Hall.
To commemorate Bastille Day, an all-French program was presented at Lewisohn Stadium last evening by Pierre Monteux and the Stadium Symphony Orchestra.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The United States and Britain concluded their talks on the smoldering Middle East this afternoon without any formal announcement of agreement but some privately expressed reports of progress.

ALBANY, July 14 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals threw out today an Appellate Division ruling that prohibited a racket investigating Manhattan grand jury from examining the personal records of Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 -- Two freighters collided in a heavy fog outside the Golden Gate today and the outbound Jacob Luckenbach, en route to the Far East with a mixed military and commercial cargo, sank soon after, but no lives were lost.
Some of New York's best known restaurants were closed yesterday by a dispute between the Restaurant League of New York and three locals of the Consolidated Dining Room Employes Union, A. F. L.

The American export trade, which long has derived indirect benefits from Export-Import Bank loans to foreign countries, can expect "tougher" policy in this Federal agency's future lending activities, members of the Export Managers Club were advised yesterday.

DIAMOND, Mo., July 14 -- Dr. George Washington Carver, who was born a slave and lived to become one of the world's outstanding scientists, was honored today when his birthplace near here was made a national monument.

HONOLULU, July 14 (AP) -- Searchers said today that a violent explosion aboard a Transocean Air Lines four-engined plane apparently plunged its fifty-eight occupants to death in the Pacific without warning Saturday night, 350 miles east of Wake Island in Pacific waters teeming with sharks.

MONTAUK, L. I., July 14 -- Now that the first white marlin has been brought in at Montauk, and the school tuna are present in good numbers, it would seem that the giant tuna specialists should begin chumming off Rosie's Ledge and Nebraska Shoals.
The New York Regional Blood Program of the American Red Cross needs more donations today for whole blood for Korea. Response yesterday was good but more blood will be needed today and tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed legislation today permitting wheat growers to plant 62,000,000 acres next year and still get high price supports. The measure raises the allotment level for growers 7,000,000 acres above the 55,000,000 provided in the old law.

Controller Lazarus Joseph proposed yesterday that the City Charter be amended to make Mayors ineligible for re-election after a single five-year term so that the city "can obtain the best type of administration."

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Senate Republican leadership indicated today that no thought had been given to granting priority to a bill to restrict the transmission of racing news that could be used for gambling purposes. The prospect thus raised was that Senate action was not probable at this session.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Eisenhower sent to the Senate today the nomination of Joseph Campbell to serve as a member of the Atomic Energy Commission until June 30, 1955, to fill out the unexpired term of Thomas Keith Glennan, who recently resigned.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, warned Congressional economizers today "not to weaken our position there" by a major reduction in the $5,157,232,500 foreign-aid authorization. He admonished the Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives that such action might cause our Allies to "lose confidence in us" at a critical time.

BERLIN, July 14 -- Scarce items of food for residents of the Soviet sector of Berlin were put on sale in West Berlin today and between 1,000 and 2,000 persons crossed the border to buy milk and oranges.

The same city officials who, by their action or inaction, ran the transit system into bankruptcy are now filling the air with lamentations that the new Transit Authority is unable to economize its way out of a multi-million-dollar operating deficit instead of raising the fare.

SINGAPORE, July 14 -- The Royal Air Force intensified today the air offensive against Malayan Communist guerrillas, dropping more than 100 500-pound bombs on pin-pointed terrorist camps. The air raid was one of the heaviest of the campaign against the Communists.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Arthur E. Summerfield, Postmaster General, said tonight that 183 major cities would get improved mail service beginning next Monday.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The United States today issued a 5-cent green stamp in commemoration of Commodore Perry's opening of Japan to trade.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Chairman Jerome Kuykendall of the Federal Power Commission labeled "unconstitutional" today a bill the Detroit Edison Company says is necessary for a power hook-up with Canada. The bill would permit the company to connect its steam power system with Ontario's hydroelectric system and still stay free from rate regulation by the commission.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Republic of Korea presented today its Independence Medal to Richard J. H. Johnston, a member of the Chicago bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, for a "lasting contribution" to the Korean people. Dr. You Chan Yang, Korean Ambassador, made the presentation at a ceremony in the Korean Embassy.

Fifth Avenue yesterday looked more than a little like something out of the Arabian Nights as the Ancient Arabic Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine took over. The Shriners are here in abundance, a hundred thousand of them or so, and every state in the Union has sent its quota.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 14 -- Pat Hinman of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club finished third and first, respectively, in the opening races of the Syce Cup matches for the women's Long Island Sound sailing championship for 14 1/2 points to tie Judy Webb of Riverside at the end of the day at the Manhasset Bay Y. C.

Regardless of the fact that Senator McCarthy is creating dissension, it appears that he is getting results. McCarthy may be extremely aggressive in his actions, but time after time men have gone before his committee and refused to answer questions pertaining to their participation in the Communist conspiracy.

The excesses of Senator McCarthy in his "investigations" of everyone and everything that happen to strike his fancy are beginning to produce the inevitable reaction.
