With the notable exception of Senator Lehman few Senators in recent months have had the stomach directly to criticize Mr. McCarthy's activities on the Senate floor.

Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt, a New York banker and an authority on savings, was injured critically last night in a fall from the bedroom window of his fourth floor apartment at 71 East Seventy-seventh Street.
Three old hands at picking pockets, their records dating back to the days of Teddy Roosevelt's Administration, were taken into custody again yesterday, bringing to 109 their collective arrests.

LONDON, July 14 -- Labor party peers in the House of Lords sharply questioned today the necessity for the measures taken by the British military commander in Egypt after the kidnapping of a British aircraftsman and demanded to know whether the commander had consulted the Foreign Office before acting.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A visit to the White House by two of the principal contenders failed today to break the deadlock in the Senate Judiciary Committe that is preventing action on the administration's request for the admission to this country of 240,000 unfortunates from abroad.

The 250 "Wall Streeters" who could not get into the Downtown Athletic Club two weeks ago to hear William Zeckendorf, president of Webb Knapp, Inc., tell the New York Society of Security Analysts what that multimillion realty organization was doing with its stockholders' money had their treat yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- The city's ban on the controversial Italian motion picture, "The Miracle," was ruled illegal today by Judge Harry M. Fisher in Cook County Circuit Court. He ruled in a suit brought by the American Civil Liberties Union. The picture deals with a demented peasant woman who is seduced by a stranger she thinks is a saint.

With the recent arrival of currants and gooseberries, the season for making jellies and preserves is under way. To see how one busy cook was progressing with this culinary chore, we visited Mrs. Mary Armstrong, proprietor, cook and sales clerk for the Little Old Lady jelly shop, 174 Ninth Avenue, between Twentieth and Twenty-first Streets.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 14 -- About 300 mothers from the religious suburbs of Jerusalem tried to storm the Knesset (Parliament) this evening and were dispersed by streams of water from a fire engine hose. They were protesting against a bill soon to be introduced by the Government that will require girls exempt from regular military service on the ground of religious objection to render other forms of national service.

HONG KONG, July 14 -- A number of Chinese workers were reported today to have been killed and wounded by security troops at a state-owned alcohol distillery near Tsunyi in Kweichow Province in a May 1 riot that led to a fire destroying part of the plant. There was no official confirmation of this mainland report.

CINCINNATI, July 14 -- Awesome home run shelling was supposed to go on display today as major league baseball's twentieth All-Star game unfolded on Crosley Field before a capacity crowd of 80,846. But it did not materialize.

ALBANY, July 14 -- The Court of Appeals today ordered a new trial at the Supreme Court level in an eight-year-old case involving control of St. Nicholas Cathedral, 15 East Seventy-ninth Street, New York, by two Russian religious factions.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 14 -- The collapse in Scarsdale of one corner of a four-story office building under construction at Popham and Overhill Roads, was not caused by faulty footings even though the entire site along Overhill Road had been marshy, District Attorney Samuel Faile was told here today by builders.

STRATFORD, Ont., July 14 -- Spectacular production; shallow performance. That may be the quick way to describe the "Richard III" that opened the Shakespeare Festival last evening, with Alec Guinness as the deformed, dissembling Duke of Gloucester.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The foreign ministers of Britain, France and the United States warned the Communist world today that their three Governments would go back to war in Korea at once if the expected early armistice was violated by renewed aggression from the Communist side.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 14 -- The effective existence of the Iranian Majlis (lower and sole existing legislative chamber) ended late tonight with the resignation of twenty-seven members of the pro-Government National Movement faction.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies during June showed an aggregate gain of 6.9 per cent over the corresponding period of 1952, according to a compilation of forty-one companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 14 (AP) -- Nipper Hanover, a 5-year-old gelding owned by Cleo A. Young of Timmonsville, S. C., closed with a blazing stretch effort to win the feature $4,000 Southampton Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in a photo finish.

Thomas W. Massoth has been appointed operations control manager of the engineering products department of RCA Victor division of Radio Corporation of America, and Wilbur E. Lloyd has been named controller. Edward J. Meehan Jr. was appointed home office sales coordinator of AM and FM radio transmitters and broadcast audio equipment of the broadcast marketing division.

PARIS, July 14 -- Seven persons were killed and 130 injured, more than a score of them seriously, in a clash with the police today during a counter-demonstration by the Communists to the traditional military parade in Paris on Bastille Day.

A new novel by Russell Janney has been scheduled for publication by Hermitage House on Sept. 9, the anniversary of the publication of the author's best-seller "The Miracle of the Bells." Entitled "So Long As Love Remembers." the forthcoming story deals with a composer, a Wilkes-Barre girl he marries, a song the girl writes and a statue in the Cloisters here.

Knoxville, Tenn., sold yesterday an issue of $5,000,000 sewer revenue bonds due on each Jan. 1 from 1957 to 1988 to a syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 3,809 per cent. The bid was 100.05 for interest coupons of 5 per cent, 3 1/2 per cent and 3.8 per cent.
The city Department of Health's annual budget of $17,000,000 is twice as great as the amount spent by the United Nations World Health Organization, Mayor Impellitteri told New Yorkers last night.

Emergency crews of workmen of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity were repairing yesterday the damage done by a break in a twelve-inch water main that caused a chunk of Eighth Avenue, south of Fourteenth Street, to drop five feet.
It cost the Administration 75 cents in postage to remove the obstinate William A. Carroll, Democratic hold-over, from the office as United States Marshal for the Southern District of New York.

BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., July 14 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair, the state champion, gained 28 points today to take the first-round lead in the Elizabeth Goss round-robin tournament at the Somerset Hills Golf Club.

If, as and when we finally get a truce in Korea it would be well for us to understand the logic of our position there; for the great confusion in our current popular thinking about Korea is due, I believe, to the Administration's failure to make the logic of our position there clear to the American people.
Eighteen birds of paradise, most of them never before exhibited in the United States, arrived at the Bronx Zoo last night from a remote valley in New Guinea.

The elevator operator is following the old rope control into extinction, according to Le Roy A. Petersen, president of the Otis Elevator Company. He and Otis engineers displayed for the first time yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel a huge working model of four banks of automatic elevators in a ten-story building.

Reporting on operations at the annual meeting of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., in Richmond, Va., yesterday, O. Parker McComas, the president, said sales for the six months ended June 30 increased 5.75 per cent to $159,692,000, from $151,007,000 in the 1952 period.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Representative Noah M. Mason explained in an interview today why his bill applied to the movies and not to the theatre.

Brimful of enthusiasm for Venice, Mr. John has returned from a recent trip to the Queen of the Adriatic with one of the best of his recent collections. While it is romantic, it is not sentimental, and though its theme is Venetian it is not arty but rather practical and adaptable to the present-day fashions, which are at once simple and elegant.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 14 (AP) -- A group of Americans with no official United States connections is helping train and supply Chinese Nationalist guerrillas on a group of Nationalist-held islands off the Red China coast, informed quarters here said today.

The 1953 campaign of the Greater New York Fund has raised more than $6,000,000 in cash and pledges for the most successful drive in its sixteen-year history, G. Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange and chairman of the campaign, announced yesterday.

A dispatch from Washington in your July 7 issue states that the Army's program is "falling flat" in its attempt to maintain a ready reserve of trained men made up of former draftees; that is, of so-called returnees who have completed two years of active service and who, under existing laws, have a further military obligation to fulfill in a reserve status.
DALLAS, Tex., July 14 (UP) -- Drought-plagued Texas farmers were accused today of taking more than their share of Rio Grande water, thereby causing Mexican cotton growers to lose $1,500,000 in crops.
A return of the Port of New York on Jan. 1 to security conditions that existed during World War II, but on a voluntary industry participation basis, seemed assured yesterday.

Police Lieut. Arthur Miller, 42 years old, of 181 Langham Street, Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, was accused yesterday by the Police Department of having lied to a superior officer when he denied any association with Communist or subversive groups.

Telegrams of protest were sent yesterday to all New York Congressmen, urging them to take steps against the bill introduced by Representative Noah M. Mason, Republican of Illinois, to repeal the 20 per cent Federal admission tax for movies only.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 14 -- The first round of the New York State twenty-fourth annual women's championship was completed without any mishaps at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

ALBANY, July 14 -- Two restaurant union officers, both conceded former Communists, told a subcommittee of the House of Representatives Committee on Un- American Activities today that there was an active cell of Communist party members in the state government in the late Nineteen Thirties.

Sileck Estates, Inc., of which William Erkert is president, sold the five-story apartment house accommodating sixty-five families at 5704 to 5722 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, to Elfran Estates, Inc., headed by Oscar Weinstein. Julius A. Weiss and Nathaniel Barmen were the brokers. Title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company. The property, on a plot about 200 by 100 feet, is assessed at $217,000. It was sold for cash above mortgages of $106,332.

NOVI SAD, Yugoslavia, July 14 -- With a fine harvest expected and despite the chronic problem of overpopulation in the agricultural areas, Yugoslavia faces in some regions a shortage of farm labor and fears have been expressed that much land will go uncultivated after the forthcoming crop is reaped.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 14 -- Max Steiner, music director at Warner Brothers for the last sixteen years, will leave the studio next month when his current contract with the studio expires. He plans to enter the music publishing business and confine himself to scoring a limited number of films a year.

The Venezuelan Government has confiscated the entire shipment of 250 copies of the July 2 International Air Edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES consigned for distribution in that country, according to word received here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The foreign ministers of Britain, France and the United States proposed tonight that the foreign minister of the Soviet Union join them in a four-power conference early in the autumn to discuss reunification of Germany and the conclusion of a treaty re-establishing independence for Austria.
CINCINNATI, July 14 -- "Hiya, Muscles," said Yogi Berra. "Ya ain't changed a bit." "Yogi," exclaimed Ted Williams, laughing happily. "Now I know I'm home."

Commodore Matthew Calbraith Perry was described as a symbol of friendship between the United States and Japan at a ceremony yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, Tenth Street and Second Avenue, commemorating the 100th anniversary of the naval hero's historic visit to Japan in 1853.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Foreign Minister of France, the acting Foreign Secretary of the United Kingdom and the Secretary of State of the United States issued the following communique at the end of a five-day meeting here.

CAIRO, July 14 (AP) -- Maj. Salah Salem, Minister of National Guidance, declared today that "lots of Egyptians are being killed, injured and robbed by British troops" and that two were killed in the Suez Canal zone yesterday.

The 10-cent fare is expected to continue on eight privately operated bus lines until September. It became known yesterday that the Board of Estimate, which sets the fare on the private lines, plans to await an arbitration decision on a forty-hour week for the private operators before granting them a fare increase.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Unbeaten Miz Clementine, the Calumet Farm's newest sensation, tops a field of fourteen 2-year-old fillies entered tomorrow in the richest race of its kind ever offered -- the $106,735 Arlington Lassie Stakes.

BUENOS AIRES, July 14 -- President Juan Peron today presented to Congress a bill designed to make Argentina once again an attractive market for foreign investment and to bring to an end the decapitalization process that had been going on since 1947.

Under the Niagara Treaty of 1950 with Canada the Niagara River is to be "redeveloped" without detracting from the scenic beauty of the Falls so as to provide about twelve billion kilowatt-hours on the United States side. A rider on the treaty suspended the Federal Power Act and gave Congress authority over the development of Niagara hydroelectric power.

McGUIRE AIR BASE, Fort Dix, N. J., July 14 -- Officials of the New Jersey Division of Civil Defense were briefed today on the nation's air defense program in a tour of Air Force installations here, marking the first anniversary of the twenty-four hour Civil Defense air spotting program in the state.

The continued worth of democracy as a standard will rest a great deal upon the integrity with which the fiscal accounts of our national and local governments are managed. And to meet the challenge we shall have to find a supplementary form of just and workable taxation for use in times of stress, one that will permit collections by the Federal Government for partial redistribution to the various localities.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 14 -A Roman Catholic clergyman charge today that 25,000,000 American school children had never heard "the word of God spoken" and that 70,000,000 persons never attended church. He declared that because of immorality and secularism, "there is virtually a revolt against God in the United States."

George Auerbach's Maedic colt, Dictar, who had recorded four second places since his last victory on a New York track, put the top layer on the sandwich at the Empire- at-Jamaica meeting yesterday by winning the T. M. Dorsett Handicap for 3-year-olds.

The net estate of Eugene Higgins, famous in the Gay Nineties as the wealthiest bachelor in New York, who died on July 28, 1948, in Torquay, England, was valued yesterday at $40,111,999 in an estate tax appraisal at the State Office Building.
The Right Rev. James P. De Wolfe, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Long Island, called upon church officials yesterday to clean their own houses of subversive clergymen.

RICHMOND, Va., July 14 (UP) -- Former United States Representative Thomas B. Stanley of Henry County, won the Democratic nomination for Governor of Virginia today, which virtually assured him of election.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14 -- Over the last few months a pattern of increasing awareness by business interests, both United States and foreign, of the value of economic research facilities at United Nations headquarters has emerged here. The most unmistakable sign has been an expansion of the demand for statistical bulletins and reports of the Economic and Social Council and its subsidiaries.

The Long Island Rail Road carried 76,000,000 passengers last year, officials of the line declared yesterday before the Public Service Commission, and they contended in effect that most of the riders were contented commuters.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14 -- The high cost of transmitting news dispatches internationally is a major obstacle to the free flow of information around the world, a British news expert reported today.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Top- seeded Vic Seixas led sixteen survivors into the fourth round of the national clay courts tennis tournament today with a pair of easy straight-set triumphs.

Arbitrary and unrestrained Congressional investigations into education present as great a danger to academic freedom as do conspiratorial Communist minorities, Dr. R. Freeman Butts of Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday.

A young woman and a Brooklyn pretzel baker were held in $3,500 bail each yesterday in Felony Court on charges of extortion and forgery. They were accused of having tried to victimize Edgar F. Luckenbach Jr., a member of a prominent shipping family.

Boys and girls compelled to practice scales on the piano got a new champion yesterday in Ernest Weidner of Boston. A teacher himself, Mr. Weidner spoke at the second-day session of the convention of the International Piano Teachers Association at the Statler Hotel.

LONDON, July 14 -- A late recovery enable the stock markets to eliminate a major part of the early losses today or to make minor gains. Initial weakness was ascribed to yesterday's fall in Wall Street and the trend of events in Egypt.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- L. R. Sanford, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, urged today the scrapping of 1,000 of the 1,500 World War II Liberty vessels in this country's reserve fleet.

TEMAZCAL, Mexico, June 28 -- The President Aleman Dam, on the River Tonto near this jungle town, is nearing completion. Soon, for the first time in man's memory, the 1,000,000 inhabitants of the Papaloapam River Valley will be free of the danger of floods.

Title has been conveyed on the fifteen-story sixty-family apartment house at 179-183 East Seventy-ninth Street through the sale of stock of the owning corporation by Charles B. Hanan to an investor represented by Herman N. Finkelstein, attorney. Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., was the broker. The property, on a plot 65 by 102 feet is assessed at $465,000. It was sold subject to a mortgage of $290,000.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 14 -- Two young Hibberds from Rye, N. Y., 14-year-old Fred and 12-year-old sis, made a family affair of the eighth annual junior regatta of the New York Yacht Club today.
CHICAGO, July 14 -- Extremely light country offerings of wheat stimulated further buying of wheat futures here today and the recovery which had begun yesterday was extended substantially.

ALBANY, July 14 (AP) -- The perjury conviction of James E. Reardon, former New York City plainclothes policeman and one-time associate of Harry Gross, the bookmaker, was unanimously upheld today by the State Court of Appeals. There was no opinion.

A city policy decision is needed before the problem of a new central wholesale fruit and vegetable market can be solved, Walter P. Hedden, port development consultant for the Port of New York Authority, told the New York State Temporary Commission on Agriculture yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Eisenhower signed legislation today to enable drought-stricken farmers and ranchers in the Southwest to get more liberal Federal credit and to provide all types of farm producers with emergency credit in the event of a disaster.

Directors of the Consumers Power Company approved yesterday a negotiated price of 100.54 for a new issue of 3 3/4 per cent first mortgage bonds totaling $25,000,000. The issue, which will mature in thirty years, was sold to an investment banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co. This represents a money cost to the Michigan utility of 3.72 per cent.

YON CASSIUS, who had a lean and hungry look, read much and looked quite through the deeds of men, was by no means as honorable a man as Brutus; but he was a far better judge of men and politics. His own weaknesses, jealousies and ambitions enabled him to understand other weak, jealous and ambitious men.

There are various types of beaches, each having its own particular group of devoted adherents. Coney Island naturally is set apart for those who like people along with the sand, while for the misanthrope there are such places as the dunes of Cape Cod -- after the season.

When the earliest morning sounds are shouts of children at play, when milk is warm when brought in from the stoop, and when the talk is of degrees, per cents and vacations, the weather is getting hot. When small boys skip stones on ponds, pick tar from the roads with sticks and the strongest soap doesn't get them clean again it's well past the mid-year mark.

One hundred and twenty-three graduates of the evening division of New York University's College of Engineering were honored last night at "class day" exercises on the University Heights campus in the Bronx.
HONOLULU, July 14 (AP) -- Ralph E. Larrabee's 161-foot schooner, Goodwill, raced for the Diamond Head finish line of the trans-Pacific yacht race in a final burst of speed today.

THE same Board of Transportation crews that refitted the city's 2,647 subway turnstiles when the subway fare went from 5 cents to 10 cents five years ago think they may better their time on the change-over for the 15-cent tokens next week.
Merry and orderly, 25,000 colorfully costumed Shriners shared their good-natured cheer yesterday with half a million persons who watched them parade down sun-speckled Fifth Avenue.

James D. Norris, head of the International Boxing Club, yesterday disclosed that contracts for the world heavyweight title bout between Rocky Marciano of Brockton, Mass., the champion, and Roland La Starza of the Bronx would be signed today at the offices of the New York State Athletic Commission.
Grover A. Whalen, coordinator of recruiting and public information of the city's Office of Civil Defense, called yesterday on New Yorkers to volunteer as plane-spotters in the Ground Observer Corps.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Eisenhower fought off tonight by a direct appeal to the Senate a powerful attack on one of the last remaining items in his foreign program for this session of Congress, but the final and critical decision was put over until tomorrow.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, July 15 -- Rain, South Koreans and roaring Allied guns checked the raging Chinese offensive on the east-central Korean front today after it had smashed miles into United Nations territory.
The following pamphlet, recently published and directed to young persons, should help them to understand the menace that confronts their world:

STATE COLLEGE, Miss., July 14 -- Home economics and the homemaker have come a long way from the day when the former was called "domestic science" and the latter "a good housekeeper," Dr. Gertrude Weiss said today at a luncheon meeting here. The luncheon was held in connection with the seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of Mississippi State College.
With light trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, futures closed steady, with gains of 3 to 10 points yesterday.

YONKERS, July 14 -- Seeded players moved into the quarterfinal round in the junior division of the annual Eastern clay courts tennis championships for junior girls and girls which started today at the Amackassin Club. Top- ranked Mary Lenore Blair, Oyster Bay, L. I., defeated Ruth Ann Peterson, Baldwin, 6 -- 2, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 3, in the opening bracket, then eliminated Georgia Carrington, Montclair, N. J., 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 14 -- The Senate investigating subcommittee headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is "much more open to criticism" than the committees headed by Representative Harold H. Velde or Senator William E. Jenner, the Rev. Robert C. Hartnett, editor in chief of the Roman Catholic weekly America, said here today.

The State of Georgia is planning to come to market again today with a second major borrowing of funds to finance the building of local schools under the State School Building Authority set up in 1951. The first borrowing was $32,097,000 and took place in September of last year at an interest cost of 2.6 per cent to the authority.

With the five Democratic county leaders scheduled to meet at noon today to try to reach a decision on a candidate for Mayor, Senator Herbert H. Lehman was reported to have urged the nomination of either Averell Harriman or Robert F. Wagner Jr.
BALTIMORE, July 14 (AP) -- President Elpidio Quirino of the Philippines told his people today that he had found in the United States "gross misrepresentations of Philippine conditions."

The report of the special committee of the United Nations and the International Labor Organization on forced labor -- an extraordinary and significant document -- was placed on the agenda of the Economic and Social Council for discussion at its current meeting in Geneva.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, attacked today the honesty of the Eisenhower Administration's proposal to increase by 1 cent the postage for out-of-town letters sent by first-class mail.

Maureen Connolly, of San Diego, Calif., returned yesterday after winning her second consecutive Wimbledon tennis championship. She arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 8:30 A. M., on a Scandinavian airliner from Copenhagen.
A New Jersey artist who painted a miniature of President Eisenhower's mother, the late Mrs. Ida Eisenhower, has learned that the President keeps the portrait on his desk in his White House study.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 15 -- The United Nations and Communist truce delegations met for only twenty-one minutes at Panmunjom today, apparently still deadlocked over Chinese and North Korean demands for guarantees against possible action by the rebellious South Korean President, Dr. Syngman Rhee, to upset an armistice in Korea.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, threw his support today behind a proposed Small Business Administration and said it should be "a completely independent agency, reporting directly to the President."

TOKYO, July 14 (Reuters) -- The Government warned today that Japan's economy is sweeping toward disaster on the crest of an artificial prosperity created by United States military orders for the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- President Eisenhower nominated today the Rev. Dr. Joseph Simonson, a Lutheran pastor of Glen Cove, L. I., to be Ambassador to Ethiopia. There has been a vacancy in that post since Jan. 18.

ATHENS, July 14 -- Demetrios Babakos, Minister of Justice, offered a draft law to the Parliamentary recess committee today, amending the section of the penal code dealing with press affairs. It introduces what for this country are radical measures. By the terms of the draft comments and criticism regarding persons on trial are forbidden before the final verdict is published.

The heavy Communist attack in Korea, which had made serious penetrations last night, comes at a time when enemy forces have reached maximum strength and when the Allies are somewhat demoralized by Korean-United States friction and by the anticipation of a truce that has never come.

The Greenwich, Conn., branch of Franklin Simon Co. will close on Saturday and re-open early in September as a branch of Oppenheim, Collins Co. to permit a retail operation at popular prices in place of a higher price specialty store, it was learned yesterday.

In these days of tension it is very heartening to read so refreshing an article as that published in Topics of The Times on July 9. I do not know to whom the credit goes for this wonderful understanding how children at camp behave, but I am sure he must have experienced the long wait for mail which never seems to come.

ROME, July 14 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi called on President Luigi Einaudi this morning and formally accepted the task of forming a new government to replace the one that resigned at the end of last month after the Italian elections.

I have a suggestion to improve the beauty of the Palisades and the hills facing the Hudson as far as West Point. It will render the river during the month of May the most unique and unmatched beauty spot anywhere in the world.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, has told Sherman Adams, Presidential assistant, in effect that the White House was appeasing "immoral political forces" in refusing to nominate John W. Edelman, former Socialist, as Assistant Secretary of Labor.

ALBANY, July 14 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that a national bank in New York State cannot use the words "saving" and "savings" in its advertising, even though Federal laws empower it to accept "savings deposits" and to pay interest on them.

The Board of Health amended the Sanitary Code at its meeting yesterday to permit the continued use of certain pre-1929 tenement cellars as homes. It accepted the minimum standards of health and safety drafted for such premises by the Department of Health and the Department of Housing and Buildings.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Allen W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, agreed today to seek a formula under which the Congressional panel might call and question personnel of the top-secret organization, but under conditions that would not imperil its security mission.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Eisenhower's request for continuation of the excess profits tax until Dec. 31 was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee. Quick Senate passage was forecast.
The controversy still raging today over the best method for feeding babies is, it seems, age-old.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, N. Y., July 14 -- Aquila C. Giles of Meadow Brook, who won the Connecticut amateur title twenty-eight years ago, today led the Long Island District qualifiers for the Metropolitan amateur golf championship. The tourney begins with match play rounds at the Fenway Golf Club, White Plains, next Wednesday.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 14 -- The Turkish Government instructed its Ambassador in Moscow today to inform the Soviet Union that the historic Dardanelles Straits question could not be resolved in bilateral negotiations, as intimated in a Soviet note to Ankara on May 30.

VIENNA, July 14 -- Mrs. Eva Kapus, sister-in-law of William Key, formerly a lieutenant in the United States military mission in Budapest, Hungary, was critically wounded by the explosion of a grenade hurled at her by a Hungarian frontier guardsman early Sunday morning while she was escaping across the Austro-Hungarian frontier.

The lady from Arkansas showed her hand when she complained: "Why can't the 'hired' help * * * show visitors a smattering of courtesy?" They will, ma'am, they will. Next time you visit New York forget they are hired help. You'll find most of them wonderfully human.

With first-seeded Donald Dell of Bethesda, Md., showing the way, the boys' division made its start and completed the second round yesterday in the Eastern junior and boys' tennis championships at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

GENEVA, July 14 -- The United Nations program of technical assistance to underdeveloped countries has now grown and is ready to take on new and tougher jobs, David Owen, chairman of the United Nations Technical Assistance Board, said here today in a review of the work of his and other agencies cooperating in this endeavor.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 14 -- Television in the Netherlands is on an extremely small scale -- only one hour and a half of programming on Tuesday and Friday evenings. But the Government has just decided to go ahead on a broader basis and the Dutch have been putting their experimental period to good advantage.

LONDON, July 14 -- An attorney appointed by the British Government to determine whether Timothy John Evans was executed unjustly three years ago for the murder of his infant daughter reported today that he was satisfied Evans had killed both the child and his wife.
CINCINNATI, July 14 -- Casey Stengel of the Yankees, a four-time loser, who under the Baumes Law could get "life," can have the job of managing the American League All-Stars again next year.

BONN, Germany, July 14 -- Adlai E. Stevenson disclosed here today some of the conclusions he had reached on United States foreign policy during his four-and-a-half-month tour around the world. His press conference was attended by more than 100 German reporters and a score of American, British and French correspondents.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 14 (UP) -- Pass Play and Incrimination ran a dead heat for first place in the featured New Jersey State Assembly Purse today at Monmouth Park, while Pleiades, the 9-to-5 favorite, finished last in the field of eight 3-year-olds. Nebullus was third, a length-and-a-quarter behind the co-winners.

Three new films will open at firstrun theatres this morning. "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," Twentieth Century-Fox' Technicolor adaptation of the musical comedy by Joseph Fields and Anita Loos, Istarring Jane Russell and Marilyn Monroe, is at the Roxy.

JERSEY CITY, July 14 -- Hudson County taxpayers are footing the bill to keep on the payroll at a million dollars a year 300 county employes who do little or no work, County Supervisor Bernard M. Hartnett charged today.
A rigorous course in driving for chronic traffic violators and accident repeaters was suggested yesterday at the highway safety conference at the New York University Law Center.

Remarkable results from cooperative newspaper advertising are reported by Living for Young Homemakers in connection with the magazine's own promotion in March of the Monterey prefabricated house with the National Homes Corporation.
The majority report of a committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York has some interesting suggestions, but no complete solution, for the vexing problem of communism in unions.

Chris Rogers had just enough room to drive Mrs. Alfred Roberts' Eatontown between F. Ambrose Ciark's Tea-Maker and Mrs. Jan Burke's Squared Away and win the $22,175 Fleetwing Handicap in a finish that had many of the 21,863 onlookers whooping with excitement at the Jamaica track yesterday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 14 -- France's appeal for more United States aid in Indo-China is being watched attentively here, but there is general agreement in this capital that without some changes in political and military strategy, more money and materiel won't win this war.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- The Senate voted a contempt citation today against Timothy J. O'Mara, New York waterfront figure who refused to answer questions on port conditions before Senator Charles W. Tobey's Senate Commerce subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- An American Federation of Labor official testified today he felt it would be a "grave mistake" to allow the present United States shipbuilding labor force of 128,000 to shrink further.
Jersey will be an important fashion fabric this fall. It is already appearing in many items.

Rocky Marciano and Roland La Starza signed contracts yesterday to box fifteen rounds for the former's world title at the Polo Grounds on Thursday, night, Sept. 24, thus setting the stage for New York's first heavyweight championship fight in more than two years.

GENEVA, July 15 -- The Soviet Government announced unexpectedly here today that it would give 4,000,000 rubles to the United Nations Technical Assistance Fund for aid to underdeveloped areas during 1953. If, as was implied in the Russian statement, these are to be convertible gold rubles, this would be equivalent to $1,000,000.
Willis Rabbe has been elected president of the David White Company, manufacturer of engineering instruments.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 15 -- The summer housewares show reached its half-way mark here today with manufacturers expressing increased optimism for business conditions the rest of the year as buying ranged between fair and good.

The Georgia State Building Authority raised $63,300,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of revenue bonds to finance the construction of school buildings of simple, standardized design for seventy-four of the state's 202 local school systems.

Two Dutch Princesses, 15-year-old Beatrix, heiress to the throne of the Netherlands, and her 14-year-old sister, Princess Irene, arrived here yesterday to spend a six-week vacation at the summer home of Mr. and Mrs. H. F. B. Feaver at Chatham, Mass.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Net profits after taxes of manufacturing corporations amounted to $2,800,000,000 in the first quarter of this year, according to a joint study completed this week by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Trade Commission. The figure compares with $2,965,000,000 for the final quarter of 1952 but represents an increase of 11 per cent from earnings in the corresponding quarter of last year.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- A blistering report signed by five Democrats on the Senate Banking Committee threatened today a major fight on a Republican-sponsored plan to dispose of twenty-nine Government - owned rubber plants.

Discovery of a large deposit of high grade manganese ore near Franceville, French Equatorial Africa, by a French concern named Comilog was announced yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation, which has a 49 per cent interest in the Comilog.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- Oil price rises will cost United States taxpayers $50,000,000 in added military costs in the next twelve months, Department of Defense officials said today.

CHICAGO, July 15 (UP) -- Queen Hopeful, a dark bay filly from the Hasty House Farm, today beat the Calumet Farm's 1-to-2 favorite, Miz Clementine, in a photo finish of the richest 2-year-old filly race ever run, the $105,735 Arlington Lassie Stakes.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- Ezra T. Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, today fixed a 62,000,000-acre limit on next year's wheat crop in the first acreage allotment since 1942.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- If there is a truce in Korea and the Communists "renew their aggression" or "threaten the principles of the United Nations," the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Great Britain and France are on record with the pledge that, as members of the United Nations, their Governments will "again support the restoration of peace and security."

The leaders of two young gangs from the South Jamaica section of Queens, arrested on April 19 for unlawful assembly in the gang killing of a teen-age boy, were sentenced to a maximum of three years each in the Elmira Reception Center yesterday.

Seventeen cases of poliomyelitis in the city have been reported to the Department of Health in the last three days. This compares with thirty-nine confirmed cases in the corresponding three days of 1949, the last year in which the disese reached epidemic proportions here.

Commodity prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Hides, soybean oil, wool, rubber, lead and zinc showed gains; cocoa and coffee eased, and cottonseed oil, copper, sugar, potatoes and tin were mixed. Volume, though continuing good, was off from Tuesday's levels.

This is the season for the watermelon as a companion to luncheon or dinner in restaurants and homes all over the country. Properly cooled, the watermelon has a way of proving highly satisfactory as a summer dessert.
F. Guild Devere has been appointed sales manager for Decoware of the Continental Can Company.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Diplomatic officials regarded the East German move today to negotiate free elections directly with West Germany as an "empty gesture" designed to beat the Western powers to the punch.

Riders on the Long Island Rail Road will have somewhat better chances of getting a seat this year with the addition of 4,444 seats on commuter trains, according to figures presented yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission at 233 Broadway.

The development of small thin crystals that have a remarkable ability to store up information was announced yesterday by the Bell Telephone Laboratories. Such mechanical memorizers are vital to telephone dial systems, electronic calculators and the like.
COLUMBIA, S. C., July 15 (AP) -- A suit that pits two national advertising characters -- Reddy Kilowatt and Willie Wirehand -- against each other was filed in Federal court here today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 15 (UP) -- Two leaders of the National Revolutionary Movement, the Government party, were expelled today and four others were scheduled for trial by special "courts of honor" for "failing to follow the Government line" in dealing with the recent Indian uprising in the Cochabramba Valley.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 15 -- Dr. You Chan Yang, the South Korean Ambassador to the United States, warned the Western world here today not to adopt what he called a new world policy based on compromise with evil.

The two-day hearings by the Temporary State Commission to Study the Organizational Structure of the Government of the City of New York developed a substantial fund of testimony and the overwhelming opinion that better administration of city affairs is possible and desirable.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 15 -- Edmund L. Palmieri, New York attorney, lost a suit against the Dutch Government today when a District Court here ruled itself unqualified to determine whether a Dutch Foreign Office note had injured his reputation.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Favorites, headed by top-seeded Vic Seixas and Maureen Connolly, today breezed into quarter-final play in the singles of the national clay courts tennis tourney.

The future of Washington Market -- whether to move it away, modernize it, or simply leave it as it is where it is -- was debated here yesterday by representatives of railroads, truck lines and steamship companies.

Dr. Allen B. Du Mont, television scientist and yachtsman, was declared yesterday the first winner of the new Commodore's Trophy, put up for challenge competition by William Edgar John of Rye, first commodore of the newly organized Eastern Cruiser Association.

CARDIFF, Wales, July 15 -- The possibility that historians of the future may regard the antibiotics era as merely a short bright respite in man's age-long fight against disease was the theme implicit in many papers presented here today at the annual general meeting of the British Medical Association.

A miniature radio-controlled amphibious jeep sounded a siren, fired a miniature gun and hummed a tune while cavorting about the 1953 Industrial Arts Award display yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Charging that the enforcement of the city's building laws had deteriorated in recent years, a grand jury that investigated a Bronx factory fire in which seven persons died March 3 returned a presentment yesterday directing the filing of criminal informations against unnamed persons.

MONTAUK, L. I., July 15 -- The desire for the sight and touch of a firm, unyielding dock was not an uncommon emotion among those who discovered today that tossing seas tend to nullify the claims printed in large type on the labels of seasick remedies.

The five-story building containing four stores and fourteen apartments at 833 Madison Avenue, which they acquired last April from the George G. Moore estate, has been resold by Hugh K. McGovern and Loomis J. Grossman, operators, to the 833 Madison Avenue Corporation, of which Monroe A. Lawrence is president.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Expressing confidence that the problems of German reunification and Austrian independence were capable of early solution, the Governments of the United States, Britain and France formally asked the Soviet Union tonight to agree to a short conference of the four foreign ministers "about the end of September" at a mutually satisfactory place.
LONDON, July 15 -- The stock markets here developed a brighter tone today and although business expanded only slightly, prices rose in nearly all groups.

DANBURY, Conn., July 15 -- Kenneth H. Hanna, former executive secretary of the City Housing Authority, was charged today with having embezzled $3,815 in funds belonging to the authority's veterans' emergency housing division. Arrested on a Superior Court bench warrant, Mr. Hanna was released later in $1,500 bail pending arraignment at the September term of court.

HARTFORD, July 15 -- A one-man grand jury report filed in Superior Court today by Newell Jennings, retired Associate Justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court, found "probable cause to believe" that a Republican state legislator and a Connecticut fireworks manufacturer were guilty in 1951 of violating state statutes concerning bribery and attempting to influence legislation.

PARIS, July 15 -- Four members of the French National Assembly representing different parties announced today their intention of questioning the Government with regard to the riots that took place during the Communist demonstration on Bastille Day yesterday.

BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., July 15 -- The Palm Beach style of scoring came to the rescue of Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair today and the state champion increased her total in the second round of the Elizabeth Goss round robin sponsored by the Women's New Jersey Golf Association to plus 52.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 15 -- Several close matches and one minor upset marked the second round today of the twenty-fourth annual Women's New York State golf championship at the Hempstead Club.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Mayor Norris Poulson of Los Angeles said today he had reached agreement with Federal authorities on the California city's controversial public housing program. However, it is up to Congress and the city of Los Angeles to put the compromise into effect.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A Government Operations subcommittee of the House of Representatives called today on Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, to submit by Oct. 31 "a comprehensive program for correcting deficiencies in supply and stock management practices of the military departments."

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 15 (AP) -- P. S. Willard, superintendent of the Procter and Gamble Company plant here, said his company asked for an essential occupation draft deferment for John V. Beamer Jr., 24-year-old son of an Indiana United States Representative.

A 212-foot, seven-and-one-half-ton steel radio transmitting tower tore itself loose from its concrete base in the East River last night and crashed across Vernon Boulevard, Astoria, Queens, its tip missing by ten feet about sixty children in a housing project playground.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 15 (AP) -- Mrs. S. M. Pistoria's Tuscany, carrying top weight of 122 pounds, dashed to a new track record before 22,481 racegoers at Monmouth Park today by taking the $15,000 Salvator Mile.

ROME, July 15 -- The Cabinet crisis brought about by Premier Alcide De Gasperi's resignation June 29 was virtually closed late this evening when he submitted his eighth consecutive government to President Luigi Einaudi. The Cabinet is composed entirely of Christian Democrats.

MILWAUKEE, July 15 (AP) -- Welterweight Champion Kid Gavilan won a unanimous ten-round decision tonight over Ramon Fuentes of Los Angeles in a non-title fight in the Milwaukee Arena. This was Milwaukee's first nationally televised bout.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Scheduled airlines operating trunk routes within the United States flew 23.6 per cent more revenue passenger miles in the first five months of 1953 than in the comparable period last year, the Air Transport Association reported today.

Anyone complaining about the heat these days might feel better if he considered the plight of the men who tend the ceaseless fires in the furnaces of the city's eleven incinerators. Those fires roar twenty-four hours a day every day in the year to consume nearly 1,400,000 tons of garbage collected throughout New York annually. The temperature inside each furnace ranges from 1,600 to 2,000 degrees Fahrenheit.

The Interstate Mold Bobbing Corporation has leased a one-story factory to be built for it by the Ioric Construction Company in Iorio Court, off Route 22 and near Springfield Road, in Union, N. J. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Administration won a significant foreign policy victory in the Senate today after a personal intervention by President Eisenhower that greatly changed the climate overnight.

The manner in which President Eisenhower's proposal for extending the excess profits tax was handled in the Senate this week contrasted strikingly with its earlier vicissitudes at the hands of the House. In the House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Reed sat on the measure for weeks, and for a time it appeared that he had succeeded in holding it up for good.

The five Democratic county leaders held yesterday what was supposed to be a secret meeting, but it was learned that they had not designated a candidate for Mayor. By agreement there was no formal discussion of candidates.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission's participation in the reorganization of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road not only is wasteful of the Federal agency's time but "it also leads inevitably to the evils which result when one company is subject to dual regulation," Benjamin F. Feinberg, chairman of the New York State Public Service Commission, told a Congressional subcommittee today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Board of Immigration Appeals announced today dismissal of an appeal by Max Young, described as an important international Communist functionary, from a deportation order against him. Young, also known as Boris Richard Daniman, was arrested in New York, May 1 and is being held on Ellis Island without bail.

To fill the gap left by cessation of Voice of America radio programs interpreting the United States to Latin - American countries, WRUL, short wave station near Boston has increased its broadcasts beamed at Central and South America, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- United States battle casualties in Korea now total 138,246, an increase of 332 over last week's report, the Department of Defense announced today.
Two seeded players were eliminated in the third round of the Eastern junior tennis championships yesterday at the West Side Club in Forest Hills, Queens.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 15 (Reuters) -- African political leaders today called off their month-old boycott of talks with the British on constitutional revision, and agreed to send delegates to London.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 15 -- The Grand National Assembly rejected overwhelmingly today a proposal to allow Turkish civil servants to marry foreigners. The move to repeal a measure, adopted in 1926, providing compulsory discharge of any state employe who married a foreign national was made by a member of the Republican People's party Opposition.

A syndicate of forty-one underwriting houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $25,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds of the Consumers Power Company, Michigan utility enterprise. The bonds, sold to the banking syndicate by negotiation, bear interest of 3 3/4 per cent and are priced at 101 to yield 3.68 per cent to maturity in 1983.

After the three-day All-Star game interim, major league baseball resumes full-scale operation today, with the Dodgers and Giants opening home stands against Western rivals and the Yankees visiting St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- The Veterans Administration disclosed today it might require non-service-connected medical cases to list income and assets under oath and swear they could not afford private treatment before they were cared for at a V. A. hospital.
BALTIMORE, Md., July 15 -- The new 25,000-ton Sinclair Oil Corporation tanker M. L. Gosney was launched today at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Sparrows Point shipyard near here.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 15 (AP) -- Adios Boy, owned by J. S. Turner of Nassawadox, Va., tied the track record for 2-year-old pacers tonight with a 2:04 2/5 mile effort at Roosevelt Raceway.

STRATFORD, Ont., July 15 -- After enjoying the Tyrone Guthrie production of "All's Well That Ends Well" in the Stratford festival tent theatre last evening, one can easily understand why Mr. Guthrie and Alec Guinness have selected this minor comedy to alternate with "Richard III."

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Representative Robert J. Corbett, Republican of Pennsylvania, taxed the Administration today with presenting a "very greatly swollen" estimate of the prospective post office deficit to obtain an increase in postal rates.

A decrease last week of 444,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 144,053,000 barrels, compared with 144,497,000 a week earlier and 118,332,000 a year ago.

ALBANY, July 15 -- A former district organizer for the Communist party testfied today that State, employes had been "the backbone of the party" in Albany in 1946 and 1947 but that they never had had a chance to bring their views to bear on the Government.

John T. Harrison Jr. and others have sold the five-story apartment house accommodating twenty families at 35-25 Ninety-fourth Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, to William Heller who plans to hold the property for investment. The property, on a plot 55 by 100 feet, was sold through John J. Reynolds, Inc., as broker.

PHOENIX, Ariz., July 15 (UP) -- School officials today predicted "complete integration" on unsegregated grade school classes here by September, 1954. Elementary schools of Phoenix will begin eliminating segregation this fall under an unanimous ruling of the elementary school trustees.

The American Smelting and Refining Company, one of the nation's major suppliers of zinc, announced a price action yesterday that would have the effect of reducing the cost of prime Western zinc to consumers in the East and on the Pacific Coast, although increasing the cost to some customers in the Midwest.

FONTAINEBLEAU, France, July 15 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, rested but still not fully recovered from the miseries that dogged him the day he won the British open golf championship, today played an exhibition match for military personnel and proved that he still had his master's touch.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- While experienced Moscow observers expressed their opinion today that Soviet policy in Germany had shown some signs of the preparation of conditions looking toward all-German elections, there was no belief here that the Kremlin would react with great enthusiasm to the Western bid for new discussions on Germany.

The world's largest communications enterprise, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported yesterday consolidated gross revenues for the Bell System of $4,204,490,349 in the twelve months to May 31 -- the first time the system reached such a figure in a twelve-month period.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Americans for Democratic Action challenged Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today to sue the organization for libel for having reproduced and distributed a Senate Investigating subcommittee's report on the Wisconsin Republican's financial transactions.

LONDON, July 15 -- A Government spokesman hotly denied today that the British military restrictions in the Suez Canal zone, the lifting of which has been demanded by the Egyptian Government, constituted "inflammatory action."
Ready to parade again after a day's respite, the Shriners received Mayor Impellitteri's assurances yesterday that New Yorkers "don't mind a little noise."

TOKYO, July 15 -- Japan and the United States opened formal talks today aimed at working out a mutual security agreement under which the United States would assist the Japanese to assume an increasing share of their own defense.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- The leading organs of the Communist party warned today that the most dangerous enemies were those concealed under the mask of communism and declared the party's strength could be maintained only by mercilessly purging itself of all alien and bourgeois elements.

ALBANY, July 15 -- The state's top Republican leadership, headed by Governor Dewey, sent a personal appeal today to the United States Senate to promote passage of legislation that would permit the state, rather than private utilities, to develop Niagara River power.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Liberal flour sales in the Southwest spurred active buying of wheat futures today, the action of the trade reflecting the opinion that big bakers of the country may have missed their market, due to the absence of the usual selling pressure after harvest.

Even a casual study of the waterfront problems indicates that Congressional approval of the bi-state compact must be given now if we are effectively to reform conditions on the waterfront. This is not intended to sound didactic, but the startling fact is that almost everyone who appeared at the hearings before Governor Dewey admitted the need for urgency of action and the validity of reform.

" The Musicians and Petrillo," a new work by Robert D. Leiter, will be published by Bookman Associates on Aug. 12. It is a study of the American Federation of Musicians and a biography of its present head, James Caesar Petrillo. The book also deals with many colorful and leading personalities of the entertainment world.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Following is the 52-to-34 vote by which the Senate defeated today a small business exemption amendment to the excess profits tax extension bill:
The results of a study conducted recently by Cornell University indicate that adolescents in this state are less likely to eat properly than their younger sisters and brothers.

Peter J. Schweitzer, Inc., manufacturer of cigarette papers, has leased a floor in the twenty-eight-story office building being built at 261 Madison Avenue, in the east block-front between Thirty-eighth and Thitry-ninth Streets.

James T. Sherwin of New York, after resigning his adjourned first-round game to Klaus Darga of West Germany, defeated Bent Larsen of Denmark in the second round of the world junior chess championship finals, according to a report from Copenhagen yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Somewhat reduced arrivals of hogs allowed that market to continue holding recent gains today. Trading ruled steady to strong generally although closing clean-up sales were on the weak side.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The United States is taking a cautious look at fresh proposals to help the Chinese Nationalists hold some little islands fringing the South China coast. The islands, from which hit-and-run raids have been staged against the Chinese Communists, have been excluded from the United States protection afforded Formosa since the outbreak of war in Korea.

RICHMOND, Va., July 15 -- Thomas B. Stanley, the wealthy furniture manufacturer who won the Democratic nomination for Governor in yesterday's primary election in Virginia, has a wide political background to carry him into the general election in November.

Among the measures of primary importance that must not be overlooked in the drive for adjournment is the bill for federal development of under-sea natural resources beyond state boundaries on the Continental Shelf. Each house of Congress has passed its own version of this legislation, which is a necessary supplement to -- and to some degree an offset of -- the submerged-lands bill that became law almost two months ago.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 15 -- The United States Embassy informed the Israeli Foreign Ministry today that it had been instructed by Washington to confine its relations with the Foreign Ministry to the ministry office in the Government quarter of Tel Aviv for the time being.

Good gains in motors, steels, aircrafts and oils spotted the New York Stock Exchange list at yesterday's close but there were so many small losses elsewhere that THE NEW YORK TIMES industrial average ended the day with a net loss of 0.01 point.

CAIRO, July 15 -- Egypt has protested strongly to the British Government against measures taken by the British forces in the Suez Canal zone following the disappearance of a British airman -- notably the establishment of roadblocks around Ismailia -- and has demanded that these be lifted.

A two-day public hearing on administration of the city ended yesterday after twenty-three civic leaders had appeared as witnesses, most of them favoring modernization of the city government by appointment of a general manager or deputy mayor to serve as director of administration under the Mayor.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- The Government Operations Committee of the House of Representatives rebelled against Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan, its chairman, today and voted to strip him of authority to appoint special investigating subcommittees.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 15 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan, addressing a joint meeting of the two houses of Parliament, appealed today for an amended Constitution that would allow him to remove South African nationals of mixed blood rom the common electoral roll.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 15 -- The Riverside Yacht Club, with Judy Webb at the helm, today gained the sole lead for the Syce Cup, symbolic of the women's Long Island Sound sailing championship.

LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- Function in furniture is here to stay, Charles Eames, internationally known designer, told members of the Home Fashions League, Inc., at a luncheon meeting today at the Biltmore.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Following is the text of the United States note to the Soviet Government concerning a four-power conference:

An appeal to President Eisenhower to establish a commission of clergymen and educators to draw up a "bold religious Point-Four program" principally designed to fight the "specter of McCarthyism" was urged yesterday by Dr. Maurice N. Eisendrath, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

Nicholas Lana, who lost his city job last March after forty-five years of service under the name of Joseph Porgie, will be back at work in the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity as soon as the necessary red tape can be unwound. He will return to the payroll under his right name with his pension rights intact.

TRENTON, July 15 -- New Jersey chiropractors received limited recognition today as Gov. Alfred F. Driscoll signed a measure providing separate regulation and licensing under the State Board of Medical Examiners, which is composed largely of physicians.

Ruling out any discussion of municipal problems although he has been mentioned as a possible candidate for Mayor, Averell Harriman, former Director for Mutual Security, spoke yesterday about national and international affairs at a meeting of the New York Young Democratic Club.

LONDON, July 15 -- The Soviet axe fell on one of Lavrenti P. Beria's top lieutenants today in a drastic shake-up in his home republic of Georgia that may signal the beginning of a nation-wide purge of the ousted police chief's closest henchmen.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a bill to continue the excess profits tax through Dec. 31, thereby sealing the hardest fought victory of this Congressional session for the Eisenhower Administration.
GALLUP, N. M., July 16 (AP) -- I Mr. Emmons has declared his ad-I i ministration policy as Indian Corn-I missioner would be to "liquidate' the trusteeship of Indians as quickly as possible."
" Daphne," a new comedy by Thaddeus C. Suski, is scheduled for presentation here on Sept. 30 under the sponsorship of Huntington Hartford 2d.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Eisenhower made a strong personal appeal to Congressional appropriations committeemen today against cutting the $5,157,232,000 foreign aid authorization.

A $12,000,000 gain in revenues enabled American Airlines, Inc., to increase its half-year income to $6,658,150 from $5,099,518 in the initial six months last year despite a substantially larger tax bill, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, July 15 -- Looking like a fellow who had just shaken himself loose from a harrowing nightmare, Manager Casey Stengel today sought forgetfulness in the wake of his fourth straight All-Star disaster, in Cincinnati yesterday, by concentrating on his Yankees. Tomorrow they resume pushing on toward that coveted fifth straight American League pennant.

Extraordinary increases of 134 per cent in sales and 129 per cent in earnings made by the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc. in its half-year period, prompted directors yesterday to lift the quarterly dividend to $1 and to give an extra of $1.50 to shareholders on Aug. 19.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Dr. Robert L. Johnson, filling out his last few weeks as head of the State Department's International Information Administration, declared today that many of its "most effective" programs for fighting communism were being damaged by "unsupported charges that they are somehow soft on communism."

The sale of 15-cent tokens for the city's subway and elevated lines should begin at 12:01 A. M. next Wednesday, three days before the higher fare becomes effective, it has been recommended to the New York City Transit Authority by operating officials of the city-owned transit system.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Sales of records exceeded $200,000,000 in 1952, according to a report made here today to the convention of the National Association of Music Merchants. Though this level was said to be well above that of the previous year, the amount of rise was not reported.

Public and private building construction costing many millions of dollars was stopped yesterday or nearing the shutdown stage because of a strike -- now in its second week -- of 1,800 truck drivers who deliver sand, gravel and ready mixed cement.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Documents in support of a Constitutional amendment introduced by Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, to change the Electoral College system were presented to a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 15 -- Lloyd Ribner, New Jersey amateur golf champion, and J. Henry Attas, former Westchester titleholder, combined forces today and captured the British Victory tourney at the Sunningdale Country Club with a best-ball score of 68.
Outstanding profit gains were realized by two steel companies, whose semi-annual reports yesterday -- first of the industry -- disclosed that their sales had established new records for the period.

Maybe it's that Australians don't read American encyclopedias, but according to one such source "the emu has been much diminished in numbers by constant persecution"; according to another "the bird is in danger of extinction." And a third states that "coursing the emu has been carried to such an extent that * * * [it is] now in many parts exterminated."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 15 -- Commenting on information that the Soviet Union was prepared to donate 4,000,000 rubles to the technical assistance program of the United Nations, Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said all contributions would be most welcome.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Congress has a moral obligation to take care of a moonshiner who was crippled for life by a shot fired by a deputy sheriff who was helping "revenoors" raid a still, the United States Court of Claims held today.

An employment program "for the abolition of the shape-up and the establishment of a new system of hiring" was presented yesterday to the New York Shipping Association by the International Longshoremen's Association.

PARIS, July 15 -- The proposal of the Western Big Three powers for a conference with the Soviet Union on Germany and Austria caused great satisfaction in France today even though the negotiation was placed at the level of the foreign ministers instead of at the level of the heads of government, as Sir Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister, had urged.

KITALE, Kenya, July 15 (Reuters) -- Kenya's Supreme Court today wiped out a seven-year hard labor sentence imposed on Jomo (Burning Spear) Kenyatta and five other alleged Mau Mau terrorist leaders but ordered them held in custody for retrial on the original charges.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress for a supplemental appropriation of $150,000,000 for the Department of Agriculture today to provide emergency assistance to farmers ranchers in the drought-ridden and Southwest.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 16 -- United Nations and Communist negotiators met for twenty-four minutes at Panmunjom this morning while enemy propaganda sources bitterly attacked the United States for "secret agreements" with the rebellious South Korean President, Dr. Syngman Rhee.
A galaxy of contemporary chair designs is the star of the summer furniture show at Abraham Straus. In addition to the chairs, there are seventeen newly redecorated model rooms.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Glenn L. Emmons, 57-year-old banker of Gallup, N. M., known as the Indian Capital of the Southwest, was nominated today to be Commissioner of Indian Affairs by President Eisenhower.

Equitable subway and bus fares can be maintained in the future only if tolls are placed on all of Manhattan's bridges to provide funds to help support the city's transportation system, Goodhue Livingston Jr., a member of the City Planning Commission, said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 15 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council set up a new committee today to examine the possibility of giving native peoples a chance to participate in the council's work.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, July 16 (AP) -- Three South Korean divisions rolled forward in a counterattack on the east-central front today and, at first reports, had gained one mile in a push to retake ground lost to the Reds early this week.

The White House statement on the report of the President's Committee on International Information Activities (THE TIMES, July 9) suggests that the report itself is an audacious and highly realistic document which, acted upon, may bring about tremendous results in our struggle with communism.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 15 -- Eight more deputies resigned today from the helpless remains of the Majlis, the lower and sole existing legislative chamber, while the Government indicated it would go ahead with a national referendum designed to send what is left of the House the way of the Senate, which was dissolved last fall.

BOSTON, July 15 (UP) -- A 17-year-old American Legion baseball star warmed the bench during a championship game tonight because the Cleveland Indians, Milwaukee Braves and New York Giants were found guilty of "tampering" with him.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Walter S. Robertson, Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, returned from South Korea today with assurances that the United Nations could now sign a Korean truce "in good faith" if the Communists were ready to follow suit.

LONDON, July 15 -- The Government's methods of suppressing the Mau Mau terrorist society in Kenya were attacked today in the House of Commons by members of the Labor Opposition following the Kenya Supreme Court's ruling that the convictions of Jomo Kenyatta and five other African leaders as Mau Mau leaders were invalid.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- J. B. Matthews, who was ousted as executive director of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations last week after he had charged that the largest single group supporting the Communist apparatus in America was composed of Protestant clergymen, asked the Committee on Un-American Activities of the House of Representatives today for a hearing.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., is preparing to market an improved type of high-tenacity rayon tire yarn, it was announced yesterday. The product, to be sold under the trade name "Super Cordura," is a result of more than eight years of research by du Pont's textile fibers department. It gives promise of safe, stronger tires for automobiles and trucks.

The city of San Antonio, Tex., sold yesterday $10,000,000 of electric and gas revenue bonds due from 1955 to 1976 to a syndicate headed by Union Securities Corporation at a bid of 100.24 for interest of 2.9 per cent, an interest cost of 2.884 per cent.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet and steady yesterday closing 5 points higher to 3 points lower than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Following is the 72-15 vote by which the Senate today ratified a treaty dealing with the status of United States forces stationed in North Atlantic Treaty nations that gives foreign courts authority to try United States soldiers:
GEORGE KELL leaned against the batting cage in Cincinnati the other day and stared reflectively across the field at Ted Williams fighting his way through well-wishers.
BERLIN, July 15 -- The East German Government proposed tonight an immediate conference of delegates from East and West Germany to discuss preparations for "free all-German elections."
The volume of shipbuilding orders in American shipyards declined again in June and has now reached its lowest level in two years, the Shipbuilders Council of America reported yesterday.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program cited the Royal-Liverpool Insurance Group at 150 William Street yesterday for its outstanding support of the program. Since July, 1949, employers of the concern have given 1,400 pints of blood.

I am surprised to find in your paper of July 13 a letter addressed to you by Dr. Herbert V. Evatt expressing his opposition to a revision of the Chinese text of the Genocide Convention. I suspect that Dr. Evatt relied on incorrect and secondhand information.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 8, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today an omnibus $168,155,584 appropriations bill after approving drastic slashes in funds for civil defense, Air Force construction and overseas information activities.
LONDON, July 15 -- Britain's reaction today to the Western Big Three proposal for a four-power foreign ministers' meeting seemed to be that half a loaf was better than no loaf at all.

A Federal sales tax is not favored by American business men as a substitute for income taxes or as a separate tax by itself, according to a survey by the Standard Factors Corporation released yesterday by Theodore H. Silbert, president.

Thousands of Georgian Communists face the prospect of being purged as Beria followers, Georgian exiles in this country commented yesterday after hearing of Mr. Dekanozov's ouster as Minister of Internal Affairs for the Soviet republic of Georgia.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 15 -- One of the most remarkable contemporary experiments in human relations was launched yesterday in London by the royal assent to the Central African Federation Act after it had passed the House of Lords.
Both suburban horticulture and commercial farming in the metropolitan area are suffering severely from a six-week dry spell, farmers and farm agents said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- An important new research program into retrolental fibroplasia, the new disease blinding premature infants, based on the belief that the oxygen used in giving them life may cause the malady, was described today at the annual convention of the American Association of Workers for the Blind.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 16 -- Forty-five thousand Allied troops, supported by swarms of fighter-bombers, tanks and massed artillery, counter-attacked the Communists along the Korean central front bulge today in what was described as the biggest assault by United Nations Command forces in two years.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- Leonard Goldstein's deal with Twentieth Century-Fox to produce independently a series of films for release by the studio was signed today.
TOKYO, Thursday, July 16 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,676, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Tuesday, Korean time:
BONN, Germany, July 15 -- Results of Washington conference of United States, British and French foreign ministers were received here with mixed feelings.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 16--Announcement was made today by Donald C. Mathews, director of the State Park and Forest Commission at Hartford, that an informal agreement to buy for $32,500 a state-owned eleven-acre tract here for the construction of a theatre had been reached by the commission and Lawrence Langner, treasurer of the American Shakespeare Festival theatre and Academy.
SEATTLE, July 16 (AP) -- Two Californians, Irving Cooper of Long Beach and Ted Richards of Santa Monica, today gained the semi-finals of the national public links golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, urged Congress today to let President Eisenhower use "food stockpiles like ammunition stockpiles" in the "cold war."

CLEVELAND, July 16 (AP) -- A grand slam home run by Cleveland's Al Rosen made the difference tonight as the Indians defeated the Athletics, 5 -- 3. Rosen's bases-loaded blow off Mario Fricano broke a scoreless deadlock in the third inning.

Assets of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States increased by $181,380,897 in the first half of this year to a record total of $6,753,075,391, Ray D. Murphy, president, reported yesterday in the society's semi-annual statement.
CHICAGO, July 16 (UP) -- The White Sox rallied today to sweep a double-header from the Senators, 6 to 5 in ten innings and 5 to 4, before 31,136 ladies' day fans.

A dog owner's suit against the Canine University in Putnam, N. Y., was dismissed without prejudice in Municipal Court, Long Island City, Queens, yesterday, shortly before the district attorney's office announced it would investigate a series of complaints against the school.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 16 -- The Long Island Lighting Company filed with the New York State Public Service Commission today revised and simplified electric rate schedules that would become effective Sept. 1 and bring additional revenue of $1,902,000.

BONN, Germany, July 16 -- The West German Government and the Social Democratic party Opposition joined hands today to reject the proposal of the East German Government that a conference be held by representatives of the two governments in Germany to discuss all-German elections.

The Senate has ratified, without a roll-call vote, a three-year renewal of the 1949 International Wheat Agreement.
