Thus at a time when we are pledging ourselves to a continuance of liberal foreign trade policy by extending the Trade Agreements Act without crippling amendments we are riding off in the opposite direction, in a manner of speaking, by continuing as a member of an international commodity cartel which is the antithesis of trade liberalism.

Two war veterans who had applied for a license to operate a carrousel, a penny arcade and other amusement devices in a vacant lot in the Kings Bay section of Brooklyn must have wished they were back in the service yesterday.

ALBANY, July 16 -- A state tax examiner who used to belong to the Communist party today identified thirty-seven persons, including nine state employes, as members of a local party group between 1942 and 1948 but painted a pretty dismal picture of their organization.

A special Brazilian Finance Minister mission met Wednesday with State Department and Export-Import Rank officials with the evident purpose of renegotiating terms of a $300,000,000 loan agreement signed last April 30.

Away winging on a first-inning grand-slam homer by Gil Hodges, the Dodgers last night opened a fifteen-game home stand at Ebbets Field by routing the Cardinals, 9--2, behind the steady eight-hit pitching of Preacher Roe.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Eisenhower, victorious in a hard and bitter fight for extension of the excess-profits tax, is apparently resigned now to seeing Congress adjourn without acting on other phases of his tax program.

Five buildings on a plot 99 by 100 feet at 330-338 West Fifty-fifth Street have been resold by the Archbishopric of New York to Henry Luskin, builder and operator, who plans to raze the present tenements and erect an eleven-story building.

Not easily scared by a rebellious throat, Rosalind Russell is determined to continue in her role as the star of "Wonderful Town." Yesterday Miss Russell said she would not take a rest until Lehman Engel, musical director of the show, couldn't hear her. In the meantime, Dr. Stuart L. Craig is administering treatment.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- Live hogs were steady to 25 cents higher today in a moderately active trade.
TOKYO, Friday, July 17 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,678, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

THERMAL, Calif., July 16 -- An Air Force officer flashed to an air speed record of 715.7 miles an hour today in a North American F-86D Sabe jet. Skimming over the hot beach of Southern California's Salton sea, Lieut. Col. William F. Barhs, 32 years old, broke the record set last -Nov. 19 over the same run by Capt. J. Slade Nash of Edwards Air Force Base.

Production of newsprint in Canada during June amounted to 463,193 tons and shipments to 486,389 tons, it was announced yesterday by the Newsprint Service Bureau. Output in the United States was 90,727 and shipments, 89,640 tons, making total North American output and shipments for June, 553,920 and 576,029 tons, respectively.

Foodstuffs from as far west as Grand Rapids, Mich., and as close as Brooklyn converged by truck, rail and barge yesterday at a Chelsea pier as loading of the first installment of the United States food relief program for East Germany got under way. tons of cargo had been loaded.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Supreme Court was acting clearly within its powers and exercising its responsibility to supervise the administration of criminal justice by the Federal judiciary when it vacated the stay of execution granted by Associate Justice William O. Douglas to Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the atomic spies, Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson held in a formal opinion issued today.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 16 -- Two former champions and two metropolitan contenders reached the semi-final round of the twenty-fourth women's New York State golf championship at the Hempstead Country Club course.

Commercial paper outstanding on the books of dealers surveyed by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York totaled $408,000,000 on June 30. It had declined $33,000,000 during June, a seasonal drop of about 8 per cent. The volume was about 18 per cent below that of June, 1952, and the smallest since September, 1951.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., July 16 -- Bert Schneider and Dorothy Lowenstein of Fenway posted a 38, 36 -- 74 to win the Metropolitan Golf Association's mixed foursomes tournament at the Briar Hall Golf and Country Club today.

Women with good typing or stenographic skills are in great demand for part-time work, according to Miss Sarah Kretchmer, senior interviewer at a special ground-floor office recently set up by the New York Employment Service at 1 East Nineteenth Street to accommodate persons wanting part-time and temporary office jobs.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, said today he believed J. B. Matthews should have an opportunity to tell the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives what he knows about his charges of Communist infiltration among the clergy.
Futures were quiet on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, but the undertone was steady and closing prices were 9 to 23 points net higher than on Wednesday.

BERLIN, July 16 -- Last night's unity proposal by the East German Government has convinced a number of Western officials here that recent events in East Germany and the Kremlin have thrown the Soviet Union off balance and necessitated a delay in its long-awaited bid for a unified, neutralized Germany.
The New York Central and the Chesapeake and Ohio railroads announced yesterday a joint arrangement looking to the building of passenger carrying cars light in weight and lower in cost of operation.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 16 (AP) -- Stanton Hal, owned by Mrs. William Haris of Massapequa, L. I., scored an easy victory tonight in the Orient Beach Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

The recent approval by the Federal Court of the payment of $2,046,831 in city taxes by the Long Island Rail Road, which effected a total saving of $6,744,623 of the road's total tax accruals, has enabled the bankrupt carrier to show an estimated net income of $327,790 for the current year, William Wyer, trustee for the railroad declared yesterday.

SEATTLE, July 16 (AP) -- The Seattle local of the American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., struck The Seattle Times today in a dispute over wages and some other contract provisions and the newspaper suspended publication.

CAIRO, July 16 -- The British forces relaxed their security cordon around the Suez Canal zone city of Ismailia today as part of an effort to recover what is openly and universally listed here as a major diplomatic fumble -- the issuance of an ultimatum to the Egyptian Government in connection with the disappearance of a Royal Air Force enlisted man.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The United Nations has handed a firm but not bellicose message to the Communists in the Korean truce talks, setting forth the view that they have all the assurances they need that South Korea will comply with an armistice.

With a buyers' market developing in many phases of the economy, two important sources reported yesterday that manufacturers and distributors were turning to advertising in a way that will produce more expenditures in many media than ever before.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Without a single voice being raised in dissent, the Senate passed today a bill giving Congressional approval to the bi-state compact under which New York and New Jersey hope to end crime and racketeering on the New York waterfront.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -Prompt passage of pending bills to permit sale of properties held by the Office of Alien Property regardless of lawsuits pending against them would be in the public interest and accelerate the removal of the Government from private business, the Department of Justice today advised the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

Yesterday provided some devastating illustrations of how thin the stock market has become. The volume was 790,000 shares and 1,008 issues were traded, which means an average volume of fewer than 800 shares an issue. The turnover in the most active stock, Lockheed, was only 12,900 shares. One of the leaders, Bethlehem Steel, had a volume of only 1,300 shares, and 500 shares of them were traded in the final thirty minutes.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., July 16 (AP) -- The Government today agreed to a stipulation offered by defense counsel that Lieut. Sheppard C. Thierman had not been involved in subversive activities while in Korea. The 31-year-old Medical Corps officer from Brooklyn, N. Y., is charged under Army Court-Martial with having obtained his commission fraudulently by concealing Communist party membership.

ON THE CENTRAL FRONT, in Korea, Friday, July 17 -- Allied artillery hurled shell after shell head on at advancing enemy forces early this morning to break and shatter a concen trated Chinese Communist offensive short of the Kumhwa Valley, which leads to the capital city of Seoul.

West Chester Area Joint School Authority, Pa., sold yesterday $1,800,000 of revenue bonds due from 1955 to 1978 to Blyth Co., Inc., and associates at a bid of 98.50 for a net interest cost of 3.1625 per cent. The issue, consisting of twenty-two coupon maturities, was reoffered at yields ranging from 1.80 per cent to 3.35 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 16 -- Allied Artists will immediately embark upon its most ambitious program, calling for the production of at least thirty-six films during the next twelve months with twenty scheduled to be made before the end of 1953, according to Walter Mirisch, executive producer.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Civil Service Commission moved in today to protect the rights of 102 employes discharged by the National Production Authority on June 30. An equal number of workers was assigned to the new Business Services Administration, which succeeded the National Production Authority, but these workers had less job-retention rights than those discharged.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Senate adopted and sent to the House of Representatives today a proposed amendment to the Constitution that would guarantee equal rights for women under Federal and state laws, but would protect present or future legal privileges granted to women.
LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- The Kremlin's big shake-up spread to the Soviet Ukraine today with the purge of another lieutenant of Lavrenti P. Beria, the ousted Russian Deputy Premier and police bossA.

DALLAS, July 16 (UP) -- Up to three inches of rain and an inch of hail pounded Fort Worth today and weather forecasters predicted rain for nearly all of drought-stricken Texas. Fort Worth had hired a rainmaker just before the storm broke.

Remmie L. Arnold of Petersburg, Va., a 59-year-old pen manufacturer, became yesterday the sixty-fourth Imperial Potentate of the Ancient Order of Nobles of the Mystic Shrine and the head for the next twelve months of some 700,000 Shriners in the United States, Canada and Mexico.
DETROIT, July 16 (AP) -- A pair of 380-foot home runs by Gene Stephens and Jim Piersall gave the Red Sox a 3-2 victory over the Tigers tonight.
The truce negotiations in Korea were recessed again -- and perhaps stalled --yesterday, but the Communists still used the arguments of force in the largest drive they had launched since 1951.

PARIS, July 16 -- The United States, Britain and France have invited Yugoslavia to send a military mission to Washington in order to discuss defensive planning and other problems with the Western Big Three powers and it is understood that Marshal Tito's Government has accepted the invitation.

A collection of biographical sketches of "rebellious" American women who broke with tradition in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries will be published Aug. 24 by Farrar, Straus Young. The author is Helen Beal Woodward, and among those she discusses in "The Bold Women" are Anne Royall, newspaperwoman-lobbyist: Fanny Wright, who fought for trade unionism, and Jane Swisshelm, burned in effigy as "the mother of the Republican party."

MOSCOW, Friday, July 17 -- The first report on Soviet industrial production to be issued this year showed today that output was up 10 per cent above last year. It said production goals had been fulfilled 100 per cent as a whole, although six categories of industry were slightly below the target figure.

BERNARDSVILLE, N. J. -- Mrs. William Tracy, Glen Ridge, carded a 74 today to take the lead after three days of play in the Elizabeth Goss round-robin golf tournament over the Somerset Hills course here.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 16 (AP) -- F. Ambrose Clark's Acefull displayed unexpected speed at Monmouth Park today and outraced the front-running Blue Rhymer to win the $5,000 American Legion Purse before 17,787 spectators.
A strike that had forced sixty well-known Manhattan restaurants to close for three days was settled yesterday. A few places reopened last night, but most were planning to resume operations today.

The body of Florence Forsberg, 25 years old, a singer and a member of the cast in a Broadway musical hit, who had been stabbed several times, was found in her apartment at 34 West Sixty-ninth Street yesterday morning. The discovery was made a short time after a Korean war veteran had shot and killed himself in his apartment at 255 West 108th Street, leaving a note confessing to the singer's death.

On record sales of $1,560,448,000, the General Electric Company earned $75,417,000 in the first half of this year. This was the second-highest income for any six months in the company's history, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday by Ralph J. Cordiner, president.

IF a fellow has sharp ears and a durable constitution, he can pick up considerable information by merely listening to the endless conversation that flows at any baseball gathering. That goes for the All-Star game, the world series, the winter meetings or wherever the clan assembles. Not all the information is important, of course.

LOS ANGELES, July 16 -- Fifty thousand Boy Scouts from all parts of this country and several foreign lands converged tonight on a 3,000-acre tract of sunbaked ranchland forty miles south of this city for their organization's third national jamboree.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Courses to train young blind persons to be able to travel about independently, and offered only in the last ten years, won the praise today of Paul J. Langan, superintendent of the Kentucky School for the Blind, as opening up a new world of employment opportunities for the sightless.

A series of half-hour programs on which diplomatic representatives of Latin-American nations will be interviewed will begin at noon on Sunday, July 26, over C. B. S. radio. The program follows a path already shaped by a similar series on the internal and external affairs of Asian, Middle Eastern and European nations.

EVERY Tuesday afternoon throughout the summer a massive six-footer, white-haired, mahogany-browned and bearing his 83 years with astonishing buoyancy, flies or takes rail passage from Boston to New York to put on night fireworks shows on a barge off Coney Island.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- West Point cadets and naval midshipmen may get a rise in pay. Boards of Visitors to the two service academies reported today that the student officers were underpaid, whereupon President Eisenhower requested Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, to submit recommendations "to alleviate the situation."

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 16 -- In a signed confession introduced today by the prosecution at the resumption of the military trial of eleven men and three women charged with belonging to a terrorist organization, Pvt. Yefet Taize of the Israeli Army, one of the defendants, said he had pledged during his initiation to fight for the "overthrow of the regime of the state of Israel."
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -- The Public Health Service announced today that 949 new polio cases were reported last week, compared with 1,004 in the correspondingly last year.

The new dean of Fordham University's Graduate School of Arts and Sciences will be the Rev. Arthur A. North, former dean of the Graduate and Evening Schools of Loyola College, Baltimore. The appointment was announced yesterday by Fordham's president, the Very Rev. Laurence J. McGinley.

We welcome heartily not only your interest in the problem of the rising aggregate cost of pensions in the budget of the City of New York but also your recognition of its critical nature in terms of municipal finance and the necessity for action to meet the problems posed.

Volume on the New York Stock Exchange dropped away yesterday to the lowest level since July 21 of last year as prices went through a day of erratic fluctuations. Almost every major group ended the day mixed.

NEW DELHI, India, July 16 -- The dissident Dravidians of Madras state in South India, descendants of the race that occupied most of India before the Aryan invasion about 3,000 years ago, are in the third day of violent demonstrations against the Government that have cost at least six lives and seriously disrupted railway service throughout the lower part of the peninsula.

Shipments of rayon and acetate yarn and staple in June by United States producers were 108,500,000 pounds, a decline of a half of one per cent from the previous month, according to a report issued by the Textile Organon, statistical bulletin of the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

The right of Hawaii and Alaska to statehood has long since been demonstrated, and the continued failure of Congress to grant them that right does little credit to Congress. But there is another group of Americans, much closer home, to whom Congress has thus far refused even the elementary principle of self-government, which the Hawaiians and the Alaskans have had for years.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee voted today, 11 to 3, to create a Small Business Administration, authorized to lend money to and otherwise assist smaller enterprise. It also provided for a temporary rather than permanent agency.
LONDON, July 16 -- Queen Elizabeth II entertained 7,500 guests day in her garden at Buckingham Palace in the rain.
The rise of about 25 cents a barrel in the price of crude oil that began in the United States a month ago has spread to all important producing areas throughout the world.
ST. PAUL, July 16 (AP) -- Jimmy Clark and Ted Rhodes scored 66's today to spearhead a par-crushing field in the opening round of the $15,000 St. Paul open golf tournament.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 16 -- The New Zealand Government has an embarrassing thirty tons of war medals that it cannot give away. It ordered the medals for all the 300,000 World War II veterans entitled to them but only 60,000 have applied.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 16 (Reuters) -- Chinese Nationalist guerrillas have captured Communist-held Tungshan Island in their biggest raid since Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's government was forced off the Chinese mainland in 1949.

Other major zinc producers and refiners declined to go along yesterday with the American Smelting and Refining Company's action on Wednesday in abandoning the industry's traditional East St. Louis basing point system for pricing prime Western grade zinc.

MOSCOW, July 16 -- The Soviet armed forces have pledged full support of the Government and party in the action taken against Lavrenti P. Beria, former First Deputy Premier, who now faces trial for treason.
GREAT NECK, L. I., July 16 -- Light-hearted and confident, Yves Bertranet, a 33-year-old French engineer, prepared today for his take-off at 11 A. M. Saturday on a sailing trip to Europe.
The second, third and fourth seeded players were eliminated from the Eastern junior tennis championships in the quarter-final round yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

The taxpayer building known as Market Square at Power House and Roslyn Roads in East Park, L. I., has been sold by Levitt Sons to Jack Brause, investor. The building, containing a super market and three other stores, was erected by the Levitt interests to serve their housing developments.

CENTRAL CITY, Colo., July 16 -- The revival of Nicolai's "Merry Wives of Windsor" witnessed here last night in the little Central City Opera House of historic fame, must be ranked as one of the most distinguished and delightful productions that Central City Opera Festival has given in many seasons.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Lacking any important mill buying of futures, the wheat market was inclined to drag today and rallies were hard to hold. Flour buyers appeared to be satisfied for the time being and the outside demand in general was slow except on the moderate recessions.

ST. LOUIS, July 16 -- The Yankees cracked head on into something they didn't expect as they opened their third Western tour of the year tonight with an even break against the lowly but still rambunctious Browns in a twilight-night double-header.
LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- Big city bookmakers took a bad beating on a horse today -- all because of a telephone breakdown.

LONDON, July 16 -- A committee appointed last September to study means of preventing oil pollution of the waters around the United Kingdom reported to the Government today that only international action could end the nuisance.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A union publication's friendly view of the activities of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, stirred lively discussion in labor circles today.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, in a 2,000-word letter to the three Democrats who resigned last week from his Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, urged them to return to duty today, but in effect they blew out the candle he had put in the window.
Running races under a blazing sun was how members of the Police Athletic League tried to forget the heat yesterday on forty-five play streets and eleven playgrounds.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Shippers added their plea today before a Senate Commerce subcommittee for an adequate merchant marine and a consistent Federal policy toward its maintenance.

TOKYO, Friday, July 17 -- As the armistice negotiations at Panmunjom, Korea, stood in recess today, the Chinese Communists renewed their charges that the United States had made secret agreements with Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President, that could add to his "potentialities" to wreck a truce.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 16 -New cuts planned in Brazil's imports, even of essential items, are so drastic some Brazilian industrial circles assert they will hamper the country's power to overcome the dollar deficit.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., July 16 -- This city was saddled with horse trouble early today. Forty thoroughbreds, Palominos and quarter-horses escaped through a break in the barbed-wire corral at the Peekskill Dude Ranch shortly after midnight and trotted three miles northward on the concrete pavement of Maple Avenue into the business section.

The beginning of the new fiscal year in Nationalist China has been marked by two forward steps in administration. The first is the creation of a new Economic Stabilization Board that will take over the functions of a large number of scattered organizations and bring provincial and national economic policies into closer coordination.

Amid political overtones and under sunny skies, the City Hall reporters met and conquered a soft ball team of City Councilmen in a seven-inning game yesterday at the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island. The score was 17 to 6.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- United States department stores sales in the week ended on Saturday were 11 per cent above those in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

There is bitter irony in the fact that just at the time when there seemed to be a substantial prospect of truce in Korea there should have been launched the heaviest Communist attack in many months and now a severe counter-attack. More lives are being lost at a time when we had hoped they could be saved.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The steaming blanket over Washington that is the local substitute for summer air is in place again after having been blown away for a few days by winds from Canada, and its irritating effect on the political community has always been noticeable about this time despite the arrival of air conditioning.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 16 -- James A. Farley, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said here today that much of the criticism of the recent elimination of certain books from the overseas libraries of the United States Information Service was "hysteria" on the part of persons who had not ascertained the facts.

LONDON, July 16 -- British Government issues led the securities markets here today with a general advance of up to five-sixteenths of 1 per cent. Prices of other securities also rose, though the volume of business expanded only slightly.

YONKERS, July 16 -- Doris Knoeppel, Cliffside Park, N. J., and Carol La Roza, Westfield, N. J., won the junior division doubles championship of the girls' Eastern clay courts tennis tournament today at the Amackassin Club. They defeated Georgia Carrington, Montclair, and Barbara Sturges, Westfield, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.

Ten Government-owned cargo ships used for carrying military supplies will be returned soon to lay-up fleets to make way for privately owned American tonnage looking for business in a slow shipping market.

PARIS, July 16 -- Voting 339 to 252 to shelve discussion of the Bastille Day riots, the National Assembly tonight began debate on changes in the French Constitution. It is hoped the changes will pass on the first reading before the Assembly adjourns, about July 24, for its summer recess.

LONDON, July 16 -- When and whether there will be a conference with the Soviet Union at the highest level will depend on the outcome of a foreign ministers' meeting to which the Soviet Government has been invited, R. A. Butler, acting Chairman of the British Cabinet, indicated today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (UP) -- Gran Hamner hit a two-run homer in the eight inning tonight to give the Phillies a 3-2 victory over the Redlegs in the second game of a double-header. A bases-loaded double by Smoky Burgess gave the Phils a 3-1 victory in the opener.

I am very much interested in the editorial entitled "Communist Dominated Unions" which appeared in the July 1 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES and which relates to legislation I have introduced in the United States Senate.

Facts of Life made her record two for two yesterday. The 3-year-old filly that runs in the colors of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt engaged in the second race of her career in the feature event on the Empire City-at-Jamaica program, and she scored by a nose over C. V. Whitney's White Witch.
A six-year program for the construction of 312 new schools and additions at a cost of $500,000,000 was approved yesterday by the Board of Education for inclusion in its capital budget request.

Lewisohn Stadium last night offered to New York music lovers an event peculiarly its own, the annual all-Gershwin concert with Alexander Smallens conducting the Stadium Symphony Orchestra, and with Oscar Levant playing the Concerto in F and the "Rhapsody in Blue."
Familiar and unfamiliar paintings, both American and French, are included in three of the local exhibitions now enlivening an otherwise quiet period in the art world.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 16 -- Dr. O. Frederick Nolde of Philadelphia, a Protestant leader, said today that he had "frankly" informed President Syngman Rhee of South Korea on a recent visit to Seoul that the Christian world disagreed with any obstruction of a truce in the Korean war and favored a prompt armistice on United Nations terms.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 16 -- Judy Webb of the Riverside Yacht Club appeared likely to regain the women's Long Island Sound sailing championship she won in 1951 after finishing second in the sixth and seventh races of the series today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 16 -- The devaluation of Israel's currency and the abolition of the present system of multiple exchange rates are among the fiscal reforms advocated by a committee of nine experts appointed by Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion to investigate the possibility of decontrolling foreign currency.

Business loans of New York City banks for the week ended on Wednesday rose moderately for the second successive time according to a report of the Federal Reserve Bank here. Commercial, industrial and agricultural credits rose, $19,000,000, compared with an increase of $10,000,000 the week before.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 (UP) -The Pirates broke a ten-game losing streak tonight by stealing four bases in a four-run fourth inning to defeat the Braves, 5--2.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- During the week ended July 15, member bank reserves decreased $293,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

When a child must be separated, perhaps permanently, from one or both of his parents, it may seem easier to the adults who take over his care to let the absent mother or dad just fade out of his life. But this "fade-out" is not so easily accomplished, according to Dr. Ralph D. Rabinovitch, chief of the children's service at the University of Michigan's Neuropsychiatric Institute.

BUENOS AIRES, July. 16 -- Disappointed by the reaction of the nation's major opposition party, President Juan Peron, through his Minister of the Interior, Angel Borlenghi, today dashed all hopes of a general amnesty of political prisoners.

What seems a perennial problem is now much in evidence in New York. This is the matter of begging by the blind in public places. They pass on busy streets and in our subway trains, with their pleading cups before them, sometimes with plaintive murmurings or chanting a lugubrious song. There is often ready and eager response to their appeals from the easily moved but unthinking public.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 16 -- Six Arab states complained formally to the United Nations today that Israel's transfer of her Foreign Office from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem was a "fresh blow" at Middle East peace.

HONOLULU, July 16 (AP) -- The yachts Chiriqui and Chubasco fought for handicap honors in the trans-Pacific race today as the ninety-six-foot ketch Morning Star crossed the finish line second but out of the handicap running.

Dishes cool and refreshing are in demand to tempt the palate on days when temperatures soar. Fresh fruits in season add piquancy to desserts such as Bavarian cream or tapioca. Or a tall frosty drink might present the delightful taste combination of pineapple and fresh mint.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 16 -- One of the more pleasant customs of television in Britain and on the Continent is to use a video hostess, a young lady who introduces the evening's program, fills in the intervals between attractions and serves as a liaison with the viewer.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 16 (UP) -- President Marcos Perez Jimenez has given up the post of Defense Minister in a cabinet shake-up which also affected five other government portfolios, it was announced today.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, July 17 (AP) -- A frontline report said the Chinese hurled a new battalion-strength counter-attack south of Kumsong early today, but the South Koreans turned it back after about an hour and kept pressing north.

PARIS, July 16 -- Pattern is all-important in the new silks, rayons and velvets being shown here. They reflect the influence of prints that returned to favor this summer. In them are blended two or more of the season's colors: the dark rich blues, moss, olive and bronze greens, burgundy, prune or egg-plant shades, charcoal gray, brown, or the softer muted beiges, nutshell and fur browns, the golden hue of cognac.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 16 (Reuters) -- A Danish shipyard launched a new 13,000-ton tanker, the Tuapse, for the Soviet Union here today. The vessel is the second built by the Burmeister and Wain yards here for the Russians under a 1948 contract.

VIENNA, July 16 -- While his 6-year-old daughter, Eva, played with her doll, Dr. Geza Kapus, escaped Budapest lawyer, told foreign newspaper men today the hopes of the Hungarian people had soared when Premier Imre Nagy proclaimed his new economic policy a week ago Saturday but dropped again when Matyas Rakosi, Communist leader, had watered down the promises a week later.

A Brooklyn housewife squared off in Flatbush Magistrate's Court yesterday against a battery of lawyers representing the air-conditioning industry and won a new hearing in her efforts to have a neighbor's noisy room cooler unplugged.

TRENTON, July 16 -- Freed from State Prison and temporarily past two more brushes with the law, Joe Adonis, gambler, headed tonight for his Palisades Park, N. J., home and the first night's sleep in his own bed in twenty-six months.

Futures on the New York commodity exchanges closed irregular yesterday. Although volume continued to ease generally, zinc registered the most trades since May 27. Zinc, coffee, cocoa, hides and rubber ended lower; cottonseed oil, soybean oil, sugar, lead and potatoes, higher, and copper, wool and tin, mixed.

Another exhibit pointing up the alliance between fine and applied arts, this entitled "Leather Originals," will open at the Brooklyn Museum today. Arranged by the Leather Industries of America in collaboration with the Edward C. Blum Industrial Design Laboratory at the museum, the exhibit had a preview last night in conjunction with a style show.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., July 16 --Approximately 18,000 nonunion employes of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation today received increases in wages, salaries and pension benefits. The pay rise, effective as of July 1, is the ninth since mid-1946.
Retail meat prices rose sharply this week as a result of wholesale increases in beef described by some members of the trade as the most spectacular in at least thirty years.

NEW DELHI, July 16 -- In response to representations from the Ceylon Government, India has agreed to liberalize its restrictive import policy and to buy through private trade channels the entire quantity of tobacco grown in Jaffna for the next four years.

Your correspondent described on July 10 how Secretary of State John Foster Dulles was compelled to fight a tough and courageous battle in the Senate Appropriations Committee against those who would cut the heart out of the pending foreign-aid bill.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -Japan is scheduled to get between $125,000,000 and $150,000,000 in United States aid this fiscal year for partial rearmament under the Mutual Security Act.

Plans to form a United States national committee unit of the International Cargo Handling Coordination Association are being made in response to many requests by American shipping industry concerns, it has been revealed here.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- Grant Golden of Wilmette, Ill., seeded No. 8, today upset the defender, Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., to advance to the semi-finals of the national clay courts tennis tournament along with the top-seeded Vic Seixas.
David E. Durst has been appointed manager of industrial relations of the international division of United States Rubber Company.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 16 -- A high Iranian Government official said tonight that Premier Mohammed Mossadegh might decree the dissolution of the Majlis, the lower and sole existing legislative chamber, after a plebiscite, thus bypassing imperial authority.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -The Post Office Committee of the House of Representatives decided today it would be "rather undignified" to have beer advertisements on mail trucks but otherwise reached no conclusion in its consideration of proposed higher postal rates.

Although there has been a marked decline in the death rate from tuberculosis, there was a 5 per cent increase in the number of new cases here in the first three months of 1953 compared with the same period last year.

The remarks offered in Lester A. Walton's communication regarding the more or less synonymous use of the words "slum" and "Harlem" by THE NEW YORK TIMES in a recent article constitute an unduly subjective view of a complex matter. As a tour of that northerly portion of our city will disclose, more than half of the housing clearly is in a state of disrepair.
The five Democratic county leaders held a five-hour session last night and adjourned without designating a candidate for Mayor.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -The House Committee on Un-American Activities agreed today to hear persons accused of being Communists or involved in Red activities.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- The Medal of Honor, the nation's highest award for valor, was presented this afternoon to the widow of a Camden, N. J., sailor who sacrificed his life to save two wounded Marines in Korea.

THE week-end prospects are excellent, at least for the salt-water angler, and reports from Barnegat to Cape Cod indicate a real variety, but the picture seems even brighter in the northern zone of this strip.
Six hundred lumber truck drivers yesterday joined the strike of building material teamsters that has slowed or halted millions of dollars worth of public and private construction.

It looked bad for Sal Maglie and the Giants when Hank Sauer teed off with a three-run homer, handing the Cubs a 3-0 lead in the first inning at the Polo Grounds last night. But in the end Manager Leo Durocher's aroused athletes, who had won eight out of nine prior to the All-Star break, romped home with a 10-3 victory, with Whitey Lockman, Don Mueller and Alvin Dark connecting for round-trippers.

Seven vacant parcels of land in Brooklyn and one in the Bronx were sold at auction by the City of New York yesterday for a total of $87,450. The sale, conducted by Fred Berger of the auctioneering concern bearing his name, was held in the Municipal Building under the direction of William M. Ellard, director of the Bureau of Real Estate.

President Eisenhower has done the natural and humane thing in asking Congress for a supplemental appropriation of $150,000,000 to relieve farmers and ranchers now threatened with ruin by the drought in the Southwest. They need feed, credit, a chance to market their stock in the normal way without sacrificial price cuts.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- An Appropriations subcommittee of the House of Representatives voted today to cut $1,100,000,000 from President Eisenhower's foreign aid program. The recommendation required only the formality of full committee approval to be written into the appropriation bill and this was a foregone conclusion.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 14--Various attempts have been made on Washington's Capitol Hill recently to force the French to grant complete independence to the Associated States of Indo-China. However, when well informed officials here talk about a new political strategy in this peninsula they mean something much more than a French promise to go home.
Four new foreign-flag ships are scheduled to call at New York for the first time within the next seven weeks, three of them on their maiden voyages.

The New York Council of the American Association of Advertising Agencies is obviating the necessity for the "Boy Wanted" -and the "Girl Wanted" sign too -in the windows of its members. It is distributing this week a list of sixty-nine boys and girls who passed successfully the aptitude tests given by the association to some 200 college students from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut last spring.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 16 -- Nguyen Van Tam, Premier of Vietnam, said here today he was prepared to demand a revision of all agreements between his country and France that constitute an infringement on Vietnamese sovereignty.

Whenever common sense and fair play win out in a Senate vote one is likely to find the name of Senator McCarthy of Wisconsin among the dissenters. It was so on Wednesday when an amendment to the North Atlantic Treaty passed by a vote of 72 to 15. Mr. McCarthy had congenial company in Senators Jenner, Bricker and Dirksen on the Republican side and Senator McCarran on the Democratic side.

The pilot boat Sandy Hook of the New York and New Jersey Pilots Association was placed in commission yesterday afternoon at Pier 18, Clifton, S. I. She went on duty last night off the Ambrose Lightship at the entrance to New York Harbor.

EASTHAMPTON, Mass., July 16 (AP) -- The National Americanism Committee of the American Legion today reinstated Frank Lejac, suspended 17-year-old first baseman for the Easthampton Post junior Legion team.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 11, 1953, were 721,454 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The State Insurance Department began yesterday an investigation to determine whether it should clamp down on the payment by insurance companies of fees to the administrators of union -management welfare funds.

The buying of securities for their investment portfolios by 111 open-end investment companies, or mutual funds, substantially exceeded sales of securities in the three months to June 30, a period of generally declining markets, the National Association of Investment Companies announced yesterday.
LONDON, July 16 -- United States-British talks in Washington on the future of the British military base in the Suez Canal zone were being discussed privately today at the Foreign Office.
Earnings of the Caterpillar Tractor Company for the quarter and six months ended June 30 fell behind those of a year ago, reflecting a lower sales volume, the concern's report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today President Eisenhower's appointment of Miss Frances Willis, a career diplomat, as first United States Ambassador to Switzerland.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- An Armed Services subcommittee of the House of Representatives today deferred action on an Air Force proposal to spend $3,745,000 for land acquisition and other purposes at the proposed Plattsburg, New York, strategic bomber base.
Waves of red-fezzed Shriners, festooned in oriental raiment, inundated Times Square last night and converted that mecca of generations of theatre hopefuls into their own exuberant playground.

CARDIFF, Wales, July 16 -- The British are more susceptible to pains in the neck -- an illness known in this country as fibrositis -- than any other peoples in the world, according to several speakers at a symposium on the subject at today's annual general meeting of the British Medical Association here.

Nowhere is more profound joy and sadness squeezed into each twenty-four hours than in the hospital. Around the clock, day after day, in every general hospital of the city the balance wheel continues on its interminable path. Children are born. men and women die, suffering is eased, pain is ended.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Senators avoided a decision in the controversy over funds and size of the Air Force tonight by passing it on to the full Appropriations Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to permit Federal Food and Drug Administration inspectors to enter factories without warrants or the owner's permission. The Supreme Court ruled in December that the present Food and Drug Act did not clearly grant to Federal inspectors these powers.

I noted with considerable interest the editorial in THE TIMES of July 9 "Double Victory." In substance it relates to the action on the excess profits tax -- the victory being credited to the Administration and the President.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- White House political advisers are seeking new top leadership for the Citizens for Eisenhower organization, which is being revised to help rally independent voters behind Republican Congressional candidates in the crucial 1954 midterm elections.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- George Maxman, attorney and a Republican member of the Philadelphia City Council from 1936 until 1952, was drowned today while canoeing at Averill, Vt., a summer lake resort on the Canadian border.
FRESNO, Calif., July 16--A suit to halt wastage of natural gas in the Coalinga Nose oil field was filed in Fresno County Superior Court today by Attorney General Edmund G. Brown.

BOSTON, July 16 -- The Federal Communications Commission today granted a license for this city's first educational television station, with Channel 2 being assigned to the Lowell Institute Cooperative Broadcasting Council.

ATHENS, July 16 -- A responsible governmental source said tonight that the Soviet Union had asked Greece to approve the sending of an ambassador to Athens. He added that the Greek Government would approve and ask for reciprocity.

MONTICELLO, Ill., July 16 -- The Institute on International Trade at the University of Illinois, in conference at the Allerton House here, was told today by a foreign exchange expert that world trade transactions stemming from the sale of overvalued foreign currencies at less than the official rates could be "vastly increased" if the reluctance of American business men to participate in such transactions could be overcome.

A 65-year-old retired waiter, who put his life savings into a four-story brownstone building last year and planned to take it easy, found himself yesterday on "probation" until he clears up thirty-eight housing violations the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission listed on the building at 146 West Sixty-fourth Street.
GUATEMALA, July 16 (Reuters) -- Guatemala power plant employes resumed work tonight in the United States-owned Empresa Electrica Power Company, seized during the day by the left-wing Government.
Ephraim F. Jeffe, the only member of the New York City Transit Authority to vote against the increase in the transit fare from 10 to 15 cents, has submitted his resignation to Mayor Impellitteri.
Kentucky i The State of Kentucky announced yesterday that it will offer for sale on Aug. 7 an issue of $4,361,000 of bridge revenue bonds dated July 1, 1953 and due July 1 1954 to 1983.
LONDON, July 17 (Reuters) -- Middlesex maintained a six-point lead in the county cricket championship table today although its match with Derbyshire was abandoned because of rain.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- In a rare outburst, members of the House Government Operations Committee took the House floor today to attack their 77-year-old chairman, Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan.

COLUMBIA, S. C., July 17 (AP) -- William A. Kimbel of Murrell's Inlet, state chairman of Citizens for Eisenhower in the 1952 Presidential campaign, was named Republican national committeeman for South Carolina today. State executive committee members said to represent a majority of that body voted for a complete shake-up of the party organization.

ON THE CENTRAL FRONT, in Korea, Saturday, July 18 -- A blazing artillery duel between guns of the Allies and the Chinese Reds cast eerie shadows last night over the "Sniper Ridge" sector. The skies were splashed with crimson from the muzzle flames and bursting shells.

A fictionalized biography of the Minnesota progressive, Ignatius Donnelly, is one of two books published today. Issued by Vantage Press at $3.50, the biography is titled "North Star Sage" and is written by Oscar M. Sullivan. The second book, also published by Vantage, is "What Every Person Should Know About Jury Trials," by Samuel W. McCart.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 17 -- A woman was killed and four other persons, including Vasilije Milovanovic, financial counselor of the Yugoslav Embassy in Washington, were seriously injured at 6 P. M. here today when Mr. Milovanovic lost control of his car on the Merritt Parkway and crashed head-on into another automobile.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 17 -- Harvard University has re-opened the case of a woman faculty member accused of having been a Communist and has suspended her with pay.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 17 (AP) -- A fire which the police said was set deliberately scorched heavy rolls of newsprint at The Atlantic City Press plant today as a strike of the paper's five stereotypers went into its second day. The small blaze was doused by a sprinkler system shortly after it started at about 3 A. M.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- Jeanne Crain, Dana Andrews, George Marshall, the director, and Tony Owen, the producer, will leave shortly for Johannesburg to film "Duel in The Jungle."

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, July 18 -- South Korean infantry advancing in the battle-devastated Kumsong River valley recovered as much as five and a half miles of ground but ran into stiff Communist resistance today as they drew near the Reds' new main defense line.
New York's weather set three new heat records yesterday as the temperature skyrocketed to 95.8 degrees at 7:15 P. M., but the low humidity mitigated the discomfort of this hottest day of the year.
Your editorial of July 2 "Abating a Nuisance" has been read with considerable interest, particularly as it pertains to Newark Airport, operated by the Port of New York Authority.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 17 -- The Newport of an earlier day than the one generally known is revealing unsuspected riches these days as, more and more, this old town uncovers from the heyday of its long past an astonishing heritage.

Soviet censorship over outgoing dispatches from foreign correspondents in Moscow apparently has increased very sharply in severity since the first news of the purge of Lavrenti P. Beria, First Deputy Premier and Minister of Internal Affairs.
PARIS, July 17 (AP) -- H. O. Pickworth, a 37-year-old Australian pro, today stroked his way into the lead in the French open golf championship with sub-par rounds of 69 and 67.

Many a good man who spent four years in the service during the Second World War found that the white paper he was given at the end of it no more changed him into a civilian overnight than did the khaki uniform he was handed four years before magically transform him into the complete soldier.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Congres is likely to adjourn without acting on the Administration's request for higher postal rates, Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, reported today. The acting majority leader in the Senate also indicated that a proposal by Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, for a constitutional amendment restricting the Government's treaty-making powers would not come to a vote this session.

The New Jersey Zinc Company and the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company increased the prices of high grade and special high grade zinc by 1/4 per cent a pound yesterday. This move brought their prices of high grade to 12.60 cents a pound east of the Rockies and 12.85 cents west of the Rockies, and of special high grade to 12.75 cents east of the Rockies and 13 cents in the Far West.

" General" approval of the plan for a war chest for the International Longshoremen's Association for its fight upon the constitutionality of recent New York-New Jersey waterfront control laws was indicated by union officials yesterday.

The editorial published in your July 5 issue under the heading "A Wise Course in Egypt" shows approval of the new policy launched by President Naguib, which gives more attention to internal problems and the country's economic difficulties. I agree with you that internal problems were, still are, and will always remain of importance to the new regime, which fully believes in the inherent strength of the people.

GENEVA, July 17 -- There is a good chance that the next moves toward getting rid of the economic crutches Western Europe has felt it necessary to employ since World War II may include some that are of direct benefit to the United States.
DETROIT, July 17 (AP) -- Car and truck output in the United States this week will total 164,746 units, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Buying of wheat gained momentum today largely on commission house support, causing uneasiness among the shorts. Light country offerings, tight cash trade conditions, especially at outside markets, and concern over reports that rust had reached damaging proportions in some Northwest areas were all constructive factors.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today $34,511,302,000 in appropriations for the Army, Navy and Air Force in the fiscal year ending June 30, 1954, along with unexpended balances estimated around $57,600,000,000. Senate debate on the bill is scheduled for next Wednesday.

The eight-day convention of the New World Society Assembly of Jehovah's Witnesses will open at 9:30 A. M. tomorrow at Yankee Stadium, where at least 70,000 zealous followers of the faith will be on hand to praise God and to look "neither East nor West, but heavenward."

In Paris Gen. Henri-Eugene Navarre, Commander in Chief of French Union forces in Indo-China, has been presenting his three-point plan for victory. M. Bidault, the Foreign Minister, has conveyed the essence of this plan to our Government in his recent visit here. One phase of carrying out a part of the plan is illustrated in the paratroop capture of the frontier town of Langson in northern Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Senate was thrown into gloom today when it was announced in New York that the ailing Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio "does not intend to return to his duties at this session of Congress."

DOTHAN, Ala., Saturday, July 18 -- The Alabama Highway Patrol reported that a Marine Corps plane had crashed at Allentown, Ala., early today, killing at least forty persons. The highway patrol said some persons were believed to have survived the crash.

DETROIT, July 17 (AP) -- George J. Kolowich, president of the Detroit and Cleveland Navigation Company, said today his company had acquired a major interest in the Freuhauf Trailer Company in a $3,000,000 stock transfer.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- An Administration request to Congress for a higher legal debt limit appeared virtually certain today as the Treasury announced a new peak indebtedness totaling $272,361,259,803.91. The present statutory limit is $275,000,000,000.

NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., July 17 -- The third national jamboree of the Boy Scouts of America opened here today, with more than 50,000 participants and with an assurance from President Eisenhower that the occasion had potential national and international importance.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 18 -- The Communists obtained today a twenty-four-hour delay in the crucial meeting of the Korean armistice delegations that might decide whether the Chinese and North Koreans would sign a truce on terms proposed by the United Nations or face collapse of the recently resumed talks.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 18 (UP) -- The world flyweight champion, Yoshio Shirai, knocked Vic Herman out of the ring in the tenth round last night to win by a technical knockout in a non-title, ten-round fight before 15,000 fans at Korakuen Stadium. Each fighter weighed 112 3/4 pounds.

Basic economic laws of supply and demand are responsible for the appearance here of two new canned beef products. These are Wilson's chopped beef, packed in a rectangular can like that used for luncheon meats, and Swift's beef steaks in gravy, in a thirteen-ounce round container.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- President Eisenhower's plans for the creation of two independent agencies to handle overseas information and foreign aid programs were sustained today by the House of Representatives.

Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr., candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, wrote to the New York City C. I. O. Council yesterday thanking it for its endorsement and outlining a program to meet the urgent needs of the city. His recommendations were:

BATH, England, July 17 (Reuters) -- British Government investigators revealed tonight that a phone cable to Bath race track was cut by an acetylene torch yesterday. Some $280,000 for bettors on a 10-to-1 horse and the greatest racing coup in British history would have resulted had the bookies paid off.

On July 10 you carried a story from Washington by The United Press the opening sentence of which reads: "The House passed tonight a bill to allow five private companies to develop the vast power potential at Niagara Falls."

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Dr. Robert L. Johnson, head of the State Department's International Information Administration until about the end of this month, today again accused the new director of research for the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations of making "flagrantly inaccurate" statements and disregarding facts.

At another time and in a different group of world circumstances the disaster that has been suffered on the island of Kyushu in Japan would have had the major headlines all over the world. This flood was of disastrous proportions. Approximately a million persons have been made homeless.

Quiz Song, a 5-year-old mare owned by John Howard Clark, showed excellent closing ability to take the $10,080 Capra Handicap that topped the Empire-at-Jamaica program yesterday. Willie Lester moved the daughter of Sun Again into the lead in the stretch of the six-furlong race, and she moved along formidably enough to score by a length and a quarter over Harry La Montagne's Valadium.

The city's official citation for public service was bestowed by Mayor Impellitteri at City Hall yesterday upon Col. Robert V. Shinn, public information officer of the First Army, and Lieut. Comdr. James P. Farrell, former assistant director of discipline and special events of the Third Naval District.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- President Eisenhower nominated Harvey V. Higley of Marinette, Wis., today to be Administrator of Veterans Affairs, succeeding Carl R. Gray Jr., who resigned.

The Bricker amendment represents a composite of American thought and sentiment which is and has been out of step with the changing scene of world affairs. It is the articulation of the abiding fear of the arrogation of power in the Executive. It is the hot, dry voice of Middle Western isolationism.

New scenic designs as well as some flocked patterns are included in a collection of LeBoff wallpapers on view in the new Decor Mart at Wanamaker's. A fairly comprehensive collection of paints bearing the Wanamaker label and a number of moderately priced collections of wallpapers by various manufacturers are available in this shop.

CLEVELAND, July 17 (AP) -- Bob Lemon continued tonight to set the pace for Indian pitchers by gaining his twelfth victory, a five-hit, 5-0 shutout of the Athletics. Luke Easter poled a three - run homer and Larry Doby followed immediately with his seventeenth homer of the year in the sixth, when the Tribe scored four runs off Bobby Shantz.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Judge Henry A. Schweinhaut, in the Federal District Court here, heard arguments today in an action by the North American Airlines group of unscheduled flight operators against a ruling by the Civil Aeronautics Board which, they held, would put them out of business.
One hundred and twenty-five children, three bus drivers and five counselors were stricken by food poisoning yesterday after luncheon at the day camp of the Ocean Parkway Jewish Center in Brooklyn.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 -- Frank N. Balgrano Jr., president and chairman of the board of Transamerica Corporation, said of the Philadelphia decision:

The city's accumulation of unpaid taxes has been reduced by $28,000,000 in the last seven and a half years, from $156,000,000 to $128,000,000, City Treasurer Spencer C. Young told Mayor Impellitteri yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 17 (UP) -- Virgil (Fire) Trucks hurled a three-hitter tonight as the White Sox won their seventh straight game and their twenty-eighth in the last thirty-four contests, 4 to 1, over the Senators before 23,278 fans.
CHICAGO, July 17 -- Mr. Higley is one of the best known leaders in the fields of politics, business and veterans affairs in Wisconsin.

Mike Green of Miami Beach, Fla., national boys' and interscholastic titleholder, reached the final of the Eastern Junior tennis championship in singles and won the doubles crown with Stephen Bank of New York yesterday.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 17 -- Judy Webb of the Riverside Club over on the Connecticut shore won the Syce Cup, emblematic of the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound for the second time today, though she sat anchored at the first mark for half an hour and finished seventh in the final of the eight-race series conducted by the Manhasset Yacht Club.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Despite the Catholic Church's discouraging of marriages between Roman Catholics and persons of other religions, The New World, official publication of the Archdiocese of Chicago, disclosed today, 40 per cent of the Catholics questioned in a poll made no objection to such mixed marriages.

The Mayor's special mediation committee to find a peace formula in the fifteen-day strike of 1,800 construction material drivers met at City Hall yesterday but adjourned with the walkout no nearer settlement.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The 22-year-old son of an Indiana Representative in Congress whose induction deferment led to the resignation of his local draft board, now faces a call for service next month. Selective Service national headquarters decided today that the case for John V. Beamer Jr. was too weak to warrant consideration by the Presidential Appeal Board.
Donald E. Mook has been appointed director of the new products research laboratory of the Borden Company.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, said today three officials of the United Brewery Workers Union, C. I. O., had been called for testimony on Monday before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

MELBOURNE, July 17 (UP) -- The Melbourne Racing Club decided today to invite the champion jockeys from the United States, England, South Africa and New Zealand to compete in the Invitation Stakes at Caulfield Track Sept. 24.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 17 (AP) -- Freddie Haas dismantled the Keller course's already-battered par-72 with a blazing 64 today to take the lead at the halfway mark in the St. Paul open golf tournament.

PARIS, July 17 -- Jacques Camille Paris, Secretary General of the Council of Europe since the organization was founded in 1949, was killed today in an automobile accident near Bordeaux, where he was spending his summer vacation. Mr. Paris' three daughters, his mother and a friend of his wife, who were in the car, were injured but not seriously.
TOKYO, Saturday, July 18 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,679, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korean time:

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 17 -- The Commonwealth Government investigation officers in Sydney armed with search warrants under the Commenwealth Crimes Act simultaneously raided today the Communist party's headquarters, the Communist bookshop and the Communist party's printing plant, which produces the Communist newspaper Tribune.

Soviet industry seems headed for new production records this year, but the rate of increase is continuing to fall compared with earlier years, according to an analysis of the economic data for the first half of 1953 released by the Soviet Government yesterday.

ALBANY, July 17 -- The State Thruway Authority reported today that it had entered into negotiations with three restaurant companies for exclusive, concessions along the 427-mile route of the expressway between New York and Buffalo.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, July 16 -- Amid the many rumors concerning the health of Aloysius Cardinal Stepinac -- newspapermen are forbidden to visit him at Krasic where the Cardinal is on parole serving out a war crimes sentence -- serious new battles are taking place in the Church-State struggle.

A one-story garage-type building at 12-10 Broadway in Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by Julian Bartelstone from the 71-15 Austin Street Real Estate Corporation and will be used for the storage, warehousing and maintenance of refrigeration equipment.

" The Wooden Dish," Edmund Morris new play, is expected to be presented locally at either the Martin Beck Theatre or the Morosco in mid-October. The offering will be under the sponsorship of Richard Aldrich and Richard Myers.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A spokesman here said the Federal Reserve Board would reserve comment until it received copies of the reversal order in the Transamerica Corporation case. However, he said, it is understood the board have ninety days in which to

The twenty-family apartment house at 203 Avenue F, corner of East Second Street, in Brooklyn has been purchased by the Joelsen Realty Corporation from Morris Knee. Caserta Co. were the brokers and the attorneys were Sidney Landes for the buyer and Goldstein Goldstein for the seller.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today heard complete agreement among contestants for the New England natural gas market on a compromise reached on July 3.
COPENHAGEN, July 17 (AP) -- Denmark signed contracts today to build five more cold storage freighters for the Soviet Union within the next two years.
DETROIT, July 17 -- Some 180 objects will go on display when the Design from Britain Exhibit is opened in the Museum of the Cranbrook Academy of Art in suburban Bloomfield Hills tomorrow.

NEW ORLEANS, July 17 (AP) -- A tornado ripped through the outskirts of New Orleans today, destroying a Catholic church, a small home and injuring one person. Other homes were damaged. Two priests in the living quarters of the church escaped injury.

The Larchmont Yacht Club's fifty-fifth Race Week will begin today. It will continue through next Saturday and will bring to the western end of Long Island Sound the year's greatest concentration of sailing craft, ranging from twelve-meter yachts of about 70 feet on deck to 12-foot knock-abouts.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 17 -- Mr. and Mrs. Donald O'Brien of the host club carded an alternate stroke, 38, 36 -- 74 to win the women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association mixed foursome tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club today. The play was according to the Pinehurst system.

A three-story commercial structure built the full area of the land on lot 25 by 100 feet at 17 Jones Street in the Greenwich Village area has been sold by Mrs. Emily Brush to an investing client of Abraham M. Weinberg, attorney. William Alfred White was the broker.
BALTIMORE, July 17 (UP) -- The Baltimore Colts today obtained a former All-America quarterback Bob Williams, and two other players from the Chicago Bears in a trade.

At the invitation of the Right Rev. Richard A. Reeves, Anglican Bishop of Johannesburg, the Right Rev. Wilburn C. Campbell, Bishop Coadjutor of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of West Virginia, will spend September in the Union of South Africa addressing public meetings and consulting with civic leaders.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 17 -- A strong force of French Union paratroopers dropped into Vietminh territory this morning at Langson, in North Tonkin, ten miles from the Chinese frontier, and, after subduing scattered resistance, proceeded to wreck the main Vietminh center for supplies from Communist China.
CENTRAL CITY, Colo., July 17 "Carmen" is presented here as nowhere else in the United States -- professedly in the opera's original form, as Bizet and his librettists created it.

There is reason to feel considerable satisfaction in the result of the Greater New York Fund's 1953 campaign. While the early, announced goal of $9,000,000 was by no means reached, total contributions are expected to be $6,300,000 to $6,450,000 when the clean-up work on unrenewed pledges is completed.

A young parole violator went out on the town early yesterday morning in Brooklyn and in little more than two hours had managed to beat up and rob a garage attendant, steal an automobile, hold up a tavern, fight a running pistol battle with the police and finally crash into another car and injure seven persons besides himself.
New York Hospital, at 525 East Sixty-eighth Street, reported yesterday that Senator Taft did not intend to resume his duties in Washington during the present session of Congress.

By three measurements yesterday's market on the New York Stock Exchange was the most bullish in some time. For the first time since July 1 the number of issues that rose in price topped the combined total of those that fell or were unchanged.

Emerson Foote has purchased a contemporary-style house and about three-quarters of an acre in North Manursing Island in Long Island Sound at Rye, N. Y., according to Previews, Inc. The property was sold by Lawrence Management Inc., of Bronxville through Edward V. Siedle, broker.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today remanded to the district court for trial twenty suits involving all the major tire manufacturers of the country and several large distributors in which a ruling of the Federal Trade Commission fixing quantity limits on purchases for price discount purposes was at issue.

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 17 -- An 84 - year - old Puerto Rican adventurer set sail from here to Spain last week on a goodwill tour in which he will carry greetings to the Spanish from the people of Puerto Rico. He has been planning the trip for thirty years.
ST. LOUIS, July 17 -- The Yankees retained their four-game lead in the American League race tonight by polishing off the seventh-place Browns, 6 to 4. But it wasn't as easy as all that.

Stuart Denton Morris, general secretary of the British Peace Pledge Union, who was detained thirteen days on Ellis Island when he entered the United States in May, departed by air yesterday for London after a transcontinental lecture tour..

BERLIN, July 17 -- East Germany's Communists appeared today to be calling a halt to their Government's retreats that followed the June 17 uprising and at the same time to be preparing to purge the party of the lingering Social Democrats.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 17 -- Two Metropolitan district champions, Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks and Mrs. Mortimer May of Middle Bay, will meet in the thirty-six-hole final of the Women's New York State golf championship tomorrow.
The plastics industry expects 1953 sales to establish a new high.

Val Peterson, Federal Civil Defense Administrator, will interview Cabinet members and other guests on "Disaster Strikes," a weekly series of ten-minute programs beginning at 7:05 P.M. tomorrow on the A. B.C. radio network. The series will provide information on Mr. Peterson's duties in combating the effects of floods, tornadoes and other disasters.

If Senator McCarthy's abuse of the investigative power can finally induce the Congress to adopt uniform rules of decent procedure for its investigating committees, then some good will have come out of evil after all.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 17 -- Indonesia's Nationalist and Communist parties have increased their pressure for formation of a "united anti-terrorist front" as armed bands in West Java continue to make raids.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, July 14 -- The Army Corps of Engineers is engaged here in an effort to make the construction of United States air bases in French Morocco a more economical and businesslike operation than has hitherto been the case.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 17 (AP) -- Uhleen Fingo, owned by Mr. and Mrs. C. T. Black of Berryville, Va., tonight paced the fastest mile of the year for 3-year-old fillies, and also smashed the Roosevelt Raceway record for her class.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The United States Court of Military Appeals unanimously upheld today the conviction of Maj. Gen. Robert W. Grow, whose diary fell into Communist hands.
PITTSBURGH, July 17 (UP) -- Warren Spahn pitched the Braves to an 8-2 decision over the Pirates tonight to register his twelfth victory of the season.

Ephraim F. Jeffe, the only member of the New York City Transit Authority to vote against a 15-cent fare on the municipal subway and surface lines, has reconsidered for the time being the resignation he sent to City Hall last Monday.

TURKU, Finland, July 17 (UP) -- Mal Whitfield, the middle distance runner who hopes to set ten world records this year, collected his fourth today when he won the 880-yard run in 1 minute 48.6 seconds in the final meet of the United States track and field tour.

UNITED NATIONS, N.. Y., July 17 -- Attorneys for the United Nations said today that United States staff members must be prepared to give up constitutional rights if their exercise conflicted with the best interests of the world organization.

Arrangements for expanding operations on a global basis have been completed by Ar-Tik Systems, Inc., for Dairy Queen, a frozen dessert sold through franchised retailers in forty-seven states, Cuba, Mexico, Canada and Alaska.

The slackening in securities underwriting will continue to be noticeable in the market next week. Tax-exempt-interest bonds of local governments will again figure largely in the business, with such offerings topped by the State of Maryland's offering of $25,000,000 of State Roads Commission bonds on Tuesday.

LONDON, July 17 -- The stock markets maintained a confident note today despite the usual falling off of business before the week-end. British Government securities improved further. Small rises were fairly widely distributed among the industrials though some of the recently active issues tended to slip back in the late dealings on week-end profit-taking.

Police Lieut. Arthur Miller, scheduled to go on departmental trial at Police Headquarters yesterday for allegedly giving false answers about Communist affiliations, failed to appear for the proceedings.
New Yorkers gave 827 pints of blood on Thursday to the regional Red Cross blood program.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 17 (AP) -- James F. McHugh's River Jordan made a runaway of the $5,000 Monmouth National Maiden Hurdle race at Monmouth Park today, scoring by seven lengths before 16,200 spectators.

Pageantry and frivolity over, the seventy-ninth annual convention of the Ancient Arabic Order of Nobles of the Mystic Shrine ended yesterday on a note of praise for the city and its people for their hospitality.

FROM the reports that have been coming in from some of the famous salmon rivers of Quebec and New Brunswick, it is apparent that the bank-side price of Atlantic salmon has reached a new high, for low water has sent many an angler home without fish.

After routing the Cardinals, 14 -- 0, behind Johnny Podres in the most lopsided shutout of the major league campaign, the torrid Dodgers last night made it three in a row over the Redbirds by taking the second game of a twilight-night double-header by a 7-4 score. The twin bill attracted 29,793 paying spectators to Ebbets Field.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to homemakers:

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The weather in this theatre of turf operations today was the kind that's fine for farmers -- and rough on jockeys. After a nine-day dry spell, rain bucketed onto the area this morning, and the afternoon was showery. So the Arlington Park Race Track was deep in slop, and it seems likely that there'll be an "off" track for tomorrow's twenty-fifth running of the $100,000 added Arlington Classic.
Futures were quiet on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closing prices were barely steady and 3 to 8 points net lower than on Thursday.
TANNERSVILLE, N. Y., July 17 -- Maude Adams, one of the great actresses of the American stage, died here today of a heart attack at her home in the Cat-skills. She was 80 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- The National Association of Manufacturers "vigorously" endorsed the Administration's request for a postal rate increase today, but the National Small Business Men's Association said it would be an "insurmountable burden."
DETROIT, July 17 (AP) -- The Red Sox used four pitchers to edge the Tigers, 3 -- 2, tonight to extend their road record to twenty-four victories against twenty losses.

BONN, Germany, July 17 -- The Bundesrat, upper house of the West German Parliament, completed today ratification of the London Debt Agreement settling Germany's pre-war and post-war foreign debts but refused to approve the bill indemnifying the victims of Nazi persecution.
Bills to allow the sale of twelve American ships to Brazil for use in coastwise service are now being considered by Congress.

Fridrik Olafsson of Iceland, adopting an ingenious continuation against a Sicilian defense, defeated James T. Sherwin of New York in the fourth round of the world junior chess championship finals, according to a report from Copenhagen yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit set aside today a Federal Reserve Board ruling that had ordered the Transamerica Corporation to dispose of all its stock in forty-seven independent commercial banks in California, Washington, Oregon, Nevada and Arizona.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Bad news today from the Smithsonian Institution: Three new kinds of cockroaches have invaded this country and at least one of them threatens to become a serious pest.

Down-Easters are going in for advertising and promotion in a big way. The Maine sardine industry soon will launch a national campaign in various media to sell its 1953 pack. The sardine packers, through Batten, Barton, Durstine and Osborn, will use Sunday newspaper supplements, consumer magazines, radio spots and trade papers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17 -- It is generally felt here that, regardless of the outcome of the armistice talks at Panmunjom, the United Nations General Assembly will not be called back into session before the second week in August at the earliest.
T. A. van Griethuysen has been elected a vice president of the Continental Oil Company.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., July 17 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair fired a 34, 38 -- 72 today to set a women's record for the Essex Fells course and win a Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament by eight shots.

CLEVELAND, July 17 (AP) -- Record shipments in June raised to a new high the amount of iron ore moved down the Great Lakes before July 1, according to the Lake Carriers Association. The addition of larger and faster vessels to the ore fleets was the main reason for the heavy movement, said the association.
PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (UP) -- Harry Perkowski, with two innings of relief aid from Clyde King, pitched the Redlegs to a 3-2 victory tonight to end the Phils' seven-game winning streak.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Resolutions urging greater job opportunities for the blind were voted at today's closing session of the twenty-seventh annual convention of the American Association of Workers for the Blind.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) The Justice Department cited Charles Lamb's essay on the origin of roast pig today to explain its reluctance to produce evidence against an alleged Communist front. The Subversive Activities Control Board was not greatly impressed, and the Department did not gain its point.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Tariff protectionists scored a point in the House of Representatives today as the Rules Committee cleared a bill, opposed by the Administration, for mandatory curbs on certain foreign imports and other restrictive measures.

SEATTLE, July 17 (AP) -- A pair of sharpshooting Californians gained the final of the national public links golf tournament today. Ted Richards of Santa Monica defeated Doug Sanders of Cedartown, Ga., 5 and 4, and Irving Cooper of Long Beach downed Ed Hart of Denver, 12 and 11.

A month after the stirring events of June 17 Soviet tanks have again rumbled through the streets of East Berlin.
