The objective, in all likelihood, was to remind the residents of that part of the city that the military force which had ended last month's demonstration is still in the neighborhood, available and ready to apply new terror against German workers if needed.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- A House Armed Services subcommittee rejected today a request by the Navy that it be permitted to renew its lease of Pier 26 from the City of New York.

WILLIAMS AIR FORCE BASE, Ariz., July 17 (AP) -- Two B-50 bombers, one flying blind, smashed together at 27,000 feet over the central Arizona desert today. Eight airmen lost their lives as one of the big planes plunged to earth and burned.
BONN, Germany, July 17 -- West Germany's gold and foreign currency holdings have set another new post-war record as the country's free market economy continues to make progress.

The designation of Mayor Impellitteri as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor by three of the five Democratic county leaders is expected to take place at their fourth meeting on Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Three maritime bills, one designed to facilitate the private financing of new ship construction, were introduced in the Senate today by Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan and chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Maritime Subsidies.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee voted tentatively tonight to admit 220,000 anti-Communist East European refugees into the United States.

ATHENS, July 17 -- John E. Peurifoy has been recalled to Washington for consultation pending his reassignment, according to a United States Embassy statement released tonight. The announcement followed an official statement by the Greek Government to the effect that King Paul had approved Cavendish W. Cannon, the United States Ambassador to Portugal, as Mr. Peurifoy's successor in Athens.

Results now available from the driver- testing clinics held last month by the Greater New York Safety Council indicate the solid value of this undertaking, aimed at enabling the driving public to test its own efficiencies and deficiencies. Eight thousand motorists took the tests.

TOKYO, July 17 -- The Japanese conservative parties, in a rare but expected show of cooperation, pushed the national budget for fiscal 1953-54 through the House of Representatives tonight by a vote of 301 to 132. The measure was sent immediately to the House of Councilors, which, under the Constitution, is able only to delay, not reject, the Administration's financial measure.

Following is the text of a radio- television report to the nation last night by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Assistant Secretary Walter S. Robertson, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Time was -- and not so long ago -- when the rhythm of the city was set to the tune of hoof- beats going clop-clop upon the paved streets. We have been reminded that this was so by a man who confessed to being brought up in the deep country where, even in the small towns, the hoofs were planted on dirt roads.

GROTON, Conn., July 17 -- The smallest submarine built by the United States Navy since 1910, and the first submarine since 1907 with only a single propeller, slid down the ways at the Electric Boat Company at noon here today.

The third annual Institute on religious and Sacerdotal Vocations will be held in Collins Auditorium at Fordham University beginning July 29. Twelve hundred Roman Catholic brothers, sisters and lay teachers from all parts of the United States and Canada are expected to attend the two-day meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 110 Korean war casualties in a new list that included 11 killed, 93 wounded, one missing and five injured. There were no casualties reported from New Jersey or Connecticut. Casualties from New York were:
MOSCOW, July 17 -- A series of institutions and other establishments have been turned over to the new Ministry of Medium Machine Construction, headed by Vyacheslav A. Malyshev.

Mrs. Marion von Rospach of San Francisco, 27-year-old publisher and executive editor of Overseas Weekly, published in Frankfurt, Germany, and distributed to United States Army personnel and United States civilians abroad, protested yesterday the banning of her publication by United States Army authorities in Germany.

ELIZABETHTON, Tenn., July 17 (AP) -- A polio quarantine went into effect here today as Carter County health authorities sought to prevent the disease from spreading. Two more cases of infantile paralysis were reported yesterday, raising the total in recent weeks to twenty.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 17 (AP) -- Chinese Nationalist guerrillas who stormed Tungshan Island off the coast of Red China yesterday crushed resistance of "bandit troops" and occupied the principal city, then withdrew today, the Defense Ministry announced.

VALDOSTA, Ga., July 17 (AP) -- Opening 1953 Georgia-Florida tobacco sales averaged 72 cents a hundred pounds above last season's high figure and prices held firm with quality good today, the second of the selling season.

Because they are rated more cautious drivers than men and have an interest in safety programs, women were urged yesterday to go into traffic safety engineering. The suggestion came in a resolution passed at the closing session of the Highway Safety Conference at New York University Law Center.

LINDEN, N. J., July 17 -- A strike at the assembly plant of the General Motors Corporation here today halted production of Buick, Pontiac and Oldsmobile cars. Both the management and Michael Collins, president of Local 595, United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., termed the strike "unauthorized."

A machine tool operated by a sound wave pitched so high that human ears cannot hear it has been developed by the Raytheon Manufacturing Company of Waltham, Mass., and the device is expected to have widespread applications in many metal-working industries.
MONTREAL, July 17 (UP) -- Canada swept both singles matches from Mexico today in the first round of the North American zone Davis Cup eliminations.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee moved today to plug a statutory loophole whereby some movie actors and retired business men have escaped income taxes by going abroad for extended periods.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.5 per cent to 110.4 per cent of the 1947-49 average in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The advance, the largest in 1953, reflected sharp price rises for most livestock, meats and fish.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, declared tonight that the United Nations was seeking an honorable peace in Korea, but if the Communists chose to continue the war, "We must be ready for that, too."

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A paddle for disciplining children without injuring their anatomy appeared among the 828 inventions patented this week. The inventor, George F. Jorgenson of Norfolk, Va., places no faith in parental restraint -- the handle of his paddle breaks if papa hits too hard.
Anent "burning books," I have not seen this aspect discussed:

Perhaps before you start out for that welcome vacation you will remember the children who are imprisoned in the city in summer without hope of relief -- the homebound handicapped children. New York has many such children -- too badly crippled to take advantage of any camp, to go on even the shortest outing or even join the other children reveling in the showerbath from the fire hydrant.

The Lehigh Valley Coal Corporation suffered a further setback in the first six months this year. The anthracite producer reported its net loss at $1,146,019 yesterday, more than double the $569,093 loss for the initial half of 1952.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 16 -- An explosion of ideas and a clash of ideologies have been touched off in Central Africa by the law federating the two Rhodesias and Nyasaland.
Flaring tempers aboard the Long Island Rail Road brought a commuter and a trainman into Flushing Magistrate's Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Senate's Republican leaders sidetracked today the St. Lawrence Seaway bill until January, at the earliest. The acting majority leader, Senator William F. Knowland, of California, said that even though the bill had the blessing of the Senate Republican Policy Committee it would not be considered this session, now scheduled to end July 31.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., July 17 -- One hundred and twenty-five Liberty ships, in dead storage since shortly after World War II, are being converted into floating granaries to handle 750,000 tons of Government surplus wheat under a Government program started last May.

Most commodity prices on the New York Exchanges were higher yesterday. Volume continued to ease generally but rubber, soybean oil and coffee showed increased activity. Sugar, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, rubber, lead, zinc and hides closed higher, and coffee, cocoa, potatoes, wool and copper, mixed.

BARBECUE is mouthwatering magic to Americans in whatever region they live. An increasing number of outdoor grills will be used throughout the United States this summer. Whether it's a lowly frankfurter sizzling over a small grill in a suburban backyard or a great haunch of beautiful beef that's "still kickin'" on a spit at a huge ranch, a barbecue stands for feast and fun.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 -- Few persons in this area seem disposed to express any praise for Senator McCarthy. But neither does the average man appear particularly excited about him or about "McCarthyism."

"I TOOK several fast deep breaths, adjusted my face mask, checked the safety lock on my speargun, and dived back down again into the Red Sea." Thus begins "Lady With a Spear" and the inveterate reader of undersea literature may groan that here again is the old aqualung derring do -- this time with a lady diver for variety.

Only one of the 125 children and one of the five counselors made ill by tainted food eaten at the Ocean Parkway Jewish Center in Brooklyn Friday remained in the hospital yesterday. Neither was seriously ill, according to the New York Health Department, and both were expected to go home some time today.

Companies which heretofore have relied on public transportation for their executives are turning to the use of corporate-owned aircraft in increasing numbers, in one of the most revolutionary transportation trends in recent years. In 1952 airplanes belonging to corporations outnumbered those of all domestic-scheduled airlines combined by almost seven to one, and they flew almost as many miles as the airliners.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada and bitter foe of the Eisenhower bill to admit more than 200,000 refugees, declared today the adjournment of Congress would be delayed if the bill is brought to the Senate floor.

PRINCE LOUIS DE BROGLIE is one of a bright band of Nobel laureates that includes the late Max Planck, Niels Bohr, Albert Einstein, Erwin Schrodinger and Werner Heisenberg, and that has brought about a revolution in physics as sensational and profound as that associated with the names of Copernicus, Galileo, Kepler and Newton.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sunday, July 19 -- The Communists announced today that they were prepared to discuss with the Allies preparations for signing an armistice in the Korean war.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 18 -- The membership of the Majlis (lower house of Parliament) was reduced to twenty-five today upon the resignation of two more pro-Government deputies with the approval of the Government. A total of fifty-four Deputies has resigned.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, Republican of New Jersey, said today that the International Longshoremen's Association was attempting "to muster Congressional assistance" in opposing House of Representatives approval of a New York-New Jersey compact creating a commission to combat racket conditions on the New York waterfront.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The decision of the House Appropriations Committee today to cut more than $1,000,000,000 from President Eisenhower's foreign aid program has pinpointed the sometimes conflicting responsibilities of this Government for free world leadership and for maintaining its own solvency.
ST. LOUIS, July 18 -- the Yankees got the Browns out in broad daylight today and this time they made no mistakes.

WASHINGTON -- The ceremonies for the observance, on July 14, of the centenary of Matthew Calbraith Perry's achievement in opening Japanese ports to commerce, were perhaps the most impressive ever held in connection with the release of a new United States stamp -- the 5-cent green carrying Perry's portrait and picturing his fleet.

Few things excite men's curiosities and desires as much as prohibitions. Man is a contrary creature from the start; the child burns his fingers on the forbidden matches, the youth challenges and tests the school's restraints, the man pricks up his ears when a license commissioner threatens to close the doors of a theatre.
TOKYO, Sunday, July 19 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,680, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korean time:

AT approximately the ninety-eighth meridian, two-thirds of the way across Kansas from east to west, the High Plains begin -- a vast tableland sloping imperceptibly across some 360 miles, upward to the foothills of the Rockies. Here and there the plains are broken by shallow valleys made by streams of intermittent flow; occasionally the plains gently roll, like a mild sea.

CRATER, LAKE NATIONAL PARK, Ore. -- Early July visitors here and in Mount Lassen Volcanic National Park -- especially if they came from the East or Midwest -- have had added thrills this year. Both the east and north entrances to Crater Lake Park were blocked with snow until mid-July.

A DIFFERENT and highly significant use of television which could have almost world-wide application in furtherance of democratic ideals is to be found in over 100 rural communities to the northeast of Paris.

ALMOST 300 fairs will be staged in eleven Eastern states between this Tuesday and Nov. 21. Among the eleven states Pennsylvania once again has far and away the greatest number of fairs, heading the list with 97 announced thus far.

CATO, it is said, started learning Greek when he was 80. At the same age, Bertrand Russell tells us that for reasons completely unknown to him he suddenly wished to write the stories in this volume, although he had never before thought of doing such a thing.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Sol Whitman of New Brunswick, Middlesex County title-holder, defeated Virginia Micchelli of East Orange today, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1, in an opening-round match of the third annual New Jersey all-amateur women's singles tennis tournament.
SEOUL, July 18 (AP) -- The Air Force said today that Airman, First Class, Thomas L. Kinder had been sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of a South Korean civilian.
James T. Sherwin of New York lost to Dieter Keller of Switzerland in the fifth round of the world junior chess championship tournament, according to a report received yesterday from Copenhagen.

THE Federal Bureau of Investigation fascinates foreign authors of mystery novels. There are extensive series of books in French and Spanish (usually by writers with "American" pseudonyms ) dealing with its activities (most of which would surprise J. Edgar Hoover no end) : and even in England, Peter Cheyney's Lemmy Caution is nominally a member of the F. B. I.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 -- King coal has toppled off his throne as the nation's principal energy source. For half a century other fuels have been nibbling away at coal's empire; now, for the first time, Government statistics show that oil has supplanted coal as America's chief fuel.
With the opening of the football season, there will be many discussions, pro and con, of the one change in the football rules which will affect players, coaches and spectators.

All last week on the Korean war front time seemed to turn backward. U. N. and Communist armies fought ferociously in massive drives that Eighth Army Commander, Gen. Maxwell Taylor, called "the first resumption of open warfare in two years." The bloody fighting recalled the time when Korea was a no-quarter war and peace seemed a distant dream.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The squabbling precipitated in Congress by the Eisenhower Administration's request for the admission of 240,000 refugees over a two-year period seems incongruous, from the point of view of numbers, when measured against the magnitude of the refugee problem confronting the Western world.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 18 (UP) -- A 9-year-old boy who stabbed a 5-year-old girl to death in a game of cowboys and Indians faced a possible death sentence today under strict Federal laws governing territories. The formal first-degree murder charge was placed against Jimmy Ellis yesterday under the law that excludes no one for reason of age from the maximum charge.

Divided Germany bridges a gap between two rival systems. To the east Russian power has riveted communism on the satellites. To the west democracy holds sway. Germany, in the middle, with a population of 70,000,000, rich resources in coal and iron, and a highly developed industrial plant is potentially the strongest power in Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, said today Congress would have to raise taxes next year or face the prospect of piling $10,000,000,000 on top of the record peacetime Federal debt. He made this prediction as indications increased President Eisenhower would ask Congress next week to increase the present statutory debt ceiling of $275,000,000,000.

A CAREFUL examination of the marble corridor leading from the south elevator to suite 215 in the Senate Office Building probably would reveal a shallow trough worn into it by the ceaselessly pounding feet of the Senate's new acting Majority Leader, the senior Senator from California, William Fife Knowland.

During July and August, when more than 32,000,000 students are on vacation from schools and colleges, many of the nation's teachers take a busman's holiday. Nearly 1,000,000 persons, more than half from the teaching profession, are attending summer classes on hundreds of college campuses in every section of the country.

ONE of the most fascinating pursuits in Washington is searching out the origins of important decisions and discovering who caused them to be made. Sometimes the facts remain hidden, baffling assiduous contemporary observers.
Robert Moses announced yesterday that he was not a candidate for the Republican nomination for Mayor.

MEXICO CITY, July 18 (UP) -- Five Mexican social security officials have been arrested in connection with a false-quota racket believed to have cost the Government "many millions of pesos," it was announced today.

COPPER CENTER, Alaska, July 18 -- Four scientist mountaineers are established in a camp that they hope will become a permanent observatory at the summit of 14,005-foot Mount Wrangell in Central Alaska.

THE bland title of this rugged volume is deceptive. It is a violent, blood-splattered, first-person account of life in one of our toughest big houses by an unusual cop-killer and robber. Serving life, the author was paroled after twenty years for saving the lives of six prison guards under heroic circumstances.

The number of rats in Central Park has been held in check in recent years, according to William H. Latham, director of maintenance and operations of the Department of Parks, but there is not much prospect of getting rid of them.

LILIES make a handsome addition to any garden in summer. Not only do they comprise one of the most interesting and decorative plant groups, but they're easy to grow, too. What is more, by a colorful selection of different varieties, bloom may be had from June until the middle of October.

BOSTON, July 18 -- New Englanders have followed the latest developments in the "McCarthy case" with considerable interest, but there is little indication that the attitudes of individuals toward the Senator have changed noticeably.

ASCOT, England, July 18 -- Pinza, winner of the Epsom Derby, did it again today when he captured England's richest race, the $76,300 King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes. Sir Gordon Richards was the jockey.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The first session of the first Eisenhower Congress is now drawing quietly to its close in a humid atmosphere of few crises met and rather more crises postponed.

As the city-owned ferryboat running to Rikers and North Brother Islands pulled into her slip on the Bronx side of the East River at 3:30 P. M. last Thursday, a quiet, neat-appearing young man stood apart from the passengers. In outward appearance this boy did not differ from thousands of other youths.

The opening of the fall hunting season is more than two months in the future, but the urban sportsman who depends upon the generosity of the farmer for his hunting should begin making his contacts right now, rather than wait until the week before the season opens.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- According to important Republican politicians in the Midwest, one of Senator McCarthy's recent clashes with the Administration has reduced his stature in some areas outside his home state of Wisconsin.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP) -- Harry Hoffman of Philadelphia won the Eastern States clay courts championship today but his wife, Ann, lost in her bid for the women's title.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Eisenhower will issue next week an executive order creating a National Agricultural Advisory Commission. This will follow up his campaign pledge to establish an advisory group to deal with the complex and controversial problems of agriculture in the United States.

BOSTON, July 18 (AP) -- Wilbur Wilson, a Boston schoolboy, put on a blistering finish to gain a split decision over Gerald Dreyer, British Empire welterweight boxing champion, in a bruising ten-round nationally televised bout tonight at Mechanics Building.

THE blurbist, for once, is right. Mr. Grierson's third novel has enough "dash and sparkle" to send the reader in quest of the first and second. "The Hastening Wind" is lively yarning, fast in action and unusually felicitous in style.

ALTHOUGH nothing is yet official at this writing, an announcement appears imminent that Roger Stevens, Robert W. Dowling and Robert Whitehead have worked out an agreement creating a new Broadway producing corporation.

The Westchester County estate of Senator and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman is under contract of sale to Joseph F. Stein, founder and chairman of the board of Stein's Stores, Inc., according to Previews, Inc., realty marketing agents.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 18 -- Professional nurses from forty-six countries closed the tenth quadrennial congress of the International Council of Nurses at Petropolis, near here, yesterday, after having formally adopted the first international code of nursing ethics.

TO those who know its meaning, the word potpourri (pronounced po-poor-ree) brings to mind the delicious scented mixture of dried rose petals and other fragrant blossoms. Any gardener who grows roses and other scented flowers can make a potpourri by starting to gather and dry petals in summer.
SALTAIR, Utah -- Visitors to this upland desert region are again bobbing like corks atop the highly saline waters of the Great Salt Lake. The lake, as Utahans put it, has "done a comeback."

NORMAN, Okla., July 18 (AP) -Few students and faculty members were on the University of Oklahoma campus today, but news that twenty-two naval R. O. T. C. students had been killed in a plane cash struck a sudden blow, putting many into unashamed tears.

A NEW type of furniture, just put on the market, should offer adults as much fun as children get out of building blocks. For, since this furniture comes in parts, it enables the amateur to build storage units and room dividers according to his own design.

THE American Recording Society, which has labored tirelessly to give music by native composers the permanence of recording, this week offers on disks Quincy Porter's Concerto for Viola and Orchestra, with Paul Angerer as soloist and Max Schoenherr conducting the A. R. S. Orchestra; and Norman Dello Joio's Serenade for Orchestra, played by the A. R. S. Orchestra with Hans Swarowsky conducting.
Trans World Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Administration yesterday for permission to fly the Atlantic without using navigators.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, proposed changes in Senate rules today to prevent the recurrence of what he characterized as hasty action on treaties and constitutional amendments "by rote and routine."

The testing of an atomic bomb at Monte Bello, in the Pacific, last year marked the first stage in Britain's development of her atomic weapons. A second stage is planned -- a more elaborate stage in which more than one type of atomic weapon will be tested.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 18 -- Freddie Haas stood off a phalanx of under-70-shooting challengers today to hold a one-stroke lead after fifty-four holes in the St. Paul open golf tournament.

ALLAN BARNARD has swept together thirteen pieces on the Whitechapel bawd murders that horrified not only London but all mankind in the nineteenth century. Thirteen is an unlucky number -- and this would have been a better book if some of the pieces had been omitted.

AS a provider of film scripts, Shakespeare seems to offer a challenge to deeds of daring and what he himself called "vaulting ambition" in a way no other writer does. A group of highly talented, but not very experienced film-wise, people here are now in the throes of preparing to put "The Tempest" on the screen.
DETROIT, July 18 (UP) -- Hoot Evers and Sammy White hit ninthinning homers to account for Boston's runs today as the Red Sox rallied to defeat the Tigers, 5 -- 3, before 5,160 fans at Briggs Stadium.

MADRID, July 18 -- Faced with a shortage of wheat and other cereals because of a drought, the Spanish Government has warned farmers that penalties will be imposed upon those who fail to declare the amount of wheat in their possession after the present harvest.

READERS who enjoyed Mr. Cotterell's "Strait and Narrow" when it appeared in this country two years ago may be taken aback, at first, by his second novel to cross the Atlantic. "Strait and Narrow" was a witty, well-sandpapered, Marquandish study of a London barrister on the make.

THIS is a sequel to the author's "The Epic of Russian Literature." The earlier volume, published in 1950, ended with Tolstoy; the present volume discusses Russian literary development in the pre-revolutionary decades and in the Soviet period.
Bids for ten Queens sewer projects expected to cost $203,500 will be opened July 27, C. Parke Masterson, acting Borough President, announced yesterday.

PARIS, July 18 -- Centuries before the birth of communism, plot and counterplot skirmished through the dark corridors and mournful cellars of the Kremlin. The silent stroke of treachery, the sudden outburst of revenge, were familiar attributes of that great fortress long before its present ideology was conceived.

GENEVA, July 18 (AP) -- John C. Baker, United States delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, told the council today the United States would not give priority to defense needs over the economic development of underdeveloped countries.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 18 -- Dr. I. Ben Rubin's Ankaway from Charlton, N. Y., scored a half-length victory over the onrushing Red Sails in the $6,000 Brookhaven junior free for-all pacing feature at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

Hopes for a speedy end to the ruinous ship cargo rate war that has been waged in the Japanese trade for the last four months were dashed last week when a meeting at Tokyo ended with no attempt made toward stabilizing the tariffs.

GAETANO MEROLA is bringing six new singers from Europe for the thirty-first season of the San Francisco Opera this fall. Two are Italians, Cesare Valletti, tenor, who will sing later at the Metropolitan, and Giulietta Simionata, contralto, whose voice has preceded her to this country in the title role of the recorded version of Rossini's "La Cenerentola."

I AM far from thinking that New Yorkers, in the mass, are either less human or less humane than the inhabitants of any other great city: indeed, if you are going to draw distinctions at all, which is a silly thing to do, and if you are considering, not potentialities, but a realized development, then they are clearly much gentler than many.

New York had another record-breaking day of heat yesterday. From 12:50 P. M. until just after 1, the official thermometer at the Weather Bureau read 96 degrees. At Plainfield, N. J., the official mark was 101 at 2:50 P. M., while in exposed spots over the metropolis the mercury showed unmistakably -- if unofficially -- at 100.

A FORMER public-links caddie, nickel-tipped into a state of sullen withdrawal twenty-five years ago by a generation of lady golfers who ultimately traded him in anyway for a two-wheeled hand cart during the war recently uncovered a major alteration in the thinking of the profession: caddies now regard women as good bags for the most part.

DAYLILIES come in such a wide choice of colors and heights that there are certain to be varieties to suit the needs of almost any gardener. And, of course, a judicious selection will extend the period of bloom from June to September.
THURMONT, Md., July 18 -- President Eisenhower drew on his waders early this morning, cast his dry flies in a stream near Camp David and returned around mid-day with two trout for the skillet.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The House Appropriations Committee cut $1,120,050,575 from President Eisenhower's foreign aid program today and admonished his Administration that the strength needed for a continuing war on communism could come "only from a balanced budget and a sound economy."
PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- Recent events, including President Eisenhower's rebuke, appear to have had little effect on feeling for or against Senator McCarthy in this area.

THE Windy City came up with something the other day in connection with the showing of the film, "The Moon Is Blue," which if used rationally feel should go a long way in allowing the American screen to come of age (something which foreign films arrived at long ago).

Although severe drought and unfavorable weather conditions restricted production in several areas, the nation's farmers this year will produce a near-record grain crop. With the carry-over from previous crops unusually large, supplies for this crop year will be at peak levels.

Tongues are wagging and yarns are being spun in every near-by yacht club grill over the phenomenal accuracy that is being demonstrated by owners of power cruisers this year in the popular predicted log races. Strictly speaking, they are not races in the sense that the yachtsmen vie for speed honors.

THE title of a round - up of new phonograph recordings which feature the voices of famous actors and actresses of the past and present might be "From Edwin Booth to Maurice Evans." And the new disks underline rather sadly that, whatever the greatness of the old-timers, their voices will not be remembered by posterity so well as those of current actors.

Business in the department stores was sluggish in the week, and trade observers, store controllers among them, were puzzled as to the reason. As the week opened volume was good but, beginning on Tuesday, customer traffic and sales began to slide off. The weather was warm, but about the same as in the 1952 week, so that the drop-off from 1952, estimated variously at 6 to 8 per cent, was all the more unaccountable.

SEOUL, Korea, July 18 -- Since last Tuesday morning, when news of the heavy Chinese Communist attack against the South Korean forces on the central front began to reach people here, there has been a noticeable change in attitude. By that night, when it had become apparent that Republic of Korea troops were taking a beating from the numerically superior enemy, a somberness almost heavy enough to see fell on Seoul.

May I as a British reader express my appreciation of your excellent survey of the causes underlying American-British misunderstanding, "America and Britain -- A Vital Partnership," by Lester Markel (June 14).

WHEN the fields are "in clover," nature lovers, farmers, cows, children, butterflies and bees rejoice. Few wild flowers are as useful as well as ornamental, as fragrant and abundant as these clovers that bloom from June to October in meadows and pastures everywhere.

Maude Adams was carried on the stage when she was a baby of nine months. Old photographs show her recognizably herself as early as the age of 5 years. She was a famous actress and a star when she played Lady Babbie in "The Little Minister" at the age of 25.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP) -- The Detroit Boat Club snatched a last-minute lead over the favored Vesper Boating Club of Philadelphia at the end of the first round of the national rowing championships on the Schuylkill River today.

When the Consumers Power Company of Jackson, Mich., began to build an addition to its electric power plant at Essexville, near Bay City, Mich., it encountered wet and shifting soils. It was decided to use a process developed in Germany by Dr. Leo Casagrande, now of Harvard University.

In the weary heat of another summer of crisis, amidst purges in Russia and attacks in Korea, it was refreshing to note this week that sailors still have "the craziest ideas," and that the cruiser Los Angeles is now the talk of the fleet.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Members of the Senate and House of Representatives reached a compromise agreement today on two money bills providing more than $5,000,000,000 for more than a score of Federal agencies, including the Atomic Energy Commission, the Veterans Administration, the Housing and Home Finance Agency and the Tennessee Valley Authority.

CENTRAL FRONT, Korea, Sunday, July 19--Thousands of artillery shells were sent from big Allied guns at moving Chinese Communist troops yesterday in an effort to destroy reinforcements headed for enemy positions along the Kumsong River line.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 18 -- Several awards for the quality of content and format of its publications have been received by the Princeton University Press in the last year, according to a report submitted today by Norvell B. Samuels, '24, acting director of the press, to its board of trustees.

Count Turf and Conn McCreary relived past glories yesterday in winning the Questionnaire Handicap at Jamaica. The cool jockey and the 5-year-old horse once again were the perfect combination as they wrapped up the $28,650 event with ease, but at the finish Count Turf broke down and as a result he will never race again.

IT takes a pretty good bridge player, kibitzing in on an expert game, to escape the conclusion that the best players are vastly overrated. After nearly every hand there are accusations and recriminations. The kibitzer could pardonably get the idea that our best bridge players hardly ever do anything right.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., July 18 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey and Maj. Gen. Edward C. Rose, chief of staff of the New Jersey Department of Defense, left this military reservation this afternoon by plane for New Jersey after reviewing the Fiftieth Armored Division, New Jersey National Guard, now in training here.

SILVERSTONE, England, July 18 (UP) -- Alberto Ascari and Giuseppe Farina, two of Italy's crack automobile racing drivers, steered their Ferraris to record performances today in winning the British Grand Prix and Formula Libre races before 100,000 at the Silverstone track
New progress in the slow and difficult task of improving conditions for American private investment and business abroad has just been achieved in Washington and Geneva.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 18 -- Victories by two European yachtsmen, Ernst Bermester of Germany with the 12-meter Aschanti and Squadron Leader Charles T. Nance of England's Royal Air Force in a Thistle, gave a touch of international importance to the beginning of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week today.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 18 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift, 22-year-old star from the Glen Oaks Country Club, of Great Neck, L. I., continued her sweep of recent tournaments in this area when she took the women's New York State golf title at the Hempstead Club today.

IDA Lupino, up to her delicate neck currently as star, director and co-producer of "The Bigamist," has no time to talk about the ambitious future plans of Filmakers, the company into which she and Collier Young are putting all their strength and effort.

AN important goal, the widespread knowledge and use of Labanotation has been made possible through a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation. This award was made to the Dance Notation Bureau for the specific purpose of preparing a textbook on this system of recording movement.

With the purge of Lavrenti P. Beria it is now clear that much of the astounding pattern of events in the Soviet Union during the last six months is explainable in terms of a bitter struggle for power in which the relative strength of the contestants changed several times.

PENSACOLA, Fla., July 18 (AP) -- Following is the list of the names of five survivors and forty-one killed in the crash of a Marine cargo plane near Milton, Fla., last midnight, as released by the Navy:

NOW that he has completed his first stint as a director on "Go, Man, Go!" the Alfred Palca production dealing with Abe Saperstein and his Harlem Globetrotters troupe, James Wong Howe is ready to try his hand at a second independent venture.

LAST year the Polaris Press initiated its laudable project of reprinting long-forgotten classics of fantasy. Their first, Francis Stevens' "The Heads of Cerberus," was an engrossing tale, fully deserving the attention of modern readers.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Senator McCarthy's recent threat to subpoena officials of the Central Intelligence Agency has focused unwelcome attention on the shyest of our security organizations.

CONSIDERABLE comment on the complex life of today's wife and mother reached us after publication four weeks ago of the column headed "How Girls Judge Mother's Role." Most of our correspondents agreed with the implications of the material we presented -- that many women today, in their quest for perfection in varied fields, are exhausting themselves and discouraging their daughters from the usual normal wish to follow in mom's footsteps.

ROME, July 18 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi's efforts to get Parliament to ratify the European Defense Community treaty were believed to have suffered a severe setback as a consequence of the invitation of the Western Big Three to Yugoslavia to send a mission to Washington for military conversations, before any steps had been made toward a solution of the quarrel between Italy and the Government of President Tito over Trieste.

We are still living in the Stone Age. A modern version, of course, but none the less a genuine Stone Age. Many of our necessities and luxuries -- including some of our food, drink, power and heat -- are derived from the minerals and ores in rocks and stones.

THE foresighted gardener who applied a mulch over his flower or vegetable plot after the last soaking rain is now benefiting in two ways. Not only does a mulch give a neat appearance and keep down weeds, but it also helps to preserve the moisture in the soil during periods of dry weather.

AT least one man in Canada's Stratford is feeling easier this morning. After dreaming for years of setting up a Shakespearean festival in a small isolated community, Tom Patterson, a local resident, knows now that it can be done and that theatregoers everywhere will have to take it seriously.

Manager Eddie Stanky, who has been speaking to umpires with acerbity for three days, probably was talking to himself in the same vein last night after seeing his Cardinals beaten by the Dodgers for the fourth straight time at Ebbets Field yesterday.

IT'S getting so any self-respecting resort community feels it ought to have at least one celebration a season to bring crowds and attention its way. A number of fairs, pageants and open house days are on the current schedule.

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 18 -- The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico will celebrate its first anniversary as a self-governing state July 25. It will be an important milestone in the four-century history of the Caribbean island.

A THOROUGH understanding of road maps before the vacation trip begins, particularly on the part of motorists who are planning extensive journeys, can add to enjoyment of the trip. Often many miles are wasted by taking the wrong route, and the driver risks fatigue and a ruffled temper while backtracking to get to the right destination.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Boot camps for recruits -- old stuff to the armed forces -- are being introduced into the Justice Department by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- The customers at Arlington Park today learned first-hand why so many superlatives have appeared in the public prints in describing Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's gray 3-year-old colt, Native Dancer.

A FORMER industrial worker, John Greenway is a folksong singer and gitbox-pounder as well as a trained scholar now teaching at Rutgers. He has in "American Folksongs of Protest" turned in a job of rescue.

HERE is that sensitive lieutenant, junior grade, again, bucking tradition and the Academy, sticking up for his gun crew. for Negroes who want to rise out of the messboy hole and into combat, for the tough but philosophical Jewish sailor from Brooklyn who thrives on salami sandwiches.

In a contest lasting 3 hours 20 minutes in torrid heat, Mike Green of Miami Beach, Fla., came from far behind to defeat Kalman Hettleman of Baltimore and win the Eastern junior championship yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

DAMARISCOTTA, Me. -- New Englanders showed an early penchant for boxing the compass with the name of a parent town: a village like Liverpool was established, and the new towns springing up within a radius of five miles became North, South, East and West Liverpool respectively.

I was rather appalled by Clifton Daniel's quite idyllic representation of the British Health Service, "A British Doctor Weighs the Health Service" (July 5). If Dr. Harper's practice is at all typical of current British medical procedure the British public must be getting grossly inadequate medical care.

PATERSON, N. J., July 18 -- David L. Cole of this city, president of the Shapiro Foundation, announced today that the foundation's annual scholarships, totaling $12,400, would go to sixty-two college students.
PITTSBURGH, July 18 (AP) -- Eddie Mathews blasted his twenty-eighth homer of the season and Joe Adcock connected for his ninth to power the Braves to a 4-3 victory today over the Pirates.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan, came back swinging today at House of Representatives colleagues who called him "testy" and "old" in an unusual floor attack yesterday. The 77-year-old chairman of the House Committee on Government Operations said he would get up in the House Monday "to make adequate reply to the gentlemen."

Sheet music published from 1614 to 1950, reflecting the opinion of the times on tobacco and its use, will be on exhibition to mid-September, beginning Thursday, at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

The liquor industry is a little more cheerful these days because of two factors. The slight increase in prices posted for the package stores in New York State on July 1 has resulted in no reduction in volume traceable to it. There has been a substantial and unexpected reduction in the stocks of whisky in bonded warehouses.

FORT DIX, N. J., July 18 -- Seven soldiers, including four from New York City, have been found guilty of mutiny by a general court martial, it was confirmed today by Capt. Harry M. Lapham, post public information officer. The men have received sentences of fifteen to twenty years each, dishonorable discharges and forfeiture of all pay and all allowances.
After a modest recovery movement that had extended over a three-week period, the stock market seesawed within a narrow price range last week and closed fractions lower.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Business activity in the Chicago area set new records during the first half of 1953, but there are indications that the retail field failed to keep pace with production, employment, money income and most other categories. The Chicago Association of Credit Men in its quarterly report for the period ended on May $1 revealed a decline in the number of retailers taking discounts.

On these pages are recent photographs from Russia distributed by the official Soviet picture agency, Sovfoto. The captions are quoted from Sovfoto's own descriptions. They convey a general impression of quiet and order, of prosperity and well-being. Significantly, Sovfoto has not recently sent abroad any pictures of Russia's leaders -- a sure indication of the bitter struggle for power that has been raging in the Kremlin.

IF someone offered to sell you a pass valid for a month for free travel on all the United States' major railroads and on Great Lakes and Mississippi River steamboats, and for half-fare on almost all interurban bus lines, and if the end of the month would prove that you had saved at the most only a few dollars on your total mileage, would you buy the pass?

MOSCOW, Sunday, July 19 -- M. D. Bagirov, chairman of the Council of Ministers (Premier) of the Soviet Middle East republic of Azerbaijan and one of the alternate members of the fourteen-man Presidium of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Union, has been dismissed from his posts on charges of grave errors.

Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., may never realize Paul Erlich's dream of finding the therapia sterilsans magna -- the one magic chemical bullet that would kill all the organisms that attack the human body. But in the past decade or so, this 104-year-old manufacturer of pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals, those used in filling doctors' prescriptions, has thrown up a powerful barrage against man's microbic foes.

STATISTICIANS report some startling facts about lonely girls at the seaside. And this is the most startling: Of the 6,000,000 women who will go away for their holidays this year, 1,500,000 will be alone. There just aren't enough men to go around.

The financial market place is reflecting the welter of expedients being used by the governments of the various states to help under-propertied and fast-growing local districts to put up badly needed schools which could not be financed from local tax resources.

Ephraim F. Jeffe, the only member of the New York City Transit Authority to vote last Monday against a 15-cent fare on the municipal subway and surface lines, will formally quit his post tomorrow. He made his intention clear in a telegram to City Hall yesterday.

CAMDEN, Me., July 18 -- An invited audience of 100 persons, including thirty members of the Maine Press and Radio Women's Association, packed Whitehall Inn this afternoon for the dedication of the music room in memory of Edna St. Vincent Millay, Pulitzer Prize winning poet, who spent her early life in this town.
ELIZABETH, N. J., July 18 -- The whereabouts of twelve tons of paving blocks posed a mystery today for the police and Abraham Rogow, owner of an auto trailer park in Bayone.
The Floyd Bennett Post No. 1061 of the American Legion, Brooklyn, will act as sponsor for blood donations to the Red Cross on Tuesday.

I am one of a group which has never, to my knowledge, been represented in your Sunday Mail Bag, a theatregoer confined to a wheelchair. Admittedly ours is a difficult problem for the theatre personnel, as well as ourselves, but oftentimes the inconvenience we cause is blatantly brought to our attention in an embarrassing way.

JAMBOREE CITY, Calif., July 18 (AP) -- The third National Boy Scout Jamboree, swinging into its second day, developed into a humming conglomeration of scoutcraft demonstrations, Indian dancing, ocean swimming, horse shows, swapping and boyish pranks today.

PARIS, July 18 (AP) -- Bobby Locke of South Africa won his second straight French open golf title today, snatching the lead with a record 65 on the third round and holding it with a final 69 for a seventy-two-hole total of 276.

TOKYO publishers are making it easier for serious and casual students of Nippon. Japanese and expatriate American publishers are issuing more translations of indigenous books and English originals about this country. Not all are scholarly. There is pleasure reading for all ages, from kindergarten on up.

Although I nodded my head (mentally of course) in agreement with most of your fine column of last Sunday, I felt that your argument for Production Code approval of the movie, "The Moon Is Blue," because the play "had proved tasteful to hundreds of thousands of theatregoers," overlooks two fundamental differences between the screen and stage.

CAIRO, July 18 -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson is expected to bring back to Cairo tomorrow the latest thinking of London and Washington on the future of the important military base in the Suez Canal Zone.

INVENTORIES are beginning to feel burdensome in several areas of the business community. Thus far the pressure has proved more annoying than painful, but it is reflected in lengthened invoice collection periods and requests on the part of both durable and non-durable consumer goods manufacturers for extra dating.

The National Scholarship Service and Fund for Negro Students, Inc., 31 West 110th Street, has awarded supplementary college scholarships ranging from $100 to $400 each to thirty-four outstanding boys and girls from twelve southern states and the District of Columbia.

WHAT a genius for folly Rolfe had! It makes his literary gifts look commonplace though he gave to his novels all the store of curious learning, all the gorgeous but off-hand style, all the headlong and self- betraying fancy that hard and careful work could stimulate.

WITH the sonorous title of "Special Commemorative Coronation Release," London has celebrated the recent ceremonies in England with the issue of a group of disks devoted to British music. It is, in a way, a survey of music in the period between the two Elizabeths, except that Handel (who, after all, was a Londoner) is missing and the great gap between the Elizabethans and Elgar remains a great gap.

In the quiz, "Superlative Place" (July 12) you stated that the Missouri is the next longest river in the Western Hemisphere. Though we Missourians are proud of our muddy but mighty Mo, I'm sure you know that the Mississippi is the longer, and second only to the Amazon as the longest.

This city has at least 1,500 neglected children who are in danger of becoming seriously delinquent because they lack homes or proper care, Justice Hubert T. Delany of the Domestic Relations Court said yesterday.
Police Lieut. Arthur Miller, facing a departmental trial on charges that he lied about Communist affiliations to a superior officer, was found fit for duty yesterday by two physicians.
CHICAGO, July 18 -- The top-seeded favorites, Maureen Connolly and Victor Seixas, advanced to the singles finals of the national clay court tennis tournament today.

IN fiction, as in life, old women given to quoting maxims, proverbs and muttering to themselves as they go about doing good deeds can be engaging and even entertaining. On the other hand, they can be pretty dull.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 -- A rankling fear of internationalism long manifested by a small but vociferous minority of Los Angeles' 2,000,000 citizens welled up this week to cause the abrupt rejection of a $335,000 grant to the community from the Ford Foundation.

THESE new titles in the Man and His World Series for junior and senior high schools are welcome additions to the science shelf. "The Way of Science" is written so simply that all children will find it interesting and instructive. The book contains material not easily available elsewhere in such readable form.
CHICAGO, July 18 -- The White Sox scored three times in the eighth inning today for a 10-6 victory over the Senators to sweep a four-game series and gain their eighth straight triumph.

IN the world of the future, a series of tests establishes a man's rank. Eldin Raigmore, a manufactured human, comes to life knowing he is actually an extra-terrestrial. He does not know his assignment, save that he must become a White Star, the tests' highest rating.

N A. E. Popham's "The Drawings of Leonardo da Vinci" (1946), the Keeper of Drawings at the British Museum writes: "It is of course impossible for any but a professed anatomist to pass judgment on the significance of Leonardo's work in this field."

The final make-up of the fifteen-man United States track and field team, which is to compete in the International Maccabiah Games in Tel Aviv, Israel, Sept. 20-29, has been completed. Brutus Hamilton, who coached the American Olympic team last summer at Helsinki, will direct the United States Maccabians.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- The acting Senate Republican Leader, William F. Knowland of California, promised today to give priority to the Administration's $240,000,000 postal rate increase bill this session if the House of Representatives approved it.

PIRACY is one of the oldest professions. It probably began with maritime history, and carried through till the twentieth century. At one period it enjoyed the patronage of royalty and nobility and was regarded as a respectable occupation, even by men of substance and education.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified 179 Korean war casualties today, including twenty-four killed, 133 wounded, two missing, eleven captured and nine injured. Casualties from New York and New Jersey follow (none from Connecticut):

MILTON, Fla., July 18 (UP) -A Navy investigating board rushed here to study the debris of the Marine transport plane and impounded the wreckage today. The crash was believed the worst single air disaster in the history of operations of the Pensacola Naval Air Station -- the "Annapolis of the air."

LONDON, July 18 -- Miss Peggy Cripps, daughter of the late Sir Stafford Cripps, former Chancellor of the Exchequer in the Labor Government, and Joseph E. Appiah, an Ashanti tribesman, were married here today.

ST. LOUIS, July 18 (UP) -- Washington University announced today its archaeological expedition in Greece had located the graves of the seven legendary heroes who marched to their death on the seven gates of Thebes, and said the find might be the most important archaeological discovery of the year.

TODAY'S column continues the discussion of science fiction begun last Sunday. It will not be my final word on the subject, because I propose, during the weeks of comparative leisure which are enticingly imminent, to acquire a first-hand acquaintance with what is currently being written by the contributors to such magazines as Astounding, Galaxy, and Fantasy Science Fiction.

America's most promising young scholars are produced by fifty of the nation's 800 colleges and universities, according to a report published by the University of Chicago-Wesleyan University Press. Privately supported co-educational colleges in the East and Middle West are the main producers of the future "bright young men."

Jehovah's Witnesses poured into New York yesterday by the thousands. They came by plane, train, ship and motorcar. Some limped into a New Jersey tent and trailer city in steaming "jalopies"; others arrived at their hotels in high-priced limousines.

BUENOS AIRES, July 18 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, the President's special envoy, arrived here this morning for a week-end visit during the course of which foundations may be laid for more cordial relations between this country and the United States.

TOKYO, Sunday, July 19 (AP) -- Rain-fed flood waters that raged suddenly down a steep, narrow valley in central Japan took a toll of almost 5,000 dead and missing, the police reported today. Many more thousands were driven from their homes.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 18 -- Larger corn and cattle marketing helped to hold cash farm income lover the Ninth Federal Reserve District pretty well in line during the first five months of the year, the Minneapolis Reserve Bank reported. The area as a whole showed a 3 per cent decline over 1952, the bank said, but Minnesota reported a 5 per cent increase, largely due to its record 1952 corn crop.

HONOLULU, July 18 (AP) -- Freshening winds today sent four more yachts across the finish line of the 2,225-mile California-Hawaii race, but the little ketch Staghound, well at sea, was the only serious challenger to the first-place position held by the yawl Chubasco, owned by W. L. Stewart Jr. of Pasadena, Calif.

FARMINGTON, Conn., July 18 -- Ch. Braeval Biscuit, a miniature poodle imported from Wales, was named best in the Farmington Valley Kennel Club's show today. The dog from the Seafren Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Saunders L. Meade of Malvern, Pa., scored in a final which included the consistent English springer spaniel, Ch. Melilotus Lucky Star, owned by Susan Schwerdtle of Stepney Depot, Conn. Lucky Star gained the award as best American-bred.
Expansion of shipping service to the new industrial city of Kitimat on the coast of British Columbia has been announced by Saguenay Terminals of Montreal.

SALLY CARRIGHAR must be the first author of the year for whose work an entire race of beguiling rodents has acted as a sort of advance drum beater. For a month to the day before her "Icebound Summer" came out (see page 3), the newspapers were reporting the start of the periodic march of Alaskan lemmings to the sea.

THE mid-July lull in gardening activities affords gardeners -- both amateur and professional -- temporary respite from their busy round of chores. Commercial growers are currently making good use of this week of grace.

BERLIN, July 18 -- As a result of the fall of Lavrenti P. Beria, every member of East Germany's Socialist Unity (Communist) party must be screened, regardless of how lofty a position he may hold. Neues Deutschland, the official party newspaper said today.

In theory, major party candidates for Mayor of New York City are chosen by party voters in primary elections. But in practice, the five county leaders of each party meet long before primary day and hand-pick their candidate who is then duly nominated because the leaders control the primaries.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 18 -- Senator McCarthy has his sphere of influence in Texas, as shown in editorials and letters-to-the-editor columns in the state's newspapers. But while in some areas the Senator appears to be riding a wave of popularity, in others his stock is consistently low.

A big but little-known concern that for thirty years has been making the innards first of radio sets and lately of television receivers has begun, after all these years, to make an end-product, one that can be used in "as is" form by the customer in his home.

IN this volume is told once again the already thrice-told tale of the conviction of Alger Hiss for perjury. After hearing and observing all the witnesses, a jury of twelve was satisfied beyond any reasonable doubt that Hiss had falsely stated to a Federal grand jury that he had not given copies of secret state papers to Whittaker Chambers and that he had not seen Chambers after Jan. 1, 1937.

MILTON, Fla., July 18 -- Navy investigators seeking the cause of the crash of a Marine transport plane that killed forty-one men hoped tonight that five survivors could supply a clue. Thirty-seven naval Reserve Officers Training Corps college students and four crewmen were killed in the fiery crash of the twin-engined cargo plane.

THE Germans have a word for a writer who let his hail (and standards) down. They call him "unbuttoned." Dr. A. J. Cronin must have been in very unbuttoned mood when he wrote "Beyond This Place," an old- fashioned melodrammer of the kind popular circa Ouida and Marie Corelli.

The great mulleins stand majestic in the pastures and along the roadsides, gray-green and in lonely grandeur. They are weeds and of no consequence as flowering plants, not half as pretty as a thistle, for instance. But there is a classic beauty in their symmetry and their tall, straight stems and carefully graduated leaves.

THE serious teen-age science student as well as young readers with an interest in the subject will find this book a valuable companion. Here is a condensed science reference volume that contains accurate and up-to-date information on such subjects as astronomy, physics, botany, zoology, human physiology -- plus a final chapter on the origin and evolution of man.

WHOEVER would say a good word for intuition nowadays must expect from some quarters a very stiff resistance, if not downright suspicion. Jacques Maritain, the French Catholic philosopher, has therefore his job cut out for him in this book, which grew out of the Mellon Lectures, delivered at the National Gallery in Washington in 1952.

LOUIS M. HACKER closes his review of T. K. Quinn's "Giant Business" with the following statement: "Our real problem is the conservation of our economic power, within the proper context of a responsible world; the utopian hankering after equality can destroy us as effectively as authoritarianism."

TWO months ago Frank B. Laughlin, then acting United States Collector of Customs for District 10, which covers the Port of New York, revised the procedure for processing baggage inspection for all travelers entering this port.

Hydrazine, a clear, waterlike liquid composed of nitrogen and oxygen and made from ammonia, was Germany's secret rocket fuel in World War II. As late as last year we imported hydrazine. Now it is made at Lake Charles, La.

Academic freedom is an essential part of our system of liberty. The right of professionally qualified members of college faculties to discover, publish and teach the truth as they see it is indispensable, not just to a free educational system, but to a free society.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The three Democrats who resigned July 10 from Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations formally rejected today his invitation to return to duty.

THERE was some instinctive hesitation in the mind of this reviewer the other day when he came out and said "The Band Wagon" might be one of the best musical films ever made. Lofty comments of that nature sometimes have a way of popping up a few weeks or months later and causing the maker's face to turn bright red.

HAVING used, successively and to no apparent avail, Frank Sinatra, motion pictures, a variety show and Ernie Kovacs in the 8 to 9 o'clock time period on Tuesday nights opposite Milton Berle, the C. B. S television network this fall will offer a new combination: a tried and true Western show starring Gene Autry at 8 and a refurbished and revivified Red Skelton, at 8:30.

* * * The review certainly gave me a jar and Louis Hacker a wide opportunity to express his prejudices against Jacksonian Democracy, Populism, President Wilson's New Freedom. Justice Brandeis, Tawney, the Webbs, et al.
DETROIT, July 18 (AP) -- Housewives working in auto plants may be first to feel employment cuts resulting from further defense production curtailments.

BOONTON, N. J., July 18 -- The teams of Phil Dameo and Chet Sanok, Metropolitan open champion, and Mike Cestone and Stanley Gural, all of the Forsgate Country Club, tied with one-over-par 71's at the end of the first round of the thirty-six-hole New Jersey State Golf Association Scotch foursome championship at the Knoll Country Club today.

Representative Francis E. Dorn, Republican of New York, emphasized last week that if a second aircraft carrier of the Saratoga class was authorized for construction he would urge that the ship be built at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn. The Representative is a member of Congress from the Twelfth New York District comprising parts of Brooklyn.
A. B. Chandler, former Baseball Commissioner, said yesterday he would "do anything to help the players" but was not interested in any job as a players' representative.

The Indo-China war has been going on for nearly eight years. The French and Indo-Chinese forces have been able to hold the principal cities, keep the main lines of communication open -- but with great difficulty -- maintain a series of perimeter forts, and repulse the major offensives of the Communist Vietminh forces.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 18 -The Joint Brazil-United States Economic Development Commission will cease to exist as of July 31 after having studied and approved projects involving loans of $380,000,000 from the Export-Import Bank and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development for vital economic development in Brazil.

The historian Arnold Toynbee has written that "it is far more likely that we shall lack the courage than the wisdom" in approaching the problems of our Western civilization. This admonition covers many issues confronting the United States, among them farm commodity price policies.

GLEN COVE, L. I., July 18 -- The Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, only institution in the United States with its course devoted exclusively to naval architecture and marine engineering, conferred degrees upon eighteen men today at its fifty-eighth annual commencement.
Both private industry and the Government are steadily widening the search within the United States for new sources of the atomic fuel uranium.

THE 1953 competition for the Ten Best Amateur Films of the year and the Hiram Percy Maxim Award is announced by the Amateur Cinema League, 420 Lexington Avenue, the sponsor. The contest is open to all amateurs, whether or not members of the league, and films of every type in 8mm or 16mm size.

BERLIN, July 18 -- At no time since the end of the Second World War has the United States undertaken such an intensive propaganda campaign, according to American officials here, as is being developed in connection with President Eisenhower's offer of $15,000,000 worth of food to East Germany.

THIS is the fifth volume in Edward E. Smith's serial saga of the Lensmen, those interplanetary police who always get their man. For the benefit of those who came in late, it may be said that these stories combine an incredible naivete with an incredible ingenuity and verve.

In a paper read before the Institute of Marine Engineers (London) Sir John Cockcroft estimated that, assuming an efficiency of 25 per cent, an atomic ship-propulsion plant that would develop 10,000 shaft horsepower, would require twelve kilograms ( thirty pounds) of "fuel" a year, or sixty kilograms if the fuel had to be changed after 20 per cent had been consumed.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The equal rights amendment, continuously pending in Congress for more than thirty years, was voted by the Senate this week in a way that resolved none of the feminine controversy that surrounds it:

HONG KONG, July l8 - Despite the Chinese Communist attacks this week on the central front in Korea, official political observers here continue to cling to the belief that the Peiping Government really wants an armistice. But there are developing doubts in some quarters as to the ability of the Panmunjom conferences to resolve the present impasse, short of an unforeseen basic concession by one side of the other.

THE entrance of the United States into World War I confronted the American Society of Friends with a difficult dilemma. The Quaker declaration of 1660 had said, "We utterly deny all outward wars and strife and fighting with outward weapons to any end and under any pretense whatever.
"THE principles of Jefferson," wrote Abraham Lincoln in 1859, "are the definitions and axioms of free society."

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 18 --One of the leading figures in British Africa south of the Equator, Michael Blundell, parliamentary leader of the Kenya settlers, has brought out into the open here the fear and hostility toward India.

NEW DELHI, India, July 18 -- Increased Communist activity in Nepal, the Himalayan kingdom between India and Tibet, has aroused considerable interest here as it could create a potentially dangerous border situation for this country.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 -- Retail activity among Twelfth District department stores showed a healthy gain last week in all key areas except Salt Lake City. Oakland set the pace with a 15 per cent increase over last year while the Los Angeles area registered a 12 per cent gain.

PEOPLE in Nairobi, the capital of Kenya, are fond of describing their city as a frontier town. Although it is the largest and most important town in that curious association of protectorates, colonies and trust territories known as British East Africa, still it is a very young city.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 18 (UP) -- Lights Up, the horse that came hack to the races after breaking down, scored the greatest victory of his career today as he captured Hollywood Park's top distance stakes, the $105,950 Sunset Handicap at a mile and five-eighths, by a neck.

Robert Waithman in "Rah! Cheltenham!" (July 12) reports the astounding news that British girls in private schools are allowed as seniors to wear nylons and use lipstick "discreetly." No good can come of this.

In his relations with Congress, Theodore Roosevelt acted on what he called the "Jackson-Lincoln theory" -- "that the Presidency should be a powerful office, and the President a powerful man, who will take every advantage of it." During the 1952 campaign President Eisenhower promised to show "respect for the great functions of the Legislature," which, he said, "is, after all, the United States and speaks for the population."

ABILENE, Kan., July 18 -- Construction work on the museum that will house the war and political trophies of President Eisenhower has been completed and directors of the Eisenhower Memorial Foundation waited today for the last shipments of these trophies before starting the task of arranging them into displays.

BERLIN, July 18 (AP) -- Premier Otto Grotewohl insisted today that his East German Government was continuing steadfastly on its new course "to make ineffective the political agitation of enemies of the Republic." He ordered the Communist-controlled press to "drop old methods of propaganda."

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 18 -- George Uhe and Fred Lazard, Cherry Valley, the medal winners, led the way into the quarter-final round of the twelfth annual Charles R. Casey Memorial member-guest golf tournament with a 5-and-3 victory over Stanley Mackney and Tony Cisco, St. George's, at the Wheatley Hills Club today.

RICHMOND LATTIMORE is that rata avis in our age, the classical scholar who is at the same time an accomplished poet. A few years ago he gave us the finest translation into English of the "Odes" of Pindar. This was followed by an equally impressive rendering of the "Illiad," and still later came the "Agamemnon" of Aeschylus and Euripides' "The Trojan Women."

The fire that trapped and killed fourteen student missionaries and a forester in a California canyon is now reported to have been an incendiary blaze, deliberately ignited by a young man who wanted work in fighting forest fires. The dramatic horror of this story is shocking enough; but let no one be comforted by the thought that incendiary forest fires are, after all, few and far between.

MOSCOW, Sunday, July 19 (AP) -- The Soviet Union published today the text of a note in which it officially withdrew its claims against Turkey for territory and a share in the defense of the Dardanelles. In reply, Turkey declared her "satisfaction."

ATLANTA, Ga., July 18 -- The quarterly survey of the Georgia Association of Management released this week showed 87.5 per cent of retail accounts were discounting or paying when due as of the end of May. Last year's report showed 80 per cent either discounting or paying when due.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Although lawns, shrubs and trees, flower borders and all plantings need water, local restrictions or other conditions limit what can be done. Unless the drought is broken soon by heavy rains, decision must be made on what to water. Precedence should be given to trees and shrubs, particularly those set out during the last year.

FOR those in search of psychotherapy, there has long been a need for such an untechnical and informative book as this one on mental illness. Long known as the ablest reporter in the field of mental hygiene, Lucy Freeman explains in "Hope For the Troubled" the opportunities available in consultation and treatment for the maladjusted individual.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- The Smithsonian Institution disclosed today it was X-raying pre-historic diseased human bones to see if modern doctors could learn any "lost" techniques from ancient medicine men.
Your editorial on the recent incident involving the Soviet chess players is not only timely, but justly accords the decision the satirical treatment it so richly deserves.

WRITTEN largely from the British point of view, this little book on radar in war -- and in peace -- should interest all scientifically-minded boys. They will learn that radar has turned out to be almost as useful as radio, and now not only guides ships and aircraft through fog, but also is used in directing harbor traffic, whaling, weather forecasting, map making and astronomy.

SANTA FE, N. M. -- Several field study groups in archaeology and paleontology are at work in the Southwest this summer, and a few of their camps are accessible to tourists and within easy walking distance of paved highways.

Little merchandise was available for clearance sales in the wholesale markets here last week, according to Kirby, Block Co., residence buying office. Manufacturers concentrated on fall deliveries. Fur-trimmed coats started to sell with white and blue fox, beaver and persian wanted at better prices.

VIENNA, July 18 -- The Austrian Government has decided to build a big new Danubian hydroelectric plant and a four-lane east-west automobile highway in the Soviet zone of Austria despite objections raised on security grounds. Defending these plans in a speech today Chancellor Julius Raab said the power plant could be destroyed quickly in case of war and that the highway would be as useful to one side as to the other.
CLEVELAND, July 18 (UP) -- Harry Byrd recovered from a shaky start today to pitch the Athletics to a 9-3 victory over the Indians and salvage the last contest of their three-game series.

LONDON, July 18 -- General Sir Brian Robertson, a member of the British team for negotiations with Egypt on the British military base in the Suez Canal zone, will fly back to Cairo tomorrow carrying with him Britain's hopes for a profitable resumption of the talks.

ESSENTIALLY, "The Secret Masters" is the always-good story of the conspirators who have a secret by means of which they plan to take over the government. In this thriller with science - fiction overtones, the conspirators are the "Sciocrats" (they evidently pay more attention to atomic physics than to etymology), a group whose ideas begin where the Fascists leave off.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas today deplored as "a drop in the bucket" the Eisenhower Administration's efforts to help livestock producers in the drought-stricken Southwest.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, July 19 -- South Korean infantrymen pressed forward against heavier resistance today on the devastated central front. The Chinese Communists were pouring thousands of troops, bulwarked by tanks, across the Kumsong River in an effort to hold their gains of last week or to spring a new offensive.

GIVE an imaginative, inquiring producer a skilled staff, a generous supply of money, and the job of seeking out timely, factual stories for broadcast over upwards of 200 radio stations. Would this make him happy, and set him on the road to pleasing his audience?

THE Movie Sound 8, an 8mm magnetic sound-on-film combination recorder and projector, is now available. The price is $398.50. By means of an easily operated set of controls the 8mm movie maker can now dub in a sound track along the edge of his films merely by turning on a switch, talking into a microphone or recording music from a record player or other sound device.

CHILDREN who like scientific facts in story form will enjoy this new series, Everyday Science Stories, edited by Ruth Wyler. Each book weaves some aspect of everyday science into a tale for boys and girls of middle-grade age.
A LETTER from a reader in Elizabeth, N. J., raises several questions which may be troubling other people, and perhaps it would be useful to attempt the answers in this corner, First the letter:

The article "To Save the Houses of Our Heritage" in your issue of June 28 poses a somewhat thorny problem, and in the same issue as the straightening out of the "clamorous" monkey business at the Cloisters, too.

SUMMER, as Sally Carrighar found it just this side of the permanent polar ice pack in northwest Alaska, is a brief, uncertain season. In May and June, the sun shines from eighteen to twenty hours a day; the remaining hours are dusky.
A silent but bitter behind-the-scenes battle is brewing between the National and American Leagues for Los Angeles and San Francisco as possible new cities for major league baseball clubs.
Dry cargo rates continued last week their gradual decline toward the point of no return while tanker prices made a small surprising rally.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (UP) -- The Redlegs tied their club-season mark for home runs today and Willard Marshall batted in six runs as Cincinnati walloped the Phillis, 11 -- 0, with the help of three-hit pitching by Jackie Collum.

The twentieth annual women's open golf championship of Westchester and Fairfield Counties for the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy gets under way tomorrow over the West course of the Westchester Country Club at Rye, N. Y.

TOM SHEEHAN is a massive man. He stands 6-foot-5 or so and carries some 240 pounds of hard-packed muscle on his frame. Tom is a Giant in size as well as affiliation, being Horace Stoneham's chief trouble-shooter as scout, coach, talent-inspector and what-not. When he speaks, everyone listens. In the first place he has a deep and commanding voice.

THE great doomed poets of Romanticism, les poets maudits, Holderlin, Baudelaire, Poe, Rimbaud, were tormented by their mothers. All of them were hag-ridden by female super-egos of exceptional ferocity. Only Holderlin went completely mad.

WHEN the International Music Council held its first General Assembly at UNESCO House, Paris, early in 1950, a program of activities and initiatives was drawn up that looked too ambitious and far-reaching in view of the small subsidies available.

BERLIN, Sunday, July 19 -- The Soviet Union charged last night that United States planes had circled low over two Soviet airfields near Berlin almost daily during the last two weeks, dropping anti-Soviet leaflets. United States officials termed the charge "nonsense," The United Press reported.]
