WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Washington Star said tonight that Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg got part of his testimony before Congress on Air Force budget cuts deleted from the official record -- after it was printed -- so he could avoid a direct clash with President Eisenhower.
Parties for hospitalized servicemen and disabled veterans will be given this week by the 52 Association of New York, Inc.

THERE was a time not long ago when we saw China through the eyes of her Western educated scholars. They knew, we thought, more than we would ever know; and when they painted China as a land of delicate contrasts and unalterable rituals we believed them. perhaps because we wanted to believe them.

CAIRO, July 18 -- Action by the British military authorities in the Suez Canal Zone this week goaded Egyptian leaders to bitter indignation and severely tested their decision to shift their main effort from a political dispute with Britain over control of the Canal Zone to a battle with Egypt's pressing economic problems.

STE. ADELE, Que. -- Thanks to what might be described as a spirit of cooperative competition among the resorts, vacationists this summer in the Laurentian Mountains north of Montreal are, more than ever before, getting their money's worth.

Secretary of State Dulles and Assistant Secretary Robertson made excellent use of a relatively new medium of communication in their radio and television report to the nation on Friday night. Their audience heard a lucid review both of the recent Foreign Ministers' conference and of Mr. Robertson's mission to Korea.

SEVERAL uses of the photographic medium are demonstrated in current one-man shows by five photographers. They range from the straight record to experiment and include journalistic, sociological and candid portraiture approaches.

Match play in the fifty-first Metropolitan amateur golf championship will start Wednesday at the Fenway Golf Club in White Plains and continue through Saturday when the thirty-six hole final will be contested.

HOWEVER high modern verse has soared beyond all that went before it, we must none the less give honor to the father of the whole movement, Edward Lear. His nonsense verse was nonsense only in that it transcended sense, and should be spoken of always as supra-sense rather than nonsense, which does not give the real meaning its full flavor.

SHORTLY after World War II business men were surprised to learn that their youngest employes -- office boys, clerks and typists in their first jobs -- were spending their two-week vacations in Florida. They left New York Friday night or Saturday morning, spent a full fourteen days at Miami Beach or Key West and flew back Sunday night, ready for work the next morning.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 18 -- The French Union parachutists dropped yesterday on the Vietminh-held China border town of Langson are making "satisfactory progress" in an overland withdrawal back to the French lines, a military spokesman announced here this evening.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 18 -- Joseph Gavegnano's colt Errard King, favorite in a field of twelve 2-year-old colts and geldings, won the $15,000 added Tyro Stakes at Monmouth Park today, defeating J. C. Brady's fast-closing Artismo by two lengths.

The Giants surveyed the world from the first division today for the first time since the National League pennant race took shape. Leo Durocher's spurting forces, which have won ten of their last eleven games, moved past the Cardinals into fourth place by walloping the Cubs, 12 -- 7, before 6,514 spectators at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Former President Herbert Hoover is likely to be asked to head a new commission to reorganize the Executive branch of Government, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A Senate investigation report charged today that since the outbreak of the Korean war, Western Allies of the United States had permitted an increasing and flourishing trade of more than $2,000,000,000 with Red China and other Communist countries at the cost of lives of United Nations troops.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association membership committee will need an extra day to finish its secret study of nine schools charged with athletic policy violations.

Two bands, a police escort and reception committee, Mayor Impellitteri and thousands of spectators will greet Ben Hogan on Tuesday morning when he returns to the United States with the British Open Golf Championship he won recently in Scotland.

Union College, Schenectady, N. Y., will offer a new five-year program leading to two bachelor's degrees in liberal arts and engineering. The new program may be elected by students enrolled in the college. Dr. Carter Davidson, president of the college, explained that students will now have a chance to develop themselves in both liberal arts and engineering, thereby providing a fuller background for work in industry concerned with problems in engineering.

BY far the most controversial work of the last decade has been the painting in extremely abstract manner by the American artists who have frequently been called the advance guard painters. Quantities of words have been poured out in defense and explanation as well as in ridicule and attack.

HERE we have Fletcher Pratt retelling, in terms of interstellar flight and against the background of an intergalactic culture, the myth of Jason and his Argonauts. The Jason of the far future is Thorwald Paulsson, disgraced captain of the Space Command, who thunders out across space to wrest from the Bosses of the planet Danaan their Golden Fleece, in this case a neptunium motor, and so free himself from the frame-up that ruined him.

THE problems that have confronted him during his first six months in the White House undoubtedly have conveyed to President Eisenhower full appreciation of Jefferson's view that the Presidency is "a splendid misery" -- the problems of exerting leadership, the opportunities of working with destiny, the frustrations.

The Jason of the far future is Thorwald Paulsson, disgraced captain of the Space Command, who thunders out across space to wrest from the Bosses of the planet Danaan their Golden Fleece, in this case a neptunium motor, and so free himself from the frame-up that ruined him.

THE problems that have confronted him during his first six months in the White House undoubtedly have conveyed to President Eisenhower full appreciation of Jefferson's view that the Presidency is "a splendid misery" -- the problems of exerting leadership, the opportunities of working with destiny, the frustrations.

YOUR article on the Barter Theatre in Abingdon, Va., on July 5 was of particular interest to me because of a somewhat parallel development in postwar Germany -- one in which, however, the impetus came from the audiences rather than from the players and producers.

PHOTOGRAPHS of Israel's coming stamps mentioned here two weeks ago have been made available by Jacques Minkus, director of the Israel Philatelic Agency in New York. The commemorative for the Seventh International Congress for the History of Science, in August, is a 110-pruta blue with portrait of Rabbi Moshe Ben Maimonides (1135-1204), philosopher and physician.

In the belief that a union's membership is entitled to a full report on its internal discipline, The Seafarers Log, official biweekly newspaper of the Seafarers International Union, Atlantic and Gulf District, A. F. L., has printed in its latest issue its first full report on the trials and appeals of the union's members.

WASHINGTON, -- Summertime's outdoor activities may cause stamp collectors' interest to wane and to some extent affect dealers' business, but there is no evidence in Washington of any lessening in official awareness of philately's existence.

AS quiet as a Jersey Joe Walcott rooter, T. S. Eliot slipped into his native country and out again. He spent most of his time in St. Louis (the place where he was born) and while looking over old sites and some family he also tucked away a degree, given him by Washington University.

A promising new vaccine against brucellosis in sheep and goats has been developed at the University of California by Drs. Sanford Elberg and Mendel Herzberg. Brucellosis afflicts domestic animals. It is often transmitted to man and is then called undulant fever.

William Mace Hickey wasn't born with a silver spoon in his mouth. Thousands of stockholders of the once giant utility holding company, the United Corporation, found themselves in the same situation after the market break of 1929 and the subsequent depression days of the Thirties. Today. United's stockholders are much happier.

Thousands of venders of pots and pans, other housewares and small electrical appliances were as busy last week as the proverbial paperhanger. They canvassed in all four corners of Atlantic City's huge Convention Hall seeking to make a killing at the annual Housewares Show there.

The conquest of Nanga Parbat, second highest peak to be scaled by man, followed by only thirty-six days the climbing of Mount Everest. Now the attempt to "conquer the unconquerable" continues, for reasons which many mountaineers have tried to explain. George Leigh-Mallory, one of the greatest climbers, once said that he wanted to climb Everest "because it was there." Here are some of the reasons given by others on why men climb mountains.
A call for help led the police last night to the discovery of the bodies of a psychiatrist and his wife sprawled across a double bed in their apartment on Central Park South.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 19 -- A rail-down fifteen-knot east-northeast wind gave some of the 266 starters miscellaneous troubles in the second regatta of Larchmont Race Week today, kept the race committee on the jump and brought the usual assortment of victories in fast time over long courses.

BERLIN, July 19 -- West Berlin's Mayor Ernst Reuter said today that a week from tomorrow a plan would go into effect for distributing food parcels to the East Germans, including East Berliners, who visit the Western sectors of this city.
The use of color to enhance the appearance of wood is demonstrated in a new group of five serene-looking room settings at Stern's.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Methodist Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam said today that "the church has done more to combat communism than all the Congressional committees put together."

LONDON, July 19 -- The British Foreign Office was hopeful tonight that the optimistic comment of Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations commander, on today's Korean truce developments meant "even better news" in the immediate future.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 19 -- Hal E. Chester, the producer, returned this week-end from a trip to England and Italy, where he set up a new method of American motion picture financing and guarantees for production.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Yesterday's fears of enemy "stalling" at Panmunjom were partly removed by the Communists' statement this morning that they were ready to undertake the preliminaries to the signing of a truce in the Korean war.

The bowling greens at Central Park echoed yesterday with the crack of bowls reminiscent of sounds heard on the first Bowling Green on the tip of Manhattan Island 300 years ago, as twenty-eight teams of lawn bowlers competed for the annual open doubles cup.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 19 (AP) -- Twenty-nine-year-old Shella Mayfield scored the first major victory of his professional career today with a nineteen-under par 269 to win the St. Paul open golf tournament.

Warning that the proposed sale of the Matson liner Mariposa for operation under a foreign flag could mean the loss of the ship as a transport in a national emergency, Hoyt S. Haddock, executive secretary of the C. I. O. Maritime Committee, yesterday reiterated his group's position that it is "undesirable and dangerous" to sell or transfer American-flag vessels to foreign registry.

The fact that the Soviet press and radio are keeping Soviet citizens in ignorance of important aspects of Hungary's retreat from Communist economic policy is arousing wide interest among diplomatic observers. This interest has been particularly stimulated in the last few days by evidence that Pravda deliberately censored its version of a speech by Matyas Rakosi, Hungarian Communist chief, to hide the full magnitude of the satellite's retreat from former policy.
ELIZABETH, La., July 19 -- A paper mill workers' strike that has drawn national attention to this community because of the attendant violence is now in its eleventh month.
ST. LOUIS, July 19 (UP) -- The Senators split a doubleheader with the Browns today, winning the second game, 13 -- 4, to snap an eight-game losing streak after dropping the first, 5 -- 4.
President Eisenhower has failed to "exert leadership" mainly because he is not too well informed on many issues, Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. asserted yesterday.

DETROIT, July 19 -- Poised today at the summit of its production curve, the automobile industry knows that the next inevitable step will be downhill. Manufacturers and dealers agree that an "adjustment" is near.

MADISON -- Wisconsin, a mixture of nearly all European nationalities, is a melting pot in its food tastes as well as its people. Because of its cheese and other dairy products, the state is well known as "America's Dairyland." But no one food is typical of it.

One of the major problems with which President Eisenhower had to deal when he took office last January, lest the reader may already have forgotten, was the problem of price controls, and what should be done about them. The President lost no time in clearing the air of the hypochondria that had settled, like murky fog, in this area.

RAPALLO, Italy, July 19 (AP) -- Lewis Hoad and Ken Rosewall, the Wimbledon champions, lost only two games in a three-set match today to win the doubles title in the Rapallo junior tennis tournament. The 18-year-old Australians overwhelmed Italians Pietrangeli and Jacobini, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0.

Five hundred passengers on the Staten Island ferryboat Pvt. Joseph F. Merrell had an extra adventure for their nickels yesterday when the engine lost its power and the ferryboat drifted aimlessly off Governors Island until a rescuing tug took her in tow.

Eleven singers of the "Porgy and Bess" company have formed a group called Allied Singers, whose aim is to give recital opportunities to its members. Yesterday afternoon at Carl Fischer Concert Hall the first two of the group were heard -- Joseph Crawford, the tenor who sings the Honey Man, and Clarice Crawford, mezzo soprano, a member of the chorus.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, July 20 -- Chinese Communists drove Leathernecks of the United States First Marine Division from twin outposts on the western Korean front northeast of Panmunjom early today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Representative Richard M. Simpson said today that the Republicans would pitch next year's election campaign on the theme that President Eisenhower needed a G.O.P. Congress to complete his Administration's full four-year program.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 19 -- After six days of intensive efforts to revive Iran's paralyzed Majlis, the lower and sole existing house of Parliament, the Speaker, Dr. Abdullah Moazami, conceded today "there can be no hope of further sessions" and added "this has been the most difficult phase in Iran's parliamentary life."

LONDON, July 19 -- The report of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, accusing Western countries and particularly Britain of the "shocking policy of fighting the enemy China with one hand and trading with him on the other," elicited no specific denials here today.

Al Worthington is not Superman after all. Yesterday at the Polo Grounds the Braves exposed him for what he is -- a 23-year-old rookie right-hander who has a promising future with the Giants. After two successive shutouts in his first two major-league games, Worthington not only was scored upon, he was beaten, 2-1, in the five-inning second contest, which was called on account of darkness at 6:50 P.M.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, predicted today bigger business earnings and higher national income would help Government receipts to a second successive record high in the 1954 fiscal year that started July 1.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The International Monetary Fund today voiced "satisfaction" over the Eisenhower Administration's decision to study this country's foreign economic policy "with a view to permitting a freer flow of trade."

Jehovah's Witnesses jammed the Yankee Stadium yesterday in a moving display of faith. The participants, from over the country and most parts of the world, outnumbered the greatest baseball crowd ever to attend a game in New York.
Mrs. Myra Baxt of New York City has sold her nine-room home with twenty acres of land in Highland Mills, N. Y., to Mrs. M. Guterding of Searington, L. I., according to Previews, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -- The Administration has completed plans to reorganize the National Labor Relations Board along lines long urged by Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, an informed source said today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 19 -- The sucessful overland withdrawal of French Union paratroopers who jumped Friday in airborne attack on the Vietminh-held China border town of Langson was announced here tonight by the French High Command.

Combining delicate design, richness of detail and some important construction changes, the Delman fall shoe collection demonstrated the increasing importance of footwear as a major accessory in the field of fashion.

Sixty-three acres of land along Chestnut Ridge Road in Saddle River, N. J., have been acquired by George W. Peterson Sons, builders, who will divide the property into two-acre plots and start to build homes there next spring. The dwellings will be built in various styles from plans by Harvey E. Mather, architect, and will be priced at about $35,000 to $40,000.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 19 -- Paul S. Samuels of Poughkeepsie was elected commander of the New York State Department of the American Legion today. He succeeds Bruce Percy of Rochester.
Under the new Post Office administration it appears that postmen are turning into something of a corps d'elite, and here in New York they are going to look the part from now on.

The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, denounced yesterday as 'wholly inadequate" and "very disappointing" the decision of the House Committee on Un-American Activities to continue its present procedural policies with only one change.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -- Two champions in the Senate of high farm price supports today pledged an all-out, bipartisan effort to extend the current pricing program over the objections of the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra T. Benson.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine and chairman of a Senate investigating subcommittee, said today her group might study a reported shortage of Navy bombs and ammunitions.

MONTREAL, July 19 (UP) -- A singles victory by Lorne Main of Toronto and Vancouver today gave Canada a 3-2 triumph over Mexico and the right to meet Cuba in the second round of the American zone eliminations in Davis Cup tennis play.
TOKYO, Monday, July 20 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 449, for Sunday to 6 P. M.:
A cooling breeze swept in off the Atlantic Ocean yesterday and provided partial, but only temporary, relief from the heat wave.

The six-story loft building on a plot 75 by 200 feet at 622-26 Broadway, near East Houston Street, has been sold to the 622 Broadway Corporation by the Murrimac Realty Corporation and Charles Ross, as co-broker. The property is assessed at $260,000.
Six new films, including importations from Italy and England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

BLED, Yugoslavia, July 18 -- With the announcement today of the imminent formation of a second border commission with Yugoslavia's Cominform neighbors, the predictions by Yugoslav leaders that relations with the Soviet satellites would improve appeared to be coming true.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that the three Democrats who walked out on his Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations had raised a "phony issue" over his right, as chairman, to employ whom he pleased as staff members.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP) -- Willie Jones' single drove in the winning run as the Phillies pushed over three tallies in the bottom of the ninth to beat the Cubs, 6 -- 5, in the second game of a twin bill today. Homers won the opener for the Cubs, 5 -- 3, as Dee Fondy connected with the bases empty and Hal Jeffcoat hit a three-run round-tripper in the Cubs' five-run fourth inning.

The Crystal Transparent Corporation of New York has purchased from Beggs Brothers, Inc., a site of 30,000 square feet at the northeast corner of William Street and Forest Avenue in Englewood, N. J., for the erection of a factory building with 20,000 square feet of space for its cellophane printing business.

The annual one-day pulpit appeal for contributions to the work of the Society of St. Vincent de Paul in this area was made yesterday, the feast day of the saint on the church calendar, at all masses in the 387 Roman Catholic churches of the Archdiocese of New York.

TOKYO, Monday, July 20 -- The Communists' agreement to go ahead with preparations for signing of an armistice in the Korean war is a "most encouraging" development, Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations commander, said yesterday.

ZURICH, July 19 -- By a decision of the Swiss Federal Council on Friday, Charbonnages de France, French national coal mining corporation, will obtain a credit of 60,000,000 Swiss francs from the Swiss Bank Consortium at 4 1/2 per cent interest for a period of six to eight years.

The Continental Can Company, in the initial six months this year achieved the highest sales and earnings for a first half-year in its forty-eight-year history, according to the report of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, hoard chairman, mailed to stockholders today.

The fall of Lavrenti P. Beria Minister of Internal Affairs in the Soviet Union, is only the first major incident in a continuing "palace" struggle for power in which the Soviet Army will play a large part.

AMSTERDAM, July 19 -- The money market at present is dominated by the policy of the Treasury which has resulted in an abundance of money. The Treasury has not renewed its outstanding paper but held a tender last week on which, however, only 30 per cent was allotted.

Among the subjects for philosophical and academic discussion there is this: Which is the loneliest hour of the day.? Some hold out for the time of going to work, when the milling subway crowds merely intensify a sad feeling of personal solitude.

Tomorrow is the occasion of a pleasant anniversary for New Yorkers. On July 21, 1853, the State Legislature passed a bill declaring all the land bounded by Fifty-ninth and 106th Streets and by Fifth and Eighth Avenues to be "a public place." In 1859 the land up to 110th Street was added by Legislative act, making up the Central Park which we enjoy today as one of the blessings of the city.

An irregular trend was evident in the foreign exchange market during the last week. Amount of business transacted in the pound sterling picked up considerably over previous weeks and the Canadian dollar was moderately active.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 19 -- The Mianus River, last natural water supply source within the limits of this fast-growing community, is the prize in a long, hard-fought battle believed to be nearing a decisive phase.

In the expectation that a majority of the Democratic county leaders will vote today to designate Mayor Impellitteri for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, who is opposed to Mr. Impellitteri, will suggest that an attempt be made to reach agreement on candidates for the nomination for Controller and President of the City Council.

A distribution of 246,866 new shares of capital stock of Boston Edison Company is being made today to the company's stockholders on the basis of one share for each ten shares held. Stockholders can subscribe at $45 a share until Aug. 3. This represents the first equity financing by the 67-year-old utility company in eighteen years.

Paul Strauss of Chicago, who previously had been heard here only in his capacity as a ballet conductor, made his New York debut as a symphonic conductor late yesterday afternoon when he led the first of two concerts with the N. B. C. Summer Symphony in Radio City.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on major roll-calls in Congress during the period July 11 through July 17 are given in the appended tabulation:

LONDON, July 19 -- The stock markets are displaying a remarkably cheerful tone despite the summer paucity of business and the uncertainties in the international and home economic outlook. The ebb and flow of Korean peace hopes seem now to have little practical influence except in the commodity markets, where metals and particularly tin have continued to fall.

CHICAGO, July 19 (UP) -- The membership committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association said today it was sending three cases of suspected violations of rules to the N. C. A. A. council for action.
A prominent Fundamentalist clergyman charged yesterday that some of the leading theological seminaries in this country were turning out graduates who "do not believe in Christ."

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Total civilian employment in the United States remained at record levels last year, averaging 61,300,000 for the year, according to the annual labor force report released today by the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce.

Reports so far from 1953 Community Chest and United Fund Campaigns begun last fall indicate that the proceeds probably will be more than $265,000,000, Ralph H. Blanchard, executive director of Community Chests and Councils of America, announced yesterday.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 19 -- The annual benefit fair of the Ladies Village Improvement Society will be held on July 31 at historic Mulford Farm here. Proceeds from the event, which is under the general chairmanship of Mrs. Francis Kennedy, will be used for village improvements and for the support of charitable organizations in the area.

LONG LAKE, N. Y., July 19 (AP) -- Rains slowed a rampaging forest fire in the central Adirondacks tonight, and firefighters said they hoped to have the flames under control by morning. The Conservation Department called the fire along the Cold River "potentially the most dangerous in many years."

ISRAELI, July 19 -- About 5,000 ultra-Orthodox men and women, in a protest rally at the Great Synagogue here this evening, pledged themselves to what amounted to civil disobedience if the Government enacted legislation requiring girls exempt from military service i because of religious objections to perform civilian forms of national service.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -- The Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, J. Earl Coke, said today he felt sure that Government agencies under the Eisenhower Administration "can work together in a coordinated attack" on the nation' water problem.

BONN, Germany, July 19 -- Six hundred and twenty delegates representing thirty neo-Nazi splinter groups in all parts of West Germany met today in Mannheim, where they founded the National Rally, which will put up candidates in forthcoming general elections.

I was appalled at the letter of Lawrence Null which was printed in your issue of July 15. To buttress his position that "McCarthy's way is the only way * * * to get rid of the Communist traitors," he maintains that reliance on the Fifth Amendment by witnesses before Congressional committees is, to use his own wording, "a direct admission of guilt."
TOKYO, July 19 (AP) -- More than 6,000 Japanese were reported dead or missing today in a sudden, violent flood that swallowed whole villages about 200 miles southwest of Tokyo.

NEVADA CITY, Calif., July 19 (UP) -- A 200-man posse rescued Elmer Oates, a deputy sheriff, from three 18-year-old kidnappers today after they had forced him to accompany them as they robbed a tavern and had held him in a Yiva River camp all night.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen, Director for Mutual Security, indicated today that he disagreed with a charge by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's permanent investigating committee that Western trade with Communist China was a "shocking policy."

THE New Yorker stumbling in and out of subway burrows is apt to be a bit blind to Nature's endless manifestions. Seldom does he become aware of them until he has driven past the city line, and then they seem to come swarming at his picnic lunch or at sensitive areas not covered by a bathing suit.

" Lincoln McKeever," a new novel by Eleazar Lipsky, has been placed on Appleton-Century-Croft's November publication list. It is about a land grant case in a border town in the Territory of New Mexico toward the end of the nineteenth century. Like Mr. Lipsky's two other novels, "The Kiss of Death" and "The People Against O'Hara," the coming book is a Literary Guild choice -- for December.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 19 (AP) -- Communists in this country have succeeded in establishing a "little iron curtain over America," Louis F. Budenz, former member of the Communist party's national committee and a former managing editor of The Daily Worker, said on a radio forum here tonight.

Marjorie Larney, an 18-year-old Woodhaven athlete who holds the national javelin title, was the star of the annual Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior women's track and field championships yesterday at Victory Field, Glendale, Queens.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 19 -- Establishment of the "National Copper Corporation" in accordance with a decree submitted for the President's signature, constitutes one of the most important steps taken for copper in many years, it was maintained in government circles here today.

BUENOS AIRES, July 19 -- Members of Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower's goodwill and fact-finding mission, which is making a tour of ten Latin-American countries, denied today reports current here that the United States was prepared to offer Argentina half a billion dollars in economic aid or that the Argentine Government was seeking any United States loan.

PARIS, July 19 -- News of progress toward a truce in Korea was received with caution in French circles tonight in view of numerous disappointments after similar reports before. In fact, the attainment of an armistice in Korea would cause mixed feelings among the different groups in France.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 19 -- A winning par 4 by Fred Lazard at the seventeenth hole enabled the team of George Uhe and Lazard, Cherry Valley, to eliminate the defending titleholders, Dr. Ray Bowles and Richard Fales, Nassau, 1 up, in the quarter-final round of the twelfth annual Charles R. Casey Memorial member-guest golf tournament at Wheatley Hills today.

Increasing the subway fare from a nickel to a dime in 1948 was "a calamity," and raising it to 15 cents next Saturday will be "compounding the felony," Louis Broido, chairman of the advisory committee of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., declared yesterday.

Heretofore, Huntington Hartford 2d had kept under wraps the identity of the classic that he was adapting for his wife, Marjorie Steele, to act in. Yesterday, the A. P. heir disclosed that he was almost finished with the dramatization of Charlotte Bronte's novel, "Jane Eyre," in which Miss Steele will portray the leading feminine role.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified 130 Korean war casualties today. Of the total, ten are dead, 108 wounded, three missing in action, three captured and six injured in battle zone accidents. The following were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

Many persons no doubt think of the Tennessee Valley Authority as nothing but a public power project in competition with private power companies -- and approve or disapprove accordingly. Another aspect of T.V.A.'s work came up in connection with an item in a money bill agreed upon in a conference committee of the two Houses on Saturday.

The house dress has graduated into a new and interesting class. It is no longer the dull, utilitarian garment that a woman wears only when she's in the kitchen. Today it is styled and practical, easy to get into and to launder -- a dress that is both useful and good-looking in the house and on the street.

Labor and management groups should give more attention in their collective bargaining to the possible effects of their actions on the economic system as a whole, a special committee of the Twentieth Century Fund said yesterday in a report on "Employment and Wages in the United States."
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, July 20 -- Pyun Yung Tai, South Korean Foreign Minister, said today that there were "many traps" in the Communist agreement to proceed with preparations for signing a truce.

The Rakosi regime has been defeated in subjugated Hungary. Rakosi, who actually held power since the Coup d'etat against my Government in May, 1947, is succeeded as Premier by an Agrarian-Communist of less importance, Imre Nagy. The shelving of Rakosi is of much greater importance both from the Hungarian-and international points of view than it appears at first.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- The American League pennant seemed like a will o' the wisp to Chicagoans today after the Yankees had flattened out the White Sox in both ends of a sizzling double-header.

According to recent press reports and your optimistic editorial on the proposed Jones inlet jetty, we are about to see once more another engineering adventure to establish local control of the Atlantic Ocean, at the expense of nearly three million dollars of taxpayers' money.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 19 -Dedicated a quarter of a century ago last month, Goethals Bridge, linking this city and Staten Island and once dubbed "a white elephant," is gaining in revenue over the two other Staten Island bridges -- the Outerbridge Crossing to Perth Amboy and the Bayonne Bridge.

Council President Rudolph Halley favors a "strong Mayor" for New York and opposes the city manager plan, he declared yesterday in a letter to Devereux C. Josephs, chairman of the Temporary State Commission to Study Organizational Structure of the Government of the City of New York.

INWOOD, L. I., July 19 -- Maitland Jones of Bedford, N. Y., playing his first season in senior tennis competition, eliminated third-seeded Weller B. Evans of East Orange, N. J., 6 -- 3, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 4, today to reach the quarter-final round of the Eastern senior tennis championships at the Inwood Country Club.
TURIN, Italy, July 19 (AP) -- A touring American track and field squad won ten of eleven events today against an Italian all-star team at Turin's Municipal Stadium.

The American Jewish Committee, reporting the results of special survey, charged yesterday that neo-Nazis had made "dangerous" headway in Western Germany within recent months and had infiltrated into major political parties.
The first permanent installation of plastic crosswalk markers to guide pedestrians across congested intersections was made yesterday at Madison Square.

The automobile market in the New York metropolitan area is in sharp competition with itself because there is not a sufficient number of potential customers to absorb the heavy production of new cars or the used cars that are being traded in for 1953 models.

BOONTON, N. J., July 19 -- Billy Dear and Arnold Zimmerman, Morris County, erased a three-stroke deficit with a 70 today to tie Michael Cestone and Stanley Gural, Forsgate, with 144's in the Daniel Dameo Memorial Scotch foursome, sponsored by the New Jersey State Golf Association at The Knoll. The teams will stage a play-off on Friday at the same course.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., holder of the United States, Wimbledon and Australian tennis championships, added the national women's clay court title to her collection today, defeating Althea Gibson of New York City, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, in a fifty-two-minute match.

HONG KONG, July 19 -- The British have devoted the last 500 years to proving that the "inevitable" does not always happen and that logic, even if it seems to be catching up with them in this generation, is a vastly overrated commodity.
DAMASCUS, Syria, July 19 (AP) -President Adib Shishekly, who took office eight days ago, completed his Cabinet today.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., July 19 -- Pete Cooper, the Century professional, set a competitive course record at the Vernon Hills Country Club today with a 33, 31 -- 64, seven below par, during the club's fifth annual charity pro-member tournament.
Several major appliance makers reported yesterday a somewhat unexpected increase in sales and two of them announced forthcoming increases in prices.

Two new furnaces at the Raritan Copper Works of the International Smelting and Refining Company in Perth Amboy, N. J., have started producing copper cakes, or slabs, weighing from 1,800 to 3,000 pounds each, it was announced over the week-end.

General Eisenhower's Administration is clearly very serious about reorganizing the Executive branch of the Government. The reorganization and reorientation have resulted in many personnel changes and in some personnel curtailment. The job at hand is a large one and the focus of the Administration has been, in my opinion, too narrow.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $85,012,197,760. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

HOLYOKE, Mass., July 19 -- The Holyoke Kennel Club's annual show drew a quality field today. Hans Oberhammer of New York judged the final and selected the Iradell Kennels' Skye terrier, Ch. Ivory Jock of Iradell, handled by Walter Foster. It was the first best in show for the Iradell dog.

Westervelt A. Taylor, a former assistant district attorney in Queens, was arrested late yesterday afternoon in the St. Albans section of Queens after the police said he had interfered with an investigation of an automobile accident involving his niece.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (UP) -- Jack Kelly Jr., two-time Diamond Sculls champion, added to his many rowing titles today when he won two crowns in the seventy-ninth national rowing championships on the Schuylkill River.
READING, England, July 19 (AP) -- Scotland Yard's fraud squad today nabbed a pair of identical race horses in a bid to solve a betting mystery which almost cost Britain's bookies 250,000 ($700,000).

PITTSBURGH, July 19 (AP) -- Stan (The Man) Musial batted across three runs with a double and his eleventh homer of the year and Solly Hemus banged out four singles for St. Louis as the Cardinals snapped a six-game losing streak with an 8-2 victory over the Pirates today in the first game of a double-header.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 19 -- In a home-made hull built of plywood, 18-year-old Paul A. Peterson of Rumson, who was graduated last month from his local high school and is now planning an early enlistment in the Navy, this afternoon won the third annual Two Rivers outboard marathon.

Now that ,the 15-cent subway fare has become a certainty, I wonder how many of our midtown multi-million dollar business men have realized the harm they have done their business by not having offered to help subsidize our subways through taxes? With the fare increase the public will pay for the subway directly, while midtown business suffers a decline in volume and pays for it indirectly.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 -- The steel market appears to have more strength than the experts are willing to concede at this time. While new business does not have the dash it had a month or so ago it still rolls in at a good volume. Not only that but the diversification is broad.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, declared yesterday that the Rent Commission's "get tough" policy with landlords was proving highly successful in persuading them to restore services for tenants.
PARIS, July 19 -- For the third consecutive year the price of wheat in France is going to be fixed at 3,600 francs (about $10.25) a quintal. This is the price that was first set in 1951.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 19 -- German television is seriously considering a most wonderful idea for commercial video. Its aim is to have all the advantages of sponsored TV and none of the annoyances. David Sarnoff and William S. Paley: Achtung!

BERLIN, July 19 -- The continuing seriousness of the situation in East Germany since the June 17 riots was reflected today in a discussion of defeatism within the party by the official Communist newspaper Neues Deutschland.

If, by some feat of transmogrification, a magician could change Walter K. Gutman's "Money Magic in Chemical Stocks," reviewed last week, and Douglas H. Bellemore's "Investments: Principles and Practices"* into fighting cocks, there would be feathers all over Wall Street.

Effective on Aug. 3, the National Broadcasting Company will separate the program, sales and promotion activities of its television and radio networks into independent operating divisions, Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, board chairman of the Radio Corporation of America and N. B. C., announced over the week-end.

Neither the Dodgers nor the 15,652 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday had anything to be happy about until the eighth inning of the second game with the Redlegs. The Brooks had lost the opener, 4 -- 1, to the home-run hitting of Ted Kluszewski and the fine pitching of Fred Baczewski.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Many conflicting price trends marked trading in grains last week. Uncertainty regarding the outlook for a truce in Korea was an adverse factor. Weather conditions, as well as possible rust damage in the Northwest, spurred buying of wheat.

CLEVELAND, July 19 (AP) -- The Red Sox shut out the Indians, 2 -- 0, on a one-hitter in today's opener and took the second game, 7 -- 5, on George Kell's three-run homer in the eighth inning to sweep a doubleheader. The Sox, who have won five straight and nine of their last ten, took over third place, a half game in front of the Tribe.

TOKYO, July 19 -- Navy Lieut. Guy Pierre Bordelon of Monroe, La., officially became a hero today as the Navy Cross, one of the nation's highest military decorations, was pinned on his chest. Thus a story book finish was written for the Korean saga of a squat little Soviet biplane that once had dusted crops in India and of a frustrated flier who finally conquered it in battle.

The Stadium Concerts' annual "Italian Night" was presented at Lewisohn Stadium Saturday evening with Alfredo Antonini conducting the Stadium Symphony Orchestra, and with Herva Nelli, soprano, Jan Peerce, tenor, and Frank Guarrera, baritone, as soloists.

DETROIT, July 19 (AP) -- Ralph Branca, Brooklyn cast-off, won his first American League game today for the Tigers, stopping the Athletics, 13 -- 3, with a seven-hitter in the first game of a double-header. The nightcap ended in an 8-8 tie, called after eleven innings because of darkness.

The men's clothing industry operated at 88 per cent of capacity in May, compared with 68 per cent during the corresponding month last year, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. For the first five months of this year operations were at 88 per cent of capacity against 70 per cent in the 1952 period.

The traveling salesman's daughter who said her mother's maiden name was Pullman on account of the names an the towels at last has a friend. The Match Industry Information Bureau exhorts all Willy Lomans to leave the towels and the Gideon Bible, but to take the book of matches bearing the hotel's name instead.
The New York Shipping Association will present its position today on a proposed twenty-four-point longshore union hiring plan, and the answer is not expected to be favorable.

SHERIDAN, Wyo., July 19 (AP) -- Spokesmen for Indians asked today more freedom for tribesmen and more voice in management of their affairs, but they expressed no demand for the Government to give them complete independence.

VIENNA, July 19 (Reuters) -- Four Hungarian Ministers ousted from the Cabinet earlier this month when Imre Nagy succeeded Matyas Rakosi as Premier have been named to new posts, the Budapest radio announced today. Four other Ministers who had played important roles in the former Government were not reappointed.

An engineer was critically injured and three other persons suffered painful burns in an explosion in a steam locomotive last night in the Brooklyn Eastern District Terminal at North Ninth Street and the East River in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

TWENTY-THREE years ago a Scots doctor spent a vacation snatched from his successful London practice writing a novel which he nearly didn't bother to submit for publication. Fortunately, he changed his mind -- and "Hatter's Castle" became an international triumph. Its author, Archibald Joseph Cronin, had always hankered for a literary career.

Thirty-eight hundred city high school pupils, enrolled in courses where they alternate work on the job with work in school, earned $2,284,292 in the last academic year, according to a report yesterday by Miss Grace Brennan, Director of Cooperative Education, to Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 19 -- All Israel languished today in searing heat ranging from 90 degrees in Haifa to 115 in Elath. All except Louis Hertzberg, 65, a brewer of Trenton, N. J., who has just transported to the Holy Land the old Fidelio Brewery from First Avenue between Twenty-ninth and Thirtieth Streets, opposite Bellevue Hospital in New York.

Cotton future prices showed moderate advances last week on the New York Cotton Exchange. Gains posted on the exchange were 11 to 19 points, or 55 cents to 95 cents a bale. The July, 1953, contract closed out on Wednesday at prices ranging from 33 1/2 to 33 4/5 cents a pound.

In a ten-year lease involving an aggregate rental of about $300,000, Amalgamated Textiles, Inc., headed by Henry Booth, leased the twenty-seventh floor of the twenty-eight-story air-conditioned office building under construction at 261 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The threat of a legislative logjam that might jeopardize the scheduled July 31 adjournment of Congress gave rise to the possibility today that the Senate might be kept at work fifteen hours a day to clear the docket.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- The right of citizens to know what their Government is doing made noteworthy gains this year in State Legislatures. With the long 1953 lawmaking season virtually ended, a survey by The Associated Press shows:

The saying commonly ascribed to Mark Twain that "everybody talks about the weather but nobody does anything about it" may some day be rendered obsolete. According to Dr. Harry Wexler, chief of the Scientific Services Division of the United States Weather Bureau, scientists could regulate the weather just by altering the content of the atmosphere.

If there is reason for optimism concerning the apparent break in the truce negotiations stalemate at Panmunjom there is likewise good reason for the caution with which such optimism is tempered. The fact that the Communists have declared their willingness to proceed with the final details of drafting a truce agreement is ground for the optimism.

Five men, who the police charged participated directly or indirectly in a $7,119 payroll hold-up on Friday were rounded up yesterday, but only $4.800 of the loot was recovered. The rest of the money, it was said, had been dissipated on slow horses and a night of high living.

Seventy Negro children from Harlem and Brooklyn returned to the city last night after a two-week vacation in Vermont, happy, healthy and envious of ten of their playmates who were invited to remain longer in the Green Mountain state.

TOKYO, Monday, July 20 (AP) -- The Peiping radio broadcast today the following statement by North Korean Lieut. Gen. Nam Il, senior delegate of the Communist truce team, and said it was delivered at Panmunjom Sunday:

The Right Rev. Stephen C. Neill, retired Anglican Bishop of Tinnevelly, India, preaching yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, declared that the church existed today "only because there are men and women who are willing to die for Jesus Christ."

RYE, N. Y., July 20 -- The twentieth Elizabeth Wheeler Cup golf tournament got under way today with Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century, the defending champion, and Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis leading the field in the first round of the 54-hole, medal-play event over the Westchester Country Club west course.
The cotton futures market lost 2 to 7 points net yesterday following a quiet-session.

There is nothing like a day at the beach, now that summer is here. The gleaming stretches of white sand; the thunder of the bounding surf; the exhilarating saltwater breezes, these are the magnets that attract millions from the teeming tenements and the towering penthouses of the city.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 20 -- Arthur Deacon in the Star, Armade; Bus Mosbacher in the International, Susan; Ted Reyling in the Atlantic, Flying Cloud and Warner Willcox in the Herreshoff S boat, Twister, were among the winners today in an afternoon of light airs and fog at Larchmont Race Week.

BUENOS AIRES, July 20 -- Postponing his departure for an hour and a half in order to make time for a half-hour talk with President Juan Peron, Dr. Milton Eisenhower left this capital at noon today for Asuncion, Paraguay.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Eisenhower, by executive order, established today a National Agricultural Advisory Commission to collaborate with the Secretary of Agriculture on policies and the administration of Federal farm programs.

GENEVA, July 20 -- The growing carelessness with which amateur climbers tackle the high mountains of the Alps combined with bad weather to make last week-end one of the worst on record for the loss of life in climbing accidents in the Alpine region.

New Yorkers sweltered in muggy, mist-laden air again yesterday and probably will do likewise today and tomorrow, as the Weather Bureau could see no relief in sight from the heat and drought that have scorched the lawns and shrubbery of outlying areas and brought on serious water shortages.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Great Lakes seamen who tied up seventeen tankers when they went on strike last month are manning the ships again pending a vote on acceptance of a new contract, a union spokesman said today.

Mayor Impellitteri yesterday accepted the resignation from the New York City Transit Authority of Ephraim F. Jeffe, one of his two appointees. Mr. Jeffe, the only authority member to vote against the 15-cent fare on July 13, submitted his resignation the same day.

United Gas Corporation yesterday designated $21 a share as the subscription price for 1,171,863 shares of new common stock being offered to United stockholders. The offering is to United stockholders. The offering is tobecome effective today and to stay in force until Aug. 14.

Police Lieut. Arthur Miller failed for the second time yesterday to appear for a departmental trial on charges that he had given false information regarding his Communist affiliations. He faces trial in absentia if he fails to appear at 11 o'clock this morning.

Reflecting an 18 per cent rise in sales, E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., in the first half of this year increased earnings to $2.41 a share of common stock from $2.12 a common share reported for the first six months of 1952.

MEXICO CITY, July 20 -- The Mexican Government has banned the import of whisky from Britain, the United States and Canada in an apparent effort to force barter agreements with these countries for surplus Mexican commodities.
DUBLIN, July 17 -- Things essentially Irish inspired Sybil Connolly's second export collection, shown last night at Dunsany Castle, the seat of Lord Dunsany in County Meath.

Medical authorities made plans yesterday to extend the fight against infantile paralysis with gamma globulin shots in three new states amid reports that some children might have received "bootleg" shots in Illinois, The United Press reported.

The East and West are represented in two new collections of decorative fabrics, one by members of the Folk Arts Society of Japan at Kogei, 23 East Sixty-seventh Street, the other by Scalamandre, available through decorators at that concern's showroom, 598 Madison Avenue.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 -- Tyrone Power will be too busy to make "Bengal Rifle," the .picture for which he had entered into a profit participation deal with Universal. He was to have made the film in the fall with Ted Richmond, the producer, and Rudolph Mate, the director, who worked on "Mississippi Gambler" one of the studio's biggest money makers this year.

LONDON, July 20 -- The announcement that Britain must import coal to keep her householders warm this winter has added new urgency to the dogged fight that has been going on here since the end of World War II against chronic fuel shortage.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The nation set new production, consumption and investment records in the second quarter of this year, the Department of Commerce said today.

ROME, July 20 -- Italian fashion entered the competitive world market by curtseying to American and European merchandisers and representatives of the press today in an inauguration of six days' showings by leading couturiers. Eight Rome houses will present collections during the first two days, after which the visitors will move to Florence for G. G. Giorgini's sixth national exhibition.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 20 -- Four national and two state associations were honored here today as leaders in service to American industry and the public when they were named recipients of the 1953 awards of the American Trade Association Executives.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Business, labor and educational groups joined today in attacking a move by the Eisenhower Administration for immediate increases in postal rates.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 13 -- The tilapia, a little fish that multiplies with incredible rapidity, is fast becoming one of the food staples of Thailand.

DENVER, July 20 -- Hopes for settlement without a strike were voiced by officials of the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers today despite the fact that early returns from balloting indicated the membership favored a walkout if negotiations collapsed.

CHICAGO, July 20 (UP) -- Gravediggers and other workers went on strike at seventeen Roman Catholic cemeteries today for higher pay. Union hearse and funeral car drivers refused to cross picket lines, forcing funeral directors and mourners to carry or trundle caskets to previously dug graves.

PARIS, July 20 -- The Foreign Ministry took the unusual course of issuing a formal statement tonight to brand as "mendacious" an article in an afternoon newspaper saying that John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, and Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, had privately agreed on a plan that would give the United States the major responsibility for the war in Indo-China.
It is unfortunate that the "battle of the books" has been so thrown out of focus, particularly by the nightmare way in which Senator McCarthy distorted the issue.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The new Senate rule proposed by Senator Monroney was evoked by some of the investigatory practices followed by Senator McCarthy, and it must run the gantlet of McCarthy's supporters on the Rules Committee, to which it has been referred.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, July 20 -- Nearing the end of a three-month globe-circling tour, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that the people of the United States must study carefully the distinctions between Socialist and Soviet-style Communist countries, for there was room for real collaboration with Socialist countries.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 20 (AP) -- A subpoena served on former President Harry S. Truman to explain why the United States entered the Korean conflict was quashed today in United States District Court. The subpoena, served by Fyke Farmer, Nashville, Tenn.. attorney and leader in a world peace movement, had directed the former President to produce certain records of his Administration.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 20 (AP) -- Gen. Rene Cogny, commander of French Union forces in northern Indo-China, declared today that his forces had delivered a crushing blow to plans of the Communist-led Vietminh for an early offensive.

Three of the five Democratic county leaders -- James A. Roe of Queens, Kenneth F. Sutherland of Kings, and Jeremiah A. Sullivan of Richmond -- designated Mayor Impellitteri yesterday for the party nomination for Mayor:

On what used to be a Polo Grounds parking lot the Board of Education is building an elementary school, and if pupil attendance there is not up to par, the teachers will not have to look far to find out why.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Eisenhower rounded out six months in office today, but he let the occasion pass. He began the day with an early morning meeting with Congressional leaders in which he reviewed legislative progress and made new requests for action on the party's program.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Eisenhower assured Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, today that, despite the Kremlin's refusal, United States food shipments would be sent to alleviate hunger in East Germany.

CINCINNATI, July 20 -- Consolidation of the Crosley division and the Bendix home appliances division of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation, under the supervision of a single distributor organization, was announced yesterday by Victor Emanuel, chairman and president of Avco.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UP) -- Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan, defended himself today against accusations that he used a Los Angeles hearing for "political purposes." His House speech was a continuation of a battle with members of the House Government Operations Committee, of which he is chairman.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 21 -- The Soviet Government, in a note handed to the Turkish Ambassador yesterday, requested supplementary information with regard to a proposed visit of United States and British warships to Istanbul, which it said "may be considered as some kind of a military demonstration."

To the accompaniment of the squeals of the stuck favorite players, the Saratoga Association inaugurated its down-state meeting at the Jamaica race track yesterday. A crowd of 20,445 witnessed the program which was marked by the failure of two successive odds-on choices to win.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Senate members of the Joint Atomic Committee voted unanimously today to recommend the confirmation of Joseph Campbell, 53 years old, of Cooperstown, N. Y., as a member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was generally light but lead had the most active day of the month and the domestic sugar contract the second most active. Coffee, sugar, zinc, lead and rubber were higher; cottonseed oil, soybean oil, cocoa, wool, tin and hides, lower, and potatoes and copper, mixed.

BONN, Germany, July 20 -- The Allied High Commission announced today that the United States, British and French Governments had acceded to a request from Chancellor Konrad Adenauer that Germans be included in zonal consultative boards to recommend clemency or parole for war criminals imprisoned by the Allies.

NEWARK, July 20 -- New Jersey's ban on sale of nonprescription drugs except in drugstores was lifted today when Superior Court Judge Frederic C. Colie described as "unreason able" the State Board of Pharmacy's official definition of medicines.

Two farm bloc Senators -- Mr. Russell of Georgia and Mr. Young of North Dakota -- have announced that they mean to lead an all-out fight for continuing the present policy of high and rigid price supports for the so-called "basic" farm crops. Mr. Young is quoted as saying that he is "very much disturbed" by the present farm price outlook.

There was an official announcement yesterday that Roger L. Stevens, Robert Whitehead, the City Investing Company, headed by Robert W. Dowling, and the Playwrights' Company had formed a new corporation to produce plays and operate theatres.
LONDON, July 20 (AP) -- Britain announced today abandonment of the Brabazon aircraft project as uneconomical.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 20 -- Morris J. Kaplan, an attorney representing a group of United Nations employes dismissed after they had invoked the Fifth Amendment in their testimony before a Senate Internal Security subcommittee, this afternoon characterized as "a tainted document that should be struck down," the questionnaire circulated to United States nationals in current loyalty surveys.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 20 -- The Atomic Energy Commission said today it would roll back the curtains to give the traveling public its first glimpse of the giant sprawling atomic plants in the secret areas of Oak Ridge.

JOLIET, Ill., July 20 (AP) -- Convicts in Stateville Penitentiary are giving their breath to research. Scientists from the Atomic Energy Commission's Argonne National Laboratory are conducting tests with the help of volunteer inmates.

T The Duke owned the buildingl and land occupied by 'the Unitedi States Embassy and extensive es:: I tates in Scotland, Wales and other parts of England. He was one Of the last of the British aristocrats to live in lavish style.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican of Iowa, told the Senate today that the United States would not have too much fissionable atomic material "in the foreseeable future."

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UP) -- The House of Representatives today passed a bill to repeal the 20 per cent Federal tax on movie admission tickets and thus give a better break to theatre owners in their struggle to compete with television.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 21 -- The United Nations and Communist commands pushed preparations today for early signature of an armistice in the three-year-old Korean war.

The Rockefeller interests have increased their holdings on Fifth Avenue through the purchase of land occupied by Saks Fifth Avenue Store on the east side of the avenue between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets and directly opposite Rockefeller Center.

LONDON, July 20 -- In the opinion of authoritative quarters here, there are ways of reconciling the British and Egyptian views on the British occupation of the Suez Canal zone, provided the Egyptian Government is willing to consider them.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 20 (AP) -- Howard Larkin's Flying Polly, a filly who was claimed for $5,000 a month ago, scored by five lengths today in 1:10-3/5, fastest six-furlong time of the Monmouth Park meeting. The 4-year-old daughter of War, Dog defeated Mrs. C, er.axd S. Smith's Nilufer in the $6;000 King Saxon purse. ROman Fair was 'third.

HAWTHORNE, N. Y., July 20 -- Public officials, traffic experts, motorists, taxpayers and civil defense heads today inspected the new headquarters of the Westchester Parkway Police here when the County Park Commission held open house.

The Long Island Transit Authority announced yesterday that it had been forced to abandon its program to reorganize and improve the Long Island Rail Road, as a result of Federal Court approval of the tax settlement made by William Wyer, trustee of the road, with the City of New York.

Oscar Panno of Argentina, tied for first place with Klaus Darga of Germany, defeated James T. Sherwin, United States, in a King's Indian defense in the sixth round of the world junior chess championship, according to a report received yesterday from Copenhagen.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The International Wheat Agreement may cost the United States $108,000,000 during the coming year, Congress was told today.

The aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on July 15 was 1,812,352 shares, compared with 1,785,725 shares a month earlier, the Exchange reported yesterday. A year earlier the figure was 1,750,711 shares.

The future role of the Soviet armed forces in the struggle for power in the Soviet Union will be determined in part by the military, as well as the political, changes that have occurred since the death of Premier Stalin.

Shipments in May of 7,209,396 tons of steel products by steel companies were reported yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. These were the second largest for any month and were exceeded only by shipments of 7,436,919 tons in March. For the first five months of this year shipments were 35,429,320 tons, for an increase of 3,700,000 tons, or 11.7 per cent, over the similar period of 1952.

Forty exchange students from Egypt, Italy, Greece, Spain and Iraq arrived here yesterday aboard the American Export liner Independence. They were the first of 670 young men and women from sixty-seven countries who are coming to this country within the next ten days for a year's study in American colleges and universities under the sponsorship of the United States Government.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 20 (AP) -- Belgium won the European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition today, turning back Denmark, three matches to two.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The seventh annual scientific and clinical conference of the Association for Physical and Mental Rehabilitation opened here today with a Mount Alto Hospital session on the Roland technique of corrective therapy for catatonic or "frozen" schizophrenics.
LONDON, July 20 (AP) -- The Board of Trade released figures today showing Briltain's business in nonstrategic goods with Communist China was climbing despite American Congressional complaints.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Republican as well as Democratic misgivings, grounded largely in fear of a depression, were expressed as the Senate signed the death notice of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today in approving a bill establishing an independent Small Business Administration.

The Southern Company, a major utility holding company whose subsidiaries in Alabama, Geogia, Florida and Mississippi serve electricity to an estimated 6,300,000 persons, reported yesterday a net income of $21,042,848 for the twelve months to June 30.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 -- A total of 182 Japanese, most of whom have children and grandchildren who were born American citizens, became American citizens today.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 21 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique 1,682, for the twenty-four hours ending at 6 A. M. Tuesday:
OTTAWA, July 20 (Canadian Press) -- Canada today warned the United States of possible "serious implications" if Washington imposed import restrictions on Canadian oats and ground fish fillets.

The letter of Simon W. Gerson, avowed Communist spokesman, which you published July 13, is a good example of the adherence of Communists to Lenin's dictum that distortion is permissible to a Communist in promoting the interests of the Communist party.

I congratulate THE NEW YORK TIMES for the proper interpretation of the latest events in the Soviet Union, especially that made by Harry Schwartz. His last article, "Beria Seen Victim of Great Russians," convincingly proves that the Achilles heel of the Soviet Union, the nationalism of the Ukraine and Georgia, became a very important factor in the struggle among the Kremlin gang for power in the U. S. S. R.

The entire Putnam division of the New York Central Railroad operates at a loss, the division superintendent said yesterday at a Public Service Commission hearing on the Central's proposal to discontinue six passenger trains on that line.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Back in 1916, when there was trouble along the Rio Grande, Cpl. Tom Blazina vowed that some day, God willing, he would have a son like his "second louie."

Robert Moses would have been a great Mayor of New York City. It is with real regret that we must accept as unchangeable his decision not to be a candidate. A candidate in the sense of seeking the office he had never been. His announcement of unavailability was made necessary by the fact that the office was seeking him.

Mayor Impellitteri called on 1,800 striking truck drivers yesterday to empower their union representatives to negotiate a settlement of the malkout, now in its nineteenth day, that has made 100,000 construction workers idle in the metropolitan area.

Despite vacations and the heat, 3,271 persons donated a pint of blood each last week to the regional Red Cross blood program. Of this amount, 296 pints were collected on Friday, 194 of them from volunteers who visited the New York Red Cross chapter house at Thirty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue.

An armistice in Korea will not reduce this country's peril, it was asserted yesterday by Dr. Arthur S. Flemming, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization. He addressed a luncheonmeeting of the American Association of Nurserymen, which opened its seventy-eighth annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Government asked the United States District Court here yesterday to cancel a contract for the purchase of 1,200,000,000 pounds of aluminum by the Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa) from Aluminum, Ltd., of Canada on the ground that the pact would give Alcoa "competitive advantages" out of harmony with the intent of the anti-trust laws.

BERLIN, July 20 (AP) -- A freelance photographer was sentenced to life imprisonment and fifteen alleged accomplices were condemned to prison in Dresden today in the largest showy trial of East German rebels so far held by the Communists.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 20 -- Tanks began rumbling through the streets in the last twenty-four hours and three army brigades received orders to move into the city before morning as Teheran braced itself for huge demonstrations tomorrow in which both Tudeh (Communist partisans) and Nationalist groups will observe the first anniversary of the bloody riots that ended the four-day Premiership of Ahmad Ghavam and returned Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh to power.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The armed services and the Department of Defense are struggling with a troublesome dilemma created by a surplus of graduates from the Reserve Officers Training Corps.
The union conducting the nine-week-old strike at Hearn's department stores offered yesterday to send the 800 strikers back to their jobs without a contract.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 20 -- Students from fourteen foreign countries who spent one year in the United States chose one American freedom above all others today -- the liberty of unchaperoned romance.

At the turn of the century coal, hard and soft, provided almost nine-tenths of all the energy used in the United States. Last year 34 per cent of our mechanical power came from coal, 39.4 per cent from crude oil, 22.5 per cent from natural gas and 4.1 from falling water. These figures are taken from an article by A. H. Raskin published in this newspaper a few days ago.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities voted 6 to 3 today to hear J. B. Matthews, who resigned last week as executive director of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.
Bernarr Macfadden, the physical culturist, who will be 85 years old Aug. 16, announced yesterday his acceptance of the nomination of the Honest party for Mayor.
WASHINGTON, JULY 20 (AP) -- The Senate unanimously confirmed today President Eisenhower's nomination of Miss Frances E. Willis, a career diplomat, to be United States Ambassador to Switzerland.

Food poisoning such as that which struck more than 100 children at the Ocean Parkway Jewish Center Day Camp last Friday is a threat, especially in summer, to families as well as institutions. For advice on how to avoid unfortunate occurrences of this nature, we consulted the Department of Health and other authorities on proper food storage.

Clifford C. Johnston of the Christian Science Committee on Publication for the State of New York took issue yesterday with a remark made on Sunday by the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb, pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 114th Street.

A new edition of a social-anthropological work called "Facing Mount Kenya," by Jomo Kenyatta, will be distributed by the British Book Centre on Aug. 28. The author was recently sentenced to prison for ten years on the charge of having administered Mau Mau oaths to those implicated in the murder campaign in Kenya.

Leading sugar refiners increased their quotations by about 10 cents a hundred pounds here yesterday while others withdrew concessions for early orders. New basic prices ranged around $8.85 in the East and Southeast and $8.80 in the deep South.

The Playwrights' Company now has four plays scheduled for presentation here this season. The latest to be listed is Elmer Rice's "The Winner." It is set in New York and will have two acts, two settings and eleven characters. Mr. Rice probably will direct.

The Staff Officers Association of America, A. F. L., announced yesterday that pursers on ten of eleven Isbrandtsen Company freighters had voted in favor of the union as collective bargaining agent in contract negotiations with the steamship line.
Seventy-two thousand Jehovah's Witnesses squeezed themselves into Yankee Stadium yesterday to re-affirm their faith in government by God rather than by man.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 20 -- Chiang Kai-shek today approved of the truce terms in Korea but urged the United States to follow any armistice there with a bolder security policy in the Pacific.

THE high survival rate resulting from a mild winter seems to have off-set the poor nesting and rearing season caused by the wet spring which reduced the early hatches of upland game birds in many areas, but the New York Conservation Department insists that prospects are bright for the fall hunting.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Wheat futures continued firm here today, with hedge selling lighter than expected and with increased outside interest in the market on the buying side. Several of the larger floor traders took positions in the market.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The National Federation of American Shipping said today that the number of United States merchant ships in coastal and intercoastal trade was falling, while this country's fleet participating in foreign commerce continued on a scale of post-war expansion.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 20 -- The turf court tennis season was launched on the beautiful lawns of the Merion Cricket Club today with the beginning of play in the men's Pennsylvania State and the women's Pennsylvania and Eastern State's championships.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 20 -- The threat of drastic cuts in United States contributions to United Nations technical assistance and child welfare activities was received with grave concern here today.
As befitted a beauty with confidence in the future as well as recollections of a glamorous past, Central Park ignored a birthday yesterday.

TRENTON, July 20 (AP) -- The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company said today it needed an $18,250,000 rate increase because its earnings "have decreased to depression levels during a period when other industries are enjoying record profits."

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, in its fiscal year ended on last April 30, transacted the largest sales in its eighty years of continuous manufacture of paper and allied products. Consolidated net sales were $163,620,794, an increase of $9,858,965, or 6.4 per cent over the previous fiscal year.

Formation of a company to study, make and sell hydrazine, a new commercial chemical, was announced yesterday by John M. Olin, president of Olin Industries, Inc., and Thomas S. Nichols, president of the Mathieson Chemical Corporation.
CLIFTON, N. J., July 20 (AP) -- A coolheaded policeman, dangling at the end of a rope 100 feet above ground, plucked a frightened child rock-climber from the sheer face of a cliff today.

The Columbia Broadcasting System announced formally yesterday that Arthur Godfrey would be back on the air next week. He returns Monday to his "Talent Scouts" and two nights later resumes his place in "Arthur Gorfrey and His Friends."

If she is bright-eyed, well-groomed and, above all, equipped with good skills in typing and stenography, the girl who was graduated from high school last month stands in a fair way to make a better starting salary on her first job than many boys who were graduated with her.

Two one-story garage-type buildings at 27-16 Forty-first Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, have been leased by Milton Green, plumbing and heating contractor, from the Eye Gate Realty Corporation. Queens Industrials was the broker.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- A Senate Commerce subcommittee approved today two bills designed to encourage and protect shipbuilders in building up America's active reserve fleets of tankers and merchant vessels.

Desirable as it may seem to the leaders of Congress, adjournment by Aug. 1 is not the most important thing in the world. It is not so important -- either to the party or to the country -- as the necessity that Congress accomplish a minimum legislative program at this session.
TORONTO, July 20 (AP) -- Play went according to the script in the opening round of the Canadian tennis championship today.

Samuel Schwartz, a 49-year-old flour broker, was revived last evening by two patrolmen after attempting to kill himself by gas in his apartment at 990 President Street, Brooklyn. The patrolmen went to the scene in response to the call of a friend who feared such an attempt.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Interhandel, a Swiss holding company which claims ownership of 90 per cent of the stock of General Aniline and Film Corporation, asked a Senate Judiciary Subcommittee today for return of the property which is held by the Alien Property Office.
Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, will not return to his Congress, but will try to appear on the Senate floor if there is a close issue on which his vote might be a decisive factor.

Ben Hogan, returning from his latest golfing conquest, will receive an official welcome by the City of New York today. The winner of the British open championship is slated to arrive with Mrs. Hogan aboard the liner United States at 8 o'clock this morning.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 20 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks, the Long Island, metropolitan and New York State women's champion, played with her home professional, Bill Collins, to shoot 38, 36 -- 74 for the low gross prize in the Long Island Professional Golfers Association pro-lady tournament held on an alternate shot basis at the Sands Point Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The State Department undertook today to reassure Italians that projected conferences with representatives of Yugoslavia would not concern themselves with the future of Trieste or any other matters in which Italy had a direct interest.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Office of the Comptroller of Currency raised objection today at a Senate Banking subcommittee hearing to a bill which would permit national banks to make loans of up to ten years on timber tracts.
