Eight years ago at the end of the Second World War former Vice President Henry A. Wallace wrote a book called "Sixty Million Jobs." Mr. Wallace, an idealistic man sometimes deceived by wishful thinking, seemed to be describing a kind of Utopia. The Utopia, such as it is, has now arrived.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 (AP) -- Steve Bilko, benched for weak hitting, returned to the line-up today and drove in four runs with his eleventh and twelfth homers and a pair of singles to lead the Cardinals to a 9-4 victory over the Pirates.

As a step toward building better day-to-day labor relations in the steel industry, David J. McDonald, new president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., and Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, will make a series of joint visits to major steel mills this fall.

The steel industry's operating rate, which has been depressed recently because of the vacation season and hot weather, showed improvement last week and is expected to rise further this week. The rate last week was 94.7 per cent of theoretical capacity and production was 2.134,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
Sales of beer and the machinery to make it showed substantial gains in two reports made public yesterday.

CLEVELAND, July 20 -- Casey Stengel may still be seething a bit over that fourth straight All-Star setback that overtook him in Cincinnati last week. But this much you can take for sure: The Ol' Perfessor is determined to wreak a terrible vengeance upon the rest of the American League, which he doubtless, in a measure, holds responsible for that singularly disastrous showing.

Motor issues were under moderate pressure yesterday as the stock market wiped out the gains it made on Friday. The retreat was on a broad front, hardly a major industrial group resisting the movement, but volume was small, only 830,000 shares.

Advances in cleaning up objectionable advertising practices are reported by the National Better Business Bureau. In summarizing the first six months of 1953 in its July news bulletin, the bureau said 167 cases, more than twice the number for the first half of 1952, had been closed through "voluntary cooperation."

CLEVELAND, July 20 -- Highly elated over the manner in which his Yankees put down the White Sox rebellion in Chicago yesterday, Casey Stengel was laying his battle lines today for another coup. This has for its objective the flattening of the Indians once and for all so far as the 1953 flag race is concerned.

To many French and many of their friends the day-by-day news from Indo-China has been just as dark and frustrating as the news from Korea has often been to us. In the midst of that feeling comes the bright ray of the news of the highly successful paratroop raid by French Union forces on the Communist supply base at Langson.

IN 1804 Georges Cadoudal, a Royalist commander who had led a determined resistance movement against the forces of the French Revolution, was arrested and executed in Paris. During his exile in England his loyalty to the Bourbons had not wavered. Sent back to France with English financial backing, he had organized a conspiracy against Napoleon, then First Consul.

BERLIN, Tuesday, July 21 -- The Soviet Union has extended to East Germany credits equivalent to $57,000,000 for the purchase of foods in the second half of this year, the East German Government official news agency announced this morning.

The two-story machine shop at 383 Douglas Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Leo Sussman to the Cyn Realty Corporation which plans to alter the building for occupancy as a factory for the manufacture of plastic products.
LONDON, July 20 -- Resolutions published today and to be presented to the Labor party's annual conference in the fall marked the cleavage between the industrial and political sections of the party.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Northwest Orient Airlines and Pan American World Airways proposed tourist fare air travel today between the Pacific Northwest and the Hawaiian Islands.
LONDON, July 20 (AP) -- The Moscow radio broadcast today the following text of the Israeli-Soviet exchange leading to the resumption of relations between the two countries:

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, July 21 -- A series of scattered, savage hill battles broke out on South Korean sectors of the central front last night and early today. United States divisions reported only patrol action.

Brooklyn's existing social agencies do not have the resources to cope with the growth in the borough's Puerto Rican population and must turn to the Federal and State Governments for help, a report on the problem declared yesterday.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 20 (AP) -- Twenty-year-old Ian Mc Donald, tennis champion of Cambridge University, is expected to play the leading role in the Davis Cup debut of the British West Indies against the United States this week.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 21 (AP) -- Torrential new rains raised rivers and broke dikes 100 miles southwest of Tokyo, threatening today to bring on Japan's third disastrous flood in three weeks.

TRENTON, July 20 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll announced today that he would appear before a Congressional subcommittee hearing in Washington Wednesday morning in support of legislation to curb crime on the New York waterfront.

JERUSALEM, July 20 -- Diplomatic relations between Israel and the Soviet Union were resumed tonight with the simultaneous release here and in Moscow of an exchange of letters between Moshe Sharett, Israeli Foreign Minister, and Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister.

Last night at Ebbets Field the Dodgers beat the Cubs, 3 -- 0, before a Ladies' Night crowd of 21,877 and increased their National League lead over the second-place Braves to three and a half games, matching their longest first-place advantage of the season.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday July 21 (AP) -- A highly placed South Korean Government source said today that President Syngman Rhee was awaiting a reply from Washington on matters he said had been left unsettled after conferences early this month with Walter S. Robertson, United States Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 20 -- The fate of the common franchise enjoyed by South Africans of mixed blood is hanging in the balance after secret talks between Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan and "a person or persons" connected with the United party, the main Opposition.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UP) -- The Senate and House of Representatives today passed and sent to the White House a compromise appropriations bill carrying $5,253,177,664 for four big Federal agencies.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Scott McLeod, head of the State Department security system, has stated that he would not knowingly permit a Socialist to be hired for a policy-making position, nor to be retained if he already held such a post.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, today accused Dr. Robert L. Johnson, retiring director of the State Department's International Information Administration, of a "completely dishonest" attack on a member of the Senator's inquiry staff.

NEW DELHI, India, July 20 -- Portuguese jurisdiction over Roman Catholic congregations in India will cease by September through an arrangement between the Indian Government and the Vatican, it was announced here today.

PARIS, July 20 -- Moderately high chechias, cone shapes and flat little calots set far back of the hairline and held to the head by descending clamps and partial brims are Gilbert Orcel's contributions to fall millinery.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, was struck by an automobile in downtown Washington this morning, and remained in Emergency Hospital tonight for rest and observation.

GENEVA, July 20 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council unanimously voted today to establish the United Nations International Childrens Fund as a permanent agency, dropping the word "Emergency" from its title, but retaining the symbol "UNICEF" by which the organization is known throughout the world.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 20 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit today stayed the disbarment of Harry Sacher, New York lawyer who defended some of this country's eleven top Communists, to allow him time to ask the Supreme Court to review his case.
Ernest Resch, 68 years old, a retired butcher, and his wife, Margaret, also 68, were found shot dead yesterday in their apartment at 30-06 Thirty-third Street, Astoria, Queens.
HONOLULU, July 20 (AP) -- Owner-skipper Ira P. Fulmor of Pasadena, Calif., said today his tiny ketch, Staghound, won the 2,225-mile California-to-Hawaii yacht race by "chasing every squall in sight."

NEW DELHI, India, July 20 -- Portuguese jurisdiction over Roman Catholic congregations in India will cease by September through an arrangement between the Indian Government and the Vatican, it was announced here today.

PARIS, July 20 -- Moderately high chechias, cone shapes and flat little calots set far back of the hairline and held to the head by descending clamps and partial brims are Gilbert Orcel's contributions to fall millinery.
HONOLULU, July 20 (AP) -- Owner-skipper Ira P. Fulmor of Pasadena, Calif., said today his tiny ketch, Staghound, won the 2,225-mile California-to-Hawaii yacht race by "chasing every squall in sight."

New York is a nice place to visit, but it's no place to be stranded without money, Mrs. Marguerite Speer of Los Angeles concluded yesterday. On Monday, while shopping in a department store, Mrs. Speer had lost her purse, her money, papers, car keys and a good deal of faith in human nature.
The police are investigating the smashing of stained glass windows in a Baptist church and in a synagogue on the upper West Side by vandals early yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, put the United States on record today against discussion at the prospective Korean political conference of possible Chinese Communist membership in the United Nations.

Child workers 6 to 17 years old were involved in more than 100 accidents with farming machines during this spring's planting and last fall's harvesting in nine farming states, according to a survey by the National Child Labor Committee.

A couple of popular London performers will be returning here after long absences to star in the reproduction of Roger MacDougall's flourishing West End comedy, "Escapade." They are Roger Livesey and his wife, Ursula Jeans, who will have the same roles acted abroad by Nigel Patrick and Patricia Calvert.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Fourteen bank holding companies today told the Senate Banking Committee there is no need for additional federal regulation in their field.

OLYMPIA, Wash., July 22 -- The proposed merger of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company and the Washington Waterpower Company should result in economies that would more than match the increased costs for interest charges and pensions, the State Public Service Commission was told at a hearing today.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 21 (AP) -- The Detroit yawl Escapade won the Mackinac Cup today for the best corrected time in the Class A cruising division of the Port Huron-to-Mackinac race.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Senate approved today the nomination of Joseph Campbell of New York to be a member of the Atomic Energy Commission. His term runs until June 30, 1955. He takes the place of Thomas Keith Glennan, who resigned.

Arnold Constable, in showing new fall fur designs yesterday, took into consideration the shrinking purchasing power of the public's dollar. To make the furs doubly tempting, prices were substantially shaved under last season's.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Dr. Fritz Friedland, chief of the Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation Service at the Veterans Administration hospital in Boston, told the seventh annual conference of the Association for the Physically Handicapped today that the survival of paraplegics had stimulated physical medicine to grow rapidly in recent years.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- American Airlines, Inc., offered today to carry first class mail on its New York-Los Angeles route for a test period of one year. It told the Post Office Department it was ready to start the service on two weeks' notice.

WASHINGTON, July 21 - Former President Herbert Hoover, who will be 79 years old Aug. 10, agreed today to serve his country once more -- as chairman of a new and more powerful "Hoover" commission to study the organization and functions of the Federal Government.

LONDON, July 21 -- Business fell off in the stock markets here today, with the result that prices in some groups drifted slightly lower. However, industrials held firm, although dollar stocks were dull on overnight advices from Wall Street.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, July 22 -- South Korean troops before dawn yesterday stormed and seized five hills held by the Chinese Reds on the central front. Each hill was defended by about 100 of the enemy.

TORONTO, July 21 (UP) -- Tony Vincent of New York, the 1951 champion, turned back the Mexican Davis Cup star, Pancho Contreras, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 0, in a second-round match in the Canadian lawn tennis championships today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- This country's gross national product, representing the total value of goods and services produced by the nation, neared the $350,000,000,000 level in 1952 and was running at an annual rate of $363,400,000,000 in the first quarter of this year, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Senate and House of Representatives passed and sent to the White House today an appropriations bill providing the compromise sum of $440,093,600 for so-called civil functions of the Army in the current fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Yugoslavia is requesting 430,000 tons of wheat from the United States, primarily as a supplement to other forms of economic aid and for the purpose of enabling the Belgrade Government to relax some of its food restrictions, authorities disclosed today.

Once a year the weather drives me to ink. The time has come to make my annual plea for help for the sweltering male. This may be the year when sartorial ingenuity will come to the aid of New York's sizzling men -- for it is we who are the "second sex" during the summer months.

BERLIN, July 21 -- Television from behind the Iron Curtain is not something the Communists should boast about. It is the dullest darned video anywhere. The evening programs from the Soviet-controlled station in East Berlin are mostly all propaganda plus a dash of sex now and then.

THE "great striped bass war" between the sports and commercial fishermen, which has raged for the past two years in New Jersey, was brought to the armistice stage yesterday when Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll signed the bill, sponsored by the sportsmen, protecting these fish from the shad netters.

JERUSALEM, July 21 -- A highly placed Israel Government official explained today that the reason Israel used such great efforts to bring about the renewal of diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union was that it reopened a chink in the Iron Curtain through which Israel might restore some contact with the Jews of Russia.

In testifying before the Tariff Commission in Washington against the motion of the Department of Agriculture to restrict the import of oats by the application of limited import quotas which would apply primarily against Canada, I was struck with how simple is the proof (apparent) of need for restriction and how difficult the proof of the gains from keeping trade channels clear, even for the unimportant commodity of eats.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- The Trusteeship Council of the United Nations adjourned its twelfth session this afternoon after extensive reviews of reports by administering nations on conditions in New Guinea, Nauru, Western Samoa, Somaliland and the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Republican leaders of the House of Representatives refused today an Administration appeal to sponsor the restoration of part of the $58,263,500 cut in technical foreign aid ordered by the Appropriations Committee.
The annual Oldtimers Day, sponsored by the Yankees since 1947, will take place, Aug. 22, at the Yankee Stadium in conjunction with the regularly scheduled Yankees-Athletics game.
The nation's largest operating electric and gas utility, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday sharply increased net income in the twelve months to June 30.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Un-American Activities Committee challenged Bishop Oxnam tonight with a long list of reported ties to Communist fronts and the Bishop thundered back: "I am fundamentally opposed to the whole Communist movement."

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 22 -- The Korean truce negotiators pushed closer today to completion of their preparations for an armistice in the Korean war, but Communist propaganda sources warned that important questions remained to be settled before the historic document could be signed.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee reported favorably today a joint resolution extending the thanks of Congress to Gen. Peyton C. March, Chief of Staff of the Army at the end of World War I. General March, Who is now 88 years old, retired in 1921.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Eisenhower took under advisement today a resolution adopted by the Catholic War Veterans of America urging him to intervene personally on behalf of the two minor sons of Mr. and Mrs. V. C. Georgescu of New York, who are in a concentration camp in Rumania.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, defended the State Department's International Information Administration today and urged against sharply curtailing its activities even though it was to be a separate agency.

Hayden Cooper Covington, chief counsel for the Jehovah's Witnesses, urged members of the sect yesterday to learn their rights under law so they could be "cautious as serpents, innocent as doves, and fearless as an armored tank" in prosecuting their beliefs throughout the world.

Agudath Israel of America, a national organization of 25,000 Orthodox Jews, reported that special prayers were said yesterday and resolutions adopted in 700 synagouges in all parts of the country in protest against the proposed draft of women in Israel.

PARIS, July 21 -- A plan to send Reinforcements to liquidate the war in Indo-China as soon as possible was understood to have won strong support in the French Cabinet after a meeting of the principal ministers today. It will be studied in technical detail by the Committee of National Defense, Friday, preparatory to a Government decision.

Oscar Panno, 18-year-old student from Buenos Aires, officially was declared the world junior chess champion after a first-place tie at 5 1/2 points with Klaus Darga of West Germany in the biennial tournament, according to a report from Copenhagen yesterday.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 21 (AP) -- Stenographer scored an unexpected Grand Circuit Victory at Saratoga Raceway tonight, winning the $10,000 Bostwick 2-year-old trot in 2:11 3/5.
An eighteen-hit attack that included four home runs, and stalwart relief pitching by Ben Wade, sturdy right-hander, brought a 15-4 victory for the Dodgers over the Cubs at Ebbets Field yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, July 21 -- The Mexican Government today ordered the immediate freeing of whisky imports from the United States and Canada, banned last month, and the issuance of import licenses for Scotch on the basis of last year's rate of imports.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Second Chance," R. K. O.'s first three-dimensional offering, in Technicolor, with Robert Mitchum, Linda Darnell and Jack Palance, is at the Criterion. Edmund Grainger produced and Rudolph Mate directed from a screen play by Oscar Millard and Sydney Boehm.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- V. D. Dardi, a San Francisco investment banker, said today his company had worked out a deal to buy the General Aniline and Film Corporation, seized by the Government as enemy property, for $60,000,000 from a Swiss concern if the United States Government would relinquish its claim.

The New York City Transit Authority feels strongly that it not only can hold the new fare on the entire city-owned transit system at 15 cents but also might be able to sell seven tokens for $1 after Jan. 1, 1954, the next earliest date at which the fare can be revised, Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, chairman, asserted yesterday.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 21 -- A six-goal surge in the first two chukkers sparked the Farmington poloists to a 9-5 victory over the Palo Duro team in the semifinal round of the Wheatley Cups tournament on Whitney Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

LONDON, July 21 -- While voicing Britain's hopes for better relations with the Soviet Union, R. A. Butler, acting chairman of the British Cabinet, firmly declared today that in the proposed four-power negotiations on the future of Germany there could be no compromise on essential principles.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closing prices were unchanged to 10 points lower than Monday.

Leland Hayward, producer of "South Pacific," "Mister Roberts," and other Broadway musical and dramatic hits, has agreed to become a television producer and production consultant for the National Broadcasting Company. John K. Herbert. vice president in charge of the N. B. C.-TV network, announced the agreement yesterday.

The Knights of Pythias of the Forty-third District will hold a "summer vacation blood donor night" tonight at the Bronx Red Cross blood donor center at St. Barnabas Hospital, 183d Street and Third Avenue. From 4 until 8 P. M., members will contribute to the regional blood program and then hold a Dutch treat supper.

Ben Hogan, arch foe of par, returned to the United States yesterday with his recently won British open golf championship to find New York's traditional Broadway parade-City Hall reception routine "the hardest course I've ever played." to my eyes," the slight, sun-tanned champion told the Mayor, the reception committee and some 5,000 persons gathered before the City Hall.
HONOLULU, July 21 (UP) -- The 40-foot ketch Marmaduke, unheard from for eleven days during the Transpacific yacht race, today was located about 500 miles east of here by the tanker Mission San Juan.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, July 22 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Church came to grips with the House Committee on Un-American Activities yesterday in a nine-hour session that lasted until 12:20 this morning. He assailed what he termed derogatory reports about him and asserted they had been released freely from committee files without the group's acceptance of responsibility for their accuracy.

The bill to extend the Reciprocal Trade Act for one year has been stalled in conference a fortnight because of disagreement over a House proposal to add one member to the Tariff Commission, thus making it a seven-man body under majority control of the party in power.

The one-story industrial building at 442-450 East Westfield Avenue in Roselle, N. J., has been leased by the J. F. Wood Products, Inc., of Elizabeth with an option for purchase. Frank W. Nolan is the owner and the transaction was negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.

LONDON, July 21 (Reuters) -- The touring Australian cricketers, who will start the fourth test match with England on Thursday, got in some useful batting practice today with a first-innings' 416 against the top county team, Middlesex.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Bricker constitutional amendment to limit the President's treaty-making power in effect was put aside today for this session of Congress as the Republican leaders buckled down to the Eisenhower Administration's "must" legislative program.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 -- Judge Thomas J. Clary of the Federal District Court here ruled today that the Eastern Railroad Presidents Conference and thirty railroads must go to trial in the $250,000,000 damage suit brought against them last January.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- Frank J. Donner, an attorney representing ten United States citizens who are seeking reinstatement as employes of the United Nations after dismissal by the Secretary General, today told the Administrative Tribunal, which is hearing their appeals, that the group had found itself blacklisted on the labor market as a result of termination of their United Nations employment.

The linking of my name in a by-line dispatch by Gladwin Hill in THE TIMES of July 9 dealing with an exhibition of Orozco paintings in Pasadena makes it desirable that I clarify certain points in connection with various published statements.

Racking up Sal Maglie in short order, the Cardinals beat the Giants, 10-6, before 16,340 paying spectators at the Polo Grounds last night. As a result of the triumph, Eddie Stanky's Redbirds vaulted over the New Yorkers back into fourth place.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Senate ratified today treaties of friendship and commerce with eight foreign nations. The vote was 86 to 1, with Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada in opposition.
BAKER, Ore., July 21 (AP) -- Mrs. William O. Douglas won an uncontested divorce today from the Supreme Court Justice. She charged desertion.
PITTSBURGH, July 21 (UP) -- Ken Raffensberger belted a three-run homer and pitched ten-hit ball tonight to lead the Redlegs to a 7-2 victory over the Pirates.

MADRID, July 21 -- Spain's monarchists learned today from an officially inspired editorial that Generalissimo Francisco Franco intended to remain in power until the end of his life and that in appointing a successor he might refuse to acknowledge the claims of the House of Bourbon to the Spanish throne.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 21 -- The first championship of Larchmont Race Week went to John Matthews' Twelve-Meter Vim today through the drawing of a number from a hat though she didn't race.
Police and telephone company personnel, informed yesterday by relatives of a jewelry salesman that he was threatening to commit suicide, combined forces to stop him.

For years it was the United States cavalry that sent a wave of hope and enthusiasm through endangered communities in the West. Later the Marines became the symbol of rescue, but today normal Americans can toss their hats in the air and roar "Here Comes THE NEW YORK TIMES!"

AMAGANSETT, L. I., July 21 -- The setting as well as the wares shown are of interest in the new Hampton Gallery and Workshop here. The gallery, which is owned by James Monroe Perkins and his wife Catherine, is housed in a building about 200 years old, while the paintings, sculpture, ceramics and other decorative accessories shown in it are contemporary.

PARIS, July 21 -- Claude Saint Cyr's silhouette in autmn hats is that of two pancakes, one posed level on the hairline, the other flat at the back of the head and reaching down to the nape. The two, overlapping, form an indentation high at each side.

An investment banking syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. will offer to investors today $20,000,000 of new cumulative preferred stock of El Paso Natural Gas Company. The offering consists of 200,000 shares of $100 par value 5.65 per cent dividend stock at $100 a share.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Val Peterson, Federal Civic Defense Administrator, said today that the United States was "living in a fool's paradise" by refusing to spend money on civil defense. "We spend billions on how to defeat the enemy," Mr. Peterson told the Senate Appropriations Committee, "but only a handful of dollars on how to protect the American people'' from possible enemy atomic bombs.

Aluminum, Ltd., issued a statement yesterday saying that its legal counsel in the United States believed there was no violation of United States anti-trust laws in a long-term contract to supply aluminum to the Aluminum Company of America.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 21 (AP) -- Top officers of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., and the Atlantic City Press met today in an effort to work out a contract and avoid a strike.
A 19-year-old girl who refused to give up her American citizenship stopped here briefly yesterday on her way home to Chicago after spending four years in Communist Poland.

The owner of the Governor Clinton Hotel thought it would be nice for his bellhops to wear saucer-size buttons welcoming guests to New York, but the bellhops' union objected so strenuously that the issue wound up yesterday before Edward P. Mulrooney, impartial chairman of labor relations in the hotel industry.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UP) -- Air Force papers stamped "secret" were found by two reporters today in an unattended Defense Department conference room. Air Force officials, who appeared disturbed over the discovery, said they did not know how they came to be left there.

The fundamental responsibility for developing and maintaining the best system for marketing food rests with the trade and not the Department of Agriculture, Howard H. Gordon, administrator of the production and marketing administration of that department, said yesterday.

JERUSALEM, July 21 -- An authorized Israeli Army source charged today that there were strong indications that the Jordanian raids into Israel during the past few weeks were carried out by highly trained paramilitary units.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., July 21 -- The reported absence of a green canvas bag containing $5,826 from the night depository of the Levittown branch of the Franklin National Bank was being investigated today by the Nassau County police. The Federal Bureau of Investigation also is scheduled to make an inquiry.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 -- The powerful all-court attack of Tony Trabert was functioning with overpowering proficiency on turf today as the rugged youth from Cincinnati and Victor Seixas scored crushing victories in the Pennsylvania state tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club.
LONDON, July 21 -- The Press Council, a voluntary body set up to regulate the ethics of the British press and uphold its freedom, held its first meeting here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 21 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has purchased "Empress of the Dusk," an historical novel dealing with Theodora and the Emperor Justinian, and will star Ava Gardner in the title role, Dore Schary announced today.
The magnetic amplifier in control systems is opening one of the last gates along the long road to complete automatization of mills and factories.

Young performers for young listeners will be emphasized in the thirtieth annual series of Young People's Concerts under the auspices of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony next season, it was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 -- Belief that the Bank of America, the world's largest, would continue to outdistance Eastern rivals like the National City and Chase National Banks was voiced today by Alfred J. Gock, board chairman of the Bank of America, as he observed his fiftieth anniversary in the banking business.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- Delays in completing security checks, which have hampered the recruitment of United States citizens for many United Nations posts, are creating difficulties for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees.

On record sales of $528,155,328, the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation realized its second highest earnings for an initial half-year period with a net income of $52,478,580 for the six months ended on June 30.

The National Peach Council has designated this as National Peach Week. New Yorkers may observe the occasion with a luscious peach shortcake or perhaps a peach pie, since the fruit is readily available here.

RYE, N. Y., July 21 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century, playing with a new set of golf clubs, gained a two-stroke lead in the Elizabeth Wheeler open golf championship as thirty-six holes were completed over the west course of the Westchester Country Club today.

Those who felt there was something strange about the weather here yesterday were right. Meteorologically speaking, the city was on the front line in a cosmic conflict between two great oceans of air, one wet and hot, the other one cool.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 21 (AP) -- Jean Corvino of Orange today trounced Mrs. Saul Whitman, Middlesex County champion, to gain a quarter-final berth in the New Jersey all-amateur women's tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A completed plan for West Germany's active participation in the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development should be ready to present to the bank at its annual meeting here in September, Fritz Schaeffer, West German Minister of Finance said today.

The American Natural Gas Company, which owns important operating utilities in the industrial areas of Michigan and Wisconsin, is planning construction of a thirty-inch natural gas pipeline from the Gulf Coast area to Detroit. Officials of the company said yesterday that application to transport gas from Louisiana to American Natural's markets would be made soon to the Federal Power Commission in Washington.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 21 -- In one of the biggest popular demonstrations in Iran's history, the Tudeh (Communist) party served notice today that as the nation's strongest and best disciplined political force it could no longer be ignored.

Mrs. Ruth Gill, Mrs. Naoma D. Norris, Thomas M. Reilly, Thomas M. Riddick, Marjorie K. Kilpatrick, George A. Shepard, Mrs. Grace M. Bebell, Edward L. Walton, Charles A. Hahn, B. D. Rubel Barbara Kelly, in 200 East End Ave -- Roger S. Smith, agent.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Members of the Washington Stock Exchange voted today to merge with the Philadelphia-Baltimore Stock Exchange.

The designations of Julius Helfand for the Democratic nomination for President of the City Council and Charles E. Keegan for Controller by the party leaders backing Mayor Impellitteri for re-election bring to the Mayor's slate two men who long have been in public service.

It was another wait-and-see day in Wall Street yesterday. Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to only 850,000 shares, about two-thirds of the level necessaary to meet the payroll and take care of the rent for the average brokerage house.

BOSTON, July 21 -- Most of the teachers who refused to answer questions at hearings of the House Un-American Activities Committee and the Senate Internal Security subcommittee have lost their jobs or are in danger of dismissal, a survey showed today.

A program of new product development was urged on members of the New York Chapter of the Young Presidents Organization yesterday at a meeting held at the Prince George Hotel on "current economic conditions."

When one wakes from a sleep made fitful by heat and encounters a morning of heavy atmosphere and sunlight like burnished bronze, few things are more welcome than an approaching thunderstorm and its promise of cool air and rain. Sometimes the thunder rumbles briefly and dies away, and one's hopes for relief are cheated.

Having rejected President Eisenhower's offer of $15,000,000 worth of free food for hungry Eastern Germany, the Kremlin now announces a "relief" program of its own. It promises, at least on paper, to ship $57,500,000 worth of foods and other materials to its rebellious satellite in an effort to counteract the effect of the President's offer and to abate the still-seething unrest of the population.

Form made a creditable appearance at the Jamaica race track yesterday, with enough of the "chalk" horses winning to satisfy most of the 17.817 fans on hand for the second day of the Saratoga Association's meeting.

CLEVELAND, July 21 -- Cleveland's supposedly comatose Indians bounced back to life tonight with startling effect as they laid violent hands on the front-running Bombers and brought them down with a resounding crash.

Plans fop a rectory and gymnasium to cost $800,000 were filed yesterday by Eggers Higgins, architects, for the Loyola School Corporation, 980 Park Avenue. The proposed building will occupy a site at 43 to 63 East Eighty-third Street, adjoining St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church and the Loyola School.
BERLIN, Wednesday, July 22 -- Vladimir S. Semyenov, Soviet High Commissioner in Germany, demanded today that the United States halt the distribution of free food to East Berliners.

The present presses hard upon us today in this miscellaneously inhabited city feverishly engaged in its multiple activities and busy making itself over in the image of an impatient future. In such circumstances the past is properly retired from immediate concern.

Four persons and two corporations were charged yesterday with violations of the Administrative Code and the State Labor Law in in connection with a Bronx factory fire in which seven persons died March 3.

Charles E. Keegan of the Bronx, chairman of the Finance Committee of the City Council, and Julius Helfand, assistant District Attorney of Kings County, were selected yesterday as Mayor Impellitteri's running mates in what promises to be one of the bitterest primary contests ever held in this city.

Among the new proposals to ameliorate current vexing problems in public debt management "with mirrors" is an ingenious measure introduced in Congress under which holders of the Treasury's long-term bonds would be permitted to exchange them for Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May) mortgages.

The following dispatch is by Eddy Gilmore, correspondent of The Associated Press in Moscow for eleven years, who was recently permitted to leave the Soviet Union with his family en route to the United States.
SEATTLE, July 21 (AP) -- Dr. Herbert J. Phillips, dismissed from the University of Washington faculty after admitting Communist party membership, was held in contempt of court today in Federal Court.

Mayor Impellitteri, a candidate for re-election, announced yesterday that he had canceled his weekly discussion program at the request of television station WNBT, which said his talks might be considered "political."
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 22 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,693, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Wednesday, Korean time:

ROME, July 21 -- The North Atlantic pact and European collaboration continue to be the cornerstone of Italian foreign policy, but the Italian people expect a solution of the Trieste problem in accordance with justice and any error that Western democracies commit in this field may have adverse effects "even on western solidarity," Premier Alcide De Gasperi declared today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 -- The invalidation of a representation election held last December among galley workers on Pacific Coast steam schooners has been recommended by a hearing officer of the National Labor Relations Board.

LONDON, July 21 (Reuters) -- The estimated 7,800,000 regular riders on London's buses and subway trains received bad news today -- for the fourth time in eight years. Fares are going up, starting Aug. 16.

Jimmy Slade, 174 pounds, New York, won an unpopular split decision over Herbie Hayes, 167, Elmsford, N. Y., in the feature bout of ten rounds before 1,200 fans at Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn, last night.

Anthony Anastasia, the powerful Brooklyn dock leader, announced yesterday that he would lead a reorganization of Brooklyn locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., by merging eleven locals.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Twenty organizations were formally added to the Department of Justice's subversive list today, after they had failed to contest the designation.
DETROIT, July 21 -- Automobile production and defense work at the Hudson Motor Car Company were halted today in a wildcat strike that made about 10,000 employes idle.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 21 (AP) -- Peg Jones, owned by J. H. Black of Sea View, Va., charged down the stretch to win the Cutchogue Pace by a head at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Bob Walker, driving Peg Jones, closed on the outside to nip Proclamation at the wire. Victory Red Stone was third.

Your editorial of July 17 "Is Washington America?" struck home. It is a question many of its residents often put to themselves. Our Washington papers do what they can to promote home rule for the District of Columbia. But most of the people reached by the local press are the ones most concerned and least able to be heard beyond the local area.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, stirred angry debate on the Senate floor today by reviving a 1948 letter in which Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, had extended his sympathy to Alger Hiss.

In its first change of ownership in twenty-one years, the four-story dwelling containing fifteen apartments on lot 20 by 100 feet at 120 West Eightieth Street has been sold by Mary Kelly to Milton Dreyer, operator, in a deal negotiated by L. J. Phillips Co., brokers.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 (UP) -- Carl (Bobo) Olson's manager agreed today "in principle" to a world middleweight championship fight matching his American champion with the European titleholder, Randy Turpin.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UP) -- Tax Commissioner T. Coleman Andrews refused today to support a recent United States Tax Court decision permitting a couple with a tentative divorce decree to file a joint income tax return.
DETROIT, July 21 (UP) -- Don Lund's tenth-inning double with two out drove in the tying and winning runs today as the Tigers defeated the Senators, 8 -- 7, at Briggs Stadium.

The Indian subsidiary of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation has been awarded a $4,000,000 contract to construct an extensive system of submarine and overland pipelines that will link two oil refineries at Bombay, India, with an offshore marine terminal.

The dolorous prophecy expressed in Ralph Proodian's letter appearing in THE TIMES of July 20 seems to be open to question. He presents the motion picture and department store industries, locally, as examples subject to substantial declines in volume of business due to the increased fare. He cites an "average family of four" attending movies en masse.

LONDON, July 21 -- Consideration is being given in London, Washington and other Allied capitals to the question of including the Soviet Union in the political conference that would be held after an armistice in Korea. There is some support among diplomatic experts on both side of the Atlantic for the inclusion of the Moscow Government but no firm decision has been taken either here or there.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Senate passed tonight a bill setting up the machinery for the sale of Government - owned synthetic rubber plants under a timetable allowing eight months longer than a House-approved measure for disposal of the properties.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 21 -- Patsy Boughton, a 13-year-old schoolgirl in blue jeans, put the Greenwich police force to shame this morning when she accomplished in ten minutes what it had tried in vain to do over the preceding twenty-four hours.

Trading was more active yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges but it was still below normal for most items. The world sugar contract had the largest volume June 17 and lead experienced the busiest day of the month. Prices were generally lower, with cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, potatoes, lead, tin, rubber and wool easing. Sugar, coffee, zinc and hides were mixed and copper closed higher.

An off-duty patrolman, driving home last night from a vacation swim with three of his eight children, noticed a hold-up in a grocery store, quickly deposited his youngsters at the curb and took chase in his car after the suspects, a gang of teen-agers.

Local 205 of the International Longshoremen's Association. A. F. L., which has been on strike in lumber plants in the metropolitan area and in Nassau and Suffolk Counties for the last two days, has rejected unanimously a new two-year contract offered by a joint committee representing the sixty companies under contract, Sigmund J. Brovarsky, secretary-treasurer of the local, said yesterday.

For the first time in its history, the United Corporation, once a large utility holding company, is making investments in the oil and other fields, its semi-annual report issued yesterday showed. The company, which has reduced its holdings in utilities in conformance with the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, now is operating as an investment concern.

Miguel Sandoval, 50 - year - old Guatemalan composer, conductor and pianist, collapsed yesterday morning of a heart condition at Lewisohn Stadium while rehearsing for his debut as a Stadium Concerts conductor.
Without wishing to appraise the merits of George J. Burger's encomium upon Representative Dan Reed in THE TIMES of July 17 there is one point which needs clarification.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (UP) -- Robin Roberts pitched his sixteenth victory of the season when the Phillies blanked the Braves, 10 -- 0, in the twilight first game of a double-header tonight but Milwaukee routed Lefty Curt Simmons to win the second game, 7 -- 3.

The United States registered the largest gain among the world's shipbuilding nations in the last three months and continued to hold second place in global standings, next to Great Britain, Lloyd's Register of Shipping reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Eisenhower named today as new Assistant Secretaries of Defense Dr. Melvin A. Casberg to be in charge of health and medical affairs and Franklin G. Floete to head the office of properties and installations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- There are increasing indications that, if a Korean armistice is signed by the end of the week, the United Nations General Assembly will reconvene in mid-August. August 13 is the date most frequently discussed, but since this will be a Thursday, some sources believe that the Assembly will not resume work before Aug. 17 or 18.
CHINESE elders in New York cling to ancient beliefs and to ancient customs and traditions. Some still believe, for example, in ancient Chinese remedies -- snake wine, wildcat soup and monkey soup.

The whole staff of 100 chasers and engravers of wedding rings on the sixth floor of the loft building at 216 East Forty-fifth Street watched anxiously late yesterday afternoon when a gray pigeon boldly came through a window to feed her two young at a corner work bench.
GENEVA, July 21 -- The improvement in trade relations between the Soviet Union and Western Europe has moved from a category of a possibility to that of an accomplished fact.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 21 (AP) -- William H. Foales' Scobeyville returned to his winning ways at Monmouth Park today in the $6,000 Zev Purse before 16,590.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- United States ship operators on the Great Lakes are up against not only a rapidly growing Canadian fleet but also "the even more devastating competition of European flag vessels," a Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce subcommitte was told today.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today that draft calls might be reduced from the present 23,000 a month to 15,000 to 18,000 if a truce was effected in Korea.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 21 -- The world's first water - based fighter plane -- a futuristic craft that floats and take off on retractable "hydro-skis" -- was demonstrated publicly today.
The Maryland State Roads Commission borrowed $25,000,000 yesterday on highway revenue bonds due from 1954 to 1968 at an interest cost of 2.5874 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay announced today that the Defense Minerals Exploration Administration had executed 517 contracts up to June 30 under the defense program aimed at discovery and bringing into production critical and strategic minerals.
The Protestant Council of the City of New York began yesterday to distribute 6,000 placards welcoming members of the armed forces to the city's churches.

Secretary of the Treasury Humphrey is of the opinion that Government receipts will make their second successive high in the fiscal year now beginning. He predicts that they will reach approximately $68,500,000,000, which would surpass by $3,300,000,000 the 1953 figure of $65,200,000,000.

STOCKHOLM, July 21 (UP) -- Wes Santee and Mal Whitfield failed in their bids for world records tonight, but the touring United States track and field stars swept all nine events at Stockholm Olympic Stadium before a crowd of 10,000.

While everyone else in the city was trying desperately to devise ways of escaping the heat and humidity, a group of 10-year-olds attending the play school at Public School 125, at 425 West 123d Street, cooked and served pancakes to visitors yesterday in a demonstration of the school's activities.
BONN, Germany, July 21 (AP) -- Six Germans have been arrested on charges of spying for the Soviet Union on secret British military installations along the Iron Curtain, the British said today.

ROME, July 21 -- Sorelle Fontana (the Fontana sisters), who invariably follow a theme through their collections, have this season drawn inspiration from the Italian renaissance. Jewel colors in opulent silks, satins and velvets reflected paintings of this era.

Plans have been advanced at recent meetings at the Waldorf-Astoria for the entertainment, known as the Dolls and Dogs fashion show and luncheon to be held on Oct. 14 in the Empire Room of the hotel under the auspices of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

Clement V. Conole, president of Hearn Department Stores, asserted yesterday that the company could not legally accept any of the proposals put forward by the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers, C. I. O., for settlement of its nine-week-old strike at Hearn's.

LOS ANGELES, July 21 -- Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins, former chancellor of the University of Chicago and now associate director of the Ford Foundation, attacked the Los Angeles Board of Education today for the basis on which he said it refused funds from the foundation for a five-year teacher-training experiment.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Another attempt to write a comprehensive revision of the Taft-Hartley law failed today, and the White House was reported considering a message of Congress, carrying a few specific suggestions, to put President Eisenhower on record at this session.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Members of Congress reported today that a number of complaints from drought-stricken Southwestern livestock producers asserted the cattlemen had to be broke and out of the business before they could get Government-owned feed to help them keep herds intact.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- With an assist from the Democrats, Administration forces on the House Judiciary Committee snuffed out today an attempt to sidetrack full committee consideration for at least a week of the proposal to admit 247,000 refugees to this country in the next two years.

An indication that industrial design, which ranges from airplane interiors to cigarette packages in this country, is considered a necessary part of mass production in other parts of the world are the home furnishings shown in these pictures.

The Continental Oil CompanyI has announced the following pro-i motions in its marketing depart-I ment: 0. B. Lloyd from general sales manager to executive assistant to the vice president of marketing, and S. D. Breitweiser from acting general manager of the Eastern region to general sales manager.
SIDNEY WOOD, with Donald Budge and Jack Kramer kibitzing, was selecting the composite perfect tennis game, compounded of the master strokes of the kings of the court down through the years.
Two super-transistors that do tricks earlier models of the midget devices could not do have been produced by Sylvania Electric Products, Inc.

NEW DELHI, India, July 21 -- India has asked Washington and Peiping for clarification of the prospective truce conditions in Korea to determine how they will affect this country's fulfillment of her responsibilities as sole custodian of prisoners who do not wish to be repatriated to their home forces.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 20 -- President Eisenhower's gesture of sending William R. Ball as special delegate with the rank of Minister to visit the Central African Exhibition at Bulawayo was greeted here with enthusiasm as a friendly greeting to the newborn Central African Federation.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Following is the text of the statement presented today by Bishop G. Bromley Oxnan, Methodist leader for the Washington area, to the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives, plus additional material he said he ]would have presented had he received additional time:

LONDON, July 21 -- Thousands of Britons have letters after their names that puzzle Americans -- letters like O. B. E. or K. C. V. O. or C. M. G. These three groups happen to be used by persons who are members of The Most Excellent Order of the British Empire or Knights Commander of the Royal Victorian Order or Companions of the Most Distinguished Order of St. Michael and St. George.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Wheat failed to hold early gains today as longs were disturbed by reports that news of a truce in Korea might come overnight. Volume of buying was not as large as in recent days, which was not much of a surprise considering that the market has had a rather substantial advance of late.

Some increases of gross profit margins, together with greater emphasis on higher-priced merchandise to raise per-unit sales receipts, were among general suggestions made yesterday for overcoming declining profits in major wholesale and retail fields.

A strike of Trans World Airlines navigators that has caused trans-Atlantic flight cancellations for the last twelve days ended last night when the navigators voted to return to work under an agreement signed yesterday in Washington.

Police Lieut. Arthur Miller was identified yesterday by John Lautner, former security chief for the New York State Communist party, as a dues-paying Communist party member who bad been groomed for the post of Police Commissioner since 1949.

GLEN RIDGE, N. J., July 21 -- Mrs. William Tracy gained a 4-point lead today in the Elizabeth Goss round-robin golf turnament with a round of 36, 37 -- 73, one under women's par for the Glen Ridge Country Club course.

The manuscript of Morton Thompson's second novel about doctors was received by Scribners a short time before he died of a heart attack on July 7. As in "The Cry and the Covenant," Mr. Thompson's fictionalized biography of Ignaz Philipp Semelweiss, "Not As a Stranger," is a story about an American doctor who was dedicated to his profession and fought the abuses in it.
A new elementary school for the East Side of Manhattan, the first in thirty-two years, will be placed under construction before the end of the year, the Board of Education announced yesterday.

Mechanical merchandising, a revolution in retailing as great as that brought about by the supermarket, is on the way, it was asserted yesterday by Arthur C. Fatt, executive vice president of Grey Advertising Agency, Inc. In a talk at a meeting of Operations, Inc., at the Sheraton Hotel in Chicago yesterday Mr. Fatt listed "basic reasons" for this view:

Amid a public display of bad feeling and recrimination over past party defeats the five Democratic county leaders of New York City have come to a parting of the ways. Three of them, from Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island, have designated Mayor Impellitteri for the Democratic nomination to succeed himself.
When a distillery union began organizing blousemakers, David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., decided it was time to put the cork back in the bottle.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The mid-June consumers' price index, jacked up by higher food costs, broke through the record highs of last summer and fall. This means automatic wage rises for an estimated 100,000 workers.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Grain markets were influenced today by the closing out of July contracts, especially of corn and soybeans. Open interest was large in both July corn and soybeans, and while prices were lower most of the session, there was an upturn just before trading ceased.

LONDON, July 22 -- The stock markets here brightened today, an expansion of business being accompanied by price gains in almost all groups. The improvement was most marked among industrial leaders, which rose fairly sharply. Tobacco shares led the way, followed by the textiles, building automobile and store groups.

The market for the tax-exempt-interest bonds of local government is continuing to give a good account of itself in its comeback from the low prices touched in the spring's final market decline. A tag-end of about $2,000,000 of bonds of the $5,900,000 issue of Cook County, Ill., High School District 201 has been sold this week.

NEWARK, July 22 -- Mrs. Mary Pado, a plump, 42-year-old woman with redish-blond hair, confessed today, the police said, to thefts totaling $75,000 over nine years from department stores, institutions and retail shops that employed her.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 22 -- A negative answer was given today at a Stanford University business conference to the question whether economic adjustments in the field of agriculture would precipitate a general economic depression.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Eisenhower Administration moved today not merely to delay but to supplant with a softer version Senator John W. Bricker's proposed amendment to the Constitution to limit the President's treaty-making power.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, July 23 (AP) -- United States F-86 Sabre pilots shot down three Communist MIG's in air battles over North Korea yesterday, the Air Force reported. South Korean soldiers grappled with the Chinese Reds in a series of small but stiff fights along the muddy battlefront.

THERE is concern over the failure of the white marlin to appear in their usual numbers off eastern Long Island, but in view of the reasonable abundance of these fish off Ocean City, Md., this scarcity is marked down to tardiness rather than a shift in migration.

The "superb performance" of Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Church before the House Committee on Un-American Activities may be "the turning point in this whole business of the methods employed by these committees," the Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert said last night.
Charles A. Glover has been appointed interline sales manager of Eastern Air Lines, Inc.

The International Longshoremen's Association and Anthony Anastasia patched up an uneasy peace yesterday, leaving the Brooklyn dock leader free to try to merge all Brooklyn longshore locals in a single group.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., July 22 (AP) -- George Auerbach's Dictar, one of the many 3-year-olds beaten by Native Dancer this season, came from behind to defeat James Cox Brady's Landlocked by a half-length in the $25,000 added Providence Stakes at Narragansett Park today.

With the approval of their executive committees, Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, and Edward J. Flynn, Bronx leader, yesterday designated Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, to run against Mayor Impellitteri for the Democratic nomination for Mayor at the primary election Sept. 15.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 22 (AP) -- For the third year in succession, the New York Athletic Club dominated the opening events of the Royal Canadian Henley Regatta as the seventy-first competition started today.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 23 -- The Communists today angrily attacked as a fresh threat to an armistice in the Korean war the new reservations to a truce agreement voiced yesterday in a public statement by the rebellious South Korean President, Syngman Rhee.

SEOUL, Korea, July 22 -- President Syngman Rhee of South Korea aroused new fears for the outcome of the armistice negotiations today by renewing his demand for the withdrawal of Chinese Communist troops from Korea.

DOVER, England, July 22 (AP) -- Rough seas and icy water today forced Scotsman Ned Barnie to give up this season's first attempt Sw the English Chel, eI had been the water 14 hours and 25 minutes en route to lCTce.

Business elements adversely affected by "Buy American" Act restrictions on foreign buying by the United States Government were urged yesterday to keep up their fight for repeal during the projected special commission study of foreign economic policy recommended by President Eisenhower.
Announcement of a thirteen-film schedule for the next six months was made during the recently concluded R. K. O. sales meeting by J. R. Grainger, company president.

LONDON, July 22 -- One after another, Labor members of the House of Commons hammered away today and tonight at the charge that the Conservative Government had failed to carry through the grand design of its ailing leader, Sir Winston Churchill, for a four-power meeting at the top level.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower nominated Cavendish W. Cannon today to be Ambassador to Greece and Raymond A. Hare to be Ambassador to Lebanon. Both men are career Foreign Service officers.

NEW YORK, Ford Madox Ford used to say with grand finality, is not America. It was an oblique compliment. For if he had said that America was not New York, no one would have paid any particular attention whatever. But the challenge implied in the suggestion that there was something to be said for the rest of the country always was received with a kind of angry gratitude.

Since July 3 New York's construction industry has been in the grip of a strange and increasingly serious strike that has affected -- in whole or in part -- $600,000,000 in public and private projects and brought unemployment to 100,000 building trades workers. But the curious thing about this tie-up is that the construction industry has no quarrel with anyone, and neither does any of the building trades unions.

The five Republican county chairmen have designated Harold Riegelman as the party's candidate for Mayor of New York City. Mr. Riegelman, who has not yet accepted the designation, is a man of upright and forthright character who has lived with the city's governmental problems for more than twenty years.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- The Department of Defense today announced a new total of 139,272 United States battle casualties in Korea, an increase of 1,026 over last week's report.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 22 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, arriving in Rio de Janeiro this afternoon on the last leg of his goodwill and fact-finding tour of South America, assured Brazilians that "we share your faith in your country's destiny."

Your editorial of July 2, and M. C. Ellenstein's letter of July 18, prompt me to add that I do not believe anything will be accomplished until commercial pilots themselves are aware of the terrible and nerve-racking nuisance of plane noise.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 22 -- South Africa's inability to obtain the capital she needs from abroad -- attributed to the secession movement in Natal Province by the Nationalist Government and to Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's race policies by the United party Opposition -- was reflected in the national budget presented to Parliament today by Finance Minister N. C. Havenga.

The Jehovah's Witnesses who have encamped in New Market, N. J., this week in order to attend the ceremonies at the Yankee Stadium did not seek out New York for its cocktail parties, its tall towers, or its air-conditioned restaurants.

New York may deserve a good many of the mean things people say about it. It may be dirty, lack polish and politesse, be geared to a man-killing pace, be too hot or too cold, too humid, too rainy, too big, too confusing. But one thing, New York can turn out for a hero returning with a plum like the British Open.

A forty-two-story office skyscraper -- the largest commercial building project to be erected in Manhattan since Rockefeller Center -- will go up in the block bounded by Lexington and Third Avenues, Forty-first and Forty-second Streets.

ROME, July 20 -- The Vatican said today that an address by Alfredo Cardinal Ottaviani here, March 2, supporting the Spanish Bishops' position favoring restriction of Protestant minorities in Roman Catholic countries in the face of criticism by some French and United States Catholics, was not official or semi-official but was nevertheless "unexceptionable."

RYE, N. Y., July 22 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century successfully defended the Elizabeth Wheeler golf title as she added an even-par 78 to her first two rounds of 81, 82 for 241 in the fifty-four-hole medal-play championship at Westchester Country Club today.

Brazil's outstanding draft indebtedness to United States exporters fall $21,000,000 in June, reducing the debt to $175,700,000, a thirteen-month low, the Federal Reserve Bank here said yesterday. The figures represent debt to exporters whose financing is reported by the fifteen banks participating in the Reserve Bank's monthly survey of Latin American export credit conditions.

ATHENS, July 22 -- The wheat crop this year will amount to between 1,300,000 and 1,400,000 metric tons, according to the Ministry of Agriculture's forecast. (A metric ton is 2,204 pounds.) It was estimated that 1,600,000 metric tons would be required to cover Greece's internal wheat needs.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 22 -- Records of the committee that reviewed the efficiency of 1,000 United Nations staff members have been destroyed, the Administrative Tribunal, the United Nations' highest appeal board for staff affairs was told today. The charge was made by Frank J. Donner, representing some of the group whose appeals for reinstatement are under review by the tribunal.

BERLIN, July 22 -- West Berlin prepared today to begin the delivery of 1,000,000 food parcels to residents of East Berlin next week despite the note from Vladimir S. Semyenov, Soviet High Commissioner, made public early this morning demanding the food project be halted.

Trans World Airlines, Inc., achieved the highest operating revenues in its history in both the quarter and the six months ended on June 30. As a result, net profits bettered those of the corresponding periods of 1952.

JERUSALEM, July 22 -- The controversial women's service bill, which requires women exempt from military conscription on the grounds of religious objection to render two years' national service in Orthodox communal farms, immigrant camps or in social or health services, was approved tonight on its first reading in the Knesset (Parliament) by fifty-nine votes to six, with eight abstentions.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 22 -- Mayor Nicholas S. Lacorte, titular held of the Republican party here, will have to get along with a Democratic secretary, John C. Tuehy, according to a ruling today by the State Civil Service Commission that ordered Mr. Tuehy restored with back pay to the post from which he was ousted Jan. 1 when Mr. Lacorte took office.
TOKYO, Thursday, July 23 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,684, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

ELMIRA, N. Y., July 22 -- A survey released at the mid-year meeting of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute here shows that 96 per cent of the department stores buy through wholesalers: about 63 per cent buy 10 per cent or more of their volume from wholesalers. and 23 per cent buy half or more from wholesalers.

Its continued effort to achieve coalition despite initial failure suggests that the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee might profitably re-examine its premise as to the most useful way to make its contribution to good government in New York.
The number of poliomyelitis cases reported to the Health Department so far this month has been increasing, but not at a pace that would indicate a bad polio year for the city.

Children will have an opportunity to share experiences with their parents this year, as toy manufacturers are stressing realism and functionalism in their lines. Playthings exhibited yesterday at a Christmas preview sponsored by the Toy Guidance Council introduced no startling new ideas but showed major improvements on existing items.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 -- Paul Jarrico, producer of "Salt of The Earth," told his attorneys today to prepare a damage suit against persons he says have held up completion of the controversial film made in Silver City, N. M.

A decline last week of 233,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies aggregated 143,820,000 barrels, compared with 144,053,000 a week earlier and 117,380,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The work of a young Washington designer is being watched with increasing interest by fashion experts here. The designer, Philip Robertson, is now creating fifteen ball gowns for a fall fashion show and hopes to be able to show another such collection in Paris next spring.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Automobile dealers and representatives of companies that finance their sales wound up a conference here today on a note of optimism regarding the outlook for the auto industry.
MOSCOW, July 22 -- The Soviet press reported today the death after a long serious illness of Air Col. Gen. Timon Timofeyevich Khryukin.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The head of Bethlehem Steel Company's shipbuilding division forecast today a "nearly complete cessation" of shipbuilding in the United States by the end of next year. Daniel D. Strohmeier, top man in Bethlehem's system of eleven shipyards and 25,000 shipbuilding workers, said there would be a severe loss of employment and a "dissipation of shipbuilding skills" unless new orders were found immediately.

Electric power production for the week ended on Saturday increased to 8,209,203,000 kilowatt-hours from 8,096,149,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended on July 19, 1952, was 7,180,328,000. Percentage changes from the like weeks of last year are:

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 22 -- The main proceedings of Larchmont Yacht Club's fifty-fifth race week were halted today. The seasoned sailors had the afternoon off while the juniors took over the western end of Long Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- A new contract for boat service to the Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor was announced today along with word that a new ship able to handle about 500 passengers might be in service in 1954.

Early in June THE NEW YORK TIMES ran a press release from the New York State Library quoting figures on library support. These were taken from a survey made by the library of the funds spent for library service throughout the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Eisenhower is by no means satisfied with the speed of progress by his Administration in carrying out campaign promises during its first six months in office. He believes some progress has been made, but it would be deceitful for him to pretend that all he had hoped for had been accomplished in the first eighth of his term.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 22 (AP) -- Hal Tryax, owned and driven by Sanders Russell of Stevenson, Ala., won the Calverton Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight by a head from Prince Terry. Imprudent was third.

PARIS, July 22 -- Returning to a deeper crown, Maud et Nano introduce a forward silhouette that lies flat on the brow, forming a gracious arc just above the eyebrows. The edge then turns at an angle on the temples and sweeps up in back to the top of the head.

The five Republican county leaders designated Acting Postmaster Harold Riegelman yesterday as the party's candidate for Mayor. They chose as Mr. Riegelman's running mates Representative Henry J. Latham of Queens for President of the City Council and Representative Paul A. Fino of the Bronx for Controller.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities, after nearly eight hours of questioning of Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Church that continued past last midnight, found itself divided today over just how much it apparently had "cleared" the ecclesiastic of Communist affiliation.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 23 (AP) -- Pravda's editorial assailing the West's call for a four-power foreign ministers' conference was the first Soviet reaction to the invitation extended to Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov on July 15 after the Washington meeting of British, French and American foreign ministers.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 22 -- On slippery turf following a drenching rain the top favorites in the Pennsylvania state championships underwent their most trying day of the week at the Merion Cricket Club today. Some exceedingly clever tennis was forthcoming to reward the gallery that waited an hour and forty minutes for the weather to clear.

The "Battle of the Punched Holder" raged last night aboard a Long Island Rail Road commuter train, and the results of the clash included an unscheduled stop at Jamaica, Queens, the arrest of the president of a Wall Street concern on disorderly conduct charges and an inconclusive hearing at Manhattan Night Court.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Northwest Natural Gas Company jumped back today into the contest for permission to build the first natural gas pipeline into the Pacific Northwest. Its attorney, Arthur G. Lane, said it could save consumers in that area $50,000,000 in twenty years in comparison with what two other competitors for a permit can do.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Food from the United States will continue to be shipped to West Germany for the humanitarian purpose of feeding the hungry in the Soviet-controlled Eastern zone despite Russian objections, President Eisenhower said today.

SYRACUSE, July 22 -- A "human rights" course for policemen was suggested today by George P. Monaghan, New York City Police Commissioner, speaking before the fifty-third annual conference of the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today an increase of 100,000 tons in the quantity of sugar that may be imported this year.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., July 22 (AP) -- The Scotia-Glenville Board of Education announced today that it had canceled the appointment of a teacher who declined to tell Congressional investigators whether she was or ever had been a Communist.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A band of Senate Democrats was organized hastily today to fight a Senate-House conference compromise, described as "completely acceptable" by President Eisenhower, that would cut the number of public housing starts for the current fiscal year to 20,000 units.

ITHACA, N. Y., July 22 -- Aviators and explorers have specially designed clothing that actually helps "to promote their adventures.'' Growing children who are learning physical skills that must last them a lifetime should have no less, according to a bulletin on clothing for children, revised and reissued by Cornell University.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau reported today that moderate to heavy rains had narrowed greatly the country's drought areas and checked threats of serious crop damages.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Unexpected oratory kept the Senate from passing on the $34,500,000,000 defense appropriation bill tonight. After twelve hours of debate, the Republican leadership gave up its attempt to force passage and called for a recess at 9:54 P. M. until noon tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Eisenhower said today there was no question of politics in the Federal drought relief program for Southwestern states.

BERLIN, July 22 -- Reports filtering from East German villages and recent official East German accounts indicate that contrary to earlier belief the June 17 uprising in many cases involved rural areas as well as industrial centers.

The two-family dwelling at 120-43 195th Street in St. Albans, Queens, has been sold by Lorain Manor, Inc., to Salvatore V. Parisi. Title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

CHICAGO, July 22 (UP) -- Virgil Trucks limited the Red Sox to four hits today for his seventh straight victory as the White Sox scored a 1-0 victory before 13,245 and broke a five-game Boston winning streak.

Former President Herbert Hoover will be 79 years old Aug. 10, and it is twenty years since he has sought any office or asked any favor from the Republican party. But over these two decades he has invariably been prepared to place his knowledge, his experience and his time at the disposal of his country unhesitatingly and without stint.

PARIS, July 22 -- After the Cabinet meeting today it appeared unlikely that the French could achieve their long-cherished aim of linking peace negotiations in Indo-China directly with an eventual Korean settlement.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Following is the 288-to-115 vote by which the House today passed and sent to the Senate a bill appropriating $4,438,678,000 to finance the foreign-aid program during this fiscal year:

LEVITTOWN, L. I., July 22 -- Last Sunday's receipts at the Levittown Safeway store, a total of $5,826 that had been reported missing from the night depository of the Franklin National Bank's Levittown branch, were redeposited this morning in the mail box in front of the bank building -- minus $96.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 23 -- Pravda, in a long page-one editorial, declared today that the recent Washington conference of the three Western powers made it apparent that no one could any longer deny the urgent necessity for solutions of disputed international questions by peaceful conversations.

Two powerful tugboats of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company have been chartered by the Alaska Freight Line to tow two huge DeLong tramway barges from Charleston. S. C., and Orange, Tex., to Whittier, Alaska, where the barges will replace dock facilities recently destroyed by fire.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Republican members of the House of Representatives rejected President Eisenhower's eleventh-hour attempt today to head off a $1,120,050,575 cut in his foreign aid program. The House passed and sent to the Senate a Mutual Security appropriation totaling $4,438,678,000.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by White House rules:

Fountain pen manufacturers are still pitching for the conventional pens even though they sell the ball point type. Sheaffer Pen Company is distributing plastic talkie tapes -- "Hello, Sweetheart" and "Stick 'em up, wrangler!" -- that sound off when a thumbnail is drawn across them, with an empty four-ounce Skrip carton as amplifier.

PITTSBURGH, July 22 (AP) -- Dr. Peter Lindstrom, chief neurosurgeon at Aspinwall, Pa., Veterans Hospital, is conducting advanced research into a method of controlling pain with supersonics, it was disclosed today by the Addison H. Gibson Laboratory at the University of Pittsburgh.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- A long-shot chestnut, Arab Actress, turned on stretch speed for a six-length victory today in the $29,075 Cleopatra Handicap for 3-year-old fillies at Arlington Park.

The former director of the Czechoslovak Program, Radio Free Europe, Paul Tigrid, pleads for "an all-out 'psychological warfare' offensive," in which he sees "the possibility of actually wrenching from the Kremlin's grasp one or more satellite States."
