Such advice is dangerous both for the satellite peoples and ourselves.

KEARNY, N. J., July 22 -- A bomb exploded early today in the parked automobile of a longshoreman, wrecking the car and touching off a new investigation into waterfront crime and violence along the Hudson River.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 22 -- A grant of $225,000 by the Ford Foundation to the Hoover Institute and Library on War, Revolution and Peace, to be distributed over three years, was announced today by Dr. Douglas H. Whitaker, Provost of Stanford University.

With Gil Hodges leading the way at bat in both contests, Johnny Padres and Carl Erskine pitched the sizzling Dodgers to 9-3 and 11-1 triumphs over the hapless Cubs before 18,855 at Ebbets Field last night. Victorious in ten of their last eleven games, the Brooks widened their lead over the second-place Braves to five and a half games and are threatening to break the National League race wide open.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 22 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh appeared unmoved today by the enormous Tudeh (Communist) demonstration last night and gave the impression that his Government's present de facto, if not de jure, recognition of the outlawed party would continue for the time being.

LONDON, July 22 -- R. A. Butler, Acting Chairman of the British Cabinet, assured the House of Commons today that the full influence of the British Government would be brought to bear to prevent President Syngman Rhee of South Korea from sabotaging the conclusion of a Korean truce.

Coming up with four hits and two runs with one out in the ninth, the Giants bounced back to the first division in the National League pennant chase yesterday by topping the Cardinals, 6-5, at the Polo Grounds.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and prices closed 2 points higher to 2 points lower than on Tuesday.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 22 (AP) -- Jimmy Stout scored his seventh stakes victory of the meet at Monmouth Park today by booting home Mrs. S. M. Pistorio's Tuscany in the $15,000 added Rumson Handicap.
PARIS, July 22 -- It was early that March morning when the telephone rang, and the Russian voice said:

THE weather outside was broiling. The market on thermometers was going up steadily because the mercury was spilling over the tops of whatever gauges were near by. Everywhere people were wilting, scarcely moving lest the effort cause them to forget propriety so completely as to apply Mark Twain's counsel to "take off their skin and just sit around in their bones."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 22 -- Upsets marked the opening day's program of the fifty-third annual Metropolitan amateur golf championship at the Fenway Club and only two former winners of the title were left in the tourney tonight.

GENEVA, July 22 -- A reduction of contributions to programs of technical assistance in underdeveloped countries for 1954 would have "catastrophic" consequences, David Owen, director of the United Nations Technical Assistance Administration told the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations today.

MADRID, July 9 -- Spanish ecclesiastical circles said today that the doctrinal stand taken by the Roman Catholic Episcopacy of Spain on what it considered the duties and obligations of a Catholic state toward religion in general and the Protestant minorities in particular had been confirmed by the Vatican.

SAN ANTONIO, July 22 -- Next year's conventions of the Catholic Central Verein of America and the National Catholic Women's Union will be held in New Haven, Conn., it was decided at their conventions today.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, July 22 -- Gen. Lauris Norstad, newly appointed Deputy Supreme Allied Commander for Air, will officially begin his duties here on Monday, it was announced today. General Norstad, who succeeds British Air Chief Marshal Sir Hugh Saunders, is expected to revamp separate Allied air forces in Europe into a single weapon backed by United States atomic airpower.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 (AP) -- Little Bobby Shantz limited the Browns to five hits as the Athletics scored an 11-1 victory tonight. Dave Philley and Cass Michaels hit home runs to lead a seventeen-hit Philadelphia attack.

the Warlnanco Park Courts, were Mss Jean Corvino, Orange, who defeated Mrs. LUlian Dowd, Newark 6--3, 6--2; Miss Betty Coumbe, Westfield, who toppled Mrs. Dorothy Johnston, Elizabeth, 6--1, 6--2, and Mrs. Nana D. Vaughan, Elizabetl, who beat Fay Shaw, Elizabeth, 6, 6--2, 6--0.

Philip K. Crowe, recently appointed United States Ambassador to Ceylon, has a book about sports on Van Nostrand's list for Oct. 15 publication. In "Sport Is Where You Find It," he tells stories of pig sticking, horse racing, shooting big game, fishing, beagling and hare hunting from China and India to Nantucket and Maryland's Eastern Shore.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Two Interstate Commerce Commission examiners recommended today that the Federal Government's claims for an estimated $2,000,000,000 refund on freight charges paid the railroads in World War II be rejected.

A man who resisted all efforts to rescue him apparently succeeded in committing suicide at 5:20 P. M. yesterday in the waters of Paerdegat Basin, Jamaica Bay, Queens. His body had not been recovered at a late hour.
Save for the rubbers, which were weak, and the rails, oils and motors, which were firm, there was little that could be called a pattern of movement in yesterday's New York Stock Exchange trading.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 22 -- Chester C. Kelsey, of New York, president of the American Trade Association Executives, today pledged the cooperation of the membership to the Eisenhower Administration "to balance the budget, eliminate deficit financing, and once more permit us to do business in a sane and solvent economy."
DETROIT, July 22 (UP) -- Hal Newhouser, a high school "boy wonder" who became one of the top pitchers in the major leagues, received his unconditional release today from the Tigers.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 22 -- While the Chinese Nationalist Government has shown marked restraint in its official comments on the Korean armistice proceedings, with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek publicly endorsing the present armistice terms in a recent interview, there is obvious disappointment in Nationalist circles here about the turn of events in Korea.

LONDON, July 22 -- The British love of dressing up and having a parade, which has become a mild mania in this coronation year, was gratified again today by a three-mile-long river pageant. It was sponsored by the Lord Mayor, Sir Rupert de la Bere, because he felt that Londoners were forgetting the importance of the Thames.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Senate and House of Representatives conferees agreed today on $718,395,398 to run the Department of Agriculture for the year ending June 30, 1954. This is $5,647,570 more than the amount originally approved by the House and $1,665,000 more than the eSnate had allowed.

HOLLYWOOD, July 22 (UP) -- Bing Crosby's sixty-five race horses go on sale tomorrow in his first move to help raise $1,000,000 inheritance tax on his wife's estate. She died in November. He also has put on the market his Holmby Hills mansion in West Los Angeles and his summer home at Pebble Beach, Calif.

CHICAGO, July 22 (UP) -- Dan Bucceroni, a Philadelphia heavyweight with plenty of punch, scored a ten-round decision over Tommy Harrison tonight on the weekly television fight feature from the Chicago Stadium.

At the annual meeting of the General Foods Corporation here yesterday stockholders approved an increase in the authorized stock to 15,000,000 from 6,000,000 shares. There are now 5,814,605 shares outstanding.

LONDON, July 22 -- Parliament will enact a law this year to designate the Duke of Edinburgh in place of Princess Margaret as Regent for his son Prince Charles if the Prince should become King before reaching his majority.
SEOUL, Korea, July 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of the answers today by President Syngman Rhee of South Korea to questions submitted to him by foreign correspondents:
A Trans World Airlines Constellation on a trans-Atlantic flight to Paris turned back yesterday when the passenger cabin became filed with smoke at 17,000 feet over Montauk Point, L. I.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, took public issue with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy tonight over handling of the J. B. Matthews issue and the Wisconsin Republican Senator's charges against Democrats on the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

There were strong indications yesterday that New Yorkers are not token-broken. Fewer than 400,000 metal tickets to subway and elevated lines were purchased by future users farsighted enough to buy the 15-cent tokens that went on sale seventy-two hours in advance of the higher fare, effective at 12:01 A. M. Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP) -- The Phillies got away to a four-run lead in the first inning -- topped by Gran Hamner's two-run homer -- and coasted to a 6-3 victory over the Braves tonight. Jim Konstanty racked up his eleventh triumph with an assist from Karl Drews.

The National Community Relations Advisory Council, made up of six national and thirty local Jewish organizations, yesterday attacked Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's assertion last Sunday that criticism of two of his Senate subcommittee staff was an example of anti-Semitism. It called his remarks "an irresponsible attempt to thwart the legitimate right of criticism."
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Following is the text of a statement made today by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of Steate, on the Korean armistice problem:

Henry Fonda will be starred as Lieutenant Greenwald, the defense attorney, in Paul Gregory's production of "The Caine Mutiny Court Martial." The play, a dramatization by Herman Wouk of a part of his Pulitzer Prize novel, "The Caine Mutiny," is expected to reach Broadway early in January after a tour beginning in Phoenix, Ariz., on or about Oct. 8.

LONDON, July 22 -- Dr. A. J. P. Martin, Nobel Prize winner and one of Britain's most famous chemists, has devised a method of analyzing minute amounts of elusive volatile substances that may revolutionize basic research into a host of chemical processes from explosives to the constituents of antibiotics and the cancer cell.

The General Education Board of the Rockefeller Foundation, which has spent nearly $316,000,000 in grants and benefits of all kinds, has exhausted its funds and consequently is ending its active role as a helping hand for schools and for their scholars and students.

The projected truce in Korea, for which the contending forces have been negotiating for more than two years, continues to hang in the balance because of President Rhee's persisting anxiety about the future of his country -- an anxiety that has been further aggravated by the cynical Communist attacks on his army at a time when hopes for peace appeared brightest.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 22 -- Preliminary steps are being taken for a special research study on child discipline which the Guidance Center at 81 Center Avenue will conduct this fall under the direction of Dr. Goodwin Watson, director of research and educational consultant at the center.

PITTSBURGH, July 22 (AP) -- Outfielder Cal Abrams blasted his ninth and tenth homers of the season and Hal Rice collected three singles as the Pirates edged the Redlegs, 3 -- 2, today before 1,567, smallest crowd of the season.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 15, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

Robert B. Blaikie, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor and Democratic leader of the Seventh Manhattan Assembly District, yesterday attacked both Mayor Impellitteri and Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr., other candidates for the nomination.
The Transit Authority would like us to believe %hat tde nev 1S-cent se I compares favorably with the 15~cent to 120-cent fares in effect in most other large cities. It doesn't

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A stripped-down version of the Administration's bill for simplification of customs procedures was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee in the interest of compleitng Congressional action before adjournment.

It wasn't so much the heat yesterday, the Weather Bureau said, it was the . . . uh huh . . . but maybe tonight or tomorrow morning that slow-motion cold air mass that started moving this way three days ago from the Pacific Northwest will arrive and dry New York's humid blanket.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The ideal of a physician functioning also as a social scientist in a new therapy called "comprehensive medicine" was put before the Association for Physical and Mental Rehabilitation today by Dr. Irwin J. Cohen, manager of the Veterans Administration Hospital, Baltimore.

Cocoa prices soared yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange in the most active dealings since April 13. Trading was marked by delayed dealer hedging and short covering. Nineteen notices were posted and were stopped immediately.

In his statement to the House Un-American Activities Committee Bishop Oxnam of the Methodist Church performed a public service by exposing in clear terms and with specific examples the kind of un-American tactics that the committee has followed. Bishop Oxnam is among the more prominent of the loyal Americans who have been victimized by one or another of the Congressional inquisitions, and he deserves congratulations in refusing to take the implication of disloyalty lying down.

With clock-like precision, 4,640 Jehovah's Witnesses were baptized by immersion yesterday at the Riverside Cascade Pool, Broadway and 134th Street. The five-hour public demonstration symbolized the desire of each new Witness to "serve his God uncompromisingly."
BORDENTOWN, N. J., July 22 -- A once proud holder of the "blue ribbon" for the fastest Atlantic crossing in sail arrived here under tow yesterday from City Island, N. Y., to be broken up for scrap.

The South Plainfield Township, N. J., School District incurred an interest cost of 4 1/2 per cent yesterday in borrowing $1,650,000 on serial bonds ranging from 1954 to 1973. The bonds were bought by a syndicate headed by B. J. Van Ingen Co., the only bidder.

Plans for a concerted year-end effort to make the independent drug store headquarters for Christmas gift buying were outlined yesterday at a meeting of wholesale drug executives at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Operations of the Sun Oil Company and its subsidiaries in the first half of this year resulted in a consolidated net income of $21,659,462, slightly better than that in the 1952 period, according to the report yesterday of Joseph N. Pew Jr., board chairman.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 -- Charges by Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins that the Board of Education rejected Ford Foundation funds for a five-year teacher-training experiment because the board felt the foundation was dominated by Communist sympathizers stirred spirited comment today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- National Airlines, Inc. told the Civil Aeronautics Board today it should reject a proposed merger of Colonial Airlines, Inc., with Eastern Air Lines, Inc., as "contrary to the public interest."

In nine 1953 races prior to yesterday's main event at Jamaica, Harry B. Cohen's 5-year-old gelding Mully S. had failed to win and had collected only $2,250. So, of course, there was no rush to bet on him. And up he popped, in the role of fourth choice in a five-horse contest, as the winner of first money of $3,250.

A program to encourage manufacturers of the New York-New Jersey area who are not now engaged in exporting to enter this field was announced yesterday by the New York regional office of the United States Department of Commerce.

NEW DELHI, India, July 22 -- Reliable sources here believe that Washington's note reassuring India that her troops would be allowed to carry out her post-armistice role in Korea has resolved New Delhi's doubts on this and related matters that were raised this week in official queries to the Governments of United States and Communist China.

TORONTO, July 22 (AP) -- Lorne Main, Canada's last big threat to win the Canadian tennis championships, was eliminated by Mexico's Mario Llamas 7 -- 5, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 3 in the third round of the men's singles today.

CLEVELAND, July 22 -- Along about 11:07 on the huge centerfield clock tonight a lot of expert opinion was doing a terrific lot of back-tracking. For the Yankees, it develops, not only are not tearing the American League flag race apart, hut it looks as though they are about to go into another bit of a tailspin that may yet make a merry chase of it.

Eighteen hundred drivers of sand, gravel and ready-mix concrete trucks, whose three-week-old strike has forced 100,000 construction workers into idleness, will meet today for the first time since the tie-up began.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The United States Government brushed aside today new anti-armistice gestures by Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President, and declared its continuing confidence that he would honor his solemn, unconditional assurances in writing not to obstruct a cease-fire agreement expected soon between the United Nations and the Chinese and North Korean Communist regimes.

TOKYO, July 22 -- Japan's Supreme Court belatedly declared unconstitutional today the outdated laws providing punishment for persons guilty of criticizing General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's Allied occupation of Japan.

BOSTON, July 22 -- More than 3,000 mourners, including many men prominent in public life, today attended a funeral service for Maurice J. Tobin, former Secretary of Labor and one-time Governor of Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee said today it would conduct hearings tomorrow on an Administration bill to permit the Government to buy up old tankers whose owners would build fast new ones.

The advance sale of 15-cent tokens for the higher fare on city subway and elevated lines started yesterday to ease possible snarls at the 518 rapid transit stations after the new rate goes into effect at 12:01 A. M. Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives approved tonight a bill giving Congressional consent to a New York-New Jersey compact for formation of a commission to rid the New York waterfront of criminal elements.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- It is reported that when the Secretary of the Treasury, George M. Humphrey, told the Cabinet of his plan to have Congress raise the ceiling on the public debt, and added that the lift might as well be all the way from the present $275 billions to the Second World War level of $300 billions, no one suggested that Congress might take the dim view of the idea it promptly did.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Senate Finance Committee quickly voted approval today of a House of Representatives bill to exempt motion picture theatres from the 20 per cent admissions tax, and Senate passage appeared certain.

The program that was rained out at Lewisohn Stadium on Monday evening took place last night, thereby making happy at least two persons -- Gordon Manley, who played the Brahms D minor Piano Concerto, and Roman Totenberg, violin soloist in Lalo's "Symphonie Espagnole."

Rather than get the homemaker out of the kitchen on hot days, there seems to be a growing trend to keep her in it for longer periods, not only by including equipment for sewing and laundering as well as cooking appliances, but by "decorating" the room to make it comfortable and attractive to work in.

A police trial commissioner ruled yesterday that Police Lieut. Arthur Miller, on trial on charges of lying about alleged Communist affiliations, should have one more chance to defend himself in view of the "prima facie" case established against him.

Patrons of the ancient art of herb cookery will be interested in two new methods of preserving these flavorful greens. One was suggested by Mrs. Gertrude B. Foster, editor of The Herb Grower Magazine, Falls Village, Conn., and the other by the United States Department of Agriculture.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee today abandoned for the rest of the year consideration of bills proposing tight new controls on bank holding companies.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, expressed the belief today that the amendment he added to the Senate-approved bill authorizing the sale of Government-owned synthetic rubber plants would assure realizing $500,000,000 in the involved transaction.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -House investigators today demanded punishment for military officials responsible for the "fiasco" of $3,000,000 spent for worthless Navy forklift trucks, $45,000,000 for unsuitable Army overcoats, and $1,000,000 for chain link fence the Air Force did not need.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative to the United Nations, said today that he was confident that any move to admit Communist China to the United Nations could be defeated.
PITTSBURGH, July 23 (AP) -Harry Perkowski, Redlegs southpaw, blanked the Pirates, 7 -- 0, on eight hits today for his eighth victory of the season.

Careless drivers who halt cars on crosswalks at traffic lights in mid-Manhattan are hurting business and discouraging convention trade, the Broadway Association said yesterday. Hundreds of complaints have been received by the association against motorists who force pedestrians into the paths of oncoming travel.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, July 24 -- President Syngman Rhee charged today that the United Nations Command had given the Communists promises on an armistice to which South Korea could not agree.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A panel on the rehabilitation of the cerebral palsied child, held today by the Association for Physical and Mental Rehabilitation, reached the conclusion that thousands of such patients would benefit by the addition of the corrective therapist to the treatment "team."

By unanimous vote of the seven members present, the Board of Education elected David H. Moskowitz yesterday to a six-year term as associate superintendent of schools. Thirty-seven years in the school system, Mr. Moscowitz has been an assistant superintendent since 1937.

Bobby Jones, golfing star of the Twenties, made one of his few public appearances last night when he joined other links notables in paying tribute to Ben Hogan, current king of the fairways, at a testimonial dinner sponsored by the United States Golf Association at the Park Lane Hotel.

The fashion in which the first shipment of wheat from the United States was received in Pakistan is excellent evidence of the soundness of the gift. The spirit that lay behind the American action was obviously well understood in Karachi and the reciprocal sentiments of friendship were expressed with gratifying warmth by Pakistani officials and the Pakistani press.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., July 23 -- Pittsburgh Steel Company, traditionally a producer of wire, wire and seamless tube products, today moved into the sheet metal market. A new $28,000,000 hot mill and finishing facilities, covering an area of 350,000 feet, was officially put into operation at the company's Allenport plant, twenty-five miles from here.

QUANTICO, Va., July 23 -Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, at the opening here tonight of a get-together in informal surroundings of the nation's defense leaders, told top-ranking generals, admirals and other key members of the military establishment to end their interservice feuds and jealous competition.

Robert Payson Hill, a concert pianist, asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to prohibit President Justice William Lyman of the Municipal Court from holding further hearings on a letter written by Mr. Hill and published by THE NEW YORK TIMES, complaining of the behavior of Municipal Court judges before whom he had served as a juror.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Eisenhower Administration won a decisive victory over well organized tariff protectionists today as the House of Representatives killed a bill for sharp restrictions on the execution of foreign trade policies.

Steel-rolling operations at the century-old Schuylkill Iron Works plant of the Alan Wood Steel Company at Conshohocken, Pa., will be halted during the month of August, and the buildings and utilities will be put on the block for sale, the company announced yesterday. The firm's nail plant, however, will continue in operation at Conshohocken.

In the midst of all the shows he is nurturing, Joshua Logan has acquired another one, "The Private Life of Helen." Yesterday, the busy author-director-producer acknowledged that he had purchased the play, which emanates from the John Erskine novel, "The Private Life of Helen of Troy."

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Senate approved tonight by acclamation an appropriation bill providing $34,511,284,500 for the support of the national military establishment in the fiscal year to end June 30, 1954.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Following is the text of the letter from President Eisenhower to Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, on foreign aid:

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Opposition to President Eisenhower's proposal to provide a haven in this country for 240,000 refugees from abroad appeared to be crumbling today both in the Senate and the House of Representatives under concessions made by the Administration.

Plans have been advanced at recent meetings for the annual Gros$ venor Ball for the benefit of Grosvenor Neighborhood House to be held on the night of Nov. 28 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. George J. Leness is chairman ''ef the committee for the fete.

The average market price of all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange on June 30 was $39.37, or 95 cents lower than the May 29 level and the lowest month-end figure since the end of June, 1951, when it was $38.73.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 23 -- Rain interrupted play and caused a postponement of most of the third round of match play in the Metropolitan amateur golf championship at the Fenway Club today.

A 30-year-old warehouse employe, his arm caught in a drainpipe, drowned in fifteen inches of water yesterday morning on the rooftop of a five-story midtown building as three companions, unaware of his condition, stood in an enclosed shelter less than twelve feet away.

NEW DELHI, India, July 23 -- Before leaving for Nepal today after consultations with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and other top-ranking Indians, Prime Minister Matrika Prasad Koirala gained assurances that the New Delhi Government would finance urgent projects needed to modernize the erstwhile "hermit" kingdom of the Himalayas.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Eisenhower moved today to fill the three vacancies on the National Security Training Commission. He also directed the reconstituted five-member group to report to him by Dec. 1 on the feasibility and desirability of operating a military training program to supply trained non-veteran reserves concurrently with operation of a Selective Service System to provide men for the armed forces.

The announcement that a new fortytwo-story, fully air-conditioned office building will rise on the whole block bordered by Lexington and Third Avenues and Forty-first and Forty-second Streets, to become in considerable part the home executive office of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company and bear its name, is of great interest on several counts.
The "heavyweight" title in the tanker class will change hands tomorrow as the new 45,000-dead-weight-ton Tina Onassis is launched from the Howaldtswerke Shipyard in Hamburg, Germany.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce announced today a new, relaxed system of supervising trade in controlled products between the United States and Latin America.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 23 -- This was a day of shore news from the yachting front. A nor'easter heavy with rain piped up to fifty miles an hour in mid-Long Island Sound and caused the cancellation of the sixth regatta of Larchmont Race Week. From West Forty-fourth Street came word that Queen Elizabeth had put up a new perpetual trophy for competition in the New York Yacht Club cruise, which begins next week.
PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- The Philadelphia Zoological Gardens has a litter of fourteen unwanted opossum and ni Israel there are hyraxes to spare.

DETROIT, July 23 (AP) -- The Tigers, making a bid to climb out of the cellar, swept a doubleheader today from the stumbling Senators, winning by 9 -- 6 in the first game on Ray Boone's three-run homer in the tenth inning, and 5 -- 4 on Jerry Priddy's key two-run single.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 23 -- Borrowing a concept upheld by the United States in Korea, most of Gen. Li Mi's Chinese Nationalist guerrillas along the Burma-Yunnan border are now refusing to be evacuated to Formosa from Burma on the ground that they are natives of the border region and that their removal would violate the principle of "voluntary repatriation.''

Torrential rain kept both the Dodgers and the Giants idle yesterday. The Brooks rescheduled their contest with the Cubs as part of a twilight-night double-header at Ebbets Field on Aug. 25. The Giants will make up their game with the Cardinals in the same way on the same date at the Polo Grounds.

The governors of the New York Stock Exchange submitted to the membership yesterday a constitutional amendment embodying a proposed new schedule of minimum commission rates. If a majority of the members votes on it and a majority of those voting is in favor of the change, it will take effect on Aug. 17.

ROME, July 23 -- The outlook for Premier Alcide De Gasperi's eighth Cabinet, on which a vote of confidence is pending in the Chamber of Deputies, took a turn for the worse today when the Monarchist party decided to deny Dr. De Gasperi its support.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 23 -- A shouting mob, estimated at 2,000 to 3,000 persons, assaulted a Yugoslav Roman Catholic priest in the vicinity of a monastery at Makarska, near Split on the Dalmatian coast, this morning.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- John F. Floberg, leaving office today as Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air, said he looked forward with certainty to a day when "virtually all combat ships of the Navy will be atomic powered."
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -The Federal Communications Commission turned down today a request by New York City to turn its street lights off and on through a special radio signal from station WNYC.

The Rockefeller Foundation made grants totaling $3,693,000 in the second quarter of this year for educational, scientific, cultural and research purposes in the United States and abroad, it was announced yesterday by Dean Rusk, president of the foundation.

Police Lieut. Arthur Miller, charged with lying about his alleged Communist affiliations, lost his last chance to clear his name yesterday when he failed to appear for his departmental trial at Police Headquarters.

I doubt whether anyone could take exception to the notion that the Executive branch of the present Republican Administration should be quite free to exclude any category of human beings from its rosters, whether they be Socialists, Prohibitionists, or even Democrats, so long as Civil Service regulations are not violated.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -Senator Joseph R. McCarthy asserted today that "New Deal reporters" tried to "badger" a member of his investigating subcommittee into making an anti-McCarthy statement on a radio broadcast last night.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Government, in its selection of art objects, has been getting "adequate work by second rate artists," but rarely obtaining "outstanding works of art by the most distinguished artists from every section of the country," one member of the Federal Commission of Fine Arts charged today in a report by the group to President Eisenhower.

A $1,065,000,000 improvement program for the city-owned transit system over the next six years received the approval yesterday of the New York City Transit Authority, which also adopted a budget of capital expenditures for 1954 of $155,199,613, more than double the amount for this year.

The jeep makers are going to build television transmitters and station equipment in a package. Willys Motors, Inc., which came into being last April when Kaiser Manufacturing Corporation acquired the assets of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., with $,72,600,000 of Kaiser and other private capital and bank loans of $35,000,000, made the announcement yesterday in Toledo.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Former President Herbert Hoover emphasized today the Eisenhower Administration's desire to approach problems of governmental reorganization on a nonpartisan basis, but said there was not, so far as he knew, any plan to name the only other former President, Harry S. Truman, to the commission that would study methods for improving the Federal Government.

Five youths were arrested yesterday in connection with me fatal stabbing of a rigger at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, early Wednesday morning. The police said one of them confessed the slaying. He was Francisco Nazario, 19 years old, of 157 Bergen Street, Brooklyn.

THE transfer of fishing pressure from the trout stream to the bass lake and salt water has provided the fly fisherman with some of the solitude he craves, but, according to reports, it has done little to increase the weight of his creel.

Suburban New York bankers are beginning to make adjustment for the changes in industrial and residential patterns which the New York State Thruway will likely bring to the environs of the metropolitan area.

Hope for ending the labor dispute that has forced 100,000 New York construction workers into idleness faded yesterday when 800 striking drivers of sand, gravel and ready-mix concrete trucks refused to empower their union negotiators to enter into any compromise settlement of their three-week-old tie-up.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Liberal Roman Catholic prelates have been put "in the dog house" by a Vatican statement justifying the views of an Italian Cardinal on curbing Protestant minorities, Glenn L. Archer, Director of Protestants and Other Americans United for Separation of Church and State, said here today.

While the Manhattan and Bronx Democratic organizations were having difficulty in getting running mates for Robert F. Wagner Jr., their candidate for the nomination for Mayor, the New York County Republican executive committee yesterday designated Elmer Anderson Carter, a Negro, for nomination for Borough President of Manhattan.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 -- Excessive towing speed and a series of mechanical failures and operational errors were blamed today by an Army investigating board for the sinking of the Army's experimental amphibious cargo vehicle Barc 1-X off the California coast on March 27.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization authorized Federal tax benefits today to assist private industry with 177 defense plant expansion projects to cost more than $209,644,234.
TORONTO, July 23 (AP) -- Eddie Moylan of Trenton and three Australians qualified for the semi-finals of the men's singles in the Canadian tennis championships today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 23 -- Rabbinical control over Jewish marriage and divorce in Israel would be consolidated by a bill that has passed its first reading in the Knesset (Parliament) and is now being prepared by a parliamentary legislation committee for a final vote in the House.

LEEDS, England, July 23 (Reuters) -- Australia's gamble of sending England in to bat after winning the toss paid off when England lost seven wickets for 142 runs on the opening day of the fourth test today. The top batsmen, Len Hutton and Denis Compton, were out for ducks.

Officers, enlisted men and civilians of First Army Area posts donated 1,447 pints of blood last month to the American Red Cross Blood Bank for the Armed Services in Korea, First Army Headquarters announced yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, July 23 -- While ready "to make any sacrifice for peace" the Indian Government feels that the present situation in Korea would be eased if the United States showed "more firmness with Syngman Rhee," a top-ranking official declared tonight.

The Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, Ltd., announced yesterday a reduction of 10 cents a barrel in crude oil from Iraq for delivery at Tripoli, Syria, or Banias, Lebanon, retroactive to July 16. The new price is $2.44 a barrel for 36-36.9 gravity oil. This action rescinds part of the 25-cents-a-barrel advance in crude oil at Eastern Mediterranean ports announced by the company on July 15.

Shareholders of Beaunit Mills, Inc., rayon yarn and fabric maker, can expect a resumption of dividend payments on their holdings within a few months, I. Rogosin, chairman, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -- The National Association of Manufacturers urged Congress today to let private industry develop commercial atomic power. But the Congress of Industrial Organizations said this would be a multi-billion dollar give-away."

BONN, Germany, July 23 -- Competent observers are being more and more impressed with the growing boldness of the neo-Nazi splinter groups, numerous nationalistic war veterans associations, and the overt efforts of Government coalition leaders to court the latter as the campaign for the Sept. 6 general election approaches.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The substitute offered by Senator Knowland for the constitutional amendment proposed by Senator Bricker is an acknowledgment by the Administration that real concern exists in this country over possible abuses of the treaty-making power, an inheritance from international compacts made by the last two Presidents.

GLASGOW, Scotland, July 20 -- A dearth of new orders and keener competition from foreign countries are causing British shipbuilders considerable uneasiness but they are determined not to yield Britain's position as the world's leader in the industry.
CLEVELAND, July 23 -- There are times when even a man of Casey Stengel's infinite capacity as a conversationalist finds himself at a loss for words.

Before the smallest turnout at a local track in a decade, C. V. Whitney's Carry the News won the Molly Brant Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The mile-and-a-sixteenth event for fillies and mares had a gross value of $10,030, and Carry the News earned $6,525 as her share.

BERLIN, July 23 -- Censorship is not yet a very critical problem for television in Britain or on the Continent. However, in Brussels the question of varying moral standards was raised should many European countries ultimately be tied together in a video network as now seems likely.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 23 -- Red flares cast an eerie glow on the landscape, emergency blinkers flashed warnings to fast-moving vehicles, searchlight generators whirred at the side of the pavement and giant trucks snorted to a sudden halt at the upper end of North Broadway here last night and early today as the state police sprang a trap for violators of the state's new truck tax law.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 23 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies, who reached Freemantle today from South Africa on his way home from the Coronation, said it was unfortunate that discussions of the New Zealand, Australia, United States defense pact had made it appear the treaty was a matter of dispute between the United Kingdom and the Australian Governments.

LONDON, July 23 -- There was a striking similarity to be seen today between the comments in Pravda, the Soviet Communist newspaper, on the Western powers proposal for a four-power foreign ministers' meeting and the criticisms of that proposal uttered by Labor members in the House of Commons this week.

BONN, Germany, July 23 -- The Krupp works of Essen has submitted a bid and a plan at the request of the Turkish Government to build a suspension bridge spanning the Bosporus and connecting the Asian and European parts of Istanbul.
A second commercial airline is planning to make regular international flights over the North Pole.

" May blessings be upon the head of Cadmus or the Phoenicians, or whoever invented books!" wrote Thomas Carlyle. "* * * an art that carries the voice of man to the extremities of the earth * * *." Since Mr. Carlyle died in 1881, he showed amazing foresight in predicting the popularity of subway reading.

Business borrowings from New York City banks for the week ended on Wednesday declined $15,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank here reported yesterday. The reduction was in contrast to two successive weekly rises totaling $29,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Eisenhower nominated today four Republicans and three Democrats to be members of the Federal Board of Parole. The nominees include the first Negro ever named to the board. Two of the Democrats were reappointed to their present jobs.
TRENTON, July 23 -- Near Jersey will not discipline Harold G. Hoffman, State Employment Security Director, for attempting to aid an underworld figure.
LONDON, July 23 (UP) -- A British surgeon operated today on Bonar Colleano, screen actor, whose face was mutilated when he fell twenty-five feet last week.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The oldest pending anti-trust suit -- filed against Columbia Gas and Electric Company of New York -- has been dismissed, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today.
IN various stages of undress, the Giants were lounging about the clubhouse preparatory to taking the field for pre-game practice.

MOSCOW, July 23 -- Moscow diplomats were convinced after a close study of the Pravda attack on the Washington conference today that the Soviet Union, while not rejecting outright the Western bid to a four-power foreign ministers' conference, would make important counter-proposals of its own.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 23 -- A cottage hospital covering forty-two acres that will serve 100,000 members of Kupet Holim, the sick fund of the General Federation of Labor, in the Negev and Southern Judea was formally dedicated tonight in Rehovot in memory of Eliezer Kaplan, Israel's first Finance Minister.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Anticipating a note from the Soviet Union possibly within the next twenty-four hours, the State Department withheld its fire today from the Pravda editorial on the Western three-power proposal for a Big Four foreign ministers' conference, observing only that the article was not "constructive."
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- During the week ended July 22, member bank reserves increased $345,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Retail jewelry store sales declined 18 per cent in 1952, compared with 1950, the American National Retail Jewelers Association announced yesterday. In 1950, net sales had risen 18 per cent over the preceding year and broke the downward trend started in 1947.

The President has tried hard to reach agreement with Senator Bricker in the latter's effort to put Congressional chains about the treaty-making power. But there is a point beyond which there can be no further retreat; and that is the point where to satisfy such extremists as Mr. Bricker the President would have to surrender his constitutional right to manage the foreign relations of the United States.
The Mayor's Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs in New York City formulated yesterday a program of future objectives, among them the employment of Spanish-speaking personnel by city agencies.
ST. LOUIS, July 23 (UP) -- Pete Suder's fourteenth-inning single gave the Athletics a 7-4 victory over the Browns tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- North and South in the coal industry fought a battle of words today, heralding probable wage negotiations between the operators and John L. Lewis in the not distant future.

Subway traffic on the Times Square-Flushing line of the I. R. T. was disrupted for almost three hours last night and early this morning when a short-circuit blaze burned out a rail in the tunnel at First Avenue and Forty-second Street and sent dense smoke clouds into the Grand Central station platform.

Retail meat prices this week show the effect of what the United States Department of Agriculture has called "the most drastic upturn in steer prices for a long time," Reflecting increases at wholesale last week, beef rose 10 to 12 cents a pound, fresh porks was about 16 cents more than two weeks ago and lamb and veal also advanced in price.

It's one thing to become exuberant over Dodger victories in a night double-header, but a different matter to carry these feelings to excess, especially to the extent of squirting beer on near-by fans.

A vacant plot 160 by 100 feet on the south side of Archer Place, 375 feet west of 150th Street, in Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by clients of Walter Adikes, attorney, to the M. O. Realty Corporation. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title.

FLORENCE, July 23 -- G. B. Giorgini's sixth Italian Fashion Show presented new evidence of exquisite workmanship, fabric and detail today. Costumes shown this afternoon were hand knit, loomed, sewn, embroidered or painted.
SEOUL, Korea, July 23 -- In an atmosphere of unrelieved somberness, South Korea appears to be moving toward the signing of an agreement at least temporarily ending hostilities here.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- Raymond Pace Alexander introduced a resolution in the City Council this afternoon calling on the Board of City Trusts to admit Negro pupils to Girard College under a threat that the college otherwise might lose its tax-exempt status.
TOKYO, Friday, July 24 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,685, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 23 (AP) -- "Malaria has been conquered," a member of the National Research Council reported today after a final check on a long series of tests at Fort Knox.

Three three-story buildings occupying a plot 55 by 100 feet at 247 to 251 East Fifty-first Street, near Second Avenue, have been sold by the heirs of Augusta Pusch to Frank Grasso for investment. The sale was the first involving the property in more than fifty years and was negotiated by the P. Zaccaro Company.

By pure coincidence the proposed range of foreign aid expenditures during the current fiscal year is within a few hundred million dollars, one way or the other, of the amount the Administration decided to cut out of the original Air Force appropriation. President Eisenhower asked for $5.8 billions for Mutual Security, a drop from the $7.6 billions that ex-President Truman had requested.
PARIS, July 23--By a vote of 468 to 127, the French National Assembly today adopted on its first reading the Constitutional Reform Bill which aims to make French Cabinets more stable.

NEW ORLEANS, July 23 (UP) -A young former medical corpsman with a charming bedside manner practiced for his impersonation of a hospital psychiatrist by treating his fellow boarders free, his former landlady recalled today.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- A House agriculture subcommittee reported today it found nothing illegal about the sale of 80,000 tons of Government-owned peas at a loss of $6,257,197.

A pounding rainstorm smashed the dry spell yesterday, ending the hot spell, disrupting subway service, undermining highways, flooding basements, imperiling traffic -- and bringing welcome relief to parched farmland in the metropolitan area.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- This city's "smooth-working" Mayor-manager form of government, which is in operation under the 1951 charter revision, could be adapted to New York City's needs, according to Devereux C. Josephs, chairman of New York's Temporary State Commission to Study the Organizational Structure of the Government of the City of New York.

CAIRO, July 23 -- Cairo crowds, celebrating the first anniversary of the army-sponsored revolution, cheered parades by the nation's land and air forces today and heard President Mohammed Naguib outline the accomplishments and objectives of his regime.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Wheat prices declined rather sharply today but there was some recovery from the extreme bottom because of reports of stem rust from the spring wheat states. Earlier influences were the favorable weekly Canadian crop report, heavy rains in dry portions of the Southwest and the absence of export sales.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 23 (UP) -- Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., and Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, swept to straight-set victtories in the opening singles matches today to give the United States a 2-0 lead over the British West Indies in their second-round American zone Davis Cup series.

BEAVERLODGE, Sask., July 17 -- Uranium is now being produced at the Eldorado Mining and Refining Company's mine here in what has become a world-famous region just under the Sixtieth Parallel in the northwest corner of Saskatchewan.

With an optimistic expansion in volume as prices rose, the stock market yesterday climbed to higher levels. It could not be called a strong market, for it was losing its early gains all afternoon and more than half the issues traded either declined or stood still, but THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average closed at 176.91, a gain of 0.65 points, after a high of 177.5 and a low of 175.92.

Sales of the Gerber Products Company for the three months to June 30, first fiscal quarter, were $18,528,000 or about 30 per cent ahead of the $14,208,000 volume in the 1952 period, Dan Gerber, president, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Fremont, Mich. Earnings, he said, will compare favorably with the $698,058 or $1.05 a common share made in the June quarter last year.

TOKYO, Friday, July 24 -- Communist propaganda sources hinted today that the Chinese and North Koreans would sign an armistice in the Korean war if the United States and United Nations would renew guarantees that the truce would not be upset by a new revolt of President Syngman Rhee of South Korea.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The House of Representatives' Committee on Un-American Activities voted today to subpoena the Rev. Jack Richard McMichael, pastor of the Methodist Church at Upper Lake, Calif., for questioning next Thursday as to whether he was now or had been a member of the Communist party.

The proponents of book labeling have been busy in the recent past in Boston and San Antonio. Now this not very feasible scheme has cropped up in New York. I am referring to a letter by Murray Quigg which appeared in your letters column of July 13.

Grants totaling $990,000, intended to promote better understanding, were awarded during April, May and June by the Carnegie Corporation of New York, the fund announced yesterday in its third quarterly report for the current fiscal year.

An unidentified philatelist, who may also have been a bookworm, gambled and lost yesterday with a $5 bid submitted by mail on the second and last day of a Customs Service auction of unclaimed, abandoned and confiscated merchandise.

Although gross income of the Phillips Petroleum Company and its subsidiaries increased to $370,202,569 in the first half of this year from $346,508,597 in the 1952 period, the net profit decreased $4,708,596, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 23 -Garson Kanin has turned his hand to the musical comedy and has come up with an item called "Spotlight," which Columbia has purchased for filming, Jerry Wald, executive producer, announced today.

The American Council of Christian Churches charged last night that Methodist Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam's connections indicated his "pro-Communist sympathies," and that the impact of his influence "has been in the direction of state socialism with its inherent hostility to our republican form of government."
CHICAGO, July 23 (UP) -- The Red Sox broke a seven-game losing streak to the White Sox today; winning by 4 -- 3 behind the four-hit hurling of Hector (Skinny) Brown before 28,263 Ladies' Day fans.

Sales of Food Fair Stores, Inc., which operates a chain of 165 supermarkets, reached a record $292,659,754 in the fiscal year ended April 25, according to the annual report sent to stockholders today. The report is the last which will be signed by George Friedland as president of the company.

ALBANY, July 23 -- They're still hitching horses to shays, or reasonable facsimiles thereof, in upstate New York to transport children to and from school. The New York State Education Department revealed today that in the school year that ended June 30 the state still had fifty horse-drawn vehicles among the 6,151 conveyances used outside of the cities.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association said today that the Post Office Department's system for allocating its cost of operations had led to the "smear" that publishers and other users of second class mail were getting a Government subsidy.
Despite a pelting, wind-whipped rain, 42,110 Jehovah's Witnesses gathered yesterday at Yankee stadium in a "show-must-go-on" spirit.

LONDON, July 23 -- Nearly all sections of the stock markets continued to gain today despite a further decline in business and Chancellor R. A. Butler's warning yesterday of the troubles facing the British economy.
Frozen purees, delicious and adaptable for many uses, are one excellent way to preserve the fresh fruits that will be abundantly available in the next few weeks.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -Approximately a third of the supply of gamma globulin expected to be available this year for mass inoculation use against paralytic poliomyelitis already has been distributed.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 23 (AP) -Officials of the Harvard University summer school said today that editors of The Summer Crimson, undergraduate weekly publication, had been ordered to cease printing editorials.

RICHMOND, Va., July 23 (AP) -A Federal District Court today dismissed a perjury indictment against Jerome Mayo Greenberg, former Government physicist, who was accused of asserting falsely that he had never been a Communist.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 23 (AP) -- Galen Hanover, owned by Mrs. Virginia Nottingham of Cape Charles, Va., scored a two-length victory tonight in the Mattituck Pace at Roosevelt Raceway. Warner Bull took Galen Hanover to the front at the five-length pole and finished in 2:05 1/5.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Slow demand for fresh pork at wholesale continued to depress the market for live hogs today. Prices fell 25 to 75 cents.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 22 -- Southern Rhodesia's farmers, meeting here in annual convention, are faced with the fact, which is of considerable significance for the new Central African Federation, that the native Africans, with about 30,000,000 acres in their reserve to the white man's 47,000,000, are feeding close to the whole population.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Department store sales in the week ended July 18 were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 23 -- The seventh annual Turf Charity Ball for the benefit of hospitals and charitable organizations in Monmouth County will be held Saturday night at the Monmouth Park Jockey Club. Mrs. Philip Iselin is chairman of the committee for the fete, arranged under the auspices of the Monmouth County Jockey Club, of which Amory L. Haskell is president.

The four-story apartment house accommodating sixteen families at 2543 Church Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by the Estate Securities Company, real estate operators, to Mrs. Olga Gelblum, who purchased the contract of Raysteve Realties, Inc. Sale was for cash above mortgages of $34,000.
In THE TIMES of July 19 you printed a photograph of automobiles stalled due to overheated motors.
KANSAS CITY, July 23 (AP) -- Ed (Porky) Oliver knocked seven strokes off par for a 65 and the first round lead in the $17,500 Kansas City open golf tournament today.

The bookstores of this country offer the would-be purchaser a rich and varied selection of mystery novels, spy stories and related reading of intrigue and suspense. One may doubt, however, whether any of these artfully contrived tales begins to match the similar qualities exhibited by events in the Kremlin since the beginning of this year.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Members of Representative Clare E. Hoffman's Government Operations Committee rebelled again today against their 77-year-old chairman by refusing to let him make a recording of their remarks.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 23 -- The Swedish Foreign Ministry and security police have branded as a forgery a letter signed with the name of Vladimir Kovalev, a chauffeur at the Soviet Embassy, in which the writer said he was being sent home to Russia because he had disobeyed the orders of his embassy superiors to spy on Sweden.

Gimbels believe, in traditional weddings, with the bride in white with a long flowing train. Yesterday, in its showing of fall bridal designs, the store made plain that it would have no part of the short informal frock. Long gowns of gleaming satin and lace spread out in formal trains or curved into "chapel sweeps," as abbreviated trains are called.

The National Television System Committee formally asked the Federal Communications Commission in Washington yesterday to adopt new standards for color television broadcasting. At the same time, plans of the Columbia Broadcasting System for experimental telecasts in color were announced here by J. L. Van Volkenburg, president of C. B. S. Television.

An imaginative use of materials and an oriental flavor in style characterize several new collections of contemporary furniture on view in Macy's midsummer furniture show. Colorful room settings have been arranged by Peter Ross.

PARIS, July 23 -- The debate on how to settle the Indo-Chinese war, which absorbs the Cabinet's attention and has produced more warmth than light so far, is really a discussion of what role France can play in the contemporary world, limited as her resources are in comparison with her overextended responsibilities.

GOTHENBURG, Sweden, July 23 (UP) -- Wes Santee ran the fastest 1,500 meters ever raced by an American to beat Sweden's Sune Karlsson by an eyelash tonight and it appeared that only a rain-drenched track kept the University of Kansas star from lowering Gunder Haegg's 9-year-old world record of 3 minutes 43 seconds.
The cotton futures market here closed barely steady yesterday, off 3 to 10 points.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 18, 1953, were the Association of 791,414 cars, American Railroads announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (UP) -- The American Federation of Government Employes charged today that 4,700 workers at the naval aviation supply depot here were locked inside the gates after working hours during a Navy-sponsored birthday celebration last Friday.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, July 24 (AP) -- South Korean infantrymen smashed back to the crest of one central-front hill position today and were carrying the fight to the Communists on three other hills in the Kumsong sector. The four hills are among six lost to the Reds yesterday.

While the average European may be short on food or clothing, he does not lack for cigarettes, most of them American. Dollars are short, currency is restricted, government tobacco monopolies set high prices, competition from domestic and other imported brands is rough and promotion and advertising are limited, but sales of American cigarettes are at their highest and steadily increasing.

Volume continued light on most New York commodity exchanges but coffee had the sixth most active day of the year and lead had the largest sales this month. Coffee, soybean oil and copper were mixed; sugar, cocoa, potatoes, wool and tin lower, and lead, cottonseed oil, hides, rubber and zinc higher.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- T. E. Buchanan, general manager of the Texas Company maritime department, told a Senate committee today that the prospect for the American tanker fleet was gloomy unless the Government gave more help. Right after World War II, he testified to a Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce subcommittee, nearly 60 per cent of the world's tanker carrying capacity was under United States registry, but he added:

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -Capt. Ted Williams will be released from active duty on Aug. 1, the Marine Corps announced today, and there were growing indications that he would be back in his Boston Red Sox uniform before September.

PARIS, July 23 -- Paulette's opening show included toques with a somewhat triangular flap lying flat on the brow over one eye. There were also deep cone-shaped cloches, all in one piece, of plain, beaver or printed felts utterly untrimmed, cut-out calots and profile calots of velvet with a jewel bearing wing down over one ear.

Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate to award, without public letting, contracts for the purchase and installation of 15,000 parking meters in thirty-six new areas in the city. Twenty-one areas already have them.

The State Department has acknowledged as a "misunderstanding" the removal from shelves of United States Information Service libraries abroad of books by Mrs. Vera Micheles Dean, political analyst and editor of Foreign Policy Association publications.

Your pointed editorial "Drafting Fathers" interested me, a former GI, for various reason, most important of all being that it is somewhat tardy in its regard for fathers recalled to the service from the reserves.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Governor Dewey of New York ridiculed charges of socialism aimed at his proposaI for state development of the power potential of the Niagara River as he sought today to stop the movement, already approved by the House of Representatives, to turn over the $400,000, 000 project to five private companies.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The $1,115,000,000 cut in foreign aid funds by the House of Representatives yesterday, in which Republicans participated overwhelmingly, was viewed in some Capitol quarters today as stemming largely from an unusual political event that took place at the Congressional Hotel July 14.
NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., July 23 -The Third National Boy Scout Jamboree broke camp today with nearly 50,000 Boy Scouts singing "Auld Lang Syne."

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Eisenhower accepted today the retirement of Judge Augustus N. Hand from active service on the Second Circuit Court of Appeals but told him that in "the literal sense" he would never be able to retire because his "great contribution to American jurisprudence is a part of history and will continue to serve as an inspiration" to judges and generations to come.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Eisenhower served notice on the Senate today that "grave consequences" for the United States and the free world would follow any such major cut in his $5,138,922,277 Mutual Security Program as was voted yesterday by the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Ernest O. Thompson, chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission, told at a hearing today that Texas' oil conservation laws are aimed at preventing waste and have nothing to do with prices.

BAIREUTH, Germany, July 23 -The annual Wagner Festival opened here tonight with a new production of "Lohengrin" in which the two female leads were taken by American singers of the Metropolitan Opera Company -- Eleanor Steber, the Elsa, and Astrid Varnay, the Ortrud.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A transfer of major ordnance research and development work now performed by the Bureau of Standards to the Department of Defense was decided upon today. The forthcoming transfer was announced in a joint statement by Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, and Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce.

NORWALK, Conn., July 23 -Two brothers, 9 and 12 years old, told the police today about a year-long spree of petty crime during which they had staged thirteen burglaries, attempted five others and set four fires.
JIM GRIMES thinks that when the 15-cent fare goes into effect tomorrow his job as catcher of subway fare chiselers may enter the busiest phase he's known in twenty-five years' work underground.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 23 (Reuters) -- The lower house of the Dutch Parliament ratified the European army treaty tonight but attached a qualifying amendment.
PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 23 (AP) -- The St. Catharines Rowing Club moved into the lead today after two days of racing at the Seventy-first Royal Canadian Henley Regatta.

THREE years ago a speleologist (a scientific student of caves) was sitting on a mountain slope in the Basque country of the Pyrenees almost exactly on the French-Spanish border when he saw a crow seem to fly directly out of the solid rock of a cliff. Assuming that the crow had a nest in the tunnel of a cave, he investigated and discovered the entrance to the Pierre Saint-Martin Caves.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 23 -- Although the French answer to Cambodia's independence demands has not yet arrived in the Cambodian capital of Pnompenh, its principal elements are sufficiently known to cause dissatisfaction there.

A full page of individual listings of businesses and real estate for sale in all parts of the country is scheduled to appear in metropolitan newspapers. Charles Ford Associates of the Midwest, Inc., national real estate and brokerage concern, is placing the advertising in other cities after a trial in Chicago.

The first phase of the city's coordinated drive against tuberculosis got under way this week at twenty-three Health Department clinics, where 500 previously selected sufferers from the disease reported to collect a month's supply of isoniazid and PAS (paraaminosalicylic acid) pills.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -John A. Hannah, Assistant Defense Secretary, said today that a Korean truce would permit a slight cut in draft calls this year but that inductions would have to be doubled a year from now.

City Council President Rudolph Halley yesterday lost his vigorous fight to extend the life of the temporary veterans' housing project at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. The Board of Estimate voted down by 13 to 3 Mr. Halley's resolution calling on the city to operate the project for at least one more year.

Two new films will open today at first-run showcases. "It Started in Paradise," a British-made drama, in Technicolor, of the London fashion world, is at the Normandie, Martita Hunt, Jane Hylton, Terence Morgan, Roland Squire, Muriel Pavlow and Ian Hunter have the principal roles in the J. Arthur Rank presentation, which was directed by Compton Bennett and produced by Sergei Nolbandov and Leslie Parkyn from a screen play by Marghanita Laski.

Last February Lippincott published P. R. Reid's "The Colditz Story," an account of the author's adventures in and out of the German "escape-proof" prisoner-of-war fortress. On Aug. 13, an American edition of a book by Airey Neave, the "first" man to escape from Colditz, will be issued by Little, Brown under the title "They Have Their Exits."

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 23 -- Play in the Pennsylvania state tennis championships will be resumed tomorrow following the cancellation of today's program on the rain-soaked turf of the Merion Cricket Club. A steady downpour last night and showers this morning made the courts unplayable and Chairman William J. Clothier Jr. called off the matches.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- The richest race for 2-year-olds ever, tomorrow's $157,915 Arlington Futurity, appears a toss-up among eighteen swift thoroughbreds.

The city's new program of treating unhospitalized cases of tuberculosis is "a worthwhile and definitely sound procedure." Dr. Herbert R. Edwards, executive director of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, declared yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24 -- Lester B. Pearson of Canada, President of the General Assembly, said today that a call for a special meeting of the Assembly would go out within twenty-four hours of the signing of an armistice in Korea.
Officials of the New York regional Red Cross blood program expect no lessening of the need for blood donations here, Dr. William M. Markel, administrator, said yesterday.

Plants of the Arma Corporation, maker of electronic precision instruments for the Defense Department, were struck yesterday in Brooklyn and Garden City, L. I., by two locals of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O.

EDMONTON, Alberta, July 19 -- The chief interest here in western Canada in the general election of Aug. 10 lies in the efforts of the Social Credit party to increase its representation in Ottawa and thus to assume national prominence. As of today, it is strictly an Alberta-British Columbia organization, labeled by its opponents as the "funny money" party.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 24 -- One hundred and twenty prominent scientists from nineteen western countries convened here to discuss the problem of how defend freedom of science against the encroachments and requirements of the modern state.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee voted today to give President Eisenhower a free hand in the distribution of $100,000,000 worth of surplus farm products to friendly nations or peoples.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, told the Association for Physical and Mental Rehabilitation today that community health and vocational groups must take over responsibility for rehabilitating the disabled where the hospital left off.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 24 -- Tony Trabert narrowly escaped disaster today in gaining the semi-finals of the Pennsylvania state tennis championship with Victor Seixas, Straight Clark and Grant Golden.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 24 -- Many beaches on the Long Island Sound and Hudson River shores of Westchester County were closed today by public health officials because of pollution after yesterday's heavy rains. All are scheduled to reopen by noon tomorrow.

A city decision is due Tuesday on whether zoning and building restrictions can be waived sufficiently to permit the construction of Frank Lloyd Wright's controversial Solomon R. Guggenheim Memorial Museum. The $2,000,000 structure would occupy the block-long front on Fifth Avenue between Eighty-eighth and Eighty-ninth Streets facing Central Park.

The majority of a committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York which has recommended legislation to deal with communism in unions proposes an alternative if its suggestion of a separate law is not enacted. It recommends amending the Taft-Hartley Law as follows:

Commodity prices closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume continued light generally but cottonseed oil and rubber showed sizable increases in activity. Rubber, cocoa, soybean oil, zinc, lead, tin and hides were lower; cottonseed oil, sugar and potatoes, mixed; coffee and wool, higher, and copper was unchanged.

LONDON, July 24 -- The British Iron and Steel Research Association claims that new markets are being opened up here by the development of a cheap hot-dip method of coating steel with aluminum by the addition of glycerol or glycerine.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 24 -- The ministers of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, meeting here today, concluded and signed a long protocol providing "temporary safeguard measures" to cope with the crisis that has been plaguing the Benelux customs union. Spokesmen for all three Governments voiced their belief that today's agreement had put an end to the long crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, proposed today a system of withholding foreign aid from free world nations that traded with Communist China or whose commercial ships hauled goods for the Chinese Communists.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Representative Albert P. Morano, Republican of Connecticut, appealed to Governor Dewey today to ask the New York Legislature to drop the state's tax on earnings of nonresidents.
Keith Minthorne has been named sales manager of the Super Cel Sponge division of the American Sponge and Chamois Company, Inc.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- A plan to merge Creameries of America, Inc., with the Beatrice Foods Company was approved today by stockholders of both dairy companies. A spokesman for the Beatrice company said:

SEOUL, Korea, July 24 -- In his statement this afternoon, President Syngman Rhee threatened to disregard an armistice unless the intentions of the United States were further clarified to his satisfaction.

A horse that cost $35,000 was the favorite and a horse that was claimed for $10,000 was the second choice in the $7,500 added handicap that topped the program at the Jamaica Track yesterday. They didn't pay off on the price tags. The ex-claimer, Timely Reward, who also is an ex-stakes racer, was the winner.
The long-expected chartering of foreign ships to carry grain to Pakistan began last week, but it failed to rouse the market from its extended lethargy.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 24 -- A historic cannon at Compo Beach commemorating the stand by American patriots against the British invaders in the Revolutionary War, was shattered at 4 A. M. today by an explosive charge laid to pranksters.

If I may, without seeming unappreciative of the notice THE TIMES has taken of recent expressions of opinion on my part, I should like to raise the question of the standards by which you select from addresses you report the parts you consider "newsworthy."

China Institute in America, principal clearing house for the 6,000 Chinese students stranded in this country, announced yesterday the award of nine fellowships to scholars from a blue-ribbon list of seventy-six.

Anyone who has been downtown or in the mid-Bronx this week has noticed many men and women, boys and girls, wearing the rectangular identification cards of the Watchtower Bible and Tract Society. Above the cards have been the open, sincere, often lively faces of many obvious out-of-towners.

PARIS, Saturday, July 25 -Adjournment of the French National Assembly for its summer recess shortly before 1 A. M. today leaves Premier Joseph Laniel's Cabinet free to put in operation a series of reforms in the budget and the Administration under the emergency finance bill which the Assembly has adopted.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 24 -- Bus Mosbacher in the International, Susan, and Warner Willcox in the Herreshoff S boat, Twister, achieved third Successive triumphs in the next-to-last regatta of Larchrmont Race Week today to maintain the point leads in their respective classes.

The Giants took another step in the right direction last night by defeating the Redlegs, 3 -- 1, at the Polo Grounds. After Ted Kluszewski had tied the score in the fourth inning with his twenty-ninth home run of the season, Henry Thompson walloped his nineteenth in the same round and Daryl Spencer smashed his fifteenth in the seventh to seal the victory for Ruben Gomez.

The birth 170 years ago of Simon Bolivar, South American liberator, was marked here yesterday as 250 members and friends of the Latin-American diplomatic colony gathered before the equestrian statue of the soldier-statesman at Central Park South and the Avenue of the Americas to pay tribute to the man and his ideals.

GENEVA, July 24 -- For the first time since World War II the flight of capital from Europe to other parts of the world believed to be safer havens from political storms and a possible third world war has ceased to make itself felt as a factor complicating Europe's many other economic troubles.

WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 24 -- That an old-fashioned pastime has modern day acceptance is evidenced by the fact that more than 300 women -- and a few men -- from throughout New England came to Storrowton on the Eastern States Exposition grounds yesterday to attend the third annual hooking bee and hooked rug exhibit.

DETROIT, July 24 -- Casey Stengel was still having a fearful time with the working mechanism of his once flawless Yankees tonight with the result that even the lowly Tigers took a turn at harassing the world champions.

GLASGOW, Scotland, July 21 -- Nowhere is the determination of British shipbuilders to meet growing foreign competition in a dwindling world market more clearly expressed than in the sprawling yards that line both banks of the Clyde in this area.

DETROIT, July 24 (UP) -- Oil Capitol, a seasoned handicap star, and Van Crosby, a speedy 3-year-old colt, will lead a field of thirteen postward tomorrow in the $50,000 added Michigan Mile at the Detroit Race Track.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- Army officials diclosed plans today to extend the tour of duty of Regular Army enlisted men in this country in an attempt to counter an "alarming" drop in re-enlistment rates.

ROME, July 24 -- If Italian workers were to live a single month under communism they would chase Communists out of their labor unions and never again have anything to do with them, said Walter Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, during a press conference in Rome this afternoon.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, July 24 -- The retirement here Monday of Air Chief Marshal Sir Hugh Saunders of the Royal Air Force, Deputy Supreme Allied Commander for Air in the North Atlantic Treaty Forces during the last two years, will mark the end of one stage of an impressive qualitative improvement of the Allies air-power in Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A committee of Congress expressed today its disappointment at the progress of efforts to improve the lot of Arab refugees from Palestine and warned that United States aid "cannot continue indefinitely."
A hold-up man shot a 6-year-old boy in the abdomen after robbing and knocking down a Bronx grocer yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, July 24 -- Sir Winston Churchill, the British Prime Minister, has "benefited greatly" from the month's complete rest prescribed by his doctors, an announcement from his office stated today. But he is not yet coming back to work in London.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Eisenhower appointed today two leading antagonists of the 1932 Presidential campaign -- former President Herbert Hoover and James A. Farley, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee -- to serve as public members of a new Commission on Government Reorganization.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 1 to 5 points lower than on Thursday.

The Hardwood Plywood Institute will put on a two-year trade promotion program over the next two years. The group's trade promotion committee has approved a tentative budget on the first phase of the program, which takes in development of a catalogue, grade-marking, trade-marking and quality control.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A high Government official said tonight that the United States had turned down a request by the Israeli Government for a $75,000,000 loan. However, Y. Harry L evin, Counselor of the Embassy of Israel, said: "We have made no application to the United States Government for a loan."

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower nominated today Robert D. Coe of Cody, Wyo., to be Ambassador to Denmark succeeding Mrs. Eugenie Anderson of Minnesota, Mr. Coe was in the Foreign Service from 1928 to 1952 when he retired.
