SALISBURY, South Rhodesia, July 24 -- The former president of the African National Congress in the South African Union, Dr. A. B. Xuma, an American-trained surgeon, in an address here has warned the new Central African Federation that it cannot become a nation if it pays attention to skin color.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -The Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives today approved four Air Force construction projects that it had set aside earlier for further study. They are at Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y., Hammonton, N. J., Little Rock, Ark. and Omaha, Neb.

Japanese ships tripled and German ships doubled their trade to the Port of New York in the fiscal year that ended last month, Francis B. Laughlin, acting Collector of Customs in the port, reported here yesterday.
FLORENCE, Italy, July 24 -- Now, well into the second half of the Italian fashion display in Florence, a few recurrent themes have become apparent.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- A tacit agreement between opposing sides apparently opened the way today for Senate passage of a bill to admit 209,000 refugees to the United States in the next three years. The emergency immigration measure, requested by President Eisenhower, had shaped up as a major obstacle to adjournment of Congress by the end of the next, week.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department announced today a breakdown among the states of a 62,000,000-acre wheat allotment, set for 1954, under a production control program announced last week by Secretary Ezra Taft Benson.

I was disturbed to read in THE TIMES on July 12 that "conservationists" oppose construction of the Panther Mountain Dam and support the proposed Ostrander-Cooke constitutional amendment which would bar river-regulating reservoirs from the Forest Preserve.

The Silver Bow County School District No. 1 of Montana yesterday sold $2,950,000 of bonds due from 1954 to 1973 to a syndicate headed by Northern Trust Company, Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Blyth Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.389 for interest of 3 3/4 per cent.

President Eisenhower has now filled the three civilian vacancies on the National Security Training Commission and opened the way to a wider study of the whole manpower and military service problem. He has asked for a report from the commission by Dec. 1 and has given a broad frame of reference for that report.
Reflecting the substantial increase in output at its plants, net profit of the Boeing Airplane Company in the first six months this year rose to $9,178,473 from $5,877,875 a year ago.

TOKYO, July 24 -- Japanese Government leaders and many Western diplomats stationed here expect the Soviet Union to launch a major propaganda campaign aimed at Japan as soon as a Korean armistice materializes. The obvious goal of such an effort, these officials say, would be to wean Japan away from her present strong ties with the West, particularly the United States.
KANSAS CITY, July 24 (AP) -- Earl Stewart Jr. of Dallas bolted into the lead at the halfway point of the $17,500 Kansas City open golf tornament today on a 5-under-par 67 for a 36-hole total of 133.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- Municipal Judge Thomas C. Scalley ruled today the Federal gambling tax could not constitutionally be enforced in the District of Columbia because of the District was governed by Federal law.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A collision indicator that tells who was involved and where the accident happened was patented this week by Loyal Vern Wilson of Albany, Ore. It spatters dye on both cars and on the part of the street that the newspaper artists usually mark with an X.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 24 -- Spotted rains in the vast Texas drought area have brought some cheer but no end to the four-year dry spell that prompted Gov. Allan Shivers to declare parts of the state disaster and public calamity areas. Some farmers will get relief from the rains, but months more of general rains must fall before normal greenness can return to West Texas.

Administration leaders in the House, with a handsome assist from their Democratic colleagues, have delivered a deserved rebuke to the die-hard protectionist wing in Congress. They did this by voting to send back to the Committee on Ways and Means the so-called "second Simpson bill." This bill if enacted into law, would for all practical purposes have nullified the effects of the "first Simpson bill," providing for the extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, disclosed today an agreement has been worked out for the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate alleged bribery, extortion or other crimes by Treasury Department employes.
VAUGHAN, Miss., July 24 (UP) -- The words were different and they didn't rhyme, but tonight railroaders heard the straight story of Casey Jones -- from his fireman on that last, storied ride.

May I, speaking as the only "American woman climber" who has ever been on Nanga Parbat -- although I did not actually "perish" there, as reported in a TIMES dispatch from Gilgit -- beg for space to straighten out a few of the discrepancies in the recent TIMES stories of the successful ascent of Nanga Parbat.
VIENNA, July 24 -- "Senator [Joseph R.] McCarthy has assumed more importance in other parts of the world than he really has," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today at a press conference here.

SINGAPORE, July 24 -- The Federation of Malay's Deputy High Commissioner, Sir Donald MacGillivray, now in London for financial talks, is to seek material aid from Britain and the United States comparable to Lend-Lease during World War II, the Kuala Lumpur correspondent of The Straits Times wrote tonight.
TOKYO, Saturday, July 25 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,686, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Saturday, Korean time:

The Corn Products Refining Company and its domestic subsidiary sales companies increased their net income in the first half of this year to $7,590,009, or $2.53 a common share, from $4,743,689, or $1.46 a share, earned in the corresponding six months of last year.

The Bank of Montreal, discussing Canada's status as a debtor nation, points out in its current business review that during the last decade Canada financed domestically a greater part of its business expansion than in earlier years, except in mining and petroleum development.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 24 -- The Communists of Costa Rica were ruled out of Sunday's elections when President Otilio Ulate tonight signed a law passed by Congress last week declaring the Independent Progressive party a subversive political organization as outlawed by the Constitution.

LONDON, July 24 -- The stock markets were quieter today and prices moved narrowly and irregularly. However, the undertone in most groups again was described as firm. A feature of the late business was an expansion in buying of German bonds.

Kings County District Attorney Miles F. McDonald, president of the National Association of County and Prosecuting Attorneys, announced yesterday the award of scholarships by the association. The grants entitle recipients to enroll for the courses for public prosecutors at the Practicing Law Institute and Northwestern University.

Assemblyman Ludwig Teller, a member of the Temporary State Commission to Study the Organizational Structure of the Government of the City of New York, objected yesterday to the statement of Devereux C. Josephs, its chairman, that the Philadelphia plan for city government under its revised charter could be adapted to the needs of this city.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 21 -- Every refugee government fights a heartbreaking war and the Chinese Nationalists certainly are no exception. If they were actually attacking the mainland or even defending this island against invaders their psychological problem would not be so hard.

LONDON, July 24 -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, United States Ambassador in London, replied tonight to complaints made since the recent foreign ministers conference in Washington that Western diplomacy has been too rigid and incapable of reacting to the apparently changed attitude of the Soviet Union.

A licensing arrangement for manufacture in Colombia of Arrow shirts and other products under the same label was announced yesterday by Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., as the first step in a new program for expanding foreign business.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Administration prospects of obtaining passage at the current session of Congress of bills that would increase postage charges and provide an estimated $240,000,000 in additional annual revenue for the Post Office Department appeared today to be fading.

Assemblyman Lewis W. Olliffe was designated yesterday as the Republican candidate for Borough President of Brooklyn by the Kings County Republican executive committee at its headquarters, 16 Court Street. Carmine A. Ventiera was named candidate for Kings County District Attorney and Alfred C. McKenzie for a County Court vacancy.

PORT - OF - SPAIN, Trinidad, July 24 -- Iron ore deposits in Trinidad, estimated at 20,000,000 tons, are to be worked by American Capital under a twenty-one year mining lease which will provide a 10 per cent royalty to the Trinidad Government.

DETROIT, July 24 (AP) -- Despite curtailed schedules at Chrysler and several of the smaller companies, July passenger car production probably will reach a thirty-three-month high, Ward's Reports said today. July car output, it estimated, should reach 616,000 units.

For gallantry in action in Korea, a Silver Star was awarded posthumously yesterday on Governors Island to Sgt. Raymond S. Taylor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond S. Taylor of 309 East Seventy-fourth Street. Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress, First Army commander, presented the medal to Sergeant Taylor's mother.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The House of Representatives hurried through today a bill to provide $150,000,000 for emergency relief in the drought-stricken Southwest. With unanimous approval, the measure was sent to the Senate, where quick action is expected.
LONDON, July 24 (UP) -- Communist-dominated Albania announced today a Government shake-up that stripped Dictator Marshal Enver Hoxha of many of his powers but left him the Premiership.

PHILADELPHIA, -- July 24 (UP) -- Gran Hamner hit two home runs tonight -- the second with one out in the ninth inning -- to pace the Phillies to a 2-1 victory over the Cardinals in a pitching duel between Righthander Bob Miller and Southpaw Harvey Haddix.

HARTFORD, July 24 -- John A. Danaher of West Hartford, former Republican United States Senator from Connecticut, appears to be assured of nomination by President Eisenhower as a judge of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, Second District.

Fritz Schaeffer, Finance Minister of the German Federal Republic, announced here yesterday that National City Bank of New York and J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., had been appointed as depositaries for the validation of Germany's pre-war dollar bonds.
An 11-year-old boy named James John Hayes went down into the basement of his apartment building in Brooklyn Thursday night and picked up two shiny pebbles that he thought looked like diamonds.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, July 25 -- Chinese Communist forces supported by Soviet-style Katusha rockets, fought hand to hand with United States Marines early today for three outposts northeast of Panmunjom, the site of the truce negotiations.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 24 -- An atmosphere of good-will and conjecture prevails in this capital on the eve of a meeting of the Prime Ministers of Pakistan and India to discuss a settlement of three major issues that have threatened the peace of the two nations since Pakistan was created by partition from India six years ago.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 24 -- Premier Penn Nouth of Cambodia, upon receipt today a French note in answer to Cambodia's demands for independence, made reservations both as to procedure and the military portion of the Paris statement. The Premier said he would leave Pnompenh, the Cambodian capital, tomorrow for Sienreap to confer with. King Norodom Sihanouk, who will make the final decision regarding the French program.

ALTHOUGH they still are having trouble locating school tuna in numbers, New Jersey off-shore anglers seem to be reaping an unusual bluefish harvest. Reports yesterday indicated that as many as ninety to 110 blues were being brought in by boats chumming near the Mud Hole and Shrewsbury Rocks.
The 15-cent fare on the city's subways and surface lines went into effect today without any major hitch, but with some initial congestion and a few complaints by the traveling public.

The European Defense Community -- key both to American policy in Europe and to further progress toward European unity and security -- passed another milestone on the long and rocky road toward realization when the lower house of the Netherlands Parliament approved its ratification by the decisive vote of 75 to 11.

CHICAGO, July 24 (UP) -- A home run in the twelfth inning by Cass Michaels after a single by Gus Zernial, both traded away by the White Sox, gave the Athletics a 4-to-2 victory over the Chicagoans tonight before 32,487 fans.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Capt. Hyman George Rickover, the Navy's atomic propulsion expert who was twice passed over for promotion, will be named a rear admiral, the Navy announced tonight. Captain Rickover's name was among twenty-eight captains selected for the higher rank.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., July 24 -- The Fiftieth Armored Division, New Jersey National Guard, began moving out of Camp Drum today after completing two weeks of summer training. The Seventy-eighth Infantry Division, New Jersey reserve outfit, will leave for home tomorrow night.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, July 24 (AP) -- American track and field stars, headed by Mal Whitfield of the Grand Street Boys Club of New York, won four events at an international meet in Slottsskogsvallen Stadium tonight.

KANSAS CITY, July 24 (AP) -- Arthur Eisenhower, a brother of the President, acknowledged today that he had called Senator Joseph R. McCarthy "the most dangerous menace to America," but said he did not understand why the remark had caused excitement.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Government today sold its Inland Waterways Corporation, the barge line that operates in the Midwest and South, for $9,000,000. The Federal Waterways Corporation, newly formed subsidiary of the St. Louis Shipbuilding and Steel Company, was the successful bidder.

Jean Arabo, wine merchant and amateur chef, acquired most of his culinary knowledge in southern France where he grew up. One of his favorite recipes, for Salade Nicoise, is especially appropriate for summer.
Eight teen-age girls were brought into court yesterday after the police had broken up a threatened pitched battle between rival gangs of girl warriors over the affections of a boy.
CLEVELAND, July 24 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon's triple and double drove in half of Washington's runs tonight as the Senators beat the Indians, 6 -- 4.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Wheat failed to find active support and was lower in most of today's session. Talk of rust in spring wheat fields continued but weather in Northwestern states was not favorable for spread of the disease. Interest in Washington measures to give away food surpluses brought support to wheat in the latter part of the session.
SEOUL, Korea July 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by President Syngman Rhee of South Korea:

TOKYO, Saturday, July 25 -- Staff and liaison officers of both sides pressed ahead with preparations for an armistice in the Korean war in apparent disregard of new last-ditch protests by President Syngman Rhee of South Korea.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Indications mounted tonight that an armistice in the Korean war would be signed during the week-end.

PARIS, July 24 -- Two slipcovers for the same bonnet was an idea presented at Simone Vernet's show for persons who travel light and have neither the time nor the patience for packing with reams of tissue paper.

Congratulations and thanks for the column in Topics of The Times on New York of the Past as recorded by Percy G. Byron's photographs now on exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York. It is a subject that needs much more publicity than it has had.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 24 -- Sal Maddalone of the Rose Hill Club in the Bronx won his first golf tournament today, carding a par 72 to take the gross prize in the Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day handicap event at the Hempstead Club.

The Studebaker Corporation and its subsidiaries in the six months ended June 30 suffered a sharp setback in earnings, but directors voted the regular quarterly dividend yesterday of 75 cents a share payable to common stockholders on Sept. 2.

In the course of each season the home gardener undergoes a sort of refresher course covering a good many fields of varied if related information. During the spring, or planting, period he learns again that the frost provides the greatest lifting force yet known, easily pushing to the surface of the earth unremovable boulders and rocks.

A series of short biographies of important persons is planned for publication next year by Knopf. The volumes will vary in length between 50,000 and 60,000 words. The author of each book will be a well- known writer. Among the early titles will be "Gandhi" by Vincent Sheean, "Benjamin Franklin" by Odell Shepard, "Alexander Hamilton'' by Louis Hacker and "Hans Christian Andersen" by Rumer Godden.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker: ...

BALDWIN, L. I., July 24 -- Nassau County police took advantage today of the sunny skies, balmy weather and resulting heavy travel to and from Jones Beach to set up a trap for motorists who violate traffic regulations.
A near-capacity crowd of 68,448 Jehovah's Witnesses crowded Yankee Stadium yesterday to pay tribute to their mission work in Africa.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 24 (AP) -- The St. Catharine's Rowing Club maintained its lead after three days of racing in the seventy-first Royal Canadian Henley Regatta today although it failed to win an event.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- The Federal Communications Commission proposed today to make its television station licenses good for three years instead of one.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 24 -- Humphrey Bogart and William Holden will be romantic rivals for the hand of Audrey Hepburn in the screen version of "Sabrina Fair," which Billy Wilder will produce and direct for Paramount early this fall.

Twenty-five years ago today Secretary of State Kellogg dispatched a note to the Foreign Office of the Nationalist Government of China through our Minister in Peiping, John V. A. MacMurray. It constituted a de facto recognition of that Government and expressed the readiness of the United States to conclude a new treaty with China that would restore complete tariff autonomy to the Chinese Republic.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Government is allowing an atomic medical substance to be sent from Oak Ridge, Tenn., to Yugoslavia to treat ailing Aloysius Cardinal Stepinac, officials said tonight.

CAMDEN, N. J., July 24 -- Five suspects were under arrest today as the police announced the solution of the recent $100,000 theft of 8,400 radio crystals from the R. C. A. Victor plant here. One of the men accused of larceny was said to have sold some of the crystals for 25 cents each, although they were valued at $14 apiece.

" THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA," by Henry Bamford Parkes, is almost as long as some of our recent historical novels and far more interesting. I've been quarrying away at it for three days now, finding in it the fundamental material of many books, written and unwritten. For here is the great story from which so many stories have been made; this is the forever unfinished symphony that holds so many of our undying tunes.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 24 (AP) -- Red Sails, owned by H. T. King, of Lynn, Ind., scored a nose victory tonight in the $5,000 Ronkonkoma Pace at Roosevelt Raceway, holding off Philip Scott in a sensational photo finish.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- The Senate tonight rejected a $447,429,000 House of Representatives-Senate compromise appropriations bill to run a score of Government agencies this year because of a conflict over what the conferees had really done.

WASHINGTON, July, 24 (UP) -- Harold Boisvert a Commerce Department lawyer, asserted today that he was being dismissed because he had reported to top officials on "subversives and sex deviates" among the department's employes and "irregularities" in export licenses.

Eleven swarthy hired men were on their knees in sun-warmed loam yesterday, thinning and pulling beets in a corner of the largest work farm in New York City. Robins fluted in the trees along one farm boundary. Smaller winged things droned and buzzed.

UPPER LAKE, Calif., July 24 -- A subpoena was served today on the Rev. Jack R. McMichael, 36- year-old pastor of the Methodist Church here, calling upon him to answer charges of Communist affiliations before the House of Representatives Committee on Un- American Activities. He is to appear next Thursday in Washington.

BONN, Germany, July 24 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer recently sent an aide memoire to the Western Big Three foreign ministers suggesting the possibility of a West European offer of a non-aggression pact to the Soviet Union, a Bonn Foreign Office source revealed today.

Milwaukee's Braves last night served notice on the Dodgers that they still were in the National League pennant race by slugging their way to an 11-6 triumph over Brooklyn's league-leading champions before 27,948 paying spectators at Ebbets Field. By their victory, the second-place Braves reduced the Dodger margin to four and a half games.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The question whether fares would be raised or lowered on the Long Island Rail Road in case the New York State Public Service Commission receives exclusive jurisdiction over them was left hanging today as a Congressional sub-committee heard arguments on a bill to exclude the Interstate Commerce Commission from any control over fares.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Saturday, July 25 -- Indonesian Army units engaged armed bands of the Moslem terrorist organization, Darul Islam at three points in West Java today. The small Indonesian Air Force again bombed guerrilla hige-outs in the mountains in what appeared to be stepped-up military operations in Java's undeclared war.

With the trial of Lieut. Arthur Miller disposed of, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan announced yesterday that "four or five" more members of the department are being investigated by the commissioner's confidential squad regarding alleged Communist party membership or connections.

FORT WORTH, July 24 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, the great "wee mon" of golf, came home again today and walked a red carpet of welcome spread by the town that saw him grow from a skinny, little caddy to the acknowledged master of the game.

MEXICO CITY, July 24 -- Evidence has been accumulating here that there is in the making a new Export-Import Bank policy which would limit foreign loans to comparatively short-term credits for the purchase of American equipment.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 24 (AP) -- The United States won the second-round American zone Davis Cup tie against the British West Indies today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24 -- It will cost the sixty United Nations member governments $41,660,200 to run the world organization in 1954 -- about $555,300 less than this year -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold estimated today in his annual budget report.
Stanley Young has completed revisions of his comedy, "The Big People," and Jule Styne may sponsor the work this season if casting problems can be solved.

BERLIN, July 24 -- Wilhelm Zaisser, East Germany's Minister of State Security, member of the Politburo and the "General Gomez" of Spanish Civil War fame as a leader of the Spanish Republic's International Brigade, was dropped from the Government today in a reshuffle that absorbed his office into the Ministry of the Interior.

Last night's all-Brahms concert at Lewisohn Stadium by Alexander Smallens and the Stadium Symphony Orchestra, with Claudio Arrau as soloist, was marked by a tribute to Mr. Smallens on the completion of his twentieth season as a Stadium conductor.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Rebellious members of the Government Operations Committee of the House of Representatives backtracked today from their decision to deny special investigating powers to Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan, their chairman. By a unanimous vote, they gave him authority to renew his investigation of racketeering in Kansas City and Detroit although they limited the period of inquiry to sixty days.

PITTSBURGH, July 24 (UP) -- Former Pirate Ralph Kiner drove in a pair of runs and collected three singles before a "welcome home" crowd tonight as Left-Hander Paul Minner pitched the Cubs to a 7-1 victory over Pittsburgh.

William C. Chanler, chairman of the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee, sent a letter to its members yesterday assailing both the Liberal party and the Republican leaders for failure to name a coalition ticket, headed by Representative Jacob K. Javits, a Republican, as the candidate for Mayor.

Nearly half of the 18,000 Protestant missionaries from the United States serving in foreign lands in 1952 were stationed in Africa, Latin America and the West Indies. One-third of the total served in East Asia, India and Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Chairman George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, said today the Senate Agriculture Committee will take no further action on pending cotton acreage legislation unless the South and the Southwest reach an agreement.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The views of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, on the proper books to grace the shelves of United States information centers abroad brought him into heated clashes today with fellow Senators and with Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Under Secretary of State.
OSAKA, Japan, July 24 (UP) -- When Japanese baseball fans shout "Kill the umpire," they aren't fooling.

BRESCIA, Italy, July 24 (AP) -- A touring American track and field squad swept all eleven events in a meet against an Italian team at Brescia Stadium tonight. About 5,000 fans watched Art Bragg of Baltimore score two victories.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 24 (UP) -- The Red Sox moved into third place tonight as they swept a twilight-night double-header from the Browns, winning the second game by 6 -- 0 after taking the first 8 -- 0.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 24 -- Joe Gagliardi of Winged Foot, the 1951 winner, beat another former titleholder in the quarter-finals of the Metropolitan amateur championship at the Fenway Golf Club today.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The executive council of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., tossed Anthony Anastasia out of his Brooklyn dock union job today.
Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan, candidate of Tammany and the Bronx for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, still lacked running mates yesterday.
BERLIN, July 24 -- The West Berlin Government announced today a new plan for distribution of relief food to residents of the Soviet-occupied areas which it believes is immune to Communist forgeries.

HANOI, Vietnam, July 24 -- French military quarters here foresee the biggest Vietminh military effort of the seven-year-old Indo-China war during the dry season that will begin here next September. Heavy fighting that could have a determining influence on the outcome of the war is expected.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, who delighted television audiences with biblical quotations and sharp rebukes to some witnesses as a member of the Senate Crime Committee, died tonight, two days after his seventy-third birthday.
WEST CALDWELL, N. J., July 24 -- Mr. and Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association husband-and-wife championship at Mountain Ridge today.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders, working in an informal coalition, broke down today two formidable barriers to the Eisenhower Administration's "must" legislative program.

There is virtually no chance that any loss of business suffered by retail stores because of the in-increase in the transit fares from 10 cents to 15 cents will be offset by city action to reduce the 3 per cent sales tax.
LONDON, July 24 (AP) -- The Times of London assailed today the talk about Princess Margaret's reported romance as scandalmongering.

Rails showed weakness in yesterday's stock market. So did a few oils. With the rest of the market holding up prices had a spotty appearance at the close. THE NEW YORK TIMES averages all fell slightly and gains and losses among the more active issues were about evenly divided, but 387 issues advanced while 358 fell and 306 were unchanged.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24 -- In the battle for more food and better living conditions for the world, civilization has no mightier tool than modern technology, but technology can also create more havoc than it alleviates, Dr. Margaret Mead and other anthropologists report in a completed study of the impact of industrialization on backward peoples.

TORONTO, July 24 (UP) -- Eddie Moylan of Trenton and Robin Willner of Los Angeles fought to the final point today before losing to Mervyn Rose and Rex Hartwig in the Canadian title tennis doubles semi-finals, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.
QUANTICO, Va., July 24 -- President Eisenhower took command tonight of the three-day work and play gathering of the nation's defense leaders at this Marine Corps base.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 25 -- The resumption of diplomatic relations between Israel and the Soviet Union this week offset for a short time the misgivings of Israeli leaders about the new look of United States policy in the Middle East.

Border-line "gift shops" selling shoddy merchandise and factory reject are moving into the Times Square area because they find more gullible out-of-town persons to victimize, according to John E. Gannon, executive vice president of the Forty-second Street-Mid-Manhattan Association.

BERLIN, July 25 -- Communist newspapers devoted their attention today to the West Berlin food distribution project, due to go into effect Monday. They continued to brand it a Western trick to place the citizens of the Soviet zone and East Berlin under obligations to the West, thus making "agents" of them.

IN the gardener's summer-long battle with the insect horde there is such a thing as being too thorough. Although most of the grubs and worms that invade a yard deserve to be exterminated on sight, a certain few caterpillars definitely merit a reprieve.

ROSLYN, L. I., July 25 -- Because of legal technicalities the Roslyn Water District, for the first time since it was established in 1910, is having difficulty raising funds to finance additional facilities needed for its increased population. Emergency measures curtailing the use of water are in effect until further notice.
A young artist who climbed onto a church roof yesterday to rescue his pet canary failed to catch his bird and had to be rescued himself.

FORT LEE, N. J., July 25 -- Five young adventurers, from 7 to 12 years old, were rediscovered by their parents at noon here today, after a resident had phoned the police that a group of campers near his home strongly resembled the New York children for whom a thirteen-state alarm had gone out last night.

TO DATE, 1953 promises to be a banner year for complaints about the weather, particularly from gardeners. A mild, open winter in the Northeast pointed to plant losses -- by winterkilling, above-normal rainfall from January to June interfered with spring planting and, starting in early June, subnormal rainfall aggravated in some areas by high winds and brilliant sun has brought other problems.
BOGOR, Indonesia, Sunday, July 26 -- A strange theft, the rarest in the 145-year-old history of the world famous West Java Bogor Botanical Gardens, has occurred here.

NEITHER the sun nor the drought, which have affected adversely the bloom of many flowers, are likely to prevent flowering of plantain lilies. This is only on of several varieties of hosta or funkia, all of which grow and flower successfully in the shade.

NEW DELHI, India, July 25 -Western observers here are looking forward with great interest to India's assumption of her duties in Korea as a custodian of prisoners who refuse repatriation to the Communist side. This will be New Delhi's first contact with the problems of the Far East and communism on a practical rather than a consultative plane and some diplomats believe it will be an educating experience.

Charley Grimm, manager of the Braves, who said recently that he was "not impressed" by the Dodgers, must have revised his opinion slightly at the end of yesterday's game at Ebbets Field, watched by 25,963 fans, including 7,100 Knothole Club youngsters and 500 Milwaukee fans.

BONN, Germany, July 25 (UP) -- The Social Democratic party protested today what it called an attempt by President Eisenhower to link the June 17 uprisings in East Germany with the "faulty and accursed" policies of West German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.

LONDON, July 25 -- A mild and mannerly debate over the constitutional position of the Duke of Edinburgh, Queen Elizabeth's consort, has been started here by the decision to designate him as Regent for his son Prince Charles in case the Prince should succeed to the throne while still a minor.
MOST mystery writers (and other novelists, for that matter) discover the sort of story they're goad at, and stick to it -- a sensible practice both commercially and, probably, esthetically.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 25 -Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, and Mohammed Ali, Pakistan's Prime Minister, met for two hours and ten minutes this afternoon in the first of five meetings here looking to the solution of several major problems that have threatened peace between the two countries for more than six years.

ONE of the more interesting aspects of television on the Continent and in Britain is the question of the artistic freedom and opportunity for those who work in the medium -the producers, actors and writers. If laborers in America's video vineyard have some reasons for complaints, they should recognize that it is not all milk and honey over here where there are no sponsors.

Only minor incidents of confusion and delay were reported yesterday as passengers and transit workers adjusted quickly to the use of tokens for subway and elevated trips on the first day of the 15-cent fare on city-owned lines.

Passage of a legislative measure destroying the rights of nearly all United States Indians appears imminent. This bill would make "scraps of paper" of our Government's treaties and agreements with Indian tribes.

Henry Steele Commager's very arresting article, "'Yet the Nation Survived --'" (July 5) needs one correction, as follows: "The only thing we have to fear is fear itself" appears in Francis Bacon's "De Augmentis Scientiarum" published in the seventeenth century, while in the article it appears as a brain child of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

SPECULATOR, N. Y., July 25 -A new speed boat regatta series began today in this isolated but picturesque section that is one of the rooftops of the mountainous Adirondacks and which has been known to other sports.
AS one who gratefully derives a good deal of pleasure from watching television. I'd like to make one little request to the people who create the comedy situation shows. It is this:

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 25 -- My Celeste, the 7-year-old distance-loving mare owned by Constance Morabito, gave a typical home-grounds performance in winning the $34,350 Monmouth Handicap today. Trailing the leader by as many as a dozen lengths in the mile-and-a-quarter fixture, My Celeste staged a characteristic closing rush to gain the victory by a head over Again II, the Argentine-bred lightweight in the field of six.

HARTFORD, July 25 -- The Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors will hold a hearing in October on a challenge by the state Democratic party to a law passed by the 1953 General Assembly that changes the boundary lines of the thirty-six State Senate districts.
Edward J. Flynn, Bronx Democratic leader, left here yesterday on the Cunard liner Mauretania for a month's vacation in Ireland with only one comment on the municipal political situation.

A thoroughly charming set of pay-off figures went up on the board after the running of the $23,700 Saranac Handicap at the Jamaica track yesterday. First Aid, representing Mrs. Isabel Dodge Sloane's Brookmeade Stable, took first money -- and he was $134.40 to win, $25.40 to place, $12.90 to show.

THE match rifle shooters are now willing to admit that the "good old days" of open competition are being revived, for, after moving from pillar to post for many years, the National Rifle and Pistol Matches will return to their old home, the scene of many shooting triumphs, Camp Perry, Ohio.

SEVERAL years ago I had occasion to spend a day at the summer school of Drake University in Des Moines and had a series of public and private meetings with students interested in music. Nearly all these student were adults, teachers of music in the secondary schools of the Middle West.

A WRITER not a Negro who attempts a book tracing a Negro family through three generations, and who aims to transport his readers deep into the thought-patterns and emotions of his characters, needs courage, skill and a profound knowledge of his subject.

MOTORISTS who allow children to stand up or romp about in the car merely because they are running along at twenty miles an hour are risking serious inside-the-vehicle accidents. This is proved by a series of tests described by O. K. Normann, highway transport research branch, Bureau of Public Roads.

NEWARK, July 25 -- Whether non-prescription drugs may be sold in retail outlets other than drug stores, a long-disputed issue in the New Jersey courts, seems likely to be tested by new litigation, notwithstanding a ruling this week by Supreme Court Judge Frederic R. Colie.

LONDON, July 25 -- An oblique reply by a Minister of the Crown into an equally oblique question by a Labor member of the House of Commons on Wednesday was the first governmental recognition of an item of gossip that had been agitating most of the press and some of the subjects of this kingdom for three weeks.

HAS anyone been troubled that the stage isn't what it used to be? There is no need to be alarmed. Conditions are normal, since the theatre continues to be agitated over real and fancied problems. We are currently, for example, much concerned over our directors' role in stage production.

The heavy rain of Thursday punched a hole in the week's business in the district's department stores, so that no gain was recorded over the 1952 period. Because of the storm, which drowned out the day's retail volume, observers estimated that the week would show very little change from 1952.

CAIRO, July 25 -- Egypt unveiled today a token force of paratroopers as part of the growing military strength that, according to Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, the President, makes it possible to evict the British forces from the Suez Canal Zone "at any time we like."

ROME, July 21 -- Many Americans have been surprised to find that, despite $3,000,000,000 of United States aid poured into Italy since the end of World War II, the total vote of the extreme Left-wing parties increased from 8,136,000 in the general elections of 1948 to 9,561,000 in 1953.

PARIS, July 25 -- In a note to the French Government published here today by the High Commissioner of Cambodia, that Indo-Chinese state said it would agree to adhere to "a French union in which it enjoyed a status at least equal to that of India in the [British] Commonwealth."

So Mrs. Myrtle Glasscock Hance, according to Stanley Walker in "Book Branding -A Case History" (July 12) wants certain books branded and one follower suggests that the names of readers of such books be turned over to the F. B. I.!
DETROIT, July 25 -- All the world loves a mystery. But there is one defying solution in these parts that nobody seems to like. Even if you came up with the right answer, it wouldn't be popular.

City Council President Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, was criticized last night by Robert B. Blaikie, insurgent Democratic district leader, for failing to enter the Democratic primary.

Among the most successful persons in post-war international commercial aviation are two men who raised $20,000 six years ago, began operations with one plane and now have a fleet of ten four-engined transports operating in many parts of the world. They are the brothers Norden, Raymond A., 36 years old, and Arthur V., 39, president and executive vice president-general manager, respectively, of Seaboard and Western Airlines.

Are there eggs in egg noodles? To answer, a new "electric eye" method of determining the egg content of noodles has been developed by chemists of the United States Army's Quartermaster Subsistence Testing Laboratory, Chicago, according to a report in the Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry.

MOSCOW, Sunday, July 26 -- An important and lengthy statement of basic Communist party policy, stressing the necessity for struggle against all manifestations of fractionalism within the party and for peaceful friendly relations abroad and the avoidance of a new war, was made public today.

The ending of George May's "Gray War That Worries Moscow" (July 12), forcefully reveals the basic weakness of our foreign policy. We speak about the liberation of the satellite peoples, but leave them in the dark about what would happen to them once they were liberated.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Hasty Road, a fast-stepping son of Roman, romped home in record time today to win the richest 2-year-old stake ever run and the richest race in Arlington Park history, the $157,915 Futurity, by two and one-half lengths.

IF a tourist-book genius tried to describe America and Americans to a cheese-headed Dutchman he would be left on a hill of adjectives. He could extol its grain-drenched Midwestern plains, its majestic snow-capped mountains, lonely desert sands, endless evergreen forests of the West, its smooth rolling Southern hills dotted with brown and gold bundles of trees, its throbbing beat of ingenious machines in the industrial East.

BRIGHT, shiny, plastic-coated cards were scattered all over my desk. A clack sunburst pattern glistened on one side of each: the other sides sparkled with vivid, carnival colors and subtle hues and a vast array of patterns -- marbleized, zigzagged, checkered, flowered, paisley, dotted, lozened, each one different.

TEEN-AGERS by the thousands are drifting through summer -- by couples, in canoes or strolling along country paths, in groups at the soda fountain or down at the swimming dock. Puppy love, summer romance, may swell the hearts of some. Others have discovered merely that tennis or picnics, almost any activity in fact, is more fun when boys and girls are together.

THOUGH we have not been blinded with ticker-tape or confetti like Atlantic fliers, channel swimmers or war heroes, Arthur Schwartz and I, on a recent tour of the more populous centers of the east, have been welcomed with a good deal of fanfare.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 25 -- Dr. Samuel Anziano and Dr. Joseph Teta, North Hempstead, and James Cullen and James Lytell, North Hills, will meet in the final of the twelfth annual Charles R. Casey memorial member-guest tournament at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club tomorrow.

THE stirring tale by Florence Whitfield Barton about the Reformation in France, "The Sage and the Olive," is a hard book to classify. It is almost too documented and literal for a novel, yet it is not quite a biography, since its pages are filled with invented dialogue and possibly invented scenes.

HARDLY a little girl is alive who hasn't dreamed of being a ballerina in a fluffy pink tutu. Even the ones who prefer baseball will sympathize with Susie who on her sixth birthday finds that she is still "too young" for most of the things she wants to do.
The answers to the question "Why do men climb mountains?" in "Men and Mountains" (July 19) are not quite complete.
LINCOLN, Neb., July 25 -- A subject for discussion in Nebraska the last sixteen years -- the one-House State Legislature -- is being debated even more hotly this year.
Three hundred world travelers will take to the air in the next two weeks for a tour of eleven European countries -- after saving for four years.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., July 25 -- Dr. George Dinsmore Stoddard resigned early today as president of the University of Illinois after the board of trustees had voted 6 to 3 that it had no confidence in his administration.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., July 25 -- A belated Independence Day celebration, dictated by the facts of history, was observed here today with colorful pageantry reminiscent of July 25, 1776, when the Declaration of Independence was officially proclaimed in this town.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Eisenhower's return to the White House from the Quantico, Va., Marine Base was postponed today until late tomorrow afternoon, apparently on advice from the State Department, which has kept the President informed on Korean truce developments.

Republican Congressional leaders, after years of fulminating against unbalanced budgets and a mounting federal debt under Democratic Administrations, seem, in their zeal to adhere to self-established "mandates," anxious to aggravate an already distorted national debt by removing revenue sources in a time of need.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -"This country's economy will be closer to so-called normal after the coming week than it has been since 1942."

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a company could not refuse to bargain with a newly certified labor union just because the concern had a long-term contract with another union.

THE growing accumulation of three - dimensional (stereoscopic) films, two more of which put in their appearance on one single day here last week, is such as to lead a candid skeptic of this method of projection to despair of any early abandonment of it or any sudden improvement in its use.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is planning to shift his investigating committee's emphasis soon from alleged communism to charges of corruption under the Truman Administration.

OUR country is badly in need of an informed, responsible and effective policy to meet the Communist threat to our free society -- a policy that will give us genuine security without imperiling the individual liberties that are the heart of the difference between our democracy and the slave system of the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- What may be the most important vote test for Republicans and the Eisenhower Administration since Nov. 4, 1952 will be held next month.
TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., July 25 -- Bernice B. Ashdown's Samoyed, Champion Silvertips Scion of Wychwood went best-in-show today at the Tuxedo Kennel Club's thirty-first annual event.

Charles William Tobey of New Hampshire had been in public life for forty years, beginning as a selectman and winding up as a United States Senator. A large section of the American public first became aware of him, however, when he appeared on television as a member of the Kefauver Committee in 1951.
PASADENA, Calif., July 26 (UP) -- Cy Young of the San Francisco Olympic Club, hurled the javelin 256 feet 4 inches today to set an American record.
HANOVER, N. H., July 25 -- Dartmouth College announced today the start of a new study of long - range radio transmission through the sound barriers of Arctic areas.
DETROIT, July 25 (AP) -- Second Avenue, a 10-to-1 shot, won the $57,250 Michigan Mile today as Van Crosby and Oil Capitol ran out of the money.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Dr. Lee M. Thurston, the new United States Commissioner of Education, stressed this week in an interview with this reporter that education is a local and state function. The local autonomy of the country's 75,000 school districts, he said, makes education in the United States democratic and strong.
ST. LOUIS, July 25 (UP) -- The Red Sox defeated the Browns, 7 -- 6, today on Johnny Lipon's squeeze bunt, which went for a single. The ninth-inning victory enabled the Sox to remain in third place.

MARSHAL TITO may be the subject of a feature film to be produced in Belgrade under Yugoslav-American auspices. Last week Marion Gering, producer-director of the independent G-L Enterprises, relayed word from Rome that Charles Spellman, a Los Angeles business man and representative of G-L, had signed an agreement with Dejan Obradovic, director of the Yugoslav firm, Avala-Film, for the co-production of a feature based on the book, "Tito," by Vladimir Dedijer.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified sixty-seven Korean war casualties today, including twelve killed, fifty-three wounded, one missing and one injured. Casualties from New York and Connecticut follow (none from New Jersey):

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 25 -- Flowing in from Communist China and from Iron Curtain countries of Europe to a 285-foot-high tower that dominates the lower San Francisco Bay area is a steady stream of contemporary documents eagerly studied by Western scholars as soon as they become available.

HAWLEY, Pa. -- Difficult as it may be to understand, some free public recreational facilities are going begging here. Pennsylvania's largest lake, 5,760-acre Lake Wallenpaupack, has four public campsites that could use more visitors.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Flags at the Capitol flew at half staff and the Senate cut short a Saturday session today and adjourned until Monday at noon, out of respect to Senator Charles W. Tobey, the colorful New Hampshire Republican who died last night of coronary thrombosis.

TWENTY-SEVEN black-andwhite night pictures are on display starting today at the Kodak Photographic Information Center on the east balcony of Grand Central Terminal. The show, which will continue through Aug. 24, also includes an exhibit of twenty-eight color prints by photographers in various parts of the country.

The Eisenhower Administration apparently having decided to continue the farm product price control methods of the Democratic Administrations in the last twenty years, more than usual interest centers on the reaction of wheat growers to the imposition of acreage controls on the 1954 crop.

Japan's external dollar debt, in good standing less than a year following resumption of interest payments on fourteen issues of bonds totaling about $76,000,000, is beginning to shrink visibly. Sinking funds, in operation this year for the first time since the bonds went into default in 1941, are the reason.

WHEN city-reared Robin Reed spends a country summer with her Aunt Roberta she finds things very dull until her accidental meeting with Cherub Talbut and the sturdy pony, Mr. Jones. Robin is overjoyed when Cherub, ably assisted by Mr. Jones, starts her on the road to real horsemanship.

Horse players on their way by boat to and from Monmouth Park Race Track at Oceanport, N. J., were taught a lesson in gambling yesterday. They dropped $5,000 to six card sharks whose agile handling of an ace under pressure would have been the envy of a Mississippi sharper operating on a sternwheeler.

FOR a self-styled "very impatient person," Alec Guinness' behavior, both on and off the screen, hardly bears him out. The actor, stopping here briefly en route to Canada definitely was not the helpless, browbeaten milquetoast he so convincingly portrays in the stylish, subtle British comedies which have won him international acclaim.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 25 -- The creation of more regional defense organizations would lead to the strengthening of the United Nations and the bolstering of world stability, according to a report issued today by the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 25 -American industry has diversified its activities in the post-war years, a suvey by Arthur D. Litle, Inc., here shows.

A new bulletin, entitled "Developing Children's Power of Self-Expression Through Writing," is being distributed to the New York City elementary schools. The booklet was published in response to requests from teachers for more help in assisting children to express themselves in writing.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- The Federal Government may take about 400 grain millers and traders to court in a move to recover $7,819,717 on Government-owned grain sold illegally.
In the case of M-G-M "The Band Wagon" I fail to see what the shouting is about.
Twenty-five months ago this week Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, the U. N. commander in Korea, sent out over Tokyo radio transmitters a message that began:

PARIS, July 25 -- Accompanied by their aunt, Mme. Hedwig Rosner, two Jewish war orphans, Robert and Gerald Finaly, 12 and 10 years old, respectively, finally left for Israel tonight to begin a new life, far from the storm and movement that has been their lot up to now.
The nation's industries sold more than $4,900,000,000 of securities in the first half of this year, according to a study of new corporate financing made by the Investment Dealers' Digest.
LONDON, Sunday, July 26 (Reuters) -- The Hungarian Government, announcing an amnesty, said today that it would disband all concentration camps, the official Hungarian news agency said in a dispatch.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 25 -- A 35-year-old man, described by the Nassau County police as the "week-end burglar" of Long Island residential areas, was killed late tonight in a pistol battle with a county policeman in Wantagh, L. I.

Defense of the salesman as essential to the mass movement of goods of all types came last week from Robert Z. Greene, the man who, more than anyone else, has made a volume industry of selling by machine.

A 41-year-old cafeteria counter man who admitted having sent two threatening letters to President Eisenhower demanding improvements in cancer research techniques was arrested last night as a fugitive from justice.

WICHITA, Kan. -- The buffalo is coming back to the open ranges, away from city zoos. Kansas has half a dozen herds on the range and dozens of ranches dabbling in buffalo. If the tourist wants to be served "buffaloburgers," let him go to western Kansas where excess males from buffalo herds are being marketed right along with cattle.

Carlos Hevia, who was President of Cuba in 1934 and a candidate for the Presidency last year, said last week that disturbed economic and political conditions in Cuba were of "the type that have always produced revolutions in the past."

BERLIN, July 25 -- Efforts of the East German Government to recover from the catastrophe of the June 17 uprising entered a new phase this week. While continuing its policy of broad economic concessions, the Soviet-sponsored regime began an all-out struggle to crush a growing underground organization of anti-Communist workers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP) -- Jerry Ford, former varsity football player and director of freshman athletics at the University of Pennsylvania today was named director of intercollegiate athletics at Penn. He succeeds Francis T. Murray.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- Golf's greatest stampede starts next week. It's the scramble for part of the $120,000 offered by promoter George S. May in his Tam O'Shanter tournaments.

ATLANTA, July 25 -- New lightweight men's clothing, made with blends of synthetic fibers, has greatly increased buyer interest and resulted in Atlanta stores reporting sales increases ranging as high as 15 per cent above 1952. June employment in the Atlanta area reached a new high of 290,500 workers with an estimated 884,100 persons working in Georgia during June.

Business of $2,000,000,000 a year is done by the automotive and allied industries in this city, according to a survey by Joseph F. Farlow, executive vice president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York, presented yesterday by the West Side Association of Commerce.

FISHKILL, N. Y., July 25 -Sharpe Reservation, 1,000-acre new camping center of The New York Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund, in East Fishkill, Dutchess County, was praised as a model example of conservation of human and natural resources by state and Federal Government officials in addresses at dedication exercises today.
SEOUL, Sunday, July 26 -- Nearly 5,000 Chinese Red infantrymen pressed savage attacks today on the central and western Korean fronts, apparently as a propaganda gesture in a dying war.
ALBANY, July 25 -- New York State will begin soon to lend public health specialists to the Republic of Indonesia in a joint Federal-State project, Governor Dewey announced today.

QUANTICO, Va., July 25 -- President Eisenhower today heard his military chiefs set forth their views on global defense and civilian leaders outline their problems. The Commander in Chief sat in on the final session of the three-day conference of civilian and uniformed defense leaders called by Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense.

NEWARK, July 25 -- There was some talk again this week about Will A. Theuer retiring as vice president of the National State Bank, now that he is past his eighty-third birthday and has completed sixty-four years of service.

Recently you published a very interesting letter from Robert P. Skinner, who suggested that our wheat surplus would vanish if we ate as much bread as the Italians do. Your correspondent attributed our relatively low rate of flour consumption to the quality of our bread.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 25 -- Jack Kelly Jr. of the Philadelphia Vesper Boat Club won the singles sculling title for the third time and then added the senior doubles to his triumphs as the four-day Royal Canadian Henley regatta ended today.

NOT long before the outbreak of the last war the city of Venice launched a series of exhibitions of her greatest painters. Their twin purpose was to reassert the glories of the Venetian School and to provide special attractions for the alternate years between one Biennale and the next.

Never since Jan. 1, 1898, when the City of Brooklyn and Queens and Richmond Counties were added to what is now New York City, have the voters of the city been confronted with such a confused political situation preceding a municipal election.

IF the United States Air Force can hang jet power pods on some of its multi-million-dollar bombers like the Consolidated Vultee B-36 (adding four new turbine engines to its six conventional power plants) and the Boeing B-47 six-jet Stratofortress that crossed the country in less than four hours, then the operators of commercial airlines can do the same with their transports.

WHEN Casey Stengel was managing Brooklyn Dodgers many years ago, his maladroit and hapless heroes had just lost a double-header to the Cincinnati Reds in typically preposterous fashion, thereby extending their long losing streak to heaven knows what. After the second game, Stengel dropped into a barber shop and ordered a shave.

NICE things do happen. A Dartmouth chap, in celebration of a fiftieth reunion, handed over to The Baker Library of Dartmouth College a Charles Dickens' annotated copy of Samuel Pepys' "Diary" (a four-volume job plus a volume of Pepys' correspondence).

WESTPORT, Conn., July 25 -Bob Huggins of the Winchester (Mass.) Boat Club sailed his Shady Too to victory in the opener today of the annual three-race Long Island Sound Snipe sailing championship off the Cedar Point Yacht Club.
DEL MAR, Calif., July 25 (UP) -- Lucky Star Stable's Fortune Teller led from the start today to win the $11,300 Oceanside Handicap at Del Mar, opening-day feature of the track's fourteenth season.

Concerning the excellent article by Richard N. Gardner, "What Would Cecil Rhodes Say?" (June 28) and commented upon by J. M. Macdonnell and yourself I would like to be permitted to express a fact or two regarding it.

POSTMASTER General Arthur E. Summerfield's announcement that the over-the-roads hauling industry is to be honored with a commemorative in October completes his philatelic program for 1953. Of the thirteen special stamps being issued, six have been released and seven are in preparation.

The Ford Foundation has given Columbia University a grant of $280,000 to be used for the continuation and expansion of the work of the National Manpower Council. The council, consisting of distinguished citizens from all parts of the country, is engaged in an appraisal of the country's significant manpower problems and policies in a period of enduring emergency.

Girls who have sought "a little extra" exposure to the hot summer sun by wearing somewhat more abbreviated costumes in the parks than they would attempt in the city's streets will discover to their dismay that henceforth, even in the parks, they must "cover up."

As a lay observer of the film scene, I have occasionally felt somewhat dubious concerning certain American photoplays selected to compete at the various highly-publicized European film festivals. In several instances, the choice has fallen upon a "good" picture, while others that could be rated "excellent" were ruled out on the pretext of technicalities, many of which seem flimsy, indeed.

UPPER LAKE, Calif., July 25 -- The Rev. Jack R. McMichael, Methodist minister subpoenaed to appeal before the House Committee on Un-American Activities to be questioned on whether he had Communist affiliations, said today that whether he could present a convincing case for himself depended on "whether the committee will be fair and judicial."

TOPEKA, Kan., July 25 -- The Kansas Turnpike Authority completed plans this week for an engineering study of a four-lane toll road that when completed would link Kansas City, Kan., Topeka, and Wichita.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, has said he is convinced Russia will not start a European war.

HAVING, four months ago, routed out the news that Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin, producers of the current Cole Porter - Abe Burrows musical hit, "Can - Can," had reached an agreement with Mr. Porter to work together again, the departmental ferret now brings to light the fact that the musical Mr. Porter will do is "Ninotchka."

TORONTO, July 25 (AP) -- Australia sent two of its Davis Cup stars into the final round of the Canadian tennis championships today but failed to win one title when Melita Ramirez of Mexico retained her women's singles crown.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 25 -- Western savants who are meeting here to discuss freedom of science within the framework of the modern state demonstrated today the meaning of this freedom in the West compared with the subjection of science to official doctrine in the Soviet world.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A lot of people had been "educated" to expect quietly falling prices about this time. Some reputable forecasters had said the steam was out of inflation, that the dollar would be worth more.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 25 -- The United Nations has retained a New York law firm headed by two former members of the United States delegation to the United Nations to help handle personnel, visa, passport and other problems arising out of United States legislation and executive orders.

There is a morbid fascination in dying a thousand new deaths as we reread the chronicles of the years of appeasement and war.

GARDENERS who have already planted the summer-flowering bulbs Lycoris squamigera and Ismene calathina know they have some interesting bloom to watch for. Others who did not include them in their planting scheme for this year may want to consider them for the future.

To Hyman Kirsch, Simferopol in Russia's Crimea seems no further from Brooklyn than No-Cal is from the soft drink syrups he compounded there before the turn of the century. No-Cal is a soft drink brand which is described as the fastest growing in its field.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 25 (AP) -- A major preview of 3-year-olds for the $100,000 Hambletonian Stakes is scheduled for Wednesday night at Roosevelt Raceway when a large field lines up for the $30,000 Old Country Trot.

THE Joint Chiefs of Staff picked by President Eisenhower to guide the destinies of the nation's armed services for the next two years are now assuming office in a period of both internal and external changes. They take charge only a few months after an almost complete change-over in the Pentagon's civilian directorate, and at a time when the Defense Department reorganization has just gone into effect.
Adoption of new commission rates for the New York Stock Exchange seems virtually certain to take effect on Aug. 17.

PROTESTANT, Anglo-Irish and in his fifties, Arland Ussher is a descendant of an old Ascendancy family; his published writings range from studies of Existentialism to an English verse translation of that merry eighteenth-century Gaelic poem, "The Midnight Court."

PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 25 -- This little village, which lies between the battle lines, is now ready for the final signing ceremony that is to bring a halt to the more than three-year-old war in Korea.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., July 25 (AP) -- Third-seeded Gerald Moss, Miami Beach, upset the defending champion, Jon Douglas, Santa Monica, Calif., today for the Western junior tennis title.

Fall buying in the ready-to-wear wholesale market here last week was stimulated by exceptional values, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. Stores expect heavy fall business. Deliveries appear to be good and should remain so with the possible exception of cashmere coats, which have been ordered in large quantities.

Color, bane of television receiver producers in the months ahead, will prove a boon in the next five years, according to industry statisticians. Imminence of color is slowing down sales of black and white receivers, but it presents a challenge to the industry in that it holds the prospect of full replacement of the 24,500,000 sets now in use.

TOKYO, Sunday, July 26 -Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations commander, announced that agreement was reached today on an armistice in the three-year-old Korean war. He said the agreement would be signed at 10 A. M. tomorrow [9 P. M. Sunday, Eastern daylight time].

The tendency of turtles toward longevity and of man toward perpetuating his memory by carving initials and dates on anything -- including turtles -- has presented the Bronx Zoo with a box tortoise that may be at least 109 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -House of Representatives investigators, capping a story of wartime intrigue and murder, reported today that there was sufficient evidence to indict two former United States soldiers for the Holohan slaying, but said that there was no legal way to prosecute them.

A HIGHLY simplified and earnest little novel, "Summer Street." Only four characters are involved in its story of a turbulent experience of adolescence. The central and point-of-view figure is Mick, "a 16-year-old male animal with the down on his upper lip already dark and toughening."

AS Malcolm Cowley observed in a recent magazine article, a goodly portion of the so-called "new" fiction concerns a short period of time during which practically nothing happens -- a period as lived, observed or remembered by either a child or an old person.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 25 -- The dollar volume of general business activity in the Ninth Federal Reserve District showed a 3 per cent gain over 1952 for the first half of the year, reports to the Minneapolis bank showed. Northwestern Wisconsin with a 10 per cent increase and upper Michigan, where a revived copper industry helped to establish a 6 per cent gain, led the parade.

The eight-day assembly of Jehovah's Witnesses at the Yankee Stadium will end today with what by all indications will be the most heavily attended session of all.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- Continuing on the high plane of recent months, the durable goods industry showed no over-all change in employment in June, although wages and working time declined 1 per cent. Employment fluctuations in the major durable industries groups, according to the Department of Research at the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank ranged from a decrease of 4 per cent in furniture to an increase of 2 per cent in plants producing miscellaneous articles.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 25 -Two teen-age Bayonne boys, charged with breaking into the Elizabeth Armory early Thursday, have admitted participation in a series of hold-ups that netted them $1,500 in cash, Detective Capt. August F. Winkelmann said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 25 -- The conclusion of an armistice in Korea will confront the United States with perhaps the most complex diplomatic problem in its history: What to do about the Communist Government that has won control over the nation with the largest population on earth.

AS the curtain is ready to descend on the 1953 session of Congress, the country once more witnesses the end-of-the-session legislative jam that has become a familiar feature of the last days of our national legislature. And once again Senators are heard complaining about the last-minute rush to pass important bills and objecting to "this gun-point method of law making."

A FAMILY of Polish D. P.'s named Voda arrive, as the story opens, in a farming community in Alabama. Little Tilka, a war-orphaned cousin whom the Vodas have adopted, has a hard time fitting into the strange new surroundings.

SEOUL, July 25 -- South Korea has suffered enormous devastation and extreme hardships as a result of the war. The damage after three years of conflict fought over almost every acre of South Korea is greater than that suffered by any other country in modern history.

Few persons ever reach the ripe old age of 94 -- a fact to which the statistics in any of the nation's hundreds of insurance company offices attest. The financial community has just had another trying week. With investor enthusiasm dampened by the tedious effort to fashion a truce in Korea and by other uncertainties in international relations, security markets continued to move in low gear along the same indecisive course that has been followed for the last month.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 25 -- Victor Seixas of Philadelphia, champion of Wimbledon, will defend his Pennsylvania state turf tennis title tomorrow against his Davis Cup team mate, Tony Trabert of Cincinnati, in the final at the Merion Cricket Club.

CONCORD, N. H., July 25 -- Governor Gregg announced today that he would not appoint a successor to Senator Tobey until after the funeral services. He joined with other top state officials in refraining from discussing who would succeed Mr. Tobey.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 25 -- Doug Ford of Harrison, N. Y., birdied four of the last five holes for a third-round 5-under-par 67 today and pulled up even with Earl Stewart Jr. of Dallas with a fifty-four-hole score of 202 in the Kansas City Open golf tournament.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 25 -- The new Central African Federation is looking to the United States for "billions of dollars" in commercial investment needed for development, Sir Godfrey Huggins, who will be appointed first Prime Minister of the federation, has indicated in an interview here.
DETROIT, July 25 (AP) -- Plastic-body autos are getting considerable engineering attention right now but years may pass before they become commonplace.

How to protect widows of employes who have died before retirement, or shortly thereafter, from serious loss of income is being recognized more widely as a major problem in employe welfare planning. There is a growing demand for greater effort to increase such protection.

Her story opens as two knights, Jean de Metz and Bertrand de Poulengy, ride through Vaucouleur toward the house where Joan is staying to offer allegiance in her divinely appointed task of freeing France from the English.

SINCE nursing and aviation are two of the careers uppermost in the minds of many girls, "Sue Morris: Sky Nurse" should find a large and eager audience. Miss Deming, author of the Penny Marsh series and other stories of nursing careers, knows her chosen subject well.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Cut flowers for bouquets only in early morning or evening. If they are to last, conditioning overnight or at least several hours is essential. That is, after stripping the leaves from the stems and making a fresh slantwise cut, flowers are placed in a pail of water in a cool, dim place. Queen Anne's lace and other roadside blooms eke out the scanty garden supply now.

DALLAS, Texas, July 25 -Scattered showers this week over a good portion of the Southwest improved the farm and ranch outlook in the eleventh Federal Reserve District, but the showers were spotty and nowhere were they considered drought-breaking.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Congress is about to adjourn some of its problems to next January but it is not adjourning Topic A in Washington -- that is, speculation about the present and future standing of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 25 -Seventeen thousand visitors have paid a half dollar each to go through Sagamore Hill, one-time summer White House and home of Theodore Roosevelt, which was dedicated last month as a national shrine by President Eisenhower.

QUANTICO, Va., July 25 -- President Eisenhower has ordered the Third Marine Division to the Far East Command for use as Gen. Mark W. Clark, United States and United Nations commander in the Far East, may decide.

MARGOT PINTER, a young German pianist who has not yet appeared in this country, is featured by Urania in two disks devoted to piano concertos on the periphery of the repertoire -- Tchaikovsky's No. 2 in G and the Khatchaturian.

DESPITE severe drought in some regions the 78,000,000 acres planted to wheat this year by American farmers the country over are producing another good harvest. And that adds to what has become an almost perennial problem -- a surplus of America's chief bread grain. The forecast output of 1,174,708,000 bushels, combined with 575,000,000 already on hand, make a record supply.

TOKYO, Sunday, July 26 -- The Government-controlled Chinese radio charged today that "American bellicose elements" had encouraged President Syngman Rhee of South Korea to maintain resistance to an armistice.

HAVANA, July 25 -- The dreaded Aedes Aegypti, the mosquito carrier of yellow fever, also is responsible for an epidemic of equine encephalitis that in the past few weeks has killed twenty-five persons and 20,000 horses throughout Cuba, according to Dr. Alberto Recio, Director General of Public Health.

MOLLOSUND, Sweden -Here in this sleepy little fishing village on the west coast of Sweden, where the savings bank opens listlessly every Wednesday just in case, you almost don't need money. Certainly you don't need much. A room costs 80 cents a night single, $1.20 double.

QUANTICO, Va., July 25 -- President Eisenhower expressed the belief in a letter made public today that "the Communist empire" would disintegrate.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 25 -- Six of the outstanding trotters stabled at the Roosevelt Raceway track engaged in a junior free-for-all worth $5,000 tonight and they came up with a thriller. WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -The Council of Motion Picture Organizations contended today that repeal of the 20 per cent tax on movie theatre tickets actually would mean more revenue for the Government than if the tax stayed on.

The superliner United States has entered her second year of operation with an impressive docking performance. The big ship arrived here last Tuesday along with her running mate, the America.

PARIS, July 25 -- The decision of the three Western powers for a Foreign Ministers' conference with the Russians as a substitute for or a prelude to a meeting "on the highest level" brought hostile comment this week from Moscow and from Clement R. Attlee, British Labor party leader.

LONDON, July 25 (Reuters) -Rain limited play to one hour and 40 minutes in the third day of the fourth test cricket match between England and Australia at Leeds today. In that time, the English team scored 62 for one wicket in the second innings, to trail by 37 runs.

SYRACUSE, July 25 (AP) -- Billy Graham and Carmen Basilio battled twelve torrid rounds to a draw tonight at War Memorial Auditorium with one official rating them even and the other two split on the winner. Each boxer weighed 147 pounds.

NEWARK -- The handsome new passenger terminal at Newark Airport, which the Port of New York Authority will dedicate on Wednesday, has an abundance of space and a welcome assortment of conveniences provided solely for the airlines' customers.

COLORADO SPRINGS, July 25 (AP) -- Dick Spangler of Lincoln, Neb., and E. J. Rogers Jr. of Oklahoma City will meet tomorrow in the final of the thirty-third annual Broadmoor invitation golf tournament.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 25 (AP) -- Hal Price Headley, thoroughbred horseman who took over the management of Beaumont Farm at the age of 19 because of the illness of his father, said today that he was disposing of all of his broodmares.

Steve Oven, coach of the New York Football Giants, who perfected the A formation, plans to introduce another new offensive system, the Swing T, into National Football League this fall. Owen will begin teaching the system to the Giants when they open training at St. Peter, Minn., on Saturday.

DEPARTMENT stores and specialty shops throughout the nation raised their net profit six-tenths of 1 per cent in the first quarter of 1953, compared with 1952. WEST POINT, N. Y., July 25 -Ray Fisher of Michigan was named college baseball's Coach of the Year today, it was disclosed by Chairman Paul Amen of Army, who tabulated the votes of the American College Baseball Coaches Association.

YOUNG readers were introduced to the Norstrom family and their unusual home aboard a Chinese junk in "The House With Red Sails." This story takes the Norstroms down the Atlantic seacoast from New Rochelle. N. Y., to Williamsburg, Va. Captain and Mrs. Norstrom and their children -- Woodie, Gerald and Debbie -- are joined for the trip by salty old Uncle Dan and a young Chinese friend.
