SAIGON, Vietnam, July 25 -Informed French quarters here were dubious today over the possibility of an adjustment of relations between Cambodia and France. There was the belief among some officials that the prospects for an agreement had been improved by recent developments.

DANNY KAYE and his wife, Sylvia Fine, have embarked on an attempt to bring to the screen something of the comedian's personality they feel has been lacking in his previous film efforts. Together with Melvin Frank and Norman Panama, two youthful veterans of writing, producing and directing motion pictures, they are going to try to prove that films can capture the quality of spontaneity which Kaye reveals on stage before an audience.

Another blow at pollution in New York Harbor will be struck at 2:30 P. M. next Wednesday when Mayor Impellitteri is scheduled to take part in ceremonies formally putting into operation the new $2,500,000 sewage treatment works at Port Richmond, S. I.

MEXICO CITY, July 22 -- By the yardstick of the betting handle, the one that counts most in judging a race track's success, Mrs. Deborah Rood Everitt has passed her first season as boss of the Hipodromo de las Americas with flying colors -- turquoise blue, it might be said, since these are Mrs. Everitt's own racing colors.

INWOOD, L. I., July 25 -- Fourth-seeded Harold MacGuffin of New York scored an upset victory over second-seeded Berkeley Bell of Cresskill, N. J., ranked first nationally, today to enter the final round of the eastern senior tennis championships at the Inwood Country Club.

Police Lieut. Arthur Miller may have quietly removed himself from the Police Department rolls under an Administrative Code provision providing automatic dismissal upon five consecutive days' unauthorized absence, it was said at Police Headquarters yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- A Senate-passed bill with a potential built-in pay increase for Congressmen was assailed today by two members of the House of Representatives as "sneaky, crooked" and "a backdoor approach."

BOSTON, July 25 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, tanned but still twenty pounds under his normal weight of 161 pounds, left for home tonight after undergoing a final check-up by the surgeon who operated on him for a gall bladder ailment June 11.

A NEW inexpensive enlarger for beginners in photographic darkroom work was announced last week by Federal Manufacturing and Engineering Corp., 213 Steuben Street, Brooklyn 5. The $24.95 Federal Model 240 Store-Away Compact Enlarger, which is the second enlarger at this price to appear on the market (the other is the $24.95 FR Enlarger), takes negatives up to 2 1/4x3 1/4 inches and is quickly stored in self-contained carrying case.

DETROIT, July 25 -- The American League's rollicking pennant race took another weird turn today as the Yankees, apparently on their way toward another thrashing, which would have been their fifth in a row, staged a miraculous recovery.

RYE, N. Y., July 25 -- Yves Bertranet, who embarked in a homemade catamaran on Wednesday evening from Great Neck, L. I., bound on a 3-800-mile sailing-drifting Atlantic crossing to France, was just 3,812 miles short of his goal today.

WHEN Eartha Kitt's carefully exuberant style of vocalizing was introduced in New Faces of 1952, she appeared to be a particularly promising entertainment personality. STAMFORD, Conn., July 25 -- Stamford Yacht Club staged a new power cruiser race today, a predicted log test for the Mortimer L. Doolittle Memorial Trophy.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 25 (UP) -- The United States completed a 5-0 sweep of its second-round American zone Davis Cup Tennis series with the British West Indies today when Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., and Bob Perry of Los Angeles scored straight set victories.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 25 -- Win or lose, Jose Figueres has so dominated Costa Rica's election campaign that tomorrow's voting for a new President has been reduced to the simplest of issues: for or against the avowed Socialist who led and won the so-called civilians' revolution of 1948.

TO the hardy, superstitious pioneers in the Lake Michigan wilderness, the giant white sturgeon was a living legend -- a portent of disaster. It seemed to make its ghostly appearance always at the height of tempestuous storms on that great, unpredictable body of water, and the bodies of many a shipwrecked crew gave substance to the legend.

MAN has known about as long as he has known anything, that blood means life. Today people are more than ever conscious of the importance and mystery of this warm, red fluid. Millions of Americans are giving their own blood to save the lives of soldiers in Korea and to supply such blood fractions as gamma globulin, which is being used against polio in epidemic areas this summer.

AFTER seven weeks without a rain that amounts to anything, certain flowers and plants stand out handsomely among others in my garden. They have not wilted even with day after day of brilliant sun and drying winds. In fact, the foliage of a notable few has stayed green and their flowers continue to open, whereas many other annuals and perennials have stopped growing or have turned brown.

THIS is as good a time as any to start a compost pile, and there are several ways in which it can be done. Compost is, of course, decayed organic matter that is used to fertilize or recondition soil. Almost any plant material (such as leaves, grass and hay) may be used. It is not advisable, however, to use diseased plants.

Three-run homers by Willard Marshall and Jim Greengrass in the wake of glaring Giant errors gave Cincinnati six unearned runs at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The result was a 7-5 victory for Rogers Hornsby's Redlegs that dampened the New Yorkers' hopes of making further progress in the National League pennant race.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., July 25 -- A new skirmish in the transatlantic battle over the production of civil and military airplanes developed today when it was disclosed that the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation had taken steps toward a multimillion dollar program for a high speed, jet-powered cargo plane.

Hours were long and tempers short in Congress last week. Both houses were trying to wind up their affairs and adjourn at the end of the month. The Senate, which was considerably further behind than the House, plunged into a series of twelve and fourteen-hour sessions.

PITTSBURGH, July 25 (UP) -A home run by Dee Fondy, his fourth hit of the game, broke up a ninth-inning deadlock today and gave the Cubs a 5-4 triumph over the Pirates.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., July 25 -Commuters here, doubled in numbers in the summer because of the influx of vacationists headed for near-by lakes, were assured today by Ralph F. Hopkins, Parking Authority chairman, that the off-street parking area near the railroad station would be opened in three weeks.

THIS is the signing-off piece. By the time it appears I hope to be well west of the Mississippi. To be exact, by the time this Sunday's issue is thumping down outside your door, I should be in the Canadian province of Alberta, watching the sun-dance of the Bloods, who are the Canadian branch of the Blackfeet.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 25 -- Continuing his bid to win his second district title, Joe Gagliardi, 41-year-old Winged Foot representative, gained the final of the Metropolitan Amateur Golf Championship at the Fenway Club today along with Wilson Barnes Jr. of Mount Kisco.

" ESTIMATES on Florida's tourist business last year, recently completed by the state's Chamber of Commerce, point up the importance of the summer season there, which is now at its peak. According to the State Chamber, around 4,950,000 tourists visited Florida during the twelve months of 1952 and spent $900,000,000 while vacationing there.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (UP) -- Robin Roberts pitched his seventeenth victory of the season and his second straight shut-out tonight as the Phillies defeated the Cardinals, 3 -- 0, before 27,003 at Connie Mack Stadium.
More than fifty members of the low-handicap women's Tri-County Golf Association will start in the ninth Tri-County championship at the Old Oaks Country Club, Purchase, N. Y., tomorrow.

MUNICH, Germany, July 25 -- A Czechoslovak mechanic ripped the Iron Curtain in a home-made armored car today and escaped to West Germany with seven other persons under the noses of a stunned Czech border patrol.

During the week just ended President Eisenhower entered the second six months of his term. Asked in his Wednesday press conference to give an estimate of the progress made, he thought there had been some, but added that he had not gone as fast as he would like. And legislatively, at least, if present adjournment plans are carried out, only five days remain to get something done this summer.

BECAUSE of union restrictions American jazz bands cannot play in England and English jazz combinations cannot play here. But this week James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, is meeting Hardie Ratcliffe, secretary of the British Musicians' Union, in Paris, and the indications are that they will work out a scheme to end the two-way ban. What is expected is an exchange!
MEXICO CITY, July 25 -- An agreement was announced today between Mexican and United States shrimp boat owners.

POPILLIA JAPONICA is a handsome insect just under a half-inch long with "gorgeous" metallic green coloring and coppery wing covers. It is also one of the most notorious pests ever to entrench itself in this country.
STUDENTS of the West have reason to rejoice. Muriel Sibell Wolle's long-awaited book on mining camps turns out to be a successful digging of a rich historical vein.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee voted tonight to restore almost half of the $1,115,050,575 cut in President Eisenhower's foreign aid program ordered earlier this week by the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -Following is the text of a letter from President Eisenhauer to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of the West German Republic as released today by the White House. It was dated July 23, 1953:

SAN ANTONIO, July 25 (AP) -Dolores Ann Dwyer, the 1952 United States Olympic star competing unattached, became the first champion crowned in the National Amateur Athletic Union Senior Track and Field Meet tonight when she captured the 200-meter dash.
CLEVELAND, July 25 (UP) -- Al Rosen hit his twenty-sixth home run of the season with two out in the tenth inning today to give the Indians a 6-4 triumph over the Senators before 9,560 fans.

What is expected is an exchange!

Expansion of governmental administration by separate authorities rather than by city and county government was urged yesterday by Goodhue Livingston, a member of the City Planning Commission.

KANSAS CITY, July 26 (AP) -- Ed (Porky) Oliver of Palm Springs, Calif., set a new tournament record of 269 -- nineteen strokes under par -- in winning the $17,500 fifth Kansas City open golf tournament today.

CLEVELAND, July 26 (UP) -- Bobby Avila hit his sixth home run of the year in the eighth inning to enable the Indians to gain a 7-6 victory over Washington today after Senators tallied two unearned runs in the ninth inning to win the opener, 4-3, before a crowd of 24,460.

Record sales and services for the quarter and six months ended June 30, resulted in increases of 43 and 61 per cent, respectively, in earnings of the Radio Corporation of America and its subsidiaries, David Sarnoff, board chairman, revealed in his report today.

Sales and operating revenues of the Aluminum Company of America and its subsidiaries increased more than 30 per cent in the first half of this year from those in the like 1952 period, and net income rose nearly 17 per cent, the company reported yesterday.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 26 -- Armed with newly won legal power to curb political opposition, the Government planned today to proceed with an investigation of the small conservative Nation party.

Appearing on the eve of the Korean truce, the new fifty-year history of the Soviet Union's Communist party is undoubtedly an authoritative statement of the post-Beria party line. As such, it is being studied carefully for any clues it may yield to future Soviet policy, particularly those aspects of that policy which bear on the central question of war or peace in the future.

SCHROON LAKE, N. Y., July 26 -- Nearly 1,000 vacationers and local residents of this Adirondack resort town crowded the Central High School auditorium here tonight to hear an extemporaneous address by Alben W. Barkley, the former Vice President.
ITHACA, N. Y., July 26 -- The truant officer, villain in the minds of generations of errant school children, is yielding his job to the professionally trained attendance teacher.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, said today that the Justice Department had evidence against "several people who have betrayed the United States" but could not legally prosecute them.

The United States privately owned ocean-going tanker fleet, at present the largest in the world, increased its size by one third during the last fourteen years, the National Federation of American Shipping said yesterday.
Grants totaling $1,944,151 for seventy-nine medical schools, including $218,048 for nine schools in this state, were announced yesterday by the National Fund for Medical Education.

IN June of 1950, when the Korean war began, Philip Deane was in Athens as the correspondent of The London Observer. A few weeks later, on July 23, he was a prisoner of the North Koreans. Wounded in his right shoulder, right hand and four times in his left thigh, with his hands tied behind his back with telephone wire, stripped to his underpants, Mr. Deane faced a bleak future as a civilian internee.

VIENNA, July 26 -- The amnesty announced early this morning by the Hungarian Government is as remarkable for crimes it does not as for those it does cover. It cancels all prison sentences up to two years to which the conditions apply and remits one-third of those over two years.
MOSCOW, Monday, July 27 -- Leonid G. Melnikov, former Ukrainian party secretary, has been named Soviet Ambassador to Rumania, it was announced today.

Much needed rain fell on the drought-stricken Cotton Belt last week. As a result cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange drifted into lower territory. At the close of trading on the exchange on Friday final prices for the week were off 55 cents to $1.25 a bale.

SEATTLE -- The Pacific Northwest is comparatively young country with a constantly growing population. There has not been time to develop traditions, culinary or otherwise.
AIX LES BAINS, France, July 26 (UP) -- Elie Bayot of France in an Osca won the Grand Prix auto race today, covering the 240 kilometers in 2 hours 22 minutes 45.4 seconds.
PARIS, July 26 (AP) -- Louison Bobet, a 28-year-old one-time baker, today won the fortieth running of the Tour de France bicycle race, giving France its first victory in six years.
The end of the shooting in Korea must inevitably invite a stock-taking. Where do we stand now and where do we go from here?

A steady tone that prevailed in the foreign exchange market during the past week caused rates to be confined to a limited movement. Dealings were reported to be only moderate in size and mostly routine.

BERLIN, July 26 -- With West Berlin's program to give away food to a million residents of East Berlin and East Germany due to begin tomorrow the Communist war of nerves against potential beneficiaries of the plan reached a climax.

The pleasantly rolling banks of Little Neck Bay, at Kings Point, L. I., where the late automobile executive Walter P. Chrysler used to survey the lawns of his twelve-acre estate from a luxurious cream-colored mansion, are teeming with activity these days.

HONG KONG, July 10 -- After three years of reconstruction, the Chinese Communists have launched their first five-year plan this year with the objective of industralizing agricultural China just as the Communists industrialized the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Office of International Trade of the United States Department of Commerce has come to the conclusion that prospects for a sharp increase in American private investments abroad is improbable "in the next few years."

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Korean armistice was hailed in Washington tonight as a victory for the United Nations, a disastrous and costly defeat for Communist aggression, and a sizable political asset for the six-month-old Administration of President Eisenhower.

The Welfare and Health Council of New York City has named J. Donald Kingsley as its executive director, effective next Monday, Carl M. Loeb Jr., president, announced yesterday. Mr. Kingsley, former United Nations Agent General for Korean Reconstruction and former Director General of the International Refugee Organization, succeeds Raymond M. Hilliard, who resigned on June 15.

PARIS, July 26 -- Officials here believe that the French Government has a good chance of keeping prices stable until the end of the year, providing measures can be taken in the next few weeks to offset some unfavorable trends that have appeared, notably for meat, butter, steel and transport.

A problem posed by children's metal play coins that register in subway and elevated turnstiles as readily as the official 5-cent tokens was solved yesterday by Sidney H. Bingham, general manager of the New York City Transit Authority, who had helped to design the turnstiles in 1921.

SEOUL, Monday, July 27 (AP) -- The South Korean Foreign Minister, Pyun Yung Tai, promised last night that neither the people nor the Army of the Republic of Korea would revolt against the armistice "at this time."

LAKE HOPATCONG, N. J., July 25 -- Residents and summer visitors here and at other lakes in New Jersey are concerned over the lack of laws to curb reckless operation of motor boats on inland waters. Instances have been reported in recent weeks of some of the 3,500 registered motorboats here running wild, with irresponsible drivers at the wheel of the craft and the law standing by helplessly.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, July 26 -- The difficult annual task of assembling defense statistics from the fourteen North Atlantic treaty nations and preparing an over-all Allied defense program for next year is already threatened with delay.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 26 -- Wilson Barnes Jr., of the Mount Kisco Country Club, a newcomer to the tournament, won the fifty-third annual metropolitan amateur golf championship at the Fenway Golf Club today.
Five new films, including an importation from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Grain prices were mostly lower last week but near-by deliveries of corn and oats were notable exceptions. News from Korea discouraged buying. There was no improvement in export demand for wheat and weather conditions in the spring wheat country were favorable for crop growth and unfavorable for rust development.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, July 27 -- Korea got its truce at last today, and it was almost too weary and skeptical to believe it.

The eight-day New World Society Assembly of Jehovah's Witnesses closed shortly before dusk yesterday, with a vast throng from many lands listening quietly to its leader's portrayal of Armageddon -- "the war of the great day of God the Almighty" -- on which the forces of evil are to be destroyed.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 26 -- Victor Seixas wore the mantle of a Wimbledon champion in one of his shining performances today and won the Pennsylvania State turf court tennis crown for the third successive year.

LOS ANGELES, July 26 -- Fashions for all occasions from early daytime to dining and dancing plus lively accents of fun and lounge togs made up the showings on the first day of California Fall Dress Week. The featured designers were the affiliated Addie Masters, De De Johnson, Marjorie Montgomery, Irene M. Bury, Peggy Hunt and Jeannette Alexander.

Despite a faulty defense, which made for a hard first game and cost Larry Jansen a shut-out in the second, the Giants swept their getaway double-header with the Redlegs, 10 -- 6 and 5 -- 1, yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Two homers by Daryl Spencer, one with the bases loaded, and the fine relief hurling of Dave Koslo, who replaced Sal Maglie, marked the opener before 16,399 fans.

WILLIAMS GROVE, Pa., July 26 (AP) -- Jimmy Davies, a Van Nuys, Calif., veteran of the Korean war, set a track record today in winning the twenty-five-mile all-Indianapolis auto race at the Williams Grove Speedway.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial text of the Korean armistice agreement, as made public by the Stats Department today:

An investor has purchased the six-story apartment house for sixty-two families at 357 East 201st Street, northeast corner of Marion Avenue and Bedford Park, in the Bronx, from the Concourse Crescent Corporation. E. Osborne Smith, Inc., was the broker in the sale of the house, which contains apartments of two to four and one-half rooms.

ROME, July 26 -- At ten minutes to one yesterday morning weary buyers sitting in Florence's Pitti Palace on their fifth grueling day of viewing Italian fashions were still applauding with much more enthusiasm than they had ever shown in previous days. The reason was the entrance eight hours before of the star of the show --fabric.

I should like to comment on the wonderful surveys of the auto industry by Elie Abel and Joseph C. Ingraham which appeared in the July 20 issue, particularly because of the fact that this industry plays such a vital role in our over-all economic picture.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The drive for adjournment of Congress by Saturday appeared more certain of success today as the Eisenhower Administration privately indicated it could operate under the $4,562,664,000 foreign aid fund bill approved yesterday by the Senate Appropriations Committee.

ST. LOUIS, July 26 (AP) -- Jim Dyck's third home run of the day scored three runs in the seventh inning and enabled the Browns to beat the Red Sox, 8 -- 5, in the second game today after dropping the opener to Boston, 7 -- 5.
New accessories to give a fresh look to the home in the midsummer doldrums are on display in the gift shop of Bonwit Teller. Some of them might also make unusual presents for a weekend hostess.

ZURICH, July 26 -- In Zurich last week Interhandel shares jumped from 1,620 francs to 1,723 because of the action of Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat of New Mexico, in pressing for Congressional passage of his bill recommending that the Office of Alien Property return all West German property seized in the United States during World War II as enemy-owned.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 26 -- R. K. O. has handed Betta St. John, the Los Angeles dancer, her most important screen role and will co-star her in "Rangers of the North." She will join Victor Mature, with whom she worked in "The Robe," Piper Laurie, Vincent Price and William Bendix in the big Technicolor outdoor story.

PITTSBURGH, July 26 -- The steel rate rebounded into the upper 90's last week, along with the weather, which made the performance all the more outstanding. The ingot rate was up two points last week to 97 per cent of capacity. It may be that it will fluctuate between 93 and 98 per cent until vacations and hot weather are eliminated.

Lawrence E. Gerosa, a Bronx contractor, and Abe Stark, a Brooklyn merchant, were selected as running mates yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr., who was chosen last week by the Democratic organizations of Bronx and New York Counties as their candidate for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Diplomatic officials, searching the statement on Communist policy published in Moscow today, for political straws in the wind, reported generally that they had found none right away to grasp.

HAVANA, July 26 -- Fifty-five persons were reported killed and many more wounded in a rebellion today at Santiago de Cuba and near-by Bayamo. Martial law was imposed in Santiago following the uprising and military authorities began to round up members of revolutionary groups.

The third volume in the memoirs of James Boswell will be issued by McGraw-Hill on Oct. 19. "Boswell on the Grand Tour: Germany and Switzerland, 1764" picks up Boswell's story after his departure from Utrecht. It describes his stay in Berlin and his attempts to gain an audience with Frederick; his visits to other courts and his assuming the title of baron; his leaving Germany and traveling to Switzerland.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 26 -- James Cullen and James Lytell of North Hills matched par for seventeen holes to defeat Dr. Samuel Anziano and Dr. Joseph Teta of North Hempstead, 2 and 1, in the final of the twelfth annual Charles R. Casey Memorial member-guest tournament at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

Accessories contribute importantly to a costume. Now that the days are long and women sit enjoying holiday hours, they can keep their hands busy fashioning those extras that will enhance their early-autumn dresses.

Responding to the challenge of the second-place Braves with some magnificent pitching, timely hitting and brilliant fielding, the Dodgers yesterday beat Milwaukee twice, 3 -- 2 and 2 -- 1. The victories enabled the Brooks to leave on their third Western trip today holding a first-place margin of seven and one-half games.

A few hours from now, all along the line that runs across Korea from the mouth of the Imjin River on the Yellow Sea to the Sea of Japan below Kosong, men dazed by sudden silence will be rising to their feet. This moment, to their last days, they will remember, for it will give them back the gifts of life, of wholeness of body and of all the bright hopes of youth.
AMSTERDAM, July 26 -- The Netherlands Bank's liabilities last week were, for the first time since the war, covered by more than 100 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- President Eisenhower greeted the news of the Korean armistice tonight with prayers of thanksgiving but warned the nation that the Allies had won an armistice only on a single battleground and had not achieved peace in the world.

TOKYO, Monday, July 27 -- Communist and United Nations delegates in Panmunjom signed an armistice at 10:01 A. M. today [9:01 P.M., Sunday, Eastern daylight time]. Under the truce terms, hostilities in the three-year- old Korean war are to cease at 10 o'clock tonight [9 A. M., Monday, Eastern daylight time].

HARRISON, N. Y., July 26 -- Gus Salerno of Hampshire and Dave Lapkin won the Harrison Country Club pro-member tournament from eighty-nine rival teams with a 30, 33 -- 63 today as Lapkin tied the amateur competitive course record with 33, 34 -- 67.
OLD WESTBURY, L. I., July 26 In one of the finest polo games of the season, the 25-goal Nassau quartet scored a 7-3 victory over Palo Duro in the weekly high-goal game on Bostwick Field today.

Mayor Impellitteri appealed yesterday to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to try its hand at unscrambling the twenty-four-day strike of 1,800 drivers of sand, gravel and ready-mix concrete trucks in the metropolitan area.

The annual Viennese Night attracted 13,000 listeners to Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday evening. Jarmila Novotna and Charles Kullmann were the soloists, singing familiar shreds and patches from Johann Strauss, Kalman, Sieczynski and Lehar.

The staggering sum wanted by the New York City Transit Authority for physical improvements in the next few years pointedly emphasizes one reason why the fare has gone up to 15 cents. The Authority asks capital budget funds for the calendar year 1954 totaling $155,199,613, and for six years $1,065,000,000, including money for the delayed Second Avenue Subway.

Sales of General Mills, Inc., in its twenty-fifth year of operations ended on May 31, rose to a new high of $483,067,177, resulting in an increase in net earnings to $11,468,171 from the $9,549,466 earned in the preceding fiscal year, according to the annual report to be mailed to stockholders today.

PURCHASE, N. Y., July 26 -- William Trilling, a Long Island aviation executive, cruised the length and breadth of the island in somebody else's small green plane this week-end while a young Philadelphia couple spent the same week-end searching for the craft. Meanwhile, the small green plane in which Mr. Trilling had intended to fly remained securely tied down at Westchester County Airport here.

LONDON, June 26 -- The British Government announced today that it had made available to Pakistan a credit ofj u10,000,000 ($28,000,000) to enable her to purchase in Britain capital goods that would help solve her food problem.

There will be little variation in the buying trend for boys' and students' clothing next spring from that of the 1953 period, but sectional differences in fiber demand will be important, according to the first semi-annual survey on buying habits released by the Boys Apparel Buyers Association and the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.

BAIREUTH, Germany, July 26 -- Two Metropolitan Opera artists, Ramon Vinay. tenor, and Regina Resnik, soprano, figured importantly in tonight's "Die Walkuere" in the first of the two "Ring" cycles of the current Wagner festival.
TOKYO, Monday, July 27 (A. P.) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 255, for Sunday to 6 P. M.:

PARIS, July 26 -- French official quarters noted with satisfaction tonight the part of the Communist party statement issued in Moscow that renewed assertions of the possibility of a "long coexistence" of the socialist and capitalist systems. It was stated that French diplomatic circles would be eager to see this demonstration by the position of the Soviet Union in a four-power conference to smooth out the conflicts between these two systems in the world today.

MOSCOW, July 26 -- Analysis of today's 7,500-word declaration of the Communist party of the Soviet Union reveals that it is a document that marks an important milestone in party thought, as well as comprising a concise statement of principles and policies that are expected to guide the present Soviet leadership.

Extension of the Whitney Visiting Professors Program to include six additional appointees for 1953-54, who will be known as New York Foundation Professors, was announced yesterday by the New York Foundation and the John Hay Whitney Foundation.
THE 1,100 red plush orchestra seats taken up in the current Metropolitan Opera House reconstruction are going to odd places.
TORONTO, July 26 -- W. Garfield Weston, Canadian industrialist, has acquired control of Loblaw, Inc., of Buffalo, supermarket chain with 133 United States stores.
The fascination of a New Jersey mulberry tree for a bird, as yet unidentified, landed the bird in the Staten Island Zoo yesterday, where it was greeted by one of its new neighbors.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 26 -- Princess Ashraf, twin sister of the 34-year-old Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, was summarily ordered today to leave Iran immediately and given a sharp official tongue lashing for her unauthorized and unexpected arrival yesterday.

FOR about a year an international event of considerable magnitude has been building up quietly, mostly through the mails. The fruits will bloom on Long Island Sound off Oyster Bay in September when Six-Meter yachts of at least seven nations, and possibly ten, engage in a series of cup events that will match anything in yachting in this country for many seasons.

SEOUL, Monday, July 27 -- Syngman Rhee said today the armistice signed this morning at Panmunjom would not be disturbed by South Korean action for a "limited time" while an international political conference sought by peaceful means to unify the peninsula.

LONDON, July 26 -- British gratification at the Korean truce news was tempered in political circles tonight by the fear that when the killing stopped Western cooperation in the Far East might no longer be as easy as it had been.
LEXINGTON, Ky., July 26 (AP) -- A strong thoroughbred yearling market was forecast today for the Keeneland summer sales beginning tomorrow.
DETROIT, July 26 -- The Yankees wound up their third Western trip today, still swaying a bit uncertainly on the top of the American League.

BUENOS AIRES, July 26 -- The attention of Argentina was focused today on ceremonies marking the first anniversary of the death of Eva Peron. All activities, with the exception of transport and essential services, were brought to a half for twenty-four hours.

On April 29, last, President Eisenhower completed his 100th day in occupancy of the White House. For reasons that have never been entirely clear this somewhat synthetic event has come increasingly to be recognized in every editorial office throughout the country as a sort of prearranged signal to come out with a full dress appraisal of the new Administration and the performance of the President in particular.

The American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday the return of its first expedition to the French island of Madagascar. Ethnological material collected on the two-month expedition is now being studied by museum experts.

THE conflict that raged across the Korean Peninsula's barren rocky mountains, mud-glutted rice paddies, thatched villages and modern cities provided the United Nations with its first opportunity to take collective military action to "resist aggression" and restore peace.
Citations for heroism and meritorious acts in the line of duty have been made to 181 members of the Police Department. Commissioner George P. Monaghan announced yesterday.

NEWTON, N. J., July 26 -- A black cocker spaniel, Ch. Estadt's Tarheel, owned by Henry Steeger of New York, carried off the top award today in the Lake Mohawk Kennel Club's tenth annual show at Memory Park.

Times Square, a kind of real-estate barometer to a New Yorker's feelings about war and peace, was last night less than an echo of its V-J Day self when news that the Korean truce had been signed was flashed around the running sign on the Times Tower.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 26 -- The official newspaper of Jose (Pepe) Figueres claimed tonight an overwhelming victory for the National Liberation party candidate in Costa Rica's Presidential election, on the basis of unofficial returns showing Senor Figueres
The time for a "bill of women's rights in religion" is long overdue, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Henry Prince, head of the department of sociology at King's College, Halifax, N. S., said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The United States has agreed to join South Korea in walking out of the projected Korean political conference ninety days after it begins if this Government is convinced that the Communists are not negotiating in good faith and that further sessions would be futile.

Despite all the delays, threats and obstructions that its opponents could throw in the way, the Administration's refugee bill -- or a fairly reasonable facsimile thereof -- has at last cleared committees of both the Senate and the House and will presumably be acted on this week.

Fearing he would die soon and that his wife would be lonely without him, Charles Amato, 65 years old, a retired tailor, shot and killed Mrs. Amato, 60, as she lay asleep in their two-family house at 1253 Glenmore Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday at 2:50 A. M., the police reported.

LONDON, July 26 -- The quiet firmness of the stock markets continues despite the restricting influence the holiday season is exerting on public interest. However, this is by no means at an unsatisfactory level, having regard to the lack of anything like clarity in the business and economic outlook generally.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP) -- The Cardinals won a battle of extra base hits today, defeating the Phillies, 8 -- 6, with Stan Musial's thirteenth homer of the year -- a three-run blast in the sixth -- the deciding blow. Del Ennis hit a pair of round trippers for the losers to increase his total to twenty.

LONDON, July 26 -- Although somewhat impressed by the signing of a Korean armistice, diplomatic quarters here showed no sign today of relaxing their wait-and-see attitude toward Soviet protestations of its willingness to live in peaceful competition with the capitalist nations.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 26 (UP) -- Charlie Boswell of Birmingham, sightless master of the links, captured his sixth consecutive national championship today by winning the tournament for blind golfers, ten strokes ahead of his nearest rival.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 26 -- The Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association sailors, offered a day off by the schedule following the pressure of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week, didn't take advantage of the proffered rest today.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 26 -- Switzerland last week began its own television service from a transmitter atop a mountain overlooking this cosmopolitan city. And therein lies a video story perhaps unique in the medium's history.

BUFFALO, July 26 -- Harold C. Hanover, secretary-treasurer of the New York State Federation of Labor, asserted today that New York was slipping behind other states in the field of progressive social legislation. He called for a re-examination of such laws with the aim of improving them.
LAWRENCE, L. I., July 26 -Mrs. Philip Casher and her son, Melvin, 23 years old, were robbed by three armed thugs early this morning in their two-story frame house at 380 Broadway here.

Legislative action to compel steamship conferences to make their tariffs available to shippers will be sought if such groups continue in their refusal to publish this information on a voluntary basis.

The battle between Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia and the officers of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., over Anastasia's ouster as union boss of the Brooklyn docks may be confined to press releases, it was indicated yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 26 -- Promptly upon receiving formal notification of the signing of the Korean armistice, Lester B. Pearson of Canada, President of the General Assembly, issued a call tonight to member delegations for resumption on Aug. 17 of the suspended seventh Assembly session.

PITTSBURGH, July 26 -- During 1951 and 1952 the Maurice and Laura Falk Foundation made grants of $1,282,310, bringing its total disbursements since its establishment in 1929 to $6,288,783.23, according to a report published today.

PITTSBURGH, July 26 (AP) -- Johnny Klippstein relieved Bubba Church with the bases loaded in the eighth inning and halted a threat by the Pirates to preserve a 7-3 victory today for the Cubs in the second game of a twin-bill. Shortstop Roy Smalley's bobble of Eddie O'Brien's slow roller with two on in the ninth enabled the Bucs to gain a 3-2 triumph in the opener.

TOKYO, Monday, July 27 -- Chinese Communist troops threw "last hour propaganda" attacks at Allied forces on the central and western fronts of the rain-swept Korean battle line today, only a few hours before the armistice was signed at Panmunjom.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee declared that it had developed convincing evidence that the American school and college systems had been invaded to a dangerous degree by teachers bent on distorting education to Communist advantage.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 26 -- The Korean armistice marks the first time in history that an aggression has been checked by the forces of an international organization. It is therefore a notable victory for the United Nations and for the cause of collective security, even though earlier hopes of overthrowing the Communist regime in North Korea, which launched the attack, have not been fulfilled.

In an analysis of anxiety as the major ill affecting our age, the Rev. Dr. John M. Krumm, chaplain of Columbia University, yesterday characterized "American hysteria about communism" as "an outlet for our anxiety."
WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- The following is the text of a supplemental agreement on Korean prisoners of war made public today by the State Department:
MUNSAN, Korea, July 27 (UP) -- Following is the text of Gen. Mark W. Clark's armistice message to his United Nations Command:

HAGUE, N. Y., July 26 -- Lake George, which almost never is ruffled by a southeast breeze, had a beaut up to half-gale proportions for several hours this afternoon, and most of the speedboat pilots assembled here for the first regatta ever attempted by the Hague Chamber of Commerce shook their heads and started for home.

SEOUL, Korea, July 26 -- Tonight, on the eve of the armistice, front-line G. I.'s faced their last full night of fighting in the thirty-seven-month-old Korean war. Only a few minor clashes had taken place by early morning, and from all indications the war would be unofficially ended by dawn. No patrols were scheduled for tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -The Soil Conservation Service is ready to launch a coast-to-coast "pilot plant" demonstration of up-stream watershed flood control.

Two four-story apartment and store buildings at 1738 and 1742 Broadway in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn have been sold by Frank Fitzgerald, a plumbing contractor, to an investing client of Murray Selby, New York attorney, in a deal negotiated by George Brezel, vice president in charge of apartment house sales of Sydney M. Siegel Co., Kew Gardens brokers.

The Teachers Union, which was expelled from the American Federation of Teachers twelve years ago and from the Congress of Industrial Organizations three years ago as Communist-dominated, petitioned the State Education Department yesterday for reinstatement or vacation pay, or both, for eleven teachers suspended or dismissed by the Board of Education on June 18.

LONDON, July 26 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from an article in Pravda, Moscow Communist newspaper, outlining a party manifesto issued on the party's fiftieth anniversary, as broadcast from MOSCOW :
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of the agreement signed at Panmunjom on repatriation of prisoners of war in Korea, as made public today by the State Department:

Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, made public yesterday his Opinion No. 98, concerning services included in maximum rent. The date that determines the maximum rent is March 1, 1950, Mr. McGoldrick ruled.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today restoration of the people's confidence in Government had been the greatest accomplishment of the Eisenhower Administration in its first six months in office.

QUANTICO, Va., July 26 -- Defense officials attending the high-level defense conference at the Marine Corps base here predicted today that with any kind of "decent" Korean truce defense spending could be trimmed by as much as $1,000,000,000 in the next twelve months.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 26 -- A plumber and a Wall Street banker are burning the midnight oil in a work room on the top floor of the Town Hall, plugging leaks in the municipal budget.
The truce in Korea came as "a welcome anticlimax" to many of the nation's business and financial leaders.

Three wholly-owned subsidiaries of Joseph Bancroft Sons Company, textile finishers, dyers and printers, have rented the twenty-first and twenty-second floors in the twenty-two-story air-conditioned office building to go up at 1430 Broadway, on the former site of the Empire Theatre.

SAN ANTONIO, July 26 (AP) -- The Chicago Catholic Youth Organization, paced by Olympic star Mabel Landry, won the 1953 National A. A. U. senior women's track and field meet here last night, with a total of 102 2-5 points.

LEE, Mass., July 26 -- Residents of this small Berkshire County town want a new bridge across the Housatonic River in South Lee, but they do not want to lose the old wooden covered bridge that has served for more than a century.

CHICAGO, July 26 (UP) -- Virgil Trucks hurled his second consecutive shutout and gained his eighth straight victory today as the White Sox tripped the Athletics, 4 to 0, in the second game of a double-header before 21,149 fans. The Athletics won the first game, 4 to 3, as Bobby Shantz gained his fifth victory against seven defeats.

MUNSAN, Korea, Monday, July 27 -- The news that the truce was to be signed today did not touch off and wild celebration here. For the most part United Nations soldiers listened to the good word in solemn fashion. Then many shook their heads quietly and said, "Thank God!"
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, July 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, commander of the Eighth Army, on the Korean armistice:

Preaching on the feast of St. Anne, mother of the Virgin Mary, the Rev. James H. Griffin of the St. Patrick's Cathedral staff said yesterday that grandparents' love for their children's offspring was a manifestation of the human heart's continuing search for the kingdom of heaven.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified 295 Korean war casualties today in a list that included thirty-two killed, 215 wounded, fifteen missing and thirty-three injured. The following were from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

Almost precisely an hour after it had been announced last night that the Korean armistice had been signed, President Eisenhower went on the air to sound a note both of thanksgiving and of warning. With "solemn gratitude," he said, we welcome the end of the bitter fighting and the prospect of the return of our prisoners from behind the enemy lines.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 26 -Pakistan and India moved closer to agreement today on one of the major issues that have kept the contiguous nations in an armed neighbors' state of tension for more than Six years.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 26 (AP) -- Dizzy Dean and Al Simmons will be welcomed officially to the Hall of Fame tomorrow when their plaques will be dedicated at the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum.

Until yesterday it had been assumed that Shirley Booth's next local appearance would be in the Robert Fryer production of "Selena Peake," dramatized by Horton Foote from Edna Ferber's novel, "So Big." Instead the star, who is laden with acting tributes, has switched to "By the Beautiful Sea," a new musical about Coney Island at the turn of the century, written by Herbert and Dorothy Fields.

PARIS, July 26 -- Robert and Gerard Finaly, the two Jewish orphan boys, 12 and 10 years old, respectively, who had been surrendered to relatives after having been spirited across the Spanish border by Roman Catholic guardians, had left France and were in Israel today, but the controversy they stirred remained behind them.

Luis E. Heysen, in a recent letter discussing the sugar situation in Puerto Rico, says, "* * * Certainly one thing is apparent: That in order not to darken Puerto Rico's future she must be given a higher quota for her sugar, so that the actual surplus may be absorbed and ease to be a source of anxiety to the agriculturists."

SHORT CREEK, Ariz., July 26 -- Arizona authorities, under an unusual proclamation of insurrection, needed this remote farming hamlet on the state's northern border at dawn today and placed virtually the entire adult population under arrest in an effort to wipe out the nation's last remaining center of organized polygamy.

Many thousands of home owners are buying life insurance to pay off mortgages. Under this plan the home owner may obtain a mortgage tied in with a straight life policy and he makes a single monthly payment which covers the mortgage installment and the policy premium.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, has been named chairman of the state employes division for the New York United Service Organizations Defense Fund, Artemus L. Gates, fund president, announced yesterday.

SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, July 26 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark said tonight he was prepared to start shipping Communist prisoners of war to North Korea and Communist China within a "few days," but he thought it would be two or three weeks before American prisoners would reach the United States.

Four changes of officers of the Barber Line group of companies were announced here yesterday by Vincent G. Barnett, newly elected board chairman. Mr. Barnett succeeds Edward J. Barber, who died last month.

The police arrested four youths and confiscated seven guns and 100 rounds of ammunition yesterday in an investigation growing out of a teen-agers' rooftop gun battle on Wednesday in East Harlem in which a bystander was wounded critically.

BONN, Germany, July 26 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer opened today his general election campaign with a warning to the West German people to beware of right-wing nationalists whose increasing boldness of late had caused some concern.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- The Defense Materials Procurement Agency announced today the resignation of Tom Lyon, retired mining executive whose nomination as director of the Federal Bureau of Mines set off a controversy.

The blazing battlefront that for more than three years swayed back and forth across Korea in a holocaust of death and destruction has now been replaced by an armistice line; the guns stand mute; the free world offers prayers of thanksgiving that the slaughter is ended.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 27 -- Dr. Milton Eisenhower rounded out a five-day survey of Brazil today with a series of visits to Cabinet Ministers and Congressional leaders culminating in a final meeting with President Getulio Vargas.
MANHASSET, L. I., July 27 -- After an eight-year struggle the North Shore Hospital, a nonprofit community institution, opened today.

Your editorial on Postmaster Harold Riegelman's "spruce-up" order was quite correct as far as it went. But I think it missed an important point. While the order requires cleanliness and neatness of attire and appearance of postal employes, it directs postal clerks to be comfortable these hot days in short-sleeved, open-collared, blue sport shirts.

With Negro members dissenting, the Tammany executive committee designated Assemblyman Herman Katz of the Tenth District for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of Manhattan at a meeting yesterday at its headquarters, 331 Madison Avenue.
CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- With the supply the largest in three weeks, prices on hogs moved 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds lower today. Trading was slow on the decline.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 -- Mayor Elmer E. Robinson announced today that Gen. Mark W. Clark, the United Nations commander, would arrive here from Korea on Thursday morning and be honored at a public reception.

The New York City Transit Authority reported yesterday that the number of riders on the city's transit system declined Saturday and Sunday, the first two days of the 15-cent fare, as compared to the previous weekend, when the 10-cent fare was in effect.

At least three of the stage productions scheduled for Broadway this season will have as their setting American seaside communities. Two of the presentations, Norman Rosten's play, "Mardi Gras," and the Herbert and Dorothy Fields musical, "By the Beautiful Sea," take place in Coney Island.

The Korean war has written into history two dates that will be remembered for a long time to come. The first of these was June 26, 1950, when the United Nations Security Council, acting under the Charter, ordered the North Korean Communist aggressors to cease fire and go back beyond the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- The Defense Department said today it would take two weeks to compile tentative final figures on Korean war casualties but that even these would be subject to change for months.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 27 -- The end of hostilities in Korea was received today with tempered optimism by most United Nations delegates. Sir Gladwyn Jebb of Britain said the enduring significance of the armistice was that "aggression has been defeated by the United Nations and has been shown not to pay."

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- It is reliably reported that, in an official top- level discussion of the post-armistice courses of the United States in Korea, agreement was general that the Eisenhower Administration will not allow this nation to be bound by the policies of our allies in the United Nations to anything like the degree the Truman Administration was bound.

With the announcement that "although there has been a ceasefire order on the battlefields in Korea, there is no truce between any Reds in the Police Department and Monaghan," Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan discharged yesterday Lieut. Arthur Miller for his alleged Communist affiliations.

Since it has not been possible to report in great detail my address before the Colgate University Conference on American Foreign Policy I should like to call attention to some points which I feel are important.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- The House Judiciary Committee endorsed today the proposed New York-New Jersey commission to police the crime-ridden waterfronts of the two states.

PITTSBURGH, July 27 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company reported today record net sales of $232,658,635 for the first half of 1953, an increase of 19 per cent over the $196,255,715 for the same period in 1952.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to restore $20,000,000 that the House of Representatives slashed from funds of the State Department's controversial Overseas Information Program.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today the nominations of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler of New York, Dr. Karl T. Compton of Massachusetts and Warren Atherton of California to be members of the National Security Training Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Eisenhower today sent to the Senate the nomination of Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina to be a member of the United States delegation to the eighth session of the United Nations General Assembly, opening Sept. 15.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, told ninety youths attending the "Eighth Annual Boys Nation," sponsored by the American Legion, that the Korean war had been worth fighting because it made this country infinitely safer through the establishment of two great principles.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered motor carriers operating in New York State to stop collecting by Sept. 4 a surcharge levied on shippers to cover the cost to the carriers of the weight-distance tax on motor trucks which went into effect in October, 1951.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- James L. Murphy, young San Francisco import-export company official, has undertaken the task of seeking to rally the 2,000,000 or more members of the Citizens for Eisenhower into a series of Congressional committees designed to increase the Republican membership of the House of Representatives by seventy-five in next year's critical mid-term elections.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 219 Korean war casualties in a new list that reported 19 killed, 184 wounded, 7 missing and 9 injured. Issuance of these list lags some time behind the period when the casualties occurred.

A force of 206 Customs officers "cleaned up" the waterfront in short order yesterday. They processed 5,425 passengers coming ashore from thirteen vessels that arrived from foreign ports in seven hours.

The new history of the Soviet Communist party published throughout Russia Sunday apparently completes the propaganda task of reducing Stalin's heroic stature to modest proportions. Diplomatic observers believe it provides a new Communist guide to replace an earlier history, credited to Stalin's authorship, that had been supreme since 1939.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission has ordered the Champion Spark Plug Company, the General Motors Corporation and the Electric Auto-Lite Company to cease what it termed discrimination in the price of spark plugs sold for replacement.

HAVANA, July 27 -- President Fulgencio Batista warned his people today that his tolerance with the opposition was at an end as Cuban armed forces stamped out the last vestige of the revolt in Oriente Province and rounded up members of the opposition throughout the island.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Senate and House of Representatives Armed Services Committees today approved scores of military construction projects in this country and abroad.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress today on Korean rehabilitation:
The National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday that, on the basis of a recent survey of 189 industrial executives, there was little indication of a serious economic decline this year.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 27 -- Adios Betty, a 2-year-old bay filly by Adios -- Shy Ann was driven to a world record of 2:04 2-5 for pacing fillies over a half-mile track by Delvin Miller in the second division of the $20,067 Abbedale Stake at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 28 -- The United Nations and Communist commands pushed ahead today to carry out the terms of the armistice in Korea, as the guns ceased to sound along the battlefront and the troops began to fall back to set up a neutral buffer zone between the two armies.

Domestic steel mills operated at 94.4 per cent of theoretical capacity last week, or 0.3 point less than in the preceeding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. Production of ingots and steel for castings thus slipped 6,000 tons to 2,128,000 tons.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., July 27 -- A strike described by officials of the Atomic Energy Commission as "the first major one at atomic energy plants in the history of Oak Ridge" started today.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- The House passed a compromise bill today to abolish the twenty-one-year-old Reconstruction Finance Corporation and create a new agency to handle small business loans.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- Revised reports by unions show that the American Federation of Labor now has a membership of more than 10,000,000.

LONDON, July 27 (Reuters) -- The British Government will not take official action in the case of Cedric Belfrage, British editor of a left-wing paper who now is facing deportation proceedings in the United States, the House of Commons was told today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- Edward B. Williams, attorney, moved today to have dismissed as defective an indictment charging Representative Ernest K. Bramblett, Republican of California, with false statements in connection with his office payroll.

The summer is pleasant in a good many ways. The beaches, for example, form an attractive rim for a swimming pool stretching to Europe. The mountains are green, the black bass are hungry, and sometime during the summer there comes that brief foretaste of Utopia known as vacation.

SEOUL, Korea, July 27 -- With the signing today of the armistice in the Korean war the relationship between the United Nations Command and the South Korean Government surprisingly took its most encouraging turn since Maj. Gen. Choi Duk Shin, South Korean delegate to the truce talks, began to boycott the Panmunjom meetings May 25.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- The House of Representatives today approved three measures affecting the Indian, including the ban on selling intoxicants to them.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to close a legal loophole that had allowed many motion picture stars to build up tax-free fortunes while they lived and worked overseas.

The Erie Railroad announced yesterday that it would acquire direct ownership of two companies whose properties it now operates under lease. These are the Sharon Railway and the Paterson and Hudson River Railroad. The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the move on June 11.
Sales of dwellings and home sites in Rumson, Monmouth County, N. J., were reported by the John L. Minugh Agency, brokers, who noted a steady demand for residential properties in the area.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 27 -- Editorials in several Pakistani newspapers this morning cautioned readers against optimism on the outcome of the three-day meeting here of Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, and Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, in which they are seeking solutions of the major problems between the neighboring countries.
It was a sight that seemed unbelievable. There in the middle of East Ninety-fifth Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, a Renault, a tiny French automobile, lay on its top at 4 A.M. yesterday.

By 1960 this country should be experiencing "the biggest boom we have ever seen," Floyd Cramer, president of the Washington Heights Federal Savings and Loan Association, told the Advertising Men's Post, No. 209, of the American Legion, at the Lexington Hotel yesterday.

The City Title Insurance Company, of which Saul Fromkes is president, announced yesterday that it had devised a new and simplified deed form designed to reduce time, space and cost of recording such instruments in the New York area.

The report of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, made public Sunday, which charged that Communists had infiltrated the nation's schools and colleges, was criticized yesterday by Abraham Lederman, president of the New York Teachers Union.

MILWAUKEE, July 27 -- Leo Durocher observed his forty-seventh birthday today, but at a late hour tonight the harassed manager of the Giants looked a lot older -- perhaps thirteen years older, or one year for each run scored against his club by the Braves.

An audience of 11,000 assembled at the Lewisohn Stadium last night for the program presented by the ballet company headed by Mia Slavenska and Frederic Franklin, with Alexander Danilova as the guest artist. As with other dance attractions there, the Stadium Symphony played from the field level so the stage was free.

SHORT CREEK, Ariz., July 27 (AP) -- The men of the polygamy colony of Short Creek were locked in jail at distant Kingsman today and their many wives and children left behind here in custody of the state. A predawn raid yesterday sized thirty-four men, fifty women and 263 children.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 27 -- By an overwhelming margin, Jose (Pepe) Figueres, leader of the victorious 1948 civilians' revolution, has been elected President of Costa Rica with an indisputable mandate to embark the country on an era of Socialist change.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- An early flurry of selling in wheat futures was not extensive and the market soon developed strength. Local buying was largely responsible for the rally and was due to belief that the effect of the Korean truce has been thoroughly liquidated and to disquieting reports on rust in the Northwest.
LONDON, July 27 -- Bald men are likely to be more virile than those with a thick thatch of hair, according to a medical correspondent in the British Medical Association's magazine, Family Doctor.

ROME, July 27 -- After one week's debate, the Chamber of Deputies is to vote tomorrow on whether to grant or deny its confidence to Premier Alcide de Gasperi and his eighth Cabinet. His chances of victory were considered far from bright tonight.

The cease-fire in Korea had little visible effect yesterday on the people of New York. There was no organized public demonstration, either to celebrate or to give thanks. The mood appeared to be one of apathy.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges, influenced by the Korean truce, were easier yesterday. Declines were moderate, however, because traders had discounted most of the effect of the cease-fire order. Coffee was the only item to show strength in all positions.
MEXICO CITY, July 27 -- A strange uneasiness has developed in the relations between Mexico and the United States.

MANILA, July 27 -- Philippine participation in any post-armistice conference on Korean peace is regarded officially as imperative in the interest of national security, particularly to guard against concessions to the Communists on Formosa.

LONDON, July 27 -- Selwyn Lloyd, Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, promised Parliament today that the British Government would soon press for discussions on the admission of the Communist Chinese to the United Nations.
The International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., indicated yesterday that it might forgive and forget its feud with Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, union boss of the Brooklyn docks.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 1 to 13 points net yesterday. The market opened 4 to 8 points lower than on Froday, selling being prompted by the Korean peace, but later the market steadied.

A FIGHTER BASE IN KOREA, July 27 -- Jet warfare in the sub-zero stratosphere over Korea halted tonight shortly after 8 o'clock when six pilots grounded their bristling fighter planes on the long runway here.
Tulsa, Okla., announced yesterday that it will take bids on Aug. 18 on bond issues totaling $7,616,000. The obligations will come due serially from 1955 to 1978.

LONDON, July 27 (Reuters) -- Hungary has promised to review the case of Edgar Sanders, British business man imprisoned there in 1950 on espionage charges, Minister of State Selwyn Lloyd said today. He told the House of Commons that Britain asked the new Hungarian Government for a review June 17.

Communist willingness to end the Korean conflict was increased by Soviet concern over dissension behind the Iron Curtain, George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared yesterday as he returned from the convention in Stockholm of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

CARLE PLACE, L. I., July 27 -- An angry crowd of 2,000 pickets surrounded the strike-bound Arma Corporation plant at Roosevelt Field here today after windows were broken and a striking employe was arrested during an early-morning fracas at the main gate.

PUSAN, Korea, Tuesday, July 28 (AP) -- An estimated 3,000 Chinese and North Korean war prisoners boarded three United States Navy vessels at Koje and Cheju Islands today for shipment to Inchon and later transfer to Communist authorities at Panmunjom.
PARIS, July 27 -- Georges Bidault, the Foreign Minister, said today that for France the armistice in Korea was essentially "a victory, a lesson and a cause for hope."
How long does one boil a lobster?
Herbert, M. Stein has been appointed general sales manager of Ronson Art Metal Works, Inc.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- A union leader appealed to Congress today to help end street begging by disabled.

CAIRO, July 27 -- Jerusalem today became the second capital of the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan when Jordan's Cabinet held its first meeting in the Arab section of the partitioned holy city to counter Israel's transfer of her Foreign Ministry from Tel Aviv to the Jewish-held section of the disputed city.
LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of Premier Malenkov's message of good wishes to "comrade Kitty II Sung, chairman of the North Korean Council of Ministers": ...
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 28 (AP) -- United Nations Headquarters communique for Monday:
The Communist party of the U. S. A. declared yesterday in a six-page statement that the basic credit for the armistice in Korea was due to the North Korean and Chinese armies.

Wall Street, which had awaited a Korean truce for 763 days, took the event yesterday with little excitement. Prices were wobbly at the opening, amusements pushing upward against a drift downward by some of the aircrafts, coppers, rails and chemicals.

The substructure of the city's revolutionary pier in the Hudson River at West Fifteenth Street is virtually completed, and work on the two-story shed of the $12,250,000 terminal will begin in a few weeks, Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The American Red Cross completed plans today to join the international team of Red Cross workers who, under the terms of the Korean armistice, will be allowed to go behind Communist lines and visit United Nations prisoners of war.

Consolidated net earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), estimated at $261,000,000 for the first six months this year, were exceeded in a first half-year period only by the peak of $265,000,000 achieved in the corresponding period last year.
TOKYO, July 27 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark told Japan the termination of the shooting war in Korea today had not reduced "in any way" the internal and external dangers to Japan.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 -- The Screen Actors Guild by an overwhelming majority today adopted a bylaw that prohibits any member of the Communist party from joining the guild.

The agreement reached after Prime Minister Winston Churchill's visit to the United States early last year, whereby England agreed to provide this country with aluminum and other nonferrous metals in exchange for steel, helped lift United States exports of steel products to 4,160,000 tons in 1952, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Countess Jane, the only filly in the field, scampered to a decisive triumph in what served as the feature race at the Saratoga-at-Jamaica program yesterday. With Willie Boland in the saddle, the daughter of Count Speed moved into the lead at the start of the six-furlong sprint, and she remained there to score by a length and a half.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee said tonight the Mutual Security Agency had agreed to abandon the practice of paying other countries for war equipment they had built on their own initiative.
PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP) -- The fire that swept a tanker at Wilmington last Thursday night, taking eight lives, may have started in a tug alongside, the captain of the tanker said today.

PARIS, July 27 -- The spectacular change in silhouette at Jacques Fath's opening today was broadened shoulders rounded in a line suggesting a Roman arch. Inflated three-quarter sleeves continued the rounded line from the side of the neck to the forearm, a schematic line that was, of course, one-half of a rounded arch.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau announced today it had settled for $300,000 a $874,608 tax claim against Dr. Louis A. Bunim, 52 years old, of 1701 Avenue K, Brooklyn.

" The War of the Worlds," Paramount's film version of the famed H. G. Wells tale of the invasion of this planet by Martians, will be the next attraction at the Mayfair, the management announced yesterday. The science-fiction spectacle was produced by George Pal, is in Technicolor and stars Gene Barry and Ann Robinson.

Leonard F. Erikson, a New York advertising agency official, was sworn in yesterday as the new chief of the Voice of America. An announcement by Dr. Robert L. Johnson, administrator of the International Information Administration, said that Mr. Erikson had been brought in "to reorganize the entire radio effort" of the overseas information program.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 27 -- The homecoming of Jake Tuli, Johannesburg Negro who won the professional flyweight boxing championship of the British Commonwealth, has caused a split in the all-White City Council and may have national repercussions.

Walter Erickson, 41 - year- old cafeteria porter and former inmate of a Hudson County, N. J., mental institution, was held in $10,000 bail yesterday for writing a threatening letter to President Eisenhower.

The dispatch in THE TIMES of July 18 quoting Governor Munoz Marin as saying that it is up to Puerto Rico to "erase the impression in Latin America that the United States has imperialistic ambitions in that area" suggests comment on another recent plea for recognition of the true nature of our "imperialism."

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- Naval units from nine of the fourteen North Atlantic Treaty nations will conduct large-scale exercises in the North Atlantic for nineteen days beginning Sept. 16, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- A move developed today to take from Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan, sole control of funds granted to the House of Representatives Government Operations Committee, of which he is chairman.

DENVER, July 27 (AP) -- The Oil Workers International Union, C. I. O., announced today that it had reached agreements with nearly all major oil companies with which it has contracts for a 4 per cent general wage increase.

IT is difficult to realize that eighteen years have passed since the publication of Lin Yutang's "My Country and My People," that wise, humorous and altogether charming book about traditional Chinese civilization. Since then a great many changes have been made in Chinese civilization, most of them for the worse. We have been forced to revise our ideas about China several times and have been saddened by the process.

Buyers of household textile products are keeping their eye on fall requirements and have not let the Korean truce interfere in making commitments, according to exhibiting manufacturers at the combined New York Curtain and Drapery Show and the National Domestics and Linen Show at the New Yorker Hotel.
James A. Van Fleet, former commanding general of the United Nations ground forces in Korea, predicted yesterday that North and South Korea would eventually be united under President Syngman Rhee.

BALTIMORE, July 27 -- An international field that includes representatives of Australia, England, Japan, Canada and Mexico, as well as leading players of this country, started out today in the Middle Atlantic grass-court tennis championships at the Baltimore Country Club.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Administration leaders on Capitol Hill abandoned hope today that Congress would pass a bill for increases in postal rates this year.
Greater emphasis on the education of handicapped and intellectually gifted youngsters, to make full use of the nation's human resources, was urged yesterday at a special program at Hunter College.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 -- A strike against forty of California's largest fruit and vegetable canneries, which are pointing toward an August peak in their processing work was called today by the Cannery Workers Union, A. F. L., after a breakdown of negotiations over wages.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- As the fighting in Korea ceased, President Eisenhower formally masked Congress today to authorize a $200,000,000 initial emergency rehabilitation fund to rebuild the war damaged economy of South Korea.
TOKYO, July 27 (Reuters) -- The map, drawn by the truce negotiators, designates "ports of entry" which may be used to rotate troops and replace outworn equipment during the armistice.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Eisenhower gave another dinner tonight for a number of men who are prominent in many fields.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 27 (AP) -- Melvin Ferral, riding the favored Cavalry Charge in a maiden hurdle race, suffered a fractured collarbone at Monmouth Park today when his mount stumbled and fell on him after the fifth jump.
JIMMY DEMARET has established a reputation as one of the nation's leading golfers, one of the game's most unusually attired players and a pal who can always make Ben Hogan laugh.
The bond market was little affected yesterday by announcement of the Korean truce.
Esther Kim, a 22-year-old Korean nurse, kept a rendezvous yesterday with Irene Robson, a Californian who was her superior on the staff of the Seventh-day Adventist Hospital in Seoul.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 27 -- George K. C. Yeh, the Chinese Nationalist Foreign Minister, warned tonight of possible Communist new aggression elsewhere in Asia and of a Communist attempt to gain "political compensations from the United Nations."

The House of Representatives sheared approximately a billion dollars from the President's request for our Mutual Security Program. This cut was excessive and the Senate Appropriations Committee moved in the right direction when it restored about half of this amount. But the Senate group, unaccountably, took a simultaneous action that can be greatly damaging to our cause and that of our allies.

An elaborate editorial supplement on style trends in all aspects of men's and boys' clothing, with a series of sixteen advertisements for use by newspapers in developing a greater volume of advertising by retailers, was issued yesterday by the Men's Wear-Inter-Industry Council.

BERLIN, July 27 -- Two of East Germany's leading Communists have been ejected from their party posts because of their "defeatism," the Central Committee announced today. These removals and other shake-ups in the party appeared to be an aftermath of the June 17 uprising.
I should like to raise one voice against the advisability and wisdom of the creation of a new Hoover Commission of 1953.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- Representative Kit Clardy, Republican of Michigan, said today that the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives would disclose soon how the Communists had "plotted to infiltrate the church" and destroy "all religion."

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- The Senate passed today and sent to the House of Representatives a bill authorizing the Interstate Commerce Commission to order installation of radio and electronic safety devices on railroads.

It is over -- the bloodshed and the suffering of the fighting and the tears. It is finished -- the hard-fought war, the war that was not won but was not lost. It is ended -- the mud and misery, the frustration and the pain.
LONDON, July 27 -- The Marquess of Salisbury, Britain's Acting Foreign Secretary, gave a luncheon for Adlai E. Stevenson today at Carlton Gardens, the Briton's official residence.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 27 -- Two hours before the Nassau County Department of Public Works dedicated its new two-way radio system today it was called into use to help rescue five persons stranded all night aboard a grounded cabin cruiser.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 27 (UP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Hugh Stewart of San Marino, Calif., gained the second round in the men's singles today as frequent showers marred the opening of the German international tennis championships.

The bill to provide for federal development of the undersea mineral resources of the outer Continental Shelf is still deadlocked in conference. We believe that it is an obligation of the Administration and of Congress to see that this measure is not left in limbo. It is a necessary supplement to the submerged lands bill that became law earlier in the session.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, July 27 -- After consulting with physicians of Aloysius Cardinal Stepinac and examining him twice, two doctors from the United States reported today that Cardinal Stepinac was "not in any immediate danger."

A vacant plot 112 by 100 feet on the east side of Beach Thirty-first Street, near Dwight Place, in the Bayswater section of Far Rockaway, Queens, has been sold by the Lionel Construction Corporation to Morris Stein. Lewis H. May Company was the broker.

HONG KONG, July 11 -- Official reports of building activity on the mainland point to Manchuria and various sectors of North, West and Northwest China as the key development areas in the Peiping Government's present industrialization program.
PURCHASE, N. Y., July 27 -- Mrs. Sally Francis of Apawamis won the qualifying medal in the ninth annual women's Tri-County golf championship with a A1, 39 -- 80 over the Old Oaks course today.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 27 -- Relations between France and Cambodia remained unsettled and difficult here today. A reply from Cambodia to a French note of July 12, delivered this afternoon to Jean Risterucci, French High Commissioner, demonstrated continued disagreement between the two countries on two matters.
