The medical benefits of the pension and welfare plan of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., will be extended Saturday to cover an estimated 100,000 dependents of seamen.

Garth Panter, Salt Lake City middleweight, scored an upset victory over Walter Cartier, Greenwich Village, gaining the unanimous decision in the main bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Panter weighed 161 1/4; Cartier, 161 1/2.

With production and sales at a new high record in the first six months this year, the Armco Steel Corporation realized a net income of $16,078,533, equal to $3.08 a share on 5,213,638 common shares, Charles R. Hook, chairman, reported yesterday.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 27 -- One of the prestige events of American yachting, the annual New York Yacht Club cruise, was in the process of formation today, with yachts either here or arriving for the rendezvous. The racing will begin tomorrow.
Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio will not leave New York hospital tomorrow, as had been announced last week, nor has any further date been set for his return to Washington.

The fourteenth and fifteenth floors in the twenty-eight-story office building under construction at 261 Madison Avenue have been leased by the Research Institute of America, Inc., an advisory organization on tax and economic matters headed by Carl Hovgard.
The end of the shooting in Korea does not mean any earlier return to baseball uniform for the half a hundred major leaguers in military services.

TOKYO, July 27 -- The new Korean military demarcation line agreed to by the Allied and Communist negotiators in the sessions at Panmunjom gave the Communists almost all the ground they won recently in the Kumsong bulge in their greatest offensive in two years, a map released by Gen. Mark W. Clark's headquarters showed today.

BUFFALO, July 27 -- William F. Schnitzler, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor, assailed today the Republican leadership in Washington and called on workers to use the ballot box to achieve a more potent voice on national issues.

THE school tuna seem to have moved closer inshore, both on the Long Island and New Jersey margins, but the weekend catches indicated that the fish were hard to lure despite their abundance in some areas.

The public that feels free to blame government officials when blame is deserved should be equally ready to commend when things go well. Sidney H. Bingham, general manager of the New York City Transit Authority, has just weathered the week-end of transition to the new 15-cent token fare. It was not easy.

LONDON, July 27 -- The truce in Korea had no appreciable effect on stock market trading here today. Business was at a low ebb, investors apparently awaiting Wall Street's reaction to the Far Eastern events.
LONDON, July 27 -- Showing his first collection in his own right today, the young designer Michael featured a "Tang Dynasty" line, reminiscent of figures commonly seen in Chinese art.
I hope that space will permit a brief discussion on an abused medical concept.

ON THE KOREAN FRONT, July 27 -- It's all over for now. About 10 o'clock tonight the guns here fell silent, and now it is possible for a soldier to jump outside his trench and stretch his arms and legs without fear. Tomorrow morning he can even take the path forward that winds through a tangle of barbed wire toward the base of the hill.

Plans are under way for a benefit performance of Anna Russell's Little Show on the night of Oct. 14 at the Vanderbilt Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Masters Nursery. Mrs. John J. Lenhart heads the benefit committee. Serving with her as vice chairman are Mrs. Henry C. Brunie, Mrs. Mary Hall Furber and Mrs. Will W. White.

NEW HAVEN, July 27 -- The council of the Connecticut Bar Association appointed a three-man committee this afternoon to investigate the qualifications of former Senator John A. Danaher for the post of judge in the Second District Circuit Court of Appeals. The action came at a meeting held here at the request of Whitney North Seymour, a member of the American Bar Association's standing committee on the Federal judiciary.

The Board of Education warned yesterday that delays in school construction caused by the twenty-five-day strike of building supply drivers might force the board to arrange emergency accommodations for 4,000 Queens pupils when the school year opened Sept. 14.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- When Ted Williams is released from the Marine Corps tomorrow he will go to Boston immediately to rejoin the Red Sox, but he's a bit afraid that he might hurt the club if he get back into the lineup too soon.
Venezuela has declared her intention of withdrawing her six ships and selling her 45 per cent share of the Flota Mercante Grancolombia.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- By a roll-call vote of 209 to 163 the House of Representatives adopted tonight a resolution authorizing a second investigation into the operations of educational and philanthropic foundations.

FORT WORTH, July 27 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, the youngster who told his mother twenty-four years ago "I'm going to be the greatest golfer in the world," was informed by his fellow townsmen today that he had accomplished that objective.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 27 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh told Iranian voters in a half-hour nation-wide broadcast today that they must choose between him and the Majlis (the lower and sole remaining House of Parliament).

For the first time in its history, twelve months' earnings of the American Gas and Electric System have crossed the $30,000,000 mark. The utility, the nation's largest from the standpoint of electric output, announced yesterday that net income in the twelve months to June 30, 1953, reached $30,227,533, a gain of $5,367,395, or 21.6 per cent, from that in the preceding twelve months.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 27 -- President Eisenhower's message today asking Congress to appropriate $200,000,000 for Korean relief found a warm welcome here, particularly among officials of the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency.

NEW DELHI, India, July 27 -- The signing of the Korean truce has obviously given India additional fuel for her long-standing drive to obtain Communist China's admittance to the United Nations. New Delhi may be expected to press this campaign with renewed vigor in any international conference affecting Asian affairs with which this country may be associated in the future.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 27 (AP) -- Dizzy Dean and Al Simmons, two of baseball's former greats, were inducted formally into the Hall of Fame today when their plaques were dedicated by George Trautman, president of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues (the minors) in ceremonies held in front of the national baseball Hall of Fame and Museum.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Congress greeted the Korean truce with somber reservations today, generally agreeing only that at least there was now to be an end of the dying, and pointedly left the whole responsibility for the armistice and its consequences to President Eisenhower.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 27 -- The Suffolk County Government's severest critic threatened in a series of ultimatums today to try to throw every top official out of office and break the will of the late William K. Vanderbilt Jr. to boot.

MOSCOW, July 27 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov today pledged full Soviet support to North Korea in the great task standing before it "of restoring the national unity of the Korean state and, at the same time, of rehabilitating the national economy."

LEEDS, England, July 27 (Reuters) -- England was in a precarious position at the close of the fourth day's play in the fourth test match, only 78 runs ahead of Australia with five second-innings wickets down. If the Australians win tomrorow, they will keep the mythical ashes, symbol of world cricket supremacy.

Back in early April, when the news showed that prospects were increasing for a resumption of full-scale armistice negotiations in Korea, the stock market here went through a pretty bad time. In one trading session alone, that of Monday, April 6, selling became so general that the volume of trading crossed the 3,000,000 mark for the first time since early 1951.

BERLIN, July 27 -- West Berlin's food give-away program got off to a successful, though at times stormy, start today. Almost 100,000 residents of the Soviet-controlled areas poured into West Berlin armed with many types of containers, from knapsacks to baby carriages. fainted after hours of waiting when they were only a few minutes from the registration tables. Police officials estimated that 5,000 persons had been treated during the day for injuries.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Tuesday, July 28 (AP) -- The Allied-Communist Military Armistice Commission held its first meeting today -- a two-hour, two-minute session -- and recessed until 11 A. M. tomorrow [10 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern daylight time].

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 27 -- St. John's College here, one of the country's oldest and home of the "great books" course, has become the Mutual Security Agency's orientation center for foreign labor groups coming to the United States under the Technical Assistance Program to study American labor management.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Livestock receipts were cut well below the forecast today in the wake of Monday's widespread declines. The price bolstering move was largely successful. Hogs moved steady to 50 cents higher with heavier weights and sows at best advantage. Cattle and sheep also were steady to 50 cents a hundrd pounds higher.

MILWAUKEE, July 28 -- Here in the Beer Belt, where every night the Braves play is like New Year's Eve, the Giants are still looking for their first run on the current road trip. Leo Durocher's lads were blanked again tonight, 2 -- 0, this, time by Bob Buhl's six-hit pitching before 30,021 fans.

LOS ANGELES, July 28 -- "During the twenty years since Repeal the Government has imposed so many ludicrous regulations on the liquor industry that today what we've got is semi-prohibition," J. H. (Mike) Elwood, president of the Beverly Hills Distributing Company of Llords Elwood, said here today.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 29 -- The Communist and United Nations commands will begin the exchange of prisoners of the Korean war Aug. 5, it was announced yesterday. Preliminary arrangements for Operation Big Switch were made yesterday at a meeting of staff officers of both sides at Panmunjom and were officially made public later by the joint Military Armistice Commission, which will police the cease-fire.

BERLIN, July 28 -- In what appeared to be a new Communist ruse to disrupt West Berlin's food giveaway program, thousands of bogus newspapers were distributed today telling West Berlin's unemployed and pensioners that they, too, would receive handouts tomorrow.

TOKYO, July 28 -- Japan, which ruled Korea with an iron hand for forty years until the end of World War II, would like to be represented at any political conference called to consider settlement of the problems of that troubled peninsula.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Brig. Gen. John H. Stokes Jr., who has been assistant Chief of Staff for Plans and Operations of Allied Forces in Southern Europe, was named today to command the New Jersey Military District, with headquarters at the Kearny shipyards. He will take over from Col. Hayden A. Sears next month or in September.

BOSTON, July 28 (UP) -- Harry Dorish, a Red Sox cast-off, halted his former mates tonight with the aid of a pair of home runs as the second-place White Sox beat Boston, 4 -- 2, before the largest Fenway Park crowd of the season, 35,385 fans.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 28 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower terminated his combined goodwill and fact-finding tour of the ten South American Republics and left for Washington at 9:30 this morning after a final promise to the Brazilians that the United States would continue its long-standing policy of cooperation for the development of Brazil.

NEWTON, N. J., July 28 -- One of the largest stills ever discovered in this rural area of Northern New Jersey was raided today by state and local policemen. One man, who protested he was only a farmer, was arrested and lodged in the Sussex County jail.

Your editorial "Bishop Oxnam's Reply" with its statement, "In its clash with Bishop Oxnam the Un-American Activities Committee clearly came off second best," will, I think, be generally supported, as will the resolution passed unanimously by the committee itself: "This committee has no record of Communist
Thomas M. McDade has been elected controller of the General Foods Corporation.

ROSENDALE, N. Y., July 28 -- Four persons, three of them members of a Brooklyn family, were killed and eleven others were injured early this morning when fire of undetermined origin destroyed the Williams Lake Hotel and its adjoining lodge in this Catskill community.

Allie Reynolds went to the rescue Of Whitey Ford last night as the world champion Yankees opened a fourteen - game home stand by beating the Indians, 4 -- 2, before 57,461 fans at the Stadium. It was the largest gathering to pay to watch a Stadium contest, excluding world series games, since 1951.

BALTIMORE, July 28 -- Hamilton Richardson had the most trying ordeal of the top-favored Americans in gaining the third round of the Middle Atlantic grass court tennis championships today as all of the foreign contenders were eliminated with the exception of two Australians and a Japanese.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The possibility that the Korean truce may be endangered by intensified guerrilla fighting in Indo-China was discussed privately today by Senators seeking to restore a cut of $100,000,000 ordered by the Senate Appropriations Committee in United States aid to that military effort.
MUNSAN, Wednesday, July 29 (AP) -- Communist members of the Korean Armistice Commission today charged the Allies with eight separate violations of the truce agreement signed Monday.
Sharp increases in juvenile delinquency are posing serious problems for the city's outmoded youth detention centers, which in recent years have been taxed to capacity.

HARTFORD, July 28 -- Connecticut Republican leaders said today they had cleared the appointment of Mrs. Anne Mitchell of West Hartford, secretary of the Republican State Central Committee, as Collector of Customs for Connecticut.

Volume on the New York commodity exchanges increased substantially yesterday. Rubber registered the greatest activity since June 24, the world sugar market the greatest since June 4 and cocoa the third largest volume of the year. Trading in coffee was also unusually heavy.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Detroit spurted into an 8-0 lead against Washington in the early innings and gained an 8-5 victory tonight. It marked the Tigers' fifth straight triumph over the Senators.

Five four-story buildings at 630 to 638 Third Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-first Street, opposite the block to be improved with the $45,000,000 Socony-Vacuum Building, have been purchased for investment by the Dalis Realty Corporation, represented by Nathan Tannenbaum and Morris Schwalb, attorneys.

The shipping industry is aroused again over bills in Congress that would authorize the export of $100,000,000 in "surplus commodities" without the observance of the usual fifty-fifty clause, which provides that half of such goods be moved in United States-flag ships.

I certainly agree with your editorial of July 22 that "the election lines are taking final shape in unprecedented perplexity -- we do not believe that the voter will find within either the Democratic or the Liberal camp a Mayoral candidate who offers any real prospect for vigorous, sound leadership to deal with the pressing problems of New York City."

The Hayden rider attached in the Senate to the Equal Rights Amendment without consent of the Judiciary Committee fastens discriminatory legislation on women, and therefore nullifies the amendment. For the amendment reads "equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged on account of sex."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 28 -- Rummaging recently through the files of the late Mark Hellinger, Les Hafner, television film producer who owns all movie rights for the Hellinger short stories, came across a hitherto undiscovered motion-picture script, which will be filmed soon for exhibition in theatres.

A PALL of gloom, that would be dissipated by the appearance of a few bluefin tuna or marlin flags flying from the outriggers of boats in the slips, or even a nice mess of school tuna on the dock, seems to have settled over the Montauk Yacht Club.

Anticipating by a few months the date of the Wright brothers' achievement, Newark Airport will observe the fiftieth anniversary of powered flight and the airport's own twenty-fifth anniversary by dedicating today a new $8,500,000 passenger terminal building of impressive proportions and convenience to the public.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -The Agriculture Department said today that farm income in the first half of this year was down 5 per cent from a year ago. It totaled $12,600,000,000.

Every time there is a parade on Fifth Avenue, or any other important arterial thoroughfare in Manhattan, there are at least as many people who wonder about the advisability of the line of march as there are people in it or watching it. It is neither discourteous nor inhospitable to suggest that New York needs and should have parades, but not on main arterial highways and streets.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 249 Korean war casualties in a new list that included 17 killed, 185 wounded, 39 missing and 8 injured. These lists lag behind the period when the casualties occurred.

Some hope developed yesterday that a peace formula might be worked out today to end the strike of 1,800 building materials drivers that has halted $600,000,000 in public and private projects and made 100,000 construction workers idle.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Marine Corps "ordered" Capt. Ted Williams back to Fenway Park today and baseball's most celebrated citizen set out for Boston to resume his twice-interrupted career.

The Democratic faction opposed to Mayor Impellitteri's renomination accepted yesterday Harry Cassidy, a city engineer, as the Staten Island running mate of Robert F. Wagner Jr., Man hattan Borough President who will oppose Mr. Impellitteri in the party primary.

The sufferer from hay fever long has had a deplorable manner of life. As though the reddened eyes and tickling nose were not enough, he has received for his pains something more nearly approaching ridicule than it does sympathy.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 28 -- In a note delivered to the West German Government yesterday the Dutch Government expressed the Netherlands' "serious anxiety" over German discrimination against Dutch in Rhine Inland shipping.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 28 (AP) -- Bohemia Stable's Maid of Flight scored an easy victory in the feature race at Monmouth Park today before 19,513 spectators.

One of the largest commercial leasing transactions in the Grand Central area thus far this year was reported by brokers yesterday with the announcement that Compton Advertising, Inc., had leased four floors in the twenty-eight-story office building being built at 261 Madison Avenue.

Carrano Realty, Inc., bought 413-19 Bond Street, Brooklyn, from Princess Holding Corporation through Farber-Wittman, Inc., brokers, who also bought 148 Third Street for Julius Michael and Morris Mishkin Bond Industrial Company to the same buyer.

DENVER, July 28 -- Colorado's Weather Control Commission adopted a resolution today recommending that the state conduct a survey to determine whether Colorado should finance a rainmaking project. However, Gov. Dan Thornton told the commission the state had no funds for such a project and the only method of obtaining the money would be through an appropriation by the Legislature.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., July 28 -- Eighteen department heads who served under Dr. George D. Stoddard at the University of Illinois joined today in condemning the action by the board of trustees last Friday that forced his resignation as president by a 6-to-3 vote of no confidence in his administration.

Despite the Korean truce the demand for steel in this country "is still very good," Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman of the nation's largest steel-producing concern, the United States Steel Corporation, declared yesterday.

Managerial interests connected with the theatre are urging President Eisenhower to veto the measure to repeal the 20 per cent Federal admission tax for movies only. The bill, which was introduced by Representative Noah M. Mason, Republican of Illinois, was speedily adopted by Congress with little if any opposition.

HAVANA, July 28 -- The censorship imposed yesterday by the Government on four publications considered to reflect the opinions of the opposition was extended today to all newspapers and magazines. The Government censorship decree followed supension of constitutional guarantees following the abortive revolt of Sunday.

We heard the other day that there are more pizzerias in the United States than in all of Italy. The highly seasoned pizza with its tough crust and tomato topping, is such a gastronomical craze that the open pie threatens the preeminence of the hot dog and the hamburger.
PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (AP) -- Ray Murray's homer with Cass Michaels on base in the eighth inning enabled the Athletics to score a 9-7 victory over the Browns tonight.

STORRS, Conn., July 28 -- The University of Connecticut announced tonight that it was reinstating but "severely censuring" Dr. Paul R. Zilsel, an assistant professor of physics who was suspended from the university's faculty last April after refusing to tell a Congressional investigating committee in Washington whether he had been a Communist from 1946 to 1948.

The N. B. C. radio network announced three appointments yesterday. John P. Cleary moved up from radio network program manager to director of radio network programs. Merrill Mueller, who had been news editor of the TV program "Today," became radio news and features executive.

CARLE PLACE, L. I., July 28 -- Violence flared for the second day along the picket line at the strikebound Arma Corporation plant at Roosevelt Field this morning. Nassau County police charged fourteen strikers with disorderly conduct and filed against one an additional charge of assaulting a patrolman.
PARIS, July 28 -- A war of the vine broke out today in four departments of Southern France where wine growers are angry over the Government's refusal to buy up excess stocks of wine.

One of the three administrators appointed by the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., to take over the duties of Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, union boss of the Brooklyn docks, ventured into Brooklyn yesterday, but stopped a half-mile short of the union office the administrators were supposed to be running.

Danny Giovanelli of Brooklyn, a 3-1 favorite, will carry a string of thirteen consecutive victories into the Madison Square Garden ring tonight when he meets Carmine Fiore, also of Brooklyn, in a welterweight bout of ten rounds.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is to be investigated by the Califronia Senate Committee on Un-American Activities.

Workmen began yesterday the task of attaching 1,800 prefabricated aluminum and glass panels to the steel and concrete framework of the new twenty-six-story office building at 99 Park Avenue in what the owners of the building called an unusual application of assembly line methods to skyscraper construction.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 28 -- A strike of Oak Ridge-American Federation of Labor workers was called off and they started back to work late today.

The Senate Appropriations Committee was well advised in restoring most of the cut made by the House in funds for the Government's overseas information activities. In proposing the sum of $80 millions -- which is $20 millions more than the House figure -- the Senate committee has approved what the

Frank Lloyd Wright, the apostle of unconventional modern architecture, yielded thirty inches more yesterday to New York's conventional building and zoning laws. He retreated gracefully, but not without disappointment.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that nothing Dr. Konrad Adenaur, West German Chancellor, had written to him would indicate that the Chancellor was advocating a non-aggression pact between the European Defense Community and the Soviet Union.

COSTA RICA, July 28 -- Jose Figueres, Costa Rican President-elect, promised today an "environment of safety and honesty" for United States capital that wants to invest in Costa Rica, but he emphasized his belief that the country's development must depend primarily on its own efforts.

CINCINNATI, July 28 (AP) Southpaw Harry Perkowski weathered a four-run eighth inning tonight to pitch the Redlegs to a 15-4 victory over the Phillies. The triumph was Perkowski's fourth straight and his eighth in his last nine games.

The cotton futures market opened yesterday with gains of 1 to 10 points and closed 7 to 15 points net up on active months. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet all day. There was some early price fixing credited to domestic, Spanish and Yugoslavian mills.
When parents plan their vacations they think of tickets or road maps, of resort reservations, packing and such -- and one further important thing: how to keep the children amused on the trip.

Bail of $75,000 was fixed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Louis J. Capozzoli for Frank Smith, a former fight manager, after the court was informed that the defendant "had been hired by people in Massachusetts to shoot and kill Sol Rosenblatt."

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Glenn L. Emmons, nominated by President Eisenhower to be Indian Commissioner, denied today that there ever had been a shortage in the accounts of a Gallup, N. M., bank, of which he was an officer.

The latest news from East Germany makes clearer than ever that June 17 -the day of German heroism against Communist oppression -- was a watershed in the flow of history, one whose consequences have only begun to be appreciated. It is to the events of that day undoubtedly that we must trace
Sea Gate, a private community at the western end of Coney Island, will have its garbage collected beginning today by Department of Sanitation trucks.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Department of Justice was absolved today by a House of Representatives Judiciary subcommittee from charges that it interfered with a New York Federal Grand Jury's inquiry into Communist infiltration of the staff of the United Nations.
Today's college girl is no longer a creature of strange fashion fads and fancies. She's discarded red flannel pajamas for trim designs favored by her business girl sister.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Senate Rules Committee approved today a resolution authorizing a Senate study of a proposed revision of the United Nations Charter. Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, said the group at a closed-door meeting had approved the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's request for permission to undertake the study, but had voted only $35,000 of the $75,000 requested.

The performance of the stock market yesterday was encouraging to investors and traders in several respects. Although early liquidation depressed the list to the lowest level since mid-June, offerings were small and the selling gained no momentum. Prices stabilized during the early afternoon and by the close most issues were at or near Monday's final levels.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, July 29 (AP) -- The Eighth Army today reportedly issued strict orders against fraternization with the Reds as the withdrawal of Allied and Communist armies reached full swing across the Korean battlefront.

MOSCOW, July 27 -- The appointment of Leonid Melnikov as Soviet Ambassador to Rumania today placed in sharp relief the fact that this is a time in the Soviet Union when a careful review is being made of the judgments and decisions that were crammed into the eventful months from March to July.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- Severe weakness developed in wheat futures late in the session today when the market was apparently unable to absorb hedge selling and long liquidation.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) -- Makers of home laundry equipment urged repeal of the 10 per cent tax on ironers and driers tonight as the House Ways and Means Committee began hearings on proposed excise tax changes. W. R. Dabney of Mount Clemens, Mich., president of the American Home Laundry Manufacturers Association, said the 10 per cent tax threatens to put many small companies out of business.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) -Philip Young, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, named five persons today to a new loyalty board designed to check the loyalty of Americans hired by the United Nations or other international organizations.

Perhaps if the United Nations Technical Assistance Administration was known by its less abstruse deeds of Helping Human Beings to Live Longer, Produce More, and Help Themselves to a More Decent Way of Life, people in the more fortunate areas of the world would more readily grasp

CHICAGO, July 28 (UP) -- Mr. Davis said he had written an advisory opinion before he left the post of chief counsel of the bureau but would not say what it was. Now with a Chicago law firm, he said the opinion was "advisory and confidential."

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -The House Judiciary Committee approved today a bill to add twenty-six to the total of Federal judgeships. The bill would add three circuit seats and twenty-three district seats. A bill passed by the Senate in May would create thirty-nine seats, four circuit and thirty-five district.

Five oil companies issued income statements yesterday for the first six months of this year and all showed gains over the similar period last year, when a strike which started in May affected earnings.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Senate confirmed today President Eisenhower's three nominations to the National Security Training Commission.

The name of the trade group formerly known as the Radio-Television Manufacturers Association of Washington, D. C., has been changed to the Radio-Electronics-Television Manufacturers Association. The organization also has been reorganized by expanding the board of directors and providing larger representation for new segments of the industry, particularly in the advanced electronics field.
Three turnstile modifications designed to foil those who substitute cheap slugs for 15-cent transit, tokens were demonstrated yesterday by Sidney H. Bingham, general manager of the Transit Authority.

On record sales and rentals of $278,719,378, the American Can Company realized net earnings of $12,421,109, after providing $15,491,494 for taxes, in the six months ended on June 30, according to the report of William C. Stolk, president, issued yesterday. Net for the 1952 period was $10,315,428 after $11,175,047 for taxes.

BOMBAY, India, July 28 -- The Indian Government is planning to film the 2000-year-old fresco paintings and sculpture of Ajanta and Ellora Caves in Hyderabad State for distribution in foreign lands and also for the benefit of the Indian people.

In a final bid to escape ouster from the American Federation of Labor, the crime-infested International Longshoremen's Association offered yesterday to set up a trial procedure for the expulsion of union officials with criminal records or gang affiliations.
BUENOS AIRES, July 28 -- Washington's action was interpreted here as a dramatic manifestation of a change in United States policy toward Argentina.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Congress went into full stride today in its drive for adjournment by the week-end. The possibility of a new and serious barrier arose, however, with persistent reports of an imminent Administration request for an increase in the statutory ceiling on the national debt.

Fischer-Landis, operators and investors, have contracted to buy two connecting apartment houses at 1735 Walton Avenue and 1734 Townsend Avenue in the Bronx. The buildings occupy a blockfront on West 175th Street between Walton and Townsend Avenues and contain fifty-two apartments and twelve stores.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The White House press office was requested today to consider holding some of President Eisenhower's news conferences late in the day to give morning newspapers an equal opportunity to play the news first.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- A Senate-House conference committee agreed today on an appropriation of $34,371,541,000 for the Defense Department in the current fiscal year.

ROME, July 28 -- The second Italian Cabinet crisis within a month was precipitated early this afternoon when the Chamber of Deputies, amid the triumphant cheers of the Communists and other Opposition parties, denied its confidence to Premier Alcide De Gasperi's eighth Government by a vote of 282 to 263, with 37 abstentions.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Albert Nufer, Ambassador to Argentina since April, 1952, will be retained in that post despite an announcement made earlier this month that he would be replaced by Willard Beaulac, another career diplomat, it was announced at the State Department today.

The other day you published a letter on the important subject of the Fifth Amendment and the protection it affords to a witness. This letter, from William M. Kunstler, was misleading. Mr. Kunstler writes that there "are many reasons for invocation of the Fifth Amendment besides present involvement in subversive activities" and goes on to give some of these reasons.

A special squad of sixty policemen boarded all buses along First and Second Avenues last night in a futile five-hour search for a parcel of two laboratory uniforms believed to be contaminated with deadly disease germs. They gave up their hunt at midnight after examining sixty buses.
Keeping its house in order is an unending chore for the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Charles Sparks Thomas of Los Angeles to be Assistant Secretary of Defense for Supply and Logistics, and Donald A. Quarles of Englewood, N. J., and Albuquerque, N. M., to be Assistant Secretary for Research and Development.

SINGAPORE, July 28 -- Planes flew today over the jungles of Malaya dropping leaflets telling the Communist guerrillas hiding there of the armistice in Korea. Simultaneously the "voice plane," a broadcasting aircraft, also flew over making announcements.

With the armistice signed and sealed the whole Korean front is in motion again, but this time it is a movement of disengagement, as the armies of both sides withdraw for one and a quarter miles. This is the first step in the execution of the armistice terms, and it is being accomplished without incident.
SHORT CREEK, Ariz., July 28 (UP) -- Members of a polygamous sect arrested in a week-end raid here have been visiting other wives in Canada and Mexico, an authorative source disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Eisenhower today nominated Philip Ray Rodgers of Maryland to be a member of the National Labor Relations Board, Seaborn Lee Digby of Louisiana to be a member of the Federal Power Commission and Kenneth H. Tuggle of Kentucky to be an Interstate Commerce Commissioner.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 28 -- French Union forces hammered today by air, sea and land at a 3,000 - man Vietminh regiment based near the coast north of Hue, the capital of Central Vietnam.

PURCHASE, N. Y., July 28 -- The first upset of the ninth annual women's Tri-County golf championship for the Edith R. Limburg Trophy occurred when Mrs. Robert C. Ackerman of Century defeated Mrs. Sally Francis of Apawamis, 1 up, in twenty holes over the Old Oaks course as the first round was completed today.
OTTAWA, July 28 (AP) -- Canada's five political parties sent a total of 902 candidates into the lists today, battling for the 265 House of Commons seats in the Aug. 10 Federal elections.

NEW YORK'S most difficult bulb-changing job, switching beacon lights on the Empire State Building TV tower, 1,472 feet above the pavement, is usually left to John Freehill, 51 years old, and to John Walsh, 43, two steeplejacks enrolled in Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A. F. L.

Thomas Schippers, young American conductor, led the Stadium Symphony Orchestra in an all-orchestral program last night at Lewisohn Stadium. Quite early in the program it was possible to see that Mr. Schippers has made good use of his time since his Stadium appearances last summer.

PARIS, July 28 -- Christian Dior today showed dresses hiked seventeen inches off the floor in another "new look" that he called his "dome," or "cupola," silhouette. He gives it that name because, from below a princess waistline, short gowns curve out over the hips in the rounded contours of a dome, in perfect smoothness and cut in six or eight gores.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Counsel for the Civil Aeronautics Board today joined with National Airlines in opposing a proposed merger of Colonial and Eastern Airlines.
In the ten years that ended yesterday the American Red Cross and various hospitals have received even gallons of the blood of Alfred Ross, 47 years old, of 242 East Seventy-ninth Street.
Excerpts from the report submitted to the American Federation of Labor by the International Longshoremen's Association follow:
Bicarb, owned by Mrs. Philip Bieber and ridden by Dave Gorman, won the Gnome Handicap at the Saratoga-at-Jamaica meeting yesterday, after a stretch run that thrilled a crowd of 17,579 onlookers.

MOSCOW, July 28 -- Foreign diplomatic circles believed tonight that the Soviet Union would submit in the United Nations Korean discussions specific plans looking toward the unification of Korea as well as a program for the withdrawal of all foreign forces from North Korea and South Korea and all-Korean elections.

Magistrate David P. McKean authorized a Long Island Rail Road conductor yesterday to withdraw his complaint of disorderly conduct against a veteran commuter who let himself be arrested last Wednesday rather than allow his ticket to be punched after it had been glued onto a plastic holder.

An incident in a Fifty-second Street night spot about midnight Saturday resulted yesterday in a patrolman's being investigated by the Police Department, and in a male nurse's being held for trial on the charge of impersonating a policeman.

Deposits in the 528 mutual savings banks of the nation reached $23,614,000,000, a record high, on June 30, according to Richard A. Booth, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. During the first six months of 1953 deposits increased $1,003,000,000, which was 15 per cent more than the gain for the corresponding period of 1952.

LONDON, July 28 -- Adlai E. Stevenson cautioned here today that any tendency to think "that somehow something has changed basically in the imperialist objectives of world communism" was alarming and dangerous.

Joe E. Lewis has a verbal agreement with Lou Walters, nocturnal boniface of the Latin Quarter and other spots, to head a revue specially built around the entertainer. Material is now being assembled for the yet untitled show, with the hope of going into rehearsal in mid-October for a local premiere on Christmas Eve, Mr. Walters said yesterday.

THE other evening, having nothing better to occupy our time, we did what most anyone with a deep rooted interest in baseball would have done under similar circumstances. We dialed the radio until we came upon the pleasing voice of one of our favorite broadcasters.
Former President Truman has asked the Internal Revenue Bureau to let him spread his income tax payments on the sale of his memoirs over six years, but the bureau has not yet given its ruling.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A second investigation into tax-exempt educational and philanthropic foundations, authorized by the House of Representatives yesterday, was expected today to get under way during perhaps the early weeks of the Congressional adjournment between legistative sessions.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Edward A. Kaier, general attorney of the Pennsylvania Railroad, told a subcommittee of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today that more than 90 per cent of the Long Island Rail Road's annual freight revenue was derived from interstate shipments, and that since freight revenues were more than a third as great as passenger revenues, "obviously, the Long Island is an interstate operation."

NEW DELHI, India, July 28 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru returned from Karachi today immensely encouraged by the goodwill toward India he found in the Pakistani capital where he held preliminary conferences with the Pakistani Prime Minister, Mohammed Ali, on disputes between the two countries.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Eisenhower gave White House leadership today to plans for a great highway safety campaign aimed at saving 17,000 lives and $1,250,000,000 in a year.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 28 -- The institution of the secret ballot, inviolate since the Iranian Constitution adopted it in 1906, was swept aside by a Cabinet decree published today.

ZAGREB, Yougoslavia, July 28 -- This is a country of Esperantists as well as Titoists, it was disclosed here at the Thirty-eighth Congress sponsored by the Universal Esperanto Association. Moreover, the Yugoslav leader himself speaks and understands Esperanto. He learned the language in jail.

Two books on American education are scheduled for publication in September. Atlantic - Little, Brown will issue on Sept. 10 Albert Lynd's "Quackery in the Public Schools." On Sept. 30, McGraw-Hill will publish "Let's Talk Sense About Our Schools" by Paul Woodring, Professor of Psychology at Western Washington College of Education.

A new method of making a light, strong and rigid sheet of plastic material in a continuous process at low cost was introduced in action yesterday by the Campco division of Chicago Molded Products Corporation.

The Government securities market continued to mark time yesterday in a trading session that was moderately active, considering seasonal factors making for quiet. There was some shading of prices among the longest-maturing 2 1/2 per cent bonds, where the market is thinnest, but bonds, notes and certificates eligible for bank investment continued firm.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, accompanied by a bipartisan Senate delegation, will leave for Korea, probably Sunday morning, for a series of discussions with President Syngman Rhee relative to the forthcoming political conference and to negotiations of a security pact between the United States and South Korea.
SEOUL, Korea, July 28 -- When he arrives here next week Secretary of State John Foster Dulles will embark on one of the most delicate diplomatic missions of his long career.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Errie Ball today led a 124-man contingent seeking places in Tam O'Shanter's All-American professional golf championship field by shooting a 34, 32 -- 66 in qualifying play.
BUFFALO, N. Y., July 28 (AP) -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur got in the last word today in a verbal exchange with an ex-corporal who represents small stockholders in big corporations.

Shipbuilding throughout the world is in a strong position at present and prospects are good for 1954 but beyond that year grave doubt exists for the industry's future, particularly in the United States.

Cook County, Ill., borrowed $15,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance construction of a superhighway at an interest cost of about 2.89 per cent. This compares with a cost of about 3.05 per cent offered by bankers for the same issue @f bonds at a scheduled: sale on July 7, when Cook County declined to accep% the bid.

BONN, Germany, July 28 -- Dr. Werner Naumann, arrested Jan. 15 by the British security police on suspicion of heading a Nazi conspiracy to overthrow the Bonn Government, was released today without bail by the West German Supreme Court in Karlsruhe.

BUFFALO, July 28 -- As a result of increasing problems for workers in connection with unemployment insurance, the State Federation of Labor authorized today a program of legal assistance to A. F. of L. members involved in precedent-making cases under the Unemployment Insurance Act.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 28 -- The Newport Stock Farm's Newport Dream from South Plainfield, N. J., scored a two-length victory over Stenographer in 2:08 3/5 in the United States Harness Writers Trophy race for 2-year-old trotters for a purse of $11,950 on the Grand Circuit card at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

Charles James Daniell, 38 years old, was sentenced yesterday in the Queens County Court, Long Island City, to five to ten years in prison for two robberies of the Jackson Heights branch of the Prudential Insurance Company of America that netted him $271.

ST. LOUIS, July 28 (AP) -- Ray Jablonski batted in three runs with a pair of singles tonight to lead the Cardinals to a 6-4 victory over Pittsburgh as Cliff Chambers and Joe Presko teamed to hold the pirates to seven hits.

ECONOMICS, says the dictionary handiest to my desk, is "the science of the production, distribution and consumption of wealth." If that word "science," which implies exact knowledge, were changed to "study," which leaves room for speculation, imponderables and abstract theory, it seems to me the definition would be improved.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- The Dodgers found the Cubs more than hospitable at Wrigley Field today and romped to a 13-2 victory before 16,938 fans as they opened their western invasion.

SAN FRANCISO, July. 28 -- Cannery workers walked out at sixty California fruit and vegetable packing plants today. The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service almost immediately appointed a three-man panel to try to resolve a wage dispute between the Cannery Workers Union, A. F. L., and the California Processors and Growers, Inc.

The performance by Congress last week in which both houses passed, by voice vote and with little or no debate, a bill repealing the 20 per cent excise tax on motion-picture theatres is one of those things that are inexplicable except in the crudest political terms. As our story of the Senate action on Friday noted:

Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, has taken a sudden turn for the worse, the New York Hospital announced yesterday morning and added in a special bulletin at 6 P. M. that Mr. Taft's condition "continues to be unsatisfactory."
SEOUL, Korea, July 28 (AP) -- The Fifth Air Force announced today that its planes had destroyed 984 Communist planes during the three-year Korean war.
BOSTON, July 28 -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue will begin pushing 5,000,000 New England doorbells tomorrow in a systematic canvass to uncover income tax delinquents.
LONDON, July 28 -- The stock markets here were slightly stronger today largely because of a little more buying of industrials, Japanese bonds and South African gold shares.

CINCINNATI, July 28 (AP) -- Mae Murray, Rutland, Vt., held the spotlight today as sixteen of the nation's top golfers advanced through the first round of match play in the women's Western Amateur tournament.

BERLIN, July 28 -- In a long report analyzing the causes of the June 17 uprising and setting forth the party's policies for the future, East Germany's Communists said today they were confronted with an extensive United States-supported underground.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 28 -- The mood of Pakistan changed today with ominous sharpness to one of keen disappointment in the wake of the three-day meeting of the Indian and Pakistani Prime Ministers that ended yesterday with no decision on the dispute over Kashmir.

LONDON, July 28 -- Fur-lined three-quarter coats worn over suits of similar light-weight fabrics or slim frocks, each with a small but important difference of detail following a definite theme, were the first models shown by Mattli today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 28 -- The Soviet-controlled East Germans have suddenly surprised Swedish State Railway authorities by offering again to permit train ferries carrying through sleepers to and from Berlin to ply to Sassnitz on the Island of Ruegen. This means a four-hour saving on train traffic between Sweden and Berlin.

While most 3-and-4-year-old children in New York are left to play on city streets when their older brothers and sisters go to camp, those from the Virginia Day Nursery are among the really exclusive few who are included in an agency's plans for overnight camping.

MILAN, Italy, July 28 -- Italian television, currently limited to the northern cities of Milan and Turin, has found the ideal solution to the problem of summer replacements. It just has gone off the air until Sept. 1.

QUINCY, Mass., July 28 -- The 29,500-deadweigth-ton tanker Orion Comet slipped smoothly down the ways of the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyards here today, one of the largest ships of her type built for United States flag service.

NEWARK, July 28 -- The new $8,500,000 terminal building at Newark Airport will be dedicated at 11:30 A. M. tomorrow, but the mayors of Newark and nearby Elizabeth will not attend the ceremonies. Six members of the Elizabeth City Council termed the invitation to participate in the opening of the terminal "an insult."
Raymond Durrell has been named director of public and trade relations of Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, Louisville, Ky.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) -- The House today approved a compromise bill to sell the Government's synthetic rubber plants, but Senate Democratic leaders said they would demand additional safeguards against monopoly.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 28 -- Fred. Grieve Jr. of Glen Head led the way into the semi-final round of the Long Island Golf Association's junior championship with a 5-and-4 victory over Don Parker of Plandome, the medalist, at the Cherry Valley Club today.

Appointment of Frederic C. LeRocker to the new post of associate general manager of the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases, 444 East Sixty-eighth Street, was announced yesterday by Reginald G. Coombe, chairman of the board of managers.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., July 28 -- A simulated beach invasion and destruction of an "enemy" radar station at Fort Hancock on Sandy Hook was viewed today more than ten miles away over a television hook-up in the first demonstration of its kind, according to the Army Signal Corps.

MEXICO CITY, July 28 -- Former United States Ambassador William O'Dwyer, who has settled down in Mexico, opened today the new law firm of O'Dwyer, Bernstien Correa for television cameras and newsmen. The formal opening of the offices is next Saturday, but Mr. O'Dwyer said the firm had been operating for several weeks.
HARTFORD, July 28 (UP) -- The State Supreme Court upheld a lower court ruling today invalidating a will written by a man after his second wife allegedly had plied him with liquor and narcotics.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Months will pass before a decision regarding the easing of trade restrictions with Hong Kong and the Portuguese island of Macao are made by the Administration, according to officials here. When and if the embargo against trade with Red China is eased will be decided at a more distant date, it was added.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 28 -- Sea Lion, a year-old German-built 67-foot yawl owned by Gilbert Verney of Nantucket, became the first winner of the Queen's Cup in the opening event of the New York Yacht Club cruise today.

GREENSBURG, Pa., July 28 (UP) -- A truck driver was shot to death today as he slept in the cab of his parked tractor-trailer along the Pennsylvania Turnpike. He was the second driver to be slain under similar circumstances along the western stretches of the cross-state "dream highway" within four days.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission approved today a settlement under which the Tennessee Gas Transmission Corporation of Houston will increase its wholesale natural gas rates by about $13,700,000 a year, based on 1952 operations.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Army outlined today a new peacetime policy for the rotation of personnel assigned to Korea and other areas of the Far East Command. The policy will become effective Oct. 1.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Army outlined today a new peacetime policy for the rotation of personnel assigned to Korea and other areas of the Far East Command. The policy will become effective Oct. 1.
LEXINGTON, Ky., July 28 (AP) -- A bay daughter of Polynesian-Buddy Kenney brought $24,500 today to top the summer thorough-bred yearling auctions at Keeneland.

PARIS, July 28 -- There is a "shadow" on the French rejoicing over the Korean armistice, Premier Joseph Laniel regretfully observed today. He told a luncheon gathering of Latin-Americans in Paris that the cease-fire in Korea "leaves France the only great Western nation still at war."

Philip M. Werner has been named manager of passenger sales of the United Air Lines, Charles M. Mason assistant vice president of personnel at Chicago and J. W. Eberly director of personnel field services at Denver.

A display of new fabrics, all contemporary in design, is on view at Macy's. Supplementing these, in coordinated colors, is an interesting assortment of accessories such as lamps, wastebaskets and accent rugs.
SEOUL, Thursday, July 30 (AP) -- Gen. Sun Yup Paik, Korean Army Chief of Staff urged today strengthening of the South Korean Army to meet any renewed Communist aggression.
TOLEDO, Ohio, July 29 (AP) -- The recently combined Kaiser Motors Corporation and Willys Motors, Inc., are going after a greater part of the automotive market, both domestic and export.

The decision in Washington to retain Albert F. Nufer as Ambassador to Argentina, although the nomination of a "successor" had already been sent to the Senate, is a tribute to a man and to a policy. It should not be taken as an indication of a change in policy, or necessarily as a direct result of the Latin-American mission of Dr. Milton Eisenhower, from which the President's brother returned yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) --Lessened hot weather demand for pork helped slice 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds off live hog prices today. Receipts were in line with trade forecasts, but demand, particularly from outside order buyers for bacon types, was below normal. Cattle turned steady to 50 cents lower but veal calves were strong and sheep steady to 50 cents higher.

NEW DELHI, India, July 29 -- The program of the Indian advance party for the Korean prisoner repatriation commission, as announced today, carefully avoids the South Korean Republic, but the group, headed by Foreign Secretary R. K. Nehru, will spend two days in Pyongyang, capital of Communist North Korea.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- President Eisenhower nominated today Maj. Gen. William J. (Wild Bill) Donovan, hero of two world wars, to be Ambassador to Thailand.

TULSA, Okla., July 29 (AP) -- Keith Lopp, Long Beach, Calif., defeated Robert Prall, Salem, Ore., 1 up, in a twenty-three-hole struggle as the United States Golf Association's journey tournament started today.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 29 -- Edward Garbisch of Piping Rock defeated Frank Cittadino of Lawrence, 5 and 4, to win the junior title during the Long Island Golf Association junior and boys' championships at the Cherry Valley Club today.

Commodity prices on the New York exchanges closed generally higher yesterday, influenced by strong grain markets. Coffee, cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, wool, copper, zinc, hides and rubber were higher; potatoes and tin lower, and sugar and lead mixed.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 30 -- For the second time in two days, the Communists charged this morning that the United Nations Command had violated the demilitarized zone in the course of its establishment between the two armies in Korea by the withdrawal from the former battlefront.

Michael J. (Barney) Prendergast, the owner and part-owner of a number of West Side taverns, was found slain yesterday morning in a wooded section of Fort Washington Park, at 190th Street, near the northbound lanes of the Henry Hudson Parkway.

HONG KONG, Thursday, July 30 -- The Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party has reaffirmed its solidarity with the Communists of the Soviet Union and expressed hope that the friendship between the two peoples "will be consolidated with each passing day."
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Real Delight, Calumet Farm's 1952 queen of turfdom, scored her first triumph this year by length and three-quarters today in the' $43,700 Arlington Matron Handicap.

The nation's electric power and light industry set a new record last week. Private and public power generating plants turned out in the week ended on July 25 8,460,427,000 kilowatt-hours of electrical energy. The accomplishment had more than a passing interest for the average electric bill-payer.

ST. LOUIS, July 29 (AP) -- The Cardinals tonight backed Harvey Haddix' steady pitching with a heavy thirteen-hit attack that buried the Pirates, 8 -- 2, for the Redbirds' third straight victory and their young left-hander's twelfth triumph of the season.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Tax agents in four states are making what the Internal Revenue Bureau described today as a "friendly and orderly effort" to find out how many people do not file tax returns.

On the coldest winter days the Health Department gets as many as 500 complaints that landlords are not providing enough heat in apartments. In the last week it has received three complaints that landlords are providing a midsummer bonus of central heating, raising room temperatures 10 or 12 degrees above the heat wave outside.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., July 29 -- Dr. George D. Stoddard today accused Park Livingston, head of the Board of Trustees, which forced his resignation Saturday as president of the University of Illinois, of sacrificing the best interests of the university to political ambition.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 29 -- India has been doing some diplomatic campaigning for Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit as president of the United Nations General Assembly's eighth regular session, opening Sept. 15.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 29 (AP) -- Greentree Stamble's My Sin captured the $20,000 added Miss Woodford Stakes at Monmouth Park today in a driving climax which saw three fillies finish noses apart in the six-furlong dash.

Plans are being formulated during the summer months at luncheon and tea meetings at the Plaza for the annual New York Junior League Debutante Ball to be held on Nov. 25 in the main ballroom of the hotel for the benefit of the organization's welfare fund.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 29 -- W. Ellery Allyn, State Insurance Commissioner, declared today that Connecticut was the only state in the union that discriminated in taxation against its domestic insurance companies.

BONN, Germany, July 29 -- The first Bundestag of the West German Federal Republic concluded its legislative career today by reenacting a bill to indemnify those persecuted by the Nazis, or their heirs living in Germany or abroad.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- Navy Waves are going to be assigned to sea duty.

The first important break in the four-week-old strike of building supply drivers came yesterday with the acceptance by a union negotiating committee of an employer offer of 40 cents an hour in wage increases, plus 5 per cent in welfare and pension benefits.
WITH SEVENTH DIVISION, in Korea, Thursday, July 30 (AP) -- Lieut. Richard Tom Shea Jr., holder of four West Point track records, today was recommended for the Medal of Honor.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Senate unanimously approved today a declaration favoring an effective world disarmament to be undertaken to the degree that the United States found success in its efforts to persuade the Soviet Union to accept the basic conditions for peace.

ROME, July 29 -- The extreme Left Wing press was jubilant today over the fall of Premier Alcide De Gasperi's eighth government yesterday. Unita in its editorial this morning jeered at Dr. De Gasperi and demanded the creation of a government that respects the will of the people.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the International Wheat Council, meeting in London, has made plans to begin operation of a renewed international wheat agreement on Saturday.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Tam O'Shanter's par was slaughtered today in a qualifying round of little-known pros and in practice tune-ups by exempted stars as they polished up for the $30,000 All-American golf tourney.

CINCINNATI, July 29 (UP) -- The Redlegs toppled Pitcher Robin Roberts of the Phillies to his worst beating of the season tonight, scoring six hits and six runs in the first three innings and gaining an easy 13 -- 4 Triumph.

LONDON, July 29 -- A reorganization of the British Government, probably involving a change of duties and a higher status for Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, will almost certainly take place in the fall when Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, and Mr. Eden, the Deputy Prime Minister, return to duty. That is the expectation in the best informed political quarters here.

PADANARAM, Mass., July 29 -- A 53-foot schooner, William Zeigler Jr.'s Bounding Home, registered from New York and having her anchorage at Noroton, Conn., was one of the winners of the Navy Challenge Cups that were up for competition in the New York Yacht Club cruise today.

Colin Wills, an Australian writer and traveler, has two books scheduled for publication a week apart by Roy Publishers. On Aug. 31, the concern will issue "Australian Passport," an insight into the author's native land, wherein he predicts that its people "are going to be a force in human affairs."

LONDON, July 29 -- There will not be any "radical changes" in Britain's rearmament program until it can clearly be seen whether the recent changes in the international climate really portend peace, Capt. Harry Crookshank, leader of the House of Commons, declared today.

CAIRO, July 29 -- The dispute between Britain and Egypt over the future of the Suez Canal zone military base, vital to Middle East defense, has entered a new and critically delicate phase as a result of weeks of secret diplomatic maneuvering that has greatly reduced the area of disagreement between the two governments.

FORT DIX, N. J., July 29 -- Long prison terms for seven young soldiers, including four from New York City, who were convicted of mutiny by a general court martial on July 9, were reduced today by Maj. Gen. Homer W. Kiefer.

BERLIN, July 29 -- As the first planeload and truckloads of United States food arrived in Berlin today to support West Berlin's relief program for the people of the Soviet zone, the East German Premier, Otto Grotewohl, offered to buy $15,000,000 worth of food from the United States -- "or even more."

SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., July 29 -- Bob Kuntz of Bonnie Briar, the defending champion, won the medal in the Westchester amateur golf championship with a 2-under-par 68 at Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

CHICAGO, July 29 (UP) -- Democratic leaders today announced plans for a mammoth fund-raising rally to welcome Adlai E. Stevenson home from his world tour, and said the possibility of a "mid-term" national party convention would be discussed.
LONDON, July 29 -- Still pressing to "catch up" after the Coronation, Norman Hartnell, the Queen's dressmaker, showed a collection of only twenty-four models today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a 15 per cent increase in express rates and charges on express shipments and told the Railway Express Agency it could put the increase into effect before Oct. 1, on fifteen days' notice to the public.

COLOGNE, July 29 (AP) -- Mal Whitfield turned in the fastest 400 meters of the year tonight when he stepped the distance in 0:46.2 seconds to complete a double in an international track and field meet.

MOSCOW, July 29 -- Premier Alexei Kleshchev of Byelorussia has been relieved of his duties and important changes in high personnel in the Moldavian Soviet Republic have been carried out, according to provincial newspapers arriving in Moscow.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., July 29 -- Fifteen persons were injured, three of them seriously, when a truck rushing an injured man to a hospital was in collision this afternoon with an automobile carrying nine persons to Bear Mountain for an outing.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- The cost of making television receivers has risen 21.8 per cent since a year ago. John S. Meck, president of Scott Radio Laboratories, Inc., Chicago, said today. He asserted that the rise "must be reflected" in selling prices in the fall.

Weathering a second-inning storm in which the invaders got all their runs, Vic Raschi achieved a fine route-going performance yesterday as the Yankees defeated the Indians for the second straight time, 7 to 3, before 23,290 paying fans at the Stadium.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 29 -- Elby Hanover, owned by Saunder Mills, Inc., of Toledo, Ohio, and Newport Star from the Newport Stock Farm at South Plainfield N. J., were the winners tonight as nineteen 3-year-old trotters, ten of them eligible for the Hambletonian at Goshen on Aug. 12, competed in the two divisions of the Old Country Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, announced today that Pope Pius XII had elevated the Most Rev. Albert G. Meyer, Bishop of Superior, Wis., to become the seventh Archbishop of Milwaukee, succeeding the late Archbishop Moses E. Kiley, who died in April.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 29 (AP) -- The Treasury Department is going to send a Memphis minister $325 to compensate him for money he destroyed to keep it out of the hands of Chinese Reds.

A record 1,959,013 passenger cars and trucks rolled off the General Motors Corporation's assembly lines in the United States and Canada in the first half of 1953, according to the semi-annual report of Harlow H. Curtice, president, and Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, mailed yesterday to G. M.'s 491,000 shareholders.

ON THE WESTERN FRONT, Korea, July 29 -- By 10 o'clock tomorrow night all of the men and most of the equipment of both the Communist and Allied forces will be about one and one-quarter miles from the positions they held Monday, when the Korean armistice was signed.

George McAneny was one of our finest and most useful citizens, whether in the role of civic reformer, public official or business man. He loved New York City, knew and well remembered its history and its landmarks, worked for its improvement. The list of public offices he held was extraordinarily long and only one index of his versatility and the esteem in which he was held.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Harry Edwards of Yonkers, N. Y., assist ant to the sales manager of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation in New York City, was nominated today by President Eisenhower to be Surveyor of Customs of the Collection District No. 10, with headquarters in New York City.

Secretary Dulles plans to fly to Korea soon to confer with President Rhee in an effort to dispel remaining misunderstandings and to establish a common front, backed by a mutual security pact, on the central issue that will face the political conference to which the armistice is a prelude.

The Times Square area has many attractions, but it certainly has its detractions too in the eruption of tinhorn auctions, panhandlers and sellers of absurd novelty hats and suggestive literature and pictures. This activity proceeds against a background of brash recorded music blaring out onto the streets, and immense and garish signs that read, "

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Wheat turned strong in late trading today, buying being prompted by pessimistic crop reports from the spring wheat country. The menace of stem rust continues a factor in the Northwest. Earlier there was buying by export houses against the sale of 1,200,000 bushels to Mexico.

PARIS, July 29 (Reuters) -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization reinstated today a United States civilian employe who had been suspended from his post for having failed to appear before a Federal Grand Jury in New York.

ATHENS, July 18 -- Under the general direction of the American School of Classical Studies in Athens, work has been started on the reconstruction of one of the ancient world's most remarkable buildings, the Stoa of Attalos.

CINCINNATI, July 29 (UP) -- Polly Riley, defending champion from Fort Worth Tex., rallied on the back nine holes of the second round of the women's Western amateur golf tournament today to defeat Edean Anderson of Helena, Mont, 1 up.

A mathematical map that promises to open roads through the intellectual jungles of the cosmos, which Prof. Albert Einstein has been seeking to penetrate for more than thirty years, was outlined yesterday at Indiana University, Bloomington, Ind., by Prof. Vaclav Hlavaty, one of the world's select group of experts on the highly involved mathematics of multi-dimensional space.

The need for maintaining closer control over unspent Federal budget funds is emphasized in the current issue of the Guaranty Trust Company's monthly review, "Guaranty Survey." Billions might be saved by making unexpended appropriations subject to continuing review and by sharply limiting the practice of authorizing contractual obligations extending for years into the future, the bank review holds.
ALBANY, July 29 (AP) -- The State Health Department today tentatively credited a mass gamma globulin inoculation of 37,125 children with cutting sharply into a polio epidemic in two upstate counties.
LONDON, July 29 (Reuters) -- The English Cricket Board of Control today asked the Australian board to agree to an extension to six days of the fifth and final test match between the two countries.
NEWARK, July 29 -- The Port of New York Authority dedicated its new passenger terminal at Newark Airport today as thousands of persons filled the spacious $8,500,000 building.

COMMODORE FRASER of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club and his race committee sat on the bow of the Ilse III a couple of weeks ago and prayed for wind. Long Island Sound was smooth as milady's boudoir mirror. Smoke from a tug far out along the island shore hung like a plumb line in the sky. Close by, eight Lightning Class craft drifted in gentle swells at the end of tow ropes.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (UP) -- Eddie Robinson hit a two-run homer and Ray Murray drove a two-run triple tonight as the Athletics defeated the Browns, 9 -- 3, for their seventh victory in their last eight starts.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Glen G. Edgerton and Lynn U. Stambaugh, nominated by President Eisenhower to run the Export-Import Bank, got a Senatorial warning today that they were taking over an agency that faced heavy criticism and sharp investigation.

It would be interesting to know whether Daniel C. Reuter, who has stated his opposition to the Ostrander amendment, has ever visited the site of the Panther Mountain Dam or whether he is merely quoting the literature of the Black River Regulating District. While I was still a resident of New York State I did so with other members of the Adirondack Mountain Club Conservation Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Defense Department ruled today that 13,000 to 14,000 college juniors enrolled in the Reserve Officers Training Corps of the Air Force must take flight training or drop out and become eligible for the draft.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, a brother of the President, declared today that friendly relations between the United States and the South American republics were "critically important in the world-wide struggle for the winning of men's minds and allegiances."
Aaron Feld, former plainclothes man, yesterday lost his two-year fight to stay out of prison.

WOLVERTON, England, July 29 -- (Reuters) -- A document recording the marriage of a signer of the Declaration of Independence will remain in St. Peter's Church here instead of being sold to the United States for a reported $28,000.
The Transit Authority, which has just taken new steps to eliminate the use of slugs in turnstiles, reported yesterday that on Monday 4,364 "spurious" coins had been dropped into fare slots.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon, the American League's leading hitter, blasted a three-run homer and two singles tonight as the Senators crushed the Tigers, 13 -- 5, on a barrage of sixteen hits. The box score:

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Senate rejected today a compromise measure looking toward the sale of twenty-nine Government synthetic rubber plants to private industry, sending the legislation back to the House for another conference.

The Committee for the Companies and Agents -- Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, whose membership comprises some forty steamship lines, yesterday wound up three and a half months of negotiations with five maritime unions. Accords were reached with all five.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- Russ Meyer, unbeaten by the Cubs since 1950. came up with his ninth straight triumph over them as the Dodgers defeated the Bruins by 6 -- 5 today before 11,625 Wrigley Field fans.

A third application for the right to Channel 31, the sole remaining commercial television channel available here, was filed yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission in Washington. The new applicant was WHOV-TV, Inc., a corporation set up by the operators of radio stations WHOM and WOV.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, oldest and second largest manufacturer of electric apparatus and appliances, rang up the largest dollar sales for any six months in its history during the first half of 1953 and increased earnings by 13.2 per cent over a year ago.

Fifty-two insurance companies, banks and pension funds have finished negotiations for lending $420,000,000 to finance the Ohio Valley Electric Corporation's commitment to supply power for the United States Atomic Energy Commission's new atomic diffusion plant near Portsmouth, Ohio.

Since the horses (and the horse players) transferred their activities from Aqueduct to Jamaica on July 13, fifteen of eighteen odds-on favorites have failed to deliver the goods. The fifteenth case of non-delivery -- a case that puzzled owner, trainer and jockey -- was recorded in the $12,425 Albany Stakes yesterday.

The ouster of Joseph P. Ryan, lifetime president of the International Longshoremen's Association, or the designation of an administrator to clean up the union appeared yesterday to be the only developments that could keep the racket-infested pier union in the American Federation of Labor.

PARIS, July 29 -- Large square ermine collars on black suits, an ermine train on a black sheath, pillboxes in the same snowy pelt and black wool stoles tipped deeply in white fox were typical of the elegance of Balenciaga's showing today.

The use of full-page ads in daily newspapers has played a prominent part in the rise in sales of Duncan Hines Cake Mixes, it has been reported to the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, off 9 to 14 points.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 30 -- The Soviet Government has delivered to Austria a new note on the question of an Austrian treaty, again urging that the so-called short draft of the Austrian treaty be withdraw with a view to facilitating discussions aimed at concluding an agreement.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation today announced the arrest of six Communist party officials in Philadelphia and Weymouth, N. J.

CARLE PLACE, L. I., July 29 -- There was more trouble on the picket line of the strike-bound Arma Corporation today at Roosevelt Field, and for the third straight day the incidents ended in District Court.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 29 -- During the first year of its operation, 23,000 families in Copenhagen alone have taken advantage of a law providing Government-subsidized household help during family emergencies at a cost scaled on the family's ability to pay.
BOSTON, July 29 (UP) -- Ted Williams came back to Fenway Park today, signed a contract to play for the Red Sox through 1954 and then indulged in a light pre-game workout with the team.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 29 -- Eventual agreement between France and Cambodia appears probable here, despite the contentiousness that has marked recent relations between the two countries. If a settlement is reached, the 1,000-year-old Cambodian Kingdom will regain attributes of independence that it relinquished when it was made a French Protectorate the middle of the last century.

MEXICO CITY, July 29 -- A list of public school text books recognized as pro-Communist is being compiled by the Mexican Ministry of Education with the view to banning them from schools and substituting more objective texts.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 29 -- Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, said today the pivotal dispute over Kashmir between India and Pakistan might not be settled for a year.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- As it finally cleared Congress today the military appropriations bill called for $34,371,541,000 in new money for the present fiscal year. President Truman had asked $40,719,931,000 and President Eisenhower $35,771,563,000. Thus Congress chopped more than $6,000,000,000 from Truman's request and nearly $1,500,000,000 from General Eisenhower's.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The United States called on the Czechoslovak Government today to submit detailed evidence in support of its claim that an F-84 jet fighter plane was shot down last March 10 over Czechoslovakia rather than over Germany as the United States has contended.
BOSTON, July 29 (AP) -- Chicago's aroused White Sox ruined Ted Williams' homecoming today by setting off a ninth-inning rally that gave them an 8-3 victory over the Red Sox.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Following is the 63-30 roll-call vote by which the Senate today passed a bill to admit 209,000 refugees to the United States in the next three years:

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 29 -- Replying to the statement by John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, regretting that Israel had moved her Foreign Ministry to Jerusalem, Moshe Sharett, Israeli Foreign Minister, said today that he could not understand how the move would have come as a surprise to the United States Government or why it should embarrass the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to deprive Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan, of control of money appropriated for subcommittees of the Government Operations Committee, of which he is chairman.

The trade unions of the free world have taken a significant step in voting to raise substantial funds to aid the heroic men and women of East Germany who rose last month in what might yet be known in history as "the workers' revolt" against Communist oppression.

SEOUL, Korea, July 29 -- The United Nations army continued its massive withdrawal from its fronline positions today. Hundreds of thousands of men and tons of equipment were involved in the operation, which is taking place under a blazing summer sun. On the roads the trucks were bumper to bumper, enveloped in great clouds of choking dust.
