Over the years in New York City the relationship has become steadily closer between the theory of commercial and industrial work and the actual practice of it. In the academic year just past 3,800 city high school pupils, enrolled in courses where they alternate work on the job with work in school, earned $2,284,292, according to a report on cooperative education just made to Superintendent of Schools Jansen.

Leather has soared to the top in fashion for fall. Its touch is almost the mark of news. It not only will be seen in garments fashioned of it entirely but it has also been introduced with great success as trim. Shorts, skirts, blouses, jackets and coats are the principal items entirely of leather, but it will also be observed on dresses, suits, skirts, blouses and coats as novel and conversation-making trim.

It is a minor note after the crashing silence of the truce, but it should be sounded. Because of the urgent needs in Korea the Red Cross and the other blood collecting agencies have been able in the past three years to get their call dramatically across to the public.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, July 30 -- The Senate passed a $6,745,318,202 Mutual Security appropriation bill early today after a bipartisan majority had withstood attempts all through last night to cut the measure by various amounts up to $548,630,023 under the Appropriations Committee's recommendation.

PURCHASE, N. Y., July 29 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis, the defending champion, and Mrs. Donald O'Brien of Winged Foot, a former titleholder, will meet in the semi-final round of the ninth annual Women's Tri-County golf championship over the Old Oaks course tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Following is the text of a statement made in the Senate today by Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, in opposition to increasing the Federal debt limit:

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The United States Tariff Commission rejected the application of producers of cotton carding machinery and parts today for higher duties on competitive imports in that field. The five-man commission held unanimously that the imports were not being brought into the country in such volume "as to cause or threaten serious injury to the domestic industry."

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 -- Mrs. Mary Rush Bartol, member of a prominent old American family, was burned to death early today when flames swept through her bedroom in the Bartol residence in suburban Penn Valley.

Special Sessions Justice Matthew J. Troy accepted yesterday the invitation of Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Manhattan Borough President, to seek the Democratic nomination for Brooklyn Bor ough President in the Sept. 15 primary.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Franciszek Jarecki, who zoomed to freedom from satellite Poland in a Russian jet airplane, happily watched today as President Eisenhower signed the bill that gave him asylum in the United States.
TOKYO, July 29 -- Japan's House of Representatives approved unanimously today a resolution calling for more trade with Communist China.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- A Government color film showing farmers how to get Federal aid to set up telephone service has been withdrawn from circulation because, officials said, private concerns found it stepped on their toes.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 29 -- Mrs. L. V. E. Hommel and Charles Benesch of North Hempstead scored 31, 34 -- 65 to win first prize in the Women's Long Island Golf Association mixed foursomes best-ball tournament for the benefit of the American Red Cross at North Hempstead today.

LONDON, July 29 -- Britain's acting Foreign Secretary, the Marques of Salisbury, proposed today two controversial candidates, the Soviet Union and India, for inclusion in the political conference on a Korean settlement.
Shepard Traube, who will present the musical, "The Girl in Pink Tights," this season, is negotiating for the services of two foreign performers for important male roles in the production.

Unionized longshoremen in this port will get an increase of at least $15 a month in their pension benefits, Patrick J. Connolly, executive vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Eisenhower has called key Congressional Republicans and Democrats to the White House for breakfast tomorrow to discuss a possible increase in the statutory ceiling on the national debt.

MILWAUKEE, July 29 (AP) -- Milwaukee's seventy-six-day-old brewery strike ended last night with the announcement that strikers had voted by more than a 3 to 1 to accept a contract offer from the city's six breweries.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A proposed sounding of the Senate's desire to assume responsibility for the actions of its investigating committees was both projected and abandoned in jig-time today.
WASHINGTON, Juy 29 -- By a vote of 63 to 30, the Senate today approved a bill to admit 209,000 over-quota refugees to this country in the next three years and eight months.

BALTIMORE, July 29 -- In two hours of continuous play, Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo defeated Clyde Wilderspin of Australia today in the Middle Atlantic grass court tennis championships at the Baltimore Country Club. The score was 8 -- 6, 8 -- 10, 12 -- 10.

A wise man once remarked that conversation about the weather can be a delightful medium of social intercourse, but only up to the point at which the director of the local weather bureau enters the room. From there on light conversation is impossible; the expert who knows the answers to idly posed questions, who understands the true facts about curious phenomena over which amateurs love to speculate, invariably kills off enthusiasm by his mere presence.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 29 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has initiated a policy of closer cooperation with the secretariat at all levels, as formulated and announced jointly today with representatives of the staff committee.

Motorists taking their cars abroad to travel in foreign countries on business or pleasure are setting a new volume record. Since the beginning of the year 3,848 passenger automobiles have been shipped from this port by the International travel department of the American Automobile Association as compared with 3,523 in the corresponding period in 1952.

BUFFALO, July 29 -- Spencer Miller Jr., newly-appointed Federal Assistant Secretary of Labor, urged today a policy of firmness toward Russia and said this nation should let the masters of the Kremlin understand that the United States had been a "dupe of their machinations for the last time."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 29 -- "Giant," Edna Ferber's novel about Texas that was published last year, will be brought to the screen by Warner Brothers with George Stevens as producer and director. Negotiations were completed today between the studio and Miss Ferber, now visiting southern California; Mr. Stevens, and Henry Ginsberg, who joined forces in May to produce the story.
Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, who stubbed his toe in the process, has inadvertently revealed one of the weaknesses of the Central Intelligence Agency, a key unit in our national security system.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- President Eisenhower greeted the ninety-two members of Boys' Nation today and praised their dedication to the idea of serving their Government.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 22, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

LONDON, July 29 (Reuters) -- The De Havilland Engine Company, makers of Britain's Comet jetliners, disclosed today it had produced what it calls the world's most powerful jet engine, called the Gyron.

CONCORD, N. H., July 29 -- The recent deaths of two political leaders, in New Hampshire and in Massachusetts, have given rise to considerable speculation in the last few days as to developments between now and the 1954 national election.

MILWAUKEE, July 29 -- After twenty-one consecutive scoreless innings by the Giants something had to be done, so tonight at County Stadium Leo Durocher made two moves. He benched Daryl Spencer -- and himself. Whether the restoring of Alvin Dark to the starting shortstop spot or the removal of Durocher as third-base coach was mainly responsible, the fact is that the Giants not only scored against the Braves, they beat Milwaukee, 3 -- 2.

Although the Long Island Rail Road will have improved its cash position by $2,000,000 as a result of summer business, William Wyer, trustee, said yesterday that this sum would be needed to meet deficits.

How to keep brown sugar from hardening into a brick-like lump may seem a trifling problem to house-husbands. But to their wives it has proved so annoying that over the years, in their quest for help, they have written an untold number of letters to Government agencies, sugar manufacturers, food writers and so on.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- If Robert A. Taft's illness obliges him to retire from the Senate at any time before the Eighty-third Congress adjourns sine die, Governor Lausche of Ohio replaces him with a Democrat and the rest of the Senate remains as it was, the body will number forty-eight Democrats, forty-seven Republicans and one Independent.

ALBANY, July 29 (AP) -- Governor Dewey and Republican legislative leaders named an eleven-member commission today to conduct a $575,000 analysis of the state's financial operations and to prepare for possible revision of overlapping Federal, state and local taxes.

New headway toward unity between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations was reported yesterday, but there also were fresh indications that some C. I. O. unions might not wait for an over-all merger before joining the federation.

THE hunting regulations for doves, rails, gallinules and scoters have been announced by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, with seasons and bag limits on rails and scoters, the two species with which the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut shooters, are concerned, about the same as last year.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- The toll of United States casualties in Korea reached 140,546 today and will climb even higher before the Department of Defense brings the statistics up to truce day.
PARIS, July 29 -- French officials and commentators today saw in the downfall of Premier De Gasperi another in the series of blows affecting the chances of an early development of European unity.

But to their wives it has proved so annoying that over the years, in their quest for help, they have written an untold number of letters to Government agencies, sugar manufacturers, food writers and so on.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- If Robert A. Taft's illness obliges him to retire from the Senate at any time before the Eighty-third Congress adjourns sine die, Governor Lausche of Ohio replaces him with a Democrat and the rest of the Senate remains as it was, the body will number forty-eight Democrats, forty-seven Republicans and one Independent.

Five hundred persons who attended yesterday the opening of 2,510,000 Port Richmond Pollution Control Project on Staten Island heard Mayor Impellitteri and Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen assail detractors of New York City's accomplishments.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Chilean Government has informally approached the United States on the possibility of this country buying around 65,000 tons of copper which Chile is unable to sell at its price of 36 1/2 cents a pound.
